title: Hull Finishes Season With 86 Goals
description: Brett Hull scored his 86th goal, giving him the third-best total in National Hockey League history, and assisted on Dan Quinn's game-winner as the St. Louis Blues defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 2-1, tonight to end the regular season on a seven-game winning streak.

title: Warsaw Pact Formally Ends 36 Years As a Military Force
description: The Warsaw Pact, which held Eastern Europe under tight Kremlin control for 36 years, formally ended its existence as a military force Sunday when Soviet commanders surrendered their powers.

title: Teddy R. Zausner; Volunteer, 82
description: Teddy R. Zausner, the first president of the Manhattan chapter of Women's American O.R.T, or Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 82 years old.

title: Police Accuse Deaf Man of Killing Another
description: A deaf man stabbed another deaf man to death and wounded a deaf couple early yesterday in a Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: We Don't Need War Between the Generations; Social Day Care Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Minimum Wage Up by 45
description: The minimum wage will increase by 45 cents an hour on Monday, to $4.25, but labor advocates are pressing for more.

title: Kansas Looks For Opportunities
description: The shot that could have broken Duke's hearts had just caromed from the basket and into the hands of Bobby Hurley and a celebration of Blue Devils.

title: Metro Matters; Deja Vu Again? This Fiscal Crisis Has New Rules
description: "He wants to be the white knight," Barry Feinstein, the teamsters local leader, said contemptuously of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Top New York Officer Resigns at Chiat/Day
description: After just seven months on the job, Robert Perkins has resigned as president of Chiat/Day/Mojo's New York office. Mr. Perkins will become the senior vice president of marketing for Pizza Hut.

title: New York Can Handle Cuts Better Than Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Bird Stars in Celtic Victory
description: Larry Bird is not playing with his customary fluidity. He is straining himself. Defenders are forcing him to put the ball on the floor. His 45.3 shooting percentge from the field and 19.3 scoring average are the lowest of his 12-year career.

title: Fly-Fishing and Other Essentials
description: Sex, Death and Fly-Fishing By John Gierach 238 pages. Firestone/Simon & Schuster. Paper, $8.95. Where the Trout Are All as Long as Your Leg By John Gierach Illustrated. 84 pages. Lyons & Burford. $15.95.

title: Brazil Effort On Loans
description: Brazil says it will ask the Inter-American Development Bank to explain reports that its loans are being blocked.

title: You Can Call Me Mr. Mattingly
description: DON MATTINGLY may sign more free autographs than any other premier baseball player, but even the first baseman with the left hand that never tires has rules about signing. After signing autographs for more than 30 minutes after a Yankee game this spring, Mattingly offered some do's and don'ts to those seeking his signature.

title: Teacher Says Her Conviction Was a Surprise
description: In a newspaper interview from prison, a high school teacher convicted of conspiring with a student to kill her husband has conceded acting oddly after the killing, but said, "Nobody gave me the 22-year-old widow's handbook."

title: Pope Denounces the Gulf War as 'Darkness'
description: Pope John Paul II delivered a scathing denunciation of the Persian Gulf war today, calling it a "darkness" that he said had "cast a shadow over the whole human community."

title: Japan Acts on Polish Debt
description: Japan announced last week that it had agreed to reschedule Poland's debt to it for the fifth time. The pact covers at least $51.7 million in principal and interest owed by the commercial Bank of Warsaw to Japanese state and commercial banks, and commercial debt to Japanese creditors and insured by the Japanese Government that was due for repayment before today.

title: Concert Postponed
description: Tonight's concert with the pianist Olegna Fuschi and the Orchestra of St. Luke's at Carnegie Hall has been postponed because of illness. The date for a rescheduled concert is to be announced shortly, and tickets for tonight's concert will be honored.

title: A Water Wonder Returns to Racing
description: IN less than two weeks, 41-year-old Mark Spitz will try to recapture his youth. The coach who is preparing him said Spitz is doing fine, but he also cautioned about expecting too much from the aging swimmer.

title: Queens Journal; For Local Colombians, An Atypical Lions Club
description: As a Saturday night gives out in Queens, women drift home down a sidewalk along Kissena Boulevard, some speaking Korean, some Chinese. Behind them, the Free Synagogue of Flushing advertises services. And from the depths of the temple comes muffled music. The theme from "Rocky"? Set to a salsa beat?

title: Editorial Notebook; Mixed Messages From a Drug Bust
description: No safe havens for drugs -- that is the message local law enforcement officials say they were trying to send when they recently raided and seized three University of Virginia fraternity houses.

title: Donor's Goal: Keeping the Art Together
description: In this exchange from an interview, Walter H. Annenberg discusses the conditions of his bequest to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Confidence and Will
description: The Economist of London reports on the United States with more care and insight than any other foreign journal -- or most American papers. When it analyzes a large subject, it speaks with the sympathy of a friend but the detachment of a realist.

title: Tokyo Stocks Finish Lower
description: Tokyo stocks were lower today in light trading. But brokers said that the downward trend lacked momentum, and that small selling moved the market because volume was so thin. Most leading overseas markets were closed on Friday and today for the Easter holiday, leaving Tokyo adrift.

title: Lafleur, in an Encore, Bids Fans Adieu
description: With an extraordinary outpouring of emotion, Quebecers said adieu to a native son over the weekend, saluting Guy Lafleur in the final days of a long and unusual career, which to many in the French-speaking province signified more than hockey alone.

title: Channels Seek Identity In Made-for-Cable Films
description: Cable television channels are spending heavily on original programming in their efforts to attract audiences on the increasingly crowded cable systems.

title: Soviet Georgians Vote in Independence Plebiscite
description: Georgia became the latest Soviet republic to formally call for independence today as voters cast their ballots in a plebiscite that separatist leaders predicted would register overwhelming support for total freedom from Moscow's rule.

title: Reviews/Television; Uplifting Hearts, Minds and Ratings
description: Even more than usual, romance and uplift are in the television air these days. The reason: The 1990 network season officially ends in less than two weeks and the ratings race is very near a dead heat, with NBC currently maintaining a razor-thin edge over CBS and ABC . It's showdown time, and that means a return to uncomplicated commercial-television staples, the kind that often leave critics squirming.

title: Correction
description: An article on Saturday about the attempted theft of a transit police car in the Bronx included an incorrect address supplied by the transit police for the suspect, Aundray Burns. The correct address is 926 East 214th Street.

title: Suit Names Merrill Lynch
description: A suit filed by the City of Waterbury contends that Merrill Lynch & Company was negligent in investing pension funds and seeks to recoup the losses.

title: Eliot Reif; Union Official, 84
description: Eliot Reif, the president since 1980 of the retirees association of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, died yesterday at the home of a daughter, Marilyn Cooper, in Rye, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Boston U. Left Dazed in Finale
description: "What was all that about?"

title: Child World Reports Loss
description: Child World Inc., the nation's second-largest toy retailer, says it lost $162 million in its fourth quarter because of a one-time reorganization charge.

title: States Lead on Environment And Industries Complain
description: As a result of Federal inaction, many important environmental policies are being set at the state level, often to the dismay of the industries affected.

title: 46,952 Watch Knights Lose
description: Stan Gelbaugh threw for 326 yards and hit a 61-yard scoring pass to Andre Riley as the London Monarchs won their World League of American Football home opener, 22-18, today over the New York/New Jersey Knights before 46,952 fans at Wembley Stadium.

title: A Noh Drama Poses New Questions in Old Forms
description: A new Noh play is a rarity in Japan, a country that thinks there are only a few good examples of the genre, all of them written 400 years ago. But Dr. Tomio Tada, a professor at Tokyo University's medical school, has used this dusty old art form to tap a deep modern sense of ambivalence over the boundary between life and death. And his Noh play "The Well of Ignorance" has become something of a surprise hit.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEE IACOCCA wed a 42-year-old restaurateur, DARRIEN EARLE, in a private ceremony Saturday attended by family members and about 100 friends. The ceremony was held at the home of ALLEN PAULSON, a former business partner of Mr. Iacocca, the 66-year-old chairman of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Vols Capture Women's Title
description: As the Final Four of the women's national collegiate basketball tournament started here this weekend, attention was focused on Virginia point guard Dawn Staley, the national player of the year.

title: School Libraries, Too, Require Our Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: Deadly Clash in a Yugoslav Republic
description: Policemen and rebels fought for control of a rebel-held national park in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia today, and at least 1 person was killed and 13 were wounded.

title: Series of Sexual Attacks Spreads Fear in Flatbush
description: Women in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn say 14 sexual attacks since November, apparently by a serial rapist, have left them fearful and increasingly cautious.

title: Miami Plans to Evict Cuban Art Museum from City Building
description: The Cuban Museum of Arts and Culture here, which was bombed twice in recent years for exhibiting works by artists living in Cuba, is facing eviction from a city-owned building on Monday.

title: Yanks-Bonilla Deal? Brrrrr!
description: The Yankees are talking trade, and they are talking to the Pittsburgh Pirates, but each day that passes makes it less likely they will strike a deal involving Bobby Bonilla.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 31, 1991: MONDAY

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Blackhawks 5, Red Wings 1: The Chicago Blackhawks won their first-ever President's Trophy for the National Hockey League's best record with a victory over Detroit last night in Chicago behind Dirk Graham's two goals. The Blackhawks pulled it out in a down-to-the-wire race with the St. Louis Blues, 106 points to 105. The Blues earlier beat Minnesota, 2-1, to put the pressure on the Blackhawks to win. The victory also gave Chicago the Norris Division title and matched them with Minnesota in the first round of the playoffs. Detroit will meet the Blues. (AP)

title: Barkley Has Knee Injury
description: Charles Barkley, Philadelphia's All-Star forward, suffered a torn ligament in his left knee today when he bumped into his teammate Rick Mahorn midway in the third period of the 76ers' game with the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Mets to Unfurl Banners for G.I.s
description: THE Mets have long been known for banner-day parades. Whether the team was good, bad or ugly, on one day each summer, fans would trek across Shea Stadium with some of the most creative sheets since Bart Simpson met the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles.

title: MGM-Pathe Faces Filing By Creditors
description: A group of creditors has increased the financial pressure on the MGM-Pathe Communications Company by filing a petition seeking to force the company into involuntary bankruptcy.

title: Stocks Rose Broadly in Quarter
description: The stock market just completed one of its strongest quarters since 1980. Investors, who stood on the sidelines after Iraq invaded Kuwait, gleefully dived back into the equity markets in the first quarter, which ended last week, after the American-led assault in the gulf seemed a success.

title: Donations to PAC's Dropped for First Time in '90
description: Donations to political action committees fell for the first time in the 1990 political campaigns, and the drop was caused almost entirely by a sharp decline in fund raising by ideological groups, says a new Federal study.

title: New Jersey Cuts Cost Of Driving
description: Automobile insurance premiums across New Jersey will drop by $222 beginning today as a major provision of Gov. Jim Florio's insurance legislation takes effect.

title: Sisyphus and the Phoenix
description: ANYONE who enjoys college basketball enjoyed watching Nevada-Las Vegas this season, just as anyone who appreciates success could appreciate the magnitude of U.N.L.V.'s 45-game winning streak over two seasons.

title: Playoff-Bound Devils Finish Below .500
description: The negatives outnumbered the positives by quite a margin in the regular season for the Devils, whose biggest accomplishment is that they are on the list of 16 teams that made the playoffs.

title: Rangers Hold 2d Place; Nicholls Is Irked
description: The Rangers clinched second place and the home-ice advantage for the first round of the playoffs last night with a 6-3 victory over the Penguins in the regular-season finale at Madison Square Garden.

title: New Hampshire Air Base to Close, Draining a City
description: Pease Air Force Base, one of the biggest military installations to fall under the Defense Department budget ax three years ago, is about to be the first to close.

title: Rockefeller U. Anxious as Leader Feels Pain of Science-Fraud Case
description: The recent disclosure that crucial research data had been fabricated in a scientific report signed by Dr. David Baltimore not only damaged the reputation of the Nobel laureate and eminent biologist. It has also left a trail of anger, uncertainty and anxiety at Rockefeller University, which hired him as president in 1989.

title: A Versatile Weight Machine
description: A former Mr. Universe, Bob Gajda of Chicago, has developed a fitness machine that allows you to combine weight-training exercises with field or court practice. The machine, the C.M.F. (for Conforming Moving Force), relies on a sliding pulley system to reproduce the motions of tennis, basketball, bowling, swimming, running, football, baseball or golf.

title: 2 Drowning Victims Found
description: Rescue crews have found the bodies of two young brothers who were swept into the flooded Calaveras River, the last of the four victims who drowned when they stumbled into the chilly water on Wednesday. The bodies of Herbert Pich, 9 years old, and his brother Danalee, 8, were found Friday, several hundred yards from where they entered the river.

title: Pentagon Is Trying Harder to Ease Combat Stress of Returning Troops
description: If the war in the Persian Gulf broke new ground in weapons and tactics, the process of bringing home the troops is being carried out with more concern than ever before for the emotional welfare of servicemen, servicewomen and their families.

title: A Writer Who Says Getting His Own Way Is the Way to Success
description: At age 62, many writers, directors and actors are begging for work. But Warren Adler is being courted by Hollywood.

title: The Cost of a Late Budget
description: While late budgets have become almost de rigueur in the New York State Capitol -- today will mark the seventh year in a row that the Legislature has missed the April 1 constitutional deadline -- they are far from painless.

title: Tower of Pisa Update
description: The tower of Pisa has leaned an extra four hundredths of an inch in the last three months, nearly as much as it usually leans in a year, experts said on Saturday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALICE S. HUANG, a professor of microbiology and molecular genetics at the Harvard Medical School, has been appointed dean of science of New York University's faculty of arts and sciences. In the newly created post, Professor Huang, 52, will oversee the school's science research and work to secure research money.

title: Bush's Moral Crisis
description: Why did all the weight of the Bush Administration come down on General Schwarzkopf for revealing that the decision to abort the war a day too soon was not unanimous -- or as the general later half-clarified, not as originally planned?

title: High Tech Turns Down and Dirty
description: AN intriguing television innovation that the World League of American Football has promoted to gain viewers for its national broadcasts on ABC Sports is placing microphones in the helmets of quarterbacks. Fans can hear head coaches' and the field leaders' instructions -- and sundry ad-lib comments.

title: None of Kuwait's Oil Well Fires Put Out Yet
description: It will be at least a week more and probably longer before firefighters can begin trying to put out the hundreds of blazing oil wells torched by Saddam Hussein's fleeing army more than a month ago, American oil experts said today.

title: A Diplomatic Dance to Win the Annenberg
description: In the late spring of 1986, Anne d'Harnoncourt, the director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, was seated beside Walter H. Annenberg at a dinner party in Philadelphia. They needed no introduction.

title: Free Agents Put Pinch On Networks
description: Like baseball owners, the networks have to deal with some expensive free agents this year, and they have an enormous incentive to try to keep their costs down.

title: Sofia Backs Money Trade
description: Bulgarian officials say they will soon publish new regulations allowing private citizens to trade all kinds of currencies.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Ex-S.& L. Chief Granted Relief
description: Federal regulators are willing to grant hardship status to the ousted chairman of the Centrust Savings Bank, David L. Paul, on the condition that he stay on a short financial leash, according to court documents obtained on Friday.

title: Schoolgirl on Pace For 3,310 Points
description: JOHN SOMOGYI'S 23-year old New Jersey high school basketball record for career points could be in jeopardy next season. The player who will challenge the 3,310 points Somogyi scored at St. Peter's High School in New Brunswick, N.J., is the girl he used to tuck into bed. His record is being threatened by Kristen Somogyi, his 17-year-old daughter.

title: Gilbert Helps U.S. Gain in Davis Cup
description: Brad Gilbert had always played a supporting role on the United States Davis Cup team.

title: Reviews/Pop; Onstage: Gloom and Smoke; Off: Black Clothes and Angst
description: Smoke began pouring onto the stage of the Ritz half an hour before the Sisters of Mercy appeared on Saturday night. A good haze is essential to bands like the Sisters of Mercy. Fans call them gothic, a category that requires gloomy, cryptic lyrics, an aura of mystery and a pounding dance beat; the music draws audiences that wear black clothes and heavy makeup, signifying sensitivity, angst and an acute fashion sense.

title: People
description: * Bruce Hopman, Ralph Palamidessi, Drew Burke and Rule Johnson-Morris have been named senior vice presidents at Lintas New York. * Robert Tramondo has been named New York advertising manager for Penthouse magazine.

title: Review/Pop; English Band Attacks Lies Danceably
description: In the ceaseless search for the perfect pop formula, an English band called E.M.F. has come up with one that suits the current moment. It's the latest version of a danceable bottom with a rock superstructure, using choppy hip-hop drumming, concise pop-punk riffs and James Atkin's hoarse, sullenly belligerent vocals, often denouncing other people's lies. At the Marquee on Thursday night, E.M.F. played a short hyperactive set, with band members jumping around the stage like professionals and audience members jumping off it.

title: Gooden, Mets Near New Deal
description: After months of negotiations and a handful of crises concerning deadlines and threats of filing for free agency, Dwight Gooden appears on the verge of an agreement with the Mets for a three-year contract extension.

title: Outdoors: Sighting the 'Extinct' Eastern Cougar
description: FEDERAL and state wildlife experts say the animal is extinct, doesn't exist, isn't here, can't be found.

title: Fed Kept Policy Steady in February
description: The policy-making body of the Federal Reserve voted unanimously at its February meeting to leave credit policy unchanged, but with a tilt toward lower rates, minutes of the meeting show.

title: 20,000 U.S. TROOPS TO BE WITHDRAWN FROM SOUTH IRAQ
description: The United States Army plans to begin withdrawing about 20,000 troops from southern Iraq within two weeks, Army commanders said today. The pullout would amount to about a quarter of the American combat forces in the region.

title: Review/Television; The Painful Conundrum Of American Education
description: "America's Schools: Who Gives a Damn?" is the question posed by the latest Columbia University Seminar on Media and Society. On the evidence of this two-part program, at least its 18 informed and earnest participants do. But their discussion, which starts at 10 tonight on Channel 13 and 49 and concludes tomorrow at the same hour, may leave you wondering whether anything can be done to improve what this pride of educators, officials and business executives agree is an appalling situation.

title: Price Fixing Isn't Always Gouging
description: Should a manufacturer ever be allowed to stop a retailer from cutting prices? No, said the Supreme Court in 1911, declaring any such attempts automatically illegal. No, say many consumers, fearing the demise of their favorite discounter.

title: Review/Music; The Tokyo String Quartet
description: The Tokyo String Quartet traversed familiar ground on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, as if to luxuriate in the lofty current state of its art. The program consisted of Beethoven's early F-major Quartet (Op. 18, No. 1), Toru Takemitsu's "A Way a Lone," commissioned by the group a decade ago for its 10th anniversary, and Brahms's Piano Quintet (Op. 34). Barry Douglas, the pianist in the Tokyo's 1987 RCA recording of the Brahms, was also on hand.

title: We Don't Need War Between the Generations; Tax Cut Blunder
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: A Lineup to Respect

title: Fight to Save Salmon Starts Fight Over Water
description: A shout away from the point on the Continental Divide where Lewis and Clark crested the Rockies in 1805, another of the American West's wonder creatures is about to become extinct.

title: INSIDE
description: A Credit-Card Incentive Citibank plans to guarantee people who shop with its cards that they will pay the lowest available price for their purchases. Page D1.

title: Closing of Gospel Show Echoing in Legal Battle
description: Eight years of rhythmical foot stomping and hand clapping, rolling bass notes and soaring high C's on the stage of the Heckscher Theater came to a halt Saturday night.

title: Where to Find High-Priced Help
description: FOR anyone surprised by the release of Bo Jackson and Fernando Valenzuela, check the waiver wire at 2 P.M. tomorrow. That is the latest hour a major league team can ask waivers on a player and not have to pay his entire 1991 salary, if it was not guaranteed.

title: Macy Edges Away From Abyss
description: Success is a relative thing, and nowhere is that clearer than at R. H. Macy & Company, the huge retailer, where the financial picture is finally starting to look brighter after more than two years of severe problems.

title: Health Chief's Illness Leaves Albany Policies in Doubt
description: One month after New York State's Health Commissioner suffered a crippling stroke, there is growing uncertainty about whether Dr. David Axelrod's myriad innovations can survive without his iron will and his unrivaled influence with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Iran Says U.S. Incited and Then Deserted Rebels
description: A senior Iranian official accused the United States today of having misled the Iraqi people by encouraging them to overthrow President Saddam Hussein and then giving Iraq a "green light" to suppress the rebellion.

title: North Dakota Honors Dr. King
description: North Dakota has become the 48th state to give its workers a paid day off in memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Gov. George Sinner, a Democrat, signed the legislation on Thursday and said the holiday would remind North Dakotans of the philosophy of civil rights and nonviolence that Dr. King espoused. Arizona and New Hampshire are now the only states without a paid holiday in honor of Dr. King.

title: New Campaigns
description: * To demonstrate the smoothness of its Glenfiddich malt scotch, William Grant & Sons compares drinking the beverage with performing various activities under ideal conditions: sailing in a swimming pool, using a putter to strike a golf ball on top of a pool table and driving a vintage race car on a marble floor. The campaign, which was prepared by Chiat/Day/ Mojo New York, first appeared in weekly magazines in March and appears in the April editions of several monthly magazines. * In a new television ad prepared by Lintas New York, the International Business Machines Corporation illustrates the power of its new PS/2 laptop computer with a man on an airplane who opens his brief case and discovers an entire office inside. "Imagine having your office right in your lap, wherever you go," an announcer says. "Now, I.B.M. has a new laptop computer that lets you retrieve information, revise budgets, create presentations -- even at 30,000 feet."

title: CHRONICLE
description: PATRICIA L. FRANCY, the treasurer and controller of Columbia University, is the new chairwoman of the Stella and Charles Guttman Breast Diagnostic Institute in Manhattan, a center dedicated to early detection of breast cancer. Ms. Francy, 45, is also chairwoman of the Women's Economic Round Table, composed of financial executives.

title: Miscellaneous
description: * Carmichael Lynch, a Minneapolis agency, has agreed to acquire Harris & West Advertising, also in Minneapolis. Terms were not disclosed. * Time Warner Inc. has signed an $18 million, two-year deal with TV Guide magazine. The agreement calls for advertising in TV Guide, as well as joint marketing programs between the magazine and Time Warner's books, movies, music and television operations.

title: Student-Athletes? Not Unthinkable.
description: Colleges can have both brains and brawn -- the most powerful sports teams in the nation and athletes who get bona fide educations. That's one lesson contained in a study of college graduation rates published last week in The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: Slovak Separatists Proud of Nazi Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Anything with an American flag on it is selling through the roof in Europe right now." -- Zapata Espinosa, editor of Mountain Bike Action. [ D5:1. ]

title: Berra Plays It Safe on Bronx
description: THERE may not be a whole lot of reasons to keep a close eye on the Yankees this year, but one date bears watching: Old-Timers Day, July 27, 1991.

title: Accounts
description: * Tropicana International Group, Bradenton, Fla., to Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, for its international advertising. Billings were not disclosed. * U.S. Sports, Lake Worth, Fla., to Pagano Schenck & Kay, Providence, R.I., for its canvas footwear. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Soviets Brace for Less of Less On Eve of Big Price Increases
description: Consumer prices across the Soviet Union will soar by an average of 250 percent on Tuesday as the Government begins its long-awaited price reform. Outside the Kremlin, there are not many who believe that the measure will bring more than another spiral of misery.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Boom in Mountain Bikes Revives the U.S. Industry
description: The easy-riding mountain bike -- a fat-wheeled bicycle devised for the dirt trails of California -- is sweeping the world in popularity and propelling American manufacturers to the front of the pack.

title: Indians May Transport Peyote
description: Indians can legally transport the hallucinogenic drug peyote to reservations for religious ceremonies and health purposes under an Idaho law that goes into effect on July 1. Gov. Cecil Andrus signed a bill Friday. Twenty-three states have similar laws, and Federal law already allows Indians to use the drug on reservations. Tribal leaders say peyote has medicinal and sacramental uses.

title: Korean G.N.P. Up a Brisk 9%
description: South Korea's economy grew 9 percent in 1990, up from 6.8 percent in 1989, despite sluggish exports and setbacks in the farming sector, the Bank of Korea reports.

title: Homes for 35,000 Planned on Suburban Site the Size of Manhattan
description: In an Orange County forest the size of Manhattan, the Sterling Forest Corporation plans to create a suburban network of residential hamlets and commercial centers where 35,000 people will eventually live.

title: Woman, Dancing in Street, Is Struck and Killed by Car
description: A friend of Rosanna Escalante's said the young Queens woman was dancing in the street early yesterday when she was struck and killed by a passing car that dragged her body for four blocks and sped away.

title: Orioles Trade Pete's Son to Sox
description: PETE ROSE'S son hasn't had a taste of major league ball yet but he now knows what it's like to be traded. Pete Jr. was dealt yesterday from the Baltimore Orioles' organization to the Chicago White Sox minor league system. Rose, a 21-year-old infielder, batted .232 at Class A Frederick last season. He was Baltimore's 13th pick in the June 1988 amateur draft. Joe Borowski, a 19-year-old pitcher who was 2-8 with Class A Sarasota last season, was sent to the Oriole system in exchange for Rose . . . Atlanta Braves first baseman Nick Esasky, who is seeking to come back from the effects of vertigo, has been sued for divorce by his wife. Vicki Suzanne Esasky filed a divorce petition in Cobb Superior Court in Marietta, Ga., on March 20, stating that their marriage "is irretrievably broken" and seeking custody of the couple's two children. Esasky has played in some "B" exhibition games, but yesterday was placed on the 15-day disabled list.

title: Review/Dance; A Perceptive Wanderer Grapples With Objects
description: An amiable-looking man wandered through the world, gazing in puzzlement about him. Wherever he went, the world loomed ominously up at him, as if to say, "What do you think you're staring at, kid?" Yet he kept on staring.

title: Postcard for Carnegie Hall
description: In an uncharacteristically silent centennial celebration, Car-negie Hall will be honored today by a postal card issued by the United States Postal Service.

title: 35-40 News Managers Lose Jobs, Union Says
description: Thirty-five to 40 management workers who supervised mailers, paperhandlers and pressmen at The Daily News were laid off over the weekend, the head of the Allied Printing Trades Council said yesterday.

title: Halina Rosenthal, 73, a Leader In Efforts to Save Landmarks, Dies
description: Halina Rosenthal, a leader in promoting zoning laws and landmarks legislation throughout New York City, died yesterday afternoon at her home in Manhattan. She was 73 years old.

title: Review/Theater; Two Disparate Couples Know Pain of Adoption
description: The usefulness of theater as a forum for contemporary issues is confirmed by "The Baby Dance," Jane Anderson's play about problems of adoption. The fact that the work (at Long Wharf Theater) is flawed does not decrease one's interest in the arguments raised. It is a play that audiences will take home with them; it might provoke disagreement, as do the issues themselves.

title: Foreign Stocks Gain, But U.S. Investors Lag
description: It was a good quarter for investors in foreign stock markets. But it was not so good for Americans.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Capital Cities/ABC Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $500 million shelf offering of debt securities and warrants to buy debt securities. * Tenneco Inc. and its Tenneco Credit Corp. subsidiary have filed with the S.E.C. for $1 billion in debt securities, with each registering to sell $500 million.

title: Dollar Called Important As Factor in Fed Policy
description: The dollar, seemingly ignored by the Federal Reserve Board when it was weak, may be rising in importance as a policy consideration now that it is strong, credit market analysts say.

title: A Troubled Operation PUSH Struggles to Focus Its Mission
description: Operation PUSH, the Chicago civil rights organization founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, is going through a period of upheaval, struggling to reshape its identity in the face of financial troubles and the resignation of its executive director, the Rev. Tyrone Crider.

title: America Needs Alaska's Oil
description: The Congressional debate over U.S. energy policy is taking place 4,000 miles from an area that lies at the heart of the issue -- the coastal plain of Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

title: Lennox Plans Job Cuts
description: Lennox Industries, a maker of air-conditioners, furnaces and heat pumps, said Friday that it would eliminate 600 jobs this year in closing a sales office and a manufacturing operation in Forth Worth. Corwin Hall, a spokesman for the company, based in Richardson, Tex., said the sales office, which doubles as Southwest division headquarters for a five-state region, would close by June. He said operations at the manufacturing plant would be phased out starting in June and that it would be closed by the end of the year. Some employees would be offered transfers to headquarters, he said, but most would lose their jobs.

title: Reviews/Music; The Return Of 'Tosca': Big Sight, Big Sound
description: Franco Zeffirelli's six-year-old production of "Tosca" returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night, its smooth surface intact. The opulent gigantism of Mr. Zeffirelli's scenery still set audiences back in their seats. Saturday's singing boomed healthily. Little of subtlety transpired, but then is Puccini's opera -- with its cartoonlike characters and superb melodrama -- terribly subtle to begin with?

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARTHUR L. LIMAN, who was chief counsel to the 1987 United States Senate committee that investigated OLIVER L. NORTH and the Iran-contra connection, in which the Government diverted profits from weapons sold to Iran to aid the Nicaraguan rebels, and who represents MICHAEL R. MILKEN, the convicted junk-bond dealer, is to receive the Legal Aid Society's highest award on April 23. A partner in the Manhattan law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, Mr. Liman, 58 years old, is a former president of the society and helped mobilize major law firms to contribute legal services to the poor.

title: Israel Decides to Broaden Expulsion Policy
description: The Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir formally decided today to widen the policy of deporting Palestinians from the occupied territories, authorizing the expulsion of people suspected of having incited others to attack Jews.

title: No Budget By Deadline In New York
description: As New York State enters a new fiscal year on Monday without a budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders are mired in a severe dispute that focuses in large part on taxes -- not just how much more of them there should be but who exactly should pay them.

title: Eastern Parkway Mired as Rules Protect Slow Contractor
description: In 1939, the Works Progress Administration guidebook to New York City said that Eastern Parkway -- whose grandeur and idealistic conception were a model for urban boulevards throughout America -- "recalls the Champs-Elysees."

title: Market Place; Volatile Trading In Collectible Cars
description: TWO years ago the prices of older exotic European cars like Ferrari, Aston Martin and Jaguar were skyrocketing, often doubling in a few months. Then early last year, the bottom dropped out of the market. Cars went unsold at auctions or were bid on only by owners trying to prop up the market.

title: Ireland's Easter: Amid Grieving, Hope's Renewal
description: More death has come to Northern Ireland along with the resurrection of hope this season, and so on Easter Sunday today, the Roman Catholic people of this little town had to bury three more victims of sectarian killing.

title: Trophy Car For Indy Winner
description: MANY major league baseball players have bats and gloves with their signatures on them, so it figures a race car driver would choose a car when selling something with his signature.

title:
N.C.A.A. SHOWDOWN: SCOUTING REPORT;
Matchup to Test Mental Prowess
description: When the invitations were sent to all the teams to attend the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship, few experts figured the last two teams on the court would be Duke and Kansas.

title: Starks Can't Stop Impressing Knicks
description: When John Starks has got an opportunity, he has made the most of it.

title: Cautiously, Advertisers Rush to Eastern Europe
description: With little fanfare, Hungarians have been eating Herz Salami for decades. Soon, they are going to learn why they should eat competing salamis, one ad at a time.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. The Treasury will also auction a one-year bill.

title: Albania Rulers and Foes in Close Race
description: Initial voting results in Albania's first modern and free legislative elections indicated late tonight that the newly formed opposition Democratic Party was in a tight race with the Communist Party, which has tyrannized this country for the last 46 years.

title: Press Empire Wields Great Power in Spain
description: Jesus de Polanco is used to being called Spain's Rupert Murdoch or Robert Maxwell, but he quickly dismisses the analogy as inaccurate. "They are businessmen and financiers," he said recently. "I think of myself as a professional of communications and culture."

title: Alcott Keeps Word, Takes The Plunge
description: Amy Alcott completed one of the most dominating performances in the recent history of women's golf today when she won the 20th Nabisco Dinah Shore, the first major championship of the Ladies Professional Golf Association season.

title: Louisiana Farmers, Finding Gold in Alligator Skins, Face a Changing Market
description: Raywood Stelly opened the shed door on more than 200 small alligators, releasing their gamey aroma in a gush of suffocatingly hot, moist air.

title:
Two-Handed Backswing Versus One: Advantage, Both;
The Stroke Of Power
description: Tennis, like anything else, is a game of fads. As long as the Australian serve-and-volley players were ruling the roost in the 60's, and the American serve-and-volley players before them, nobody ever seriously thought about hitting anything except a one-handed backhand.

title: Japanese Couldn't Break the Navajo Code
description: To the Editor:

title: A Citibank Promise To Shoppers
description: In the latest enticement to credit-card users, Citibank plans to announce as early as today that it will guarantee people who shop with its cards that they will pay the lowest available price for their purchases.

title: Middle-Class Flight Feared By New York City Experts
description: With a job at an advertising agency and a one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side, Matthew Luba settled into the life he had looked forward to. He was a New Yorker.

title: Favoring the Gas Guzzlers
description: President Bush has challenged Congress to approve his transportation program within 100 days. That won't happen. Congress's real challenge is more daunting -- to rethink and reshape the Government's role in an efficient transportation system, now that the interstate highway network is nearly complete. Mr. Bush is only stumbling in the right direction.

title: Bridge
description: Some famous collections of deals have been placed in unlikely settings. In "Right Through the Pack" Robert Darvas had each card tell a story during a dream. And Victor Mollo, in a series of books, had the Hideous Hog, the Rueful Rabbit and other animal characters reveal their shrewdness or lack of it. There has been a collection involving the personalities of the Trojan War, and another set in Valhalla with a variety of historical figures.

title: What Feminist Victory in the Court?
description: Am I the only feminist less than thrilled at the Supreme Court's decision on March 20 to grant women the right to risk the health of their unborn?

title: Iraq Asserts It Has Retaken 3 Vital Towns From Kurds
description: Challenged by the most intense and widespread uprising in Iraq's modern history, Baghdad asserted today that the worst of the revolt was over, saying loyalist forces had retaken three important towns in the Kurdish north, including the oil town of Kirkuk.

title: We Don't Need War Between the Generations
description: To the Editor:

title: The Search for Real People For Poli-Grip Commercials
description: AS advertisers rely more heavily on the real touch in product endorsements, consumers are popping up far more often as featured players in commercials. But advertisers find it tough to locate the right real people.

title: Canseco Next Up To Face a Jinx
description: EXACTLY six years ago, Sports Illustrated wrote about a Mets pitcher named Sidd Finch who was odd looking and had odd habits and an amazing 168-mile-an-hour fastball. Readers were duped by the story about the strange character who threw incredibly harder than Dwight Gooden -- until they checked the date of the magazine. April Fools'!

title: Elkington Captures The Players Title
description: Steve Elkington rose out of a pack of golfers and a shallow divot today to birdie the final hole and win the Players Championship by one shot over Fuzzy Zoeller.

title: Hershiser Put on Disabled List
description: Orel Hershiser, still recovering from last year's shoulder surgery, was put on the 15-day disabled list by the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

title: Hurley Can Face Friends
description: After Duke's redemptive victory over Nevada-Las Vegas in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament on Saturday night, Bobby Hurley can do something that he hasn't been able to do for a year: make eye contact with his friends.

title: Seoul Journal; A Window Opens on Japan, the Forbidden Land
description: One of the lasting legacies of Japan's brutal occupation of Korea for most of the first half of this century is a nearly ironclad ban on Japanese culture. South Korea's theaters are forbidden from showing Japanese movies. Japanese-language pop songs are barred from airwaves. Seoul may be the only major capital in Asia where it is virtually impossible to find a Toyota on the streets.

title:
Two-Handed Backswing Versus One: Advantage, Both;
A Shot That Delivers Pace
description: A lot has happened in tennis in the last 20 years, since Bjorn Borg and Chris Evert came around, and Tracy Austin, this little girl with the two-handed backhand.

title: Graf Defeats Seles For First '91 Title
description: Steffi Graf will not regain the No. 1 world ranking after defeating Monica Seles, 6-4, 6-3, today in the final of the United States women's hardcourt championships.

title: War Stories
description: The most telling comment on the war with Iraq was made by Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who said, "We certainly did not expect it to go this way."

title: Review/Television; Exploring the Beauty of Ancient Maps
description: Take a helping of simple curiosity; add practical needs, political aspirations, religious faith and abiding superstitions, and prepare with mathematical calculation, careful observation, intuition and imagination, and you have the makings of what an ambitious new PBS series calls "The Shape of the World." The six-parter, which begins at 9 tonight on Channel 13 and at 10 on Channel 21, explores the history of map-making with elegance and intelligence.

title: Barfield Makes Some Contact
description: MIAMI, March 31 -- No one seems worried about Jesse Barfield, but time is running out and he is still having trouble at the plate. In one week, the Yankees' season will open in Detroit, and there is a distinct possibility that Barfield will not be the Yankees' everyday right fielder.

title: McDonald's Loses Case in Worker's Crash
description: A jury has held the McDonald's Corporation liable for a fatal traffic accident caused by an employee who fell asleep at the wheel after working all night.

title: U.N. Council Closer to Approving Iraq Resolution
description: The Security Council moved closer today to approving a tough new resolution that could officially end the gulf war later this week and allow the withdrawal of all remaining allied forces from southern Iraq, Western diplomats said.

title: Hard Times For Innovator In Graphics
description: Steven P. Jobs's other company, Pixar, is having difficulties, just as his Next Inc. has begun to report improved sales of its computer work station.

title: Anthropology Casts an Eye On the Culture That Made It
description: BY studying other societies, Western anthropologists have sought to derive lessons about their own, as Dr. Margaret Mead did in her classic 1928 study, "Coming of Age in Samoa." In a signficant new trend, some anthropologists in this country are focusing on coming of age here at home, using the same methods of ethnography they would apply in an exotic land.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about new charges for applicants for the A.T.&T. Universal Card misattributed a comment in some editions. The statement -- that A.T.&T. appeared to be giving up promoting the card -- was made by Joseph E. Wallace, a credit card consultant in Chicago. (David F. Robertson, vice president of the Nilson Report, a credit card newsletter, said the changes made financial sense.)

title: People
description: * Chuck Riley has been named executive vice president and group director on the Chevron account at Young & Rubicam San Francisco. * Edward Keane, Xenia Politis, James Nealey and Thomas Collins have been named vice presidents at FCB/Lewis, Gilman & Kynett Inc., Philadelphia.

title: Jets Drop Murdoch
description: After the Winnipeg Jets failed to make the National Hockey League playoffs for the second time in three years, Bob Murdoch was dismissed yesterday as the team's head coach. He had been named coach of the year for the 1989-90 season after taking over a dismal Winnipeg team and adding 21 points to its total of the previous season.

title: Ban on Cuban Art Is Eased
description: A 28-year ban on bringing Cuban paintings and drawings into the United States has been lifted by the United States Treasury Department, which yesterday issued a new regulation allowing their importation.

title: Large Insurer Has Big Loss For Quarter
description: The First Executive Corporation, the insurance company hobbled by its large investment in "junk bonds," reported another large quarterly loss today. The company's auditors warned that the loss could imperil First Executive's future.

title: On My Mind; Why the Betrayal?
description: Why has President Bush rejected his own human and military instinct to prevent Saddam Hussein's gunship helicopters from massacring Iraqi rebels? Why, when a White House order would have grounded them?

title: The Day the Eating Stopped
description: Everybody's got a story about why it happened. For one person it was the small plop of risotto with baby shrimp listed as a "starter" for $25. For another it was the 30 minutes he spent cooling his heels near the coat check at the place where he'd reserved two weeks in advance. For a third it was the plonk that was the cheapest thing on the wine list at $25 a bottle. For all of them, though, it was the day the eating stopped.

title: T.W.A. Suitor Is Described By Icahn as 'a Spoiler' in Bid
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, said today that Kirk Kerkorian, a wealthy Los Angeles investor, was trying to be "a spoiler" in his effort to buy T.W.A.

title: Air Force Rocket Booster Explodes in Initial Firing
description: A section of a new rocket booster being developed by the Air Force exploded today during a test firing at Edwards Air Force Base, dealing another setback to the nation's space program, Air Force officials and civilian experts said.

title: Long-Lasting Livestock Threat
description: FOR years, an unidentified infectious agent has been killing large numbers of sheep in Iceland by turning their brains to mush. Worse yet, a new study indicates this virus-like substance remains lethal in the soil for at least three years after the infected animals are buried there.

title: Chess
description: Feasibility is one of the game's most important considerations. For instance, you may want to play in good old gambit style, but if you have not laid the groundwork properly, you will fail. It is no different if your preference is severe positional play in the manner of Anatoly Karpov. You must first establish sufficient control of the position to bring about your favorite battleground.

title: Save the Child Before She Becomes a High-Risk Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians Tense on Eve of Price Rises
description: Battered Soviet consumers braced themselves today on the eve of sweeping retail price increases, with extra goods expected in the sparsely stocked stores and extra troops already patrolling the anxious nation's cities.

title: Rebel Serbs Complicate Rift on Yugoslav Unity
description: Rebel Serbs in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia announced today that they had decided to unite their area politically with Serbia and mobilize armed civil-defense and volunteer units loyal to them.

title: Paulo Muwanga, 70, Ex-Ugandan Official
description: Former Vice President Paulo Muwanga died today, the state radio reported. He was 70 years old.

title: Review/Dance; 3 Women, One Stage Set, No Stage Set
description: Contact improvisation is a resilient, flowing form of physical improvisation in which bodies act as springboards and levers for other bodies. It can be exhilarating to watch. And it has three gifted and witty practitioners in D. D. Dorvillier, Jennifer Monson and Yvonne Meier, who performed in Miss Meier's "Pommes Fritz" on Friday night at Performance Space 122.

title: Gunmen in Santiago Slay Pinochet Adviser
description: A longtime friend and close adviser to Chile's former military ruler, General Augusto Pinochet, was shot and killed this evening in Santiago, apparently by leftist gunmen.

title: Most New York City Bridges Are Failing, a Study Finds
description: Almost 70 percent of New York City's 2,027 bridges are no longer able to carry the loads for which they were designed because of deteriorating decks, supports or superstructures, according to city and state data compiled jointly by two nonprofit research groups.

title: Business and Health; Hospital Pacts With Specialists
description: STATE courts have been redefining the professional rights of specialist physicians who have been barred from hospital facilities when their exclusive contracts were ended. The hospitals have usually prevailed but some state courts have sided with the doctors.

title: Help for the Terrified Elderly
description: Millions of elderly Americans live in terror in their own homes -- abused by spouses, children, even grandchildren. Neighbors steal Medicare checks; daughters sell the vacuum cleaner for drug money; sons steal money set aside for dentures. Some 2.5 million Americans over the age of 60 are said to suffer abuse.

title: Send Army to Georgia, Gorbachev Is Advised
description: Hours after residents of Georgia voted overwhelmingly for independence, the Soviet Parliament recommended today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declare a state of emergency and send Soviet troops into a section of the republic torn by ethnic violence.

title: Continental Ends Talks
description: Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. said today that it had ended talks to sell large parts of the carrier and was optimistic it could raise capital and remain independent.

title: Veto in North Dakota For Abortion Measure
description: Gov. George Sinner today vetoed what would have been the strictest anti-abortion bill in the nation.

title: Bush, Out for Bonefish, Catches Barracuda
description: President Bush said today that he had caught only barracuda, not the bonefish he was seeking, on the first day of his fishing vacation here.

title: English Orchestra Gets a New Concert Hall
description: The City of Birmingham likes its Symphony Orchestra so much that it has built a brilliant new concert hall it hopes will be the best in England when it opens on April 15.

title: Joffrey Appointment
description: Robert Yesselman has been named executive director of the Joffrey Ballet. He was executive director of the Paul Taylor Dance Company for 14 years, and was general manager of American Ballet Theater's Ballet Repertory Company in the early 1970's. He is a former chairman of the dance panel of the New York State Council on the Arts, and received a distinguished achievement award from Dance Magazine in 1988. The Joffrey Ballet will begin a three-month national tour on April 16.

title: Craig Rushes to Raiders As Plan B Season Ends
description: The Los Angeles Raiders added another former San Francisco star to their roster when they signed running back Roger Craig yesterday, the final day for Plan B free agents to change teams.

title: Tokyo Stocks Advance
description: Stocks were higher in Tokyo today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 244.6 points, or 0.94 percent, to close at 26,252.

title: Fannie Mae Pricing $1.3 Billion Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association plans to price a total of $1.3 billion in bonds today through various securities dealers.

title: World's Deepest Lake Shows 8-Year Turnover
description: TRACES of an implacable atmospheric pollutant have enabled scientists to track and time the way water circulates from the surface to the bottom and back again in the world's deepest and largest body of fresh water, Lake Baikal in the Soviet Union.

title: Yanks Release Balboni After Below-Par Spring
description: Steve Balboni walked over to Don Mattingly today, stuck out his right hand and blinked back tears.

title: Texas Instruments In Pact With NEC
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said it had come to basic terms with the NEC Corporation of Japan for a new five-year semiconductor patent cross-license agreement to replace a five-year pact that had expired at the end of 1990.

title: Regulators Back Crossland Savings' Plan
description: Crossland Savings, the largest savings institution in New York City, said yesterday that Federal regulators had approved the company's plan to strengthen its financial condition.

title: Books of The Times; Stories of Confusion and Conflict
description: A Model World and Other Stories By Michael Chabon 207 pages. William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Albert W. Wein, 75; Created Sculptures In the Art Deco Style
description: Albert W. Wein, a sculptor known for his heroic Art Deco style, died on Saturday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Red Sox Trade Murphy
description: The Boston Red Sox traded left-handed reliever Rob Murphy to the Seattle Mariners yesterday for right-hander Mike Gardiner, the Class AA Eastern League's 1990 Pitcher of the Year at Williamsport.

title: How Can the U.S. Stand Idly By?
description: The question becomes all the more poignant as wounded Iraqis straggle into allied-held territory bearing the marks of their oppression: How can Americans watch Saddam Hussein's army crush opponents of his hateful regime without doing anything? Even some G.I.'s wonder why they can't finish the job instead of pulling back from Iraq. And critics flay the Bush Administration for failing to overthrow Saddam Hussein, or at least protect the rebels.

title: Save the Child Before She Becomes a High-Risk Mother; Catastrophic Damage
description: To the Editor:

title: Anger and Resignation Greet Romania's Food-Price Rises
description: Romanians confronted their biggest food-price increases in almost half a century today with a mixture of anger and grudging acceptance.

title: U.S. Orders Changes at First City of Texas
description: Federal banking regulators, citing insufficient capital funds at the four largest subsidiary banks of the First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc., have ordered the banks to take several steps to shore up their lending practices and devise a long-term plan, First City said.

title: Scowcroft Went to Talk With Saudis, U.S. Says
description: President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, traveled to Saudi Arabia last week for high-level security consultations requested by senior advisers to King Fahd, according to Administration officials.

title: Swanton Journal; Town Tilts With a Wolf. Or a Dog?
description: The tim ing could scarcely have been worse. Last Tuesday, less than 24 hours after the movie "Dances With Wolves" won seven Oscars at this year's Academy Awards ceremonies, lawyers for this town of 5,600 people in northwestern Vermont were asking a court for permission to destroy a wolf. Worse yet, the wolf belongs to an Indian tribe.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Long Island Lighting Co., Hicksville, L.I., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of $830 million in general and refunding bonds and $65 million in preferred stock.

title: Children of Empire Outdo Britannia's Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Stakes at Small Film Company
description: Last Monday was a great night for Kevin Costner, whose movie, "Dances With Wolves," won seven Academy Awards. But next to Mr. Costner, perhaps no one enjoyed the evening more or stands to benefit as directly from the film's success as a former Subaru car distributor whose small company is producing Mr. Costner's next film.

title: G.I.'s, Facing a Moral Quandary, Try to Aid Iraqis
description: At Checkpoint Bravo here in the Euphrates River Valley, Lieut. Col. Stephen Smith has the unpleasant duty of asking fleeing Iraqis to go home.

title: Road To Derby Is a Toll Road
description: The road to the Kentucky Derby, which is always lined with broken horses and broken dreams, counted some significant new victims over the weekend.

title: Cable TV Loss Higher in '90
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the big cable television provider, today reported a net loss of $287 million for 1990. The company cited higher interest expenses, among other factors.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Presents Panel to Review Police Dept.
description: Mayor Tom Bradley today introduced his citizens' panel that will investigate the Police Department in the aftermath of a videotaped beating of a motorist a month ago.

title: Dinkins Will Visit Ex-I.R.A. Member
description: Fulfilling a long-held wish, Mayor David N. Dinkins on Thursday will visit Joseph Doherty, the former member of the Irish Republican Army who has been held in the Federal Metropolitan Correctional Center in Lower Manhattan since 1983.

title: Defendant Asks to Face Grand Jury
description: A New York City correction officer who was charged with assaulting a police officer in a disturbance in Harlem last year is asking to appear before a grand jury so she can accuse the arresting officer of brutality and false arrest.

title: 3 Divisions Set At D.M.B.& B.
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Inc. said yesterday that it had reorganized its operations into three geographical divisions and reassigned several top managers to new positions.

title: GAMBLING RETURNS TO THE MISSISSIPPI
description: The stern faces of blackjack players, the whoops and shouts of winners and the resigned side glances of losers returned to the muddy water of the Mississippi River today for the first time since hard-drinking roughnecks ruled turn-of-the-century paddle wheelers.

title: Careers; An Overhaul For Business Education
description: STUDENTS who plan to enroll in undergraduate and graduate business schools in a few years should be interested in what happens at a meeting in St. Louis later this month.

title: Nicholls Summoned From the Rangers' Bench to Neilson's Carpet
description: The scene came straight from school days, when the student stays after the final bell for detention in the principal's office.

title: Shift in Command Made At K Mart of Canada
description: Donald A. Beaumont yesterday was appointed president and chief executive officer of K Mart Canada Ltd., a subsidiary of the K Mart Corporation, the third-largest American retailer. The appointment of the 56-year-old Mr. Beaumont, a Canadian, returns the subsidiary to the supervision of a Canadian for the first time since 1988.

title: An Editorial Haircut
description: Today's editorial and Op-Ed pages introduce some alterations of typography, the arrangement of material printed from type, and typology, which concerns types, or categories. These are not dramatic costume changes but refinements, on the order of a haircut, that are intended to serve legibility and logic.

title: Duke's N.C.A.A. Drought Comes to End
description: No sooner had Duke dethroned Nevada-Las Vegas on Saturday, the so-called experts began to theorize that the Blue Devils might be too drained and emotionally spent against Kansas tonight to carry the task through and bring the school its first national championship.

title: Failure Rate In England
description: Almost 8,000 businesses collapsed in the first three months of 1991 in England and Wales, the highest failure rate in any quarter since 1980, a Dun & Bradstreet survey showed today.

title: Patterns
description: Good Sales in Paris

title: Ketchum Unit Wins Yellow Pages Accounts
description: Ketchum Directory Advertising, Chicago, said yesterday that it had won two Yellow Pages accounts: the Allstate Insurance Company account for the Western half of the United States, with billings of about $7 million, and the Budget Rent A Car corporate account, with billings of about $8 million.

title: Review/Music; Israeli Pianist in Recital
description: Rina Dokshinsky, an Israeli pianist who won a Young Concert Artists award in 1987, gave a consistently eloquent and exciting recital last Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y.

title: First Nationwide Bank In Pact With Regulators
description: First Nationwide Bank, the savings institution owned by the Ford Motor Company, has signed an agreement with Federal regulators requiring it to overhaul its management practices and correct possible violations of savings rules.

title: Afghan Rebels Take Garrison Town, U.S. Reports
description: Afghan guerrillas have seized the garrison town of Khost and captured 6,000 Government troops to begin a spring offensive to try to topple the Soviet-backed Government, Administration officials said today.

title: Assad and Mubarak Meet And Oppose Breakup of Iraq
description: In their first meeting since the end of the Persian Gulf war, the Presidents of Egypt and Syria said today that they were opposed to the splintering of Iraq, and they called for an international peace conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Review/Theater; An Evening of One-Acts On Rules of Relationships
description: Rules and rigidities of marital and business relationships are at the core of an evening of five one-acts presented by the Women's Project. Four of the plays are as literal as they are commonplace. Only one, Marlane Meyer's "Relativity," has even a spark of mystery to it, and that is not enough to save it from the mediocrity of the evening.

title: In Europe, Too, Auto Sales Sag
description: Executives of Europe's major car manufacturers speak of the Germans these days with reverence, and for good reason: The booming German market is all that separates the European car industry from disaster.

title: New Jersey Ruling Upholds Drug Testing by Businesses
description: An appeals court panel today upheld random drug testing by private employers, saying the tests do not violate the right of privacy or constitutional protections against unreasonable searches.

title: Hyman Ashman; Physician, 81
description: Hyman Ashman, a physician for 50 years who retired in 1985, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Lawrence K. Miller; Publisher, 83
description: Lawrence K. Miller, former editor and publisher of The Berkshire Eagle, died of pneumonia on Sunday. He was 83 years old.

title: Corrections
description: The 1991 major league baseball schedules in the Sports section on Sunday omitted an explanation for asterisks that appeared next to many dates. The symbol denoted night games.

title: 2 Campeau Units Narrow Losses
description: The two American retailing units of Canada's troubled Campeau Corporation reported improved sales and narrower losses for February. The Federated Department Stores Corporation and Allied Stores Inc. provided the data to the bankruptcy court in Cincinnati, where they are reorganizing under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code.

title: Dwight Gooden: Video Star
description: What with Fernando Valenzuela and Bo Jackson going down, it was refreshing to see the Mets finding room for one of their venerable heroes with a bit of a price tag to him.

title: General Instrument To Sell Radar Unit
description: Litton Industries Inc. said it had agreed to purchase the Defense Systems Group of the General Instrument Corporation for an undisclosed price. Litton, a military contractor and industrial company based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said the acquisition would add about $200 million in annual sales to its electronic warfare systems business. Litton and the General Instrument group each make radar warning systems used by aircraft, helicopters and ships to evade enemies.

title: Chemical May Draw Sperm To Egg
description: SCIENTISTS may have discovered an important clue in the mystery of human conception. A new study suggests that a substance in the fluid surrounding a woman's egg beckons waiting sperm to swim over when the egg is ready to be fertilized.

title: Bulls Suspend King
description: The Chicago Bulls suspended Stacey King, a reserve, for one game without pay for missing practice yesterday. He will sit out tonight's home game against the Orlando Magic, said a Bulls spokeswoman, Joyce Szymanski.

title: Mysterious Asteroid
description: A rocky asteroid about 3.1 miles across, suspected of being a dead comet, has been found in an unusual orbit between Mars and Uranus, Australian astronomers have reported.

title: U.S. Eases Irish Trade
description: The Commerce Department said today that it was easing regulations governing the exports of controlled goods and technology to Ireland. The revised regulations include expedited license processing and re-exports from Ireland of more American-made products to China and some allied nations. Controls are established for national security reasons and the department's policy is to extend licensing benefits to countries that have programs designed to guard against diversion of controlled items.

title: Reviews/Dance; Nature Is the Subject Of Erick Hawkins Bill
description: As a choreographer, Erick Hawkins would never fit into the life-is-art school. The random has no place in his dances, and he would probably feel less at home with Marcel Duchamp than with Picasso, who drew a distinct line between art and nature.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARIANNE WIGGINS is seeking a divorce from SALMAN RUSHDIE , she told The Sunday Times of London. Ms. Wiggins, an American writer, married Mr. Rushdie in January 1988, 13 months before he was forced into seclusion after his novel "The Satanic Verses" provoked a death threat from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the late Iranian leader. He accused Mr. Rushdie of blasphemy against Islam.

title: Judge Rejects Paramount Request, But Buchwald Hasn't Won Yet
description: The Superior Court judge in Art Buchwald's suit to obtain a share of the profits from the hit movie "Coming to America" today refused a request by Paramount Pictures to reopen arguments in the case, saying he would not allow himself to be manipulated into reconsidering his earlier ruling that the standard movie studio contract is inherently unfair.

title: Cutbacks by Network News Ground Bush's Press Plane
description: In a symbol of the financial retrenchment taking place throughout the network news business, the press plane covering the President of the United States was canceled by the White House for a trip last weekend after the networks significantly reduced their staffing on the Presidential fishing vacation.

title: Some Top Ogilvy Officials Seen in Plan to Buy Agency
description: SOME of Ogilvy & Mather's top executives have been quietly talking with at least one investment bank about a plan to buy the agency back from the WPP Group, its financially troubled parent, some prominent American advertising executives and bankers said yesterday.

title: KURDS FALL BACK FROM IRAQ FORCES
description: Kurdish rebels in Iraq were reported falling back on snowbound mountain fastnesses today as Baghdad's forces pressed a campaign of retribution into their adversaries' northernmost refuges.

title: Cambodia May Be Last Vietnam War Casualty
description: To the Editor:

title: Environmentalists Criticize Plan For Sterling Forest Development
description: Environmentalists and New Jersey officials today bitterly protested a private company's plan to build a suburban-style development in Sterling Forest, the largest woodland left in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Study of Premature Infants Finds Drug Aids Survival
description: Immediately treating highly premature infants with a chemical extracted from calf lungs can sharply reduce the risk that they will develop potentially fatal breathing problems, a team of New York doctors says.

title: Realtors' Ads To Protest Rise in Taxes
description: Led by major realtors and landlords, an unusual coalition of New York City property owners is about to start a million-dollar advertising and direct-mail campaign urging taxpayers to write Mayor David N. Dinkins and other officials to oppose the Mayor's proposal for higher real-estate taxes.

title: Brooklyn Undercover Officer Shot in Hand in Drug Chase
description: An 24-year-old undercover officer was shot in the hand in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn last night when narcotics investigators exchanged shots with a suspect.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Germany Completes Sweep Germany, already assured of a place in the Davis Cup semifinals, completed a 5-0 victory over Argentina by winning both singles matches yesterday in Berlin. Boris Becker beat Martin Jaite, 6-1, 7-6, and Michael Stich beat Javier Frana, 6-7, 6-1, 6-1. The singles matches yesterday, meaningless after Germany won the doubles Sunday for a 3-0 lead, were reduced to two-of-three-set matches. Germany, Davis Cup champion in 1988 and 1989, will meet either Spain or the United States in the semifinals in September. (AP) Sabatini and Capriati Win in Doubles: Singles play in the opening round of the $500,000 Family Circle Magazine Cup in Hilton Head, S.C., was overshadowed by a doubles match yesterday that teamed Gabriela Sabatini and Jennifer Capriati on the same side of the net. The two, both ranked in the top 10 in the world and playing as a doubles team for only the second time, eliminated Helen Kelesi and Katerina Maleeva, 6-4, 6-4. The winners were unseeded while Kelesi and Maleeva were seeded sixth. (AP) BOXING McCallum Retains Championship Mike McCallum of Jamaica edged Patrizio Kalembay, a Zairean-born Italian, to retain his World Boxing Association middleweight title last night in Monte Carlo, Monaco, in a 12-round split decision. McCallum won the verdict on two of the three judges' cards. The third judge had Kalembay ahead by a point. Both fighters are 34 years old and have each held the W.B.A. title over the last two years. (AP) HORSE RACING Lucky Tent Pulls Away to Victory Robert Brennan's Lucky Tent took the lead in the stretch and pulled away to carry Jean-Luc Samyn to a 5 1/2-length victory yesterday in the featured race at Aqueduct. Lucky Tent, who covered a mile on the muddy track in 1:36 2/5 under 119 pounds to earn $19,800 and return $5.00, $3.40 and $2.40 for $2 across the board. (AP) DOG SHOW Pomeranian Wins Best in Show The smallest dog in the ring, a Pomeranian, Ch. Tambo Champagne Wishes, owned by Robert Koeppel, a Manhattan lawyer, and handled by Joy Brewster, yesterday scored the biggest victory of his career, when he was named best in show at the 82d fixture of the Queensboro Kennel Club at the Nassau Coliseum, in Uniondale, L.I. In gaining the victory, the little toy dog defeated the Chow Chow, Ch. Love-Chows Risen Star, who triumphed on Saturday, and the Scottie, Ch. Brookhill Morning Edition, who was best on Sunday.

title: Dry Climate May Have Forced Invention of Agriculture
description: A SMALL step for a man, a giant leap for mankind: that's the phrase grandly applied to the first moon landing. But it suits even better an event whose outlines are emerging ever more clearly from the mists of prehistory: the discovery that wild grasses could be deliberately planted, cultivated and harvested as cereals.

title: Bridge
description: Many observers at the Spring Nationals in Atlantic City in March were impressed by the skillful play of a foursome of Soviet immigrants, who defeated two top-ranked squads in the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams before succumbing to the defending champions. An example is the diagramed deal in which Michael Prahin of New City, N.Y., and Simon Satanovsky of Brooklyn, sat North and South.

title: Leonard Hears Words of Support
description: The reaction of the boxing world to Sugar Ray Leonard's acknowledgement that he used cocaine and drank heavily in the early 1980's has been mostly sympathetic.

title: How To Avoid Burn-In
description: SCREEN-SAVER programs are useful and fun, but the ones available for I.B.M. PC's and compatibles have been rather boring compared with those available for Apple Macintosh computers. With the arrival of Microsoft Windows 3.0 and a new program called After Dark for Windows, PC screen savers have become colorful and festive.

title: A. M. McBurney, 77, Retired Executive, Dies
description: Andrew M. McBurney, a retired executive vice president of the Oxford Paper Company and a former official of the Office of Price Stabilization in Washington, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and also lived in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Islander Post-Mortem: For Shame and for Sale
description: Ask any player. Ask the coach. In the case of the 1990-91 Islanders, an obituary seems more appropriate than a review. And none of them will deny that they buried themselves.

title: By Design; The Springtime Glow of Vinyl
description: It's hard to miss the thing that makes this season's trench coats, jeans, shirts, T-shirts and even the occasional dress look new. It's vinyl, and you can spot the shine a mile away.

title: Duke's Extended Family Enjoys the Net Result
description: The national champion Duke Blue Devils were completing a ritual that had escaped them too many times. As the players took their turns climbing a ladder and cutting the strands from the net, Mike Krzyzewski, their coach, stood in the lane, looking upward.

title: Gun Law's Effectiveness Questioned
description: While Congress appears poised to pass legislation requiring at least a seven-day waiting period for the purchase of a handgun, questions are being raised about how effective even stricter measures have been in California.

title: Martha Graham Dies at 96; A Revolutionary in Dance
description: Martha Graham, a prime revolutionary in the arts of this century and the American dancer and choreographer whose name became synonymous with modern dance, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96 years old.

title: Connecticut Will Lay Off 2,600; Agencies to Close 2 Days a Month
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that the state would begin sending layoff notices to 2,600 employees, or about 5 percent of the state work force, on Tuesday and that he would order most state agencies to close their doors two additional days a month beginning in July.

title: In Westchester, A Plan to Share Homeless Pupils
description: Several suburbs in Westchester County have become the first in the state to agree to share the responsibility of educating children of homeless families.

title: Hyman Korn, 88; Served for 30 Years As New York Judge
description: Hyman Korn, a retired justice of New York State Supreme Court, died on Sunday at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rig Count Dips by One
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the nation slipped by one last week from the week before, to 910, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year earlier, there were 946 working rigs, the toolmaker reported. Two weeks ago, the number of rigs increased by three following a plunge of 40 in the previous week. Baker Hughes officials said the rig count traditionally declines through April each year.

title: FOREIGN OFFICIALS EVICTED BY GROCER
description: A delegation of official visitors from Bulgaria was ordered out of a grocery store in this Minneapolis suburb on Friday when the store's owner, worried about reports of "gypsy-looking" shoplifters, mistook the group for gypsies.

title: Observer; A Basket of Eels, Perhaps?
