description: My first impulse was to interview my wife about the awful situation in Iraq. Fortunately she was in no mood for it. She had lost her great recipe for borscht and, what's more, had just discovered that her fantastic Japanese camera was broken.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD RESTON , the paper's editor and co-publisher, said yesterday, "I've been in hiding all weekend."

title: From Journey's End to a Commuter Stop
description: It's enough to throw the New Yorker magazine's made-up railroad maven, E. M. Frimbo, into a tizzy. When the Rip Van Winkle chugs out of Grand Central Terminal on Saturday night, the Beaux-Arts landmark -- which once billed itself as the gateway to a continent -- will turn into just another commuter station: the gateway to Pelham and Poughkeepsie.

title: Report Finds Misuse Of Funds at Institute
description: The state-financed Martin Luther King Institute for Nonviolence, created in 1988 to promote racial harmony and sensitivity, has been so poorly managed that public funds were routinely misused, a report by the State Inspector General has concluded.

title: Cuomo Aide to Take New Post; Could Be Harbinger of Departures
description: One of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's most senior aides, Henrik N. Dullea, will leave the administration on June 1 for a top position at Cornell University, leading what could be a new stream of departures from the Governor's inner circle.

title: Gooden's Deal Is a Hit With Fans
description: The news came to Greg Pacelko last night as he poured a beer behind the bar at Charlie O's on 33d Street in Manhattan. Dwight Gooden had agreed to a three-year contract extension with the Mets worth $15.45 million, making him the highest paid player in the National League and the second-highest paid player in baseball behind Roger Clemens of the Boston Red Sox.

title: Beating the Best, Except for One
description: Throughout this tournament the Kansas Jayhawks had felt like longshots. Tonight the odds caught up with them as the Jayhawks fell to Duke, 72-65, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association national championship basketball game.

title: Two U.S. Sailors Deny Carrier Sabotage Plot
description: Two American sailors charged with plotting to sabotage a United States aircraft carrier during the Persian Gulf war declared their innocence today, saying they had been unjustly accused.

title: HIGH COURT LIMITS USING RACE TO BAR PEOPLE FROM JURY
description: The Supreme Court today broadened the right of criminal defendants to object to the use of race in jury selection.

title: Prague Spy Charges Raise Witch-Hunt Fear
description: Calls for the expulsion from Parliament of members accused of collaborating with the old Communist secret police have led to a sharp debate over whether the charges are appropriate or whether they represent a witch hunt.

title: Iraqi Agents and Fronts Listed by the Treasury
description: The Treasury Department, hoping to expose and neutralize a hidden financial and trading network used by Iraq to acquire military technology, released a list of 52 companies and 37 people today that it has identified as being fronts or agents for Iraq.

title: Iacocca Might Sell Shares
description: Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that he might sell as many as 315,000 shares of Chrysler's common stock, or more than three-quarters of his personal holdings.

title: Cambodia May Be Last Vietnam War Casualty; We Won on Battlefield
description: To the Editor:

title: Emory Teacher Quits Amid New Sex Charges
description: The founder and head of Emory University Law School's litigation program, resigned today amid new allegations that he had sexually harassed female law school students.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, named Allen C. Holmes vice president and general tax officer. * Hoechst Celanese Corp., Somerville, N.J., a chemicals manufacturer and subsidiary of Germany's Hoechst A.G., named Alban J. Schuele president of Celanese Canada Inc. and Hoechst Canada Inc.

title: Explorer's Rescue Is Pressed in Deepest U.S. Cave
description: A cave explorer from New York was trapped Sunday when a falling rock broke her leg about two miles into the nation's deepest cave. Rescuers said today it would take at least 24 hours to pull the woman to safety.

title: John Carter, 61, Jazz Clarinetist, Composer and Improviser, Is Dead
description: John Carter, the clarinetist and composer, died at Daniel Freeman Hospital in Los Angeles on Sunday morning. He was 61 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Is Hollywood Burning?
description: Better to be a Sioux, a Swiss or a Turk, that night of the Academy Awards, which you had decided not to attend, Gerard, for your own good reasons. The 4,000 voting members, who dwindle to 200, at most, when it comes to choosing the best foreign film, awarded the prize this year to a Swiss film depicting the "Journey of Hope" -- its title -- of an brave and nice family of Turks. As nobody has yet seen the film, it would be unfair to poke fun at it.

title: Doctor Is Criticized in Choking-Death Query
description: A lawyer for one of five police officers charged with choking a Queens man to death said yesterday that a deputy medical examiner who performed the autopsy on the man helped prevent a second autopsy because he feared a review by another pathologist.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boise Cascade Corp., Boise, Idaho, a forest products company, said Appleton Papers Inc., Appleton, Wis., was terminating its agreement to buy Boise's paper mill in Vancouver, Wash. * Citibank F.S.B., Chicago, a unit of Citicorp, said its Illinois division had acquired the stock of the Brookfield Bancshares Corp., Brookfield, Ill., for about $19.8 million.

title: Review/Dance; Tisch School Students Present Their Work
description: Two students and three guest choreographers contributed works to the spring program of the Second Avenue Dance Company.

title: Corrections
description: The calendar of events in the Westchester Weekly on Sunday included an incorrect date for the "20th Anniversary Performance" by Rondo Dance Theater at the State University of New York at Purchase. It will be presented at 8 P.M. on Saturday and at 3 P.M. on Sunday. There is no show on Friday.

title: Purchasers' Report Sees Slight Gain
description: A monthly survey of purchasing managers showed that the nation's economic activity picked up slightly in March but that the economy remained in a recession. The survey, by the National Association of Purchasing Management, showed a modest improvement in new orders, particularly from abroad.

title: Federal Judge Narrows Case Against Flake
description: A Federal judge substantially narrowed the prosecution's embezzlement and tax evasion case yesterday against the Rev. Floyd H. Flake and his wife, Margarett, and indicated that he might dismiss all charges against Mrs. Flake.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Notebook; Barkley To Miss 2 Weeks
description: An examination yesterday revealed that Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers' high-scoring, outspoken forward, suffered a partial tear of a ligament in his left knee Sunday and would be sidelined for a minimum of two weeks.

title: INSIDE
description: Flake Prosecutors Set Back A Federal judge in Brooklyn dealt a severe blow to the Government's embezzlement case against a Queens Congressman, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake. Page B1. How Well a Gun Law Works California has handgun restrictions that are stricter than those being proposed on the Federal level, but statistics suggest they prevent relatively few purchases. Page A12. Communists Win in Albania Albania's Communist Party overcame voting setbacks in cities and retained power in the nation's first modern free elections. Page A3.

title: U.S. Envoy Is Back in Beirut
description: The United States Ambassador to Lebanon, Ryan Crocker, told President Elias Hrawi today that Western hostages in Lebanon should be freed unconditionally. Six Americans are among 12 Westerners believed to be held by Shiite Muslim militants affiliated with Iran. Mr. Crocker reopened the American Embassy over the weekend.

title: Criticism of Clemency May Affect Efforts to Free Battered Women
description: Extensive criticism of last month's decision by Maryland's Governor to commute the sentences of eight battered women convicted of killing or assaulting their mates may make women's groups more cautious about seeking similar grants of clemency in other states.

title: Combination Trucks Benefit the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Pirates Shop Bonilla
description: Pittsburgh Pirates General Manager Larry Doughty contacted all but two National League teams yesterday to see if any were interested in dealing for outfielder Bobby Bonilla. The Pirates and Bonilla reached a contract impasse last Friday. Doughty said he would get in touch with the 14 American League clubs today.

title: Key Rates
Mets Sign Gooden for 3 Years In Deal Worth $15.45 Million
description: The Mets ended weeks of intense and emotional negotiations today by signing Dwight Gooden, one of the most luminous stars in the history of their franchise, to a three-year contract extension that will give him the second-highest average annual salary in baseball.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Construction Outlays Fall A Slim 0.1%
description: Construction spending dipped by one-tenth of 1 percent in February, the Government said today, but analysts suggested that the barely perceptible drop pointed to an upturn ahead. Construction outlays have now declined for 11 straight months.

title: Our Towns; Visiting Readers Make Story Hour A 2-Way Treat
description: For more than 15 school years, Rhea Steinhardt has run a book report contest for her second-grade pupils here. For every book they read on their own, they may pin up another section of a paper "bookworm" on the classroom wall. By June in many school years, the bookworm stretches from the chalkboards clear around to the windows.

title: The Synergy of Art and 'The Twilight Zone'
description: Submitted for your approval: A young man and his obsession. An obsession as vast as space and as timeless as infinity. An obsession that unifies television and art, Surrealism and pop culture. That obsession is . . . "The Twilight Zone." DEE-DEE dee-dee DEE-DEE dee-dee . . .

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Triangle Murder, a Stronger Case
description: After 11 weeks in which 47 witnesses took the stand and a far-off war was waged and won, the prosecution in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus rested a case today that seemed stronger and tauter than it did in opening arguments.

title: Malcolm E. Phelps; Physician, 85
description: Dr. Malcom E. Phelps, a founder of the American Academy of Family Physicians, died Friday. He was 85 years old.

title: Ames Extension
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. said it had received an 18-month extension through Oct. 24, 1992, on $250 million of revolving credit from a group of banks led by the Chemical Banking Corporation. Ames, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, said the extension, together with its operating cash flow, would be adequate to support seasonal working capital requirements in the fall. It said its current fiscal-year budget reflects an expected operating profit by the end of the year.

title: Communists Win Free Vote in Albania
description: The Communist Party, entrenched here for more than four decades, overcame voting setbacks in Albania's cities and returned to power in this country's first modern and free elections, all parties agreed today.

title: Accounts
description: * Lindt & Sprungli, a chocolate company based in Stratham, N.H., to Mullen Advertising Inc., Wenham, Mass., with a budget estimated at $1 million.

title: Miami Museum Defies City's Order to Vacate
description: Directors of a Cuban art museum here defied an order to vacate their city-owned building today, saying they would not give in to three years of bombs and threats by anti-Castro groups.

title: Lawsuit Is Settled By 2 Xerox Units
description: The California Micro Devices Corporation, a maker of semiconductors, said it had reached a settlement with two subsidiaries of the Xerox Corporation. California Micro said the terms of the agreement were confidential, but the settlement "significantly strengthens" its financial position. California Micro's stock rose 25 cents today, to $2.75 a share, in over-the-counter trading. Xerox fell $1.50 a share, to $55.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Fabricland to Merge With House of Fabrics
description: Ending a three-month takeover battle, the directors of Fabricland Inc., a regional fabric retailer based in Portland Ore., agreed today to a merger with House of Fabrics Inc., a California-based competitor.

title: A Keyboard Squeeze Finds Room for Mouse
description: THE piece of furniture that holds my main machine was specially designed for computers. The monitor sits on the top surface, as did the computer itself before I bought a floor model that stands on its own two feet. A lower, adjustable surface holds the keyboard at a comfortable height and angle. And the mouse. . .

title: Yanks' Sanderson Sidesteps Women in Locker Room
description: A woman in the Yankee clubhouse? If there is one and she wants an interview with Scott Sanderson, it won't be conducted within the view of his teammates.

title: German Economic Aide Slain; Red Army Faction Suspected
description: Detlev Rohwedder, who headed the agency charged with privatizing the economy of the former East Germany and was a leading German manager, was shot to death in his home tonight, the authorities said.

title: David Goodman, 79, Ex-Official in Peekskill
description: David Goodman, a government administrator and former city manager of Peekskill, N.Y., died on Friday at the Country House, a retirement home in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Nike in Pact With NBC For Tennis Exclusives
description: Nike said it had signed a four-year agreement with NBC under which it would become the only athletic footwear and apparel maker to advertise during the network's coverage of the French Open and Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: Surgery for Ex-Georgia Leader ATLANTA, April 1
description: Lester Maddox, the segregationist who brandished an ax handle and was elected Governor of Georgia 25 years ago, underwent heart surgery here today, a spokeswoman for the Emory University hospital said.

title: P.L.O. Refuses Order to Disarm in Lebanon
description: In defiance of a new Government ban on private armed groups in the country, the Palestine Liberation Organization said on Sunday that it would not lay down its weapons and vowed that thousands of its guerrillas would continue to fight Israel from southern Lebanon.

title: At Last, Legs Have a Mind of Their Own
description: It seems probable that, for the first time in recent fashion history, the transition in skirt lengths will be peaceful, orderly and nontraumatic.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 24 about the restoration of the Firemen's Memorial on Riverside Drive in Manhattan omitted the name of the sculptor. A recent letter from a reader pointed out that the sculptor was Attilio Piccirilli.

title: Transit Officers Seek Shift in Dispatching
description: The union repre senting 3,600 transit police officers sued yesterday in an attempt to force the city to test a communications system that would connect the dispatching systems of the city police and the transit police.

title: Cambodia May Be Last Vietnam War Casualty; Talk to Phnom Penh
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: April Flowers

title: Using Fewer Pesticides Is Seen as Beneficial
description: AMERICAN farmers have long maintained that using fewer pesticides would result in greater crop losses and increased food prices. But a comprehensive analysis of the benefits and costs of the present heavy dependence on chemical methods of pest control strongly suggests otherwise.

title: Court Upholds Antitrust Immunity of Local Governments
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that local governments enjoyed broad immunity from antitrust liability for action that would amount to an illegal antitrust conspiracy if it took place in a purely private context.

title: Treasury Securities Prices Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, despite a report on the economy that should have been viewed in a salutary light by credit market participants.

title: The Dirty War in Kuwait
description: The accounts of abductions, of beatings and humiliation, sometimes of unspeakable torture, were depressingly familiar. The treatment meted out to Palestinians and other foreign residents of Kuwait mirrors that suffered by native Kuwaitis at the hands of Iraqis in the seven-month occupation.

title: Devils' Goalie Situation a Mystery
description: Coach Tom McVie's hoarse voice came through loud and clear in his office here after the Devils practiced today in preparation for the playoff series against Pittsburgh.

title: Human Heads Found in a Box: Murder? No, Medicine
description: Whoever it was who stole a box from Dr. William Portnoy's car in the East Village before dawn yesterday got a nasty surprise.

title: Words and Music About Severed Roots
description: Literary works about the experience of being uprooted will be the focus of "Writing Between Homes," a literary and musical event being sponsored by the Jewish Museum tomorrow at 7 P.M. at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "To them, it's a business, and so you can't blame them for having tried to get me for as cheap as possible. They did what they felt they had to do." -- Dwight Gooden, who settled for $15.45 million. [ B10:1. ]

title: Joan Colebrook; Writer, 80
description: Joan Colebrook, a writer, died on Saturday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. She was 80 years old and lived in Truro, Mass.

title: Miscellany
description: * LCA Entertainment, the domestic licensing arm of Warner Brothers Worldwide Merchandising, and DC Comics Inc. have entered into a licensing agreement with Signal Apparel Co., Chattanooga, Tenn., and the Shirt Shed Inc., Wabash, Ind., regarding the coming sequel to the motion picture "Batman." Under terms of the agreement, Signal and the Shirt Shed will have an exclusive license to make and sell several categories of casual apparel emblazoned with the logo and characters from the motion picture, as well as with characters DC's "Batman" comic books and an animated television show from Warner based on the same subject.

title: American Air Sees Big Loss
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said today that it expected a 'significant' net loss in the first quarter of 1991.

title: Market Place; Year of Questions For Capital Cities
description: IT used to be so easy to forecast how the three television networks would do each year. Advertising sales predictably pushed up revenues by double digits annually.

title: Oranjestad Journal; Uneasy Caribbean Islands Warm to Motherlands
description: In 1986, this small, scrubby island just off the coast of Venezuela broke away from an association of self-administered Dutch Caribbean possessions and confidently set out on a path expected to lead to full independence within 10 years.

title: Ex-Officer of Chrysler Gets Dillon, Read Job
description: After a career in the automobile industry and a fling of participation in a major buyout, Gerald Greenwald is hanging out his shingle on Wall Street.

title: Dreary Day, but Sunny Outlook for Trout Season
description: The opening day of trout season is much like the opening day of baseball: It is often cold or rainy; sometimes it snows. The level of the game will certainly improve as the season goes along.

title: Quayle Leads Tribute to Atwater In South Carolina Church Service
description: Hundreds of mourners led by Vice President Dan Quayle and members of the Cabinet paid tribute to Lee Atwater today, praising the skill that took him to the height of national political power until cancer cut short his life last week at the age of 40.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Time and tide wait for no man, and this was doubly true Sunday on Martha's Vineyard. All over the Massachusetts island, people were popping up one hour earlier than expected.

title: Court Rejects Yonkers Plea
description: The Supreme Court rejected today an emergency request by Yonkers officials seeking to block the building of five public housing complexes, part of a court-ordered desegregation plan. The court, without comment, turned away arguments aimed at postponing construction until a Federal appeals court in New York considers a formal appeal by Yonkers officials.

title: LOW MEDICAID FEES SEEN AS DEPRIVING THE POOR OF CARE
description: Medicaid, the health program for poor people, pays doctors much less than either Medicare or private health insurers for the same services, and as a result many doctors are refusing to take Medicaid patients, a Federal advisory commission said today.

title: Study Finds Men's Brains Deteriorate at Greater Rate
description: Men may lose their verbal abilities faster than women as they age, researchers at the University of Pennsylvania reported today.

title: Bid Extended For Square D
description: Groupe Schneider S.A., the French electric equipment concern, said that Square D shareholders had tendered 67.5 percent of their shares in support of its $78-a-share cash offer for Square D.

title: Bankruptcy Filing By Metro Airlines
description: Metro Airlines Inc., a commuter line based in Dallas, said it and two of its subsidiaries, Metroflight Inc. and Metro Leasing Inc., had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Metro said that its operations would not be affected by the filing and that the airline would continue to operate all flights as scheduled. It said it would honor all tickets issued before the filing and would fulfill agreements with other airlines.

title: Payson Art Collection To Maine Museum
description: The art collection of John Whitney Payson, a collector of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings perhaps best known for having achieved an auction record in 1987 when he sold van Gogh's "Irises" for $53.9 million, is to move to the Portland Museum of Art in Portland, Me.

title: Wang Seeks New Strategy For Business
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. is looking for its niche. The faltering Massachusetts computer maker said yesterday that it had notified its major customers that it would focus its business on the electronic-imaging market and attempt to move its current customers to a new industry-standard computing approach.

title: Electromagnetic Fields Are Being Scrutinized For Linkage to Cancer
description: BIRDS and bees do it. So do some bacteria, salmon and whales. But whether the human body can detect extremely faint electromagnetic fields, and whether those fields play a role in diseases like cancer, is one of the most intensely debated issues in medicine today.

title: Review/Guitar; William Anderson Recital
description: William Anderson is a guitarist with an affinity for contemporary music, and on Wednesday evening he played a recital of 20th-century works for guitar alone and in various chamber combinations. He does not yet play with the fluidity and command one hears in the work of his mentor, David Starobin. But his interpretations of Hans Werner Henze's "Drei Tentos" and Toru Takemitsu's "Folios" showed him to be a sensitive, thoughtful player.

title: Dow Plunges by 32.67 to Close at 2,881.19
description: Stock prices sank yesterday in sluggish trading as investors expressed concern that the economy was sagging badly.

title: Newsprint Prices Cut
description: Abitibi-Price Inc. said today that it had canceled its Jan. 1 newsprint price increase, reducing its list price for newsprint to $685 a ton, from $720. The price cut is effective April 1. "Demand growth was lower than expected," said Ed Ahern, the company's marketing director. According to newspaper reports, Canadian Pacific Forest Products Ltd. also cut its list prices for newsprint.

title: Airline Routes To London Set
description: The Transportation Department gave temporary approval today for United Airlines and Northwest Airlines to serve routes to London under authority held by Pan American World Airways.

title: Carnegie 'Tosca' Is Canceled
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra has canceled its performance of Puccini's "Tosca" at Carnegie Hall tonight because of the illness of Carol Vaness, who was to sing the title role. The concert will not be rescheduled. Subscribers and those who ordered tickets through Carnegie Charge will receive credit automatically. Others may return tickets, no later than May 17, in person or by mail to the Carnegie Hall Box Office, 154 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019, marked to the attention of Philadelphia Refund. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Telescope Is to Open New Window On Most Violent Events in Cosmos
description: THE serenity of the night sky is a twinkling illusion. It masks the rampant violence in the universe, where stars collapse and explode with titanic reverberations, maelstroms of gas and dust roil galaxies at their cores, and matter and antimatter collide in mutual annihilation.

title: A.T.&T. Says It Has 60% of NCR
description: A.T.&T. estimates that it received about 60 percent of the outstanding shares of the NCR Corporation at last week's shareholders meeting, according to court documents released today. That would be short of the 80 percent needed to replace the entire 12 members of NCR's board.

title: Global Warming Gases
description: A buildup in the atmosphere of two gases that promote global warming has been encouraged by the cultivation of grasslands and the use of nitrogen fertilizer, a new study suggests.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 24 about arson at Florida churches included an incomplete quotation from Dr. Kathleen Hurty of the National Council of Churches. She was quoted as saying that "arson has not been a major issue for churches except, of course, for some black churches during the civil rights era." In a letter dated March 5, Dr. Hurty points out that she also said this exception continued to exist. This correction was delayed by mail handling and editing lapses at The Times.

title: Puhl Released; Elster Going North
description: The Mets, taking steps both to finalize their roster and to avert a potential controversy, today released outfielder Terry Puhl and announced that shortstop Kevin Elster would travel with the team to New York for the start of the season April 8.

title: A Slaying Inflames Chilean Rightists
description: Angry demonstrations erupted here today after the killing of a prominent Chilean Senator and close adviser to Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Alfred C. Buck, Knife Manufacturer, 80
description: Alfred Charles Buck, developer of the folding Buck Hunting Knife, died of cancer Sunday at his home. He was 80 years old.

title: U.S. Shoe Planning A Big Revamping
description: The U.S. Shoe Corporation, a manufacturer and retailer of footwear, apparel and eyewear, said it planned to sell 95 stores and shut a plant in an 18-month, $90 million restructuring plan. It said it would close a plant in Osgood, Ind., idling 275 workers. The company recently shut two plants in Kentucky, eliminating 510 jobs.

title: Not Too Late for Albanian Democracy
description: The contested election that took place Sunday in Albania, Europe's last Communist tyranny, was more than a historical curiosity. Not long ago, everything seemed to be forbidden in Stalinist Albania -- attending church, owning a car or murmuring a single critical syllable about Enver Hoxha, the cheerless party boss from 1945 until his death in 1985. So the mere fact of what appears to have been a free vote is more striking than the outcome -- a Communist victory over the newly formed opposition party, the Democrats.

title: Life as Migrant Worker Is Found to Nurture TB
description: Poor living conditions, inadequate medical care and other problems have produced so many cases of tuberculosis among migrant farm workers that the disease should be considered an occupational hazard, researchers said today.

title: Continental Airlines in Pact
description: Continental Airlines and some of its aircraft lessors agreed today to a plan to cut costs, partly satisfying a judge's ruling that forces the airline to settle with the companies that lease its more than 100 planes.

title: Rangers Add 2 Collegians
description: In the last few days, both Coach Roger Neilson and General Manager Neil Smith have used the word "desperate" to describe the state of the Rangers, who open the Stanley Cup playoffs against Washington tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Federal Inquiry at F.D.A.
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating allegations that employees at the Food and Drug Administration took cash in exchange for informing brokerage firms when the agency would approve certain drugs, an F.D.A. official said today.

title: Fleeing Iraqis Find a Refuge, And Kind Treatment, in Iran
description: Abbas Bossfon stepped on a land mine and lost his left foot fighting Iran in the Iraq-Iran war six years ago. Six days ago, he turned to the country he had fought asking for safe haven, and was granted refuge.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Red Army Faction Is Suspected in German Killing
description: The police said today that they believed that the Red Army Faction, the far-left German guerrilla group, was responsible for the killing of an industrialist late Monday night.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALEX HALEYis giving his papers, including his notes and manuscripts for his books "Roots" and "The Autobiography of Malcolm X," to the University of Tennessee in Knoxville.

title: United Seen In New Talks About Routes
description: United Airlines has shown a renewed interest in acquiring large parts of Pan American World Airways in talks between the carriers in recent weeks, two people in the industry say.

title: Metromedia to Keep Stake In Orion After Recent Hits
description: Buoyed by recent successes at the Orion Pictures Corporation, including the Oscar-winning film "Dances With Wolves," Orion's controlling shareholder, Metromedia Inc., said today that it was no longer seeking a buyer for its stake in the troubled Hollywood studio.

title: Faded Rangers Still Have Edge
description: The Rangers and the Capitals open the Stanley Cup playoffs at Madison Square Garden tonight with similar records after dissimilar finishes.

title: Topics of The Times; Pen Chic
description: Close observers of male executives' shirt pockets have discovered a transformation. Pens, once something to write with, have become something to wear .

title: Celtics Roll Past Poor-Shooting Nets
description: The Boston Celtics are headed for the playoffs, where they seem to have an annual reservation. The New Jersey Nets are headed for their fifth consecutive draft lottery, which decides the order of choice for the 11 non-playoff teams.

title: Troupe Contemplates Life Without Graham
description: The death of Martha Graham, who was 96 years old and had been under treatment for pneumonia for the last two months, was hardly unexpected. Yet the news on Monday afternoon still shocked her dancers and the administrators of her company.

title: Maradona in Argentina
description: Diego Maradona, the international star who faces a possible two-year suspension from the Italian Soccer Federation after testing positive for cocaine following a league match last month, flew from Rome to his native Argentina yesterday to "recover some tranquillity" in his life, he said.

title: Romance Novels Discover a Baby Boom
description: Sam Ellison, a globe-trotting geologist, was doing what comes naturally in a romance novel. "He cupped her face in his hands, pressing a butterfly kiss onto her lips." When the heroine reponds by cringing, the dashing hero of Silhouette Special Edition No. 609 is not offended. " 'Breathe in through your nose and exhale through your lips,' Sam instructed, coaching her through the labor pain with the exercises they had learned in the prenatal class."

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON THE PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE, LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE -- 10:30 A.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Johnson's 30 Points Sparks Lakers Magic Johnson had 30 points, 12 rebounds and 10 assists -- his 13th triple-double of the season and third in four games -- as the Los Angeles Lakers defeated the San Antonio Spurs, 122-115, last night in San Antonio. Johnson's effort overshadowed David Robinson's 36 points and career-high 23 rebounds and ended the Spurs' five-game winning streak. It was also the Spurs' first loss in 11 home outings. (AP) Suns 131, Jazz 117: Kevin Johnson scored 12 of his 37 points in a span of 2:02 in the third quarter and had a season-high 20 assists for Phoenix. Xavier McDaniel had 28 points and 12 rebounds for the Suns. John Stockton scored a season-high 28 points for Utah, which missed a chance to pull even with San Antonio in the Midwest Division. Karl Malone had 25 points and Jeff Malone 20 for the Jazz, who lost their 10th consecutive regular-season game in Phoenix. (AP) Trail Blazers 104, Timberwolves 93: Jerome Kersey scored 25 points and joined with Terry Porter to key a third-quarter surge as Portland, playing in Minnesota, won its seventh game in a row. (AP) Pistons 83, Hornets 78: Joe Dumars scored 24 points and extended his club record by making his 59th consecutive free throw as the Detroit beat the Hornets in Charlotte for their fourth consecutive victory. (AP) Bulls 106, Magic 102: Michael Jordan scored a season-high 44 points, including the go-ahead basket on an alley-oop slam dunk with 1:12 remaining, as Chicago rallied at home for the victory. (AP) TENNIS Rusty Navratilova Comes Through Top-seeded Martina Navratilova, playing in her first competition in a month, conceded she was rusty but scored a victory yesterday over Amanda Coetzer of South Africa, 6-2, 7-5, on the opening day of the Family Circle Magazine Cup tournament at Hilton Head Island, S.C., where she is thedefending champion. (AP) Gomez Defeated at Estoril Open: Top-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador, the No. 11-ranked player in the world, was among four highly ranked players beaten in the first round of the Estoril Open yesterday in Lisbon. Gomez was defeated by Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-4, 6-3. Second-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain, fourth-seeded Andrei Cherkasov of the Soviet Union and fifth-seeded Marc Rosset of Switzerland were also eliminated from the Association of Tennis Professionals tournament. (AP) McEnroe Loses in Hong Kong: Second-seeded John McEnroe was upset, 6-3, 5-7, 7-6, by an American, Todd Witsken, at the Hong Kong Open. McEnroe arrived in Hong Kong only 24 hours before his match and showed signs of jet lag as he struggled against the steady play of Witsken, ranked 82d in the world. (AP) Sampras, Gilbert Advance: Second-seeded Pete Sampras beat Brad Pearce, 6-2, 6-2, and defending champion Brad Gilbert overcame an early challenge from Chile's Pedro Rebolledo, 2-6, 6-1, 6-1, in the Prudential Securities Classic tournament in Orlando, Fla. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said today that Egypt and the United States Defense Department had signed an agreement for a new Egyptian order of General Dynamics' F-16 fighter aircraft.

title: Looking at History With a Military Slant
description: The Lessons of History By Michael Howard 217 pages. Yale University Press. $27.50.

title: Forget Those 19 Losses; Leary Will Open for Yanks
description: For most of the spring, it was the best-kept secret in the Yankee camp. But today Stump Merrill made it official: Tim Leary will be the team's opening day starter Monday in Detroit.

title: Kenneth B. McCredie, Researcher, 55
description: Dr. Kenneth B. McCredie, a pioneer in the treatment of leukemia, died Saturday at his home. He was 55 years old.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the performance of stocks in the first quarter misapplied The Times's guidelines in citing two stocks among the worst performers on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Issue: Food as a Weapon. Solution: Disarmament.
description: CHRIS CHAPMAN was in her office listening to a middle-aged, somewhat overweight man complain about what he called an embarrassing passion: frozen pastries.

title: Muscles for Feeding
description: To The Living Section:

title: Economic Scene; The High Cost Of Low Savings
description: IT'S morning in America, say two economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York -- the morning after. Since the mid-1980's analysts have been quarreling over the consequences of the free-spending ways of Americans. Now, Ethan Harris and Charles Steindel have produced what may be the definitive study of low savings and its impact.

title: Bridge
description: The level of bridge expertise in New York City is so great that players who win regularly in national events often have trouble at the local level.

title: John Zorek Dies at 79; Travel Agent in Music
description: John Zorek, a travel agent who specialized in travel plans for symphony orchestras and others in the music world, died on Friday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: North Dakota Districts Are Facing Rising Tide In Nation: Consolidation
description: At the start of this school year, the Karlsruhe, N.D., public school system received a new lease on its academic life. But the school system, which has just 66 students, may also have received a death sentence.

title: Miscellany
description: * CBS said yesterday that it would undertake new promotions in May with 7-Eleven and with Domino's Pizza. Using game cards obtained at 7-Eleven, viewers can win cash by matching numbers on the cards to numbers broadcast during the CBS program "The Flash," which is broadcast on Saturday evenings. And in a game-card promotion begun with Domino's, CBS viewers who are Domino's customers can win Chrysler mini-vans. * The New York Times Company Magazine Group has developed an advertising package that offers advertisers a combined circulation of 2.8 million readers of six magazines in its sports/leisure division, in addition to services like client entertainment at sports events, the creation of sales promotion events and customized research. The publications are Golf Digest, Golf World, Tennis magazine, Snow Country, Cruising World and Sailing World.

title: Detroit's W. B. Doner Gets $30 Million in New Business
description: A DETROIT agency, W. B. Doner, said yesterday that it had picked up $30 million in new accounts for local retail advertising and promotion. The most notable addition was Pearle Inc.'s account for Pearle Vision Centers, which is expected to have billings of about $10 million.

title: N.F.L. Veterans Jump at Plan B
description: The third year of Plan B -- the National Football League's answer to free agency in its attempt to satisfy the courts while a collective bargaining agreement with its players remains in limbo -- offered big moves by big names, but the downward trend in total signings continued.

title: U.S. Proposes Listing a Salmon as Endangered
description: Setting the stage for an epic fight over use of the biggest river in the West, the Federal Government proposed today that a type of Columbia River salmon be listed as an endangered species.

title: Inquiry Starts on Chip Patent Dispute
description: The Patent and Trademark Office has opened an inquiry to re-examine a disputed patent that covers the basic design of computer chips.

title: Sutcliffe Out 15 Days
description: The Chicago Cubs yesterday placed pitcher Rick Sutcliffe on the 15-day disabled list. He will remain in Arizona when the Cubs head back to Chicagoand continue rehabilitation on the right shoulder on which he underwent surgery last year. (AP)

title: Bonilla a Bargain
description: Bobby Bonilla isn't headed for New York and the Yankees, but his agent, Dennis Gilbert, said today that he's still a bargain, whether he stays with the Pittsburgh Pirates or is eventually traded.

title: Kuwaitis Urged to Halt Attacks on Palestinians
description: American military and diplomatic officials are pressing the Kuwaiti Government to prevent further attacks against Palestinians like those that occurred in the first weeks after the end of the Iraqi occupation.

title: Foreign Affairs; Iraq: Drawing the Line
description: An Iraqi Shiite who has devoted his life to opposing Saddam Hussein visited me on Monday. "I know what you would not do," he said over bagels and coffee. "You would not intervene with military force in my country's civil war. I disagree, yet I understand. But what do you think the United States should do" to stop the killing of Shiites and Kurds, short of such intervention?

title: Where Old Havana Plays, Exiles Fear Another Revolution
description: FOR Liliam Martinez, the impulse to sing is overwhelming as she listens to musicians playing sultry Latin tunes in the darkened lounge of the Big Five Club. She rises from her table near the bar, takes a microphone from one of the professional singers and slips into an old Cuban torch song accompanied by a single guitar player. For 15 minutes, her dusky voice seems to peel away the years and transports her husband and other middle-aged club members back to old Havana.

title: Harrelson Reveals Mets Lineup
description: Bud Harrelson, after much debate, a handful of meetings with players and more than a month of experiments on the field, has decided on a lineup at the plate.

title: Smoke Over Kuwait
description: About six million barrels of oil, weighing roughly a million tons, around 10 percent of the world's daily oil ration, are going up in smoke every day from the 550 Kuwaiti wells set afire by Iraqi occupiers.

title: Soon: Faster and Wiser Networks
description: At an engineering laboratory here, Charles P. Thacker, a computer scientist at the Digital Equipment Corporation, ends a tour with a dramatic demonstration. Standing in the closet that houses the guts of the center's computer network, he yanks a cable out of its connector.

title: Is California 40 Percent Wetlands?
description: Even though rainstorms have brought relief to drought-stricken California, most people believe that the only wetlands in the state are a few oceanside marshes.

title: SOVIET PRICE RISE IGNITES DISILLUSION
description: After waiting and worrying and hoarding, Soviet citizens faced the first day of steep consumer price increases today by doing what they have been doing every day for years: they stood in lines for shabby and scarce goods and grumbled about the Government's ineptitude in improving the country's grave economic lot.

title: To Our Readers
description: The Times today begins printing articles from a newly founded news agency, Bloomberg Business News. The service, which will focus on financial and corporate news, has more than 50 reporters in New York, Washington, London, Tokyo, Toronto and Princeton, N.J.

title: America Deserts The Rebels Cynically
description: The justification for the war is being put in doubt by the coalition's willingness to let Saddam Hussein snatch victory, over his own people, from defeat at allied hands.

title: Tokyo Stocks Higher
description: Tokyo stocks were higher at midday today, following the surge on Wall Street. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 528.06 points, or 2.01 percent, to 26,780.06.

title: Rose Set for Release From Halfway House
description: Pete Rose, although still fulfilling a community service sentence as part of his Federal income tax conviction, is eligible to be released on Friday from a halfway house in Cincinnati where he has been living since his release from Federal prison in Marion, Ill., on Jan. 7.

title: Officials Held In Extortion Of Developers
description: The technique was often as subtle as the brush of a hand across the face. Two fingers on the nose meant "$2,000 and we'll give you what you want." Four fingers on the cheek meant $4,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I think we're at a crucial juncture in terms of how we think about civil rights as a country. If civil rights is defined as quotas, it's a losing hand. If it's defined as protection against discrimination and efforts to promote opportunity, then it will remain a mainstream value in American life." -- Geoffrey Garin, a poll-taker who did research for the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. [ A18:1. ]

title: Successor to Lefebvre Vows at Rite to Persist
description: Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, whose opposition to changes adopted by the 1962-65 Vatican Council caused a split in the Roman Catholic Church, was buried today, and his successor promised to carry on his fight.

title: Rights Movement in Struggle For an Image as Well as a Bill
description: As Congress prepares to reconsider civil rights legislation vetoed last fall by President Bush, groups pressing for passage of the bill find themselves facing a second and ultimately more crucial battle: one to define the image, agenda and relevance of the civil rights movement itself.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Debt Accord Set For Bally's Grand
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said its Bally's Grand casino unit in Nevada had reached an agreement with creditors to restructure $412.8 million in debt. Under the arrangement, Bally's Nevada operations will cease to be a subsidiary of Bally Manufacturing. Bally's Grand failed to make a $5.5 million interest payment on March 31.

title: Carlos Montalban, 87; Actor and Dancer Dies
description: Carlos Montalban, an actor and dancer whose film career spanned four decades, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: 2-Part Offering By Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, priced a two-part bond offering yesterday totaling $1.3 billion through various securities dealers.

title: Correction; Correction
description: An article and a picture caption on Monday about Japanese cultural influences in South Korea misidentified a Japanese singer. She is Tokiko Kato.

title: Broncos' Kay Arrested
description: Denver Broncos tight end Clarence Kay, who twice has violated the National Football Leagues's substance-abuse policy, was arrested in Aurora, Colo., yesterday for driving under the influence of alcohol, police said. The arrest could jeopardize Kay's N.F.L. career. The league's policy requires an immediate ban after three offenses.

title: Alaska Hasn't Agreed To Exxon Settlement
description: To the Editor:

title: Kellogg Files Slander Suit
description: THE Kellogg Company is suing a public official for slander for the first time, charging that he maligned the cereal maker by characterizing some of its health claims as lies.

title: U.N., Near Cease-Fire Deal, Sets Aside Rebels' Plight
description: The Security Council moved closer today to a resolution setting terms for a permanent cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, and it temporarily set aside calls by France and Turkey for action to halt Iraq's suppression of Kurdish and Shiite Muslim rebellions.

title: Business, Not Bombs, Will Unite Ireland; Oppression Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Says She Was Raped at Kennedy Estate
description: A 30-year-old woman says she was raped at the Kennedy family's beachfront estate early Saturday, after encountering Senator Edward M. Kennedy, one of his sons and one of his nephews at a luxurious nightclub here, the police said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD M. NIXON met yesterday in Moscow with MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV , the Soviet President, and then with BORIS N. YELTSIN , President of the Russian republic. Details of the discussions were not released. Mr. Nixon has been in the Soviet Union for about two weeks.

title: Canada Retail Sales Off
description: Canada retail sales fell 7.6 percent in January to a seasonally adjusted $14.7 billion (Canadian), or about $12.6 billion (United States), from a revised $15.8 billion (Canadian), or about $13.6 billion, in December, the Government said today.

title: Eating Well
description: PERHAPS you noticed the Florida Citrus Commission's television commercials this winter, which told consumers that the lack of brightness and the presence of scarring on some Florida oranges had no effect on the sweetness of the fruit.

title: FBI MAY PUNISH 11 IN RACIAL INCIDENT
description: An internal inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into a case of racial harassment against a black agent has resulted in a recommendation that William S. Sessions, the agency's director, consider disciplining 11 employees for their involvement.

title: Stanley Diamond Dies; An Anthropologist, 69
description: Stanley Diamond, a poet and anthropologist who founded the anthropology department at the New School for Social Research in Manhattan, died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Martin Journal; Scrap the Tanks? For Slovaks, It's a Call to Arms
description: This is the town that was supposed to hammer swords into plowshares.

title: Valenzuela a Free Agent
description: Fernando Valenzuela, released by the Dodgers last week, cleared waivers yesterday and became a free agent.

title: More About Buns
description: To The Living Section:

title: Silicon Graphics, Microsoft in Deal
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. said it had agreed to license its three-dimensional graphics technology to the Microsoft Corporation for use on personal computers. The agreement allows Microsoft to integrate Silicon Graphics' Iris graphics library technology with Microsoft systems and applications software.

title: Fiber May Help in Preventing Breast Cancer
description: A study of rats who ate a high-fiber diet suggests that fiber may help protect against breast cancer, researchers say.

title: H. Hunter Williams, Executive, 82
description: H. Hunter Williams, a retired New York Telephone executive, died on Friday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 82 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: In Praise of Graham and Her Legacy to Dance
description: For many whose lives she touched and transformed, Martha Graham's achievements transcended esthetics and reached moral truths.

title: DEALS
description: N.B.A. HOUSTON -- Placed Dave Feitl, center, on the injured list.

title: Briton Freed by Iran Is Now Home
description: Looking tired and gaunt but with his sense of humor intact, Roger Cooper, a British businessman held by Iran for over five years on spying charges, arrived back in Britain today after being suddenly released from prison in Teheran.

title: High TV Ratings for College Basketball
description: After a slow start that had CBS executives concerned about the price they had paid for rights to college basketball, the semifinals and finals of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament provided winning ratings for the network.

title: Declaration of Independence Found in a $4 Picture Frame
description: A collector who spent $4 at a Pennsylvania flea market two years ago for a dismal painting because he liked the frame now finds himself the possessor of a first printing of the Declaration of Independence. It is expected to bring $800,000 to $1 million at an auction on June 4.

title: Fannie Mae Chief Gets $27 Million
description: The chairman and chief executive of the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, retired this year with $27 million in compensation, The Washington Post reported in its Wednesday issue.

title: Panel Confirms Stangl As Chief of the M.T.A.
description: When a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train arrived at Grand Central Terminal after skipping the 125th Street Station, Peter E. Stangl, the railroad's president, ordered the train's crew to return to Harlem and apologize to passengers.

title: As Texas Watches, Ryan Hurls Against Ryan
description: Nolan Ryan, a veteran of many major-league campaigns for both the Astros and the Rangers, is used to pitching with the eyes of Texas upon him.

title: Key Rates
Dow Rises To 2,945.05, Up by 63.86
description: The prospect of lower interest rates plus rising hopes for an economic recovery helped to push stocks sharply higher yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 63.86 points and many broader averages reached record highs.

title: Shuttle Countdown Begins, But Rain Could Stall Liftoff
description: The countdown for the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis began today as weather forecasters kept an eye on an approaching cold front that could delay the liftoff, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said.

title: Myers Considers Quitting His Job As Health Chief
description: Dr. Woodrow A. Myers, the New York City Health Commissioner, may resign his position because of a family illness, his spokesman said last night.

title: New Grape Spawns A Bone-Dry Wine
description: THE Cornell University research laboratory that bred the popular Cayuga white grape, as well as melody and horizon grapes, has sent another new white-wine grape, the chardonel, into the world.

title: 9 BOMBS LAUNCHED ON AN I.R.S. CENTER
description: Nine pipe bombs shot from launchers landed near an Internal Revenue Service center here on Sunday and Monday. Six of them exploded, but there were no injuries.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Elizabeth Arden Co., New York, a subsidiary of the Faberge Co., named Janice Handler vice president and general counsel. * Exxon Corp., Irving, Tex., named Carol C. Tatkon senior vice president of Exxon Company U.S.A.

title: Wine Talk
description: BENMARL, a vineyard, winery and modest social experiment in the Hudson Valley, celebrates twin 20th anniversaries this year: its own as a commercial venture, and that of its Societe des Vignerons, one of the least-known, but hardiest, wine clubs in the country. It also looks ahead to an uncertain future.

title: Software Suit
description: A Federal District judge in Boston ruled that Mosaic Software must stop selling a spreadsheet program that copies the appearance of the 1-2-3 spreadsheet of the Lotus Development Corporation. The court had ruled in January that the Mosaic program called Twin infringed on Lotus's copyright. A Mosaic executive said the company would appeal.

title: Prosecution Will Press Case Against 5 Officers
description: The Queens District Attorney said yesterday that he would press ahead with his prosecution of five police officers charged with killing a car-theft suspect even though new problems with evidence kept cropping up.

title: Federal Charges Against Flakes May Be Voided
description: Federal prosecutors will move today to drop all charges against Margarett Flake and are deciding whether to continue the case against her husband, Representative Floyd H. Flake, people close to the prosecution said.

title: William F. Shea, 88; Wagner's Budget Chief
description: William Francis Shea, who was budget director for New York City in the early 1960's, died on Monday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Colorado River Unit Bonds Priced to Yield Up to 7.125%
description: The Lower Colorado River Authority priced $161.8 million in tax-exempt priority refunding bonds yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.125 percent for an issue due in 2011, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: U.S. and Panama Agree On Access to Bank Data
description: United States and Panamanian negotiators have reached an accord that will open bank records in Panama for American criminal investigators to develop evidence on money laundering and drug crimes, Administration officials said today.

title: 35 Journalists Escape From Iraq Into Turkey
description: The Foreign Ministry said today that 35 foreign journalists had escaped into Turkey from northern Iraq. A Turkish news agency said one journalist was killed and two were wounded in clashes between Iraqi troops and Kurds.

title: Grumman Will Cut 1,900 Jobs, and L.I. Will Be Hit Hardest
description: The Grumman Corporation announced yesterday that it would eliminate 1,900 jobs, about three-fourths of them on Long Island, because of cuts in defense spending and a need to trim expenses to become more competitive.

title: News Corp. Will Cut Costs
description: The News Corporation, the international media concern headed by Rupert Murdoch, plans to cut costs by at least 10 percent in the next year, its new chief operating officer said in an interview published today.

title: Alaska Hasn't Agreed To Exxon Settlement
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Right Hands, The Lowly Meatloaf Finds It's a Star
description: THE way Sharon Moore talks about meatloaf, one would think she was describing the latest creation from the kitchen of the Four Seasons in New York.

title: Woman Moved in Cave Rescue
description: A woman who broke her leg on an expedition in the nation's deepest known cave was helped over large boulders and through passageways today as she made her way toward the entrance. The woman, Emily Davis Mobley, 40 years old, of Schoharie, N.Y., was injured Sunday when she was struck by an 80-pound rock in Lechuguilla Cave, just west of Carlsbad Caverns. Rescuers are rigging ropes and pulleys to lift her out the vertical shaft. The cave is 54 miles long and 1,565 feet deep.

title: Big Insurer May Face Seizures
description: The First Executive Corporation has acknowledged that growing financial pressure on its insurance subsidiaries has increased the likelihood that they will be seized by regulators.

title: A Sinful Bloody Mary
description: To The Living Section:

title: CHRONICLE
description: In his 21 years on "As the World Turns," LARRY BRYGGMAN has lived through six wives and three children, only two of them born out of wedlock. And there may be more, since the actor is still playing Dr. John Dixon, the CBS-TV soap opera's longtime villain.

title: Trial by Jury, Made Fairer
description: The Supreme Court's ruling that even white defendants may challenge the exclusion of blacks from a jury is a dramatic and welcome blow against racial discrimination in the American system of justice.

title: Cholera Toll Rises in Peru
description: More than 170 people died of cholera during Easter week, the highest seven-day toll since the epidemic began in late January, health officials said today. Health Ministry officials blamed contaminated seafood. Fish is a traditional dish during Easter holidays in this largely Roman Catholic country. At least 780 people have died in the epidemic.

title: Why Don't Consumers See Lower Milk Prices?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Deal Looks Doubtful to Viola
description: Unique. Innovative. Special.

title: Declining C.D. Yield Slows
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts have fallen for the fifth consecutive week. But the decline was less for the period that ended yesterday than in the previous two weeks.

title: Daley Easily Defeats 3 Others In Mayoral Race in Chicago
description: Richard M. Daley, who won a special mayoral election in 1989 after Mayor Harold Washington died in office, was elected today to a full term, easily defeating three opponents.

title: Work Ordered on Texas Plan
description: A Texas district court judge has ordered a state education official to devise a school finance plan by April 15, effectively giving the Legislature two weeks to produce its own measure that would make the current financing more equitable.

title: New York at Work; Gossip's Hot, and Hers Is the Name to Drop
description: So you say you don't read the gossip columns. Names like Suzy and William Norwich and, especially, Liz Smith are just vaguely out there someplace -- tabloid commentators who satisfy the rest of the public's yearning to experience vicariously the glittering lives of the rich and famous.

title: Civilian Named in Mali as Interim Premier
description: Mali's new military rulers named a civilian today to oversee a transitional Government that is expected to serve until multi-party elections are held.

title: LOS ANGELES CHIEF ASSAILED BY MAYOR
description: After hesitating for a month after the beating of a black motorist by white police officers, Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles called today for the resignation of Chief Daryl F. Gates.

title: Woman Cleared After Drug Use in Pregnancy
description: A Michigan appeals court today ruled that a women should not stand trial on charges of delivering cocaine to her newborn son through the umbilical cord in a case that civil libertarians said could set the tone for future cases involving pregnant women who abuse drugs.

title: Matthew P. Deane, 60, A Former Stockbroker
description: Matthew P. Deane, a retired investment banker and stockbroker, died on Friday at his home in Todt Hill, S.I. He was 60 years old.

title: BUSH NOT PRESSING KUWAIT ON REFORM
description: Although frustrated by the slow pace of political and economic revival in Kuwait, President Bush believes there is little he can do to force democratic reform and is not putting any heavy pressure on the Emir, Administration officials said today.

title: Review/Television; Risks of Living and Other Adventures
description: If you find yourself being distracted from a promising documentary by a giddiness of graphics, odds are that the producer has not had enough confidence in the material to present it straight. Take tonight's three-hour report, "Living Against the Odds," at 8 on Channels 13 and 49. Assessing risk in this risky world can be a stimulating exercise, abounding in implications for policy planners. But the people at the WGBH Science Unit who put the program together evidently decided to hedge their bet with gimmicks, gizmos and gags.

title: James B. Moore Jr., Yachtsman, 79
description: James B. Moore Jr., a yachtsman who competed on Long Island Sound for more than 60 years, died Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn. He was 79 years old.

title: Plan to Create Jobs to Cut New York Welfare Rolls
description: In reaction to growing political pressure to trim New York's welfare rolls, the state's Social Services Commissioner proposed a program today that would pay private employers to create long-term jobs for welfare recipients.

title: Review/Television; Awards for Being Funny. Seriously.
description: Coming on the heels of the always glittery Academy Awards, the "Fifth Annual American Comedy Awards" is a relatively scruffy affair, but it is more endearing. If nothing else, it has a sense of humor, brought home hilariously by performers including Jonathan Winters, Steve Martin and Mel Brooks. The show, which was taped on March 9 in Los Angeles and edited to two hours, may be seen at 9 tonight on ABC .

title: Abortion Bill Veto Upheld in North Dakota
description: The North Dakota House failed today to override Gov. George Sinner's veto of an abortion bill that would have been the nation's strictest.

title: Book Notes
description: The Way Publishing Was

title: California's Fiscal Crisis Tests Government's Role
description: Facing a budget shortfall wider than ever before encountered by a state, the government of California has been plunged into a deep crisis that many lawmakers say could force a fundamental restructuring of government in the nation's most populous state.

title: Meredith Corp. Buys Pali Arts
description: The Meredith Corporation, a publisher of magazines that include The Ladies' Home Journal and Better Homes and Gardens, said today that it had acquired Pali Arts Communications, the San Francisco-based publisher of the American Park Network visitor guide magazines.

title: Market Place; David vs. Goliath In Retail Struggle
description: THERE are small towns, and there are very small towns. As the growing giants of retailing scour the country for new sites, they have aimed at small cities but have often spurned the small towns with a population of less than 8,000.

title: 'Shadowlands' to Close
description: "Shadowlands," a play by William Nicholson, is to close after the matinee performance on Sunday at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street. The Sunday matinee of the play, directed by Elijah Moshinsky, will be its 169th regular performance; it had 11 previews.

title: Nestle Brands To McCann
description: The Nestle Beverage Company has awarded the advertising accounts for its Nestea and Coffee-mate brands, with total billings of $18 million, to McCann-Erickson New York.

title: Texan Gets Five Years In Big S.& L. Collapse
description: Don R. Dixon, a former developer who led the Vernon Savings and Loan Association on a blinding course of fast deals during a precipitous collapse in the 1980's, was given a five-year prison term today for defrauding regulators, illegally spending depositors' money and other misdeeds as the owner of Vernon.

title: Exhibition of Artworks By Those 55 and Over
description: An exhibition of 53 works by artists at least 55 years old is to open today in SoHo. The show, which is titled "Discoveries," is the sixth annual exhibition to feature the work of older artists and is sponsored by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation.

title: Court Rejects a Big East Side Project Over Sewage
description: A $500 million housing and commercial complex that the New York City Board of Estimate had approved for Manhattan's East Side was rejected yesterday by a state appeals court.

title: New Soviet-U.S. X-ray Lens Is Developed
description: An American and a Soviet scientist said yesterday that they had developed a new type of X-ray lens capable of focusing powerful beams that can be used in manufacturing a new generation of extremely powerful computer chips. The lens can also be used in a variety of other scientific and medical applications.

title: People
description: * Christopher T. Linen, the president and chief executive of Time Warner Direct, has been named general chairman and chief operating officer of the 1991 John Caples International Awards, which recognize the most creative work in the direct-marketing field this year. * Susan Chiafullo has been promoted to senior vice president in the Minneapolis office of Campbell-Mithun-Esty.

title: Treasury Securities Up Slightly
description: Expectations that employment data to be released on Friday will show that the economy weakened further in March helped push prices of Treasury securities up modestly yesterday.

title: Umpires File Labor Charge
description: Everybody knows that the major league baseball season begins next Monday. But when it does, who will shout "play ball?"

title: T.W.A. Retains Legal Help
description: Trans World Airlines Inc., which defaulted on $75 million in debt payments in February, said today that it had retained bankruptcy lawyers in case it was forced to seek Chapter 11 protection.

title: Business, Not Bombs, Will Unite Ireland
description: To the Editor: Re "The Bullet and the Ballot Box" by Padraig O'Malley (Op-Ed, March 2), I would like to ask Irish-Americans who support Noraid and indirectly the Irish Republican Army: What must happen before Britain will consider serious negotiations on home rule?

title: Samuel J. Powers, Lawyer, 73
description: Samuel Joseph Powers, a White House lawyer who found the 18-minute gap on President Richard M. Nixon's Watergate tapes, died Friday. He was 73 years old.

title: On Connecticut Tax Plan, Town Mutters, What Next?
description: Sandy Maloney's outrage at the idea of a state income tax is passionate and personal, aimed at the man she believes is nothing less than a turncoat: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Baxter International Inc. is offering $100 million in 8.2 percent noncallable notes due 99.896 to yield 8.23 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&P. * Chandler, Ariz., is offering water and sewer tax-exempt revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 7.15 percent through underwriters led by First Boston Corp. Yields on shorter maturities range from 5.25 percent in 1992 to 6.65 percent in 2001. Another bond due in 2006 is priced to yield 7.07 percent. The financing is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company and rated triple-A by both Moody's and S.&P. * Sears Euro Accounts Receivable Select Trust, formed by Sears, Roebuck & Co. to securitize credit card receivables, plans to offer in the Eurobond market a $750 million issue of five-year bonds through Credit Suisse First Boston. * Society Corp., Cleveland, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million in debt securities and up to $200 million in preferred stock. COMMON STOCK * Florida Progress Corp., St. Petersburg, Fla., has filed for an offering of 2.7 million common shares through Merrill Lynch & Co. * Healthsource Inc., Concord, N.H., has filed for 1.75 million common shares through Robertson Stephens & Co.

title: Topics of The Times; Capitalist Stretch
description: The American family car may, more and more, tend to be of Japanese manufacture, but no one beats the American stretch limousine. An extravagance once confined to meccas of glitter like New York and Hollywood, it is everywhere now. A startled New Yorker recently spotted a stretch Jeep Wagoneer while skiing in Aspen, Colo. He would get another jolt if he were now to visit Poland.

title: Excerpts From Draft U.N. Council Resolution on the Cease-Fire in the Gulf
description: Following are excerpts from the draft United Nations Security Council resolution declaring a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war: THE SECURITY COUNCIL,

title: Dave Morrah, Humorist, 77
description: Dave Morrah, known for his humorous articles and cartoons in The Saturday Evening Post from 1946 to 1962, died on Friday. He was 77 years old.

title: Lawmaker's Aid to Alma Mater Skews U.S. Budget
description: A Congressional leader arranged an $8 million Federal grant to his alma mater two weeks ago, and that small act may end up setting off spending cuts in a wide range of domestic programs.

title: About New York; Remembering Woolf: Where But the Library?
description: Last Thursday was the 50th anniversary of the gray day Virginia Woolf, who had just suffered another breakdown, drowned herself in the River Ouse.

title: Article 480491 -- No Title
description: A three-year-old biotechnology company that is years away from having any product on the market raised $99 million in an initial public stock offering today. Its success suggests that the shortage of capital that had threatened young pharmaceutical companies is now over.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Stones Live

title: Musical America Magazine Announces Reorganization
description: The editorial staff of Musical America, the oldest classical music magazine in the United States and the only one to cover not only recordings but live performances on a national scale, was reorganized on Monday by its new publisher, Gerry M. Ritterman. Mr. Ritterman bought the magazine from Capital Cities/ABC in February at an undisclosed price. He had previously been the publisher of Soap Opera Digest, which he sold to Murdoch Publishing in 1989 at a profit of $50 million.

title: Study Finds 80,000 Women May Carry HIV
description: Up to 80,000 women in the United States of child-bearing age may be infected with the virus that causes AIDS, a new study concludes.

title: Barry Offers Insight on Destructive Life Style
description: In an article in a small Washington magazine, former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has given a strikingly detailed description of how his life came to revolve around drinking, drugs and women.

title: Duke Takes Crown and the Pressure to Repeat
description: By 3 o'clock this morning, the elbow-to-elbow celebration of Duke fans, players and friends had thinned out. The lobby of the Holiday Inn had cleared. The party was over.

title: Yale Tries to Strengthen Its Studies in the Sciences
description: Yale University has begun a drive to strengthen its science programs, redesigning its curriculum, building laboratories and aggressively recruiting science majors.

title: Woman Says She Was Raped at Kennedy Estate
description: A 30-year-old woman says she was raped at the Kennedy family's beachfront estate early Saturday, after encountering Senator Edward M. Kennedy, one of his sons and one of his nephews at a luxurious nightclub here, the police said today.

title: Korean Companies in China
description: Three more South Korean companies said today that they had received official approval to open branch operations in Beijing.

title: IRAQI REVOLTS EBB AS KURDISH FORCES FLEE TO MOUNTAINS
description: Iraq's Army appeared today to have crushed a monthlong rebellion as fighting ebbed in the south and Kurdish guerrillas in the north abandoned major cities, fleeing into the mountainous border with Turkey and Iran, Administration officials said.

title: New Salsa Is True to Newman's Own Taste
description: PAUL NEWMAN likes his salsa hot. But not too hot. Definitely not hot enough to bring tears to his baby-blue eyes. And the actor is counting on others' agreeing with him.

title: Robert Klausner, 72, Real Estate Developer
description: Robert J. Klausner, a founding partner of Klausner Associates, real-estate investors and developers, died on Saturday at White Plains Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: MOST home cooks are still intimidated by souffles, believing they are something reserved for experienced restaurant chefs. In fact, souffles are no more challenging than poached eggs. And with today's food processors, they can be prepared in minutes.

title: Secret Nuclear-Powered Rocket Being Developed for 'Star Wars'
description: In great secrecy, the Pentagon is developing a nuclear-powered rocket for hauling giant weapons and other military payloads into space as part of the "Star Wars" program.

title: Woman Says She Was Raped at Kennedy Estate
description: A 30-year-old woman says she was raped at the Kennedy family's beachfront estate early Saturday, after encountering Senator Edward M. Kennedy, one of his sons and one of his nephews at a luxurious nightclub here, the police said today.

title: San Francisco's Refunding Bonds
description: The Redevelopment Agency of the City and County of San Francisco is offering $60.3 million in refunding bonds to refund lease revenue bonds outstanding issued in 1979 and used to finance the construction of the Mascone Convention Center.

title: Lawrence Jay Taylor, Music Librarian, 44
description: Lawrence Jay Taylor, a music librarian, producer and singer, died on March 18 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 44 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amcast Industrial Corp., Kettering, Ohio, an iron and aluminum products company, will invest $20 million to expand its cast-aluminum auto wheel business. * Anchor Bancorp Inc., Hewlett, L.I., a holding company, completed its reorganization plan under which Anchor Savings Bank became a wholly owned subsidiary of Anchor Bancorp.

title: Higher Fees for Doctors May Not Help Medicaid
description: When Medicaid was established, many members of Congress assumed it would supplant charity care provided by doctors at no charge. But now 26 years later, Medicaid fees lag so far behind the costs of providing care that some doctors offer free care without bothering to file Medicaid claims and others do not serve Medicaid patients at all.

title: New York Picks a June Date For a Parade for Gulf Troops
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday that the city would hold a $3 million welcome-home celebration for Persian Gulf troops in early June, including fireworks and a parade up Broadway from Wall Street that he said would be "the world's largest."

title: Amid Feud, an Offer for Penrod
description: The Energy Service Company, a Dallas-based driller that headed a group of prominent investors who bought the Penrod Drilling Corporation last year, offered $8 a share yesterday for most of the shares now owned by its estranged partner, R. D. Smith & Company.

title: Virginia Electric Issue Is Priced
description: The Virginia Electric and Power Company, a subsidiary of Dominion Resources Inc., priced through competitive bidding $100 million in 30-year first and refunding bonds yesterday through Merrill Lynch & Company as sole manager.

title: Road Service Offer By Universal Card
description: The Universal Card, the combination credit card and telephone charge card issued by A.T.& T., said it would offer a toll-free number for emergency auto service.

title: Samara Moves Up
description: Fred Samara, Princeton's longtime head coach of field events, will become head coach of track events as well beginning with the next indoor season. Samara, recently named to the 1992 United States Olympic team coaching staff, will assume the duties from Larry Ellis, who will continue to work with athletes in running events and continue to serve as coach of the men's cross-country team.

title: Addiction Illogic
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Don't Consumers See Lower Milk Prices?; Fewer Farm Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Yeltsin's Foes Back Away From Effort to Topple Him
description: The Communist apparatus retreated today from its attempt to bring down Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, after a week of hardball politics that seemed only to have increased his popularity in relation to that of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: A Better Economic Mood; Many Say the Gulf Crisis Shook Confidence And Foresee a Recovery as Hope Revives
description: The current recession may be the first in memory that can be attributed to a case of nerves. And now that confidence has come roaring back, signs are that an economic recovery is not far behind. But will the recovery be nearly as strong as the dramatic lift in consumer spirits?

title: New N.B.A. Campaign Looks at the Ordinary
description: The National Basketball Association begins a new campaign tomorrow that uses everyday situations, rather than fast-paced N.B.A. action, to lure fans to the game.

title: Shearson Is Paying $750,000 To Settle With Big Board
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers has agreed to pay $750,000 to the New York Stock Exchange to settle accusations of wide-ranging violations of the exchange's rules at one of the brokerage firm's most profitable branches.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS

title: Canada Economic Index
description: Canada's leading economic indicator fell 1 percent in January after a revised seven-tenths of 1 percent drop in December, the Government statistics office said today.

title: Factory Orders Down In February
description: Orders received by factories in the United States fell for the fourth straight month in February, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Sol C. Chaikin, 73, Ex-Organizer Who Led Garment Workers, Dies
