description: Sol C. Chaikin, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union from 1975 until 1986 and more recently acting head of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on Manhattan's West Side, died on Monday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, Queens. He was 73 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Fiscal Cuts May Still Harlem Pupils' Violins
description: Roberta Guaspari Tzavaras's violin class at Central Park East I Elementary School in Manhattan would not be dismissed. Fifteen minutes after she had announced -- with a quick, graceful bow of thanks -- that the day was over and the school bus waiting, the 28 students continued to play around.

title: Review/Film; History Plays Tricks With a Documentary On the Berlin Wall
description: Nothing ever goes according to schedule for Ross McElwee, which is his good fortune and ours.

title: School Closings In Archdiocese Won't Exceed 5
description: The Archdiocese of New York said yesterday that no more than five of its 312 schools would close this year. But an archdiocese official said they could be just the first wave of closings over the next few years because of financial hardships.

title: Top Shearson Official To Join Smith Barney
description: The top ranks of two Wall Street firms shifted yesterday, when Robert Druskin, the chief financial officer of Shearson Lehman Brothers, agreed to join Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. He will take on the titles of senior executive vice president and co-chief administrative officer at Smith Barney.

title: Brooklyn's Boulevard of Broken Promises
description: Designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, Eastern Parkway was once the Champs Elysees of Brooklyn, a grand, tree-lined thoroughfare and a model for urban boulevards throughout the nation. Now, four years after New York City awarded a $59 million contract to restore the parkway's faded 19th-century elegance, the avenue and its once parklike pedestrian malls are in shambles -- a trash-strewn symbol of the failure of city government.

title: Bucks Sign Dantley
description: The Milwaukee Bucks signed forward Adrian Dantley for the rest of the season today and placed guard Dale Ellis on the injured list with a herniated disk.

title: Devils Must Check Lemieux and Penalties
description: Containing Mario Lemieux and Paul Coffey and refraining from frequent trips to the penalty box are the main tasks for the Devils if they are to have any success in their playoff series with the Penguins.

title: Where to Get Pastries With Star Quality
description: WHAT do the movies "Moonstruck," "Married to the Mob" and "Bright Lights, Big City" have in common? They all had scenes with cakes in them, and those cakes all came from a cheerful, bustling mom-and-pop store called Mazur's Bakery. Rather than being a trendy place in an urban area, Mazur's is on the main street in this small town in northern New Jersey.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NICK NOLTEand REBECCA NOLTE have filed for divorce after a seven-year marriage. The announcement was made in Los Angeles yesterday by their press agent. The couple will have joint custody of their son, Brawley King Nolte, four years old. The divorce was described as very amicable.

title: The Bolshoi Summer Tour Rescued From Bankruptcy
description: The financially threatened summer season of the Bolshoi Opera and the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House and a planned 31-city tour of "Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet" were rescued by legal maneuvers in bankruptcy court yesterday.

title: Domingo to Star In Carnegie Hall Benefit
description: Placido Domingo is to star in a benefit concert for Carnegie Hall on April 12, with the Orchestra of St. Luke's under the direction of Enrique Garcia-Asensio. Ainoa Arteta, a soprano, and Dolora Zajick, a mezzo-soprano, will take part in the program, which will consist of arias from Spanish-inspired operas by Bizet, Donizetti, Mozart, Rossini and Verdi, and excerpts from zarzuelas by Sorozabal, Torroba and others.

title: Food Notes
description: Olives and Olive Oil

title: INSIDE
description: Killing Angers Chilean Right Right-wing demonstrators accused the Government of killing a senator who was a close adviser to Chile's former military rulers. Page A3. 3 Albanian Protesters Killed Army units fired on anti-Communist demonstrators in a northern city, killing 3, wounding 30 and setting off a rampage by the protesters. Page A3. A California Fiscal Crisis A "catastrophic" California budget deficit may force fundamental changes in the way the most populous state operates. Page A12. Los Angeles Mayor's Stand Mayor Tom Bradley called for Chief Daryl F. Gates to resign, saying the public had lost confidence in the head of the Police Department. Page A17. 5 Years in S.&L. Case Don R. Dixon was given a five-year sentence for fraud and other misdeeds in the $1 billion collapse of a Texas savings association. Page D1. TB Among Migrant Workers Tuberculosis rates are so high among migrant farm workers that the disease is a virtual occupational hazard, researchers say. Page A16.

title: Albanian Troops Kill 3 Protesters and Wound 30
description: Army units fired today on anti-Communist demonstrators protesting election results by sitting in the main square of this northern Albanian city, killing three of them and wounding 30.

title: Dorothy M. Dunbar, Executive, 58
description: Dorothy M. Dunbar, creative director of Time-Life Home Video, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 58 years old.

title: Washington Talk; Old Split Reveals Itself In Court's Juror Ruling
description: A Supreme Court ruling this week was a reminder that neither the passage of time nor the accumulation of precedent has been able to heal a decades-old fault line within the Court.

title: Chairman of Polaroid Plans to Retire May 7
description: William J. McCune Jr. plans to retire as chairman of the Polaroid Corporation on May 7 after the company's annual meeting, the company has announced. Polaroid said I. MacAllister Booth, its president and chief executive, is expected to be given the additional post of chairman.

title: Real Estate; Sears Seeking to Fill Tower's Large Floors
description: OVER two million square feet of space in the Sears Tower is coming onto the market at a time of low demand caused by overbuilding. But Sears, Roebuck & Company, which owns the tower, has taken the first steps toward filling the space, with one signed lease for three floors and a letter of intent for at least five more.

title: Pressed Private Colleges Reining In Tuition
description: Squeezed by the recession and a shrinking number of high school graduates headed for college, private colleges and universities are trying to attract students by keeping tuition increases to their lowest levels in more than 15 years.

title: Feeding Babies
description: To The Living Section:

title: Capital Findings on Jell-O: Loved, Hated, Hard to Nail Down
description: It was April Fool's Day. So perhaps it was fitting that a group of historians and social scientists at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History spent a few hours Monday in a scholarly sendup of that quivery, shimmery jewel-toned gelatin that Americans have been eating for almost a century: Jell-O.

title: Rangers' Kocur Ready To Resume Fighting
description: The hand is an open wound, scarred and oozing around the knuckles, but Joe Kocur said his right fist can still be closed for business.

title: Albany Republicans Seek Fairness to Suburbs in School Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL: N.C.A.A. CHAMPIONSHIP;
Emotional Aftermath for U.N.L.V.
description: I didn't watch the national championship game last night. I didn't look forward to seeing it, I can say that, but it wasn't that I didn't want to. Between coming up here to New York and seeing my friends, I really didn't get an opportunity. Plus, the season's over for me..

title: Japan Concern Turns to Bonds
description: The Kinki Nippon Railway Company has submitted an application to sell 30 billion yen (about $215 million) in fixed-rate bonds to the Ministry of Finance, according to the newspaper Nihon Keizai. If approved, this would be the first sale of fixed interest-rate bonds in Japan since November 1988, except by public utility companies.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 'Excuse Me, But I Can't Stop Smiling'
description: On a much, much too bright morning after, when the people eased quietly into Cameron Indoor Stadium, the scoreboards appeared just the way they had on that championship night before: Duke, 72-65.

title: Chinese Leadership Names 2 Deputy Premiers
description: The Chinese leadership has tentatively decided to name two new Deputy Prime Ministers, including the reformist Mayor of Shanghai, in a move that is expected to give a lift to the faction that favors more rapid economic change.

title: An 18-Year-Old Pleads Guilty In a Bombing at Wesleyan U.
description: An 18-year-old nephew of a Wesleyan University professor pleaded guilty on Monday in the firebombing of the university president's office. He acknowledged that he had planned the bombing with a student, Nicholas Haddad, who was slain last summer in a dispute involving a drug ring.

title: Orioles Sign Flanagan
description: Mike Flanagan, who was released by Toronto early last season and whose career was considered over, has convinced the Baltimore Orioles, the team he spent most of his career with, that he is back in form. Flanagan agreed yesterday to a one-year contract worth $250,000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: GOV. WILDER ACTS ON CAMPUS CRIME
description: Saying he wants his state to be a model for the rest of the country, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia has established a group to study ways to fight campus crime, including the possibility of mandatory testing of college students for drug use.

title: Measuring Wear and Tear on Teeth
description: Using a powerful scanning electron microscope, a scientist has developed a method for precisely measuring daily and weekly wear and tear on teeth.

title: Bankers Reportedly Press WPP to Add Board Member
description: MARTIN SORRELL, chief executive of the WPP Group, has hit another roadblock in his negotiations with a syndicate of banks on a $1 billion plan to renegotiate his company's debt. Some of the banks are demanding that Mr. Sorrell appoint at least one more senior executive to the company's board, said bankers involved in the discussions and advertising industry analysts.

title: Austin Journal; Rap Sheet Is a Candidate's Platform
description: This state boasts a rich history of bizarre politics, but the story that surfaced here today stretches even Texas's standards.

title: Table-Top Verities Are Toppling, It Seems
description: A SIDE table is, to most people, a handy spot for a coaster and a glass. A coffee table is a place to put newspapers. Or maybe feet.

title: Officials Say Hospitals Skirt Reporting Rules
description: State Health Department officials maintained today that hospitals are skirting state regulations by reporting only a small fraction of the injuries that occur on their premises, whether bruises from accidental falls or deaths from excessive anesthesia.

title: First Executive Chief Is at the Brink
description: Fred Carr, the chairman of the First Executive Corporation, has weathered intense competition in building the company into one of the nation's largest insurers. He has endured lengthy Federal investigations into his ties to Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. without being implicated in wrongdoing. And he has fought off a hostile takeover bid and an attempt to oust him by one of First Executive's largest shareholders.

title: Ammirati Is Said to Lose Nynex Account Review
description: Ammirati & Puris has been eliminated as a finalist in the hotly contested review for the Nynex Corporation's $20 million to $30 million corporate account, apparently clearing the way for Ogilvy & Mather, the other finalist, industry executives said.

title: The Stuff of Mosaics or Place Mats
description: LIORA MANNE, the developer of "Lamontage," a new fiber process, describes it reverently: " 'Lamina' for layers and 'montage' for image."

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Currency Devalued In an effort to undercut the local black market, the Soviet Union more than quadrupled the number of rubles tourists may buy with each dollar. But the move stopped short of freeing the exchange rate. Page A5. A Televised Exorcism With the consent of a priest of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, a camera crew has filmed an exorcism and is to broadcast it on network television. Page A19. Teen Dating in the Bedroom Some parents have concluded that allowing their teen-agers to have sex at home is a way of protecting them from AIDS, drugs, crime and other realities of teen-age life. The Home Section, page C1. White Sox Gamble on Bo Bo Jackson, the two-sport star with the questionable hip, has reached a three-year agreement worth from $700,000 to $8.15 million to play baseball for Chicago. Page D21. New on Thursdays: Home Video The column has moved from Arts and Leisure to become a weekly feature in the arts pages. Today, a look at why some classic movies are still not available on videocassette. Page C19.

title: The War's Not Over Yet
description: Saddam Hussein's war against the world won't finally end until he accepts the cease-fire terms voted yesterday by the United Nations Security Council. But those terms are so tough and comprehensive that the Iraqi dictator might well refuse, or at least stall, even as tens of thousands of refugees flee from his rule. Where would that leave the victorious Desert Storm allies, now eager to pull out of Iraq and go home?

title: R. D. Smith Skeptical of $100 Million Bid for Penrod Stake
description: R. D. Smith & Company said yesterday that it was skeptical of an offer for roughly $100 million that its investor group had received on Tuesday from the Energy Service Company for most of its shares in the Penrod Drilling Corporation. The response suggests that a feud between the two companies could drag on for some time.

title: Regeneron Shares Post 13.6% Decline
description: The shares of Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc., which on Tuesday completed one of the largest initial public offerings in the history of the biotechnology industry, dropped sharply. The stock, traded over-the-counter, fell $2.875 a share, or 13.6 percent, to close at $18.25, after a drop of 87.5 cents on Tuesday. That means the stock is already 17 percent below its initial price of $22.

title: NASA Goal: 2 Space Shuttle Missions This Month
description: With two space shuttles on launching pads here, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is trying to do something it has not attempted in more than five years: launch two shuttle missions in a single month.

title: A 3M Vice President Will Become Chairman
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company yesterday named one of its longtime executives to replace Allen F. Jacobson as chairman and chief executive. Livio D. DeSimone, the executive vice president of the company's information and imaging technologies sector, will take the chairman's job at the end of October, upon Mr. Jacobson's retirement. The 54-year-old Mr. DeSimone, who has been with the company for 33 years, has been a member of its board since 1986.

title: First Death Under Drug Law Is Favored by Alabama Jury
description: A jury recommended today that a man convicted of running a drug operation become the first person in the nation sentenced to death under a 1988 Federal law allowing capital punishment in drug-related killings.

title: Lebanese Cabinet Tells P.L.O. Guerrillas to Disarm
description: Muslim and Christian Government leaders said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization must disarm thousands of its guerrillas in Lebanon and end its "state within the Lebanese state."

title: Business and the Law; Antitrust Changes Split Insurers
description: IN most industries, the smaller companies are more likely to use the antitrust laws against larger competitors than the biggest players, who tend to find such laws distasteful.

title: Graham Greene, 86, Dies; Novelist of the Soul
description: Graham Greene, the British author whose novels of suspense and moral ambiguity plumbed the sordid politics of the modern world and the inner torments of mankind, died yesterday at La Providence Hospital in Vevey, near Lake Geneva in Switzerland. He was 86 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aaron Rents Inc., Atlanta, a furniture rental and sales company, named Thomas Sullivan director of its new corporate amenities unit, which will supply household accessories to the company's rental customers. * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., named Dr. Mark W. Atwood vice president of development for its agricultural research division.

title: No Sparks, Few Hits From Mets
description: Bud Harrelson sat slumped in his office chair and ran a shaky hand through his hair. Harrelson had minutes before walked off the field here, feeling faint and complaining of dizziness. The manager of the Mets laughed off the symptoms and blamed the episode on age, extra pounds and general fatigue.

title: Oil Pipeline Crew Is Found Lacking
description: A four-month government investigation into charges of shoddy testing for rust and cracks in the Trans-Alaska Pipeline has concluded that workers were poorly trained for some tasks and that the pipeline company provided inadequate supervision.

title: U.S.-Made Honda Wagons in Japan
description: The Honda Motor Company began selling a new compact station wagon model in Japan that was designed and manufactured in the United States. The cars, derived from Honda's popular Accord model, have a base price of $19,580 in Japan at current exchange rates. The same vehicle, with the steering wheel on the left-hand side for American drivers, went on sale in the United States in December, with a base price of $17,300.

title: Big Board Aide Plans to Resign
description: After almost nine years with the New York Stock Exchange, Richard Torrenzano, a senior vice president and spokesman, will leave the Big Board for a job at the public relations firm of Hill & Knowlton, the firm said yesterday.

title: Getting Out the Votes Of the 18-Year-Olds
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Mexico Pact Faces Hurdle on Tuna Fishing
description: With the North American free-trade agreement at a critical stage, the United States and Mexico are locked in a dispute over the environmental damage caused by Mexico's tuna-fishing fleet.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Fast -- and Prosperous -- Track
description: Congress confronts two chances, one monumental, to boost prosperity through freer trade:

title: Rape Investigation Continues at Kennedy Estate
description: It might be "days or even weeks" before the police here conclude their investigation into a reported rape at the Kennedy family compound over Easter weekend, Chief Joseph L. Terlizzese of the Palm Beach Police Department said today.

title: The Perfect Flower For Midsummer
description: ACCORDING to "Hortus Third," the genus Hypericum is large, made up of more than 300 species of woody shrubs and herbaceous perennials from Asia, Europe and North America. These plants have some history to them, as well as a good bit of mythology and theology.

title: Evans Leaves School
description: Prompted in part by the N.C.A.A.'s new restrictions on training time, Janet Evans, a sophomore at Stanford and the world's leading female swimmer for the last four years, renounced her last two years of college eligibility today to train full time for next year's Olympics. Melvin Stewart, a junior at Tennessee who holds the men's world record and world championship in the 200-meter butterfly, did the same.

title: Public & Private; Social Conscience
description: The nuns who run The Nurturing Place here will never forget what Freddie said at the seashore. Almost none of the kids had ever seen the ocean before; their faces, when they came over the dunes and saw the water spread before them in all its fractious glory, were something to see. But Freddie captured the undercurrent of all their little lives after they went out to dinner and came back to the beach. The first one over the crest of sand, he turned to say triumphantly, "It's still there."

title: Stocks Close Mixed as Dow Falls by 18.32
description: Stock prices ended on a mixed note yesterday with the blue chips and the rest of the big stocks giving way but the smaller stocks continuing to show strong gains.

title: Kremlin and Striking Miners Reach Accord to Raise Pay
description: The Soviet Government and striking coal miners reached agreement today on a pay package that would double wages within a year in exchange for commitments on higher productivity.

title: Coral Lansbury, 61, a Novelist And Victorian Scholar, Is Dead
description: Coral Lansbury, an author, Victorian scholar and dean of the Graduate School of English at Rutgers University's Camden campus, died on Tuesday at her home in Philadelphia. She was 61 years old.

title: Compaq to Buy Stake in Silicon Graphics
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation will invest $185 million in Silicon Graphics Inc. as part of a strategic alliance that could upset the balance of power in the computer industry.

title: Times Expanding Sports Coverage
description: The New York Times will introduce an expanded daily sports report, beginning on Tuesday. It will include greater coverage of local teams and increased use of photographs, charts, diagrams and statistics.

title: For a Drizzle of Pepper And a Sprinkle of Salt
description: IT'S one of those ideas that brings a smile and the question, "Why didn't I think of it?"

title: Getting U.S. Goods Wholesale in Moscow
description: A wholesale showroom offering United States goods will open Monday in Moscow on the grounds of the Soviet Space Research Institute, only a few miles from Red Square.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
Young, Privileged And Unemployed
description: We are young, urban and professional. We are literate, respectable, intelligent and charming. But foremost and above all, we know what it's like to be unemployed.

title: Accounts
description: * The Newspaper Advertising Bureau, the marketing association of the newspaper industry, to W.B. Doner & Co., Baltimore. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Padding the Gulf War Bill
description: When the U.S. decided on military action against Iraq, it made two decisions about financing. First, the costs of the operation would be off- budget, and thus not counted in the deficit. And second, our allies would be asked to pay 80 percent of the costs.

title: Mayor Daley Wins Full Term After Quiet Chicago Election
description: Mayor Richard M. Daley was easily elected to his first full term on Tuesday after one of the quietest campaigns in Chicago history.

title: Knicks Have Injuries But No Real Excuse
description: Even without Gerald Wilkins and Trent Tucker, the Knicks had no excuses for losing tonight.

title: As Police Talks Stall, Motorists Gain
description: Police officers across New York City have virtually stopped writing tickets to protest an impasse in contract talks, police and union officials said.

title: Rape Investigation Continues at Kennedy Estate
description: It might be "days or even weeks" before the police here conclude their investigation into a reported rape at the Kennedy family compound over Easter weekend, Chief Joseph L. Terlizzese of the Palm Beach Police Department said today.

title: Blacks Claim Victory in Georgia Suit on Fire Department Racism
description: A black citizens' group in the small southwestern Georgia community of Blakely proclaimed victory today after settling a lawsuit charging that the Fire Department was dominated by Ku Klux Klan members who provided insufficient protection or no protection at all for black neighborhoods.

title: Investigating Police: A Flood of New Cases
description: The Manhattan District Attorney has quietly created a special unit to handle police misconduct cases, including accusations of brutality and corruption, which the unit's chief said are rising sharply.

title: Voting Plummets in Mexico: A Gesture of No-Confidence?
description: As politicians here square off in a yearlong schedule of crucial midterm elections, a key player in Mexico's electoral drama has turned up missing: the Mexican voter.

title: 'Tough' Year No Reason to Quit, Myers Says
description: New York City's Health Commissioner, Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr., yesterday expressed frustration over his first year with city government, but said his mother-in-law's illness would determine whether he stayed on the job.

title: Sallie Mae Sets Note Offering
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million in floating-rate notes due April 17, 1995, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: No-Stop Tolls: 3 States Agree To Automation
description: In the not too distant future, it will be possible to drive from Albany to Philadelphia -- or anywhere in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania -- without stopping to pay any tolls.

title: Bill to Void Adultery Laws to Go to Weicker
description: The State Senate voted overwhelmingly today to rescind Connecticut's anti-adultery criminal statutes, but lawmakers were careful to tread a fine line. Sex outside the bonds of marriage is still morally offensive, many stressed, but in the waning days of the 20th century it should not be an offense that could land one in jail.

title: Kuwaiti Dissident Warns of Showdown on Reform
description: A prominent figure in the opposition to the Kuwaiti ruling family said today that the nation's confrontation over democratic reforms was entering "a crucial phase" that could lead to clashes between the ruling family and those who want it to surrender some power.

title: Being Left-Handed May Be Dangerous To Life, Study Says
description: Left-handed people tend to live significantly shorter lives than right-handers, perhaps because they face more perils in a world dominated by the right-handed, according to new research.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Bush's Vacation Part II: Long Way From Maine
description: The scene: a sun-splashed seaside village. The opening shot: the President of the United States roars off in a motorboat for a day of fishing. The closing shot: the Commander in Chief hits the links for a quick round of golf.

title: Solar Energy Advancement
description: Texas Instruments Inc. and the Southern California Edison Company said today that they had developed a way to use inexpensive low-purity silicon in solar cells, which could halve the cost of converting sunlight into electricity.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Named
description: James Garrity Jr., the chief of the tax unit in the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, has been named a judge to fill a vacancy in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York. The seven judges of the court, based in Manhattan, handle some of the most complex corporate bankruptcy cases.

title: Iran Will Accept Iraqi Kurds, and It Asks for Aid
description: Iran said today that it would welcome Kurdish refugees seeking shelter from Saddam Hussein's troops and made a rare request for international aid to help it house and feed the influx it now expects.

title: Bailout Agency Accuses Law Firms of Deception
description: The agency overseeing the bailout of the nation's savings industry has said that law firms in Cleveland and Phoenix contributed to the $2.6 billion collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and should be listed as defendants in a racketeering lawsuit.

title: Wringing More Costs Out of Wall St. Firms
description: The falling ax on Wall Street has become as commonplace as the rising Dow. But now, with the most obvious cuts of employees and expenses out of the way, investment houses are picking up the scalpel in hopes of completing a historic and complex reorganization of the back office, one of the least understood aspects of their business.

title: Turkey Rejects Mass Entry of Kurds
description: Turkey accused Iraq today of putting the lives of more than 200,000 Kurds in "mortal danger" by trying to push them out of northern Iraq, but said it would not permit a mass entry of refugees into Turkey's largely Kurdish southeast.

title: Sarah Vaughan Tribute
description: A musical tribute to Sarah Vaughan is planned this evening at 7 o'clock at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Among those taking part will be Sylvia Sims, Annie Ross, Kenny Burrell, Jackie Cain, Roy Kral, Patti Bown, Rex Reed and Gary Giddins.

title: F.A.A. to Seek Tighter Security at Airports
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has proposed higher standards in the hiring, training and performance of security employees of airlines and airports.

title: Just Bring Elbow Grease; The Rags Are Supplied
description: THE invitation reads: "Dress warm; wear old clothes; bring your own gloves. We'll supply rags, cleaning materials."

title: Are Insurers Overly Risky? New Rules Aim to Find Out
description: Amid deepening public concern over the health of insurers, a new regulation now taking effect may help separate the financially strong from the shaky.

title: Suspect in Robbery Is Killed
description: The owner of a Bronx bodega killed a robbery suspect during a struggle in his store on Tuesday night and was himself wounded in an exchange of gunfire, the police said yesterday. Gilberto Lozado, 42 years old, the owner of Lozado Brothers, at 199 East 165th Street in the Melrose section, was inside the store when a man identified as Carlos Vasquez, 22, of 2482 Valentine Avenue in the Fordham section, robbed him of an undetermined amount of cash, said a police spokesman, Officer Fred Weiner.

title: New York Pension Funds Buy Israel Bonds
description: New York City pension funds have purchased $12 million in Israeli bonds, Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman announced yesterday.

title: Clemens Is Confused
description: Red Sox pitcher Roger Clemens said yesterday that he was confused and shocked by the decision of Bobby Brown, president of the American League, to uphold a five-game suspension and a $10,000 fine for Clemens's behavior in Game 4 of the playoffs last year.

title: Surrogate Inquiry Leads to Indictment of a Lawyer as a Tax Evader
description: A Federal investigation of Marie M. Lambert, a retired judge of Surrogate's Court in Manhattan, produced its first indictment yesterday -- that of a lawyer who is charged with failure to pay taxes on more than $770,000 in income.

title: Review/Pop; A Rock Pioneer of the 50's And Her Rhythm-and-Blues
description: Recognition of her historical place in rock-and-roll has come belatedly to LaVern Baker, the pioneering rhythm-and-blues singer who is appearing at the Village Gate on Friday and Saturday evenings through next weekend. More than 20 years ago, Miss Baker, whose 1950's hits included "Tweedlee Dee," "Jim Dandy" and "I Cried a Tear," left the United States to entertain American troops in Vietnam and remained abroad.

title: The $27 Million Retirement
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, has paid more than $27 million to its chairman, David O. Maxwell, who retired on Jan. 31.

title: Treasury Securities Fall in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in light trading yesterday, as dealers took profits following Tuesday's mini-rally.

title: Review/Pop; A Double Bill of Rappers Seriously Lacking in Audacity
description: The lackluster bill at the Marquee Tuesday night, featuring EPMD and Run-D.M.C., didn't prove anything, although it did reinforce several trends. For one, the opening night of what was to be a two-night stand was barely full; the second night was canceled. Without a current hit -- and Run-D.M.C. is several years older than its last real hit -- black rap groups traditionally don't draw a large audience.

title: Score One for Nicholls in His Return
description: The evening began for Bernie Nicholls with an assortment of jeers from the home crowd, and ended with a fast exit onto Eighth Avenue.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Sixers Win Without Barkley Ron Anderson came off the bench to score 23 of his 27 points in the first half last night as Philadelphia, playing without the injured Charles Barkley and Rick Mahorn, beat Indiana, 107-104, in Indianapolis. The 76ers handed Indiana its 11th loss in 37 home games despite the absence of Barkley, out for at least two weeks with a knee injury, and Mahorn, who has a bruised right heel. (AP) SuperSonics 106, Kings 91: Sacramento lost on the road for the 33d straight time, one short of the National Basketball Association record over two seasons, held by the Nets. The Kings already hold the single-season mark and will tie New Jersey's record if they lose on Sunday to the Los Angeles Clippers. Over all, the Kings are 1-36 on the road this season. (AP) Warriors 127, Heat 114: In Oakland, Calif., Golden State clinched a playoff berth as Chris Mullin scored 12 of his 28 points in the fourth quarter and Tim Hardaway had a career-high 8 steals. The Warriors will make only their third playoff appearance since 1977, but second in three years since Don Nelson became head coach. They are 8-0 in three seasons against the Heat. (AP) TENNIS Unheralded Italian Upsets Maleeva Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria, ranked ninth in the world, lost to 56th-ranked Federica Bonsignori of Italy, 6-7, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in the Family Circle Cup on Hilton Head Island, S.C. Twelfth-seeded Isabel Cueto of Germany was also upset, falling to Halle Cioffi, 6-1, 4-6, 6-4. In other singles matches, Natalya Zvereva beat Donna Faber, 6-1, 6-3; Leila Meskhi beat Radka Zrubakova, 6-3, 6-2; Helen Kelesi defeated Camille Benjamin, 6-1, 1-6, 6-2. Sandra Cecchini cruised past Beverly Bowes, 6-1, 6-0; Mercedes Paz beat Andrea Temesvari, 6-3, 6-1; Sabine Hack defeated Renata Baranski, 6-2, 6-1; Petra Langrova beat Mariaan DeSwardt, 6-1, 6-2, and Florencia Labat defeated Angela Kerek, 7-5, 6-2. Hong Kong Field Thins Out: Two more seeded players left the Hong Kong Open yesterday when third-seeded Michael Stich was beaten and Anders Jarryd retired with a leg injury. Stich, a member of Germany's Davis Cup team, lost a first-round match to Eduardo Masso of Belgium, 7-5, 6-3. Jarryd, who pulled a calf muscle, quit his match with Patrick Kuhnen of Germany after losing the first set, 6-7. Last year's runner-up, Alex Antonitsch of Austria, entered the quarterfianls when he beat Todd Witsken, 6-1, 7-6. (AP) Chesnokov Advances: Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union came back from an opening-set loss to beat Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 5-7, 7-5, 6-1, and advance to the quarterfinals of the Estoril Open in Lisbon. Chesnokov will face Horst Skoff of Austria, who defeated Richard Fromberg of Australia, 6-4, 6-2. (AP)

title: Key Rates
Ravaged City on Mississippi Floundering at Rock Bottom
description: A river and a world away from the glass towers and preoccupied hum of St. Louis lies a charred skeleton of a town that is perhaps the starkest example of a near-total collapse of an American city and the forces that are supposed to keep it afloat.

title: More Applying For Mortgages
description: Applications for mortgages in March were double the level of March 1990 and should continue at higher levels through the summer, an executive of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today.

title: Devils Travel the Road to Somewhere
description: The Devils erased a seasonlong road stigma in convincing fashion tonight in their playoff opener against the Penguins at the Civic Arena.

title: U.S. Criticizes Albania Vote, But Backs Multi-Party Rules
description: The United States said today that Albanian elections had been less than free and fair, but called on Albania's citizens to help the new multi-party system work.

title: Mesa Trust Plans To Halt Payments
description: The Mesa Offshore Trust said it would suspend its monthly distributions starting in May to pay the costs of two exploratory wells to be drilled within months by Mesa L.P. on the trust's royalty properties. To cover the costs, estimated at $3 million, the trust said it would establish a reserve by reducing its April distribution and by eliminating the distributions. The distributions are expected to be suspended for the rest of 1991 and possibly beyond.

title: Students as Volunteers: Privileged Aid the Poor
description: The fastest-growing extracurricular activity at some of New York City's elite private schools is feeding the homeless and tutoring public school children.

title: State Dept. Led Our Pre-Aug. 2 Iraq Tilt; In Shirer's Footsteps
description: To the Editor:

title: For Now, Pride Is Enough for These Ohio Voters
description: Flags are still flying along the neat blocks of bungalows on the border of Cleveland and Euclid. Shops still carry signs urging all who pass to "support our troops."

title: Judge Rules That Wolf, or Dog Is Religious Symbol for Tribe
description: A judge has ruled that an animal seized by the authorities in Swanton from its Abenaki Indian owners is a religious symbol and must be released.

title: 10 Urban Areas Join Lawsuit Challenging '90 Census Numbers
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York City said yesterday that San Francisco, Philadelphia and eight other cities and urban areas had joined a lawsuit challenging the 1990 census, which he said had undercounted the nation's urban population by "historic and disastrous proportions."

title: Academy's Tradition Goes on Trial
description: It has been more than a month since "break-out," the mud-and-glory ritual by which freshmen at the Virginia Military Institute achieve the school's version of manhood. Forced into a blinding mud bath, they wrestle upperclassmen until they can crawl, clamber and tug each other up two steep hills.

title: Home Video
description: The Old Movies

title: A Murdoch Paper Is Closed
description: The Australian arm of Rupert Murdoch's media empire said today that it would close one of its major newspapers just six months after merging the morning and evening dailies in Sydney and Melbourne.

title: Democrats Disconcerted by Senate Leader's Opposition to Gun Bill
description: Last week former President Ronald Reagan surprised the Republican Party with his endorsement of a bill requiring a waiting period for the purchase of handguns. This week, after the Senate Democratic leader expressed his opposition to the measure, it was the Democrats' turn.

title: Art Deco Facades, for Just a Little Fun
description: VISITORS to Miami Beach who are fond of the candy-colored Art Deco buildings that put the South Beach area on preservationists' maps can now take home miniatures.

title: Thomson and Bull Get $1.1 Billion From France
description: To bolster France's beleaguered electronics industry, the French Government announced today that it was injecting a total of $1.1 billion into two large state-owned companies: Bull, the computer manufacturer, and Thomson, the military and consumer electronics company.

title: Robert Veyron-Lacroix, Pianist, 68
description: Robert Veyron-Lacroix, a pianist and harpsichordist known for his collaboration with the flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 68 years old.

title: Umpires Negotiate
description: Negotiators for baseball's umpires and the American and the National Leagues met yesterday in New York yesterday for six hours and will resume their bargaining on a new contract in Philadelphia today amid the possibility of a strike or lockout for opening day.

title: Calendar: An Auction For Book Arts Center
description: Literary Theme Christie's New York, 502 Park Avenue (59th Street); (212) 460-9768.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking regulations will be suspended today for Orthodox Holy Thursday, tomorrow for Orthodox Good Friday and the seventh day of Passover, and Saturday for the eighth day of Passover.

title: For Nascimento, a Leap to Mass Popularity
description: His voice, an agonizingly pure tenor that often slips into an ethereal falsetto, has been described as that of an angel. But the Brazilian singer Milton Nascimento recognizes that "you can be the biggest genius on the planet, but you're going to end up singing in the shower" unless given an opportunity to make people aware of your talents.

title: The Pain Is Unremitting; So Is the Determination
description: In three weeks, Beth Barr will mark the second anniversary of an accident that almost cost her her right arm.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chevron U.K. Ltd., a unit of Chevron Corp., San Francisco, will sell its 50 percent stake in several British North Sea blocks to ARCO British Ltd., a unit of ARCO, Los Angeles. No terms were disclosed. * W. R. Grace & Co., New York, said its Agracetus Inc. unit had received a patent for genetically engineered cotton.

title: To Prepare Future Colin Powells for CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Kurdish Refugees, by Thousands, Flee Vengeance of the Iraqi Army
description: Thousands of Kurdish civilians were reported fleeing vengeance from the Iraqi Army today as their month-old revolt collapsed and a mass exodus began by truck, car, cart and mule along twisting roads from Kurdish cities to the mountains.

title: I.B.M. Rating Cut By Duff & Phelps
description: The Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company announced yesterday that it had downgraded the triple-A debt rating of the International Business Machine Corporation's senior notes and debentures and convertible subordinated debentures.

title: At 60, Santucci Sees Retirement As a Possibility
description: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens indicated yesterday that he might not remain in office long enough to see the conclusion of the controversial murder case he is prosecuting against five New York City police officers.

title: Coors to Distribute Nonalcoholic Beer
description: The Coors Brewing Company has entered the nonalcoholic beer market by acquiring North American distribution rights for Moussy, a low-calorie nonalcoholic beer made in Switzerland. Moussy has been marketed and distributed in North America by a unit of the Swiss company Sibra Holding S.A. It has sold Moussy in the United States since 1983.

title: White Sox Decide to Gamble on Bo Jackson
description: With questions about his health and athletic future still unanswered, Bo Jackson made a rapid return to baseball employment yesterday, signing a contract with the Chicago White Sox in which both sides will share the economic risk of the unknown.

title: The Danger Of 'Arena' Addiction
description: For marquee athletes, the most dangerous drug is not sold on street corners. For them, the most dangerous drug is what Sugar Ray Leonard has described as "that arena," alias that stage, alias that ego trip of triumph. Being deprived of "that arena" can trigger the search for substitutes, such as cocaine and alcohol, as the now-retired boxing champion has acknowledged doing for a few years after his surgery for a detached retina in 1982.

title: Navy Critic of Cheney's Plan Asks for an Early Retirement
description: The admiral responsible for the design and development of Navy ships and weapons has asked for early retirement after criticizing plans by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to overhaul the Pentagon's weapons-buying system.

title: Graham Greene, 86, Dies; Novelist of the Soul
description: Graham Greene, the British author whose novels of suspense and moral ambiguity plumbed the sordid politics of the modern world and the inner torments of mankind, died yesterday at La Providence Hospital in Vevey, near Lake Geneva in Switzerland. He was 86 years old.

title: Review/Dance; Hawkins's 'Intensities Of Space, And Wind'
description: "Intensities of Space, and Wind," a new dance work by Erick Hawkins, is a winner. Rarely has Mr. Hawkins's love of things Japanese and his admiration for an Asian sensibility come together so perfectly as in the premiere that the Erick Hawkins Dance Company presented on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street). The evening began on a solemn note with a tribute to Martha Graham, who died on Monday. In 1938, Mr. Hawkins became the first male dancer in the hitherto all-female Graham troupe. His collaboration with Miss Graham, to whom he was married in the 1940's and early 1950's, can still be sensed in the leading roles that he created.

title: Harold J. Treanor, Lawyer, 91
description: Harold J. Treanor, a lawyer who served as counsel to the Real Estate Board of New York for almost 50 years, died on Tuesday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Pelham, N.Y.

title: Boston Bank Is Supported
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation has raised the capital it needs to support a bid for the failed Bank of New England Corporation and is set to announce details of the infusion on Thursday, a person in the banking industry said today.

title: Save Libraries, and New York's Future
description: When Andrew Carnegie gave New York City the money for its branch library system, his intent was "to help those who will help themselves; to provide part of the means by which those who desire to improve may do so."

title: Dinkins Seeks Budget Delay Till State Acts
description: The Dinkins administration said yesterday that a delay in the adoption of a state budget was forcing it to seek a postponement in the submission of Mayor David N. Dinkins's own executive budget at a crucial moment in the city's fiscal struggles.

title: HOME VIDEO
description: This column, formerly published on alternate Sundays in the Arts and Leisure section, will now appear every Thursday in this space.

title: The Mantel Dismantled
description: HE said it was his way of coming to terms with "such heroic architecture figures as Mies and Gropius."

title: Bridge
description: The diagramed deal, played in the Regional Swiss Teams in Stamford, Conn., in October 1989, might well be called the mystery of the king of diamonds. Two players failed to solve that problem, which was surprising because they were teammates sitting in different directions at the table.

title: Tourists Will Now Get More Rubles to the Dollar
description: Officials have decided to compete with the country's flourishing black market by more than quadrupling the amount of rubles that tourists will receive. This exchange rate will now be about 27 to the dollar.

title: Car Exports Up In South Korea
description: South Korea's car exports increased to 69,127 units in the first three months of the year, up 10.9 percent from a year earlier because of a rise in exports to Europe, according to preliminary figures of the Korea Automobile Manufacturers' Association.

title: Possible Loss at Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation is telling its shareholders that it could face an additional loss of $500 million from the canceled A-12 aircraft program if it is unsuccessful in its legal challenge against the Government.

title: Miscellany
description: * Eugene B. Cofsky has left his position as president of the entertainment division of AC & R Advertising Inc. and established an entertainment and sports marketing consulting firm, Tedlor Entertainment Marketing, in Tarzana, Calif. The new firm offers creative services, media planning, licensing and merchandising and international marketing.

title: Home Video; New Video Releases
description: The Last Picture Show 1971. RCA/Columbia. $59.95. Laser disk, $34.95. 1 hour, 58 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: 'Taming of Shrew' Opera
description: "The Taming of the Shrew," a 1953 opera by the American composer Vittorio Giannini based on the Shakespeare comedy, is to be presented by the John Brownlee Opera Theater of the Manhattan School of Music at 8 P.M. on Wednesday and April 12 and at 2:30 P.M. on April 14. David Gilbert is to conduct. Tickets are $12 and $15; the proceeds are to benefit the school's voice scholarship fund. Information: (212) 749-2802.

title: A Hardy House Plant That Thrives on Just a Shrug
description: THERE is hope for those who are less than compulsive when it comes to caring for house plants. The answer is not a greenwork of plastic but a live species called bay or sweet bay (Laurus nobilis). This is the choice for busy people who want a house plant that is an unusual, handsome and versatile (not to mention a tasty) alternative to the ubiquitous weeping fig, which bay somewhat resembles. But best of all, bay tolerates an astonishing amount of abuse.

title: Trump Plaza Posts $10.6 Million Loss
description: Donald J. Trump said that his Trump Plaza casino lost $10.6 million last year and that the Atlantic City operation might have to seek bankruptcy protection if its debt could not be restructured. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, two Trump companies that operate the 555-room Trump Plaza said the 1990 loss compared with a $24.6 million profit in 1989. Trump Plaza Funding Inc. and Trump Plaza Associates also said their cash flow declined by 79.6 percent, or more than $29 million, last year from 1989.

title: Bush's Bay of Pigs
description: The enormity of the dishonor brought on the United States by President Bush's decision to betray the Kurdish people is beginning to sink in at the White House.

title: William Esbitt Is Dead; U.S. Attorney Aide, 80
description: William Esbitt, a lawyer, retired brigadier general in the Army Reserve and former assistant United States attorney, died on Monday at the J.F.K. Medical Center in Atlantis, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Atlantis.

title: Just a Game? Yes, but These Are Real Real
description: THE patient is lying before me, anesthetized, his head shaved. It's my first time in the O.R., and my hands are cold and sweaty.

title: Whalers Stem Tide To Cut Down Bruins
description: John Cullen scored one goal and set up two others as the Hartford Whalers snapped a seven-game streak without a victory with a 5-2 upset of the Boston Bruins tonight in the opening game of their Adams Division semifinal playoff series.

title: The Long Neglected Sister of the Singer Family
description: In Europe some years before World War I, a young woman on her way to marry a man she had never met and would never love shared a secret with her mother as their train rushed through the Polish countryside. She unwrapped a parcel and showed her mother pages and pages of stories, essays and fantasies she had written in secret. "Tear them up and throw them out the window," the mother commanded. The young woman obeyed.

title: JVC Jazz To Feature A Varied Lineup
description: Miles Davis, B. B. King and Ray Charles are to appear at the JVC Jazz Festival this year along with some unexpected performers, including Ornette Coleman, Tito Puente and Celia Cruz, George Wein, the head of Festival Productions, said yesterday. The festival, to run from June 21 to 29 at locations across New York City and in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., is in its 36th year.

title: Sharp Debate on Value Of an Alzheimer's Drug
description: A proposed treatment for Alzheimer's disease has renewed the debate over one of the thorniest questions in medicine: How effective must a drug be to win marketing approval when the disease is life-threatening and there are no other treatments?

title: Banks Say Stiff Credit Is Easing
description: The credit drought that some worry will cause the recession to drag on may not be over but there are signs that it is easing. "The risk that credit problems would prevent a recovery appear to have declined," William Brown, chief economist at J. P. Morgan & Company, said.

title: Market Place; Small-Stock Funds Post Strong Gains
description: AND the last shall be first.

title: Officer Stabbed in Arm Subduing Disturbed Man
description: A police officer was stabbed last night as he and five other officers subdued an emotionally disturbed man who had barricaded himself inside his Queens apartment, the police said.

title: Molecular 'Hot Spot' Hints At a Cause of Liver Cancer
description: Scientists have detected a molecular "hot spot" that is strongly linked to liver cancer, one of the commonest and most lethal malignancies in the world. The spot is a tiny region of a single gene where toxins that infiltrate the liver seem to home in, sabotaging the gene and touching off cancerous growth.

title: Chronicle
description: JANE FONDA has closed the aerobics studio where she began her fitness career. She plans to concentrate on the tapes and books that have made her even richer and more famous, her fitness organization says.

title: 2 Months After Ousting Despot, Somalia Faces Life as an Abandoned Pawn
description: Amid the debris of its civil war, Somalia is struggling to start anew.

title: Nanne Steps Down
description: Lou Nanne, the senior vice president of the Minnesota North Stars, said yesterday that he was leaving the club after 23 years as an administrator and player to become vice president of an investment firm, Piper, Jaffray and Hopwood.

title: Bringing Wayward Furniture Doors to Heel
description: When doors in old furniture do not move smoothly or will not close tightly, there are various ways to pinpoint and then correct the problem in the home workshop.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON THE PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE-LEGAL SUCOMMITTEE -- 10:30 A.M.

title: Inquiry Turns to Engineer In Amtrak Crash in Boston
description: Federal investigators believe an engineer's error rather than mechanical failure caused a train collision in Boston last year that injured 267 people.

title: Money Market Fund Yields Mixed for 5th Straight Week
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the fifth consecutive week, ending yesterday.

title: Decision Not to Help Iraqi Rebels Puts U.S. in an Awkward Position
description: Having decided not to intervene further in Iraq, the Bush Administration found itself today in the awkward position at the United Nations of seeming reluctant to back appeals for strong action to halt the repression of the Kurds.

title: Poland's Plans to Use Debt Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Prime Rate Cut
description: Canada's big commercial banks have cut their prime lending rates by a quarter-point. The Bank of Montreal dropped its prime to 10 3/4 percent from 11 percent Tuesday, and all other major banks followed. The prime is the key rate used to set rates on many consumer loans. Canada's prime has fallen steadily since it topped 14 percent last May.

title: Maradona Quitting?
description: Diego Maradona, facing up to two years of banishment after testing positive for cocaine use, has been quoted in an Italian newspaper as saying that he will not play professional soccer again.

title: Knights' Executive Relishes a Challenge
description: Risks? What risks? Mention risks to Reggie Williams, the general manager of the New York-New Jersey Knights of the new World League of American Football, and he cringes. Williams prefers challenges.

title: Selleck No Hit at Bat In Cameo Appearance
description: Cincinnati's Tim Layana struck out the actor Tom Selleck to end the Detroit eighth inning last night in an exhibition game in Lakeland, Fla.

title: Baker Aide Talks With Iraqi Dissidents in U.S.
description: As a senior State Department official met with Iraqi dissident intellectuals in a symbolic show of sympathy, Kurdish campaigners today expressed sharp criticism of President Bush's refusal to commit military aid to the uprisings opposing President Saddam Hussein.

title: Books of The Times; Cultivating a Garden, Cultivating a Mind
description: Second Nature By Michael Pollan 258 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press . $21.95.

title: Japan to Ease Insurers' Bar
description: Japan is moving to let life and non-life insurers enter each other's core businesses as part of its program of financial deregulation, Ministry of Finance officials said today.

title: In Flake's District, Reaction Isn't Simply by Race
description: Shortly before noon yesterday, as about 100 people prepared to eat lunch at a senior citizens' center in Jamaica, Queens, Henry J. Smith, a volunteer worker, made an announcement.

title: Review/Theater; Penn and Teller Offer Several Variations On a Magic Theme
description: A chandelier drops to the stage in "Phantom of the Opera." A helicopter lands in "Miss Saigon." And in "Penn and Teller: The Refrigerator Tour," a refrigerator crashes down on the show's two stars. Where the Broadway competition delays a big theatrical moment in order to increase anticipation, Penn and Teller brazenly use it to begin their show. Should something go awry, it would of course end the show. Fearful theatergoers need not worry about the squashing of Penn and Teller. They survive the refrigerator, laugh at the audience's gasp and move into two hours of iconoclastic assault on the temple of magic.

title: Paper Raising Prices
description: The St. Louis Post-Dispatch said today that it would raise newsstand and vending machine prices for its daily and Sunday newspapers because of rising costs and declining advertising revenue. On April 15, prices will increase by 25 cents, to 50 cents for the daily paper and $1.25 for the Sunday paper. Rates for subscriptions will not change.

title: GE Capital Interested In Goldome
description: The GE Capital Corporation said yesterday that it was interested in buying a "significant portion" of Goldome, a savings bank based in Buffalo that is operating at a profit but is looking for investors to provide additional capital, which it needs to remain in business.

title: U.N. VOTES STERN CONDITIONS FOR FORMALLY ENDING WAR; IRAQI RESPONSE IS UNCERTAIN
description: The United Nations Security Council overwhelmingly approved a resolution today that offers to end the gulf war and progressively lift most sanctions against Iraq if President Saddam Hussein accepts a series of tough military and financial conditions.

title: Flow of Soviet Jews Into Israel Surges Again
description: Immigration of Jews from the Soviet Union last month reached a total of almost 15,000 and will climb to 25,000 this month, according to the head of the agency that organizes immigrants' preparation and transport.

title: W.L.A.F. Is Getting Off to a Promising Start Overseas
description: Mike Lynn, president of the fledgling World League of American Football, took National Football League teams on tour for summer exhibitions in London in 1983 and in Sweden in 1989 while he was general manager of the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Washington Talk; Japan, the Trade Gap And America's 2 Minds
description: As consumers, Americans are happy enough to buy cars, television sets, videocassette recorders and all kinds of other things from Japan. As producers, they live in constant fear of the threat to themselves that their own appetites present. And after a decade in which Americans bought $350 billion more from Japan than Japan bought from them, these conflicting impulses are fully reflected in seemingly contradictory Administration policies.

title: 100 Years of Architectural Diversity
description: Columbia University is celebrating the centennial of the Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library with a new show, "Contemporary Architectural Drawings: Donations to the Avery Library Centennial Drawings Archive," which opened yesterday. More than 300 drawings were donated by 120 architects and designers, including Richard Meier, Cesar Pelli and Michael Graves; 149 are being exhibited.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Moscow Journal; In Gorbachev, Nixon Detects a Fellow Scrapper
description: To Richard M. Nixon, Mikhail S. Gorbachev is a survivor, a man who fought hard to get where he is, who will not walk off without a fight.

title: Life as a Cabaret of Kander and Ebb Show Tunes
description: For the director Scott Ellis and the choreographer Susan Stroman, life these days is a cabaret. Or, to put it another way, their new revue, "And the World Goes 'Round: The Songs of Kander and Ebb," has become very much a part of New York, New York.

title: Profits Mixed In 4th Quarter
description: Profits earned by United States retailers rose in the fourth quarter of 1990, but profits for manufacturers fell compared with the fourth quarter of 1989, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: People
description: * Rudi Golyn has been named co-creative director, a new position, in the San Francisco office of J. Walter Thompson. * James David Linne, Jonathan Edward Moore and William V. Weston have been named vice presidents of Leo Burnett Co., Chicago.

title: French Auto Sales Off
description: The French Car Makers Committee said today that sales of new cars in France dropped 18.5 percent in March, to 181,260 vehicles, from 222,418 in March 1990. Sales in February had fallen by 18.8 percent from a year earlier. For the first quarter of 1991, new-car sales fell 20.6 percent, to 514,520 units, from 648,214 in the firt quarter of 1990. Sales of foreign cars fell 13.2 percent in March to 74,280 units, against 85,589 in March 1990. But their share of the French market increased slightly, to 41 percent, from 40.9 percent in February, the committee said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * International Movie Group Inc., Los Angeles, has privately placed $6.9 million in 12 percent subordinated convertible ebentures due 1998. The debentures are convertible into common stock at $1.50 a share. * Nassau County, L.I., is tentatively offering $47.2 million in tax-exempt general-obligation sewer refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 6.90 percent for an issue due 2011 through underwriters led by Chemical Securities. Shorter maturity yields range from 4.75 percent in 1992 to 6.85 percent in 2010. The issue is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp. and rated triple-A by Moody's and S.&P.

title: Brady Bill Will Help Illegal Gun Runners
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: RESTYLING a kitchen doesn't have to mean replacing the cabinets. Striking results can be achieved simply by resurfacing them with wood veneer.

title: Hollis Journal; Just a Waist-High Game But, Boy a Big Match
description: On the bus from Brooklyn, his stocking cap yanked down to his eyebrows, Omar Edwards stared out the window as though deeply focused on the competition to come -- his left forefinger inserted in his ear, his right thumb in his mouth.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: LOSING a job tests the mettle of a family. The emotional effects, felt by children and spouse alike, can be as severe as the economic problems that result.

title: Chronicle
description: OLGA KORBUT underwent tests yesterday at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle to determine whether she has suffered radiation exposure. The former gymnastics champion, 36, her husband, LEONID BORTKEVICH, 41, and their son, RICHARD BORTKEVICH, 12, were living in Minsk in the Soviet Union when the Chernobyl nuclear reactor exploded 180 miles away five years ago.

title: Chronicle
description: London's music world whirls briskly: ANDRE PREVIN quit yesterday as principal conductor of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, and the rival London Symphony Orchestra announced his appointment as its conductor laureate. He is to leave the Philharmonic in July 1992 and take on his new job in October 1992.

title: Soviet TV Viewers Want Public Affairs
description: To the Editor:

title: Events: Green Thumbs And Walks Into History
description: Basic Botany Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433.

title: Perez Could Pitch by May
description: Pascual Perez's ailing right shoulder passed a significant test today when the Yankee pitcher threw 10 minutes of batting practice. Perez then said he might be ready to join the team earlier than expected.

title: Gilded Wastebaskets
description: PEOPLE kick them, throw things at them and fill them with whatever they don't want. But Wendy Weaver, director of Portmerion Ltd., an East Side antiques and interior shop, thinks the wastebasket should be functional and attractive.

title: Penny Stock Indictments
description: Three New York penny stock traders were among 22 individuals and firms indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of securities fraud and conspiracy.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 12 about the burial of Maj. Marie T. Rossi, a helicopter pilot in the Persian Gulf war, referred incorrectly to her husband. He is Chief Warrant Officer John A. Cayton.

title: A Bedtime Story That's Different
description: IT started out like a typical morning in a suburban Long Island home. A woman was in the kitchen making breakfast when above the roar of the coffee grinder she heard a familiar low-pitched "good morning." It was her son, a junior in high school.

title: Yanks View Trims and Additions
description: In the final days of spring training, as the Yankees search for ways to trim players from their roster, they are also looking to add players to it.

title: U.S. Dismisses Charges Faced By Rep. Flake
description: At the request of prosecutors, all criminal charges against the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, a United States Representative from Queens, and his wife, Margarett, were dismissed yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "In the American vernacular, Gorbachev is Wall Street, Yeltsin is Main Street. Gorbachev is Georgetown drawing room, Yeltsin is Newark factory gate." -- Richard M. Nixon. [ A4:3. ]

title: Personal Health
description: Before jogging and walking gave it a run for the money, swimming was America's favorite form of exercise. Now exercising in the water is making a strong comeback, even for people who cannot swim.

title: Brazil-I.M.F. Talks Stalled
description: Brazil will probably not seek a new debt accord with the International Monetary Fund soon because of uncertainty over the economy and the country's big debt to commercial banks, its Economy Minister said today.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misstated a projection by two economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the annual loss in national output if the low savings rate of the 1980's persists through the 1990's. It is $750 billion, not $750 million.

title: Rape Investigation Continues at Kennedy Estate
description: It might be "days or even weeks" before the police here conclude their investigation into a reported rape at the Kennedy family compound over Easter weekend, Chief Joseph L. Terlizzese of the Palm Beach Police Department said today.

title: Metro Matters; Borough Chiefs See Their Sliver Of Pie Crumbling
description: The name Five Percenters recalls a 1960's revolutionary black organization that regarded itself as the best hope for its constituents. Now the name is being associated with a decidedly less radical, though equally self-absorbed, group: New York City's five borough presidents.

title: Shearson Lehman
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. yesterday priced $150 million in notes due April 1, 1996, through its Lehman Brothers Inc. unit. The noncallable notes have a 9 3/4 percent coupon and are priced at 99.875, to yield 9.781, or about 208 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: Judge Rules California Officers Beat Inmate
description: Three former Orange County sheriff's deputies have been convicted of beating a jail inmate while they were off duty.

title: State Dept. Led Our Pre-Aug. 2 Iraq Tilt
description: To the Editor:

title: Florio Backs Blue Cross On Cost Shift
description: The Florio administration today supported a plan to have commercial health-insurance companies and New Jersey Blue Cross group policyholders pay a larger share of hospital costs to hold down premium increases for 500,000 individual Blue Cross subscribers.

title: Securities Regulator Joining First Investors
description: One of the nation's best-known securities regulators has decided to join a securities firm that has been under fire in some states for what are described as fraudulent sales practices.

title: Media General Sells Cliggott
description: Media General Inc. said today that it had sold the Cliggott Publishing Company of Greenwich, Conn., to Cliggott's management.

title: A Bitter Split For Albania; Emotions Stirred Up By Divisive Election
description: By most accounts, Albania's national elections on Sunday, the first multi-party voting in 68 years, went smoothly. But it has since become clear that they left this Communist-ruled country bitterly divided.

title: NBC Wins Approval of FNN Deal
description: NBC moved a big step closer yesterday toward acquiring the Financial News Network, the ailing cable channel, after a series of maneuvers in Federal bankruptcy court.

title: Exorcism, Filmed With Priest's Consent, to Be Shown on TV
description: With the consent of a priest of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, a camera crew has filmed an exorcism performed on a 16-year-old girl and is to broadcast it on network television tomorrow night.

title: For Refugees in Iraq, Where Is Hope?
description: In a ramshackle trailer just down the road from the cease-fire line in southern Iraq, Awath Sharif sat on a dusty green-and-white carpet surrounded by flies.

title: Back From Bench, Nicholls Gives Rangers a Spark
description: Bernie Nicholls returned from a one-game benching to do what he does best: He attacked in the offensive zone, he scored a goal and he came close a half-dozen other times.

title: Bernard Fensterwald, 69, Lawyer For James Ray and Watergate Spy
description: Bernard Fensterwald Jr., a former Government lawyer who later defended James Earl Ray and James W. McCord Jr., a Watergate burglar, died Tuesday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 69 years old.

title: A Thorny Question For Alzheimer's Drug
description: A treatment for Alzheimer's disease, an ailment that causes loss of memory and reasoning, has set off a debate over how effective a drug must be to enter the marketplace.

title: For Children
description: Junior Ranger Naturalist Program Various New York City parks Recommended ages: 8 to 13 (212) 360-2774

title: THE WORLD: Iraq; For the Kurds, Rumors of More War
description: The Kurds in northern Iraq, emerging from one of the severest winters in decades, must once again face the specter of renewed Iraqi hostilities along their 120-mile front line.

title: The Arabs Find A World in Which They Count Less
description: As they try to define their new relationship with the United States and the rest of the triumphant West, the Arabs are reaching the conclusion that they do not matter as much as they thought they did.

title: Wake Up From Your 80's Slumber, America; Not Reagan's Heir
description: To the Editor:

title: Geologists See Huge Quake Risk in the Northwest
description: Geologists have discovered striking evidence that the Pacific Northwest, long viewed as relatively safe from earthquakes, is a seismic danger zone that could produce one of the strongest earthquakes ever.

title: Blackhawks Stunned By Stars in Overtime
description: Brian Propp scored on a power play 4 minutes 14 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Minnesota North Stars a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Blackhawks in the first game of their Norris Division semifinal series.

title: New Jobless Claims at 8-Year High
description: The number of Americans applying for unemployment insurance jumped in late March to 543,000, the highest level since January 1983, the Labor Department said yesterday. The report suggested that the economy was still mired in recession.

title: In Bubba Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Autographs Could Be Expensive
description: Picture this: One of America's greatest heroes, let's call him Jose Canseco, is sitting at a table signing his name for $10 a pop, or whatever his signature gets these days.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, named Raymond C. Egan executive vice president of its pharmaceuticals and nutritional group, and Kenneth E. Weg president of its pharmaceuticals group. * Kraft USA, Glenview, Ill., a unit of Kraft General Foods, named Mary Kay Haben vice president and general manager of Churny Co., a specialty cheese manufacturer.

title: Treasuries Up on Economic Data
description: An unexpected rise in initial unemployment claims, an increase analysts say virtually assures that March employment data expected to be released today will be weak, pushed up prices of Treasury securities yesterday.

title: The Spoken Word
description: STORYTELLING AND EXHIBITION, La Mama, 6 East First Street, Manhattan. Tribute to the tree, with paintings by Elisa Decker and storytelling by Marcia Lane, Sunday at 3 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 505-2476.

title: Restaurants
description: Raoul's

title: WPP Receives Bank Approval
description: Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of the WPP Group, has persuaded a 30-member syndicate of banks to approve a plan to reorganize the giant communications and advertising company's $800 million in debt.

title: Dow Off 2.23 Points at Closing, to 2,924.50
description: Blue-chip stocks lost ground yesterday, but smaller stocks picked up speed as Wall Street weighed the evidence pointing to a further drop in interest rates -- the kind of news that should give the market a shot in the arm.

title:
Projects on Staten Island;
Town Houses Feature a Patch of Green
description: Though residential construction has drastically slowed in much of the Northeast, three Staten Island builders are moving forward on a 200-unit town house complex in the Rossville section on the South Shore. They think that superior architecture, reasonable prices and a patch of green that people can call their own will attract buyers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Restaurants Corp., Ventura, Calif., a restaurant chain, said it would sell its Wendy's division, consisting of 11 Wendy's restaurants in Southern California, for $6.5 million. * Atherton Technology, Sunnyvale, Calif., a developer of computer-assisted software, said it had completed negotiations giving Thomson CSF, Paris, a maker of military electronic systems, a majority stake. Terms were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Auditing 4 Colleges For Expenses in Grants
description: In the wake of an investigation into Stanford University's use of Federal research grants for luxury items, a Federal agency has undertaken an audit of four leading universities and said it could expand the inquiry to include as many as 22 colleges.

title: Backer Spielvogel Wins New Zealand Account
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide Inc. said yesterday that it had won the $15 million European marketing communications account for the New Zealand Kiwifruit Marketing Board.

title: Barbara A. Bannon; Editor, 67
description: Barbara A. Bannon, a retired executive editor of Publishers Weekly, died last Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital from injuries in a fall the day before. She was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Kennedy's Nephew Is Identified as Rape Suspect
description: A police captain today identified William Kennedy Smith, a 30-year-old nephew of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, as the suspect in the reported rape of a young woman at the Kennedy family compound.

title: Safety Note
description: The New York City Fire Department recommends that smoke alarm batteries be changed twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight time. The date this spring is Sunday.

title: Wake Up From Your 80's Slumber, America; G.O.P. Redistribution
description: To the Editor:

title: Did Race Inspire The Flake Case? Maybe, He Says
description: A day after the prosecution ended his embezzlement and tax-evasion trial, Floyd H. Flake, the Queens Congressman and minister, said there could have been a racial motive in his prosecution.

title: PNC Executive Pay Cut
description: Top executives at the PNC Financial Corporation, the nation's 14th-largest banking company, received pay cuts of as much as one-third in 1990 as the company suffered its worst performance in its eight-year history. The figures were contained in PNC's 1991 proxy statements to shareholders. The chairman, Thomas H. O'Brien, saw his total pay fall to $740,834 last year from $1,090,072 the year before. The vice chairman, Daniel C. Ulmer, had a pay reduction of 31 percent, to $325,000. PNC's net income plunged 81 percent, to $70.9 million, in 1990.

title: The Allies' New Duty: Refugees
description: The figures shock the heart. A ragged tide of a million or more is fleeing Iraq, most heading to Iran, many to Turkey. Politicians and pundits argue bitterly over who is to blame. But everyone can agree that responsibility for aiding these poignant victims rests squarely on President Bush and America's coalition partners.

title: Ho (Clang) Hum
description: It appears that John Gotti won't have New York to kick around any more. Mr. Gotti, who wore $1,800 suits and a chilling smile as he headed the most powerful organized-crime family in the nation, is headed for prison. He was convicted last week of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy and a host of separate criminal acts from murder on down. Convicted with him of many of the same charges was his underboss, Frank Locascio, and both face life in jail when they are sentenced on June 23. Not joining them will be Salvatore (Sammy the Bull) Gravano, who was Mr. Gotti's No. 2 man before he became No. 1 prosecution witness in this, Mr. Gotti's fourth trial. Mr. Gotti will certainly appeal, but prosecutors don't expect to see him free soon, if ever. What does this mean to the average citizen? "The mob as we know it is on its way out," said a top regional Federal investigator. But the head of a state crime panel said, "Gotti's conviction won't create a ripple in New York organized crime."

title: Gene Finding Reveals a Secret of Smell
description: Humans and other mammals detect an exquisitely complex bouquet of smells by using at least a thousand different genes that are active exclusively in nose cells, scientists have found.

title: Rethinking the Law That Gives Golden Eggs After the Goose Is Dead
description: Never have corporate deadbeats been treated so charitably as during the last decade, an era not otherwise known for indulging the downtrodden and the impoverished. Under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978, derelict managers have kept their jobs while the courts helped them renege on promises to banks, bondholders, employees, retirees, suppliers, government agencies -- almost everyone but the lawyers, accountants and financiers who had the sense to specialize in the art of going bust.

title: Mallette Follows Collision Course
description: If Troy Mallette of the Rangers competed in an individual sport like boxing or swimming, fans would quickly recognize him as a sight to behold.

title:
DECONSTRUCTING JERRY BROWN;
He's a New Age Demagogue
description: This is a season of self-proclaimed saviors and strongmen. H. Ross Perot, the self-made-man as putative national boss, is merely the latest entry.
