But the most successful in this wave of false messiahs, from David Duke to John Silber to Patrick Buchanan -- and perhaps the prototype for the future -- is Edmund G. Brown Jr. His rise, like those of the others, has been stirred by the undercurrents of economic decline and political paralysis. But he is novel: the new class populist demogogue, a Huey Long for the post-modern age.

title: If the G.N.P. Counted Housework, Would Women Count for More?
description: Homemakers often feel their work is taken for granted, and advocates in the women's movement argue that the statistical invisibility of what used to be called women's work has policy implications that undermine a wide range of family issues. And so, there is an international movement to add housework to the gross national product as a way of elevating the work's status and, by extension, that of women.

title: Cutbacks at Newspaper
description: The Worcester Telegram and Gazette is requiring all full-time employees to take a five-day unpaid furlough before Aug. 1. In addition, performance and holiday bonuses for all managers and supervisors will be eliminated or reduced. The daily newspaper has roughly 550 full-time employees. The paper said the measures were necessary because of a "soft financial situation" and to avoid layoffs.

title: Be Prepared for Free Agency, Agent Suggests to Mets' Viola
description: The agent for Frank Viola said today that negotiations with the Mets on a contract extension for the standout left-hander were all but hopelessly stalemated. He said he had counseled his client to be prepared to file for free agency at the end of the season.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Delta Natural Gas Co., Winchester, Ky., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $10 million in debentures due in 2011 through Edward D. Jones & Co. * Florida Power and Light, West Palm Beach, Fla., has privately placed $125 million in debentures that are secured by nuclear fuel leases. The debt is divided into five parts: 8.3 percent debentures due in 1994, 8.06 percent debentures due in 1993, 8.55 percent debentures due in 1995, 9.06 percent notes due in 1998 and 8.8 percent notes due in 1996.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Alternate-side parking regulations will be suspended today for Orthodox Good Friday and the seventh day of Passover, and tomorrow for the eighth day of Passover.

title: 13 Postal Workers Charged In Drug Sales in Minneapolis
description: Thirteen mail clerks and mail handlers at the city's main post office have been arrested and charged with distributing narcotics, the United States Attorney's office said today.

title: Japan Endorses Motorola Standard
description: A mobile telephone system developed by Motorola Inc. has been endorsed by Japan. A Government agency selected Motorola's digital mobile phone system over systems developed by six Japanese companies.

title: Wake Up From Your 80's Slumber, America
description: To the Editor:

title: A Garden Idyll, Before Spring Gets Too Pushy
description: "SPRING scares me," confides a friend. "Everything pulsating. All the longer daylight means to me is that I have to lower the window shades earlier to watch TV." Many urban souls thrive on winter depression, enjoying the flu as an excuse to cuddle under covers, popping cough drops and videocassettes. One recent afternoon, several city friends refused to accompany me to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, saying they didn't care to "see everything in bloom, looking, you know, so hyper-real and computer-enhanced."

title: Turkey's New Role At a Crossroads of Tensions
description: For more than four decades, Turkey was the West's easternmost bulwark against Soviet Communism, and that was enough to define its place in the world. Now all bets seem to be off. In place of its secure and valued niche in the old world order, Turkey is confronted with the new world order's explosive mix of ethnicity and war, faith and violence.

title: Will More Guns for the Generals Aid or Threaten Democracy?
description: AT first everyone fell into a hush, and then they gawked as the black, sharp-angled F-117 Stealth fighter built in the United States streaked over a desert airstrip on the outskirts of Santiago like a strange Andean bird. It was the kickoff last month of Chile's 1992 International Air and Space Show, the pride of the Chilean military.

title: Space Shuttle Crew Is Set for Launching, Weather Permitting
description: A space shuttle mission to place an astronomy satellite in orbit and conduct the first American space walk in six years is set for launching Friday morning.

title: Salvadorans and Rebels Open Talks to End Their Civil War
description: The Salvadoran Government and rebel guerrilla commanders began detailed new talks here today, in what both sides have described as a potentially decisive round of negotiations to end El Salvador's 11-year civil war.

title: Race and Juries: Burden Could Shift to Defense
description: Earlier this week the United States Supreme Court again took aim at the ability of prosecutors to eliminate potential jurors on the basis of race or sex alone. Now, legal experts predict that the Court may turn its attention to the jury selection practices of defense lawyers.

title: Lucy J. F. Buhler, 73, An Investment Broker
description: Lucy Jane Ford Buhler, former president of the Women's Investment League, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 73 years old.

title: Reed's Wrist Is Fractured
description: For Darren Reed, the week that began with what was considered a big break ended with an ugly fracture today.

title: Review/Film; 'Poison,' Three Stories Inspired by Jean Genet
description: "Who is Richie Beacon and where is he now?" asks the narrator of the mock-documentary titled "Hero," one of the three stories that make up Todd Haynes's "Poison," opening today at the Angelika Film Center.

title: Bush and Japanese Call End to 'Bashing'
description: Trying to ease tensions arising from American criticism of Japan's role in the Persian Gulf war, President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu agreed today that the image problem could best be resolved by focusing on the fundamental alliance between the two nations.

title: TURKEY IS KEEPING FRONTIERS CLOSED
description: Despite growing international and domestic pressure to let in a flood of Kurdish refugees from northern Iraq, Turkey insisted today that it did not have the resources to deal with a mass migration and would keep its borders closed.

title: At the Movies
description: Next for Whoopi Goldberg

title: George Meltzer; Architect, 69
description: George Meltzer, an architect and professor of architecture at New York Institute of Technology, died on Tuesday at his home in East Norwich, L.I. He was 69 years old.

title: Key Rates
Sale by Banc One Of Preferred Stock
description: Several companies took advantage of the drop in Treasury bond yields to price new securities yesterday, after a larger-than-expected rise in the weekly unemployment claims data. But other issuers are expected to wait until today's employment news to see whether interest rates may be pushed even lower.

title: Haiti's Government Arrests Ex-President In Coup That Failed
description: The Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide arrested his predecessor today on charges of complicity in an unsuccessful military coup in January.

title: Capriati Is Learning Hard Lesson
description: So far, her sophomore year has not been a halcyon year, and 15-year-old Jennifer Capriati is learning more than she wants to know about the school of hard knocks.

title: Wake Up From Your 80's Slumber, America
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Says One Million Iraqi Kurds Are on Its Border and May Be Admitted
description: The official Iranian press agency said today that more than a million Iraqi Kurdish refugees had massed on the Iranian border, hoping to cross. It added that they might all be permitted to enter the country.

title: Japanese Improve Share as U.S. Car Sales Decline
description: Against a backdrop of sluggish sales in March, Japanese auto makers improved their share of the American automotive market at the expense of the Big Three domestic auto makers.

title: GTE to Lay Off 500 Employees
description: The GTE Corporation is laying off about 500 engineering, administrative and technical employees at three Massachusetts operations involved in military contracting. The layoffs, effective April 12, affect about 8 percent of the workers at operations of the GTE Government Systems unit in Needham, Taunton and Westboro.

title: Reviews/Art; David Salle Enters a Rococo Phase
description: The 1980's may be over, but David Salle, an artist indelibly identified with the decade, is not letting up. His exhibition of new work at his new venue, the Gagosian Gallery, is one of his best. The strength of this show should give pause to those who are busy writing off the 80's as a period of meager artistic achievement.

title: On Not Hiding From the Balloonman
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art; Of People Without Power
description: SEBASTIAO SALGADO photographs people outside power. He spent months in the Sahel region of Africa taking pictures of victims and survivors of drought and famine. He spent parts of seven years traveling through Latin America taking pictures of rural lives that seem untouched by the revolution in communications. In 1986, he began documenting the kind of pitiless manual labor, sometimes reassuring in its commitment and skill, sometimes frightening in its blind intensity, that he believes is becoming obsolete.

title: David Kay; Executive, 86
description: David Kay, a retired pharmaceutical industry executive, died on Wednesday at his home in Pompano, Fla. He was 86 years old.

title: Young & Rubicam Unit In a Soviet Campaign
description: Young & Rubicam/Sovero, a two-year-old Soviet venture of Young & Rubicam Inc., has been selected to develop and execute a direct mail and public relations campaign in the Soviet Union for Curtis Instruments of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Big Cuts Expected For CBS
description: CBS is expected to announce today that it will cut its work force by 300 to 400 employees, as well as report a first-quarter loss estimated at $17 million.

title: Wake Up From Your 80's Slumber, America; Not Reagan's Heir
description: To the Editor:

title: Managers Backed At Campbell Soup
description: A leading member of the Dorrance family, the controlling shareholders of the Campbell Soup Company, has broken ranks with family members who want to sell the company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Diana Strawbridge Norris, who holds about 4 million shares, or approximately 3 percent of those outstanding, said she would support current management headed by David Johnson, who was brought in last January from Gerber Foods to revive the company.

title: Chairman Is Named For Blackstone Unit
description: The Blackstone Group announced yesterday that Sheldon S. Gordon, chief executive of the Stamford Capital Group, was joining the firm as a general partner and the chairman of the newly created Blackstone Europe unit.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The lasting fame of MARTHA GRAHAM will be further assured by JACQUELINE KENNEDY ONASSIS, who has been working with Miss Graham on her autobiography since 1987. The completed manuscript was delivered to Mrs. Onassis at Doubleday in January just after Miss Graham, who died on Monday, became ill with pneumonia, a Doubleday spokeswoman said.

title: In Bubba Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Trenton at Work; Senator Seizes Chance to Revise Image
description: The stream of supplicants and nervous politicians never seems to stop flowing through the offices of John A. Lynch, the second most powerful politician in New Jersey and the man who recently managed to reshape this capital's political agenda.

title: Tigers, Anderson Agree
description: Sparky Anderson has agreed to a method for remaining with the Detroit Tigers indefinitely under a series of one-year contracts, The Lakeland (Fla.) Ledger reported yesterday.

title: Herr Looking to Sharpen Focus
description: He has "wandered mentally" in the field and all but sleepwalked on the basepaths. His torturous trots to his position force one to wonder if his knee surgery wasn't last week instead of last decade. He has made lifting the bat off his shoulder seem as much a victory as lifting a base hit into the outfield. Veteran's Approach

title: John Mullen; Baseball Executive, 66
description: John Mullen, vice president and assistant general manager of the Atlanta Braves, was found dead in his hotel room on Wednesday. He was 66 years old.

title: Large Union Donation
description: The National Football League Players Association, which has ceased representing players in collective bargaining and no longer collects dues, is contributing $500,000 to a fund to assist retired players who face catastrophic illnesses or other personal crises.

title: Calumet Shake-Up
description: Calumet Farm, struggling financially as it attempts to regain its eminence as the most successful racing farm in America, announced a changing of the guard yesterday: J. T. Lundy, president since 1982, resigned and will be succeeded by John T. Ward Jr., a horse trainer, owner of the Sugar Grove Farm and onetime member of the Kentucky State Racing Commission.

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review last Friday about the "21" Club misstated the restaurant's summer lunch schedule. From Memorial Day to Labor Day, lunch is served Monday through Friday only.

title: Bonilla, Bonds to Yanks? Only for Ruth and Gehrig
description: The deal might look enticing, but it isn't going to take place. Despite the rumors, Barry Bonds and Bobby Bonilla are not coming to the Bronx.

title: Slaying Bid Recalled At Trial of Teacher
description: A New Jersey trucker testified today at the Carolyn Warmus murder trial that an investigator asked him to commit a murder in the summer of 1988.

title: Homeless Mentally Ill Need Housing, Not More Case Managers; Obstacle Course
description: To the Editor:

title: Training for Olympics Forced Evans's Move
description: Janet Evans, the world's best female distance swimmer, had several reasons for giving up college competition, sources said today: prospects of limited training for next year's Olympics, personality conflicts with her coach and unhappiness with her progress.

title: Los Angeles Police Chief Removed For 60 Days in Inquiry on Beating
description: A month after a group of white Los Angeles police officers severely beat a black motorist, the city's Chief of Police, Daryl F. Gates, was temporarily relieved of his command today. Mr. Gates immediately said he would fight the suspension in court.

title: Gap Between Rich And Poor Widens
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Shopping Settles Lawsuits
description: Home Shopping Network Inc., a shop-by-television channel, said it would pay about $33 million to settle class action suits by bondholders and shareholders. It also said it had raised income tax reserves to about $15 million to reflect a notice of deficiency from the Internal Revenue Service received after the release of second-quarter earnings.

title: He Listens to People
description: In their musings on the "enigma" of Edmund G. Brown Jr., the media overlook the unusual ecology of his campaign. As a result of his reliance on tiny contributions, collected via an 800 number, he is first major candidate to live off the land.

title: Pinchas Zukerman
description: Pinchas Zukerman is to conduct the English Chamber Orchestra in Dvorak's Serenade for Strings (Op. 22) and Mozart's Symphony No. 4 (K. 500) at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. Mr. Zukerman is also to be the viola soloist in Hindemith's "Trauermusik" and the violin soloist in the Beethoven Romances in F (Op. 40) and G (Op. 50). Tickets are $13 to $25. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Our Towns; After 2 Deaths, Now a School Grieves for Itself
description: News of a school closing affects different people in different ways. At Sunquam Elementary School, one second grader took all the Sunquam literature out of her mother's wastebasket and put it up in her bedroom. "If I hang it all up," she told her mother, "they won't close Sunquam."

title: Reynolds Turned Down
description: A request by sprinter Butch Reynolds for a court order to allow him to run in races while he challenges a two-year suspension for alleged steroid use was turned down yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Cincinnati.

title: Reviews/Film; Schoolboys Conspire To Help Bury Mother
description: At first, the French schoolchildren of Jacques Fansten's "Cross My Heart" appear shockingly blase. What they are involved in, after all, is the surreptitious burial of an adult, the mother of Martin (Sylvain Copans), who is fatherless and thus fears being sent to an orphanage if his mother's death (of natural causes) is discovered. When Martin's classmates learn his secret, they join forces to protect him from the adult world.

title: Big Bond Insurer Planning To Sell 11.5 Million Shares
description: MBIA Inc., which through its MBIA Corporation unit is one of the leading insurers of municipal bonds, said yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a secondary offering of 11.5 million common shares through underwriters led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: Miles F. McDonald, 85, Ex-Judge And Brooklyn District Attorney
description: Miles F. McDonald, whose investigation into police corruption as Brooklyn District Attorney led to Mayor William O'Dwyer's resignation, died on Wednesday at Jupiter Hospital in Tequesta, Fla. He was 85 years old and lived in Tequesta.

title: Senator Heinz and 6 Others Killed In Midair Crash Near Philadelphia
description: Senator John Heinz and six other people died today when his chartered plane collided in the air with a helicopter inspecting the plane's landing gear.

title: Limits of Therapy
description: One of the problems with straying from the beaten path is that you never know where you'll end up. In the case of Dr. Margaret Bean-Bayog, a Harvard Medical School psychiatrist, no one is quite sure how far she went with her admittedly "unconventional" therapy for Paul Lozano, a medical student more than 20 years her junior. Mr. Lozano was referred to Dr. Bean-Bayog when he complained of depression and homesickness, and committed suicide a year ago after she ended the therapy. Now Mr. Lozano's parents have sued, contending that the doctor became sexually involved with their son and that malpractice led to his death. In an affidavit filed last week, a psychotherapist acquainted with Dr. Bean-Bayog and Mr. Lozano said that the student had told her of having a "kinky" sexual relationship with the doctor, who has denied it. Dr. Bean-Bayog contends instead that she is being "raped by the calculated actions of people who have a financial interest in distorting the truth."

title: Earthquake Threat Is Seen in Northwest
description: A seismic zone that a scientist calls "the most dangerous fault in the United States" has been found in the Pacific Northwest.

title: INSIDE
description: 5 Die in Hostage Case Police officers stormed a Sacramento store where gunmen had held 20 hostages. Three gunmen and two hostages were killed. Page A12. Penalties for Coal Industry

title: USX Expects Large Loss
description: The USX Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, will post a significant first-quarter loss, Charles A. Corry, its chairman, said today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Trionfo

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Drexel Reorganization Plan Accepted by Most Creditors
description: The likelihood that Drexel Burnham Lambert would emerge from bankruptcy as an operating company grew stronger yesterday, as all but one of the groups of creditors and equity holders in the case accepted an outline for the firm's reorganization.

title: United and Pilots in Accord as Heathrow Service Begins
description: United Airlines and its pilots said today that they had reached a tentative agreement after more than three years of bargaining and several attempts by the pilots to buy the carrier.

title: GERMAN FAR LEFT DOGS NEW AGENCY
description: Until recently, the privatizing agency known as Treuhand was only the most hated Government agency in eastern Germany. Now it has become a target of deadly terrorism.

title: Albany Tax Inquiry Accuses Accountants
description: New York State officials announced criminal charges yesterday against eight accountants who are accused of failing to file income tax returns.

title: Cabby Suspected in 5 Bronx Killings
description: Detective commanders say they have uncovered evidence that makes a gypsy-cab driver the main suspect in the mysterious slayings of 10-year-old Jessica Guzman and four other young Bronx residents in the last two years.

title: Three Warrior Stars Avoid Serious Injury
description: The Golden State Warriors' high-scoring threesome of Chris Mullin, Tim Hardaway and Mitch Richmond escaped injury in San Francisco yesterday when debris from an earthquake-damaged freeway shattered the sunroof of the pickup truck being driven by Mullin.

title: Knicks to Ewing: Take Our Millions, Please
description: In an effort to keep their All-Star center in New York during the prime years of his career, the Knicks have begun preliminary contract discussions with Patrick Ewing.

title:
DECONSTRUCTING JERRY BROWN;
He's a New Age Demagogue
description: This is a season of self-proclaimed saviors and strongmen. H. Ross Perot, the self-made-man as putative national boss, is merely the latest entry. But the most successful in this wave of false messiahs, from David Duke to John Silber to Patrick Buchanan -- and perhaps the prototype for the future -- is Edmund G. Brown Jr. His rise, like those of the others, has been stirred by the undercurrents of economic decline and political paralysis. But he is novel: the new class populist demogogue, a Huey Long for the post-modern age.

title: Police Brutality Is Not the Norm
description: The videotaped beating by Los Angeles police of an unresisting black motorist rapidly generated some erroneous assumptions: that similar things happen in most major cities, that the best solution to police brutality is civilian complaint review boards, that improved training can correct improper police behavior and that college graduates serving four or five years in police departments would upgrade overall performance.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BJORN BORG, the five-time Wimbledon champion, has returned to Monaco after living for five years in his native Sweden. Mr. Borg's lawyer, Stefan Persson, said in an interview with Expressen, a Swedish newspaper, that his client had moved from Stockholm a few weeks ago.

title: Award in G.E. Age Case
description: A Wayne County jury awarded $1 million to a former salesman for the General Electric Company who sued the company and a G.E. joint venture on age discrimination charges, his lawyers said today. Richard N. Pietsch, 58 years old, also accused the companies of breach of employment contract and of failing to abide by promises made to him when G.E. hired him in 1981. The award could benefit other employees whose jobs have been lost or are threatened under "reorganization," "reduction in force" or other actions cited by their employers, the statement said.

title: Even a Spare Celtic Looks Good Against Nets
description: Derek Smith was signed as an unrestricted free agent by the Boston Celtics last December, three months after undergoing a fourth operation on his left knee. When healthy, Smith was one of the premier scoring guards in the National Basketball Association.

title: John Heinz, 52, Heir to a Fortune And Senator From Pennsylvania
description: In 20 years on Capitol Hill, 5 of them in the House and 15 in the Senate representing Pennsylvania, John Heinz built a solid record as a persistent defender of the nation's growing elderly population and of the declining steel industry.

title: Abroad at Home; The New World Order
description: This was the war to bring about a new world order. It ended a month ago in almost bloodless triumph for the United States and its allies. So we were told.

title: Screamin' Jay Hawkins As Pitchman and Actor
description: When Screamin' Jay Hawkins sings, he never simply sings: he bellows, sputters, moans and cackles, embroidering the words with his own arcane jibberish. Thus a simple, romantic line like "Bring yourself on home," from his 1957 recording "Person to Person," becomes "Bring your big-fine-foxy-great-googly-moogly-wuuuhhh-lookadat-self on home whaa yeah!" This extraordinary vocalist and showman will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Lone Star Roadhouse.

title: Paul Newman Speaks
description: Paul Newman is to be the speaker in a performance of Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex" by the Orchestra of St. Luke's at Avery Fisher Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. The concert, on the 20th anniversary of Stravinsky's death, is to be conducted by Robert Craft, who was Stravinsky's assistant in the final years of his life. The program is also to include the "Symphony of Psalms," the "Requiem Canticles" and an excerpt from "Apollo." The soloists in "Oedipus Rex" are to be Jon Humphrey, tenor; Wendy White, mezzo-soprano; David Gordon, tenor; John Ostendorf, bass-baritone, and John Cheek, bass-baritone. Miss White and Mr. Ostendorf are also to be the soloists in the "Requiem Canticles." Tickets, $14 to $30. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: How Fair's a Fair Share? Just Check the Formula
description: To even the most inveterate follower of the New York State Legislature, the debate over the allocation of surplus toll revenues from the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority gets a bit obscure. Suffice it to say that the basic question here is whether the New York City Transit Authority should get $24 million and split the rest with commuter railroads, as it does now, or $72 million plus 70 percent of the rest.

title: Wake Up From Your 80's Slumber, America; G.O.P. Redistribution
description: To the Editor:

title: Max Frisch, 79, Writer, Is Dead In Switzerland
description: Max Frisch, the Swiss novelist, dramatist and essayist, died yesterday at his home outside Zurich. He was 79 years old.

title: Reversal by Witness Clouds Death Case Against Officers
description: A Queens teen-ager who says he saw police officers kill a suspect told the authorities and police union investigators six times that the officers had acted properly before he reversed himself and charged that the police had made him lie.

title: High Court Clears Way for Extradition of a Harlem Man in a 1946 Slaying
description: New York State's highest court today declined to block the extradition of 62-year-old Leroy Strachan, who had led a quiet, churchgoing life in Harlem until he was arrested last year and charged in the murder of a Miami police officer 43 years earlier.

title: 5 Are Killed as Officers Storm Store in California
description: Law-enforcement officers stormed an electronics store in south Sacramento late tonight in an attempt to save an estimated 20 hostages held by four armed men after a robbery attempt was foiled. Three armed men and at least two hostages were killed, the Sheriff said.

title: NCR Reviews A.T.&T. Bid
description: The board of the NCR Corporation met yesterday in New York to review A.T.& T.'s takeover proposal. A person with access to the meeting said the two companies had been holding discussions all week about a possible deal.

title: Howe Is Sent To the Minors
description: Steve Howe's long climb back to the big leagues is going to take a little longer than he expected. The Yankees sent the left-handed relief pitcher to their Columbus farm team today, although his contract allows him to become a free agent if his stay there is longer than six weeks.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Unlikely Union in Albany: Feminists and Liquor Sellers
description: It is no surprise that some restaurant, tavern and package-store owners are lobbying against a bill that would require them to post signs warning pregnant women of the dangers of alcohol consumption.

title: Jordan Works His Magic: A 24-Point Lead Vanishes
description: Certainly, the Knicks were not expected to lead the Chicago Bulls by 24 points in the first place. But to lead by that much, only to lose, made last night's defeat even more crushing.

title: Homeless Mentally Ill Need Housing, Not More Case Managers
description: To the Editor:

title: Nielsen Plans Hispanic Effort
description: Nielsen Media Research, a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, said yesterday that it planned to introduce a survey and rating system to measure television viewing patterns in Hispanic households.

title: Plan to Ease Bank Credit is Criticized
description: The nation's senior auditor said today that the Bush Administration's proposals to ease credit conditions were misleading "accounting gimmicks."

title: New Marks Set For 200 Meters
description: Fourteen-year-old Anita Nall of Towson, Md., and 16-year-old Janie Wagstaff of Mission Hills, Kan., swam the second-fastest times in history tonight in winning women's titles in the Phillips 66/United States Swimming spring championships.

title: Schools Panel Urges Addition Of New Districts
description: In the first sweeping evaluation of New York City's schools since they were decentralized 20 years ago, a special state commission has recommended more decentralization as a way of depoliticizing the corruption-plagued system.

title: Stay Out of Iraq's Civil War
description: President Bush is right in resisting pressures to commit U.S. forces to intervene in northern Iraq. The suffering of the Kurds and other Iraqis would become even more tragic if American troops moved in.

title: Japan Denies It Has an AIDS Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Investment Abroad Easing
description: American companies plan to increase investments overseas by 6 percent this year, down from the 19 percent average increase posted during the previous three years, the Government said today.

title: Fears for Fate of Refugees
description: More than 15,000 Iraqi civil war refugees being cared for by the United States military will be returned to Baghdad's control when American forces leave Iraq under the United Nations cease-fire plan, a Red Cross official said today.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Two Shows at Once for Tommy Tune

title: Offer Is Rejected By Ocean Drilling
description: The Ocean Drilling and Exploration Company rejected a takeover offer from the Murphy Oil Corporation. Murphy, which already owns 61 percent of Ocean Drilling, offered half a share of Murphy common for each remaining Ocean Drilling share. The offer is to expire on May 1.

title: Demise of Flake Case: Choice of Tactic at Issue
description: When the Rev. Floyd H. Flake was indicted on tax-evasion and embezzlement charges, Andrew J. Maloney, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn who brought the case, said, "We go wherever the evidence takes us." On Wednesday, a frustrated and embarrassed but still adamant Mr. Maloney found that the evidence in this case went nowhere.

title: Economic Scene; Giving the Banks Greater Powers
description: EXECUTIVES of the big money center banks are the strongest supporters of the Administration proposals for overhauling the banking system -- especially freeing the banks to expand all over the country and giving them broader powers, like the sale of securities and insurance.

title: Next Posts Gain in Computer Sales
description: Next Inc., the company started in 1985 by Steven P. Jobs after he lost control of Apple Computer Inc., said today that it had sold 8,000 computers in the first quarter of 1991, greatly exceeding previous sales levels.

title: Poll Finds Most Satisfied With Police
description: A majority of Americans express satisfaction with the performance of their local police, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. But blacks and whites are sharply divided on how they are treated by the police, with blacks far more likely than whites to believe that they would receive harsh treatment from law-enforcement officers.

title: Ogilvy Wins $20 Million Nynex Account
description: OGILVY & MATHER yesterday won the battle for Nynex's $20 million corporate account.

title: Review/Theater; Genteel Vehicle For Julie Harris
description: THE Playbill for "Lucifer's Child," Julie Harris's solo performance on Broadway as the writer Isak Dinesen, says that the play takes place in its heroine's study in Rungstedlund, Denmark. But the curtain is up as the audience files into the Music Box, and the room in view seems to belong to another cultural realm entirely. With a jutting ceiling that resembles a proscenium arch, some sticker-plastered steamer trunks and an array of proudly displayed costume gowns, the setting for "Lucifer's Child" looks not so much like a lionized Danish writer's den as a star actress's dressing room on the road. Though it's hard to picture the author of "Out of Africa" at work here, who would doubt that Miss Harris is completely at home?

title: A New President For Metro-North
description: Donald N. Nelson, executive vice president and chief executive officer of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, will succeed Peter E. Stangl as president of the commuter railroad, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.

title: SOVIET PRICE RISES IGNITE BIG PROTEST
description: Tens of thousands of workers took to the streets of an important provincial capital today in the first mass protest against nationwide price increases, while in Moscow, Boris N. Yeltsin began a surprise new power play.

title: Ex-Aide to Koch Admits He Lied About Job Bank
description: Joseph DeVincenzo, who was Mayor Edward I. Koch's personnel chief, pleaded guilty yesterday to lying to a state commission in 1989, when he denied that a City Hall office set up to recruit women and minorities was used to doleout political patronage.

title: USF&G Is Cutting 2,000 More Jobs
description: The USF&G Corporation, the struggling insurance conglomerate, said it was cutting 2,000 jobs and merging 14 branch offices in a reorganization to curb losses. The cuts, on top of previously announced reductions, will reduce the company's work force by 25 percent by the end of the year, a company spokeswoman said. The company, which recently stopped writing unprofitable property and casualty insurance in Texas and Louisiana, expects to save $100 million in addition to $75 million from earlier cuts.

title: With $24 Billion, Allies Hope to Buy Peaceful Transition
description: In moments of national challenge, when the arguments President Bush must make to Congress and the public seem beyond his usual oratorical grasp, he often looks for help to the World War II era that formed his own world view.

title: Big Five Sign Up for Gulf Duty
description: The permanent members of the Security Council have agreed to contribute to a U.N. observer force along the Iraq-Kuwait border. Page A9.

title: CIT Group Notes
description: CIT Group Holdings Inc. yesterday priced $150 million in notes due in 1998 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes have an 8 3/4 percent coupon and are priced at 99.75, to yield 8.80 percent, or about 90 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The underwriters said the notes were noncallable through maturity and were rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: For F.D.I.C.'s Top Law Firm, Fees Reaching $600 an Hour
description: The Government has agreed to pay lawyers at a prominent Manhattan firm as much as $600 an hour for their work in several cases involving some of the nation's largest failed savings and loan associations.

title: Executive Is Selected To Run Globex System
description: Gary D. Ginter, an expert on computers and the futures industry, was named yesterday as managing director of the Globex Corporation, a worldwide electronic after-hours trading system developed by the Chicago futures exchanges and Reuters Holdings P.L.C.

title: Dinkins Backs Tests For an Abortion Pill
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he had begun a letter-writing campaign to enlist the support of the nation's mayors for having a French-made abortion pill approved for testing in the United States.

title: BOXING: Notebook; Holmes in Duel With Promoter
description: Former heavyweight champion Larry Holmes, preparing for a comeback fight against Tim (Doc) Anderson on Sunday, is feuding with the corporation promoting his bouts.

title: Market Place; The Guesswork In Initial Offerings
description: FEW things in investment banking are more difficult than pricing an initial public offering. With no existing trading market, gauging the demand for the stock can be tough, and anger can mount if the pricing turns out to be far too high or too low.

title: Reviews/Film; History Fights Talent And Wins Decisively
description: There is something inherently sobering about a documentary film that examines people's lives from early childhood to decrepitude and death; it reminds us that even the most glorious life stories have the same finality. And when that film also portrays its subjects as helplessly buffeted by the currents of history, the feeling deepens into sadness.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: In Orbit; Heading Off the Big One
description: Brilliant Pebbles was the Reagan Administration's name for its spaced-based defense against reasonably intelligent Soviet warheads But a NASA team is now suggesting that all nations get together to watch out for One Big Dumb Rock -- the one with Earth's name on it.

title: TV Weekend; The Historic Challenge to Segregation
description: Tracing events that led to the United States Supreme Court's school-desegregation decision in 1954, "Separate but Equal" is the kind of film that today is likely to be done only for television. The heart of the story is about fundamental national issues that have to be placed in historical, legal and moral contexts. Crucial information must be digested. No action-adventure pyrotechnics here. These are serious matters and, quite admirably, "Separate but Equal" keeps them that way in its deliberately slow, almost stately fashion. The four-hour movie, a "G.M. Mark of Excellence" presentation, will be broadast in two segments, Sunday and Monday, on ABC at 9 o'clock.

title: U.S. Drafts Guidelines For Doctors With AIDS
description: In a draft of proposed new Federal guidelines, the Centers for Disease Control says doctors and dentists infected with the AIDS virus should get permission from local panels of experts before continuing to perform certain operations and invasive procedures.

title: Schneider Changes Its Square D Slate
description: The Square D Company, the target of a hostile takeover attempt by Schneider S.A. of France, said Schneider had changed the slate of directors it had originally proposed for election at Square D's upcoming annual meeting. Square D said Schneider was trying to change its candidates to avoid a legal conflict with the interlocking director provisions of antitrust laws raised by Schneider's initial slate of nominees.

title: New York Forces Step By Insurer
description: New York State regulators today forced one of the First Executive Corporation's insurance subsidiaries to set aside an additional $125 million to pay claims, pushing the insurer into deeper financial trouble and increasing the possibility that it could lapse into insolvency.

title: Washington at Work; Clark Clifford, Symbol of the Permanent Capital, Is Faced With a Dilemma
description: To many, Clark M. Clifford is the political equivalent of the ballplayer who stays in the game long after he is unable to hit a fastball, or the boxer who finds he can no longer duck the blows.

title: John Tesoriero; College Official, 53
description: John Tesoriero, who retired as vice president of Hunter College for finance and facilities in 1985, died on Friday at his home in Eltingville, S.I. He was 53 years old.

title: Ozone Loss Over U.S. Is Found To Be Twice as Bad as Predicted
description: The ozone layer, which protects living things from the Sun's harmful ultraviolet rays, has been depleted in many areas of the globe, and at the latitudes of the United States the loss is proceeding more than twice as fast as scientists had expected, the Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Loudon Wainwright 3d

title: The Rite Of Exorcism On '20/20'
description: Your reaction to the scenes of exorcism displayed tonight on "20/20" is likely to depend on your attitude toward the Devil. If you share the faith of the two Roman Catholic priests who believe they are driving sinister spirits from a troubled girl named Gina, then you may see the encounter, at 10 P.M. on ABC, as a conflict between good and evil. Otherwise, it may strike you as a throwback to medieval attitudes toward mental illness.

title: Leo Grebler, 90, Dies; Authority on Land Use
description: Leo Grebler, professor emeritus of urban land economics at the University of California at Los Angeles, died Tuesday at U.C.L.A. Medical Center. He was 90 years old and lived in West Los Angeles.

title: As Bianchi Leaves, Bitterness Lingers
description: The dream is about Chicago, about the N.B.A. playoffs of 1989. About what might have been. In Al Bianchi's mind, what should have been. He can not let go. He's nurtured such a dream for 40 years.

title: At the Bar; In which a personal injury lawyer trips over his Porsche and thereby dents his own case.
description: Porsches. Mercedes. Jaguars. BMW's. They are the Pulitzer Prizes of the legal profession. But as a Dallas personal injury lawyer named John Cracken was recently reminded, fancy cars are sometimes best left at home.

title: Firm Is Named in Inquiry
description: Federal officials are investigating whether a California investment firm received confidential information from employees of the Food and Drug Administration to use in illegal insider stock trading, a Government official said today.

title: Account
description: * Regatta Sports Ltd., New York, a sportswear manufacturer, to Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss Inc., New York, with a budget of $5 million.

title: U.S. Army Doing the Work in Kuwait
description: The men and women who are trying to rebuild Kuwait wear the brown or green camouflage uniforms of the United States Army.

title: Alzheimer's Also Stirs Families to Heroism
description: To the Editor:

title: Only Tough Penalties Can Halt Police Brutality; Gays Also Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Family Publishing Empire Crumbles Into Money
description: The Patriarch The Rise and Fall of the Bingham Dynasty By Susan E. Tifft and Alex S. Jones Illustrated. 574 pages. Summit Books. $24.95.

title: Auctions
description: Rococo French Silver

title: Review/Film; Marriage as Eternal Punishment
description: Call out the coroner.

title: Critic's Choice/Dance; Erick Hawkins Continues His Joyous Discoveries
description: There is everything and nothing new under the sun as far as Erick Hawkins is concerned. The 82-year-old master modern-dance choreographer, whose company is performing through Sunday at the Joyce Theater, has never given up plumbing the possibilities of the unpressured, flowing style of dance for which he is known. And his dances are as full of clarity, joy and gentle passion as ever, with each one representing, it seems, some new discovery for the choreographer.

title: On My Mind; The Jews of Iraq
description: They are killing the Jews again.

title: United Telecom In Note Offering
description: United Telecommunications Inc. is offering $200 million in notes due in 2003 through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: U.S. Fines 500 Mine Companies for False Air Tests
description: Saying that the lives of coal miners were jeopardized by mining companies' fraud, the Labor Department announced today that it was levying $5 million in penalties against 500 mining companies for tampering with the coal dust samples that Federal inspectors test for the risk of black lung disease.

title: Political Memo; Show Dulls Democrats' View of '92
description: Democrats expected President Bush to ride a tide of good feelings in the aftermath of the war in the Persian Gulf, and they were not surprised when Republican strategists began to present the war's outcome as the vindication of 10 years of Republican policies.

title: Seasonal Work
description: La difference was relatively short lived. After some strenuous lobbying on her own behalf, Edith Cresson resigned last week after just 10 months as France's first female Prime Minister. Her fall followed the bashing her Socialist Party took in March regional elections, in which the party had its worst showing ever, getting just 18.3 percent of the vote and losing a departmental council it had held since 1934. The Government of President Francois Mitterrand has been under increasing pressure lately, with rising unemployment and strikes last fall by social workers, nurses and other traditional supporters of the Socialists. In addition to bad economic indicators, Mrs. Cresson has suffered from perceived political ineptitude, creating diplomatic uproars by criticizing the Japanese social order on one hand, and British masculinity on the other. President Mitterrand dipped in among his party loyalists and selected the Finance Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, to replace Mrs. Cresson.

title: 3 Iraqis Accused Of Smuggling
description: A Federal grand jury in Alexandria, Va., indicted three Iraqi citizens today on charges of trying to smuggle millions of dollars worth of embargoed electronic parts for military equipment to Baghdad.

title: Powell Says U.S. Warplanes Will Stay in Iraq Indefinitely
description: United States warplanes will continue to patrol Iraqi airspace "for an indefinite period," and their eventual removal will hinge on Saddam Hussein's compliance with the United Nations Security Council cease-fire resolution, Gen. Colin L. Powell said today.

title: A Nonprofit Council Honors 7 Corporations as 'Models'
description: The Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit group whose shopping and investment guidebooks have made it the best known of the many self-appointed watchdogs of corporate behavior, honored seven companies last night as "models for other corporations."

title: Good Medicine for Police Brutality
description: The proposed Police Corps, now part of a crime bill introduced by Senator Joseph Biden of Delaware, would provide Federal scholarship money for college students willing to serve four years with a local police department after graduation. It was always a good idea; the national furor over police brutality underscores the need.

title: 17-Year-Old Seized in Rapes In Flatbush
description: A 17-year-old high school student was arrested Wednesday night in a series of rapes that terrorized the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

title: Alzheimer's Also Stirs Families to Heroism
description: To the Editor:

title: Only Tough Penalties Can Halt Police Brutality
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. URGES TURKEY TO OPEN BORDERS TO FLEEING KURDS
description: Despite domestic and foreign pressure to help thousands of Kurds attempting to flee the Iraqi Army, the United States limited its actions today to calling on Turkey to open its borders to the refugees.

title: Poles Brace for Soviet Pullout
description: The Soviet Union plans to withdraw 10,000 of its 50,000 troops in Poland this year and to leave the country completely by 1993, a Polish general said today.

title: Fixing World Crises Isn't Just a Job for Diplomats
description: As delegates from more than 160 governments negotiated the new environmental measures being prepared for signing at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in June, they were being watched, bullied, cajoled and lectured by an increasingly important group of actors on the international stage.

title: G.O.P. Offers Own Budget Plans
description: The Republicans who control the State Senate said today that the state might be able to offset the need for $1 billion in new taxes by selling office buildings and other state assets, calling in loans to public authorities, dipping into reserve funds and declaring a state tax amnesty.

title: Health Threat From Oil Fires May Rise in Summer
description: The first studies of air pollution caused by refinery and oil-well fires in Kuwait found no significant levels of toxic chemicals in the Persian Gulf atmosphere, but "considerable uncertainty" exists over the extent of the health threat, Government scientists have reported.

title: Top U.N. Council Members Agree to Aid Observer Force
description: The United States and the four other permanent Security Council members have agreed to contribute officers to a force of about 300 military observers the United Nations plans to deploy between Iraq and Kuwait. The observer force, to be formed if Iraq accepts the Security Council plan for ending the Persian Gulf war, would be the first to include troops from all five countries.

title: Shanghai Journal; 20 Months of Prison Torment (for the Warden)
description: Prison was a miserable experience for Zhang Weiguo, an ordeal of crowded cells, awful food and constant browbeating, a 20-month stretch in which he was never allowed a visit from his family and was permitted outside to exercise just once. But it wasn't easy on his jailers either.

title: Let Yugoslavs Settle Their Own Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial for Fodor
description: A memorial service for Eugene Fodor, founder of Fodor's Travel Guides, will be held on Tuesday at 5:30 P.M. at the Century Club, 7 West 43d Street. Mr. Fodor died on Feb. 18 at the age of 85.

title: BAGHDAD ASSAILS U.N.'S TRUCE PLAN
description: Iraq's official newspapers today criticized the United Nations Security Council resolution for a formal cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, calling it an American plan to control the world, but gave no clue as to whether or when Baghdad might accept it.

title: Reviews/Art; 'Works on Paper,' 1500's to Today
description: This is the weekend for people who like their artworks on the small side to make their way to the Seventh Regiment Armory. There, the third annual "Works on Paper" exhibition is in full swing until 7 P.M. Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about former President Richard M. Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union, and the Quotation of the Day, rendered a quotation from Mr. Nixon incorrectly in some editions. It should have said, "In the American vernacular, Gorbachev is Wall Street, and Yeltsin is Main Street."

title: 'Baby Bell' Arguments Set
description: Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene today scheduled oral arguments for April 18-l9 on whether the regional Bell telephone companies should be allowed to own information services.

title: New Weapons Prolong the Computer Wars
description: Adecade and a half after it was started by a small band of hobbyists, the personal computer industry is light-years away from the simplicity of the automobile industry, where each car has a gearshift, gas pedal and brake in the same place, or the standardization of the phone system so any user can talk to any other in the world. Instead of turning the planet into a global village, the computer industry has found itself divided by warring camps of manufacturers whose machines can't communicate with each other.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANNIE LEIBOVITZ, whose unconventional photographs enliven American Express advertisements, is to receive a distinguished achievement award from New York Women in Communications Inc. on Wednesday at a lunch at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Kaufman & Broad
description: The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation said it was part of a group awarded the rights to redevelop a site in Paris that is being vacated by Esso S.A., a unit of the Exxon Corporation. Kaufman said the development comprised two 45-story office towers, three smaller office buildings and a 65,000-square-foot art museum. The cost of buying the property is about $508 million. Construction is expected to start in November 1992 and be completed by 1995. Esso is moving to new headquarters outside Paris.

title: Apple Planning A Revamping
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would reorganize to focus on new areas.

title: Only Tough Penalties Can Halt Police Brutality; Incident in Miami Beach
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town
description: New Jazz Network

title: Editorial Notebook; The Imperial Press -- Grounded
description: Neither democracy nor the First Amendment suffered when the press charter for reporters covering President Bush's fishing trip to Islamorada, Fla., was canceled last week. The only real casualty was the imperial press, which could not travel in its usual grand, proconsular style to cover the imperial Presidency. Still, to a reporter who spent five years on press planes, the news was surprising. According to the White House Transportation Office, the grounding was the first in 30 years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: To his collection of Tony, Emmy and Obie awards, VINCENT GARDENIA will add a Biffy, which he is to receive Sunday from the Baltimore International Film Festival. The award is given for achievement by a character actor.

title: Fred Capossela; Race-Track Announcer, 88
description: Fred Capossela, the announcer at New York thoroughbred race tracks for 37 years before his retirement in 1971, died Wednesday night at his home. He was 88 years old.

title: 2 Convicted in Undercover Officer's Murder
description: Two men suspected of being drug dealers were convicted of murder yesterday in the slaying of a state police undercover officer during a bust-and-buy operation on the Lower East Side last year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Chang Beats Van Rensburg Michael Chang, the top-seeded man, became the only seeded player left in the Hong Kong Open when he beat Christo Van Rensburg of South Africa, 7-5, 6-7, 6-4, yesterday. Chang broke Van Rensburg three times in the final set, after being broken twice himself, and advanced to the quarterfinals. Amos Mansdorf of Israel, No. 7, followed the other seeded players out of the tournament when he lost, 6-7, 6-4, 6-2, to Alexander Mronz of Germany in a second-round match.(AP) Gilbert in Quarterfinals: Defending champion Brad Gilbert joined Malivei Washington and Chuck Adams in moving into the quarterfinals of the $225,000 Prudential Securities Tennis Classic yesterday in Orlando, Fla. Gilbert, seeded third, defeated Patrick Baur of Germany, 6-3, 7-6, and Washington beat Nicolas Pereira of Venezuela, 6-1, 6-3. Adams struggled past Bryan Shelton, 3-6, 7-6, 7-6, in a match in which Shelton had 14 aces and did not have his service broken once.(AP) GOLF Johnson and King Tie for Lead Chris Johnson birdied the 18th hole to tie Betsy King at five-under-par 67 and share the first-round lead of the $350,000 PING-Welch's Championship yesterday in Tucson, Ariz.

title: The Fungus That Ate Michigan
description: It weighs 100 tons. It may have been born at the end of the last Ice Age. It's the biggest and oldest living thing on earth, and it's still growing. But it's relatively harmless: a fungus that extends for 30 acres through the soil of a forest near Crystal Falls, Mich.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Wednesday misidentified the parent company of the Elizabeth Arden Company. It is Unilever P.L.C.

title: An 18.2% Gain Is Seen For Money Managers
description: With the stock market finally snapping back after months of uncertainty because of events in the Persian Gulf, the nation's money managers saw the estimated value of their equity portfolios shoot up 18.2 percent in the first quarter, according to CDA Investment Technologies, a Rockville, Md., firm that tracks their performance.

title: A Fair Way to Educate the Homeless
description: Where should homeless children be educated? The question has divided New Yorkers, most often along neighborhood or school district lines.

title: Devils Keep It Simple: Hit and Hit
description: Tom McVie of the Devils is a man of simple human values and strategy as a hockey coach. He proclaims that only a genius gets involved in complicated strategies. His main philosophy -- and he hates such words -- is simply hitting and checking.

title: California Appoints Business Executive To Lead University
description: The trustees of California State University today selected Barry Munitz, the president of a real estate management company, to oversee the nation's largest four-year university system.

title: A Malformed Infant's Brief Life Forces an Issue of Medical Ethics
description: How much brain must a human being have to be considered alive? That issue -- one that has divided doctors and ethicists for more than 25 years -- was raised anew last week as a baby lay dying, born with only a brain stem. Could doctors take organs, even a heart, from a newborn who would never experience consciousness, pain, emotion or thought? Or must they wait until brain function had ceased altogether, when the organs had deteriorated and become unusable?

title: Samuel Schafler, 62, Rabbi and Educator
description: Rabbi Samuel Schafler, the president of Hebrew College in Brookline, Mass., died Wednesday at his home in Brookline. He was 62 years old.

title: NBC Announces Co-Host On 'Today' Won't Return
description: The troubled tenure of Deborah Norville at the "Today" show came to an end officially yesterday, as NBC announced she would not return as co-host of the program on April 29, as had been previously announced.

title: Hated It!
description: Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, put on his movie critic boots last week and jumped all over Oliver Stone's film "J.F.K." Mr. Valenti was a friend and aide of Lyndon B. Johnson, and took lengthy issue with Mr. Stone's directoral implication that President Johnson had some hand in covering up a Government conspiracy in the assassination of John F. Kennedy. The resultant "accusatory lunacy," said Mr. Valenti, was propaganda on a par with Leni Reifenstahl's cinematic glorification of Hitler and the Nazi Party. Mr. Valenti, who was in Dallas as L.B.J.'s press secretary when J.F.K. was assassinated, said he held off his criticism until after the Academy Awards -- "J.F.K." won two Oscars -- so as not to influence the industry's judgment. Mr. Stone said that he found Mr. Valenti's "emotional diatribe off the mark." Most Americans, he said, believe that President Kennedy was the victim of a conspiracy that included Government officials.

title: Frank Gustine; Baseball Player, 71
description: Frank Gustine, an All-Star infielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates in 1946, 1947 and 1948, died of a heart attack on Monday in Davenport, Iowa. He was 71 years old.

title: The Old Litmus Tests Are Abandoned In the New York Democratic Primary
description: The more raucous it gets, the more cozily familiar a New York Democratic Presidential primary can feel. After a couple of weeks of in-your-face protests, spats over Israel, splashy appearances by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, press harpoons and candidate snits, this uncharacteristically important race approaches its Tuesday climax in what at first blush appears to be the standard indigenous style.

title: United and Pilots in Accord as Heathrow Service Begins; Flights to London
description: United Airlines planes from Washington, New York, Miami and San Francisco landed at Heathrow Airport here today, heralding the beginning of the airline's service between London and the United States and marking the weakening of its marketing alliance with British Airways P.L.C., Western Europe's largest carrier.

title: Japan Denies It Has an AIDS Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Lamar Alford; Actor, Writer and Composer
description: Lamar Alford, an actor and singer who made his Broadway debut as Lamar in the 1971 musical "Godspell," died on Friday at Crawford Long Hospital here. He was 46 years old.

title: Chileans Plan Anti-Terror Drive
description: The Chilean Government has announced a 150 percent increase in spending for the national police force as concern over terrorism grows after the killing of a prominent rightist Senator.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It is stunning information. It is unexpected, it is disturbing and it possesses implications we have not yet had time to fully explore." -- William K. Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, on a new estimate of ozone depletion. [ A1:1. ]

title: State Dept. Can Act Against Burmese Regime; Transfer of Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Jazz; Trio Offers A Free Rein To a Roving Saxophone
description: In a trio of saxophone, bass and drums, the saxophonist faces a marathon, as he plays nearly every solo. He also has the chance to rove far afield, since there is no chordal instrument to establish the harmonies. Branford Marsalis is using that lineup at the Village Vanguard through tomorrow; in Wednesday's first set, he made the challenge sound both easy and exhilarating.

title: Of Course, Athletes Are Paid Too Much
description: To the Editor:

title: John G. Tower, 65, Longtime Senator From Texas
description: In his 24 years in the United States Senate, John G. Tower, the first Republican Senator from Texas since Reconstruction, became one of the most influential and knowledgeable lawmakers on military and national security issues. But when he left Washington in 1989, he departed in virtual humiliation, as the Senate rejected a nominee of a new President for the first time.

title: Boston Harbor Cleanup Haunts a New Governor
description: As the Republican Presidential candidate in 1988, George Bush used the pollution of Boston Harbor as one of his main campaign themes to defeat his Democratic rival, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

title: Tarpley Suspended
description: Roy Tarpley, the Dallas Mavericks' injured forward, was suspended indefinitely without pay yesterday for violating his aftercare program for substance abuse mandated by the National Basketball Association.

title: Taking Mound for 1991, Cone Seeks a Higher Level
description: David Cone's fight is for control. The struggle, though, is not with curveballs or fastballs: with a split of his fingers, a snap of his wrist, Cone wields an all but tyrannical mastery of the baseball.

title: CHRONICLE
description: This year's Leatherneck Ball, held last night at the Sheraton Centre in Manhattan, raised money for scholarships for children of military personnel from all the services killed in the Persian Gulf war. Normally, the annual event provides scholarship money for children of marines only.

title: The Council's Flawed Budget
description: To the surprise of its many critics, the New York City Council has proposed a plausible budget, a flawed but serious plan to close the enormous deficit. That may not sound like much, but for the city's legislature it represents a leap from a do-nothing past toward the responsible exercise of power under the new City Charter.

title: Weatherford to Send New Chief to Kuwait
description: In a few weeks, Philip L. Burguieres plans to get on an airplane headed for Kuwait to scout out sales prospects for Weatherford International Inc. He said the destruction of the oil wells there by Iraqi soldiers would provide opportunities for the company, which makes equipment used in wells and provides services for drillers.

title: Consarc Gets Big Award Against Iraq
description: A Federal judge awarded a $64 million default judgment against Iraq today to an American company whose sale of industrial furnaces to Iraq was blocked by President Bush.

title: New Insurance Offered to Protect Adoptive Parents
description: Two major insurance companies are starting to sell adoption insurance. The policies are designed to provide financial protection for people who independently arrange to adopt infants through lawyers rather than public or private agencies.

title: Consumer Borrowing Drops 3.7%
description: Consumer credit declined at a 3.7 percent annual rate in February, the first time in four years that installment debt has decreased for three straight months, the Government said today.

title: Suzuki Geo Output
description: The Suzuki Motor Corporation said it planned to supply 20,000 made-in-Japan Geo Metro convertibles to the General Motors Corporation this year, up from 12,000 the year before.

title: Tourney Off Until October
description: THE WOODLANDS, Tex., April 5

title: Yankee Lineup Game: Hit Ball and Win Job
description: A simple question -- Exactly who will play third base for the Yankees this season? -- does not necessarily result in a simple response from the manager. Stump Merrill listened, leaned forward in his chair, then spit a small stream of tobacco juice into a trash can.

title: Kenya Moves to Improve Political Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedy Nephew Refusing Questions in Rape Inquiry
description: William Kennedy Smith has refused to make himself available for questioning in the investigation of a reported rape at the Kennedy estate, according to the police, who officially named him today as the suspect.

title: Patents; Blood Cells in Placenta Stored for Transplants
description: A biotechnology company in New York City has patented what is says is a new source of blood cells that can be used in bone-marrow transplants: blood cells taken from the placenta and umbilical cords of newborn babies, and stored until needed by freezing.

title: KURDISH REFUGEES RETURNING TO IRAQ
description: Thousands of Kurdish refugees who had fled fighting between the Government and rebels poured back into this northern city today, hungry, thirsty and tired.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A Thomas Scores 15 in Return

title: Surgery for Hernandez
description: Keith Hernandez, the 37-year-old first baseman who played in only 43 games for Cleveland last season because of calf injuries, will undergo back surgery on Monday and it is uncertain when the first baseman will return. The procedure will be performed at the Hospital for Joint Diseases in New York. (AP)

title: Los Angeles Council Backs Suspended Chief of Police
description: Intensifying a political battle that has flared here in the aftermath of the police beating of a black motorist, the City Council moved today to overrule Thursday's suspension of Police Chief Daryl F. Gates.

title: Phils Release Reliever
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, also choosing youth over a fading veteran, yesterday released 36-year-old Guillermo Hernandez and kept 23-year-old Chuck McElroy as their left-handed reliever. "One guy is a lot younger and a pretty good prospect and up and coming," Manager Nick Leyva said. "It makes sense."

title: Campeau May Merge Federated and Allied
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, the United States retailing units of Canada's troubled Campeau Corporation, may be combined into a single public company.

title: At Grand Central, a Stop and a Start
description: In the pursuit of efficiency, Amtrak, the nation's long-distance passenger rail system, will begin tomorrow to run all its long-distance trains headed north of Poughkeepsie through Pennsylvania Station instead of starting them at Grand Central Terminal. That may or may not make good economic sense; what it does mean is that after the Albany-bound Rip Van Winkle leaves Grand Central tonight, the magnificent Beaux Arts landmark that once called itself the gateway to a continent will become just another commuter station.

title: INSIDE
description: Police Chief Gets Support

title: Jessye Norman Cancellation
description: Jessye Norman has withdrawn from the world-premiere performances of Sir Michael Tippett's "Byzantium" with the Chicago Symphony, the orchestra has announced. The soprano Faye Robinson is to sing the work in Chicago on Thursday and next Saturday and at Carnegie Hall on April 15 and 18. Sir Georg Solti is to conduct the four performances, his last as music director of the orchestra.

title: Spelling Deal by Financier
description: Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati financier, increased his Hollywood interests today by agreeing to buy more of Spelling Entertainment Inc., the entertainment company headed by the producer Aaron Spelling.

title: Capt. Manley Lanier Carter, 43; Physician and Shuttle Astronaut
description: Capt. Manley Lanier Carter Jr. of the Navy, the astronaut who was killed yesterday when a commuter airliner crashed in Georgia, was a physician who spent 120 hours in orbit aboard the space shuttle Discovery on a secret military venture.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: BRIEFS
description: * Casablanca Industries Inc., City of Industry, Calif., a maker of ceiling fans and lighting products, has put itself up for sale for an undisclosed price. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month. * Centaur Partners said it increased its common stock in National Intergroup Inc., Pittsburgh, a pharmaceutcals, steel and petroleum products company, to 18.27 percent from 17.53 percent.

title: Genentech Testing
description: Genentech Inc. said it had begun human testing of an antibody that could be used to treat breast and ovarian cancer. The biotechnology company said the antibody selects as a target a protein in a tumor cell that is present in about a third of all cases of ovarian and breast cancer. An antibody is a protein produced in the body that creates immunity to a toxin or other foreign substance. In laboratory studies, the Genentech antibody inhibits the growth of tumor cells and increases the vulnerability of tumors to the immune system, the company said. Shares of Genentech were unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $26.125.

title: 2 G.I.'s Killed in Crash in Iraq
description: An American Army OH-58C Kiowa scout helicopter crashed today during a reconnaissance mission over southern Iraq, killing both crew members, the Central Command reported. The cause of the crash was unknown, but officials ruled out Iraqi fire. The victims were assigned to the Fourth Battalion, 229th Aviation Regiment, 11th Aviation Brigade, VII Corps.

title: Review/Music; Saxophonist, Jazz Ensemble And Electronic Effects
description: For Jane Ira Bloom, music suggests shapes in space. Working with small groups, she often swings her soprano saxophone in wide arcs, adding electronic effects like sonic vapor trails. At Town Hall on Tuesday night, she deployed people along with electronics, adding a 20-piece wind ensemble to her jazz group. Brass and woodwind players were on stage and in the balcony, swinging their instruments and playing chords so dense they were almost palpable.

title: Freeing of Hostages in Lebanon Still Stymied
description: Despite some hopeful statements and diplomatic signals, efforts to win the release of American and other Western hostages in Lebanon remain stymied by the unfulfilled demands of Lebanese Shiite Muslim captors, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Key Rates
Observer; The Age of Eloquence
description: The Declaration of Independence was written by human hand on paper with a pen that had to be dipped repeatedly in ink. Considering the primitive technology, it was pretty good writing. "When in the course of human events," and so forth.

title: All Lights Were Red For Cerone
description: In 1979, Rickey Henderson was a rookie outfielder for the Oakland A's and Rick Cerone was a third-year catcher for Toronto, and each stole his first base in the major leagues. They then parted company. Over these last 12 seasons, no player has stolen more bases than Henderson, 936, and none has stolen fewer than Cerone, 4.

title: Ford Plans to Cut Salaried Workers
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to trim the costs of its salaried work force by 20 percent over the next five years to hold down expenses in the sales slump. Alex Trotman, an executive vice president and head of Ford's North American automotive operations, made the comment at an awards ceremony at a Ford assembly plant here. He stressed that the 20 percent figure was an estimate and could change.

title: The Brahms Requiem
description: The soprano Harolyn Blackwell and the baritone Roger Roloff are to be the solosts with the Collegiate Chorale in Brahms's "German Requiem" at Carnegie Hall at 8 o'clock tonight. The performance is to be conducted by Robert Bass. Tickets, $11 to $45. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES FARMER, the civil rights leader, was honored by the Fund for an Open Society on Thursday at a reception in Manhattan. He received the society's Distinguished Service Award, presented by MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS . The Philadelphia-based fund, which Mr. Farmer co-founded in 1975, provides low-interest mortgages for integrated housing. About 100 people attended the ceremony.

title: Penguins Get Even With Devils on Rookie's Goal in Overtime
description: Jaromir Jagr, the 19-year-old rookie from Czechoslovakia, scored his first goal in the Stanley Cup playoffs, 8 minutes 52 seconds into overtime, to give the Pittsburgh Penguins a 5-4 victory tonight over the Devils.

title: Corrections
description: The "Your Money" column in Business Day last Saturday misstated the portion of the health-insurance premium that could be deductible for self-employed people not eligible for employer-sponsored coverage. It is one-quarter, not half.

title: In a Crack House: Dinner and Drugs on the Stove
description: In a dingy basement apartment in Harlem, a well-dressed man in his late 40's drew deeply from a pipe fashioned from a miniature whisky bottle and a stubby glass tube. Holding his breath, he passed the pipe, with the blue-gray smoke of crack still swirling in its chamber, to a friend sitting at his side at a crowded old wooden dining table.

title: Guns Found Near Bush Jet
description: Secret Service agents found two pistols in the cars of workers for news organizations as they tried to enter the secure area at Los Angeles International Airport not long before President Bush flew from there to Houston.

title: Water Meters Punish Apartment Landlords
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: H. PATRICK SWYGERT was formally inaugurated yesterday as the president of the State University of New York at Albany. Mr. Swygert, 48 years old, is the first black president of a SUNY center. He took over last August.

title: Canadiens Win Again For 2-0 Series Lead
description: Guy Carbonneau scored with 1 minute 21 seconds left in the third period tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 5-4 victory over the Buffalo Sabres and a two-game lead in their Adams Division semifinal playoff series.

title: Brick Maker's Upturn Spurs Hope
description: The mood has turned upbeat this week at the headquarters here of the Glen-Gery Corporation, the nation's third-largest brick maker, as the company posted its first two-million day for brick shipments since Nov. 21.

title: Gun-Toting Student Expelled
description: The Board of Education has expelled a high school student who brought a pistol to school in January and then accidentally shot himself in class. The student, Wattson Rountree, 16 years old, was expelled for the remainder of the academic year at West Haven High School, school officials said.

title: Dinkins Scoffs At Fiscal Plan By Council
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday began a harsh counterattack on the City Council's alternative to his plan for balancing the budget, sarcastically dismissing most of its cost-cutting and revenue-raising ideas as "provocative" but too vague or unworkable to be counted on.

title: Kurds on Turkey Border Scramble for the Basics
description: As if the Iraqi Kurds had not been punished enough, the heavens deepened their misery today with a pounding, cold rain.

title: Bank of Boston Plans New Issue With Bid
description: The Bank of Boston strengthened its hand in bidding for the Bank of New England yesterday, by announcing plans to issue $1 billion of new securities if its bid is accepted.

title: Copeland Forced Into Chapter 11
description: Creditors owed nearly $400 million have forced the owner of Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken and Church's Fried Chicken into bankruptcy proceedings. The creditors, led by the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Merrill Lynch & Company, filed an involuntary Chapter 11 petition Thursday against Al Copeland Enterprises Inc. The action follows six months of negotiations between Mr. Copeland and the creditors. The Toronto-based Canadian Imperial Bank lent Mr. Copeland $249 million and Merrill Lynch lent him $142 million to acquire Church's in 1989.

title: Coping/With Stereo Equalizers
description: Once found only in recording studios, stereo equalizers are becoming more and more popular in home audio systems. It's easy to see why. An equalizer -- a set of controls that each affect a narrower band of tones than the usual bass and treble knobs -- can improve the sound of bad recordings and compensate for a host of problems caused by speaker limitations or room acoustics, from hollowness and shrillness to a weak or boomy bass.

title: Boeing-Sikorsky Gets Copter Pact
description: The Pentagon chose a team headed by the Boeing Company and the United Technologies Corporation's Sikorsky Aircraft division today to build a new generation of combat helicopters for the Army. The contract could ultimately be worth $34 billion.

title: A Witch Hunt in Prague?
description: The story is depressingly familiar in Eastern Europe today. Jan Kavan, a former dissident now in the Czech Parliament, has been accused by a parliamentary commission of collaborating with the Communist secret police 20 years ago. He denies the charge but his reputation is already besmirched by whispered rumor, public denunciation and some officials' inquisitorial zeal.

title: 2 Protesters Shot to Death At Iraqi Consulate in Turkey
description: Gunfire from the Iraqi Consulate killed two demonstrators today while protesters shouting, "Freedom to the Kurds!" stoned the building, the police said.

title: Yeltsin Attains Greater Powers In His Republic
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the champion of forces arrayed against the central Government, capped a week of parliamentary victories today by winning expanded powers to rule by decree in the Russian republic and the establishment of a republican presidency.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The economy is likely to rebound by the middle of the year if the Fed makes sure to sustain growth in money and credit." -- Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser. [ 28:1. ]

title: A 1465 Bell, War Booty, To Go Back To Okinawa
description: A 15th-century Buddhist temple bell seized by United States Marines on Okinawa in June 1945 and exhibited as a war trophy at the Virginia Military Institute in Lexington, Va., for the last 45 years will be returned to Okinawa next week.

title: Morgan Creek, Warner in Pact
