description: Warner Brothers Inc. said it had entered into an exclusive three-year deal with Morgan Creek Productions for all United States and Canadian distribution rights to a planned slate of about two dozen films. Morgan Creek is an independent Los Angeles-based film studio founded in 1987.

title: Disney Planning to Produce a Nationwide Lottery Show
description: An association of state lotteries has teamed up with the Walt Disney Company on a new television show that could, in effect, create the first nationwide lottery.

title: Capitals Shut Out Rangers to Even Series at 1-1
description: Neil Sheehy, Washington's veteran defenseman from Harvard, didn't score any of the goals last night when the Capitals beat the Rangers, 3-0. He didn't even get much ice time in Game 2 of the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs at Madison Square Garden.

title: Ghosts of Broadway, Some Still Standing
description: Between 1882 and 1932, nearly 90 theaters were built from Times Square to Columbus Circle, giving New York City the largest concentration of playhouses in the world. But the Depression made many of them unnecessary, and rising real-estate values and taxes made many others insufficiently profitable. Little by little, they vanished; by 1991, more than 50 had been demolished or converted to other uses.

title: Review/Television; A Portrait of Cuba Without the Warts
description: "I love Fidel very much, and I know whatever Fidel does is the best," says a woman. A baseball star says he would feel guilty if he were paid more: "I feel great pride in representing my country and my comandante." A young doctor tells of receiving her medical education free and avows her dedication to the people. A soldier, back from fighting for the Marxist Government in Angola, says he is willing to die for socialism. Such are the faces that viewers are likely to take away from "Portrait of Castro's Cuba," a two-hour documentary at 7 P.M. Sunday on TBS .

title: Reviews/Music; Brass Quintet Introduces A Concerto Written for It
description: The Saturday Brass Quintet, a resident ensemble at the Manhattan School of Music, won the Naumburg Chamber Music Award in 1990. Its prize included a concert and a commissioned work, and the group presented both on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: U.S. Says Agreement Will Cut Role of Mobsters in a Union
description: The Federal Government said today that it was near an agreement that would eliminate organized-crime influence from the union that represents 22,000 workers in Atlantic City's casinos, hotels and restaurants without taking union officials to court.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Foyt Returns to the Wheel
description: A. J. Foyt today took to a race track for the first time since his legs and feet were badly injured in a crash at Elkhart Lake, Wis., last year.

title: At a Field of Ghosts, a Shadow of a Park
description: A lone fisherman, bundled up against the chill wind blowing across the bay, waits patiently for a flounder to bite. In nearby grasslands, birders peer through binoculars in search of American kestrels, northern harriers and other birds. By day, the seven campgrounds are quiet, but after dusk, campfires glow as teen-agers tell stories and tents are pitched amid pine groves.

title: Of Sex, a Senator and a Press Circus
description: An accusation of rape at the Kennedy family's estate in Palm Beach, Fla., last weekend has generated what may be the most intense news coverage of any story since the war in the Persian Gulf ended last month.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Higher After Wild Swings
description: Prices of long-term Treasury issues swung wildly yesterday before settling slightly higher.

title: No Opener for Rose
description: Pete Rose, the former player and manager of the Reds, ended his three-month stay at a halfway house in Cincinnati yesterday, but still must perform three months of community service as part of his sentence for income-tax evasion.

title: Jobless Rate Rose to 6.8% in March, Highest Since 1986
description: Reflecting an increasingly grim labor market, the Government reported today that the nation's unemployment rate climbed three-tenths of a point in March, to 6.8 percent, the highest rate since late 1986.

title: About New York; Despite the Gash, Just Something About That Face
description: You hear amazing stories in this city, you really do. The phone rang yesterday morning with one. It was about one of those coincidences that make New York seem like a small town. One suggesting that lending a hand to someone in the gutter might be the same as helping a friend.

title: Lithuania and Oxford Are Linked by Yiddish
description: The Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, has of late been the center of revolt against the Soviet central Government. But once the city was a bastion of Litvak Yiddish, and now a link between Vilnius and Oxford University, citadel of the queen's English, is being forged by a Brooklyn scholar fluent in Kings County English and in the Yiddish of his forebears.

title: Florio Reminds Radio Listeners of His Bigger Tax Rebate
description: The Florio administration, the target of protests much of the last year for raising state taxes, is spending $240,000 on radio messages in which Gov. Jim Florio reminds people to file for their annual property-tax rebates.

title: Rebels Black Out Much of Peru
description: Maoist guerrillas bombed and shelled embassies and banks and blacked out much of the country Friday night in their most extensive attack since President Alberto Fujimori took office nine months ago, the police said today.

title: Agreement Reached on TV Reruns
description: A majority of the members of the Federal Communications Commission reached agreement tonight on a new proposal for relaxing the rules that bar television networks from the lucrative TV rerun market.

title: Robert Schoelkopf; Art Dealer Was 63
description: Robert Schoelkopf, a dealer in 20th-century American art, died on Thursday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 63 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Compensation Sought
description: Mickey Shuler and Joe Morris, cut by the Jets and the Giants, respectively, in training camp last year, have filed a suit against the National Football League that could eventually force teams to pay many players released in training camp 10 percent of their annual salaries.

title: U.S. WILL AIRDROP FOOD AND CLOTHES TO KURDS IN IRAQ
description: Under intense pressure to help thousands of Kurds fleeing the Iraqi Army, President Bush ordered Air Force transports today to begin dropping food, blankets and clothing to Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq on Sunday.

title: Frantic Fire Rescue, As if a Fuse Burned
description: Firefighters call it the flashover point: the moment when gases in a burning room become so overheated that the introduction of new oxygen makes the space explode.

title: Militants Back 'Queer,' Shoving 'Gay' the Way of 'Negro'
description: "Queer," a word long bandied in schoolyards and bars as a taunt, has acquired a new meaning: it has been adopted, proudly and defiantly, by a new generation of young militants. Their use of the word has created a rift in the gay community, alienating many older members haunted by its pejorative connotations.

title: The Hudson Dispatch, 117, Is No More
description: The Hudson Dispatch, a morning newspaper that has covered Hudson County in New Jersey for 117 years, was sold yesterday to a rival, The Jersey Journal, and ended publication with yesterday's issue.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LUCILLE LORTEL, the theater producer, will be honored by the University of Bridgeport next Saturday with its Patron of the Arts Award. It is to be presented at a concert performance of "Magic Memories," a new musical that is the first in the Connecticut university's works-in-progress series. JUNE HAVOC will be the master of ceremonies at the program, to be held in the Mertens Theater on campus.

title: Eastern Europe Is Out of Print
description: More than a year after revolutions toppled Communism in Eastern and Central Europe, book publishing in the region remains in chains.

title: Oscar Barrera, 63, Horse Trainer
description: Oscar Barrera, one of five brothers from Cuba who became well-known trainers of thoroughbred horses in the United States, died Thursday night at Jamaica Hospital in Queens. He was 63 years old.

title: U.N. Votes to Condemn Handling of Iraq Rebels
description: The Security Council voted tonight to condemn President Saddam Hussein's reppression of the Iraqi Kurds and of other civilian groups and asked the Secretary General to investigate their plight.

title: Horse Racing; Across the Map, 3 Chances For Contenders to Show Off
description: The countdown to the Triple Crown will intensify today -- one month from the Kentucky Derby -- when 20 contenders compete in three major stakes races, at Santa Anita, Gulfstream Park and Aqueduct.

title: Grappelli at Carnegie
description: The jazz violinist Stephane Grappelli and the Swingle Singers will perform together for the first time on Thursday at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The Swingle Singers, who are from London, will perform a blend of jazz, baroque and popular songs. Included in Mr. Grappelli's program will be music he has composed for films. Tickets range from $15 to $30. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Already, Speculation on Heinz Seat
description: The death of Senator John Heinz of Pennsylvania in a plane crash on Thursday has set up an off-year election in November that could become a fierce test of strength between the national parties a year before the 1992 Congressional elections.

title: Isabella Is No Saint
description: To people outside the Vatican, canonization is rather like winning the Nobel prize. No one knows why one candidate for sainthood is chosen over another or who, apart from the pope, does the selecting.

title: Chet Lemon Is Placed On Waivers by Tigers
description: The Detroit Tigers yesterday waived outfielder Chet Lemon, a 16-year veteran, granting him an unconditional release. He is in the final year of a long-term contract that would have paid him $828,000 if the Tigers had kept him this season.

title: 38 Killed in 3 Quakes in Peru
description: Three strong earthquakes jolted Peru within 24 hours, killing at least 38 people and injuring about 750, officials said today. Mayor Cesar Arevalo of Moyobamba, capital of the San Martin region, said the city of 50,000 people was "practically destroyed" and that 90 percent of the city's homes were damaged in the first quake on Thursday morning. A civil defense spokesman said 20 people were killed in the village of Nueva Cajamarca, 9 in Moyobamba, 6 in Rioja and 3 in Union.

title: Cut Parking on Avenues During Business Hours
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a legislative commission's report on the New York City schools misstated the party affiliation of Senator John J. Marchi of Staten Island. He is a Republican.

title: U.S. REPORTS DROP IN INFANT DEATHS
description: The nation's infant mortality rate dropped last year by the largest amount in nearly a decade, Government statistics show.

title: F.B.I. Chief and Black Agents Meet to Prevent Bias Lawsuit
description: In an effort to head off a lawsuit by black agents, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation met today with a group of the agents to reassure them that he was committed to correcting discrimination in the agency.

title: Dow Drops 27.72 as Fed Fails to Act
description: Stocks sagged yesterday after the Federal Reserve failed to fulfill widespread Wall Street expectations that it would lower interest rates quickly to deal with the sluggish economy.

title: Hollywood Knows Only One Shade of Black
description: Sidney Poitier, the gifted actor, looks nothing at all like Thurgood Marshall, the longtime Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. Yet, on Sunday and Monday nights, Mr. Poitier will appear as Justice Marshall in a four-hour ABC miniseries, "Separate but Equal."

title: Teacher Saved Child From a Wall of Fire
description: Ivy Weeks, a reading teacher at Merion Elementary School, said she heard Thursday's crash of a plane and helicopter and opened her classroom door to see a boy running through a wall of fire.

title: Of Course, Athletes Are Paid Too Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Companies Join Ranks of Auto Clubs
description: As the peak season for automobile travel approaches, many drivers are tuning up their cars and thinking about who will help them in emergencies on the road.

title: Iran Calls on Rebels To Continue Battling Baghdad 'Until End'
description: Iran urged dissidents in neighboring Iraq today to continue their revolt "until the end," while Baghdad offered an amnesty to rebellious Kurds, including army and police deserters, but excluding those who had committed "murder, rape and looting during acts of riot and treason."

title: Patents; Low-Calorie Substitute For Sugar
description: A small chemical company has patented a method for producing a new low-calorie sugar substitute that executives say comes closer to the real thing than alternative sweeteners.

title: Violence Imperils Talks in South Africa
description: The African National Congress warned President F. W. de Klerk today that it would pull out of discussions on South Africa's future unless his Government moved within five weeks to stop the violence afflicting black townships.

title: Correction
description: In an April 1 letter on Social Security from C. Eric Olsen, the estimated cost to workers of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's tax-cut plan appeared incorrectly. The figure is $1.06 trillion, not $1.06 billion.

title: As Elderly Increase, So Do Travel Discounts
description: As Americans live longer and enjoy their resources more, hotels, transportation companies and restaurants are stepping up discount programs to appeal to older people.

title: Widow Found Beaten to Death in Brownsville
description: An 83-year-old widow who lived alone and relied on the kindness of her neighbors was found bludgeoned to death in her Brooklyn apartment on Thursday night. The police said she was probably robbed and killed by someone she knew.

title: Religion Notes
description: Setback on Isabella

title: Dinkins Joins Police Dinner and Feud
description: Three weeks after navigating the stormy waters of the St. Patrick's Day parade, Mayor David N. Dinkins stepped into another matter of some political delicacy last night.

title: Day Care, Lasers and, Oh Yes, Football
description: Keeping with their theme of entertainment for the entire family, the New York/New Jersey Knights are going to offer day care -- or as General Manager Reggie Williams calls it, "Knight" care -- for parents with children who attend the World League of American Football home opener between the Knights and the Frankfurt Galaxy tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: On Brink of Defeat, Respite for Navratilova
description: Poised just one game away from elimination in the cozy event in which she holds five titles and is the defending champion, Martina Navratilova saw her fate temporarily postponed by a cloudburst.

title: Part of an AIDS Virus Enzyme Is Deciphered
description: Researchers at a California pharmaceutical company say they have solved the three-dimensional structure of a key part of an AIDS virus enzyme, mapping a possible new target for drugs that can attack the disease.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * GFT USA Corp., New York, a subsidiary of Gruppo GFT, a maker of men's and women's apparel, named Colombe M. Nicholas president and chief operating officer of its Giorgio Armani Fashion Corp., a new post. * Jones Apparel Group, Bristol, Pa., named Andrew Grossman president, replacing Sidney Kimmel, who remains chairman and chief executive.

title: Your Money; At Tax Deadline Without the Cash
description: For thousands of reputable middle-class Americans, April 15 represents a guilty secret. They fail to file income tax returns, and there are indications that with layoffs rising their numbers may grow this year.

title: NCR Talks Said to Be At Impasse
description: Negotiations between the NCR Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company appear to be at an impasse, with neither side indicating any willingness to budge on the amount it believes NCR is worth, people involved in the deal said yesterday.

title: Madrid Journal; Church and State Spar Over Condoms and Greed
description: In a sense, the local Roman Catholic hierarchy's latest denunciation of what it called Government-sponsored sexual promiscuity and rampant materialism came as no surprise, since the church in Spain has often complained that nine years of Socialist rule have spawned immorality and hedonism.

title: Farmer Cleared of Mercy Killing
description: A 60-year-old farmer accused of killing his sickly brother last summer was found not guilty of second-degree murder late last night.

title: WIC Works
description: In the 19 years since it was invented, a Federal food program called WIC has won impressive support, and rightly so. WIC, which stands for Women, Infants and Children, feeds poor pregnant or nursing women and their babies. Congress likes WIC and so does President Bush; he is calling for a generous increase in its funding.

title: CBS Profits Drop 72.7%; Layoffs Set
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that its earnings had declined 72.7 percent in the first quarter, to $23.3 million, or $1.21 a share, from $85.3 million, or $3.31 a share, in the first quarter last year. Although broadcasting analysts had predicted that the company would report a loss for the quarter, unexpected one-time income from interest and capital-gains payments offset the expected loss.

title: Plane Crash in Georgia Kills 23, Including Former Senator Tower
description: A commuter plane carrying 23 people, including former Senator John G. Tower of Texas, crashed and burned today a mile and a half short of the airport near this Georgia coast city, killing everyone on board.

title: Kidnapped Boy Is Returned Safe On Long Island
description: Call this a kidnapping for the 90's. The kidnapper needed day care.

title: Atlantis Is Launched, Carrying 5 To Loft $600 Million Observatory
description: Five astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis rocketed into orbit today on a mission to deploy a $600 million astronomy satellite and to practice techniques for assembling a large space station later in this decade.

title: A Medal of Honor For Black Soldier From World War I
description: President Bush will award a posthumous Medal of Honor to a black soldier killed in World War I. The soldier would be the first black to be honored with the nation's highest citation for valor in World War I or World War II, Administration officials said today.

title: International Phone Venture
description: The major telephone companies of Britain, Japan and Germany are discussing a joint venture that would provide services to international business customers.

title: Tryout for Hurley
description: Bobby Hurley, whose playmaking led Duke to the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, heads a list of 66 players invited to try out for the United States basketball team for the Pan American Games on Aug. 13-15 in Havana. Among the others invited to Colorado Springs this month are Terry Dehere of Seton Hall, and Malik Sealy and Robert Werdann of St. John's. (AP)

title: Newsweek Executive Editor Is Dismissed in Restructuring
description: Stephen Smith has been dismissed as the executive editor of Newsweek, the third highest editorial position on the magazine, and will leave in June, Mr. Smith said yesterday.

title: Lawsuit Presses Faster Fix-Up of a Parkway
description: New York City plans to take legal action to make sure that the restoration of Eastern Parkway to its former grandeur will be completed, after years of delay, city officials say.

title: Guidepost; In Case of Fire
description: Household fires are frightening enough, but hotel fires can be even worse because guests are generally unfamiliar with the building's layout and don't know how to escape. Here are some safety tips to improve the chance of surviving a hotel fire. When You Check In

title: Pro Basketball; Anyway You Look, Knicks Are Hurting
description: Having lost six of their last seven games, the Knicks (35-39) are hurting both on and off the court.

title: Safety Note
description: The New York City Fire Department recommends that smoke alarm batteries be changed twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight time. The date this spring is tomorrow.

title: C. J. Lawrence Official Leaves for Soros Post
description: After almost 10 years at C. J. Lawrence Inc., Robert M. Raiff, a managing director and co-director of research at the firm, has resigned to join Soros Fund Management, a hedge-fund operator.

title: Patents; Device Determines When Life Has Stopped
description: Two doctors have invented a handheld device to accurately distinguish life and death. The device is designed to pick up faint electrical signals from the heart and brain that may betray a lingering spark of life in a person whose heartbeat and breathing may have stopped.

title: Professor Is Slain on Street in Massachusetts
description: Mary Joe Frug, A law professor who was a leader in feminist studies, was slain Thursday evening on a street near her home in Cambridge, Mass., the Cambridge police reported. She was 49 years old.

title: P. J. Boatwright Jr., Authority on Rules for Golf, Dies at 63
description: P. J. Boatwright Jr., long known as the world's foremost authority on the Rules of Golf, died of bone cancer yesterday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N.J. He was 63 years old and lived in Gladstone, N.J.

title: Kurd Gives Account Of Broadcasts to Iraq Linked to the C.I.A.
description: A Kurdish expatriate in London says he was recruited by Saudi intelligence this year to record broadcasts at a clandestine radio station in which he urged fellow Kurds inside Iraq to overthrow President Saddam Hussein.

title: Backgrounds of Astronauts On the 39th Shuttle Mission
description: Steven R. Nagel Mission Commander

title: 6 Are Killed as 8-Hour Siege By Gang Ends in California
description: Three Vietnamese gunmen from a youth gang and three hostages died in a chaotic hail of gunfire late Thursday as county sheriff's deputies stormed an electronics store that the gang had held for eight hours.

title: Unemployment Rises in Canada
description: Canada's unemployment rate jumped to 10.5 percent in March, the highest in six years, the Government reported today. February's rate was 10.2 percent.

title: Conservation Corps Also Plans Reunion
description: To the Editor:

title: Traffic Alert
description: Alternate-side parking regulations will be suspended today for the eighth day of Passover.

title: State Dept. Can Act Against Burmese Regime
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Spouse Told To Testify on a Source
description: A city judge here has ordered the husband of a newspaper reporter to testify about the identity of one of her sources.

title: Review/Dance; Tetley Premiere by Harlem Troupe
description: Art is not about money, despite what you hear. Nonetheless, the Dance Theater of Harlem has not been able to afford a full-scale season in New York City since the summer of 1989.

title: Review/Music; A Rousing, All-American Program to Stir the Blood
description: When the recent war in the Persian Gulf forced the New York Philharmonic to cancel its European tour as a precaution against terrorism, six concerts were hastily arranged to fill the hole in the orchestra's schedule. One of four such ad hoc events at Avery Fisher Hall took place on Thursday evening when Leonard Slatkin led "An All-American Program" of short, mostly popular, pieces by such natives as Aaron Copland, Charles Ives, Leonard Bernstein and Samuel Barber. The intent, as Mr. Slatkin suggested in prefatory remarks, was to honor worthy American music, while not incidentally sending red blood coursing through the veins of patriots.

title: Refugees Fear Future in Iraq Without U.S.
description: For many Iraqis who are flocking to this region, the Americans who are handing out food and medicine are regarded as benefactors. For others here, these same Americans are seen as the major threat to a cherished way of life.

title: Review/Music; Award Winner Takes Rare Path In Piano Recital
description: A standard strategy for recital debuts is a program so familiar that attention shifts to the player and away from the played. Pedja Muzijevic's evening at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday -- sponsored by the Juilliard School's Petschek awards -- took another approach: come hear some interesting music, it seemed to be saying, and in the process get to know me.

title: American Stores to Sell 145 Outlets
description: The American Stores Company said it had reached a definitive agreement to sell 145 Alpha Beta supermarkets in the Los Angeles area to Food 4 Less Supermarkets Inc. for $248 million. It said the price consisted of $237 million cash and the assumption of $11 million of lease obligations. American said it would retain 15 San Diego Alpha Beta stores, which it plans to operate as Lucky Stores.

title: Bridge
description: Some spot cards are totally unimportant, and can be squandered by a defender without risk. But there may be a concealed risk, and West discovered this the hard way on the diagramed deal from the Open Pair Championship at the Spring Nationals in Atlantic City in March.

title: Drug Chief Opposes Campus Tests
description: The new Director of National Drug Control Policy, Bob Martinez, said today that colleges had not been aggressive enough in fighting drug abuse on campus. But he rejected the idea of mandatory drug tests for students.

title: In the Nation; War's Real Choices
description: The turmoil now convulsing Iraq was predictable before a single smart bomb was launched at Baghdad. It became certain when the U.S. Air Force proceeded to blow that nation back into the "pre-industrial age."

title: Care and Feeding Of Commuters
description: MICHAEL LUCAS earned a respectable 3.0 grade point average in his freshman year at Rutgers College. But he was still dissatisfied, and it had nothing to do with grades.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL
description: ON THE RUN The Never Dull and Often Shocking Life of Maury Wills. By Maury Wills and Mike Celizic. Carroll & Graf, $19.95.

title: THE ROMANIANS SEE MORE WOES AHEAD
description: The leaders of this country, the unhappiest of the formerly Communist nations of eastern Europe, concede that it is going through hardship as it jettisons the Communist legacy and struggles toward a market economy.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
On-the-Job Parent Conferences
description: GUIDANCE counselors from the Newton-Conover School District in Catawba County, North Carolina, have devised a solution to a common problem: Since working parents can't come to school for conferences, the counselors go to the parents. The district's eight counselors visit workplaces one day of each month for 15-minute parent conferences.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; The Hartford Builds on Spec in Hometown
description: FIFTY-FIVE Farmington, the first large office building to be completed in Hartford since 1989, and the last expected for another two to three years, opened two weeks ago after a troubled history.

title: Camera
description: In the beep-and-grind world of today's photographic marketplace, film is a decidedly unsexy commodity. The problem is that its mechanisms are invisible. You can stroke an old Leica range finder and feel how smoothly it advances the film; you can point a new Canon ultrasonic lens at Spot and see how efficiently its built-in motor snaps his lugubrious mug into focus. Film, however good it may be, always comes in the same plain little cartridge. And real differences between films are sometimes lost in the translation to a machine-made, postcard-sized print.

title: Roman Heroes Over the Ages From Domingo
description: Those whose education comes principally from stray background reading about opera (and there are more of us than you might think) will enjoy Placido Domingo's "Roman Heroes" (Angel CDC 7 54053 2; CD and cassette), drawn from operas set in the Eternal City or based on important figures from Roman history. It's a great excuse to spend a few hours in Tacitus or Gibbon or the wonderful old 11th Britannica, where the Romans of old are chronicled and evaluated with superb concision and confidence. And it's a solid, nicely varied program of music as well.

title: Selective Passions
description: A LONG ISLAND couple, serious collectors of English ceramics, still have the first pieces they ever bought: two Wedgwood blue-and-white cups and saucers, purchased 30 years ago for $15. "I don't think they're worth more than $120 now," says one. "We've kept them for their sentimental value. But I think if we had to do it over again, we'd have started by being more selective."

title: Kathryn Teaze Is Dead; a Red Cross Aide, 93
description: Kathryn Teaze, a Red Cross volunteer whose more than 70 years of service spanned two world wars, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Fairfield, Conn. She was 93 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: Tested Tactics
description: THE GULF between the theory of using computers in schools and the reality is wide and deep. It's a rare educator who does not believe that computers have a place in the classroom, but just how the computer is to be integrated is still subject to intense debate. Even basic issues, like whether the system should be based in classrooms or in a separate laboratory, or whether or not it should be tied into a schoolwide network, engender argument.

title: The Pervasive Problem of Lead Paint
description: AFTER decades of anxiety over the health risks of lead-based paint in older American homes, a spate of suits, court rulings, Government reports and medical studies is raising broad new fears over the extent of the problem and the huge cost of removing the threat.

title: Thou Shall Not Allow Rose Into the Hall!
description: When Pete Rose's athletic alma mater opens the season as world champions in Cincinnati tomorrow, baseball's record hit master will be on the outside looking in. Like a kid with his nose pressed to a candy store window, Charley Hustler will also find himself excluded at Cooperstown, and with good reason.

title: AS OLD AS YOU DRIVE
description: As a married pre-retiree, I savored every word of Virginia Van der Veer Hamilton's Hers column "As Old As You Drive" (March 10). I hope my "squeeze" and I cruise into retirement with as much style and humor as the Hamiltons. I'll be anxious to read what Ms. Hamilton will hear herself saying to the car salesman on her 80th birthday. MARIA NEKOS DAVIS New York, N.Y.

title: Managing; Putting the Best Face on Bankruptcy
description: ONE Saturday afternoon in September 1989, Jess Hay, the chief executive of the Lomas Financial Corporation, summoned the top officers of the troubled bank to an emergency meeting. The next morning, with 100 managers from around the country assembled at Lomas's Dallas headquarters, Mr. Hay broke the bad news: The company, with $6.5 billion in assets, would file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy that night.

title: What If This Is a 50-Year Drought?
description: THE California drought has been particularly difficult for businesses that rely heavily on water. Drastic cuts imposed by California's local water authorities have had a profound effect on businesses ranging from wineries to electronics manufacturers to paper and food processors.

title: Byting the S.A.T.
description: TAKING the two-and-a-half-hour Scholastic Aptitude Test is a ritual filled with anxiety for many students applying to college. By the year 2000, however, technological advances may substantially change what the test looks like and the way in which it is administered.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "While declaring that this resolution is unjust, they have found there was no other choice than to accept it in order to defeat the American-Zionist plot. We must sometimes, for our own good, accept that which displeases us."

title: Classes Once Removed
description: TECHNOLOGY was once taught in American schools almost as an afterthought -- tucked into science or social studies classes and limited to talks about inventions and inventors. Not anymore. As pressure mounts to shore up the nation's eroding technological edge, public schools are scrambling to play catch-up. Many efforts to upgrade technology instruction fall short of recommendations from the Federal Government and private groups.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SQUARING OFF By Leonard Todd. 150 pp. New York: Viking. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: An Obelisk For Korean Veterans
description: WHEN "The Universal Soldier," a monument to Korean War veterans, is unveiled on June 25 in Battery Park in Manhattan, a faculty member from the State University College at Old Westbury plans to watch. The 20-foot-tall black polished-granite obelisk with a stainless-steel cutout of a soldier was designed by Mac Adams, an assistant professor of visual arts at Old Westbury.

title: N.L. West: Will Dodgers Leave Rest in Their Stardust?
description: The National League preview was reported and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in order of predicted finish, with the Mets picked for third in the East. Los Angeles Dodgers

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Sunset Park
description: ALTHOUGH people of many ethnic backgrounds live in the 4.2-square-mile Brooklyn neighborhood of Sunset Park, residents and business owners say the community is more a stew pot than a melting pot.

title: Ann Luskey Plans Wedding in June
description: June wedding plans for Ann Keating Luskey and Matthew Ternan Weir, a son of Mrs. Bromley DeMeritt of Greenwich, Conn., and Anthony Weir of Exton, Pa., have been announced by her parents, Mrs. William C. Ramsay of Chevy Chase, Md., and E. Joseph Luskey of Washington.

title: Too Few Starters Concerns the Yanks
description: The last day of the Yankees' spring ended before it really began. In West Palm Beach, a torrential rain washed out their game against the Montreal Expos this afternoon, and the grounds at their home field were so wet that they couldn't even play an intrasquad game.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 7, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 25 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An F.B.I. man and woman track a serial killer. 2 5 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $5.95.) Jason Bourne plans to infiltrate the ruthless Medusa Brigade. 3 4 RED DRAGON, by Thomas Harris. (Dell, $5.95.) A retired F.B.I. agent returns to service to track down a serial killer. 4 5 BITTER SWEET, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Jove, $5.95.) A widow's ordeal after meeting an old flame, now a less than happily married man. 5 2 SKINNY LEGS AND ALL, by Tom Robbins. (Bantam, $5.95.) The horror and humor of the upcoming apocalypse, played out in a restaurant. 6 17 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 7 1 THE EVENING NEWS, by Arthur Hailey. (Dell, $5.95.) Life as lived by two competitive correspondents for a television network. 8 7 SLEEPING WITH THE ENEMY, by Nancy Price. (Berkley, $4.95.) To escape a cruel marriage, a woman fakes her death. 9 1 WHISPER TO ME OF LOVE, by Shirlee Busbee. (Avon, $4.95.) The passionate relationship of a street waif and a wealthy American planter in 18th-century London. 10 7 THE ANASTASIA SYNDROME: And Other Stories, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.95.) Five stories of romance and the macabre. 11 2 THE FIFTH PROFESSION, by David Morrell. (Warner, $5.95.) Two security agents try to rescue a woman held captive by her billionaire husband. 12 * 5 THE SCIONS OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $5.95.) The adventures of two brothers in a fantasy land. 13 2 A FLAG FULL OF STARS, by Brad Ferguson. (Pocket, $4.95.) Admiral Kirk and the Enterprise crew in a new "Star Trek" story. 14 6 THE GOLD COAST, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $5.95.) Life changes for an old WASP family when the head of a crime family becomes its neighbor. 15 1 AMERICAN PSYCHO, by Bret Easton Ellis. (Vintage, $11.) A yuppie of the 1980's on a round of sadistic murders and mayhem. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 3 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 34 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict over the past decade. 3 38 NO ONE HERE GETS OUT ALIVE, by Jerry Hopkins and Danny Sugerman. (Warner, $5.95.) The life of Jim Morrison, lead singer of the Doors. 4 72 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 5 12 NOT WITHOUT MY DAUGHTER, by Betty Mahmoody with William Hoffer. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An American woman held captive in Iran. 6 387 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 7 3 THE SEARCH FOR THE GREEN RIVER KILLER, by Carlton Smith and Tomas Guillen. (Onyx, $4.99.) A serial killer in Washington State. 8 6 A PEACE TO END ALL PEACE, by David Fromkin. (Avon, $14.95.) How, during 1914-22, the Allies laid the groundwork for Mideast conflicts. 9 27 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) A historian remembers her childhood on an Australian sheep farm. 10 * 119 LOVE, MEDICINE, AND MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper Perennial, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 11 * 1 BARBARIANS AT THE GATE, by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar. (Harper Perennial, $10.95.) The 1988 battle for control of RJR Nabisco. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 3 THE REVENGE OF THE BABY-SAT, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $7.95.) "Calvin and Hobbes" cartoons. 2 36 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) How to reduce fat in one's diet. 3 16 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. 4 19 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 5 124 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/HarperSanFrancisco, $8.95.) Solving your own problems while caring for other people. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Dollar Loses Momentum
Majors' Umpires Stop Work
description: Major league umpires stopped working yesterday and do not plan to work regular-season games beginning with tomorrow's opening-day schedule. The umpires' lawyer said the umpires were being locked out; the owners' chief negotiator said the umpires were engaged in a work stoppage.

title: Headliners; Learning Process
description: Bo Jackson, who knows baseball, football, endorsements and commercials, last week ended his brief acquaintance with unemployment. Jackson, who sustained a career-threatening hip injury while running the football for the Los Angeles Raiders three months ago, was released last month by his baseball team, the Kansas City Royals, after the team doctor concluded that the outfielder's career might be over. During the two-week waiver period that followed, no team showed an interest in taking on his $2.4 million Royals contract with no guarantee that he could play. But then Jackson was up for bids, and the Chicago White Sox spoke up. The team will pay him as little as $700,000 for one year or, if his hip and his hitting hold up, as much as $8.15 million over three years. But the deal could mean more to Jackson than any White Sox pay check. Since his football days are over, the end of his baseball career might also have meant an end to his endorsements, which reportedly bring him about $5 million a year.

title: China Province Forges Regional Trade Links
description: After watching for years as coastal China prospered because of its links with Hong Kong and Taiwan, the remote southwest of China is hoping to build a future on international trade as well, by cultivating growing exchanges with Myanmar, Laos and Vietnam.

title: A Past Too Horrible to Talk About
description: I REMEMBER NOTHING MORE The Warsaw Children's Hospital and the Jewish Resistance. By Adina Blady Szwajger. Translated by Tasja Darowska and Danusia Stok. Illustrated. 184 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $20.

title: A.L. East: Red Sox Hitters Go for Yet Another Flag
description: The American League preview was reported and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in order of predicted finish, with the Yankees picked for fifth in the East.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: What comes out of the mouth of babes? Sounds that often make nearby adults grind their teeth.

title: Within Limits
description: ARCHITECTURE IS NOT free verse. It's more like a sonnet: It demands creativity within a highly structured framework. Designing buildings is a struggle to make art within limits, to soar without wings, to make magic without pretending that the world is supernatural. It is the ultimate exercise in accommodating to reality.

title: Revisiting Japanese Internment
description: SOME 50 years after 120,000 Japanese-Americans were removed from thei homes and sent to detention camps, their grandchildren and the grandchildren of those who detained them are learning about this dark side of America's World War II policies.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: NEW ROCHELLE PUBLIC LIBRARY;
Making Ends Meet as Money Dwindles
description: KERRY FARAONE won't be at the New Rochelle Public Library this afternoon. Usually Mrs. Faraone and her family stroll into town on Sundays, to the library on Lawton Place, where they spend hours browsing and picking out books. But today their favorite destination is closed.

title: Priority: The Kitchen; Cook's Choice
description: FOR SIX MONTHS THIS kitchen was the only finished common room in a Manhattan apartment filled with packing boxes and sawdust, wet paint and dangling light switches. Explains Alison Spear, the New York architect who worked on the renovation: "The kitchen came first because it's the center of family life." Originally the space reflected the building's 1930 vintage: there was a narrow pantry and almost no place to work. Spear removed the wall between the pantry and kitchen to make room for a breakfast area, and replaced the dark vinyl floors with bleached wood. She also added a central work island with cabinets above it. "Not only is the island practical for cooking," says Spear, "it visually divides the working and dining spaces."

title: Players' Greed Tarnishes Game
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Displays of Artifacts Trace Nazi Propaganda
description: THE Holocaust most often brings to mind concentration camps or deportation trains full of emaciated people. But there were other events, as well as subtle social changes, that led up to the extermination policy of Nazi Germany. It is this mileu that is depicted through historical photographs, documents and artifacts from prewar Nazi Germany in an exhibit at Temple Israel of New Rochelle.

title: Gymnastics; Star-Spangled Romanian
description: In these times of heightened political sensitivities, there's nothing like good old American standards to energize a crowd, and that's precisely what Cristina Bontas intended today in a dual meet of leading female gymnasts from the United States and Romania.

title: Tossing Around the 'Quota' Bomb
description: There's probably no more incendiary epithet in present public discourse than the word quota . Americans see ambition, brains and hard work as the keys to success and they recoil from the idea of quotas -- rigid numerical expressions of preferment by race, sex, religion.

title: Nancy Ann Zoubek to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Zoubek of Holmdel, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Nancy Ann Zoubek and Taro John Kawamura, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Takeo Kawamura of Bangor, Me. Ms. Zoubek, 30 years old, and her fiance, 29, received law degrees from American University. Miss Zoubek, a graduate of Georgetown University, is an associate with the New York law firm of Pennie & Edmonds. Mr. Kawamura, a Bates College graduate, is an associate with the New York law firm of Dreyer & Traub.

title: Campus Life: Princeton; Senior Thesis Debated: Enrichment or Torture?
description: Huddled over their computers and encirled by stacks of books in the Firestone Library, bleary-eyed Princeton University seniors are scrambling to complete within the next week or so the hallmark of their "Princeton experience": the thesis, a research paper on the order of a Ph.D. dissertation.

title: Patricia Skinner Daly, Historian, 59
description: Patricia Skinner Daly, a historian and authority on foods of the Middle Ages and the Colonial period, died on Thursday at her home in Fairfield, Conn. She was 59 years old.

title: Judith Christy, Ad Executive, Is Wed To Rod Gilbert, Former Hockey Star
description: Judith Christy, a New York advertising executive, and Rod Gilbert, the former New York Rangers hockey star, who is now a Madison Square Garden executive, were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations. Mayor David N. Dinkins performed the ceremony.

title: Haiti's Spirits: Soaring to the Heavens, Wallowing in the Mud
description: THE Atrium Gallery, at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, is small and its current show large. Fifty photographs and 35 flags combine into a quilt that leaves hardly an inch of wall to spare. Organized by the gallery's director, Sal Scalora, the display is a celebration.

title: Dinkins's Request for Delay Gets a 'No' and a Rebuke From Vallone
description: In response to letters from Mayor David N. Dinkins asking the City Council for a month's delay in submitting a budget and criticizing the Council's own budget plan, Speaker Peter F. Vallone yesterday answered "no" to the first and dismissed parts of the second as "a cheap shot."

title: Stuart Scott Engaged to Ellen Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. James F. Smith of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Ellen Hawley Anne Smith, and Stuart Paul Scott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Scott of Syosett, L.I.

title: All About/Wall Street Technology; Wall Street's Cutbacks Sidestep Fat Budgets for High-Tech Trading
description: As Wall Street's investment houses shove thousands of employees out the back door, billions of dollars of high-technology equipment and software are being wheeled in the front. This is one of the Street's most significant structural changes in decades.

title: When There Were Giants in This Town . . .
description: THE HOME RUN HEARD 'ROUND THE WORLD The Dramatic Story of the 1951 Giants-Dodgers Pennant Race. By Ray Robinson. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $19.95.

title: Barbara Josephson to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Barry M. Josephson of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Barbara Sue Josephson and David Bruce Nemetz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Nemetz of Encino, Calif. Miss Josephson and her fiance are 24 years old and graduates of Lafayette College. She is an information systems coordinator at the Security Pacific Capital Corporation in Costa Mesa, Calif. He is the general manager of Oilab Inc., a lubrication and oil change service for fleet cars in Santa Ana, Calif.

title: Census Sees Changing Faces In the State's Urban Population
description: ON the West Side of Bridgeport, the Bon Ton used to be the favorite sports bar. Every night, blue-collar customers crowded into the place, where two television sets allowed them to cheer the Mets and Yankees at the same time. Those who preferred a more quiet evening sought sanctuary, and a few hands of pinochle, in the Bon Ton's Casino Room.

title: Derby Favorites Stumble in Preps
description: No clues and maybe no contenders were furnished for the Kentucky Derby in major prep races in New York and Florida yesterday when Cahill Road led a herd of favorites who went down to defeat in races around the country.

title: UConn's Newest Hybrids: Farmers for the 90's
description: WILLIAM CULLINA was a nature lover as a child, he said, growing his own garden from the time he was 6 years old and later teaching his friends to take care of the environment. He grew up and earned a psychology degree, but now the 26-year-old Mansfield Center resident is back at the University of Connecticut pursuing a degree and certification as a landscape architect.

title: New Equation For Saving Energy
description: MIX together a dedicated group of people with authority from the top, whip up awareness and support at the bottom and add a generous amount of dough. The result, according to Walter Simpson, is energy conservation a la mode.

title: Devils Looking to Sundstrom for Boost
description: Although Patrik Sundstrom's performance this season has bordered on mediocrity, given his usual standards, there are those in the New Jersey Devils camp who believe the team cannot advance in the Stanley Cup playoffs without him.

title: Biscuit Tins, Bird Cages and Bandboxes Aplenty
description: The most compelling of the disparate objects assembled in an exhibition at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in Manhattan are offbeat collectibles that range from an ancient Egyptian boat model to a see-through telephone, from a six-foot Roman-style iron radiator of the 19th century to a 1930's "Buck Rogers" pop-up book.

title: As American as Blue Jeans and Sweat Shirts
description: Strolling down a Key West street lined with porches can feel a bit like domestic window-shopping. There are moody porches with silent old men in rocking chairs, and gaudy porches whose sole occupant is a squawking parrot in a cage. There are grand porches with elegant wicker furniture and overhead fans, and sagging porches with cracked car seats and plants in old tin tubs. A cascade of bougainvillea can turn the most ordinary porch into a magical arbor. Some porches are primly restored but obviously unused, others have the comfortable, slightly grimy appearance of old, well-worn clothes. There are bohemian porches with wind chimes, yuppie porches with 12-speed mountain bikes, and proletarian porches with old, vinyl-covered armchairs. There are even eccentric porches, like the one built by Octavio Castillo in 1941, with V-for-Victory-shaped windows.

title: These Could Be Tomorrow's Stars
description: Jeff Bagwell 1b, Houston

title: The Nation; 1992 Election Is Far Off, But Not Far Enough for Some
description: IT is a measure of President Bush's strength and the opposition's woes that Democratic leaders have been selling a poignantly simple message in recent weeks: As one party strategist puts it, "Yes, Virginia, there will be a Presidential election in 1992."

title: Inquiry Begins Into Georgia Plane Crash
description: As investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board today began piecing together the causes of a commuter airliner crash that killed former Senator John G. Tower and 22 others, Elaine Gwin quietly grieved by the side of Touchstone Parkway.

title: Miss Schmaltz to Wed Jeffrey James Lasher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Robert Schmaltz of Wyomissing, Pa., and Darien, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Heide Ann Schmaltz, and Jeffery James Lasher, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard James Lasher of Chatham Township, N.J.

title: Five Sisters
description: CAROLINE'S DAUGHTERS By Alice Adams. 307 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: ORGANICALLY GROWN
description: In the article accompanying the organic recipes for children, the author describes adding honey to her child's cereal. She does not state how old her child was at the time, but your readers should not assume that honey is, in general, a viable alternative to sugar in infant feeding. Adding honey to the food of a baby who is less than a year old can pose serious health risks, as honey may contain bacterial spores that can cause infant botulism and lead to pneumonia and dehydration and, in certain cases, paralysis or death. LISA MARTIN New York, N.Y.

title: Van Slyke Makes a Big Catch
description: For two months, Bobby Bonilla and his agent, Dennis Gilbert, have publicly squabbled with the Pittsburgh Pirates over a contract. The Pirates offered $16 million for four years, but Bonilla rejected it, even when the Pirates reiterated the offer after he lost in arbitration and had to settle for a $2.4 million salary. The Pirates, in effect, wanted to give him $13.6 million for three extra years, but player and agent said no.

title: Campus Life: Rice; Collegial Advice Seeks to Prevent Sex Harassment
description: Professors at Rice University have approved a "collegial statement" to discourage amorous relationships between students and faculty members.

title: Rowing; Two U.S. Scullers Qualify for Classic
description: The United States today qualified two scullers for Sunday's final of the World Cup in opening-day heats of this year's 18th annual San Diego Crew Classic rowing event.

title: Mayor Dinkins: Every Day a Test
description: On a blustery afternoon last month, two of New York's top labor leaders mounted the steps of City Hall to blast the Mayor they had helped elect. "The head stinks," said Stanley Hill, leader of the city's largest municipal union. Barry Feinstein, president of the teamsters' local that represents city workers, exploded: "This administration is going into the toilet."

title: The Ballet By Special Olympians
description: JON MARTIN, a teacher and dancer at The Pennsylvania Ballet, was not prepared for the response he received when he showed a videotape of a professional performance to a new group of students a year and a half ago.

title: Emily R. Moran, Editor, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Bertrand Moran of Monroe, La., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emily Ruth Moran, to Ronald Peter Bianchini Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bianchini of Brooklyn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Harry T. Montgomery, Retired A.P. Executive
description: Harry T. Montgomery, a retired deputy general manager and vice president of The Associated Press, died on Thursday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Review/Dance From a Lessing Novel
description: Linda Rappaport calls her dance company House on Fire. But "The Last Child," which the troupe presented Thursday night at the Dia Center for the Arts in SoHo, generated more smoke of obfuscation than flames of revelation.

title: Refugees Escaping to Turkey Rely on Fellow Kurds for Aid
description: At a dismal refugee camp near this mountain outpost, it has become clear that if the Kurds who ran for their lives from Iraq are to survive their first few days at the Turkish border, it will be mainly because of help from fellow Kurds in Turkey.

title: Alice Glover Plans Wedding in June
description: Mrs. William Harvey Glover of Locust, N.J., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Alice Cecilia Glover and Paul Joseph McKeon, a son of Mrs. Peter Thomas McKeon and the late Mr. McKeon of Riverside, Conn. Miss Glover is also the daughter of the late Mr. Glover.

title:
The Executive Life;
It's Women, It's Power, But Not Much Is New
description: No doubt about it -- it was a most unusual sight. On a recent gray Saturday morning, hundreds of women picked their way through the trash-littered and otherwise deserted streets of Manhattan's West Side, headed for the huge Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and the 11th annual conference of the American Woman's Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit women's group.

title: No-Frills Spas, Western Style . . .
description: THE Western states are spa country, home to those luxury camps for adults, where guests stay in exquisite surroundings, wear themselves out with fitness classes and eat low calorie food disguised to look exciting, all for around $500 a day. But spa country also includes a handful of places where guests can partake of healthy food and hearty play at a much lower price.

title: 1941: An Unmatchable Summer
description: On a gleaming spring day in Florida 50 years ago, Joe DiMaggio, eager as usual to get to work, received a traffic ticket for speeding. As things turned out, so the exaggeration goes, it was the only time that the New York Yankees' center fielder was stopped during that enchanted year.

title: Stanford Freshman Stays Busy
description: For Monday-to-Friday people, this was a day off from work. For Summer Sanders, it was a day of work unlike any she had ever faced.

title: Data Bank/April 7, 1991
Bringing Theater to Young Audiences
description: WHEN it comes to arts education for young people, Mark and Gary Blackman, 34-year-old identical twins, not only look alike but also think alike.

title: The Stuff of Legend for Soap Opera Fans
description: JUST the other day, Nancy Hughes was at it again. Nancy bristled with disapproval as she encountered Dr. Susan Stuart in the hospital cafeteria. After all, everyone knew about Susan's one-night stand with Nancy's son, Bob, which had almost broken up Bob's marriage to Kim. Of course, Kim had earlier stolen Susan's husband. And Susan had helped Bob's stepson, Andy, that time he almost killed himself with carbon monoxide.

title: ORGANICALLY GROWN
description: I enjoyed Dulcie Leimbach's article "Organically Grown" (Children's Food, March 3). I had to laugh at myself as I thought about the hours I've spent searching for the perfect organic avocado, organic grains and goat's-milk yogurt for my 6-month-old.

title: Topics of The Times; Run Now; Move Later
description: It's a tossup who would be helped more, incumbents or challengers. But voters and democracy would surely gain if state lawmakers relaxed the residency rule for running in this year's special election for New York City Council.

title: Rerun Rights Proposal Angers Hollywood Studios
description: Hollywood movie studios and producers reacted angrily today to a proposal at the Federal Communications Commission that significantly expands television networks' rights to reruns of many of the programs they broadcast.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cambridge, Mass.;
Affordable Town Houses
description: A SLOW but steady stream of low-cost housing is coming on the market in this city of 95,802 residents.

title: A Recreation Center for Brownsville
description: Many Manhattan health clubs charge well over $1,000 a year for access to a swimming pool, a weight room, indoor basketball courts, pool tables and the other amenities available at a reborn recreation center that has opened in one of Brooklyn's poorest neighborhoods.

title: Back in Business; Iraq Is Left to the Mercy of Saddam Hussein
description: BY the time the United Nations Security Council agreed last week on the conditions for a permanent cease-fire in Iraq, the countries that fought Saddam Hussein had already, in effect, made their peace with him. After more than a month of civil war, the Council also finally condemned the Iraqi President for his bloody repression of the insurrections within his country, and some nations were planning to air-drop humanitarian aid to masses of Kurdish refugees fleeing his tanks and helicopter gunships. But these steps only underscored the political morass that President Bush, as the leader of the anti-Iraq coalition, found himself in when he decided to stand aside as Iraqi troops broke the back of the rebellions and the spirit of his people.

title: India Moves Against Kashmir Rebels
description: For three days in March, the people of Batamaloo, a middle-class neighborhood here, were victims of India's war against an independence movement it can no longer contain except by force.

title: Power Play
description: NOTHING COULD BE less a priority, it would seem, than acquiring yet another electronic object. Do we really need three-inch television sets or pocket organizers or portable piano keyboards or programmable remote controls? But electronic objects, it turns out, can become priorities even in the most difficult times. They serve as consolations and distractions, providing a sort of comforting hum when all else is unpredictable. With their mysteriously unmoving innards and seemingly magical influences, electronic objects offer a sense of power and control in a world otherwise beyond either. The more unexpected their form, the greater their appeal. A watch that can take one's blood pressure (Casio BP-100, $159.95), for example, or a remote control shaped like a pen (the Mitsubishi PRM-1, $49.95, for the company's televisions) are electronic fantasies that will find a home even in a recession. (Prices given here are list, but most of these products are available at discount.)

title: A Reminder
description: Daylight saving time resumed at 2 A.M. today. Clocks were set ahead one hour.

title: Miranda Richardson Is at Home
description: When Miranda Richardson was preparing for her role as Sidonie Reiger, a British translator whose life is thrown into chaos when her two children are kidnapped, in the current PBS series "Die Kinder," she had one question for Paula Milne, the writer of the drama: Did Sidonie wear cowboy boots?

title:
DANCE;
Measuring the Steps of a Giant
description: So, she has gone.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Diversifying Atlantic County's Tax Base
description: LIKE an old factory town, Atlantic County has relied heavily on one industry -- gambling -- for much of its tax base. But in the 15 years since gaming became legal, casinos have not fully delivered on their promises to help turn Atlantic City around and revitalize the county economy.

title:
END PAPER;
Education Amendments
description: IT'S ALWAYS hard to admit one's mistakes -- the little ones as well as the larger ons. But I've learned from personal experience that much of the pain can be diminished if you're willing to learn from those mistakes and do something to correct them.

title: Deaf Children Are Able to Create Their Own Sign Languages
description: To the Editor:

title: French or Caribbean? Take Your Choice
description: TRADITION and innovation now stand together on Sunrise Highway in Baldwin. Just about 100 fried-chicken lengths east of Raay Nor's nostalgic outpost of downhome cooking is the exciting new French-Caribbean Chez Antoine.

title: 'Miss Saigon' Flirts With Art and Reality
description: Art is the only method we have for stopping time, so it's our principal means of coming to terms with history. The popular arts go a long way toward forming a general perception of the common experience. This process can be seen at work in "Miss Saigon," a musical that seems derived in unequal parts from "Madama Butterfly," "West Side Story" and "South Pacific" and is set in wartime Saigon. It comes almost exactly 18 years after the last American troops left Vietnam and on the heels of another American overseas engagement with a far different outcome.

title: Safety Note
description: The New York City Fire Department recommends that smoke alarm batteries be changed twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight time. The date this spring is today.

title: The World; The 'Good Czar' And the Wise Men: A Sad Tale Retold
description: THE saga of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's shift to the right has been a field day for interpreters of the Russian soul.

title: A Playwright Summons the Ghost of John Barrymore
description: Denizens of the theater, particularly in those hand-wringing days before a show opens, are justifiably superstitious. Modern synthetics are the bane of such jitters: how can anybody knock on wood-grain Formica for luck? Omens are everywhere; a piece of furniture that I recently sold was innocently purchased by the set designer of my play, "I Hate Hamlet," due to open tomorrow at the Walter Kerr Theater. Imagine my shock when my oak table magically reappeared in Act II. "I Hate Hamlet" features the ghost of that legendary actor John Barrymore; during our rehearsal period, the cast and I decided that a seance was definitely in order.

title: Focus: Retirement Communities; Ripples From the Bay State's Soft Market
description: CHESTER W. NIMITZ JR., a retired rear admiral, might fairly feel entitled to a certain impatience with waiting lists.

title: Old Roslyn Church, Its Roof Leaking, Opens Fund Drive
description: WHEN Trinity Episcopal Church was built in Roslyn 85 years ago, it represented the convergence of three distinctive early 20th-century personalities, Stanford White, the architect; Louis Comfort Tiffany, the stained-glass artist, and Katherine Duer Mackay, wife of Clarence Mackay, heir to the silver fortune of the Comstock Lode and future mother-in-law of Irving Berlin.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Many of the ceiling tiles in our newly built house are stained by water. The floor of the attic crawl space is covered with a thick layer of insulation, and on inspecting the attic we found the insulation to be quite wet. There are vents near the peak at each end of the attic, and there is no sign of a roof leak. What could be causing the moisture problem that is staining our ceilings?

title: Why the Rich Should Pay an Extra Tax Share; System Dismantled
description: To the Editor:

title: On Taking a Larger View
description: To the Editor:

title: Company Cafeterias Adopt Menus To Help Heart
description: THE Heart Healthy salad that Bonnie Lorber, a video-communications specialist at Lilco, made for herself at the company cafeteria's salad bar, was low in calories, cholesterol, fat and sodium.

title: Social Events
description: For Young Musicians April 9 -- A concert at 8 P.M. in memory of the late soprano Eleanor Steber at the Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall will benefit New Music for Young Ensembles, which sponsors an annual competition for American composers. The group will present the world premieres of "Woodwind Quintet" by Joelle Wallach for flute, clarinet and piano by Ronn Yedidia. The Arioso Trio, the Meridian Quartet, the soprano Marni Nixon and the pianist and arranger Peter Howard will be among the performers. George Jellinek is the host. Dessert and a reception at the Carnegie Cafe in the hall will follow the concert. Tickets $35; (212) 601-0085. Broadway Cares

title: Article 599992 -- No Title
description: Tolls on the six Port Authority bridges and tunnels went up today, rising for passenger cars by $1, to $4.

title: Ellen A. Kiernan To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Kiernan of New Scotland, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Ellen Ann Kiernan and Jeffrey John Ayers, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William B. Ayers of Old Brookville, L.I.

title: Miss Sciutto Marries T. D. Hooper 2d
description: Ellen Higgins Sciutto, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest S. Sciutto of New York, was married yesterday to Thornton Dayton Hooper 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce H. Hooper of Newtown Square, Pa. The Rev. Robert Haskins officiated at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Fundamental Things Apply: It's Baseball Time
description: You must remember this," Stump Merrill began.

title: Black Businesses Work in Schools
description: NEAR the Robert Taylor public-housing project on Chicago's South Side, the Soft Sheen Products Company has developed a special relationship with Beethoven Elementary School. Executives of Soft Sheen, which manufactures hair-care products and is the nation's sixth-largest black-owned company, make themselves available for a host of programs, from developing parents' associations to helping establish tutorial programs.

title: The Cultivated Gardener; The Rigors of Double Digging in Pursuit of Bounty
description: Ever since I dug my first pea trench, I have done so in the shadow of the great double-digging myth.

title: 'Cross My Heart' Learns Its Lessons From Children
description: When he completed "Cross My Heart" last spring, Jacques Fansten recalls thinking he had made "a nice little film." And why not? It was certainly "little" -- it cost only $1.5 million. It was also an unusual story of a group of 12-year-old schoolchildren closing ranks around Martin, one of their number whose mother dies suddenly. The 45-year-old director had enjoyed making it; friends had enjoyed watching it.

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.; Salute to Women At a School Once 99.6% Male
description: When Ellen Swallow Richards came to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in January 1871, she was the first woman to attend the institute, then based in Boston. One woman and 250 men made up that historic coeducational class.

title: Ann Weinbaum, Physician, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander S. Weinbaum 3d of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Ann Kay Weinbaum, to William Bennett Sacher, the son of Philip Sacher of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Esther Sacher. A November wedding is planned.

title: Colleges Break Up Dangerous Liaisons
description: EROTIC component in teaching? Look at Socrates, Heloise and Abelard, Patty Hearst and Steven Weed. Almost everyone has heard of such teacher-student liaisons. But colleges and universities have increasingly been legislating on them. Some policies warn; others forbid. All attempt to deter a practice that looks more reprehensible now than it did a generation ago.

title: Brooke Mallory, Decorator, Weds
description: Brooke April Mallory was married yesterday to Julian Marquis Russell, the son of Diana Caprara of London and the late Victor Russell. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Mallory of New York and Snedens Landing, near Palisades, N.Y. The Rev. Laurie Ferguson officiated at the Presbyterian Church in Snedens Landing.

title: Miss Silverman to Wed S. R. Lapidus
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Silverman of West Long Branch, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Amy Silverman, to Stephen R. Lapidus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Lapidus of Clark, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

title: ART VIEW: Mike Kelley's Toys Play Nasty Games
description: It is no accident that Mike Kelley's show here at the Hirshhorn Museum summons up thoughts of carnivals and freak shows. Two galleries are filled with more than 30 of the objects he has put together from discarded toys, stuffed dolls and afghans. A giant, wide-eyed pink snake dominates the floor of one room, a loose-limbed leopard lies atop a blanket in a corner nearby, and from the ceiling and on the walls hang dozens of monkeys, rabbits, piglets, bears and other brightly colored animals sewn or placed together by Mr. Kelley in various combinations.

title: Stargazers Offer Guided Tours of the Sky
description: EVERY week, people in Westport enjoy an unusual night out, a majestic encounter with explosions of energy in a vast, celestial theater. Each Wednesday at the Rolnick Observatory, members of the Westport Astronomical Society offer a tour of the planets, stars, nebulae and other objects in the night sky through a 12.5-inch Newtonian reflector telescope.

title: How a Computer Can Carry a Tune

title: Miss Meek, Democrats' Aide, to Wed
description: The engagement of Katherine Amy Meek to Thomas Joseph Lehner, a son of Mary Lehner of Truckee, Calif., and the late Robert J. Lehner, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Phillip J. Meek of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Tribute to Black and Indian Whalers
description: THE exploits of Connecticut's whaling industry have been attributed to white, mainly Anglo-Saxon crews. But a multimedia presentation being prepared for the Charles W. Morgan, the 150-year-old whaling ship at Mystic Seaport, tells of the role of blacks and American Indians in the great voyages, adventures and ecological disasters of whaling.

title: Corrections
description: Two articles today in Education Life, section 4A, carry reversed headlines and bylines. "Inventive Curriculums," by William Celis 3d, appears on page 20; "Classes Once Removed," by Roberto Suro, is on page 21.

description: A police officer's leg was broken yesterday morning when she was struck by an out-of-control car just as a Little League parade was about to begin in Harlem, the police said.

title: HEADSTRONG: CHARLES BARKLEY
description: Those who expect Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers to fall into the ready mold of athletic superstardom underestimate him. As Jeff Coplon adroitly points out in his article "Headstrong" (March 17), Barkley succeeds precisely because of his immersion in the game.

title: A Canyon Ranch In the Berkshires
description: CANYON RANCH IN THE BERKSHIRES seems less like a name than an oxymoron. There are no canyons in the Berkshires, and there are surely no ranches. What kind of a place is this?

title: Chess
description: How do you win by defense? You persevere ingeniously.

title: Plane Crashes
description: To the Editor: I have been a flight attendant for almost 22 years and wish to offer additional information on survival after a crash: First and foremost the passenger must take responsibility for his or her safety and be prepared to do what is necessary to survive. Passengers who ignore safety briefings are endangering not only themselves but also everyone else on the aircraft.

title: Suffolk Moves To 2d Phase Of Buying Watersheds
description: J. STEWART McLOUGHLIN, a lawyer from Bay Shore, pays $9.09 a year in property taxes for sixth-tenths of an acre of pine barrens he owns south of the Long Island Expressway.

title: The World: A Word to the Wily; Nixon Sizes Up Soviets
description: RICHARD M. NIXON did not conceal his empathy with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political plight. At the end of a hectic two-week tour of the Soviet Union last week, the former American President advised Mr. Gorbachev not to believe that another grand summit meeting could salvage his sagging fortunes. "Even by our standards some summits do not help an American president at home, as I am well aware," Mr. Nixon, now 78 years old, said with a hint of a wink.

Subtly and not so subtly, they change music's evolution, whether by perfecting the repeater action on a piano key or finding a snare-drum sound that suits a microchip.

The floor of the attic crawl space is covered with a thick layer of insulation, and on inspecting the attic we found the insulation to be quite wet. title: Ideas & Trends; How Accurately Does The Government Measure The Pinch of Inflation?
description: TO many consumers, suffering such real-life financial jolts as $140 traffic tickets, $50 drugstore prescriptions and $1,000-plus annual increases in college tuitions, the nation's official retail inflation gauge seems somewhat disconnected from reality.

title: India
description: To the Editor: While in Banglaore, India, last year I purchased several artifacts from Natesan's Antiquarts. This was supposedly a well-known establishment with several offices in India. After they were unable to package my purchases so that I could take them with me they told me that they would charge me $150 all inclusive to have the items delivered in New York. When the items arrived, there were other fees of approximately $60 due. When I wrote to Natesan's for reimbursement, they ignored their commitment and stated that the fees were "probably some port charges and incidental expenses." They added that they themselves had incurred additional expenses but did not bill us for them as we were "an esteemed customer."

title: A Bedazzled Critic Finds Oz, in Paris
description: A recent trip to Europe brought visions of cultural grandeur and impoverishment. Unfortunately, the impoverishment was not so much in the eastern parts of Germany, where cultural pride remains high despite severe economic woes, but looking back cross the ocean, in the United States.

title: Sheryl Meyers Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Meyers of New York have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Sheryl Lynn Meyers and Mark Alexander Young, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Young of Chelmsford, Mass. Miss Meyers, 30 years old, and Mr. Young, 33, are certified public accountants. She graduated from the University of Delaware and is a consultant in the Boston office of Source Services Inc., a national executive recruiting firm. Mr. Young graduated from Boston College and is the treasurer of Cambridge Neuroscience, a biotechnology company in Cambridge, Mass.

description: ONE SHINING SEASON By Michael Fedo. Pharos, $16.95.

description: My eyes flickered past the recent headline "Requiring Helmets for Young Skiers," with a casual thought that it was probably not a bad idea.
