description: Morrissey: 'Kill Uncle' Sire 26514; CD and cassette.

title: A NEED FOR HOME
description: THE HUMAN NEED for richly nurturing surroundings is so pervasive and so fundamental that wherever we are -- at home, at work, on the road or on vacation and away from it all -- we have to have places around us that nourish our eyes, our ears and all our senses simultaneously to be able to flourish as human beings and feel at home with ourselves. Indeed, there's now a lot of evidence that in any kind of diminished setting -- not just in slums or public schoolrooms 20 feet away from rumbling, screeching elevated trains, but also in places generally considered clean and neat and adequate to their purposes -- our health can deteriorate, and even our judgment can be impaired. One hospital study found that patients recovering from surgery who could look out their windows and see leafy trees rather than blank brick walls required milder painkillers and recovered faster. In fact, they were released from the hospital almost a day sooner than patients who had to stare at a featureless and unchanging view.

title: Travel Advisory; Grand Central Trains Rerouted To Penn Station
description: In a move that will affect one million passengers a year, all Amtrak trains bound for Grand Central Terminal will, beginning today, go to Pennsylvania Station instead. The project will shift 20 trains a day serving upstate New York and Canada to Penn Station, which has had about 100 Amtrak trains a day carrying 5.5 million passengers a year, according to an Amtrak spokesman, R. Clifford Black 4th. Only Metro-North commuter trains, primarily serving Connecticut and Westchester County, will continue to use Grand Central.

title: Ms. Kassanoff to Wed Daniel H. Schulman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Kassanoff of Dallas have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Jennie Ann Kassanoff, and Daniel Harris Schulman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Schulman of Princeton, N.J.

title: U.S. QUIZZES W.H.O. ON ABORTION PILL
description: The State Department has demanded an accounting from the World Health Organization on whether American funds are going to promote the use of RU-486, the French abortion pill.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the sale of assets of failed savings and loan institutions misidentified the government body that gave the Resolution Trust Corporation permission to extend credit to some purchasers. It was the corporation's oversight board. Two picture captions with the article were reversed. The CenTrust Tower was at the upper right; the Colorado First Building was shown below it.

title: The Region; Why City Election Funds Go Begging
description: NEW YORK CITY'S offer of matching funds for candidates for local office -- designed to make the odds more even between incumbents and challengers and to encourage more candidates to take on solidly entrenched officeholders -- is about to face its second and potentially crucial test after a shaky start.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT J. LANDY;
Looking Behind the Roles People Play
description: ALL people, regardless of age, play roles, sometimes constant roles, sometimes changing ones. By understanding these roles, a person can gain insight into his own personality. This is one of the premises of drama therapy -- a therapy that uses role-playing and action as tools instead of relying primarily on verbal analysis.

title: Travel Advisory; Busy in Paris
description: The American Embassy in Paris warns that hotel accommodations in the city will be extremely difficult to obtain from May 30 to June 24 because of various events, including the Paris Air Show. Visitors should make sure before arrival that they have confirmed reservations. Deposits are required to hold reserved rooms during this period, the embassy reports, adding that cancellations must be made at least a week in advance.

title: Students Are Profiting From Business Lessons
description: ASHLEY C. CIMINI and her classmates at Wilton High School recently became entrepreneurs for a semester, learning that running a business is not all glamour and easy money.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: ROBERT PELTON;
Recalling Barnum, Pioneer of Promotion
description: ONE hundred years ago today, the showman P. T. Barnum died in his Bridgeport home. Barnum was the leading contributor to the 19th-century development of the city, said Robert Pelton, who has served as curator of the Barnum Museum for 15 years and helped supervise its $7 million renovation, which was completed two years ago. Last year, the museum attracted 50,000 visitors.

title: Wendy Dreier to Marry
description: July wedding plans for Wendy L. Dreier and Simon C. Ditcham, the son of Pauline Bradbury of Pooland Colin Ditcham on the Isle of Wight in England, have been announced by her parents, Carol A. Cudia of San Francisco and Gustav H. Dreier of Stoughton, Mass. Miss Dreier, 24 years old and a Princeton University graduate, is a systems analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York. Mr. Ditcham, 23, graduated from Exeter University in England and is a senior consultant at Seer Technologies, a systems consulting company in San Francisco.

title: The Region: Q & A -- Klepper of the T.A.; Keeping Riders In the Hard Stretch That Lies Ahead
description: ALAN F. KIEPPER, president of New York City's Transit Authority, took charge 13 months ago after an eight-year career in the Houston transportation system and 10 years in Atlanta's. His agency now has a $215 million budget gap, and service cuts and fare increases are almost certain. In an interview last week with Stephanie Strom, a reporter for The Times, Mr. Kiepper discussed the system, which transports millions of riders daily in 3,565 buses and over more than 700 miles of tracks, and what those riders might expect in a time of financial crisis. Here are excerpts from the interview.

title: Heard the One About the Madcap Trill?
description: Can music itself, without recourse to verbal description, text or stage action, express humor? This is a question that concerns the Austrian pianist Alfred Brendel, who will perform at Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening. Mr. Brendel's new collection of essays and interviews, "Music Sounded Out" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), includes a chapter called "Must Classical Music Be Entirely Serious?." He explored the subject further in a recent conversation with Bernard Holland, a music critic of The Times.

title: Briton and Chinese Still Split on Hong Kong Airport Plan
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, pledged today to consult China on matters relating to Hong Kong's future but acknowledged that he had been unable to reach agreement with Chinese leaders on a major new port and airport complex for Hong Kong.

title: Gulf Oil Spill Vexing Cleanup Efforts
description: Oil spilled during the Persian Gulf war had for weeks been largely contained by favorable winds and a notch in the coastline north of here, but it has begun spreading more widely, although substantial progress is being made in scooping up oil still on the water.

title: The Answers
description: 1. President Herbert Hoover in March 1930.

title: Style Makers; Ira and Judy Rosen, Ballpark Photographers
description: When Ira Rosen goes out to the ball game, he takes his camera. Last October he and his wife, Judy, formed Stadium Views, a company that seeks, in large color photographs, to capture fans' attachment to ballparks.

title:
Northeast Notebook: West Warwick, R.I.;
Minimalism For $94,900
description: A DEVELOPER who specializes in partially finished starter homes has completed the first of 167 units in a new subdivision. All are priced at $94,900, $30,000 below the state's median price for a one-family house.

title: Pressing to Save Jobs From Pentagon Cuts
description: MOUNTING concern over the survival of some of the region's largest military installations has sparked a vigorous lobbying effort in New Jersey and on Capitol Hill.

title: A Spectator in Morocco
description: DAYS

title: Pedaling Their Way Across America
description: WHEN you travel at 10 miles per hour, the world has time to wave. That's what I liked most about the TransAmerica bicycle trail: as my college friend and I crept across 4,500 miles of back roads from Astoria, Ore., to Yorktown, Va., people couldn't help but smile at the sight of two disheveled vagabonds atop bicycles overloaded like pack horses. Pedestrians struck up conversations, farmers offered us fruit, motorists questioned our sanity. And everywhere we were greeted with a friendly wave.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Cambridge, Mass.;
Affordable Town Houses
description: A SLOW but steady stream of low-cost housing is coming on the market in this city of 95,802 residents.

title: Postings: Coming in Beacon; New, Bigger Courthouse
description: Justice will finally prevail under better circumstances in Beacon, N.Y., once a building for a new courthouse and police station is completed on Fishkill Avenue in November 1992.

title: Action Criticized
description: Action taken by Arkansas basketball Coach Nolan Richardson and Athletic Director Frank Broyles following a sexual incident involving basketball players wasn't as fast or as stern as the university's chancellor wanted.

title: Priority: Staying Put; Same Space, Different Face
description: JUAN MONTOYA ADMITS IT WOULD HAVE been easier to move. "I did look for a new apartment," says the interior designer. "But this one really had everything I wanted." Originally, the one-bedroom Manhattan apartment had to function as both Montoya's residence and work room. Now he has a large, separate office. "I do still need a place for guests to sleep, however," explains the designer, "which is why I designed the sofa and ottoman so that they can join together to become a bed." Esthetically, Montoya's priorities had also changed over 15 years. When he first got the apartment, he decorated it in 70's minimalism. The walls, stripped of architectural details, were painted white. "I wanted the apartment to float in the skyline," recalls the designer. "This time, I tried to capture the building's historical flavor."

title: I.O.C. and Rights: Double Standard?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 24 Hours in Due East, S.C.
description: WHO DO YOU LOVE By Valerie Sayers. 325 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: 'Comfort' Unsettles the Nerves
description: The first chuckle in "The Comfort of Strangers" comes at the very start. A voice that turns out to be Christopher Walken's speaks in a mongrel-European accent that is probably, given the backdrop of Venice, meant to be Italian. "My father was a very big man," the voice says with slow solemnity. But when he gets to the line "I was his favorite," it sounds a little too much like "I was his ferret" to be taken seriously.

title: Japan's Sleight of Hand in Trade . . .
description: America's trade deficit with Japan often serves as a rallying point against adversarial Japanese trade practices, but because of the gulf war, the Commerce Department's release of the 1990 trade figures passed almost unnoticed.

title: Cartoon Hero's Message to Children: Let's Help Others

title: New York's Economy: Rebound Seems Distant
description: The New York metropolitan region, which began an economic slide before the rest of the nation, will lag behind a national turnaround, according to several recent forecasts.

title: Nassau County Divorce Lawyers Bask in National Attention
description: WHEN Leonore Grossman saw her eight-year marriage breaking up in 1985, she hired Joel Brandes, a divorce lawyer in Garden City, to represent her. "I needed the best I could get," Ms. Grossman said.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: San Jose
description: San Jose has more reasons to crow these days as it continues its rivalry with its northerly neighbor, San Francisco. In the past few years, San Jose has worked hard to shed its stodgy image and has emerged as not only the largest city in northern California -- surpassing San Francisco in 1989 with a population of 765,000 -- but the one with the smartest new downtown. The $1 billion-plus redevelopment project, begun eight years ago, has given the city a new vibrancy. The downtown area, once deserted after hours, now teems on weekends with crowds gathered at the spruced-up Plaza Park for festivals or free concerts. New restaurants, museums and nightclubs are also luring people downtown. A comfort for those taking advantage of these offerings is that since 1988 San Jose has had the lowest overall crime rate in the nation among cities with a population of 400,000 or more.

title: St. Agnes Is Put on a Path To Self-Sufficiency
description: ST. AGNES HOSPITAL, an 85-year-old institution widely perceived to be at death's doorstep a few months ago, emerged last week from a series of consultations with a smaller staff, new medical roles and improved chances for a complete recovery.

title: The World; Club of Europe Is Seething About the Greeks
description: LIKE members of an exclusive club, European governments usually say polite things about one another. But in the Brussels headquarters of the European Community and among its diplomats stationed here, the snarling is getting louder about the black sheep in their midst. No government has said so publicly, but most Community members are now stating privately that it was a mistake to invite Greece into their group.

title: Norman Cohen Is Dead; Condo Builder Was 67
description: Norman Cohen, former president of the Cohen Brothers Dress Corporation in Manhattan and a Florida real-estate developer, died on Wednesday at the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Miami. He was 67 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Food; A Bird in Hand . . .
description: When Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin wrote about the pheasant in 1825, he warned that the bird must be aged to the "peak of ripeness" to achieve its tenderness. That peak, he wrote, is reached only when the pheasant "begins to decompose" and its "aroma develops." He was speaking here (in the classic M. F. K. Fisher translation of "The Physiology of Taste") of a bird that has now all but disappeared from much of the United States. The wild pheasant of Brillat-Savarin's reveries is a tough customer indeed -- feisty and active in the wild -- a bird that requires quite a bit of aging (that is, digestion by the natural environment) before it is ready for human consumption.

title: March Madness, Mad Money
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BORGE IN PURCHASE

title: Shari Stein to Marry Andrew Munitz
description: The engagement of Shari Lynn Stein to Andrew Samuel Munitz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton K. Munitz of Scarborough, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Stein of Pueblo, Colo. An August wedding is planned.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THE morning sounds began filtering through the window. First the wake-up call of a song sparrow. Then a cardinal sounding reveille. Then a crow. Then a turkey. Then the Canada geese trumpeting like heralds.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Darien, Conn. 450,000 23 Old Parish Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old ranch; recently repainted inside and outside, screened porch, walk to station, 1 acre; taxes $4,841. New Canaan, Conn. 739,000 90 Parade Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial; 2-story entry, 3 fireplaces, pool, 1.3 acres; taxes $6,386. Norwalk, Conn. 131,000 22 Todd Road. 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old ranch; roof, gutters and siding replaced, needs work, 1/3 acre; taxes $2,607. Bronxville, N.Y. 275,000 93 Kensington Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 71-year-old town house; fireplace, screened porch, Jacuzzi, 1-car garage; taxes $5,640. Chappaqua, N.Y. 522,700 54 Seven Bridges Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 29-year-old colonial; library, deck, studio, rec room, workshop, 1.5 acres; taxes $7,218. Larchmont, N.Y. 250,000 283 Murray Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 66-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, deck, 2-car detached garage; taxes $6,483. OTHER AREAS Bridgewater, N.J. 170,000 96 Hillside Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; family room, deck, eat-in-kitchen, porch; taxes $2,472. Monroe, N.J. 225,000 180 Old Forge Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 4-year-old ranch; 4 skylights, deck, Jacuzzi, eat-in-kitchen; taxes $3,100. East Patchogue, L.I. 129,900 9 Neptune Street, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 17-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage, pool; taxes $3,200.

title: The Lord's Boy in the Blue Ridge Mountains
description: GOSPEL HOUR

title: Sunday Outing; Chinatown: More Than Restaurants
description: Manhattan's Chinatown is for the adventurous shopper who delights in a treasure hunt and considers a babel of foreign dialects -- Shanghai-ese, Cantonese, Mandarin, Fukienese, Toisan and more -- music to the ear.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Amateur on the Podium

title:
DINING OUT;
A Tiny Place With a Sophisticated Menu
description: ALTHOUGH Culinary Renaissance sounds awfully grand for a shoebox cafe beside the railroad tracks in the Middlesex County town of Metuchen, the pretentious name does justice to the generally superb food served there.

title: Political Talk
description: Selling New York Assets

title: Why Mr. Right Shouldn't Handle Your Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Many of the ceiling tiles in our newly built house are stained by water. The floor of the attic crawl space is covered with a thick layer of insulation, and on inspecting the attic we found the insulation to be quite wet. There are vents near the peak at each end of the attic, and there is no sign of a roof leak. What could be causing the moisture problem that is staining our ceilings?

title: New Ways to Teach Students to Think
description: I was extremely pleased to read the article "Medical Ethics: A New Way to Teach Students to Think" (March 3) as I greatly value approaches that challenge and engage students while developing their thinking skills.

title: New Zealand
description: To the Editor: Having just completed a yearlong visit to New Zealand, I was pleased to see mention of that country's network of Youth Hostel Association hostels (Travel Advisory, Feb. 17). These homey, cheap hostels are pleasant places to retire for the night. Prospective hostelers should know, however, that policies vary. At some, unmarried couples may not be permitted to room together. At others, enjoying a bottle of wine with your dinner may be forbidden.

title: 'Other Boroughs'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Lord of the Rings Is Called de Sade
description: I don't want to be thought perverse, especially considering the lengths to which the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus is going to wrap up its 121st edition in an orgy of patriotism. I mean, all the performers -- dozens of them -- are waving starry banderoles, showers of white confetti are raining down from on high, while strains of "America, the Beautiful" are filling up Madison Square Garden to the brim. Even the sequins seem to be blaring out a deeply held belief in the country's goodness.

title: Diamond in the Booth
description: Watch Ernie Harwell talking to players during pregame batting practice. He gets grins from everybody; they all love him. He knows the game inside and out and has all kinds of stories to tell, hundreds of them packed into ERNIE HARWELL'S DIAMOND GEMS (Momentum Books, 210 Collingwood, Suite 106, Ann Arbor, Mich. 48103, $17.95) -- stories about some of the greats, about phenoms who lit up briefly and burned out, about managers and umpires. And there are some memorable one-liners. For example, here's Brooklyn Dodger Manager Charlie Dressen: "Just hold them for a few innings, fellas. I'll think of something." Umpire Bill Klem: "It ain't nothin' till I call it." Mickey Mantle: "All I have is natural ability." Ernie's another natural, with a plaque in the Baseball Hall of Fame. His first major-league broadcast was a Dodgers-Cubs game at Ebbets Field on Aug. 4, 1948, when he filled in for Red Barber. Since then Ernie has broadcast for the New York Giants, the Baltimore Orioles and, since 1960, the Detroit Tigers. What no one can understand is why the Tigers' management is cutting Ernie loose following the 1991 season. Are they nuts? No one in baseball does a better play-by-play. They expected criticism, but not the blast they got from fans all over the country. One theory holds that the Tigers management wants to jazz up the team's image and feels that Ernie, at the age of 73, has become old hat. They see the Detroit Pistons raking it in at their suburban Palace, entertaining a full house at every basketball game with rap music and light shows, and they think, yeah, that's the way to go. What the Tiger bosses must fail to realize is that baseball moves at a much different tempo. Rather than razzle-dazzle, it's heavy on tradition, nostalgia, stats comparing new stars with the old greats. It has a sense of humor and an image epitomized by Ernie Harwell and his comfortable down-home Georgia delivery. What makes baseball so popular is what "Ernie Harwell's Diamond Gems" is about: the kind of stuff fans love to read and talk about, presented by a guy you can listen to all night. If we didn't have a written language, I think Ernie Harwell would be known as one of our great tribal storytellers -- if he isn't already.

title: Wine; Designer Seconds
description: Which is the better deal: a used 1987 Cadillac or a new 1991 Chevy at the same price? There are not many used wines around, but there is a roughly similar choice to be made in the wine market.

title: N.F.L. Calls End Run For Schools
description: VERY few school athletes become professional sports stars. Even fewer become an Archie Griffin, who won the Heisman Trophy twice at Ohio State University and was a running back for the Cincinnati Bengals in the National Football League.

title: On Language; A Foreign Affair
description: FROM R. E. (TED) Turner, founder of the broadcasting system that bears his name (I like those archaic formulations), has come this memo to personnel at his Cable News Network: "It is the policy of TBS that any person, event, etc. which [ sic ] is not part of the United States be referred to as international rather than foreign ."

title: Iran, Admitting Kurds, Says It Needs More Aid
description: Iran expressed concern today about the influx of Iraqi Kurds into its territory but called on its own citizens to offer immediate help. It also faulted other nations for indifference and insufficient aid.

title: On Installing a Ceiling
description: SUSPENDED or dropped ceilings are easy to install. Consisting of lightweight panels supported by a grid of metal strips hung from the existing ceiling, or from joists above an unfinished ceiling, they are an excellent way to conceal overhead pipes, ducts and wiring, as well as dilapidated ceilings too costly to repair.

title: The Yankee From Oklahoma
description: MY FAVORITE SUMMER 1956 By Mickey Mantle and Phil Pepe. Illustrated. 246 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: The World; Gorbachev's Plan Could Shock More Than Just Prices
description: IT was all pain and no gain for Soviet consumers last week. The prices of many staple goods doubled or tripled, but the wait to buy a kilo of sausage or a tin of sardines was just as long. Rather than affirming Moscow's ability to cope with crisis, the price shock further undermined the state's legitimacy: A system anchored on the promise of bread for the masses no longer seems able to deliver the goods, whatever the price.

title: Plane Crashes
description: To the Editor: Safe and expedient exiting lies with passengers. Passengers should be drilled on exit procedures. Doesn't anyone remember fire drills from elementary school? Even office buildings conduct building-wide fire drills, imposing a fine or penalty on workers who do not participate.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Thou Shall Not Allow Rose Into the Hall!
description: When Pete Rose's athletic alma mater opens the season as world champions in Cincinnati tomorrow, baseball's record hit master will be on the outside looking in. Like a kid with his nose pressed to a candy store window, Charley Hustler will also find himself excluded at Cooperstown, and with good reason.

title: Foyt Eager to Go
description: When you're 56 years old, broken bones don't mend as quickly as they once might have. But seven months after he shattered his legs and feet in a crash, A. J. Foyt is back at the wheel, preparing for his 34th Indianapolis 500.

title: Hers; The Smurfette Principle
description: This Christmas, I finally caved in: I gave my 3-year-old daughter, Sophie, her very own cassette of "The Little Mermaid." Now, she, too, can sit transfixed by Ariel, the perky teen-ager with the curvy tail who trades her voice for a pair of shapely legs and a shot at marriage to a prince. ("On land it's much preferred for ladies not to say a word," sings the cynical sea witch, "and she who holds her tongue will get her man." Since she's the villain, we're not meant to notice that events prove her correct.)

title: Samantha Mclean Planning to Marry William Halsey Spruance Jr. in July
description: July wedding plans for Samantha Mclean and William Halsey Spruance Jr., a son of Sydney Spruance and Mr. Spruance, both of Wilmington, Del., have been announced by her parents, Mrs. Randall W. Hackett of New York and Locke Mclean of London.

title: The Best Part of Every Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Republicans Propose Budget Without State Income Tax
description: State Republican leaders unveiled a 1991-92 budget without a state income tax today, and voted to begin discussions with Democrats on preparing an alternative to Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s budget.

title: Holly Lord to Wed in July
description: July wedding plans for Holly Lynn Lord and Edward R. Jenkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Jenkins of Pittsburgh, have been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. George M. Lord of Bucksport, Me. Miss Lord, 29 years old, is a consultant with Travcorps, a nurse placement agency in Boston. She graduated from the University of Maine. Mr. Jenkins, 28, is a vice president at Bank of Tokyo Financial Services in Boston. He graduated from Colby College.

title:
ART;
Using the Camera to Record Details of Her Surroundings
description: SONIA GECHTOFF, the current artist in residence at Adelphi University in Garden City, has long been interested in the juxtaposition of constructed and natural forms. Her paintings use the rational structures of architecture and engineering as foils for the random, sometimes chaotic rhythms of water, clouds and the organic forms of plant life.

title: Wall Street; Tidying Up That Old Bottom Line
description: As usual, hard times are producing soft earnings.

title: A Soviet Childhood
description: IN THE BEGINNING By Irina Ratushinskaya. Translated by Alyona Kojevnikov. 320 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: An Easygoing Spa
description: CONSIDERING that my profession requires spending five to six hours a day amassing calories in restaurants, when thoughts turn to vacation I often look for places that offer exercise along with relaxation. At the same time, my wife and I also gravitate toward beaches. Caribbean spas, of which there have been an increasing number in recent years, combine both.

title: How to Limit Everybody's Missiles
description: Now that Washington's abuzz with schemes to control Middle East weaponry, let's push one arms control scheme that's straightforward, timely, effective and verifiable: Expand the bilateral ban on intermediate-range nuclear forces -- the I.N.F. treaty that Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev signed in 1987 -- into a multilateral treaty that bans Scud-type missiles.

title: Susan Roberts to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Roberts of Asheville, N.C., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter, Dr. Mary Susan Roberts, and Dr. Sander Warren Leivy, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David M. Leivy of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. Dr. Roberts, who is known as Susan, and her fiance are 30 years old and are residents at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont in Burlington, she in radiology and he in neurosurgery. She graduated from Davidson College and received her M.D. degree from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Dr. Leivy graduated from Boston University and received his M.D. from Jefferson Medical College.

title: Earth Is Their Stage
description: AMERICAN students are notorious for their lack of knowledge about people and places beyond their homes, schools and hangouts. Programs like the excellent Carmen Sandiego series from Broderbund Software have helped remedy this weakness, but its maps are simplistic.

title: As Power Plant's Tax Share Drops, Town Seeks Ways to Compensate
description: LIKE a rich uncle who helps pay the rent when the money is short, Haddam has long relied on the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant to provide the funds for many town services. This fiscal year, taxes on the Connecticut Yankee plant will pay about $5 million of the town's $10.5 million budget. But starting next year, the plant's share of the municipal finances will begin to decline dramatically.

title: LeMond to Race In Tour du Pont
description: Greg LeMond, three-time Tour de France winner, and Eric Breukink of the Netherlands will head a field of 126 riders in the first Tour du Pont.

title: Mexico's Leader to Defend Trade Pact in U.S.
description: In an effort to rally political support for a proposed North American free-trade agreement, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is to make a campaign-style trip to the United States and Canada beginning Sunday.

title: A Ural Spring Thaw, an Ideology Clog
description: A great weariness from all the talk of distant Moscow democracy is evident among the people here as the first thaw of the Ural spring flows down Lenin Street.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Where Youngsters Go for Fun and to Hone Skills
description: If your children are looking for something beyond the usual summer camp experience, Adventure Quest in Woodstock, Vt., may be the answer.

title: The Nation; Atlanta and the Olympics: The Games Have Already Begun
description: WHEN Atlanta pulled off the remarkable coup of being chosen to host the 1996 summer Olympics, it marked the culmination of a zealous marketing effort aimed at portraying an image of unity, prosperity and racial harmony.

title: Rockwell's Point Man in the Health-Care Campaign
description: The bad news comes in a telephone call to Daniel P. Heslin, the employee-benefits director of the Rockwell International Corporation. Doctors attending to an employee report that she has leukemia. They want to do a bone marrow transplant. The cost: more than $100,000. Will Rockwell pay?

title: A Bounty of Recitals On the State's Campuses
description: GOING to school this week can yield delights from concertos to cabaret, from a duo for double basses to a trio of shakuhachi, koto and shamisen.

title: The World; Jittery Asia Has Visions Of a Nuclear North Korea
description: THE destruction of Saddam Hussein's nuclear capability in the opening hours of the Persian Gulf war was met with more than a little cheering here. It was the right idea, a senior South Korean official said recently, adding with a wry smile, "too bad it was the wrong reactor."

title: Amy Wheeler to Wed T. P. Sullivan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Wheeler of Northford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy L. Wheeler to the Rev. Thomas P. Sullivan, a son of Dr. Cornelius H. Sullivan and the Rev. Dr. Virginia S. Sullivan of Westerly, R.I. A June wedding is planned.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
'Teachers, Quit That Shushing'
description: AFTER long pursuit of quiet, orderly classrooms, teachers are being urged to consider the educational advantages of organized cacophony.

title: 56 Die in Cuban Derailment, Country's Worst Rail Crash
description: A crowded Cuban passenger train traveling from Havana to the eastern city of Guantanamo derailed in darkness early today, killing 56 people and injuring more than 200, Cuba's Transport Ministry said.

title: Gooden Can Use Some Backing Up
description: Dwight Gooden will emerge from the Shea Stadium dugout at 3:08 P.M. tomorrow and stride to the center of the diamond. He will accept the baseball from the umpire and remove his cap for the opening day national anthem.

title: Those Who Died on Flight 2311
description: Here are the names and hometowns of the victims from Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311, which crashed and burned Friday outside Brunswick, Ga., killing all 23 people on board. The list does not include the identity of one passenger, which is being withheld until relatives are notified. Crew CRABTREE, Cindy Crabtree, Atlanta, flight attendant. FRIEDLINE, Mark, Atlanta, pilot. JOHNSTON, Hank, Atlanta, co-pilot. Passengers AMLIE, June T., Baltimore. BANNING, D., Washington, D.C. BIRDSONG, Brian, Atlanta. BIRDSONG, Laura, Atlanta. CARTER, Manley Lamier Jr., Houston. DAVIES, Dr. Nicholas E., Atlanta. GWIN, Thomas B., Brunswick, Ga. HART, Gerald T., Tallahassee, Fla. JOHNSTON, Hub, Knoxville, Tenn. JOHNSTON, Rita Marie, Knoxville, Tenn. LaVIE, A. J., New Orleans. MOORE, Mike, Dallas. PARDO, Joseph G., New Orleans. MORGAN, Tami, Brunswick, Ga. THURSTON, Penelope, Syracuse. THURSTON, Roger, Syracuse. TOWER, John G., Dallas. TOWER, Marian, Dallas. WARD, Kelly, Kansas City, Mo.

title: Pool Reconstruction Project Disputed
description: RESIDENTS of Harbor Hills Park in Great Neck are going to court to try to force the Town of North Hempstead to answers questions on the reconstruction of their pool.

title: Public & Private; Mr. Smith Goes to Heaven
description: Jason Oliver C. Smith, a big dumb guy who was tan, died March 30 of lung cancer and old age. He was 13 years old and lived in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and the back section of the mini-van, behind the kids' seat.

title: THE WRONG MAN
description: The mysterious admirer that Richard Bernstein describes in his About Men column "The Wrong Man" (March 3) is probably suffering from erotomania, a rare but long-recognized psychiatric condition in which a person of humble origins (usually a woman) spontaneously develops the delusion that a mutual romantic attachment exists between her and a male figure whom she sees as her superior in social, professional or financial status. Those in the public eye (politicians, celebrities, journalists) or authority figures like teachers, doctors or ministers are common objects of erotomanic delusions, which sometimes lead to harassment and, more rarely, danger for the object of the delusions.

title: No-Frills Spas, Western Style . . .And in Maine and Massachusetts
description: PICKING a spa, especially an inexpensive one, means figuring out exactly what you most want and need. Few spas that cost less than $150 a day a person will have the smorgasbord of services offered by a Canyon Ranch or a Golden Door. It helps to know whether you want to lose weight, or quit smoking, or learn yoga, or meet people, or be alone.

title: The World Held Its Breath
description: THE TRUTH ABOUT CHERNOBYL By Grigori Medvedev. Translated by Evelyn Rossiter. Foreword by Andrei Sakharov. 274 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: On Victims and Heroes
description: To the Editor:

title: Gymnastics; Star-Spangled Romanian
description: In these times of heightened political sensitivities, there's nothing like good old American standards to energize a crowd, and that's precisely what Cristina Bontas intended today in a dual meet of leading female gymnasts from the United States and Romania.

title: Is There Life After Marley and Juice Ads?
description: Once the quintessential outsiders' sound, reggae now appears to be safe in America's pop firmament. Its off-center beat has high name recognition among casual music fans and pervades commercials for fruit juice and tropical vacations. But reggae has a vitality problem: its revered past and sluggish present threaten to stifle its future.

title: The Best Part of Every Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Vans Carry a Dream Of Healing Children
description: DR. Irwin Redlener has several thousand patients in three New York City boroughs, but it's not often that the New Rochelle pediatrician pulls out his stethoscope or prescription pad.

title: Marcos Lawyer Challenges Manila Visa Ban
description: A lawyer for Imelda Marcos said today that the Philippines' refusal to give her a passport to return was illegal and violated her rights.

title: Kathy Neisloss, Publisher, Weds
description: Kathy Ann Neisloss, a magazine publisher, and Richard Benjamin Leventhal, an executive, were married last evening in the Pegasus Suite at the Rainbow Room in New York by Cantor Nathaniel Benjamin.

title: Violent Movies Make Violent Audiences
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Grand Rapids, Mich.;
Bright Outlook For Offices
description: ROBERT GROOTERS has so much confidence in this city's office market that he has used $7 million of his own money to begin the largest office project in the city's history.

title: Miss Zeltt Weds James Weinberg
description: Denise Leigh Zeltt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold N. Zeltt of Yardley, Pa., was married last evening at Har Sinai Temple in Trenton to James Jay Weinberg, the son of Judge and Mrs. Norman S. Weinberg of Boston. Rabbi David Strauss performed the ceremony.

title: Campus Life: Carleton; Lawsuit Charges Mishandling Of Rape Cases
description: Four women have brought suit against Carleton College, charging that the college mishandled allegations of rape on campus.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Adding Roses

title: Hijacked Out of His Liberal Guilt
description: FLYING HERO CLASS By Thomas Keneally. 289 pp. New York: Warner Books. $19.95.

title: Pupils Build Knowledge of Architecture
description: WHEN the buzz saws and jackhammers begin rattling classrooms at the Fox Meadow Elementary Schoolhere in May, the clamor will be more than background noise to the students.

title: POWER SKATING
description: The idea of a style of figure skating based solely on jumps seems rather like a performance of Brahms played mostly on cymbals: when one element, no matter how flashy, takes over, the whole suffers ("Power Skating," by Jared Lubarsky, March 10).

title: Special Today:
description: Home Design/Magazine Part 2 Special Today: Education Life/Section 4A

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Many of the ceiling tiles in our newly built house are stained by water. The floor of the attic crawl space is covered with a thick layer of insulation, and on inspecting the attic we found the insulation to be quite wet. There are vents near the peak at each end of the attic, and there is no sign of a roof leak. What could be causing the moisture problem that is staining our ceilings?

title: Afghan Rebels Torn by New Quarrel
description: Afghan guerrillas who seized an outpost of the Kabul Government here nearly a week ago are squabbling over the spoils of victory while bodies of the dead still lie on the ground.

title: Small Labels, Eternal Hope
description: And still they come: new classical labels crowding into an already overcrowded field, each convinced it has something special to offer. The explosion of new labels in the compact-disk era has added welcome spice to a field increasingly dominated by huge companies.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
B.A. at $100 A Year for The Retired
description: MANY students at the University of Michigan's Dearborn campus know that Herbert Hoover was President when the Great Depression began. But 76-year-old Amelia Duke remembers it. Mrs. Duke, an arts administration major from Bloomfield Hills, Mich., is a charter member of the Retired Persons' Scholarship Program, which offers Detroit-area retirees a college education for only $50 a semester.

title: Peruvian Rebels Cut Power and Attack Embassies
description: Maoist guerrillas plunged nearly half of Peru's population into darkness and bombed embassies and banks in Lima in the most widespread attacks of Alberto Fujimori's nine-month-old presidency, the police said today.

title: Vast Majority of Americans Feel Sting of Recession, Survey Finds
description: A large portion of Americans, far more than the 6.8 percent who are unemployed, have been deeply stung by the recession and may be in no position, financially or psychologically, to help bail out the economy by going on a shopping spree, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: The Digital Tape War Begins
description: Barely a year has passed since digital audio tape, or DAT, made its American debut, and a corporate power struggle is already threatening to throttle the young medium. DAT is backed by a Japanese consortium headed by Sony. Now, a European contender, Philips of the Netherlands, is challenging DAT with a digital tape format of its own.

title: Gwyn Osnos Engaged to John White
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. B. Osnos of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Gwyn Rachel Osnos and John Stanford White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. F. L. Peter White of St. James, L.I.

title: Mozart Dominates Performance Schedule
description: HOW much Mozart is too much? That is a question we may be facing as celebrations of his bicentennial multiply.

title: HEADSTRONG: CHARLES BARKLEY
description: After all of Coplon's gushy prose, it turns out that Barkley is noteworthy because, in addition to his ability to rebound and score, he frequently plays dirty.

title: Dr. Hodas Wed In White Plains
description: Dr. Lauren Ruth Hodas, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Hodas of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday evening in White Plains to Dr. Andrei Cernea, the son of Dr. Michael M. Cernea of Bethesda, Md., and the late Dr. Stela Javetz Cernea. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. officiated at the Metropolis Country Club.

title: Talking: Shortfalls; If a Sale Fails to Pay The Loan
description: THE decline in home values in the last few years is forcing some sellers to accept buyers' offers that do not cover still-outstanding mortgage balances.

title: Fundamentals
description: EVERYONE HAS TO DO it at least once: shop for basic necessities like tables and chairs, wine glasses and water pitchers. Well-made classics are always a good investment. They usually last longer and don't look dated. The furniture and objects shown on these pages represent different approaches to the classics. Some, like the lacquer screen by Eileen Gray, are replicas of vintage pieces; others, like the metal bistro chair, are variations on traditional themes. Basics have been adapted to meet today's needs. For those living in cramped quarters, for instance, an oval table by the French designer Philippe Starck tilts to become a standing mirror. Even wallpapers have been subject to classic twists. This season, star patterns are especially popular. In these troubled times, maybe we need something to wish on.

title: Headliners; Keeping a Closer Eye on Global Ozone Gauge
description: SINCE the mid-80's, scientists and governments have been worried that the infamous Antarctic "hole" in the earth's protective ozone shield would spread around the globe, exposing people and other living things to harmful ultraviolet rays from the sun. Most nations pledged last year to stop producing industrial chemicals, mainly chlorofluorocarbons, that are believed to weaken the ozone shield.

title: Christine Pagliaro Weds
description: Christine Patrice Pagliaro, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Pagliaro of White Plains, was married in Ardsley, N.Y., yesterday to Robert Christopher Raciti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Raciti of Yonkers. The Rev. Theodosius Corley officiated at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Raciti, 26 years old, is the executive director of the Ardsley Musical Instrument Service in Scarsdale, N.Y. She graduated from Concordia College. Mr. Raciti, also 26, is a systems engineer at Loral Electronic Systems, a manufacturer of radar warning devices in Yonkers. He graduated cum laude from Manhattan College.

title: Corrections
description: Two articles today in Education Life, section 4A, carry reversed headlines and bylines. "Inventive Curriculums," by William Celis 3d, appears on page 20; "Classes Once Removed," by Roberto Suro, is on page 21.

title: Priority: The Bathroom; A Big Splash
description: COMMODIOUS BATHROOMS HAVE BECOME A SYMBOL OF American style. "This is definitely a time when people are paying more attention to themselves, and pampering is a big part of the picture," says Joseph Cicio, corporate senior vice president at Macy's. Cicio speaks from firsthand experience. Recently, when he joined two Manhattan apartments to make a duplex for himself, he redesigned the upstairs kitchen into a master bathroom. The 6-foot-4-inch Cicio was not simply looking for luxury. He needed a bathtub big enough so he could soak his bad back comfortably -- without his neck and toes sticking out at either end. A tall order, he soon realized. "I ended up having one custom-built," he says. The rest of the bathroom was more straightforward. White marble covers the surfaces, mirrors dominate the walls and antique Lalique wall sconces provide soft, diffused lighting for the space. "I call this the Bristol bathroom," says Cicio. "It reminds me of the wonderful old bathrooms at the Bristol Hotel in Paris."

title: Henderson to Get Job
description: The National Football League is getting ready to name an Amtrak official as its executive vice president for labor relations, according to a published report. Harold Henderson, a vice president and attorney for the railroad company, would become the highest ranking black executive in the history of the N.F.L.

title: Palm Beach Journal; A Refuge Of the Rich Is a Trove of Scandal
description: A place that prides itself on propriety takes a dim view of scandals.

title: Astronauts Ready to Release Gamma Ray Satellite
description: The space shuttle astronauts have flexed their 50-foot mechanical arm, inspected gear for a spacewalk and checked the performance of the big satellite in the cargo bay -- all in preparation for the high point of their mission, the deployment of the Gamma Ray Observatory on Sunday.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Giving Voice to Sorrow and Joy In "The Artist and His Time" Albert Camus (1913-1960) argued that the true vocation of the artist is to give solace and strength to those who struggle for a just world. The essay is included in "The Myth of Sisyphus and Other Essays" (Vintage International, paper).

title: Topics of The Times; Better Cuddly Than Brow-Antlered
description: Dale Marcellini, curator of reptiles at the National Zoo in Washington, studies more than snakes. He's also interested in who likes what at the zoo. Tracking more than 700 visitors over the last five summers, Mr. Marcellini and his colleagues found that zoo-goers spent the most time gazing at Ling-Ling and Hsing-Hsing, the famous pair of pandas.

title: Elizabeth Wechsler to Wed in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Wechsler of Winchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Anne Wechsler to Rodolfo Mata, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reyes Mata of El Paso, Tex. An August wedding is planned.

title: Stabbed Man Dies After Ambulance Crash
description: A Brooklyn man who was stabbed more than a dozen times in the chest died yesterday morning after a collision between a car and a private ambulance that was carrying him to a hospital. The crash injured three other people, the police said.

title: DE KLERK ACCUSES MANDELA'S GROUP
description: The recent stormy relationship between the African National Congress and the South African Government sank to a new low today as President F. W. de Klerk accused the nationalist organization of seeking to exploit the factional violence in black townships for its political advantage.

title: Data Update
Chile
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from a month in Santiago and a car trip with friends about 1,000 miles south on the Pan American Highway to find your article about an expensive, secluded hacienda in Chile (Travel, Feb. 24).

title: Columbus
description: To the Editor: Thank you for listing Columbus Quincentenary events in 1992. I hope this doesn't turn into a Ping-Pong match, but I must respond to Mark Keeve, who implied that 1992 is not an event to be celebrated (Letters on Travel, March 10). Many people say that 1992 should not be celebrated because they only see the destruction of civilizations by the imperialism of the Spaniards and their wealth usurped. The year 1992 is not a celebration, it's a commemoration of Spanish heritage.

title: A Place Where Love Becomes a Chronic Invalid
description: Varick Street is what happens to Seventh Avenue when all is lost. Where this bleak thoroughfare crosses West Houston Street in lower Manhattan stands the Film Forum, housing three cinemas decorated in a style that one movie critic has described as "warehouse modern," each equipped with a screen the size of a postage stamp. This building is the natural home of pictures that fall into the category of unabashed festival material. One such feature, now showing there, is "Paris Is Burning," a documentary by Jennie Livingston about a gay fashion ball in Harlem and the stylized dance called voguing.

title: Review/Cabaret; Dawn Hampton, and Lyrics
description: Dawn Hampton is a veteran singer to whom the words of a song are more important than the melody.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MUSEUM BENEFIT

title: Correction
description: An article on March 10 about the actor Sam Wanamaker misidentified the producer of the film "Give Us This Day." He is Rod E. Geiger.

title: Ms. Kershbaum to Wed Jason Evans
description: Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Lowell Kershbaum of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Elizabeth Kershbaum to Jason Edward Murrow Evans, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mayer Evans of Atlanta. A June wedding is planned.

title: Viola and Mets Strike Out
description: Negotiations on a contract extension for Frank Viola, headed nowhere for weeks, yesterday came to a crashing halt, a development that raises the distinct chance that in six months the star pitcher's career with the Mets will come to an end.

title: Where's the Rest of Them?
description: HIS OTHER HALF Men Looking at Women Through Art. By Wendy Lesser. Illustrated. 294 pp. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University Press.

title: Retirement Communities Feel Effects of Soft Market
description: Chester W. Nimitz Jr., a retired rear admiral, might fairly feel entitled to a certain impatience with waiting lists.

title: Campus Life: Purdue; Toll-Free Number May Prevent Some Frustration
description: With a little help from a toll-free telephone number, some students at Purdue University will soon be testing a different way of dealing with academic bureaucracy.

title: The Power of Steam in London
description: MOST cities have an underground network of pipes and tunnels to supply and remove that essential commodity, water for its citizens. Some of these man-made waterways are renowned: the Parisian sewers through which slips the Phantom of the Opera, the Viennese ones through which travels the Third Man. According to urban lore, others, like those of New York, are populated by alligators or, like London's, have private railroads running through their confines.

title: FLASHCARDS
description: THE Southern Regional Education Board reports that white students on historically black college campuses share attitudes about campus life with black students at predominantly white schools. The board surveyed by mail more than 4,500 students at 20 predominantly white and 20 historically black colleges and universities in 14 Southern states. Almost half the students who were in a minority on campus, regardless of their race, said they would not select the same school again.

title: Memos to the Mets
description: To Bud Harrelson:

title: Kathleen Smith, Teacher, to Marry
description: July wedding plans for Kathleen Mary Smith and Christopher William Ennis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Beaven Ennis of Armonk, N.Y., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Smith of Wyckoff, N.J.

title: N.L. East: Cubs' Bats Could Knock Out All Contenders
description: The National League preview was reported and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in order of predicted finish, with the Mets picked for third in the East.

title: The Nation; A Double Dose of Pain for the Poor
description: IN their State of the State messages this year, many of the nation's governors emphasized the importance of investing in the health and welfare of children, even as they proposed cutbacks in social welfare programs serving low- income families with children.

title: Priority: Getting Organized; Everything In Its Place
description: FOLDING SCREENS HAVE a long history of dividing, organizing and concealing awkward spaces. Their forms inspired the designer Tom Pritchard when he devised a three-dimensional structure to bring order to what had been a set of cramped rooms in a New York apartment. "Everything was too small," recalls Pritchard, who is part owner of Pure Madderlake, the landscape and architectural designers. First he combined the two rooms and corridor to gain needed inches. Then, "by creating this intricate cabinetwork I was able to buy more space," he adds. Finished in rare dappled sapele wood veneer, the roomlike construction serves many functions. It neatly hides a walk-in closet and dressing area off the bedroom and provides ample bookshelves and storage for the study.

title: Too Good for the Nobel Prize
description: Quick, now. What do these great writers have in common: Tolstoy, Ibsen, Proust, Joyce, Strindberg, Hardy, Colette, Valery, Malraux, Nabokov and Rilke? The answer: None was deemed worthy of a Nobel Prize in Literature by the parochial Swedish committee that doles out what is still -- alas! -- the world's most prestigious literary award.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL
description: THE YEAR THEY CALLED OFF THE WORLD SERIES A True Story. By Benton Stark. Avery, $17.95.

title: WHAT DIVIDES BERLIN NOW?
description: Sam, an Egyptian living in Berlin, recently added a controversial item to the usual curiosities he sells from a couple of rickety tables in the shadow of the Brandenburg Gate. In addition to Soviet Army caps and pieces of the wall encased in plastic, he began hawking T-shirts with a slogan that read, "I Want My Wall Back Again." And they were moving well.

title: In a Sculptor's Hands, A Chair Becomes Art
description: CHARLES PERRY, an architectural sculptor whose large-scale works spice an international landscape -- from the Ministry of Defense and Air in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to the National Air and Space Museum in Washington -- has temporarily stepped out of his usual medium to design a chair.

title: Postings: On Lincoln Place; Redone Co-ops In Crown Heights
description: For anyone with enough money -- but not too much -- looking for a co-op there are bargains on Lincoln Place in Brooklyn's Crown Heights area, thanks to hefty renovation subsidies to a 53-unit project sponsored by the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: The Mud Treatment in Italy
description: IN the mid-first century A.D., on the island of Ischia, a woman named Argenne, an ex-slave of the Empress Poppaea Sabina, wife of Nero, dedicated a votive offering to the god Apollo and the nymphs of the spring known today as Nitrodi. Presumably she had had a successful cure.

title: Washington at Work; Side by Side by Solarz and Schumer: A Rivalry
description: If not good friends, Steve Solarz and Chuck Schumer should at least be allies. They're both New York boys made good, standout members of the House of Representatives, and they represent adjoining districts in Brooklyn. Driven by ambition and skilled at self-promotion, the two liberals are counted among the brightest lawmakers in Congress.

title: Bound by Favors
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; The Final Verse
description: Marianne Wiggins was already a writer of some note when she married Salman Rushdie in January 1988. But when Mr. Rushdie's book "The Satanic Verses" was published a year later, her career was quickly overshadowed. She joined her husband in hiding when he received death threats because of the book, but announced in July 1989 -- about the time her fourth novel, "John Dollar," was published -- that they had separated. Now they are getting a divorce -- Ms. Wiggins cites "ideological differences" -- and she lashed out at her soon-to-be-ex in an interview in The Sunday Times of London. "I am incredibly sad about him, not because our marriage is over, but sad as a writer because all the attention he has garnered in the past two years has been about Salman Rushdie," she said. "The great fallacy he committed was to think he was the issue," instead of free speech or racism. Ms. Wiggins is working on a new play, "Revenge," whose subject matter was not disclosed.

title: Priority: The View; City Lights
description: PANORAMIC VIEW OF THE NEW YORK skyline makes this 650-square-foot studio seem spacious. Mirrored walls open it up even more. "Light -- night and day -- was my top priori- ty," says the owner and decorator Jeffrey Bilhuber. Streamlining the design helped. Bilhuber stuck to one color, ivory, for both the upholstery and the carpeting. "Possessions have been pared down to the absolute minimum," he adds. "There are no oversized pieces that would be view blockers. This is like having the biggest apartment in New York, but there's only one room to dust."

title: Pro Football; Knights' Fans Warming Up
description: Two-year old Ryan Cappuzzo wasn't too happy tonight, a fact that he made known to anyone within earshot of his piercing scream.

title:
Your Own Account;
Last-Minute Thoughts on Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Service estimates that 34 million taxpayers -- 30 percent of those filing this year -- will mail their returns during the coming week, just ahead of the April 15 filing deadline. For many, then, the next few days will be hectic and mistakes are inevitable, say tax specialists. Never mind the really basic errors -- like forgetting to sign the return -- there are several other common oversights.

title: Expanded Recycling Site Upsets an Ossining Neighborhood
description: RESIDENTS of Hunter Street here have been joined by several regional environmental groups in contesting a decision by the Village Planning Board to allow a construction-debris processing plant to operate on the crowded residential block.

title: Why the Rich Should Pay an Extra Tax Share
description: To the Editor:

title: A Reader's Guide to the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Paying for Repairs Question: We are senior citizens living in a rent-controlled apartment in a building converted to a cooperative under a noneviction plan. The owner of our apartment, the former building owner, refuses to pay for repairs, claiming that the co-op management should pay. Meanwhile, the superintendent says it's our responsibility. Who should pay and how does one get them to pay? . . . Herbert Stessin, Manhattan Answer: Your dispute is probably with your shareholding landlord, and you have recourse to the courts and state regulators. Michael R. Finder, a Manhattan housing lawyer, said a co-op's lease usually provides that repairs within a unit, such as a leaky faucet, are the owner's responsibility and that structural repairs, such as a leaky roof, are management's.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Community Psychiatric Centers referred erroneously to a competitor, the Charter Medical Corporation. Charter operates hospitals across the country, not mainly in the East.

title: Laurna Godwin, TV Anchor, Wed
description: Laurna Corrynne Godwin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer F. Godwin of Shrewsbury, N.J., was married there yesterday to Samuel Compton Hutchinson Jr., the son of Evelyn Leonard of St. Louis and the late Mr. Hutchinson. The Rev. James La Sage performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church.

title:
ART;
Riotous Color, With Discipline
description: THE campus at Westchester Community College here is so beautiful that even the switchboard operator is an unabashed booster, declaring its year-round virtues to the strangers who call. "And you should see it when the lilacs are out," she said on a day when spring was beginning to stir.

title: Landmarks Or Bric-a-Brac?
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Booksellers Find Their Niches
description: CARRIE COARD and Sisko Bauerle are mavericks: in ependent booksellers who, despite the proliferation of book discounters and chain stores, have each managed to find a successful market niche.

title: Fashion Preview; A PEEK AT THE FALL
description: American designers have some task ahead of them. This week, they will introduce their fall '91 collections. The fireworks will have to be considerable to compete with the Paris showings last month. The clothes shown here, by some of New York's top designers, were selected from previews before the French collections took place. They illustrate the fresh thinking taking place on this side of the Atlantic too. In general, hemlines will still be on the short side, but not as much as in the past. Nevertheless, most remain above the knee. Curving silhouettes are almost every designer's choice -- lines that mold to the bosom, torso and waist. Leggings finish off a suit as often as a skirt does. Louis Dell'Olio for Anne Klein is even planning "a major statement": stretch-velour leggings that are made all-in-one with high-heel pumps. Pull them on and the bottom half of an outfit is totally complete. The exceptions are slouchy pants suits, all mannish tailoring on the first take, but -- like those of Isaac Mizrahi (see page 70) -- revealing very feminine stuff underneath. Plenty of the fall drama will come from color, combinations thereof and unexpected uses of fabric. Tweed, for example, is a favorite for evening as well as day. In fact, contrasts are becoming commonplace -- a trench coat made of lace, or leather for a black-tie ensemble.

title: Kurdish Oppression in Turkey Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: Christine Mary McCarthy Weds Michael W. Casey
description: Christine Mary McCarthy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. McCarthy of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Micheal William Casey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Casey of Mooresville, Ind. The Rev. Patrick J. Carroll, a Roman Catholic priest and the uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Assumption Roman Catholic Church, assisted by the Rev. Caroline Reed, a United Church of Christ minister and the bridegroom's sister.

title: Miss Field Wed To D. M. Moyle Jr.
description: Christiane Parsons Field, a daughter of Paul L. Field of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Irene Champlin, was married yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church in New York to Donald Miller Moyle Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro performed the cermeony.
