title: Priorities
description: ALMOST NO ONE CAN AFFORD TO DO IT ALL. THESE DAYS, WITH THE high cost of materials and craftsmanship, making any change at home -- whether minor redecorating or total renovation -- is a significant investment. The most practical solution is to set priorities, to give careful thought to what is most important. For some people, it's just not home without a well-designed kitchen. Others couldn't do without a luxurious bathroom or an organized closet or a spectacular view. Even gardeners make choices based on how they live: Early risers, for example, might plant morning glories. Setting limits often promotes creativity as well. Some of the most renowned architects have done their best work on a shoestring. And some of the most interesting collections have been assembled by antiques lovers with tight budgets and a selective eye. Selectivity, in fact, is emblematic of the 1990's. Even furnishings reveal the trend: The freshest designs now are less whimsical and more classic in form. After all, familiar objects and beautiful surroundings are the essence of comfort. And comfort is the ultimate priority.

title: Jehovah's Witnesses Build Center on Dairy Farm
description: A huge religious complex is being built on a former dairy farm here as the training center of the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, better known as the Jehovah's Witnesses.

title: Eager Meulens Leads a Youth Movement
description: The first time he walked into the Yankees' spring training clubhouse, Hensley Meulens was 20 years old, still awed at how quickly he had risen in his career and uncertain where the coming days would lead him. It was 1988.

title: Campus Life: Lehigh; Fraternity Alters Its Style and Goals To Improve Image
description: The members of Tau Epsilon Phi fraternity at Lehigh University have devised what they call "the New Vision" in an effort to break the "Animal House" stereotype connected with fraternities.

title: KURDS IN U.S. CALL FOR MORE BACKING
description: Kurdish-Americans are welcoming American and international emergency relief for their compatriots in Iraq but continuing to voice anger over the refusal of the Bush Administration to support the Kurdish rebellion there.

title: Tuneups
description: EVEN THOSE PASSIONATE AUDIOPHILES and video fans who usually manage to persuade themselves that stereo and video equipment falls in the same budgetary bracket as rent and groceries are apt to be more circumspect in their purchases these days. Instead of revamping an entire audio or video rig, most people are now thinking in terms of selective updating, one item at a time. This means setting priorities for replacement and figuring out ways to make the most improvement with the least cash outlay.

title: Lee S. Richards 3d Marries Ann Lyons in Philadelphia
description: Ann Starr Lyons, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Lyons of Philadelphia, was married there yesterday to Lee Sumner Richards 3d, a son of Mr. Richards Jr. of Stuart, Fla., and the late Elaine G. Richards. The Rev. C. Vincent Wilson officiated at the Presbyterian Church of Chestnut Hill.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 24 with an article about dance festivals in Europe misidentified a dancer in "La Poudre des Anges." She was Marianne Isson; Karine Saporta was the choreographer.

title: Japan's Sleight of Hand in Trade . . . And Its Duty to U.S. Auto Workers
description: The number of people working in automobile manufacturing in this country has shrunk more than 20 percent since 1978, and that includes employees at Japan's newly established operations here. Obviously, an even steeper decline has taken place at Detroit's Big Three.

title:
DINING OUT;
Fresh Fish at Moderate Prices in Tuckahoe
description: IN its three-year tenure in downtown Tuckahoe, this branch of several Manhattan-based seafood establishments has dug in for the long haul, offering its diverse clientele moderate prices and fresh fish. For late-night arrivals, there are a number of light dishes, and on Thursdays through Saturdays, there is entertainment. Those interested in dining only tend to come in early for the fish, pasta and salads. A younger crowd queues up later, when greeting, meeting and light eating take over, with food a secondary concern.

title: Dr. Christine Rider Weds
description: Dr. Christine Rider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Rider of Cambridge, England, was married yesterday in Brooklyn to Dr. Gary Mongiovi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Mongiovi of Brooklyn. The Rev. Stanley Bass performed a nondenominational ceremony at Sirico's restaurant. The couple have doctorates in economics from the New School for Social Research, and they teach economics at St. John's University in Queens, where the bridegroom received his undergraduate degree. The bride, who is keeping her name, graduated from the London School of Economics. Her previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Rostagno Upsets Sampras: Derrick Rostagno, seeded fourth, beat second-seeded Pete Sampras, 7-5, 6-4, yesterday to advance to the final of the Prudential Securities Classic in Orlando, Fla. Last night, top-seeded Andre Agassi was to face unseeded MaliVai Washington, who began the day by knocking out Brad Gilbert, 6-2, 6-7, 6-2, in a quarterfinal carried over from Friday. Gilbert was the defending champion. Agassi reached the semifinals yesterday by completing his rain-delayed quarterfinal victory over Chuck Adams, 6-4, 7-6. With Rostagno serving at 5-5, love-15, Sampras was forced to take a timeout because of a nosebleed. Rostagno held serve and won the game with a pair of service aces. Then Sampras, the defending United States Open champion, double-faulted to set up set point, and Rostagno hit a forehand crosscourt winner for the set. In the second set, Sampras scored his first service break with a spectacular forehand winner to lead, 3-2. But Rostagno broke back to 4-4 and then put increasing pressure on his second serve. Sampras double-faulted and then fought off two match points before pushing a backhand long on the third. (AP)

title: Barbara Stock Weds James A. Dolan
description: Barbara Ellen Stock, the daughter of Robert W. Stock and Phyllis Stock-Morton, both of New York, was married yesterday to James A. Dolan, a son of Marjorie B. Dolan of Williston Park, L.I., and the late James A. Dolan. The Rev. Harold Barrett performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Chief Gates Sets Strict Rules for TV Interviews of Officers
description: All television interviews with employees of the Los Angeles Police Department on the police beating of a motorist must be broadcast live or unedited, according to a new policy set by Chief Daryl F. Gates.

title: The Best Part of Every Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Amsterdam
description: To the Editor: When you next run a list of hotels in Amsterdam, you might want to re-evaluate the Hotel Ambassade, based on the experience of my wife, daughter and myself. We had a duplex facing the Herrengracht, with windows about eight feet above the sidewalk. It was quite hot when we were there, so we left the windows open about 12 inches when we retired.

title: Plane Crashes
description: To the Editor: Instead of just reading the cards and instructions placed inside the seat pockets, why can't travelers get some hands-on practice using some of the safety and survival equipment? Knowing where an emergency door is located and knowing how to open it during an emergency are two different things. I think there should be mock displays in airport lounge areas where passengers could go through the steps of pushing open an airplane door. Also, I would like the chance to put on an oxygen mask, pull out a seat cushion and try on an inflatable vest. Why not have modular safety displays inside airport terminals? JAAK VIKATI Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Canada
description: To the Editor: I noted with interest the item "New Tax (and Refunds) in Canada" (Travel Advisory, March 3). As the president of the Royal Connaught Hotel in Hamilton, I would like to thank you for this informative article on the new 7 percent goods and services tax. In particular, I would like to thank you for pointing out the ease with which a traveler can receive a refund of this tax.

title: Holmes Explains Comeback
description: On Thursday, sweat flew off Larry Holmes as he shadow-boxed in a ring set up in a showroom of the Diplomat Hotel.

title: Iraq Approval Starts Peace Schedule
description: Iraq's formal acceptance of the Security Council's Persian Gulf peace offer today meets the conditions for an immediate cease-fire and clears the way for the destruction of Iraq's most dangerous weapons, the establishment of a procedure for Iraqi reparations to Kuwait and the lifting of trade sanctions against Baghdad.

title: American's Killing in Guatemala Hurts Drug Fight
description: Washington's hopes of enlisting Guatemala in its fight against cocaine trafficking rest on the resolution of a murder case involving an American innkeeper reportedly slain by Guatemalan troops, Bush Administration officials say.

title: Technology; A Faster Path to Finished Steel
description: In a wide stretch of quiet farmland in northwestern Indiana, the Inland Steel Company is engaged in a joint venture with the Nippon Steel Corporation to produce finished steel using a new process that cuts manufacturing time to less than an hour, from about 12 days.

title: Biotechnology: Great Science, Greater Fools
description: With the economy in a recession, earnings disappointments are to be expected. So why not put your money in stocks that are guaranteed not to have such setbacks?

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Thou Shall Not Allow Rose Into the Hall!
description: When Pete Rose's athletic alma mater opens the season as world champions in Cincinnati tomorrow, baseball's record hit master will be on the outside looking in. Like a kid with his nose pressed to a candy store window, Charley Hustler will also find himself excluded at Cooperstown, and with good reason.

title: Spring Chores Demand Attention Now
description: BUDS are bursting. All kinds of shoots and leaves are pushing up through the ground. Gardeners should be outdoors and busy.

title: Headliners; Policing a Chief
description: Some years ago, the job of Los Angeles police chief was layered with civil service protection to insulate the position from political pressure. Now some in Los Angeles, Mayor Tom Bradley among them, seem to be wondering if Chief Daryl F. Gates has not been accorded a little too much insulation. A groundswell of outraged demands for Mr. Gates's resignation began last month after television news shows broadcast a videotape of white police officers brutally beating an unresisting black motorist. Mayor Bradley eventually joined the chorus, but noted that he was powerless to remove the Chief. The Bradley-appointed Police Commission came up with a compromise of sorts last week, putting Mr. Gates on a two-month paid leave. This would give the commission time to determine whether Mr. Gates's "style, rhetoric and conduct contribute to police abuses," said the head a libertarian group that is pushing for the Chief's ouster. Mr. Gates said he felt "disgraced and defamed" by the action, and vowed to fight it in court.

title: Plane Crashes
description: To the Editor: I have been a frequent flier for the past five years. There have been many articles about whom not to put by an emergency exit door and who should sit there. Why don't the airlines ask frequent fliers to get training on how to open the emergency doors and escape? I'd volunteer for this training. Why shouldn't the person sitting near an exit have some knowledge and experience? DAVID M. HYMAN Hillside, N.J.

title: 'YOU COULD OUTLIVE YOUR DOCTOR'
description: Brian Hayes is made of all the right stuff. His description of the trauma -- the emotional elevator ride between the despair and optimism in his bout with testicular cancer -- left me deeply moved. As he says, he is by no means the only person ever to experience the pain of cancer, but he shows a remarkable and inspiring strength in attempting, as best he can, to overcome all the hurdles to a full recovery.

title: Sunday Menu; Potato Crusts: Elegant Wraps for Salmon
description: Restaurants seem to be cooking everything in potato crusts these days. The preparation sounds glamorous and difficult, but it is neither. If you know how to make potato pancakes (grate the peeled potatoes in the food processor), you can make a crust of potatoes for anything.

title: 'Shove It Down Their Throats'
description: TJ My Twenty-six Years in Baseball. By Tommy John with Dan Valenti. Illustrated. 305 pp. New York: Bantam Books.

title: Copter Rotor Hit Heinz's Plane, Early Data Find
description: Federal investigators said Friday night that their preliminary inquiry shows a helicopter rotor struck the right wing of the small airplane carrying Senator John Heinz moments before the two aircraft crashed into a schoolyard in Lower Merion Township.

title: Cynthia Gerrity Weds Ronald Holland
description: Cynthia Margaret Gerrity, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Gerrity of Loudonville, N.Y., was married in Troy, N.Y., yesterday to Ronald Philip Holland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond C. Holland of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Laman Bruner, an Episcopal priest who is the chaplain of the New York State Assembly, and the Rev. Michael A. Farano, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the alumnae chapel of the Emma Willard School.

title: Combating a Rare Genetic Disease
description: STANDING by the crib of her 18-month-old daughter at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, Fiffi Eliades described the anxiety and uncertainty of awaiting Samantha's diagnosis.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-17

title: Florio Plan to Sell Roads Is Criticized
description: GOV. JIM FLORIO's plan to to cut the projected $800 million state budget deficit in half by selling state highways to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority is drawing criticism from financial analysts, urban policy experts and a growing number of legislators, including some influential Democrats.

title: Leanne Pudick to Marry
description: The engagement of Leanne Tamar Pudick to George Anthony McGowan 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George McGowan Jr. of Little Silver, Md., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jack Pudick of Somers, N.Y. A wedding in August 1992 is planned. Ms. Pudick, 24 years old, is the assistant to the director of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art. She graduated from Washington University in St. Louis. Mr. McGowan, also 24, graduated from Manhattan College and is a law student at Seton Hall University. He is a clerk at the law firm of Ravin, Sarasohn, Cook, Baumgarten, Fisch & Baime in Roseland, N.J.

title: Travel Advisory; Bumping Cut
description: The Department of Transportation reports a big drop in the number of passengers denied boarding on oversold flights by United States airlines in 1990 compared with the previous year. Last year the airlines registered 68,560 denied boardings, or 1.55 per 10,000 passengers, compared with 106,765, or 2.59 per 10,000, in 1989, according to the department's air travel consumer report.

title: The Fun, the Majesty, the Joy
description: BASEBALL IN AMERICA

title: Newly Rewarded Skiles Helps Magic Beat Celtics
description: Scott Skiles, signed to a new contract earlier in the day, scored 26 points and Otis Smith and Jerry Reynolds hit four free throws in the final 18 seconds tonight to help the Orlando Magic beat the Boston Celtics for the first time in the club's two-year history.

title:
Travel Advisory;
Hong Kong Hotel Discounts
description: A drop in tourist arrivals and a glut of available rooms have produced price cuts at Hong Kong's hotels. And with the number of rooms expected to rise by about a third, to nearly 37,000, in the next three years and the Chinese takeover of the colony in 1997 likely to put a damper on tourism, the bargains seem set for a long stay.

title: They'll Always Have Istanbul
description: SIRO By David Ignatius. 465 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: Consultants Or Con Artists?
description: THE COST of a year's tuition, room and board can easily exceed $13,000 at private colleges and $5,000 at public institutions. But thousands of anxious secondary school students and their families are undertaking another big cost these days, to help them select -- and be selected by -- a college.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL
description: STOLEN SEASON A Journey Through America and Baseball's Minor Leagues. By David Lamb. Random House, $20.

title: The Executive Computer; Why the Privacy Issue Will Never Go Away
description: "It's astonishing the things you can do on a desktop computer in five minutes, which five years ago would have taken overnight computer runs on a mainframe," said Charles W. Stryker, president of Trinet America Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., which provided the data for Marketplace: Business, a listing of American business that the Lotus Development Corporation offered, then withdrew, last year.

title: Travel Advisory; Relais Adds Two in Canada
description: The Paris-based Relais & Chateaux Association, which represents 377 inns, hotels, resorts and restaurants in 37 countries, has added 20 hotels and 7 restaurants this year, including two Canadian hotels, Langdon Hall, near Toronto, and the Post Hotel at Lake Louise, near Banff.

title:
MUSIC;
'Frederick Douglass,' Opera, to Open
description: IT has been nearly 20 years since Donald Dorr, librettist, and Ulysses Kay, composer, began discussing the idea for an opera based on the life of the 19th-century black statesman and orator Frederick Douglass, and they wondered if they would ever see the work staged. This week, six years after the completion of the opera, the New Jersey State Opera will present the world premiere of "Frederick Douglass" in Newark Symphony Hall.

title: Plane Crashes
description: To the Editor: There remains a problem that Betsy Wade did not mention. The public address systems on almost all planes are so poor that the garbled messages would be of little help in an emergency. I have ceased even trying to understand what is being said. CAROLINE POPE Salisbury, Conn.

OTHER AREAS Sayville, L.I. 179,000 18 Fairway East, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 52-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, den, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,300. Larchmont, N.Y. 250,000 283 Murray Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 66-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, eat-in kitchen, deck, 2-car detached garage; taxes $6,483. title: Harlem's Healers: A Hospital in Distress A special report.; For the Sickest Patients, an Ailing Hospital
description: A veteran nurse who spends long hours sorting through the ailing bodies, wounded spirits and disordered lives that seek healing at the Harlem Hospital Center carries a card in her wallet with this message: Do Not Take Me to Harlem Hospital in an Emergency.

title: Bulgaria to Open Its Files on Shooting of Pope
description: Nearly 10 years after the assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II, the Bulgarian Government announced this week that it would open its intelligence files that may unravel the mystery of who was behind the shooting.

title: Bartending Class Mixes Knowledge and Practice
description: "Is there something I can get you?" Jamie Berger asked the five people sitting on the other side of the bar.

title: Like Vintage Wine
description: To the Editor:

title: Lori Rubin Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Rubin of Stratham, N.H., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Lori Jon Rubin and Peter Fields Brill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Brill of Cranbury, N.J. Ms. Rubin, 30 years old, is the clinical director of the Van Ost Institute in Englewood, N.J., an outpatient counseling center for drug addicts and alcoholics. She graduated from Boston University and received a master's degree in psychology from Columbia University. Mr. Brill, 30, graduated from Rutgers University and is studying for a master's in education at Montclair State College.

title: About Cars; A Week of Concepts, a Day at the Park
description: This has been auto-show week in New York, and it has been a week for questions. Are there free tickets, was the one most asked, but there were others less venal. Is the show good? What's new? Is it exciting?

title: Redistricting Worries Democrats
description: THE population shifts reflected in the 1990 census have led to a reshuffling of New Jersey's 40 legislative districts that appears to diminish the Democratic Party's chances of maintaining its slim majorities in both the State Senate and Assembly.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL
description: THE YANKEES READER Edited by Miro Weinberger and Dan Riley. Houghton Mifflin, Paper, $9.95.

title: Kurdish Oppression in Turkey Goes On; Short-Lived Republic
description: To the Editor:

title: Benjamin Covino, 60, Anesthesiologist, Dies
description: Dr. Benjamin G. Covino, chairman of the department of anesthesia at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston and a professor at Harvard Medical School, died Thursday at his home in Shrewsbury, Mass. He was 60 years old.

title: Meskhi Comes Back to Finish Navratilova
description: It happened so quickly that she didn't even have time to work up a tear. Martina Navratilova not only faced but also fell victim to sudden death on a still, sultry Saturday morning as she failed to prevent Leila Meskhi from securing the single service game she needed to carve a 6-4, 2-6, 6-4 upset into the career of the third-best player on the women's circuit.

title: IN SHORT/BASEBALL
description: ONCE MORE AROUND THE PARK A Baseball Reader. By Roger Angell. Ballantine, $18.95.

title: Bridge
description: Very few men, or women, become famous for their contributions to two totally different activities, neither related to the business of earning a living. Such a one was Harold Sterling Vanderbilt, who died 21 years ago, just short of his 86th birthday.

title: Team-Spirited Classrooms
description: AMERICANS are putting their heads together. In the schoolrooms of cities as diverse as Fort Wayne, Ind., and New York, in colleges and graduate schools like M.I.T. and the Wharton School, at corporations like Xerox and Ford, people are coming out from behind their desks to team up with their peers. Educators call this cooperative learning. Business managers call it the team approach to problem-solving. Experts in each field say it is the way of the future -- primarily because of foreign competition.

title: Too Few Starters Concerns the Yanks
description: The last day of the Yankees' spring ended before it really began. In West Palm Beach, a torrential rain washed out their game against the Montreal Expos this afternoon, and the grounds at their home field were so wet that they couldn't even play an intrasquad game.

title: U.S. Lists Noncombat Death of Sailor and Soldier in Gulf
description: The United States Central Command today reported two more noncombat deaths in Persian Gulf operations.

title: Is It Really What's Inside That Counts?
description: To the Editor:

title: Starting April 14
description: The Times will have coverage throughout this season of the mementous 1941 campaings of Ted Williams and Joe DiMaggio.

title: Perspectives: East Flatbush Auction; Seizing the Moment on Linden Boulevard
description: AUCTIONS are systematically soaking up the oversupply of newly built condominiums across the Northeast, but in Brooklyn, in what essentially is a moderate-income housing market, the auction process is having a special impact. It is allowing blue-collar workers to latch on to exceptional housing values.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
For Offices, It's Mostly Custom-Building
description: WITH bank loans practically nonexistent for new speculative development, much of Long Island's office building is now being stirred up directly by companies that intend to use the new space.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. FRANCES J. DUNSTON;
Leading a Fight Against Lead Poisoning
description: AS New Jersey's Health Commissioner, Dr. Frances J. Dunston is leading the state's effort to screen children for lead poisoning and to educate the public about the disease, which she calls the most serious environmental and health danger to children.

title: Sheryl Watkins to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald R. Watkins of Darien, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Sheryl Ann Watkins, and Patrick Synan Dunleavy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Dunleavy of New York. Miss Watkins, an associate at the New York law firm of Webster & Sheffield, graduated cum laude from Boston College. She and her fiance received law degrees from Fordham University, where Mr. Dunleavy graduated summa cum laude and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He is an associate at the New York law firm of Willkie, Farr & Gallagher.

title: Somers H. Sturgis, 86, Birth Control Pioneer
description: Somers Hayes Sturgis, a pioneer in birth control research who was a founder of the first abortion clinic in Massachusetts, died Wednesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: Lori Shilkret Is Engaged to C. Duncan Parsons
description: October wedding plans for Lori Jill Shilkret and C. Duncan Parsons, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Parsons of Bedford, N.Y., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Del Shilkret of Millbrook, N.Y.

title: August Wedding For Ms. Goodman
description: Deborah Lynn Goodman, the curatorial assistant at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven, and Gerald Richard Davis, an architect who is studying for a graduate degree in business, plan to marry in August. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Goodman of Montreal; he is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Davis of Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: The Shape of Achievement, in the Artist's Own Words
description: In addition to being a dancer-choreographer, Martha Graham was an articulate voice for the arts in general. These excerpts, reflecting on dancers, choreographing and the artist's life, are drawn from her speeches, interviews and writings.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Lida Sunderland Wed in Baltimore
description: Lida Elizabeth Sunderland, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wallace Sunderland of Baltimore, was married there yesterday to Thomas Maurice Fitzgerald 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fitzgerald Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Van H. Gardner performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, assisted by the Rev. Robert J. Rokusek, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Corrections
description: A report about Israel in the Travel Advisory column on March 24 misstated the location of the Taba Hilton. It is in Egypt, not Israel. The Red Sea resort of Taba was handed back to Egypt in 1989, completing the return of Sinai territory occupied since 1967.

title: Walking the Colorado Trail
description: IT is not, not yet anyway, among the great walks of the world, not the longest or the highest or the most historic, even in the United States, though parts of it are startlingly beautiful. It does pass within climbing distance of the continental United States's second highest peak, Mount Elbert, which is 14,433 feet, and crosses the headwaters of the now tortured Rio Grande.

title: Dirk Bogarde Journeys Into 'Nostalgia'
description: After 13 years away from the cinema, Dirk Bogarde is back, in Bertrand Tavernier's "Daddy Nostalgia." He plays an aging businessman, with a French wife and an English daughter, confronting death with all the elegance and irony he can muster in a modest villa in the south of France. Although Mr. Bogarde, a nattily attired, improbably youthful 70-year-old, says it is his last film, he immediately qualifies the assertion by adding, "For Tavernier, I'd do a Japanese handbook on refrigerators, because I know he'd make something magical of it."

title: Paula McCarty and G. Alexander Stege to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. McCarty of Malden, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paula Anne McCarty, to G. Alexander Stege, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Stege of Greenwich, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia; Renovating A 1914 Tower
description: THE Widener Building, nearly eight decades old, is about to return to the downtown market after an $80 million rehabilitation begun after its major tenant decided to move.

title: Shifting Currents Affect Day Care in County
description: MORE parents are driving their young children to the office each morning as corporate-sponsored day-care programs proliferate in the county. At the same time, many day-care programs for the children of low-income workers are struggling as government subsidies are threatened.

title: Career Clothes, of a Feminine Variety
description: This spring many career women are exchanging tropical-wool styles that are spinoffs of men's suits for softly feminine fabrics, fluid silhouettes, warm colors and mix-and-match separates.

title: With Inspiration From Jim Thorpe
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nicole Polak Wed To Dr. P. D. Berk
description: Nicole Susan Polak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henri Polak of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday evening in East Norwich, L.I., to Dr. Paul David Berk, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Berk of Lakehurst, N.J. Rabbi Martin Rozenberg performed the ceremony at the Muttontown Club.

title: The World; Chile: Most Want the Past to Sleep, A Few Still Live in Nightmares
description: LUCIA TURIEL lives in a poor, outlying section of Santiago, in a small cinder-block house that is part of a car repair lot. She lives with her 7-year-old son and has been divorced twice. The lines in her gaunt face make her seem older than her 40 years. They are the result, in part, of a 15-year search for her brother, Mariano Turiel, who was abducted off the streets of Santiago on July 15, 1976. Until 1989, she believed he was alive, confined on one of Chile's thousands of islands. But two years ago, a former member of the Chilean secret police privately told the family that Mariano's body had been cut into pieces and buried in Colina, a city north of here.

title: Bilingual Tutoring Benefits Both Sides
description: MONDAY afternoons, after their last class ends, about 15 students in the Byram Hills High School Spanish Club jump into several cars for the drive down to the White Plains Public Library. They spend the next hour with Hispanic middle-school students who need help with English and other subjects.

title: Jourdan Arpelle, Art Consultant, Wed To Henry Steinway Ziegler, a Lawyer
description: Jourdan Arpelle and Henry Steinway Ziegler were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York by the Rev. Richard D. Leonard. The bride is the daughter of Mary Jane Demarest of Houston and Delmar E. Gerard of New Orleans. Mr. Ziegler is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederich J. Ziegler.

title: Sunday Dining; For Lunch, Dinner, Even Breakfast
description: Appetites do not always conform to the clock, especially on weekends, when schedules are less structured (and especially on this particular day, when daylight time begins). On Sundays, a number of downtown restaurants in Manhattan serve continuously, morning to night; others take just a brief break in the late afternoon. Here are three suggestions. La Boheme

title: Going On-Line
description: Until recent years, high technology in education amounted to some overhead projectors and VCR's in classrooms. Today, the roster starts with computers and goes on to something out of "Star Trek" -- virtual reality, whose advanced electronics can recreate an object, a person or an entire environment with which students interact. Clearly, American schools are not for the technophobic. But the problems of integrating technology into education are many: teacher resistance to new gadgetry; administrators who don't understand what is available and what it can do; hardware whose price may drive another wedge between have and have-not schools. A users' guide would be useful.

title: Ellen A. Sullivan to Wed Christopher J. Crovatto
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert G. Sullivan of Howard Beach, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen A. Sullivan to Christopher J. Crovatto, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Crovatto of Branford, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Franklin Simon 2d, 64, an Apparel Executive
description: Franklin Simon 2d, an apparel industry executive, died Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 64 years old.

title: Miss Cimilluca Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Michael Cimilluca of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Courtney Hampton Cimilluca, to Bartholomew Thomas Zanelli Jr., a son of Judith Brown Zanelli of Summit and the late Mr. Zanelli. A December wedding is planned.

description: A riddle for the ages, or at least for the Rangers: When is a goon not a goon?

description: Far From Moscow, Apathy

description: OUR GAME

title: Ann Wade and Richard Banchoff Wed in Capital
description: Ann Cotter Wade, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Barclay Wade of Interlaken, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Gerard Banchoff, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Banchoff of Ewing Township, N.J. The Rev. Ronald Murphy officiated at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Excess Romps Through Crafts Exhibit
description: "GILDING THE LILY," the show at the Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven, playfully challenges the notion that "less is more." More than 150 works by 40 artists make a persuasive case, subtly or blatantly, that more is -- well -- more.

title: Convenience Store Jobs: High Risks Alone at Night
description: "It's just a spur-of-the-moment thing," Daniel E. Remeta, in handcuffs and Government-issue blue cotton trousers and yellow T-shirt, explained of his post-midnight encounter with convenience store clerks. "Sometimes there wasn't going to be no robbery. Then somebody would say, 'Let's rob it.' "

title: Goat Cheese: The New American Staple
description: ONE of the more startling phenomenon in American eating in the last decade is the widespread acceptance of goat-milk cheese. And in great measure it has to do with the development of a domestic goat's milk cheese industry.

title: Hyla S. Tansky To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burton Tansky of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hyla Sharon Tansky, to Dr. Eric Weiss, a son of Dr. Richard Weiss of Norristown, Pa., and Dr. Norma Svedosh of Tewksbury Township, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Keri Schiowitz and Mayer Naiman Plan to Marry
description: Keri Schiowitz and Mayer Naiman, law students at Fordham University, plan to marry in August. Miss Schiowtiz, 23 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Schiowitz of Brooklyn. She graduated magna cum laude from Barnard College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Her fiance, 23, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Naiman of St. Louis. He graduated cum laude from Yeshiva University.

title: Tower Was Overcoming His Troubles When Death Struck
description: Only once, for a farewell luncheon with some Republican friends, did former Senator John G. Tower return to the Senate after his colleagues rejected his nomination for secretary of defense, the job he had long coveted.

title: Fond of Mystery, an Artist Lets the Work Speak for Itself
description: HARD times beget anxiety in the art world, as in any other, and for some museums and galleries the solution seems to be generating more paper. Never one copy of a press release when six will do seems to be the order of the day now.

title: World Markets; Top U.K. Index Hits Peaks, Thrice
description: The leading British stock-market index reached record closing highs last week on three successive days, as the London market rode a crest of optimism about lower interest rates, falling inflation and a relatively early end to the recession.

title: Plane Crashes
description: To the Editor: Regarding Betsy Wade's "Surviving a Plane Crash" (Practical Traveler, March 3), one of the most important considerations for airline safety was omitted. Namely, if the airlines reconfigured their planes so that the seats were facing backward it would substantially reduce death and injury during impact. (Notice how the cabin crew sits backward, with shoulder harness, during takeoffs and landings?)

title: Target: Drexel. Weapon: Tom Barr.
description: For 13 years during the epic antitrust battle that made his name, Thomas D. Barr of Cravath, Swaine & Moore waged total war against the United States Government. He clashed with several generations of antitrust lawyers from the Justice Department who were trying to break up his client, the International Business Machines Corporation. And he repeatedly attacked Federal District Court Judge David Edelstein, whom he accused of bias against I.B.M. and Cravath and tried to take off the case. Judge Edelstein once accused Mr. Barr of "threatening" and "bullying" him by gesticulating with a red pen. At other times, the Judge called him "a very spoiled brat," "a bad boy," and "a baby"; charged him with trying to turn the trial into "a stevedore's brawl," and of conducting himself in a fashion that he variously described as "unprofessional," "undignified," "intolerable," "slippery" and "absurd."

title: Yachting; Last Go-Round for Collegians
description: While most racing yachtsmen are just beginning to think about putting their boats in the water, collegiate sailors are winding down their 1990-91 season.

title: Streetscapes: The Ninth Milestone; At 473 West 152d, A 1769 Curiosity
description: UPPER Manhattan is the scene of a struggle of -- or at least over -- historic character.

title: Stamps
description: An early cover bearing the world's first postage stamp, the British Penny Black, has been sold at auction for $2.4 million, almost double the highest previous price for a philatelic item.

title: Nicholas Davies, 65; Was President-Elect of Doctors' Society
description: Dr. Nicholas E. Davies, an internist who was to assume office as president of the American College of Physicians later this week, was killed Friday in the commuter airline crash that also took the life of former Senator John G. Tower. Dr. Davies was 65 years old and lived in Atlanta.

title: Heard on the Street
description: RAINMAKER The Saga of Jeff Beck, Wall Street's Mad Dog. By Anthony Bianco. Illustrated. 486 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: Postings: A Panel at the Hilton; Regional Planning Forum
description: As part of an effort to shape the third major plan for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit advisory group, has assembled an array of prominent speakers and panelists for its 1991 Regional Assembly, a forum next Thursday from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M., at the New York Hilton Hotel..

title: Review/Cabaret; 'Follies' In Miniature
description: Twenty years ago, on April 4, 1971, the Broadway musical "Follies" opened at the Winter Garden Theater, where it played for 522 performances and won seven Tony awards. To commemorate that event, Jo Sullivan has put together what might be described as a living-room-musicale version of the show, which will play at Michael's Pub through April 27.

title: Campus Life: Tufts; Reports of Abuse At Housing Office Lead to Inquiries
description: Tufts University will audit the housing office after reports that student employees unfairly obtained prime campus dormitory rooms for themselves and their friends in the last two years.

title: A La Carte: Cheers for Island Wines
description: LONG ISLAND wines continue to make news and garner awards.

title: Travel Advisory; Yugoslavia
description: The Department of State advises Americans to defer nonessential travel to Yugoslavia because of political tensions, ethnic demonstrations and disruption of travel. Incidents in many areas of the country have included road blockades and injuries to bystanders, says a travel advisory issued by the department last month. Arbitary detentions, arrests and searches have involved Americans in some cases, it adds.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: East Patchogue 129,900 9 Neptune Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 17-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage, pool; taxes $3,200. Great River 240,000 7 Pinetree Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old farm ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, family room, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $6,000. Levittown 112,000 38 Border Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 41-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 60- by 100-foot lot; taxes $2,700. Sayville 179,000 18 Fairway East 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 52- year-old Cape Cod; dining room, den, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,300. Smithtown 230,000 56 Winston Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; den with fireplace, finished basement, deck, 1.6 acres, barn; taxes $5,100. Williston Park 207,500 34 Lafayette Street 3-bedroom, 2- bath, 60-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, patio; 40- by 150-foot lot; taxes $3,400. OTHER AREAS Larchmont, N.Y. 250,000 283 Murray Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 66-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, eat-in kitchen, deck, 2-car detached garage; taxes $6,483. Norwalk, Conn. 131,000 22 Todd Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 39-year-old ranch; roof, gutters and siding replaced, needs work, 0.33 acre; taxes $2,607 Bridgewater, N.J. 170,000 96 Hillside Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; family room, deck, eat-in-kitchen, porch; taxes $2,472.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Campus Life pages on March 17 about the Massachusetts Institute of Technology misstated the amount of money students must pay to spend a fifth year at the school, devoted solely to teaching. It is the regular tuition, currently $15,600, not $1,000.

title: SPECIAL REPORT: Ex Machina; The Electronic Edge
description: WHEN IT COMES to technology in education, "it's hard to use a crystal ball because the technology is changing every 18 months," said Sam Petruso, coordinator of computer services in the Mill Creek Township School District in Pennsylvania. Still, Mr. Petruso has engaged in a fair amount of crystal-gazing of late, equipping his district's elementary schools with computers, laser disks, compact-disk players, 8-millimeter video camcorders, videocassette recorders and Sony Watchman televisions.

title: 'YOU COULD OUTLIVE YOUR DOCTOR'
description: As a testicular-cancer victor and a physician, I read with intense interest the article by Brian F. Hayes, " 'Who Knows? You Could Outlive Your Doctor' " (March 17). My case was one of the luckier ones, requiring only two operations.

title: Visions Vs. Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: Maradona Suspended
description: Three weeks after testing positive for cocaine, Diego Maradona was given a 15-month suspension from international soccer yesterday, a penalty that could mean the end of the 30-year-old star's career as captain of the Naples team in Italy and of the Argentine national squad.

title: Gardens of the Heart
description: IT'S AS SIMPLE AS NIGHT AND DAY. You don't plant morning glories if you sleep until noon. Every gardener's priorities and values come from conscious and unconscious self-knowledge. But because home is so close to the heart, it is quite possible to be oblivious to the process of self-examination that shapes the way you garden.

title: Commercial Property: Failed Assemblages; Midtown Holdouts Produce Eclectic Menu of Uses
description: CRAB CAKES and kishka are coming to an old theater and loft building at Broadway and 47th Street and diners in the theater district may have reason to be grateful for a failed real-estate assemblage.

title: Mutual Funds; When Your Broker Cheats You
description: John D, a tax preparer in New York, had established a relationship with Nicodemus E. Faitos. He had worked with Faitos & Company, a brokerage firm in Huntington, N.Y., for many years without disappointment. He had attended the christenings of Mr. Faitos's children and had received flowers from Mr. Faitos on his 25th wedding anniversary. So he was flabbergasted when he discovered that Mr. Faitos was bilking clients.

title: A Heart To Heart Workout
description: BEFORE my first visit to a spa, I was ready for anything -- tofu tuna, underwater yoga, aerobic knitting, herbal wraps infused with frankincense and myrrh -- but I wasn't prepared for the way instant intimacy blossoms in that closed universe. Pampering and restorative physical exercise were foregone conclusions, but no one told me spas were so verbal.

title: No Charge Planned for Girl Accused of Dumping Baby
description: The 12-year-old Brooklyn girl accused of dropping her newborn boy into a trash compactor will not be charged with trying to kill the baby, the authorities in Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: Alma Maters Court Their Daughters
description: WEEKLY, MONTHLY, YEARLY, CAMPUS-GIVING PLEAS tumble into the mailboxes of America's college and university alumni, stirring memories and disturbing consciences. Each glossy full-color brochure, reunion invitation, nostalgia-inducing video and perky telefund call carries a single urgent subtext: send cash. But for many female college graduates, reactions to such appeals can be complex -- and getting more so.

title: Kinkmeister
description: While grocery shopping recently in Eddie's, a genteel food market in North Baltimore, the writer and director John Waters was approached -- as he recalls the incident -- by an elderly, well-heeled lady. "Oh, I love all your movies!" she gushed.

title: Willful, Combative -- and Honest
description: To the Editor:

title: BAGHDAD FORMALLY AGREES TO 'UNJUST' U.N. CONDITIONS FOR PERMANENT CEASE-FIRE
description: Five weeks after the United States and its allies drove Saddam Hussein's army from Kuwait, Iraq today accepted United Nations terms for a formal cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.

title: The Good Parts
description: As for Jim Brady, the man who had almost died and was left permanently brain-damaged, Nancy refused to invite him to any White House social functions. Only when she found out that she was going to be publicly criticized in a biography of Brady for such callous disregard did he receive an invitation.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on March 24 about European music festivals misstated the date of the Istanbul Festival. It is June 15 to July 25 (not July 15 to July 25).

title: Business Diary/March 31-April 5
description: COMPANIES Compaq, MIPs and a Strategic Graphics Alliance

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BORGE AT PURCHASE

title: When There Were Giants in This Town . . . And Dodgers, Too
description: SUPERSTARS AND SCREWBALLS

title: Suit by A.C.L.U. Challenges New Utah Anti-abortion Law
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has filed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of Utah's new anti-abortion law, the toughest in any state.

title: U.S. Medics Nurse Birds Felled by Oil
description: Thousands of square feet of camouflage netting, once intended to protect allied tanks from Iraqi air strikes, had instead been formed into a giant cage, and sitting inside in a listless row were 40 recently scrubbed birds, casualties of the Persian Gulf war oil spill.

title: Arts Program Falls in Budget Crisis
description: IN a small, windowless office on the first floor of New Haven's City Hall, the city's cultural affairs director, Allen Lowe, sat at his desk last month, surrounded by several beat-up chairs and filing cabinets. Despite the makeshift quality of the room, Mr. Lowe had managed to add some personal touches: his son's paintings, an old stereo system, a postcard bearing a black-and-white image of the jazz legend Charlie Parker and a bright yellow Homer Simpson doll, which sported Mr. Lowe's city identification badge.

title: Justice Loses Her Blindfold
description: Lawyers are clogging the corridors of fictional television this season, but viewers are not likely to be terribly comforted by the implied state of law, order or justice in the nation. Far from being a solid body of established precedent, law on a typical weekly series is a malleable commodity that can be bent, manipulated or simply ignored, depending on who is handling your case or how well you can bamboozle your lawyer.

title: U.S. Links 6 Deaths to Poor Hospital Care
description: The Government says six men who died at a large veterans' hospital in suburban Chicago were the victims of inadequate care.

title: Kidnappers of Long Island Boy Sought in Queens
description: The Nassau County police were searching in Queens yesterday for four young men in the kidnapping of a Long Island boy who was returned unharmed to his parents on Friday night by a baby-sitting service.

title: Wall Street; Bowne & Company - Is the Gain Really Justified?
description: Wall Street has apparently decided that Bowne & Company, a leading financial printer, will benefit in a big way from the paperwork to be generated by the anticipated boom in new stock and bond issues this year. Bowne's soaring shares closed on Friday at $16.25, their highest level since before the 1987 crash.

title: The Quiz
description: A troubled economy, bank failures and a war: sounds a bit like old times -- the 1930's, to be exact. But there are also significant differences between then and now that go well beyond Presidential initials. The Quiz points the way. (Answers on page 28.)

title: Why the Rich Should Pay an Extra Tax Share; Less Local Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Inventive CurriculumsCorrections
description: WHEN the Foreign Language Association of Georgia held its annual high school competition last spring, three of the topfour prizes in the Japanese section were taken by students who learned the language from teachers they had never seen in the flesh.

title: Elisabeth M. Quill To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Quill Jr. of Old Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Miller Quill, to Michael Scott Duncan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Duncan Jr. of Tenafly, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Genet Inspires Film on Fictional L.I. Town
description: IN a fictitious Long Island town, a 7-year-old boy sees his mother being beaten by his father and murders him. The boy disappears.

title: On the Street; That Touch of Whimsy
description: Whimsical, imaginative accessories are lifting spirits and announcing the arrival of spring. Among the eye-catchers sighted recently, a giant jeweled fly was perched on the shoulder of a classic coat. A chandelier motif seems popular: one made of fabric and crystal drops was appliqued on the back of a suit jacket; another, a miniature crystal chandelier, dangled as a lavaliere.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Palm Beach, Fla.;
Subdividing Trump Estate
description: DONALD TRUMP has filed plans to subdivide Mar-a-Lago, his Palm Beach estate, on which he has paid almost $300,000 a year in property taxes for the last several years.

title: Many Hands Make Daylight Work
description: In the Land of the Rising Sun, the sun rises (and sets) on standard time all year. No "extra" daylight for the industrious Japanese, thank you. Having had daylight time imposed on them by the American occupation authorities after World War II, they ditched it as soon as they regained their sovereignty in 1952. Then they got even.

title: Where Little Nothings Turn Into Big Somethings
description: Right now, the artist's sketchbook is all over town -- at "The Drawings of Anthony van Dyck" at the Pierpont Morgan Library (through April 21), in "Eugene Delacroix," which opens to the public on Wednesday (through June 16) at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and in an innovatory exhibition of contemporary "Artists' Sketchbooks" at the Matthew Marks Gallery on the Upper East Side (through May 4).

title: First Things First
description: WHETHER THE project is as small as painting a bathroom or as large as building a house, what are the top priorities for design professionals? What should you do if your own priority is to transform a dreary room without spending a fortune? Here is a sampling of advice from leading architects and interior designers who have confronted all these challenges -- and more.Establishing Priorities

title: Older Athletes Flock to Badminton
description: EVERY Friday afternoon, Ruth Marks goes to the Greenwich Y.W.C.A. to play badminton. She is working hard to improve her game and enters as many tournaments as possible to sharpen her competitive instincts. Although she only took up the game in early 1990, she said she was determined to become one of the best players in the state and hoped to earn a spot in the Olympics. The Senior Olympics.

title: CRIME
description: Rick Swenson, this year's winner of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, probably thought he had it rough, what with 20-below temperatures and 40-mile-an-hour winds roaring off the Bering Sea. Piece of cake, compared with the murderous conditions on the thousand-mile run from Anchorage to Nome in MURDER ON THE IDITAROD TRAIL (Atlantic Monthly, $18.95). The first fatality in this adrenaline-pumping debut novel by the Anchorage author Sue Henry occurs somewhere between Skwentna and Finger Lake, when one of the race leaders nods off from a doped drink and crashes into the woods. A second musher is killed when her sliced gang line snaps, sending her over a cliff into Happy Valley. There's another horror scene at Rainy Pass checkpoint, where a racer is torn apart by his drugged dog team.

title: About That Little P/E-Bond Yield Calculation
description: To the Editor:

title: L.A. Juice Bars: Tamarindo and Beyond
description: IS it any wonder that Southern California is home to a variety of juice bars (from stark to voluptuous, clearly ethnic to clearly wacky) when it has been home to body cultists (from Gaylord Hauser, seer to Garbo, to Arnold Schwarzenegger, muscle millionaire) and takes pride in its cult of gastronomy? Happily, juice tastes better when it's better for you: just squeezed from seasonal fruit. And in Los Angeles, where there's even a supermarket chain (Pavilions Place) with its own juice bar, you can find anything from fresh tamarindo to a connoisseur's collection of apple.

title: KEEPER OF THE FLAME
description: AT AGE 8, I DEBUTED as a decorator. Raised by two bachelor uncles who deferred to my sense of style, I had no doubts about what I wanted: an orange-, pink- and white-striped apartment, inspired by the design of a popsicle.

title: Miss Richards Wed to John Conklin 3d
description: Jennifer Ann Richards, a daughter of Marjorie Q. Richards of Falls Church, Va., and the late Col. Howard W. Richards, was married yesterday to John Joseph Conklin 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Conklin Jr. of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Hughes performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson.

title: Mutual Funds; Long and Short, the Bond Fund Gap
description: As a general rule, short-term bond funds react more quickly to changing interest rates than long-term funds. After a lag, the yields on long-term funds follow.

title: Dr. Janine Wollis To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Wollis of Great Neck, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Dr. Janine Gayle Wollis, and Robert Royal Tabas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Tabas of Haverford, Pa.

title: The Sandinista Decade
description: BLOOD OF BROTHERS Life and War in Nicaragua. By Stephen Kinzer. Illustrated. 450 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95.

title: Courtney Shands Walsh Is Married To Peter M. Phleger in Washington
description: Courtney Shands Walsh, the daughter of Courtney McFadden Price of Washington and Dr. John H. Walsh of Los Angeles, was married yesterday at St. Albans Episcopal Church in Washington to Peter Macondray Phleger, a son of Joan Casserly of Lower Lake, Calif., and the late Atherton Macondray Phleger. The Rev. Dr. Francis H. Wade and the Rev. Margaret McNaughton officiated.

title: Postings: Rowhouse Storefront; Stop-and-Go
description: Unbroken by storefronts for 102 years, a row of houses at Lexington Avenue and 89th Street is finally getting a taste of the 20th century -- complete with controversy, stop-work orders and a criminal summons.

title: All That Glitters Is Not Real, Book on Nancy Reagan Says
description: Of all the fictions perpetrated in American politics, perhaps one of the most absurd is that First Ladies have no power. They might occasionally weigh in on personnel issues, the nation is assured, but they would never meddle in policy.

title: Marie Jastrow, 93, Author of 2 Books on Immigrant Life
description: Marie Jastrow, who wrote two critically praised books describing immigrant life in turn-of-the-century New York, died at her home in Tucson, Ariz., on March 30. She was 93 years old.

title: Mass Graves Linked to Colombia Rebels
description: Soldiers searching a former guerrilla mountain headquarters have uncovered mass graves estimated to contain about 400 bodies, army officers say.

title: Taking the Cure the French Way
description: IT has been fashionable in some quarters of France to fight off the exercise craze with the saying that the reason humans have a body is to support the head. The head holds the brain, which can be fully exercised in clever conversation, and the mouth, which happily is there to be fed.

title: Jennifer Avellino Is Engaged to Zachary Levine
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alex Avellino of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Jennifer Avellino, and Zachary Levine, a son of Dr. Rhea C. Levine and Dr. Stephen M. Levine of Haddonfield, N.J. Ms. Avellino and her fiance are 23 years old and graduates of Dartmouth College. She is an associate producer for "Sonya Live," a talk show on the Cable News Network, in New York. He is studying medicine at New York University.

title: Knicks Defeat Pistons in Confidence Builder
description: The Knicks built another big lead last night. This time, they held on for a victory.

title: Living Out an Updike Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: Farmer Is Acquitted of Killing His Brother
description: A 60-year-old farmer accused of killing his sickly brother last June was found not guilty of second-degree murder late Friday night.

title:
Tech Notes;
Adding a Cylinder for Kick
description: Since the earliest automobiles, most cars have had two, four, six or eight cylinders. An even number of cylinders allows the up-and-down motion of each piston to be offset by another piston. An engine with an odd number of cylinders tends to vibrate more. Nevertheless, a few companies have used engines with three or five cylinders. Honda's new four-door Vigor comes with a five-cylinder engine (right) so as to pack more horsepower in a small engine compartment. Honda engineers dampened the vibration by careful timing of each piston's stroke. Their design also incorporates hydraulic devices at points where the engine is attached to the car's frame. The all-aluminum engine displaces 2.5 liters and produces 176 horsepower. By contrast, the Honda Accord has a 2.2 liter four-cylinder engine that produces 125 horsepower.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY:The first of three hearings on proposed U.S.-Mexico free-trade agreements. * National Labor Relations Board hearing on Greyhound. * Treasury report on auction of three- and six-month bills. * Federal Reserve reports on selected interest rates. TUESDAY: Center for Auto Safety releases report on fuel economy.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CAMPING WITH THE PRINCE AND OTHER TALES OF SCIENCE IN AFRICA, by Thomas A. Bass. (Penguin, $9.95.) In two years of accompanying scientists on their African expeditions, Thomas A. Bass met such engaging characters as a Kenyan biologist trying to reconcile scientific objectivity with a traditional belief in the spirit world and a Western ornithologist trying to protect heron habitats by putting together a hit song about reforestation. Last year our reviewer, Tony Eprile, said the author "succeeds admirably at providing a refreshing antidote to the news media's bleak portrayal of contemporary black Africa. . . . Mr. Bass makes a strong case for the limitless scientific possibilities of the continent, and for the adventurous scientists who frequently risk their lives for the 'something new' that always comes out of Africa."

title: For the Good of the Children
description: More than 900 guests filled Paine Webber's 39th-floor board dining room on Wednesday for a pre-theater cocktail buffet hosted by the company's chairman, Donald Marron, and his wife, Catie. The party then moved on to a preview of "Miss Saigon."

title: Louis Joxe, Gaullist, Dies at 89; Negotiated Algeria's Sovereignty
description: Louis Joxe, a veteran public servant and senior Gaullist official credited with negotiating Algeria's independence from France, died yesterday in Paris. He was 89 years old.

title: Review/Opera; 'Hospital,' By Protege Of Glass
description: "The Hospital (The Night Nurse)" is a new, 45-minute chamber opera by John Moran that opened on Thursday at Cafe La Mama, 74A East Fourth Street, and will run there Thursdays through Saturdays at 10 P.M. through April 20.

title: Pizza and Pasta on a Light-Hearted Menu
description: A RESTAURANT'S skills can often best be measured by the dishes that dominate the menu. The point is brought home at Centro, a new restaurant in Glenville section of Greenwich, on the Westchester line, where the primary categories are pastas and pizzas. In-depth exploration of the menu confirmed that these are the specialties in which Centro shines. Centro in Fairfield has been thriving for several years, but its Greenwich offshoot is new, situated in a converted brick mill facing a waterfall.

title: Too Few Starters Concerns the Yanks
description: The last day of the Yankees' spring ended before it really began. In West Palm Beach, a torrential rain washed out their game against the Montreal Expos this afternoon, and the grounds at their home field were so wet that they couldn't even play an intrasquad game.

title: Guy Boudin, Photographer, 57
description: Guy Boudin, a photographer of the erotic-surrealistic school of fashion popular with fashion magazines, died March 29 in Paris. He was 57 years old and lived in Paris.

title: Ms. Keeshan Wed To J. B. McGovern
description: Margaret Mary Keeshan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Keeshan Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Brian McGovern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. McGovern of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. The Rev. Charles W. Stubbs officiated at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: Revisiting a Milestone on the Road to Civil Rights
description: The British film maker David Lean once told George Stevens Jr. that the most difficult part of making a film was finding a story that you fall in love with.

title: Potters' Show Mixes Serenity and Whimsy
description: THE Potters' Guild of New Jersey Invitational Show sums up the diversity of contemporary ceramic styles, with a few flashbacks to classics of the past. Although the occasional juxtaposition of smooth, serene vases with whimsical sculptures can be jarring, the shock waves help to emphasize the distinctive qualities of both.

title: U.S. Sets Up Quake Detectors
description: New earthquake detectors, the first of a planned nationwide network of 100, have been installed in North Carolina and West Virginia. The new instruments, which went into service Wednesday, can tell scientists more about quakes and deliver the information more quickly than has been possible in the past, the United States Geological Survey said.

title: Jill Solodar Married to Alle Jetze Jacob Schilstra
description: Jill Suzanne Solodar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Solodar of Port Washington, L.I., was married in New York last evening to Alle Jetze Jacob Schilstra, the son of Nynke Louwsma-Kramer of Bolsward, the Netherlands. The Rev. David Stevens, a Methodist minister, and Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz performed the interdenominational ceremony at the Georgian Suite.

title: After the Homecoming, Another Battle Begins
description: UNLIKE soldiers who served in Vietnam, military personnel returning from the Persian Gulf are being warmly welcomed and widely lauded for their efforts. Nonetheless, when the hullabaloo dies down and life returns to normal, some of these newest combat veterans will suffer emotional damage from their experience, physicians and other veterans said.

title: Miss Haas Wed To M. B. Hosbein
description: Stephanie Elizabeth Haas, the daughter of Mrs. John C. Wright of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church to Mark Burkhart Hosbein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger L. Hosbein of Winnetka, Ill. The Rev. Foster C. Wilson officiated.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a picture from The Associated Press last Sunday showing the Russian Parliament in session referred incorrectly to the members shown. They were delegates from Leningrad who supported President Boris N. Yeltsin and were attempting to disrupt a speaker. The speaker was not a supporter of Mr. Yeltsin.

title:
DANCE;
Finding What 'Grabs' Newark Audiences
description: WITH a performance by the Joseph Holmes Chicago Dance Theater on April 26, Leon Denmark, the executive director of Newark Symphony Hall, takes his programming philosophy another step forward.

title: Neely Controls Adrenaline
description: Scoring goals is what the Boston Bruins' Cam Neely does best, as long as he doesn't try too hard.

title: Scrap Consensus, Try Diversity
description: One of the great bogus concepts wafting through management suites is something called "consensus:" solving knotty problems through unanimity.

title: The Many Sources Of Water Pollution
description: Julian Kane, in his response on March 3 to Mr. Ellinger's letter of Feb. 17, implies that the public water suppliers are responsible for ground-water contamination in Nassau County. This is not true.

title: Campus Life: Clarkson; Solar Car Steers Pupils to Careers In Engineering
description: What does one do with a used homemade car -- especially one that relies on solar power and has been driven more than 1,600 miles?

title: All Over the Map
description: THE MIND OF THE TRAVELER From Gilgamesh to Global Tourism. By Eric J. Leed. Illustrated. 328 pp. New York: Basic Books. $24.95.

title: Cast as Villains in Drought, Rice Farmers Defend Water Rights
description: Any day now, the rice farmers in the Sacramento Valley will burn, disk, furrow, fertilize and flood their fields and plant the crop that has made them the arch-villains of California's drought.

title: Campus Life: S.M.U.; Student Senators Ban Harassment Of Gay Students
description: The Southern Methodist University Student Senate overwhelmingly passed a proposal last week that prohibits harassment of gay students.

title: Bravest of the Braves
description: I HAD A HAMMER The Hank Aaron Story. By Henry Aaron with Lonnie Wheeler. Illustrated. 333 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $21.95.

title: September Bridal For Gail Ascher
description: Alan Ascher of Larchmont, N.Y., and Irma Ascher of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Gail Ascher to Thomas Minnock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Minnock of Tucson, Ariz. A September wedding is planned.

title:
END PAPER;
Education Amendments
description: EACH life has a turning point, a time when perspectives change and priorities are reorganized. Mine came when I earned my General Equivalency Diploma while I was in the United States Navy.

title: Q and A
description: Swiss Chocolate Factories

title: AS OLD AS YOU DRIVE
description: Virginia! How could you? You are a car salesman's dream come true! You didn't haggle, and you paid in cash by day's end. How can I buy the hardtop convertible of my retirement dreams if you are such a showroom pushover? You didn't even kick the tires. You didn't slam a door to listen to the thunk or run your hand over the seats to release that delicious new-car aroma.

title: Safety Skills For Older Drivers
description: MOST older people think that they are much safer drivers than the young people they see weaving perilously through speeding traffic, often enough with bare feet stuck out the window. After all, say the older drivers, we still drive as well as we did 20 years ago and we have never had an accident. If those teen-age menaces were off the road, older drivers say, driving problems would go away.

title: Headliners; What Evidence?
description: The Federal tax-evasion case against the Rev. Floyd H. Flake collapsed in a heap last week when the trial judge ruled that the prosecutors had failed to prove their central allegation -- that a normally tax-exempt fund for ministerial expenses was really both personal and taxable. The government had contended that Mr. Flake, who is also a Congressman, and his wife, Margarett, had not only evaded taxes on $228,000 that went into the fund over several years, but had also embezzled Federal funds, since some of the money came from a Government-subsidized program run by Mr. Flake's church in Queens. With the bulk of their evidence thrown out, the prosecutors dropped all charges. Surrounded by cheering supporters, Mr. Flake said, "I feel great." Some of his supporters said the indictment was racially motivated, but Mr. Flake, who is black, did not go that far. He said that the case may have been seen simply as an opportunity for "career advancement." Prosecutors denied both charges.

title: Review/Music; Lyons Orchestra Keeps a Tradition Alive
description: Charles DeGaulle's remark about the ungovernability of a country that makes 240 kinds of cheese also applies to France's symphony orchestras. In a musical culture known for its splendid wind and brass players, even the most celebrated French orchestras disappoint international ears. There is no out-and-out chaos, but instead a coarseness that hints at corporate dissatisfaction or, better yet, resigned indifference. The French do not take well to unanimity of opinion.

title: Kennedy Nephew Gives Blood to Police
description: William Kennedy Smith, the suspect in the reported rape of a young woman at the Kennedy family mansion here, voluntarily gave samples of his blood and hair to a Palm Beach police detective in Washington this morning, his lawyer said.

title: Fed Expected to Put Off Easing of Interest Rates
description: Despite shreds of evidence that suggest otherwise, most credit market analysts say the recession is still very much with us. Hopes that a turnaround may begin in the current quarter are merely that, they say.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday Balance of Trade . . . Feb. Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Producer Price Index . . . March Retail Sales . . . March Friday Consumer Price Index . . . March Business Inventories . . . Feb.

title: Richter Revels In First Shutout
description: When his first career shutout was in the books, when Mike Richter had made a final pad save on a three-line shot by Washington defenseman Rod Langway, there was John Vanbiesbrouck out on the ice hugging the Rangers' starting goaltender in a jumble of pads and well wishes.

title: INSIDE
description: Cooperating With Inquiry William Kennedy Smith, the suspect in the reported rape at the Kennedy family mansion, gave blood and hair samples to the police. Page A8. Judges to Go to Rikers Hoping to ease jail and court congestion, New York City will open two courtrooms inside Rikers Island's prison fences. Page B1.

title: Despite Butterflies, Gooden Is Ready
description: There are more dollars in his bank account than most mortals could conceive of spending, much less amassing. There is more magic in his right arm than most pitchers could imagine enjoying for a single start, much less employing for a career. Still, Dwight Gooden was expecting yesterday that there would be butterflies in his stomach when he awoke this morning, if indeed he fell off to sleep at all.

title: Miscellany
description: * Sassy Magazine, a publication of Lang Communications, will be published in Japan, beginning with the September 1991 issue. Sassy has given Kadokawa Shoten Publishing Inc. the rights to publish its Japanese edition.

title: Greenspan's Authority Curtailed On Interest Rates, Officials Say
description: Amid a debate at the Federal Reserve Board over whether lower interest rates are needed to help the nation out of recession, the central bank's policy-making body has curtailed the authority of its chairman, Alan Greenspan, to reduce rates on his own, high Government officials said over the weekend.

title: RN re: MG/BY
description: Marshal Yazov, the lugubrious Soviet Defense Minister, is apparently not the insensitive clod I always thought him to be.

title: Sentences for Cross Burnings
description: After a judge refused to accept the contention that burning crosses in front of two neighbors' homes was a prank, three men were sentenced to jail and fined on Friday. William Willis and Robert Dickson were sentenced in Polk County Court to four months in jail and fined $1,000. Larry D. Layne received two months in jail and a $500 fine. Two seven-foot crosses were set afire on March 24 outside the homes of a black family and a white woman who has black friends.

title: Nothing Legendary About Irish in France
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 7: MONDAY Carolina Frght Corp Phillips Pete Co Mercury Fin Co TUESDAY Hillebrand Inds Inc ITT Corp Procter & Gamble Co Travelers Corp WEDNESDAY Burlington Res Inc Hunt Mfg Co Southwestern Energy Co Walgreen Co Woolworth Corp THURSDAY Adams Express Co Arvin Inds Inc Ford Mtr Co Hartmarx Corp Parker Hannifin Corp Petroleum & Res Corp Universal Foods Corp Wisconsin Pub Svc Corp FRIDAY Flowers Inds Inc

title: A Maturing Beethoven
description: Three Beethoven string quartets, each from a different period, will be played by the Cleveland Quartet on Wednesday at 8 P.M. at the Miller Theater, Broadway and 116th Street. Tickets are $15 ($8 for students and the elderly). Phone: (212) 854-7799.

title: Review/Television; Certifying the Holocaust's Horrors
description: The Holocaust does not lend itself easily to film dramatization. Too often, the spectacle of well-fed, sparklingly toothy actors trying to depict the inhumanity of Nazi Germany's death camps is so absurd as to be almost obscene. On screen, the terrible story seems to be best captured when the focus is limited to a single person or incident, one of the most outstanding examples being "The Diary of Anne Frank." It's as if the enormity of the crime can only be fully grasped through mundane details.

title: Let the Bats and Patriotism Ring to Celebrate a New Season
description: There is always an urgency for the dawning of the major league baseball season. Adults call in sick for work and sneak away to the ball park on opening day. Children buy fresh packs of baseball cards. Presidents throw out first balls.

title: Hollywood's Man on the Hill Still Spinning a Web
description: Two months ago, word on the street was that Jack Valenti, a man many consider one of the best lobbyists in the capital, might be losing his magic.

title: With a Ban Lifted, Myers Fights Back
description: In 1988, Angel Myers almost had it all. She seemed about to win five Olympic swimming medals.

title: Sabres Triumph But Trail Series, 2-1
description: Defenseman Mike Ramsey's soft shot flipped over the shoulder of goalie Patrick Roy to snap a tie and give the Buffalo Sabres a 5-4 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight and their first victory in the three games of their playoff series.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers Wins in Overtime: Hersey Hawkins scored 31 points and Philadelphia tied the National Basketball Association record for most overtime victories in a season by beating the Bulls, 114-111, yesterday in Chicago. Hawkins scored 8 points in overtime as the 76ers handed the Bulls their second straight home loss. The Bulls are 32-6 at home, and two of the losses have been to Philadelphia. The overtime victory was Philadelphia's eighth this season, tying the mark set by Milwaukee in 1977-78. The 76ers also equaled a league record with their 13th overtime game of the season, matching the mark set by the Knicks in 1950-51.(AP)

title: Corporate Chiefs See Need For U.S. Health-Care Action
description: A survey on health care, taken among chief executives of the nation's largest companies, has found that 91 percent of them say a fundamental change or complete rebuilding of the health-care system is needed.

title: Bridge
description: Anyone who wishes to play in the biggest team event anywhere in the world in 1991 has probably missed the boat. Four hundred teams took part in the Lao Fong Xiang Cup in Shanghai in January, and it seems unlikely that this mark will be beaten, except perhaps in the same city, for the rest of the year. The people of China's major cities have become fervent devotees of a game that was banned during the Cultural Revolution.

title: Bank Plan Drawing Opposition
description: Two elements of the Bush Administration banking plan -- repairing the bank insurance fund and giving regulators power to move sooner into troubled banks -- may well become law, lawmakers and their aides say, but a proposal to permit industrial ownership of banks seems sure to die.

title: People
description: * Betty Anne Cooper has been named senior vice president-associate media director of Ogilvy & Mather Direct, New York. * John Joseph Condon and Mark John Oosthuizen have been named vice presidents at Leo Burnett Co., Chicago. * Scott Mauro has joined the Los Angeles office of Great Scott Advertising as senior vice president-entertainment marketing and production. * The New York Times Company Magazine Group named Madelyn Alpert-Roberts advertising director of McCall's magazine and Jayne Jamison advertising director of Child magazine.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Tokyo stocks finished lower today in light trading. Brokers said that investors were reluctant to move while the direction of interest and exchange rates remained uncertain. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended down 159.68 points, or less than 1 percent, to 26,607.65. At midday, the Nikkei was stronger, up 29.00 points, to 26,796.33, on a volume of 250 million shares. "The market is extremely boring," one trader said after morning trading. "But it is proving quite resilient in the light of Friday's fall in New York." On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 27.72 points, to 2,896.78.

title: Review/Television; 'Arab World': Attempt To Counter Stereotypes
description: "The Arab World" is a benign effort by Bill Moyers to counter the stereotype of the ugly Arab that has been circulating in recent years. Beginning tonight, at 10:30 on Channel 13, and running through Friday, he chats with Arab-Americans about the unpleasant images and admirable aspects of Arab society.

title: Market Place; HomeFed's Steep And Sudden Dive
description: THE HomeFed Corporation of San Diego once appeared to be a case history of how the deregulation of the savings and loan industry was supposed to work.
