HomeFed de-emphasized traditional single-family home lending, concentrating instead on making loans to commercial real estate and apartment developers while building a real estate development business of its own.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MILTON GLASER, the noted designer, is to receive the Herb Lubalin Award from the Society of Publication Designers at its annual gala on May 3 at the New York Public Library. The award, which is named for the highly regarded graphic designer, who died in 1981, recognizes Mr. Glaser's work.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: A Chronicler of America's Great Black Migration
description: Driving around sections of Philadelphia in 1980 while researching a newspaper series about a welfare mother, Nicholas Lemann got to thinking about what he was seeing out his car window. "I suddenly realized that these communities had gone through incredibly rapid changes in the space of one generation," Mr. Lemann says. "They had been white, and they had become black almost overnight. And I thought there was a story there."

title: Kohl Hears Few Cheers on Visit to Eastern Germany
description: On the same plaza where 130,000 ecstatic supporters cheered him as a redeemer just 14 months ago, Chancellor Helmut Kohl found only a handful of people today who were willing to welcome him.

title: Faldo Approaches Highest Plateau
description: WITH the same calm obsessiveness that has steadily taken him to the top of the game, Nick Faldo will attempt this week to do what no golfer has done and what only one other has ever had the chance to do -- win the Masters three years in a row.

title: Ewing and Jackson Are Turning It Up
description: This has been a memorable season for the Knick guard Mark Jackson, but for all the wrong reasons. He has been benched. He has been suspended. He has been involved in controversy and trade rumors.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Neither the United States nor anybody else can impose peace in the Middle East. And you are not going to get peace in the Middle East unless the parties themselves really want it, and at the most the United States can only serve as a catalyst." -- Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. [ A7:3. ]

title: Deals
description: Baseball American League

title: Physicians Shouldn't Assist Patients in Suicide; She Decided When
description: To the Editor:

title: Friends See Fragmenting Of Kennedys
description: Close friends of the Kennedy family say that its handling of allegations that a woman was raped at the Kennedy mansion in Palm Beach show how the once-vaunted Kennedy organization of the 1960's no longer functions in a smooth well-coordinated way.

title: New York City Promoting Parade for Veterans of Gulf
description: WITH the help of American Express and that company's marketing expertise, New York City is beginning an extensive campaign today to promote its "welcome home" parade in June for the troops who served in the Persian Gulf.

title: Robert Venturi Is to Receive Pritzker Architecture Prize
description: Robert Venturi, the Philadelphia-based architect who was instrumental in architecture's shift in the last quarter century from the simple austerity of modernism to an appreciation of past and popular styles, is to be named today as winner of the 1991 Pritzker Architecture Prize.

title: 2 Business Advisers Urge Dinkins To Take 3 Steps to Save Millions
description: The leaders of Mayor David N. Dinkins's business-labor advisory panel on management are prodding him to adopt three of the group's recommendations that they say could eventually save New York City hundreds of millions of dollars a year and reduce the need for crippling service cuts and higher taxes.

title: '900'-Call Safeguards
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Piano; Igniting the Keyboard
description: Kathleen Supove, the pianist who gave a contemporary-music concert at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening, called her program "The Exploding Piano." She did not literally detonate her instrument, but she drew a great many figurative sparks from it.

title: Physicians Shouldn't Assist Patients in Suicide; Many Take Active Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Sixers in a 'Feud'; Tears in Brooklyn
description: THE Philadelphia 76ers staged their own version of "Family Feud" at a recent fund-raiser for the Special Olympics, with Rick Mahorn's Thumpers beating Charles Barkley's Bumpers, 4-2. Some of the questions included the silliest nicknames and shiniest heads in the league. The winning (or losing) nicknames were Spud, Mookie, Pooh, Sleepy and Muggsy. The baldest domes belonged to Barkley, Michael Jordan, Brian Oliver, Xavier McDaniel and Atlanta coach Bob Weiss. . . . Nostalgia baseball buffs, especially those from Brooklyn, may need a box of tissues if they remember what happened on tomorrow's date in 1913. Ebbets Field opened.

title: Eliza Heimann Wed to Jon Greenberg
description: Eliza Faith Heimann, the daughter of Margaret F. Heimann and John G. Heimann, both of New York, was married yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York to Jon Greenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Greenberg of New York. Rabbi Leonard Beerman, an uncle of the bride, officiated.

title: Physicians Shouldn't Assist Patients in Suicide; Following the Statutes
description: To the Editor:

title: Flawless Sabatini Subdues Meskhi
description: Time was when Gabriela Sabatini, unsure on the tennis court and insecure away from it, scared herself: she didn't know if she was the player many people claimed she should be.

title: Newark's Loss May Really Be Its Renaissance
description: Newark may be America's most incredible shrinking city, but its ego is growing.

title: A Fielder's Dreams
description: I love baseball, but when the season opens today in Kansas City and Baltimore and New York and half a dozen other cities, I won't be at the ballpark and I won't be in front of a TV set. I'm not very good at spectator sports. I'll be fishing.

title: Hyundai Plans China Venture
description: South Korea's Hyundai conglomerate plans to invest in vehicle manufacturing in China, a company spokesman said today.

title: Study Shows Power Of Public-Service Ads
description: In the advertising industry's first comprehensive study of public-service campaigns, researchers have found that television commercials can induce striking changes in people's behavior regarding health.

title: Outdoors: Gizmos and Gadgets for Graceful Casting
description: ALONG with its graceful, seductive rewards, fly fishing can also be a sport that dispenses enormous frustration. The business of getting into a slippery channel of fast, pushy water, and fiddling with umpteen mechanical devices that hang from or nestle in umpteen vest pockets is tricky and humbling.

title: How Politics, Not Voters, Molds Budget In New York
description: Schoolchildren, motorists and nursing-home patients. Library users, beachgoers and business executives. All these groups, indeed, virtually all of New York's 18 million residents, are affected by the state budget.

title: Dance in Review
description: Betsy Hulton and Dancers St. Mark's Church 131 East 10th Street

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE, LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE -- 10:30 A.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION -- 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON PALESTINIAN RIGHTS -- 3 P.M.

title: Colombia Ties Drug Cache to 3 in Jail
description: Are the Ochoa brothers trafficking in cocaine from jail?

title: Futures Brokers Indicted
description: Two futures brokers who were expelled from the industry and fined last year for cheating customers have been indicted on Federal criminal charges, according to the United States Attorney's office in Chicago. Norman Furlett and Ira Greenspon, who solicited customers for the defunct futures trading company GNP Commodities Inc., are charged with diverting more than $100,000 in profits from winning trades into their personal accounts while allocating losing trades worth more than $200,000 into their customers' accounts in 1986. If convicted on all counts, the two could each face up to 70 years in prison, a spokesman for the United States Attorney's office said.

title: Two Jurors Visit Church To Hear Flake's Sermon
description: On the first Sunday after a Federal tax-evasion and embezzlement case against him was dropped, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake looked out from his church pulpit in Queens to find two jurors from his trial attending a late-morning service.

title: 6 U.S. PLANES BEGIN AIRLIFTING RELIEF TO KURDS IN IRAQ
description: Beginning an airlift that Air Force officers said could continue for weeks, six United States cargo planes parachuted tons of packaged meals, bottled water and medical supplies today to Kurdish refugees scrambling to reach Turkey from Iraq.

title: A Homecoming At Shea Opener
description: A QUICK opening day baseball quiz: What five players were in the starting lineup at Shea Stadium last year and will be today? The first four are easy: Dwight Gooden, Gregg Jefferies, Howard Johnson and Kevin McReynolds. The last one is not so simple. No, it is not the organ player or the scoreboard operator. The answer is Wally Backman. That's right, the scrappy fellow who teamed up with Lenny Dykstra at the top of the lineup when the Mets won the 1986 World Series, is reunited with Dykstra as the starting second baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies. The Mets play host to the Phillies today, so Backman is back at Shea. Last season, he started at third base for the Pirates when the Mets opened against Pittsburgh. If you want to know where Backman will be next season, just check out the Mets' 1992 schedule.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Ford Motor Credit Co. is offering $250 million in 8 5/8 percent noncallable notes, due in 1996, at 100, through Goldman, Sachs & Co., to yield a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: Holmes's Real Fight In the Parking Lot
description: Larry Holmes's comeback fight -- an easy one-round knockout over Tim (Doc) Anderson tonight -- was overshadowed by a bizarre brawl afterward between Holmes and another former heavyweight champion, Trevor Berbick, before a shocked crowd in front of the Diplomat Hotel here.

title: Arrest Heats Up Ethnic Tensions In Williamsburg
description: Hasidic and Hispanic groups gathered outside the Williamsburg precinct station house in Brooklyn yesterday after a Hasidic man was charged with assaulting a Hispanic officer who has asserted that Jews in the area get special treatment from the police.

title: Nancy S. Henken Is Married on L.I.
description: Nancy Sue Henken, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Henken of Jericho, L.I., and Randolph Arthur Stuzin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore D. Stuzin of Plainview, L.I., were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Kenneth Hain.

title: Storm Clouds Over Stadium Dim the Opener in Detroit
description: Baseball has been played at the corner of Michigan and Trumbull for more than 90 years, but that will change soon if the owner of the Detroit Tigers has his way.

title: San Francisco Journal; Where Quaint Doesn't Mean Quiet
description: Nothing else is so instantly identified with San Francisco as its cable cars, those quaint relics lumbering up the hills, cumbersome but precious keepsakes from the city's Victorian past.

title: Leahy Legacy On Irish Diamond
description: WHEN it comes to famous names in Notre Dame sports history, that of the late Frank Leahy ranks near the top. The renowned football coach guided the Fighting Irish to an 87-11-9 record and five national championships in 11 seasons. Now his grandson Pat is on campus making a new name for his family in a different sport.

title: Bush Pledges To Fight for Mexico Pact
description: President Bush promised today to fight organized labor "head on head" to win Congressional approval of a free-trade agreement with Mexico.

title: Review/Theater; The Bizarre World of Barbie Dolls and Nuns
description: In "Sister Bernice," the final sketch of his dazzlingly funny evening of character comedy, Jeffrey Essmann, wearing a nun's habit, impersonates an ancient parochial-school teacher grimly introducing herself to a fourth-grade class on the first day of school. Shaking her finger, she announces that her very name embodies a terrible warning. Those who are not "nice," she says, hissing, will "burn" in Hell.

title: NCR Head Remains Firm
description: The chairman of the NCR Corporation said yesterday that he would not recommend a sale of the computer maker to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for less than $110 a share, or $7.45 billion. The price has been rejected several times by A.T.& T.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Books of The Times; Son's Last Duty: The Final Decision
description: Someday By Andrew H. Malcolm Illustrated. 296 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: 6-Finger Fastball May Be Coming
description: CAN a six-finger pitcher get more on his deliveries than a five-finger thrower? Antonio Alfonseca, an 18-year-old right-hander from the Dominican Republic who has six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, is in extended spring training with the Montreal Expos trying to find out.

title: A Weight Rolls Away, and Russians Rejoice
description: If the talk in Moscow these days is of backsliding and crisis, the celebration of Easter served to remind people of how far the nation has traveled in only a few short years.

title: 44 Years Later, Murder Haunts A 'New' Man
description: He is a gentle, heavyset man of 62, with grayish hair, a parchment face and one eye to read his Bible every day. For most of his life, he lived in Harlem and worked as an elevator operator. By all accounts, he was a good family man and father who sang in a church choir and led a quiet, upstanding life.

title: To Papers, Funnies Are No Joke
description: When The Washington Post recently tried to drop the venerable comic strips "Mark Trail," "Gasoline Alley" and "Steve Roper & Mike Nomad," the response was overwhelming and -- to old hands at the very serious business of syndicated newspaper comics -- predictable.

title: Nona Balakian, 72, Retired Book Critic And Editor for Times
description: Nona Balakian, a literary critic, essayist and a former editor on the staff of The New York Times Sunday Book Review, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 72 years old.

title: French Shift on State-Owned Sector
description: In a sharp reversal of policy, the Socialist Government of France has announced that it will allow private investors to acquire up to 49 percent of companies in the huge state-owned sector.

title: Helicopter and Heinz's Plane Were Beyond Controller Area
description: Federal investigators have said the collision between a helicopter and a small plane that killed Senator John Heinz and six other people occurred in airspace outside the responsibility of the air traffic controller.

title: Rikers to Bring Judges to Inmates, Instead of Inmates to Judges
description: New York City will soon open two courtrooms inside Rikers Island's prison fences to ease jail and court congestion.

title: 'Seeds of Race Hate'
description: An extraordinary two-part television film began last night on the ABC network and concludes this evening. It is called "Separate but Equal," and it tells the story of the school segregation case decided by the Supreme Court in 1954.

title: Emir Vows to Hold Elections But He Offers No Firm Date
description: In an effort to calm mounting demands for democratic reform, the Emir of Kuwait said tonight that parliamentary elections would be held "during the coming year, God willing."

title: Why 'Other' Is Our Second Fastest Growing Racial Category
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Demoted; Or is it Promoted?
description: WHEN Princeton announced it was switching Larry Ellis from head track coach to men's cross-country coach for next season, the antenna quickly went up. Was Ellis taking the fall for the embarrassment that was caused by the great Princeton impostor, Alexi Indris-Santana, who attended the school and ran track even though he was a 31-year-old fugitive? According to Ellis, who had to stop laughing before he answered the question, he is not being penalized for the escapades of the real James A. Hogue. Ellis is stepping aside because he is one of the leading candidates to become president of The Athletics Congress, not because he is a fall guy.

title: How to Save Money in New York City
description: New Yorkers are bombarded with daily accounts of the city's purported collapse. City Hall is accused of incompetence. Business and labor are said to be fleeing or ripping off the city. The public and private cooperation that rescued the city in the 1970's is deemed history.

title: McCann Yugoslav Unit In Training Program
description: Jadran McCann-Erickson, the Yugoslav agency of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, has set up a training program for students at the University of Zagreb in northern Yugoslavia.

title: Louis Joxe, Gaullist, Dies at 89; Negotiated Algeria's Sovereignty
description: Louis Joxe, a veteran public servant and senior Gaullist official credited with negotiating Algeria's independence from France, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 89 years old.

title: Utilities Design Car Battery
description: The Arizona Public Service Company and the Southern California Edison Company say they have developed a battery that can power an electric car at speeds of up to 85 miles an hour and a range of up to 125 miles.

title: G.I.'s Recall Destruction Of Powerful Iraqi Force
description: Even by the grim standards of the Persian Gulf war, this stretch of desert, where troops from Iraq's Medina Division made their last stand, is an impressive tableau of destruction.

title: Child Support Payments Stop At State Lines, Panel Is Told
description: It has been nearly a year since Christine Allen last received the $55 weekly payment her former husband was ordered to pay to support their 5-year-old daughter, Ashleigh. In the meantime she lost her job, and her former husband, who lives in Alabama, has evaded what she considers the weak efforts of officials there to take him to court.

title: In Tennis, Child Prodigies Whet the Agents' Appetites
description: The next time an ambitious parent hangs a cute tennis mobile above a child's crib the way Andre Agassi's father once did, there could very well be an agent standing by to jiggle it with one hand and sign the prodigy to a business contract with the other.

title: Redistricting Brings About Odd Alliance
description: In a nationwide alliance of political convenience, Republicans have joined with traditionally Democratic Hispanic and black groups in the battle to redraw Congressional districts before the 1992 elections, with both pressing for districts in which minority populations would dominate.

title: Elections to Be Held, Emir Tells Kuwaitis
description: As frustration mounted in Kuwait over the lack of democratic change, the Emir said parliamentary elections would be held "during the coming year, God willing."

title: Dance in Review
description: Battery Dance Company Gould Hall 55 East 59th Street

title: Excerpts From Letter to U.N.: Iraqis 'Accept This Resolution'
description: Following are excerpts from a broadcast by the Baghdad radio today of the letter sent by Foreign Minister Ahmed Hussein of Iraq to the Secretary General of the United Nations and the President of the Security Council, accepting the Security Council's cease-fire terms, as monitored and translated by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: For Vietnamese, a Wave of Gang Terror
description: Roaming the freeways around the country, their weapons in the trunks of their cars, growing numbers of Vietnamese gangs are terrorizing refugee neighborhoods with what the police have come to call home invasions.

title: Sanjurjo Can Play; But Can He Cook?
description: DEPENDING on who you ask, John Sanjurjo is known for burying jump shots or making sweet potato pie. His basketball coach at Bronx Community College mentions his shooting prowess, and the two younger brothers he helps raise rave about his cooking ability.

title: Public-Safety Steps Are Still Incomplete On New Train Route
description: A train route untraveled for decades through Manhattan's Upper West Side, where homeless people built homes and children played, opened yesterday with few warning signs and no fencing in some areas to prevent trespassing.

title: Seeking to Stay Out of Proxy Battles
description: Dozens of companies that want to avoid messy proxy battles are quietly accepting the demands of pension funds to lower their takeover defenses and broaden the rights of shareholders.

title: Unshackle Nursing Home Patients
description: Every day, half a million elderly patients are tied down, strapped in or drugged into a stupor in American nursing homes. Only a few are dangerous to themselves or others. The overwhelming majority are restrained or sedated because it makes them easier to handle. The practice is not only bad for the patient; it blemishes the nursing home industry.

title: For 7th Avenue's Garment Industry, Nowhere to Go but Up
description: Designers worked late and ate deli. Stringbean-slim models hurried up and down in grimy freight elevators for last-minute fittings. Hems were pinned up and then let down again, as the garment center, New York's No. 1 manufacturing industry, cranked up and painted its face last week for another round of seasonal showings.

title: Fans: Best Teams Are A's and Reds
description: THE 26 major league baseball teams are starting even today with 162 blank scorecards to fill in during the months ahead, but if the national pastime's most devoted -- and presumably most knowledgeable -- fans know their apples, when April hope dwindles to October reckoning, it will be the Cincinnati Reds and the Oakland Athletics in the World Series once again and this time the A's will win.

title: Accounts
description: * Bulova Corp., New York, to Weiss, Whitten Inc., New York. Although total billings were not disclosed, the assignment includes the company's new start of its Accutron line of watches, with a budget of $5 million. The incumbent agency was McCaffery & Ratner Inc., New York. * Stroh Brewery Co., Detroit, awarded its Canadian advertising account for its Old Milwaukee and Old Milwaukee Light brands to Ross Roy Canada Ltd. Billings were not disclosed. * Korff U.S.A., a producer of skin-care products, to Deutsch Inc., with a budget of $2.6 million. Saatchi & Saatchi had been the incumbent. * Olsten Corp., a temporary employment service based in Westbury, L.I., to Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss Inc., New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Review/Music; Three Women Perform Vanguard Voice Works
description: The Composers' Forum had a nice idea to invite three leading female singers of contemporary music to share a program Wednesday night at Merkin Concert Hall. With Christine Schadeberg, Dora Ohrenstein and Joan La Barbara on the stage, Meredith Monk and John Cage in the audience and the spirits of Cathy Berberian and Philip Glass in the air, the concert proved a real feast of vanguard singing and vanguard composition for the voice, with six world premieres and five New York premieres.

title: Progress in Umpire Talks
description: Making a final effort to get major league umpires on the field for today's season openers, negotiators for the umpires and baseball's club owners appeared to make progress last night in their talks for a new collective bargaining agreement. But then the talks hit a snag over the owners' pension contribution.

title: The Woman Who Replaced Jane Pauley's Replacement
description: From the moment Katherine Couric walked onto the set of the "Today" program and smiled into the camera, NBC insiders began whispering that Deborah Norville, the co-host, was history.

title: Islamic Radicals Lose Their Tight Grip on Iran
description: The revolution that transformed Iran's Western-oriented cosmopolitan society into a militantly Islamic republic seems to be on the wane.

title: A Rookie's Mistake Is Costly to Devils
description: An unfortunate mistake by Eric Weinrich, the rookie defenseman of the Devils, led to Mark Recchi's second goal in the game with 50 seconds left and that lifted the Penguins to a 4-3 triumph over the Devils.

title: U.S. to Sell Bills and 7-Year Note This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills and an auction on Wednesday of a new seven-year note.

title: Baker Starts Mideast Trip as Peace Hope Dims
description: Opening a swing through the Middle East, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other officials acknowledged today that their initial, exploratory efforts for an Arab-Israeli settlement had gotten nowhere and that it was now time for Washington to begin pressing the parties for specific concessions to one another.

title: A Mayoral Boost for RU-486
description: If the French "abortion pill," known as RU-486, were available in this country, abortion would be as private a decision as it should be and considerably safer than it now is with surgical procedures. But thanks to what New York's Mayor David Dinkins rightly calls "lonely hecklers . . . who should be ignored," it is not yet available.

title: New Computer Alliance Forms
description: In an extraordinary alliance, more than a dozen computer companies will announce tomorrow their commitment to a new and untried chip they hope will dominate the computing world in the years to come.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two professors have won Columbia University's Bancroft Prizes in American history. LIZABETH COHEN of Carnegie-Mellon University and LAUREL THATCHER ULRICH of the University of New Hampshire received the awards, along with $4,000 each, on Wednesday at Columbia.

title: Sarah H. Reines, Student, Marries
description: Sarah Helaine Reines, the daughter of Miriam K. Reines of New York and the late Borah Reines, was married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in New York to Richard Alan Bornstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Bornstein of Stoughton, Mass. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel and Cantor Howard Nevison performed the ceremony.

title: Hugh R. Chace Banker, 86
description: Hugh R. Chace, a former senior executive vice president of the Bank of New York, died March 30 at Baptist Medical Center in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. He was 86 years old and lived in Ponte Vedra Beach.

title: Two Favorite Sons Take Time to Get Acquainted
description: THEY are two of southern Indiana's biggest sports heroes, with hometowns two hours apart, but Don Mattingly and Larry Bird had never met until last week. "Different seasons," Mattingly explained. "I'm around during the winter and he's around during the summer."

title: New Assembly Hall Opening At the Brooklyn Museum
description: Never mind the cuts in staff, the reductions in visiting hours, the pared-to-the-bone economies that the city's financial plight has thrust on it. Tomorrow there'll be joy at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Somebody Has to Pay for Our Cheap Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Engine Wreckage of Tower's Plane Is Examined
description: Federal investigators examined engine wreckage and combed through maintenance records today for clues to whether some kind of engine failure led to the plane crash that killed former Senator John G. Tower and 22 others on Friday.

title: J. C. Hill, 76, Teacher; Led Arbitration Panel
description: James C. Hill, a former arbitrator of labor-management disputes in New York, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in Fort Myers.

title: Kohlberg-Granite Deal
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and the Granite Capital Group said yesterday that they had formed the Granum Communications Company to buy and manage radio stations. Herbert W. McCord was named president and chief executive of Granum, which will be based in New York. Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts would not disclose how much capital it had invested in the new company. Granum is similar in structure to K-III Holdings Inc., a company formed in 1989 by Kohlberg, Kravis and several former executives of Macmillan Inc. to acquire publishing companies.

title: Question Box
description: Ruth's Driest Spell

title: Spira Goes On Trial
description: Howard Spira, the Bronx man whose involvement with George Steinbrenner triggered the Yankee owner's ouster as the team's managing partner, goes on trial in United States District Court in Manhattan today.

title: Mortgage Rates Down
description: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.49 percent last week, down from 9.52 percent in the previous week, according to a national survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.39 percent, down from 7.41 percent in the previous week and the lowest since 1984, when data collection started.

title: Riding the Past From Grand Central
description: Looking back from the observation platform, one hand on the polished old railing, John Wilson wanted to make a few remarks. Mr. Wilson has been a redcap at Grand Central for the last eight years and is as talkative a fellow as you could find anywhere between Manhattan and the long-winded politicians of Albany. But for once not even he could come up with the right words.

title: Pentagon Payment Decision
description: Two House panels are investigating the Pentagon's decision to allow manufacturers of the canceled A-12 Stealth fighter plane to defer repaying $1.35 billion to the Government.

title: Yanks Take Aim at Forgetting Last Year
description: Even if the memories of 1990 still seem vivid, the season that unfolds for the Yankees on Monday afternoon may make them easier to forget.

title: Los Angeles Times Revamps Magazine in a Bid for Ads
description: The Los Angeles Times Magazine has for years been something of a stepchild at the newspaper, inconsistent in quality even in the view of its own staff members, and not terribly appealing to advertisers.

title: Dance in Review
description: Juilliard Dance Ensemble Juilliard Theater 155 West 65th Street

title: In Freeze's Wake, Desperation for Citrus Workers
description: Since they were youngsters, Jose and Delia Ayon toiled under the California sun to pick and pack the fruits and vegetables that fill American supermarkets. Now they cannot get enough food for their seven children, and they face losing the small house they built with their own hands.

title: Spacewalking Astronaut Repairs Satellite With a Quick Push
description: Two astronauts took a spacewalk outside the shuttle Atlantis today to make an emergency repair of a major malfunction, freeing a jammed antenna and clearing the way for deploying an astronomy satellite that is to observe the mysteries of galaxies and black holes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARJORIE WYLER is to receive the Eternal Light Award from the National Women's Patrons Society of the Jewish Theological Seminary at a luncheon on Tuesday at the Water Club in Manhattan. The award is given annually by the society, which raises money for the seminary, to a person who embodies scriptural values. Mrs. Wyler, 75 years old, is director of radio and television relations at the seminary.

title: BASEBALL '91: On Baseball; Nothing Can Delay First Pitch
description: IT happens every spring.

title: Drinks Draw Women, And Women Draw Men
description: Ladies' Night at the Far Out Lounge. Two nervous young women, huddled at the dark end of a bar on First Avenue, slug down something that makes them wince.

title: Physicians Shouldn't Assist Patients in Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL '91: Sports of The Times; 'Play Ball!' and All That Jazz
description: YOU realize, of course, that daring to say something negative about the opening of the baseball season is like putting the knock on Christmas.

title: Jobless Rate: Don't Overreact
description: Last week the Labor Department announced that the unemployment rate jumped to 6.8 percent in March, its highest level in more than four years. About 2 million Americans have lost their jobs since last summer, more than 700,000 since January.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; Victory in a Boxing Match May Go to Pay-Per-View
description: AS Seth G. Abraham, the president of Time Warner Sports, sees it, the television industry will change irrevocably on the morning of April 20.

title: Tough Solutions for Connecticut
description: From sea to shining sea, governors are grappling with steep budget problems, none steeper than Connecticut's. Faced with a deficit that's one-third of the whole budget, and still growing, Gov. Lowell Weicker has ordered that 2,600 state workers be laid off, and most state agencies shut down for two days a month. Mr. Weicker has always talked tough. Now he's acting, and none too soon.

title: Robert Andrews, 68, Automotive Designer
description: Robert F. Andrews, an industrial designer who specialized in streamlining cars, died on Friday at the Flower Hospital in Toledo, Ohio. He was 68 years old and lived in Monroe, Mich.

title: Poor Little Rich Land, Ruing the Life It Lately Led
description: To be fair, many Andorrans are quick to blame themselves. Indeed, they add repentantly, if this tiny principality tucked in the Pyrenees is now bemoaning its identity crisis, it is because its citizens have been too anxious to get rich quickly.

title: Rangers Trounce the Capitals, 6-0
description: Mike Richter's first National Hockey League shutout had the obvious marquee value tonight when the Rangers beat the Washington Capitals, 6-0.

title: Firefighters Extinguish Kuwait Oil-Well Blaze
description: A Texas firefighting team today extinguished the first of 500 oil-well fires set by Iraqi troops and declared a "small victory" that could mark a turning point in the operation.

title: Nicklaus Rallies To Win
description: Jack Nicklaus, making another of his legendary final-round runs, shot a five-under-par 67 this afternoon in The Tradition tournament to defend his title with a one-stroke victory over Jim Colbert, Phil Rodgers and Jim Dent.

title: Philip Morris Is Criticized
description: Three health groups criticized the Philip Morris Companies today for marketing low-nicotine cigarettes, which they said would mislead smokers into believing these brands were safer and less addictive than other cigarettes.

title: Broten Leaves His Mark As a Capital Winds Up Swathed in an Ice Bag
description: They don't keep statistics for all of Paul Broten's contributions, but sometimes there is evidence -- like the big ice bag that was tied to the right leg of Washington's Dimitri Khristich after practice today at the Capital Centre.

title: Detroit Strives to Reclaim Lost Generation of Buyers
description: When Sue Anderson passed her driver's exam 10 years ago, she inherited the family Mazda. After graduation from college, she bought her family's Saab. Last year, the 26-year-old graphic designer from Grand Rapids, Mich., bought her first new car. It was a 1990 Mitsubishi Eclipse.

title: I.B.M. Introduces Airline Software
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had introduced a new software system for airline services and was working with USAir Group Inc. to develop applications for the airline industry. I.B.M. said USAir had participated in field tests for the new product, called the Airline Application Development System, and that it would begin installing the software in trial applications in July.

title: Trade Panel Meets in Japan
description: A new high-level committee of Japanese and foreigners created to explore ways to cut Tokyo's huge trade surplus had its first meeting today, and American business executives warned the group of rising resentment in the United States over Japanese practices.

title: PROTEST BLOCKS A TRIAL IN CROATIA
description: Several thousand jeering Croatian nationalists threw stones, potatoes and eggs at the Yugoslav federal military courthouse here today and forced the postponement of a trial in which seven people are charged with plotting a Croatian armed rebellion against Yugoslavia.

title: Review/Dance; Kentucky Troupe Brings New Ideas to 'Swan Lake'
description: The Louisville Ballet made its New York City debut in 1985 with several mixed bills that created more than a good impression. The Kentucky company's revival of "La Fete Etrange," a poetic dramatic ballet created in 1940 by the English choreographer Andree Howard, was nothing short of outstanding. Yet for all the enterprising repertory that Alun Jones has attempted since 1978, when he became the troupe's artistic director, he obviously needs to meet the demands made on virtually all regional ballet companies in America. That is, he has had to stage a full-length 19th-century classic.

title: Big Refugee Role for U.N.
description: Responsibility for protecting the 27,000 refugees now in southern Iraq against Government reprisals after allied forces leave will be in the hands of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the Red Cross under the terms of a plan drawn up here, United Nations officials say.

title: Getting Close to a Work Station
description: THERE is a fuzzy dividing line between personal computers and a class of computers known as work stations, and the boundary is constantly drifting upward as PC's become more powerful. In general, though, a work station can be defined as a single-user computer that is more powerful than the fastest PC's, but not as powerful as the minicomputers used by businesses to run entire departments.

title: May Stores Offers 9.5% Debentures
description: The May Department Stores Company is offering $150 million, up from $100 million, of 30-year amortizing debentures, due April 15, 2021, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Dissatisfied Kuwaitis Gather, Upset Over Delays in Reform
description: More than a thousand Kuwaitis of varied political persuasions rallied tonight to grumble that Emir Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah's promise of parliamentary elections "in the coming year, God willing" fell short of their post-war demands for increased democracy.

title: A Man Is Pronounced Dead After Jumping Three Stories
description: A Brooklyn man who jumped from a three-story window last night and ran about shouting incoherently died after officials took him to the hospital, the police said.

title: Los Angeles Police Chief Staying For Now After Suing to Keep Job
description: Chief Daryl F. Gates resumed command of the Los Angeles Police Department today, four days after he was suspended by the city Police Commission. But the judge who lifted the suspension scheduled a hearing in two weeks, and it seemed clear that control of the department would remain a divisive political issue.

title: Music in Review
description: Manhattan Philharmonic Alice Tully Hall

title: Tuning Out Network Bias
description: In 1989, during a panel discussion at the Bumbershoot Arts Festival in Seattle, I expressed dismay at television's relentlessly negative news coverage of African Americans and Hispanic Americans. Half-seriously, I suggested that a boycott of prime-time network news might be in order. I was shocked by the sustained applause that greeted this remark from an audience that was predominantly white.

title: Cairo Journal; Where Envoys Waltzed, Now the Wrecker's Ball
description: Glimpsed through wrought-iron gates, the elegant two-story building was just the sort of thing one might expect of an American embassy somewhere on the far side of the world: a whitewashed mansion framed by a wide marble staircase, and set against a deep yard of palm trees and dusty green grass.

title: Daniel R. Ginsberg, 41, Lawyer and Developer
description: Daniel R. Ginsberg, a lawyer and real-estate developer, died on Saturday in a glider accident in Wurtsboro, N.Y. He was 41 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Review/Television; The Surprise Operation That Unseated Noriega
description: Since network television cameras and correspondents were not invited by the Pentagon to record the United States invasion of Panama in December 1989, tonight's edition of "Frontline" is the fullest opportunity so far for Americans to witness the brief but violent encounter. Using pictures taken by Air Force combat cameramen, "War and Peace in Panama," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, captures the few explosive hours that brought an end to the career of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Harcourt Offer Is Extended
description: The General Cinema Corporation today extended its deadline to buy Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. by 10 days, saying it had failed to reach an agreement with Harcourt's bondholders.

title: F.D.A. Approves Genzyme's Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved Ceredase, a drug developed by the Genzyme Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., for the treatment of Gaucher's disease, a disorder that causes anemia and enlargement of the liver and spleen. The disease affects an estimated 10,000 to 15,000 people in the United States, of whom about 2,000 to 3,000 need treatment. Patients often suffer fatigue, distended abdomens and fragile and painful bones.

title: EUROPEANS URGING ENCLAVE FOR KURDS IN NORTHERN IRAQ
description: European Community leaders called on the United Nations today to create a haven in northern Iraq where Kurdish refugees could be protected from further repression.

title: Homes for Middle Class Rise on Blighted Blocks
description: Empty lots surround the two rundown apartment buildings on the north side of Jefferson Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant. A block east, three large abandoned buildings tower over the elevated subway tracks that run above Broadway in Brooklyn.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Baseball Lessons for the Young
description: Is your child wide-eyed for a baseball hero's autograph, now that the baseball season is under way? You might not get it at the stadium. Instead, you may have to drive the kid to the mall, pay $10 and crush into line with a thousand people. Then pray that the hero looks up from his frantic scribbling as the child is hustled past him, and the barker cries out, "Next!"

title: David Meyers, Owner Of Garages, Dies at 85
description: David Meyers, the founder of the Meyers Brothers Parking System Inc., which once operated more than 200 garages and parking lots in the United States, Britain and Puerto Rico, died on Saturday at Hollywood Hospital in Florida. He was 85 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: States, Following Bush Plan, Ask Congress to Consolidate U.S. Aid
description: State officials asked Congress today to combine dozens of Federal programs into a handful of block grants they said would improve their ability to allocate $15 billion to $21 billion for education, agriculture, the environment and transportation programs.

title: Polygamists Emerge From Secrecy, Seeking Not Just Peace but Respect
description: With arms full of groceries, three women in long, flowered dresses emerged from the general store here on a sun-splashed afternoon. After rounding up their playful children, they climbed into a car and headed back down the gravel road to the house, and the husband, they share.

title: Child World Sale Completed
description: The CNC Holding Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell the 82 percent of Child World Inc. it owns to WC Acquisition, an investment group headed by two former senior executives of Toys "R" Us Inc., W. John Devine and Ronald Tuchman.

title: Enlarging Hard Disks
description: THERE is no such thing as a hard disk drive that is too big. When they first became generally available, hard disks with a capacity of 10 megabytes of storage seemed like bottomless pits. That was 10 million characters at a time when floppy disks held 360 thousand characters. How could anyone ever fill all that space? After all, a double-spaced typewritten page is about 2,000 characters.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Kennedy family's handling of a rape allegation in Palm Beach, Fla., misstated the date of Joseph P. Kennedy's death. It was November 1969.

title: Witness Says He Overheard 2 Men Plotting in Warmus Murder Case
description: A defense witness at the Carolyn Warmus murder trial testified today that he overheard Paul Solomon and a private detective exchange $20,000 and talk about throwing a gun in a river the night Mr. Solomon's wife was killed.

title: Bridge
description: It is true, fortunately for the game, that very few bridge players cheat. It is also true that nearly all readers of bridge columns cheat. If you doubt this, consider the diagramed deal and try to solve the puzzle it presents. The puzzle, conceived many moons ago by some unknown genius, is to find a way to make seven no-trump without scoring a trick with an ace. (You may look at all 52 cards.)

title: Improving Mainframes At I.B.M.
description: The new president of I.B.M.'s mainframe computer division said in an interview yesterday that the company was working to "reincarnate" its most powerful and expensive computers using the same low-cost and speedy technologies that have led to the explosive growth of work stations and personal computers.

title: Will Pennant Races Be Good for Business?
description: If only CBS Sports could match the results of its National Collegiate Athletic Association Final Four men's basketball tournament -- exciting games, upscale advertisers, young viewers and solid ratings -- and use them for baseball, then all would be right at Black Rock.

title: Murderer in Brooklyn Gets Maximum Term
description: A man convicted of killing a Brooklyn woman who campaigned against drug trafficking was sentenced yesterday to a maximum term of 36 years to life in prison.

title: PATTERNS
description: Bywords for the Openings

title: Study on School Custodians Doesn't Even Scratch the Surface
description: To the Editor:

title: Backman Says Mets Got Assist From Ump
description: Wally Backman saw Tommy Herr break for second in the fourth inning yesterday and the Phillies' second baseman quickly glanced at third, where Hubie Brooks was straying off the base. The Mets were executing a double steal and Backman sprang into action.

title: Tap the Treasure in Rent Control
description: While New Yorkers ponder emergency measures to repair their city's deteriorating financial condition, a hoard of taxable value remains untapped under the welter of rent control regulations that keep the rents for many apartments unjustifiably low.

title: A Zillion Miles to Go
description: John Veitch, who has trained Alydar and many other superstars of racing, considered the long odds of even getting a horse to the post for the Kentucky Derby in the next 26 days, and said:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dayton Power and Light Co., Dayton, Ohio, a subsidiary of DPL Inc., named Stewart D. Roll general counsel. * Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York, named Bernard Schoen vice president for sales.

title: Saatchi Wins Back Britain's Conservatives
description: SAATCHI & SAATCHI'S flagship London office has won back the estimated $40 million account for Britain's Conservative Party.

title: Sallie Mae Prices $650 Million Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association has priced $650 million in short-term floating-rate notes through various securities dealers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The 15th annual Laurence Olivier Awards were handed out in London on Sunday. Sir IAN McKELLEN was named actor of the year for his portrayal of "Richard III" at the National Theater. KATHRYN HUNTER was named actress of the year for her performance in the Theatre de Complicite's production of "The Visit."

title: Sadie H. Zaidens, Doctor, 80
description: Sadie H. Zaidens, a dermatologist and psychiatrist, died on April 1 at St. Clare's Hospital and Medical Center. She was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: IN SOVIET GEORGIA, THREAT OF STRIKE
description: Intent on independence, the government of Soviet Georgia has threatened a general strike unless President Mikhail S. Gorbachev withdraws the Soviet troops protecting the republic's separatist minority in the South Ossetia region.

title: A Minority Plan For City Council
description: In a preview of the possibilities and the passions that will be ignited in the quest for 51 new New York City Council districts, a private group yesterday offered a plan in which black, Asian-American and Hispanic residents represent the majority in 29 of the districts.

title: In Commercialized-Science Era, Fraud Thrives; Overweening Pride
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL 500th Victory for Jones K. C. Jones became the 14th coach in National Basketball Association history to win 500 games as the Seattle SuperSonics won for the fifth time in six games, a 118-112 victory over the Denver Nuggets last night in Seattle. (AP) Hawks 105, Bullets 94: Glenn Rivers and John Battle scored key baskets to help Atlanta preserve a victory over visiting Washington. The Bullets had scored 8 consecutive points to cut their deficit to 95-89 when Rivers scored successive baskets. Battle then scored the final 6 points for the Hawks, who handed the Bullets their 5th road loss in a row and 13th in 14 games. (AP) Spurs 115, Warriors 105: In San Antonio, Sean Elliott scored 26 points, 7 in a decisive fourth-quarter rally, and the Spurs won their fourth consecutive game. David Robinson added 24 points as the Spurs moved a game and a half ahead of idle Houston in the race for the Midwest Division title. (AP) Jazz 111, Magic 95: Karl Malone scored 15 of his 34 points in the fourth quarter and Jeff Malone added 20 points as Utah beat Orlando in Salt Lake City. Dennis Scott led the Magic with 26 points. (AP) TENNIS Jarryd Wins in Tokyo Anders Jarryd of Sweden, the only seeded player in action yesterday, beat Jason Stoltenberg of Australia, 6-0, 6-3, in the first round of the Japan Open in Tokyo. (AP) HORSE RACING Duel Continues At Aqueduct, one of the season's best rivalries continued yesterday when Angel Cordero Jr. and Art Madrid Jr. each won one race in their duel in the New York jockey standing. Madrid snatched the lead last Wednesday by riding three winners and took a lead of one race over Cordero, who came back to ride three winners Sunday. Score at the close of business yesterday: Cordero, 23 winners; Madrid, 21. But now, the bad news: Madrid was suspended yesterday for seven days, starting tomorrow, for careless riding in the sixth race Sunday.

title: 2d Rape Suspect Seized in Week Near U.N.
description: Two New York City police officers patrolling the United Nations area arrested a homeless man as a rape suspect on Sunday, one week after they arrested another homeless man in the same neighborhood in an unrelated rape case.

title: U.S. Seeks to Prevent Saudis From Being Sued
description: At the request of the Saudi Embassy, the Bush Administration has asked a Federal appeals court to reverse a ruling that allows the Saudi Government to be sued in the United States for the reported torture of an American businessman.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Producers' Bid To Delay Syndication Ruling
description: One day before its scheduled vote on revising the rules governing the ownership of television programs, the Federal Communications Commission today rejected an attempt by producers to postpone the action.

title: Dinkins Says He May Miss Council's Budget Deadline
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins suggested yesterday that he might not be able to submit his proposed budget on time if the City Council, as it has threatened, grants him only a week's extension beyond the legal deadline of April 26.

title: OUR TOWNS
description: When Yonkers opens the first public housing built under a Federal desegregation order, the new residents selected by housing officials are likely to be people from southwest Yonkers, where the city's minority population is concentrated, spending upward of half their income on rent or living in overcrowded apartments.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARJORY STONEMAN DOUGLAS, the Florida environmentalist, celebrated her 101st birthday on Sunday. Instead of being given a party, Mrs. Douglas asked that trees be planted in her name. The "Plant a Tree for Marjory" campaign began, fittingly, at the Marjory Stoneman Douglas Biscayne Nature Center on Key Biscayne, where Mrs. Douglas watched as the first tree, a silver palm, was planted.

title: Coleman and Jefferies Team Up for Success
description: In measuring the Mets' 2-1 victory over the Phillies and what it suggests for the coming months, we present "The Tale of the Table Setter." It opened yesterday at Shea Stadium to hearty reviews.

title: Health Chief Under Fire For Low-Profile Style
description: The New York City Health Commissioner, Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr., was ushered into office by controversy over his views on AIDS policy. Now the possibility of his leaving after only one year because a family member is ill is getting just as much attention.

title: Katherine Warren, Research Scientist, 82
description: Katherine Warren, a research scientist and former grants administrator for the National Institutes of Health, died March 23 at Greater Laurel Beltsville Hospital in Laurel, Md. She was 82 years old and lived in Laurel.

title: Park Rangers in Yellowstone Kill 3 Bison Before Judge Blocks Hunt
description: Park rangers here shot and killed three bison today for disease research before a judge temporarily blocked them from killing 22 other bison.

title: Democrat's Budget Plan Assures Conflict With Bush
description: The House Budget Committee chairman today unveiled a budget for the next fiscal year that calls for more spending on social programs than President Bush had proposed, virtually assuring the first of many confrontations over domestic priorities after Congress returns Tuesday from a two-week Easter recess.

title: Border Near San Diego Is Home to More Violence
description: Along the ripped and sagging wire fence that forms the country's southern border here, small white crosses mark the spots where people have died trying to enter the United States illegally.

title: Review/Fashion; For Fall, a New Blass And a More Casual Ellis
description: Bill Blass opened the week of fall fashion shows with a whole new image. Broad stripes, bold plaids and stiff full skirts or fluttery pleated styles gave his presentation yesterday at the Pierre a lively, young look. Carolina Herrera followed at the Plaza with more plaids, glimmering lame and wool crepe evening dresses and some bold checks.

title: Tokyo Election Defeat Stuns Japan's Governing Party
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Government was badly jolted today by the lopsided defeat of the ruling party's candidate for Governor of Tokyo, forcing the resignation of the party's chief political operative.

title: Terrorism Alert
description: One surprise of the Persian Gulf war was the success of anti-terrorism measures taken by the U.S. and its allies. But there are no grounds for complacency today.

title: Monsanto to Sell Feed-Unit Lines
description: The Monsanto Company said today that it had agreed to sell most of its animal feed ingredients business to two Japanese companies.

title: Surge of Water in Uncapped Wells To Hamper Kuwait Oil Production
description: Causing long-term damage to Kuwait's oil supply, underground water is increasingly surging into its uncapped wells, making oil more costly and difficult to produce in the future, Kuwaiti officials say.

title: Chinese Leadership Appoints 2 Deputies To Prime Minister Li
description: The Chinese Government today installed two Deputy Prime Ministers with strong economic experience, in what many Chinese hope is a step toward greater restructuring of the nation's wheezing economy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I never really considered buying an American car, which is not to say I wouldn't. I guess buying a foreign car has been kind of ingrained in me." -- Sue Anderson, 26, of Grand Rapids, Mich. [ A1:3. ]

title: Review/Cabaret; Phoebe Legere Flaunts Contradictions
description: After struggling for years to meld her diverse talents into a coherent act, the cult cabaret diva Phoebe Legere has finally succeeded in her one-woman show "From Sea to Shining C," which plays at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) through April 21.

title: An Appraisal Of Top-Level Job Seekers
description: CANNY, BOWEN INC., a management recruiting firm based in New York, decided to survey high-level executives who had sent in their resumes. It took the step after receiving about a thousand resumes a week since the late fall.

title: D'Amato Law Firm Partner Is Being Investigated by U.S.
description: The Justice Department is investigating whether a law partner of Armand D'Amato, the brother of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, benefited from a land deal he helped negotiate while serving as counsel to the Nassau County Board of Supervisors 10 years ago, officials within the department said yesterday.

title: A Temporary Thrill: Calling Gooden's Strikes
description: Bob Nelson, replacement umpire and computer salesman, woke up yesterday morning to discover his latest sports fantasy stint would be a short one.

title: Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the West Coast department store chain operating under bankruptcy court protection, said today that it had received court approval for its $550 million accounts receivable financing package. The company previously received approval of a $250 million package, meaning it has now secured $800 million in financing, all from the Chemical Bank. The company said it had enough permanent financing to proceed with its reorganization.

title: Pro-Syrian P.L.O. Renegades Propose to End Split
description: Renegade Palestinian factions based in Damascus put forward a Syrian-backed initiative today for reconciliation with the mainstream Palestine Liberation Organization after an eight-year split during which they sought to overthrow Yasir Arafat.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LODWRICK M. COOK, chairman and chief executive officer of ARCO, received the 18th annual Whitney Young Award last Thursday in Century City, Calif. Named after a former director of the Urban League, the award is given by the Los Angeles Urban League to people who work to bring different segments of the community together.

title: Gooden Leaves His Stamp on the Phillies
description: The autograph cost only the price of admission, so there was something modest yet enduring about the memento Dwight Gooden gave the 50,800 people at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; Trapped in a Somber Dialectic of Faith and Flesh
description: Scum By Isaac Bashevis Singer 218 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $19.95.

title: Ford Reports No '90 Bonuses
description: Executives of the Ford Motor Company did not receive bonuses in 1990, according to the auto maker's annual proxy statement released today.

title: Aid Sought for Sabena
description: The Belgian Government has asked the European Community to approve a $554 million aid package for Sabena, the state-owned airline, the community's commission said today. The commission will decide within two months if the proposal meets community competition rules limiting state assistance to companies, said a community official who insisted on anonymity. The Government also agreed to forgive $466 million of the airline's long-term debt.

title: Wallace Journal; As Jobs Come Calling, The Now-Wary Unite
description: Along River Road, which meanders for miles through the remnants of plantation country, the black and white residents have shared little over the years but mutual distrust and a high cancer rate, which many believe is caused by the dozens of industrial plants that line the Mississippi River.

title: Blaze Kills a Man in Queens
description: An unidentified man was killed last night in a quickly spreading fire in a house in Jamaica, Queens, fire officials said. The fire at 87-22 168th Street, near Hillside Avenue, was declared suspicious, said Lieut. Jim Powell, a Fire Department spokesman. He said the first alarm was received at 5 P.M. and firefighters reached the scene within three minutes. He said the blaze was declared under control at 5:53 P.M.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Thornburgh to Appear Before Supreme Court
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh will personally urge the Supreme Court to allow juries considering the death penalty in murder cases to hear testimony from the victim's survivors, his spokesman said today.

title: In Commercialized-Science Era, Fraud Thrives
description: To the Editor:

title: It's 'Bovary.' It's French. Don't Expect Harmony.
description: "Madame Bovary, c'est moi," Gustave Flaubert proclaimed in 1856 after completing what would eventually become a classic of French literature. "Flaubert, c'est moi," added Claude Chabrol after completing his loyal-to-a-fault cinema version of "Madame Bovary."

title: 2 Found Dead After Relative Testifies
description: The day after a witness testified in a major drug-related murder trial in Queens last week, his father-in-law and sister-in-law were found slain in a South Jamaica housing project, the police said.

title: Expert on Bankruptcy To Join Manufacturers
description: As the burden of debts from the 1980's weighs more heavily on corporations, Darla D. Moore, a banker and expert on lending to bankrupt companies, expects an abundance of opportunities.

title: Strawberry Gone, but Hardly Forgotten
description: Jesse Otero put the finishing touches on his beat-up 1976 Olds 98 at 10 A.M. yesterday. He spray painted "Doc Gooden vs. Mulholland" on the passenger side and "Let's Go Mets" on the driver side, in white, blue and orange. The hood and trunk were custom painted in orange with the Mets' logo and a crossed NY. The car cost $150. The paint job cost $750.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, priced $350 million in 30-year debentures yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The financing orginally called for $200 million in debt to be sold, but was raised because of strong investor demand.

title: Black Factions' Truce Threatened in South Africa
description: The fragile peace between South Africa's two largest black political groups threatened to unravel today as the leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party denounced the African National Congress for demanding concessions from the Government that he said could lead to civil war.

title: Germany Lets Poles In Without Visas
description: The borders dividing Eastern and Western Europe continued to fall today as five countries in the West began allowing Polish citizens to come and go without visas.

title: Baker Sees and Hears Kurds' Pain In a Brief Visit at Turkish Border
description: From afar, it looks like any other meadow in the snow-dusted mountains of Kurdistan. Then bright colors begin to appear, and what seemed like rocks begin to move. Then there is a person. Then two. And then 100, and then a thousand, and suddenly 50,000 people are carpeting the mountainsides like wildflowers almost as far as the eye can see.

title: Cholesterol Tests Are Recommended for a Quarter of Children
description: Doctors should test the cholesterol levels of all children whose parents or grandparents had heart attacks or certain other cardiovascular problems at an early age, a panel of Federal experts said today.

title: Ryan Strikes Out 9, but Brewers Win on Yount's Homer
description: President Bush got the applause, Nolan Ryan got the strikeouts and the Milwaukee Brewers got the victory.

title: Alcohol Screening for Prom
description: Students in this northern Minnesota town will be tested for alcohol before being admitted to the high school prom on April 20. Those who fail a breath test must wait while their parents are called to come to take them home. No one on the prom planning committee at Pine River-Backus High School opposed the action. Most students support the tests, but Mark Johnson, president of the Student Council, said: "I know it's for a good cause, but I don't like it. It's almost like people don't trust you."

title: Iran Tries to Decentralize Economy, Causing Widespread Pain
description: The usually chaotic airport here was deserted on Thursday. The Government had just raised international fares purchased in local currency eight-fold. In less than a year, the price of postage stamps has tripled. The cost of chicken rose in the bazaar by about 30 percent recently. Prices for most food have shot up, as have taxes.

title: Sports of The Times; Another Opening, Another Show
description: THE smell floats permanently in the ancient corridors of Tiger Stadium, a heady mixture of animal fats and cooking oils and spices and relishes and mustards and popcorn and coffee, 91 years' worth.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE, LEGAL SUBCOMMITTEE -- 10:30 A.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON AFRICAN ECONOMIC RECOVERY AND DEVELOPMENT -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Boy, 13, Shot as a Drug Arrest Goes Awry
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy was shot in the stomach last night on a street in Brooklyn when a "buy and bust" drug operation by an undercover narcotics team went awry, the police said.

title: Astronomical Mystery: Dark, Lurking Object
description: ASTRONOMERS reported yesterday that they had discovered a dark, mysterious and almost inconceivably massive object lurking within a shell of luminous gas that is circulating around two colliding galaxies at speeds of almost two million miles an hour.

title: Stocks Down in Tokyo
description: Stock prices closed lower in Tokyo today, ending the afternoon trading session with a loss of just over 1 percent. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 290.26, to 26,317.39.

title: EX-SPEAKER TO PAY $15,000 IN INQUIRY
description: Former Speaker Jim Wright has agreed to pay $15,000 to settle charges that he accepted thousands of dollars in excessive and illegal campaign contributions, Federal officials said today.

title: Health-Care Merger
description: Gianettino & Meredith Advertising, a New Jersey agency, and Philips-Miller & Associates, a New York agency specializing in pharmaceutical ads, have entered into an agreement to form a new agency that will specialize in health-care advertising. The merged agency, to be based in New York, will be called Philips, Gianettino & Meredith. It will be headed by Dorothy Philips, the founder of Philips-Miller, who will be the chairman and chief executive.

title: Accounts
description: * Country Life, Hauppauge, L.I., to Garvan Advertising Inc., Hicksville, L.I., for its vitamins, minerals and nutritional supplements. The account, with a budget of $1 million, was previously handled internally. * United Illuminating Co., a public utility for 17 towns based in New Haven, to Mason & Madison Inc., New Haven. Billings are $1 million to $1.5 million.

title: Yankees' Defense Wastes No Time Reaching Mediocrity
description: The start of the Yankees' new season produced a finish like most of last season.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about Easter in the Ethiopian Orthodox Church misstated the timing of the observance in some editions. In some Eastern Orthodox churches, Easter must be not only the first Sunday following the full moon after the vernal equinox, but also the Sunday following the eight-day celebration of the Jewish Passover.

title: Marianne Wiggins And Life on the Run
description: "We were on the lam in Wales," Marianne Wiggins writes in a new short-story collection, and sure enough they were. Ms. Wiggins and her husband, the novelist Salman Rushdie, were in Wales in April 1989, two months after the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death sentence against Mr. Rushdie sent the couple underground.

title: Trump Aims to Turn Most of Plaza Hotel Into Condominiums
description: If Donald Trump's latest plan goes through, most of the rooms at the Plaza Hotel will be converted into condominium units.

title: KENNEDY RAPE CASE AWAITS LAB TESTS
description: As investigators sifted confusing and contradictory accounts in the case of a complaint of rape at the Kennedy mansion here, the police announced today that it would be a week or more before laboratory tests were completed on blood and hair samples obtained from William Kennedy Smith, the official suspect.

title: Cuomo Challenging Teacher Subsidy He Helped Enact
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is pressing to eliminate a program he helped enact five years ago to bolster the quality and prestige of teachers by supplementing their salaries.

title: Umpires Get 4-Year Pact and All Are to Return Today
description: Major-league umpires signed a new four-year contract yesterday, but not in time, league officials said, to avoid using replacement crews in all but one of the opening day games.

title: The Thief of Baseball, Closing In on the Treasure
description: Rickey Henderson is about to slide past Lou Brock again into baseball's record book. The overwhelming odds are that it will happen this week and that Henderson will go in head first.

title: Terrorism Jolts a Prospering Chile
description: A new nervousness has gripped the business community in Chile this week over whether the recent spate of terrorist actions will upset the political stability of the country and threaten the Chilean economic miracle.

title: INSIDE
description: Political Turmoil in Japan

title: Microbe May Be Key to Uranium Cleanups
description: A STRAIN of bacterium usually found in mud might be the key to cleaning up waterways and nuclear waste sites contaminated with uranium.

title: Chess
description: There are no ghosts, of course, except in the movies, but the nearest thing to one came back to haunt the chess world three weeks ago.

title: A Youthful Touch Just May Be the Ticket
description: For one day, the Yankees' commitment to youth seemed like the right thing to do.

title: City College Student Sit-In Keeps 75% Out of Classes
description: In what they called a last resort "to save the City University of New York," 50 to 100 City College students shut down most of their campus early yesterday when they barricaded themselves inside the school's largest academic building to protest proposed tuition increases and budget cuts.

title: Spira Trial Under Way
description: Jury selectionh began yesterday in the trial of Howard Spira, an avowed gambler whose association with George Steinbrenner eventually cost Steinbrenner control of the Yankees. Spira is charged with making threats and trying to extort money from Steinbrenner and a Houston lawyer, Earle Lilly. In testimony before baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent last year, Steinbrenner said he paid Spira $40,000 because he and his family were "scared stiff" after being threatened.

title: Barry Silverman, Lawyer, 57
description: Barry Silverman, a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Dornbush, Mandelstam & Silverman, died on Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Late Program Buying Lifts Dow to 2,918.56
description: Stocks chugged along most of the day yesterday with little movement, but heavy program buying carried the Dow Jones industrial average sharply ahead in the final hour.

title: Music in Review
description: Stravinsky Concert Robert Craft Avery Fisher Hall

title: Advanced Micro, Sony Sign Accord
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and the Sony Corporation signed a broad-ranging patent and copyright cross-license agreement under which they would share the technologies of computer chips. The agreement, which runs through April 1, 1996, is intended to lead to the joint development of a new process to make smaller chips begun when Sony acquired Advanced Micro's San Antonio plant last year.

title: Trade Issues Enter Crucial Political Phase
description: At their meeting Thursday, President Bush warned Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu that Congressional concerns over Japanese trade practices could damage the relationship between the two countries. In Houston Sunday, Mr. Bush presumably told President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico that American lawmakers would require Mexico to adopt stronger environmental measures and perhaps take other steps before Congress would accede to a bilateral free-trade pact.

title: A Simpler Way to Employ RU486 Is Reported
description: THE French scientist who pioneered the development of the RU486 abortion pill reported yesterday that he had devised a simpler way to use the therapy.

title: Avis Reviewing B.S.B. Account
description: There may soon be more bad news for one of Saatchi & Saatchi's agencies, Backer Spielvogel Bates. Avis is quietly reviewing its estimated $30 million account, Ray Noble, a spokesman for the car-rental company, said yesterday.

title: A Field-Trip Bonanza
description: A COLLEGE student on a field trip with his introductory paleontology class has discovered a five-foot-long skull from what is believed to be an 80-million-year-old horned dinosaur called a chasmosaurus.

title: Holmes's Real Fight Comes After the Bout
description: Larry Holmes's comeback bout was not much to speak of, but the brawl that followed was another story.

title: Pact Reached On Brazil's Interest Debt
description: Brazil and its commerical bankers announced an agreement yesterday for the country to retire $8 billion in unpaid interest.

title: Theodore Distler, 92; Was College President
description: Theodore A. Distler, president emeritus of Franklin and Marshall College, died Sunday at the Homestead Village health care center in Lancaster, Pa. He was 92 years old.

title: Observer; The Manly Joy of Anguish
description: The moral argument for intervening against Saddam Hussein's slaughter of rebelling Kurds and Shiites was never answered by the Bush people. They didn't have to answer it really. They had the popularity polls on their side.

title: North Stars Score 5 Goals in First Period, Then Lose, 6-5
description: Jeremy Roenick scored a controversial goal with 13 minutes 45 seconds to play as the Chicago Blackhawks rallied from a 5-2 deficit and defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 6-5, tonight to take a two-games-to-one lead in the Norris Division semifinal series.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 1 about a reduction in automobile-insurance premiums in New Jersey omitted an explanation of the varying reductions. The maximum reduction will be $222 a year, for a car covered by liability, comprehensive and collision insurance; the minimum will be $44, for a car owned by someone 65 years old or over and carrying only liability insurance.

title: People
description: * Ashley Hundley and Liane Revzin have been named vice presidents at Lintas New York. * Joseph T. Plummer, Arthur Selkowitz, John Farrell and Lance Smith have been elected to the board of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York. Dennis Barham has been named creative director and co-managing director of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Canada, Toronto. * Frank W. Merriam has been promoted to senior vice president/ creative director of the Earle Palmer Brown office in Kalamazoo, Mich. * Jesse Lependorf has been named associate creative director at Hammond Farrell Inc., New York. * Glenn Goldberg has been promoted to vice president-management supervisor at Asher Gould Advertising, Los Angeles. * Thomas R. Jordan has joined Hill & Knowlton, New York, as a senior vice president, heading its new energy and utilities practice. * John R. Campbell has been named senior vice president-publisher of Financial World magazine.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Kansas City Power and Light Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $150 million in medium-term notes through Merrill Lynch & Co. PREFERRED STOCK * Morgan Stanley Group Inc. has filed for two million shares of convertible preferred, expected to be offered at $50 a share through Morgan Stanley & Co. COMMON STOCK * BWIP Holding Inc., Long Beach, Calif., has filed for an initial public offering of eight million common shares through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The company is a global supplier of advanced technology fluid transfer and control equipment, and was formed by the private investment firm of Clayton & Dubilier Inc.

title: In Commercialized-Science Era, Fraud Thrives; Taking Undue Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: 10-Year 8.5% Notes From BP America
description: BP America Inc. is offering $200 million in 10-year notes through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Forecast on Kuwaiti Oil
description: Oil production in Kuwait will not reach pre-invasion levels until the end of 1993, an American oil expert said today. The expert, Daniel Yergin, president of the Cambridge Energy Research Institute, a private research group, said in a speech here that Kuwait would produce 50,000 barrels a day as a symbolic gesture in several weeks and that he expected exports of 350,000 barrels a day by the end of 1991. But it will take a year to put out all the oilfield fires in Kuwait, he said, and output should be back to 1.5 million barrels a day, the level before last August's invasion by Iraq, by the end of 1993, he added.

title: Knicks End Pursuit
description: The Knicks last week looked into signing guard Robert Reid, a free agent who had a 12-year career in the N.B.A., but the team has decided not to pursue him. Knicks President Dave Checketts said yesterday that the team would probably not sign any new players before the playoffs.

title: 2 Exchanges In Merger Talks
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange will give quick consideration to a proposal it received last week from another exchange to merge their options markets, its top official said today.

title: Henry Shapiro, 84, Longtime Reporter In Moscow for U.P.I.
description: Henry Shapiro, a longtime Moscow correspondent for United Press International before he retired in 1973, died on Thursday at Meritor Hospital in Madison, Wis. He was 84 years old and lived in Madison.

title: Methane Worldwide
description: Scientists may have overestimated by about 25 percent in calculating worldwide emissions of a gas that promotes global warming, a study says.

title: Music in Review
description: Tokyo Metropolitan Symphony Orchestra Carnegie Hall

title: U.S. in Court Appeal for Saudis
description: Arguing that an important national interest exists, the Administration seeks the reversal of a ruling allowing an American businessman to sue Saudi Arabia for torture. Page A12.

title: Teen-Ager Critically Injured Riding Outside Subway Car
description: A 16-year-old Harlem high school student riding on the side of a subway train slammed into a platform pillar and was critically injured on Sunday.

title: John F. Maun Jr., Executive, 52
description: John F. Maun Jr., a former advertising director at Bonwit Teller in Manhattan, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 52 years old.

title: Miscellany
