description: * Kameny Spitzer Felix Advertising, New York, has formed a new division, KSF/Sales Promotion, to develop programs for the agency and its Crimmins Co-op Marketing division. Irving Binder will serve as president. * Five former senior executives of Hill & Knowlton have formed an international public affairs firm, Capitoline International Group, Washington. They are: Lawrence J. Brady, Josephine S. Cooper, Larry I. Good, Paul R. Locigno and Charles R. Pucie Jr.

title: On My Mind; America at the Vistula
description: The United States Government has failed to tell Americans the full meaning of what is happening in Iraq. A monumental camouflage of reality is taking place.

title: Murder Jolts Haven for Elite in Boston Area
description: For years, an exclusive corner of this city known as the Brattle Street neighborhood has been a haven of safety and civility for Harvard professors and Boston's elite.

title: 142-Year Sentence for Rapist
description: A judge sentenced a man convicted of raping seven women to 142 years in prison today, telling him it was not likely "you'll see the light of a free society again." Prosecutors told Judge Robert Fitzgerald of Orange County Superior Court that the defendant, Robert Dasenbrock, 26 years old, attacked the women between 1985 and 1987, raping one woman twice in a year and another on Christmas Day.

title: Market Place; Surging Volume In Smaller Stocks
description: ALMOST by definition, large stocks trade in higher volume than smaller ones. So when Nasdaq volume suddenly exceeds turnover on the New York Stock Exchange, it provides another indication that small-stock fever is sweeping Wall Street.

title: Mobil Reports Gas Find
description: The Mobil Corporation said that a natural gas well in the Gulf of Mexico in which it is principal owner had produced flow rates of gas and condensates that are the highest the company has ever encountered in a Gulf of Mexico well. The well, more than 14,000 feet deep, is 42.9 percent owned by mobil. The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company has 37.5 percent, Unocal Exploration Ltd. 13.6 percent and American Petrofina Inc. 5.9 percent.

title: Town Aids a Simple Man in Big Trouble
description: On the warm June day when Adelbert Ward was arrested, Munnsville reluctantly lost its faith in the system. Now it has it back.

title: Va. Tech Names Foster
description: Bill Foster, the former coach at Clemson, who has a 431-247 career record, was appointed coach at Virginia Tech yesterday. Foster, who coached most recently at Miami, signed a four-year contract. He replaces Frankie Allen. (AP)

title: Music in Review
description: Sine Nomine Singers Alice Tully Hall

title: Wanted: New Ways to Battle Flaming Wells
description: INVENTORS, scientists and entrepreneurs are racing to perfect innovative ways of extinguishing the fires that have turned Kuwaiti oil fields into raging infernos.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Citing Default Rate, White House Is to Revamp Student Loan Office
description: Saying it was responding to widespread fraud and abuse and to the high default rate of Federal student loan programs, the Bush Administration announced today that it was reorganizing the office that manages the programs.

title: Devils Seek To Restrain Generosity
description: In the eyes of Devils Coach Tom McVie, allowing nine goals in two games in the Stanley Cup playoffs can mean spring vacation.

title: Business Scene; The New Drag On Auto Sales
description: MOST forecasts that the recession is about to end assume that consumers will soon buy cars in greater numbers -- a prerequisite for an upturn since the auto industry is such a major part of the economy. The problem with this assumption is that many would-be car buyers are failing to qualify for loans.

title: N.B.A. Draft, Here I Come, Says Kenny Anderson
description: While the National Basketball Association's general managers, personnel directors and scouts were evaluating the best of the college seniors yesterday at the Orlando Classic in Florida, the likely order of the picks in the league's draft was undergoing a change some 300 miles away in Atlanta.

title: Not Just Music, Bird Song Is a Means of Courtship and Defense
description: Teach me half the gladness thay thy brain must know such harmonious madness from my lips would flow the world should listen then, as I am listening now. -- "To a Skylark," by Percy Bysshe Shelley

title: Glaxo Sues Maker Of Generic Drugs
description: Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. filed a lawsuit in the United States against a generic drug company that wanted to invalidate the Glaxo patent for the ulcer drug Zantac, the world's top-selling drug. Glaxo said Genpharm Pharmaceuticals Inc. had filed an Abbreviated New Drug Application with the Food and Drug Administration for a generic form of Zantac. Sales of the drug account for 50 percent of Glaxo's revenues.

title: As Angola Turns to West, Cubans Are Resentful
description: The streets of the Angolan capital are festooned with posters of Fidel Castro, Che Guevara and other Cuban revolutionary heroes, and there are slogans on peeling facades proclaiming the valiant role Cuba has played in African liberation movements. But the feeling in Luanda these days is that these are outdated and perhaps naive artifacts from another era.

title: Clemens, at Ease With a Stand-in Umpire, Serves Up Gruel to the Blue Jays, 6-2
description: Unlike the last time he encountered an umpire in a meaningful game, Roger Clemens chatted amiably today with John Higgins, the umpire who was calling his pitches balls or strikes.

title: Ozone Layer Thinner, But Forces Are in Place For Slow Improvement
description: THE life-protecting ozone shield in the high atmosphere has weakened by up to 5 percent since 1978 under the influence of industrial chemicals. That conclusion, based on direct satellite measurements, was announced last week by the Environmental Protection Agency, along with its calculations that many more Americans are now likely to die of skin cancer because of the higher doses of ultra-violet radiation that the weakened shield will let through.

title: Resolution of the Arms Impasse
description: Washington and Moscow are close to resolving a dispute over Soviet compliance that would open the way to ratification of the historic 22-nation treaty to cut conventional forces in Europe. A settlement would also remove any reason for delaying completion of the pending accord on nuclear arms with the Soviets.

title: U.S. Issues Up in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in very slow trading yesterday and short-term bill rates were at the lowest levels since 1987, as dealers began to mark time in advance of inflation reports scheduled later in the week.

title: Main U.S. Forces Begin Withdrawal
description: The first major element of the United States Army's VII Corps in southern Iraq pulled back into Saudi Arabia today, beginning a withdrawal that could end the American occupation this month as United Nations observer forces and international relief organizations replace them.

title: On Eve of Baker Visit, Israel Says It Will Free 1,000 Palestinians
description: The Israeli Defense Ministry said today that it would free more than 1,000 of the approximately 14,000 Palestinian prisoners held for actions connected with the uprising in the occupied territories. The announcement came a few hours before Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived for talks on Tuesday with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: What the Cockroach Said to Its Flatterers
description: To the Editor: i ll never understand you humans

title: Big Round of Discount Fares Was a Success, Airlines Say
description: The big discount fares offered by most large airlines in the last four weeks attracted thousands of bookings by travelers who had sharply limited air travel in January and February because of worries about recession and terrorism related to the Persian Gulf war.

title: Europeans Discuss Union
description: Germany urged its trading partners today to start a rapid effort to bring their economies in line as part of efforts to form an economic and monetary union.

title: 6-Hour Walk in Space Called 'Way to Travel'
description: For the second day in a row, two astronauts of the shuttle Atlantis ventured outside for spacewalks, this time not in response to an emergency but for planned tests of equipment and techniques for moving about while constructing an orbiting space station.

title: Hitachi Making Shift
description: Hitachi Ltd. said today that Tsutomu Kanai, 62 years old, the company's executive vice president, had been nominated as the new president. The current president, Katsushige Mita, 67, will become chairman, it said. The nominations are expected to be confirmed at a shareholders meeting on June 27.

title: N.F.L. Adds Executive
description: The reorganization at the top of the National Football League was completed yesterday with the appointment of Harold Henderson to run the newly created post of executive vice president for labor relations. The 48-year-old Henderson joins the league from Amtrak, where he had been vice president specializing in labor relations. He becomes the highest-ranking black in league history.

title: Scientist Tells Silent Victims' Tales of Terror
description: CLYDE COLLINS SNOW snuffed out his cigarette and turned over the golf-ball-size knob of bone the sheriff had handed him, minutely examining its contours and cracks.

title: Kraft Names Heads For 3 Big Divisions
description: Kraft General Foods, the nation's largest food company, yesterday named three senior officers to important subsidiaries, including General Foods USA, the maker of Jell-O, Kool-Aid and Maxwell House.

title: Reagan Calls New Book About Wife 'Untrue'
description: Ronald Reagan said today that a new book about his wife contained lies that "clearly exceed the bounds of decency."

title: Key Rates
Worker Skill Said to Slip
description: More midsized United States companies are turning to automation because of a perceived decline in the American worker's competence, according to a survey of top executives.

title: 11 Die Violently in Chicago; Police Say Heat Is a Factor
description: Eleven people were killed in separate incidents in Chicago over the weekend, and the authorities attributed the violence in part to warm weather.

title: Review/Theater; Williamson as Specter in 'I Hate Hamlet'
description: "I love this apartment because it's like a stage set, it's like the theater," says Andy Rally, a young bicoastal actor who has taken up new digs in Greenwich Village after the cancellation of his television series "L.A. Medical." And no wonder. Andy's new flat is the extravagantly Gothic apartment long ago occupied by John Barrymore, and even in 1991 it remains a suitably regal throne room for any show-business prince, past, present or still aspiring. Since Andy (Evan Handler) is about to assume Barrymore's most celebrated Shakespearean role in a Joseph Papp production in Central Park, what is to stand in the way of his complete artistic fulfillment? Only one thing. Much as Andy loves his apartment, loves the theater and loves stardom, he hates Hamlet.

title: In Commercialized-Science Era, Fraud Thrives; Error of Judgment
description: To the Editor: In "Cold-Fusion Claim Is Faulted on Ethics as Well as Science" (front page, March 17), you state that prominent scientists conclude that the cold-fusion claims of Dr. Martin Fleischmann and Dr. B. Stanley Pons were "based on 'invented' data whose publication involved a serious breach of ethics." The indictment is unfair. Better, the whole affair was, in the words of Frank Close, who wrote the book on the subject that you discuss, a "serious error of judgment."

title: John M. Blewer, 60, Investing Counselor At Several Concerns
description: John MacGregor Blewer, a lawyer and president of Pacific American Investors Inc., an investment counseling concern in Salt Lake City, died on Sunday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 60 years old.

title: Ruth Page, Dancer, Is Dead at 92; Proudly American Choreographer
description: Ruth Page, a pioneering American ballet dancer and one of the first ballet choreographers to employ American subject matter, died on Sunday at her home in Chicago. She was 92 years old.

title: A Leader for Some Seasons
description: When Saddam Hussein devoured Kuwait, George Bush stirred a desert storm. But now, in response to the vast tide of Iraqi refugees, the President who assembled a mighty coalition to humble Iraq now offers only lukewarm words and grudging gestures. Mr. Bush, who worked so skillfully to lead the United Nations against aggression, now ducks passively behind it.

title: Q&A
description: Battery Drain

title: Would Straw Have Hustled To Third?
description: ONE small base for Hubie Brooks, one giant base for Metkind.

title: Westchester Halts Dumping Of Putnam's Sewage Waste
description: Westchester County today revoked the licenses of five septic-tank-pumping companies, accusing them of illegally dumping waste from Putnam County into Westchester's sewage system.

title: NCR Is Willing To Restart Talks
description: The NCR Corporation is willing to restart merger talks with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company but is not willing to go below NCR's asking price of $110 a share. A spokesman for the computer maker said the company was open to renewing the merger talks, which stalled after NCR's annual meeting last month. Face-to-face negotiations between Charles E. Exley, NCR's chairman, and Robert E. Allen, A.T.& T.'s chairman, made no headway last Thursday.

title: NEW SPORTS PAGES, MORE SPORTS NEWS
description: * 50% more weekdaysports news * New, original graphics * More statistics New columns and features

title: Champion Reds Throw a Party; Even Rain Can't Stop Parade
description: In a town where opening day turned into a festive cottage industry long ago, the Cincinnati Reds don't usually require any more reason than a first pitch to throw the biggest coming-out party in major-league baseball.

title: Music in Review
description: Mitsuko Uchida Alice Tully Hall

title: Americans Generally Healthier, U.S. Report Shows
description: Americans were generally healthier in 1990, but the Department of Health and Human Services said today that some significant problems persisted, including higher homicide rates, increased deaths from AIDS and more people who lack health insurance.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas in the United States fell by 29 last week, to 881, from 910 in the previous week, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The total was 56 fewer than the 937 rigs a year earlier, the company said. The count reached a peak of 4,500 in the oil boom of December 1981, but plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986.

title: U.S. TO SIMPLIFY INSURANCE PLANS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: In a move to protect consumers and reduce confusion among the elderly, the nation's insurance commissioners have chosen nine private health insurance policies to supplement coverage provided by the Federal Government through Medicare. The nine policies will soon replace the bewildering jumble of supplemental policies now offered in the private market.

title: London Zoo Goads British: We'll Close
description: The London Zoo, one of the oldest in Europe, has threatened to close next fall and do away with any of the 5,000 animals for whom new homes cannot be found, unless it gets a Government subsidy.

title: By Design; An Explosion of Color
description: If you like color, this is certainly your season. It's hard to remember such an assault of high-voltage shades. Stores are chockablock with suits, jackets, dresses, sweaters, accessories and even lingerie in every color. And this is not just a top-ticket phenomenon; the explosion of color covers fashion at every price level.

title: Trenton Legislator Proposes Overhaul of Welfare System
description: A leading legislator today introduced a plan intended to change a welfare system that he said encouraged families to break up and discouraged the poor from entering the job market.

title: Layoffs Line the Road to Recovery
description: Last month's surge in unemployment made a lot of people wonder how the recession can wind down as long as workers are losing jobs. In fact, layoffs and unemployment typically keep climbing long after spending starts to revive.

title: Selection of Jury Gets Under Way In Bid-Rigging Case Tied to Mob
description: Thirteen years ago, the authorities say, a group of mobsters began rigging bids that skimmed millions of dollars from contracts to install windows for New York City's Housing Authority.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Biospherics Inc., Beltsville, Md., a maker of water pollution control equipment, received a patent for a less costly way of producing its low-calorie sugar substitute, D-Tagatose. * Cambridge Biotech Corp., Worcester, Mass., has acquired Noctech Ltd., an Irish concern, in an exchange of 1,036,683 shares of Cambridge common stock for all of Noctech's common shares. Cambridge previously had an 18 percent stake in Noctech.

title: Soviets Try to Help Elderly and Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Selma Gross, Educator, 57
description: Selma Gross, a teacher and administrator in the New York City public school system for 32 years, died on Sunday at the Whitehall Convalescent and Nursing Home in Chicago. She was 57 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: New Computer Consortium
description: Twenty-one computer makers and software publishers said yesterday that they planned to develop a computing system based on two competing computer chips and two software operating systems.

title: Nonsmoker Speaks Up for Freedom of Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonsmoker Speaks Up for Freedom of Choice; Shifting the Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign by Turkey To Attract U.S. Visitors
description: As Turkey is deluged with requests for sanctuary from hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees that it says it cannot accommodate, it has undertaken a campaign to attract tourists from the United States.

title: Newspaper Editors Gather, With Stress On Small and Lean
description: As the nation's newspaper editors begin their annual convention here, many of the conversations will probably center on ways to cover the news more frugally.

title: Defying the Wisdom for '92, Ex-Senator Tsongas Dives In
description: The heavyweights in the Democratic Party are temporizing, stalling, waiting for the odds to improve before making any commitment to enter the 1992 Presidential campaign. Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, has simply plunged in, calmly defying the collective wisdom of the Capital Beltway.

title: Ford Motor
description: The Ford Motor Company said the use of chlorofluorocarbons, a chemical compound suspected of causing depletion of the earth's ozone layer, will be eliminated from 90 percent of its manufacturing by the fourth quarter of 1992. The company said the use of chlorofluorocarbons in plastic foam for seats and interior trim will be eliminated before 1993.

title: Probert Suspended
description: Detroit forward Bob Probert was suspended for one game and fined $500 yesterday for slugging St. Louis goaltender Vincent Riendeau during Game 2 of their National Hockey League playoff series.

title: Fear Rises as Another Palestinian Dies in Kuwait
description: A prominent Palestinian has been shot to death here in circumstances that have raised concern among American officials that Kuwaitis, including some army and Government officials, are still abusing Palestinians.

title: The Whalers Bounce Back
description: The Hartford Whalers did all their scoring in the first 15 minutes 55 seconds and then held on for a 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight to even their Adams Division semifinal series at two victories apiece.

title: Safeway Offering Of Common Stock
description: Safeway Inc. is offering about $350 million in common stock through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company as part of a previously announced capital exependiture plan.

title: Airlift to Stranded Kurds: Rations Familiar to G.I.'s
description: From the flight deck of a United States military cargo plane, Iraq's northern-most frontier is a line of cars parked helter-skelter and snaking for miles through brown mountains.

title: INSIDE
description: An Anti-Weicker Coalition

title: CHRONICLE
description: Playing tough guys on the screen is one thing, but proving toughness in real life is another. The actor MICKEY ROURKE will make his debut as a professional boxer on May 23 at the Fort Lauderdale War Memorial Auditorium in Florida. Mr. Rourke, 34, fought 26 fights as an amateur in the 1970's before he started a film career that has included "9 1/2 Weeks," "The Pope of Greenwich Village," "Diner," "Angel Heart" and "Barfly."

title: Utah Abortion Law Is Suspended
description: Enforcement of Utah's stringent new abortion law and provisions of older abortion laws will be suspended while a challenge to the constitutionality of the restrictions moves through the Federal courts.

title: Pulitzer Prizes in Letters Go to Updike and Simon
description: "Rabbit at Rest," John Updike's conclusion to a quartet of novels that portrayed the psychic ups and downs of America through the life of a small-town car salesman, and "Lost in Yonkers," Neil Simon's play about the relationship of two teen-agers and their iron-willed grandmother, won 1991 Pulitzer Prizes yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: A player from Jacksonville, Fla., was probably both the oldest player and the luckiest in the world championships in Geneva in September. She is Etta Gibbs, 83 years old, and on the diagramed deal she had the good fortune to be playing against the world's greatest optimist.

title: Citytrust Reports A Greater Loss
description: Citytrust Bancorp, which operates commercial banks in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey, reported a revised $64.5 million fourth-quarter loss and said it had filed for Federal assistance and forbearance from regulatory capital and other requirements.

title: Desperate Iraqis Rush to Surrender
description: At Checkpoint Charlie about 30 miles northwest of here, a steady stream of young Iraqis are trying to be taken prisoner.

title: SECESSION DECREED BY SOVIET GEORGIA
description: The republic of Georgia declared its independence today, further confounding President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's uncertain hold on the deeply troubled Soviet nation.

title: Jokes and Jitters Greet Quake Report
description: At a popular bakery near the University of Washington, Jeff Carter finished his cappuccino and then pretended to be standing at the epicenter of a major earthquake.

title: Rethink 4 Food Groups, Doctors Tell U.S.
description: A group of physicians is asking the Federal Department of Agriculture to abandon the traditional four food groups -- meat, fish and poultry; grains; dairy products; and fruits and vegetables -- and to substitute what many will consider a radical new grouping of foods. The four new groups, proposed at a news conference here on Monday, are fruits; grains; vegetables; and legumes, which includes beans, peanut butter and soybeans. Meat and dairy products are options, and minor ones at that.

title: Hubie The Hero Blushes at Success
description: It is not always going to be this way, Hubie Brooks knows. It won't always be this sweet. He cannot give the Mets the stuff of storybooks every day. He cannot make the ball park tense and electric and occasionally furious the way his predecessor in right field could.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Catharsis and Coup de Theatre For Women Veterans of Vietnam
description: As the lights came up on a reproduction of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, women who served in that war placed mementoes of their experience as if they were flowers on a grave. The reaction of the audience at the Actors Theater of Louisville was palpable. Sobs filled the house in a crescendo that became a group lamentation. This final scene in Shirley Lauro's new play, "A Piece of My Heart," is a catharsis as well as a coup de theatre. The women in the play are the most forgotten among all those who had been forgotten in Vietnam.

title:
Real Estate;
Fordham Rd. Faring Well In Retailing
description: ALTHOUGH New York City's economy is sluggish and the market for retail space is generally in the doldrums, the 11-block Fordham Road shopping corridor in the Bronx is showing signs of stable health. Of the 400 retail spaces that line the corridor from the Grand Concourse to Third Avenue, barely a handful, far less than 5 percent, are vacant.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Just seven months after arriving in Washington, PETER ZWACK has been removed as Hungary's Ambassador to the United States. Mr. Zwack immigrated to the United States with his family in 1948 but renounced his American citizenship when he took the post. Since his arrival, Mr. Zwack, 57 years old, enlivened Washington with festive dinners at the embassy and vigorous support of Hungary's transition into capitalism.

title: GORBACHEV ORDERS REPUBLICS TO HALT REBELLIOUS MOVES
description: Warning that the Soviet Union faced economic collapse and a paralysis of power, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented a crisis program today that combined calls for strict discipline with a stepped-up transition to a market economy.

title: I.R.S. Operations Called Smoothest in Some Time
description: With less than a week to go until April 15, the Internal Revenue Service is finding far less than the usual tax-season grumbling aimed its way this year.

title: Favored Cambodians Lose U.S. Aid
description: Washington has suspended new aid to the non-Communist Cambodian factions, Administration, Congressional and non-Communist Cambodian officials say.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Care Group Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a provider of home health-care services for AIDS patients, will acquire Children's Nursing Services/Medstaff, Houston, a provider of pediatric nursing services. Terms are being negotiated. * Chrysler Corp., Highland Park, Mich., will open a parts distribution center in Belgium next month.

title: Singer Says Part of Voice on Hit Is Hers
description: In the wake of lawsuits surrounding Milli Vanilli and Black Box, another invisible pop singer has taken to the courts to gain credit for a hit vocal. Yvette Marine, a former member of a group called the Mary Jane Girls, is suing Paula Abdul's record company, Virgin Records, and its distributor, Warner-Elektra-Atlantic, to receive full credit and royalties for her work on three songs on Ms. Abdul's debut album, "Forever Your Girl," released in 1988, which has sold seven million copies in the United States. Ms. Marine has not sued Ms. Abdul.

title: San Marcos Journal; A Move for Marijuana Where the 60's Survive
description: The nation's anti-drug fervor is lost on a small band of refugees from the 1960's in this laid-back college town on the edge of the Texas hill country.

title: Unpaid-Leave Proposals Deserve Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; SmithKline's Expiring Patents
description: SINCE last April, the prices of the British shares and American equity units of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the British drug company, have soared 73 percent and 80 percent, respectively.

title: Soviets Reduce Forces in Poland, Saying They Will Decide the Pace
description: The Soviet Union began withdrawing its 50,000 troops from Poland today, and their commander defiantly declared that Moscow alone would set the timetable for completing the process.

title: Books of The Times; In a Reality That's Hostile to Idealists
description: War Fever By J. G. Ballard 176 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux . $18.95.

title: Program Selling Pushes Dow Down 45.54
description: Heavy waves of program selling toppled the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday, carrying the broader market down sharply as well.

title: Thomas B. Meade; Periodontist, 75
description: Dr. Thomas B. Meade, a Brooklyn periodontist, died on Saturday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 75 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Sports of The Times; Where Bam-Bam Fits In
description: OF course ballplayers make too much money. Of course owners make too much money. And of course you and I don't make enough. A large majority of Americans emphasized this, according to the reading here of The New York Times/CBS News Poll released yesterday on a wide variety of subjects relating to baseball.

title: Cranston Gets 2 More Weeks
description: The Senate Ethics Committee today gave Senator Alan Cranston two additional weeks to respond to its finding of "substantial credible evidence" of his misconduct in ties to Charles H. Keating Jr., the indicted savings and loan executive. Mr. Cranston, Democrat of California, had been scheduled to respond in writing by Monday but requested an extension to April 22.

title: ISRAEL BACKS PLAN FOR SINGLE SESSION ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: Israel said today for the first time that it was willing in principle to attend a regional peace meeting co-sponsored by Washington and Moscow.

title: End of Slump Seen in Quarter
description: Seventy percent of the nation's top economists believe that the United States economy will pull out of the recession in the current quarter, according to a survey released today.

title: The Pulitzer Prizes
description: ARTS: Fiction -- "Rabbit at Rest" by John Updike. Drama -- "Lost in Yonkers" by Neil Simon. History -- 'A Midwife's Tale: The Life of Martha Ballard, Based on Her Diary 1785-1812" by Laurel Thatcher Ulrich. Biography -- "Jackson Pollock: An American Saga" by Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith. Poetry -- "Near Changes" by Mona Van Duyn. General Nonfiction -- "The Ants" by Bert Holldobler and Edward O. Wilson. Music -- "Symphony" by Shulamit Ran. JOURNALISM: Public Service -- The Des Moines Register for reporting by Jane Schorer. Spot News Reporting -- The Miami Herald staff. Investigative Reporting -- Joseph T. Hallinan and Susan M. Headden of The Indianapolis Star. Explanatory Journalism -- Susan C. Faludi of The Wall Street Journal. Beat Reporting -- Natalie Angier of The New York Times. National Reporting -- Marjie Lundstrom and Rochelle Sharpe of Gannett News Service. International Reporting -- Caryle Murphy of The Washington Post and Serge Schmemann of The New York Times. Feature Writing -- Sheryl James of the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times. Commentary -- Jim Hoagland of The Washington Post. Criticism -- David Shaw of The Los Angeles Times. Editorial Writing -- Ron Casey, Harold Jackson and Joey Kennedy of The Birmingham (Ala.) News. Editorial Cartooning -- Jim Borgman of The Cincinnati Enquirer. Spot News Photography -- Greg Marinovich of The Associated Press. Feature Photography -- William Snyder of The Dallas Morning News.

title: Frenchwoman's Death Is Linked To Abortion Pill and a Hormone
description: France's Health Ministry has announced that for the first time a woman has died after undergoing treatment for a nonsurgical abortion using the combination of a French abortion pill, RU-486, and a follow-up hormone injection.

title:
GOLF;
Hills and Greens at Masters Frustrate Even the Best
description: If it weren't for the beauty of the place, the history that was made there and the difficulty of the golf course, Augusta National would have nothing to recommend itself.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * General Dynamics Corp., St. Louis, named Harvey Kapnick vice chairman. * Outlet Communications Inc., Providence, R.I., named James Babb chairman, president and chief executive. He succeeds Leonard Lieberman, who had held those positions on an interim basis since Jan. 7, after David E. Henderson died in December.

title:
HORSE RACING;
Car Accident Leaves Shoemaker Paralyzed
description: Bill Shoemaker, the most successful jockey in thoroughbred-racing history, was critically injured and paralyzed Monday night after the car he was driving flipped over and plunged down a 50-foot embankment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Eloise would be terribly upset." -- Prof. James Shenton, on Donald Trump's plans for the Plaza Hotel. [ B3:1. ]

title: Economic Scene; The Faxes Are Coming
description: "YOU can't shake hands with a fax," headlined the ad from Go-USA, a coalition of companies seeking to put the bloom back in the cheeks of the depressed travel business. "Nothing can replace . . . the special feeling that comes only from being there." But such considerations have not stopped Arthur D. Little, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., from imagining an America in which improved telecommunications replaced 10 to 20 percent of the miles now logged by commuters, shoppers and business travelers.

title:
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
To Improve Artificial Knees: Custom Options
description: Surgeons perform knee replacement operations as many as 140,000 times a year in this country on patients ranging from 17-year-old dancers to 30-year-old athletes to 69-year-old retirees. In most cases, doctors routinely replace damaged joints with artificial knee sets available from a dozen companies.

title: After Jail-Policy Disputes, Koch Appointee Quits Panel
description: After a series of policy disputes with New York City's Correction Commissioner, Robert Kasanof resigned yesterday as chairman of the Board of Correction, the agency that oversees conditions in city jails.

title: Cigar Smokers Try to Prove Freud Wrong
description: ROBERT BLY, take heart. The "wild man" that the Pied Piper of the wayward male psyche wishes more men would unleash is alive and well and defiantly blowing cigar smoke in society's face.

title: Food Notes
description: Taste of the Nation

title: Views of the Kennedy House: Poignant Past, Busy Present
description: When John F. Kennedy was President, it was known as the Florida White House, with Secret Service agents stationed in the servants' quarters and direct telephone lines to the White House in Washington.

title: Scratching at the Teflon
description: This is what readers will learn from a new book called "Nancy Reagan, the Unauthorized Biography."

title: Harvard Medical School Withdraws Bill to U.S.
description: Harvard Medical School said yesterday that it had subtracted $500,000 from the $28 million it billed the Federal Government this year for research costs and that some of the reduction was the result of errors or questionable charges by the school.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. GIOVANNI ROVERA has been named the director of the Wistar Institute, the nation's oldest independant biomedical research institution. He succeeds Dr. HILARY KOPROWSKI , who becomes the institute's president.

title: Minoso Bid Blocked
description: Minnie Minoso's bid to play professional baseball in a sixth decade was blocked yesterday when his contract with the Miami Miracle of the Florida State League was rejected by the baseball commissioner's office.

title: Capitals Play Tough and Tie Series at 2-2
description: The game between the Rangers and the Washington Capitals here tonight was the best thus far of their first-round National Hockey League playoff series, but that will be of little consolation to the Rangers or their fans.

title: Asset Sale By Revlon Called Near
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics giant headed by Ronald O. Perelman, is expected to announce as early as today that it plans to sell its Max Factor division and a German subsidiary to Procter & Gamble for about $1 billion.

title: Developer Suing NBC Over a News Program
description: A New Jersey real-estate developer has sued NBC, contending that it erroneously identified him as the leader of a Vietnamese street gang in New York on a television news program last year.

title: Irwin Sobel, 89, Dies; Pediatrician-Novelist
description: Dr. Irwin Philip Sobel, a pediatrician and novelist, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Treasury Prices Decline Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in listless trading yesterday, as dealers sold some securities in advance of an auction today of $8.5 billion worth of new seven-year Treasury notes.

title: PROSTITUTES JOIN MEXICO AIDS FIGHT
description: When they come looking to buy sex in the dim alleys and side streets of this sprawling city, many Mexican men look for something else first: a small white identity card.

title: Nicholas Marotta, 61, Food-Industry Official
description: Nicholas G. Marotta, retired president of the National Starch and Chemical Corporation, died on Monday at his home in Watchung, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: Rape Case: Badge vs. Badge
description: Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said yesterday the New York City Police Department was investigating a charge by a police officer that she had been raped by a fellow officer in a stairwell at Police Headquarters.

title: Power Failure Strikes Hawaii's Main Island
description: The failure of a transmission line knocked out power throughout Hawaii's most-populous island, Oahu, this morning, stranding people in elevators, tangling traffic and disrupting some communications.

title: Kurds, the New Palestinians
description: Humanitarian concerns aside, the U.S. decision not to help the Iraqi Kurds does not make much sense in pure cold-blooded geopolitical terms. The flight of millions of Kurds from their Iraqi homeland to the Turkish and Iranian frontiers may prove to be the prelude to a political disaster like that of the Middle East's other stateless people, the Palestinians.

title: Winners of the 1991 Pulitzer Prizes in the Arts and Journalism
description: Biography Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith "Jackson Pollock: An American Saga"

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article last Wednesday about the burial of Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre referred incorrectly to the Rev. Franz Schmidberger, titular head of the St. Pius X Fraternity of Priests. He was not one of the four bishops whom Archbishop Lefebvre ordained in 1988 in defiance of the Vatican.

title: Hasbro Extends Its Offer for Tonka
description: Hasbro Inc. today extended its deadline for the bondholders and shareholders of the Tonka Corporation to tender their securities. But Hasbro warned that it could not maintain its $470 million buyout offer indefinitely.

title: Alfred L. Frechette; Health Official, 81
description: Dr. Alfred L. Frechette, a former Massachusetts Health Commissioner, died Sunday at Framingham Union Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FRESH mussels from the tidal waters near my home on eastern Long Island are true harbingers of spring. But it is not necessary to live on the water to have access to good mussels today, for many fishmongers carry domestic and imported varieties that are impeccable. Cultivated mussels, like those that grow on ropes in the chilly waters of Maine, have the added advantage of being grit free.

title: Review/Recital; Keyboard Fireworks From Alfred Brendel
description: Pianists who write well about music are not unheard of. Liszt was a paragon in that respect, the touchstone for his century. A more recent list of literary keyboardists would also have to include Sir Donald Tovey, Paul Badura-Skoda and Charles Rosen. Few doubly gifted artists, however, have been as successful as Alfred Brendel in attaining comparable stardom as both author and performer. The Austrian pianist is not only an international best seller while wearing his performer's hat; his cultivated essays on music, collected into two successful books, have found an expanded audience by being reprinted in literary journals.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: OPENING DAY You don't need a diamond, or a wall or bases, much less a crowd; just the two of you in sweats, two mitts and a ball. Start close, then throw longer and longer, higher and higher on a cool spring afternoon. -- ED ROSSMANN

title: Two Big Swings Are Just Enough for the Mets
description: Crack in the 9th inning.

title: Ailing Knicks Almost Stun Bulls
description: The Knicks almost pulled off a shocking victory tonight. They almost beat the Chicago Bulls, despite playing without Gerald Wilkins (sprained ankle) and Charles Oakley (sore knee). And they almost snapped a four-year losing streak at Chicago Stadium.

title: Firm to Do Research For McCabe
description: ED McCABE likes to do the unexpected, and the advertising executive said yesterday that he had struck an innovative deal with Oxtoby-Smith, a leading consumer research firm. The firm will serve as a research department for the agency Mr. McCabe started two months ago.

title: Michelin Layoffs
description: Michelin, Europe's largest tire manufacturer, will lay off 4,900 workers at French factories to improve its productivity amid depressed car sales in Europe and North America. Of the planned cuts, 2,400 will affect workers at Michelin's operations in the Clermont-Ferrand region. Michelin also said it expected to report a loss in 1990.

title: Measure Is Offered to Repeal South African Apartheid Law
description: The South African Government formally proposed a draft bill in Parliament today to repeal the Population Registration Act, a pillar of apartheid that classifies people by race.

title: Iraq Rejects European Plan For Kurdish Haven in North
description: Iraq today rejected the European Community's proposal for creating a haven for Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.

title: Grants Rejected; Scholars Grumble
description: Lynne V. Cheney, the chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, and a group of scholars are embroiled in a dispute over Mrs. Cheney's rejection of a series of grants for projects marking the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus's discovery of the New World.

title: In the Nation; Bad News From Above
description: The news was very bad -- not so heart-rending as the plight of the Kurdish refugees but more deadly for the future: The ozone layer, at the latitude of the United States, is disappearing more than twice as swiftly as scientists had thought.

title: Hard-Hitting Devils In Control as Penguins Barely Stand a Chance
description: The Devils were determined to make the black-and-gold clad Penguins turn black and blue tonight.

title: Civil-Rights Advocate Says She Is a Lesbian
description: In a personal appeal for legislative support for gay rights, the head of the state's anti-discrimination agency has publicly declared that she is a lesbian.

title: SportsWednesday
description: * Seventy-one percent of Americans say baseball players earn too much money. Look at every major league salary and decide for yourself. * How tough is tough? For golfers at the Masters, no hole is easy, but five are more fearsome than the rest. Pages B5-12.

title: Max Janowski, 79, Composer and Teacher
description: Max Janowski, a composer of Jewish liturgical music, died on Monday at his home in Hyde Park, Ill. He was 79 years old.

title: Los Angeles Mayor and Police Chief Call a Truce
description: In a dramatic joint appearance at City Hall this evening, Mayor Tom Bradley and Chief Daryl F. Gates of the Police Department called a truce in their public feud and asked for a cooling of the rhetoric that has divided the city for more than a month since the beating of a black motorist by white police officers.

title: Imagining The Plaza As Condos
description: Donald J. Trump says that turning the Plaza Hotel into condominiums won't transform the turreted landmark into the Manhattan equivalent of a time-share in the Catskills. But there are those who have their doubts about his plans for what has been a home away from home for generations of sultans, starlets and well-heeled sightseers.

title: Rochester: An Uneasy Symbol of School Reform
description: This is a story of perestroika, of bureaucrats fighting to keep power, citizens confused, civil servants clinging to the old ways and unions battling management amid economic chaos.

title: Ireland Issues Bonds in U.S.
description: Ireland issued its first bonds in the United States yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Portrait of Religion in U.S. Holds Dozens of Surprises
description: The state with the highest proportion of people who profess no religion is Oregon.

title: Defendant Denies Link to 2 Queens Killings
description: The lawyer for a reputed drug-ring leader being tried on murder charges said yesterday that his client had nothing to do with the Queens killings last week of two people linked to a prosecution witness.

title: 3 Cigna Executives Are Shot on Street; Doctor Is Arrested
description: Three insurance executives were shot, one fatally, on a downtown boulevard here on Monday afternoon as they returned from a birthday celebration. Today the police in Elberon, Va., arrested a suspect about a mile from his parent's home as he was jogging.

title: Arthur P. Wales, 73, Smith Corona Official
description: Arthur Paul Wales, a retired vice president of the Smith Corona Marchant Corporation in Manhattan, died March 27 at a nursing home in Lantana, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Lantana.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the front page of Business Day yesterday titled "What Turns Up as Recessions End" placed some recessions incorrectly. A corrected chart appears today on page D16.

title: Spira Jury Chosen
description: A jury of 10 men and two women will hear the Federal Government's case against Howard Spira, the Bronx man who is charged with making threats and extortion and whose association with George Steinbrenner cost Steinbrenner control of the New York Yankees last year.

title: Cray Computer
description: Cray Research Inc. announced a new mid-priced supercomputer it said would make supercomputing more accessible. The Cray Y-MP4E will be available in May for about $7.3 million, about two-thirds as much as similar supercomputers, said John A. Rollwagen, chairman and chief executive of the Minneapolis-based company. Mr. Rollwagen said Cray was announcing the computer in Japan because it expected the computer would sell well here. Supercomputers are used for high-speed, repetitive and scientific calculations.

title: Rises Noted In Car Prices
description: Prices for 1991-model cars and trucks have been moving higher, with Mazda Motor of America raising prices three times, according to an automotive journal.

title: Chinese Premier Defends '89 Crackdown on Protesters
description: Prime Minister Li Peng today gave a vigorous defense of the violent crackdown on the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement and suggested that the Government was ready to use similar methods to crush future protests.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about John M. Blewer, a lawyer who headed an investment counseling concern, rendered the name of a surviving son incorrectly and omitted the name of the son's mother. The son is John MacGregor Blewer Jr. of Manhattan. His mother, whose marriage to Mr. Blewer ended in divorce, is Barbara Welter.

title: Franklin R. Hall; Executive, 74
description: Franklin R. Hall, who directed operations abroad for Exxon, died on March 31 at the Arbors nursing home in Shelburne, Vt., where he lived. He was 74 years old and had lived in Bronxville, N.Y., and New Milford, Conn.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: MANY consumers are confused by the high wattage ratings now stamped on microwave ovens, some of them 800 watts or more.

title: Hero's Tribute to 24 for Water Rescues
description: It was just another day in the life of Donald Carney when he jumped into the East River at 34th Street in Manhattan last April and helped rescue a man who was trying to drown himself. Four hours later and nine blocks to the south, he went into the river again and rescued another emotionally disturbed man.

title: A Coach Learns Again to Love the Game
description: Steve Mandl, the baseball coach at George Washington High School in Washington Heights, looks toward opening day tomorrow and remembers how it all began.

title: The Pop Life
description: Trombone Triumphant

title: Strawberry, the Mets And a Passing Glance
description: DARRYL STRAWBERRY'S name was penciled in the Los Angeles lineup, after Juan Samuel's and before Eddie Murray's. Everything was set. The debut with the Dodgers -- the new start the former Mets right fielder had engineered to occur as far away from the New York stage on which he performed passionately, if not perfectly, for so long -- was minutes away.

title: Nicklaus, the Master of the Masters, Still Gets Attention
description: There are no numbers, only 88 names, on the huge scoreboard that will chart the 55th Masters starting Thursday. Scanning it, the eye stops easily to consider names like Faldo, Norman, Strange and Woosnam. But despite the tug of common sense, the eye also unavoidably settles on the name Nicklaus.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Dinkins Has Tough Talk With Police Graduates
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday urged the largest class of rookie police officers in nine years to avoid becoming "burned-out bullies with billy clubs."

title: A Coach Learns Again to Love the Game
description: Steve Mandl, the baseball coach at George Washington High School in Washington Heights, looks toward opening day tomorrow and remembers how it all began.

title: Budget Woe Gets Worse For Dinkins
description: The Dinkins administration, already struggling to balance New York City's budget, got more bad news yesterday: further erosion in tax collections and renewed refusals by municipal union leaders to cooperate by making money-saving concessions.

title: Accusations Against China on Tibet Can't Withstand Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE -- Legal Subcommittee -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON AFRICAN ECONOMIC RECOVERY AND DEVELOPMENT -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 'Wish List' Site for Sale But Cuomo Still Wishes
description: A Georgia developer has put up for sale a large expanse of Adirondack land that New York State wants to preserve as wilderness but says it cannot afford.

title: Senators, Back in Session, Mourn Colleagues
description: Still shaken by the deaths of Senator John Heinz of Pennsylvania and former Senator John G. Tower of Texas last week, senators devoted much of their return today from a two-week Easter recess to offering tributes to the two Republicans.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Business Loans Put Bank in Red
description: The Bank of New York said yesterday that problems with business loans, many of them to finance corporate takeovers, resulted in a $63 million quarterly loss.

title: Key Rates
Bucks Too Big, a Majority Tells Poll
description: If you're convinced that, say, Dwight Gooden is worth every penny of the $1,850 or so he will make for every pitch he throws next season, or that Jose Canseco deserves the $5,000 he earns every time he bats, boy, do you have an argument on your hands.

title: Americans, in Shift, Say War Ended Too Soon
description: A majority of Americans now say the United States and its allies should have continued fighting until President Saddam Hussein was removed from power, but a majority also say it is best for the United States to stay out of active involvement in the current turmoil in Iraq, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Nicholls On a Roll, But Can't Do It All
description: Four scores and seven games ago, Bernie Nicholls was in such a severe slump only he believed there was nothing amiss.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: F.T.C. in Accord With Campbell
description: The Campbell Soup Company, accused by the Federal Trade Commission of making deceptive health claims about its soups, agreed to disclose the soups' sodium content in certain ads.

title: Let the Pill Into the U.S.
description: The Bush Administration is again wielding the anti-abortion club. This time its bias threatens access to a drug that is an alternative to surgical abortion and a potentially effective treatment for breast and brain cancer, Cushing's disease, glaucoma and diabetes.

title: Aubrey Mallach, 85, Social Service Leader
description: Aubrey Mallach, a former executive of social service organizations in New York City, died on Monday at White Plains Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: The Presidential Check-Off:
description: Full Federal funding for next year's Presidential election is in jeopardy. The millions of taxpayers who will file their returns in the few remaining days before Monday's deadline can do something about it.

title: G.O.P. PANEL FINED FOR FINANCE LAPSE
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the National Republican Senatorial Committee violated campaign finance law by raising more than $2.3 million for 12 Senate candidates in 1986 and failing to report the contributions.

title: Nonsmoker Speaks Up for Freedom of Choice; Weight Gain
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about a Kurdish expatriate's account of radio broadcasts to Iraq referred incorrectly to the Saudi city of Jidda. It is not the capital.

title: Kennedy's Day Filled With Senate Business
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who has been battling the taint of family scandal since a woman told the police she was raped at the Kennedy estate in Palm Beach, Fla., during the Easter recess, returned today to a full schedule on Capitol Hill.

title: Thirty-Six Degrees of Separation
description: A man who hadn't been to his health club in a few days was startled yesterday morning when he passed the coat rack. The last time he had looked it was jammed with an array of Burberrys and London Fogs, thick with their winter linings, escorted by a phalanx of battered briefcases. Yesterday morning he saw only the briefcases, under a rack of empty hangers.

title: Bonds for Denver Airport Priced to Yield Up to 9.185%
description: A $500 million revenue bond issue, which is being sold to help the city and county of Denver finance the construction of the new Denver International Airport, was priced yesterday with a maximum yield of about 9.185 percent for a debt security due 2023 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: 120 Jobs Are Cut At Hercules Unit
description: The Hercules Aerospace Company laid off 120 workers at its Bacchus Works here and stopped work on the Titan 4 missile. The moves came after a Hercules-built Titan 4 motor exploded during a recent test. The missile represents about 8 percent of the Wilmington, Del., company's business. A spokesman, Dave Nicponski, said, however, that the layoffs were aimed at improving results and were not connected to the stop-work order.

title: Wool Price Supports
description: Wool producers will get about $105 million in Federal subsidies beginning on Wednesday to help compensate for low prices last year, the Agriculture Department said. The 1990 support price level as determined by Congress was $1.82 a pound of wool. But the average market price was only 80 cents a pound. Producers of mohair will also collect about $60 million for their sales last year. Mohair supports were slightly more than $4.53 a pound, while the market price averaged 93 cents.

title: Put the Aid Back in Medicaid
description: When they're sick, poor people in New York State suffer twice. Beyond injury and disease, they must struggle with a health care system that sends them from emergency room to clinic to Medicaid mill, looking for treatment they're not likely to find. They rarely see the same doctor twice, rarely get the attention that private patients do and even more rarely develop relationships with doctors who know their medical histories.

title: Mexico-U.S. Phone Lines To Increase
description: A.T.& T. announced today that it would increase the telecommunications capacity between the United States and Mexico fivefold by the end of this year, as part of a broad new focus on Latin America.

title: F.C.C. Adopts Limits on TV Ads Aimed at Children
description: The Federal Communications Commission adopted rules today limiting advertising on television shows for children and setting standards intended to improve the educational quality of children's programs.

title: Measuring Audiences: 3-Year Study Planned
description: The Committee on Nationwide Television Audience Measurement, an organization that represents the three leading broadcast networks, said yesterday that it had commissioned a three-year study intended to improve the methods used to estimate national television audiences.

title: Review/Film; 3 Vignettes of Israel, Bleak and Pessimistic
description: The three short Israeli films that constitute "Echoes of Conflict," the new program at the Film Forum, share the same tension and malaise. The anxiety level in each of these short dramas is unbearably high. Paranoia is everywhere, and the reactions it provokes are often trigger-happy and frightening. These stories of contemporary Israel are united by this inescapable strain and by their pessimism. None of the three film makers hold out much hope for a peaceful future.

title: Germany Records a Deficit
description: Germany reported a large gap in its balance of payments for the second consecutive month today, a result of the difficulties of unification and the costs of the Persian Gulf war.

title: CUNY Student Protest Spreads to 4 More Colleges
description: Students took over buildings at Manhattan Community, Bronx Community, Lehman and Hunter Colleges yesterday, as a protest against proposed tuition increases and budget cuts spread from City College to other campuses of the City University of New York.

title: Seeing the Light in a Miniature Office
description: With neat little desks, five tiny windows and ceilings that are 10 inches high, it looks at first glance like a doll house. But playtime is at a minimum in this elaborate little world.

title: Religion in America: Snapshots
description: From a telephone survey of 13,000 households in the 48 contiguous states conducted from April 1989 to April 1990. Numbers are rounded. Politics Percentage identifying with each party. Religion Democrat Republican Jewish 43% 22% Baptist 43% 27% Pentecostal 38% 27% Catholic 38% 27% Methodist 35% 36% Presbyterian 28% 44% Lutheran 26% 37% Episcopalian 25% 41% Mormon 23% 51% RESIDENCY For each religion, percentage of the total U.S. population, and the five states with the largest percentage. Catholic 26% R.I. 62 Mass. 54 Conn. 50 La. 47 N.J. 46 Baptist 19% Mass. 55 Ala. 51 Ga. 51 N.C. 47 D.C. 47 Methodist 8% Del. 27 Iowa 16 S.C. 16 W. Va. 15 Kan. 15 Lutheran 5% N.D. 37 Minn. 34 S.D. 30 Wis. 26 Neb. 16 Jewish 2% N.Y. 7 N.J. 4 Fla. 4 Mass. 4 Md. 3 No Religion 8% Ore. 17 Wash. 14 Wyo. 14 Calif. 13 Ariz. 12 MARRIAGE Groups with the highest percentage of adults in each category. Married Mormon 73% Brethren 71% Asembly/God 70% Church/Christ 70% Church/God 68% Divorced Unitarian 18% No Religion 11% Christ. Sci. 11% Pentecostal 11% Assembly/God 10% Single Muslim 39% Buddhist 38% Greek Orthod. 31% Hindu 31% No Relig. 31% (Source: The Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York.)

title: New York Tests Electronic Ball and Chain
description: New York City jail guards strapped electronic transmitters on the left ankles of two inmates and then opened the gates for them. As the men strolled from the Brooklyn House of Detention last month they became the first to be released under a city program in which defendants awaiting trial are placed under house arrest and monitored by electronic surveillance.

title: Overflights to Continue
description: The White House said today that the United States would continue military surveillance flights over Iraqi territory even after the withdrawal of American forces to insure that Iraq obeys the United Nations cease-fire resolution.

title: Union Head Cites Difficulty In Vote by Two Film Locals
description: Although a tentative agreement was recently reached between two film unions and Hollywood producers that would end the stalemate that had shut down film making in New York City, it is "impossible to predict" whether the membership of one union will accept the agreement, said its president.

title: U.S. Says Harm From Valdez Spill Is Much Worse Than Was Thought
description: In the most comprehensive public account of the damage caused when oil spilled from the Exxon Valdez two years ago, the Government said today that far more wildlife had been killed and that environmental damage would persist much longer than scientists had originally thought.

title: Damage Awards in False Arrests
description: Eight men who were falsely arrested by transit police officers in a scandal that shook the department have been awarded more than $1 million in damages and legal fees by a Federal judge.

title: Fred Thormann; Executive, 81
description: Fred Thormann, retired vice president of Conde Nast Publications, died on Monday at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut. He was 81 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Next Renegade State
description: What country with 23 million people run by a vicious dictator has missiles, a million men under arms and is likely to possess nuclear weapons in a few years?

title: Senior Rhone Official To Head U.S. Operation
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the large French chemical and pharmaceutical company, has named a senior executive to be the president of its new specialty chemicals business in the United States. John A. Wichtrich, the new president, has served as a senior vice president in the formative specialty chemicals area with Rhone-Poulenc Inc., the North American subsidiary.

title: In Angola's Civil War, Education Is a Casualty
description: Marcelino Amado was giving the kind of restless, hectoring, cajoling performance that can be the hallmark of a gifted educator. His students were clearly enthralled, one moment laughing at his gentle joke, the next eagerly competing for his attention.

title: Nabilatuk Journal; A Fierce Uganda Tribe, Rustlers of the Old School
description: Around the waist of his sarong, 25-year-old Nangiro draped a double bandoleer of polished bullets that glinted in the sun like gold. Around his neck he wore a symbol of victory, a string of white ostrich shell representing the white bones of an enemy shot in a recent cattle raid.

title: Michael Fardink, 36, Pianist and Conductor
description: Michael Fardink, a pianist and conductor and the music director of opera at Rutgers, died on March 31 at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 36 years old and lived in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Sallie Mae Sets Note Offering
description: A $300 million issue of notes of the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, was priced yesterday through Morgan Stanley & Company, as sole underwriter.

title: Wine Talk
description: NICOLAS JOLY had put in two years with Morgan Guaranty in New York, advising on investments in chemical companies, then a year in London. In 1976, the bank wanted to move him once more. He quit instead, and came home here to another bank, that of the Loire River, and his family's estate at Coulee de Serrant, a tiny hamlet 15 minutes by car from Angers, the regional capital.

title: Benjamin Apologizes
description: Seattle SuperSonics center Benoit Benjamin apologized yesterday to Los Angeles Clippers fans for an obscene gesture he made at them as they booed him last Friday night during a loss to his former team. Benjamin called his actions totally unprofessional.(AP)

title: 'Oh, Kay!' Sets Reopening
description: The revival of the Broadway musical "Oh, Kay!," starring Rae Dawn Chong and Ron Richardson, is scheduled to reopen on April 18 at the Lunt Fontanne Theater. Produced by David Merrick, the musical originally opened last November at the Richard Rodgers Theater and gave 77 performances before closing for a winter hiatus in January. In addition to the casting changes, the production, which began previews April 2, also features some new orchestration.

title: Kurds Will Die in Vast Numbers Without Swift Aid, Agencies Say
description: The suddenness and size of the Kurds' exodus from Iraq into Iran and Turkey has created a crisis in which hundreds if not thousands could die if aid does not reach them soon, officials of international relief agencies said today.

title: Broken-Field Running
description: Raghib (Rocket) Ismail, the favorite to be the No. 1 pick in the National Football League draft on April 21, was scheduled to leave for Toronto this morning for a closer look at the Canadian Football League and the Toronto Argonauts. The Argonauts' owner, Bruce McNall, has reportedly offered Ismail a two-year, $6 million deal to touch down in the C.F.L. Tomorrow Ismail will fly to Los Angeles to meet with McNall.

title: Reagan Biography: In Quest of What?
description: Kitty Kelley goes to unusual lengths to underline her thoroughness in her biography of Nancy Reagan. She is photographed on the back cover amid several hundred files. The dust jacket boasts of "over 1,000 interviews." No fewer than seven pages in the acknowledgments section are filled with names of people who have helped her. There are 40 pages of notes on her sources.

title: Hewlett Alliance
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it had formed a sales, support and product development alliance with the Allen Bradley Company, a unit of the Rockwell International Corporation specializing in manufacturing-automation. The alliance's first product, Network DTL HP-UX, is a software intended to speed data transfers between Hewlett-Packard computers and Allen-Bradley automation equipment.

title: Theater in Review
description: Advice From a Caterpillar Lucille Lortel Theater 121 Christopher Street By Douglas Carter Beane; directed by Edgar Lansbury; scenery by Rick Dennis; costumes by Jonathan Bixby; lighting by Brian Nason; original music by David Abir. Presented by John Nassivera and Don Schneider, by special arrangement with Lucille Lortel. With: Dennis Christopher, David Lansbury, Ally Sheedy and Harley Venton.

title: Danny Jackson's Cub Debut Is Spoiled by Cardinals, 4-1
description: The St. Louis Cardinals spoiled Danny Jackson's Cub debut with three runs in the eighth inning today, and beat Chicago, 4-1, in the season opener for both teams.

title: About New York
description: The New York Botanical Garden is an emerald delight in a frazzled stretch of the Bronx. It includes what is said to be the last stand of virgin forest in New York City.

title: Rerun Ruling Can Only Complicate Deal-Making
description: The Federal Communications Commission's decision on rerun rights yesterday is likely to lead to ever-more-convoluted television deal-making in Hollywood, already famed for its Byzantine business practices.

title: Theater in Review
description: Eddie Goes to Poetry City: Part 2 La Mama, Annex Theater 74A East Fourth Street Through April 28 Written, directed and designed by Richard Foreman; lighting designer, Heather Carson; costume designer, Donna Zakowska. An Ontological-Hysteric Theater production presented by La Mama E.T.C. With: Kyle deCamp, Brian Delate, Rebecca Ellens, Colin Hodgson and Henry Stram.

title: U.S. Tells How 6 Died From Poor Care in Hospital
description: Two of six men who died from poor care at a Government veterans' hospital suffered ruptured aneurysms that were misdiagnosed, the Veterans Affairs Department said today.

title: Edsel Ford Becomes Finance Unit President
description: A familiar name was heard yesterday in the announcement of an important promotion at the Ford Motor Company.

title: Book Notes
description: Notable Absences

title: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Fall Again
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the period ended yesterday -- their sixth straight weekly drop -- with yield declines a little larger than the previous week.

title: Europeans Back Off Plan to Help Kurds
description: Western nations backed away today from a proposal to set up an enclave in northern Iraq administered by the United Nations where Kurdish refugees could be protected against further aggression by the forces of President Saddam Hussein.

title: Boy, 14, Killed in a Dispute
description: A 14-year-old boy was shot to death on a street in the Bronx last night after a dispute with a group of youths, the police said. The boy's body was found by the police on East 216th Street near Barnes Avenue in the Williamsbridge section shortly before 8 P.M., said Officer Fred Weiner, a police spokesman. Witnesses told the police that the boy, Byron Aarons, who lived a block away at 849 East 217th Street, was chased and shot by a group of youths with whom he had been arguing.

title: Theater in Review
description: Love in Two Countries St. Peter's 54th Street and Lexington Avenue Through April 13 Two one-act operas directed by Michael Montel; libretto by Sheldon Harnick; music by Thomas Z. Shepard; sets by Marie Anne Chiment; lighting by Betsy Adams; costumes by Amanda J. Klein; choreography by Karen Azenberg; musical director, Albert Ahronheim. Presented by Musical Theater Works. THAT PIG OF A MOLETTE With: Bill Carmichael, Scott Robertson and Elizabeth Walsh. A QUESTION OF FAITH With: Michael Brian, SuEllen Estey and Lannyl Stephens.

title: Legally Bought Guns Do Plenty of Mayhem
description: To the Editor:

title: New Toyota System
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said it had developed a new front-end suspension system for front-engine, front-wheel-drive cars. The Super Strut Suspension System will enhance vehicle performance in high-speed straight-line driving, turning, lane-changing and emergency maneuvering, Japan's largest car maker said.

title: Theater in Review
description: Blues in Rags Harry De Jur Playhouse 466 Grand Street Written and directed by Marketa Kimbrell; lyrics by Ms. Kimbrell; score composed and played by Nick Cosco; set by Remy Tessier; lighting by Zdenik Kriz; choreography by Marcia Donalds. Presented by the New York Street Theater Caravan. With: Marcia Donalds, Jennifer Johnson and Ariel Joseph.

title: At Shopping Clubs, Everything Is in Bulk, Except the Frills
description: IT has been likened to shopping for the millennium: the ordinary shopping cart, replaced by a flatbed rolling cart that can hold 25 pounds of sugar, 4 pounds of raisins, 16 pounds of rice, a gross of toilet-paper rolls, 23 pounds of detergent, a case of facial tissues and much, much more.

title: Beth Israel Tries to Help Where Help Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Fashion; Simply Put, It's the Klein Scenario for Luxury
description: EASY tunics floating gently over snug unitards, tights or stretch pants. Big blanketlike coats in cashmere or shearling, worn with suede T-strap sandles or ankle-high booties. Fluid satin dresses slithering sinuously over the body, or jeweled gems in the same simple shapes embroidered all over in gold or crystal beads. These are signs of the new minimalism as practiced by Calvin Klein.

title: On the Road From Old Fashion to New, Hip-Hop
description: DESIGNERS turned to 1940's men's wear, 60's luncheon suits and jangly 90's hip-hop styles in New York shows this week, searching for the right new-old spin for contemporary fashion.

title: Missouri Tries to Revamp Public Schools
description: This fiscally conservative state, which ranks in the bottom quarter in spending on education, is debating an ambitious plan to fine-tune its public education system and increase spending $460 million a year.

title: Official Reported to Face Ouster After His Dissent on Iraq Exports
description: The White House has ordered the dismissal of an Under Secretary of Commerce for telling Congress on Monday that the Administration ignored warnings to limit the export of American technology to Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait, Administration officials said today.

title: Yankees Are Not Caught Up In the Grind of Routine Lineups
description: The biggest mystery of the Yankee spring is now the biggest mystery of the season: Who will play and for how long?

title: Review/Television; The Improving Fortunes of ABC's 'Equal Justice'
description: A weekly series can get better. It does happen occasionally. Just take a look at ABC 's "Equal Justice," completing its first full season tonight at 10.

title: Rhode Island Bailout Urged
description: Rhode Island's Governor and Senators today pleaded for a Federal bailout of the state's private deposit insurance system, saying the state had been plunged into a financial crisis even worse than it suffered during the Great Depression.

title: Record Opening-Day Salaries: Not Peanuts or Cracker Jack
description: If the fact that 223 players are making $1 million or more this year -- 32 at $3 million or more -- is not enough of an economically mind-boggling barometer of the escalation of baseball salaries, consider these developments:

title: Drexler Leads Blazers
description: Clyde Drexler scored 11 of his 26 points in a third-quarter turnaround as the Portland Trail Blazers stretched their winning streak to 11 games with a 103-93 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.

title: Subway Exit Hazards Also Need Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Block Drug to Masterson Rothberg Advertising, New York, for two oral care products. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Egypt's 'Reward': Forgiven Debt
description: Egypt is about to receive a package of debt forgiveness and other international economic assistance worth billions of dollars in the wake of the Persian Gulf war, American and international economic officials said today.

title: DDB Creative Director
description: Paul Margulies, who has worked on campaigns for Alka-Seltzer, Citibank and Pan Am, has joined DDB Needham as a creative director. Mr. Marguiles, who has served as creative director for Wells, Rich, Greene in Paris and London, helped create the "Plop-plop, fizz-fizz, oh what a relief it is" campaign for Alka-Seltzer, the "Citi never sleeps" campaign for Citibank and a campaign for Pan Am, "You can't beat the experience."

title: New Campaigns
description: * Instead of featuring a person in its new campaign, the Travelers Corporation has opted for an untemperamental star, the red umbrella that is the insurance company's longtime symbol. In the spots, which will first run on Thursday on network and cable television, a camera follows the umbrella as it is toted through various corporate settings and then opened in a rainstorm. The theme line of the campaign, created by Campbell Mithun Esty New York, is, "You're better off under the umbrella."

title: Shuttle Chases Satellite And Prepares to Land
description: The space shuttle Atlantis zigzagged in the wake of the huge Gamma Ray Observatory today as its astronauts tried out a manual system for chasing down targets in orbit.

title: Bilzerian Ban by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had won a court order barring Paul Bilzerian, the former chairman of the Singer Company, from future securities law violations like those for which he was convicted nearly two years ago. The S.E.C. will now seek more than $30 million in profits it said Mr. Bilzerian earned from illicit stock deals.

title: East Side Pipe Leak Disrupts Subway and Street Traffic
description: A steam pipe leak on East 86th Street near Lexington Avenue disrupted subway and street traffic last night at the busy intersection on Manhattan's East Side, the police said.

title: Digital Equipment to Enter Emerging Technology Field
description: Within two weeks, the Digital Equipment Corporation, the $13 billion computer giant, will become the first major computer vendor to enter what the computer industry calls the massively parallel processing market. Digital will announce a joint venture with the Maspar Computer Corporation, a Sunnyvale, Calif., start-up company, to sell software created by Digital engineers to run on a Maspar computer using parallel microprocessors.

title: A Correction: When Recessions End
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showed the beginnings and ends of some U.S. recessions incorrectly. This is a corrected version of the chart, with recessions shown as white bands. (Source: Merrill Lynch)

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Connors Wins in Tokyo Jimmy Connors, attempting a comeback from wrist surgery last October, beat Jim Pugh, 1-6, 6-4, 6-0, yesterday in the first round of the Japan Open in Tokyo. Four seeded players were eliminated in the first round on the hard courts of the Ariake Colosseum. Patrick Kuhnen beat Aaron Krickstein, seeded ninth, 6-2, 7-5; David Pate defeated Todd Woodbridge, seeded 12th, 1-6, 6-3, 6-3; Dan Goldie beat Jan Siemerink, seeded 13th, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6, and Shuzo Matsuoka defeated Kevin Curren, seeded 16th, 7-6, 6-2. (AP) Gomez Is Upset: Andres Gomez of Ecuador, the reigning French Open champion and the 11th-ranked player in the world, was beaten, 5-7, 6-4, 6-4 by Uruguay's Marcelo Filippini yesterday in a first-round match of a tournament in Barcelona, Spain. (AP)

title: RULE ON TV RERUNS REVAMPED BY F.C.C.
description: A bitterly divided Federal Communications Commission voted today to relax but not eliminate the rule that prohibits television networks from owning and selling reruns of the shows they broadcast.

title: Republicans Court Foes To Oppose Weicker Tax
description: The Republican Party, the long-suffering minority in Connecticut's legislature, has joined a growing list of individuals and interest groups willing to follow Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in tossing tradition on the ash heap.

title: Strawberry Makes Up for Error By Driving In 2 Runs in Victory
description: Darryl Strawberry's bat overcame his glove in his debut with the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

title: Copeland Motion On Creditor Move
description: A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., which operates the Church's and Popeye's fried-chicken chains, filed a motion to dismiss an involuntary Chapter 11 reorganization petition filed last week by its creditors. The creditors, led by Merrill Lynch & Company, filed the petition last Thursday, saying Copeland owed them $427.6 million for their role in financing the purchase of Church's.

title: Vera Nabokov, 89, Wife, Muse and Agent
description: Vera Nabokov, the widow of Vladimir Nabokov and the manager of his publishing affairs, died Sunday in Vevey, Switzerland. She was 89 years old.

title: Big New Round of Base Closings To Be Proposed by Defense Chief
description: The Bush Administration is about to propose a sweeping new round of military base closings, Administration officials said today. Installations to be closed would include Fort Ord in California, home to 30,000 soldiers and relatives, and a naval air station in Washington State where 21,000 service people and relatives live.

title: Ismail Launches a Pre-draft Tour of the Market
