description: Raghib (Rocket) Ismail hustled through a supermarket near the Notre Dame campus in search of laundry detergent. Gotta do the wash. In nearly eight hours he had a private flight to Toronto. It was 4:30 A.M.

title: Nancy & Abigail & Eleanor & Edith
description: In her unauthorized biography of Nancy Reagan, Kitty Kelley has said again what everybody knows but won't admit: the boss's wife is a woman with clout.

title: Daugherty and Nance Lead Cavaliers Past Pistons
description: Brad Daugherty scored 23 points and Larry Nance 22 as the Cleveland Cavaliers beat Detroit, 94-90, tonight, trimming the Pistons' lead over Milwaukee to one-half game in race for third place over all in the Eastern Conference.

title: Things That Go Into Your Water Can Hurt You; Too Much Fluoride?
description: To the Editor:

title: Space Shuttle Landing Delayed by High Wind
description: High winds swirling around the desert landing strip here today forced the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to postpone the landing of the space shuttle Atlantis for at least one day.

title: New Detail, and New Questions, in Kennedy Case
description: The woman who said she was raped at the Kennedy estate here on March 30 was "very distraught and was screaming rape" when she was picked up by a female acquaintance at 4:30 A.M. outside the house, friends of the two women said today.

title: Iraq Delivers Food to Shiites And Kurds Returning to Iraq
description: Iraq is distributing bread and powdered milk to Kurds and Shiite Muslims returning to their provinces, and has sufficient food stocks for all refugees, an official said in a report published today.

title: Review/Television; 3 Shows About AIDS (Straight AIDS, That Is)
description: An unsettling fact about American television: Being taken seriously -- never mind being treated sympathetically -- is far more likely to happen if you're white or middle class or heterosexual, preferably all three.

title: 4 Arkansas Players Suspended in Connection With Sex Incident
description: Arkansas basketball star Todd Day and three teammates were suspended from the team for a year for their part in a sexual incident at the athletic dormitory, sources said today.

title: Personal Health
description: Millions of Americans do not need the Farmer's Almanac or the nightly news to tell them that spring was early this year. Their runny noses, itching eyes and throats and spasms of sneezes tell all. For they are allergic to the pollens of springtime carried by those gentle breezes onto hypersensitive mucous membranes.

title: Odom Cleared to Play
description: Miami Dolphins linebacker Cliff Odom, hobbled by the same "dead hip" affliction that is sidelining Bo Jackson, has been cleared by his doctor to play next season.

title: Breast Implant Makers Told to Prove Safety
description: The Federal Government today gave makers of silicone breast implants 90 days to prove that the devices are safe, or to stop selling them.

title: In Los Angeles, Gridlock at the Top
description: The city of Los Angeles remained in political gridlock today after Mayor Tom Bradley and Chief Daryl F. Gates called a public truce Wednesday but did not back down from their mutually antagonistic positions.

title: INSIDE
description: Warning on Global Warming A science panel called for prompt action by the Government on the threat of global warming. Page B12. Sports Boycott Sought The Health Secretary asked fans to boycott sports events sponsored by tobacco companies. Health, page B13. CUNY Protests Spread Students protesting budget cuts occupied parts of six campuses of the City University of New York. Page B1. The Automat Is Closed A chrome-and-glass Automat in midtown Manhattan, the last in the nation, has gulped its last coin. Page B1.

title: Friends of One Branch Library Find Many Ways to Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Waltzing and Jitterbugging From Ballrooms of Yore
description: Ballroom dancing, like tap, is enjoying a renaissance, and the enormously popular American Ballroom Theater, which opened a two-week season on Tuesday night, is not so much riding a crest as sweeping along as part of the original wave.

title: Pathe Chief Accused in Suit
description: The president of the Pathe Communications Corporation reportedly completed a $1.4 billion buyout of MGM/ UA using MGM/UA shares he did not yet own, a newspaper reported today.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: Adventist Development and Relief Agency, Gulf War Victim Relief Fund, Box 4289, Silver Spring, Md. 20904. American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102. American Near East Refugee Aid, 1522 K Street, N.W., Suite 202, Washington, D.C. 20005. American Jewish World Service, 1290 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10104. American Red Cross, Box 37234, Washington, D.C. 20013. AmeriCares, 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, Conn. 06840. CARE, 660 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016. Christian Children's Fund, 203 East Cary Street, Richmond, Va. 23261. Church World Service, Box 968, Elkhart, Ind. 46515. Direct Relief International, Box 30820, Santa Barbara, Calif. 93130. Grassroots International, Box 312, Cambridge, Mass. 02139. International Relief Committee, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10016. Lutheran World Relief, 390 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10016. MAP International, 2200 Glynco Parkway, Brunswick, Ga. 31520. Mercy Corps International, 3030 S.W. First Avenue, Portland, Ore. 97201. Operation USA, 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif. 90046. Oxfam America, 115 Broadway, Boston, Mass. 02116. Presiding Bishop's Fund For World Relief -- Episcopal Church, 815 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. Save the Children, Middle East Emergency Fund, Box 975, Westport, Conn. 06881. World Concern, Box 33000, Seattle, Wash. 98133. World Relief, Box WRC, Wheaton, Ill. 60189. World Vision Relief and Development, Box 0, Pasadena, Calif. 91103. The U.S. Committee for Unicef, Middle East Fund, 333 East 38th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016. YMCA of the U.S.A., 101 North Wacker Drive, Chicago, Ill. 60606.

title: Rush-Hour Traffic Thwarts Near-Getaway in a Limousine
description: It seemed to be a well-planned bank robbery: A man armed with an imitation Mach-10 machine pistol goes into a Greenwich Village bank, grabs thousands of dollars and then jumps into a waiting getaway car. But the would-be robber who tried it yesterday did not count on one hurdle every New York motorist faces -- rush-hour traffic.

title: Simon & Schuster Pays $920,000 for a First Novel
description: In one of the largest amounts ever paid for a first novel, Simon & Schuster and Pocket Books agreed on Monday to pay $920,000 for the hard-cover and paperback rights to "Just Killing Time," a novel about a serial killer written under a pseudonym by an author described as a Washington-based communications and national security authority.

title: Talking Deals; Larger Mergers Delayed by War
description: THE economies in the United States and Britain were slumping, Saddam Hussein had invaded Kuwait and President Bush was building an international coalition to oppose the Iraqi leader. But the business of buying or merging companies apparently went on almost as usual late last year, except that some big deals seemed to fall by the wayside.

title: Easy-to-Understand Medigap Insurance
description: The nation's insurance commissioners, responding to Congress, have radically simplified the harrowing purchase of private medical insurance policies to supplement Medicare.

title: Seoul Warns On Jet Deal
description: South Korea may cancel a multibillion-dollar deal to buy American-made fighters if the contracts do not meet Seoul's demands, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Otto C. Neumann Utility Commissioner, 55
description: Otto C. Neumann, a commissioner of the Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control and former state representative, died at Hartford Hospital on Monday. He was 55 years old.

title: Chronicle
description: When KIM BASINGER bought Braselton, Ga., for $20 million last year, many of its 500 residents said they were delighted she was putting the town on the map. Since then, she has rarely been there. Her plan to develop Braselton into a tourist spot with a recording and film studio was put aside after a preliminary investigation showed that it lacked an adequate sewage-treatment system.

title: Europe's Plans to Protect Privacy Worry Business
description: The European Community is considering the adoption of sweeping rules for computerized information like personal medical and insurance records and airline reservation records that would restrict their use by businesses and government agencies.

title: With New Jersey Voters Still Angry, Whitman Looks Ahead
description: When Christine Todd Whitman came within a hair of defeating Senator Bill Bradley last fall, many said the man she had really run against was Gov. Jim Florio. Now Mrs. Whitman appears to be trying again, this time without a stand-in.

title: Things That Go Into Your Water Can Hurt You; No Cancer Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Composer's Pulitzer Makes the Telephone Her New Instrument
description: "I'm trying to keep my appointments, do the things I had planned to do, and go about my life normally," the composer Shulamit Ran said by telephone from her apartment in Chicago yesterday. "But I imagine for the next few days that might be difficult. I have not done anything except speak on the telephone since Tuesday afternoon." It was at about 4:30 P.M. on Tuesday that a friend called to tell her that she had won the 1991 Pulitzer Prize for music.

title: Last Automat Closes, Its Era Long Gone
description: The Automat, whose gleaming chrome-and-glass machines brought high-tech eating to a low-tech era, has gulped down its last coin and served up its last helping of macaroni, baked beans and kaiser rolls.

title: Phone Rules Are Adopted
description: The Federal Communications Commission has adopted new rules to help travelers reach the long-distance companies of their choice from public telephones.

title: Money Market Yields Down After Being Mixed 5 Weeks
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the period ended yesterday, after five weeks of being mixed.

title: Sports of The Times; Every Fan Could Be A Golf Judge
description: HAVING long been a critic of instant replay in sports (it takes away the human element) and having long been uninterested in golf (what a waste of open space and plaid fabrics), I find myself amazed to be an advocate of a new pastime in this gadget-crazy world of ours: Instant Replay Golf.

title: 3 East European Nations Press Trade Bloc to Lift Barriers
description: Hit hard by a plunge in trade with the Soviet Union in recent months, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have called on the European Community to remove trade barriers on their steel, textiles and farm goods.

title: Judge Orders Payments to 7 Inmates Without Beds
description: A Federal judge has ordered New York City to pay seven inmates a total of $1,050 for failing to provide them with jail beds for more than a day, officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Friends of One Branch Library Find Many Ways to Help; Not by Philanthropy
description: To the Editor:

title: Pension Ruling Lost By Chevron
description: A Federal judge in Houston ordered the Chevron Corporation today to pay an estimated $180 million in additional pension benefits to more than 19,000 former employees of the Gulf Oil Corporation, most of whom are retired.

title: Prudential Securities Has $64 Million Profit
description: Prudential Securities earned $64 million in the first three months of 1991, the firm's acting chairman said yesterday in a memorandum to employees. "Our first-quarter profits were a period record for the firm, $40 million above plan, and equal to one-half of our full-year earnings goal," the acting chairman, Robert A. Beck, said in the memorandum.

title: Gun-Control Bill Passes Its First Hurdle
description: In the first test of national gun control legislation since President Ronald Reagan's endorsement last month, a House subcommittee approved a measure today to create a seven-day waiting period to buy a handgun.

title: Kurds Endure Mud and Cold and Fear the Worst
description: Squatting in swamp-like mud high up in the mountains, stung by rain and fierce nighttime cold, lacking proper shelter, medicine and anything near enough to eat, the refugee Kurds from Iraq fear they are not going to make it.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: BEFORE Janett Selby leaves on a business trip, she gives her 4-year-old daughter, Leah, a chewable calendar: bubble gum. The number of pieces the girl gets equals the number of nights her mother will be away. She is allowed to have one piece every evening.

title: Flashback for Hawkins To That Weird July Day
description: Every inning that brought Scott Sanderson closer to a no-hitter today brought Andy Hawkins closer to last July 1.

title: Panel Denies Chevron Bid On Tankers
description: A state agency today denied a request by the Chevron Corporation for temporary permission to transport oil by tanker from a field off the central California coast to refineries near Los Angeles.

title: Ciba-Geigy Stake In Vaccine Maker
description: Ciba-Geigy Ltd. agreed to acquire a majority interest in the vaccine business of Sclavo S.p.A. of Italy for undisclosed terms. The Chiron Corporation, Ciba-Geigy's partner since 1987 in the Biocene Company, a venture to commercialize new vaccines, also has rights to acquire an equal interest in Sclavo from Ciba-Geigy, which has options to acquire up to 100 percent of the company over 10 years.

title: Stray Shot Kills Bronx Youth, 15, As He Crosses Street, Police Say
description: A 15-year-old youth walking home from his uncle's house in the Bronx on Tuesday night was killed by a bullet intended for someone else, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Louise D. Rich, 87, Author of Best Seller
description: Louise Dickinson Rich, the author of "We Took to the Woods," a best seller during World War II, died on Tuesday at her daughter's home in Mattapoisett, Mass. She was 87 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about post-recession employment trends misstated the unemployment rate after the recession that ended in November 1982. Unemployment reached its peak of 10.8 percent in the last month of that recession, not early in 1983. It held there in December 1982 and then declined.

title: Sister Parish, Reigning Arbiter Of Lovely (and Expensive) Things
description: SISTER PARISH was stretched out on a sofa in the library of her Fifth Avenue apartment, a needlepoint pillow behind her head, a fluffy throw at her feet, when someone mentioned the tribute to her to be held tonight at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum.

title: Sharon Vows to Expand Settlements
description: Housing Minister Ariel Sharon said today that he intended to continue his efforts to accelerate Jewish settlement in the occupied territories, even though Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d reportedly criticized him over the policy in meetings with Israeli leaders here on Tuesday.

title: Red Wings Roll Past Blues by 4-3, To Take 3-1 Advantage in Series
description: Third-period goals by Rick Zombo and Brent Fedyk lifted Detroit to a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight, giving the Red Wings a 3-1 advantage in their National Hockey League playoff series.

title: Venturi Firm Is Chosen For Indian Museum Project
description: The Philadelphia architectural firm of Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates has been selected by the Smithsonian Institution to develop master architectural program requirements and criteria for the design of the new National Museum of the American Indian. The firm is also to develop requirements for a $44 million storage, conservation and research center for the museum to be built in Suitland, Md.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: POCKET doors, often associated with Victorian-era houses, slide into hollow walls at the sides of doorways. They require no room for swinging and so have many advantages over conventional hinged doors.

title: Quick Steps Urged on Warming Threat
description: In a report that was welcomed by the White House and environmentalists, the National Academy of Sciences said today that the United States should act promptly to reduce the threat of global warming.

title: High Court Justice Blocks Killing of Two Monkeys in Experiments
description: A United States Supreme Court Justice today barred the National Institutes of Health from killing two monkeys in a medical experiment in Louisiana after two Federal judges rejected similar requests to intervene.

title: Thomas M. Sullivan, 77, Engineer Who Designed Huge U.S. Airports
description: Thomas M. Sullivan, a civil engineer who played a central role in the development of both Kennedy International Airport and the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, died Sunday at Humana Hospital Medical City in Dallas. He was 77 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: Memorial to Officers, From the Heart
description: Barbara Sparhawk is, she says, not very sentimental. But at the funeral, she discovered feelings of anger, grief and embarrassment that needed expression.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "That is how they will eradicate us, piece by piece. Yesterday, maybe it was six dead, the day before three, tomorrow five. It grows. Maybe after a week or 10 days, we will all be dead." -- Ahmad Ali, a Kurd from northern Iraq. [ A1:3. ]

title: N.C.A.A. Adopts Insurance Plan
description: Insurance coverage for catastrophic injury has been approved for all N.C.A.A. schools and student-athletes, for one year beginning Aug. 1.

title: Nesting Above The Store
description: GREEK temples, Gothic churches and Palladian villas have been miniaturized as birdhouses. Now they have been joined by such humble establishments as the Rising Fawn Grocery and Whitey's Fish Camp.

title: Panel Calls Federal Drug Agency Unable to Cope With Rising Tasks
description: A Federal advisory committee appointed to study the Food and Drug Administration says the agency is overwhelmed and incapable of coping with vastly increased duties caused by the AIDS epidemic, a flood of food imports and advances in medical science and technology.

title: Space Station to Get a Centrifuge
description: Under pressure, the space agency has further revamped its recently redesigned space station to include a centrifuge that could help judge if astronauts can physically withstand a long voyage to Mars.

title: Members of Study Panel
description: Following are the members of the National of Academy of Science's panel on global warming: Daniel J. Evans, chairman of Daniel J. Evans & Associates, Seattle, and a former Governor and Senator from Washington.

title: Handmade Hand Tools From Maine
description: FOR woodworkers who find joy in working with hand tools, Thomas Lie-Nielsen makes an assortment of planes, a beading tool and a corner chisel.

title: 34 Options Are Given for New Council
description: The independent body charged with creating 51 new New York City Council districts gave the first glimpse of what those possibilities could be yesterday, setting the stage for a political revolution that could for the first time send to the Council previously unrepresented groups like Asian-Americans and gay people.

title: Girls' Schools Protest; M&M Mars Pulls Ad
description: In response to criticism from two organizations that represent more than 70 girls' schools, M&M Mars Inc. said yesterday that it had withdrawn a commercial for one of its products that characterizes the idea of attending a girls' school as "bad news."

title: The Night of Wearable Architecture
description: THIS week architects turn their talents to ephemera rather than immortality. Taking scissors and paste, needle and thread, some architects are spending the next 24 hours concocting costumes of paper, cloth or wood for the Beaux-Arts Ball of the Architectural League of New York, which will be held on Saturday at the University Club at 1 West 54th Street in Manhattan.

title: Review/Pop; Serious Spectacle From the Pet Shop Boys
description: In the era of the largely prerecorded, minutely planned pop spectacle, the Pet Shop Boys are masters. At Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday night, the first of two sold-out shows, the two Pet Shop Boys and a troupe of dancers and singers unveiled a spectacle that was strange, doleful, funny and consistently absorbing. Even more unlikely, it added new dimensions to the songs. Madonna, David Bowie, Alice Cooper and Pink Floyd now have serious competition, and the group's current tour is only its second major foray out of the studio.

title: Horizontal Use for Old Iron Gates
description: TO Jennifer Rauch, even remnants of cast-iron or wrought-iron gates have a second life. She recycles them into tables.

title: If You Taped This One, Erase It
description: The game was not one for the ages. It was not, truth be told, even much of a game for April. And so the long stream of red taillights snaking out the Shea Stadium exits by the end of five innings and three hours of baseball, a line formed in pursuit of warmth and sanity, told the story as well as anything else.

title: Cadence Design
description: Cadence Design Systems Inc., a maker of software for computer-aided design systems, said two shareholders had filed a class-action lawsuit contending that the company violated Federal securities laws in its public statements and financial reports in the first quarter of the year. Damages are not specified in the suit, the company said. Cadence, based in San Jose, said that it had not yet been served with the complaint, but that it had obtained a copy and thought it to be without merit and that it would contest. Cadence's shares gained 75 cents each on the New York Stock Exchange today to close at $26.125.

title: Pop in Review
description: Lucie Arnaz Rainbow and Stars 30 Rockefeller Plaza Through Saturday

title: Books of The Times; Young Children, Old Parents and the Consequences
description: Latecomers

title: Things That Go Into Your Water Can Hurt You
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Rise In Outlays Set By Businesses
description: American businesses plan to increase spending on plants and equipment 3.2 percent this year, the smallest advance in five years, the Government said today.

title: A PAKISTANI PLAN FOR ISLAMIC CODE
description: The Government introduced legislation today that would make the Koran the supreme law of Pakistan and subject all aspects of life, from social behavior to civil liberties, to Islamic tenets.

title: A Dozen Tapestries Right From Wright
description: A Hopi weaver has transposed the designs of Frank Lloyd Wright into tapestries inspired by the shapes and colors of the desert landscape, as were many Wright buildings.

title: Selling Now in Tokyo: Tiniest I.B.M. Portable
description: When I.B.M. introduced an array of small portable computers in the United States recently, something was missing. The company said it would be months, maybe a year, before it brought out its first super-lightweight notebook-sized computer, which can fit in a briefcase.

title: Mandela Group Backs Off Demands on Pretoria
description: The African National Congress has reportedly backed away from a threat to stop talking to the Pretoria Government about the country's future unless the continuing political violence is brought to an end within a month.

title: Aide Says Spira Got Steinbrenner's Ear
description: A top aide to George Steinbrenner testified yesterday in Manhattan Federal Court that he and the former Yankees general partner were interested when Howard Spira came to them in December 1986 with accusations that money from the Dave Winfield Foundation was being misused for personal purposes by Winfield.

title: Stocks Flat Amid Uncertainty on Inflation
description: Wall Street uncertainty about how inflation figures will look today and tomorrow kept stocks from doing much of anything yesterday.

title: Students Protesting New Tuition Rise Shut 2 CUNY Colleges
description: Classes at two City University of New York campuses were canceled indefinitely yesterday as student demonstrations grew stronger and spread to six campuses.

title: Faldo Must Conquer World's Best 87 Players In Quest for 3d Masters
description: When 89-year-old Gene Sarazen officially opens this year's Masters on Thursday with his ceremonial drive off the first tee, he will again launch the best players in the world on a procession of possibilities.

title: When the Game Creeps in Its Petty Pace
description: David Cone sat in the dugout last night, waiting to get his hands on a baseball. His arms were crossed. His right foot tapped a steady beat against the ground. He was ready for the season, ready for the Phillies, even if they weren't quite ready for him.

title: Pop in Review
description: New Jazz Network Town Hall 123 West 43d Street

title: Jets Sign Quarterback
description: Turk Schonert, a backup quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengals when Coach Bruce Coslet of the Jets was an offensive coach there, was signed to a contract by the Jets yesterday as insurance in case the team's backup from last year, Tony Eason, a free agent, decides to go elsewhere. No terms of Schonert's contract were disclosed, and the 34-year-old from Stanford worked out at the Jets' minicamp in Hempstead, L.I.

title: Jerusalem Journal; Joyful Jews From 'Another Planet' Called Albania
description: Larger migrations are pouring into Israel, but none carry an emotional charge equal to that concentrated in a group of about 300 people who have arrived in virtual secrecy in recent weeks and are living in what seems to be permanent thanksgiving in four immigrant absorption centers in various parts of this country.

title: T.W.A.'s Route Sale Is Delayed
description: The Transportation Department delayed action today on the proposed sale of Trans World Airline Inc.'s primary London routes to American Airlines to give the investor Kirk Kerkorian until Friday to explain his proposal for taking over T.W.A.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Sallie Mae Net Up 15.6%
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, reported today that first-quarter net income rose 15.6 percent because of "continued growth in student loan purchases." Earnings rose to $82.1 million, or 83 cents a share, for the quarter, compared with earnings of $71 million, or 69 cents a share, a year earlier. Total assets were $42.8 billion at the end of the quarter, up 16 percent over March 31, 1990. Student loan purchases for the quarter were $1.9 billion, compared with $1.4 billion a year earlier. The amount includes $370 million in loans purchased from the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Monsanto Co., St. Louis, named R. Ian Lennox president of Monsanto Canada Inc. He succeeds J. Richard Darnaby, who has been named group vice president of the carbonated soft drink/table top group at Monsanto's Nutrasweet subsidiary. * Playtex Apparel Inc., Stamford, Conn., named Lee Chaden president of its United States apparel business.

title: Chronicle
description: SUSAN SPENCER, a CBS national correspondent since 1989, has been named White House correspondent for the network. She will succeed LESLEY STAHL, who is joining "60 Minutes," ERIC OBER, the president of CBS News, announced yesterday.

title: Article 512591 -- No Title
description: The New York State Power Authority is offering $314 million in tax-exempt general-purpose refunding revenue bonds. The bonds were priced to yield a maximum of 7.04 percent for an issue due in 2018 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Home Video; New Video Releases
description: Memphis Belle 1990. Warner. $92.95. Laser disk, $24.98. 1 hour, 47 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.

title: Bonds Are Priced By Florida County
description: Orange County, Fla., tentatively priced a tax-exempt hospital revenue bond issue yesterday with a maximum yield of 6.809 percent for a debt security due in 2005 through an underwriting group led by Ziegler Securities.

title: BRIEFS
description: COMMON STOCK * Fabri-Centers of America Inc., Cleveland, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 1.1 million common shares. * Filene's Basement Corp., Wellesley, Mass., has filed for an initial public offering of 4.5 million common shares through Goldman, Sachs & Co. * Gottschalks Inc., Fresno, Calif., has filed for a proposed offering of 2.06 million common shares through Prudential Securities Inc. * Picturetel Corp., Peabody, Mass., is offering two million common shares at $20.75 a share through Goldman, Sachs & Co. RATINGS * General Signal Corp.'s short-term debt rating has been lowered to Prime-2, from Prime-1, by Moody's Investors Service Inc. The company is based in Stamford, Conn.

title: Doctor Died of AIDS, Hospital Tells Parents
description: An Ohio hospital has notified the parents of dozens of children that a surgeon at the hospital died of AIDS and that the youngsters may be at risk, the hospital said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf Breezes to Victory Steffi Graf, the top-seeded player in the Bausch & Lomb Championships in Amelia Island, Fla., breezed into the quarterfinals yesterday with a 6-1, 6-1, victory over Isabel Cueto. No. 4 Zina Garrison, and No. 7 Leila Meskhi also advanced, winning second-round matches. Brenda Schultz upset No. 8 Sandra Cecchini, 6-3, 6-0, while No. 6 Natalia Zvereva routed Jessica Emmons, 6-1, 6-2 in a night match. (AP) Connors Advances: Jimmy Connors struggled for two and half hours yesterday to join another American, John McEnroe, and Stefan Edberg of Sweden in the third round of the $1.15 million Japan Open in Tokyo. The 38-year-old Connors, playing in his third tournament since wrist surgery last October, bounced back in the second set by spraying shots to both corners as he beat Wally Masur of Australia, 3-6, 7-6, 7-5. McEnroe beat Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, 6-1, 6-4, taking the second set with a break in the ninth game.

title: Noriega Trial Delayed Again; Start Is Now Set for July 22
description: A Federal district judge today postponed the start of the drug trafficking trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega until July 22. The trial had been scheduled to start June 24.

title: How Not to Protect the Kurds
description: Today, when Jacques Santer, the Prime Minister of Luxembourg and president of the European Community, meets with President Bush, he will plead for the idea of a "sanctuary" or "safe haven" for the Kurds in northern Iraq -- a buffer or possible demilitarized zone. The guilt-ridden Bush Administration, which has zigzagged dangerously in its policy on the Kurds, should simply walk away.

title: Miscellany
description: * Overall automobile advertising on national and regional television increased 13 percent, to $3.21 billion, in 1990, according to figures from the Television Bureau of Advertising Inc. Eight of the top 10 auto companies increased their spending on television advertising in 1990, the bureau said.

title: Esteem Said to Concern Official at Commerce
description: An official close to Under Secretary of Commerce Dennis E. Kloske acknowledged today that Mr. Kloske had planned to resign and said the Under Secretary considered his departure as a way "to preserve his reputation and that of the Commerce Department."

title: Foul Called on Referee
description: Don't get the idea that Rod Thorn, the National Basketball Association's vice president for operations, has it in only for players. Just ask Steve Javie, the referee who threw Washington Bullets forward Pervis Ellison out of a game against the Portland Trail Blazers last Thursday.

title: Talk of Living or Dying Atop a Bridge Abutment
description: Two people sat precariously on top of an abutment of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge late Tuesday night, discussing which was better: living or dying.

title: U.S. Warns Against Attack By Iraq on Kurdish Refugees
description: In a further attempt to respond to the staggering exodus of more than a million Iraqi Kurds, the Bush Administration said today that it had warned Iraq not to use its military forces in northeastern Iraq.

title: P.& G. Gets Revlon's Max Factor
description: Revlon Inc., one of the world's biggest makers of beauty products, agreed yesterday to sell some of its leading product lines, including Max Factor, to the Procter & Gamble Company, thereby doubling Procter & Gamble's beauty business and raising money to pay off Revlon's heavy bank debt.

title: Enlightening
description: An editorial Sunday declared without explanation that Japan's post-World War II experiment with daylight time, imposed by U.S. occupation authorities, was abandoned when the Japanese regained their sovereignty. The Japanese Embassy's Information and Culture Center now offers the following, printed here in its entirety.

title: Hallelujah! Amen Corner Is Saved
description: The Masters thrives on the pure continuity of its traditions, but after an intense rain storm washed out its famed 11th green last fall, it seemed that Amen Corner might never be the same again.

title: Lauren, Forever Plaid
description: FOR Ralph Lauren, tartan is not just a fabric. It is a way of life.

title: Bring Germany Into New World Order
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The continuation of a front-page article in The Living Arts yesterday on grants for ceremonies marking the Columbus quincentennial was omitted from some editions. Readers wishing copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Toyota to Sell Cars in Israel, Officials Say
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation is expected to announce that it will begin selling cars in Israel despite the continuing Arab economic boycott of that country, officials of the Japanese auto maker said today.

title: Toshiba Acquisition
description: The Toshiba Corporation of Japan said its American unit had acquired the Vertex Semiconductor Corporation, a maker of computer chips based in San Jose, Calif., for about $20 million. Toshiba said Vertex had proposed the acquisition to obtain financing to develop its technology. Vertex, which was called Integrated CMOS Systems until last summer, will keep its name, management structure and line of business, Toshiba said.

title: Up Above! It's a Bird! A Hot Tub!
description: SOME rooftops have things like teahouses, hot tubs and rural cottages. In her book, "Rooftop Architecture: The Art of Going Through the Roof," to be published next month by Henry Holt and Company, Akiko Busch discusses 30 rooftop structures she found in New York City, Los Angeles, Tokyo, Vienna and other cities.

title: Who's the Best? The Five Most Complete Answers
description: Cincinnati Reds Manager Lou Piniella, never one to back down from a test of wits, wrestled with the question for a moment.

title: Municipal Unions Fighting Contract Concessions
description: Municipal labor leaders, lashing out at Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for contributing to New York City's fiscal problems, ruled out yesterday any contract concessions sought by Mayor David N. Dinkins to help close a gap in the city's budget next year.

title: Workers Must Choose As Jobs Move
description: Lucy Carrero started working for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company as a part-time messenger when she was a 17-year-old high school student. Eighteen years later she is still there, now as supervisor of 35 medical claims approvers.

title: Accounts
description: * Etonic Tretorn Puma, a footwear and apparel manufacturer in Brockton, Mass., to Arnold Fortuna Lane, Boston, for its Tretorn division. Billings are $2.5 million to $3 million. Arnold Advertising and Emerson Lane Fortuna consolidated to form the agency last week. The incumbent agency on the account was Altschiller Reitzfeld/Tracy-Locke.

title: Shoemaker Still Critical
description: Hall of Fame jockey Bill Shoemaker remained in critical condition yesterday in Centinela Hospital Medical Center in California after suffering a fractured neck and other injuries in a car accident on Monday. (AP)

title: Panama's U.S. Envoy Quits
description: Eduardo Vallarino, Panama's Ambassador to the United States, has resigned, apparently to protest the ouster of his Christian Democratic Party from the coalition Government here, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. The move came a day after President Guillermo Endara dismissed all five Christian Democrats from his 12-member Cabinet, accusing them of arrogance and disloyalty.

title: U.S. Sending Cuba Mixed Signals
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: Gen. H. NORMAN SCHWARZKOPF will take on a different sort of leadership role next month as Grand Marshal of the Kentucky Derby Festival Pegasus Parade. He has accepted the invitation to lead the parade on May 2, DONNA BYNUM, the festival's spokeswoman, said yesterday.

title: Leo Burnett Wins A Nintendo Account
description: Leo Burnett has won a $25 million account for a campaign to launch a third product line for Nintendo of America, the Super Nintendo Entertainment System, which is based on a 16-bit chip, compared with the 8-bit chip in the standard system.

title: Hicksville Journal; Hayseeds, Eh? Shucks, That's No General Store
description: On the map of unfortunate place names (Intercourse, Pa., Zero, Mont.) Hicksville stands out.

title: HAITI'S EX-LEADER DISPUTES CHARGES
description: Former President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot says she has been released from house arrest but is barred from leaving Haiti while the authorities investigate charges that she was involved in an attempted coup against her own government.

title: An Oddity In a City That Seeks Publicity
description: In this city of publicity hogs and monstrous egos, Nicholas F. Brady is an oddity. The Treasury Secretary is so diffident, so uncomfortable in the limelight, so averse to making news that his influence in the Government is difficult to assess.

title: Toxic Blaze Sends Smoke Across Hudson
description: A fire at an illegal dump in Jersey City sent thick black smoke billowing across the Hudson River yesterday, prompting health officials to advise residents of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Staten Island and parts of Hudson County to stay inside with their windows shut.

title: Something's Missing For Knicks: Their Shots
description: The Knicks played tonight as if someone had just awakened them from a nap.

title: Effort May Pull Cup Closer to New York
description: A new effort is under way to bring the 1994 World Cup closer to New York, a move that would satisfy the wishes of the world governing body for soccer to have a greater presence in the largest United States city.

title: U.S. Supercomputer Plan To Spur G.N.P., Study Says
description: A Government-financed study says that a proposed $1.9 billion Federal program to develop improvements in supercomputers will generate more than $10 billion in revenue for the United States computer industry by the end of the decade.

title: 3 Journalists Missing in Iraq
description: At least three Western journalists are reported missing in northern Iraq.

title: Fetisov Shows Penguins His Muscles in Playoffs
description: In their years on Soviet teams, Slava Fetisov and Aleksei Kasatonov accomplished just about everything hockey players could worldwide, except getting their names onto the Stanley Cup.

title: Monitoring of Bottled Water Is Called Inadequate
description: The General Accounting Office and a House subcommittee yesterday described Federal monitoring of bottled-water safety as inadequate, declaring that in some cases consumers were paying for water that was actually less safe than what they could get from the tap.

title: Bonds Down After Tepid Auction
description: Poor demand at an auction of seven-year Treasury notes pushed down prices of outstanding notes and bonds yesterday, causing interest rates to rise.

title: Joule Division Names Chief Operating Officer
description: Mary Ann Pope has been named chief operating officer of the temporaries division of Joule Inc., a regional temporary services company in Edison, N.J.

title: Capital's Mayor Stirs Debate on Spanking
description: Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon has created a heated debate here by saying she believes that teachers should be allowed to spank unruly pupils.

title: Preventing Pneumonia in Bone Marrow Cases
description: Researchers have found a way to prevent a kind of pneumonia that is a leading cause of death among the 2,000 Americans who have bone marrow transplants each year.

title: A Budget Plan For Connecticut
description: Republican leaders in the General Assembly today released details of their plan to resolve Connecticut's revenue shortfall with a "people's budget" without an income tax, instead raising most other taxes, laying off more state employees and increasing state borrowing.

title: McDonald's Corp.
description: The McDonald's Corporation is offering $100 million in bonds due in 2011 through J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. The bonds have an 8 7/8 percent coupon and are priced at 99.447 to yield 8.934 percent, or about 72 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said the issue was noncallable by the company through maturity and was rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA by S.& P.

title: Despite Some Gains by Hispanics, Report Finds Their Income Lags
description: Hispanic Americans have made some economic strides in recent years but they still lag well behind the rest of the nation's population, according to a Census Bureau report issued today.

title: Boeing Agrees to Sell Its de Havilland Unit
description: The Boeing Company said today that it had agreed to sell its unprofitable de Havilland commuter aircraft division in Canada to Aeritalia S.p.A. of Italy and Aerospatiale S.A. of France.

title: 'Mule Bone' to Close
description: "Mule Bone," a comedy with music by Zora Neale Hurston and Langston Hughes, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street. Sunday's performance of the play, which was directed by Michael Schultz, will be its 67th regular performance; it had 27 previews.

title: Motorola Profit Declines 8.7%
description: Motorola Inc. said today that its first-quarter profits fell 8.7 percent, but Wall Street welcomed the modest decline. Motorola stock shot up $6.75 a share, to $62.875, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sullivan Would End Tie Of Sports and Tobacco
description: Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan today asked sports fans and promoters to boycott sports events sponsored by tobacco companies.

title: Transit Detective Wounded In a Shooting in Brooklyn
description: A Transit Authority detective was grazed in the head by a bullet early this morning while arresting a suspect on a street in Brooklyn, the police said. The suspect was also shot.

title: Gartner Searches for Scoring Touch
description: In the last minute of play Tuesday night, with the Rangers trailing the Capitals by a goal, the puck came to Mike Gartner, New York's top goal scorer, in the center-ice area, near the right-wing boards, outside the Washington blue line.

title: Fannie Mae Earnings Up
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association said today that its earnings rose 16 percent in the first quarter, in part because of declining mortgage foreclosures.

title: John G. Nesbett, 88, Mutual-Fund Founder
description: John G. Nesbett, founder of the New York mutual fund that became the Dreyfus Fund, died on Friday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived in Vero Beach.

title: American Academy Gives 1991 Rome Prizes
description: The 1991 Rome Prizes for outstanding contributions to cultural life in the United States were presented to 25 people at a ceremony last night at the Equitable Center in Manhattan. The prizes, given annually by the American Academy in Rome, include stipends, travel benefits and living and working accommodations at the academy's 11-acre campus in Rome for six months to two years. This year's recipients were chosen from more than 1,000 nominees.

title: Ad Agencies Scramble for Max Factor
description: Procter & Gamble's acquisition of Max Factor from Revlon yesterday has set off a scramble for the cosmetics and fragrance advertising account, which has worldwide billings of more than $40 million.

title: Philadelphia Tower Set Ablaze by Rags, Commissioner Says
description: Fire officials say a pile of oil-soaked rags left by an office renovation crew began the Feb. 23 fire that killed three firefighters in a high-rise office building.

title: Rebelling Against Limits
description: To The Home Section:

title: For Foreign Films, Vita Is No Longer Dolce
description: For a decade the Unifrance Film office here was the French Government's outpost in Hollywood, a tireless promoter of French films and film makers. This month, however, the French shut the office in favor of a much more modest effort based in the French consulate, thereby significantly scaling back their presence in a city that regards itself as the world movie capital.

title: Need Is Seen Approaching For Health-Care Rationing
description: A new study by Tufts University economists says that employers and the Federal Government have virtually run out of ammunition in their battle to slow the growth of spending for health care.

title: Costs Soar for On-the-Job Injuries
description: The workers' compensation system of insurance, the 80-year-old program in which employers pay for job-related injuries, is struggling to stay afloat in at least seven states.

title: S.E.C. Begins Investigation Of Trading in 'Junk Bonds'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into possibile illegal insider trading in the "junk bond" market. But it might have to cross new legal ground to go after any wrongdoers, officials said today.

title: Early Action Rescuing Troubled Families
description: THE turning point in Connie Neer's life, after a history of beatings, bouts of drinking and hitting bottom, came when she decided to fight to keep custody of her 2-year-old daughter, Nicole.

title: Review/Fashion; In Plaids and More, Lauren Reassures
description: PLAIDS aren't exactly a scarce commodity on the runways at the fall fashion shows this week. But they had a rich authentic glow at the Ralph Lauren presentation yesterday. In shorts, pants and dresses, they had a reassuring calmness about them; they looked as if they needed no breaking in, ready to become cozy wardrobe standbys.

title: Pop in Review
description: Milton Nascimento The Ritz 119 East 11th Street

title: Spec Towns, 77, Champion Hurdler in the 1930's
description: Forrest G. (Spec) Towns, who parlayed a barefoot backyard high jump into a world-record career as a hurdler and then spent 34 years coaching championship track teams at the University of Georgia, died on Tuesday at the Athens Regional Medical Center in Georgia.

title: SportsThursday
description: The can think. They can execute. They can play. The five baseball players who really know the game. Six months ago the 11th green at Augusta was under water. Today, as the Masters begins, it looks beautiful. How a hole was rebuilt. Pages B15-24.

title: MAIL-BOMBING CASE MOVED FROM SOUTH
description: The trial of a man charged in the mail-bomb slayings of a Federal judge in Alabama and a civil rights lawyer in Georgia will be held in Minnesota because of heavy publicity in the Southeast, a Federal judge ruled Tuesday.

title: President of Tex/Con Takes Post at Apache
description: The Apache Corporation, a Denver-based oil and natural gas exploration company, yesterday named William J. Johnson as vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Going, Going, Gone To a Queens Condo
description: BY 11:30 A.M. last Sunday, the first summery day of the spring, they were already lined up five abreast, waiting for the doors to open at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: Cora DuBois, Harvard Professor of Anthropology, Is Dead at 87
description: Cora DuBois, an anthropologist, teacher and author who was an authority on Southeast Asia, died Sunday at a nursing home in Brookline, Mass. She was 87 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Kurds Assert Few Outside Iraq Wanted Them to Win
description: As they contemplate the swift and bloody collapse of their revolt in Iraq, the exiled foes of President Saddam Hussein have come to some bitter conclusions about their defeat. Partly, they say, they were outgunned and partly overwhelmed by the speed and scope of an uprising that took even them by surprise.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League CLEVELAND INDIANS--Optioned Eddie Taubensee, catcher, to Colorado Springs of the Pacific Coast League. Purchased the contract of Jose Escobar, infielder, from Colorado Springs. HOCKEY National Hockey League NHL--Fined the St. Louis Blues $10,000 and banned General Manager Ron Caron from any press box area where opposing personnel may be seated for the remainder of the playoffs. Fined Caron $1,000 and Glen Hanlon, Detroit goalie, $100 for an altercation in the press box of the St. Louis Arena.

title: Home Video
description: French Classic on Tape

title: Corrections
description: A brief profile yesterday of Susan C. Faludi, the winner of the 1991 Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting, misstated her age. Ms. Faludi, of The Wall Street Journal, is 31.

title: Cairo Open to Baker's Meeting Proposal
description: Egypt's leaders told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that they were prepared to consider an American proposal for an Arab-Israeli peace conference sponsored by the United States and the Soviet Union, and would treat Israel's conditions for such a meeting with an open mind.

title: Phone Company Offers 9 1/2% Notes
description: United Telecommunications Inc., yesterday priced $200 million in noncallable notes due in 2003 through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: WORKERS DEFYING GORBACHEV'S CALL FOR END TO UNREST
description: Tens of thousands of workers rallied in Minsk today, as Georgian leaders called for widespread strikes and Siberian miners intensified their demands, all on the day after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed a yearlong moratorium on strikes and protests.

title: Philadelphia Utility May Lift Dividend
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company may raise its $1.20-a-share annual dividend by the end of the year, its chairman, Joseph F. Paquette Jr., said in remarks prepared for delivery at the annual meeting. The utility cut its dividend by 45 percent last year after Pennsylvania regulators dissallowed more than half of a requested rate increase to cover the costs of its Limerick 2 nuclear power plant. But Mr. Paquette said Philadelphia Electric would benefit this year from a recent settlement of the Limerick 2 case, which would allow the company to sell excess capacity to other utilities.

title: TV Stations to Get Points of Light Spots
description: Beginning on April 25, the Advertising Council will distribute to television stations nationwide a series of spots that support the Points of Light Foundation.

title: Flights of Fancy: Todd Oldham's Magic Carpet Ride
description: THE heat in the fashion showrooms this week had editors fanning for dear life and looking for a breath of fresh air.

title: Chronicle
description: DEBRA PONZEK, LIDIA BASTIANICH and NANCY SILVERTON will reign over the kitchens at the Culinary Institute of America on April 20, when the school salutes America's women who are chefs. The percentage of female students at the school in Hyde Park, N.Y., has grown from zero to 25 percent since the 1960's. "The 25 percent of females capture 80 percent of our graduation awards," said FERDINAND E. METZ, the institute's president.

title: Gardening: On Roofs
description: From Roof to Yard Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street; (212) 757-0915.

title: Key Rates
Ford Planning An Electric Car
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would build up to 100 electric-powered test cars by 1993 before going into mass production.

title: Health Care Plan Falters In Massachusetts Slump
description: The Massachusetts plan to guarantee health insurance for all, once hailed as a model for the nation, is faltering under the weight of a soured economy, a hostile new Governor and the fierce opposition of small-business owners, who would be required to pay for coverage of employees.

title: New U.S. Warning to Iraq
description: Baghdad was told to avoid military operations in northern Iraq, where an international relief effort for Kurdish refugees is under way. Page A10.

title: Review/Theater; Behind the Legend of Hugh O'Neill
description: The title of Brian Friel's "Making History" could be "Remaking History," for in it the playwright shows us how facts and opinions can be altered to suit the needs of their times. The subject is Hugh O'Neill, commonly regarded as Ireland's greatest hero, and a man who is known for his victories not for his defeats or his personal failings.

title: Bridge
description: It is sometimes possible to foresee that one of the defenders may have difficulty knowing what to do. When more than one line of play offers itself, declarer should choose the one that might bring about a misdefense.

title: Kansas City Mayor Sworn In
description: The Rev. Emanuel Cleaver, a civil rights leader, was sworn in today as the city's first black Mayor. About 3,000 people gathered for the ceremony on the south steps of City Hall on a chilly but sunny morning.

title: UConn Recruiting Season Ends on a Successful Note
description: The University of Connecticut completed one of the most successful basketball recruiting efforts in the nation yesterday when Donyell Marshall, one of the few remaining high-profile members of the national basketball class of 1995, signed a letter of intent with the university.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Board Walk
description: In 1976, a newcomer to New York State government named Mario Cuomo served on a panel that urged major pruning of the do-little boards and commissions that provide patronage for the Governor and the Legislature.

title: Help the Kurds. But Where?
description: As an observer of the tide of suffering on the Turkish border said the other day, 30,000 refugees are a humanitarian problem but a million are a political problem. The sheer scale and desperation of the Kurdish exodus from Iraq has qualitatively changed the nature of the challenge.

title: For Kuwaitis, First War and Now Wheeze
description: The weather forecast, as carried today by the Armed Forces Desert Network: smoky with a chance of thundershowers.

title: Wachtler Says Cuomo Cut Judiciary Funds Unconstitutionally
description: Like marriage, political rivalry thrives on a certain commonality of interests. Thus, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has often expressed a hankering to be a judge, and the Chief Judge of New York, Sol Wachtler, who has flirted with running for governor, would seem to be perfect foes.

title: Burger Joins Review
description: Warren E. Burger, former Chief Justice of the United States, and nine others will comprise a committee to review the N.C.A.A.'s rules enforcement and infractions process, the N.C.A.A. announced yesterday.(AP)

title: Textile Designs From a Children's Art Project
description: Armed with black house paint, white paper and wide brushes, Marty Levi, a volunteer instructor at the Children's Art Carnival in Harlem, asked her students to paint -- but without thinking about what they are going to paint.

title: Essay; Be Thou as Chaste as Ice . . .
description: I do not believe that the First Lady of the land had an affair in the family quarters of the White House with a septuagenarian crooner.

title: Officers Write 54% Fewer Tickets To Protest New York Pact Impasse
description: Ten days after they began looking the other way at traffic violations to protest an impasse in contract talks with New York City, police officers have given out 54 percent fewer tickets, according to department estimates.

title:
TENNIS;
Sampras and McEnroe Reject Davis Cup Spots
description: Pete Sampras, the reigning United States Open Champion, and John McEnroe have turned down spots on the United States Davis Cup team for its second-round match, to be played June 14-16 against Spain, somewhere on the East Coast.

title: 130 Are Feared Dead In Italian Ferry Crash
description: An Italian ferry slammed into a tanker in heavy fog outside the Mediterranean port of Livorno early today and the authorities said more than 130 people were feared dead.

title: BRIEFS
description: * D R Holdings Inc., which owns Prime Computer Inc., said it did not receive the minimum $82 million principal amount related to its offer to buy up to $163.78 million principal amount of its 15 1/2 percent senior subordinated debentures due in 2002. * Designcraft Industries, New York, a maker of components for gold jewelry, said its Baker Fendt Corp. unit would sell its assets to Hoover Findings Inc., an affiliate of Hoover & Strong Inc., Richmond. The price was $6.9 million.

title: Thanks to Twins, Brock Keeps Record One More Night
description: Rickey Henderson remained one short of tying the career stolen-base record tonight as he and the Oakland A's were stifled by Allan Anderson and Rick Aguilera of the Minnesota Twins, 4-1.

title: Bush Signs Bill Cutting Off $55 Million in Aid to Jordan
description: President Bush signed a bill today that cuts off United States aid to Jordan but allows him to restore the funds if he feels it would help the Middle East peace process.

title: New Cuts Sap Feeble School Districts
description: While California lawmakers wrestle with a record budget deficit, the Superintendent of Schools in this beachfront city hunches over his ledgers, looking for programs to cut and teachers to dismiss from a near-bankrupt school system where fat has long since given way to bone.

title: City-Size Garden Plans
description: CITY dwellers may not have lots of space, but that's no reason not to plant a garden, says Catherine Fitzsimons, the owner of Willowtown Gardens.

title: Public & Private; Public Appearances
description: More than 100 years ago, a great man did something that great men sometimes do. He fell in love. The problem was that he was married at the time and had 10 children, and that his beloved was an actress many years his junior. But the larger problem was that he was considered a kind of god, and that part of his elevation sprang from his image as champion of home and hearth.

title: Charges Against Homeless Man Are Dropped in Murder in Village
description: A Manhattan judge yesterday dismissed murder charges against a homeless man accused of shooting a West Village advertising executive to death last summer. The prosecution said it did not have enough evidence to convict him.

title: SENATOR OPPOSES JUDICIAL NOMINEE
description: In a sharp for setback for President Bush, Senator Bob Graham of Florida today asked the Senate Judiciary Committee to reject the nomination of the Federal District Judge Kenneth L. Ryskamp to a pivotal seat on the Court of Appeals .

title: The F.C.C. Cages the Networks
description: The Federal Communications Commission decided this week to "substantially relax, but not totally repeal" the rules that for 21 years have kept the television networks from owning and syndicating reruns of the shows they broadcast. But while the commission loosened some rules, it also imposed layers of bizarre new regulations.

title: Teller Kidnapped to Open Vault
description: Robbers kidnapped the head teller of a Queens bank Tuesday night and took her to the bank yesterday morning, forced her to open the vault, and stole up to $200,000, the police said.

title: B.S.B. Moves To Take Cue From Infiniti
description: BACKER SPIELVOGEL BATES said yesterday that it had hired Donald Easdon, a creative director best known for his unconventional campaign to introduce Nissan's Infiniti luxury car, which featured shots of rocks and trees, with nary a car in sight.

title: Heinz Is Remembered As a Selfless Legislator
description: Senator John Heinz, heir to the H. J. Heinz Company fortune, was remembered at his funeral today as a selfless man who used his wealth and influence to champion causes affecting the elderly, labor and the environment.

title: Critic's Notebook; TV Images That Sear and Prod
description: One set of pictures hit like a kick to the head; the other, a blow to the heart. The scenes of police officers in Los Angeles beating a man on the ground and those of Iraqi refugees in search of some meager haven display the instant power of television to jolt emotions. The days and weeks of coverage have, if anything, added to their impact.

title: Caution Urged on Recovery
description: The White House said today that it was too early to say the recession is ending, despite some hopeful signs.

title: Market Place; The Riklis Offer: A Fair Exchange?
description: MESHULAM RIKLIS, the owner of the McCrory Corporation, is making an offer to bondholders that would appear to be eminently resistable. But given Mr. Riklis's previous tough dealing with bondholders, it is possible that some holders will choose to take it.

title: Sanderson's Storybook Start Tops Tigers
description: Moments after the ball struck the top of the fence and fell to the grass below, Scott Sanderson walked off the mound at Tiger Stadium and headed slowly toward the dugout. But he was neither torn by disappointment nor shocked by the base hit that swept away his no-hitter today.

title: Assembly Passes Bill on Alcohol Warnings
description: After a debate that centered as much on abortion as on the dangers of drinking, the Assembly approved a bill today that would require sellers of alcohol to post signs warning pregnant women that alcohol consumption can cause birth defects.

title: Pop in Review
description: Danny Gatton The Ritz 119 East 11th Street

title: Bring Germany Into New World Order; Something's Rotten
description: To the Editor:

title: Events: Bauhaus and Limoges
description: Portrait of a School Herb Lubalin Study Center at Cooper Union, 7 East Seventh Street; (212) 353-4155.

title: Albanian Communists Propose a Constitution
description: The Communists, overwhelming victors in Albania's first multi-party election in decades, proposed a constitution today that would embrace human rights and pluralism but fall short of full democracy.

title: Barrett Scoville, 55, Executive and Scholar
description: Dr. Barrett Scoville, a pharmaceutical executive and medical school professor, was killed Sunday when his single-engine plane crashed on takeoff at the Great Barrington Airport in Massachusetts. He was 55 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Nintendo to Pay $25 Million In Rebates on Price Fixing
description: Nintendo has agreed to pay up to $25 million in rebates to buyers of its popular video games and $4.75 million in other costs to settle allegations of price fixing, state and Federal officials announced yesterday in Washington.

title: Economic Scene; Consumers' Role In a Recovery
description: THERE is less to the consumer debt crisis than meets the eye. Some economists doubt that households are too deeply in debt to spend the nation out of a recession. As the economy recovers, slow growth in incomes is more likely to restrain consumer spending.

title: Editors Report Gains in 1990 In Minority Journalist Hiring
description: The number of minority journalists at the nation's daily newspapers increased more in 1990 than in any of the 13 years that racial diversity in the newsroom has been monitored, according to a survey made public today at the convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

title: Harry Ginsberg, 102; Led Box Manufacturer
description: Harry Ginsberg, a philanthropist and industrialist who founded the National Container Corporation, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 102 years old.

title: Events
description: FRIDAY Music

title: Baker-Assad Talks Called Inconclusive
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d tried today to persuade President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to agree in principle to an American proposal for a regional peace conference between Israel and the Arab countries.

title: Mitchell on a Homer-Run Tear; Righetti Roughed Up in Relief
description: Will Clark and Kevin Mitchell hit run-scoring singles in the 10th inning as San Francisco recovered after losing a six-run lead to beat San Diego, 11-6, yesterday.

title: 4 Razorbacks Appeal
description: Four Arkansas players, who sources say were suspended from the team for a year following a sexual incident, filed appeals with the school yesterday, the University of Arkansas system president said. The president, B. Alan Sugg, said he would make a decision on the appeals by Tuesday or Wednesday.

title: Japan Satellite Bids Sought
description: The Satellite Japan Corporation plans to invite bidders for two telecommunications satellites it intends to launch in 1994 if its license is approved by the Government, a company official said today.

title: Teaneck, a Year After Killing, Is Striving for Racial Healing
description: One year after the fatal shooting of a black teen-ager by a white police officer unleashed a torrent of emotions in this integrated Bergen County suburb, an uneasy and uncertain attempt at racial healing is under way.

title: A Standoff With Brazil Over Sale of a Computer
description: A powerful computer that President Bush approved last year for sale to a Brazilian aircraft company has yet to be shipped because Brazil has not provided the required guarantees that the technology will not be used for military purposes or be transferred to other countries, Administration officials said today.

title: Yodo Journal; Where Want Ads Are Bait and Weddings Forced
description: The girlish Sri Lankan wearing a bright red Goofy sweater seemed an unlikely source for the troubling story she recalled in her dormitory here, on the outskirts of Kyoto.

title: Minsk Workers Agree To Talk To Gorbachev
description: Even as thousands of workers continued to protest in the capital of Byelorussia, labor leaders agreed today to negotiate with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Government. And a fresh confrontation continued building in breakaway Georgia over the smoldering civil war there.

title: Stocks Rise And the Dow Gains 30.95
description: The stock market rebounded yesterday, largely because the Government reported a modest rise in wholesale prices for March. The report was in line with expectations, and analysts expect the report on the March Consumer Price Index, which is due before the market opens this morning, will also be well received.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ATI Medical Inc., Las Vegas, Nev., a medical equipment rental agency, will sell its Cams Inc. software subsidiary to a group of investors from Georgia for undisclosed terms. * CCAir Inc., Charlotte, N.C., operator of USAir Express, filed a Chapter 11 reorganization plan with a Federal Bankruptcy Court. The plan includes return of surplus aircraft and equipment to lessors and creditors.

title: Sharp's New Solar Cell
description: The Sharp Corporation said today that it would soon begin mass production of silicon solar cells that have the highest efficiency rating of any mass-produced solar cell in the world. The new cell will have an efficiency rating of converting sunlight into energy of 19.4 percent, compared with 17.1 percent for Sharp's current commercial solar cell, the company said.

title: Picking Up Right Where We Left Off
description: AS I was saying before I went away, George Foreman will lurch through heavyweight history, Mark Spitz is going to write his name on water, and South Africa and the International Olympic Committee will play politics.

title: Charles Fleschner, Contractor, 90
description: Charles Fleschner, a demolition contractor who helped dismantle buildings at the 1939 World's Fair, died on Wednesday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 90 years old.

title: Sports Officials Shrug Off Call for Smokeless Sponsors
description: Sports officials yesterday largely shrugged off the call by Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, for fans and sports promoters to shun sports events sponsored by tobacco companies.

title: Strong Profits Are Reported At Intel and Advanced Micro
description: The Intel Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported unexpectedly strong first-quarter results today. They attributed the results to strong demand for microprocessors, the computers-on-a-chip that are the brains of personal computers, as well as some larger machines.

title: Review/Theater; 'Miss Saigon' Arrives, From the Old School
description: THERE may never have been a musical that made more people angry before its Broadway debut than "Miss Saigon."

title: Security Pacific
description: The Tokyo branch of the Security Pacific National Bank lost about $18.2 million in speculative foreign exchange trading in March, a spokesman for the California bank said. The losses occurred after a dealer at the bank sold dollars when the United States currency was surging against European currencies, touching off losses on those positions, the spokesman said. The Los Angeles-based Security Pacific National Bank, a unit of the Security Pacific Corporation group, is the first foreign bank to report such huge losses in the Tokyo currency market, foreign exchange traders said.

title: First Nationwide Picks 3 To Bolster Management
description: In an effort to strengthen its management team, First Nationwide Bank, the savings institution owned by the Ford Motor Company, named three banking industry veterans today as executive vice presidents in charge of data processing, retail banking and real estate.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I had a three-speed Victrola and a manual typewriter and thought I was well off. Now, typewriters are out and Victrolas are in museums, and students have computers, little refrigerators, VCR's and color televisions." -- Tom G. Kessinger, president of Haverford College. [ A10:4. ]

title: Restaurants
description: Cosseting Old World French restaurants, which used to set the standards for fine dining before haute grilling and tri-colored pastas became the rage, are becoming as rare as beef Wellington. One of the survivors is Le Chantilly, a sumptuous establishment wrapped in dreamy murals of the chateau that is the restaurant's namesake.

title: Unitas Meets Creditors
description: Hall of Fame quarterback Johnny Unitas and his wife owe creditors as much as $3.2 million, bankruptcy filings show. Unitas, the former Baltimore Colts star, and his wife, Sandra, met with six creditors on Wednesday to disclose their assets and debts as part of a chapter 11 bankruptcy proceeding Unitas filed for in February. (AP)

title: Catholic Editor Assails Dinkins on French Pill
description: The editor in chief of Catholic New York, the official newspaper of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, astringently criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday for his outspoken support for bringing a French abortion pill to the United States.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RUDY PERPICH, former Governor of Minnesota, says he is considering an offer to become Minister of Foreign Relations in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia.

title: The Teaneck Shooting Case
description: Important dates connected with the shooting of a black teen-ager by a Teaneck police officer a year ago. April 10, 1990: Phillip C. Pannell, 16 years old, is fatally shot in the back running from a Teaneck police officer. The police say the youth was reaching for a pistol when he was shot. April 11: A candlelight vigil for the teen-ager turns violent as blacks attack the police station and break shop windows. April 12: The officer who shot Mr. Pannell, Gary Spath, is suspended with pay. April 17: Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo transfers investigation into shooting from Bergen County prosecutor's office to state grand jury. July 31: Mr. Del Tufo announces grand jury did not indict Officer Spath and then orders a second inquiry, saying first was tainted by erroneous testimony from Bergen County Medical Examiner. Nov. 28: Officer Spath is indicted for manslaughter.

title: Kitty Kelley Cancels Tour
description: Kitty Kelley yesterday canceled a national tour and two interviews to publicize her new book, "Nancy Reagan, the Unauthorized Biography."

title: Turks Say Hussein Plotted to Drive Out the Kurds
description: Turkish officials said today that they are still convinced that the mass exodus of Kurds and others from Iraq is the result of an attempt by Saddam Hussein to empty his country's northern regions of unwanted minorities.

title: Job Prospects for Graduates Seen as Bleak
description: After investing tens of thousands of dollars and countless hours in legal education, a substantial number of third-year students at law schools nationwide may graduate this year without job offers.

title: Space Shuttle Lands After Delay
description: The space shuttle Atlantis ended its six-day mission with a smooth landing here today.

title: As Medicaid Fees Push Doctors Out, Chicago Patients Find Fewer Choices
description: Like thousands of doctors across Illinois, Dr. Claudia M. Fegan refuses to take new Medicaid patients because her practice cannot survive on the fees Medicaid pays.

title: Senior CBS Executive Leaves for Thompson
description: Jerome H. Dominus, a senior executive at CBS during much of his 25-year career there, has left the network to join J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. as its senior vice president, director of national television and programming.

title: On a Brisk April Night, Whitehurst is White Hot
description: The countdown to his first start of the season and most significant moment of his career was under three minutes away as Wally Whitehurst stood on the mound, let loose a slider and watched it break half a dozen feet from the mound to the plate.

title: Drug Director Named
description: The United States Olympic Commitee, gearing up for the 1992 Winter Games in Albertville, France, and the Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain, has named Dr. Wade Exum director of drug-control administration, Harvey W. Schiller, the executive director, said. Dr. Exum, a Branford, Conn., resident who is cerified as both a medical doctor and a psychiatrist, will direct the organization's comprehensive $6.5 million program, which includes drug control, testing and education programs for American athletes.

title: Abdul Denies 2d Voice Was Used on Album
description: The pop singer Paula Abdul today denied accusations that another singer's voice had been used to enhance hers on her 1988 debut album "Forever Your Girl," which went on to sell more than seven million copies and establish Ms. Abdul as one of the biggest stars in the booming dance-pop field.

title: Ban for Caron
description: Ron Caron, the general manager of the St. Louis Blues, has been banned from the press box area of all National Hockey League arenas for the remainder of this season's playoffs. The ban and a $10,000 fine against the Blues were levied because of comments Caron made after Game 2 of the St. Louis-Detroit playoff series at St. Louis on April 6.

title: Critic's Choice/Dance: Kovich's Stylish Antics
description: Humor is a rare commodity in dance. But Robert Kovich is a genuinely funny choreographer and performer whose comic irony glints through almost everything he does. Mr. Kovich also has an eye for dancers with something of the same cool yet intense energy and sense of fine detail that made him stand out in his years with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, in the late 1970's.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Manufacturing Chief Is Leaving Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that its top manufacturing executive had quit, the latest in a parade of top management departures from the troubled No. 3 auto maker. But several other company sources said they believed he had been forced out.

title: Congress Still Uneasy on Cambodia
description: The Administration's freeze on aid to the non-Communist guerrillas fighting in coalition with the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia has dampened but not silenced Congressional criticism of the United States role in Cambodia.

title: Norris M. Shimabuku, Actor, 44
description: Norris M. Shimabuku, an actor and member of the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, died in his sleep on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 44 years old.

title: BUSH SEES ACCORD ON 'SAFE HAVENS' FOR KURDS IN IRAQ
description: After meeting with European leaders today, President Bush said the United States had reached "total agreement" with them on informal safe havens in northern Iraq where aid would be given to the Kurdish refugees from the Baghdad Government of President Saddam Hussein.

title: Police Bias Alleged By Officer Who Says Another Raped Her
description: A policewoman who said she was raped by her police officer boyfriend asserted yesterday that law-enforcement officials were not aggressively pursuing an investigation because of sex discrimination.

title: Review/Film; Chopin, George Sand, Liszt and Some Others
description: The rustling of hoop skirts would doubtless be more evident in "Impromptu" if its heroine, George Sand (Judy Davis), did not prefer to dress as a man. As it is, this 19th-century romance achieves the usual decorousness of its genre and goes well beyond that into the realm of classical celebrity farce, whereby the great talents of Sand's day -- Franz Liszt, Frederic Chopin, Eugene Delacroix and others -- share endless outings, visits, duels and sexual intrigues. The film's style is so merrily and unapologetically contemporary that all of these events might easily be taking place in the present day, most likely on "Dallas."

title: Our Towns
description: Brian Cullen, high school science teacher, keeps getting himself into trouble.

title: Seton Hall Departure
description: Rod Baker, an assistant coach at Seton Hall for the last three seasons -- during which the Pirates made impressive runs in two National Collegiate Athletic Association tournaments before being eliminated -- has signed a four-year contract as head coach of California-Irvine.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Mackie Reworks 1920's Sparkle For the 90's
description: Most designers search eagerly for the secret to a theatrical fashion show. Bob Mackie found it in a brilliant songwriter named Cole Porter. He planned his fall opening at the Plaza yesterday around Porter standards, from "Don't Fence Me In" (black and white wool checks and the season's ubiquitous plaids) to "Begin the Beguine" (the most sumptuous long dresses).

title: On My Mind; The War Goes On
description: The United Nations proclaims that a cease-fire is now officially in effect in Iraq. That is a lie; the war goes on.

title: 3 Dance Awards
description: Mark Morris, Virginia Johnson and Jennifer Tipton have been named as the recipients of the Dance Magazine Awards 1991. Mr. Morris, a choreographer, recently ended his tenure as director of dance at the Theatre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels.
