Ms. Johnson is a leading ballerina with the Dance Theater of Harlem, and Ms. Tipton is a lighting designer for dance, theater and opera. The awards, which are given for significant contributions to dance, are to be presented on April 15 in a private ceremony in Manhattan.

title: Uncivil Disobedience
description: Students at the City University of New York who object to proposed tuition increases vent their anger by shutting down and disrupting classes. Police who object to stalled contract talks protest by writing fewer traffic tickets. What's happened to lawful dissent in New York City?

title: Joseph J. Greenberg, Sculptor, 75
description: Joseph J. Greenberg, the sculptor of the black granite Bear and Cub at the Philadelphia Zoo and many other public sculptures, has died of heart failure. He was 75 years old.

title: Review/Art; Humbler Masterworks Of the Heroic Delacroix
description: WHAT is a Delacroix exhibition without "Liberty Leading the People" or "Scenes From the Chios Massacres" or "The Barque of Dante"? Those monumental paintings by the man who epitomized French Romantic art hang where they always do, in the Louvre. On view in the Delacroix show that has opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are only paintings, drawings and prints from North American collections.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: U.S. Homeless Count Is Far Below Estimates
description: The Census Bureau found about 230,000 people in its first large-scale effort to count homeless people at shelters and selected street sites, a figure that bureau aides familiar with the count say was even lower than the modest expectations for the carefully circumscribed count.

title:
PROJECTS IN NEW JERSEY;
Move Into a New Home, Then Go Out to Tee Off
description: When the first players tee off at the new 18-hole Crystal Springs golf course scheduled to open here on Memorial Day weekend, they will include residents of the new houses clustered along the fairways.

title: Senate Panel Votes Slight Changes in Budget
description: The Senate Budget Committee voted today to make some slight adjustments in President Bush's $1.45 trillion budget, recommending an extra $3.5 billion in spending for education and child health and nutrition programs and trims of that much in other domestic areas, like space and transportation.

title: Grace H. J. Mead, 95, Foundation President
description: Grace Hartley Jenkins Mead, a philanthropist and trustee emeritus of Columbia University's Teachers College, died on Wednesday at her home in Morristown, N.J. She was 95 years old and also had residences in Norfolk, Conn., and St. Croix in the Virgin Islands.

title: Martha Graham Wrought Emotion Into Dance; Immediate Survivors
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Need a Rousing Finish
description: If the Knicks are to make more than a brief playoff appearance, they need to build momentum quickly.

title: SportsFriday
description: Encore. Robert Lipsyte comes back to The Times with a column about comebacks. Fly So Free streaks along the inside track to the Kentucky Derby. Pages B7-13.

title: Marjorie L. C. Bishopric, Socialite, 79
description: Marjorie Lee Collins Bishopric, one of the early residents of the Devon Colony in Amagansett, L.I., died on Monday at her daughter's home in Amagansett. She was 79 years old and lived in Amagansett and Greenwich, Conn.

title: 2 Schools, 2 Results on Reading Tests
description: Public School 38 in southern Queens is an old-fashioned place, as four-square as its neighborhood of brick and clapboard homes and magnolia trees that bloom every spring. It does not have open classrooms, school-based management, bilingual education, multicultural education or practically any of the other nostrums for school improvement that have been floating around for two decades.

title: The Spoken Word
description: LECTURE AND SLIDE SHOW, South Street Seaport, Museum Gallery, 213 Water Street, Manhattan. A discussion of exploration in the 16th century by Gerald Milanich of the Florida Museum of Natural History, Sunday at 2 P.M. Free with museum admission, $6 ($3 for children). Information: (212) 669-9400.

title: Spira's Letters 'a Smoke Screen'
description: Howard Spira, charged with trying to extort money from George Steinbrenner, emerged as a pathetically lone, scared and sickly figure from a series of letters and telephone conversations that took up the entire fourth day of his trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday.

title: New USX Stock To Begin Trading
description: The USX Corporation said that the stock representing its newly created steel company would begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday on a "when issued" basis. Under its plan to split its energy and steel holdings, which is set for a shareholder vote on May 6, USX will create two New York Stock Exchange stocks: one that reflects its Marathon Oil energy business and one that reflects the value of its steel, mining, real estate and other ventures.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Commercial Credit Co. is offering $150 million in 8 3/8 percent noncallable notes due 1995 at a price of 100 through Morgan Stanley & Co. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P. * Sacramento, Calif., is offering $31.8 million in tax-exempt refunding certificates of participation with a maximum yield of 6.95 percent for issues due in 2007 and 2012 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Co. For shorter maturities, yields range from 4.50 percent in 1991 to 6.45 percent in 2001. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P. Common Stock * Ann Taylor Stores Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 5.03 million common shares through Merrill Lynch & Co.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education Page Wednesday about school reform in Rochester misidentified the school that has a curriculum based on the Genesee River. It is Elementary School 6.

title: Rights and Economy Aren't Separate Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Twin Peaks' to Die
description: ABC announced yesterday that it would remove the badly fading "Twin Peaks" from its schedule after next week and would run the final two original episodes in the series as a two-hour movie on June 10. The onetime cult-hit series, which returned to ABC's schedule three weeks ago, was 77th out of 85 shows in the ratings last week.

title: Spitz Races Against The March of Time
description: We can thank Clairol for more than returning the zip to Mark Spitz's hair color. Without the dyemeisters at Clairol, we might not witness the quadragenarian swimmer's first comeback race, against Tom Jager tomorrow, (and his second, against Matt Biondi on April 27) on ABC's "Wide World of Sports.

title: J. P. Morgan Has a Surge In Earnings
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that profits after one-time items were excluded rose 61.5 percent in the first quarter, mostly because of strong gains in foreign exchange and bond trading.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Onda

title: CHRONICLE
description: MORRIS A. SCHAPIRO is showing his gratitude to his alma mater, Columbia University, by donating $10 million for its new engineering research building, now under construction. Mr. Schapiro, 88 years old, graduated from Columbia College in 1923 and received a master's degree in mining engineering in 1925 from the university. He worked in the mining business and eventually founded M. A. Schapiro & Company, a Manhattan investment concern specializing in banks.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A Florida man who contends that MERV GRIFFIN promised to support him for life filed a breach of contract suit yesterday seeking half the profits from "Wheel of Fortune."

title: In High-Tech Dorms, a Call for Power
description: College students nationwide are abandoning the minimalist look in dorm rooms for the high-tech glint of a space shuttle flight deck as they stuff a dizzying array of consumer electronics and electrical appliances into campus housing. Some colleges are even rewiring residence halls to keep up with the increased energy demands.

title: Corrections
description: An article and picture caption yesterday about student protests against proposed tuition increases at the City University of New York incompletely quoted Ricardo Fernandez, the president of Lehman College. While he expressed support for the students' desire to overturn the increases, he said they had no right to occupy buildings or disrupt classes.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL MILWAUKEE BREWERS--Placed Candy Maldonado, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Called up Don August, pitcher, from Denver of the American Association. OAKLAND ATHLETICS--Placed Gene Nelson and Eric Show, pitchers, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Reggie Harris and Joe Slusarski, pitchers, from Tacoma of the Pacific Coast League. FOOTBALL Canadian Football League OTTAWA ROUGH RIDERS--Signed William Hoggard, Christopher Poston and Joe Kubik, defensive backs. World League of American Football NEW YORK-NEW JERSEY KNIGHTS-- Signed Kevin Simons, guard, and Andre Alexander, wide receiver. Waived Rod Holder, guard, and Henry Tuten, wide receiver.

title: Discounters Show Good March Gain
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest discounter, and the K Mart Corporation, the second-largest, roared ahead in sales in March. In contrast, a struggling Sears, Roebuck & Company and the J. C. Penney Company reported sales declines from the year before.

title: Giants Hit Fans In the Wallet
description: For the first time, exhibition games are being included as a mandatory part of the Giants' season-ticket package this year.

title: As Sanderson Rests, Tigers Shell Yankees
description: Stump Merrill's description was perfect.

title: Private Relief Agencies Find Big Obstacles to Aiding Kurds
description: American private relief agencies have begun trying to rush hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of food and supplies to Kurdish refugees, but they are facing extraordinary difficulties because of the huge numbers of refugees as well as the local topography, politics and bureaucracy.

title: Shoemaker Recovering
description: Bill Shoemaker, partially paralyzed in an auto accident, was reported to be alert and responsive, but remained in critical condition yesterday at Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, Calif. Tests showed his blood-alcohol level was nearly twice the legal limit the night of the crash and authorities prepared to file drunken driving charges against him.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a concert by the Pet Shop Boys misidentified the theater where it took place. It was Radio City Music Hall, not Carnegie Hall.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Greek Independence Day Parade, Fifth Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 62d to 79th Streets from 1 P.M to 6 P.M.

title: Charles Goren, 90, Bridge Expert, Dies
description: Charles H. Goren, one of the greatest figures in the history of contract bridge, died on April 3 in Encino, Calif., one month after celebrating his 90th birthday.

title: Times Co. Profits Declined By 69.3% in First Quarter
description: Citing declining advertising revenues, The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its net income for the first three months of 1991 fell 69.3 percent, to $5.1 million, or 7 cents a share, from $16.6 million, or 22 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1990.

title: Leave Police Brutality to the Grand Jury and District Attorney
description: To the Editor:

title: Martha Graham Wrought Emotion Into Dance
description: To the Editor:

title: A Baedeker For Devotees Of the Little Silver Ball
description: HE is a pinball wizard if ever there was one. He can be identified only as ZIF for reasons that will be explained later. But one weekend at Max. Fish, a quirky downtown bar, he racked up more than a billion points. Not a million, and not quite the proverbial zillion, either. A billion.

title: Books of The Times; What John Updike Means to Him
description: U and I A True Story By Nicholson Baker 179 pages. Random House. $18.

title: Officer in Hasidic Dispute Shifted
description: A Hispanic police officer who has asserted that Jews in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn get preferential treatment from the police was temporarily transferred to a desk job in another precinct yesterday after a motorist filed a complaint against him.

title: Overtime Loss to Capitals Puts Rangers on Brink
description: After Dino Ciccarelli's overtime goal beat the Rangers last night, Mike Richter blamed himself for a mistake that even novice goalies are warned against.

title: Corrections
description: A caption with a fashion review yesterday misidentified the designer of a strapless dress with Amish patterns. He was Christian Francis Roth, not Michael Kors.

title: CBS Counsel to Join Fox
description: George Vradenburg 3d was named executive vice president of Fox Inc. yesterday, with responsibility for all legal activities for the company, . Mr. Vradenburg, who is currently vice president and general counsel at CBS Inc., will report to Barry Diller, chairman of Fox, the Los Angeles-based producer of movies and television programs. His appointment will be effective Monday. Mr. Diller said Mr. Vradenburg would be involved in developing corporate strategy and would work closely with Chase Carey, an executive vice president. Both men will report to Mr. Diller. Mr. Vradenburg had worked closely with top Fox executives as a board member of CBS-Fox.

title: Southeast Bank Has Merger Talks
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation confirmed reports that it was negotiating with several banking institutions about a possible business combination. It said that the discussions might be terminated at any time and that there was no assurance an agreement would be reached. Douglas E. Ebert, the president and chief executive, said the talks were part of an examination of several ways to bolster capital. The bank recently reported a loss, mainly because of nonperforming loans.

title: Abroad at Home; The Possible Dream
description: Imagine America in 1991 with the South still rigidly segregated and blacks playing no meaningful part in Southern political life. Imagine small numbers of rural voters controlling most of our state legislatures. Imagine America under a deadening repression of free speech and ideas.

title: At the Movies
description: Spader's Third Lawyer

title: Curb Deadly High-Tech Trade
description: The Bush Administration routinely approved sales of U.S. arms-related high technology to Iraq right up to the time that the Iraqi Army marched into Kuwait. Now that its own Under Secretary of Commerce has expressed second thoughts about that shortsighted practice, how does the White House respond? It tries to fire him, only to learn he's already resigned.

title: Schwarzkopf Says the Allies Accomplished 'Great Victory'
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, visiting Kuwait as a permanent cease-fire was about to take effect, said today that the allied forces "accomplished every single mission" assigned to them in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Committee Rejects Bush Nominee To Key Appellate Court in South
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to reject the nomination of Judge Kenneth L. Ryskamp to an important Court of Appeals seat because of questions about his sensitivity to minorities, handing President Bush his first defeat on a judicial nomination.

title: Sarah Jane Kinoy, 96, Teacher for Disabled
description: Sarah Jane Kinoy, a teacher and social worker who was an early leader in the education of children with cerebral palsy, died on Wednesday at the Jewish Home and Hospital in Manhattan. She was 96 years old and had lived in Manhattan and Tompkins Corners, N.Y.

title: Chamorro at Managua Helm: Beloved but Also Under Fire
description: As she winds up her first year in office, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro finds herself widely loved personally but with her Government besieged on all sides.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Chronicle on Wednesday about the actor Mickey Rourke's debut as a professional boxer misidentified Sal Cherch. He is president of Quest International, the company promoting the fight, to benefit the South Florida Veterans Multi-Purpose Center, which serves veterans of all wars. He is not a member of the Vietnam Veterans Association, the group sponsoring the fight.

title: Student Protests at CUNY Spread To 9 Campuses as Police Intervene
description: City University of New York students took over more buildings yesterday as the protest against tuition increases and budget cuts spread to at least nine of the system's 21 campuses.

title: Review/Art; Paintings That Liberate the Viewer's Imagination
description: In the paintings of Joan Mitchell at the Robert Miller Gallery, the metamorphic potential of abstract painting is everywhere present.

title: As Air Base Dies, Town Fights Over Its Afterlife
description: With the Persian Gulf war over, another desert conflict rages, this one over the future of George Air Force Base, where row after row of fighter jets bask in the high desert sun.

title: Pop/Jazz; Sonny Rollins and Pals In a Carnegie Reunion
description: In 1959, Sonny Rollins, considered by many critics and jazz fans to be the best young saxophonist in the business, abruptly quit performing in public. For the next two years, he practiced and experimented with new ideas on the Williamsburg Bridge; he said he didn't want to disturb the neighbors. After his self-imposed exile, he came to represent the archetype of the lone musician perfecting his craft in solitude.

title: McCaw Sells Systems In 3 States to BellSouth
description: A subsidiary of the BellSouth Corporation agreed today to buy mobile telephone systems in 18 Midwestern markets from McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. for a total of $410 million.

title: S.E.C. Settles Stock Case
description: Asher B. Edelman, who gained a reputation in the 1980's as a takeover specialist, agreed yesterday to pay $436,858 in a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Progressive Rock

title: Big Trade Surplus for Japan
description: Japan's trade surplus swelled by 24 percent in March to its highest level in more than two years, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Martha Graham Wrought Emotion Into Dance; Her Role at the Y
description: To the Editor:

title: Sewage Plant Near Capacity After 5 Years
description: Five years after it opened, the $1.1 billion North River sewage plant serving most of the West Side of Manhattan is treating almost as much sewage as it can handle, raising questions about the future water quality of the Hudson River and the future of West Side development.

title: The Soviet Slide; Efforts by Kremlin to Bolster the Economy Only Seem to Weaken Its Power to Do So
description: It is a measure of the confusion in the Soviet land that events that normally would seem momentous now come and go with a curious lack of effect.

title: Auctions
description: Rayographs in Demand

title: Weicker Vows to Veto Budget Plan That Does Not Include Income Tax
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. today placed his administration squarely in the crossroads of a confrontation with the broad middle belt of the General Assembly by vowing to veto a no-income-tax budget plan that had seemed to be gaining support in both parties.

title: Elitest Yale Breaks Precedent and Invites a Symbol of Populism to Preside at a Legal Rite
description: As one would expect from Yale Law School, the lawyer chosen to preside over the annual Thomas Swan Barristers' Union mock trial finals has always been some titan of the bar or bench. Past judges include Edward Bennett Williams, Arthur Liman and A. Leon Higgenbotham Jr. But tonight in New Haven, the proletariat meets the elite. Oyez, oyez, oyez! All rise for this year's arbiter: Judge Joseph A. Wapner of the television program "The People's Court."

title: New England Bid Delay
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it would delay for about a week the announcement of the winning bidder for the failed Bank of New England. The announcement was originally scheduled for April 16 but now is scheduled for April 24. Alan Whitney, an F.D.I.C. spokesman, said the agency needed more time to review the complex offers and that no bid had been eliminated.

title: Treasury Prices Up Moderately
description: Fresh reports presenting a mixed picture on the economy and inflation had little impact in the credit markets, where prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher yesterday in light trading.

title: Review/Film; No Money, But Trying To Be Rich
description: "The Object of Beauty," written and directed by Michael Lindsay-Hogg, is an enjoyably snobbish comedy about two heedless Americans living beyond their means in an elegant London hotel. It's gotten so bad for Jake (John Malkovich) and Tina (Andie MacDowell) that he crosses himself and she holds her breath as he hands his credit card to the headwaiter.

title: Retail Sales Fell 0.8% In March
description: In the clearest evidence to date that revived confidence has done little to spur consumer spending, the Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales fell eight-tenths of 1 percent last month. That put sales slightly below the level of March 1990.

title: So Why Don't They Give Oscars for Comedy?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Baby Sitter Strikes Back

title: Subaru Puts $60 Million Account in Review
description: EDWARD VICK, who became the president and chief executive of Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver just two months ago, is facing his first big test: Subaru of America, the agency's biggest client, said yesterday that it had put its $60 million account into review.

title: Market Place; New Amex Rule On Super Classes
description: THE American Stock Exchange adopted rules yesterday that will make it easier for companies listed on that exchange to issue super-voting shares, which provide disproportionate voting powers to their holders.

title: EXECUTIVE
description: * Guinness P.L.C., London, named Tony Robinson director of corporate strategy and financing. * Nellcor Inc., Hayward, Calif., a manufacturer of hospital equipment, named David L. Schlotterbeck executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Tokyo Stocks Gain a Bit
description: Japanese stock prices advanced slightly today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 157.31 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to end the week at 26,582.50. For the week, the index was down 184.83 points, or nearly seven-tenths of a percent.

title: Crowded Leader Board Shows Why This One Is Called the Masters
description: Past greats and anticipated ones filled the leader board today in the first round of the Masters, as the cream of the field began to rise early in the full bloom of the Augusta National Golf Club.

title: From the Law to Vogue to Esquire
description: Esquire magazine, which describes itself on its cover as "Man At His Best," yesterday named Nancy Nadler LeWinter, the advertising director of Vogue, as its publisher.

title: Penny Stock Rules Asked
description: Federal regulators, seeking to clamp down on the $2-billion-a-year fraud in the penny stock industry, proposed new rules today to protect investors in the risky low-cost securities.

title: Texas Takes Action to Shift Money From Rich School Districts to Poor
description: The Texas Legislature tonight approved a revision of the state's public school finance system that aims to redistribute property tax revenues from rich school districts to poor ones.

title: Talk and More Talk About Nancy (That One!) in Flushing
description: Perhaps it is only fitting that Nancy Reagan, a woman both admired and scorned for her regal tastes, came from Queens.

title: Canada Rues Fast-Track Trade Approval
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Coalition Is Formed, Ending 2-Week Crisis
description: Prime Minister-designate Giulio Andreotti ended a two-week political crisis today by putting together a coalition to serve as Italy's 50th postwar Government.

title: Key Rates
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Sports, Smoking and Dr. Sullivan
description: Louis Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, hates the cigarette habit. As a physician he's well aware of the heart and lung diseases that are so often its byproduct; and as a black man he's especially aware of the damage it's caused among blacks. Last year he asked an unresponsive tobacco industry to stop sponsoring sporting events. This week he ringingly raised voice to a roar.

title: Valentine-Radford Gets Campaign for U S Sprint
description: U S Sprint, which has its corporate headquarters in Kansas City, Mo., has selected Valentine-Radford Inc., a Kansas City agency, to develop a marketing campaign that highlights the company's community service activities there.

title: Review/Film; Subhumanoids Develop A Durability Problem
description: Somewhere beneath the gallons of green slime spewed by mutant creatures in "Class of Nuke 'Em High Part 2: Subhumanoid Meltdown" gurgles a message: subhumans have feelings too.

title: Bruins Pummel Whalers, 6-1
description: Ray Bourque started a six-goal outburst in the third period as the Boston Bruins beat the Hartford Whalers, 6-1, tonight and moved one victory away from advancing to the Adams Division final.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about stock market activity on Wednesday misidentified a company in some copies. The company whose stock hit a 52-week high of $49.25 was Upjohn, not Johnson & Johnson.

title: Review/Film; It's Kafka in Poland
description: In "Eminent Domain," set in Poland in the late 1970's, Donald Sutherland plays Jozef Burski, a powerful Politburo member whose party loyalty is put to a grueling test. When first seen, he is comfortable and secure, able to trade freely in the kinds of favors and black-market benefits that accompany his position. Others refer to him admiringly as "No. 6," to indicate where he stands in the Communist political hierarchy. But one day, Burski finds his security clearance revoked and his office closed. For no apparent reason, he is stripped of his privileges and power.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELLA FITZGERALD is to receive the Cole Porter centennial award tomorrow night at Radio City Music Hall. Porter's cousin MARGARET COLE RICHARDS is to present the award before the second half of Miss Fitzgerald's concert with LOUIE BELLSON and his orchestra.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Firsthand Sylvia

title: Park Service Is Halting A Project Killing Bison
description: The National Park Service today dropped its plan to shoot 25 pregnant bison in Yellowstone National Park for research into a livestock disease.

title: Review/Film; Father-Daughter Memory Portrait
description: The silences in "Daddy Nostalgia," Bertrand Tavernier's handsomely elegiac film about the last days spent together by a father and daughter, are filled with foreboding. Tony (Dirk Bogarde) has lately been hospitalized, and the prognosis is poor. Neither he nor his daughter Caroline (Jane Birkin) speaks directly about his medical condition. Instead, as Caroline pays an extended visit to her parents on the Cote d'Azur, the conversation is sometimes oblique, sometimes painfully candid, and at other times absurdly petty. "Daddy Nostalgia" recapitulates this family's full emotional history in light of the sad circumstances that bring parents and child together one last time.

title: Ball in Accord
description: The Ball Corporation, a packaging and aerospace concern, said it had signed an agreement with the lenders of Ball Packaging Products Canada Inc., its joint venture, to purchase their interest in the joint venture for $120 million. Included in the purchase were all of the bank loans and related security interests issued by Ball Canada, as well as all of Ball Canada's shares that had been pledged to its lenders. Ball shares added 12.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $26.375.

title: Top Editor at Morrow Quits; A Personality Clash Is Cited
description: Jim Landis, the editor in chief of William Morrow & Company and a widely respected figure in New York publishing, quit yesterday after what editors and agents described as an irreconcilable personality clash with Howard Kaminsky, the chief executive of Morrow's parent company.

title: Group Says It Hurled Bombs at I.R.S. Center
description: A group that took responsibility for an attempted bombing near an Internal Revenue Service office in Los Angeles a year ago has now claimed responsibility for the launching of pipe bombs toward an I.R.S. processing center in Fresno last week.

title: Calling for Bradley
description: Shawn Bradley, the 7-foot 6-inch Brigham Young center who as a freshmen averaged 14.8 points, 7.7 rebounds and 5.2 blocked shots in 34 games, will interrupt his college career for two years to serve a Mormon mission in Sydney, Australia. He will begin in June. (AP)

title: Cirque du Soleil: Circus of the Future
description: The secret is out. The Cirque du Soleil is not a circus. "What we do is not circus, it's theater," said Franco Dragone, the show's artistic director. He said it loudly, confidently, but with the barest hint of mockery.

title: Jobless Claims Drop by 70,000
description: The number of new unemployment insurance claims dropped by 70,000 in late March after soaring to the highest level in more than eight years, the Labor Department said today. But analysts cautioned that the drop might not be a sign the nation's jobless situation was stabilizing.

title: Ford Slashes Dividend As Bad Times Worsen
description: As worse news piled on top of bad in the automobile industry recently, the Ford Motor Company tried hard to hold its dividend steady, even as G.M. and Chrysler passed some of the pain along to shareholders. But Detroit's third shoe dropped today as Ford, saying business conditions were even tougher than those usually encountered when car sales are soft, cut its quarterly payout nearly in half.

title: Feltsman to Play
description: The pianist Vladimir Feltsman is to play Bach's Partita No. 2 in C minor (BWV 826), Prokofiev's Sonata No. 8 in B flat (Op. 84) and Schumann's "Carnaval" (Op. 9) at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Producer Prices Fell 0.3% in March
description: Prices at the producer level fell in March for the fourth straight month, the first time that has occurred in five years, the Government said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Retail Sales Off 0.8% As Recession's Grip Holds Retail sales fell eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government estimated, and producers' prices eased an unexpectedly large three-tenths of 1 percent, showing the economy remained mired in recession. Page D1.

title: Basketball Star In Nike Spots
description: David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs will resume his starring role next week in a series of spots for Nike parodying the television program "Mr. Rogers's Neighborhood."

title: Chiron Acquisition
description: The Chiron Corporation, a maker of medical products, said a subsidiary, Chiron Ophthalmic Inc., Irvine, Calif., had acquired a majority interest in Adatomed G.m.b.H. of Munich, Germany, a leading supplier of ophthalmic surgical products. Adatomed will remain under German management but will work closely with Chiron Ophthalmic to coordinate research and marketing between the United States and Europe, Chiron said. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Adatomed employs 75 people and had 1990 sales of $6.7 million.

title: Sports of The Times; The Arrival Of the 'Next Nicklaus'
description: THIS must be what Bob Jones had in mind when he created the Masters tournament. Sunny warmth from a blue-dome sky. Azaleas and dogwood in bloom. Just enough breeze to make the golfers think. And an amateur, as Bob Jones was in 1930 when he achieved his Grand Slam, good enough to make the pros think.

title: New Kids on the Block Look Promising for Rangers
description: Even as the Rangers' playoff picture dimmed last night in a 5-4 overtime defeat at Madison Square Garden, their long-term future brightened. Small consolation, perhaps. But two kids, fresh-faced and full of fire, skated with the big team and did not blink.

title: Review/Piano; Mozart and Granados By Alicia de Larrocha
description: The first half of Alicia de Larrocha's recital at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening brought to mind Artur Schnabel's wry remark about the piano sonatas of Mozart: "Too easy for children and too difficult for adults." Any pianist, no matter how mature or technically adept, understands the truth lurking in that paradox. The notes themselves, though not always as easily mastered as Schnabel implies, present few problems -- few, certainly, compared to those in the florid Granados pieces that Miss de Larrocha offered later in her program. In the Mozart sonatas, it is often the very simplicity of means that is intimidating. Every lapse of taste, bluntness of phrase or miscalculation of balances leaps out.

title: As Shiite Camp Faces U.S. Pullout, Even Stout Hearts Waver
description: Hassan, whose mother said he was 10 but who could have passed for 7, raised his shirt to show the six-inch scar down the center of his chest from his surgery last summer in Baghdad. It was the first of two operations needed to correct an otherwise-fatal heart valve defect.

title: Bush Aide Sees Recovery Soon
description: The chief White House economic adviser, Michael Boskin, said today that the economic recovery had not yet started but that certain precursors had been seen that precede a recovery by two to five months.

title: Mass Killer Puts Focus on Federal Appeal Policy
description: More than a decade ago, a jury convicted John Wayne Gacy of killing 33 boys and young men, one of the largest number of murders ever attributed to a single person in the United States.

title: Samuel Lambert, 78, Former Head Of Education Association, Is Dead
description: Samuel M. Lambert, retired executive secretary of the National Education Association, the country's largest professional union, died Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 78 years old.

title: Leave Police Brutality to the Grand Jury and District Attorney; Wire the Officers
description: To the Editor:

title: Seidman Asks Stiffer Bank Curbs
description: L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, asked Congress today to reverse sharply the deregulatory trend of the last two decades and adopt a law that would make it harder for banks to issue loans for construction and purchases of raw land and other real estate.

title: TV Weekend; Lives Caught Between the Zealots
description: The scene is Long Island. Marty Klein's pregnant wife, Nancy, is seriously injured in a car accident. A damaged brain stem leaves her in a coma. Concluding that Nancy cannot survive delivery of a child, Marty decides to have the pregnancy terminated. The abortion case will attract widespread press attention. This is the based-on-fact story recounted in "Absolute Strangers," a television movie on CBS at 9 P.M. Sunday.

title: Just Like Old Times For Jack And Tom
description: Jack Nicklaus and Tom Watson may already have eight Masters championships between them, but nothing will please the golf world more than to see the two greedily battling to bring their total to nine.

title: Unleaded Coffee
description: Without a trace of shame, right there in the restaurant, and in front of her husband yet, the woman said to the waiter, "What's your phone number?" The waiter and the husband burst into laughter. They understood this was the question not of a flirt but of an insomniac.

title: Triumphant Devils Put Penguins on the Ropes
description: The Devils squandered a two-goal lead going into the third period, but they came back for a 4-2 triumph over the Penguins tonight to take a 3-2 lead in the Patrick Division semifinal series.

title: The Whistle-Blower and the Train Wreck
description: After five years of confusion and dispute, the facts of what has come to be called the Baltimore case have finally become public. A National Institutes of Health draft report has found that the putative evidence for the paper that started the controversy was fabricated and called Dr. David Baltimore's defense of that paper "deeply troubling."

title: Central Europe's Central Need
description: To head off further deterioration in Central Europe, beset by fragmenting ethnic nationalism and collapsing economies, the industrial democracies must help provide the region with a new political structure. The West and Japan should not become so mesmerized by Soviet disorder that they fail to contribute to the democratic development of Central Europe and the Balkans.

title: Philip Minor, 63, Dies; A Longtime Director
description: Philip Minor, who directed plays and musical productions in New York and around the country, died on Tuesday at his brother's home in Pennington, N.J. He was 63 years old.

title: Anxiety Is High as Lawmakers Await Plan to Close Military Bases
description: For six months, Representative Tom McMillen has been nervously awaiting the news that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is to deliver Friday.

title: Review/Art; The Young Archie Rand, Reverent and Irreverent
description: Archie Rand's "Letter Paintings" are 20 years old, but in many ways they're as fresh as they were the day they were made. This is partly because these paintings are almost completely unknown. Painted between 1968 and 1971, before Mr. Rand began his exhibition career, they are only now having their first full-fledged exposure in a beautiful, bittersweet show at Exit Art in SoHo. In addition, these are precocious early works, made by an artist in his early 20's; they radiate the passion and directness of youth.

title: Frederick A. Crane, Professor, 80
description: Frederick A. Crane, who taught history at Bard College from 1949 to 1978, died on Monday at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Rhinebeck.

title: Hungarian Diplomat Ordered to Leave Post
description: Hungary's flamboyant Ambassador to United States has been given 48 hours to pack up and leave his post, the Foreign Ministry said today in a statement after a week of gossip-laden scandal at the top echelons of Hungarian diplomacy.

title: Palm Beach Rape Suspect Says the Allegation Is a Lie
description: William Kennedy Smith, a nephew of Senator Edward M. Kennedy and who is at the center of a police investigation of a rape allegation, today called the assertion a "damnable lie."

title: CALIFORNIA SEIZES INSURER BURDENED WITH 'JUNK BONDS'
description: In the largest failure of an insurer, California regulators seized control today of the Executive Life Insurance Company, which had been among the heaviest buyers of high-risk "junk bonds" in the last decade under its high-flying chief executive, Fred Carr.

title: Airport Cab Dispatchers Held in Bribery
description: In times past, getting a taxi at a New York City airport was often a Darwinian affair, a frenzied, survival-of-the-fittest scene of piled-up luggage, darting taxis and shouting cabbies looking for an edge. Then a system of taxi dispatchers was adopted to bring order rather than ordeal.

title: Texas Instruments' Singapore Venture
description: Texas Instruments Inc., the Hewlett-Packard Company, Canon Inc. and the Government of Singapore have formed a joint venture to build a computer chip factory in Singapore. The new company expects to begin production of computer chips, primarily dynamic random access memories, in 1993.

title: Midlantic Banks Takes On A Chicagoan as New Chief
description: Midlantic Banks Inc., a New Jersey banking company that has fallen on hard times because of its heavy lending to commercial real estate projects, said yesterday that it had hired Garry J. Scheuring, a Chicago banker, as its new chairman and chief executive.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Edberg Beats Connors Stefan Edberg defeated Jimmy Connors in the third round of the Japan Open in Tokyo yesterday, but needed 2 hours 40 minutes to take the battle of the world's current and former No. 1 players. The 38-year-old Connors, in his third tournament since wrist surgery last October, showed some of his former flash in the second set before Edberg prevailed, 6-4, 6-7, 6-1, at the Ariake Colosseum. Connors was the No. 1-ranked player in the world from 1974 through 1978. Recent layoffs have dropped him to No. 577.

title: Katya Delakova, 76, Dancer and Teacher
description: Katya Delakova, a dancer and choreographer who specialized in Jewish themes, died Wednesday at her home in Titusville, N.J. She was 76 years old.

title: Review/Film; Blood and Bonding in Hong Kong
description: Balletic splatter and camp sentimentality have rarely if ever been stretched to the extremes found in John Woo's movie "The Killer." Written and directed by Hong Kong's answer to Sam Peckinpah, the action thriller arrives today at the Village East Cinemas, having already acquired a cult reputation from its showings at the Toronto and Sundance film festivals.

title: U.S. Investigators Tell of Abuses In Sale of Nursing Home Insurance
description: Investigators from the General Accounting Office told Congress today that they had found numerous abuses in the sale of private insurance intended to cover the high costs of nursing home care for elderly people.

title: Expansion Plan For Pathmark
description: The Supermarkets General Holdings Corporation said today that it would spend $385 million over the next three years to expand its Pathmark supermarket division.

title: Anna Sui's Slam-Bang Look: A Wistful Glance at the 60's
description: There was a multiple fashion collision Wednesday evening. It looked as if Sly and the Family Stone crashed into Coco Chanel and then got rear-ended by Christian Lacroix. The show, the first by Anna Sui, was a riot.

title: Owner of Derby Favorite Is Singing a Happy Tune
description: Thomas Valando knows a hit when he spots one.

title: For Children
description: Children's-Book Illustrators Henry Feiwel Gallery 24 West 57th Street Manhattan (212) 977-9060 Recommended ages: 3 and up Through April 27

title: Alaska Air Offers Zero-Coupon Debt
description: The Alaska Air Group is offering $300 million in zero-coupon convertible debentures through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Jazz at the Apollo
description: Joe Sample, Gerald Albright and Lalah Hathaway will take part in a jazz concert tonight at the Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street, at 7 and 11 P.M. Vaughn Harper of WBLS radio will be the host. Tickets are $15.50 to $32.50. Information: (212) 864-0372.

title: Leonard Greenburg, Pollution Official, 98
description: Dr. Leonard Greenburg, New York City's first Commissioner of Air Pollution Control and a professor emeritus of preventive medicine at Yeshiva University, died on March 13 at Manor Nursing Home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 98 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Article 935091 -- No Title
description: A $200 million debenture issue from TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Synergen's Drug
description: Synergen Inc., a biological products company, said the Food and Drug Administration had granted orphan drug status to its SLPI product for treating cystic fibrosis and a congenital defect responsible for genetic emphysema. Orphan drug status provides market exclusivity for a product in the United States for seven years. It is meant as an incentive for companies to develop new drugs. Synergen stock rose $2.25 a share today, to $33, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Review/Film; Of a Saintly Jewish Doctor in Poland Who Died at Treblinka
description: Much like the man it honors, Andrzej Wajda's "Korczak" maintains a steely surface tranquillity in the face of unspeakable events. From time to time, the Polish film suddenly speaks out in anger, then catches itself, as if children might be listening.

title: As Toxic Hudson Fire Dies, Focus Is on Cleanup
description: Federal and state environmental officials today declared an end to the air quality emergency caused by the smoky rubbish fire that sent clouds of smoke over both sides of the Hudson River on Wednesday. The officials turned their attention to cleaning up the illegal dump site.

title: Earnings Plunge At I.B.M.
description: Stung by declining sales across almost its entire hardware product line, I.B.M. said yesterday that its operating earnings plunged 48.7 percent in the first quarter of 1991 and revenue fell 4.5 percent.

title: Revlon Unit to Sell Shares
description: National Health Laboratories Inc., a unit of Revlon Inc., said yesterday that it planned to sell 40 million shares to the public, which would raise $700 million at yesterday's market price.

title: In the Creek Without a Paddle, Nicklaus Somehow Stays in Hunt
description: After two balls spun back down the grassy slope and plopped into Rae's Creek in front of the 12th green at Augusta National today, Jack Nicklaus eventually walked off with a quadruple-bogey 7 on the 155-yard par-3 hole, a disaster that suddenly dropped him to even par on the Masters leader boards.

title: Texas Acts to Shift School Money
description: The Texas Legislature approved a revision of the state's public school finance system Thursday night that is designed to redistribute property tax revenues from wealthy school districts to poor ones.

title: Post Refuses Ads for a Maxwell Paper
description: The New York Post refused to publish advertisements in yesterday's and today's issues announcing the debut on Monday of The Racing Times, a new daily horse-racing paper owned by Robert Maxwell, the owner of The Daily News.

title: Fleet New Follower of Kenyan Tradition
description: When he was 10 years old, Richard Chelimo would run back and forth to school every day from his home in the Rift Valley of western Kenya, the region that has produced many of the world's greatest distance runners. He had to run. There are no school buses in the rural hills of Kenya.

title: After Justices Act, Lab Monkeys Are Killed
description: Two monkeys that had been part of a decade-long animal-rights battle were put to death today, hours after the National Institutes of Health received Supreme Court clearance to put them to death and experiment on them.

title: Corrections
description: The Weekend Traffic Alert yesterday misstated the day of the Greek Independence Day Parade. As noted today in the Traffic Alert on page 25, the parade will take place tomorrow on Fifth Avenue from 62d to 79th Streets from 1 P.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Ethics Panel Clears Deputy Mayor Over Trip
description: The New York City Conflicts of Interest Board ruled yesterday that First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel's January vacation in the Florida condominium of Sid Davidoff, the city's top-paid lobbyist, did not break city ethics rules. But it warned Mr. Steisel to be more careful in the future.

title: Correction
description: A traffic alert yesterday about the Greek Independence Day Parade misstated the day of the event. It is tomorrow, and Fifth Avenue will be closed from 62d to 79th Streets from 1 P.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Review/Dance; Six Couples, All With a Story to Tell
description: It takes two to tango, to waltz, and to do the fox trot and a host of other ballroom dances. No wonder, then, that American Ballroom Theater calls one of its new works, "It Takes Two."

title: It's Time to Close More Bases
description: Every proposal to close a military base generates a storm of anguished protest. The affected community sees nothing but job loss and pain, and the affected politician sees conspiracy. But maintaining unneeded installations is pure waste when the armed forces are being cut by roughly one-quarter. The Pentagon's new list of bases targeted for closing is thorough and necessary.

title: Coping/With Taxicabs
description: City-dwellers and out-of-towners alike know all too well the frustration of being trapped in a filthy, uncomfortable taxicab with a driver who behaves rudely, drives recklessly, takes a roundabout route or overcharges.

title: Better Criminal Justice for Less Money!
description: This week, 2,181 new po lice officers the largest class of rookies in nine years -- graduated from New York City's Police Academy. Many will start spending a year on the beat as part of a new community policing program. Unless a handful of money-saving, common-sense improvements are made in the criminal justice system, this expanded effort to fight crime won't reach its full potential.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of construction activity, the Park Avenue Tunnel from 33d to 40th Street will be closed from 9:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. for two weeks beginning Monday. Motorists are advised to use Lexington and Third Avenues as alternate routes.

title: Guidepost; Paying Interest
description: A home equity line of credit is sure to be several points cheaper than other loans, thanks to two cuts in the prime lending rate this year and the elimination of tax deductions for interest on most other forms of credit. Home equity loans are generally tied to the prime lending rate, currently about 9 percent. Unlike interest on other loans, finance charges paid on home equity lines of credit are fully tax-deductible in most cases. Following is an example of costs on a $10,000, five-year loan. In each category the first interest rate given is the nationwide average; the second, in parentheses, is for New York State. For home equity loans, the two rates are similar. Type Loan Interest Rate Interest paid Home Equity 10.80% $2,986 New car 11.86% 3,307 (13.47%) (3,796) Personal 17.27% 4,999 (18.52%) (5,406) Credit card 18.89% 5,528 (19.34%) (5,677) Source: Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Jim Forsberg Is Dead; Printmaker Was 71
description: Jim Forsberg, a printmaker and painter, died on April 7 at his home in Provincetown, Mass. He was 71 years old.

title: Israelis Kill 4 in Raids in Lebanon
description: Israeli Air Force bombers struck bases belonging to two radical Palestinian guerrilla organizations in southern Lebanon today, killing four people, wounding nine and causing extensive damage to buildings, the police said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abitibi-Price Inc., Toronto, a maker of newsprint and specialty papers, said it would sell its Barber-Ellis/ Kaplan division, a maker of fine papers based in Seattle, to Spicers Paper Ltd. of Australia, for about $8.7 million in United States currency.

title: G. Russell Clark, 87; Oversaw Banking Under Rockefeller
description: G. Russell Clark, who as superintendent of banking under Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller paved the way for New York City banks to expand into the suburbs, died on Wednesday at Broward General Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 87 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: Despots Dwindle as Reform Alters Face of Africa
description: An image evoked by mentioning the leaders who rule Africa is often this: a young military officer, after shooting his way to power, promotes himself to general. He bans political parties except the one he controls. And there is a variant: color portraits of the president hang in every store and restaurant. He insists on being called "doctor," or the "guide" or the "No. 1 peasant." He is the richest man in the land. He does not run for election, ever.

title: Talks Set on Eastern Europe Aid
description: Eastern Europe's difficult transition from Communism to capitalism and the growing political and economic chaos in the Soviet Union are expected to be the focus when heads of state and finance ministers of more than 40 countries gather here this weekend.

title: Observer; Home Team Blues
description: It's painful having your illusions destroyed. This, I think, explains so much public fuming about baseball players making big money. People hate having illusions crushed by realities like the dull mercantile fact that the home team isn't the home team at all, but just a troupe of strolling players.

title: Westinghouse Net Off 53.3%
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its earnings dropped 53.3 percent in the first quarter as the recession hurt sales in its broadcasting, industrial and environmental divisions.

title: Kurdish Refugees From '88 Exodus Still Languishing in Turkish Camps
description: The barbed wire that once coiled around the refugee tent city is gone, and so are the soldiers who used to stand armed guard at the main entrance.

title: Park Service Is Halting A Project Killing Bison
description: The National Park Service on Thursday dropped its plan to shoot 25 pregnant bison in Yellowstone National Park this month for research into a livestock disease.

title: From East Europe to Mideast, Water Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Spotlight on Lowlife, Then ZAP!
description: As a courtesy to his many fans, the ponytailed action hero Steven Seagal not only attacks sleaze but also goes out of his way to examine it. His films, the latest of which is "Out for Justice," insist on offering an up-close-and-personal view of exactly the kinds of thugs, punks, pimps, hit men and hookers Mr. Seagal routinely finds himself up against in his sincere quest for law and order.

title: Giving Schools a Voice
description: For two decades, New York City's school decentralization law has offered the promise that community involvement could bring educational improvement. But too often that promise has been diminished by corruption, patronage and a sclerotic bureaucracy. A state commission, focusing on student needs, has now made some sensible suggestions to rationalize the system. The recommendations deserve prompt consideration by the State Legislature.

title: Music in Review; Metropolitan Opera
description: "La Clemenza di Tito" by Mozart

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Speedy Printing Centers Inc., Bloomfield Hills, Mich., named William D. McIntyre Jr. president and chief operating officer. * Cantisano Foods Inc., New York, makers of Francesco Rinaldi and Cantisano sauces, named John LiDestri president and Edward P. Salzano corporate executive vice president.

title: Ear-Piercing Skyscraper Whistles Up a Gag Order
description: A New York City judge has found Cityspire, a West 56th Street skyscraper, guilty of whistling and has sentenced it to shut up.

title: For Tax Cheats, Lump Sums Are Hardest to Swallow
description: When it comes to cheating on taxes, it's not just how much a person owes that counts, but when and how he has to pay it, a new Government study shows.

title: Puerto Rico Is No Haven for Tax Evaders
description: To the Editor:

title: Casino Union Yields Power as Its Leaders Accept Curbs
description: The Federal Government today took over the union that represents 22,000 workers in Atlantic City's casinos, hotels and restaurants after the union's leadership accepted voluntary "banishment" from office.

title: Kashmiri Militants Say They May Kill 2 Swedes
description: In an act of desperation intended to draw attention to human rights abuses in Kashmir, a militant organization is threatening to kill two abducted Swedish engineers on Saturday if Amnesty International and the United Nations Human Rights Commission do not investigate Kashmiri grievances.

title: SALES-TAX FUNDS DECLINE BY 8.4% IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Sales-tax collections in New York City dropped sharply over the winter, according to figures released yesterday, raising new alarms about the city's economy, and forcing city officials to scramble to close a new gap of several hundred million in the city's current budget.

title: 4 Ex-Policemen Found Guilty Of Oakland Project Brutality
description: A Federal jury today convicted four former police officers of beatings, theft and civil rights violations in what a prosecutor called a campaign of brutality against residents of an Oakland housing project.

title: Your Money; Buy-Sell Accords May Create Traps
description: Thousands of owners of closely held businesses who have planned for an orderly succession have unwittingly set a trap, says Robert Willens, senior vice president of Lehman Brothers. Fortunately it is a simple situation to rectify, he said, citing a recent court decision.

title: Letter: On Latin America; Free-Trade Zone Is in Chile's Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: From East Europe to Mideast, Water Matters; Israel and Jordan
description: To the Editor:

title: Investor's T.W.A. Plan
description: Kirk Kerkorian, the California investor, said today that he wanted 60 days to try to buy troubled Trans World Airlines with its London routes intact. Representatives of Mr. Kerkorian's Tracinda Corporation gave Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner a plan for expanding T.W.A.'s routes in the United States and overseas, replacing its aging fleet of aircraft with quieter, fuel-efficient planes and attracting new management. They asked Mr. Skinner to block American Airlines, which wants to buy TWA's London routes, from interfering in talks between Tracinda and TWA's current owner, Carl Icahn.

title: Natalie Schafer, 90, Actress Who Played In 'Gilligan's Island'
description: Natalie Schafer, an actress best known as the stranded millionaire's wife, Lovey, on the long-running television series "Gilligan's Island," died on Wednesday at her home. She was 90 years old.

title: An Abrupt Departure At Marshalls Stores
description: Francis H. Arnone abruptly resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of Marshalls, the 400-store discount retailing division of the Melville Corporation. Executives close to the company said he was forced to resign because a main competitor, T. J. Maxx, has outperformed Marshalls in recent months.

title: INSIDE
description: Limited Mideast Consensus

title: Census Count of Homeless Is Disputed
description: Disclaiming any intent to provide an accurate total, the Census Bureau said yesterday that it had counted 56,728 homeless people in all of New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut in a special count it took one night in March 1990.

title: About New York
description: Tomorrow, Ralph Eckelman will line up with some 1,000 runners for the 10-kilometer Helen Hayes Hospital Classic Race in West Haverstraw, N.Y. But first, he will have risen from the wheelchair he has used for most of his life and every day since 1973.

title: Dick Manning, 79, Composer and Lyricist
description: Dick Manning, a composer, lyricist and songwriter, died on Thursday in Marietta, Ga. He was 79 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Nets Edge Cavs, 104-103, on Last-Second Foul Shot
description: Derrick Coleman's free throw with one second remaining in the game gave the Nets a 104-103 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Rates for Blue Cross Rising in New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Insurance Commissioner has approved a 9.9 percent rate increase for 250,000 individual and 240,000 elderly subscribers of New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

title: Kurds Frozen in Place at Iran's Frontier
description: Down a vast treeless bowl, high in northern Iran's mountains, an endless river of Kurdish exiles now seems almost frozen in place, by icy weather that has killed scores, by gas shortages that have immobilized hundreds of cars and vans, by stiff military security that has made passage to warmth and food on the plateau below a slow and agonizing process.

title: Editors Debate Naming Rape Victims
description: Though almost none of the nation's newspapers identify rape victims, the wisdom of that practice is being questioned this week by newspaper editors after a nephew of Senator Edward M. Kennedy was accused of raping a woman in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: David Scribner, 84, Lawyer for Unions And in Rights Cases
description: David Scribner, a lawyer who specialized in civil liberties and labor law, died on Wednesday at the Kingsbridge Center of the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in the Bronx. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 Islanders Nominated for the Hall of Fame
description: Mike Bossy and Denis Potvin, two stars of the Islander teams that won four straight Stanley Cups, were nominated for the Hall of Fame yesterday. Bob Pulford, the former Toronto star, was also nominated.

title: Concert to Aid Tibet Fund
description: A concert to benefit the Tibet Fund, a human rights organization, is to take place at Cooper Union's Great Hall, Third Avenue at Seventh Street, on Thursday at 8 P.M. The concert, "Big Planet -- Little Drum," will feature the performance artist Meredith Monk, David Murray of the World Saxophone Quartet, the Tibetan Singing Bowl Ensemble and others. A $12 donation is requested. Information: (212) 353-4196.

title: New Jersey Moves to Take Over Paterson's Troubled Schools
description: New Jersey's Education Commissioner began legal proceedings today to allow the state to seize control of schools in Paterson, saying district officials are too divided and lack the leadership to manage a troubled system.

title: James Schuyler, Poet, Dies at 67; Won the Pulitzer Prize for 1980
description: James Schuyler, who won the 1981 Pulitzer Prize for poetry, died early yesterday morning at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "It's not how much we owe over all, but feeling that we have to pay it right now, out of pocket, that radically ups the odds of cheating." -- Dr. Russell Weigel, a psychologist, on income-tax cheating. [ 6:3. ]

title: Plan to Close Bases Is Met With Protests From Affected States
description: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney faced an expected wave of Congressional protest today as he formally announced his recommendation to close 31 major military installations.

title: Cary a 20-Game Winner? He Has Only 20 More to Go
description: He is supposed to be the Yankees' next 20-game winner, but tonight, in his season debut, Chuck Cary became another of their one-game losers. Welcome to the club.

title: 2 Claims Filed in Los Angeles Beating
description: In a move that could lead to early retirement and tax-free stress-related disability pensions, two police officers involved in the beating of a motorist here have submitted workers' compensation claims to the city.

title: Mets Succumb to Expos in 11 Innings as Their Last Grasp Misses
description: For the Mets, their errors of submission at the plate have gone largely unpunished. Good fortune, great individual moments, and in the case of the Phillies, at least one bad team have helped mask the ailment and limit the damage.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a budget and tax plan offered by Republicans in the Connecticut legislature incompletely described a proposal to tighten exemptions on corporate income from investments in other companies. The plan would require companies to report as taxable income 30 percent of the dividends paid by companies in which they own less than 20 percent of the stock.

title: Sharks Select Coach
description: George Kingston, a former assistant coach with the Minnesota North Stars, was named the first head coach of the N.H.L.'s expansion San Jose Sharks.

title: Advice From Campy
description: Hall of Fame catcher Roy Campanella, permanently paralyzed in a car crash 33 years ago, added his name yesterday to the list of well-wishers pulling for jockey Bill Shoemaker to recover from his paralysis.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHARLES THURMAN, the convicted wife-abuser whose victim successfully sued a police department, was released at 12:30 A.M. yesterday from the Somers Correctional Institution in Connecticut. "Officials wanted to avoid the crush of the news media," said WILLIAM WHEELER , the spokesman for the state Department of Correction.

title: U.S. MILITARY TAKES OVER RELIEF FOR KURDISH REFUGEES IN IRAQ
description: The United States began taking control Friday of the struggling relief effort for the Iraqi Kurds by outlining plans for the American military to feed 700,000 people a day and to set up temporary refugee settlements in northern Iraq, United States officials said.

title: Rangers' Youngsters May Offer Silver Lining
description: There were many large reasons for pessimism and a few small reasons for optimism for the Rangers today, a dozen hours after a 5-4 overtime loss to Washington put the Rangers a defeat away from elimination from the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Iran Leader Blames U.S. and Iraq For Deaths, Disaster and Refugees
description: The Iranian President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, denounced the West and Iraq today for creating a regional disaster and said "the United States will eventually be put on trial."

title: Boy, 11, Is Stabbed During Horseplay
description: An 11-year-old boy was stabbed last night while he and a friend another 11-year-old -- were horsing around after school in front of a brownstone at 246 Rogers Avenue, three blocks west of Prospect Park in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Another Indictment Returned Against Ex-University Chief
description: James B. Holderman, former president of the University of South Carolina, has been indicted on charges of evading state taxes by failing to report $25,000 in income.

title: Music in Review; John Brownlee Opera Theater
description: "The Taming of the Shrew" by Giannini Manhattan School of Music, Broadway and 122d Street

title: Patents; Four at G.E. Honored on Blood-Vessel Images
description: Four researchers at the General Electric Company this week shared the award for Inventor of the Year, presented by the Intellectual Property Owners Foundation in Washington.

title: Review/Music; A Painter's Persona and Artistry Brought to Life
description: Frida Kahlo, the Mexican painter who in recent years has attracted a following of almost cultish fanaticism, might seem an ideal subject for operatic, theatrical or filmic treatment, as the avid interest of all manner of producers attests. Whatever may yet come, the American Music Theater Festival's achievement with "Frida," a quasi-operatic piece of music theater that opened on Thursday night at the Plays and Players Theater here, should not be forgotten.

title: Stocks Rise After Report on Dip in Inflation
description: The stock market ended the week on a strong note yesterday, with three leading indexes posting records. Investors were heartened by the first decline in the Consumer Price Index in five years, which renewed hopes that the Federal Reserve would reduce interest rates soon.

title: Iacocca Compensation: $4.58 Million Last Year
description: If times are tough in the automotive industry, one would never know it from Lee A. Iacocca's latest compensation package.

title: U.S. Juggling Iraq Policy
description: Six weeks after allied armies ended the war against Iraq, the formal United Nations cease-fire in the Persian Gulf has done little to bring an end to the conflict between the Bush Administration and Saddam Hussein. And it already is clear that it will not end the suffering inside Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a bank robbery at the Forest Hills branch of the Astoria Federal Savings & Loan Association misstated the bank's address. It is 63-72 108th Street.

title: Labels That Tell the Testing Story
description: Opponents of animal testing are urging companies that do not use animals in testing new products to say so on product packages.

title: SportsLeisure; How to Take a Smart Approach to Marathons
description: With the Boston Marathon on Monday and other spring marathons coming up, many runners may feel left out of the excitement if they don't have a 26.2-mile event in their plans for this year. For those looking for a race, the natural choice is the New York City Marathon in November. You've got six months to train for it.

title: William C. Fine, Executive, 73
description: William C. Fine, retired chairman of the Sherwin-Williams Company, the paint manufacturer, died Tuesday at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and had lived for many years before retirement in Rocky River, Ohio.

title: Henderson Hobbled
description: After failing Wednesday and Thursday to tie Lou Brock's record of 938 career steals, Rickey Henderson missed last night's game with a strained muscle in his left calf. Manager Tony La Russa said it was doubtful Henderson would play in any games of the Oakland Athletics' three-game series against the Seattle Mariners.

title: Church as Landmark: Battle Rejoined
description: A debate that blends lofty questions of religious freedom and cultural heritage with nuts-and-bolts worries about the cost of replacing stained-glass windows and feeding the poor is bedeviling New York City, and pitting some powerful political forces against one another.

title: Bridge
description: The number of membership clubs in New York City that include bridge among a wide range of activities has been declining in recent years, but one club bucked the trend this week. The Town Club at 9 East 86th Street instituted a program of bridge activities, hosted by Jack Greenberg, that includes a Friday night duplicate game.

title: Financial Executive Is Suspended
description: Consumers Union, publisher of Consumer Reports, said yesterday that it had suspended its chief financial officer, saying he had been involved in a kickback scheme.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Jack Valenti, head of the Motion Picture Association of America, misstated the White House response to a lobbying effort this year by representatives of Mr. Valenti, who was seeking to have the Administration change its annual Economic Report. Mr. Valenti had protested that the report favored his opponents, the television networks, in a dispute over the rights to sell television reruns. The White House response was to issue a public statement saying that the matter would be decided by the Federal Communications Commission. It did not change the report.

title: Pay Welfare for Work?
description: New York City's Commissioner of Social Services, Cesar Perales, proposes a bold plan that offers an alluring prospect to big cities all over the country: Use welfare money to move people onto payrolls. The idea is to pay up to 90 percent of the welfare grant to a private employer willing to hire a long-term welfare recipient.

title: 'Miss Julie' to Open Ingmar Bergman Series
description: A new production of Strindberg's "Miss Julie" will open a series of three plays directed by Ingmar Bergman to be presented by the Royal Dramatic Theater of Sweden in June at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (30 Lafayette Avenue, in the Fort Greene section). Lena Olin and Peter Stormare will star in the play, which replaces the previously announced "Madame de Sade." Performances are June 10, 11 and 12.

title: As a Guide For Ships, the Last of a Breed
description: In a city seething with change, Frank P. Schubert is a beacon. For 31 years, the part of New York that sailors saw first, and the last bit they glimpsed over the horizon long after they shipped out, has been the red flash of Mr. Schubert's lighthouse blinking at the tip of Coney Island.

title: Senate Seen Delaying Any Action on Insurers
description: The collapse of the Executive Life Corporation, the largest failure yet of an insurer, will prod the House to try to impose Federal regulations on the insurance industry, lawmakers and their aides said today. But the Senate is not likely to take any action quickly, with the result that Federal regulation of insurers is likely to be years away.

title: Review/Theater; Coming of Age With Help From a Wise Troublemaker
description: Growing up in the late 1950's in St. Louis, Betsey Brown is a deeply sensitive child of a black middle class committed to affirming its cultural roots. Ntozake Shange's searcher -- who is, one assumes, the author's surrogate -- has had a long history, from a 1974 story through an eponymous novel and on to the musical "Betsey Brown," now playing at the McCarter Theater. After several workshops and an earlier regional production, the show is still evolving, but the ingredients are there to make it a musical with something relevant to say about the durability of traditional values. The story is far closer in spirit to "The Member of the Wedding" than it is to Ms. Shange's own outspoken "For Colored Girls."

title: Richard M. Rosen, 55, A Former Lindsay Aide
description: Richard M. Rosen, a New York lawyer who was assistant for cultural affairs in John V. Lindsay's first administration, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 55 years old.

title: Education Chief Challenges Rule On Campus Mix
description: Education Secretary Lamar Alexander has delayed reauthorizing an important regional accrediting association for colleges and universities until he can review its new emphasis on cultural diversity in evaluating the institutions.

title: Franco Working Overtime
description: John Franco expects a lot of work. He just didn't expect his season to begin quite like this.

title: Parrott and Mozart
description: Andrew Parrott is to conduct the Classical Band in an all-Mozart program that includes the Overture to "La Clemenza di Tito," the "Gran Partita" Wind Serenade, the "Serenata Notturna," and Symphony No. 25 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art at 8 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 570-3945.

title: Brawling Blues Get to Play On
description: Adam Oates scored his first career hat trick and added two assists as the St. Louis Blues routed the Detroit Red Wings, 6-1, in a fight-filled game last night to avoid elimination in their opening-round National Hockey League playoff series.

title: More Restaurants Are Just Saying No to American Express
description: Consumers across the country are leaving home without their American Express cards because many restaurants are no longer accepting them. The fees for the card, restaurateurs say, are too high.

title: Paralysis Over Budget in Albany
description: State budget negotiations became increasingly paralyzed today as the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, suggested that so little progress was being made in talks with the Assembly and the Governor that the Senate might pass its own budget.

title: Patents; 'Daddy-Longlegs' Robot for Exploration of Mars
description: Researchers at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh patented a robot this week that resembles a daddy-longlegs and was designed to explore the rugged landscape of Mars. The robot was developed with financing from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: A. Goodwin Cooke, 86, A Lawyer and Sailor
description: A. Goodwin Cooke, a retired lawyer and yachtsman who served as president of the Destroyer Escort Captains Organization, died on Thursday at Whitney Center, a retirement community in Hamden, Conn. He was 86 years old and had moved to Whitney Center from Branford, Conn., about five years ago

title: Shift in Tobacco Sales Hurting RJR Nabisco
description: RJR Nabisco, which has won the confidence of investors who are eagerly snapping up its stock and cheers from Wall Street for the company's chairman, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., has fundamental problems in its tobacco business.

title: Doctor Not Charged in Patient's Suicide
description: No charges will be brought against a doctor who wrote in a medical journal that he had prescribed tranquilizers for a cancer patient so she could kill herself, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Consumer Prices Post 0.1% Drop
description: Consumer prices edged down in March, for the first monthly decline since early 1986, the Government reported today.

title: Hasbro Extends Tonka Bid Again
description: Hasbro Inc., which is trying to complete its planned $470 million acquisition of the Tonka Corporation, has again extended its deadline for Tonka's bondholders to tender their securities, from 7 P.M. today until 7 P.M. on Monday. The toy manufacturers said in a joint announcement that they were negotiating with each other and with Tonka's bondholders to restructure the buyout to make it more attractive to the investors, who have balked at Hasbro's offer.

title: How a Theological Issue Led to a Novel on Sex
description: The book is called "Damage." It's a first novel, a trim little volume, 198 smallish pages that tell a tale of sexual obsession. An upper-crust British Member of Parliament, a decent, loyal and devoted but passionless family man, develops a very tragic, very fatal attraction for a mysterious woman in black, his son's fiancee, who creates sexual disaster wherever she goes.

title: Baker May Have Consensus on Arab-Israeli Conference, but Not Its Agenda
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d ended his latest Middle East peace-making swing today with an apparent consensus for an Arab-Israeli conference, but with differences still unresolved on what would be discussed at such a meeting.

title: Housing Construction Starts Without Fanfare in Yonkers
description: The grinding of construction equipment cutting through the asphalt parking lot opposite Yonkers Raceway attracted little attention at first, except for a Federal agent in one parked car, plainclothes police officers in another and a private security officer in a third.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DANIEL SCHORR and RICHARD M. NIXON met socially for the first time at a private, off-the-record dinner Wednesday in Washington.

title: Patents; A Simpler Room Cooler: Air Over Ice
description: It seems like a throwback to the days before Thomas Edison, but a New Jersey company obtained a patent this week on a room air-conditioner that blows air over ice.

title: Neil Bush Seeking Job
description: President Bush's 36-year-old son Neil has left his second oil company and is in the market for a new job. Neil Bush resigned from the Apex Energy Company of Denver on April 1, associates said this week. "He's looking for a new job," said Donald Dwight, a spokesman for the Wood River Capital Corporation. "He's selling his house." Wood River and a subsidiary invested $2.3 million to start Apex, Neil Bush's second oil-exploration venture.

title: John Humpstone, 86, Real Estate Executive
description: John H. Humpstone, a real estate executive and former Foreign Service official, died yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 86 years old.

title: Lavish Memphis Art Show, Nonstop From Leningrad
description: In Memphis, they call her "Miss Kate." Known to the rest of the world as Catherine the Great, Empress of Russia in the 18th century, she is the star of an elaborate show of some 300 esthetic and historical objects -- paintings, tapestries, jewelry, costumes and furniture among them -- that comes to Memphis direct from the Hermitage museum in Leningrad. The show opened on Wednesday in the Cook Convention Center in Memphis.

title: Long-Term Rates Decline Sharply
description: Bond prices surged and long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday, as traders bought securities in the wake of positive evidence that the recession is finally beginning to have an impact on inflation.

title: Square D Asks Fed to Bar French Bid
