description: The Square D Company, which is seeking to block a hostile $1.9 billion takeover attempt by Schneider S.A. of France, asked the Federal Reserve to decide whether the bid violated United States banking laws. Square D has told the Fed's board of governors that the majority owner of Schneider's parent company is a consortium of six French financial institutions, including Banque Paribas and Societe Generale.

title: At City Hall, a Tax Form Is Released
description: Taxpayer 145-20-0976's Form 1040 shows a conservative investor with an above-average income who is sparing in his charitable contributions and lives mortgage-free in one of Manhattan's upscale neighborhoods. He also works as mayor of New York.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Opening Day, a Private Ritual
description: The trouble with springtime in Colorado is that there's no opening day of fishing season. That's because there's no closing day, no closed season at all, in fact. In Colorado, you can fish on any day of the year you can stand to be outside. It's a very civilized arrangement and I wouldn't have it any other way, but it does rob fishermen of one of the sport's great rituals.

title: The Band Plays On
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Fashion; Geoffrey Beene at the Top of His Form
description: Each fashion season, Geoffrey Beene sets out, pinning and shaping, to make the best dress in the world. Each time he comes closer to achieving his aim. His show yesterday in the auditorium of the Equitable Building was the best of his work so far. It also was by far the best of the New York fall openings, and in terms of creativity, of the European shows, too.

title: G.E. and Toshiba in Appliance Deal
description: The General Electric Company and the Toshiba Corporation agreed to work together to expand sales of G.E. appliances in Asia. The imported products, mainly large refrigerators and European-produced appliances, will be distributed by Toshiba in Japan, and Toshiba will provide after-sales services.

title: Kremlin Orders Republics To Stop Withholding Goods
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued a decree today to try to prevent economic chaos caused by republics withholding deliveries to other parts of the country, the official Tass press agency reported.

title: Zang Toi's Shining Suits; Isabel Toledo's Novel Cuts
description: Zang Toi is a talented young designer who knows his craft but has yet to learn restraint. His jackets and skirts are impeccably cut, his choice of colors are fresh and his fabrics are interesting. But, when he put on his first formal show yesterday, he piled on the decorations, nearly drowning the clothes in accessories.

title: Fredson Bowers, 85, a specialist In Bibliography and Manuscripts
description: Fredson Bowers, a specialist in manuscript editing and bibliography, died in his sleep on Thursday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 85 years old.

title: A Spy Novel's Boosters, It Seems, Aren't
description: On Wednesday, Simon & Schuster announced it had bought a novel for $920,000, one of the largest amounts ever paid for a first novel, in part on the strength of endorsements from the writers John le Carre and Joseph Wambaugh. Yesterday, Mr. le Carre and Mr. Wambaugh denied they had ever seen or heard of the book, "Just Killing Time."

title: REFUGEES IN SOUTH BEG ARMY TO STAY
description: More than 100 Iraqis held a peaceful demonstration at the main refugee camp here today, appealing to American forces to stay in southern Iraq.

title: As Bases Are Closed, Some Towns Transform Setback Into Advantage
description: What happened to the 86 military installations that the Department of Defense planned to close or scale back in 1988 after a bruising battle with Congress over how to reduce military costs?

title: Safe Havens Aren't Enough
description: Not since the Cambodian holocaust under Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge has the West so callously stood by while a brutal dictator's forces wiped out an innocent people. Since Saddam Hussein insists on violating norms of civilization, the gulf war coalition partners should modify their goals to include his ouster and internal autonomy for the Kurds. Toward that end, even though the formal cease-fire began Thursday, we should use air strikes to destroy all Iraqi units that have been attacking Kurdish civilians.

title: Devils at Loss for Words to Describe Terreri's Play
description: The Devils have just about exhausted their adjectives to describe the way Chris Terreri has been tending goal for them in the first-round playoff series against the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Booz, Allen & Hamilton Picks New Chief Executive
description: William F. Stasior, 50, has been elected chairman and chief executive of Booz, Allen & Hamilton, the consulting firm. Mr. Stasior, the firm's president and chief operating officer, succeeds R. Michael McCullough, who will become a senior partner.

title: Music in Review; Humberto Quagliata
description: Pianist St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street

title: Nemuro Journal; Kaese! Japanese Refugees Fight to Reclaim Islands
description: Mitsuo Yanami still remembers well the day in early September 1945, hours after Japan's unconditional surrender aboard the battleship Missouri, when Soviet soldiers overran the tiny island where he lived, just north of here in the frigid northern Pacific.

title: Washington Talk; Heeding the Grass Roots In Judicial Nominations
description: President Bush's first defeat on a judicial nomination came this week, when the Senate Judiciary Committee voted to reject Kenneth L. Ryskamp for an important appeals court post. But the issue may have been decidd a week before, in a Thursday meeting in a 17th-floor suite in downtown Miami.

title: Literacy Day? Read Cuomo's Lips
description: I recently received a letter from Richard C. Wade, chairman of Gov. Mario Cuomo's Commission on Libraries. In it, Mr. Wade invited me, as a member of "the community of arts and letters," to participate in Literacy Day on Wednesday. Mr. Wade described this event, established last year by the Governor, as "a spring day to celibrate [sic] the importance and joy of reading and writing."

title: Sports Saturday
description: The Masters: Tom Watson and Jack Nicklaus, paired together, thrill the gallery at Augusta National. And Watson winds up in the lead.

title: Sunscreens That Won't Wash Away
description: With the latest bad news about the thinning of the ozone layer and the increased threat of skin cancer, everyone should at least think about using a sunscreen every day. No one needs it more than those who work or play in the sun.

title: Student Opera
description: Vittorio Giannini's 1952 opera "Taming of the Shrew" is to be performed at the Manhattan School of Music, Broadway at 122d Street, at at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow. The production is to be directed by Johnathon Pape and conducted by David Gilbert, with sets and costumes by John Claassen. The performers are students in the school's opera department. Tickets are $10 and $15. Information: (212) 749-2802, extension 540 or 541.

title: In the Nation; A Time to Move
description: The central proposition of the new National Academy of Sciences report on global warming is that it's time to get a move on. Something has to be done, and the sooner the better.

title: CHRONICLE
description: YANG SHANGKUN, the President of China, is in a Beijing hospital, Reuters reported yesterday. RABBIE NAMALIU, the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, said at a news conference in Beijing that his visit with the Chinese President had been canceled because Mr. Yang, 84 years old, was ill. He said he did not know the nature or severity of the illness.

title: Germans Sigh and Say, 'Charge It'
description: After decades of scorning credit cards as a plastic plague threatening Germany's economic health, the nation's banks are discovering virtue in cashless consumerism.

title: Kevin Peter Hall, Actor, 35
description: Kevin Peter Hall, the 7-foot-2-inch star of the movie and the television series "Harry and the Hendersons," died on Wednesday of pneumonia. He was 35 years old.

title: Let No One Be Confused Anymore About Famous Ray's Pizza
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on March 21 about the International Design Center in Long Island City referred incompletely to the history of International Contract Furnishings, a furniture manufacturer. It was founded jointly by Samuel I. Friedman and Hal H. Stearns.

title: Microsoft Says F.T.C. Has Expanded Inquiry
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that the Federal Trade Commission had expanded its investigation of the competitive practices of the software company.

title:
BASEBALL;
Fans Chant 'Darryl, Darryl,' But Strawberry's Bat Is Silent
description: When Darryl Strawberry jogged out to take his position for the first time in his hometown wearing a Dodger uniform today, the fans in the right-field seats stood, wildly waving their arms, and cheering, "Darryl, Darryl." Not even former President Ronald Reagan drew such enthusiasm when he threw out the ceremonial first ball.

title: Review/Pop; The Poetry Of Songs From Canada
description: Canada, the country that produced Joni Mitchell, Leonard Cohen, Neil Young, Gordon Lightfoot and Bruce Cockburn, enjoys a more robust acoustic songwriting tradition than the United States, where such music fell out of fashion after the mid-1970's. Just how healthy that tradition remains in Canada was suggested by a tour that brought four respected Canadian songwriters to the Bottom Line on Tuesday evening.

title: Patents; Speaker-Phone Allows a Listener to Interrupt
description: Researchers at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories obtained a patent this week on telephone speaker-phones that allow people to carry on more normal conversations.

title: Prom's Alcohol Test Canceled
description: A high school in northern Minnesota has canceled plans to require students attending its prom on April 20 to take breath tests for alcohol. Don Coburn, principal of Pine River-Backus High School, said Thursday he had decided to scrap the plan, in part because of the attention it received. He also said a lawyer for the Minnesota Association for Secondary School Principals had told him that mandatory alcohol testing would infringe on students' constitutional rights.

title: Sports of The Times; Journey of an Old Miler
description: One of the first and most vigorous of the Supreme Court justices to champion the plaintiffs' cause in Brown v. Board of Education was a former miler and long-distance runner for the 1913 and 1914 Yakima (Wash.) High School track team, and one who never ran better than third in a race. He was fortunate to run at all, because he had been stricken with polio as a child and there had been doubt whether he would even walk again.

title: Tobacco Ads Shifted From Wells, Rich
description: Wells, Rich, Greene has lost its protracted battle to hang onto the estimated $20 million Benson & Hedges advertising business, one of the centerpiece accounts for the agency, which also works with I.B.M. and Hertz.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: European Group Pressing Its Offer for Executive Life
description: A day after California regulators seized the Executive Life Insurance Company, a European consortium pressed ahead today with its offer to acquire the troubled insurer while policyholders and other customers tried to assess their risk of losses.

title: Underwriters Seal Sets High Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers in Case of Kennedy Nephew Clash Over Conduct of Investigators
description: Two weeks after the reported rape at the Kennedy estate here, lawyers for the accuser and the accused clashed today over the conduct of private detectives hired by the Kennedy family to investigate the background of the woman.

title: Inventories Down 0.2%; Sales Rise
description: Stocks of unsold goods held by businesses fell in February while sales rose, the Commerce Department said today, in a sign that inventories were being held tightly in check.

title: Beliefs
description: The group was discussing the recent telecast of an exorcism and the Roman Catholic priest who arranged that broadcast. "I am not a religious person," someone said, "but I admire this priest. At least he doesn't believe in pick-and-choose religion."

title: At Fort Dix, 4,000 Are Urged to 'Hang in There'
description: Maj. Gen. James W. Wurman asked some 4,000 civilian employees at Fort Dix to "hang in there" as he announced major cutbacks today at the sprawling 74-year-old training center where some 5 million recruits have had their heads shaved and first stepped onto a drill field since World War I.

title: Masters Course Is Elementary for Surging Watson
description: On a magical day in which golf's greatest names were also golf's greatest players, Tom Watson seized the lead at the halfway mark of the Masters today to set up what could become one of the classic finishes in the tournament's 55-year history.

title: Music in Review; Thomas Zehetmair
description: Violinist Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Review/Music; Philharmonic's Accent on Estonia: Jarvi Conducts Raats
description: Something surprising happened at the New York Philharmonic concert on Thursday evening: everything went off exactly as scheduled. For a change, in a season that must be setting records for cancellations, program changes and other disruptions, stability reigned. Neeme Jarvi, the Estonian-born conductor who conducted the Philharmonic 11 years ago after emigrating to the United States, returned for the first time since then. Though far from a colorful or obviously galvanic leader, he left a good impression this time as a solid musical citizen who was willing to let a score speak for itself.

title: Opportunistic Jackson Moves Knicks Closer to Overtaking Pacers
description: Mark Jackson came alive at an opportune time.

title: Henry Glover, 69, Recording Official
description: Henry Glover, a producer, arranger and talent scout for King Records, died in St. Albans, Queens, on Sunday. He was 69 years old.

title: India Committee Announces 3-Day National Voting Plan
description: India's Election Commission announced today that general elections for a new national Parliament will be spread over three days next month -- May 20, 23 and 26 -- but that balloting would not be held simultaneously in the insurgency-shaken states of Assam, Punjab, and Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Review/Dance; The Sphinx Speaks In Pictures
description: The performance that the Message From the Sphinx Dance Company presented on Sunday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio was evidence that, although dance must be watched, its basic appeal is to the kinesthetic, not the visual, sense. Julia Watson Stewart, the company's director and choreographer, devised strange stage pictures. But she failed to get them moving.

title: ResultsPlus
description: TENNIS Fendick Stuns Garrison

title: From East Europe to Mideast, Water Matters; Egypt and the Nile
description: To the Editor:

title: Let No One Be Confused Anymore About Famous Ray's Pizza; 'Which Mario?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
Michele DeMusis To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. DeMusis of New Haven have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Michele Rose DeMusis, and John Timothy Campbell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Campbell of Kensington, Conn.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My home was built in 1965 and has custom-made birch kitchen cabinets that were put in at the time. They now look very bad, but I do not have a lot to spend. Should I refinish the cabinets or install new ones?

title: A TALE OF TWO CITIES
description: APRIL HAS BECOME THE MONTH OF FURNITURE fairs on both sides of the Atlantic. In the United States, the International Market, the country's largest to-the-trade event, opens in High Point, N.C., on Thursday and runs through April 26. Thousands of buyers and merchandise managers come to see new designs they might buy for stores this fall.

title: Scientists Tie Breast Implant to Cancer
description: Scientists for the Food and Drug Administration have determined that a kind of cosmetic breast implant that hundreds of thousands of American women have received over the last two decades breaks down in the body to produce a substance that has been shown to cause cancer in laboratory animals.

title: M. J. Landini Jr. To Wed Miss Ong
description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Ong of Hudson, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Katherine Caine Ong, to Michael John Landini Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Landini of Daytona Beach, Fla. A July wedding is planned.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 17 about the housing market in White Plains misstated the financial status of the two-building Westage Towers condominium. In a letter dated March 22, Mary Miller, president of the Westage Towers West board of managers, said her condominium was sold out and financially sound.

title: Finding Good Clothes at Good Prices: She Knows, and She's Ready to Tell
description: Elysa Lazar is a walking testament to the value of her own advice. Her black jacket came from a Basco sample sale; her black shirt, from Donna Karan. She picked up the khaki trench coat at a Hugo Boss sale. Only her crepe blouse was bought for full price in a traditional store. "Emporio Armani is my one weakness when it comes to retail," she said.

title: Technology; A Way to Hear Stock Quotes While Watching Cartoons
description: There is more to stereo television sets than enhanced sound. Even though 24 percent of all American households own stereo TV's and VCR's, few viewers realize their equipment enables them not only to hear better, but also to hear more programs.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: INTERVIEWING MATISSE Or the Woman Who Died Standing Up. By Lily Tuck. Knopf, $18.

title: The Region; AIDS Protesters Test State Needle Laws
description: TWO trials that opened last Monday on the East and West Coasts could mark a turning point in the debate over how to prevent AIDS among drug users, their sex partners and their unborn babies. The issue at stake in New York City and Redwood City, Calif., is whether the threat of AIDS justifies giving away clean needles in violation of state laws.

title: Chess
description: The over-30 crowd holds the line in Spain despite Ivanchuk's winning the tournament.

title: Dollar Becalmed, Pending Fed Action
TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title: Mere-and-Pere Restaurants
description: AS intense as the summer's sun, as penetrating as the mistral winds that sweep down the Rhone Valley, the cuisine of Provence is direct and straightforward. Likewise, many of the region's most authentic restaurants have strong, specific identities, as if to match a vibrant cuisine that revolves around fruity olive oil and fragrant black truffles, pungent fresh garlic and long-simmering stews known as daubes. Even as you pronounce certain dishes, your tongue sort of snaps to attention -- tapenade, pistou, aioli, picodon -- as if to say, this isn't a place for timid palates.

title: The New Saturn: Lustre Under the Skin
description: It has taken a very long time, but Saturn is finally here. Saturn, the ultimate answer from General Motors to all those pesky gnats from Japan.

title: A Personal Account Of Port-Wine Stain
description: When I read the article on the new method of treating extreme birthmarks, I was instantly carried back 41 years to 1949. Ironically enough, our firstborn son was born on the date of the article, March 24. His extensive hemangoma -- which spread over the entire right half of his face, from the forehead to the neck and around to the back of his head -- did not show up until 10 days after this birth. I, too, lived through the nightmare of people looking onto the baby carriage and quickly pulling away in horror -- startled at what they saw.

title: European Flavor, Canadian Setting
description: MOST visitors to Toronto, Canada's largest city, drive east from the airport to the city's downtown. But if you drive west, through the rolling Ontario countryside, past the primeval outcropping of the Niagara escarpment, you will -- 45 minutes later -- reach the village of Blair.

title: Data Update
Iraq Trying to Persuade Refugees to Return
description: Iraq, its army in firm control of its northeastern provinces after putting down a Kurdish revolt, is trying to coax hundreds of thousands of refugees down from the mountains where they fled in fear of reprisals.

title: On the Street; The Handbag to Have
description: The past is the future when it comes to this spring's fashionable handbag. It costs $2,000 to $10,000, and there's a six-month wait to get one. The bag, the original Hermes Kelly style from the late 1940's, is a scaled-down version of a saddlebag named after Grace Kelly. This roomy, constructed, box-shaped bag with its belt closing and tiny padlock is the rage among fashionable women in New York and Paris. Its popularity threatens the long reign of the quilted, gold-chained Chanel bag, which had the highest status in the 80's. The Kelly bags are made in materials ranging from calfskin (starting price $2,000) to fine-grained alligator skin ($10,000). In between are pigskin models, distinctive ostrich-skin bags and lizard bags. For the impatient, variations on the original Kelly bag are being made by manufacturers and fashion designers like Calvin Klein.

title: Campus Life: Iowa; Audit Discovers Money Is Missing At Program Office
description: A tally of University of Iowa accounts conducted by the Iowa State Auditors Office last month found more than $5,000 missing from the Office of Campus Programs and University Activities.

title: Correction
description: An obituary last Sunday about a French fashion photographer rendered his name incorrectly. He was Guy Bourdin.

title: Making a Difference; Pepsi Takes On Coke at the Fountainhead
description: For years, Pepsi-Cola has been making great strides in selling its soft drinks in supermarkets. Not so in the fountain business, where Coca-Cola still dominates the little gurgling machines that spew out syrup and fizzy water in places like McDonald's and Denny's.

title: We Can Help Kurds Without Sending Troops; Scale Down Parade
description: To the Editor:

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: CHRISTOPHER GEORGE;
War's Impact on Baghdad's Children
description: AFTER the Persian Gulf war ended, a team of workers from Save the Children, a humanitarian aid organization based in Westport, and other international organizations visited Iraq to assess the needs of children and other civilians who suffered as a result of the bombing and the war's aftermath.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CALIFORNIA'S DAUGHTER Gertrude Atherton and Her Times.By Emily Wortis Leider.Stanford University, $24.95.

title: Flu Risk May Increase in 1992, Agency Says
description: Parts of the United States saw an increase in influenza at the end of an otherwise mild winter this year, and the flu types involved could indicate that next year will be more severe, Federal health officials say.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SOVIET ACROBATS

title: Taming Hollywood's Spending Monster
description: Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer were arguably Hollywood's hottest production team during the late 1980's, with a string of hits for Paramount Pictures that included "Top Gun" and the two "Beverly Hills Cop" films. Early last year, they were rewarded by Paramount with a new five-year contract that was lucrative even by the bloated standards of the movie business. But in November, barely 10 months later, the studio severed its ties to the pair.

title: Where Are the Recent Classics?
description: Here is a plain question, posed in hopes that close followers of the contemporary music scene will answer it for me, whether plainly or fancifully. Why has so little music composed since 1950 entered the repertory? I suppose we need a definition with which most reasonable people would agree. By repertory must be meant a select body of works, popular and otherwise, that may be heard with regularity in the world's concert halls, recital rooms or opera houses. These works have risen to the repertory level because they have been particularly admired by musicians, taken to the heart by a sizable public, or both.

title: Siobhan Alden, Physician, Wed
description: Dr. Siobhan Mary Alden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Alden of Potomac, Md., and Warsaw, was married yesterday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., to Kevin Stephen Corbett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Corbett of Pelham, N.Y. The Rev. Dennis P. Keane performed the ceremony.

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title: Patti Abrams Marries Alan Howard on L.I.
description: Patti Jane Abrams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin J. Abrams of Old Westbury, L.I., was married in Lake Success, L.I., last night to Alan Bruce Howard, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bertram E. Howard of South Dartmouth, Mass. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadow Country Club.

title: Wall Street; The Wallflowers of Wall Street
description: Whatever it signified to Robert Frost, the less-traveled road is not Wall Street's idea of a good time.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Tougher Technical for High Schools
description: High school basketball players will pay a heavier penalty for technical fouls next season, the national rule-making body for school play in the sport announced this week.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My home was built in 1965 and has custom-made birch kitchen cabinets that were put in at the time. They now look very bad, but I do not have a lot to spend. Should I refinish the cabinets or install new ones?

title: Travel Advisory; Bankrupt, Midway Still Operating
description: Midway Airlines, the third airline in four months to file for protection from creditors under Federal Bankruptcy Code, is reporting no downturn in passengers and no cancellations of flights.

title: Stephanie Goldman Weds A. A. Pittel; Cindy Goldman Weds Mark Blotner
description: Stephanie Jill Goldman and Cindy Alyce Goldman, the daughters of Lorraine Goldman and Allan Goldman, both of New York, were married in a double ceremony last evening at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Growing Gunnera

title: Tech Notes; Secondary Audio's Visual Side
description: When a television is on, 525 lines running from one side of the screen to the other are scanned every one-sixtieth of a second -- too fast to be detected by the human eye. Even at a slower speed, 21 of the lines would not be visible at all, because the 525 lines are too numerous to fit across TV screens.

title: New Albanian Parliament Facing Boycott
description: The opposition said today that it would boycott Albania's first multiparty Parliament in more than six decades unless the Communist Government fixed blame for the slaying of four members of one of the opposition parties.

title: Cathedral Plan Shakes Up Schools
description: FOR more than 100 years, the spire of the Cathedral of the Incarnation has cast a stately calm over Garden City, America's first cathedral town. Now the calm is being shaken.

title: The World; When Empires Fall, Not Everyone Emerges With a State of His Own
description: VICTORY in the war against Iraq did not produce the allies' finest hour. The tragic spectacle of over a million Kurdish refugees fleeing cruel retribution from Saddam Hussein underlined not only the fundamental ambivalence of allied war aims, but also the widespread indifference the world has long shown to the principle of self-determination.

title: JAPAN RETREATING ON PROMISED LOANS
description: Angry over agreements that allow Poland and Egypt to escape foreign debt obligations, Japanese officials say the Government will not provide loans it had promised to those nations and will refuse new loans to other countries that seek debt forgiveness.

title: Headliners; Sent Back
description: President Bush's record on judicial nominations slipped to 76 and 1 last week. The Senate Judiciary Committee rejected Mr. Bush's 77th nominee for the Federal bench, Kenneth L. Ryskamp, because of lingering questions about his sensitivity to minorities. Mr. Ryskamp, who has been a Federal District Court judge in Miami since 1986, was up for elevation to the Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta, which hears many civil rights cases. In rejecting him for the post -- the vote, along party lines, was 8 to 6 -- Democrats on the panel cited his continuing membership in a country club that excludes blacks and Jews. They also noted that several of his civil rights rulings had been reversed on appeal. One of the Democrats, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., said he had been prepared to approve Judge Ryskamp -- as he had every other Bush nominee -- but that the judge's answers to the panel's question caused him to change his mind. "Kenneth Ryskamp, regretfully, is one that I cannot support," he said.

title: THE MAUVE-ING OF AMERICA
description: I am one of Martha's and Alexandra's avid fans. I do not consider myself dull. I enjoy putting into practice -- and they tell us how -- those of their ideas that suit my modest life style. One need not be famous or wealthy to enjoy a beautiful home, with handcrafted objects and foods. Feathering one's nest with beauty is very comforting in our uncertain world. MARIA S. CAREY Centereach, L.I.

title: Clemens Blanks Cleveland for His 26th Career Shutout
description: Roger Clemens continued his dominance of Cleveland with a three-hitter for his 26th career shutout as Boston ended its losing streak at three games by beating the Indians.

title: For Best Taste, Use Fresh Cornish Hens
description: ONE of the funniest food scenes I have seen took place in a Czechoslovak film I saw many years ago, "Intimate Lightning." At a family celebration in a small village the head of the household was called upon to carve a scrawny roast chicken for eight hungry guests. A silence fell over the table as he tried, with great dignity, to divide the bird into equal portions. Nobody was satisfied.

title: Thousands Heed Call: 'Swing Your Partner'
description: JOHN NICHOLSON never gave square dancing a second thought, he said, until the evening seven years ago, when he stopped in, on a whim, at a dance sponsored by the Rocking Roosters in Newtown.

title: Review/Fashion; Hopping on the Trends But Avoiding the Traps
description: For a fix on the trends of any season, just look to Adrienne Vittadini. She can always be relied on to interpret them in a way that makes them accessible to women who don't want to be fashion victims.

title: The War Between the Binghams
description: THE PATRIARCH

title: Cheryl Rizzi, an Investment Banker, Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Rizzi of Potomac, Md., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Cheryl Lynne Rizzi and Michael Gerard Barrett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher S. Barrett of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Gypsy Moths Are Finding the State Less Hospitable
description: THEY'RE on their way. Gypsy moths, those inch-long hairy creatures whose insatiable appetite for leaves has sometimes left Connecticut trees bare in mid-summer, will be visiting again this year.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Washington;
Gallic Hotelier In U.S. Debut
description: PULLMAN International Hotels of France is entering the North American market with a $6 million renovation of the historic Highland Hotel here.

title:
DANCE;
Capturing the Beauty In Ballet of Goddesses
description: WHY did Dermot Burke invite an instructor from the University of Iowa to teach "melting" to his dancers in February? The answer lies in Mr. Burke's master plan for the Princeton Ballet, which involves the acquisition of repertorial jewels by stellar choreographers to challenge both dancers and audiences.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Baton Rouge; Federal Agency Rescues Catfish
description: CATFISH TOWN, a failed festival marketplace downtown, has been converted to an office complex with the Resolution Trust Corporation as its major tenant.

title: Style Makers; Charlotte Moss, Interior Designer
description: The interior of Charlotte Moss & Company looks more like a cluttered English home than a place of business. And that's the idea. "People want to see things in their context," Ms. Moss said.

title: Firehouse With the Best Food? Contest Will Tell
description: "I'M up against a Mississippi mud pie, chocolate mousse, cheesecake and caramel- covered brownies," said Eugene LaMastro, a Union City firefighter, as he tended a pot of melting chocolate. "No problem. My flourless chocolate raspberry cake is a guaranteed winner. It's completely out of the ordinary."

title: Review/Music; Hip-Hop Meets Romance
description: On record, Tony Toni Tone and M. C. Hammer don't have much in common, although both the vocal group and the rapper hail from Oakland, Calif. Yet on stage at the Ritz on Wednesday night, Tony Toni Tone suggested an emerging Oakland school of pop.

title: Allison Dunn Is a Bride
description: Allison Grace Dunn, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allan R. Dunn of Miami, was married there last evening to Mark Etheridge Bamford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert R. Bamford of Mission Viejo, Calif. Rabbi Brett Goldstein and the Rev. Simeon Cappizzi, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Turnberry Isle Country Club. Ms. Dunn-Bamford, 26 years old, is a founding member of the Pembroke Capital Corporation in New York. She graduated from Wellesley College and received a master's degree in real-estate development and finance from Columbia University. Mr. Bamford, 28, is an investment banker at Goldman Sachs in New York. He graduated from Harvard University and received an M.B.A from Dartmouth College.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Brookhaven 130,000 355 Beaver Dam Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 120-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, front porch, 1.4 acres; taxes $2,700. East Patchogue 121,000 29 Roosevelt Boulevard 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; basement, 1-car garage, 160- by 100-foot lot; taxes $2,200. Kings Park 184,333 14 Alfred Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath colonial; dining room, c/a, 2-car attached garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $5,000. Massapequa 215,000 239 West End Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $4,000. Sayville 175,000 20 East Tower Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 70-year-old Tudor; fireplace, family room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,400. Smithtown 150,000 25 Walnut Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 14-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, finished basement, deck and patio, one-car garage; taxes $4,600. OTHER AREAS Howell, N.J. 57,000 107-B Ragley Hall 2-bedroom, 1-bath, condominium apartment in adult community; c/a, maintenance $89; taxes $1,411. Granby, Conn. 296,000 209 Day Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 19-year-old colonial; screened porch, 6 acres; taxes $4,058. Bronxville, N.Y. 275,000 93 Kensington Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 71-year-old town house; fireplace, screened porch, Jacuzzi, 1-car garage; taxes $5,640.

title:
FORUM;
After the Cheering Ends at The News
description: Journalists in Britain are watching with amazement the rapturous reaction that Robert Maxwell seems to have received in New York after he bought The Daily News. Mr. Maxwell is one of two men who dominate the British press, neither of them British-born, both up to their ears in debt and both with extensive American interests. Rupert Murdoch, the other, destroyed British printing unions overnight in 1988 and is a hated figure for labor. But he is relatively tame alongside Robert Maxwell.

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth; Recognition Is Refused For Gay Alumni
description: Dartmouth College refused last week to recognize a separate Dartmouth Gay and Lesbian Alumni Association (D-GALA), citing the need to maintain alumni unity.

title:
FOOD;
The Good Mother
description: THERE ARE THINGS I KNOW I'LL never do. Wine making -- at 39 I'm old enough to realize I've missed the college ritual of stomping Beaujolais abroad for a summer. Olive oil -- I can probably afford about four trees. Now, if I only had a place to put them.

title: Margaret Lescher To Marry in June
description: June wedding plans for Margaret Cantwell Lescher and Dr. Jonathan Alan Samuels, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Samuels of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have been announced by her parents, Mary Cantwell and Robert Lescher, both of New York.

title: Trump and Civic Groups Team Up to Oversee Big Riverside Project
description: Turning their unusual relationship into something unique in New York City, Donald J. Trump and six of his natural antagonists -- civic, environmental and neighborhood groups -- have formed a corporate partnership to oversee the design of Mr. Trump's 76-acre site on the Hudson River.

title: Foreign Dribblers, No Excuses
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A June Wedding For Ms. Glassman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jay P. Glassman of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Miriam Susan Glassman and David Bern Rukeyser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Rukeyser of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: "Strolling in the Sierras of Ancient Andalusia" (Travel, March 17) covers an area of Spain that I know moderately well. Although it is only 30 miles due east from Arcos de la Frontera to Ronda, the walk through the exceptional countryside can take anywhere from several days to more than a week, depending on the walker's pace and interests. The article cited $2,350 as the cost of this walk on a group tour, excluding the air fare to Seville.

title: Grandparents Unite Amid Drug War
description: A dozen inner-city grandparents gathered in a church basement here this week to learn about psychology and child development, addiction and co-dependency, stress management and nutrition, and other newfangled ideas that barely existed when their sons and daughters were small.

title: Illness May Force Rep. Udall to Retire, Family Says
description: Representative Morris K. Udall, the Arizona Democrat who has been a leader in Congress for many of his 30 years there, is in such poor health that he may soon have to retire, his family has told the House Speaker.

title: That Latecomer, the I.B.M. PC
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Toilet Can Save Water
description: REPLACING an old free-standing toilet with a new, ultra low-flush model not only can save money on water bills, but also contribute to household water conservation.

title: Fred Carr Is Going for the Gold
description: Among the men whose careers were built -- and ultimately destroyed -- by junk bonds, Fred Carr may have the distinction of being the one who believed in them the longest. When the going was good, he did not take the money and run.

title: With 2 Quick Swings, HoJo Drives In 3
description: The veteran within Howard Johnson realizes that a lot more happens in the final 157 games of a season than in the first 5. But as he came to bat for the first time in the game at Shea Stadium yesterday, the hitter in him knew that a peek at the scoreboard would reveal an unsatisfactory batting average of .118.

title: THE MAUVE-ING OF AMERICA
description: Mary Cantwell pokes gentle fun at Alexandra Stoddard and Martha Stewart for enjoying their "Fantin-Latour moments," but I think there is a kernel of important wisdom here -- the idea of living in the present, of paying great attention to detail, of living life with maximum consciousness.

title: Elvira and the Rosens
description: PAYMENT IN FULL

title: Changing Lives Inspire Innovative Households
description: AFTER dinner each evening, Anne Kinsella of Old Lyme washes the dishes with her husband, John, and their housemate, Joseph Cary. Then they all settle into chairs, Mrs. Kinsella said, and chat about everything from politics to water pumps. Mr. Cary, who is 40 years old and divorced, pays a nominal rent and does chores around the house and yard for the couple, who are in their early 70's.

title: 'YOU COULD OUTLIVE YOUR DOCTOR'
description: In July 1986, my husband of two years was diagnosed with testicular cancer. I felt as though someone had taken my life and slammed it against a brick wall. Like Brian Hayes, my husband was young (27) and optimistic. He, too, was told, "If you're going to get cancer, this is the best type to get." My husband went through three chemotherapy treatments and, after follow-up surgery, was told, "You're gonna live."

title: Sunday Menu; Swordfish and Salsa: Dual Enhancement
description: As good as swordfish is on its own, the mix of pungent, tart, sweet and salty flavors in this salsa gives an extra edge to any strong-flavored fish. Try it also with tuna, bluefish or mackerel.

title: Campus Life: Oklahoma; Regents Adopt Measure to Ban Anti-Gay Bias
description: Gay, lesbian and bisexual students at the University of Oklahoma have declared a major victory in a three-year battle to persuade the University of Oklahoma to enact rules protecting them from discrimination.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Britten: 'Spring Symphony' (Op. 44), Psalm 150 (Op. 67), 'Welcome Ode' (Op. 95)

title: Another Dimension
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 7 about lead-based paint poisoning misidentified an Annapolis, Md., lawyer who represented a victim. He is Bernard T. Levin.

title: EXERCISING OPTIONS
description: THERE'S CERTAINLY A SEAMY, CREEPY, culty side to what some call the "culture of exercise" -- the creepiest stuff finding its most distilled expression in Samuel Wilson Fussell's new book, "Muscle" (in which Oxford grad trades in his letters for steroids and bulimia), and Julia Phillips's lurid Hollywood tell-all, "You'll Never Eat Lunch in This Town Again" (in which Oscar-winning producer trades her freebase habit for a runner's addiction and a writer's confessional). But these are cautionary tales -- and rather outdated ones at that. I think the well-muscled, endorphin-high crew has seen its day.

title: Tea, With Its Rituals and Oddities
description: OF all the benefits the imperialists derived from their colonial exploits, tea is surely the one most fraught with social significance. For ordinary English people in pre-teabag times, "a cuppa" was a mahogany-colored brew made with Indian or Ceylon leaves and the milk went in first. At the other end of the social spectrum, a paler, slightly fishy-tasting infusion made from large China tea leaves was preferred, and the "cream," if added at all, went in last.

title: The Region; The Invisible Victims Of the City's Budget Cuts
description: "ANYBODY here been in court since last time? Anybody been in jail? What's happened?"

title: Mimi Peet to Wed L. D. Magarelli Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Chester Peet Jr. of Shelter Island, L.I., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Mary Jacqueline Peet and Louis D. Magarelli Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Magarelli of Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: Mandela's Group Offers Charter Ideas
description: In anticipation of negotiations with the Government on South Africa's future, the African National Congress is circulating for discussion proposals for a new constitution that would give political equality to the disenfranchised black majority.

title: We Can Help Kurds Without Sending Troops
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; And Now, a Message From the Proletariat
description: IN one thing, Karl Marx may yet prove right: the working class may indeed prove to be the most potent force for change. It is dubious, however, that his disciples will take much pleasure in the confirmation of this basic tenet, since that force has turned squarely against them.

title: Bridge
description: The rapid growth of bridge in the Soviet Union has been somewhat slowed by political events: A major tournament scheduled in Leningrad at Easter was canceled because many players from other countries changed their minds about participating.

title: Vehicles On Beach: Argument Intensifies
description: AN argument over whether motorists should be banned from driving along the 130 miles of coast in East Hampton is highlighting deep socioeconomic and political ruts.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Desert Diversions: Music and Healing
description: When United States Army forces burst into Iraq, the band from the Third Armored Division was on the border, dressed in chemical protection suits and playing the themes from "Patton" and "Lawrence of Arabia."

title: Mr. Updike, I'm Your Biggest Fan
description: U AND I

title: Teachers' Union Chief Assails Bush, Cuomo and Dinkins
description: Last year, the United Federation of Teachers gave its annual award for public service in education to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. This year, for the first time, the union gave its top prize, the John Dewey Award, to no one.

title: Notebook; A's Have the Greenest Arms in the American League
description: They are not Jim Palmer, Dave McNally, Mike Cuellar and Pat Dobson, who were 20-game winners for the Baltimore Orioles in 1971, but they are an interesting quartet of pitchers in their own right.

title: A Radio Veteran Paints With Sound
description: FEWER and fewer people remember the golden age of radio, before television invaded the American home. But Hamilton O'Hara remembers. He produced some of the most memorable sounds of that era. During the 1940's, when listeners heard a burst of gunfire on "Gangbusters," a roaring locomotive chugging into "Grand Central Station" or a thundering herd of horses on "You Are There," chances are it was Mr. O'Hara creating that sound in the studio.

title: Inns and Books
description: To the Editor: While reading Wayne Curtis's article, I was reminded of a wonderful vacation several winters ago. My husband and I spent a week at the Woodbound Inn in Jaffrey, N.H., accompanied by our teen-age son and daughter and my 80-some-year-old mother.

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title:
FILM;
Kathleen Turner: Going Public as a Private Eye
description: In Hollywood movies, the beautiful blonde in the detective's office is generally not the detective. More likely, she's there to beg him to take that case that just doesn't smell right. Kathleen Turner intends to change all that.

title: BHUTAN STRUGGLES TO STOP MILITANTS
description: The last of the once-isolated Himalayan Buddhist kingdoms is fighting for survival, victim of a South Asian population explosion that is changing demography on the roof of the world.

title: Postings: East 52d St. Construction; Church Changes Design
description: The Norwegian Seamen's Church is embroiled in a dispute with some of its neighbors over its plans to rebuild two East 52d Street brownstones into a new church and meeting place for the city's Scandinavian community.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
New Museums and Facelifts for Old Ones
description: SEVERAL new museums are being developed in Westchester County at a time when others are threatened with diminishing funds. Still others are renovating and at least one is leaving.

title: Mozart
description: To the Editor: There was a minor error in "A Season to Celebrate Mozart" (Travel, March 24).

title:
THEATER;
'Deal With Me as You Would Any Novice'
description: In the summer of 1956, I heard a rumor that Graham Greene was at work on his second play. In July, bearing a letter of introduction, my partner, Stanley Chase, and I arrived at Greene's London flat. The man who greeted us affably at the door was 52, tall and slim, with thinning blond-gray hair, a pinkish complexion and slightly bloodshot pale blue eyes. He wore a gray flannel double-breasted suit of excellent cut, a cream silk shirt with a plain green silk tie, and good, English brown bluchers. He moved rather awkwardly, a bit like a gangly schoolboy, as he led us into a spare white room lined with books.

title: Overflowing Treasures Range From Bach to Benny Goodman
description: "YALE knows how to take care of manuscripts," the composer Virgil Thomson once said. Howard E. Samuel, a music professor and the university's music librarian cites the quote with pride, noting that with that reputation, the Yale Music Library has become a magnet for manuscripts dating from the Middle Ages to the present. The collection includes original works by Bach, Thomson, Kurt Weill, Charles Ives and Paul Hindemith, as well as an extensive group of arrangements and recordings donated to the library by Benny Goodman.

title: Ellen L. Berdy, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Ellen Louise Berdy, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Berdy of River Edge, N.J., was married in Tarrytown, N.Y., last evening to Stephen Brody Greenberg, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Mortimer S. Greenberg of Belmont, Mass. Rabbi Neal Borovitz performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill.

title: Holyfield: Looking for Respect
description: It's not as though he is the North American Boxing Federation champion. Or the ESPN champion. Or Stroh's Beer champion. Evander Holyfield is the undisputed heavyweight champion of the world, the standard bearer of boxing's three major governing bodies.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It is not one of life's major arts or accomplishments, but there's no denying that there is a certain skill to it, and that it's useful. It's called small talk, and generally that is a pretty accurate description because it's the kind of chitchat, banter or call-it-what-you-will exchanged at large, fairly impersonal social events.

title: The Word on Strategies From A.T.& T.
description: To the Editor:

title: Inns and Books
description: To the Editor: Wayne Curtis's reflections on inns and their libraries ("Judging an Inn by Its Book Covers," Travel, March 3) reminded me of an experience a couple of summers ago. Since childhood, I have spent a week or two each August at Rockhouse Mountain Farm Inn in Eaton Center, N.H. Over the years, my parents, friends, husband and now my own children and I, avid readers all, have made our way through the eclectic collection of the inn's owners, the Edge family. One recent summer, it rained for days. We read and played Scrabble, and read, and talked, and read, and so on.

title: Tribal Rites in Westchester
description: OBJECT LESSONS

title: Sara Perkins Engaged To John C. Marshall Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Clark Perkins of New Canaan, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Sara Scott Perkins and John Calvert Marshall Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: What's Left
description: The records and the remaining games for the Knicks and the Pacers, who are fighting for the seventh playoff spot in the Eastern Conference, and for the Bulls and the Celtics, who are fighting for the first spot.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Yo-Yo: 'Make Way for the Motherlode' East-West/Atlantic 7-91605; all three formats.

title: Campus Life: Tufts; New Baseball Bat Unites Athletics And Engineering
description: As mechanical engineering students at Tufts University talked baseball in the laboratory the other day, they were not just looking for a diversion from homework. That has been their homework.

title: Thomas A. Thompson, Executive, 59
description: Thomas A. Thompson, president of Thompson Associates in Manhattan, on Friday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 59 years old and lived in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: Kurds Trudge Into Iran, Filling a Village 6 Times
description: Kurdish refugees of Iraq's civil war are being put up three families to a house in Piranshahr, a tumble-down village of stone and stucco huts about eight miles from the Iraq border. They are sleeping in the school, in mosques and in plastic-sheeting tents in Pasdaran Square. They would sleep in their cars, but an ordinance bans that. So they are sleeping in the streets, too.

title: Kathryn A. Little To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Little of Washington have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Kathryn Ann Little and Clark Carr Talkington, a son of Nancy J. Talkington and Fred M. Talkington, both of Dallas.

title: Judge Denies Bias in Calling Plaintiff a 'Homo' in Court
description: A Federal district judge has refused to disqualify himself from the case of a homosexual who is challenging dismissal from the United States Naval Academy, saying the fact that he called the plaintiff a "homo" in court does not mean he is biased.

title: Williams's 'Kingdom'
description: IN his artistic prime, Tennessee Williams memorably interwove symbols with plot and character. A hot tin roof encapsulated the agony of sexual frustration. A collection of minuscule glass ornaments illuminated the obsession of a fragile outcast. And the reigniting of desire was the most powerful antidote for a desperate woman's fear of death.

title: Way Cleared for Long-Delayed Housing
description: BY resolving several lingering disputes with community activists, some dating back more than a decade, the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins has cleared the way for the construction of nearly 4,000 new or renovated apartments and town houses in New York City.

title: Overflowing Aspirations in 'Betsey Brown'
description: AFTER a long, labyrinthine journey to the stage, "Betsey Brown" has been grounded in a muddle of musical theater cliches.

title: The Marketing Muscle Behind Mariah Carey
description: When Mariah Carey recently won two Grammy Awards, it was a fairy-tale ending for a pop-music Cinderella. The 21-year-old New Yorker was a complete unknown just a year ago. But bolstered by her Grammys -- for best new artist and best female pop performance -- her debut album has held the No. 1 spot on the pop charts for the last seven weeks. "Mariah Carey" has sold more than four million copies in the United States (seven million worldwide, according to Columbia Records) and produced three No. 1 singles -- "Vision of Love," "Love Takes Time" and "Someday."

title: Making a Difference; Moving In on First Executive
description: Since taking office in January as California's first elected insurance commissioner, John Garamendi has tackled a variety of complex and politically bruising issues, among them the long-stalled rollback in automobile insurance rates mandated by voters here more than two years ago.

title: Martha Oliver to Marry Jeffrey Crater
description: Mrs. Ralph Dean Calvert of Annapolis, Md., and R. Spencer Oliver of Washington have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Martha Teel Oliver and Jeffrey Calrow Crater, a son of Mrs. Henry A. Jandl of Richmond and the late David Hopkins Crater.

title: Jackson Picks Up Pace and Compliments, Too
description: Three years after his rookie-of-the-year season and two years removed from a trip to the All-Star Game, Knick guard Mark Jackson again has people speaking of him as something more than a bit player.

title: Further on Being Head of Household
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracy Lee Wood Married
description: Tracy Lee Wood, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elwood S. Wood 3d of Concord, Mass., was married yesterday at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Amenia, N.Y., to Pascal-Andre J. Maeter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Maeter of Brussels. The Rev. John L. Durkin officiated. The bride, 25 years old, is an associate at the A. T. Kearney management consulting company in New York. She graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Mr. Maeter, 28, is an investment banker at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Nascar Changes Rules Covering Yellow Flags
description: With its latest evolution in pit rules, which takes effect this afternoon, Nascar hopes it has found a way to put the action back onto the race track while keeping it out of pit lane.

title: A Jewel of the Provencal Coast
description: THERE is no simple translation for the French verb se promener, describing the Sunday custom of going for a stroll in the village square or park or old port, or even for a drive in one's Peugeot or Deux Chevaux, or for a dangerous careen about town on one's Vespa, as all the young do. If you live within the Marseilles, Aix-en-Provence, Toulon axis, in the South of France, a favorite promenade is the sleepy port of Cassis, a jewel box of a village tucked into the Mediterranean coastline 15 miles east of Marseilles. A modest summer playground for the affluent and idle, this old royalist resort is a hardworking fishing village the rest of the year, though slowly even the fishermen are trading in their bright fishing smacks for cabin cruisers to shepherd tourists about the harbor. In winter and early spring, when most of the hotels and restaurants have long battened shut their premises, Cassis attracts a Sunday crowd from the environs, chicly outfitted in black leather attire reminiscent of Manhattan fashions. For the long sunny afternoon hours, Cassis is transformed along its cafe-bordered quays into a bold and amusing spectacle of French manners.

title: In Danbury, Grape Leaves and Baklava
description: CONSIDERING that the Lebanese cuisine is one of the most respected in the Middle East, and that Danbury has a large Lebanese population, one might expect the city to have many Lebanese restaurants. With the appearance of Roland's of Lebanon, the number seems to have doubled -- to two.

title: Miss McGrath to Wed Andrew Brengle
description: John Hill McGrath of Shelton, Conn., and Ruth Robinson McGrath of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Emily McGrath, to Andrew Curtin Brengle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Curtin Brengle of Concord, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Threatened Services Win Reprieve
description: THE threatened cuts in county services that had raised the specter of closed parks, empty day-care centers and reduced library hours will be avoided at least until Sept. 1.

title: Arizona
description: To the Editor: At least partly because of golf, you can count me out of any future visits to Phoenix ("On the Green in the Desert," Travel, March 10).

title: The Region; How a Tribe in Connecticut Is Taking On Atlantic City
description: EACH week, busloads of bingo players from New England and the New York metropolitan area arrive at the tiny Mashantucket Pequot reservation near the Rhode Island border for the high-stakes games that were legalized in 1986. By next fall, these gamblers and thousands more may find something else: a new casino, the first on the Eastern seaboard outside of Atlantic City.

title: Review/Fashion; Raw, Pretty, Out of This World
description: Several young designers showed collections around town last week that ranged from raw to pretty to otherworldly.

title: A Soviet Version, Perhaps, of a TV Soap
description: BEWARE of the play that relies on press releases, program notes and imposed staging to convince its audience that it carries an important message. Such a play is Alexander Gelman's "Man With Connections" now at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.

title: The Italian Style Is Now Family Style
description: FAMILY-STYLE dining is the latest trend in Italian restaurants. Serving family style is as old as grandma's kitchen, but transporting this overflowing abundance to restaurant meals is the hot new ticket.

title: Imaginary Monsters That Dare a Visitor to See the Show
description: MIRIAM BEERMAN'S 41-year retrospective is more than the State Museum here can handle. It is not so much the size of the show, although the 128 works, many of them measuring 6 feet by 7 feet or more, do seem wedged into their space, but rather its character, which is somewhat forbidding. Monstrous figures in colors that are alternately somber and lurid, they challenge the visitor to enter the gallery.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My home was built in 1965 and has custom-made birch kitchen cabinets that were put in at the time. They now look very bad, but I do not have a lot to spend. Should I refinish the cabinets or install new ones?

title: N.F.L. Scrutinizes Draft-Day Signings
description: The Chicago Bears are apparently willing to defy the National Football League and Commissioner Paul Tagliabue over the signing of first-round selections on draft day. Whether the Bears will, in fact, go counter to N.F.L. policy won't be known until draft day on Sunday.

title: Huge Lead for Leary Turns Into a Bad Trip
description: A loss today could have been a disaster, even though the season is not yet one week old and there are still 157 games and almost six months to play.

title: JERSEYANA
description: IF you are one of those people who cling to the notion that fiction is stranger than truth, let me introduce you to the story of the Jersey City treasurer and the Mexican bandits.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: The Hudson Valley
description: The Hudson Valley, in the backyard of metropolitan New York, is the fastest growing area of New York State. Its proximity to the city and the scenic beauty that have spurred its growth have also brought suburban problems -- traffic congestion, crowded bridges, shopping malls and high real estate prices.

title: Campus Life: Harvard; Death of a Tree: Who Killed It? Are More in Peril?
description: A tree killer is stalking the Harvard campus, and a former city official is not pleased.

title: A June Wedding For Heidi Miller
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward Miller of Freehold, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Lynn Miller, to Francis Matthew Deiner 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Deiner of New Brunswick, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Review/Music; For Love of a Hammond B3
description: In other circumstances, the 19-year-old organist Joey DeFrancesco might be playing happily at some airport motel. Mr. DeFrancesco played six night last week at Birdland, where he flaunted his love of the sound of the Hammond B3 organ, a sound associated with deep blues and instrumental funk. But he is just as happy fooling around on a tinny synthesizer piano or using sounds usually heard at hockey rinks. Mr. DeFrancesco is corny, and he doesn't seem to care.

title: BUSH STANDS FIRM ON MILITARY POLICY IN IRAQI CIVIL WAR
description: Strongly reaffirming United States policy, President Bush said today that Washington would not "interfere" in Iraq's civil war, but he warned Iraq not to try to impede the delivery of emergency aid to refugees fleeing to Turkey and Iran.

title: Mary Hardy Wise Wed
description: Mary Hardy Wise, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Parker Stevens Wise of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday to Richard Morgan Wight, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank Clinton Wight of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Milton Murray officiated at Christ Episcopal Church. Mrs. Wight, 48 years old, manages real-estate properties in Ponte Vedra. Mr. Wight, 68, is the retired director of corporate communications for I.B.M. in Armonk, N.Y. He was a widower.

title: Bush to Propose Broad Changes in U.S. Schools
description: President Bush plans to stake his claim to be the "education President" by proposing national student testing, a Federal program of research and development contracts to invent new kinds of public schools, and a plan for schools to provide children with a range of social services, Administration officials said today.

title: Strike the Gold Catches Fly So Free in Stretch
description: The rough road to the Kentucky Derby claimed its biggest casualty today when Fly So Free, the first choice all winter and spring, was run down in the home stretch and beaten by three lengths by Strike the Gold in the Blue Grass Stakes.

title: They Rarely Leave a Note
description: THE ENIGMA OF SUICIDE By George Howe Colt. 575 pp. New York: Summit Books.

title: For Immigrant Waves, Help With English
description: The census figures are in and confirm what has been apparent to us all. Long Island's face is changing as the Hispanic and Asian newcomers arrive.

title: Prosecutors to Listen to Two Sides in Case of Kennedy Nephew
description: Before deciding whether to file formal charges, prosecutors are taking the unusual step of hearing evidence from both sides in the reported rape of a woman at the Kennedy family compound.
