title: Universities Scrambling To Maintain Enrollments
description: SPRINGTIME traditionally heralds the ritual of high school seniors scrambling to get into their chosen colleges. But this year, the colleges are doing the last-minute struggling.

title: Nuclear Complex Becomes a Huge Magnet for Money
description: Despite new projections for a much smaller nuclear arsenal, and increasing concern about controls on spending, the Department of Energy is pouring billions of dollars into the Savannah River Site in a frantic effort to repair and modernize the bomb-making equipment there.

title: Milk Profiteers Hurt Farmers and Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title:
FORUM;
Arbitrate, Don't Litigate, at Work
description: The bitter debate over new civil rights legislation has taken a new turn with a second issue emerging along with quotas as a flash point: How the law is to be enforced.

title: Once More Around the Bases
description: THE FOREVER BOYS The Bittersweet World of Major League Baseball as Seen Through the Eyes of the Men Who Played One More Time. By Peter Golenbock. Illustrated. 391 pp. New York: Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing Group. $19.95. EXTRA INNINGS A Season in the Senior League. By David Whitford. 255 pp. New York: Edward Burlingame Books/ HarperCollins Publishers. $19.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Easton
description: THREE years ago, the Connecticut Town of Easton got its first and only traffic light, a small concession to modernity in a setting where Revolutionary-era stone walls line winding roads.

title: We Can Help Kurds Without Sending Troops; We Stopped Too Soon
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutual Funds; A Small Step Away From Repos
description: When it comes to money-market funds, three things matter: safety, safety and safety. That's because most investors treat money funds like savings accounts, not investments -- an idea that the industry does not discourage.

title: Elizabeth P. Lobrano to Marry John G. Markham
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Page Lobrano to John Gregory Markham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Markham of Ridgewood, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Barbara Drake Lobrano of Stamford, Conn., and Alexander F. Lobrano of Atlanta.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
Taking Success To Arkansas
description: THE South Shore Bank, a Chicago commercial institution that has profitably made community-oriented development loans in what was perceived as a declining urban area, is testing its methods in rural Arkansas.

title: KUWAIT WILL HIRE MORE FIREFIGHTERS
description: Saying that blazing oil wells are costing this country $5 million an hour, Kuwait's Oil Minister announced today that the national oil company would bring in firefighting teams from several different countries, breaking an American and Canadian monopoly.

title: Paul E. O'Brien Is Married To Polly Glenn in Virginia
description: Pauline Eastwood Glenn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Eastwood Glenn of Roanoke, Va., was married there yesterday to Paul Edward O'Brien, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Joseph O'Brien of Brooklyn. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Revs. James Parke and Robert Lauder at the Hollins College chapel.

title: Making a Difference; Al Giacco's New Agenda: Cleaning Up on Cleanups
description: One of the chemical industry's higher-profile chief executives has put himself back in the spotlight.

title: Kenyan Democracy Advocate Is Out of Jail After 251 Days
description: Charles Rubia, a former Cabinet minister and advocate of political pluralism in this East Africa nation, has been freed from jail after 251 days of detention.

title: Head of U.N. Peacekeepers Arrives in Kuwait
description: The head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission arrived here today, but refugees on the Iraq-Kuwait border said they feared that the organization's small contingent would not be enough to protect them from President Saddam Hussein's army.

title: Children Help Stage 'Captain Noah' Opera
description: "I WANT to encourage family and young audiences to attend something other than 'Peter and the Wolf,' " said Arthur Jay, founder and director of the Children's Opera Company of Ossining, which is staging "Captain Noah and His Floating Zoo"this week.

title: Officer Is Suspended for Kissing 2 Women
description: A police officer was suspended without pay on Friday by the Borough Council because he kissed two female employees of the borough against their will.

title: Victoria C. Allen To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jon Lewis Allen of Dallas have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Victoria Cecile Allen, and John Stainsby, the son of Dr. and Mrs. George Stainsby of Leeds, West Yorkshire, England.

title: Rangers: 51 Years of Futility and Counting
description: The hockey season ended for the Rangers tonight when the Washington Capitals beat them by 4-2 to capture their first-round Stanley Cup playoff series, 4 games to 2.

title: The Nation; G.O.P. Tries a Gambit With Voting Rights
description: IT was a strange political pairing: the chief counsel for the Republican Party, the party that dreamed up the Willie Horton commercials, the party that opposes the civil rights bill before Congress, advising black lawmakers on how to win more seats.

title: Give McDonald's Its Due: Taste the Product
description: To the Editor:

title: The Unfinished Politician
description: SENATOR BOB KERREY WAS DRIVING THROUGH THE flat fields of northern Nebraska, a somber landscape in midwinter: white sky, white fields, a few brown stands of trees. The land was quiet, frozen, and farmers had time for a town meeting with their Senator, time to gripe about the price of soybeans and the inequities of the new Federal farm program.

title: Ancient Dancers Twist and Shout on an Andean Tapestry
description: Elaborately masked and costumed dancers twist and sing in an ancient Andean ritual, one that is shared by frogs, snakes, llamas, spotted cats and mythological creatures. The performers wear feathered headdresses and hold dolls, cigar-shaped stalks or arched vines.

title: Note With Pleasure
description: Flying Souls Some images seem eternal, and none more so than that which makes the butterfly the symbol of the soul. This is from "The Bestiary of Christ" by Louis Charbonneau-Lassay (Parabola Books).

title: The Man Who Detested the Sea
description: JOSEPH CONRAD A Biography. By Jeffrey Meyers. Illustrated. 428 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $27.50.

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Venturi, Gentle Subverter of Modernism
description: The most surprising thing about the announcement on Monday that this year's Pritzker Prize would go to Robert Venturi was why it had taken until 1991 for the jurors to get around to him. No architect is more deserving of this honor, which since it was created in 1979 has been thought of as architecture's rough equivalent of the Nobel Prize. As both a practicing architect and a theorist, Mr. Venturi, 65, has shaped a generation of architects, and more than any other figure has brought architecture to its present moment. He has not created a style, but he has done something much more subtle and ultimately vastly more powerful: he put forth a set of ideas that have provided an intellectual basis for a thousand different things by a thousand different architects.

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title:
Your Own Account;
Nurturing the Fragile Start-Up
description: The idea of starting a business and achieving independence appeals to more and more disillusioned executives today. But the failure rate -- only one in five business start-ups succeeds, according to the Small Business Administration -- keeps many of them in the corporate world.

title: A Few Figures for Himself and His Friends
description: The 31 Degas waxes at the National Gallery of Art make it possible to understand why this painter's sculptures have been inspiring artists for a long time. Mary Cassatt said Degas "will live to be a greater sculptor than painter." The contemporary sculptor William Tucker has written, "There seems to me no doubt that Degas's most substantial achievement rests in sculpture."

title:
ART;
Connecticut Biennial Displays Diversity
description: BIENNIAL exhibitions that survey the present course of art are often sprawling, contentious affairs. But "The Connecticut Biennial II," at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, is characterized by gracefulness. The works by 19 painters and sculptors seem to have effortlessly arranged themselves in three galleries.

title: Waiting Beyond Season's Opening Leaves Trout Unimpressed
description: This year, for the first time in a quarter of a century, I did not go forth on April 1, the opening day of New York State's trout season. Too many of those openers had been cold and miserable. By waiting a week, I reasoned, I stood a better chance of encountering warmer weather and catching more fish. I was rewarded with the former.

title: Why Is Osteoporosis Rising for Blacks?
description: DRESSED in hospital greens after undergoing a bone scan to evaluate the density of her spine, hips and wrists, Monique Whitney is an unusual volunteer for a medical study on osteoporosis, because she is black.

title: Data Bank/April 14, 1991
Debra Packman Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allan B. Packman of West Hartford, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Debra Beth Packman and Mark Bennett Landis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan S. Landis of Westport, Conn. Miss Packman, 27 years old, and Mr. Landis, 29, graduated from Union College. She is a product coordinator for MMS International, a subsidiary of McGraw-Hill, in New York. He is a first vice president in the New York office of Sanwa-BGK International, a dealer in Government securities.

title: From Upstate, a Poet Recalls Nesconset
description: THIRTY-FIVE years ago, when he left Nesconset for college and what he thought would be a future as a physical-education teacher, William Heyen had no idea that one day Archibald MacLeish would call him "the most important Long Island poet since Walt Whitman."

title: Cheryl Horowitz To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Phillip L. Horowitz of Toledo, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Cheryl Suzanne Horowitz, to Daniel E. Troy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Troy of Hollis Hills, Queens. The wedding is to take place in June.

title:
Style Makers;
Umberto Savone, Hair Stylist for Men
description: If you are a man who cares about personal grooming but wouldn't be caught dead getting a pedicure in a beauty parlor, a genial Italian hair stylist in Beverly Hills may have just the solution.

title: Commercial Property: SoHo Hotels; Moving Beyond the Talking Stage
description: HOTELS have been the talk of SoHo since the early 1980's. That is all they have been. Now, however, two young developers have come forward with a project at Mercer and Prince Streets that they say is fully financed and ready to begin.

title: Anne Reynolds, Art Consultant, Weds
description: Anne Brice Reynolds, a daughter of Sally Owen Reynolds and Richard Samuel Reynolds 3d of Richmond, was married yesterday to Matthew Leigh Robertson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Leigh Robertson of Hinsdale, Ill. The Rev. O. Benjamin Sparks officiated at the Second Presbyterian Church in Richmond.

title: Medicaid Morass/Troubled Policy in Hard Times A special report.; New York's Medicaid Costs Surge, But Health Care for the Poor Lags
description: As New York struggles through a fiscal crisis, its ever-expanding Medicaid program, already the most expensive in the nation, has emerged as discouraging proof of just how profound and intractable the state's budget problems are.

title: Lincoln Learns That Bigger Is Better
description: For the auto industry, 1990 was a nightmare of plummeting sales and large losses. The one exception was the luxury-car market and its brightest light was the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln division.

title: Happy, Not Sad, Ending
description: To the Editor:

title: American Ballet Theater Spreads Its New Wings
description: When Jane Hermann and Oliver Smith were appointed as directors of American Ballet Theater a little over a year ago, their mandate seemingly was to bring back the Ballet Theater everyone knew before Mikhail Baryshnikov's 10-year reign as artistic director. Now, with a nine-week season that opens a week from tomorrow at the Metropolitan Opera House, the new team could be charged, paradoxically, with offering only the familiar.

title: Counting Magpies and Monarchs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Talking: Co-ops; Selling Foreclosed Units
description: IN some New York City cooperatives that have been been converted from rental status, the boards have taken over ownership of apartments formerly owned by defaulting sponsors and they now face the question of how to sell these units.

title: Making a Difference; The Man with All the Numbers
description: James Bryant is one of those people who gets energized by copying the alphabetical listings out of telephone books, and so he's been doing some heavy celebrating since he found out two weeks ago that he can openly copy all the phone books he wants and get away with it.

title:
ART;
A Special Regard for Nature's Forces
description: FOR both artists and viewers, previously accepted esthetic standards inherited from Western Europe suddenly seem far too narrow in a world that wants to respect the creative ideals of many different cultures.

title: Where India's Temples Were Born
description: INDIA seems almost as old as time; Hinduism, after all, predates Christianity by some 2,000 years and its roots go back still further. It can come as a surprise, therefore, to find out that, with very few exceptions, none of its freestanding stone structures predates the sixth century A.D. Aihole and Pattadakal, two neighboring sites in the state of Karnataka, offer a perfect view of the beginnings of Indian architecture.

title: Village Is a Beacon To Hispanic Immigrants
description: THE Rev. Aramis Acosta, pastor of El Olivar Pentecostal Church on South Main Street here, remembers when there were only a few dozen members of his congregation. That was 13 years ago, when he arrived from Puerto Rico to become the new minister. Today, it is standing room only at the Spanish-language services held almost every day of the week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-15

title: A New Way to Train Firefighters
description: THE state is set to begin a training course meant to better prepare new firefighters to confront the dangers of firefighting without, it is hoped, placing too many demands on already scarce volunteers.

title: Q and A
description: Rejection on Refinancing Question: I asked permission from our co-op board to take out a home equity loan to help pay my son's college tuition. I had no mortgage and the co-op permits up to 80 percent financing for new stockholders. The board rejected my request, so I had to take a personal loan, with almost no tax benefit. Was the board's action legal? . . . Candy Eng, Jackson Heights, Queens Answer: Legal experts are unsure. Stuart M. Saft, a real estate lawyer and chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said the answer depends on whether your co-op lease requires approval for financing. If it does, he said, the next question is whether the board "treats everybody in the same situation equally." The board might distinguish between existing owners and new buyers, he said.

title: Flea Marketgate
description: I don't think there was a newspaper or TV news show in the country that didn't carry the story. A man in Pennsylvania buys a rather crummy picture and frame at a flea market for $4. When taking the picture out of the frame, he finds folded behind it an original print of the Declaration of Independence that, he learns later, is valued at $800,000 to $1 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Augusta's Rewarding 'Golf Nut'
description: For all the mystique of the Masters, the Augusta National Golf Club itself was America's last plantation. In the sprawling white clubhouse of what a century ago actually was an indigo plantation, white millionaire members in green jackets were served by black waiters and black bartenders. Out among the azaleas and dogwood on the course, their golf bags were shouldered by black caddies.

title: Samuelson Poised at Boston Crossroad
description: Within the vagaries of long-distance running, a career crossroad can be the next race, the next training run, even the next stride. So many things can happen. So many do.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: STEPHEN G. JANICK;
A Disability That Led to a New Career
description: IN 1974, when Stephen G. Janick became a quadriplegic as the result of an swimming accident, his life changed dramatically. But, surprisingly, much of the change was positive, he says.

title: Campus Life: Wisconsin; Bias Grievance Against Professor From Nigeria
description: Students from an African language class at the University of Wisconsin have filed a grievance with the university's administration, charging educational malpractice and racial discrimination by a visiting professor originally from Nigeria.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CUTTER By Virgil Suarez.Available Press/Ballantine, Paper, $7.95.

title: Driving Banks to Desperate Risks
description: The House Banking Committee is reportedly on the verge of making a grievous decision to delay action on comprehensive bank reform until after Congress fixes the deposit insurance system. If that happens, banks will be forced to pay higher costs but will have no way to increase earnings. With hundreds of banks already reeling, that's an incendiary combination.

title: Metro Datelines; Cuomo Signs Bill on Alcohol Dangers
description: Over the objections of some feminist groups, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has signed into law a measure that will require businesses that sell liquor to post signs warning pregnant women that alcohol consumption can cause birth defects.

title: The Enduring Spirit of Avignon
description: THE happenings of 600, 700 and 800 years ago still echo through the narrow cobblestone streets of Avignon but there is no cause for alarm. Avignon is not a mausoleum city designed only for tourists fixated on the past. Today this gateway to Provence is as proud of its food, wine and taste for the good life as it is of its old intellectual and its new theatrical traditions.

title: Graf Shifts Focus Within and Draws on Strength
description: Some people sing songs about soul cages. Others, like Steffi Graf, live in them, caught in chasms of ambivalence the rock musician Sting calls the inescapable fate of the introspective.

title: Blazers End Lakers' Reign Atop the Pacific Division
description: For the first time in a decade, the Los Angeles Lakers are not the Pacific Division champions.

title: Deaths of 3 Patients Not Included in Report About AIDS Experiment
description: Three of 19 AIDS-infected people who volunteered for inoculations with a vaccinelike preparation last year have died and the deaths were never reported in medical journals or to the health authorities, a newspaper has reported.

title: Politics Nurtures 'Poison'
description: To appreciate Todd Haynes's "Poison," the brash and haunting film that has caused the latest right-wing attack on the National Endowment for the Arts, it helps to know about "Superstar: The Karen Carpenter Story." Mr. Haynes's previous, 43-minute film relies on inspired casting: the late anorexic singer, her brother, Richard, and their overbearing parents are all played by Barbie-type dolls. There is the occasional close-up of a box of Ex-Lax and brief commentary on how the drive for perfection can lead women to starve themselves, but mostly the dolls trot around miniature sets, as the Carpenters' sunny, bland California-pop music plays in the background.

title: Travel Agents in a Season of Discontent
description: COUNTERPRODUCTIVE. That is how Westchester travel agents, struggling to revive a business depressed by the Persian Gulf war and the recession, describe the latest obstacle: the spate of airline promotions that offer deep cuts in domestic and international fares.

title: On Language; Can You Handle This?
description: ACCUSTOMED TO A rapid advance, Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf showed he could beat a hasty retreat when he found himself in a controversy with the President.

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruins to Play Canadiens in Adams Final
description: Boston scored on its first two shots and Andy Moog was outstanding in goal as the Bruins beat the Hartford Whalers, 3-1, tonight to advance to the Adams Division final.

title:
DINING OUT;
Beyond the Familiar in Chinese Fare
description: THERE seem to be four types of Chinese restaurants in New Jersey. They include the exciting new ones with chefs from all parts of China preparing incredibly exotic dishes (often at elevated prices), those that are offshoots of Manhattan Chinese restaurants, and the old-fashioned ones where everything is cornstarch-thickened and most of the sauces are dark brown or bright red.

title: What Went Wrong in Moscow?
description: THE SECOND SOCIALIST REVOLUTION

title: For Twins of Auschwitz, Time to Unlock Secrets
description: They are surviving members of what Irene Hizme calls "the most exclusive club in the world": Jewish twins hand-picked by the Nazi physician Josef Mengele at the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp to be guinea pigs, in her words, "for experimentation to develop a master race."

title: Sunday Dinner; Soft-Shell Crabs Arrive, Challenging Chefs' Ingenuity
description: The molting season for crabs is moving up the East Coast, delighting diners and challenging chefs. Here are three Manhattan restaurants, all open on Sunday, that do a particularly fine job with soft-shell crabs. Chin Chin

title: Sports of The Times; This Public Servant Isn't Blowing Smoke
description: This is how far we've come, babies:

title: Prayerfully, Sleeplessly, Pavarotti Takes Up the Challenge of Otello
description: Another attempt is about to be made on the pinnacle of Italian tenor roles, Verdi's Otello. The attempt is necessary, not just because the summit is there, but because somebody has to surmount it if the operagoing world is to have access to this essential opera. It's one of the few roles that borders on the impossible, at least if any kind of ideal is kept in view; almost nobody in the century of its existence has managed to sing Otello without serious compromises in one aspect or another of its myriad vocal and histrionic demands.

title: A Newsroom From the North
description: To the Editor:

title: ResultsPlus
description: TENNIS

title: Fishing For the Workplace Imposter
description: Recently, an executive with a large pharmaceutical company was promoted to head an overseas office. Although the executive had been with the company for nearly two decades, and his performance was deemed consistently outstanding, top management hired an investigator to examine his credentials before sending him abroad -- and was dismayed.

title: CHERNOBYL: Five Years Later The Danger Persists
description: EIGHT-YEAR-OLD SASHA DANILKIN left the hospital late last summer and came home to the wooden cottages and muddy roads of Tarasovka, a farming village in southeastern Byelorussia. Since then, the scar left after doctors in Minsk removed his cancerous thyroid gland has faded. His energy has returned. In the light snow of a February afternoon, Sasha chases his sisters around a decrepit green cart.

title: The Land of Oz
description: THE NEGEV IS AN UNREAL world, a landscape of whirling dunes, wind-sculptured stones and scrub trees. Jackals sleep in the nearby caves while desert hares scurry across the sand, dodging vultures. Apart from a few wandering Bedouin tribesmen on ragged camels, there is nothing human about this place. It is a vast, sprawling symbol of divine absence.

title: Style Makers; Paul Perlow, Graphic Artist
description: Anyone who thinks computers have replaced hand-crafted typography doesn't know Paul Perlow. Though he calls himself a "design osaur," clients like Viking Press and Deutsche Grammophon call him an artist.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Rodrigo: 'Concierto de Aranjuez,' 'Fantasia Para un Gentilhombre'; Villa-Lobos: Guitar Concerto Goran Sollscher, guitar; Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. Deutsche Grammophon 429 232-2; CD.

title: To Suriname Refugees, Truce Means Betrayal
description: In the sullen refugee camps and ramshackle riverside huts here that house thousands of Surinamese who have fled their country's four-year civil war, recent word of peace has brought only feelings of bitter helplessness.

title: Metro Datelines; Officer Uses Pistol in Suicide, Police Say
description: A 32-year-old police officer who was the mother of two small children shot herself in the head with a revolver in a basement locker room after she arrived at work in Queens on Friday, the police said.

title: Resurrecting Tennessee Williams
description: IN his artistic prime, Tennessee Williams memorably interwove symbols with plot and character. A hot tin roof encapsulated the agony of sexual frustration. A collection of minuscule glass ornaments illuminated the obsession of a fragile outcast. And the reigniting of desire was the most powerful antidote for a desperate woman's fear of death.

title:
ROWING;
Winning Is Child's Play for Penn Heavyweights
description: Pennsylvania's varsity heavyweight crew won the Child's Cup this morning, defeating Princeton and Columbia to retain the oldest trophy in American intercollegiate rowing.

title: H. Adler, 72, Executive in the Garment Industry
description: Herbert Adler, a garment industry executive and entrepreneur, died on Wednesday at Bethesda Medical Center in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 72 years old and lived in Cleveland and Palm Beach.

title: Rhonda Gray Is Married
description: Rhonda Susan Gray, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Gray of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Regency in New York to Stephen Thomas Robinson, a son of Helen Robinson of Clearwater, Fla., and the late Dr. James R. Robinson. Judge Walter B. Tolub of New York City Civil Court officiated. The bride, 29 years old, and the bridegroom, 34, own Baby Bear Productions, a book packaging company in New York. The bridegroom is also a technical director at Unitel Video in New York. The bride graduated from the University of South Florida, the bridegroom from the University of Florida.

title: Gabrielle Stanton to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. Stanton of South Orange, N.J., have announced summer wedding plans for their daughter Gabrielle Gail Stanton and Harry Werksman Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Werksman of Rancho Mirage, Calif. Miss Stanton, 23 years old, is the national publicity coordinator in the New York office of the Public Broadcasting Service. She graduated from Barnard College. Mr. Werksman, 26, graduated from Northwestern University and is studying for a master's degree in English history at Oxford University.

title: Laserdisks Get a New Impetus
description: Videodisks have been around for a long time, as time is measured in the restless consumer electronics business -- first in the early 1980's as needle-played relatives of the long-playing record, then as laser relatives of the compact disk. But for various reasons, some economic, they have never caught on. Now, consumers are recognizing the advantages of a format that combines sharp pictures with sound of compact-disk quality.

title: Hannah Sechrist To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Sechrist 2d of York, Pa., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Hannah Slaymaker Sechrist and Joseph R. Burns, a son of Diane Newton Sumner of Phoenix, Md.

title: Wall Street; Utilities Are a Standout in a Dull Spending Picture
description: American industry expects to spend only 2.5 percent more on plant and equipment this year than it did last year, according to Federal statistics released last week. But a notable exception has been detected by the County NatWest Investment Banking Group in New York.

title: Bush Seeks Overhaul of Laws on Foreign Aid
description: Reviving a longtime tug-of-war between Congress and the executive branch over control of foreign policy, the Bush Administration has proposed an overhaul of foreign aid laws that would give the President far greater say in how the money is spent.

title: Women's Hoops: No Place on TV
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Making a Difference; Bringing a 3-D Spin to a Computer Consortium
description: Behind last week's formation of a 21-member desktop computer consortium is a fast-moving maker of scientific and engineering work stations, Silicon Graphics Inc. And behind Silicon Graphics is James Clark, a former Stanford engineering professor who founded the company in 1982.

title: Amy Weisser to Wed Adam Yarinsky
description: Adam Yarinsky, an architect in New York, and Amy Suzanne Weisser, a doctoral student in art history at Yale University, plan to marry in July. Ms. Weisser is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Weisser of East Williston, L.I. Mr. Yarinsky is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Yarinsky of Delmar, N.Y.

title: Floral Grandeur Near San Francisco
description: THIRTY miles south of San Francisco, near the country village of Woodside, lies a wilderness where bobcats and mountain lions prowl the tangled woods of madrone and redwood, and tawny meadows sweep down the hillsides to the Crystal Springs Reservoir far below. Within this wildness lie the perfectly manicured gardens of Filoli, one of California's grandest estates.

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: Modern Architecture Photographs by Ezra Stoller By William S. Saunders Harry N. Abrams. 216 pages. $60. Ezra Stoller had just returned from giving a lecture at the University of California at Berkeley when we caught up with him the other day at his home in Rye. Mr. Stoller, who has been called the most celebrated architectural photographer of the century, said that despite his industrial design degree from New York University in 1938, he "was proud of the fact that I knew I wasn't going to be a great architect."

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Religious Centers Grow to Meet Demand
description: WITH congregations growing and willing to support construction, many religious institutions are enlarging their facilities.

title: Young Asthmatics Put It in Writing
description: "HI, my name is William, and I've got asthma. I got it when I was 8, and it messed up my whole life.

title:
FOCUS;
In the Capitol Area, Incentives Ebb as Sales Rise
description: Encouraged by signs of a strengthening real-estate market in the greater Washington area, many builders this spring are withdrawing the special incentives they used last year to lure potential buyers.

title: We Can Help Kurds Without Sending Troops; Toll Is Still Uncounted
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Met, a Cast of Hundreds
description: More than 900 guests dined and danced on the Metropolitan Opera's 174-foot deep stage last Sunday, surrounded by sets from "Tosca." "On Stage at the Met," a fund-raising party, honored Frederic V. Salerno, former New York Telephone president.

title: Victory, Elation; Refugees, Despair
description: While in Washington on Feb. 28 only a month and a half ago -- we heard the good news: The Persian Gulf war was over. And we started dreaming about the future.

title: Key West
description: To the Editor: Having enjoyed a winter vacation there two years ago, I was drawn to the article on "What's Doing in Key West" (Travel, Feb. 24).

title: Q and A
description: Canada's Provincial Taxes

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Fresh Out of the Tank DR. ROBERT VALENTI sells live fish, not for aquariums but for the dinner plate. Depending on the season, hundreds of fluke, flounder, porgies and blackfish can be found swimming in the 22 holding tanks of his company, Multi-Aquaculture Systems in Amagansett.

title: Through the Lens Brightly With Jennifer Tipton
description: What we remember of our moments in the theater depends, of course, on acting and sets, on costumes and lines. But in the emotional tenor of what we remember, we are guided by the light. The sun may shine on weddings and wars alike, but theater shuts out the noncommittal light of day, calling instead on designed -- and designing -- artificial light.

title: Social Events
description: Fashion Workshop

title: Sue Lane to Wed Steven G. Silber
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce S. Lane of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Sue Ellen Lane, and Steven Gary Silber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Silber of New Hempstead, N.Y.

title: Campus Life; Mole-Dissection Course Is Statecraft, Not Biology
description: A few years ago a roving spokesman for the Central Intelligence Agency, Arthur S. Hulnick, appeared at a University of Washington forum in Seattle "to try to explain who we are and what it is we do." A woman threw a pot at him.

title: Big Boats Take It on the Chin
description: Brokers and buyers normally crowd the docks and boatyards this time of year along the waterfront of this small Fairfield County village on Long Island Sound. This year, though, the area seems virtually abandoned, and a strange quiet, broken only by the faint clanks of rigging rattling in the wind, fills the air.

title: Costly Foot-Dragging in Albany
description: Once again, New York's leaders have failed to deliver a state budget on time. They're already 14 days late, and every day costs New Yorkers money. How can legislators and Gov. Mario Cuomo justify wasting millions of dollars even as the state sinks deeper into its recession?

title: Benjamin Greeley Wed to Miss Olds
description: Cynthia Craig Olds, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Olds of Washington, was married yesterday in the Washington Cathedral to Benjamin Betke Greeley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Greeley of St. Davids, Pa. The Rev. Fergus A. Smith, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Headliners; Europe Takes the Lead in Privacy Protection
description: IN the last two decades, the United States, once an innovator in protecting privacy, has lagged behind many Europeans nations, which have enacted wide-ranging laws to restrict the flow of personal information.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Greek Independence Day Parade, Fifth Avenue will be closed today from 62d to 79th Streets from 1 P.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Friends World Affiliation Fought
description: "YOU see humanity as being an interwoven fabric that holds together," Tandeka Guilderson, a senior at Friends World College, said. "There is a current of sameness that's everywhere, and you begin to appreciate that what makes us the same is so much more important than what makes us different."

title: For Budget Lodging, Retreats or College Dorms
description: VACATIONERS with a constricted budget may want to consider not only economy motels but also alternative lodging such as religious retreats or college dormitories. Some of these may be Spartan, but for travelers who are game, necessity can be turned into an adventure.

title: THE GUIDE
description: MASTERPIECES

title: Travel Advisory; San Francisco: 2 Hotels Redone
description: Two San Francisco hotels situated in historic buildings have completed major renovation projects. One is a new hotel, the Ritz-Carlton, which opened last week in a landmark 1909 neo-classical building; the other, the 116-year-old Sheraton Palace, reopened this month after 27 months of restoration.

title: Francesa Declines Offer
description: Late Friday, despite industry speculation that he would join ESPN, Mike Francesa turned down the cable network's offer to become its studio expert on college football and basketball and replace the late Pete Axthelm on its N.F.L. studio show. He is not expected to accept an ESPN counteroffer, said a source close to the talks.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: NETTIE B. WEBB;
Defending 'Invented Spelling' to Parents
description: IF your kindergartener comes home spelling the word book with only a B or your first or second grader forgets about commas or your third grader thinks school is spelled "skul," the word from experts these days is don't be alarmed. In fact, don't even correct them, unless asked. Just encourage your child to keep on writing.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MAASAI DAYS, by Cheryl Bentsen. (Anchor/Doubleday, $11.) To go beyond the noble-savage myths that so many Westerners attach to the East African Masai, a journalist in Kenya befriended members of the endangered tribe. In 1989 our reviewer, Louisa Dawkins, called the result "one of the most successful attempts by a Westerner to present a contemporary African world view that I have come across." THE THINGS THEY CARRIED, by Tim O'Brien. (Penguin, $8.95.) In a series of intertwined stories about Vietnam, a semifictional character named Tim O'Brien reflects on how memory and imagination magnify and distort the stories we tell ourselves about war. The author, whose 1978 novel "Going After Cacciato" won a National Book Award, "adds his second title to the short list of essential fiction about Vietnam," Robert R. Harris said here last year. "By moving beyond the horror of the fighting to examine with sensitivity and insight the nature of courage and fear, by questioning the role that imagination plays in helping to form our memories and our own versions of truth, he places 'The Things They Carried' high up on the list of best fiction about any war."

title: Julia Johnson Weds Christopher Marcil
description: Julia Claiborne Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alsey Mann Johnson of Shelbyville, Tenn., was married in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., yesterday to Christopher Edward Marcil, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Marcil of Amsterdam, N.Y. Paul Parillo, the Mayor of Amsterdam, performed the ceremony at the Hall of Springs.

title:
TELEVISION;
Dennis Hopper Prowls the Turf of Darkness Within
description: Odd, the moment when an actor realizes the character he's trying to inhabit has finally kicked in.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIKE CHINA By Varley O'Connor.Morrow, $19.95.

title: All About/Initial Public Offerings; Company Hunger, Investor Interest Mean a Hotter New-Issues Market
description: Initial public offerings -- companies' first sales of stock to the public -- have all the excitement of opening night on Broadway. Will the offering be a success? Will it flop? After months of meticulous preparation, Wall Street bankers and corporate executives hold their collective breath as the stock is tossed out onto the market and there, in the instant of a trading day, is judged a winner or shrugged off into oblivion.

title: Despite the Effects of War, Tel Aviv Will Run Its Race
description: The Persian Gulf war and Saddam Hussein's Scud missile attacks on Israel not only caused physical damage but also disrupted the Hapoel Sports Association's preparation for the 11th annual Tel Aviv Marathon here Monday. But the organizers of the event have been as determined as their countrymen were during the bombings that life should go on with minimum concession to the fear and dislocations of war.

title: THE HIGH C's OF STYLE
description: Current fashion comes out of a roiling, boiling caldron, a catchall of disparate elements. A number of "C" words go into conjuring up the soup of style. First off, it's handy to have a sprinkle of Chanelisms to toss in for flavor. (Outright copies come in handy, too.) For fall, a seasoning of vintage Courreges spices things up considerably as well. True creativity is great, but most good ideas have a cachet of times past. It takes courage to make a conversation piece, but sometimes it is what gives a designer's collection charisma. Comfort may sound colorless, but often it is what clinches the sale of clothes to a satisfied customer. (Let there be more of her!) Fortunately, there were only a few catastrophes this season, with every designer aiming for a chic statement. Some achieved it. So let's count the successes and call them out loud and clear.

title: Nigeria Weighs Ending Curbs on Pretoria
description: In a major policy shift, Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, has announced that it is considering lifting sanctions against South Africa.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BEATING THE ODDS The Untold Story Behind the Rise of ABC: The Stars, Struggles, and Egos That Transformed Network Television by the Man Who Made It Happen. By Leonard H. Goldenson with Marvin J. Wolf. Scribners, $24.95.

title: Gejdenson Is Leading Campaign-Reform Effort
description: LAST fall, the members of Connecticut's congressional delegation who sought re-election managed to fend off campaign challenges with barely a whistle stop. A big difference between the incumbents and their opponents was money. The lawmakers raised an average of $317,000 for the 1990 election, according to documents filed with the Federal Election Commission. Their challengers collected about a tenth of that.

title: Fight for Injured Woman's Abortion in a TV Movie
description: HER speech is slow and slurred, her husband, Martin Klein, said. She cannot move her right arm, and although she has regained movement in her legs, she uses a wheelchair.

title: Looking for Gladiators at New York Coliseum
description: Call it boot camp for the TV generation.

title: Public & Private; Yesterday's News
description: From time to time there are stories that come up and grab people by the throat, make them wonder for a few days what kind of world we live in, at least until a pennant race heats up. One of those stories came up not long ago. Or perhaps I should say came down, into the trash compactor and our living rooms: a baby boy, 6 pounds, 10 ounces. The baby's mother gave birth in her bedroom and didn't know what to do when it was time for school. The baby's father is her cousin and was charged with rape. Oh, and the baby's mother was 12 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We're helping out and we're going to continue to help these refugees. But I do not want one single soldier or airman shoved into a civil war in Iraq that's been going on for ages. And I'm not going to have that." -- President Bush. [ 1:6. ]

title: Shanghai Names Party Head
description: Wu Bangguo, the deputy Communist Party secretary for Shanghai since 1985, has been named to the city's top party post, the official New China News Agency reported today. Mr. Wu succeeds Zhu Rongji, who gave up his job as chief of the Shanghai party on Monday when he was chosen by China's legislature as one of two new vice premiers in the national Government.

title: 2 Lab Monkeys Killed After Top Court Acts
description: Two laboratory monkeys that for a decade had been at the center of a battle over animal rights were put to death late Friday, hours after medical researchers had received the United States Supreme Court's clearance to conduct one final set of experiments on them and then kill them.

title: 'Underground' Helps Fund Low-Cost Housing
description: WHEN Lorraine, which is not her real name, left her parents' house in West Islip to find a place of her own, she was not willing to pay more than $500 a month for rent.

title: THE MAUVE-ING OF AMERICA
description: The rash of longing by millions of American women for the sweet, if sometimes sticky, joys of housewifery (and presumably the support of an at least moderately successful husband) is really no mystery ("The Mauve-ing of America" by Mary Cantwell, March 17). The age of Athena is an exhausting one -- especially for those who are also obliged to play Aphrodite to husband or lover, Demeter to children and Hestia to any who need comforting by her fire. Urged on by Martha (Stewart), Alexandra (Stoddard) and Victoria (magazine), I can understand why many women might prefer carving cucumber hearts to analyzing balance sheets.

title: Postings: Lever House Neighbor; A 20-Story Bank Tower
description: For many years, the front yard of Lever House -- an elevated plaza at Park Avenue and 53d Street -- was bounded on the west by nothing more than the blank side wall of an old 11-story building. But that prospect is changing dramatically, day by day.

title: Miss Webb Wed To E. B. Sheridan
description: Electra Webb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gaynor Webb of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Edward Baisley Sheridan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Sheridan of Darien, Conn. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. officiated at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: It's in a Box. Maybe It's a Movie.
description: From variety comes the discouraging news that the major studios have become increasingly dependent on conventional Madison Avenue advertising tactics, the kind that tell us which toothpaste to buy. Thanks to this great breakthrough in corporate thinking, more and more films are being enthusiastically marketed as products, complete with what Variety refers to as "brand personality."

title: Undercount No Surprise in the Shacks
description: In a converted guardpost propped atop a scraggly lot on the Brooklyn waterfront, Jesus Ramos spends his days and nights watching television, drinking and waiting.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: REALISTIC ART

title: How the New Districts Shape Up
description: LAST month, the State of New Jersey adopted new legislative districts. The districts were based on the 1990 census and were intended to increase the influence of minority voters. Here is a list of the municipalities within each district.

title: Headliners; Friendly Persuader
description: Sometimes all it takes to shake off self-centered melancholy is a little perspective. Which is what Yolanda Lugo had with her as she drove across the Verrazano Narrows Bridge on her way home last week after a day's police work. The 24-year-old officer saw Irwin Cuevas, also 24, climb to the top of a bridge abutment and contemplate a 200-foot drop into oblivion. She followed him up and talked to him. He mentioned his problems -- a failing marriage, family troubles -- and she said that they could be worked out. Then, she recalled, "He said, 'How do you know? You ever had any problem?' " She had. "I told him I just got over cancer of my neck, my heart, my lungs, my liver and my stomach and how one doctor said, 'Don't bother.' " But with treatment, her disease went into remission. Suddenly things looked brighter to Mr. Cuevas, who agreed to come down and surrender to the officers who were by then waiting below. Officer Lugo said that when she visited Mr. Cuevas in the hospital where he was taken for observation he smiled and said, "You saved my life."

title: Brazil's Amazon Basin Becomes Cocaine Highway
description: A small airplane loaded with cocaine-refining chemicals crashes and explodes along Brazil's border with Bolivia. Another plane runs out of fuel and lands on a dirt road near Brazil's border with Peru. The police seize chemicals and $858,690 in United States currency.

title: Jill Nusim Weds Paul A. Fishbin
description: Jill W. Nusim, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Nusim of West Orange, N.J., was married last evening to Paul A. Fishbin, a son of Nancy Freedman and Peter Fishbin, both of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson and Cantor Henry C. Butensky officiated at the Chanticler in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Gooden Pours It On As Mets Win in Rain
description: Dwight Gooden felt the cold on his face and the rain on his neck, and so it was hard for him not to feel the current of fear course through him.

title: Jungle Love
description: WALKING WITH THE GREAT APES

title: June Weissinger, a Teacher, Marries
description: June Watrous Weissinger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Weissinger Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Douglas Carter Blackwell, the son of Mary Blackwell of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Ridge Blackwell of Los Angeles. The Rev. William Lockhart, a minister of the Christian Church, Disciples of God, who is a great-uncle of the bride, officiated at St. Mary's Church.

title: Headliners; The Bottom Line
description: Mayor Sharon Pratt Dixon of Washington seems to think that the rod has been spared long enough in that city's public schools. In the course of taping an NBC television interview that is to be broadcast this week, Mayor Dixon said that teachers should be allowed to spank unruly students. The United States Supreme Court has refused to bar corporal punishment, and it is still permitted in 30 states, but Washington has banned it since 1918. "I think that kind of authority needs to be restored starting at the earliest possible age," she said. "Young people respond to discipline." And teachers' organizations respond to such suggestions. Among the groups condemning the Mayor's remarks was the Washington Teachers Union, which declared, "Violence begets violence." The Mayor then back-pedaled a bit. Through a spokesman, she said she was simply recalling the atmosphere of order that prevailed during her own school days, and was by no means proposing to bring back spanking.

title: Her Mother's Victim
description: JOANNA

title: Carolyn A. Mann and Paul Cunningham to Marry
description: June wedding plans for Carolyn Amy Mann and Paul Richard Cunningham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Cunningham of Chappaqua, N.Y., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard O. Mann of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'VOICE OF THE PRAIRIE'

title: Susan Rothman, Physician, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Clifton Rothman of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Susan Rothman to Dr. Evan Coulson Lipsitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hilary J. Lipsitz of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. 885,000 7 Sterling Road 7-bedroom, 5 1/2-bath, 14-year-old ranch; family room, stone fireplace, wet bar, deck, 2 Jacuzzis, pond, lake w/mooring, 2 acres; taxes $13,066. Scarsdale, N.Y. 292,500 15 Barclay Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 66-year-old colonial; family room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $6,800. Waccabuc, N.Y. 315,000 15 Hunt Farm Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, eat-in kitchen, deck, Jacuzzi, 2-car garage; taxes not yet assessed. Granby, Conn. 296,000 209 Day Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 19-year-old colonial; wide plank floors, screened porch with brick floor, possible second lot, 6 acres; taxes $4,058. Hartford, Conn. 98,500 46 Nepaug Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 64-year-old colonial; pantry off kitchen, formal dining room, 1-car detached garage, 50- by 125-ft. lot; taxes $2,010. Simsbury, Conn. $285,000 6 Nod Brook Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; new kitchen with cathedral ceiling, remodeled bathrooms, skylights, 1 acre; taxes $3,846. OTHER AREAS Massapequa, L.I. 215,000 239 West End Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $4,000. Sayville, L.I. 175,000 20 East Tower Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 70-year-old Tudor; fireplace, family room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,400. Hopatcong, N.J. 105,000 31 Kaynor Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old remodeled ranch; fireplace, corner lot; taxes $2,283.

title: Where Foreign Films Have Taken Refuge
description: To the Editor:

title: Bullish on Sex
description: PRIVATE ACTS By Linda Gray Sexton. 317 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

title: The 2 'Strangers' Who Sued
description: "I'M sure that the movie will be tremendously biased," said John Broderick, an anti-abortion advocate who challenged Martin Klein in court. "You can tell that just by looking at its title."

title: U.S Presses Military Relief Effort; Hungary Kurds Await Rescue From Mud and Cold
description: United States cargo planes and helicopters stepped up their airlift of emergency supplies today as the American military extended its control over international relief operations for the refugee Iraqi Kurds.

title: Kimberley Zukor and Marc Greenberg to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mark Zukor of Monroe, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Kimberley Joi Zukor and Marc David Greenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron G. Greenberg of Livingston, N.J.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My home was built in 1965 and has custom-made birch kitchen cabinets that were put in at the time. They now look very bad, but I do not have a lot to spend. Should I refinish the cabinets or install new ones?

title: Some Breast Implants Are Tied to Cancer
description: A polyurethane-coated cosmetic device that hundreds of thousands of women have had surgically implanted in their breasts in the past 20 years can break down in the body and release a chemical that has been found to cause liver cancer in experimental animals, Government scientists have determined.

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TOUGHBOY AND SISTER

title: Blasts on Oil Tanker Increase Fears in Italy
description: A huge explosion and two smaller blasts rocked a burning tanker today, heightening fears that the sinking vessel could break apart and spill millions of gallons of oil onto the Italian Riviera.

title: RECORDS BRIEFS
description: Brahms: Serenade No. 1 (reconstruction by Rotter) Scharoun Ensemble Berlin. Koch/ Schwann Musica Mundi 311 114; CD only.

title: Caryn Furst Marries David Bromberg
description: Caryn Furst, the daughter of S. Robert Furst of Wilton, Conn., and the late Ann Furst, was married in White Plains last evening to David Bromberg, the son of Jannet Bromberg of Toronto and the late Morris Bromberg. Rabbi Mark Winer performed the ceremony at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel.

title: Reviews/Music; Stepping to the Front
description: Morris Goldberg, a white South African saxophonist and penny whistler who has maintained a close relationship with fellow South African emigre musicians since he came to the United States 30 years ago, has spent most of his career here playing supporting roles with Abdullah Ibrahim, Miriam Makeba and Hugh Masakela as well as Harry Belafonte and Paul Simon, on whose "Graceland" album his penny whistle solo was a highlight. Although his solos on alto and soprano saxophones and clarinet, as well as penny whistle, invariably stand out in any setting, he is rarely heard as leader of a group.

title: Metro Datelines; Judge Frees Woman in Custody Fight
description: A woman jailed since Tuesday for refusing to reveal the location of her young sons was freed under a judge's order on Friday after she revealed the boys' whereabouts.

title: Perspectives: Neighborhood Stores; Columbia Street Tips Hat to Commerce
description: EVEN an optimist would be hard-pressed to make the case that Columbia Street in South Brooklyn will recover the commercial vibrancy it enjoyed years ago. For Destiny has dealt it a series of blows.

title: Ms. Bounds to Wed M. T. Bradley Jr.
description: June wedding plans for Elizabeth Margaret Bounds and Michael Thomas Bradley Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley of Indianapolis, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harrison L. Bounds of New York.

title: Woosnam Stands Tall Going Into Final Round
description: The back nine at the Augusta National has long been golf's most dramatic stage, and this afternoon diminutive Ian Woosnam of Wales put on a bravura performance to take a one-shot lead into the final round of the Masters.

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rev. Stephen Robb Billings Is Married To Barbara A. Morrison in New Jersey
description: Barbara Ann Morrison, the daughter of Mrs. Robert W. Morrison of Palmyra, N.J., was married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Riverton, N.J., to the Rev. Stephen Robb Billings, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott A. Billings of Falmouth, Mass.

title: Topics of The Times; Judge Ryskamp's Own Words
description: Some supporters say people were "out to get" Kenneth Ryskamp, but what truly did him in as a nominee for a Federal appeals court was his unrepentant insensitivity.

title: Postings: Spring House Tour; Victoriana in Flatbush
description: Spring is the season of house tours, and those looking for one of the most unusual might set aside next Sunday for Flatbush, the Brooklyn neighborhood that retains New York City's best selection of large Victorian homes. A tour of a dozen of them is planned by the Flatbush Development Corporation, a nonprofit group.

title: Huntington Begins Legalizing Apartments
description: THE Town of Huntington is trying a carrot-and-stick approach to coax compliance with an ordinance legalizing accessory apartments in single-family houses.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Lisbon, Me.;
A Town's Faith Misplaced
description: OFFICIALS in this small blue-collar town 15 minutes southeast of Lewiston believed William Slattery when he promised to turn the dilapidated Farwell Mill into a thriving apartment and retail complex.

title: Rhode Island Ends Furloughs
description: Unions representing state employees have accepted a plan by Gov. Bruce Sundlun that will bring an end to the periodic one-day shutdowns of Rhode Island government that began last month and were to continue until July 1.

title: The Executive Computer; Borland Is Making the Most of Old Technology
description: For users not yet ready or willing to switch to the Windows operating system from the Microsoft Corporation, Borland International's new Quattro Pro spreadsheet, version 3.0, offers almost the same "what you see is what you get" graphics and commands. Perhaps more than any other recent program, Quattro Pro proves that there is still plenty of life left in the DOS operating system.

title: In World of Space-Age Toys, a Return of String and Spool
description: Walk the dog. Around the world. Rock the baby. Nearly everyone recognizes these phrases as the repertory of the yo-yo enthusiast. Now, 62 years after Donald F. Duncan Sr. brought it back from the Philippines, the yo-yo is enjoying a comeback.

title: Travel Advisory; Poland Ends Need for Visas For Americans
description: Poland has joined the growing number of Eastern European countries that have eliminated visas for Americans. Beginning tomorrow, United States citizens will no longer need a visa to enter the country.

title:
The Executive Life;
The Overstressed Sniff for a Dose of Relaxation
description: People will try almost anything to expel stress -- acupuncture, yoga and isolation tanks, shiatsu and the Canyon Ranch. Then there are always seaweed tablets, environmental music and smelling.

title: Warp and Weft: How Weaving Transcends Its Materials
description: THE weaver's craft, from tapestries to lace, is on display this month at "Fabrics of the 90's," a show and sale of the Handweavers Guild of Connecticut. Members are displaying more than 100 works, including rugs, wall hangings, bed coverings, table accessories, baskets, dolls and clothing. Demonstrations of weaving, spinning and basket making add another dimension to the juried show, which runs through Saturday at the Robert Allan Keeney Memorial Cultural Center in Wethersfield.

title: Legislature Confronting Proposals on Housing
description: A CONTROVERSIAL package of bills promoting a regional approach to low-cost housing squeaked through the General Assembly's Planning and Development Committee last week. The bills were hailed as "ambitious" and "visionary" by enthusiastic Democratic supporters, while Republican committee members called them "a deliberate attack against suburban life in Connecticut."

title:
FORUM;
When Executives Should Just Say No
description: I am a lawyer who works in a modern office. I can transport reams of documents across continents in an instant or close a multimillion-dollar deal in a flash. I know I should feel grateful. So why do I feel enslaved?

title: Bibliophilia: Still No Cure in Sight
description: On April 24, 1911, Henry E. Huntington confirmed his intention to form one of the world's finest libraries by spending $50,000 for a Gutenberg Bible, the most anyone had ever bid on a printed book.

title: A Takeover Fails at York College But 7 Protests Continue at CUNY
description: A student effort to take over the main building at York College in Jamaica, Queens -- part of a wave of protests by students at the City University of New York -- fizzled early yesterday when about 35 students left after three hours at the urging of college administrators, and as a police squad car arrived.

title: As Banks Struggle Back, Consumers Pay
description: AFTER enduring their worst year since the Great Depression, banks in New Jersey have begun a modest rally, but bankers and banking analysts expect the recovery to be long and arduous.

title: Camera
description: It's funny how people who think nothing of renting cars, condos and sporting goods for vacations will carry along the same old photo equipment they use for snapshots back home. But renting camera gear can put some new snap in what would otherwise be the same old shots, and it is also a good way to learn about equipment and techniques you might otherwise only daydream about.

title: Miss Fine to Wed Scott L. Pachter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Fine of Virginia Beach, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Elizabeth Fine, to Scott Larry Pachter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey L. Pachter of Melville, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on March 24 misstated the preferred telephone number for Martinair charter airline reservations. The preferred reservation number is (800) 366-4655.

title: How Private Should Archives Remain?
description: To the Editor:

title: Developer's Suit Is Ruled Retaliatory
description: IN a decision called unprecedented in state legal history, a Supreme Court justice sitting in White Plains has strongly criticized a developer's suit involving an environmental group and said he planned to have the developer pay at least part of the group's legal costs.

title:
POP MUSIC;
Now Turning the Tables . . . the D.J. as Star
description: On "Indeterminacy," a two record collection of droll anecdotes, the composer John Cage tells a wry tale about a record-breaking record player. "The jukebox was turned on so everybody could dance," he recounts. "One of the arms moved to select a record. The playing arm moved to an extraordinarily elevated position. After a slight pause, it came down rapidly and heavily on the record, smashing it." The process is repeated again and again. "And meanwhile," says Mr. Cage, with obvious relish, "all the flashing, colored lights worked perfectly, making the whole scene glamorous."

title: Decades Later, Holocaust Survivors Find Their Rescuer
description: DURING the darkest days of the Nazi Holocaust, a Christian farmer from the Ukraine risked his own life by sheltering a Jewish family in a bunker under his farmhouse for more than two years. When World War II ended, the rescuer and the rescued parted.

title: Wajda's 'Korczak' Sets Loose the Furies
description: In the closing shot of Andrzej Wajda's new film, "Korczak," a cattle car crammed with Jewish children from the Warsaw ghetto rumbles toward the Treblinka concentration camp. Suddenly the action shifts to slow motion, and the car uncouples from the train as if touched by an unseen hand. Its doors slide open, and the children spill happy and laughing into a verdant field.

title: What They're Wearing: Short With Shape
description: SOME DESIGNERS MAY BE TOUTING longer skirts, but most smartly turned-out women continue to keep their hemlines above the knee. And the short evening dress is still the overwhelming choice for festive soirees. While black continues to be worn by so very many women, strong colors definitely made inroads into the evening scene this winter, at least in Manhattan. But now that spring is here, so are all shades of pink. The unadorned slip dress is giving way to short styles with definite shape to them. Skirts are flaring out or curving in belled or flounced lines. The dresses themselves are becoming more ornamented. As a result, knockout accessories like chokers, earrings and bracelets look better on the discreet side while big jeweled buttons and evening bags in inventive shapes are becoming star touches. Flesh-toned or pale stockings are superseding dark-toned hose. But no one is about to give up their sandals or sexy high-heel evening pumps.

title: Susan Flynn to Marry Richard Carnes in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Flynn of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Susan Cathryn Flynn and Richard Christopher Carnes, a son of Dorothea Foster Carnes of Darien, Conn., and W. Robert Carnes of Stamford, Conn.

title: Travel Advisory; Festival Music In Jerusalem
description: Marking its 30th season, the Israel Festival in Jerusalem presents native artists along with visiting performers in programs of music, theater and dance from May 11 to June 1. They will be at the Sultan's Pool (Merrill Hassenfeld Amphitheater) outside the Old City walls and at other sites. Being remembered are Mozart, Dvorak, Prokofiev and Bernstein.

title: Tina Fiore to Wed Mark Zebrowski; Maria Fiore to Wed Frank Kutschera
description: Dr. and Mrs. Americo S. Fiore of Southampton, L.I., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Antoinette Joanne Fiore and Mark Allen Zebrowski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Zebrowski of Southampton, and September wedding plans for their daughter Maria Anita Fiore and Frank Matthias Kutschera, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joachim Kutschera of Hamburg, Germany.

title: Feltsman Plays It Again, this Time With Feeling
description: Instant stardom has its attractions for classical musicians: comparatively high fees, major-label recordings, prestigious concerto dates and a degree of media ubiquity. But it has its down side. Often, instant fame is followed by a swift, powerful backlash. Musicians with the flexibility to weather such precipitate reversals eventually settle into steadier careers. The others join the long list of six-minute wonders.

title: White House Is Accused of Meddling in Talks on Civil Rights
description: The White House is trying to scuttle negotiations between civil rights groups and major corporations intended to reach a compromise on an antidiscrimination bill, business executives and civil rights advocates said today.

title: Sunday Outing; A Visit to the Bayou, 26 Miles From New York
description: Just 26 miles west of New York City, a bit of the bayou flourishes. It's the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in Meyersville, N.J., and for lovers of wildlife, particularly bird watchers, spring is an opportune time for a visit.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Sales of Lower-Priced Homes Rebound
description: AFTER eight months of house-hunting, Lewis and Michelle Korngut, both 31 years old and expectant parents, moved in March from the condominium they had been renting in Lawrenceville to their first home in the same community. Mr. Korngut, an assistant prosecutor in Mercer County, and his wife, an occupational therapist, paid in the $175,000 range for their four-bedroom colonial.

title: Colleen Murphy to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John L. Murphy of Alexandria, Va., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Colleen Ann Murphy, and Ervin Elliot Shindell, a son of Sydney Shindell of Jacksonville, Fla., and the late Pearl C. Shindell. Miss Murphy is the director of corporate communications at Time Warner Direct in New York. She graduated from the University of Richmond, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received an M.B.A. degree from New York University. Mr. Shindell is an associate in the Boston office of the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and, in a joint program, received law and M.B.A. degrees from the University of Chicago.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lynn, Mass.;
Capping Off Redevelopment
description: A COMMUTER rail station being built in this 360-year-old industrial city five miles north of Boston is capping off a five-year effort to redevelop the waterfront and nearby downtown commercial district.

title: 'Ike and the Disappearing Atrocities'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; Gun Control Politics Is Most Local of All
description: WHEN it comes to gun control, members of Congress are generally more likely to vote their geography than their ideology. Thus there was less than total surprise in the capital when one of the more liberal Senate Democrats, George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, declared his opposition to the Brady bill, the gun control measure that advanced through the House last week under threat of Presidential veto.

title: Headliners; What Warnings?
description: Did Dennis E. Kloske talk himself out of his job as an Under Secretary of Commerce? Some Bush Administration officials said so last week, contending that the White House had ordered Mr. Kloske's dismissal because he told Congress that the Administration had ignored warnings to limit the export of American technology to Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait. Mr. Kloske, who is the Commerce Department's top export official, told a Congressional panel that he had expressed strong misgivings about allowing Iraq to import such "dual-use" products as computers and chemicals, and then tried to bog down such exports in red tape after the State Department ignored his warnings. One official who declined to be identified said that John H. Sununu, the White House Chief of Staff, had put in motion a demand for Mr. Kloske's resignation. But Mr. Kloske's boss, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, denied that, saying that the export administrator was indeed resigning but that his departure had been planned for months and was entirely voluntary. Mr. Kloske said he had no comment.

title: Travel Advisory; Rome Gets a New Museum
description: Rome has a new Vatican museum, but it isn't in the Vatican, and it is open only once a month. Known as the Historical Museum of the Holy See, it is housed in the Lateran Palace, which was the residence of the popes in the Middle Ages until the 13th century. It is near the Appian Way, next to the Basilica of St. John in Lateran.

title: Gandhi Accuses Police of Kashmir Abuses
description: Rajiv Gandhi, leader of the opposition Congress Party, said today that Indian security forces had "gone berserk" in Kashmir, where they are fighting a major revolt.

title: Somber 50th Birthday for Brooklyn's Main Library
description: Inscribed in bronze above the front doors of the Brooklyn Public Library's central library on Grand Army Plaza is the writer Roscoe C. E. Brown's idealistic paean to the printed word: "While men have wit to read and will to know, the door to learning is the open book."

title: Reviews/Theater; The Games of Women Trapped in Madness
description: As a test of actors' ability to sustain a menacing mood of madness, Alberto Adellach's "Sabina and Lucrecia" is a good piece of work, however deficient it may be as an instrument of entertainment, enlightenment or emotional stimulation.

title:
BackTalk;
Boxing: All Show, Little Art and No Soul
description: Caligula, the Roman emperor, used to do some matchmaking in his dreams for what his cynics labeled politically as panem et circences, bread and circuses. If he had come up with the Foreman-Holyfield fight, he would have made his horse a senator long before he did or given up sleeping.

title: Beth Margel Wed To David Dahle
description: Beth Sharon Margel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence N. Margel of Villanova, Pa., was married last evening at the Rittenhouse in Philadelphia to David Raymond Dahle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Dahle of Cincinnati. Cantor Alvin Donald officiated, assisted by Msgr. Robert P. Maginnis.

title: Secret Sharers: Solo Acts in a Confessional Age
description: I always assumed the one person play was the theater's way of dealing with the shrinking dollar. You really can't get more basic -- a performer, a platform, a text. Take away anything else and what do you have? A loon emoting in the street or a mime show.

title: Charles Wolf, Diamond Merchant, 90
description: Charles Wolf, a diamond merchant, died on April 6 at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: For 60, Home Was Once a 6-by-9-Foot Space
description: In lower Manhattan, where Jacob Riis chronicled the squalor of crowded slums a century ago, 60 immigrants had until recently been living in cold windowless cubicles smaller than jail cells.

title: Business Diary/April 7-12
description: COMPANIES Kerkorian's Strategy for T.W.A.: Cold Cash

title: Owen Kupferschmid; Executive Is Dead at 33
description: Owen M. Kupferschmid, a lawyer who was legal director of the Debt-for-Development Foundation in Washington, died on Tuesday at a New York Health and Racquet Club gymnasium on East 45th Street. He was 33 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The World; The Word From Arabs And Israelis: 'Yes, but . . . '
description: Foreign Minister David Levy, announcing last week that Israel had agreed in principle to an American proposal for a regional peace conference with the Arabs, declared that he was spelling this agreement out not only in black and white but in the "bright and illuminating daylight of the strong Israeli sun." The only problem was that it was pouring rain as he spoke.

title: Soviet Director Killed
description: The executive director of the Soviet syndicate planning the nation's first America's Cup challenge was killed in a helicopter crash on Friday, leaving the Red Star syndicate without its most stabilizing influence, said the group's spokesman in San Diego, Douglas K. Smith.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Lynn, Mass.;
Capping Off Redevelopment
description: A COMMUTER rail station being built in this 360-year-old industrial city five miles north of Boston is capping off a five-year effort to redevelop the waterfront and nearby downtown commercial district.

title: Ideas & Trends; There Still May Be Something Scientific About Cold Fusion
description: ONCE hailed as the hottest discovery of the century, cold fusion is fast leaving the phase of high-tech hyperbole: as the discoverers of the disputed phenomenon fade from public view, the Utah institute set up to commercialize their findings is running out of cash, and critics are charging that the report that started the frenzy two years ago was seriously flawed. Yet the field lives on.

title: Brice Marden Reveals His Connections
description: Brice Marden's show here at the Museum of Fine Arts is one of the most beautiful small exhibitions in recent memory. Mr. Marden is the latest participant in the museum's Connections series, for which artists juxtapose their own works with works from the permanent collection. In collaboration with Trevor Fairbrother, curator of contemporary art at the museum, he has organized a display as intelligently composed as one of his paintings.

title: Deborah Anderson Marries
description: Deborah Slaner Anderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred P. Slaner of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday to John F. Larkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Larkin Jr. of Brewster, N.Y. Justice John Friedman, a retired Scarsdale town and village judge, officiated at the Music Room of the Equitable Building. Ms. Anderson, who is 42 years old and is keeping her name, is the executive director of the Women's Sports Foundation in New York. She graduated from the University of Oregon and received an M.B.A. from the University of Maryland. Mr. Larkin, 49, is a senior partner in the New York law firm of Mendes & Mount. He graduated from Hamilton College and Albany Law School. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: Ties Are Beneficial to Partners and Patients
description: TWO of the eight community health centers in New Jersey have affiliations with hospitals that officials say benefit the partners and their patients alike.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 14, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 26 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An F.B.I. man and woman track a serial killer. 2 5 RED DRAGON, by Thomas Harris. (Dell, $5.95.) A retired F.B.I. agent returns to service to track down a serial killer. 3 18 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.)
