The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Colorful Beads of Trade in Senegal
description: SENEGALESE women heighten their allure with the gentle clicking and sweet perfume of strands of tiny beads rolled from a paste of powdered seeds and worn around the waist, underneath yards of cotton clothing. In Africa, a bead is rarely a simple ornament, whether it is displayed around the neck as a sign of status or hidden beneath the folds of a voluminous robe, an invisible yet audible signal to a husband or lover.

title: No Pictures, Please, No Pictures
description: FACE it: Family vacations are fun, but they're not 100 percent fun; a certain amount of stress is involved. And naturally, you'd like to reduce the stress. Well, I have a suggestion, but it's so weird it sounds a bit un-American.

title: Mary Therese Seaman to Marry Robert Foster
description: June wedding plans for Mary Therese Seaman and Robert Clark Foster, a son of Frances M. Foster of Ocean, N.J., and the late L. Clark Foster, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Seaman of Middletown, N.J. Miss Seaman, 30 years old, is a food writer and a recipe tester and developer for Food and Wine magazine in New York. She graduated from the University of Hartford and the culinary arts program of the New School for Social Research. The prospective bridegroom, 38, is a sales manager for Jones New York Intimates, a division of the I. Appel Corporation, a clothing manufacturer in New York. He is a graduate of the University of Notre Dame.

title: Pope Appoints New Bishops in Soviet Union
description: Pope John Paul II today named spiritual leaders for Roman Catholics in Russia and two other Soviet republics, fulfilling a major condition for a possible papal visit to the Soviet Union.

title: Suzanne Cregan, Architect, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John D. Cregan of Franklin Lakes, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Suzanne Elizabeth Cregan and Gregory Stephen Donat, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Donat of Harrison, N.J.

title: Medicare Is Approved for Liver Transplants
description: Medicare will begin paying the cost of beneficiaries' liver transplants, the Government has announced.

title: Campus Life: Texas; Infants Smarter Than We Think, Researchers Say
description: At 7 months of age, children can recognize a picture of a human face as more than just a combination of parts. Three months later they can understand how a car hits another in a cartoon. At 18 months, they can comprehend the reasoning for each step in taking a bath.

title: Highest Rate In the Nation
description: TWO million people nationwide suffer head injuries each year, according to the National Head Injury Foundation. Of those, 70,000 to 100,000 injuries result in death and 70,000 to 90,000 in life-long physical, intellectual and psychological disabilities.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Yonkers Storefront With Chandeliers
description: ALTHOUGH on recent visits to Paolo's we found less to admire than we had three years ago, when it moved to its present quarters from nearby, dusty New Main Street, the restaurant isn't dead yet. It still shows vital sparks that recall its early promise. Baskets of good bread load the tables, and an exuberant mouth-tingling mash of garlic, eggplant and olive oil stands close by, ready to be spread on the thick slices. Although house dressings vary in quality, a bowl of ordinary but crisped greens arrives to be served family style. And whole cloves of garlic lend sweetness and perfume to many dishes.

title: Easter Lilies Can Glow Past the Holiday
description: THE Easter season gave lilies a good show. Plants in full bloom were received by many as holiday gifts, and the goal now is to keep these fragrant, white trumpets glowing.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE MEDICAL CENTER ALLERGY CLINICS;
When Spring Gets an Early Start, So Does the Sneezing
description: OUTSIDE the sky was a hazy blue, the air soft and humid and the swollen buds on the trees heralded the early arrival of spring. Inside, people were sneezing, wheezing, coughing and itching.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Early April auto sales * Tentative release date for NCR's first-quarter earnings * Labor Secretary Martin testifies before House labor subcommittee on allegations that coal companies tampered with coal-dust safety studies * Last day to file income taxes

title: Search for Harlem Hospital Chief Exposes Struggle
description: The search for a new executive director for troubled Harlem Hospital is mired in a power struggle between the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and the hospital's Community Advisory Board, members of the board said yesterday.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Still a Wonder
description: It has been compared to the bow of a ship, to a locomotive and, of course, to a flatiron. New Yorkers today know it only by its famous nickname, but when the Fuller Building -- as it was called originally -- was erected in 1903, it was one of the new century's wonders. Many ridiculed the architect Daniel Burnham when its triangular shape began to rise out of the construction site on East 23d Street, but the building quickly began to attract photographers. In FLATIRON: A Photographic History of the World's First Steel Frame Skyscraper, 1901-1990 (American Institute of Architects, $29.95), Peter Gwillim Kreitler, a photographer and collector, has assembled a superb collection of their images. Edward Steichen's moody, rain-soaked portrait is beautifully reproduced, as is Alfred Steiglitz' delicate snowscape. The Photo Secessionists presented the building as a natural phenomenon looming out of the bustle of the city. Later photographers saw it as a triumph of modernism. By shooting it from an oblique angle, the Bauhaus architect Walter Gropius made the building appear to tilt, revealing the avant-garde character lurking beneath its neo-Renaissance friezes. Alongside the familiar images in Mr. Kreitler's collection are little-known finds, like the haunting night view of the Flatiron lit up like a luxury liner, a host of lesser buildings trailing in its wake.

title: Foreign Affairs; White House Guilt?
description: I've been trying to figure out President Bush's responsibility for the present human misery in Iraq -- and to better understand the mind of this man who is defining the new world order. Bear with me.

title: Jane Lattes Is Married To Norbert Swislocki
description: Jane Lattes, the daughter of Dorothy Flax of Cincinnati and the late Dr. Nathan Flax, was married in Palisades, N.Y., last night to Dr. Norbert Swislocki, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Adam Swislocki of Los Angeles. Rabbi David Fass performed the ceremony at the couple's home.

title:
Focus: Suburban Washington;
Incentives Ebbing as Housing Sales Rise
description: ENCOURAGED by signs of a strengthening real-estate market in the greater Washington area, many builders this spring are withdrawing the special incentives they used last year to lure potential buyers.

title: Travel Advisory; Mystery Tour
description: "In the Footsteps of Sherlock, Dracula and Agatha" is the title of a 14-day tour of England that will visit homes and sites associated with Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, Bram Stoker, Agatha Christie and a dozen other writers. Departure is on June 29, escorted by Dr. Arthur Liebman, a lecturer and author, and Joyce Ann Liebman, a concert pianist. Devon, Yorkshire and Cambridge as well as London are on the itinerary. The cost per person, in double occupancy, round trip from New York, is $2,989. Information: Contemporary Tours, 580 Plandome Road, Manhasset, N.Y. 11030; (516) 627-8873.

title: Reviews/Theater; Revisiting A Classic From Spain
description: For directors as well as actors, performing a play by the great 17th-century Spanish writer Calderon must seem about as easy as dancing on a high wire, and none of Calderon's plays requires a surer sense of balance than "The Mayor of Zalamea" ("El Alcalde de Zalamea"). But difficulty never seems to intimidate the Repertorio Espanol, and its presentation of this classic is a fascinating, if occasionally wobbly, effort.

title: Stoneham Journal; Private Hands May Save Zoo a State Abandoned
description: In a dark cavern once known as the Stone Zoo's Primate House, five monkeys sit in a dingy cage, looking out at the empty cages that surround them.

title: Kathleen Corcoran Weds
description: Kathleen Teresa Corcoran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Corcoran of Kings Park, L.I., was married yesterday at Infant Jesus Roman Catholic Church in Port Jefferson, L.I., to Patrick Joseph Lyons, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Lyons of Port Jefferson Station, L.I. The bride, 26 years old, is a production editor at the Scholastic publishing company in New York. She graduated from Fordham University. The bridegroom, 32, is a graphics editor at The New York Times.

title: Referendums On Golf and Tennis
description: In reporting on the Manhasset Park Commissioners' sponsorship of an advisory (implicitly binding) referendum on the acquisition of the Manhasset Country Club [ March 10 ] , you cite but do not give them enough credit for their unprecedented action.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A LOT TO ASK A Life of Barbara Pym. By Hazel Holt. Dutton, $19.95.

title: The Cultivated Gardener; Fancy Greens, Easy to Grow
description: I became addicted to arugula a few springs ago, and it's a dangerous habit to support. When that flavor gets into your blood, it's hard to say no. But market prices these days range from $1.29 to $1.49 for a bunch of limp leaves.

title: A la Carte: On the Barbecue Trail
description: GOOD barbecue and Long Island are anything but synonymous. In fact, barbecue restaurants on the Island, real down-home corn-pone barbecue, are almost an endangered species.

title: Rusting in Russia
description: STEELTOWN, USSR Soviet Society in the Gorbachev Era. By Stephen Kotkin. Illustrated. 269 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $24.95.

title: All in the Modern Stone-Age Family
description: For nearly a year reporters have been hounding Brian Henson with the same question: Can he handle Jim Henson Productions, the Muppet-based entertainment empire he took over soon after his father, Jim, died unexpectedly in May?

title: NATO Agrees to Expand a Rapid-Reaction Force
description: The military planners of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have agreed on a plan to expand their multinational rapid-reaction force to as many as 100,000 troops to meet new demands inside and outside the alliance's area of operations.

title: Community Centers Emerge as Models For Care of Poor
description: DOWN the block from the Pickin' Chicken and the West Fourth Street Superette, amid boarded-up row houses, aging duplexes and littered yards, the Plainfield Health Center cares for the city's poor.

title: The World; Fault Lines
description: IN the upper mountains, the mud is everywhere, churned by long and frequent rains, practically having a life of its own as it oozes down the slopes, swallowing up truck wheels and turning each step into slippery peril.

title: C. S. Deardorff Weds Ellie Freedman
description: Eleanor Jane Freedman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome K. Freedman of New Haven, was married last evening at the Marquand Chapel at Yale University to Craig Stephen Deardorff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Deardorff of Rockville, Md. Rabbi Stephen Mason and the Rev. William Hicks, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Harlem Groups Try to Stop St. Luke's Growth
description: A coalition of legal-rights organizations has asked the Federal Government to block a $500 million renovation of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and to stop the center from reducing services relied on by the poor at its Morningside Heights campus.

title: Coins
description: Gold coins made by the U.S. to help oil companies pay their debts to the Saudis.

title: Inns and Books
description: To the Editor: How we wish Wayne Curtis had traveled a bit more before he wrote about the dearth of good books in country inns. Had he come to the Inn at Long Last in Chester, Vt., he would have found our library of 2,000 books.

title: A Fire Island Ritual That Is Conceived in Manhattan
description: ENOUGH of this gloom and doom about Long Island's not keeping its younger generation. The children of Long Island are returning to their roots, at least on a summertime basis.

title: World Markets; The Dollar and Overseas Stocks
description: For foreign companies that do business in the United States, a rising dollar may look like a good bet. There is the bonus of translating dollar profits back into their home currencies and the competitive edge of their exports to America. But looks can be deceiving.

title:
MUSIC;
What Brendel Wants From a Piano
description: THE pianist Alfred Brendel, who was in New York City to play a Carnegie Hall recital last week, was trying out instruments at a piano company warehouse in order to select one for his coming Princeton performance.

title: He Loves, She Loves
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: The Stamps column last Sunday misstated the year of issue of the first postage stamp, the Penny Black, and the one-penny Mulready lettersheet. It was 1840, not 1851.

title: Postings: Jamaica Farmers Market; Brick Sale to Pave a Lane
description: The new indoor home for the Jamaica Farmers Market, one of the city's oldest greenmarkets, is nearing completion on 160th Street in Jamaica, Queens.

title: CRIME
description: Nature goes on a rampage in David Stout's coolly terrifying NIGHT OF THE ICE STORM (Mysterious Press/Warner, $19.95), snapping trees and utility lines in the fictional upstate New York town of Bessemer, and unleashing in one person the passion for murder. "I have killed," marvels the man who has just battered a young priest to death with his own golf club. "I am forever different because I have killed." And yet, 20 years later, the murderer remains undetected -- until some reporters gathering memories for the local newspaper's 90th anniversary play a tape of a long-ago office party at which a telling clue was dropped. Can the story-sniffing journalists solve the crime and expose its seamy cover-up before the reunion draws the murderer back home?

title: The Perspective In Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; A Space Film In Washington
description: A 45-minute look at the earth from outer space has joined the selection of films that visitors can see on a five-story screen at the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum in Washington.

description: To the Editor:

title: Phoenix Theater Moves To SUNY Arts Center
description: THE Phoenix Theater Company is moving. The three-year-old nonprofit, professional repertory company, which has been at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry since 1988, is moving to the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase this summer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 7 about the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn misstated the date of Jackie Gleason's death. It was June 24, 1987.

description: Looking for a Spokesman

title: Chinese Grow Healthier From Cradle to Grave
description: In a bare obstetrics ward at the Ninth People's Hospital, Zhang Junyong stretched out on a cot and let the doctor listen through a wooden egg cup to the heartbeat thumping from the bulge in her abdomen. "I'm just a bit nervous," Ms. Zhang confessed with a smile.

title: Still Wild at Heart, and Even Weirder
description: SAILOR'S HOLIDAY The Wild Life of Sailor and Lula. By Barry Gifford. 344 pp. New York: Random House. $20.

title: Afternoon 'Triple Play' That's Off the Diamond
description: THE calendar is filled with appearances by Connecticut-based artists and ensembles this week. Today at 3, for starters, Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann will perform at Seaverns Hall in Suffield in a preview of a program they will present at the Hartford Cathedral Theater program on April 28 at 3 P.M. In addition to works of Bach and Prokofiev, the duo will give the first performance of Aaron Copland's 1943 Violin Sonata in Mr. Clark's transcription for cello and piano, while Ms. Schuldmann plays the Connecticut premiere of Paul Constantinescu's "Toccata for Solo Piano." Tickets are available at the door today. For reservations to the Hartford recital, which also includes Robert Starer's "Excursions for a Pianist," call 232-0085.

title: Topics of The Times; Sign of Prejudice
description: The Persian Gulf war led to scattered acts of intolerance against Americans of Arab descent and Muslim faith. The response was heartening. America's civic and political leaders, including President Bush, stood up and condemned these acts. But as is evident even in the middle of Times Square, anti-Arab and Muslim prejudice still exerts its insidious influence.

title: Dispatches From a Secret Continent
description: THE SOCCER WAR

title: No Headline
description: Nigerian Shift on Sanctions

title: Tainted Well Is Shut, and Source of the Trouble Is a Mystery
description: A TINY brick building near the Ramapo River here stands as mute testimony to the delicate balance that exists between man and his fragile environment.

title: All Involved Share Blame for Research Overcharges
description: Financial exchanges between the nation's research universities and the Federal Government used to be simple: The universities submitted their bills for research-related expenses, and the Government paid them.

title:
About Men;
Answering the Howl
description: HE COMES DOWN from three months alone in the mountains, his eyes wary and haunted, his nerves already jangly from the prospect of city life. Though he does not speak of it, he had a rough time up there in the tundra. He may yet lose a toe to frostbite, and his famous dog with the eerie, colorless eyes -- Denali -- has disappeared in a lightning storm.

title: We Can Help Kurds Without Sending Troops; Not Internal Affairs
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; In Search of a Trade Pact With the Environment in Mind
description: FROM Austin to Ottawa, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico barnstormed the continent last week, promoting a free trade agreement as a way to change the world. Addressing the Texas Legislature on Friday he said, "Seldom do these opportunities arise in the course of our history."

title: The Law Learns From the Kurds
description: President Bush was so determined to avoid plunging into a quagmire like Vietnam that he initially plunged instead into what looked like a glacier of icy indifference to the fate of Iraqi Kurds and Shiites. Now, after an uproar of shock, he has warmed to his humane duty. He has moved to reinforce international rescue operations by ordering the American military to feed and provide sanctuary for the refugees. By doing so at last, he advances his, and the world's, understanding of international law.

title: Leonard Schmitt, 88; Challenged McCarthy
description: Leonard F. Schmitt, a lawyer who challenged Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin in the 1952 Republican primary, at the height of Mr. McCarthy's anti-Communist campaign, died Thursday at the Good Samaritan Health Center in Merrill, Wis. He was 88 years old and lived in Merrill.

title: THE MAUVE-ING OF AMERICA
description: Cantwell describes a "Fantin-Latour moment" in the day of a Colorado woman who is swept away by the esthetics of orange juice chilling in a heavy crystal decanter. However, it is unwise to store acidic juices in crystal, because they can leach potentially dangerous quantities of lead from the vessels. BEVERLY MERZ Chicago

title: Cindy Shmerler, Editor, Is Wed
description: Cynthia Ann Shmerler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Shmerler of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Ford Jeffrey Levy, the son of Lawrence Levy and Toba Sherwood Levy, both of New York. Rabbi Jack Stern officiated at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Elizabeth Hazlitt Is Married
description: Elizabeth Mary Hazlitt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Hazlitt of Stony Brook, L.I., was married yesterday at SS. Philip and James Roman Catholic Church in St. James, L.I., to Michael William Emerson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Emerson of Quechee, Vt. The Rev. Jeffrey J. Madley and the Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: A Case of Mutual Admiration
description: REAGAN AND THATCHER

title: The World; Bush's Uneasy Welcome For Violeta Chamorro
description: PRESIDENT VIOLETA BARRIOS de CHAMORRO of Nicaragua will be the toast of Washington when she arrives tomorrow. She will be guest of honor at a formal state dinner at the White House and accorded the rare opportunity of addressing a joint meeting of Congress. No Nicaraguan leader has received such honors since Anastasio Somoza Garcia -- the founder of the Somoza dynasty -- rode with Franklin Delano Roosevelt in a motorcade down Pennsylvania Avenue in 1939.

title: Cryptozoologists Stalk Elusive Beasts
description: DID a sea serpent visit New Haven harbor in 1896? Do strange big cats roam Connecticut today? Where on Lake Champlain might the legendary monster Champ raise its head? And what's new with Sasquatch, the creature said to leave huge footprints across the Pacific Northwest?

title: Sabatini and Graf Trudge Along Their Collision Course
description: Defending champion Steffi Graf sprinted and Gabriela Sabatini suffered but the top two seeded players at the Bausch and Lomb Championships completed their weeklong collision course and will clash here in Sunday's final.

title: 'YOU COULD OUTLIVE YOUR DOCTOR'
description: I applaud your publication of Brian F. Hayes's article, " 'Who Knows? You Could Outlive Your Doctor' " (March 17). That it was a first-person and singular account added to its moving message of courage and determination.

title: Pietrangelo's Goaltending Keeps Penguins' Hopes Alive
description: Facing elimination from the Stanley Cup playoffs, the Pittsburgh Penguins responded to the challenge tonight. The Devils took an early lead in a bid to capture their opening-round series with the Penguins, but Pittsburgh came back with four straight goals.

title: Kriss Lawless to Wed Peter Damon Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Lawless of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kriss Renee Lawless to Peter Stanley Damon Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Damon of Middletown, R.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Groups Taking Aid for the Kurds
description: American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102

title: THE MAUVE-ING OF AMERICA
description: There is most certainly a place for beauty in our lives, and a time for self-indulgence. However, today's disciples of Demeter need to care about the quality of the water used in their homes, the purity of the air and the chemical integrity of the contents of their grocery bags. Rather than retreating into a private world of make-work order and beauty, make a life of use to the world. Such a life will be far from drab. PALMA TORRISI Port Washington, L.I.

title: Jordan Pays a Big Call To Youth in the Hospital
description: A lot of boys dream of growing up to be Michael Jordan, but for 6-year-old Kevin Hardiman the dream is somewhat circumscribed. Kevin has been paralyzed since being hit by a car March 1.

title: Orville Vogel Dies; Leading Researcher of Wheat Was 83
description: Orville Alvin Vogel, a wheat breeder whose research made possible the "Green Revolution" in world food production, died Friday at the convalescent center of the Panoramic City retirement village in Lacey, Wash. He was 83 years old and lived at Panoramic City.

title:
SWIMMING;
An 'Old' Man in the Pool Bids to Reclaim Past Glory
description: Launching a comeback attempt, Mark Spitz, 41 years old, the man who won seven gold medals at the 1972 Summer Olympic games in Munich, lost in a 50-meter butterfly match race today to 26-year-old Tom Jager. The world-record holder in the 50-meter freestyle, Jager finished in 24.92 seconds, which was 1.78 seconds faster than Spitz.

title: Getting Ahead Can Be A Tussle
description: They dieted, they wrestled, they cried and vomited in the hallways and behind the bleachers of the Palumbo Center.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are this week's scheduled release dates for major economic indicators. Monday None Tuesday Housing Starts...March Industrial Production...March Capacity Utilization...March Wednesday None Thursday Balance of Trade...Feb. Friday None

title: Minnesota Eliminates Chicago
description: Jon Casey made 26 saves and Brian Bellows had two goals and an assist as the Minnesota North Stars beat the Chicago Blackhawks, 3-1, tonight, winning a playoff series for the first time since 1985 and becoming the first team in 20 years with a first-round upset of the league's regular-season champion.

title: Topics of The Times; Check, Double Check
description: About one in five American taxpayers supports public financing for Presidential election campaigns. In New York City and New Jersey, twice as many -- 40 percent -- check the campaign funding box on their tax returns.

title: Critic's Notebook; Classical Music Magazine As Endangered Species
description: The recent news that Musical America is to be converted from a consumer publication into a music business trade journal came as a shock to anyone with a sense of the 93-year-old magazine's history. It was the oldest classical music magazine in the United States, and in recent years it was the only one that covered live performances as well as recordings.

title: The Election Story of the Decade
description: SUSPICIONS about a deal between the Reagan campaign and Iran over the hostages have circulated since the day of President Reagan's inaugural, when Iran agreed to release the 52 American hostages exactly five minutes after Mr. Reagan took the oath of office. Later, as it became known that arms started to flow to Iran via Israel only a few days after the inauguration, suspicions deepened that a secret arms-for-hostages deal had been concluded.

title: I.B.M. Going on Offensive To Promote Key Software
description: I.B.M., the world's largest computer company, has been pushed out of the personal computer and software spotlight by its software partner, the Microsoft Corporation, and this week, it begins a slow process of trying to push itself back in.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Florida Mid-Bay Bridge Authority is offering $81.6 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Yields offered in the series A bonds include 8 percent for an issue due in 2006, 8.10 percent in 2017 and 8.05 percent in 2022, while yields in the series B bonds, which are to be issued in denominations of $100,000, include 9.20 percent for a bond due in 2008 and 9.25 percent for one due in 2022. None of the bonds is rated. * Heller Financial, Chicago, is offering $100 million in 8.85 percent noncallable notes, due in 1996, at a price of 100, through Merrill Lynch & Co. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: Shoemaker Gets Some Good News
description: Bill Shoemaker, critically injured in a car accident last week, got the biggest victory of his training career as Fire the Groom charged home today to win the $211,350 Santa Anita Breeders' Cup.

title: 2 Workers Are Injured in Fire At Phillips Petroleum Plant
description: Two workers were injured in fires from explosions on Saturday at a Phillips Petroleum plant, the company said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-A9

title: Knights Awaken And Romp
description: The New York/New Jersey Knights of the World League of American Football appeared finally to find the controls to their run-and-shoot offense Saturday night, defeating the Machine, 44-0, in Montreal on 504 yards of total offense.

title: Start the U.N. Search Now
description: Wanted: Experienced manager and fluent communicator skilled in politics, to manage unwieldy multinational enterprise. Salary $192,000; perks include Sutton Place mansion, travel, entertainment allowances. Must deal with quarrelsome board and 159 demanding shareholders.

title: TV Takes Stock of a Hitless Season
description: The line score for the television ratings season that officially ended last night is dominated by negatives: short runs, no hits and many errors.

title: Wakiihuri Adds Boston to His Route
description: Several years ago, Douglas Wakiihuri showed why it might be a better idea to skip running a marathon in the spring when a more important race is scheduled later in the year.

title: Yankee Stadium Journal; Field Is Lush, and Yanks Are Undefeated at Home
description: Frank Albohn flicked through his ring of keys the way a monk thumbs his beads, stopping abruptly at a brass one, a bit shinier than the rest.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I've seen that scene of making the winning putt on the 18th at the Masters so many times. Never, ever in my heart did I ever feel I would be a part of it." -- Ian Woosnam. [ C1:5. ]

title: White Accuses Georgetown Law School of Bias in Admitting Blacks
description: A white law student's allegation that black students attending Georgetown University's law school are significantly less qualified than whites has shaken the Washington campus, which prides itself on its commitment to academic freedom and student diversity.

title: People
description: * Rein Luik has been named director of client services, a new post in the New York office of DDB Needham. * John Dinkel has been named director of product communications in the Los Angeles office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc.

title: Devils Furious Over Disallowed Goal
description: The Devils headed back to Pittsburgh on a charter flight today, but most of them felt they should have been going to Landover, Md., instead.

title: Those Bicycle Speedsters in the Park on Sundays Aren't Racers
description: To the Editor:

title: Prudent Haste on Alzheimer's
description: Victims of Alzheimer's disease and their families were understandably upset last month when the Food and Drug Administration balked at giving full approval to a new drug that treats some symptoms of the devastating brain disorder. But the agency is prudent in proposing wider testing. Haste is needed in completing additional research, not in marketing a still-unproven drug.

title: Yosef Tekoah, 65, Israeli Delegate To the U.N. for 7 Years, Is Dead
description: Yosef Tekoah, one of Israel's foremost diplomats, a longtime representative to the United Nations and chancellor of Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Speculation Continues On Rate Easing by Fed
description: The Federal Reserve Board may take some of the sting out of April 15 by confirming today that it has cut short-term interest rates, some credit market analysts say.

title: Point to Gottlieb On Being Enrolled
description: Heather Gottlieb has been a tenacious tennis player since she was 12 years old. At 16, she was the No. 1 junior girls' player in the Philadelphia region. Now as an 18-year-old freshman at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, she is still making her points.

title: Post Is Filled In Germany
description: A free-market politician from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party has been named the new president of Treuhand, the powerful agency that is converting state- owned enterprises in eastern Germany to capitalism.

title: Gooden Stiff After 149 Pitches But Dip in the Whirlpool Helps
description: Dwight Gooden smiled, lifted his right arm and assured reporters that, no, it had not fallen off over night. It did not, though, exactly feel 100 percent either.

title: Man Killed in Hostage Standoff in Oregon
description: A gunman took two women hostage in a crowded store on Saturday and wounded two officers before he was killed by the police.

title: Tom Watson's Disappointment
description: TOM WATSON has thought only about winning golf tournaments. Not coming close. Not collecting a nice check. To him, winning has always been all that mattered. When he earned $74,973 in 1973, his second full year on the PGA Tour, his wife, Linda, was happy.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of construction activity, the Park Avenue Tunnel from 33d to 40th Street will be closed from 9:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. for two weeks beginning today. Motorists are advised to use Lexington and Third Avenues as alternate routes.

title: Meulens Gaining Visual Support
description: Hensley Meulens is playing left field this season with one contact lens in and one out. No, Meulens did not lose a contact while he was chasing fly balls for the Yankees. He simply needs a customized contact lens because the shape of his right eye is distorted from a childhood accident.

title: Turkey to Let Some Refugees Be Moved In to Safer Ground
description: The Turkish authorities said today that they were easing their hard-line insistence that Kurds and other Iraqi refugees stay in harsh border mountains, where they are dying in rising numbers.

title: Dance in Review
description: Robert Kovich Company 14th Street Dance Center 344 East 14th Street

title: Brooklyn Home Fire Kills 2 Baby Brothers
description: Two young brothers were killed yesterday afternoon when a fire erupted in their Brooklyn apartment, Fire Department officials said.

title: BBDO's Chrysler Spots Use Patriotic Themes
description: The Chrysler Corporation introduced a campaign yesterday evening that seeks to turn the patriotic fervor from the Persian Gulf war into a stimulus for Americans to buy cars made in the United States.

title: Jessica A. Spira Is Married
description: Jessica A. Spira, a daughter of Iris L. Spira of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Dr. Henry Spira, was married yesterday at Temple Neve Shalom in Birmingham to Robert S. Kahn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald J. Kahn of Metuchen, N.J. Rabbis Gerald Zelizer and Arnold Goodman and Cantor Mordecai Goldstein officiated. The bride and bridegroom, both 26 years old, are 1986 summa cum laude graduates of Princeton University. She is a medical student at Harvard University. He is studying medicine at Vanderbilt University.

title: Miss Furth Weds Scott A. Weisman
description: Virginia Ellen Furth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Furth of White Plains, was married yesterday at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Scott Alan Weisman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour S. Weisman of Norwalk, Conn. Rabbi Joshua L. Goldberg performed the ceremony.

title: Essay; Duty to Intervene
description: George Bush's answer to genocide is to insist angrily that "our kids" -- his new term of juvenile vulnerability for what he used to call America's armed forces -- will not be "sucked" or "shoved" by some sinister outside pressure into anybody else's civil war.

title: Betsy Rosen Is Married
description: Betsy Rosen and Robert Schwartz, who are lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden by Rabbi Allan Blaine. The bride, 30 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Rosen of Belle Harbor, Queens. She is an associate in the New York office of the Chicago law firm of McDermott, Will & Emery. She graduated from the State University Nursing School at Binghamton and cum laude from Brooklyn Law School. The bridegroom, 35, is the son of Edna Schwartz of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Alvin Schwartz, and is an assistant general counsel at Nomura Securities in New York. He graduated magna cum laude from Fairleigh Dickinson University and received a law degree from Washington University in St. Louis.

title: Sabatini Storms Back To Rattle Graf Again
description: Gabriela Sabatini coughed like Camille but played comeback tennis like a commando this steamy afternoon to defeat defending champion Steffi Graf, 7-5, 7-6, here in the final of the Bausch

title: Those Bicycles Speedsters in the Park on Sundays Aren't Racers
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal Denied By Chrysler
description: A Chrysler Corporation spokesman today dismissed as "rumor and speculation" reports that the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation would assume $220 million in expenses at their joint assembly plant in Normal, Ill.

title: Planning a Recess Around the World
description: What are the odds that five million children will exercise simultaneously?

title: No Offers of Billions to Soviets, Tokyo Says
description: Japan and the Soviet Union, seeking to overcome decades of mistrust, are expected to establish greater trade, technology and cultural ties as the centerpiece to a visit this week by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, officials of both countries say.

title: 'Magic of Macy's' Promoted by Lintas
description: In the first volley of its new $150 million television advertising effort, R. H. Macy & Company introduced a series of ads yesterday in the New York City region.

title: Metro Matters; Return of Badillo As Council Girds For Redistricting
description: Describing Herman Badillo's resurgent mayoral ambitions as suggesting a possible political comeback would be an overstatement. He never went away.

title: Trade Restrictions Would Hurt All the Chinese; Religious Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: Base Closings Pit Some Republicans Against Bush
description: Senator Arlen Specter talked to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney about military base closings on Friday and again on Saturday. And he has an appointment with President Bush's chief of staff, John H. Sununu, to talk about it some more this week.

title: Unions Threaten Strike At Freight Rail Lines
description: Leaders of eight railroad unions with more than 150,000 members who have worked without a contract for three years have threatened to cripple the nation's freight lines with a strike on Wednesday.

title: Gail Glickman Weds Frederick Horwood
description: Gail L. Glickman, the daughter of Susan Glickman and Robert Glickman, both of New York, was married yesterday to Frederick Charles Horwood, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James N. Horwood of Reston, Va. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: INSIDE
description: Nicaragua Harbored Rebels Managua defended its role in providing a haven for Salvadoran guerrillas, despite objections from Washington, arguing that the policy had paid off by moving its neighbor toward peace. Page A3. U.S. Peanut Ban Studied As it criticizes Japan for barring imports of rice, the Bush Administration faces a decision on whether to retain a ban on imported peanuts. Page D1. No Reversal of Layoffs Many economists see an economic recovery budding, but company executives say they have no plans to resume hiring soon. Page D1. Loyalty to Party Has Limits The Defense Department's plan to close 31 major military installations has stirred up some Republican lawmakers who are normally loyal to President Bush. Page A10. Little Time, Less Money New York City's fiscal crisis is no longer over the horizon: the Mayor has three months to bridge a $300 million gap. News Analysis, Page B1.

title: What Its Star Dislikes About 'I Hate Hamlet'
description: "I will give you only very direct answers," Nicol Williamson says, settling into a plain wooden chair and reaching for the half of a Watney's ale that has been placed on the table beside him. "I am not somebody who wishes to create an illusion. Except onstage."

title: Egyptian Drug Arrest: Kuwaiti Sheik
description: Egyptian officials said today that they had arrested a member of the Kuwaiti ruling family on charges of possessing nearly two pounds of heroin and trafficking in the drug.

title: Groups Taking Aid for the Kurds
description: American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102

title: Robert LoBianco, 44, A Theatrical Producer
description: Robert LoBianco, a producer of avant-garde and experimental theater, died on Thursday at the New Yrok University Medical Center. He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cardinal Plans Meeting on Closing of School
description: In an impromptu meeting after morning services yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, John Cardinal O'Connor told a group of parents, teachers and schoolchildren from a Roman Catholic elementary school in East Harlem that he would meet with them later to talk about plans to close the school.

title: Orville Vogel, 83, Leading Researcher Of Wheat for U.S.
description: Orville Alvin Vogel, a wheat breeder whose research made possible the "Green Revolution" in world food production, died Friday at the convalescent center of the Panoramic City retirement village in Lacey, Wash. He was 83 years old and lived at Panoramic City.

title: Unscheduled Flights: Unusual Hazards; Flights That Kill Celebrities Show Risks of Finding Own Way to Fly
description: They fly to the next gig or the next game, to the next political rally or the next board meeting -- another day, another town, and another ride in a corporate jet, chartered plane, helicopter or whatever other conveyance seems convenient, sometimes regardless of risk.

title: Florio's Ax Ready to Fall On State TV
description: There is one budget story yet to be carried by the New Jersey Network, a state-run television system that gives the Garden State an identity on the airwaves: the possibility of the network's own demise.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEE FALK lives in at least two worlds: as the creator of the comic strips, "Mandrake the Magician" and "The Phantom," and as a playwright and theater director. Both worlds were represented on Friday night at a surprise birthday party for Mr. Falk at the Players Club in Manhattan.

title: Years After Doctor Dies, AIDS Tests for Patients
description: The story of Aldo Fabian Rey, a surgeon who died in 1988, is for some people here a twice-told tale: a doctor dies of AIDS, there are unnerving news accounts, people talk about risks and fears, then move on to something else.

title: Rifle Group Restates Opposition To Bill Delaying Gun Purchases
description: The National Rifle Association, long considered one of the most powerful lobbying groups in Washington, is sticking to its opposition to legislation that would require a seven-day waiting period for the purchase of handguns.

title: Nicaragua Defends Role as Rebel Haven, Saying It Fostered Salvador Peace
description: Over United States objections, Salvadoran guerrillas have been permitted to remain in Nicaragua since President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro took office a year ago, and her chief minister says the policy has paid off by helping to move El Salvador toward peace.

title: Trade Restrictions Would Hurt All the Chinese
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Television; From the Heavens to Earth, on PBS
description: The week brings a sizable complement of new PBS documentaries. The subjects range from calories to computers, from political huggermugger to the mysteries of the heavens. Here are some cautionary comments about five of the more noteworthy:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The person who won a contest as a look-alike of OPRAH WINFREY is a man. But Ms. Winfrey doesn't care. She plans to have him on her television talk show anyway.

title: Battered Women Still Face Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Zuckerman, Retailer, Wed to a Sales Executive
description: Linda Zuckerman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bert M. Zuckerman of Amherst, Mass., was married there yesterday to Charles Henry Gliedman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin L. Gliedman of Atlantic Beach, L.I. Rabbi Sheila Peltz Weinberg performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community of Amherst, a synagogue.

title: Michelin Cuts Are Assessed
description: Cutbacks by Michelin will eliminate 16,000 jobs and will cost the French Government $245 million, Budget Minister Michel Charasse said on Saturday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL National Basketball Association NEW JERSEY NETS -- Placed Sam Bowie, center, on the injured list. Activated Chris Dudley, center. FOOTBALL National Football League NEW ENGLAND PATRIOTS -- Signed Steve Strachan, fullback, to a one-year contract. COLLEGE FURMAN -- Announced that Jimmy Mason, guard, will transfer from Clemson next season.

title: Food for Poor Is Said to Cost More
description: Poor people in New York City pay more for groceries in their neighborhoods and have to shop in dirtier, more cramped stores than do middle-class residents, according to a study released yesterday by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Sheri Rosenfeld, Lawyer, Marries
description: Sheri Lynn Rosenfeld, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Rosenfeld of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday to Stuart Howard Gelfond, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Gelfond of Douglaston, L.I. Rabbi Morris Barzilai performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Integrity Control Officers: Policing the Police
description: Hunkered down behind the wheel of his mud-brown Plymouth, Lieut. Gregory Dunkel lighted his third Marlboro and squinted through his aviator sunglasses at the Jamaica Arms halfway down the block. There had been an ambulance call at the transient hotel and the sector George car had radioed it was taking the job. But while the lieutenant had been watching, there had been no sign of the officers. Nor had he heard them give the job back. What was going on?

title: Showdown for Dinkins: A 'Nip and Tuck' Fiscal Drive
description: New York City's slowly unfolding fiscal drama has become a taut and immediate crisis.

title: War's End Gives Jordan Little Relief
description: The end of the Persian Gulf war has brought little relief to Jordan's economy.

title: Market Place; Fiat's Shares Rise Despite Problems
description: FIAT'S shares have jumped 22 percent since January, when they fell to their lowest level since 1985. But many analysts still lack faith in the Italian auto maker.

title: Secret Yale Club Admits Women; Alumni Angry
description: The Skull and Bones club, one of the last all-male enclaves at Yale University, has voted to accept women, setting off a battle with angry alumni.

title: Armenian Chief Steers With Subtlety
description: The Armenian counterrevolution of Levon Ter-Petrosyan is quiet -- mercifully, strategically quiet -- and this is all the more reason for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the rest of the world to pay close heed.

title: U.S. Faces Free-Trade Quandary
description: Even as the Bush Administration is pressing Japan to allow imports of rice, the United States still has what amounts to a virtual ban on imported peanuts. The Administration now faces a tough decision on whether to allow more peanuts into the country.

title: Lisa Kirch Weds
description: Lisa Kirch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Kirch of Bergenfield, N.J., was married yesterday at Beth-El Synagogue in Larchmont, N.Y., to Mark Levine, a son of Mrs. Charles J. Block of Larchmont and the late Peter Levine. Rabbi Kenneth Berger officiated. The bride, 28 years old, is a senior project director at Perception Research Services, a marketing research firm in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. She is a Rutgers University graduate. Her husband, also 28, is a senior account executive at the Silverman, Warren-Kremer public-relations company in New York. He graduated from the State University of New York at Albany.

title: Chicago's Cultural Life Bucks Downward Trend
description: This burly city of big shoulders and grand ambitions is experiencing what few other American cities could imagine in these days of recession and belt-tightening. Its cultural institutions are expanding in size and audience at a time when those in some other cities are trying to stay in business.

title: Celtic Rebounding Sinks Knicks
description: Rebounding has been a problem all season for the Knicks. This afternoon, it became a major problem.

title: When Tax Audits Might Mean Windfalls to Companies
description: Audits by the Internal Revenue Service usually do not result in windfalls for taxpayers. But many big companies facing audits of tax returns from past years may now be entitled to big refunds, thanks to a recent court decision, accountants say.

title: Hasbro Plans Revised Offer For Tonka
description: Hasbro Inc. plans to make a new offer for the Tonka Corporation, providing more money for Tonka's bondholders and less for shareholders. Goldman, Sachs & Company's Water Street Corporate Recovery Fund, Tonka's largest bondholder, has already agreed to accept the deal.

title: McCann to Do Nestle's Buying
description: Nestle USA has selected McCann-Erickson to handle its consolidated media buying account, with a budget of $250 million to $300 million.

title: British Interest Rates Cut
description: The British Government cut interest rates on Friday for the fourth time in two months as the annual increase in the Retail Price Index, the main indicator of inflation, fell to 8.2 percent in March from 8.9 percent in February.

title: Bridge
description: A million or so players of an earlier generation, who learned the game in the 40's and 50's, are mourning the passing of Charles Goren, "Mr. Bridge," who died early this month in California at the age of 90. He carried the bridge public out of the age of Culbertson, in which honor-tricks were the rule in valuing a hand, into the era of Standard American, with valuation by points.

title: Frazier and Ali, Together Again (Minus Gloves)
description: Twenty years after Muhammad Ali lost the first of a three-fight series with Joe Frazier, the man called the Greatest has conceded defeat.

title: New Reports Say 1980 Reagan Campaign Tried to Delay Hostage Release
description: Persistent but unproven accusations that Ronald Reagan's 1980 presidential campaign negotiated a secret deal with Iran to prevent the release of American hostages until after the election are being revived this week with fresh accounts of meetings between campaign officials and an Iranian cleric.

title: Ms. Rosenberg, Graphic Designer, Wed
description: Leslie Katherine Rosenberg a daughter of Mrs. Albert Rosenberg of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Rosenberg, was married yesterday to James Nathaniel Rachlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lauren Rachlin of Buffalo. Rabbi Martin Goldberg performed the ceremony at the College of Physicians in Philadelphia.

title: Those Bicycle Speedsters in the Park on Sundays Aren't Racers
description: To the Editor:

title: Katherine Murphy Weds Mitchell Myerson on S.I.
description: Katherine Giles Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Bradford Murphy of Little Silver, N.J., was married yesterday to Mitchell Benjamin Meyerson, a son of Frieda P. Meyerson of the Bronx, and the late Melvin Meyerson. The Rev. Carleton J. Sweetser, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center in Livingston, S.I.

title: Ismail's Options Give Him Leeway
description: As Raghib (Rocket) Ismail, the Notre Dame football star, was boarding a flight from Los Angeles back to South Bend, Ind., last night, his agents were in Massachusetts, entering their second negotiating session of the day with the New England Patriots.

title: But Aeroflot Pampers the Foreign Visitor
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Recovery in Sight? Don't Look at Payrolls
description: While many economists see a recovery budding in the next several months, company executives say they will wait until an expansion is in full bloom before they resume hiring.

title: Gotti's Driver Shot to Death Outside Home
description: A man identified as John Gotti's personal driver and a confidant of the reputed mob boss and his son was gunned down Saturday night in what looked like an "organized-crime hit," the police said yesterday.

title: Young, Black and Trapped in Chicago
description: There Are No Children Here By Alex Kotlowitz 324 pages. Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $21.95.

title: Satellite Is Placed Into Orbit
description: A $40 million communications satellite that was supposed to have ridden a shuttle into space four years ago finally made it Friday night, aboard an unmanned rocket. The Delta rocket blasted off at 8:09 P.M., and the satellite separated from it a half-hour later, as planned. The satellite, which joins eight others in orbit owned by the GTE Spacenet Corporaton, was supposed to be carried aloft by a shuttle in January 1987, but the plan was scrapped because of the Challenger disaster.

title: 37 Suspended After Protests In City System
description: City University of New York administrators have suspended at least 37 students involved in protests against tuition increases and budget cuts, in a toughening of the school's response to a week of protests, a university spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: Real Money in Fantasy Baseball
description: Fantasizing about baseball has become a big business.

title: CLEAR SKIES SPEED AID TO GRIM CAMP
description: At a squalid refugee camp here in this remote, mountainous border region, there were signs that dire conditions were easing for the Iraqi Kurds after a relentless two-week battle against rain, mud, thirst, hunger and illness.

title: Hawkins and Yanks Take a Flop at Outset
description: The game was over and it was another distressing loss for the Yankees, but Andy Hawkins seemed to drift back to the first inning, almost as if the day had begun and ended there. In a way, it had.

title: Lost and Found: Huge van Gogh Theft Fails
description: In one of the largest but shortest-lived art thefts on record, gunmen took 20 major paintings from the Vincent Van Gogh National Museum here before dawn today but inexplicably abandoned them in their getaway car 35 minutes later at a nearby railroad station.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Paul A. Leff Wed To Julie Abrams
description: Julie Beth Abrams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Abrams of South Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday to Paul Adam Leff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark A. Leff of Minneapolis. Rabbi Alexander Shapiro performed the ceremony at Congregation Oheb Shalom.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Bozell Inc., New York, has created a pro bono campaign for the International Rescue Committee, a voluntary agency that is soliciting donations on behalf of the hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees fleeing Iraq.

title: AIDS Patients to Gain As New Center Opens
description: Hoping to draw from the largest pool of AIDS patients in the country, a major AIDS research center will open tomorrow in New York City, with the goal of linking laboratory science and the needs of the patient.

title: Correction
description: An article in late editions of Business Day on Saturday about the chief financial officer of Consumers Union misstated an action the organization took against him. Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, said Friday that it had dismissed the executive, David Granston, accusing him of being involved in a kickback scheme. He had been suspended from his job since February.

title: Woosnam Wins On 18th Green
description: With all the strength in his powerful game and all the heart inside his diminutive body, Ian Woosnam of Wales won the Masters today in a finish as dramatic as any in the tournament's 55-year history.

title: To Locate A. J. Foyt, Don't Check Behind the Wheel
description: When A. J. Foyt showed up for his 360th Indy-car race yesterday in Long Beach, Calif., it marked a new experience for him -- and a preview of his future. For the first time ever, Foyt was attending an Indy-car event as a car owner, but wasn't driving.

title: G.I.'S IN IRAQ START MOVING TO A ZONE BORDERING KUWAIT
description: American forces have begun to pull back from the large area they have occupied in southern Iraq to a narrow buffer zone along the Iraq-Kuwait border, United States military officials said today.

title: Bills and Farm Credit Issue to Be Offered
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Miss Steinberg, Student, Marries
description: Cynthia Julie Steinberg, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jorge Steinberg of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Andrew Evan Blustein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Blustein of Forest Hills. Rabbi Joseph Grunblatt and Cantor Erno Grosz officiated at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Benetton's Magazine to Push Vision, Not Clothing
description: To critics' dismay, some magazines tend to blur the line between journalism and advertising. Benetton Group S.p.A. will give the critics fits. It is creating what may be the first magazine to be based on an advertising campaign.

title: Review/Jazz; Sonny Rollins's Anatomical Attacks on Tunes
description: When the saxophonist Sonny Rollins is in the mood, he can turn the dissection of a tune into a miracle. At Mr. Rollins's show on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall he pounced on "Long Ago and Far Away," the first piece of the night, taking each note or phrase of the melody and using it as the basis of a choruslong examination.

title: Hungarians Debate How Far Back to Go To Right Old Wrongs
description: For months now, Hungary has been debating how to compensate people who were summarily stripped of their farms, shops, factories and other property during the Communist era. But as it goes about righting the perceived wrongs committed by the Communists, the Hungarian Parliament has stumbled onto other wounds that were hidden, but never healed, during the last half century.

title: All the Rage in Fiction: Serial Murder, Multiple Murder, Hideous Murder
description: Murder -- mass murder -- seems to be the latest trend in the field of fiction, a field historically dominated by women readers. In fact, serial murders, multiple murders and hideous murders are all the rage.

title: Becoming a Hit In Little League
description: You remember her. She sat in the stands screaming when you came to bat. You acted like you didn't hear her and sheepishly looked away if you struck out. But somehow those strikeouts never mattered when you got home because she always had a consoling shoulder or a warm meal ready.

title: New Drug Chief Turns To Softer Side of Issue
description: When Bob Martinez, the new chief of national drug policy, was Governor of Florida, he developed a reputation as a leader whose solution to the drug problem was to build more prisons and execute the worst offenders.

title: STUDY CHALLENGES FEDERAL RESEARCH ON RISKS OF IUD'S
description: A new scientific study challenges the validity of medical research done more than a decade ago that was crucial in condemning the Dalkon Shield and other intrauterine contraceptive devices as dangerous.

title: Ammirati Is Finding Its Grip On Club Med Is Loosening
description: AMMIRATI & PURIS may soon lose the Club Med resorts business, a small but important account that helped establish its reputation as a New York agency that specialized in stylish, often glamorous, advertising.

title: Judge Removes Himself in Birth Control Case
description: The judge who ordered a convicted child abuser to have an innovative birth control device implanted in her arm has removed himself from the case.

title: Insurer's Role Raises Pension Fear
description: Hundreds of thousands of insurance policy holders and investors across the country are worried about the seizure of the Executive Life Insurance Company last week by California regulators, but few are as fearful and angry as those whose retirement benefits depend on the insurer's financial health.

title: Washington Talk; Will a Political Promise Bring Political Demise?
description: Like many politicians, Senator Kent Conrad made bold campaign promises when he first ran for the Senate in 1986. Like many politicians, he made promises that have not come true.

title: Abroad at Home; Politics and Decency
description: Something is missing in George Bush. An empathy gene, if there were such a thing. An instinctive response to the pain of other human beings. An internal monitor that tells him when political calculation has to stop, yielding to concern for decency.

title: Review/Jazz; Ella Fitzgerald's Playfulness Ripens With Time's Passage
description: "This is the first time I've sung in six months," said Ella Fitzgerald following the opening number of her sold-out Radio City Music Hall concert on Saturday evening. That first song, an uptempo rendition of "Sweet Georgia Brown," in which Miss Fitzgerald swung out with the Louie Bellson orchestra, set the exuberant tone for a concert that found the singer in high spirits and in unusually fine voice.

title: Who's at Short? For Mets, the Question Won't Go Away
description: Kevin Elster's home run to left in the eighth inning ended the afternoon's offense against the Expos, but only fueled once more the intrigue concerning the Mets' infield alignment.

title: Reviews/Television; An 1830's Attempt at Integration
description: The charge is familiar: A good part of the crisis in American education today may be attributable to youngsters watching too much television. Clearly uneasy, the television industry is responding with Education First Week, a special week -- imagine, a whole week -- of "pro-education" programming largely scattered among several prime-time series and some newscasts.

title: At Heart of CUNY Protests, Its Role in Educating the Poor
description: With guerrilla-like zeal and finesse, students on at least eight campuses of the City University of New York have been barricading buildings, papering over windows to conceal their movements, communicating over walkie-talkies -- all in an effort to head off tuition increases and budget cuts. But more than money is on the protesters' minds.

title: First Novelists, Don't Fret: There's Money in Newness
description: Suddenly, first novels are hot. "Damage," a short erotic novel by the English writer Josephine Hart, is on best-seller lists. So, too, is Whitney Otto's "How to Make an American Quilt." And "Just Killing Time," a first novel by Derek Goodwin (writing under the pseudonym Derek Van Arman) was sold last week to Simon & Schuster for $920,000 after the book was presented to publishers with endorsements from John le Carre and Joseph Wambaugh that turned out to be fraudulent.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Speaking at a college in Beijing yesterday, former President JIMMY CARTER warned that China and the United States were facing a serious communications gap and called for amnesty for all nonviolent Chinese dissidents.

title: This Court Crisis Isn't Necessary
description: By picking a constitutional fight over court funding with Gov. Mario Cuomo, the state's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, foments needless turmoil. There is room for compromise, so long as all parties respect the seriousness of the state's fiscal problem and negotiate in good faith.

title: Burning Supertanker, Spilling Oil, Sinks Off Italy
description: A burning supertanker, which has spilled millions of gallons of crude oil into the Bay of Genoa since a series of explosions began on Thursday, sank today in shallow water barely 2,000 yards off the northwest coast of Italy.

title: American Air Protests Bid For T.W.A.
description: Executives of American Airlines yesterday denounced a plan by the investor Kirk Kerkorian to buy T.W.A. as a delay tactic and a "half-baked, ill-conceived, poorly fleshed out excuse for a business plan."

title: Player Dies in Stabbing at Basketball Game
description: A 19-year-old basketball player from Queens was fatally stabbed with a broken-off table leg today after a fight broke out during a basketball tournament, the police said.

title: Charlotte M. McKee Wed to Dr. Mark R. Proctor
description: Charlotte Marie McKee, a daughter of Andrea McKee of San Jose, Calif., and Dennis H. McKee of Coronado, Calif., was married in Coronado yesterday to Dr. Mark Robert Proctor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Proctor of Merrick, L.I. Judge Robert McDonald of San Diego Municipal Court performed the ceremony at the Hotel del Coronado.

title: Gail Glickman Weds Frederick Horton
description: Gail L. Glickman, the daughter of Susan Glickman and Robert Glickman, both of New York, was married yesterday to Frederick Charles Horwood, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James N. Horwood of Reston, Va. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Dance in Review
description: She-Bops and Scats Pace Downtown Theater 1 Pace Plaza

title: Strike the Gold Muddles Derby Picture
description: The long black limousine eased to a silent stop outside barn 20 at the Keeneland Race Course at 9 o'clock this morning, and Giles Brophy stepped out. He is a securities executive from New York and the principal owner of Strike the Gold, the colt who on Saturday beat the favorite for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Maurice Binder, 73, 007 Film-Title Artist
description: Maurice Binder, a graphic arts designer known chiefly for his dazzling title sequences in the James Bond films, died on Tuesday at the University College Hospital in London. He was 73 years old and lived in London.

title: Winfield's 3-Homer Night Caps a Week for All Ages
description: Nolan Ryan isn't baseball's only ageless wonder. During his 18-year career, 39-year-old Dave Winfield has battled serious injury, great expectations, George Steinbrenner and hundreds of pitchers.

title: Progress in Albany Budget Talks
description: Because progress must be measured from a starting point, state leaders asserted today that they had made headway in budget talks. Their evidence was that they were talking at all.

title: Oddities Found in Charter Of Flight for Singer's Band
description: Usually, Reba McEntire flew from one performance to another, while her band took a bus. But when the I.B.M. Corporation asked the popular group to perform at a private company affair in San Diego on March 15, the group's heavily booked schedule meant that the whole entourage would have to fly.

title: Canada Airline Proposal
description: Canadian officials will consider allowing American carriers to fly between destinations in Canada, James Harris, the top Canadian negotiator in the air travel talks with Washington, said last week. The chief American negotiator, Charles Angevine, said he would consider the Canadian proposals on the internal routes, but American officials have said they will not press for such an agreement.

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stock prices rose today in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues finished up 113.03 points, or less than 1 percent, to 26,695.53. At midday, the Nikkei was stronger, at 26,864.09, up 281.59 points. On Friday, the index fell 48.53 points, to 26,268.86. Trading today was dominated by a stronger yen and hopes that interest rates would soon be lowered, traders said, because of Friday's drop of one-tenth of a percent in the United States Consumer Price Index for March.

title: Miss Levine Wed To Glenn Forrest
description: Adrienne Tami Levine, a daughter of Herman I. Levine of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Helen S. Levine, was married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., to Dr. Glenn Scott Forrest, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Forrest of East Hills, L.I. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion officiated.

title: Hydro Quebec Dispute
description: The Dominican Republic said Saturday that it had settled a dispute with a Canadian power company over a $20 million bank withdrawal. A Government communique said Hydro Quebec-Sofati Ltd. had agreed to return the $20 million to a New York bank account and renegotiate its contract with the Caribbean country. Hydro Quebec had signed a four-year $60 million contract to replace the electricity lines in Santo Domingo.

title: Accounts
description: * Chesebrough-Pond U.S.A., a subsidiary of Unilever P.L.C., is moving its American account for Pond's products from Ogilvy & Mather, New York, to McCann-Erickson, New York. Billings were not disclosed. Ogilvy will continue to handle the Pond's line outside the United States. * Tidemark Corp., a computer company, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, with a budget of $2 million to $3 million.

title: Man Is Found Shot to Death Behind Restaurant in Bronx
description: A 30-year-old man was found shot to death behind a restaurant yesterday morning in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: Seminars Examine the Giggle Factor
description: So did you hear the one about the humor convention?

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 14, 1991: MONDAY Citicorp Goodrich BF Co Dana Corp Lilly Eli & Co Dial REIT Inc Southern Co TUESDAY AAR Corp Mellon Bk Corp American Cyanamid Co Reliance Group Hldgs Inc Helene Curtis Inds Inc Scott Paper Co Honeywell Inc Security Pac Corp ICM Ppty Invs Inc M Smucker Co Inco Ltd Southern Ind Gas & Elec Co K Mart Corp V F Corp Loews Corp WEDNESDAY Bard C R Inc Dun & Bradstreet Barnett Bks Inc GTE Corp Cincinnati Gas & Elec Co Pacific Gas & Elec Co Clorox Co PSI Res Inc Columbia Gas Sys Inc Republic NY Corp Dow Jones & Co THURSDAY Archer Daniels Midland ONEOK Inc Baker Fentress & Co PPG Inds Inc Bear Stearns Cos Standard Fed Bk Troy Mich Bearings Inc Ohio Thomas Inds Inc Central & South West Trinova Corp Gillette Co Tultex Corp IMC Fertilizer Group Inc Weyerhaeuser Co Interstate Pwr Co FRIDAY ARCO Chem Co Dominion Res Inc VA Boise Cascade Corp Firstar Corp New Borden Inc Massmutual Corpocate Inv Central La Elec Inc Progressive Corp Ohio Communications Satellite Twin Disc Inc SUNDAY UNUM Corp

title: Increasing Questions Impede Case of Kennedy Nephew, Investigators Say
description: Two weeks after a woman said she was raped at the Kennedy estate here by William Kennedy Smith, the police have not charged him because they are having difficulty resolving a number of questions about what actually happened, investigators say.

title: Dance in Review
description: Purchase Dance Corps Performing Arts Center State University College Purchase, N.Y.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Edberg Thrashes Lendl

title: German Youths Harassing Polish Travelers
description: Gangs of German youths are harassing Polish travelers at crossing points to Germany in circumstances that are raising concern among German officials about the rising abuse of foreigners in the regions that were once East Germany.

title: Rangers' Grand Illusion Ends in Painful Reality
description: The Rangers of 1990-91 were in large part an illusion, and the end of an illusion can be painful for those who believed in it.

title: Doo Lough Journal; At the End of the Irish Rainbow, Blighted Fish?
description: The sere, rocky mountains and peat meadows of this part of western Ireland look as unspoiled as they were 1,500 years ago when St. Patrick is supposed to have climbed the peak now named for him to fast, pray and banish snakes.

title: QuestionBox
description: No Winning Records

title: Ryan Discovers a Will and a Way To End Long Blight Against Orioles
description: Nolan Ryan beat Baltimore for the first time since April 20, 1976, allowing two hits and striking out nine in seven innings as the Texas Rangers pounded the Orioles, 15-3, today.

title: Topics of The Times; A Credit Worth Collecting
description: With tax day here, working parents might benefit from a reminder about a Federal tax program well worth their attention. It's the earned income credit, also known as the earned income tax credit, and it can mean as much as $953 to a family.

title: Miscellany
description: * Ogilvy & Mather Direct, New York, has formed an electronic marketing division that will evaluate a variety of technological innovations. * HDM Geneva, an international business-to-business agency, has been renamed Young & Rubicam Business Communications. Young & Rubicam kept the agency in February when Eurocom, a French agency, bought back the European portion of the HDM Network from Young & Rubicam and Dentsu.

title: Brown Sponsors A Police Summit On Excess Force
description: Asserting that the videotaped beating of a motorist by Los Angeles police officers had focused national attention on excessive force, Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown yesterday urged police chiefs to confront the issue and "reconfirm America's traditional faith in law enforcement."

title: Intruder With Knife Is Shot in Texas Church
description: A man brandishing a knife terrorized worshippers at a church here on Sunday before a member of the congregation shot him to death.

title: Beef Prices at Record Highs As Cattle Shortage Continues
description: With barbecue season around the corner, a near 30-year low in the nation's cattle herd has resulted in the highest prices ever for steak, hamburger and other cuts of beef.

title: Old Guard Retaliation Suspected In Fatal Shooting of Gotti's Driver
description: Law-enforcement authorities are theorizing that John Gotti's chauffeur and bodyguard was slain in retaliation for actions taken by Mr. Gotti's son against the old guard in the Gambino organized-crime family.

title: J. S. Bach + Fractals = New Music
description: FOR anyone craving a stripped-down version of Bach -- one from which three-quarters of the master's notes have been cut away -- help is on the way. A scientist and his musician son have devised a system to condense music to its underlying essence.

title: American Express Unit Names New President
description: James M. Li has been named president of the American Express Company's Consumer Financial Services Group, a division of the company's American Express International unit.

title: U.S. Clarifies Summit Conditions
description: A White House spokesman said today that President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could hold a summit meeting without prior agreement on a treaty to limit nuclear weapons.

title: To Our Readers
description: Beginning today, some stocks will appear in different positions in the New York and American Stock Exchange and Nasdaq listings. The Associated Press, which provides most of the financial tables, has installed a new computer system that will list some companies differently, by their full name or abbreviated name.

title: Business and Health; Estimating Costs Of Retiree Benefits
description: A FEW employers have already estimated the impact of the new accounting rule that requires them to report future medical expenses for their retired employees as an expense against income. Although the big numbers do not change a company's current operating outlook, analysts say the accounting will provide some companies with a stark picture of the heavy obligations they must deal with eventually.

title: Philadelphia Transit System Nearly Out of Money
description: Intensifying their pleas for help, officials here say the nation's fourth largest mass transit system is about to run out of money.

title: Cetus, Erbamont Settle Patent Suit
description: The Cetus Corporation and Erbamont Inc. have settled litigation over Erbamont's patent on doxorubicin, the most frequently prescribed chemotherapy drug. Cetus-Ben Venue Therapeutics, a joint venture of Cetus and Ben Venue Laboratories of Bedford, Ohio, sells a generic version of the drug.

title: Fetal Tissue Used: Anguish Behind a Medical First
description: In poignant testimony, a husband and wife who oppose abortion told a Congressional subcommittee today how they nevertheless agreed to use tissue from an aborted fetus in a desperate attempt to save their unborn son from a fatal genetic disease.

title: Johnson's Blast Sets The Tone for Victory
description: Howard Johnson's first right-handed hit of the season turned out to be one he might not duplicate -- right-handed, left-handed or in his sleep.

title: Woosman Shows He's at Home in the Masters, Ltd.
description: After the thrilling fury of Sunday's finish becomes a blur, the 1991 Masters will be chiefly remembered for two things: the emergence of Ian Woosnam as a champion and the further submergence of American golfers.

title: Police Say Palm Beach Inquiry Not Near End
description: The police investigating an allegation of rape at the Kennedy estate here said today that they were "nowhere near being ready" to turn the case over to prosecutors who will decide whether to charge the suspect, William Kennedy Smith.

title: Accounts
description: * Levolor, a manufacturer of blinds, to Cleary, Kvamme & Suiter, Campbell, Calif., with a budget of about $2 million. * Casual Corner women's apparel stores, Enfield, Conn., to Advertising to Women Inc., New York. Billings have not been determined.

title: For New York Muslims, a Soaring Dome Is Ready
description: More than 1,000 worshipers crowded into the unbroken space beneath a soaring dome as the imposing new mosque on the Upper East Side of Manhattan opened yesterday on the Islamic feast day of Eid al Fitr, ending the monthlong fast of Ramadan.

title: 2 Regional Campaigns For American Airlines
description: American Airlines is introducing two regional advertising campaigns this week, one in Chicago, the corporate hometown of its chief rival, United Airlines, and the other in Dallas/Fort Worth, its own hometown.

title: Reynolds Net Drops 65% on Slack Demand
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, citing lower prices for fabricated products, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings plunged 65 percent. The company attributed the decline to the recession, saying the downturn had reduced demand for aluminum products used in the automobile, construction and manufacturing industries.

title: Key Rates
Bush Urges All Sides to Act to Avoid a Rail Strike
description: President Bush said today that "it would be prudent that all efforts and actions be taken" to avoid a nationwide rail strike, saying it would seriously disrupt a fragile economy.

title: EUROPEAN NATIONS TO LIFT SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Ignoring appeals from the African National Congress, the 12-nation European Community agreed today to lift its remaining economic sanctions against South Africa in response to the Pretoria Government's continuing moves to dismantle apartheid.

title: LIBERIAN CONFLICT ENGULFS NEIGHBOR
description: Two West African countries, Nigeria and Guinea, are reported to have sent soldiers into Sierra Leone to help repel a rebel invasion from neighboring Liberia.

title: High-Wire Cyclist Hurt in Fall
description: A high-wire motorcyclist working on props in his act at the Shrine Circus here fell at least 60 feet, breaking bones in his feet. The 25-year-old performer, Henry Lemoine, of Roanoke, Va., fell from the high wire Sunday night after a performance at the Ohio State Fairgrounds, the State Highway Patrol said. Mr. Lemoine was reported in fair condition today at Ohio State University Hospital.

title: Sweet Briar Journal; A Symbol of Solid Pine For a New Soviet Link
description: An invitingly smooth, comfortably rounded, green pine bench, longer and heavier than most anything gracing the parks of the United States, has just come thousands of miles to find a new home on Mount San Angelo at the Virginia Center for the Creative Arts.

title: James Brownlow, 70, Research Scientist
