description: James Merritt Brownlow, a research scientist who helped to develop memory cores for computers and integrated semi-conductor circuits in 34 years with International Business Machines, died Thursday at his home in Norwich, Vt. He was 70 years old.

title: Unplanned Taxi Destination: Hospital
description: EACH day thousands of people who buckle up in private cars, slip into taxis, where they ride unrestrained, trusting life and limb to fate.

title: Penguins Oust Devils With Ease
description: What occurred just as the referee was ready to drop the first puck of tonight's seventh and deciding game between the Devils and the Penguins was obviously a bad omen for the Devils.

title: In New York, the Trip Is Not Quite as Bumpy
description: Despite declining ridership, swelling budget deficits and a potential decline in Federal and state financing, New Yorkers have no reason to fear drastic cuts or elimination of service like those being considered in Philadelphia, New York transit officials said.

title: Review/Music; The Struggles Of a Black Leader In Old America
description: The life of Frederick Douglass has been an opera waiting to happen. Few historical figures so fit the measurements of a genre developed by Bellini and Donizetti and then enlarged by Verdi. Douglass, a prominent black American of the 19th century, funneled his power through oratory, and oratory is in large part the essence of Italian dramatic style.

title: People
description: * Tom Rich has resigned as president of the Pittsburgh office of Ketchum Advertising. Bob Kroyer, president of Ketchum Advertising/U.S.A., will run the office on an interim basis until a replacement is named. * Great Scott Advertising, New York, named Fred Golden executive director, Don Josephson senior vice president and Jon Bierman vice president.

title: 4 Ex-Secret Policemen Offer a Deal to Bonn
description: Four former high officials in the East German secret police have disclosed that they offered Bonn Government officials assistance in helping to limit the damage from unofficial disclosures of politically sensitive information. In exchange, they sought a general amnesty and pension benefits for former agents.

title: Furor in Seoul Over North's Atom Plant
description: South Korea's Defense Minister said last week that his country might be forced to mount a commando raid against a nuclear installation near Pyongyang that experts believe could produce crude atomic weapons within five years. In response, North Korea accused the South today of issuing "virtually a declaration of war."

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Consumer's World page on Saturday about sunscreens described Procter & Gamble's Bain de Soleil Sport Lotion incorrectly. It is a PABA-free lotion, not a PABA lotion.

title: AFTER THE WAR: SOUTHERN IRAQ Kurds 'Are Living in Hell' Stranded on Mountain Road; Army Won't Feed New Refugees
description: One day after the Bush Administration said it would take care of Iraqi refugees who moved into this southern border area, United States Army officials today declined to feed new refugees who arrived at the main refugee camp.

title: Earnings Up At Eli Lilly and Upjohn
description: Eli Lilly & Company and the Upjohn Company each reported double-digit earnings increases for the first quarter, confirming the ability of drug makers to do well despite problems in the economy.

title: Reuschel to the Bullpen
description: RICK REUSCHEL, 41, has been dropped from the Giants' rotation and moved to the bullpen, clearing a starting spot for KELLY DOWNS.

title: Toyota in Talks on Importing VW's and Audis to Japan
description: Facing growing political pressure from Europe, the Toyota Motor Company said today that it was negotiating with Volkswagen to market VW and Audi cars here, and said it was holding informal conversations with other car makers about importing their models as well.

title: Chemical Leak in Korea Brings Forth a New Era
description: When South Korea decided that the country's only chance at economic pre-eminence lay in supercharged industrialization, it started here, in a scrubby valley formed by the Naktong River.

title: Our Towns
description: It can be daunting, being on the front lines of tax reassessment.

title: Grumman Settles
description: The Grumman Corporation said it would reduce first-quarter earnings by $46.5 million to reflect a settlement with Tracor Aviation Inc., a Goleta, Calif. subcontractor that recently began bankruptcy proceedings. Grumman said the settlement was for a fraction of its claim, but the charge should not have a material effect on earnings.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON THE INDIAN OCEAN -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION -- 10 A.M. Economic and Social Council COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Syntex Venture
description: The Syntex Corporation, a pharmaceuticals company in Palo Alto, Calif., is forming a joint venture to test Chinese plants and micro-organisms for possible use as drugs. Under an agreement to be announced on Tuesday in Hong Kong, Syntex will form the venture with the not-for-profit Hong Kong Institute of Biotechnology.

title: Vallone Tops Dinkins on Gifts to Charity
description: If such a place exists, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone resided yesterday in the tender land between philanthropy and political one-upmanship, as he released his 1990 income-tax returns showing he claimed almost 50 times more than Mayor David N. Dinkins in charitable contributions.

title: Limited Approval For Mentor Drug
description: The Mentor Corporation said the Food and Drug Administration had approved a new drug for treating incontinence in men but not in women. In an letter on Friday, the F.D.A. said it would issue a marketing approval order for the drug pending a review of final labeling.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Debt Efforts Worry Japan
description: A recent agreement among major creditor nations to lighten Poland's debt load and a similar proposal for Egypt might mean that those countries would lose loans from Japan, officials in Tokyo said today.

title: Kurds 'Are Living in Hell' Stranded on Mountain Road
description: A trickle of aid has begun to reach Kurdish refugees in this remote and wild border area, but for thousands stranded on the sheer drop-offs and turns of the mountain road out of Iraq, "We are living in hell," as one of them put it.

title: Ending the End of the Cold War
description: The cold war lingers in Asia. But Mikhail Gorbachev could help end it when he meets with Prime Minister Kaifu in Tokyo today. In Europe, the Wall no longer stands in the way of improved relations with Moscow's neighbors. In the Far East, four islands -- seized from a defeated Japan by Stalin in 1945 -- still do.

title: Bois Cascade Reports Loss
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation said today that rising expenses and weak demand for its paper and wood products caused a $16.85 million loss in the first quarter of 1991.

title: Kurdish Refugee Plight Worsens, And Relief Efforts Still Fall Short
description: Despite a huge-scale rescue campaign undertaken by the United States military, conditions for the Iraqi Kurdish refugees are still deteriorating rapidly, international relief experts and diplomats said today. They warned that thousands more could die before help reaches them in their mountain enclaves on the Turkish border.

title: A Better Pagemaker
description: THE Aldus Corporation of Seattle has introduced a greatly improved version of Pagemaker, its desktop publishing program for I.B.M. PC's running the DOS-Windows 3.0 operating system. Like its Apple Macintosh counterpart, which was released earlier, Pagemaker 4.0 for Windows can meet the needs of a broad range of users, ranging from church newsletter secretaries to technical manual publishers.

title: Magic Breaks Record for Assists
description: Magic Johnson surpassed Oscar Robertson as the National Basketball Association's all-time leader for assists in the Los Angeles Lakers' 112-106 victory over the Dallas Mavericks tonight.

title: Samuelson's Tears Are for Achievement
description: At age 33, Joan Benoit Samuelson launched the second stage of her storybook career with a rejuvenating fourth-place women's finish today in the 95th Boston Marathon.

title: Pro Bono
description: * The New York office of DDB Needham has created a series of public service announcements for the Leukemia Society of America. The ads, which depict a mother absorbing the news that her daughter has leukemia, convey the theme line: "Where there's help, there's hope."

title: Giants Hoping Stars Recuperate
description: Eleven Sundays ago, the Giants won Super Bowl XXV with a backup quarterback and a broken-down tight end and an ancient running back and a ball-control offense and a wonderful game plan. Now, less than a week before the National Football League draft, they are trying to get the ailing bodies well and put the pieces, some of them new, together again.

title: Sinopoli Cancels
description: Giuseppe Sinopoli, who was scheduled to conduct the New York Philharmonic in Mahler's Ninth Symphony on Thursday, Friday, Saturday and next Tuesday, has canceled his appearances because of a family emergency. Yoel Levi, the conductor of the Atlanta Symphony, will replace him. The program is not changed. Information: (212) 874-2424.

title: Big Battle of Regulators Near Decision in Senate
description: After years of debate between the New York and Chicago markets, the Senate is expected to decide this week whether the Commodity Futures Trading Commission or the Securities and Exchange Commission will control new kinds of financial instruments that share characteristics of both futures and securities.

title: Caller Beware if Bell Companies Are Let Loose; Unfair Restrictions
description: To the Editor:

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;
Dreams Come True, Even in New York
description: I've seen a lot of stories lately about how difficult and dangerous it's become to grow up in New York. They're true. But what isn't said is how, when things go right, this city can be a wonderful and exciting place to grow up -- a city that lets you dream and then helps you make those dreams real.

title: Debate Flares Over IUD Challenge
description: A NEW challenge to the validity of research that led to the removal of the Dalkon Shield and other intrauterine devices from the United States market has raised serious questions about the factors that influence the birth-control choices made available to Americans.

title: Emanuel P. La Motta, An Internist, Dies at 81
description: Emanuel P. La Motta, an internist, died on Friday at St. Peter's Medical Center in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 81 years old and had lived in Somerset, N.J., for three years.

title: Afghan Accord Gaining Urgency as Rebels Dig In
description: Three weeks after they seized this fortress city from Government troops, Islamic rebels are digging in here, their hopes of defeating the Soviet-backed Kabul Government markedly revived by the victory.

title: Honecker Has an Operation In Moscow, Paper Reports
description: Erich Honecker, the former East German Communist leader who was spirited out of Germany last month, has undergone bowel surgery in a Moscow military hospital, a German newspaper reported today.

title: F. X. McDermott, 74, Policeman and Lawyer
description: Francis X. McDermott, a retired lawyer and New York City police officer, died on Sunday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Stoic, Iraqis Surrender to a Journalist
description: The five men who stumbled over the desert today near this town on the Iraq-Kuwait border are probably among the last Iraqi soldiers who will give themselves up in these last days before the Baghdad Government regains the land it lost in the allied invasion.

title: New Parliament in Albania Soon Breaks Up in Discord
description: The country's first multi-party Parliament session broke up in political discord today only a half-hour after it began when the main opposition party boycotted the Communist-dominated legislature.

title: Furloughing Of Workers Under Study By Dinkins
description: In a sign of its desperation to avoid fiscal receivership, the Dinkins administration said yesterday that it was studying whether it could force workers to take unpaid furloughs to help balance New York City's budget in the 11 weeks remaining in the fiscal year.

title: Corrections
description: A biographical sketch on Wednesday about the winner of the Pulitzer Prize for criticism, David Shaw of The Los Angeles Times, referred incorrectly to his 1990 reporting about minority employment at newspapers including his own. What Mr. Shaw wrote was, "The Times is widely regarded -- particularly by blacks, inside the paper and out -- as having one of the poorest records for minority advancement of any major paper in the country."

title: Carnival Cruise Is Set To Buy Premier Line
description: Carnival Cruise Lines said today that it would acquire the Dial Corporation's Premier Cruise Lines for about $372 million.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to the president of Club Med's North American operations. He is Michael Kubin.

title: Caller Beware if Bell Companies Are Let Loose
description: To the Editor:

title: NCR's Profit Dips 12%; A.T.&T. Gets Just 4 Seats
description: The NCR Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 12 percent, largely because of the cost of fighting a takeover attempt by A.T.&T.

title: Reaction Mostly Warm to Bush's School Plan
description: President Bush's education plan, which includes a call for national student testing, school choice for parents and research grants for public schools, seems to have wide support among educators, business groups and the nation's governors.

title: 'Miss Saigon' Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: Miscellany
description: * Bruce McGowin, John Barchi, Ken Taub and David Terrell have formed a new advertising and design group, McBT&T, in Smithtown, L.I.

title: Phelps Leaves Notre Dame After 20 Years as Coach
description: Digger Phelps, who as a young high school coach in Pennsylvania sent a letter to the University of Notre Dame saying he hoped to coach there, announced yesterday that he was retiring, 20 years after fulfilling the goal and helping raise the Irish basketball program from mediocrity to national acclaim.

title: Blaze at a Fraternity House
description: One student was injured today in a fraternity house fire at Syracuse University. The fire, at the Alpha Epsilon Pi house, broke out shortly before 11 A.M. and severely damaged the building, Deputy Fire Chief Richard Buck said. Greg Rosh, 19 years old, of Liberty, suffered smoke inhalation and was treated at Crouse-Irving Memorial hospital.

title: Film Workers Reject Settlement, Prolonging New York Shutdown
description: Members of a film-crafts union local rejected a tentative contract yesterday with leading Hollywood producers, prolonging a bitter and costly stalemate that has virtually shut down major-studio film making in New York City since November.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Delray Beach, Fla., is tentatively offering $22 million in tax exempt water and sewer revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of 6.90 percent for a bond due 2010, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Short maturities yield from 5 percent in 1991 to 6.70 percent in 2004, while a longer maturity of 2006 is priced to yield 6.85 percent. The financing is insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation and rated triple-A by Moody's and S.& P.

title: Lee Sabinson, 79, Broadway Producer And Film Executive
description: Lee Sabinson, a Broadway producer and film executive, died on Sunday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at the Actors' Fund Home in Englewood.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of construction, the Park Avenue Tunnel from 33d to 40th Street will be closed from 9:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. for two weeks beginning today. Motorists are advised to use Lexington and Third Avenues as alternate routes.

title: EUROPE'S ECONOMY IS FOUND TO STALL
description: A year ago, as the United States was sliding toward recession, many European officials boasted that the European Community, spurred by German unification, would take over as the locomotive of the world economy.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on April 7 about problems at Harlem Hospital Center misidentified Craig Braithwaite. He is a physician's associate, not a doctor.

title: Martin Luther King Center's Head Quits Amid Reports of Impropriety
description: The executive director of New York State's Martin Luther King Jr. Institute for Nonviolence resigned today amid allegations by the State Inspector General that the agency has been plagued by waste and misuse of public funds.

title: U.S. Home Files For Bankruptcy
description: The U.S. Home Corporation, one of the nation's leading home builders, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code after failing to restructure $156 million in unsecured bank debt.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDNA LEWIS never formally studied cooking. She learned it intuitively through her keen sense of taste and her sharp memories of her family's kitchen in Unionville, Va. As she turned 75 yesterday, she was doing what she loves most, stirring pots of aromatic Southern specialties in the kitchen of the Gage & Tollner restaurant in Brooklyn, some of them for her own birthday party.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ITT Hartford Insurance Group, Hartford, a subsidiary of ITT Corp., named Ramani Ayer president and chief operating officer for domestic property-casualty and international operations. * Lippincott & Margulies Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Marsh & McLennan Companies, named Steven V. Lawrence and Kate Moran senior vice presidents, and Constance Birdsall and Suzanne Bauschard vice presidents.

title: Searching For Words Is Behind 'Um' or 'Ah'
description: RESEARCH has shown that the inclination to "um" or "ah" during conversation is not indicative of nervousness; rather, it is the mind's way of buying time while foraging for the proper word or phrase. And now a study published in the March issue of The Journal of Personality and Social Psychology is helping to further decipher the enigma of these unconscious mutterings by contending that what we talk about affects how often we, uh, well, you know.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Mitchell Is Suspended
description: KEVIN MITCHELL of the San Francisco Giants was suspended for two games and fined an undisclosed amount by National League President Bill White yesterday for his role in a brawl on April 10 in San Diego.

title: Baker Is Returning to Middle East To Push Arab-Israeli Peace Talks
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will head back to the Middle East on Tuesday for the second time in two weeks, seeking to overcome remaining obstacles to an Arab-Israeli peace conference, Administration officials said today.

title: Argentine Officers in Attempted Coup Go on Trial
description: The trial of 15 Argentine army leaders and almost 500 of their followers who staged a military uprising on Dec. 3, just before a visit by President Bush, opened here today amid tight security.

title: French Bid Is Pressuring Square D
description: The last time Didier Pineau-Valencienne tried a hostile takeover, enraged employees of the company he was bidding for burned him in effigy and marched a coffin through Paris to the office of the French Finance Minister.

title: Jets Learn What's What in Way of Talent
description: Even though the Jets don't have a first-round draft pick this year, having forfeited it to take Rob Moore of Syracuse last year in the supplemental draft, General Manager Dick Steinberg and Coach Bruce Coslet have a much better grasp of their inventory after last week's minicamp for veterans and free agents.

title: Q&A
description: Poison Ivy

title: Running (in Circles) Toward the Derby
description: Now that Strike the Gold has outrun Fly So Free, who last month outran Strike the Gold, who was also outrun by Cahill Road, who later was outrun by two long shots, and now that Fly So Free and Strike the Gold both outran Hansel, who then outran everybody else and set a track record at Turfway Park, and now that Dinard has outrun Olympio, who a month before that outran Dinard, what's next?

title: Coffey Ignores Eye Injury And Fires Up the Defense
description: On Sunday night, Paul Coffey went on local television and talked about the healing benefits of a long, hockey-free vacation. He spoke about blood beneath his scratched cornea, and about common sense.

title: Bulls, Superstations And Power Moves
description: On a court, the Chicago Bulls' archenemy is the Detroit Pistons. But in a courtroom, where the hardwood is on the walls, Jordan & Co.'s foe is the National Basketball Association. It may seem odd that this popular team and this successful league should tangle in a Federal courtroom. Yet they are, in a rim-rocker of a lawsuit that says much about the relationship of a team to a league and how the N.B.A. wants to control television policy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JEROME A. CHAZEN, class of 1950, gave the Columbia University Graduate School of Business $10 million yesterday, the biggest single gift in its 75-year history. The gift is to be used to establish an institute of international business in the school. Mr. Chazen is chairman of Liz Claiborne Inc .

title: Forced Confession Ruling Erodes Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Great Performers Plans More Than 70 Concerts
description: More than 70 chamber, orchestral and solo performances will be offered during the 1991-92 season of Great Performers at Lincoln Center.

title: Radio Linked to C.I.A. Urges Iraqis to Overthrow Hussein
description: For more than three months, the Voice of Free Iraq, a clandestine radio station that Iraqi exiles have linked to the Central Intelligence Agency, has passionately urged the Iraqi people to rise up against President Saddam Hussein, appealed to the Iraqi Army to embrace the popular revolt and even extolled the prospect of martyrdom for the cause.

title: Don't Reward Bad-Faith Searches
description: Seventy-seven years ago the U.S. Supreme Court began excluding illegally seized evidence from criminal trials. It reasoned wisely that the Constitution's ban on unreasonable searches would be meaningless if Federal agents could profit by such illegal conduct.

title: Review/Dance; Choreography by Women at Barnard
description: The stage was small and spare. But the program presented by the Barnard College Dance Department on Thursday night at the Minor Latham Playhouse managed to cover a surprising amount of territory.

title: Music in Review
description: Vladimir Faltsman Avery Fisher Hall

title: Review/Art; French Show Finally Gives Seurat His Due
description: With the opening of the first full-scale French retrospective exhibition of the work of Georges Seurat, due honor has at last been done in his native country to one of the great French artists of all time.

title: Topics of The Times; Mistaken Identity
description: Picture a group of men and women entering a small grocery store in, say, St. Anthony, Minn., a quiet town where hospitality is woven into life's fabric. The patrons are well dressed and dignified. They speak in a foreign tongue, and appear to be accompanied by reporters.

title: Anchorage Prices $84.4 Million Issue
description: An $84.4 million tax-exempt bond issue by Anchorage was initially priced yesterday through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The maximum yield offered was 7.20 percent for an issue due 2005.

title: Bookkeeper for a Drug Ring Is Given 6 1/2 Years in Prison
description: The man who masterminded a multimillion-dollar money-laundering operation for the drug ring based in Medellin, Colombia, was sentenced today to 6 and a half years in prison and fined $50,000.

title: Labor Chief Says Coal Companies Disregard Law on Miners' Health
description: Asserting that coal mining companies have a "flagrant disregard of the law," Labor Secretary Lynn Martin said today that she would soon announce new procedures to protect miners from black lung disease and would propose higher fines for several companies accused of particularly serious health violations.

title: CUNY Adversaries Look to Albany
description: Students and administrators at the City University of New York may be on opposite sides of the barricades that have shut down all or parts of nine campuses, but they both see the source of relief in the same place: Albany.

title: CHRONICLE
description: "I'm a high school dropout who got back on track by earning my G.E.D.," Gov. JIM FLORIO of New Jersey says in a public television announcement. He goes on to tell people to watch the Channel 13 adult education programs "G.E.D. on TV" and "Learn to Read."

title: Desperation at 3 Borders
description: Whether they are fleeing toward Turkey, Iran or Kuwait, Iraqis are undergoing ordeals of desperation and uncertainty. Articles, page A8.

title: Sports of The Times; A Dark Day, But Also A New One
description: THERE was a different sort of opening day at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, and the difference had nothing to do with the cold, steady rain that made umbrellas a hot item, or the housekeeping done between innings by the frantic grounds crew to dry up the clammy infield and pitcher's mound, or the fact that a right-hander named Colin Powell, who grew up in the neighborhood, threw out the first ball, and with some mustard on it.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a picture on Saturday with a Washington Talk article about the defeat of a Presidential nomination to the judiciary carried an incorrect caption in some copies. It showed Senator Bob Graham, not a Palm Beach police officer.

title: Papers Sold In Germany
description: The agency set up to sell eastern German companies to private investors closed a multimillion-dollar deal today to sell 10 newspapers once owned and operated by the former Communist Government.

title: NWA-Trump Shuttle Deal Seen as Near
description: Donald J. Trump, Citicorp and NWA Inc. are close to a deal in which NWA could get a controlling stake in the Trump Shuttle, people involved in the talks said yesterday. In exchange, they said, NWA, the parent of Northwest Airlines, would assume much of the shuttle's debt.

title: New York at Work; At OTB, a Battler of Waste And Champion of Rights
description: Since she took office as president of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation last summer, Hazel N. Dukes says she has been tripping over "unbelievable things" going on at the agency.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I remember the front door. I remember the auditorium. I remember the feeling that you can't make it. But you can." -- Gen. Colin L. Powell, visiting his old high school in the Bronx. [ B1:3. ]

title: How About A Shuttle Without Astronauts?
description: AS astronauts guided the space shuttle Atlantis to a smooth landing last week and then celebrated the 10th anniversary of the first shuttle flight, NASA was quietly wrestling with growing pressure to endow the winged spaceships with the ability to steer themselves back to earth, putting astronauts and their skills on the sideline.

title: Igwebuike Acquitted Of Drug Smuggling
description: DONALD IGWEBUIKE, the 32-year-old place kicker for the Minnesota Vikings, was acquitted yesterday by a Federal jury of charges that he masterminded a failed effort to smuggle more than $1 million worth of heroin from his native Nigeria into the United States. Igwebuike, who if convicted would have faced up to 120 years in Federal prison and $6 million in fines, threw his fists into the air and broke into tears after the verdict was announced in a Tampa, Fla., courtroom.

title: Books of The Times; An Old-Style Hero Whose Quest for Truth Is Heroic
description: The Theory of Everything Lisa Grunwald 336 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: New York Judge Rejects State Prenatal Program That Excludes Abortion
description: A New York State judge ruled yesterday that a state program to provide prenatal care for the working poor was unconstitutional because it did not include abortion services.

title: Big Stock Offering By Delta Air Lines
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. yesterday said that it had sold about $476 million in common stock in a public offering through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Bushes' Return: $99,241 in Taxes on $452,732
description: President and Mrs. Bush paid $99,241 in taxes on an adjusted gross income of $452,732 in 1990. Their taxes and income were slightly less than in the previous year.

title: Brady Calls for Lower Rates To Stimulate World Growth
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the top economic priority for the industrialized world should be to lower interest rates.

title: Sales of U.S. Vehicles Fell 17.1% in Early April
description: Sales of American-made vehicles fell 17.1 percent in early April, as buyers remained sidelined by debt.

title: The Fear of Morality
description: Let's dream awhile. Just suppose the United States could come up with a concept for the Middle East that would give the people of the region a chance for happiness and end wars.

title: India Vows Not to Default
description: Although it is staggering under a foreign debt burden of more than $70 billion, India will not default on its loans or seek a debt rescheduling, the country's top financial official said on Sunday.

title: Florida House Majority Leader Is Replaced
description: The majority leader of the state House of Representatives was replaced today and admonished for "very disappointing" conduct stemming from accusations of sexual harassment.

title: Patterns
description: Year of the Plaid

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about forced marriages in Japan referred incorrectly to the sweater worn by a Sri Lankan woman shown in the adjoining photograph. The shirt pictured Pluto, the Walt Disney character.

title: AFTER THE WAR: TURKEY Kurds 'Are Living in Hell' Stranded on Mountain Road; First Refugees Off Mountain
description: Sanitation has become the biggest worry for the managers of the rescue effort.

title: Winners Announced for Kennedy Awards
description: Four reporters from The Detroit Free Press won the grand prize in the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Awards yesterday for a three-part series about preventable injuries and deaths in automotive-parts plants.

title: Clue to Loss of Memory In Alzheimer's Reported
description: Researchers said today that they had found a clue to the cause of debilitating memory loss connected with Alzheimer's disease.

title: U.S. to Review Dioxin Risk Given New Studies
description: The Government is reviewing the risks of dioxin, spurred partly by studies that suggest small amounts of the chemical may not be as dangerous to humans as was believed.

title: A Multiracial Council District Best Reflects Lower East Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Yosef Tekoah, 65, Israeli Delegate To the U.N. for 7 Years, Is Dead
description: Yosef Tekoah, one of Israel's foremost diplomats, its representative at the United Nations for seven years, and chancellor of Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Where's the Beef on Labels?
description: The Agriculture Department calls its new proposal for nutritional labeling a big advance for consumers. But the labeling would do more to protect meat and poultry producers than health-conscious Americans.

title: Big Jump In Profits At Chase
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday announced a first-quarter profit of $117 million, a sharp improvement from a year earlier. The news was a sign that conditions for the banking industry are improving, even though problems with bad loans remain severe.

title: Odds Look Good for Germany's Odd Challenger
description: The new leader of Germany's opposition Social Democrats, Bjorn Engholm, is an iconoclastic pipe smoker and art lover who isn't really sure he wants to be Chancellor.

title: Cheney Defends Base Closings to a Cautious Panel
description: Members of a Presidential commission appointed to reduce the number and size of military installations said today that they would treat the Pentagon's recommendations for closing 31 major bases as a good blueprint for their deliberations, not as the final word on which installations would close.

title: Assassins in Managua
description: After the Nicaraguan resistance leader Enrique Bermudez was assassinated in Managua on Feb. 16, the country's Government said that a full investigation would find the murderers. Today, the killers walk the streets of Managua as free men, and it's unclear if they will ever be brought to justice.

title: Music in Review
description: Aleksei Lubimov Debut Avery Fisher Hall

title: Fans Grin and (Somehow) Bear It
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hannan of Stratford, Conn., took their grandsons, Matthew and Joey Brisch, out to the ball game yesterday. Opening day at Yankee Stadium coincided with a week off from school. The boys, 7 and 5 years old, talked of the trip for weeks.

title: By Design; Hair: Wear It Long and Loose
description: Now that long hair is back in style, let's discuss where it's going. At first, the trend seemed to be to pile it up in a loose beehive, as Ivana Trump did last year. But judging from the models at the fall fashion shows in New York last week, the movement is now reversed. For sure, long hair is the way to go, but the direction is down.

title: The Secretary's Away?
description: ANYONE who earns all or part of a living writing, whether novels or memos, will agree that the one indispensable tool is, to be honest about it, a skilled secretary. But some of us have to make do with our own proofreading, dictionaries and thesauruses.

title: Careers; M.B.A. Study Is Urged for Some Jobless
description: THE Simon Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Rochester has some advice for young middle managers who have lost their jobs, and for a few seniors graduating without job commitments: Think about getting a master's degree in business administration. And they can start a program at some schools in January if they are too late for the September term.

title: Ames Stores Posts a Loss
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. reported a fourth-quarter loss today of $26.7 million. It was an improvement over the $198.9 million loss posted in the final quarter of 1989 by the discount retailer, which filed for bankruptcy protection in April 1990.

title: 'Textbook' Anthologies on Campuses Are Curbed by Ruling on Copyrights
description: The ubiquitous photocopier has revolutionized the spread of information on college campuses in recent years, allowing professors to improvise "textbooks" by quickly and cheaply compiling collections of materials excerpted from many sources.

title: Tokyo Stocks Gain a Bit
description: Stock prices closed higher today in Japan. At the close of the afternoon trading session, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks was up 117.77 points, or about four-tenths of a percent, to 26,813.30.

title: Article 821091 -- No Title
description: The Carolina Power and Light Company yesterday priced $100 million in first mortgage bonds through a competitive bidding won by a group of underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Caller Beware if Bell Companies Are Let Loose; Anticompetitive Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Eurocom Called a Likely Bidder for Scali
description: EUROCOM, the giant French agency, is the most likely candidate to make a bid soon for Scali, McCabe, Sloves, the troubled New York agency that has been trying to free itself from its parent, the WPP Group, some agency executives said yesterday.

title: F.D.I.C. Suit On Silverado
description: A magistrate began closed-door hearings today seeking to settle the Government's $200 million suit against the President's son, Neil Bush, and other executives charged with negligence in the collapse of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association.

title: So Happy Down South
description: For days I have been struggling not to become sanctimonious about the Kurds freezing and starving and burying the dead on that faraway mountainside. See there? I am losing the battle again. That bit about "burying the dead" should have been omitted.

title: 2 Rangers on U.S. Team
description: Goalie JOHN VANBIESBROUCK and forward BRIAN MULLEN will join the United States team that will play in the world hockey championship tournament in Finland that begins on Friday and ends on May 4, the Rangers announced yesterday.

title: Irwin Hanover, Podiatrist, 75
description: Dr. Irwin Hanover, a podiatrist who founded and published the Journal of Current Podiatric Medicine, died on Sunday at the Orlando Regional Medical Center in Florida. He was 75 years old and lived in Orlando.

title: The Aging Brain: The Mind Is Resilient, It's the Body That Fails
description: OLD age's ravages on the human body are inevitable: the eyes dim, the skin sags, the muscles soften. But the common belief that the mind too loses its edge may be just a misperception.

title: Review/Television; A Stylish Throwback With a Modern Twist
description: Given the production pressures of churning out weekly television, true quality is something of a miracle. Yet at its best, an episode of "Murphy Brown" or "Cheers" can be as skillfully crafted, as well made, as the light comedies that a generation ago were Broadway stage staples. For more and more writers today, a television formula can be both challenging and rewarding. Occasionally the result can be masterful. Tonight an exceptional example can be found, at 10 on ABC , in a "Thirtysomething" episode written and directed by Richard Kramer, one of the producers.

title: Jacoby's Homer Sends the Indians Past Red Sox in 13th Inning, 1-0
description: Brook Jacoby broke up the longest scoreless tie in Fenway Park since 1983 by hitting a home run in the 13th inning today as the Cleveland Indians beat the Boston Red Sox, 1-0.

title: Bridge
description: Many tournament players seize on a likely victim, show him a deal on a piece of paper, and issue the time-honored challenge: "Do you want to play or defend?"

title: Iraqis Attack and Isolate Kurds, Iran Says
description: Iraqi troops and tanks attacked Kurdish refugees at the Iranian border, killing a number of them and closing an escape route, Teheran radio reported today.

title: Music in Review
description: Helene Grimaud Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: An Author Hopes for a Benign Human Mutation
description: When Nicholas Mosley's novel "Hopeful Monsters" won a $40,000 prize as Whitbread Book of the Year this year, he thought: "It was what in my wildest dreams I'd hoped for."

title: Italian Officials Arrested Again In AIDS Battle
description: Two Italian legislators who came to the United States in hopes of being arrested and prosecuted for illegal needle possession got part of their wish yesterday, to the chagrin of police officers and court officials. But it took some doing.

title: Apple Computer Profits Off; Cheaper Machines Lift Sales
description: Reflecting its shift toward selling higher volumes of lower-priced machines, Apple Computer Inc. today reported increased revenues but a slight decline in earnings for the second fiscal quarter that ended on March 29.

title: Strong Mark Is Urged
description: German interest rates must stay relatively firm to protect the mark and limit domestic price risks, a Bundesbank board member, Hans Tietmeyer, said today. Speaking to bankers in Hanover, Germany, Mr. Tietmeyer said a weakening of the mark would be of no help and that the mark had to remain strong.

title: Net Rises 5.2% at G.E.; Financial Services Gain
description: Buoyed by productivity improvements and strong gains in its financial services sector, the General Electric Company said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 5.2 percent.

title: Tonka's Board To Assess Bid
description: The board of the Tonka Corporation said it would meet tomorrow to consider an amended bid from Hasbro Inc. that offers more money to bondholders and less to stockholders.

title: Archer-Daniels Net Up
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company reported today that earnings rose 1.5 percent in the third fiscal quarter, giving the company its first increase of the year amid an improvement in its corn and wheat operation.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs dropped again last week, declining by 7, to 874, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The count was 60 short of the 934 total posted a year earlier, the company said, adding that the count usually falls in the first quarter of a year and continues to decline through April.

title: Music in Review
description: Audition Winners' Concert Metropolitan Opera

title: Qin Benli, 73, Dissident Chinese Newspaper Editor
description: Qin Benli, a legendary Chinese newspaper editor whose dismissal in early 1989 gave additional impetus to the Tiananmen democracy movement, died early this morning in Shanghai, a close associate said. He was 73 years old.

title: New Card Offered By Diners Club
description: Diners Club International Ltd. announced a new charge card affiliated with British Airways. The new card, aimed at corporate customers, allows emergency check-cashing at British Airways offices, priority seating on British Airways flights, a 10 percent discount on duty-free purchases in flight and other benefits.

title: Randolfo Pacciardi; Fascists' Foe Was 91
description: Randolfo Pacciardi, an Italian anti-Fascist who organized Italian-American volunteers to fight with the Allies in World War II, died on Sunday in Rome. He was 91 years old.

title: Exxon Unit's Note To Yield 7.902%
description: The Exxon Capital Corporation, a unit of the Exxon Corporation, is offering $250 million in noncallable guaranteed notes due April 15, 1996, through Bear, Stearns and Company.

title: Creighton Fills Post
description: RICK JOHNSON, a 31-year-old assistant coach for six years at Creighton University, yesterday was named to the head-coaching position, replacing TONY BARONE, who left last week to become head coach at Texas A&M. Johnson was picked over DICK FICK, another assistant who had also been at Creighton for six years. (AP)

title: Gorbachev on Peace Mission to Japan
description: Appealing for reconciliation after an enmity long predating the cold war, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Japan today with hopes of achieving a new relationship harnessing Japanese investment and technology to help the Soviet Union out of its economic crises.

title: Deep Inside Earth
description: Some 30 portable seismometers are to be used in Iceland this summer to follow the deep movements of molten rock that, from time to time, burst forth in the great eruptions that have formed that island. The instruments will be a new class of highly sensitive earthquake recorders able to probe, as never before, critical regions of the earth's interior.

title: Supreme Court to Review Record On Bias in Mississippi Colleges
description: Nearly 30 years after James Meredith became the first black student to enroll at the University of Mississippi, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Mississippi had taken adequate steps to overcome the legacy of official segregation in its public universities.

title: Convicted Murderer Is Seized in Brooklyn After a Prison Break
description: A convicted murderer, one of four convicts who escaped from a maximum-security prison in the Catskills last month, was captured last night on a street in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Yanks Get Dressed for Success but Fail in Opener
description: The long afternoon was neither festive nor bright. Umbrellas opened, rain fell and the Yankees seemed to drag themselves through another painful day.

title: Systems Set Record for Use
description: People rode the nation's mass transit systems 8.96 billion times last year, the highest level on record and an increase of nearly 50 million from 1989, the American Public Transit Association says.

title: INSIDE
description: Old Age and the Brain

title: First Executive's Chairman Agrees to Delay His Pay
description: California insurance regulators said today that Fred Carr, the chairman of the First Executive Corporation, had agreed not to try to collect $10.7 million in long-term compensation until all the troubled insurance company's policy holders are paid in full.

title: Powell Focuses the Spotlight on a Guarded Military Plant
description: For the employees of a little-known military plant in a desolate section of the South Bronx, a visit yesterday from Gen. Colin L. Powell was a chance to dispel some of the mystery that seems to shroud the building, isolated behind fences and a guarded gate.

title: Chess
description: If computers were human, they would not put perfect trust in humans.

title: Two Brokers Report Leap In Earnings
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company reported sharp increases in first-quarter earnings yesterday, largely because of a robust stock market and a decrease in costs.

title: Review/Fashion; For Beene, Finis Means Let Us Begin
description: With a distinguished collection of innovative clothes, Geoffrey Beene brought six weeks of fall fashion shows to a brilliant conclusion on Friday. The showings, which had begun in March in a lugubrious mood in Milan, Italy, as economic clouds darkened all over the world, had a happy ending.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Confectionary Corp., Chino, Calif., filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. * Boeing Co., Seattle, said Air Malawi, the carrier of the southern African nation of Malawi, had ordered two 737-300 aircraft valued at about $65 million.

title: Michigan Mentally Ill Face Treatment Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Pay Cut for G.M. Chief in 1990
description: The General Motors Corporation's new chairman and chief executive took a big pay cut in 1990, reflecting a dismal year for the industry and the nation's No. 1 auto maker.

title: Sanders Goes on Trial
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the trial of RICKY SANDERS, the Washington Redskins wide receiver who is accused of running over a parking attendant outside a topless nightclub last May. Sanders was charged with aggravated assault, but will be tried on charges of failing to stop and render aid. The incident occurred last May in Houston. Defense attorneys say Sanders thought the attendant hit his car and that he had no intent of assaulting the man. (AP)

title: Gen. Powell Returns to the Bronx, and Remembers
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell came home to the Bronx yesterday, seeking to connect with the neighborhood of his past as he traveled its streets in search of familiar sights and sounds.

title: Music in Review
description: Milton Babbitt Tribute Alice Tully Hall

title: Florida Undercurrents Drown 4, Imperil More
description: Four swimmers drowned off beaches on Florida's east coast over the weekend and hundreds more had to be rescued because of riptides.

title: Women Sizzle in Boston Spotlight
description: The weather was perfect, the fields were strong. Yet the 95th Boston marathon today was one of the most unusual in its storied history and memorable for an assortment of curiosities, well beyond the names and times of the winners.

title: Fed Move Dims Hope Of Easing
description: Credit market traders and analysts said the Federal Reserve Board sent a clear signal yesterday that it had no current intention of lowering short-term interest rates.

title: Executive at Citicorp To Help Lead Quotron
description: Thomas J. Cirillo has been named president and chief operating officer of Quotron, a provider of stock and foreign-exchange trading information owned by Citicorp. Mr. Cirillo, who joined Citicorp in 1979, was most recently division executive in charge of much of Citicorp's leasing activities in the United States.

title: TEXAS JUDGE BACKS LAW ON SCHOOL AID
description: The Texas Legislature breathed a collective sigh of relief today when the latest law intended to change the state's system of school financing finally satisfied a judge who had threatened to halt state aid payments to public schools.

title: Dow Up 12.38, to 2,933.17, on a Volatile Day
description: Stocks turned volatile yesterday as traders tried to figure out whether the Federal Reserve would bring interest rates down to revive the economy. Weakness in I.B.M. stock was a strong factor in keeping the market from moving higher.

title: Topics of The Times; Senior Campers
description: This summer, thousands of elderly New Yorkers will get the chance to escape city heat and go to the woods and countryside -- because of the Vacations and Senior Center Association.

title: Members of Kuwait Royalty May Lose Cabinet Positions
description: Kuwait is expected to shake up its Cabinet on Saturday, with changes in the ministries of oil, defense and finance, Government officials said today.

title: British Study Disputes Lengthy Climatic Role For Kuwait Oil Fires
description: BRITISH scientists who sent a research plane and helicopters through the smoke rising from the oil fires in Kuwait say serious smog could build in the region in the coming months, but there is little evidence to support dramatic warnings about possible long-term climatic effects.

title: Market Place; Sweetener Patent Lifts Biospherics
description: WHEN it comes to stirring the public imagination in late 20th-century America, few ideas can compete with the vision of eating and eating without growing fat.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Capital Cities/ABC Inc., New York, named Ann Maynard Gray president-diversified publishing group. * Esprit de Corp., San Francisco, said Corrado Federico resigned as president and chief executive.

title: For Kennedy, No Escaping a Dark Cloud
description: After two weeks of tabloid headlines, "Geraldo" shows and dark gossip, all stemming from an allegation of rape at the Kennedy compound in Palm Beach, Fla., Senator Edward M. Kennedy went to American University today to recall the glory days of the Kennedy family.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FRESH turkey breast is both a highly versatile and healthful ingredient for the home cook. A serving of six ounces without the skin has only 230 calories and 1.2 grams of fat. Turkey also lends itself to many recipes that can be completed in well under 60 minutes.

title: Major Rail Unions Declare Strike Against Nation's Freight Carriers
description: Rail workers called a nationwide strike against freight lines this morning, raising the prospect of disruption for businesses throughout the United States and commuters in some metropolitan areas.

title: Kansas Utility Deal Gets a Poor Review
description: The Missouri Public Service Commission said its staff had recommended that the $1 billion acquisition of the Kansas Gas and Electric Company by the Kansas Power and Light Company be denied. It said that Kansas Power was paying too much for Kansas Gas, and that the merger would likely reduce Kansas Power's financial strength. Hearings will begin on May 6.

title: Chins Up, Devils Turn to Next Season
description: The morning after the Devils were eliminated from the National Hockey League playoffs, Lou Lamoriello, the team's president, was buzzing around his office in much the same way that the Penguins had buzzed around Chris Terreri's net the night before, winning Game 7 of a Patrick Division semifinal, 4-0.

title: Senator Pryor Is Hospitalized After Suffering Heart Attack
description: Senator David Pryor of Arkansas suffered a heart attack today and was hospitalized in fair condition, his office said.

title: Harrelson's 'A' Lineup Has Failing Grade
description: With seven different lineups in the eight games played, the Mets have made the routine of posting the lineup an exercise in mystery, amusement, disappointment and relief.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: U.S. TROOPS TO BUILD CAMPS IN NORTH IRAQ TO AID KURDS; BUSH SEES 'TEMPORARY' ROLE
description: President Bush said today that American, French and British troops would set up secure camps in northern Iraq that could care for more than half a million Kurdish refugees until they could be coaxed back to their homes.

title: Impasse Lingers on Next U.S.-Soviet Arms Round
description: President Bush said today that plans for a summit in Moscow are still "predicated" on being able to sign a new treaty on long-range nuclear weapons, but held open the possibility of a more informal meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev even if the arms control impasse cannot be broken.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 6 about Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn misstated its history. It was a naval air station, not an Air Force base.

title: Lawsuit on Gulf War Press Curbs Dismissed
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a lawsuit filed by a group of news organizations that challenged the constitutionality of the Pentagon's restrictions on covering the Persian Gulf war.

title: Editorial Notebook; Politically Correct: False Slogan
description: On April Fool's Day the Smithsonian Institution's American history division held its first annual conference on the history of Jell-O. Scholarly papers were read, tongue in cheek. Exhibits were judged for jiggle, odor, level of disgust and, satirizing the hot cliche of the day, political correctness.

title: Hachette to Buy Knapp's Home Magazine
description: Hachette Publications Inc. has signed an agreement to acquire Home, a consumer magazine about renovation and interior design, from the Knapp Communications Corporation, the two companies announced yesterday. A price was not disclosed.

title: Ethnic Mosaic Grows Beyond New York
description: From Westchester to Nassau, from Bergen to Fairfield, the racial and ethnic diversity once unique to New York City spread through the metropolitan region's inner ring of counties in the 1980's as they gained Hispanic, Asian and black residents while losing hundreds of thousands of whites, the 1990 census shows.

title: Wine Talk
description: "DINERS zero in on names." So said a restaurateur in Seattle, in response to the second annual poll on wine-drinking habits in restaurants compiled by Wine and Spirits magazine. The restaurateur, Lotta Hashizume, could have added: "and white wine." She did note that at her place, Chez Shea, the producer most often mentioned was Sonoma-Cutrer, a Windsor, Calif., winery that makes only chardonnay.

title: Scientist Fighting a Dismissal By U.S. Gets Surprise Support
description: A scientific rebel fighting the Energy Department and the Los Alamos National Laboratory has won unexpected support from a Federal official who said that the scientist was dismissed on false charges and that the researcher's plans to leave the country, if realized, could endanger national security.

title: Did Patriot Missiles Work? Not So Well, Scientists Say
description: Scientists said today that reliance on the Patriot anti-missile system to defend Israeli and Saudi Arabian cities from Iraqi missile attacks might have resulted in more damage from explosive debris than if the system had never been deployed.

title: Review/Television; Children Who Are Extraordinary
description: "Wonder Kids," tonight's edition of "48 Hours," visits a 5-year-old whiz in geography amd astronomy; a 9-year-old violin prodigy; an 8-year-old who has an I.Q. of 145 and who read "Hamlet" in kindergarten, and a blind boy who started playing tunes on the piano when he was 8 months old. They can be met at 10 on CBS .

title: Ambulance Service Is Faulted
description: New York City's emergency ambulance corps is slow to answer a sixth of its most serious calls during peak periods because many of its ambulances are busy taking less serious calls, a new study of the agency has found.

title: Clippers in the Futility Lottery Again
description: Mike Schuler may have meant well last year when he coined the slogan "To play in May" as his chief intention after his introduction as the 11th Los Angeles Clippers coach in 15 seasons. It turned out to be a false hope, a daydream, just as it was for the 10 coaches who preceded him.

title: Homer Bigart, Acclaimed Reporter, Dies
description: Homer Bigart, one of the most accomplished reporters in American journalism, died yesterday at the Edgewood Center in Portsmouth, N.H., where he had been hospitalized for two months. Mr. Bigart, who wrote for both The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Times, was 83 years old and lived in West Nottingham, N.H.

title: Dow Soars 53.71 to Reach Its High for Year
description: Strong buying that intensified in the afternoon lifted all sectors of the stock market in heavy trading yesterday. At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was at a high for 1991 and less than 13 points away from its record, while most other popular share indexes were at highs.

title: Add Domino's To Grey List Of Accounts
description: GREY ADVERTISING was awarded the $60 million Domino's Pizza account yesterday, its fourth big victory this year.

title: McDonald's Planning to Reduce Its Garbage
description: The McDonald's Corporation, under continued criticism from environmentalists, announced more than 40 steps today that it hopes will reduce its daily generation of two million pounds of garbage by 80 percent.

title: Nabisco Awards $9.7 Million in Grants to 15 Schools
description: The RJR Nabisco Foundation announced today that it has awarded $9.7 million in grants to innovative programs to improve public education.

title: Fetal Research Is Pro-Life
description: Guy and Terri Walden, residents of Houston, where Mr. Walden is pastor of the Broadway Baptist Church, oppose abortion. But when a fetus-to-fetus tissue transplant promised to save their unborn child's life, they agreed to the procedure. They reasoned that fetal tissue transplants are "pro-life" and are not apt to encourage abortions, as many opponents of abortion contend.

title: Sports of The Times; The Doctor Diagnoses The Fight
description: BOXING has had enough trouble in recent weeks: the death of a novice boxer in Florida, the parking-lot frolics between Larry Holmes and Trevor Berbick, and the revelation that its most appealing champ of the last 15 years, Sugar Ray Leonard, used cocaine and abused his wife.

title: Review/Music; Tippett's 'Byzantium' By Solti and Chicago
description: The controversy surrounding the world premiere of Michael Tippett's "Byzantium" by Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony last Thursday in Chicago and the New York premiere on Monday threatened to overshadow the work itself and the occasion of its performance.

title: INSIDE
description: Unions Call Rail Strike After Talks Break Off

title: Poverty Blamed for Blacks' High Cancer Rate
description: Poverty, not race, is largely to blame for the higher rate of cancer among blacks than whites, according to a study by scientists at the National Cancer Institute.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: A Few of the Reasons for Wanting to Flee New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Darman Forecasts Dire Health Costs
description: President Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, delivered a dire warning today about increases in the cost of health care, telling Congress that annual Government spending on Medicare and Medicaid would exceed Social Security outlays by the turn of the century.

title: Key Rates
Chamorro Pleads With Congress for Increases in Aid
description: Speaking in the House chamber where the debate over the war in Nicaragua resonated for years, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro pleaded today with Congress for increases in economic aid to fortify her country's new democracy.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON THE INDIAN OCEAN -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION -- 10 A.M.

title: Knicks Overcome Themselves to Win
description: The Knicks won last night, despite doing almost everything imaginable, and unimaginable, to lose.

title: Beijing Journal; Romance, a Novel Idea, Rocks Marriages in China
description: Centuries ago, a wife in China could divorce her husband only if he had denounced her ancestors or killed someone in her family. Love never entered the picture.

title: Long Ago Smitten, She Remains True to the Country Captain
description: PEOPLE'S names regularly become brand names in the New York food world. Mothers may weep, but often they do it all the way to the bank.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp. plans to announce today the interest rate for a $285 million consolidated systemwide bond issue with a maturity date of April 22, 1996 through various securities dealers. * Public Facilities Authority, Tulsa, Okla., is offering $60 million in tax-exempt capital improvement revenue bonds initially priced to yield a maximum 5.40 percent for an issue due 1993 through Merrill Lynch & Co. Other yields include 5 percent for an issue due Oct. 1, 1992, and 4.875 percent for one due April 1, 1992. The bonds are rated AA- by S.&P. Common Stock

title: Theater in Review
description: Cirque du Soleil Battery Park City Battery Place and West Street Through May 5 Franco Dragone, artistic director; Gilles Ste-Croix, creative director; Michel Crete, set designer; Dominique Lemieux, costume designer, Rene Dupere, original score and musical director; Luc Lafortune, lighting designer; Debra Brown, choreographer. With: Brian Dewhurst, Vladimir Kekhaial, France La Bonte, Anne Lepage and David Shiner.

title: Growing Old Under Siege of Social Workers; More Funds Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Surge Early but the Pacers Survive by 132-126
description: The halftime buzzer sounded, and as the New Jersey Nets made their way toward the dressing room tonight, a fan leaned over the runway railing and yelled, "You guys can't play much better than that." Unfortunately for the Nets, he was right.

title: Credit Plan Makes Arms Industry Competitive
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review
description: Only the Truth Is Funny Westside Arts Theater, Downstairs 407 West 43d Street One-man comedy with Rick Reynolds; written and directed by Mr. Reynolds. Lighting, Wendall S. Hinkle; executive producers, Jack Rollins, Charles Joffe, Scott Sanders and Ed Micone. Presented by Rollins & Joffe and Radio City Music Hall Productions, in association with Showtime Networks.

title: Yields Decline for 7th Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts fell for the seventh consecutive week in the period ended yesterday, with most declines on the moderate side.

title: Olympic Drug Testers May Use Blood Samples
description: The International Olympic Committee said today that it was considering a proposal to use blood samples to test athletes for the use of unauthorized drugs. Officials acknowledged that the procedure could cause legal and ethical controversy.

title: Oilers, in an Overtime, And Blues Take Series
description: Esa Tikkanen scored his third goal of the game at 6 minutes 58 seconds of overtime to lift the Edmonton Oilers to a 5-4 victory over the Calgary Flames tonight in Game 7 of their opening round playoff series.

title: Up From Piggy Banks To Real Thing at School
description: Students at the Immaculate Heart of Mary School in Scarsdale, N.Y., are taking part in an innovative school-based savings account program so they can buy, among other things, all the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle figures in the world.

title: A Traveling Executive At Scientific-Atlanta
description: When Jack Acker arrived in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday for a convention, it was the least exotic destination he has visited in recent months.

title: Holyfield Dares Foreman, Who Dares to Fulfill Dream
description: George Foreman showed up in a houndstooth jacket and sunglasses today, thinking positive.

title: Settlement Defeat Speeds Film Exodus From New York
description: The exodus of feature films from New York City resumed with surprising speed yesterday, a day after a film-crafts union defeated a tentative settlement in a 19-week dispute that had put a number of productions on hold.

title: 2 Counties' Bonds In Pennsylvania
description: To finance the refunding of bonds previously sold for a Philadelphia Electric Company project, the Delaware County and Montgomery County Industrial Development Authorities are selling a total of $117.03 million in pollution control revenue refunding bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Woman in Florida Rape Inquiry Fought Adversity and Sought Acceptance
description: The woman who has accused William Kennedy Smith of raping her at the Kennedy estate here was born into a modest working-class family outside Akron, Ohio, but moved sharply up the economic scale 10 years ago after her divorced mother married a wealthy industrialist.

title: Washington Talk; For the Education Plan, A Rare Rosy Forecast
description: Like the Justice Depart ment in the Ken nedy Administration, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in the Johnson Administration, Henry Kissinger's National Security Council in the Nixon Administration -- or even the Defense Department a couple of months ago -- the Department of Education is on the point of the Bush Administration these days. It is the place where great deeds are expected, the place to make a reputation.

title: For PEN, the Glitter Is Gone but Not the Gold
description: During the 1980's, the writers' organization PEN embraced glamour and the patronage of Wall Street in a way that made some authors uneasy. Books sprayed in gold paint served as decoration for PEN's annual fund-raising dinners. Held at places like the Hotel Pierre and the Roseland ballroom, the galas left the likes of E. L. Doctorow and Kurt Vonnegut muttering that writers had become little more than court jesters for junk-bond merchants.

title: Roman Jasinski, 83, Ex-Dancer And a Leader in Regional Ballet
description: Roman Jasinski, one of the stars of the cosmopolitan Ballets Russes companies that flourished from the 1930's to the 50's and a leader in American regional ballet, died yesterday morning at St. John's Medical Center in Tulsa, Okla. He was 83 years old.

title: Bookkeeper for a Drug Ring Is Given 6 1/2 Years in Prison
description: The man who masterminded a multimillion-dollar money-laundering operation for the drug ring based in Medellin, Colombia, was sentenced on Monday to six and a half years in prison and fined $50,000.

title: Medical and Food Supplies for 100,000 at Each Camp, U.S. Says
description: Pentagon officials said today that each of the refugee camps they were planning to build in northern Iraq would include food distribution and emergency medical centers for as many as 100,000 displaced Kurds.

title: Unbeaten White Sox Thwart Yankees
description: Here and there, players sat in front of their lockers and stared into the memory of another loss. There was no talk, no real movement, almost no emotion when they finally spoke.

title: Fumbling New York's Fiscal Crisis
description: New York City is in a state of emergency, suffering from an economy in free fall. Sales and income tax revenues are below even pessimistic projections, the budget gap keeps growing and no relief is in sight. Yet there is scant evidence that City Hall is prepared to make the difficult decisions to lead the city out of danger.

title: Youth Hurt in Shooting At Morris High School
description: Just one day after Gen. Colin L. Powell visited the Bronx school, a 16-year-old student showing off his pistol to a friend at Morris High was seriously wounded yesterday when the gun went off, the police and school officials said.

title: Little Snow for Balmy Buffalo
description: By Buffalo standards, the past winter was comparatively tropical. Only 57.5 inches of snow fell at the Greater Buffalo International Airport, three feet less than the average for the season, 94.5 inches. Last year's total was just an inch or two short of that average.

title: Women Athletes Do Better as Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Card Lawsuit Filed
description: Visa International and Mastercard International are seeking $95 million in damages from telemarketing companies they assert cheated thousands of people seeking low-interest credit cards.

title: Bonds Mixed in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, as market participants basically ignored Government reports on housing and industrial production.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: MORRIS R. FRIEDMAN spots the well-dressed gent walking briskly up Broadway near Herald Square. Before he can reject it, a handbill is pressed into the gentleman's hand. He crumples it up and aims it at a trash basket. He misses.

title: Phones Getting Smarter With Built-In Computer
description: The rotary dial telephone is just beginning to fade into memory, but telephone makers are about to introduce models that they hope will make the popular Touch-Tone phone a memory, too.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Thanks to LORENZA DE MEDICI, the food writer and teacher from Italy, an extraordinary group of women learned a few kitchen tricks yesterday.

title: CUOMO SEEKS SHIFT IN CITY FISCAL RULE
description: Adding to the growing edginess over New York City's finances, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo suggested today that the city be allowed to run up a larger deficit before a state panel steps in to take control of its budget.

title: Paper Says U.S. Knew Of Iraq-Embargo Leak
description: The United States allowed military spare parts to be shipped to Jordan until just before the Persian Gulf War despite intelligence that Jordan was allowing arms into neighboring Iraq, a newspaper here reported today.

title: Black to Run Unit Where Beating Occurred
description: A black police captain is being placed in command of patrol officers in the division where the beating of a black motorist by white officers was videotaped last month.

title: Actors to Join Seminar On Work in the Theater
description: Stockard Channing, Jane Alexander, Jonathan Pryce, Topol, John Guare, Jerry Zaks and Peter Stone are among the performers and writers who will take part in a three-part seminar called "Working in the Theater," to begin on Tuesday at 11 A.M. at the Graduate Center of the City University, 33 West 42d Street.

title: Seymour Freidin, 73, Author and Reporter On Eastern Europe
description: Seymour Freidin, a longtime foreign correspondent and author who reported from Eastern Europe during the cold war, died on Friday in Charlottesville, Va., where he lived in retirement. He was 73 years old.

title: New York Takes Over Big Insurer
description: New York State insurance regulators yesterday seized control of the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, the New York unit of the First Executive Corporation.

title: Justice Dept. Clears Caterpillar Deal
description: The purchase by Caterpillar Inc. of a rival maker of road-paving equipment has been cleared by the Justice Department, which had objected in March on antitrust grounds. Under an agreement, Caterpillar can proceed with its purchase of the Barber-Greene Company of DeKalb, Ill., for about $25 million if Astec Industries, arber-Greene's parent in Chattanooga, Tenn., reopens its Roadtec division.

title: Don't Demonize North Korea
description: North Korea is fast replacing Iraq as the world's number one nuclear renegade. Evidence suggests it could be a lot closer to building a bomb than Iraq ever came. The solution, say some American policy makers, is to cut off all trade and contact until Pyongyang permits international inspection of its nuclear plants.

title: Ruling on Cable TV Sales Tax
description: In a ruling likely to lead to new taxes on cable TV, the Court said states can tax one form of communication and exempt others. Page D1.

title: Trump Report On Finances
description: A report prepared by the New Jersey Gaming Enforcement Division says the Trump Organization will topple unless it completes agreements with creditors owed nearly $2 billion on assets owned by Donald J. Trump.

title: Supreme Court Puts Sharp Curbs On Repeated Death-Row Appeals
description: A Supreme Court decision today sharply curtailed the ability of death-row inmates and other state prisoners to bring multiple Federal court challenges to the constitutionality of their convictions or sentences.

title: Borg Loses in Tuneup
description: BJORN BORG had an inauspicious homecoming at the Monte Carlo country club in Monaco, when he lost in two sets, 6-4, 6-4, to fellow Swede LARS JONSSON in a practice match yesterday.

title: Talk About Culture Shock: Ant People in Sky-High Huts
description: Davi Kopenawa Yanomami had left his communal hut and traveled from his village deep in the Amazon rain forest to tell of the horrors that white men were visiting upon his people. Then he saw Times Square.

title: People
description: * Frank Mangan has joined the New York office of Lord, Dentsu & Partners as senior vice president-group account director. * Jeanette Schiavone and Gary L. Silberbauer were named senior vice presidents at J. Walter Thompson Co., New York.

title: EX-AGENT IS GUILTY ON 5 DRUG CHARGES
description: A former Federal agent, accused of stealing heroin and cocaine on drug raids and from the Drug Enforcement Administration office here, was convicted by a Federal jury today on charges of narcotics conspiracy and money laundering.

title: Review/Opera; A New Cast Takes Over 'Luisa Miller' at the Met
description: Though the final tuneup of the season for "Luisa Miller" at the Metropolitan Opera last Friday evening amounted to a major overhaul, the singing remained uneven and the acting perfunctory. Three performers were familiar from previous seasons, Aprile Millo as Luisa, Paul Plishka (who sang Count Walter earlier in the run) as Wurm and James Levine conducting. But three others, Florence Quivar (Federica), Vladimir Chernov (Miller) and Jan-Hendrik Rootering (Walter), were new to these roles at the Met.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about aviation safety misidentified the manufacturer of the aircraft used by the Detroit Pistons. The team flies a BAC-111 made by British Aerospace.

title: Spira Letters at Issue in Extortion Trial
description: Exaggeration and credibility were the major themes yesterday as the lawyer for Howard Spira, the Bronx man on trial for allegedly trying to extort $110,000 from George Steinbrenner, sought to undermine the testimony of one of the prosecution's chief witnesses.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I did tell him, if I hear of any more of these things, I'm going to send the Mormon missionaries to him. He said, 'I'm about ready.' " -- Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, about his friend Senator Edward M. Kennedy. [ A1:4. ]

title: About New York
description: Adolescent inmates on Rikers Island tend to come from the streets, where the ambitious can make serious money from drugs. Most would never have guessed that installing carpets is more lucrative.

title: Hasidic Rabbi's Soviet Flock Is Restless to Leave
description: On Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, where the Lubavitcher Hasidic Jews have their world headquarters, Rabbi Berel Lazar dreamed of being a shepherd, not a drover. But his new flock here is restless, and its members do not stay long before jetting away from him, fervid for Israel and less insecure about becoming whatever Jewish means.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of an article about the Mosque of New York misidentified the man praying at the center. He was Ali Teymour, Assistant Secretary General and Chief of Protocol of the United Nations.

title: For Many Adults, The Joy of Reading Is Better Shared
description: ONCE a month, usually on a Sunday night and always at 7:30, Jerry Patterson has a date with his reading group in New York City. Although gossip is allowed during dinner, all the food, down to the last coffee cup, is cleared away by 8:30 so that a properly serious tone prevails. The group never reads anything by Jackie Collins or even John Updike. Only dead authors make the cut.

title: Withdrawals Up at S.& L.'s
description: Net withdrawals at the nation's savings institutions jumped to $9.1 billion in January, the highest level in nine months, the Government said.

title: Pacific Telesis Advances Slightly
description: Pacific Telesis yesterday reported a slight earnings gain, while two sister Baby Bells, Ameritech and Southwestern Bell, posted modest declines. Analysts said the figures showed that all the telephone companies were feeling the impact of slower growth during the recession, especially among business customers.

title: No Longer Just a Poor Fish, The Cod Is Doing Swimmingly
description: NO need anymore for blue blood. All it takes these days, it seems, is fancy new clothes and high-powered friends to get on the right guest lists.

title: Revenue Bonds Of Tampa Priced
description: Tampa, Fla., is tapping the debt market for $138.8 million in tax-exempt utility tax refunding revenue bonds, priced to yield a maximum 6.97 percent for a security due in 2009.

title: Official's Spouse Admits Money Laundering
description: A stockbroker who is the husband of the Rhode Island Secretary of State has admitted in Federal court that he laundered $81,000.

title: A Few of the Reasons for Wanting to Flee New York City; Most Want to Stay
description: To the Editor:

title: On Names in Rape Cases
description: For a week after the accusation of rape at the Kennedy compound in Palm Beach, Fla., news organizations held to their usual policies and did not name the woman who made the complaint.

title: State Taxes on Cable TV Upheld by Supreme Court
description: In a decision likely to open the way for new state taxes on cable television, the Supreme Court ruled today that the First Amendment permitted states to impose a tax on one form of communication while exempting other forms.

title: Brooklyn Shootings Kill One Bystander; 3 Others Wounded
description: One woman was shot and killed and two girls, 11 and 13 years old, and a boy, 14, were shot and wounded in three incidents yesterday in Brooklyn. All were bystanders, the police said.

title: Protecting the Secrecy of Faxed Data
description: Facsimile machines are so much a part of office life that few people think about them beyond the constant flow of curled up sheets of glossy paper that the machines generate. But think about this, communications industry experts say that most fax machines are as easy to tap as telephones.

title: Merrill's Profits Soar; Bear Stearns Up 66.3%
