description: This year's flood of investors in the securities markets brought more good news from Wall Street yesterday, as Merrill Lynch and Bear Stearns reported sharply increased earnings for the first quarter.

title: Carol Perkins's Incendiary Performance
description: When Carol Perkins sat down in the New York Times cafeteria last week, she pulled down her lower lip and exposed two big white blisters. "They're not herpes," she announced, which certainly turned a lot of heads. But that is something she expects.

title: Growing Old Under Siege of Social Workers; Community Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Parretti Out As Chairman Of Pathe
description: The MGM-Pathe Communications Corporation said today that its main lender had agreed to provide $145 million in new loans, but only after the Italian investor Giancarlo Parretti said he would step down as head of the troubled studio and its parent company.

title: A College Acts in Desperation And Dies Playing the Lender
description: After surviving for more than a century in the tallgrass prairie of northwestern Missouri, Tarkio College, a traditional liberal arts college with Presbyterian roots, is closing at the end of May.

title: Snookums! Steve Urkel Is a Hit
description: He's so unhip that now he's cool, Steve Urkel, a regular in-your-face kind of guy. When he laughs, he snorts. When he talks, he whines in a nasal, grating voice. When he arrives, he intrudes, with his pants riding up his skinny waist and his mouth working overtime, popping out sassy, if not annoying, rejoinders.

title: Love Triangle: 2 Sides Sum Up In Murder Trial
description: In two days of summations in the trial of Carolyn Warmus, the jury heard about the victim of a sinister frame-up, a young woman whose only crime was loving a married man. But it also heard about an obsessive mistress who, not getting what she wanted, coolly plotted the murder of her lover's wife.

title: West Bank Settlement Is Opened, Just Before Baker's Mideast Trip
description: A handful of Jewish settlers moved into a cluster of mobile homes in the West Bank on Monday night, opening the first new Jewish settlement to be established in the occupied territories under the current rightist coalition Government.

title: Top Position Is Filled At World Color Press
description: Robert G. Burton, who for a short time was a professional football player, has been named chairman, president and chief executive of World Color Press Inc., which claims the distinction of being the nation's largest printer of consumer magazines.

title: Excerpts From Bush's News Conference: Relief Camps for Kurds in Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today at the White House: OPENING STATEMENT

title: 'Oh, Kay!' Closes Again
description: "Oh, Kay!," a revival of the George and Ira Gershwin musical scheduled to reopen tomorrow after a winter hiatus, closed during previews on Sunday at the Lunt Fontanne Theater. Directed by Dan Siretta, the musical ran for 16 preview performances. The show, produced by David Merrick, originally opened last November.

title: Pacific Gas Sets $200 Million Issue
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company sold $200 million in first and refunding mortgage bonds yesterday through competitive bidding, which was won by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Monday with an article about the killing of John Gotti's driver, Bartholomew Borriello, was published in error. Besides Mr. Gotti, the picture showed Joseph Watts, not Mr. Borriello.

title:
N.F.L. DRAFT;
As the Big Day Nears, It's the Agent Who Does the Signal-Calling
description: Five days before the National Football League draft, quarterback Dan McGwire was bodysurfing in Hawaii while Leigh Steinberg, his agent and lawyer, was here finessing telephone calls from interested teams, including the New England Patriots.

title: Growing Old Under Siege of Social Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams to Turn Pro
description: After fulfilling a commitment he made to Coach LUTE OLSON to play basketball at the University of Arizona for two years, BRIAN WILLIAMS has decided to foresake his final season of college eligibility and enter the National Basketball Association draft.

title: The Pop Life
description: A New Pop Star

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts by two Italian legislators to publicize their fight to legalize the possession of hypodermic needles referred incorrectly to the organization Act-Up. It is an AIDS advocacy and protest group, not a gay rights organization.

title: A Stolen Monet Goes Back on Display
description: The celebrated painting by Claude Monet that lent its name to the Impressionist movement went back on display today at the Paris museum from which it was stolen more than five years ago.

title: Market Place; Consumer Trends Bothering P.&G.
description: WHEN the Procter & Gamble Company bought Max Factor and other cosmetics lines from Revlon Inc. for $1.14 billion last week, it won general praise on Wall Street. Now comes the hard part.

title: Gorbachev Meets Kaifu and Both Urge Flexibility
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, opening the first high-level attempt at warmer ties between the Soviet Union and Japan, appealed to each other today to show greater flexibility on a territorial dispute long dividing the two countries.

title: Eating Well
description: THIS is not information you want to hear just as barbecue season is beginning, but there is increasing evidence that grilling meats over a hot charcoal fire produces substances that may cause cancer in humans.

title: Theater in Review
description: Native Speech SoHo Rep 46 Walker Street Through May 5 By Eric Overmyer; directed by John Pynchon Holms; set by Kyle Chepulis; costumes, Patricia Sarnataro; lighting, Steve Shelley. Presented by SoHo Rep. With Kario Salem, Sami Chester, James Encinas, Fracaswell Hyman, Deborah Mansy.

title: Banks' Stake Seen In Trump Shuttle
description: Two groups of bank lenders to the Trump Shuttle will take equity interests in the airline in a restrucuturing of its debt, people involved in the financial negotiations said. Donald J. Trump, the airline's owner, could get future income from the shuttle if it can generate enough income to pay off all its bank obligations. Under the reported deal, NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, will take control of the Trump Shuttle and operate it. A $135 million loan to the shuttle that was personally guaranteed by Mr. Trump will be held by the shuttle company.

title: Technologies' Net Off 70.1%
description: The United Technologies Corporation today reported a 70.1 percent slump in its first-quarter net income, saying the recession had hurt three of its key businesses: aircraft components, building supplies and automobile parts.

title: Compromise on Financial Regulation in Jeopardy
description: A legislative compromise that would resolve a long-festering dispute among futures and securities regulators appeared to be in jeopardy when it was denounced by a number of key Democrats and Republicans at a Senate Banking Committee hearing today.

title: Foreign Affairs; A New Iran Hostage Scandal?
description: Hardball politics is one thing. But Presidential candidates or their aides interfering in life-and-death, war-and-peace decisions of sitting Presidents is quite another. It is treachery.

title: Dining a la Cart: Street Food Mirrors The Tastes of a City
description: WHAT'S in the refrigerator usually indicates an individual's preferences in food. What's for sale on the street reveals the tastes of a city.

title: Continental Backed On Keeping Planes
description: A Federal appeals court granted Continental Airlines Inc. an emergency stay of a lower court order that would have allowed a leasing company to take its planes away from the airline. Involved are 47 aircraft, out of about 350 Continental flies, that the airline says are not subject to lease payments during bankruptcy proceedings. Judges of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ordered the stay to remain in effect until the outcome is decided at a hearing scheduled for May 1 on whether payment is required despite Continental's Chapter 11 filing.

title: Griffey Sr. Activated
description: KEN GRIFFEY SR., who began the baseball season on the disabled list after suffering a strained lower back in an automobile accident, was activated yesterday by the Seattle Mariners. . . . RICK SUTCLIFFE rejoined the Cubs yesterday and Manager DON ZIMMER said he would reactivate Sutcliffe tomorrow and start him against Pittsburgh that night. Sutcliffe had been recovering from shoulder surgery. (AP)

title: Police Chiefs Call for U.S. to Study Use of Force
description: Saying they were outraged by the beating of a motorist by Los Angeles police officers, police chiefs at a conference on police brutality called on the Federal Government yesterday to develop a national system for gathering information on the use of excessive police force.

title: Economic Scene; Parental Leave: Symbols Matter
description: IT'S no mystery why the Democratic leadership is pushing hard for passage of the Family and Medical Leave Act. The bill, which would require employers to give workers 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for newborns or seriously ill family members, is strongly supported by the Democrats' allies in organized labor and women's groups. And it apparently ranks up there in popularity with three-day weekends and hot fudge sundaes: A Louis Harris poll last June found that 74 percent of Americans favored the measure.

title: Home Loan Bank's $709 Million Issue
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank System yesterday priced $709 million in three-year bonds through various securities dealers.

title: F.D.A. Delay Is Criticized
description: A Federal appellate court said today that the Food and Drug Administration was taking too long to act on applications to sell new generic drugs. The court, however, refused to order the agency to work faster.

title: Football's Also-Chosen Ones: More Potential Than P.R.
description: Jake Reed grew up in Covington, Ga., 25 miles east of Atlanta. Atlanta offered excitement, city life, fast cars and fast dreams. Back in itsy-bitsy Covington, though, Reed lived in the projects with his two brothers, two sisters and his mother.

title: Bridge
description: It seems to be a nightmare. You are Omar Sharif, about to start play in a pair tournament on some remote island. Your partner has not arrived, and the substitute introduces himself as the Prime Minister.

title: Compaq Trims Prices And Sues Dell on Ads
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation slashed prices today across its product line, responding to increasingly lower pricing by competing makers of personal computers. Compaq cut its computer prices by up to 34 percent, and prices of key options, like extra memory and communications attachments, by up to 68 percent.

title: Book Notes
description: 'Nancy Reagan' Is No. 1

title: Food Notes
description: For Indoor Grilling

title: Books of The Times; Four Doomed Prisoners in a Sicilian Decameron
description: Lies of the Night By Gesualdo Bufalino Translated by Patrick Creagh. 163 pages. Atheneum. $18.95.

title: Move on Unscrambling Of Messages Is Assailed
description: A measure tucked inside a recently proposed Senate bill calls on telephone and computer companies to give the Government the means to unscramble private electronic messages and telephone conversations that have been encrypted to insure privacy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DONNIE WAHLBERG, the lead singer of the New Kids on the Block, agreed last Thursday to make public-service television announcements on fire safety and drugs in return for a reduced sentence for criminal mischief, a misdemeanor. But the judge in Louisville, Ky., who agreed to the deal said on Monday that he was disappointed in the pop star.

title: Stuck Antenna Hinders Jupiter Mission
description: The main communications antenna on the Jupiter-bound Galileo spacecraft has failed to unfurl properly, threatening to limit severely the scientific mission's ambitious plans to explore the giant planet and its moons.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League

title: Fryman and Deer Help Tigers Roll Over the Blue Jays, 6-2
description: Travis Fryman hit a three-run homer and Rob Deer, moved up to third in the batting order tonight, broke a 1-for-18 slump with a triple and double to lead the Detroit Tigers past the Toronto Blue Jays, 6-2.

title: Replacement Named
description: Princeton has named JOE SUSAN its new offensive coordinator and offensive line coach, replacing CRAIG CASON, who left last month to become head coach at Morehouse College in Atlanta.

title: Housing Starts Fell 9% in March
description: In reports suggesting that the recession could linger beyond midyear, the Government said today that the pace at which builders broke ground for new homes fell 9 percent in March while production of the nation's factories, mines and utilities fell three-tenths of a percent.

title: Iraq Asks U.N. to Permit Big Sale Of Oil to Pay for Imports of Food
description: Iraq asked the Security Council today to ease the United Nations trade embargo by giving Baghdad permission to sell almost $1 billion worth of oil on world markets over the next four months to pay for emergency imports of food and other essential humanitarian items.

title: In the Nation; The Party of April 15?
description: With millions of Americans having just trooped glumly to the post office to send in their annual tribute to the Government, why are Democrats hesitating to back Senator Daniel P. Moynihan's proposal to cut taxes for lower- and middle-income people while raising them on the affluent?

title: In Edison, a Crossroads of Diversity
description: The racial and ethnic mix achieved here and in the surrounding towns of Middlesex County in the 1980's suggests to many experts the direction in which the counties around New York City are heading.

title: Merck and American Home Report Double-Digit Growth
description: Two pharmaceutical companies yesterday reported double-digit growth in quarterly earnings..

title: David Lean, Film Director, Dies at 83
description: Sir David Lean, the leading British director of both intimate films like "Brief Encounter" and "Great Expectations" and epics like "Bridge on the River Kwai" and "Lawrence of Arabia," died yesterday at his home in London. He was 83 years old.

title: Growing Old Under Siege of Social Workers; For the Homebound
description: To the Editor:

title: Mattingly Still Waits For Glory in October
description: When the Oakland A's won the American League West in 1988, Manager Tony La Russa reminded the young players just how fortunate they were to have won something.

title: 2 Missing Journalists Are Released by Iraq
description: An American journalist and a French photographer who entered Iraq with Kurdish rebels have been released from a Baghdad prison after 18 days in detention.

title: Weicker to Close 19 More Parks in Labor Dispute
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that 19 more state parks would close on Friday, the day before the opening of the fishing season, because the state cannot reach a resolution with state employee unions over wage and benefit givebacks.

title: CUNY Students Face Court; Tuition Protest Hits SUNY
description: Demonstrations against tuition increases and budget cuts spread to a campus of the State University of New York and to the City University Graduate Center in Manhattan yesterday, and students who had taken over a building at one City University campus were ordered to appear in court.

title: Real Estate; Prudential Signs Key Tenant in Chicago
description: A LEASE signed by the Amoco Corporation for 200,000 square feet in the half-empty Prudential One building will lift occupancy close to 80 percent.

title: Storm at Georgetown Law on Admissions
description: Georgetown University law students crammed into a moot courtroom today and expressed hope that reasonable words could defuse campus tensions over an article in a student journal asserting that black law students' academic qualifications were inferior to those of whites.

title: The Gossip of Mount Olympus
description: Three weeks ago, it was Goldie Hawn's unshampooed locks in Julia Phillips's autobiography. Two weeks ago, it was the Kennedys' alleged bacchanal in Palm Beach. And last week, it was Nancy Reagan trysting with Frank Sinatra, recycling Christmas presents and feuding with her children. And this week? We all wait for the next revelation in what seems to be an epidemic of gossip for a nation of voyeurs.

title: Lintas Quits Bayer Account
description: Lintas New York said yesterday that it had resigned the $30 million account for Sterling Drug's Bayer pain remedy.

title: IRAN IS SCATTERING KURDISH REFUGEES
description: Travelers on the main road from the Iraqi border to this provincial capital on Monday night passed a line of 17 dump trucks under Iranian military escort. Each truck was filled with Kurdish refugees fleeing the Iraqi Army.

title: Sovereignty vs. Suffering
description: National sovereignty is defended as a universal and almost sacred principle. Moves that might diminish it are steadfastly resisted. Weighed against human suffering, a nation's sovereignty usually triumphs. In recent history, nothing has illuminated this conflict more poignantly than the plight of the Iraqi Kurds.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Computerland Corp., Pleasanton, Calif., said it had completed the acquisition of most of the assets of Dataphaz Inc., Phoenix, a microcomputer company, for about $4.9 million. * Caci International Inc., Arlington, Va., received two Navy contracts totaling about $18 million.

title: Wild or Tame, Thick or Thin, Asparagus Is Worth the Wait
description: SPRING always brings to mind young vegetables, particularly asparagus. When I was a child, my mother and I used to pick wild asparagus, which grew next to the Rhone River in Lyons, France.

title: Turkey's Chief Urges Global Aid to Resettle Kurds
description: President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, faced with what he called the "extraordinary difficulties" of the presence of two-thirds of a million Kurdish refugees, appealed tonight to the world to help resettle them in Iraq.

title: Blyleven Has Surgery
description: California Angels right-hander BERT BLYLEVEN, winner of 279 major league games, underwent his second shoulder operation in less than a year yesterday and will require at least nine months of rehabilitation, the team said.

title: Gains Shown by Microsoft Despite Slump for Industry
description: Despite the slump suffered by many companies in the personal computer business, the Microsoft Corporation reported today that it had a 65 percent increase in profit on a 57 percent increase in revenue.

title: Ruling Removes Last Hurdle For 6 Real-Estate Projects
description: The last legal obstacle to the construction of six major real-estate projects, including several apartment and office buildings on the West Side, was removed yesterday when a state appeals court restored two New York City zoning law amendments.

title: Baskin-Robbins
description: Baskin-Robbins Inc., one of the nation's largest ice-cream chains, said it would become the first nationwide chain to offer "fat free" desserts made with Simplesse, a new fat substitute made by the Nutrasweet Company, a unit of the Monsanto Company. Baskin-Robbins, with 2,300 stores across the country, said that two flavors of the dessert were already being offered and that it would begin advertising them next month. It said the products contained no cholesterol, were low in sodium and have 100 calories in a half-cup serving.

title: Growing Old Under Siege of Social Workers; Using the Money Well
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Big Banks Post Drops In Profits
description: Four of the nation's 10 largest banking companies announced substantially lower quarterly profits yesterday, with Citicorp's falling the most.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Accounts
description: * Jel Sert Co., Chicago, manufacturers of Fla-Vor-Ice and Pop-Ice frozen bars, to the Chicago office of BBDO. Billings are more than $1 million.

title: Winnie Mandela Takes Stand To Deny Role in Abductions
description: Winnie Mandela, the wife of the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, took the witness stand in her defense today to deny that she helped kidnap four young men and assaulted them in her home in Soweto.

title: Irish Have Trouble Filling Coaching Job
description: PETE GILLEN, long considered the most likely successor to DIGGER PHELPS as head basketball coach at Notre Dame, yesterday told the school's athletic director DICK ROSENTHAL that he planned to remain at Xavier University in Cincinnati.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a Florida legislator accused of sexual harassment misstated his leadership role in some copies. Before being replaced, he was majority leader of the state House of Representatives, not the Speaker.

title: Promotion Agencies Highly Rated by Clients
description: A survey conducted on behalf of the Council of Sales Promotion Agencies indicates that companies think they receive better service and attention from promotion agencies than from advertising agencies.

title: Warsaw Turns On the Stock Tickers
description: In a hall where the Communist Party once stored tomes of Marxist-Leninist commentary, Poland today set in motion that essential cog of capitalism: the stock market.

title:
CURRENTS;
A Design To Comfort The Sick
description: INTERIOR design isn't guaranteed to heal, but many argue that it can help by raising the spirits of the sick. Among these are Robert Gaul and Iris DeMauro of Archetype Gallery in SoHo, and Patricia Kelly, one of the gallery's artists.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: And Keep in Mind
description: AKIRA KUROSAWA'S DREAMS -- A young boy wanders through fairy tales that are "absolutely stunning to look at and listen to" (Vincent Canby). 1990. Warner. $92.95. Laser disk, $34.98. 2 hours. Closed captioned. PG. GHOST -- The deceased returns to his lover in a ghost story that "veers repeatedly from the somber to the broadly comic" (Janet Maslin). 1990. Paramount. $99.95. LD, $29.95. 2:22. CC. PG-13. HENRY AND JUNE -- Philip Kaufman's film about the three-way relationship of Henry Miller, his wife and Anais Nin is "overpowered by Nin's passionately overheated style" (Maslin). 1990. MCA/Universal. $91.95. LD, $39.98. 2:16. NC-17. THE HOT SPOT -- Dennis Hopper's film noir about a drifter in a Texas town is full of "stylized malevolence and hot-blooded mischief" (Maslin). 1990. Orion. $94.98. 2:10. CC. R. THE LAST PICTURE SHOW -- Peter Bogdanovich's film about coming of age in Anarene, Tex., is an "adventure in rediscovery of human values" (Canby). 1971. RCA/Columbia. $59.95. LD, $34.95. 1:58. CC. R. MEMPHIS BELLE -- Matthew Modine pilots a B-17 in a movie "resembling the sort of service films Hollywood made during the war" (Canby). 1990. Warner. $92.95. LD, $24.98. 1:47. CC. PG-13. PRESUMED INNOCENT -- Alan J. Pakula makes "restraint a great virtue, turning it into a slow-burning fuse" (Maslin) in his intense adaptation of Scott Turow's courtroom novel about a lawyer (Harrison Ford) accused of murder. 1990. Warner. $92.95. LD, $29.98. 2:27. CC. R. THE TALL GUY -- Jeff Goldblum is a beleaguered actor in a British comedy that is "always wickedly endearing, thanks to the off-kilter characters" (Maslin). 1990. RCA/Columbia. $89.95. LD, $34.95. 1:32. CC. R.

title: A Glamour Account To McElligott Wright
description: Chalk up another account victory for Tom McElligott, who resigned last year as executive creative director of Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York and later helped found McElligott Wright Morrison White in Minneapolis.

title: Schwab's Net Climbs Sharply
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the country's largest discount brokerage, today reported dramatically higher first-quarter earnings, a reflection of an upturn in stock market activity.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about the record producer Henry Glover described his education incorrectly. He received a bachelor's degree from Alabama Agricultural & Mechanical University and had nearly completed a master's degree at Wayne State University when he left to join the Buddy Johnson big band.

title: Reality Hits Milan Like A Flashback
description: Few people would have guessed that the school desk, the old-fashioned office cabinet and the plain kitchen table would redefine and revive the ultrasophisticated Italian design scene. But from Friday's start of the 13th Salone Internazionale del Mobile -- the International Italian Furniture Fair -- the ordinary seemed extraordinary and the banal, sublime.

title: Student Takeovers at CUNY Continue in Tuition Protest
description: Student takeovers of buildings in protest of proposed tuition increases and budget cuts spread to two more campuses of the City University of New York yesterday. And Justice Alice Schlesinger of the State Supreme Court ordered students occupying a building at another campus, the Borough of Manhattan Community College, to end their takeover by 2 P.M. today.

title: New Pathe Chairman Is a Stranger to Studios
description: Cesare De Michelis has never been seen working the crowd at Morton's, the restaurant of choice among studio executives in Hollywood. A book publisher from Italy, he is not known to have ever made a movie or to have worked in the entertainment business in the United States. And almost no one in Hollywood has ever heard of him.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Allentown, Pa., is offering $100 million in 8 3/4 percent noncallable debentures due in 2021 at 97.718 to yield 8.97 percent through Lehman Brothers. The debentures are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: TRW Earnings Down
description: TRW Inc. said today that first-quarter earnings fell nearly 40 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier largely because of weak demand in the automotive industry. The automotive, space and military technology supplier said net earnings for the three months ended March 31 totaled $35 million, or 57 cents a share, compared with $57 million, or 92 cents a share, in the coresponding period a year ago. Sales were down 4 percent, at $1.92 billion, against $1.99 billion. Automotive sales fell from $1 billion, to $977 million, with operating profit down by half, from $80 million, to $40 million. Space and military systems sales declined by 6.5 percent and operating profit fell 2 percent.

title: News Media's Use of Accuser's Name Is Debated
description: The publication and broadcast of the name of the woman who says she was raped at the Kennedy estate in Palm Beach, Fla., has unleashed a torrent of comment and criticism from news executives, women's groups and members of the public.

title: Kurd Relief Plan Takes Bush to the Edge Of the Tangle He Has Tried Hard to Avoid
description: President Bush presented his plan to aid the Kurdish refugees as a straightforward and limited humanitarian operation, but it has raised the possibility of snaring Mr. Bush in just the kind of political and military tangle that he has been trying to avoid.

title: Enemy of Local Drug Dealers Is Killed on a Brooklyn Street
description: A 68-year-old Brooklyn man who had waged a campaign against drug dealers was run over and killed by a furious van driver this week, the police said. The man's family and neighbors said the killing was in retaliation for his persistence in ordering drug dealers, addicts and prostitutes off the block.

title: Marjorie H. Bond, 80, A Fund-Raising Expert
description: Marjorie Hyde Bond, a fund-raising consultant, died on Sunday at the Community Hospital of Western Suffolk in Smithtown, L.I. She was 80 years old and lived in Peconic, L.I.

title: High Noon on High Street
description: The fierce battle between students and alumni over the admission of women to Yale's most secretive and ritualistic senior society, Skull and Bones, ranks right up there -- or down there -- with the other stories that have diverted readers from the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, including the latest Kennedy family imbroglio in Palm Beach and Kitty Kelley's book about Nancy Reagan.

title: Congress Votes to Halt Rail Strike Hours After Thousands Walk Off Job
description: Congress approved a joint resolution late Wednesday to halt the national railroad strike less than 24 hours after it began. President Bush signed the legislation early this morning.

title: House Rejects Bush Budget Plan and Adopts Own
description: After rejecting President Bush's budget request by a vote of 335 to 89, the House of Representatives today approved its own blueprint for Federal spending in the next fiscal year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Persistence has paid off for OLIVER STONE, who began directing "JFK," his film about the assassination of John F. Kennedy, this week in Dallas. Mr. Stone's requests to film from the Texas School Book Depository's sixth floor "sniper's perch," a window, were rejected by the Dallas County Commissioners three times.

title: Help With Needlework
description: ALMOST everyone who has ever knitted or done needlepoint has at some time wished for a helper to complete a half-finished sweater or canvas.

title: Japanese Vehicle Exports
description: Japanese vehicle exports in the fiscal year ended March 31 rose by one-tenth of 1 percent from a year earlier, to 5.8 million, the first year-to-year gain in five years, auto industry sources said today. The exports included 4.5 million cars, a 1.8 percent rise, and 1.3 million commercial vehicles, down 5.3 percent. Domestic vehicle production in the period rose by 4.9 percent from a year earlier, to a record 13.6 million, surpassing the previous record of 13 million a year earlier, they said.

title: U.S. Trade Panel Recommends Sanctions Against Japan
description: A long-smoldering trade dispute with Japan has heated up, with the Bush Administration's interagency Trade Policy Group recommending retaliation for Tokyo's failure to open more public works construction to American companies, like a new airport for Osaka, Administration officials said today.

title: A Gentler Baby Thermometer
description: Parents often fret over using a rectal thermometer to take the temperature of an infant, out of concern that the device might cause discomfort or injury or break. Many parents also find the mercury-filled devices difficult to read.

title: Retirement Plan For Teachers
description: The New York City Board of Education approved yesterday a plan to encourage older teachers to retire this year, thereby helping thousands of younger teachers to keep their jobs in the face of the city's fiscal troubles.

title: Recycling in the Home: A Place for Everything . . .
description: AS recycling programs expand, new products for organizing and storing trash are appearing as product designers get a surer sense of what works in the home: stackable carriers for bottles of varying sizes; an electric crusher that flattens and stores up to 24 cans; a set of bright-colored stacking storage bins with lids that can be locked open; a divider that converts one trash can into two. The Industrial Designers Society of America has given its Industrial Design Excellence Award to the Bag Hog by Form Farm Inc. It comes flat, but can be rolled into a cylinder and latched to hold a plastic trash bag.

title: Myron A. Ellis, Lawyer, 82
description: Myron A. Ellis, a lawyer for almost 60 years, died on Tuesday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Women Set Conditions
description: Even before receiving a formal invitation to participate in the Grand Slam Cup, a $6 million Munich event inaugurated with a men-only format last year, the Women's Tennis Association announced yesterday that it would participate in the tournament under two conditions. They are: that the women's field contain the same draw size and payout as the men's, and that the Grand Slam Committee agrees to compensate women on an equal basis with the men at both the French Open and Wimbledon.

title:
CURRENTS;
A Barneys Arises In Tokyo
description: THERE is an "international style" in store architecture, Peter Marino said. The New York architect was not referring to the taut planes and rectilinear forms of the Modernists, but of his design for the new Barneys in Tokyo.

title: A Little Push
description: To The Home Section:

title: NCNB and First Interstate Report Lower Profits
description: The NCNB Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest banking company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits fell 8.4 percent because of problems with bad loans.

title: A.T.&T.'s Income Rises As GTE Posts a Decline
description: A.T.& T., the nation's largest long-distance carrier, reported a modest gain in its net income for the first quarter yesterday, while the GTE Corporation, the largest owner of local telephone companies, reported a sharp decline.

title: Dance Award Is Started
description: Dr. Pearl Primus, professor of ethnic studies at Amherst College in Massachusetts, has been named recipient of the 1991 Balasaraswati/Joy Ann Dewey Beinecke Chair for Distinguished Teaching at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C. Dr. Primus, an authority on black dance, is the first person selected for the chair, which was established this month to pay tribute to dance teachers. The chair was established through an endowment of $135,000 in contributions. Ms. Balasaraswati, who died in 1984, was one of India's leading dancers and teachers. Ms. Beinecke, who died in 1989, was a dancer and member of the dance faculty at Williams College in Massachusetts.

title: Spring Is Also Season Of Home-Repair Fraud
description: Reports of home-improvement fraud are popping up as fast as the first flowers of spring around the state.

title: Integra Payments
description: The Integra Hotel and Restaurant Company, an independent operator of Holiday Inns, suspended interest payments on all its subordinated debentures issued under its former name, the Brock Hotel Corporation. The company cited a lack of sources for borrowing and negative cash flow for its decision. Integra also said it expected to pay the $2.3 million in principal owed on debentures due for redemption on May 1.

title: Americans Aiding Kurds See A 'Major Change in Direction'
description: American military officers, diplomats and aid workers in this eastern Turkish city, a staging area for relief, were taken by surprise by President Bush's speech Tuesday night announcing plans to establish camps for the Kurds.

title: Sheltering Children Of the Vietnam War
description: CHILDHOOD was mostly a matter of survival. Many children grew up in the streets, begging for food. Those who were lucky enough to go to school usually dropped out after a couple of years, succumbing to the beatings of other students who taunted them with the charge, "You look American."

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: INSTALLING a pocket door is fairly easy once the rough opening has been built. Pocket doors and frames are generally sold separately, and are available at building suppliers and home centers.

title: Fidelity of Philadelphia Gets a New President
description: Roland K. Bullard 2d was named president and chief executive of Fidelity Bank N.A. of Philadelphia yesterday. Mr. Bullard, director of mergers and acquisitions for the Corestates Financial Corporation and a vice president of that banking company, has spent most of his career with Corestates and Philadelphia National Bank, a Corestates affiliate.

title: Key Rates
Correction Officers Settle Lawsuit Over Pregnancy Bias
description: New York City reached an agreement yesterday with 22 present and former female correction officers who said they were forced to have abortions or to take brutal assignments to keep their jobs.

title: Frauke Haasemann, Choir Conductor, 68
description: Frauke Petersen Haasemann, the assistant conductor of the Westminster Choir and professor of conducting at the Westminster Choir College, died last Friday at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 68 years old.

title: Market Place; At Last, Dow Closes Above 3,000
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 3,000 for the first time yesterday, marking another milestone in a bull market that has seen stocks around the world rise sharply since last fall, when concerns peaked over the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and higher oil prices.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Bonfire of the Vanities 1990. Warner. $92.95. Laser disk, $29.98. 2 hours, 6 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: Personal Health
description: Do you start sneezing soon after the air conditioner is turned on in the car?

title:
BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
'Life in the 30's,' the Novel: Westchester Adolescence
description: Object LessonsBy Anna Quindlen262 pages. Random House. $19.

title: 13 Potential Jurors Excused in Mob Case
description: Thirteen prospective jurors were excused in the last two days from a major racketeering trial in Brooklyn when they said they were nervous or fearful because of the highly publicized slaying of John Gotti's driver.

title: Guggenheim Grants Averaging $26,500 Are Awarded to 143
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has named 143 artists, scholars and scientists as winners of its 67th annual competition for awards totaling $3,790,000.

title: Tagliabue Looks at Dollars, Deals and N.F.L. Draft
description: With the National Football League draft opening on Sunday, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said yesterday that he was not concerned that the draft's top prize -- Raghib Ismail of Notre Dame -- might shun the league and play in Canada instead. But he said he was concerned about the draft's future as it pertains to the league's economics, suggesting that a salary cap and a rookie wage scale may be unavoidable.

title: Police Strategy in Kennedy Inquiry May Make It Harder to Win Justice
description: For 48 hours after a woman reported being raped at the Kennedy estate here the Palm Beach police held back any news of the accusation, not mentioning it even when they made their initial inquiries at the Kennedy household.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Advice From Holtz
description: Some other people may be skeptical, but LOU HOLTZ, the football coach at Notre Dame, said yesterday he is convinced that DIGGER PHELPS resigned voluntarily -- and was not forced to quit -- as Notre Dame's basketball coach. In fact, Holtz said Phelps had advised him in the past to do just what Phelps did. "He told me on several occasions that I was foolish to continue to coach after we won the national championship," said Holtz at Hilton Head Island, S.C., before playing in the Heritage Classic pro-amateur tournament. "He said, 'Man, you ought to retire and get on to other things in your life.' Here's a guy who's been there 20 years. You're going to have to retire sooner or later. He chose when."(AP)

title: Once-Paternal Insurers Trim Jobs
description: America's giant insurance companies are abandoning their cherished tradition of paternalism, cutting jobs on a scale almost unthinkable a few years ago.

title: Another Bass Gives Yale $20 Million
description: For the third time in less than a year, a member of the oil-rich Bass family of Texas has given Yale University a $20 million gift, bringing the contributions by the Basses to $60 million, one of the largest commitments ever made by one family to a single institution of higher education.

title: Maxwell's Mirror Group To Go Public
description: Hoping to reduce his empire's heavy debts and take advantage of a buoyant British stock market, Robert Maxwell announced plans today to take his Mirror Group newspapers public by selling investors as much as 49 percent. The company includes five major British tabloids and might eventually add The Daily News in New York, recently acquired by Mr. Maxwell.

title: H. L. Rubendall, 80, Ex-President of College
description: Howard Lane Rubendall, a clergyman who was the retired president of Dickinson College in Carlisle, Pa., died Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: Not All That's Gilt Is Gold
description: Gilding involves coating a surface with an adhesive, and then applying a delicate film of pure gold. When finished, the surface gives the illusion of being solid gold. For sheer splendor, gilding is without equal, but it is expensive and it demands considerable skill.

title: Yale Journal; Women in the Crypt? Old Bonesmen Say No
description: Prof. Gaddis Smith, Yale '54 and a member of the history department since 1961, recalled Tap Day as it used to be. "Up until the middle of the 1950's," he said, "all juniors who had aspirations to join a secret society gathered like cattle in a college courtyard. At the stroke of 5, all the seniors would rush out and literally tap people for their societies, almost breaking their shoulders.

title: Rich's Plans To Close Its Main Store
description: Rich's Inc., a landmark in downtown Atlanta for more than a century, announced yesterday that it would close the huge store on July 13 after five years of continuing losses.

title: Tall In the Straddle
description: When the President's press secretary opined that his boss did not have to have an arms treaty all set to sign in order to meet at the summit with Mr. Gorbachev, two groups were horrified:

title: NWA in Jet Sale
description: The International Airline Support Group said it had agreed to buy 17 commercial jetliners from Northwest Airlines, a unit of NWA Inc. International Air, which said it had agreed not to disclose terms of the transaction, said the deal involved 11 DC-9's and 6 Boeing 727's. The planes are scheduled for delivery between July 1991 and January 1992, it said. International Air supplies aircraft parts and leases Boeing 737 and 727 aircraft through a joint venture.

title: Price Fixing Always Victimizes the Consumer; The Service Fallacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Record Coke Earnings On Strong Sales Abroad
description: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink maker, yesterday reported a 13.2 percent earnings increase in the first quarter, to a record $320.9 million.

title: German Prices Fall
description: Producer prices in western Germany fell three-tenths of a percent in March from February, to stand 1.8 percent above the level recorded in March 1990, the Government said today. Excluding volatile oil products, producer prices rose one-tenth of a percent in March, for an increase of 1.6 percent from the period a year earlier, federal statistics showed.

title: Michelin Plans to Cut At Least 16,000 Jobs
description: Michelin, the ailing French tire maker, said today that it would cut at least 16,000 jobs from its worldwide work force by the end of next year.

title: Sports of The Times; Torborg Never Got Egypt Job
description: ISN'T it amazing how well people do after leaving the anarchy of the Yankees? In California, there is Dave Winfield hitting three homers the other night. In Oakland, there is Rickey Henderson, fresh from two World Series.

title: Corrections
description: The Real Estate column on April 10 about the Fordham Road commercial district in the Bronx misstated a boundary. The district runs from Third Avenue to Jerome Avenue, not to the Grand Concourse.

title: Pop in Review
description: Michael Moriarty Fat Tuesday's 190 Third Avenue (at 17th Street) Through Sunday

title: De Yong Ginsberg Gets Rest of El Pollo Loco
description: Only two months after it picked up a small advertising assignment for El Pollo Loco, the chain of chicken restaurants, de Yong Ginsberg Weisman Bailey, an agency based in Irvine, Calif., has inherited most of the chain's $9 million account.

title: Return to Iraq? Kurds Quake at Thought
description: Even mention of the possibility of returning to an Iraq still controlled by Saddam Hussein arouses tremors of anxiety and mistrust among Iraqi Kurds seeking refuge in the Turkish-operated holding camp here.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 4 about John Johnson, a candidate for mayor of Austin, Tex., who has identified himself as a former hit man for the Mafia, misattributed a coment about him made by an Austin police officer. It was Capt. Lloyd Polk, not Capt. John Pope, who called Mr. Johnson "a schizo."

title: GORBACHEV PLEADS FOR JAPANESE AID TO SOVIET ECONOMY
description: Declaring that Japan and indeed the whole world had a stake in his success, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev implored Japanese lawmakers and industrial giants today to give investment and aid to help the Soviet Union avoid what he said was a "disintegration" of its economy.

title: 'Spartacus': A Classic Restored
description: Some critics dismissed it as a multi-million-dollar costume spectacular, and indeed numerous museums and costume houses provided several thousand uniforms and seven tons of custom-made armor for assorted senators, generals, gladiators and 5,000 soldiers played by real soldiers from the Spanish Army.

title: General Dynamics Reports 9% Decline in Operating Net
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the giant military contractor, said yesterday that its first-quarter operating earnings fell 9 percent, with sharply lower sales of military aircraft.

title: Loan Inquiry Centers On Hospitals Chief
description: The New York City Department of Investigation has been asked to look into accusations that the president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, J. Emilio Carrillo, accepted $8,300 in loans from subordinates.

title: Governors Seek $10 Billion in Increased Taxes
description: Governors in a majority of the 50 states have imposed $10.3 billion in new taxes during the current fiscal year to cope with the worst financial conditions many have seen since the 1983 recession, according to a report made public today.

title: Other Indexes Set Records, Like the Dow
description: As the Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 3,000 level yesterday for the first time, all other major share indexes set records for the second consecutive day.

title: Democrats, Getting a Drop on Bush, Send Education Bill to Senate
description: Senate Democrats, trying to take the edge off Thursday's scheduled announcement of President Bush's education program, sent an education bill of their own to the Senate floor today, saying they were first to put into effect the school goals set last year by the nation's governors.

title: Prince Appeals for U.S. Troops to Stay in Kuwait
description: The Crown Prince of Kuwait has appealed to American troops to stay in his country to protect it.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of the "The Killer" in Weekend on Friday listed a rating erroneously. The movie has no rating; it is not R.

title: Joseph M. Cosenza, 60, Port Agency Architect
description: Joseph M. Cosenza, the chief architect for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died on April 10 at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 60 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Senate Forms a Group to Offer Ethics Guidelines
description: Senate leaders have announced the creation of a bipartisan working group on constituent service, the first official response to the ethics case involving five Senators and the operator of a troubled savings and loan association.

title: Home Video
description: 'Bonfire' Released

title: Smiley's 1-Hitter Stops Mets
description: Vince Coleman's absence from the lineup tonight left the Mets without their speed. John Smiley's left-handed pitching wizardry left them without power or muscle or anything remotely resembling a threat. As a result, their entire effort was without so much as a pulse.

title: Dramatizing a Family That Took On Dictatorship
description: A few years ago, the British film producer Colin Callender was at the London headquarters of Amnesty International, reading files on political dissidents in search of stories that could be made into movies. When he came to the case of a Paraguayan doctor named Joel Filartiga, he knew at once that he had found a perfect example of the way, as he describes it, "small acts of heroism can result in the reaffirmation of human rights."

title: Higher New Jersey Auto Registration Offsets Insurance Cuts; No Immediate Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: Auction of Mahler's Unfinished Symphony Is Criticized
description: The announced auction of the manuscript of most of Gustav Mahler's unfinished Symphony No. 10 at Sotheby's in London on May 17 has prompted criticism by the Austrian National Library in Vienna about the actions of the composer's granddaughter, Marina Mahler.

title: U.S. SCOUTING REFUGEE SITES WELL INSIDE IRAQ'S BORDERS, AIMING TO LURE KURDS HOME
description: The United States military sent troops in helicopters into northern Iraq today to begin securing one or two large zones where they plan to build refugee camps near Kurdish cities as deep as 60 miles inside Iraqi territory.

title: Bush Asks the Army's No. 2 To Take Over the Top Spot
description: President Bush has chosen Gen. Gordon Sullivan, the Army's No. 2 officer, to be the Army's chief of staff for the next four years, the White House announced today.

title: International Lease In Debt Offering
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation, a Beverly Hills, Calif., lessor of commercial aircraft, is offering $150 million in debt securities in two maturities through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the income-tax statement of the New York City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, misstated his relationship to a restaurant in Queens. Mr. Vallone is an investor in the property where the restaurant is situated; he is not a restaurant owner.

title: 100 Officers Support 5 Accused of Murder
description: More than 100 off-duty New York City police officers outside a Queens courthouse shouted their support yesterday for five of their colleagues charged with murdering a car-theft suspect as the five appeared for a hearing.

title: Ashton-Tate Shows Profit
description: The Ashton-Tate Company said today that it returned to profitability in the first quarter after two quarters of losses.

title: The Real Palm Beach Story
description: Earlier this week, NBC News jumped off the Empire State Building. So The New York Times, like any thoughtful toddler, decided it had to follow suit. The woman who filed a complaint of rape against William Kennedy Smith has been "outed" after a week in which repeated questions have been raised in print about her actions and character. The Times's explanation for its decision to publish her name was that NBC News had done it the night before. My 5-year-old nephew couldn't have put it better.

title: Exhibition to Follow The Travels of Mozart
description: An exhibition tracing Mozart's travels through Europe is to be on display at the Vincent Astor Gallery of the New York Library for the Performing Arts, 40 Lincoln Center Plaza, at 65th Street, from May 17 through Aug. 31.

title: A Welcome for South Africa
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that he hoped that South African athletes would compete at the world track and field championships in Tokyo from Aug. 24-Sept. 1.

title: David Kadane, 77, Ex-Counsel for Lilco And Professor, Dies
description: David K. Kadane, a law professor and a former general counsel for the Long Island Lighting Company, died on Saturday at his home in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: PARENTS of children who have serious but not necessarily life-threatening medical problems, like asthma, diabetes or even premature delivery, often find that such problems color the parent-child relationship. The normal adventures of a child's development, like swimming in a pool or spending the night at a friend's house, may bring about strong feelings of concern, as well as pride, for the parents.

title: Capital Holding In Bid for Durham
description: The Capital Holding Corporation, an insurance company, said it had offered to acquire the Durham Corporation in an exchange of 0.25 share of preferred stock for each Durham common share. It said each preferred share would be convertible into 2.7982 Capital Holding common shares, assuming completion of Durham's previously announced sale of its broadcasting subsidiary and the related retirement of 835,000 Durham common shares.

title: Underclassmen Swap College for What's Behind Door No. 3
description: Fear tinges Ernie Thompson's voice when he talks about where he thinks he might be selected in this year's National Football League draft of college players. His reason forgiving up his senior year at Indiana University to enter the draft is quickly followed by hisuncertainty.

title: People
description: * Clifford Scott has joined the Los Angeles office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc. as vice president, director of business development. * James F. Boland has been named executive vice president of Bozell Healthcare.

title: Gifts Allow Mother Hale to Continue Nursery
description: Mother Hale, the frail-looking Harlem woman who has been compared to Mother Teresa and called an "American Hero," is not going to have to give up taking care of babies born addicted to crack after all.

title: G.O.P. Chairman Offers Preview of '92 Campaign
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the new chairman of the Republican National Committee, offered a preview of the 1992 campaign today, accusing the Democrats of "isolationism" in economic and foreign policy and saying their opposition to the war in the Persian Gulf was "indelibly intertwined in the American political psyche."

title: Connecticut Senate Passes Law Protecting Gay Rights
description: The Connecticut Senate gave final approval today to a bill outlawing discrimination against homosexuals, ending an 18-year struggle and pushing toward law a proposal killed so many times in the legislature that its demise had come to seem like a rite of spring.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON THE INDIAN OCEAN -- 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Clemens Indicted
description: A grand jury in Houston yesterday indicted Red Sox pitcher ROGER CLEMENS and his brother on misdemeanor charges stemming from a nightclub altercation with an off-duty policeman in January. Clemens was arrested for hindering arrest and his brother, GARY CLEMENS, for resisting arrest after they were allegedly involved in a shouting match with other nightclub patrons.(AP)

title: BOXING: When Swift Hands Meet Brute Force in the Ring; Holyfield Can Win If His Combinations Unravel the Bigger Man
description: Not long ago in Houston, where he was training for Friday's fight against George Foreman, Evander Holyfield hit a 250-pound sparring partner named Mike Bardwell with a three-punch combination that made Bardwell so goggle-eyed Holyfield had to step back and give him time to recover.

title: Review/Music; Pavarotti, Struggling With a Cold And a Handkerchief, as Otello
description: In Verdi's "Otello," as in the Shakespeare tragedy that inspired it, an innocent handkerchief becomes a key player in the drama. The Moor's gift to Desdemona falls into the hands of Iago, who uses it to incite the jealous warrior to murder and suicide. Desdemona's handkerchief was not in evidence during Tuesday evening's concert performance of "Otello" by the Chicago Symphony at Carnegie Hall, but another famous one, Luciano Pavarotti's, certainly was. That fact frequently worked to the detriment of a rousing but rather bizarre performance led by Georg Solti.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Each year, the Albert Einstein College of Medicine honors outstanding women. Its Spirit of Achievement awards this year will be given to these five: JUNE ANDERSON, the British opera singer whose recent appearances at the Met were highly acclaimed; EVELYN H. LAUDER, for her contributions in philanthropy, including longtime support of New York's parks; ANNA QUINDLEN, whose first novel, "Object Lessons," was published this month by Random House; DONNA KARAN, for her work in fashion, and FAYE WATTLETON, president of Planned Parenthood.

title: How Bush Overcame Reluctance and Embraced Kurdish Relief
description: The Administration's decision to create refugee camps for hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq came after two weeks of resisting similar proposals by President Turgut Ozal of Turkey and Prime Minister John Major of Britain.

title: Mergers at an 11-Year Low
description: Merger and acquisition activity fell to an 11-year low in the first quarter as war and recession kept deal makers wary, according to a report by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Connecticut Layoffs Averted
description: The state's labor unions agreed to $327.7 million in wage and benefit concessions to help close a budget gap and preserve 2,600 jobs. Page B5.

title: German Arrested as a Spy
description: A Bonn Defense Ministry official has been arrested on suspicion of spying for the East German Communist Government for more than two decades, the federal prosecutor's office said today. It said the man, identified only as Wolf-Heinrich P., 57 years old, was considered to be one of the most important Communist spies working in the military area. The suspect, who was arrested Monday and is being held in investigative custody, worked for the East German Ministry of State Security during 1968 and 1969, a statement said.

title: Lawrence W. Hill; Music-Theater Director, 41
description: Lawrence W. Hill, a music-theater director and conductor, died last Friday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chamorro Wins Bush Promise on Debt
description: In an endorsement of Nicaragua's new austerity policies, President Bush pledged today to President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro that he would lead an international effort to help the country clear $360 million in overdue payments on its crushing debt.

title: Baker Defends Refugee Plan at European Meeting
description: Secretary of State James. A Baker 3d started his new Middle East diplomatic mission today by defending the Bush Administration's decision to establish sanctuaries for Kurdish refugees, asserting that it was a humanitarian effort and was consistent with United Nations resolutions.

title: U.N. Discusses South Iraq Refugee Havens
description: Diplomats and United Nations officials have been discussing the possibility that thousands of refugees now in southern Iraq may be admitted into Kuwait, Iran and Saudi Arabia, United Nations officials said here today.

title: Review/Theater; Speaking, in Mamet's Words, to the Subconscious
description: David Mamet has demonstrated his affinity for Chekhov in his own work and in his adaptations of "The Cherry Orchard," "Uncle Vanya" (recently presented on WNET) and "Three Sisters," which opened last night at the Atlantic Theater. While each playwright is certainly localized within his time and environment, they share a common concern with indirect action in plays that, in Mr. Mamet's words about Chekhov, speak to our subconscious.

title: Bankruptcies On the Rise
description: The number of bankruptcies filed in United States courts each year has more than doubled since 1981, with most cases now filed by consumers, the American Bankruptcy Institute said today.

title: Yugoslav Breakup Ducks Economic Issue; Separation Is Inevitable
description: To the Editor:

title: Price of Aid for Egypt Is a Dose of Economic Pain
description: As the echoes of the Persian Gulf war fade, Egypt's huge economic problems are returning to top the list of this country's principal concerns. The situation is likely to be tougher than many Egyptians expected because there are indications that the rich Arab countries of the gulf -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other emirates -- will not be as generous as their promises indicated.

title: INSIDE
description: Congress Acts Quickly To End Rail Strike Congress approved a joint resolution aimed at halting the national railroad strike less than 24 hours after it began. The measure was then sent to President Bush, who signed it. The legislation would create a new mediation board that will have 65 days to resolve the dispute. Page B8. Debt Relief for Managua Meeting with President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, President Bush pledged to help Nicaragua meet its overdue debt payments. Page A3. Female Guards Settle Suit New York City reached an agreement with female correction officers who said they were forced to undergo abortions to keep their jobs. Page B1. Warning to Polluters U.S. companies that might try to evade U.S. pollution controls by moving to Mexico will find no haven, Mexican officials said. Page A20. Are Legal Fees Protected? A lawyer was indicted in New York for refusing to name the source and amount of her fees for defending a drug dealer. Page B1.

title: Gannett's Net Drops 33.2%
description: The Gannett Company said today that a drop in newspaper advertising sales because of the recession and the Persian Gulf war contributed to a 33.2 percent decline in first-quarter earnings.

title: Pop in Review
description: Roger McGuinn The Ritz 119 East 11th Street

title: Syria's Foreign Minister Sees Real Hope for Mideast Peace
description: As United States Mideast diplomacy gathers momentum, a senior Syrian official has asserted that Arab nations have never been so flexible and Washington has never been so serious in the quest for peace. But he said that any peace had to be based on the return of the territory that Israel captured from the Arabs in the 1967 war.

title: Judge Overturns Ruling On NBC's Deal for FNN
description: A Federal judge yesterday overturned a bankruptcy court decision issued two weeks ago that would have let CNBC, a cable news channel, buy its archrival, the Financial News Network, for $115 million.

title: Higher New Jersey Auto Registration Offsets Insurance Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title:
CURRENTS;
90's Tick, Primitive Skeleton
description: CLIFTON MONTEITH, a craftsman from Lake Ann, Mich., has made a grandfather clock for those who like something made with natural materials.

title:
CURRENTS;
Apotheosis For a '55 Dreamboat
description: IN the prosperous 1950's zooty, boat-sized cars were much coveted. Then came the 1980's; the stretch limo was born.

title: A Kemper Blanket
description: To emphasize that it makes its customers "feel good," the Kemper Corporation, the financial-services and business company, has covered the outside of a four-page insert with a soft material that feels like a blanket, its symbol. The full-color ad, which was created with the Chicago office of BBDO Inc., uses a technique called flocking, in which short, soft fibers are packed together tightly. The ad will first appear nationally in the April 22 issue of Fortune magazine.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sir PETER USTINOV celebrated his 70th birthday on Tuesday at a grand gala in Paris that brought together about 800 friends and admirers. The man who has been an actor, director, playwright, screenwriter and novelist said he hoped to spend his 80th birthday more quietly.

title: Calendar: Benefits and Old Brooklyn
description: Community Benefits International Design Center of New York, 30-20 Thomson Avenue, between 30th Street and 30th Place, Long Island City; (718) 937-7474.

title: Caps Suggested for U.S. Health Spending
description: The Comptroller General of the United States, Charles A. Bowsher, said today that the nation should seriously consider setting limits on total public and private spending for major categories of health care, like doctors' services, hospital care and new technology.

title: Comments of Gorbachev: 'A Sign of Frankness'
description: Following are excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address to the Japanese Parliament yesterday in Tokyo, as provided by the English-language service of the official Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Cuomo to Drop Idea On City Deficit Limit For Fiscal Takeover
description: A day after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo suggested easing state fiscal oversight rules for New York City, some investors sold off city bonds, raising bond yields a bit, and Mr. Cuomo said he was immediately dropping the notion.

title: Prices on Corporate Bonds Rise
description: Prices of investment-grade corporate and high-yield "junk bonds" rose sharply yesterday, as investors seeking higher yields than those offered on ultra-safe Treasury securities were active buyers.

title: Italy's Latest Coalition Cabinet, Four Days Old, Loses a Partner
description: The five-party coalition that has governed Italy for most of the last decade was reduced to a pas de quatre today when the small Republican Party walked out in a dispute over Cabinet assignments.

title: A Second South Florida Dentist Tells Patients He Has AIDS
description: A Florida dentist who specialized in orthodontics and often worked with children has informed his patients that he has AIDS and closed his practice.

title: BLOOD BANK FACES CLOSURE BY F.D.A.
description: The Food and Drug Administration today threatened to close the Blood Collection Center in Portland, Ore., after the agency found numerous violations of procedures, officials said.

title: The Real Palm Beach Story
description: Earlier this week, NBC News jumped off the Empire State Building. So The New York Times, like any thoughtful toddler, decided it had to follow suit. The woman who filed a complaint of rape against William Kennedy Smith has been "outed" after a week in which repeated questions have been raised in print about her actions and character. The Times's explanation for its decision to publish her name was that NBC News had done it the night before. My 5-year-old nephew couldn't have put it better.

title: Photographer Is Reported Killed By Iraqi Troops in Kurdish Region
description: A Romanian-born photographer working for Newsweek magazine was killed by Iraqi troops while covering the Kurdish uprising, two colleagues reported today.

title: Axelrod Retires From Health Post
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today announced the retirement of his ailing Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, and said he had begun a nationwide search for a successor to continue Dr. Axelrod's activist approach to public health.

title: U.S. Denies Allowing Export Of Military Parts to Jordan
description: The White House denied today that it allowed shipments of military spare parts to Jordan until just before the Persian Gulf war despite intelligence reports that Jordan was passing the parts on to Iraq.

title: Yugoslav Breakup Ducks Economic Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Morris Net Up 21.5% In Quarter
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products company and the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, reported yesterday that it had first-quarter earnings of $942 million, or $1.02 a share, compared with $775 million, or 84 cents a share, for the corresponding period last year. That increase of 21.5 percent was slightly better than many analysts' expectations.

title: Breast Implant Maker Asks Doctors Not to Use Device Linked to Cancer
description: The maker of a breast implant that the Food and Drug Administration has linked to cancer in animals asked yesterday that doctors refrain from using the device until the agency reviews data on its safety. The company, Bristol-Myers Squibb, said it would suspend shipments until the review was complete.

title: TBS Airport Channel Set
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. announced plans today for the Airport Channel, which will provide live newscasts and consumer and travel reports to the nation's airports.

title: Shoemaker Remains Paralyzed
description: Hall of Fame jockey Bill Shoemaker is unlikely to recover from nearly total paralysis suffered when he broke his neck and injured his spinal cord in an automobile accident, medical officials said today.

title: Lawyer Cited For Contempt Over Fee Data
description: A Manhattan grand jury has indicted a defense lawyer for criminal contempt for refusing to disclose the source and amount of legal fees she received from a major drug dealer she defended.

title: Transit Agency Is Retreating on Service Cuts
description: Transit officials are backing away from threats to close token booths at night, eliminate express and local bus routes and other drastic cuts in mass-transit services in the face of unexpectedly strong opposition from both the public and from policy-makers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Blackstone Group, New York, a merchant bank, and Sal. Oppenheim Jr. & Cie, a German bank, have agreed to jointly develop and execute trans-Atlantic mergers and acquisitions and to jointly make principal investments in Germany and the United States. Terms were not disclosed. * Dean Foods Co., Franklin Park, Ill., has completed the acquisition of the Utah and Neada fluid and ice milk business of Western Dairymen Cooperative, Salt Lake City, a dairy products company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 2 Slain and Pregnant Woman Shot in a Bronx Drug Dispute
description: A woman who was eight months pregnant was critically wounded early yesterday in a South Bronx lobby strewn with crack vials as she walked into a drug shooting that left a second woman dead and a third fatally wounded, the police said.

title: Korean Bank Gets Loan
description: The Commercial Bank of Korea will sign a $30 million offshore syndicated loan in Hong Kong to expand foreign currency loans to domestic companies, bank officials said. The loan will carry an interest rate of 0.25 percentage point over the London interbank offered rate. Redemption is expected to be three years from the drawdown in early May 1991.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A former New York City official, JAMES A. KRAUSKOPF, will be dean of the Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy at the New School for Social Research. A former commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, Mr. Krauskopf, 49 years old, will take over July 1. He is the New School's senior vice president for administration and a professor in the business school.

title: Critic's Notebook; Drawbacks to a Boycott Of TV Network News
description: The Oakland, Calif., branch of PEN, the international writers' group, is boycotting prime-time network news for the month of April, in protest against the negative coverage of blacks and Hispanic Americans. Anybody who pays attention to television news can sympathize to some degree with the complaint by Ishmael Reed, chairman of the Oakland PEN media committee, that the networks tend to "associate black and Hispanic people exclusively with drugs, crime, unwed parenthood, welfare, homelessness, child abuse and rape." And although the notion of PEN, an organization devoted to freedom of speech, going in for a boycott may seem unseemly, yet,there are not many other ways that viewers can express dissatisfaction with what shows up on the tube. Still, I wonder whether the boycotters have considered some of the possible effects of their pressure on the networks, whose chronic fear of offending often translates into blandness and evasion of issues.

title: Court Limits Liability on International Flights
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the treaty covering airline liability on international flights does not permit passengers to recover damages for mental anguish or other purely psychic injuries.

title: Study Links a Kidney Hormone to Heart Attacks
description: High levels of a kidney hormone can predispose people to heart attacks even if they have no other risk factors, a new study has found.

title: Jackson Is Hopeful
description: BO JACKSON canceled an appointment at a Birmingham (Ala.) clinic yesterday and a spokesman said the two-sport star with the career-threatening hip injury believes his recovery is going so well he did not need to see the orthopedic specialist.

title: Jerry Davis; Writer and Producer, 73
description: Jerry Davis, a writer and producer of "The Odd Couple" and other television series, died last Thursday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 73 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: For a Dispossessed Tribe, a Time of Reckoning
description: Isaac Tembani stood on the main street of this Indian Ocean port city, handing out leaflets that begged passers-by to consider the calamity that shattered his community little more than 13 years ago.

title: Capitals Score Three Goals in 3d to Beat Penguins
description: Al Iafrate scored the first even-strength goal of the game at 15 minutes 31 seconds of the third period as the Washington Capitals beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 4-2, last night.

title: Arthur H. DesGrey; Athletic Director, 86
description: Arthur H. DesGrey, who served for 41 years as an administrator of athletics and a teacher at City College, died Sunday in Miami Shores, Fla. He was 86 years old.

title: Dinkins and Fiscal Pain; Distaste for Confrontation Has Cost Mayor Room to Maneuver in City's Budget Crisis
description: By adopting an approach to New York City's fiscal problems that strived to inflict the least pain possible, Mayor David N. Dinkins has lost room to maneuver, his own aides concede, and all but assured great pain in the face of the crisis he now confronts.

title: Weicker and Labor Unions Reach an Accord
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that he and state labor unions had agreed on $327.7 million in labor concessions to help ease Connecticut's budget crisis, averting 2,600 layoffs that began to take effect this week.

title: Hammond Gets First Victory As Reds Even Their Record
description: Rookie Chris Hammond gained his first major league victory, allowing five hits in six innings tonight as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the San Diego Padres, 5-1.

title: 65% Profit Rise for Microsoft
description: Despite a slump by many companies in the personal computer business, the Microsoft Corporation reported on Tuesday that it had a 65 percent increase in profit on a 57 percent increase in revenue.

title: Mexico Proclaims an End To Sanctuary for Polluters
description: Amid growing concern that a proposed North American free-trade agreement might undermine United States pollution controls, top environmental officials from Mexico assured California officials today that American companies would find no sanctuary south of the border.

title: Profits Rise At Ralston
description: The Ralston Purina Company said today that second-quarter profits rose by 7.4 percent, helped by higher sales of akaline batteries by its Eveready Battery subsidiary.

title: Head of Ex-Im Bank Denies White House Pushed on Iraq
description: John D. Macomber, the president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank, told skeptical members of Congress today that the Reagan and Bush Administrations had exerted "absolutely no pressure" on the agency's decision to guarantee $267 million in American exports to Iraq between 1987 and 1990.

title: Reporting of Spira Threats at Issue
description: George Steinbrenner's chief trouble-shooter testified yesterday that a letter from Howard Spira threatening Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield concerned him, even though he did not report it to any law-enforcement agency.

title: A Numbers Game at Georgetown Law
description: Georgetown University's law center in Washington is in turmoil over a student-journalist's charge that admissions officers give unwarranted favoritism to blacks. The student's source: "random" statistical samples, apparently his own, from records he saw as a temporary file clerk. His column in the school's Law Weekly will further fuel the debate over affirmative action -- and illustrate a common weakness among its critics.

title: Money Fund Yields Down For Second Straight Week
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the second consecutive week in period that ended yesterday.

title: Infiltrators From Jordan Kill an Israeli
description: Armed guerrillas from Jordan managed to sneak into a border kibbutz this morning, where they shot four farmers, killing one and wounding three.

title: Mental State of Red Square Pilot Questioned
description: Mathias Rust, the German aviator who became a folk hero in 1987 when he flew a small plane to Red Square in Moscow, is mentally disturbed and should not be held responsible for attacking a student nurse, a psychiatrist said today.

title: NASA Plans a Shuttle Liftoff 18 Days After the Last Flight
description: In one of the shortest intervals between liftoffs in the history of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the space agency has set next Tuesday for the launching of the space shuttle Discovery and a crew of seven to conduct "Star Wars" experiments.

title: The Unforgotten Vietnam Vet
description: As U.S. troops return from the Persian Gulf to jubilant, flag-waving crowds, one hears and reads again and again that such a homecoming was denied to Vietnam veterans. Indeed, the effusive displays planned for the gulf war veterans often seem calculated to avoid the neglect that supposedly caused Vietnam vets festering psychological problems and an inability to readjust.

title: Guggenheim Plans SoHo Branch For Offices and Art Exhibitions
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, which has an outpost in Venice and ambitious plans for a branch in Salzburg, Austria, is now zeroing in on SoHo.

title: James Garrett, 75, Executive of Fund For Rehabilitation
description: James F. Garrett, executive vice president of the World Rehabilitation Fund, which trains doctors and provides services in physical medicine and rehabilitation, died Tuesday at the Hospice of Northern Virginia in Arlington. He was 75 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: A Budget Worth Noticing, Barely
description: The House approved a budget resolution yesterday that sets better domestic spending priorities than those proposed in the President's budget. But both budgets barely nibble at the edges of the huge Federal spending programs.

title: Mandela Group Moving to Arm Black Townships
description: The African National Congress is pressing ahead with plans to help residents of South African black townships form paramilitary self-defense units, despite the misgivings of the police and rival black groups.

title: What of Gay Teen-Agers?
description: To The Home Section:

title: Pop in Review
description: Ray Anderson Village Vanguard 178 Seventh Avenue South (at Perry Street) Through Sunday

title: Slight Thaw Is Detected in U.S.-Romania Ties
description: Romania's relations with the United States, clouded by suspicions on the part of the Bush Administration, appear to have taken a turn for the better with a visit here by Prime Minister Petre Roman.

title: Accounts
description: * National Spa and Pool Institute, Alexandria, Va., a group that represents 4,500 manufacturers and suppliers, to Solin Associates Inc., New York. Billings are about $1 million.

title:
BASEBALL;
