Ted and Joe, 1941: April 18
Consolidation By Grand Met
description: Grand Metropolitan and its American units, including Pillsbury and Burger King, have consolidated their $200 million media buying account for all national television advertising with D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York.

title: George A. Diamond; Architect, 67
description: George A. Diamond, an architect who designed many religious and educational buildings, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bronx School District 9 Is Faulted In Inquiry for Inept Management
description: Community School District 9 in the Bronx, which for 20 years has been unable to shake off a reputation for corrupt and inept administration, is once again a subject of a disciplinary inquiry by the Board of Education.

title: Iraq, Assailing Bush's Plan, Says U.N. Will Open Camps
description: The Baghdad Government today denounced President Bush's decision to send troops to northern Iraq and said it had reached its own agreement with the United Nations to set up "humanitarian centers" in both north and south, run by the United Nations, to care for refugees.

title: Confusion Is Found to Delay Aid for Kurds Fleeing to Iran
description: Western officials in Iran said today that efforts to help Kurds fleeing here from Iraq have been seriously hurt by international confusion and by some Iranian delays, endangering the lives of scores of thousands of refugees now in Iran or awaiting entry to the country.

title: Pop in Review
description: Tanita Tikaram Symphony Space 2537 Broadway (at 95th Street)

title: Business and the Law; Bank Liability For Toxic Sites
description: THE Environmental Protection Agency is expected soon to expand protection for banks that lend money for property that turns out to contain hazardous wastes.

title: James R. Graham, 83; Dealt in American Art
description: James R. Graham, a Madison Avenue art dealer specializing in American art, died on Monday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Winnie Mandela Says Evidence Was Faked
description: Winnie Mandela suggested at her trial today that the police had fabricated evidence to implicate her in the accusations of kidnapping and assault of four youths.

title: Marinovich Interests Giants
description: George Young, the Giants' general manager, threw fuel into the fire today in the potentially explosive quarterback situation on the Super Bowl champions.

title: Parent Is Seen as Key to Happiness
description: If you want to help your children have a happy adult life, cuddle them while they are young.

title: Bally to Cut Debt With Asset Sales
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, the casino, health club and manufacturing giant, said it had agreed to sell some businesses to pay down some of its $1.8 billion in debt. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bally said the businesses to be sold included a scientific games unit in Atlanta, a business in Germany, a slot machine business in Nevada and an exercise equipment business.

title: Loam in the Gloaming: It's Flower-Bed Time
description: WHEN they run out of daylight, most outdoor gardeners are ready to throw in the trowel. Not Michael Ruggiero, who planted 50 day lilies the other night in his backyard in Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Sears Dissident Gets Backing
description: The California Public Employee Retirement System said it would vote its shares for the election of a dissident shareholder to the board of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: Copland Tribute
description: A concert in memory of the composer Aaron Copland, who died on Dec. 2, is to be held on Saturday at 11 A.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Lukas Foss will conduct the American Composers Orchestra in an all-Copland program that will include "A Lincoln Portrait," narrated by William Warfield, and the Variations and Finale from "Appalachian Spring." The violinist Isaac Stern, the soprano Roberta Alexander, the baritone Kurt Ollmann, the flutist Fenwick Smith and the pianists Gilbert Kalish, Leo Smit and David Del Tredici will take part in the concert, along with the Boston Symphony Chamber Players and the Harvard Glee Club.

title: U.S. KURDISH MOVE A RELIEF TO BRITON
description: Relief was written all over Prime Minister John Major's face this morning after President Bush finally agreed to send American troops into northern Iraq on a joint United States, British and French mission to set up safety zones for hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees.

title: Net Falls 48% At Polaroid
description: The Polaroid Corporation reported a 48 percent drop in first-quarter earnings today, saying the weak economy hurt consumer spending on the company's instant film.

title: At Last, the Kurds Find Friends
description: However tardily, President Bush has finally recognized the scope of the human tragedy unfolding on the freezing mountains of northern Iraq. Whatever the risks, there is no decent alternative to using U.S. forces to build and protect camps in Iraq's lowlands for Kurdish refugees. If this marks a new turn in the world's concern with Iraq's domestic convulsions, that's welcome as well as overdue. The fear that has sent nearly two million people surging toward Turkey and Iran is as much a threat to stability as Saddam Hussein's trampling of Kuwait.

title: Looking Again at Iraq Without War Hysteria
description: To the Editor:

title: Skullduggery
description: I am not a member of Skull and Bones.

title: Dibble Suspended For Dangerous Pitch
description: ROB DIBBLE, the Cincinnati Reds' hard-throwing relief pitcher, was suspended for three games yesterday for pitching a ball a foot behind the back of Houston's ERIC YELDING during a game last week. Yelding, a shortstop, was given a one-game suspension for charging the mound and hurling his batting helmet at Dibble's left shoulder. Both players appealed the suspensions and will be permited to continue playing until BILL WHITE, the National League president, schedules hearings.

title: American Air's Parent Posts $195.6 Million Loss
description: The AMR Corporation, parent company of American Airlines, said it lost $195.6 million in the first quarter, with the weak economy and war-related travel worries cutting passenger loads. Squabbles with its pilots' union, route changes and higher prices for aviation fuel also contributed to the deficit.

title: Kermit the Frog in New Role: Plaintiff
description: Perhaps it was just not meant to be, the union of a skinny green frog with a two-dimensional celluloid mouse, although it was hailed at one point as "a business association made in family-entertainment heaven."

title: Amid Debate, Two Hospitals Get New Chiefs
description: New executive directors have been chosen for two of New York's troubled municipal hospitals, Harlem Hospital Center and Kings County Hospital Center.

title: Yanks and Cary Make Sure White Sox Won't Go 162-0
description: There's a lot that could be said for the hustle, effort and occasional little rays of hope that the Yankees have shown so far this season. But after losing six of their first eight games they needed no more moral victories. They simply needed to win.

title: Ouster of an Accounting Official Is Sought
description: In an effort to exert more control over the nation's accounting policies, some leading business groups are seeking to replace one member of the Financial Accounting Standards Board with someone they believe would better represent their interests.

title: Electronic Ads Offered By USA Today, Prodigy
description: In the publishing industry's latest foray into electronic advertising, USA Today and the Prodigy Services Company have started a national computerized classified advertising service for the nearly one million Prodigy subscribers.

title:
HOCKEY;
Gretzky Is Stalking Mr. Hockey's Record
description: Wayne Gretzky, the most dominant team athlete of our time and perhaps anybody else's time, has collected every major National Hockey League career scoring record except one, and he's not sure he wants that one.

title: Price Fixing Always Victimizes the Consumer
description: To the Editor:

title: Native Alaskans Seek to Delay Exxon Pact
description: A group representing several native Alaskan coastal villages is asking a Federal judge to halt a $1 billion settlement between the Exxon Corporation and the Government for the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989.

title:
CURRENTS;
A Fleeting Bit of Modernism in Wales
description: BRITAIN is often criticized by its architects for being too infatuated with the past. These critics should be somewhat mollified by the temporary hall that was recently opened in Cardiff, Wales.

title: Schwarzkopf Plans Return To U.S. and Fall Retirement
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, plans to return to the United States on Saturday, the American military authorities said today.

title: Trustee Appointed In Keystone Case
description: A Bankruptcy Court judge has appointed a trustee to oversee the liquidation of the Keystone Camera Products Corporation, which called itself the last American manufacturer of small cameras. Judge William F. Tuohey granted a petition by creditors to allow the liquidation of the company so that they might have a chance to get some of their money back. The company's demise means an end to about 600 jobs at Keystone's plant in Clifton, N.J.

title: Fiscal Riddle Confronts Casino Panel
description: New Jersey's casino regulators are to answer on Thursday a question that amplifies the crash alert sounding throughout the once high-flying casino industry here. Can a casino -- in this case Donald Trump's billion-dollar Taj Mahal -- be "financially stable" despite being bankrupt?

title: A Meeting Place for Africans and U.S. Blacks
description: Many black Americans, says the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, have long been ashamed of Africa and their African heritage, an attitude he is determined to confront at a conference of black Americans and Africans he has invited here for four days this week.

title: Inconsistent: A Label Knicks Can't Shake
description: The Knicks are winding down their regular season still shaky about the post-season.

title: The Real Palm Beach Story
description: Earlier this week, NBC News jumped off the Empire State Building. So The New York Times, like any thoughtful toddler, decided it had to follow suit. The woman who filed a complaint of rape against William Kennedy Smith has been "outed" after a week in which repeated questions have been raised in print about her actions and character. The Times's explanation for its decision to publish her name was that NBC News had done it the night before. My 5-year-old nephew couldn't have put it better.

title: Law Student Apologizes for Essay on Blacks
description: A Georgetown University law student apologized today for the uproar caused by a commentary he wrote contending that black students at the law school are less qualified than whites.

title: BOXING: When Swift Hands Meet Brute Force in the Ring; Foreman Can Win If He Hurts the Champ Early in the Bout
description: It was May 1989, and George Foreman was considering the possibility of fighting someone like Evander Holyfield as a way to transform his image from flamboyant fat man to a worthy challenger of the reigning champion, Mike Tyson.

title: First Western
description: The First Western Financial Corporation said its board had retained the investment banking firm of Merrill Lynch & Company to advise it on ways to maximize shareholder value, including potential mergers and sales of assets. The company, which has assets of $1.2 billion, is the parent of a 21-branch savings and loan company, the First Western Savings Association.

title: 'Right Out of Left Field' Arises a New Leonardo
description: Five hundred years after Leonardo da Vinci sculptured a clay model that wound up being used for target practice, a 73-year-old retired airline pilot and a portrait painter fresh from art school are trying to complete the master's design: a 24-foot-tall bronze horse.

title: Bobby Dill; Hockey Player, 71
description: Robert E. (Bobby) Dill, a former New York Rangers defenseman and member of the United States Hockey Hall of Fame, died Tuesday in St. John's Hospice. He was 71 years old.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an obituary of Homer Bigart misstated the year the picture was taken. It was 1972.

title: Fools Born Every Day
description: To The Home Section:

title: Commands Unheeded
description: To The Home Section:

title: S.& L.'s Backed on Tax Issue
description: The Supreme Court rejected an Internal Revenue Service position today and ruled that savings and loan institutions can create paper losses for Federal income tax purposes by swapping portfolios of low-value mortgages with other institutions.

title: Benjamin F. Baer, 73, U. S. Parole Chairman
description: Benjamin Franklin Baer, chairman of the United States Parole Commission, died April 9 at Washington Hospital Center in Washington. He was 73 years old and lived in Rockville, Md.

title: Panel Says Dialysis Cutbacks May Be Increasing Death Toll
description: Spending cuts in the Federal Government's life-saving kidney dialysis program may be resulting in unnecessary sickness and death, a panel of experts said today.

title: Talks Are Suspended On Buyout of Harcourt
description: Talks on the General Cinema Corporation's proposed buyout of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. broke off yesterday after Harcourt's bondholders rejected an increased bid by General Cinema.

title: Bridge
description: A player who died a week ago at the age of 55 will be missed by many, particularly by members of Manhattan's Beverly Club, of which he was a part owner. Richard Rosen, a real-estate lawyer, served on the Board of Directors of the Greater New York Bridge Association and represented it on the National Board of Governors.

title: New Research Tool: The Video Conference
description: THE Focus Vision Network has developed a research technique using video conferencing technology, and some advertising executives predict it will change how agencies use focus groups.

title: Subway Peddler Ouster Cheered and Jeered
description: As an F train left the 53d Street subway station Monday evening, a man carrying a black duffle bag entered the sixth car, cleared his throat and announced with great enthusiasm that he was selling the latest copy of Street News, a newspaper that says its proceeds go to feed and house homeless people.

title: Probation Is Lightened
description: Four Arkansas basketball players, including TODD DAY, the top scorer last season, will be eligible for all but a few early games next season under a reduced discipline announced yesterday.

title: Madelle Hegeler Semerjian; Volunteer, 60
description: Madelle Hegeler Semerjian, who was active in charitable and cultural affairs in Southampton, L.I., died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and Southampton.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Calvin Klein Cosmetics Co., New York, a subsidiary of Unilever United States Inc., named Robert Green to the new post of vice president for advertising. * Clairol Inc., New York, a subsidiary of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., named George L. Fotiades senior vice president and general manager for consumer products business.

title: Donnelley Prices 8 7/8% Bond Issue
description: A $150 million, 30-year bond issue by R. R. Donnelley & Sons, the Chicago-based commercial printer and publisher, was priced yesterday through a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Bristol-Myers, Warner-Lambert Lift Profits
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and the Warner-Lambert Company each said yesterday that strong drug sales had led the way to record first-quarter growth, adding to a string of pharmaceutical company reports of double-digit earnings increases.

title: McDonnell Unit To Cut 350 Jobs
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said its McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Company would cut about 350 jobs at plants in California and Arizona. A team of McDonnell Douglas and Textron Inc.'s Bell Helicopter unit lost out earlier this month on a contract to develop the Army's next-generation of light attack helicopter, which is expected to be worth up to $33 billion over the next 20 years. McDonnell said the job cuts were related in part to the loss of the contract.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "These are stormy times, and it is not easy to hold the wheel of the ship steady." -- President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A1:3. ]

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League NL -- Suspended Rob Dibble, pitcher, for three games for throwing at Houston's Eric Yelding in a game on April 11. Suspended Yelding one game for charging the mound after the pitch.

title: Marshall S. Lachner, Executive, Dies at 76
description: Marshall Smith Lachner, an executive in the soap, beer and cosmetics industries, died on Sunday at the Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in Boca Raton and Lodi, Wis.

title: Nabisco Delays Debt Offering
description: Reflecting rising prices for corporate bonds, an anticipated offering of $750 million worth of new seven-year high- yield securities from the RJR Nabisco Capital Corporation was delayed yesterday.

title: India's Soon-to-Be-Ex-Premier Likes It That Way
description: It's his 65th birthday, and Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, now serving as caretaker, is in an expansive mood as he discusses his experiences as the shortest-tenured Prime Minister in India's history here at the country retreat south of New Delhi that he has turned into a green oasis merely by conserving rainwater.

title: RULING IS SOUGHT ON RAPE NAME LAW
description: Citing the conflict between individual privacy and press freedom arising from accusations of rape at the Kennedy estate, the Palm Beach County prosecutor today asked for a court review of a Florida law that prohibits the identification of rape victims by news organizations.

title: For Children
description: Recycling Plant Tour East Harlem Recycling Plant 225 East 127th Street Manhattan (212) 876-8469 Recommended ages: 5 and up Mondays through Saturdays

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air Canada, Montreal, said it would eliminate an additional 400 management positions by midyear, beyond those identified last year. * Alltel Corp., Hudson, Ohio, a telecommunications company, will sell its Ocean Technology subsidiary to Lagnaf Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Restaurants
description: Gascony, the pastoral French province of foie gras, confit, game and Armagnac, is renowned for robust good eating. It's no wonder that the ancient Romans dubbed it the "granary of the Gauls."

title: Carl H. T. Sloss, Ad Director, 87
description: Carl H. T. Sloss, a retired advertising director and former co-publisher and advertising director of Esquire Inc.'s Apparel Arts, died yesterday at his home in Strasburg, Pa. He was 87 years old.

title: Icons of 2 Kinds
description: When I first came to live in New York City four years ago, I was eager to commune with the icons of glass, steel and stone here. Even today the Empire State Building, the Chrysler Building and the two boxes they came in (known as the World Trade Center) still impress me and awe the frequent out-of-towners I take on tours.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "If they were losing in the old park, I'd stay, These rich people are just taking over. You see all these people in suits. You see these limousines. You see these suites. I'm just a regular steelworker. We're out of here." -- Ralph Edders, a disappointed White Sox fan. [ A1:4. ]

title: Inland Steel Posts Loss
description: Inland Steel Industries yesterday reported a net loss of $40 million for the first quarter, which it attributed to lower demand from makers of automobiles and appliances.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Le Bernardin , the Manhattan restaurant, is losing its executive chef, EBERHARD MULLER. "He's leaving to open his own restaurant," said MAGUY LE COZE, who owns Le Bernardin with her brother, GILBERT LE COZE. "We're in negotiation with a young chef."

title: Tuning Up Hershiser
description: OREL HERSHISER, the Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher who has been sidelined since undergoing surgery on his pitching shoulder last year, will throw a simulated game with his team today before batting practice at Jack Murphy Stadium in San Diego. Hershiser has not thrown since March 15, when he pitched five innings in a spring training camp game, and his shoulder came up sore. He went back into the hospital, and Dr. FRANK JOBE, Hershiser's surgeon, removed scar tissue from the surgery.

title: Beijing Is Said to Allow Prison-Made Exports
description: Chinese prison officials have encouraged a practice of forcing inmates to produce goods for export, according to issues of a restricted-circulation Chinese magazine obtained by Asia Watch, the human-rights organization.

title: Whitman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 17,200,000, or 16 cents a share, and $ 25,600,000, or 25 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: Woman Killed With 3 Children In Queens Fire
description: A woman and her three children were killed in a fire that tore through their two-story house in South Jamaica, Queens, early yesterday, firefighters said.

title: Knicks Near Playoffs in a Major Muddle
description: The Knicks, no strangers to distractions this season, flew to Indianapolis yesterday amid clouds that symbolized their situation. Not only were they still uncertain who their first-round opponent would be in the playoffs next week, but they were also unsure of the status of their head coach for next season.

title: Robert Sharp Stitt, 64; Issued Bank Warning
description: Robert Sharp Stitt, a retired New York lawyer who raised warnings five years ago about the instability of Rhode Island banks, died on Wednesday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. He was 64 years old and lived in East Greenwich, R.I., where he had moved from Manhattan in 1984.

title: Trak Auto Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Time Warner reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
On My Mind; Beijing Heart Attack
description: "Please," said a disciple of the great monk, "please give credit to President Bush."

title: Texas Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included pretax gain of $ 15 million from the sale of majority stake in the company's photomask operation.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions in The Home Section yesterday with an article about the International Italian Furniture Fair were reversed. The Day and Night sofa, embroidered with a sun and moon, is by Elizabeth Garouste and Mattia Bonetti. A Thousand and One Nights, a sofa with tufted mattresses on a striped base, is by Charlotte Maugirard.

title: My Two Countries, My Flesh and Blood
description: We have been told repeatedly in recent weeks that the ghosts of Vietnam have been laid to rest in the Persian Gulf. But I still hear them in the night, and I bet I'm not alone.

title: Ron Bottcher, Baritone, 50
description: Ron Bottcher, a baritone who sang with the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation has changed its name to the New Valley Corporation. Directors of the debt-ridden telecommunications company sought the change to protect the Western Union name in a possible bankruptcy filing in June. The company has a $42.2 million cash payment due on June 15, annual payments of $25 million in pension benefits and $170 million principal payment in 1992.

title: Sutcliffe Completes Comeback With First Victory in Over a Year
description: Rick Sutcliffe pitched six innings for his first victory since Oct. 1, 1989, in a matchup of former Cy Young Award winners and Doug Drabek lost his third decision in a row as Chicago defeated Pittsburgh, 3-2, tonight.

title: U.S. Relief Commander Will Meet Iraqi Military
description: The commander of the United States military operation to aid Kurdish refugees in the rugged mountains along the Turkish-Iraqi border is scheduled to meet with senior Iraqi military leaders on Friday in the Iraqi border town of Zakho, an American military spokesman said here tonight.

title: Cuomo Vows All-Out Bid to Avoid Fiscal Takeover of New York City
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, with Mayor David N. Dinkins at his side, vowed yesterday that he would do whatever was needed to keep the Dinkins administration from losing control of New York City's budget and finances to the state.

title: President of Egghead Takes On Chief's Job
description: Egghead Discount Software, the nation's largest software-only retailer, yesterday named Matthew J. Griffin, its president, to the additional post of chief executive. Mr. Griffin, who was part of a triumvirate brought in to turn Egghead around in February 1989, has been president and chief operating officer since August 1990.

title: Notes Are Offered By Bear Stearns
description: The Bear Stearns Companies, the holding company for Bear, Stearns & Company, yesterday priced $150 million in senior notes due 1998.

title: Cuomo Tax Returns: $6,000 for Charity
description: This New York City resident is more charitable than his Mayor, but less than the City Council President.

title: Brawl at California School
description: About 200 black and Hispanic students at Leuzinger High School in this Los Angeles suburb engaged in a racially motivated melee this afternoon. One student said he received cuts and bruises on his face and head.

title: 'Salute to Magic'
description: If the hand is quicker than the eye, it will reach into the pocket to buy tickets for the annual "Salute to Magic" show, tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Hunter College Auditorium, East 69th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, in Manhattan. A half-dozen acts will participate. Admission: $22 and $25. Information: (212) 535-4045.

title: American Express to Try A Pan-European Campaign
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS will begin a series of innovative commercials in Europe this month that essentially use the same message to sell its credit cards in five countries.

title: Vertex Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Dick Lewis Goes to Ayer
description: Newmark & Lewis, the consumer-electronics retail chain based in Hicksville, L.I., has awarded its $18 million advertising account to Ayer Inc., New York.

title: New Dean at Divided Medical Center
description: New York Hospital's chief of psychiatry has been named dean of Cornell Medical College, an appointment that officials of the twinned institutions hope will begin a new era of reconciliation between them.

title: Acting Is a Great Deal More Than Skin-Deep; Together, Not Divided
description: To the Editor:

title: Offbeat Ideas For Jaded Hosts
description: VISITORS DREAD, a malady that commonly afflicts New Yorkers, is brought on by out-of-town friends who trill the following: "We are coming to New York City, and we want you to show us the town." Speaking over a long-distance telephone line, these friends have no way of knowing that their innocent words have caused normally self-possessed adults to clutch their throats and fall writhing to the floor as an inner voice keens, "Oh, no, no, no, no, no ."

title: Bush, Pushing Crime Bill, Bends Again on Gun Control
description: The Bush Administration made a second major concession on gun control today in an effort to win Congressional approval of the President's anticrime bill.

title: Legal Scholars Debate Refugee Plan, Generally Backing U.S. Stand
description: The Bush Administration's legal justification for using armed forces to establish sanctuary sites for Kurdish refugees on Iraqi soil has generally won support from international legal scholars, although some questions have been raised about the United States' acting on its own.

title: Poles Get $2.48 Billion More In Loans From the I.M.F.
description: The International Monetary Fund today approved an additional $2.48 billion in loans for Poland over the next three years. The decision coincided with concern at the agency that Eastern Europe's economic problems are more severe and less tractable than initially thought.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Tommy Flanagan

title: New Jobless-Benefit Claims Drop for 2d Straight Week
description: New claims for unemployment benefits fell for the second consecutive week, the Labor Department said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: In New York City, Altering School Aid Insures a Fight
description: Any effort by President Bush to change the formula for allocating Federal aid to poor students -- known as Chapter 1 funds -- is sure to inflame passions in New York City.

title: Many Professors at UMass Call Off Classes in Protest
description: About a third of the 1,200 professors at the University of Massachusetts canceled their classes Wednesday and today to protest Gov. William F. Weld's proposals to cut spending on public higher education as a way of bridging the state's budget deficit.

title: Meadow Star Facing Her Toughest Test
description: Angel Cordero Jr., who has often had the best seat in the house when racing history was being made, wants to remind everybody that even the great Secretariat didn't win the Wood Memorial.

title: A 16-0 Day to Forget at New Comiskey Park
description: As White Sox fans filed past the wrecking ball still swinging at their beloved old Comiskey Park today, they made their way into the $135 million, spit-shiny successor with a mixture of mourning for what was gone and euphoria over what was new.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Now 30 years old and ranked 152d by the Association of Tennis Professionals, YANNICK NOAH, the 1983 French Open champion, has found an alternative career. His first record album, "Black and What!" was released earlierthis week in France, with 11 songs, most of them written by Mr. Noah and most of them in English.

title: Loss of Millions Seen in U.S. Phone Contract
description: Members of Congress asserted today that Federal administrators had mismanaged a $25 billion contract for long-distance telephone service to the Government and cost taxpayers millions of dollars by steering a disproportionate share of the business to U S Sprint, the more expensive of two designated carriers.

title: Trump's Taj Mahal Relicensed With Provisos
description: New Jersey's Casino Control Commission renewed the gaming license of Donald J. Trump's financially ailing Taj Mahal Casino Resort today but laid down a number of conditions.

title: Transit Museum
description: It's hard to believe, I know, but there are out-of-towners out there who don't sit around singing "I Love New York" day in and day out. They have this idea that if they visit New York City, all they will see is vandalized subway cars. I say, take them to the Transit Museum. This tribute to the city's 714-mile-long underworld is in Brooklyn Heights in what must be the safest subway station in the city (perhaps because it no longer is a working station). The tracks on both sides of the long platform are filled with immaculately kept old subway cars that have wicker-covered seats and frosted-glass windows.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Saturday with a review of the American Music Theater Festival production of "Frida" bore an incorrect credit. The photographer was Mark Garvin.

title: Agamemnon Koutsogeorgas, 69, Greek Aide
description: Agamemnon Koutsogeorgas, a close aide to former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and his main co-defendant in a corruption and embezzlement trial, died today at a hospital after having a stroke nine days ago. He was 69 years old.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BOSTON RED SOX -- Signed Steve Lyons, infielder, to a one-year contract. Placed Randy Kutcher, outfielder, on waivers. National League CHICAGO CUBS -- Activated Rick Sutcliffe, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Sent Erik Pappas, infielder-catcher, to Iowa of the American Association. PITTSBURGH PIRATES -- Recalled Mark Huismann, pitcher, from Buffalo of the American Association. Sent Tom Prince, catcher, to Buffalo. Basketball National Basketball Association WASHINGTON BULLETS -- Placed Charles Jones, center, on the injured list. Signed Larry Robinson, guard. World Basketball League NASHVILLE STARS -- Signed Jamie Waller, forward. Named Kevin Legate assistant coach.

title: Texas Instruments Has $54 Million Loss
description: Texas Instruments Inc. today reported a loss of $54 million in the first quarter, compared with a profit of $13 million in the corresponding period last year. Several rival chip makers have reported healthy profits.

title: The Dow: Less Than Meets the Eye
description: Wednesday's record close for the Dow Jones industrial stock average doesn't mean that the recession is coming to an end or that the banking crisis is solved. Indeed, the Dow average finished below 3,000 yesterday. The ups and downs on Wall Street matter to the 50 million Americans who own stock, but don't mean much of anything to the national economy.

title: Caught in Crossfire: Rising Toll in Streets
description: For a teen-ager in the Bronx Wednesday night, death came as he helped his mother move out of a neighborhood she feared. For a 34-year-old woman in Brooklyn a night earlier, it came during a trip to the neighborhood bodega.

title: 'St. Matthew Passion'
description: Johannes Somary is to conduct the Amor Artis Choir, the Hampshire College Chorus and a period-instrument orchestra in Bach's "St. Matthew Passion" at St. Jean-Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue and 76th Street, Manhattan, tonight at 8 o'clock. The soloists include Patrick Romano, as the Evangelist; Brian Raynor Cook, as Christ; Suzanne Peck, soprano; Alexandra Montano, alto; John MacMaster, tenor, and Paul Rowe, bass. Tickets are $12. Information: (212) 874-4513.

title: TV Weekend; The Evil That Can't Be Buried, in 'Paris Trout'
description: A character in "Paris Trout" recalls what is supposed to be the oldest lesson of the South: "It is easier to bury than to forget." Adapted by Pete Dexter from his novel of the same name, the winner of the 1988 National Book Award, "Paris Trout" brings together several very different people tied into one another's secrets. Some will indeed be buried, but anyone who sees this unsettling cable-television movie, which is to be shown at 9 P.M. tomorrow on Showtime, is not likely to forget them.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Reuters on the Company News page of Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to the likelihood that Petrolane Gas Service L.P. would meet the terms of its bank credit agreement in 1991. Petrolane said it did not believe it would generate enough cash in the rest of the year to comply.

title: Moscow's New Power Center
description: The collapse of the Soviet economy is well under way. This year has started with drastic declines of virtually all production. Even the Government expects a slump in national income of 15 to 20 percent, and it could get worse.

title: More Needs to Be Done to Protect Blood Supplies, Officials Testify
description: The American Red Cross has made progress in insuring the safety of blood supplies, but more needs to be done to prevent errors, Red Cross officials said at a Congressional hearing today.

title: Robert H. Baraz, 61, A State Dept. Adviser
description: Robert H. Baraz, a senior State Department adviser and a high-ranking intelligence expert, died Tuesday at a Hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 61 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: Results Plus; N.B.A.
description: A Rare One for Nets The Nets snapped a road losing streak at 20 games last night, beating the Washington Bullets by 108-103 in Landover, Md., behind a 29-point, 11-rebound effort by Derrick Coleman. It was New Jersey's first victory away from the Meadowlands since Jan. 26 in Miami, and its first victory at the Capital Centre since March 17, 1986. Earlier this season, the Nets snapped a road losing streak at 34 games -- a league record since broken by Sacramento -- by winning at Phoenix on Nov. 23. (AP) Spurs 102, Rockets 95: Terry Cummings had 21 points and San Antonio survived Sleepy Floyd's fourth-quarter scoring barrage for a victory in Houston, eliminating the Rockets from the Midwest Division title race. (AP) Jazz 130, SuperSonics 103: John Stockton broke his own N.B.A. single-season assist record with his 1,135th of the season and triggered a game-breaking 25-4 run at the start of the third quarter as the Utah routed Seattle. The victory kept Utah one game behind San Antonio, which won at Houston, in the race for first place in the Midwest Division. Both teams have two games left. (AP) 76ers 122, Celtics 97: Charles Barkley scored 21 points in 24 minutes in his first game back after knee injury as Philadelphia, playing at home, routed Boston and snapped a losing streak at three games. Barkley sprained his left knee on March 31 and missed seven games. The Celtics played without Larry Bird, who missed his sixth game in a row because of back problems. (AP) GOLF Coming Back to Earth Ian Woosnam of Wales shot a 10-over-par 82 yesterday in his first round since winning the Masters. Woosnam's debacle at the Benson and Hedges International Open, a European PGA event in St. Mellion, England, included a 7 and an 8 on successive holes, and left him 12 shots behind Nick Faldo, who was dethroned by Woosnam as Masters champion after two successive championships. "I really ought not to have played in the tournament," Woosnam said. "I woke up this morning and my eyes would hardly open." (AP)

title: Premature Patriot-ism
description: When the television cameras spotted a Patriot missile shooting down an Iraqi Scud over the Dhahran air base in Saudi Arabia during the first week of the Persian Gulf war, technophoria erupted across America. Soon, Patriot intercepts became standard TV fare, and the message of success was amplified by the hype from the manufacturers and the military.

title: Critic's Notebook; Film as a Shaper of American Culture
description: The film and video works at the current Whitney Biennial come at viewers like a fist in a velvet glove. Make that a fist in Michael Jackson's sequined glove. The works include a swirl of pop-cultural images and references: Michael Jackson as child and man-child, Spencer Tracy in "Bad Day at Black Rock," Hugh Downs quoting numbers about AIDS, the rap group Public Enemy. Most of them race along at an MTV-pace, blending voice-overs, printed texts, dramatic scenes and movie clips in a style that stops just short of sensory overload. But beneath their slick surfaces is much intelligent, controlled anger at how movies and television have shaped American culture and history.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ARTHUR MITCHELL, the artistic director of the Dance Theater of Harlem, and ANTHONY DOWELL, the director of the Royal Ballet, have signed a two-year agreement to help the London troupe integrate. Mr. Mitchell's company will send two or three dancers to London, where they will join with Royal Ballet dancers for lecture-demonstrations and auditions in minority neighborhoods, beginning in October.

title: F.T.C. Votes Not to Block FNN Sale
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it would not block a sale of the Financial News Network to a rival cable news service, CNBC, on antitrust grounds. The vote was 3 to 1, with one abstention.

title: Magazine and N.E.A. Team Up for Education
description: Family Circle magazine has 26 million readers, many of them parents. The National Education Association has two million members, elementary and secondary school teachers as well as faculty members in higher education. Yesterday the two organizations announced that they were forming a partnership to hold educational seminars, develop special reports and provide expertise for articles on education.

title: Only Vincent Can Stop Clemens
description: It may be that the only thing that can stop Roger Clemens's relentless roll over American League batters is the five-day suspension that has been hanging over the pitcher's head since the fall.

title: Site Chosen for Davis Cup
description: The United States Davis Cup team has an opponent (Spain) and a site (Newport, R.I.) for the second-round matches scheduled for June 14-16.

title: Key Rates
An Education President for All?
description: George Bush has finally made a down payment on his pledge to be the education President. His America 2000 Education Strategy, announced yesterday, aims to energize states, local communities and private businesses to reshape America's schools and attitudes toward learning.

title: The Grand Entrance
description: More than a decade ago, when I had almost decided to move to New York from Chicago, my friend Eileen took it upon herself to display the place in its best light. In a whirlwind Saturday, she showed me history at Ellis Island, pure whimsy in the Alice in Wonderland characters in Central Park, the exotic at an African restaurant.

title: JAPAN-SOVIET PACT ON ISLANDS ELUSIVE
description: In marathon negotiations that churned until nearly midnight, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan failed on Thursday to resolve a territorial dispute dividing their countries since World War II.

title: Southern New England Telecommunications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $ 600,000 tax effect of dividends declared to the ESOP for the first quarter of 1991.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about the New York City Board of Education's plan to encourage early retirement of teachers misstated the eligibility requirements. Teachers may retire early if they are 55 or older, or if they have at least 30 years' service; they need not meet both conditions.

title: North Stars Hold Down Blues, 2-1
description: Jon Casey stopped 31 shots as the Minnesota North Stars continued their upset run in the National Hockey League playoffs with a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight in the opener of the Norris Division finals.

title:
A Project in Pennsylvania;
With New Housing, Much Open Space
description: Although the sluggish housing market has stalled new construction in much of the Northeast, at nearly every turn of this Bucks County suburb houses are springing up in clusters.

title: 3 of 4 Bell Companies Post Drop in Earnings
description: Four more regional telephone companies of the eight created by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984 reported first-quarter earnings yesterday suggesting that the recession had stunted their growth. The reports were in line with the trend established earlier in the week.

title: CUNY Officials Threaten to Call End to Semester
description: Stepping up their efforts to end student protests that have closed much of the City University of New York, top officials warned yesterday that they might have to cancel the rest of the semester at several campuses if students did not surrender the buildings they have seized.

title: Review/Film; Teaching In a Sicilian Reformatory
description: It stands to reason that the delinquents of Palermo, Sicily, would be unusually tough, and Marco Risi's "Forever Mary" shows them to be exactly that. Mr. Risi's film (whose sweet-sounding title character is a teen-age transvestite prostitute, formerly named Mario) takes place inside a Palermo reformatory, using a mostly nonprofessional cast of Palermo street kids to convey the bitterness and hardship of the inmates' experience.

title: Talks on New Rights Bill Divide Large and Small Companies
description: A sharp split has developed among businesses over an effort by large corporations and civil rights groups to reach an agreement on a jobs discrimination bill pending in Congress.

title: U S West Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue includes sales and other revenue.

title: Barcelona Journal; Catalan Spoken Proudly Here (Listening, Madrid?)
description: It was an exuberant morning, the sun splashing between rushing clouds, and the cathedral square was coming alive.

title: Dallas Passes on Pick
description: Just when it seemed competition for RAGHIB (ROCKET) ISMAIL was heating up, the Dallas Cowboys dropped out of the running for New England's top pick in the National Football League draft on Sunday.

title: Market Place; Global Oil Giants Expected to Surge
description: BIG international oil companies, including Exxon, Mobil and Royal Dutch/Shell, are expected to report a surge in first-quarter profits next week, but analysts say others that operate mainly in North America are likely to be less fortunate. ARCO and Unocal, among others, will probably post modest declines, they said.

title: Musical Bazaar
description: The sign at 169 West Fourth Street in Manhattan says Music Inn -- Records, and a search will turn up some aging LP's of international music. But with a remarkable collection of instruments in its minuscule space,Music Inn reminds visitors that New York City is the world's bazaar and treasure house. Its floor, walls and ceiling are crammed with instruments from just about every country and culture, celebrating the world's ingenuity in exploiting the basic physics of strings, horns, reeds, flutes and percussion. Panpipes from the Andes, a kora (harp-guitar) from West Africa, a sarod from India, accordions from Germany and bells and whistles and saxophones and lutes -- they're all at hand, defying mathematical laws under the pressure of New York real estate. (Instruments that plug in are scarce, however; try the stores on 48th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, good places to appreciate wild hairdos and technical jargon.) Music Inn also carries spare parts and has a repair department to fix just about any instrument. For a music critic, the store is a vision of sounds waiting to be heard. Information: (212) 243-5715.

title: From Rhine-Main, First Arms And Now Aid for the Kurds
description: The mottled C-5 Galaxy aircraft hunkered like some huge bird with sad sloping wings while it waited to swallow the cargo, pallet by pallet, that it would soon disgorge over a distant field in eastern Turkey or perhaps western Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: The Where to Find It column in The Home Section yesterday misstated the address of Knit Atelier, a shop for knitting supplies. It is at 80 East 11th Street in Manhattan.

title: Food and Thought
description: In the heart of what was known around the turn of the century as the Ladies' Mile shopping district around lower Fifth Avenue is a snug throwback to that mannered era. Book-Friends Cafe is both a bookstore specializing in the period 1890 to 1940 and a casual restaurant. Being both a vintage-book lover by nature and passionate eater by profession, I count this as one of my favorite nooks in the city. It is also one where an out-of-town visitor can browse through the wonderful book collection and get a taste of New York City in a more genteel era.

title: Hudson, N.Y., Police Chief Gets Probation and Fine
description: James J. Dolan, Jr., the suspended police chief of Hudson, was sentenced today to five years' probation and fined $8,000 for obstructing justice by interfering with drug investigations by other law-enforcement agencies.

title: Unifi Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Jersey Indicts 53, and Prosecutor Says 2 Crime Families Will Be Hurt
description: The New Jersey Attorney General today announced the indictments of 53 members and associates of the Lucchese and Scarfo-Bruno organized-crime families on racketeering, murder and extortion charges.

title: Tandon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Offer by Litton To Buy Intermec
description: Litton Industries said it had agreed to acquire the Intermec Corporation for about $200 million in a $24-a-share tender offer for all of Intermec's stock. Intermec, based in Lynnwood, Wash., makes automatic identification systems like the bar-code scanners used in supermarkets. Beverly Hills-based Litton produces a range of technology-based products and services.

title: Yanks Feeling Heat About Who Will Cover Hot Corner
description: For nearly two months, a host of Yankee infielders have ridden the third-base merry-go-round. No one has managed to grab the brass ring, however, making it a maddening situation for all involved.

title: Musica Sacra Concert
description: Richard Westenburg is to conduct the Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra in two rarely heard early Mozart works tonight at 8 o'clock at Avery Fisher Hall. The works are the "Grabmusik" (K. 42), which Mozart composed when he was 11 years old, and the "Litaniae de Beata Virgine" (K. 109), written four years later. The program also includes the "Vesperae Solennes de Confessore" (K. 339). The soloists are Judith Pannill, soprano; Nancy Wertsch, mezzo-soprano; Michael Lockley, tenor, and David Evitts, baritone. Tickets are $12 to $30. Information: (212) 874-3104. Center Charge: (212) 874-6770.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HENRY A. KISSINGER is to receive the annual Nelson A. Rockefeller Public Service Award at a dinner on May 22 at the New York Hilton.

title: Israel Warns U.S. Not to Press It Over Talks
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir cautioned the United States today not to try to press Israel into taking part in a peace conference not to its liking, as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived in Jerusalem in a renewed effort to put together some kind of Arab-Israeli encounter.

title: Edward Pulling, 92, Teacher and Founder Of Millbrook School
description: Edward Pulling, the founder of the Millbrook School in Millbrook, N.Y., and its headmaster for 34 years, died on Wednesday at his home in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was 92 years old.

title: Despite Recession, New York Remains World's Best Dining City
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I.R.R. Will Broaden $2 Penalties on Tickets
description: The Long Island Rail Road will soon begin charging $2 penalties for tickets purchased on board trains leaving from nine stations where ticket-vending machines are now in operation, railroad officials announced yesterday.

title: Weitek Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Acting Is a Great Deal More Than Skin-Deep; Abilities Count
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Clears Bill on Dispute in the Markets
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today for a law intended to end the years of fighting between the Chicago futures and New York securities markets and their regulators.

title: Review/Art; At the Whitney, A Biennial That's Eager to Please
description: NO event on New York City's contemporary art calendar is more of a scapegoat for the ills of the art world than the Biennial exhibition of the Whitney Museum of American Art, the latest version of which has taken over virtually every nook and cranny of the building.

title: Tonka Board Backs Deal With Hasbro
description: With Tonka bondholders apparently ending their resistance to the sale of the toy maker to Hasbro Inc., Tonka's board agreed yesterday to a sweetened $489.7 million deal that pays less for stock and more for bonds. Common shareholders must still approve the deal, but analysts say they have little choice but to go along.

title: Shearson Lehman Brothers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 9.7 million from the company's portion of an adjustment of First Capital Holdings Corp.'s net income for 1990. Shearson Lehman holds a 28-percent ownership interest in First Capital Holdings.c-Net loss and included a restructuring charge of about $ 630 million and a charge of $ 157 million for an accounting change.Shearson Lehman is a division of American Express Co.

title: Prokofiev Centenary
description: Mstislav Rostropovich and Randall Craig Fleischer are to conduct the National Symphony Orchestra and the Choral Arts Society of Washington in an all-Prokofiev program, in observance of the centenary of the composer's birth, at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. The program includes the Sinfonia Concertante for Cello and Orchestra (Op. 125) and the cantata "Alexander Nevsky" (Op. 78). Mr. Rostropovich is the soloist in the Sinfonia Concertante, with Mr. Fleischer conducting; the mezzo-soprano Tamara Sinyavskaya is the soloist in the cantata. Tickets are $17 to $35. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Barr Seeks Generic AZT Approval
description: Barr Laboratories Inc., a maker of generic drugs based in Pomona, N.Y., said yesterday that it had filed for Government approval to market a lower-priced version of AZT, the only drug approved for general use against the AIDS virus in the United States.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co. reports earnings for 13wks to March 31
description: Earnings per share in the 1990 quarter are after preferred dividends of $ 5,274,000; the latest first quarter had no preferred dividends.

title: American Express Reports $264 Million Quarterly Profit
description: Hurt by a deteriorating economy and a falloff in travel, the American Express Company yesterday reported earnings of $264 million, or 55 cents a share, for the quarter just ended. The company lost $620 million in the first quarter of 1990, reflecting record losses at Shearson Lehman Hutton, its brokerage unit that is now called Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Cray and Beta Pact
description: Cray Research Inc. has signed a licensing agreement with Beta Phase Inc., a maker of high-performance electronic connectors based in Menlo Park, Calif. The pact, which includes license fees of $750,000 payable over the next year, gives Cray the right to develop and manufacture connectors for its supercomputers based on Beta's patented technology. As part of the agreement, Cray purchased 833,334 shares of common stock in Beta for $250,000, or 30 cents a share.

title: Senate Urges War-Crimes Trials
description: The Senate approved a bill today that urges the Bush Administration to propose an international tribunal that would prosecute Iraqi war criminals.

title: TJ International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Interest on Deposits Falls, But Loan Rates Stay High
description: The nation's banks, quick to lower the rates they pay depositors as interest rates have fallen, have been much slower to reduce the rates they charge for loans. As a result, the difference between what the banks charge borrowers and what they pay to savers is the highest it has been in years.

title: Spira Defense Says Steinbrenner Aide Engineered Case
description: Trying to bolster its contention that George Steinbrenner was behind the indictment of Howard Spira on extortion charges, Spira's defense attempted to show yesterday that Philip McNiff, Steinbrenner's chief trouble-shooter, had engineered much of the Government's case against Spira.

title: Private Rocket With Satellite Is Destroyed After Misfiring
description: A commercial rocket carrying a Japanese broadcasting satellite tumbled out of control shortly after liftoff today, and both were destroyed, launching officials said.

title: Buyers Snap Up RJR 'Junk Bonds'
description: With investors clamoring for its "junk bonds," RJR Nabisco Inc. doubled its sale of the high-yield securities yesterday to $1.5 billion, or more than the value of all junk bonds offered last year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Coastal Corp., Houston, and its ANR Pipeline Company subsidiary, in Detroit, have each filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $300 million in debt securities. * Colorado River Municipal Water District is offering $55.3 million in tax-exempt water-system revenue refunding bonds through Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. at prices to yield from 4.75 percent for bonds due 1992 to 6.80 percent in 2006. Longer-term maturitries offer a yield of 6.949 percent in 2011 and 6.891 percent in 2016. All the bonds are insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corp. and rated triple-A by both Moody's and S.& P. * Maine State Turnpike Authority is offering $15.2 million in tax-exempt turnpike revenue bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Co. Yields range from 5 percent in 1992 to 6.45 percent in 2001. The issue is rated single-A by both Moody's and S.& P. * Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, is offering $300 million in noncallable 7.35 percent notes due 1994 at a price of 100 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. * Whirlpool Corp., Benton, Harbor, Mich., has filed for $500 million face amount of liquid-yield option notes due 2011. The notes are zero-coupon subordinated notes and are convertible into common stock. COMMON STOCK * American Adjustable Rate Term Trust Inc., Minneapolis, has filed for a public offering of two million common shares through Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. * Continental Medical Systems Inc., Mechanicsburg, Pa., has filed for a public offering of three million common shares through Robertson, Stephens & Co. * Enzon Inc., South Plainfield, N.J., is offering three million common shares at $11.125 a share through Morgan Stanley & Co. * Icos Corp., Seattle, has filed for an initial public offering of 4.5 million common shares through Paine Webber Inc. * Integrated Waste Services Inc., Buffalo, is offering 1.8 million common shares at $8 a share through Whale Securities. * John Nuveen & Co., Chicago, has filed for the initial public offering of common stock for two new funds, through Alex. Brown & Sons Inc., which will be tax-exempt, exchange-traded investment companies. The offerings include five million common shares for the Nuveen California Select Quality Municipal Fund Inc. and five million common shares for the Nuveen New York Select Quality Municipal Fund Inc. * Storage Technology Corp., Louisville, Colo., has filed for an offering of 2.75 million common shares through Salomon Brothers Inc. * Westinghouse Electric Corp., Pittsburgh, has filed for a public offering of 19 million common shares through Lehman Brothers. About 15 million of the shares will be offered in the domestic market and the remainder internationally. RATINGS * Laclede Gas Co.'s senior-debt rating has been increased to AA-, from AA, by S.& P.

title: Russians Weigh Taking Coal Mines From Soviets
description: The Kremlin's struggle to keep its authority intensified significantly today as the Russian federated republic, the nation's largest, announced that it was considering invoking jurisdiction over all the coal mines in its territory.

title: Music Without One Eye on the Charts
description: As pop singers go, Peter Holsapple and Chris Stamey are pretty regular guys. They don't have tall, teased coiffures and they don't carry double-necked guitars that emit flashy, screaming leads. They don't wear Spandex, satin, leopard skin or even lame suits. Mr. Stamey and Mr. Holsapple's music is as plain-spoken and direct as most pop music today is high-tech Las Vegas glitzy, and they will perform it at three shows in the New York area over the next week, including tomorrow night at Maxwell's in Hoboken, N.J.

title: Redskin Acquitted
description: RICKY SANDERS, wide receiver for the Washington Redskins, was acquitted yesterday of a charge that he failed to stop to aid a parking lot valet he had hit with his car outside a nightclub in Houston on May 1, 1990. The valet, Azzam Jamus, was hospitalized for five days with head injuries and has sued Sanders in a civil action. Sanders said he was unaware he had struck the valet.(AP)

title: BUSH SCHOOL PLAN WOULD ENCOURAGE CHOICE BY PARENTS
description: President Bush today began his campaign for improving American education, calling not only for national tests and a new kind of school, but also for a redirection of Federal money to help disadvantaged students who choose to go to private and parochial schools.

title: Wyman-Gordon Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: The company said the $ 8 million increase in revenues was due primarily to added revenues from the operations of the former Arwood Corp., which Wyman-Gordon acquired last May.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Q. Pay Cut for Topol? A. Maybe

title: Despite Recession, New York Remains World's Best Dining City
description: To the Editor:

title: Hyundai Delays Ad With Police-Chase Scene
description: The Hyundai Motor America Corporation said yesterday that it had delayed the introduction of a new commercial for its Sonata car because of complaints that its chase scene resembled the actual pursuit of a motorist who was later beaten by Los Angeles police officers.

title: Trade Gap Narrows to 7-Year Low
description: Paced by a big drop in the bill for imported oil, the nation's trade deficit shriveled to $5.3 billion in February, the smallest in more than seven years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Norman Takes a Leave
description: Denying reports that he had withdrawn from the Heritage Open tournament and had flown to Australia because his sister was facing emergency surgery, GREG NORMAN called a news conference in Brisbane yesterday and admitted that his withdrawal was to take a vacation from the golf tour and the requests for appearances. Calling himself his own worst enemy, Norman acknowledged that he never says no to anybody and that he just needed time off with his family.(AP)

title: INSIDE
description: Threat of Cholera Spreads to Brazil A cholera epidemic that has killed 1,100 Peruvians may now pose a threat to Brazil, where one confirmed and three possible cases were just reported in Amazon border towns. The epidemic has already hit Ecuador and Colombia, and doctors say its future path is guesswork. Page A3.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Smith Has No Regrets and No Apologies
description: It has been almost a week since his New York Rangers were eliminated from the Stanley Cup playoffs by the Washington Capitals. In reviewing the team and his harsh criticism of the veteran players after the final game, General Manager Neil Smith said yesterday he did not regret what he said because it was true.

title: Sematech Starts to Make Progress
description: Two years ago, Genus Inc. was selling an advanced piece of equipment used to make computer chips, but few companies were buying. Little wonder, since the machine broke down every 75 hours on average.

title: Despite Recession, New York Remains World's Best Dining City
description: To the Editor:

title: Carreon Batters Ball But Still Seeks a Spot
description: The pinch-hitter's mind, busy throughout the night studying pitchers and developing strategy, begins racing in earnest the instant he is told to pick up a bat.

title: Big Fight or Big Joke, It's Big George's Night
description: Four years ago, when he made his comeback debut against Steve Zouski in Sacramento, Calif., George Foreman was a blubbery 267 pounds and was so wooden in his movements that some people compared him to Dr. Frankenstein's monster.

title: SPX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Jury Awards $2 Million To Man Beaten by Police
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday awarded $2 million to a truck driver whom it found had been beaten by Port Authority officers in 1984. Jurors said afterward that they hoped the award would send a message that police brutality would not be tolerated.

title: Triton Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 2,311,000, or 11 cents a share.c-Net loss and included an extraordinary loss of $ 44,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $ 154,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months.

title: Thomas & Betts Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Economic Scene; Why the Markets Are So Optimistic
description: WHAT'S going on? It's hard to remember a time of so much confusion on the state of the economy and the financial markets. These questions are being asked:

title: Textron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue by business segment included investment income of the Textron parent company borrowing group.As a result of the Federal Trade Commission preliminary injunction relative to Textron's acquisition of Avdel in early 1989, Textron is precluded from consolidating Avdel's earnings with Textron's results of operations.

title: General Cinema
description: The General Cinema Corporation did not extend or terminate its $1.4 billion tender offer to acquire Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. General Cinema's offer expired at 5 P.M. yesterday, but a statement is expected by this morning. There was no indication as to whether General Cinema wuld raise its bid, as Harcourt bondholders are asking. If General Cinema abandons the deal, Harcourt, saddled with $2 billion in debt as the result of its efforts to avoid acquisition by the Maxwell Communication Corporation, may have to consider a restructuring, including a prepackaged bankruptcy.

title: Lotus Income Tumbles 71%
description: The Lotus Development Corporation said today that first-quarter earnings plunged 71 percent, partly because of increased costs from expanding the company's product line.

title: For Unions, Small Gain and New Worries in Rail Strike
description: President Bush wanted the Democratic leadership of Congress to stop the railroad strike before it began. The leadership, honoring organized labor's right to strike, refused.

title: Sergio Peresson, 78, Leading Violin Maker
description: Sergio Peresson, an Italian-born violin maker who crafted instruments for some of the leading soloists, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home. He was 78 years old.

title: Sears Nearly Doubles Net In Quarter
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, in a report that gave Wall Street a surprise, said today that its first-quarter net income nearly doubled, to $202.7 million, from $106.3 million in the 1990 period.

title: Abroad at Home; Not a Time to Celebrate
description: New York City is planning a gala ticker-tape parade on June 10 -- "the world's largest," according to Mayor David Dinkins -- to honor the victorious American forces in the Persian Gulf war. President Bush is among those invited.

title: Account
description: * The Ministry of Tourism for the Caribbean island of Curacao, to Kirshenbaum & Bond, New York, with a budget of $3 million.

title: Time Warner Operating Income Off 1.1%
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that operating income for the first quarter fell 1.1 percent, to $530 million, from $536 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Sharon C. Risk, Lawyer, 71
description: Sharon Clay Risk, a lawyer who was a former associate director of corporate finance for the Federal Communications Commission, died Wednesday at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Lawsuit Gain Aids Manville
description: The Manville Corporation reported yesterday that it netted $35 million, or 26 cents a share, in the first quarter, up 41 percent from $24.9 million, or 18 cents a share, a year ago. But a one-time, $40 million gain from settlement of a patent infringement lawsuit accounted for all of its profits.

title: Review/Film; Seeking an Evasive Truth in Timisoara
description: Dominic Paraschiv was a chemical engineer in Timisoara, Romania, in December 1989, at the beginning of the uprising that eventually overthrew the Communist dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu. Paraschiv was a Roman Catholic with well-known liberal sympathies, married, with three children.

title: Foreman-Holyfield Bout May Be (Big) Appetizer
description: Three days before tonight's George Foreman-Evander Holyfield fight, TVKO officials were saying they didn't want their pay-per-view title bout to turn into a circus, a freak show or a carnival. They cautioned Foreman to stop ingesting cheeseburgers by the gross for public consumption.

title: Henderson on the Run Faces Further Delay
description: RICKEY HENDERSON is not likely to get a chance at breaking LOU BROCK'S stolen-base record until next week. The Oakland Athletics outfielder, still one base short of Brock's career total of 938, has been sidelined since April 11 with an injured left calf.

title: Our Towns
description: Tom Kelly sat in a lawn chair, clutching his day's mail, a third-class offer to subscribe to Smithsonian. He gasped for air. It had taken five minutes to shuffle 30 feet to his mailbox. It would be 10 minutes before he felt sufficiently strong to shuffle indoors.

title: United Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included net gain of $ 6.4 million, or 31 cents a share, from an insurance claim arising from a fire that destroyed one of the company's California food processing facilities in May 1990. The company said the amount could increase when actual costs are determined.c-Included extraordinary credits of $ 1,345,000, or 10 cents a share, and $ 3,241,000, or 24 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, representing tax benefits.

title: At the Bar; Once again, the 'beauty contest' law schools loudly disdain (but secretly scrutinize).
description: In what is becoming the U.S. News & World Report annual survey of American law schools, the magazine's numbers' crunchers grade institutions the way arithmetic teachers grade tests. The top score is 100; everything else descends from there.

title: From Draft to Desert Storm, It's Football
description: THIS is no weekend for weenies. The Big Frat reaches out on Sunday for a few hundred good men, the most famous college registrants in the country, the warriors in our dreams. And this particular National Football League draft is even more than the usual tease for the coming season of male soap opera.

title: Activating Wipers Should Turn on Lights
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Hears Phone Case Arguments
description: Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene today appeared to resist the notion that he should defer to the Justice Department on whether to lift restrictions that currently bar the regional Bell telephone companies from owning information services.

title: At the Movies
description: 'Lolita'

title: Main Fear of Refugee Kurds: 'Saddam Will Kill Us'
description: Kurdish refugees piled in makeshift camps up and down the steep mountainsides here continued to insist today that they would not go to the refugee centers the United States plans to build inside Iraq as long as Saddam Hussein remains in power.

title: Philip H. Steckler Jr., Stockbroker, 72
description: Philip H. Steckler Jr., a New York stockbroker, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Purchase, N.Y., and Wilmington, Vt.

title: Iraq and U.N. to Carve Out Routes In Plan to Speed Refugees' Return
description: Iraq and the United Nations agreed today to create designated routes from the border areas and refugee relief stations in Iraq to hasten the return of hundreds of thousands of refugees to their homes.

title: Celebrating Earth Week With Games and Music
description: Earth Week celebrations start tomorrow, with activities planned through April 27. Here is a sampling of events in the New York area focusing on environmental issues. TOMORROW

title: Tandem Computers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Up to 6 Million People Overlooked In Taking Census, Survey Finds
description: The 1990 census missed four million to six million people, an undercount substantially worse than occurred 10 years ago, according to data from a survey released today by the Census Bureau.

title: Auctions
description: Photo Record: $165,000

title: Jack Yellen, 97, Wrote the Lyrics To 'Happy Days Are Here Again'
description: Jack Yellen, who wrote the lyrics for songs including "Happy Days Are Here Again," died Wednesday at his home in Springville, N.Y. He was 97 years old.

title: A Meld of Decades
description: One recent frigid evening, I was 65 stories into the sky listening to Rosemary Clooney at Rainbow and Stars, the supper club adjacent to the Rainbow Room. Deep into a heart-stopping rendition of "These Foolish Things," she had just gotten to "The Ile de France with all the gulls around it," when a sudden snowstorm swirled wildly outside the window-wrapped room. The crowd gasped; Miss Clooney continued singing. Moments later the storm melted, the dazzling city below emerged once more. For me, time melted, too: the song and the snow and the city combined magically and the 30's, 40's and all the decades into the 90's became one. I knew then that the 65th floor of the RCA Building (does anyone call it the G.E. Building?) is timeless indeed.

title: If It's Monday Night, It Must Be the Giants Against the Niners
description: Like most of his fellow football coaches, Bill Parcells likes routine and dislikes change. If he had his way, his Super Bowl champion Giants would play all of their games at 1 P.M. Sunday.

title: Teleflex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Art; The All-Including Works of Romare Bearden
description: "Memory and Metaphor: The Art of Romare Bearden, 1940-1987" at the Studio Museum in Harlem is a retrospective that works against itself. On the one hand, it is a dedicated attempt to do justice to one of America's best artists, who died in 1988 at the age of 75. The installation of 146 works, many of them never before shown, is generally successful, at times moving, and probably the first one to suggest the true complexity and scope of Bearden's achievement.

title: Energy Dept. Defends Nuclear Arms Program
description: Responding to criticism about the cost of repairing and modernizing the nuclear weapons industry, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today that plants in South Carolina and Colorado were nearly ready to reopen after long shutdowns.

title: Unocal May Fight Fine by E.P.A.
description: The Unocal Corporation said it would probably contest a $689,700 fine proposed by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, which accuses the oil company of mismanaging toxic waste at a refinery here. Unocal has until May 17 to respond to the E.P.A. complaint and also must correct the problems that led to the fine. Arthur Bentley, a Unocal spokesman, said the company would not respond further until its lawyers had reviewed the complaint.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Songwriters Sing

title: Whitney Museum Screenings
description: Films and videos that are part of the 1991 Biennial Exhibition will continue to be screened through June 16 at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street. Admission to screenings is included in museum entrance fee of $5 ($3 for the elderly and students). Information: (212) 570-3611. Here is a schedule. Today "NEW YORK PORTRAIT: PART III" (1990); "SISKYAVI: THE PLACE OF CHASMS" (1989); "FADE TO BLACK" (1990). 2 P.M. Tomorrow-Sunday

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 544 money market mutual funds decreased by $4.77 billion, to $470.77 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 190 institutional funds decreased by $3.45 billion, to $132.97 billion. The assets of the264 general-purpose funds were down by $866 million, to $180.82 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased by $451.7 million, to $156.99 billion, the institute said.

title: Fannie Mae Prices $600 Million Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, priced an unscheduled $600 million debenture offering yesterday to take advantage of the low interest rates available in the market as so many issuers have done this week.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about the singer Roger McGuinn misstated the address of the Ritz, where he performed on Saturday night. It is 254 West 54th Street.

title: New Kind of U.S. Trade Complaint: By Foreign Companies
description: With more manufacturers from abroad setting up shop in the United States, it is getting harder to tell which company is foreign, which domestic. And when trade disputes arise, the confusion mounts.

title: Novel Vaccine Used to Treat AIDS-Like Illness in Monkeys
description: In a step they say may lead to a new approach to developing an AIDS vaccine, researchers have devised a novel vaccine against an AIDS-like disease that affects monkeys.

title: The Bell Tolls for Rain Forests
description: IT now takes less than 40 years for the human race to double, and there are few consequences of the population explosion more striking than the obliteration of the world's rain forests. The American Museum of Natural History has opened an exhibition dedicated to the natural treasure we are rapidly losing.

title: Review/Film; 2 Wives and the Men Who Make Them Unhappy
description: Alan Rudolph is by now well established as a not-quite-established film maker poised on the brink of a breakthrough. Each of his 12 features (among them "Welcome to L.A.," "Choose Me," "Made in Heaven" and "Remember My Name") has shown the kind of promise that makes Mr. Rudolph's audiences truly appreciative of offbeat, exploratory film making, if not wholeheartedly appreciative of the example at hand.

title: Cholera Kills 1,100 in Peru and Marches On, Reaching the Brazilian Border
description: A fast-moving cholera epidemic that has killed 1,100 Peruvians and sickened 150,000 since January has spread to Ecuador and Colombia. Isolated cases have been reported in Chile and the United States, but perhaps the greatest concern is for Brazil, Latin America's most populous nation.

title: Measles Cases Are Epidemic In the Region
description: Health officials in New York and New Jersey say they are facing the most serious measles epidemics in more than a decade, with New York City alone reporting almost as many cases in the first four months of this year as in all of 1990..

title: Evan M. Frankel, 90, a Crusader Against L.I. Development, Is Dead
description: Evan M. Frankel, a Manhattan builder who became one of the largest landowners in East Hampton, L.I., where he fought steadfastly for half a century to preserve the Island's South Fork from development, died on Wednesday at his home in East Hampton. He was 90 years old.

title: The Spoken Word
description: PERFORMANCE AND LECTURE, Kittredge Club, 109 East 39th Street, Manhattan. Based on the works of Sholom Aleichem, presented by Philip Nolan and Raoul J. Shorr, Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission, $10. Information: (718) 241-7479.

title: Critic's Choice/Theater; A One-Man Multiplicity
description: Among the plethora of solo performers who have created multiple characters on the stage recently, Jeffrey Essmann is exceptional for the literary refinement of his language and for his esoteric choice of subjects. Who else would think of portraying a Serbo-Croatian poet whose husband fired the shots that triggered World War I? Or an English aristocrat from an E. M. Forster novel who is so repressed he cannot recognize his own homosexual urges?

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Tumble
