description: Suggestions that the steady rise in unemployment may be slowing and a press report that the Federal Reserve Board decided last month to stop easing monetary policy sent prices of Treasury securities down sharply yesterday.

title: Southeastern Mich. Gas reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Diner's Journal
description: Outdoors on the Fifth Floor

title: Murder-Suicide Ruled In 2 Mysterious Deaths
description: The mysterious deaths of a Hartford radio executive and his wife were ruled a murder-suicide by authorities on Thursday.

title: 'I Hate to Tour' Tours
description: This is the truth. I hate it when people come to visit because I really don't want to go anywhere. Most New York neighborhoods that people wish to see are either so low class you fear for your life or so trendy you want to throw up.

title: The Dow Falls Below 3,000 in 5.20 Drop
description: A burst of profit taking in the last minutes of trading yesterday ended the Dow Jones industrial average's one-night stand above the 3,000 level. Most other leading market indexes also closed below their record levels of Wednesday.

title: Washington Water Power reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,091,000, or 10 cents a share.

title: Vista Chemical Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $ 4,663,000 or 44-cents-a-share gain from an accounting change.

title: U.S. Judge Rules District of Columbia Is Abusing Rights of Foster Children
description: In a decison that could have implications around the country, a Federal judge ruled today that the District of Columbia's inability to operate an adequate foster care system for children from troubled families was unconstitutional and a violation of Federal law.

title: Nicklaus Settles Back Into Role as Seniors Leader
description: Jack Nicklaus admits he's still dizzy from his roller-coaster performance at the Masters last week, but his game was back on the straight and narrow today at the PGA Senior Championship.

title: Mice Are Altered to Help Humans Fight Disease
description: For the first time, scientists have created mice with fully functioning human immune systems by replacing the mice's bone marrow with human bone marrow. Researchers expect that the mice will be able to make human antibodies to order and could be testing grounds for vaccines and AIDS drugs.

title: In Paraguay, Rights Inquiry Must Go On
description: To the Editor:

title: Acting Is a Great Deal More Than Skin Deep; From Time of Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera Excerpts
description: "Operatic Gems in a Religious Setting," a concert of solos, duets, trios and choruses, will take place on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, 348 East 55th Street in Manhattan. Soloists are to be Rosalie Olinski, soprano; Susan Titone, mezzo-soprano; Efren Puig, tenor, and Martin Broms, baritone. Johannes Somary will conduct. Tickets are $15 ($12 for students and the elderly); proceeds are to go toward replacement of the bells at the Church of Sveti Jakob in Stjak, Yugoslavia. Information: (212) 979-7916.

title: Lawmakers Cheer Tibetan in Capitol Rotunda
description: Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, speaking to a receptive gathering of members of Congress today in the Capitol rotunda, appealed to the United States to aid Tibet in its struggle against Chinese Government control.

title: Panel Affirms Cancer Risk Involving Secondhand Smoke
description: An advisory board of scientists endorsed a Government proposal today to classify secondhand tobacco smoke as a known cause of lung cancer in nonsmokers.

title: Dr. Axelrod's Courage
description: Dr. David Axelrod, forced by sudden illness to retire this week as New York State's Health Commissioner, was an extraordinarily principled chief health officer who will be difficult to replace.

title: Acting Is a Great Deal More Than Skin-Deep
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Elephant That Fears Only a Mouse
description: TO describe the strategy of their gladiators, boxing trainers often use analogies. One favorite is the matador and the bull. But several months ago, while discussing Evander Holyfield's first heavyweight title defense, tonight against 42-year-old George Foreman, the champion's trainer, George Benton, used the mouse and the elephant.

title: Florio Mails Report Cards On Schools, Drawing Fire
description: The Florio administration began mailing New Jersey's school districts a "report card" this week comparing their taxing, spending and academic performance, prompting grumbling from the education community about distorted, misleading and in one case inaccurate information in the document.

title: Weyerhaeuser Head Plans to Retire in July
description: George H. Weyerhaeuser, the chairman and chief executive of the Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday at the company's annual meeting that he would retire when he turned 65 in July and that he would turn over the post to John W. Creighton Jr., the president. The move was expected.

title: Columbus's Diary and Queen Isabella's Jewels
description: The Crown of Columbus By Michael Dorris and Louise Erdrich 382 pages. HarperCollins. $21.95.

title: Review/Theater; A Child's Innocence Fights Bias
description: The wonderful thing about children is that they believe everything is possible. What makes Lynda Barry's first play a happy occasion is that she captures the innocent abandon of childhood with the wit of a mature writer but without letting go of the uninhibited child still lurking deep within herself.

title: Stone & Webster reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 208,000, or 1 cent a share, and $ 387,000, or 2 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, from foreign units' tax loss carryforwards. The year-ago quarter also included net of $ 2.9 million, or 19 cents a share, from sale of investment securities.Revenue represented gross earnings.Year-ago revenue was restated for reclassification of certain foreign income taxes.

title: Mildest Possible Penalty Is Imposed on Neil Bush
description: Federal regulators today imposed the mildest sanctions possible against Neil Bush, the President's son, for his role in the failure of the Denver-based Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association.

title: P.&G. Official Named To Ad Council Panel
description: John G. Smale, the chairman of the executive committee of the Procter & Gamble Company, has been named chairman of the advisory committee on public issues of the Advertising Council.

title: Digital Gains More Than Fourfold
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that its quarterly profits had increased more than fourfold, and the shares of the nation's No. 2 computer maker jumped $4, or 6 percent, to $70.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the third-most-active Big Board stock, with 2.3 million shares changing hands.

title: Central Park's Jewels
description: In few other places does the city unfold so gracefully as it does along a roughly circular route through the middle of Central Park: It begins on the winding paths through Strawberry Fields, at 72d Street and Central Park West, in the shadow of the Dakota apartments. From there go east to the Lake, where in the warm months rowboats jostle for space during the afternoon, but in the morning, year round, extraodinary quiet and calm prevail. Onward to Bethesda Fountain, jugglers and gleeful swimming dogs; then to Conservatory Water at East 74th Street, with its model-boat regattas and endless promenaders.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airgas Inc., Wilmington, Del., named Merril L. Stott president. He replaces Lanny R. Patten, who has resigned. * American Ship Building Co., Tampa, Fla., named Kenneth G. Myers chief financial officer and vice president. He replaces W. L. Carothers, who has resigned.

title: Reeling From Unrest, St. John's Awaits New Law Dean
description: For generations, St. John's Law School has been known as the place where the sons and daughters of immigrants learned to become lawyers. It is the alma mater of New York's last two Governors, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee and a host of judges and politicians.

title: Teachers Walk Out In Washington State Over Pay Increase
description: About 40 percent of Washington State's 50,000 teachers went on strike today to press their demand for greater state spending on education and a 10 percent salary increase over two years.

title: Offbeat Ideas to Amuse Visitors; New York Survival Tips
description: One striking thing about New York City is its residents' willingness to tell visitors where to go, whether recommending a good restaurant or responding to comments on their civility.

title: Surgery for Carpenter
description: BOB CARPENTER, a Boston Bruins forward who reinjured his left knee in Game 2 of a first-round playoff series victory over the Hartford Whalers, will undergo surgery tomorrow at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston and will not play again this season. Carpenter originally shattered the knee on crashing into the boards at the Montreal Forum on Dec. 8. When he returned to action against the Whalers, one of the fracture lines in his repaired kneecap opened up slightly, according to HARRY SINDEN, the general manager.(AP)

title: Denison Mines reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 3,093,000.Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: McDonnell's Earnings Soar to $58 Million
description: Helped in part by an increase in deliveries of MD-11 jetliners, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation yesterday reported a strong increase in earnings for the first quarter.

title: Excel Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Avoid Airport Delays by Packing Carefully
description: "If you're carrying on appliances or electronics, pack them on top of clothes or in the outside compartments of luggage," said Page Miller, director of marketing services for the Samsonite Corporation, the luggage manufacturer. "That way you can get to them faster and without pulling out all your other possessions."

title: Gorbachev Pursues Closer Ties to Seoul
description: The Soviet Union and South Korea continued their whirlwind courtship Friday as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here for his third meeting with South Korea's President, Roh Tae Woo, in 10 months and the first visit to this divided peninsula by a Soviet head of state.

title: Sir Austin Hill Dies; A Pioneer in Linking Smoking and Cancer
description: Sir Austin Bradford Hill, a pioneering epidemiologist who led one of the first research teams to establish a link between smoking and cancer, died on Thursday, his son said today. He was 93 years old.

title: Rangers' Surgical List
description: JAMES PATRICK of the Rangers underwent successful surgery on his left hand yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, the team announced yesterday. Defenseman RANDY MOLLER and center MARK JANSSENS will undergo surgery on their left shoulders next week.

title: Bill Rates Mixed as Bond Prices Fall
description: Prices of Treasury bonds plunged and long-term interest rates soared late yesterday. But bill rates and other short-term Treasury debt issues remained narrowly mixed.

title: Minnesota, Mining & Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Marchmont Schwartz Football Coach, 82
description: Marchmont Schwartz, a two-time all-America running back at Notre Dame who later became head football coach at Stanford, died of heart failure Thursday. He was 82 years old.

title: Alaska Air Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Harley-Davidson reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago shares outstanding are restated to reflect June 15, 1990 2-for-1 stock split.

title: What Does a Nobel Prize Mean Anyhow?; Original Intention
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Is Off 33.67 Points, to 2,965.59
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday in busy trading, mirroring a similar drop in bond prices and reflecting concerns that the Federal Reserve may not reduce interest rates.

title: Los Angeles Police Chief Offers Apology to Minorities for Remarks
description: The Los Angeles Police Chief, Daryl F. Gates, has apologized for past remarks that many considered offensive to minority members in a city divided over the videotaped beating of a black motorist by white policemen.

title: Apple Computer Settles Claim on Job Bias
description: Fourteen black people who charged that Apple Computer Inc. refused to hire them because of their race have won jobs with the company and a settlement of more than $400,000.

title: First Union Real Estate Inv reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Inclded capital gains from previously reported installment sales of $ 1,168,000, or 6 cents a share, in the latest quarter and $ 1,195,000, or 6 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.

title: Grace Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included net income of $ 1.5 million, or 6 cents a share, from a gas contract settlement, compared to net income of $ 4.3 million after tax, or 17 cents a share, from a contract settlement.The latest quarter also included the full effect of the March 1990 bankruptcy of a long-term contract customer of Colowyo Coal Co., of which a Grace Energy subsidiary is a 50 percent partner. The unfavorable after-tax impact of the bankruptcy was $ 2.7 million, in the latest first quarter, compared with $ 500,000 in year-ago period.

title: Summer Goal Is Keeping Youth Safe
description: Seeking to head off a summer of boredom and potential violence as children are caught in gunfire and their parents face the economic pressures of a recession, the Dinkins administration yesterday detailed its plan for summer jobs, counseling and school-based programs for young people.

title: Chiquita May Buy Stake in Doskocil
description: The Doskocil Companies said that Chiquita Brands International Inc. had expressed interest in acquiring a substantial minority equity interest in Doskocil upon its emergence from bankruptcy. Doskocil, a packaged-foods company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors in March, said Chiquita, a unit of the American Financial Corporation, had suggested an exchange of shares for an equity interest.

title: Guidepost; Theater on the Cheap
description: New Yorkers and visitors alike complain about the high price of theater tickets. But it is possible to buy tickets to many entertainment events at discounts of up to 65 percent off box-office prices, either through day-of-performance ticket outlets or through membership organizations. Here are some services that offer lower-priced tickets.

title: Utah Moves to Clarify Tough Abortion Law
description: The Utah Legislature voted on Thursday to clarify the nation's most restrictive abortion law, removing any possibility that women who undergo abortions and doctors who perform them could be charged with murder.

title: Prison for Ex-Cubic Official
description: The former president of Cubic Defense Systems Inc. was sentenced today to 18 months in prison for theft of Government property and conspiring to bribe an Air Force official.

title: Haitian Music From Another Era
description: Some minutes after the appointed time, 10 P.M., Le Manoir was still half-empty. Back from the dance floor, men in suits and open-necked shirts crowded the bar, calling in Creole for their next Heineken, their next Black Label and turning smiles on the women behind them.

title: M.D. Doesn't Mean 'More Deaths'
description: The distinction between executioner and physician has never been absolute. In 17th century Europe, the executioner, who broke bones at the gallows, was called upon by neighbors to set bones, his expertise turned to the purpose of healing.

title: Guam, Against the Tide, Wants Air Base Closed
description: Like many in Congress, Ben Blaz of Guam is applying pressure on the Pentagon about the status of the military base in his district. But unlike his Congressional colleagues, Mr. Blaz wants the base in his district to close.

title: Knicks End The Misery With A Loss In Indiana
description: The Knicks lost tonight and won a playoff date with the Chicago Bulls.

title: South Africans Given Approval to Compete
description: Officials of track and field's world governing body have given approval for a South African team to compete at this year's championships in Tokyo, sources said yesterday.

title: Gasoline Prices Are Going Up As Supplies Dwindle
description: Gasoline prices are likely to rise by 10 cents to 15 cents a gallon at the pump by the middle of May, to an average of $1.20 to $1.25 a gallon, according to several energy analysts.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Former President JIMMY CARTER received the 1991 Onassis International Prize for Man and Society in Athens on Thursday.

title: New Jersey Schools Warn Parents on Cuts
description: Grappling with the effects of a tax revolt, school districts around the state are warning parents to expect serious cuts in services in the next school year.

title: Kellogg Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Article 073591 -- No Title
description: Caterpillar Inc., the giant bulldozer and excavating equipment maker, yesterday reported a $32 million loss in the first quarter, attributing the results to weakened demand brought about by the recession.

title: New York's Rudeness Is Greatly Exaggerated
description: To the Editor:

title: RPC Energy Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 787,000, or 6 cents a share, and $ 804,000, or 6 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: After 41 Years, a Deserter Is in U.S. Custody
description: A 68-year-old homeless man picked up by the police here Tuesday night is being held by the Coast Guard for deserting 41 years ago, during the Korean War.

title: Heinz Won Acclaim As Environmentalist
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Awards Armstrong Rival $246 Million
description: A jury yesterday awarded a small New Jersey company $246 million in damages from Armstrong World Industries, the giant floor-covering company, in a civil antitrust conspiracy and monopoly case.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Medical Electronics Inc., Dallas, a maker of medical equipment, will acquire Levtech Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., a maker of medical devices, for $2.25 million.

title: Advice Sought in Case of Slain Contra
description: A commission named by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro to investigate the killing of the former contra military chief Enrique Bermudez has asked her to seek expert help from abroad to solve the crime.

title: Compuserve Joins Fujitsu in Venture
description: Fujitsu Ltd. said it would join with Compuserve Inc. to offer computer information services in Australia and New Zealand starting in September. The services will consist of data on corporate accounts, commodities market prices and other financial information that will be accessible through personal computer terminals.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the restoration of the 1960 film "Spartacus" misstated its opening date around the country. It is to open on Friday, not next Saturday.

title: After Landing No. 1 Draft Pick, Cowboys Are Chasing Rocket
description: The New England Patriots yesterday traded their No. 1 pick in tomorrow's National Football League draft to Dallas, giving the Cowboys the opportunity to strike a deal with Raghib (Rocket) Ismail, the Notre Dame receiver and the consensus No. 1 player in the country.

title: Schering-Plough Halts Procyte Deal
description: The Procyte Corporation said the Schering-Plough Corporation had withdrawn from an agreement to jointly develop Procyte's wound-healing drug, Iamin. Procyte said results from the second phase of Schering's topical clinical trials on patients with stasis ulcers and diabetic wounds had been "disappointing."

title: Benjamin Lipton Dies; Friend of Disabled, 79
description: Benjamin Lipton, a pioneer in establishing training programs for the disabled and a founder of sports programs for wheelchair-bound athletes, died yesterday, at his home in Malverne, L.I. He was 79 years old.

title: Kigali Journal; AIDS Outweighed by the Desire to Have a Child
description: In her mud-walled shack, Nikuze Siyapata, a tall, smiling 22-year-old, gave birth to a baby son, a tiny creature that she proudly carried on her back when he was only five days old for her visits to an AIDS clinic.

title: Division on Exports to Iraq Continues to Grow Deeper
description: Divisions within the Administration over past American exports to Iraq widened today when the top investigator of the United States Customs Service said his agency would defy the Commerce Department and investigate some companies that applied for export licenses.

title: Religion Notes
description: Faithful to God and I.R.S.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The last few ads I answered, there were 50 people there for the job. There is nothing out there." -- Dawn Salvesen of Brooklyn. [ 1:2. ]

title: Time to Unsnarl Saltwater Tackle
description: Spring angling for striped bass and bluefish catches many fishermen unprepared. They make frantic last-minute preparations for the trout season, which gets under way in April in southern New England, New York and New Jersey, only to realize that little time is left to unsnarl and refurbish saltwater tackle.

title: Clemens Granted a New Hearing
description: The case of Roger Clemens vs. the umpires was thrown back to the starting point yesterday after the Boston Red Sox star made his argument at a five-hour hearing in the commissioner's office with the help of a professional lip reader who interpreted a videotape on his behalf.

title: In the Nation; End of A Great Era
description: Homer Bigart, one of the best newspaper reporters ever to pound a typewriter, died in New Hampshire this week, at age 83. On the same day, in an irony he might have appreciated, a Federal judge pronounced what may well have been the end of the great tradition of combat correspondence in American journalism.

title: Jesus Underwent a Purely Political Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Dawson's Grand Slam Wasted as Pirates Defeat Cubs in 9th
description: Jeff King's two-out single in the bottom of the ninth inning negated Andre Dawson's grand slam in the top half as the Pittsburgh Pirates rallied to end the Chicago Cubs' winning streak at six games with a 5-4 victory tonight.

title: Twin Disc Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax benefit of $ 1,925,000 in the quarter and $ 3,025,000 in the 9 months.c-Net incomeThe company said the loss was primarily a result of pretax expenses of about $ 3.8 million associated with the restructuring of its Belgian and domestic manufacturing operations.

title: Corrections
description: A table on Tuesday with an article about budget problems of the Philadelphia transit system misstated the number of daily bus and rail trips on the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority and on New Jersey Transit. One million trips a day are made on the Washington system, and 540,000 on the New Jersey system.

title: Waiting for Rescues
description: When Gov. Mario M. Cuomo stood beside a polite and subdued Mayor David N. Dinkins the other day to announce that he would stand by New York City in its time of fiscal need, the event evoked the state's rescue of the city when it teetered on bankruptcy in 1975.

title: Minnesota Power & Light Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sports of The Times; 'Here Comes George'
description: From ringside, there was one sight that stuck out. It was the back of George Foreman's head. It is a bald head, and with a deep dimple where the head meets his beefy neck. It is a head befitting a man of considerable weight, and of a certain age.

title: Holtzman Sees Big Job Loss From Tax Effort by Dinkins
description: New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman warned yesterday that tax increases proposed or adopted by the Dinkins administration could mean the loss of 265,000 jobs in the city and delay recovery from the deep recession.

title: Addiction and Pregnancy
description: A Florida appeals court upheld the conviction of a woman charged with giving cocaine to her newborn baby through the umbilical cord. Page 6.

title: Carlisle Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Soviets Can't Take Their Reactor As U.S. Officials Cite Export Rules
description: When Soviet officials brought a model of one of their spacecraft nuclear reactors to display at a scientific convention here in January, it was considered an unusual sign of international cooperation.

title: Kennametal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After effect of pre-tax charge of $ 4.55 million from patent litigation for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Music in Review; Diamanda Galas
description: The Kitchen 512 West 19th Street

title: Tredegar Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,709,000.

title: U.S. Will Conduct Vast Study Of Women's Health Problems
description: The Government said today it would launch the most far-reaching study of women's health ever undertaken, one involving hundreds of thousands of women.

title: Oriole Homes Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Galileo Project To Be Delayed
description: No new attempt will be made to deploy the malfunctioning antenna on the Jupiter-bound Galileo spacecraft until engineers, concerned that hasty action could damage critical components, can thoroughly analyze radioed data and conduct extensive ground tests, project officials said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: With pomp and pageantry, GEORGE CAREY, a son of the working class, was enthroned yesterday as the 103d Archbishop of Canterbury. In a ceremony blending medieval splendor and gospel songs that was witnessed by 2,200 people, including QUEEN ELIZABETH II, Archbishop DESMOND TUTU of South Africa and the American evangelist BILLY GRAHAM, Archbishop Carey pledged that the Anglican Church would continue to be a strong voice on social and political issues.

title: Pyramid Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: Year-ago periods ended March 30.

title: Caterpillar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pretax nonrecurring charge of $ 21 million related to the consolidation of the North American operations of the building construction products division.c-Net income

title: Meadow Star Shoots for 10-0 in the Wood
description: For the 67th year in a row, New York will set the stage for the Kentucky Derby today when nine colts and one superstar filly race in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct. And, for an extra dash of drama, the filly is the undefeated Meadow Star, challenging colts for the first time in a test that will determine whether she goes on to the Kentucky Derby two weeks later.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Woosnam Misses Cut Ian Woosnam, winner of the Masters in Augusta, Ga., last Sunday, shot his second successive 82 at St. Mellion, England, yesterday and missed the cut of a tournament for the first time in three years. Woosnam's second straight 10-over-par round in the Benson & Hedges International got off to a good start with an eagle 2 at the third hole, but his round fell apart again in the icy winds that swept the course. (AP) Stewart Leads Heritage: Payne Stewart, playing in his first tournament in two months after suffering from a herniated disk in his neck, shot his second straight 68 to lead the rain-delayed Heritage Classic in Hilton Head Island, S.C. (AP) HOCKEY Canada Beats U.S. Geoff Courtnall, a star for the Vancouver Canucks before they were eliminated from this season's National Hockey League playoffs by the Los Angeles Kings, scored the last two goals and led Canada to a 4-3 victory over Team USA in the first round of the world championships in Helsinki, Finland. (AP)

title: Duke Power Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SuperSonics Draw the Trail Blazers
description: The Portland Trail Blazers will face the Seattle SuperSonics in the first round of the National Basketball Association playoffs. The matchup was assured Thursday night when the Utah Jazz beat Seattle, 130-103.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday with an article about conditions for Iraqi Kurdish refugees misplaced the Turkish cities of Silopi and Isikveren and, in some editions, the Iranian town of Do Ab. Their correct locations are shown today in a map on page 4.

title: Pittston Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 2,900,000, or 8 cents a share.c-Net loss

title: Offer for Harcourt Being Extended
description: The General Cinema Corporation said yesterday that it was extending its tender offer for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich until Monday, at the request of the bondholders. General Cinema, based in Newton, Mass., had offered $1.4 billion for the ailing publishing company and then raised its offer by about $50 million. Bondholders had wanted an increase to about $1.5 billion.

title: Review/Music; Olaf Baer Sings 'Mullerin' and All Is Sadness
description: The most eagerly anticipated event of the season for lieder enthusiasts had to be Olaf Baer's recital on Thursday evening. The German baritone, who canceled his New York debut last year owing to illness, had already been nominated by some English and other European critics as the successor to the long-reigning king of song, Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau. No wonder the audience at Alice Tully Hall was large and unusually attentive as Mr. Baer and his pianist, Geoffrey Parsons, played out the poignant, hourlong drama that is "Die Schone Mullerin."

title: Transit Aides Set to Borrow $278 Million
description: Subway officials said yesterday that they would issue $278 million in short-term notes as part of what for many municipalities, authorities and school districts has become an expensive rite of spring, borrowing money to tide themselves over until New York State passes a budget.

title: All Walks of Life Now Converge In New York City's Jobless Lines
description: The slide that began three years ago on Wall Street has now ricocheted throughout the city's economy, claiming jobs in everything from banking to auto repair. As the recession continues to deepen, tens of thousands of New Yorkers are discovering its pain, finding themselves in unemployment lines that are growing longer and ever-more democratic.

title: Court in Florida Upholds Conviction For Drug Delivery by Umbilical Cord
description: A Florida appeals court has upheld the first conviction in the nation of a woman charged with delivering cocaine to her newborn baby through the umbilical cord.

title: Integra reports earnings for Year to Dec 28
description: b-After a loss of $ 138,000 from discontinued operations.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 228,000 and an extraordinary loss of $ 1,593,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle in 1989.

title: Observer; Dis And Gat
description: Here's another story about respect, though maybe not, who knows? Half the stories in the news nowadays seem to be about respect, or more accurately, about not getting any respect, which seems to make people's blood boil nowadays, sometimes at murderous intensity.

title: Two Prokofiev Concerts
description: Two evenings of chamber music celebrating the 100th anniversary of Sergei Prokofiev's birth to will take place next week a Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The concerts, at 8 P.M. on Monday and Tuesday, will feature the Manhattan String Quartet; Chrostopher O'Riley and Daniel Epstein, pianists; Matthew Sullivan, oboist; Susan Salm, celist; John Deak, bassist; and the flutist Ransom Wilson. Dr Harlow Robinson, the author of "Sergei Prokofiev: A Biography," will give a preconcert lecture each evening at 6:30. Tickets are $15 for each concert, or $25 for both, and are avaliable at the Town Hall box office or through Ticketron, (212) 947-5850.

title: Giving Up the Ball? Get a New Grip On It
description: Basketball requires strong hands and nimble fingers. Unlike most other team sports, it is played with bare hands. But Bill Schulkin, president of KSL Sports of New York, would like to change that. He has invented a basketball glove with tiny rubberized dots intended to improve a player's grip on the ball. KSL Sports has enlisted former pro star Julius Erving to promote the product as Dr. J's Hot Hand basketball gloves.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League

title: Commerce Clearing House reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Square D Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included one-time charges of $ 4 million for centralization of the automation products and control products businesses and $ 1.3 million for the consolidation of two warehouses.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 20,000.

title: Holyfield Keeps Title; Foreman Wins Respect
description: The fat man was for real, but he didn't have enough to defeat the man who had the title.

title: Music in Review; New York Philharmonic
description: Avery Fisher Hall
