Air Products & Chemicals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 3.8 million, or 7 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 7.1 million or 13 cents a share, in the 6 months, both from the settlement of certain pension obligations.c-Included an after-tax gain of $ 6.3 million, or 11 cents a share, from sales of land and a business.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Slain, One Defending His Dog
description: Two teen-agers were shot in the head and killed inside a hardware store in East Harlem yesterday afternoon, and another was killed defending his dog in Queens, the police said.

title: Triad Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a nonrecurring $ 503,000 charge due to an increase in bonus accruals associated with stock options.

title: Qume Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 581,000 related to the conversion of preferred stock of one of the company's Taiwan units.c-Net income and included a pretax gain of $ 6,933,000 related to the private sales of common stock of one of the company's Taiwan units.d-Net income and included a pretax gain of $ 11,807,000 related to private sales of common stock of both of the company's Taiwan units.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of problems with the computers that transmit financial data at The Associated Press, the Mutual Funds table on page 43 shows the change from Wednesday instead of Thursday.

title: More Choices Needed In Caller ID Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Law Page yesterday about a testimonial on behalf of Patrick J. Rohan, dean of St. John's Law School in New York, referred incorrectly in some editions to the participants. From the left were Andrew J. Maloney, United States Attorney in Brooklyn; Mr. Rohan; and Deputy Mayor Milton Mollen.

title: Warmus-Murder-Case Jurors End 3d Day of Deliberations
description: Jurors in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus today completed their third full day of deliberations in Westchester County Court without reaching a verdict.

title: Frito-Lay Shifts Some Ad Accounts
description: Frito-Lay Inc. yesterday shifted two snack-food accounts worth a total of $40 million from Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver to BBDO and Tracy-Locke, a Dallas agency.

title: Mets Manage to Score But Still Can't Win
description: The string of zeros ended at last. The questions prompted by 18 consecutive scoreless innings, though, didn't. And won't.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the funeral of Bartholomew Borriello misstated the location of John Gotti Jr. He was at the right of Mr. Borriello's widow, Susan.

title: Correction
description: A sentence in an April 16 letter on regional Bell telephone companies from George Sollman appeared incorrectly as follows: "The restrictions are not limited to manufacturing by regional Bells; they also preclude vital investments in land ventures with small and medium-sized American manufacturing companies." The sentence should have read: "The restrictions are not limited to manufacturing by regional Bells; they also preclude vital investments in and joint ventures with small and medium-sized American manufacturing companies."

title: About New York
description: There was nothing about the 31-year-old black woman in the blue sweater, dangling earrings and gold-frame glasses to suggest she had AIDS. But she couldn't help thinking the hardest truth of her life was somehow written all over her.

title: Big Gain Predicted in New York City if Census Is Adjusted
description: New York City could gain hundreds of thousands of people in the 1990 census if an additional population survey conducted by the Census Bureau is used to adjust the official tally.

title: Stricken Udall Says He Will Quit House
description: Morris K. Udall, the 15-term Arizona Congressman who built a career on humor, likability and a commitment to liberal causes and candidates, announced today that he would relinquish his House seat because of ill health.

title: Justin Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Michael Foods reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split payable May 9 to stockholders of record April 29.

title: American Business Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Builder Suspects Engine Failure In Rocket's Loss
description: The builder of a rocket that had to be destroyed after it careened out of control over the Atlantic Ocean focused its investigation today on engine failure.

title: Your Money; How to Prepare for Loss of a Job
description: With waves of layoffs and offers of early retirement rolling through corporate America, all employed people should be putting their finances in shipshape condition, experts counsel. They also offer advice for those already adrift.

title: No Way to Honor Dr. King
description: The stated mission -- to promote racial understanding and nonviolent resolution of conflicts -- was noble. But rampant abuse of public funds has now tarnished New York's Martin Luther King Jr. Institute for Nonviolence.

title: Corrections
description: The "On Stage, and Off" column in Weekend yesterday included an incorrect identification supplied by the New York Shakespeare Festival for the director of its 1957 production of "Macbeth." He was Stuart Vaughan, not Joseph Papp.

title: Chemed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 594,000 from the sale of the company's Dubois Chemicals Inc. unit in April.c-Net income and included an after tax loss of $ 668,000 for Chemed's share of Omnicare's loss on the disposal of certain operations in 1990; included an after-tax gain of $ 918,000, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of leased plant facilities in St. Louis in January 1990.

title: SOME KURDS IN IRAN RETURNING TO IRAQ
description: Riddled with dysentery and typhoid after days of foul and fruitless waiting to enter Iran, some Kurdish refugees at this checkpoint on the Iran-Iraq border today abandoned their flight from Saddam Hussein's army and began heading back into Iraq.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Fall by 1.2% on Big Board
description: A short sale is the sale of borrowed stock, and it normally represents speculation that the price of the stock will fall, since a short-seller makes a profit if the stock can be bought back at a lower price. The number of shares in which a short position is still held by investors is totaled by each exchange at the end of a reporting period and represents the "short interest" for that period. Analysts' Views of 'Short Interest' Figures Differ

title: Bell & Howell Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hannah Falk Hofheimer, Philanthropist, 102
description: Hannah Falk Hofheimer, a philanthropist and a major benefactor of Barnard, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 102 years old.

title: What Does a Nobel Prize Mean Anyhow?
description: To the Editor:

title: Billions Sought in Turret Blast
description: The families of 37 of the 47 sailors killed in a gun turret explosion aboard the battleship Iowa two years ago filed wrongful-death claims totaling $2 billion against the Navy on Thursday.

title: Music in Review; Parnassus, with Adrienne Csengery
description: Merkin Concert Hall 129 West 67th Street

title: U.S. Persists on Camp Plan After a Meeting With Iraqis
description: The commander of the American-led operation to assist Iraqi refugees along the Turkish-Iraqi border met here today with two Iraqi generals, then stressed that the United States and its allies would go ahead with plans to build and defend camps inside Iraq for the refugees, despite Baghdad's objections.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN McCONNELL, the actor who portrays Huey Long in "The Kingfish," a one-man Off-Broadway show about the Louisiana political titan of the 1930's, is the focus of attention from two men who would be Governor of Louisiana in the 1990's.

title: Glenfed Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Borg's Journey Begins
description: BJORN BORG, returning to tournament tennis after an eight-year retirement, will play a clay-court specialist, JORDI ARRESE of Spain, in the opening round of the Monte Carlo Open Tuesday. Borg, 34, a five-time Wimbledon champion, has played just three official matches since 1981. If Borg gets by Arrese, his next opponent would be GORAN IVANISEVIC of Yugoslavia, seeded fifth, who received a first-round bye.(AP)

title: Consumers Packaging reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $ 3.7 million gain on the sale of land.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Leary Tosses 3-Hitter As Yanks Beat Royals
description: He is not exactly the stopper -- on this team, no one is -- but Tim Leary comes as close as anyone to being the most important pitcher on the Yankees' staff.

title: Penguins Top Capitals, 7-6, and Get Even
description: Kevin Stevens scored his second goal of the game at 8 minutes 10 seconds of overtime as Pittsburgh squandered a two-goal, third-period lead and then rallied to beat the Washington Capitals, 7-6, tonight and even the Patrick Division final at a game apiece.

title: New Assignment Seen For Rich's Chairman
description: Roger N. Farah, the chairman and chief executive of Rich's Inc., Atlanta, who announced on Wednesday the closing of the chain's downtown flagship store, will soon be reassigned by Federated Stores Inc., Rich's owner, to be chairman and chief executive of the company's New York buying office, Federated/Allied Merchandising Services, retail executives close to Federated said yesterday.

title: Teppco Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1990 results are presented on a pro-forma basis. Teepco was formed March 7, 1990. For the period between March 7, 1990, and March 31, 1990, Teppco said its actual results were a net loss of $ 600,000, on revenues of $ 12.1 million. The partnership said 1990 results reflected a $ 1.5-million charge associated with a March 13, 1990, explosion and fire on the liquefied petroleum gases pipeline near North Blenheim, N.Y.

title: Gundle Environmental Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Outing for Hershiser
description: OREL HERSHISER, the Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher who has been virtually sidelined from radical shoulder surgery since last April 27, threw 43 pitches in a four-inning simulated game against his teammates yesterday in San Diego. The Dodgers have a tentative plan to send the right-hander to Vero Beach, Fla., in their minor league system, for a 30-day rehabilitation next month.

title: Timely Help for Nicaragua
description: Gallantry abounded this week when Violeta Chamorro made the rounds in Washington, a year after her inauguration as President of Nicaragua. President Bush extolled her "exhilarating victory" over the Sandinistas. After she addressed Congress, a California Republican called her "a miracle in the Western Hemisphere." But her people can't eat bouquets, and the best news was Mr. Bush's offer to lead an international effort to help Nicaragua raise $360 million to make overdue payments on a crushing $9.4 billion foreign debt.

title: Newell Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Newell said 1990 results included a net non-recurring gain from the sale of securities of about $ 5.5 million, or 9 cents a share.

title: U.S. Orders Write-Offs By Big Banks
description: American bankers were told by Federal regulators earlier this week to write off 20 percent of their loans to Brazil and 10 percent of their loans to Argentina as losses, bankers said yesterday.

title: RasterOps reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Union Valley Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After recording a $ 14,284,000 reserve in the fourth quarter reflecting a decline in the value of the company's real estate, primarily in New Jersey. The company said this reserve resulted in part from the non-renewal of essential bank financing, which was previously reported.c-Net income

title: Ashton-Tate Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Standard Products Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 11.58 million reflecting start-up costs at the company's Silent Channel subsidiary in the United Kingdom.c-Net income

title: Thomson Advisory Group L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflected non-recurring item of approximately $ 2 million in revenue and $ 900,000 in earnings (9 cents per share) which represented complete adoption of accrual accounting for asset management fees.

title: New 400 Attempt for Lewis's Team
description: Carl Lewis, Leroy Burrell and two of their Santa Monica Track Club teammates will try for a world record in the 400-meter relay Saturday at the Mount San Antonio College Relays.

title: L.B. Foster Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chambers Development Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mortgage & Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included reorganization expenses of $ 2,538,000 for the quarter and $ 4,761,000 for the 6 months.c-Net income

title: Lincoln Scholar Rebuts Charges of Plagiarism
description: Stephen B. Oates, a scholar who has written biographies of William Faulkner, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Nat Turner, is waging an unusually visible counterattack against charges that he plagiarized portions of his 1977 biography of Abraham Lincoln.

title: Laclede Steel reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: 5 in Houston Family Die
description: A 42-year-old man made his four children stand in a row behind the family's dining room table on Thursday, then photographed them and killed them with a .45-caliber pistol before committing suicide, the police said today. The father, Chung Dinh Vu, a carpenter, was apparently distraught because his wife had left him earlier in the week.

title: No G.E. Bid for Goldome
description: The GE Capital Corporation said yesterday that it would no longer consider making a bid for Goldome, the troubled Buffalo savings bank.

title: Key Rates
IBP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net incomeIBP said operating results were affected in the first quarter by a non-cash charge of $ 2.8 million as a result of the effects of amortization of goodwill and related items.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Bo's Sore at Royals
description: BO JACKSON said yesterday that he wasn't sure when he would play baseball again but that he was sure of one thing: he got a raw deal from the Kansas City Royals.

title: A New Money Order Resistant to Tampering
description: Postal money orders were created "to promote public convenience and to insure greater security in the transfer of money through the United States mails," according to the act of Congress that established them in 1864. But incidents of counterfeiting and tampering with money orders have cost consumers $3.2 million in the last two fiscal years.

title: Bridge
description: In bygone days Benito Garozzo won 13 world team titles as a member of Italy's famed Blue Team. Since he is now a permanent United States resident, living in Palm Beach, Fla., it is not unlikely that he will someday win again representing his adopted country.

title: Review/Dance; Several Battles of the Sexes
description: Pam Quinn and Michael O'Connor began their program at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater on Thursday night on a relatively abstract note with a plotless new duet performed in silence and called "Untitled." But even here, in this fluid and complex weave of shifting dynamics and overarching movement sequences, there was the sense until the dance's last moments of two magnets drawing together despite an irresistible pull apart.

title: Critic's Notebook; Solti and the Heyday of the Blockbuster
description: With all due respect to the citizenry of Chicago, it is poetically just that Sir Georg Solti's 22-year tenure as music director of the Chicago Symphony should have ended in New York, last evening, rather than in Chicago. The Solti-Chicago phenomenon of the early 1970's, which has since lost some of its luster, owed much to the orchestra's sensational concerts in Carnegie Hall and the publicity they generated. As a transplanted Midwesterner who came east in 1970, I recall not only the clamorous enthusiasm that greeted the orchestra and its new maestro at the time in Carnegie, but also the relatively restrained reception accorded them on comparable evenings at Orchestra Hall in Chicago.

title: Colgate-Palmolive reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dominion Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1990 first quarter earnings included a one-time gain from the sale of its Virginia natural gas subsidiary.The company also said its Virginia power unit accounted for 98 cents and non-utility operations accounted for 3 cents of the $ 1.01 a share it earned in the the 1990 first quarter.

title: Trenton Relaxes Rules for Voting By the Homeless
description: The New Jersey Attorney General issued a formal opinion today confirming the right of homeless people to vote, even if they cannot meet requirements for establishing residences like arranging to pick up their mail at post offices or shelters.

title: U.S. Plans Seat-Belt Ticket Campaign
description: The police in about 1,000 cities and towns across the country are planning summer campaigns to ticket drivers who do not wear seat belts or do not put children in safety seats.

title: A Top Comsat Official Is Promoted to President
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation yesterday named Bruce L. Crockett president and chief operating officer. He has been with the company for 11 years and was president of Comsat's largest unit.

title: Durr-Fillauer Medical Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Airline Rescue Is Opposed
description: The Government should encourage competition among airlines rather than rescue the troubled industry or regulate fares again, the investigative arm of Congress asserts.

title: Borden Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ailing School District Files for Bankruptcy
description: A debt-ridden Northern California school district today became only the second school system in the state ever to seek protection in Federal bankruptcy court.

title: Salem Carpet Mills reports earnings for 13wks to March 30
description: b-Net income

title: Gabriel Celaya, Poet, 80
description: Gabriel Celaya, a poet and essayist who became a leader of literary protest against the dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco, died on Thursday in a Madrid hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: Business and Rights Groups Fail In Effort to Draft Bill on Job Bias
description: In the face of strong opposition from the White House and small businesses, an effort by leading corporations and civil rights groups to draft a job discrimination bill collapsed today.

title: Shirmax Fashions reports earnings for Year to Jan 26
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 668,000.c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 917,000.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Apartment Dwellers Prepare for Service Workers' Strike
description: Negotiators began round-the-clock talks for a new contract yesterday as apartment owners completed preparations to do their own building chores while a strike deadline of 12:01 A.M. Sunday drew near for 25,000 doormen, porters, elevator operators and other service workers.

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 37,754,000, or 47 cents a share.Share earnings are calculated after the effect of payment of $ 10,571,000 in preferred and preference share dividends in the latest quarter and payments totaling $ 9,373,000 in the 1990 quarter.

title: Silcorp Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Baker Tells Israelis of Need for Basic Compromises
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told Israeli leaders today that they were going to have to consider a series of fundamental compromises with the Arabs if they wanted to see a Middle East peace conference convened.

title: What Does a Nobel Prize Mean Anyhow?; Jerusalem Award
description: To the Editor:

title: Irwin N. Alberts, Executive, 57
description: Irwin N. Alberts, a publishing executive, died on Thursday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 57 years old.

title: Carpenter Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 4.3 million for increased costs estimates to close the company's Bridgeport, Conn., plant.

title: Barnes Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reporter's Spouse, Under Court Order, Names Chief as News Source
description: Under court order to testify in a case with implications on press freedom, the husband of a Washington Post reporter has identified the city's Chief of Police as one of his wife's confidential news sources.

title: Patents; An Electric Blanket for Premature Babies
description: William C. McCormack, a retired pediatrician in Ames, Iowa, this week patented an electrical blanket for premature infants.

title: Cocaine Use and Infant Mortality Decline Together in New York City
description: A decline in the use of cocaine by pregnant women and improved prenatal care last year helped significantly reduce infant mortality in New York City for the first time in four years, city and state health officials said yesterday.

title: Feuds Crippling Yugoslav Economy
description: When the nations of Eastern Europe began their unsteady march toward a market economy in January 1990, Yugoslavia was regarded as having some of the best prospects. Many of its worker-managed factories were already exporting goods to Western Europe, and with the region's largest per-capita income, Yugoslavia had the most prosperous domestic market.

title: INSIDE
description: Rep. Udall Stepping Down

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of construction work at the Lincoln Tunnel, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey warned motorists of delays from this morning through 5 A.M. Monday.

title: Gehl Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income

title: Peanuts, Cracker Jacks, Calculators
description: For more than a century, baseball has treated its statistics as an indispensable part of the sport, a report card for its more than 10,000 players. Even 100 years ago, with professional baseball in its infancy, box scores served as daily companions to newspaper accounts of the games.

title:
BASEBALL;
Ted and Joe, 1941: APRIL 18
Carter Hawley Is Said to Plan Consolidation
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the West Coast's largest retailer, is expected to announce next week the consolidation of two of its California department store chains, retail executives said yesterday.

title: U.S. Is Prepared to Aid Kurdish Refugees in Iran
description: The United States is prepared to make a substantial contribution to the effort to help feed and shelter Kurdish refugees fleeing from Iraq to Iran, Administration officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Airlines, Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, a subsidiary of AMR Corp., named P. Jackson Bell senior vice president-planning.

title:
SPORTS LEISURE;
Toddlers Who Take a Dip Before a First Step
description: For 45 of his 66 years, Murray Callan has been teaching children to swim, and most of them come to him before they are 3 years old.

title: Patents; A Composition for Use In Food and Cosmetics
description: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology obtained a patent this week for a composition produced by bacteria that has possible uses in food and cosmetics as well as in waste-water treatment.

title: U.N. Says Its Forces Can't Care for Iraqi Refugees in Southern Zone
description: United Nations peacekeeping forces will not take full control of the demilitarized zone between Kuwait and Iraq for up to three weeks, and even then they will not care for the 50,000 refugees now in camps at the border, the chief of the United Nations forces said today.

title: Alexander & Baldwin reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 28.4 million, or 62 cents a share, from property sale.

title: Couple Complain of Hijack Joke
description: A newlywed couple has filed a complaint with USAir saying they cut short their Florida honeymoon after being upset by flight attendants who impersonated Arab terrorists and staged a prank hijacking aboard a flight from Pittsburgh to West Palm Beach.

title: Devorah Heller, 52, Negotiator for Schools
description: Devorah Heller, the director of employee relations for the Yonkers public school system, died on Monday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. She was 52 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Music in Review; Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center
description: Alice Tully Hall

title: McDonnell Douglas reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2 million, or 5 cents a share.

title: VW Reaches Accord for Skoda Stake
description: Resolving an 11th-hour dispute, Volkswagen A. G. has closed what appears to be the biggest Western investment deal in Eastern Europe by buying a majority share in Skoda, the Czechoslovak auto maker.

title: The Court Abuses the Great Writ
description: For centuries, the writ of habeas corpus has been a glorious exemplar of the rule of law, a mighty piece of legal paper that calls kings and jailers to produce their prisoners and demonstrate the legality of their detention. The Great Writ is, however, also subject to abuse, notably by prison inmates who file blatantly frivolous claims for release.

title: Nichols Institute reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Way Out of the CUNY Impasse
description: One of the most painful signs of New York City's fiscal crisis is the proposed tuition increase at the City University. In protest, students have occupied buildings at most of CUNY's 18 campuses. But there is no guarantee that a large tuition increase will raise revenue if it decreases enrollment among students of modest means.

title: Herbert I. Calman, Dentist, 77
description: Dr. Herbert I. Calman, an educator and dentist in Manhattan for more than 45 years, died yesterday at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Sterling Capital reports earnings for As of March 31
Corrections
description: A chart in the sports pages on Thursday comparing the performances of Ted Williams and Joe DiMaggio in 1941 included an erroneous block of text about DiMaggio. A corrected version appears today on page 30.

title: Red Square Pilot Convicted of Stabbing a Student Nurse
description: Mathias Rust, who astonished the world by flying a small plane to Red Square in Moscow in 1987, was convicted today of attempted manslaughter for stabbing a student nurse who spurned his advances.

title: Mr. Carey's Bad Example Made Worse
description: A budgetary gimmick rashly adopted by Gov. Hugh Carey more than a decade ago is coming back to haunt New York State as it struggles to close a huge budget deficit. The episode provides timely warning that gimmicks are seldom a sound solution to the budget shortfalls that afflict New York and many other states.

title: What Does a Nobel Prize Mean Anyhow?; Few for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Music in Review; Alvin Lucier
description: Merkin Concert Hall 129 West 67th Street

title: Patents; Producing A Seedless Watermelon
description: Researchers at the University of Florida obtained a patent this week on a way to breed seeds for seedless watermelons that they say is far quicker and cheaper than methods in use.

title: Spring Cleaning: Medicine Cabinets
description: Medicine cabinets need spring cleaning as much as closets do. Half-used containers of after-shave lotion, hair cream, lipstick, eye shadow and moisturizer have a way of cluttering shelves for months, even years. Some products hold up; others do not. The question is which to toss out, and when.

title: BankAmerica's Eastward Push
description: When the BankAmerica Corporation was reeling from losses a few years ago, executives renounced their global ambitions and said they would concentrate on retail banking in California and the West.

title: Investigation of D'Amato's Brother Nearing End
description: Federal prosecutors investigating the brother of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York in connection with an influence-peddling scheme are near the end of their inquiry and are weighing whether the brother, Armand P. D'Amato, committed a crime, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Thomas Connolly, 91, Archbishop in Seattle
description: Thomas A. Connolly, a retired Archbishop of Seattle who was the oldest Roman Catholic bishop in the United States, died Thursday at his home here. He was 91 years old and had been in poor health for several years.

title: IRAQI REPORT SAYS CHEMICAL ARSENAL SURVIVED THE WAR
description: Iraq has informed the United Nations that a substantial arsenal of chemical and ballistic weapons survived the Persian Gulf war, but it denies having nuclear arms, nuclear-weapons-grade materials or biological weapons, according to documents made public today.

title: Ashland Coal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush's Education Vision
description: After two years of criticism that President Bush had failed to honor his pledge to be "the education President," he has finally sketched his vision for improving American schools. Now the President must prove that his answers are feasible and fair.

title: Gay Head Journal; A Town With History, but Whose?
description: This is an Indian town. Its primary residents and elected officials have almost always been members of the Wampanoag tribe. But you'd never suspect the town's rich Indian history from looking at its English name.

title: 5 Drown as Boat With Dominicans Capsizes
description: At least five people drowned today when a 20-foot motorboat loaded with more than 70 Dominicans capsized and sank in rough seas off the coast of this small western Puerto Rican port.

title: The Barnes Explores Other Byways
description: The news did not come as a surprise to those who have been keeping an eye on the Barnes Foundation, but that did not make it any less alarming. The trustees, who oversee the extraordinary collection of mostly Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art put together by the late Dr. Albert C. Barnes, petitioned a Pennsylvania court last month for the right to go against his wishes -- and the advice of several advisers -- and sell up to 15 paintings. One can only hope that the court will reject that request, and that the trustees will be persuaded to lay out a more prudent course.

title: Women's Hoops: More TV Time
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jaime Butterman Weds
description: Jaime Butterman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Weingarten of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., was married last night to Dr. Adam Goodman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Goodman of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Stuart Geller performed the ceremony at the Woodmere (L.I.) Country Club. Mrs. Goodman, 27 years old, is a financial consultant at Lehman Brothers in New York. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Goodman, 27, is a dentist in the Bronx. He graduated from the State University at Albany and received a D.M.D. degree from Penn.

title: Amy C. Roskin to Marry
description: Drs. Gerald and Joan Roskin of Roslyn, L.I., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Amy Catherine Roskin and George Michael Pushner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Pushner of New London, Conn. The couple, both 26 years old, graduated from Princeton University. She is completing her final year at New York University Medical School. Mr. Pushner, who has a master's degree in economics and public affairs from Princeton, is in a doctoral program in business economics at Columbia University.

title: Israel's Farming Success Drains It of Water
description: Israel, having made the desert bloom, a proud early achievement, is now counting the costs of its remarkable development of agriculture. It finds this symbol of national success withering.

title: Q and A
description: Short-Term Jobs Abroad

title: M.L.A. CONVENTION
description: As a professor of literature and a member of the Modern Language Association, I suppose I should be pleased that so many people take an interest in current trends in the humanities. Still, I am amazed at times by the vehemence with which changes in scholarly interest and even the smallest modifications in curriculums are attacked. Apparently, many feel that the titles of M.L.A. convention seminars should directly reflect the titles of English courses they took in college 20 years ago.

title: A New Battle On School Segregation
description: OVERLOOKING a broad lawn on quiet, tree-lined Knickerbocker Road, the stately Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood seems an unlikely hub of controversy. But it has become the centerpiece of a renewed assault on racial segregation in the state's public schools.

title:
FOOTBALL;
Seattle or New England Would Please McGwire
description: Dan McGwire likes the idea of living in the Pacific Northwest or New England and playing football next year for either the Seahawks or the Patriots.

title: In the Sun
description: To the Editor: I read with delight Kathleen Rockwell Lawrence's article "The Dark Side of the Sun" (Travel, March 10).

title:
THE VIEW FROM: ST. THOMAS EPISCOPAL CHURCH;
Debate on Helping Those in Need
description: THE REV. WILLIAM A. KOLB of St. Thomas Episcopal Church here says it is a way to fulfill a mission to help people in need. Members of the Mamaroneck Historical Society say they fear that it might violate the integrity of a structure that has been standing since 1865.

title: Headliners; Being Green
description: The Walt Disney Company stands accused of illegal use of a frog and a pig, both unlicensed. Henson Associates Inc., which owns rights to Kermit the Frog, Miss Piggy and other members of the Muppets crew, last week filed suit in Manhattan, charging Disney with "outright theft" in the sale of "counterfeit merchandise with Muppet characters." Along with unspecified damages, the Henson company wants to halt the scheduled opening next month of a new Walt Disney World attraction, MuppetVision 3-D. Disney officials say Jim Henson, the Muppet creator, let the company use his characters during merger talks between their company and his. After Mr. Henson's sudden death last year, Disney continued to use the characters while negotiating with his heirs. There was no "rush to sign a piece of paper," said a Disney spokesman. After merger talks collapsed last week, the Hensons sued. "All the people who worked for and loved my father are outraged," said Mr. Henson's son, Brian.

title:
TELEVISION;
'Here's a Story About a Bunch Called Brady . . . '
description: The lines are long, but people still wait patiently outside the Annoyance Theater here for tickets to "The Real Live Brady Bunch." The play, which is a reenactment of episodes from the popular television show that ran from 1969 to 1974, has been playing to sold-out houses at the 110-seat Annoyance since last June.

title: Another Franklin Legacy Revived
description: IN 1761, Benjamin Franklin, fascinated by the musical sounds that wine glasses produced when filled with water and gently rubbed around the edge, decided to apply his Yankee ingenuity to this European craze.

title: Campus Life: Oklahoma; Dinosaur Bones Arise Through Aid of a Grant
description: Nicholas Czaplewski applied gray cement about the consistency of peanut butter to a break in the 150-million-year-old sauropod neck bone. After smearing the goo with a Popsicle stick, he carefully fitted the broken fossil pieces together.

title: National Parks
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Dialing for Space in the National Parks" (Practical Traveler, March 17), last summer my traveling companions and I, along with many other visitors, were put on a waiting list at a supposedly fully reserved campsite on the North Rim of the Grand Canyon. We got a space later, after several people canceled their reservations, but not all those waiting were so lucky and we were surprised to find many open sites at this "full" campground -- empty both in the evening and the next morning.

title: A Man of Unspeakable Thoughts
description: BRINGING DOWN THE GREAT WALL Writings on Science, Culture, and Democracy in China. By Fang Lizhi. Edited by James H. Williams. Translated by James H. Williams and others. Introduction by Orville Schell. 336 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Schwarzkopf Leaves Gulf, Describing the Mission as Completed
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, ended his tour in Saudi Arabia today, acknowledging that he was disappointed that Saddam Hussein was still in power in Iraq but saying that the military had completed its mission of freeing Kuwait.

title: People Should Live Closer to Mass Transit
description: The article "Out of Love and Necessity, Cars Boom on L.I." [ March 31 ] on the increased use of automobiles on Long Island points up what is going to become an unprecedented problem in the not-too-distant future. This problem, pointed out by a British land-planning expert who visited Long Island last year, is the eventual need to tear down a great deal of housing and build new, more densely compacted housing units.

title: Amy Hochfelder Wed To Steven Michael Ball
description: Amy Hochfelder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Hochfelder of Old Westbury, L.I., was married last evening at the Glen Head (L.I.) Country Club to Steven Michael Ball, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome E. Ball of New York. Rabbi Aaron Petuchowski and Cantor Andrew Edison officiated.

title: Headliners; Making No Bones
description: Members of the Skull and Bones society at Yale University gave their alumni something to gnaw on last weekend. On Tap Day, when juniors crowd into a courtyard in hopes of being literally tapped for membership in one of Yale's secret societies, some senior Bonesmen actually tapped women. It was not exactly a surprise. The Bonesmen had forewarned their alumni, President Bush among them, in a letter expressing the sort of anti-elitist feelings that have diminished the cachet of college secret societies generally. Letting women in, they said, might help change that. Well, maybe. In the meantime, however, the Rev. Sidney Lovett, secretary of the Bones's parent organization and apparently on its orders, nullified the selection of new members and shut the club down for the coming year. Just in case, he also locked up the crypt where the Bonesmen are rumored to keep such famous bones as the skull of Pancho Villa. This to "prevent or discourage unauthorized efforts to change the society's traditions."

title: Privacy of Woman in Rape Case Was Invaded; Not Just Statistics
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Will Giants Pick? Someone Who Can Play
description: When the Giants make their first-round choice in the National Football League draft today, they will take a badly needed wide receiver. Or a tight end who can block. Or a quarterback for the future or a backup fullback for now. Or an outside linebacker who can rush the passer. Or a defensive back because a team can never have enough backs who can blanket receivers.

title: A. J. Lafaire Weds Regina T. Meade
description: Regina Teresa Meade and Anthony Joseph Lafaire were married yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. Joseph P. Nagle, the Rev. Charles A. Guarino, the Rev. S. B. Matarazzo and the Rev. James C. Meade, who is an uncle of the bride.

title: Iran Offers Assistance on Lebanon Hostages
description: An Iranian Deputy Foreign Minister told a visiting British official today that Iran would use its influence to help secure the release of Western hostages in Lebanon. But President Hashemi Rafsanjani denied that his country supported or maintained any link to the Lebanese hostage takers.

title: Privacy of Woman in Rape Case Was Invaded; Counseling Center
description: To the Editor:

title: What It Means to Be Sick
description: AT THE WILL OF THE BODY

title: Chess
description: It is not out of the question to cope with an opponent's surprise -- after all, the Cuban genius Jose Raul Capablanca defeated the Marshall Gambit the first time that Frank Marshall, the United States champion from 1909 to 1936, revealed it to the world, in 1918 at the Manhattan Chess Club. But, by and large, surprises disturb the opponent's equilibrium.

title: Florio and a Klan Leader Trade Accusations
description: In the wake of recruiting efforts by the Ku Klux Klan this month, Gov. Jim Florio has attacked the organization, not only for its white supremacist doctrines but also for its attempt to use the state's economic problems and his tax and gun control policies to win converts.

title: Israel, Distressed by Twists in Peace Initiative, Feels Pressure
description: Only hours after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d left Israel this morning, Government officials began saying they feared that his peace initiative might fail, and that they would get the blame.

title: Joanne Barry Marries Peter Joseph Spellane
description: Joanne Barry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Barry of Douglaston, Queens, was married there yesterday to Peter Joseph Spellane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Spellane of Mystic, Conn. The Rev. Joseph N. Grisaitis performed the ceremony at St. Anastasia Roman Catholic Church.

title: Suspect in Egyptian's Killing Escapes From a Police Van
description: A man held in connection with the killing of the Speaker of Egypt's Parliament, Rifaat al-Mahgoub, escaped from a police van on Friday while being driven from one prison to another, Interior Ministry officials said today.

title: Protesters in CUNY Building Defy a Deadline
description: A court deadline for protesters to leave a building at the Borough of Manhattan Community College passed at noon yesterday with the students saying they feared the arrival of the police, but the City University of New York saying it had no immediate plans to call in officers.

title: TV's 'Most Wanted' Brings Arrest in Killing of Ex-Brooklyn Senator
description: A man being hunted in the shooting death of former State Senator Vander L. Beatty in Brooklyn last August was arrested on Friday night in Chicago after a viewer saw his picture on the television show "America's Most Wanted" and tipped off the police, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Headliners; Making Repairs on a Faulty Census Count
description: THE Census Bureau last week unveiled the numbers that are supposed to serve both as the report card for the 1990 census and the tool for fixing it. Now statisticians are trying to decide if it can serve both functions.

title: Housatonic (PCB's and All) Wins Fame for Its Trout
description: FISHING is good on most of the Housatonic River but anglers say a nine-mile stretch between Cornwall Bridge and Lime Rock offers some of the finest trout fishing anywhere. This section of the river, where any fish caught must be thrown back alive, is rated by many sport fishermen as comparable to legendary trout streams like the Beaver Kill in New York, the Madison in Montana and the Yellowstone in Wyoming.

title: In Greenwich, Italian Style and Service
description: TO the saying "You can never be too rich or too thin," one is tempted to add "or have too many Italian restaurants."

title: IN SHORT/SCIENCE
description: BORROWED EARTH, BORROWED TIME Healing America's Chemical Wounds. By Glenn E. Schweitzer. Plenum, $27.50.

title:
Back Talk;
Too Early a Retirement for Digger
description: I think that more than anything else, Digger Phelps felt betrayed.

title: Karen Young Is Bride Of Henry E. Hamel 3d
description: Karen Leslie Young, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Young of New York, was married yesterday at Corpus Christi Church in New York to Henry E. Hamel 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamel Jr. of South Orange, N.J. Msgr. Myles M. Bourke and Msgr. Philip D. Morris performed the ceremony.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: DIVING Breaking New Water Mark Lenzi yesterday became the first person in the history of diving to crack the 100-point mark on a single dive, accomplishing the feat on his final effort to win the 3-meter springboard title at the United States indoor championships in Minneapolis. Lenzi's 101.85 points on a reverse 3 1/2-somersault from the tuck position shattered the 1983 record of 99.00 points set by Greg Louganis on a 1 1/2-somersault with 3 1/2 twists. It was the first national title for the 22-year-old from Fredericksburg, Va. (AP) BOXING Bowe Beats Tubbs Riddick Bowe, an undefeated heavyweight, won a unanimous 10-round decision over Tony Tubbs at Harrah's casino hotel in Atlantic City yesterday. But Bowe looked unimpressive, fighting as though transfixed by the other man's minimalist style. Judges Frank Cairo (96-94), Richard Strange (96-94) and Jean Williams (97-94) all had it for Bowe, who gained his 23d victory in a row. The decision was loudly booed by the crowd. The early rounds saw Tubbs use feints and footwork in an attempt to hit Bowe and run. Tubbs was only modestly successful in landing serious punches, but his cautious style was catching. Bowe's record is now 23-0 with 20 knockouts. Tubbs is 30-3 with 19 knockouts. TENNIS Jaite and Prpic in Final Martin Jaite of Argentina and Goran Prpic of Yugoslavia won semifinal matches yesterday in the Nice Open in France to set up a final between unseeded players. Jaite came from behind to down sixth-seeded Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, 4-6, 6-4, 7-6. Prpic routed a French wild-card entry, Cedric Pioline, 6-1, 6-3. (AP) ROWING Harvard Wins Again In another smooth effort, the Harvard men's heavyweight crew won the Compton Cup from Princeton and Massachusetts Institute of Technology yesterday on the Potomac River in Washington. The unbeaten Crimson eight, winning its third race of the season, beat Princeton by a convincing boat length and M.I.T. by six in the fast time of 5 minutes 53.3 seconds on the 2,000-meter course. TRACK AND FIELD Bid for Record Fails The Santa Monica Track Club's top sprinters failed to take the world 400-meter relay record from France yesterday in the 33d Mount San Antonio Relays at Walnut, Calif. Nevertheless, Mike Marsh, Larry Burrell, Carl Lewis and Mark Witherspoon finished in 38.33 seconds, the fastest time in the world this year. The record is 37.79. (AP) BOWLING First Title for Young Billy Young earned his first Professional Bowlers Association title with a come-from-behind victory in the Tums Classic yesterday in Windsor Locks, Conn. Young got by David D'Entremont in the title match, 203-201. "The key to the match was the ball change I made in the sixth frame," Young said. "It was the same ball I used all week to lead the tournament by 304 pins." (AP)

title: An Edwardian on the Concorde: Graham Greene as I Knew Him
description: 'm afraid that at the moment my health is pretty lousy," Graham Greene wrote to me not long ago from his hospital bed in Vevey, Switzerland. "I am not supposed to drink at all which is painful and my days seem taken up with blood transfusions, vitamin injections and four different kinds of pill. I suppose one could expect worse at my age."

Eifert of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Franklin Montross 4th, the son of Joan Oliver Montross of Bedford and Franklin Montross 3d of Boston. The Rev. William E. Foley, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Jack Silvey Miller, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: An Edwardian on the Concorde: Graham Greene as I Knew Him
description: "I'm afraid that at the moment my health is pretty lousy," Graham Greene wrote to me not long ago from his hospital bed in Vevey, Switzerland. "I am not supposed to drink at all which is painful and my days seem taken up with blood transfusions, vitamin injections and four different kinds of pill. I suppose one could expect worse at my age."

title: THE MILITARY VS. THE PRESS
description: Despite the constraints and frustrations that Browne inveighs against, the fact is that he and his colleagues did a credible job reporting the gulf war. The news got out, and First Amendment rights were preserved. Pool reporting is no joy to professionals in the news media. But clamping down on 1,000 get-the-story reporters may just have saved us from 999 Bob Simon episodes. ROBERT B. CECIL Herndon, Va.

title: Flash Gordon Is Merciless to Yanks
description: By the end of the day, only one thought seemed to linger in the Yankee clubhouse: the image of Tom Gordon, the Kansas City pitcher, throwing curves and sliders and fastballs into the cold, dreary afternoon.

title: County Changes Its Mind on Disposal of Sludge
description: MUCH of the county's sludge would be dried and sent to a West Virginia landfill, rather than be incinerated in Peekskill, under a tentative plan announced last week by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title:
Back Talk;
Too Early a Retirement for Digger
description: I think that more than anything else, Digger Phelps felt betrayed.

title: Business Diary/April 14-19
description: COMPANIES Judging from the rally in banking stocks last week, it would appear that defaults and delinquencies are a receding worry. But not necessarily. Several banks, including Chase Manhattan and some regionals like First Fidelity, posted sharp gains in their first-quarter profits -- a product of cost-cutting, the slowing growth of bad loans and falling interest rates. Falling rates enable banks to make money on the spread between what they pay depositors and what they charge borrowers, whose rates are not adjusted as quickly. These spreads are now their widest in years, bankers say, because they need to earn more on their good customers to make up for all the bad ones. But these benefits didn't buttress all banks. Chemical Bank, NCNB and Manfacturers Hanover all saw earnings slip. And Citicorp suffered the most. Its profits plunged 70 percent in the first quarter, to a bare $70 million. While bad real estate loans were the bane of bankers early in the downturn, souring consumer loans are a worry as the recession matures. They were to blame for the disappointing quarter at Citicorp, the nation's largest issuer of credit cards and home mortgages. So why the stock rally? The earnings held none of the surprises -- dividend cuts and big additions to loan loss reserves -- that accompanied earlier quarters.

title: Travel Advisory; A Rare Glimpse Of Old Planes
description: Airplane buffs will be able to take a behind-the-scenes look at more than 150 rarely seen planes and spacecraft in the National Air and Space Museum's collection next Saturday and Sunday, when the museum holds its 10th annual "Wings and Things" open house at the Paul E. Garber Facility, just outside Washington in Suitland, Md.

title: THE ROMANIAN BABY BAZAAR
description: I don't know who makes me sicker -- the baby brokers, the fathers who quote prices on their unborn children, the orphanage directors, the Romanian Government or the adopting couples.

title: Tests Find Electric Pulse Signals Heart Attack
description: In research on dogs, scientists studying electrical currents in the heart say they have found a pattern that predicts sudden cardiac death.

title: Viola's Ugly Bat Turns Into a Beauty
description: If you are a pitcher for the Mets, it is not enough to report to work with your fastball, changeup and curve. The state of the team's offense requires that your bat be one of the chief tools of your trade, as well.

title: Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor: Although we appreciated Ruth E. Gruber's article on the Slovak city of Bratislava("Charm and Concrete in Bratislava," Travel, March 10), we couldn't help noticing that "Getting There" omitted some important information: namely, that travelers can also reach the city by air -- especially via CSA, Czechoslovakia's national airline.

title: Football Survey: No Deaths in 1990
description: There were no deaths nationwide directly attributable to injuries received on the football field during the 1990 season, according to a study conducted at the University of North Carolina.

title: Wall Street; Looking for a Winner as the Railroads Roll Again
description: The railroads are rolling again after last week's brief strike. Tough labor issues remain, but that did not deter George O. Zimmermann, a Gruntal & Company analyst, from recommending the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation, owner of the euphonious Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe line.

title: Topics of The Times; Living Color
description: New York is not a colorful city. The skyscrapers are mostly gray, with the occasional beige exception, and the sky, while often blue, is a long way from the true azure.

title: He Told Us So
description: BEGIN HERE

title: Pride in Victory Lingers, if Clouded by Middle East Chaos and Kurds' Agony
description: There are still yellow ribbons around many of the oaks on the University of Mississippi campus and Desert Storm bumper stickers on cars. The annual Fourth of July celebration will pay tribute to all the men and women in Oxford and surrounding communities who served in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Carpe Diem Becomes Hot Advice
description: Here is the bad news about the afterlife, according to Albert Brooks: it is just as annoying as this life, at least for the first few days. There are lawyers after death and people who get better hotel rooms than you do and little old ladies on buses who talk your ear off about their pet poodles. When you die you go to Judgment City, an earthlike place where they have dead-Kiwanis meetings and stand-up comics in plaid sport jackets. They have the Weather Channel, with the Muzak version of "Misty" playing in the background.

title: Abstinence Was Out of the Question
description: CURES

title: Jane D. Bernholz, An Editor, Weds
description: Jane Donnelly Bernholz and Christian Hartwell Maltby were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by the Rev. William F. Starr, an Episcopal priest. The bride, 25 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Bernholz of New York and Lloyd Neck, L.I. The bridegroom, 27, is a son of Ruth Maltby of Port Washington, L.I., and Thomas W. Maltby of New York.

title: 2 Youths Die; 3 Families Are Haunted
description: On Friday, 16-year-old Melvyn Longmire and 18-year-old Lyndell Louallen tumbled dead onto the cold tile floor of B & B Hardware, bleeding from the holes bullets had torn in their heads.

title: Making a Difference; Laddie Is Back in the Saddle Again at MGM
description: When your father is a famous actor, it is perhaps inevitable that you will take an interest in movies. But few children of Hollywood have done so well for themselves in the entertainment industry as Alan Ladd Jr., who last week was placed firmly in charge of the MGM-Pathe Communications Corporation, the latest incarnation of the fabled Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio.

title: Philharmonia Virtuosi Opts for Smaller Scale
description: THE budget cutbacks that have so seriously afflicted the arts all over the country are wreaking havoc in Westchester, too. For the first time in its 15-year history in the county, the Philharmonia Virtuosi has been forced to substitute chamber for orchestral music at today's 3 P.M. subscription concert at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: G. L. Hoffman Weds Dana Lerner in Buffalo
description: Dana Lee Lerner, a daughter of Allan S. Lerner of New York and Mrs. Robert O. Swados of Buffalo, was married in Buffalo yesterday to Gregory Lyman Hoffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Lewis Hoffman of Clarence, N.Y. Justice Penny Wolfgang of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the 20th Century Club.

title: Topics of The Times; The Craftsman
description: Who was Homer Bigart? American reporters of middle or advanced years would likely say that he was an ornament of his trade. Mr. Bigart, who died Tuesday at 83, would not have called it a "profession." Just as a master carpenter unerringly senses the grain of the wood, this joiner of words crafted sentences with invisible seams that gave shape and coherence to chaotic happenings. It is no mean gift, and Mr. Bigart's skill earned him a brace of Pulitzers and the esteem of his colleagues.

title: THE MILITARY VS. THE PRESS
description: I did not mind seeing Toyota Land Cruisers chauffeuring the press to our field mess, wearing and dragging military clothes and gear that many marines were never issued. (Browne's issue of atropine injectors and Valium at the Dhahran International Hotel was three times mine at the Kuwaiti border.) Most marines were excited by and welcomed the press. They represent, for servicemen, an important connection with the United States: civilians telling our stories for families and friends. And yes, America had a right to information about a war that involved so many of its people. But a reporter's need to claim that he got "something meatier than the briefings" is just not a good enough reason to risk troops not returning to tell the stories themselves. T. J. SULLIVAN First Lieutenant, United States Marine Corps Saudi Arabia
