title: Melissa Weissberg, Editor, Is Married
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music was the setting last evening for the marriage of Melissa Ivy Weissberg, the daughter of Elsa Weissberg and Judge Franklin R. Weissberg, both of New York, and Randall Edward Havas, a son of George P. Havas of Lafayette, Calif., and the late Nancy A. Havas. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. to Open an M.I.A. Office in Hanoi
description: The United States has agreed to establish its first official presence in Vietnam, President Bush's special envoy for humanitarian affairs said here today.

title: Lynne L. Loposer Married To Robert Matthew Weber
description: Lynne Louise Loposer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dan Loposer of Jackson, Miss., was married last evening at Christ United Methodist Church in Jackson to Robert Matthew Weber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Weber of Hartsdale, N.Y. Cantor Lawrence Goldberg and the Rev. Tom Artmann, a Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Yale Study Measuring Radon's Link to Cancer
description: NOT far from the Guilford neighborhood where the state's highest radon level was recorded, the Yale University School of Medicine is studying the link between exposure to radon in the home and the development of cancer.

title: Mix-and-Match Music for a Zap! Age
description: On a Thursday afternoon at NBC's Studio 8H in Manhattan, Angelo Moore, Fishbone's lead singer, was swinging from the rafters. Wearing a natty sharkskin suit and pointed two-tone shoes rendered incongruous by his Mohawk haircut, he climbed amplifiers, strolled on a ledge and dangled from the steel girders of the "Saturday Night Live" set.

title: Bold Bespoke Shirts: A Gentleman's Tale
description: TO get an idea of a middle-aged man's self-image, you have only to look at his shirts. Most of us imagine ourselves the way we looked when we first started buying our own shirts, at about the age of 20. A few lucky ones can still wear the same size. Far more just think we can, and end up looking like the Michelin Man, cloth and buttons straining mightily to keep everything from getting out of hand, revealing instead that it has already.

title: David Fass to Marry Anne Weintraub
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Weintraub of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Weintraub, to David Victor Fass, a son of Elizabeth Fass of St. Louis Park, Minn., and Peter J. Fass of Larchmont. An October wedding is planned.

title: Can the Fire Catch On in Birmingham?
description: Bill Adams has been there for the Birmingham Americans of the World Football League and the Birmingham Stallions of the United States Football League, and no matter how dismal it gets, he will probably stick it out with the Birmingham Fire of the new World League of American Football.

title: Alzado Fighting Cancer
description: LYLE ALZADO, a former All-Pro defensive lineman in the National Football League, is undergoing treatment for inoperable brain cancer, his physician said yesterday in Los Angeles.

title: On-the-Job Training Goes Back to ABC's
description: THREE years ago, a worker at Dresser Industries in Stratford asked to be promoted but admitted he could not read. Soon after, another of the company's employees, who was unable to decipher a warning label, mixed a cleaning solution with acid and caused a co-worker to burn his hands.

title: DOWNTOWN COUSIN
description: My immediate reaction to Ti-Hua Chang's About Men column "Downtown Cousin" (March 17) was a mixture of outrage and concern -- outrage because my ethnic pride makes me resentful and defensive of any charge made against my race; concern because Chang has pried open an ugly but accurate account of the Chinese-American experience, a part that I share but hate to acknowledge to people of other races.

title: Dog Attacks Toddler and Bites Off His Arm
description: A 15-month-old boy was attacked by a dog that bit off his right arm just above the elbow on Friday, the police said.

title: Article 610091 -- No Title
description: In the largest libel judgment in American history, a jury here has awarded $58 million to a former District Attorney, finding that a Dallas television station recklessly defamed him in 1985 with a news series that accused him of taking payoffs for dropping drunken-driving cases.

title:
FORUM;
When the Pentagon Walks Away
description: On April 12, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney sent a shock wave through hundreds of American communities. He announced the closing of 31 major and 12 minor military bases and the "realignment" of 28 others. As a military budget reduction program proceeds, more of the nation's 889 bases will be vulnerable to closings.

title: The World; Feeding on 19th Century Conditions, Cholera Spreads in Latin America
description: WITH the specter of cholera hanging over the Dickensian slums of Latin America, a news magazine here recently reproduced a 19th-century engraving of the Thames alongside a modern-day photo of Lima's sewage-choked River Rimac. The resemblance was striking.

title: Irish Pub? No. The Specialty Is Seafood
description: PADDY McGEES says Irish Pub, but this six-year-old waterfront restaurant on Reynolds Channel in Island Park has been luring more than the burger and fries crowd with its tantalizing seafood specialties.

title: Martha Grace to Wed
description: George McKinstry Grace and Margaret WittmerGrace, both of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Moseley Grace, to Jeffrey Alexander Gordon, the son of John Alexander Gordon of Rehoboth, Del., and Kathleen Clark Gordon of Wilmington, Del. A September wedding is planned. Miss Grace, 30 years old, and her fiance, 26, are naturalists at the Victor Emanuel Company in Austin, Tex., which sponsors guided domestic and foreign tours for bird and wildlife enthusiasts. Miss Grace attended the University of Delaware, from which Mr. Gordon graduated.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. About five years ago, I painted my garage floor with a latex primer and then a coat of flat exterior latex. The appearance was fine, but the latex lifted off wherever the car's tires rested on it. A year later, I painted the floor again with a good grade of alkyd floor enamel, but the problem remained . One year later, I repeated this paint job, but with no better results. Last year, I cleaned and sanded the bare spots, then repainted with an epoxy. The problem was not quite as bad, although it is still there. Is there some special primer I should apply to the bare concrete spots to keep the paint from lifting?

title: MEDICARE TO WEIGH COST AS A FACTOR IN REIMBURSEMENT
description: In a fundamental shift, the Federal Government will explicitly weigh cost as a factor in deciding whether Medicare should pay for new medical procedures, devices and drugs for elderly people.

title: Planned Communities Are Multiplying
description: FOR Don Francis, the pieces could not have fallen together more perfectly: a new house high in the foothills of the Santa Ana mountains of Orange County, Calif., a job as vice president of a food company within walking distance of home, and an acclaimed 18-hole golf course practically at his back door.

title: Dutch Computer Rogues Infiltrate American Systems With Impunity
description: Beyond the reach of American law, a group of Dutch computer intruders have been openly defying United States military, space and intelligence authorities for almost six months. Recently they broke into a United States military computer while being filmed by a Dutch television station.

title: Public & Private; A Mistake
description: I put my notebook on the kitchen table and pointed to the top line.

title: Ideas & Trends; For Some Two-Paycheck Families, The Economics Don't Add Up
description: SHE wakes when the baby cries, gets the baby dressed and fed, then puts on her own blouse and suit ($340, plus $11 for dry-cleaning), snags her pantyhose ($2), waits for the baby sitter ($60 a day), crams into the subway ($1.15), picks up coffee and a bagel ($1), goes to the office, meets a friend for lunch ($7), goes back to work, then home on the subway ($1.15), picking up dinner at the gourmet deli ($12) because she won't have time to cook.

title: Size, Speed and Drive Emerge as Jet Standard
description: Size and speed. That's what the Jets need. They need it everywhere, specifically on the offensive line, the defensive line, at linebacker, at tight end, at quarterback.

title: Maradona's Last Game
description: The crowd and the competition may not have been what he has been accustomed to as captain of the Argentine national team and of the Napoli squad in Italy, but in a game with a local team in the Buenos Aires surburbs of San Vicente on Friday night, DIEGO MARADONA turned in a virtuoso performance.

title: In Landmarks Old, New and In-Between
description: A 20-foot-high model of the Eiffel Tower dominated the Plaza Hotel's ballroom at the French-American Foundation's dinner-dance on Wednesday. The foundation fosters political and cultural ties between the two countries.

title: Review/Theater; Wry Comedy By Moribund Playwright
description: It was Swinburne who advised "Take hand and part with laughter" (later vulgarized by George Michael Cohan into "Always leave them laughing"), and the French playwright Copi took them at their word in "Grand Finale," a comedy of the very blackest sort about an actor dying of AIDS.

title:
ART;
Painter, Known for 30's Works, Still Explores Epic Themes
description: WHEN American art of the 20th century before Abstract Expressionism becomes better known and understood, the work of Peter Blume will be a primary beneficiary. Mr. Blume, who is generally categorized as an American Surrealist, has a reputation that rests mainly on the strength of two paintings that stop viewers in their tracks: "South of Scranton," from 1931, in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and "The Eternal City," from 1937, in the Museum of Modern Art. The first painting is a fantasy, based on an automobile trip that Mr. Blume took from Scranton, Pa., to Charleston, S.C., while the second features a hideous green-faced Mussolini.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Stroudsburg, Pa.;
Adult Village Tripling Size
description: LABAR Village, an adult community on the site of a former rhododendron nursery in the Pocono Mountains, is undergoing a $70 million expansion that will triple its size to 573 units.

title: Lunch Without Peanut Butter
description: Peanut prices have doubled in the U.S. since summer, driving up the price of peanut butter, candy and baked products. That has forced the Agriculture Department to drop peanut butter -- an excellent cholesterol-free source of protein -- from the school lunch program.

title: Capture of a Terrorist
description: THE FIRST TIME I EVER HEARD OF Mohammed Rashid was my very first day on the job." It was March 30, 1984, that Victoria Toensing, a 42-year-old deputy assistant attorney general in the Justice Department, asked for the department's working files on antiterrorist investigations. There weren't many. And what cases there were lay dormant, even a promising-looking investigation into the activities of a certain Mohammed Rashid and the Baghdad-based group to which he belonged, the May 15 Organization.

title: You Will Lose What You Love
description: THE WAY THAT WATER ENTERS STONE

title: New York: Coasting on Self-Delusion?
description: To the Editor:

title: Will U.S. Currency Be Printed Overseas?
description: To the Editor:

title:
Making a Difference;
A Risky Game of Chicken for an Ailing Tucson Utility
description: Charles Bayless is uniquely qualified to do a daily dance on the brink of bankruptcy. He was a potent force as chief financial officer at the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the first utility since the Depression to seek bankruptcy protection, filing after regulators denied a rate increase in 1988.

title: Animal Instincts and Natural Powers
description: WOLFWATCHING

title: From Here to Eternity
description: LONELY HEARTS OF THE COSMOS The Scientific Quest for the Secret of the Universe. By Dennis Overbye. Illustrated. 438 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $25.

title: In Defense of Hackers
description: WHEN JOHN PERRY BARLOW picked up the phone at his home in Pinedale, Wyo., on a sunny morning last May, the last thing he expected was a call from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. But as a sometime writer and electronic gadfly who has been, among other things, a cattle rancher, Republican county chairman and, for 20 years, a lyricist for the rock band the Grateful Dead, he wasn't exactly surprised.

title: Studying Bush Plan, 2 Schools Back It for Different Reasons
description: Public School 51 and the Holy Cross School are just four blocks apart on the dreary fringes of Times Square. Many of their students are impoverished, and they speak a babel of foreign languages.

title:
ART;
Exuberance Coupled With Insight
description: CARMEN CICERO, a native of Newark, had his work displayed in the Guggenheim Museum's inaugural exhibition in 1959 in the company of stellar artists including Joan Miro, who later sent Mr. Cicero an original drawing saluting the young artist.

title: Correction
description: A chart in the Travel Advisory column on Feb. 24, about prices at Disneyland and Disney World, misstated the total cost of a cheeseburger, french fries and Coke at Disney World. The total for one person is $5.09, not $3.65, and for four people $20.36, not $14.60. A Disney World representative wrote to The Times in March about the error; the correction was delayed through an editing oversight.

title:
The Cultivated Gardener;
A Front Garden Brings Changes to a Home's Face
description: The front yard is the face a residence presents to the public. It sets the tone for the rest of the property and creates a setting for the house. A personal landscape is a friendly gesture to the neighborhood and welcomes visitors.

title: The Price of Admission?
description: To the Editor:

title: Style Makers; Myrna Hollinger, Wearable-Art Designer
description: To understand Myrna Hollinger's work, it helps to visit her disconcerting ranch house in Stamford, Conn.

title: High-Seas Reprieve of Atlantic Salmon
description: Champions of the Atlantic salmon are delighted with the news that high-seas harvesting of the species by boats from the Faeroe Islands has been halted. The Faeroes are a group of Danish islands in the North Atlantic between Iceland and the Shetland Islands.

title: Foreman Turns Defeat Into a Moral Victory
description: No more alarmism, please. The fat man, it turns out, can still fight. The only hitch is so can Evander Holyfield, the warrior in the contoured body.

title: After 40 Years, Racially Split Schools Are a Legacy of One Southern Town
description: The old whites-only high school is now an abandoned red brick hulk, but its ghosts still whisper and breathe, part of the indelible sense of race and turf that pervades this town where one of the most critical legal challenges to segregation began more than 40 years ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The same way we are worrying about the Kuwaitis should be extended to the Kurds. It's horribly wrong to see these poor souls dying in the mountains, clawing for bread from the back of trucks." -- Guillermo A. Chavarria, technical director for an architectural firm in New York. [ 14:3. ]

title: Privacy of Woman in Rape Case Was Invaded; 'An Occasion of Sin'
description: To the Editor:

title: Value Added Tax
description: To the Editor: As a frequent traveler to Europe, I have long held the impression that many countries have little or no interest in refunding V.A.T. collected from tourists, despite well-advertised tax-free offers.

title: Postings: Auctions in May; Battery Park Condo Sales
description: Developers of two condominiums in Battery Park City, the new residential neighborhood in lower Manhattan, are planning auctions to move slow-selling apartments.

title: Playing the Numbers
description: BEYOND NUMERACY Ruminations of a Numbers Man. By John Allen Paulos. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: Students Move From Art for the Client to Art for the Artist
description: ON Tuesday afternoons, Robin Smith of Greenwich doesn't worry about makeup displays, food advertisements or any of the other demands of her usual work as a graphic designer. Instead, she sits at an easel in a life-drawing class, tackling an altogether different set of challenges.

title: Tech Notes; Can Glass Keep the Fridge Cool?
description: A glass-ceramic sandwich may replace plastic foam as the insulation inside the walls of refrigerators if a concept developed by a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology proves to be practical.

title: All About/Music Videos; Making the Jump From MTV to the Retail Shelves
description: Music videos, once regarded as merely a way to promote albums, are experiencing something of a mini-boom in retail sales that record labels are hoping will blossom into full-scale demand.

title: Wisconsin Votes to Drop Baseball
description: The University of Wisconsin athletic board rebuffed pleas from student-athletes and voted, 10-7, on Friday to drop baseball and four other sports next year to close a $1.9 million budget deficit.

title: Three R's for the Middle East
description: Though I still think that punitive sanctions would have better served America's long-term interests, clearly the military victory over Iraq was easier than expected. However, there is a growing -- but still avoidable -- risk that the war may come to be seen as having precipitated a geopolitical disaster and a moral disgrace.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Nonblooming Orchids

title: Play by Howard Fast To Open at the Emelin
description: MENTION the novelist Howard Fast and one title after another will come to mind. "April Morning," "Freedom Road" and "Spartacus" are among the most familiar of his close to 60 novels.

title: Privacy of Woman in Rape Case Was Invaded
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Zooms to a '91 High
Best Performance by a Mistress
description: THE INVISIBLE WOMAN

title: The Towered City of Bellinzona
description: LOOK up from almost any point in the small, vineyard-girded capital of Switzerland's Italian-speaking region, and you are likely to glimpse one of its medieval castles. In many places you can see all three of them. Those strongholds with their grim towers and battlemented ramparts are enduring reminders of Bellinzona's strategic position. The prosperous town of 17,000 on the Ticino River straddles major European north-south routes across the Alps -- the approaches to the St. Gotthard Pass and the lofty gateways to the two headstreams of the Rhine River. Small wonder that through the centuries mighty neighbors coveted possession of Bellinzona.

title: Miss Silverstein to Marry Mark First
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Silverstein of Penn Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Rachael Eve Silverstein to Mark Leonard First, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stewart E. First of Merion, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Fashion; Mules Are Stepping Out
description: Maybe you like to mince when you walk. If so, backless mules are not for you. They slip-slap every step of the way. But if you like to stride, mules are just right: the sliding motion helps keep them on. Once, mules were just comfy items to slip into and wear in the boudoir. This spring, though, they are the most popular of shoe silhouettes, styled to be worn anywhere but the bedroom. Pilgrim-buckled patent-leather versions are designed to be worn with tailored suits to work, and silver skyscraper-heel mules are meant for dancing. The new mules have a wide variety of heels, and some are set on wedges. Even the cowboy boot has been chopped off at the top of the instep to create a dashing variation that looks great with jeans. A trick for keeping stubborn mules from slipping off: point your toes and arch your foot to create extra pressure on the shoe. Or like one exasperated model in a recent runway show, just kick them off and carry them.

title: Review/Cabaret; Iris Williams's Way With Melody and Lyric
description: With the possible exception of Richard Rodgers, Jerome Kern was the most naturally fluent melodist American popular song has produced. Kern melodies like "All the Things You Are," "Bill," "The Folks Who Live on the Hill," and "Long Ago and Far Away" demand beautiful voices. And few are more luscious than the contralto of Iris Williams, a Welsh-born singer who is making her American debut at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street) in a program devoted mostly to Kern.

title:
THEATER;
World War II's Black Pilots Fought on Two Fronts
description: It's not surprising that a medical researcher turned playwright would gather information as if he were conducting a scientific experiment. "I use the discipline of science in my writing," says Leslie Lee. "The two professions are very similar; one is physical healing and one is emotional healing."

title: Teachers Ratify New Contract
description: City teachers, who have been without a contract since the school year began, have overwhelmingly ratified a tentative contract that gives them an avergage 11 percent raise over two years, Of the 2,468 teachers voting on Friday, 96% cast ballots for the contract, "I'm pleased with the teachers' vote," said Adam Urbanski, the Rochester Teachers Association president. "But I will relax when the board has voted on Monday." The city school board rejected as too expensive a January contract proposal, which was also overwhelmingly approved by the teachers.

title:
Making a Difference;
A Risky Game of Chicken for an Ailing Tucson Utility
description: Charles Bayless is uniquely qualified to do a daily dance on the brink of bankruptcy. He was a potent force as chief financial officer at the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the first utility since the Depression to seek bankruptcy protection, filing after regulators denied a rate increase in 1988.

title: Ms. Becker Wed In Connecticut
description: Lisa Ruth Becker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Becker of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thomas Dunham Edmundson, a son of Robert Edmundson of Greenwich and Jane Norman Edmundson of New York. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Sunday Outing; Glen Cove, L.I., as It Was Before the Europeans
description: The time is 300 to 400 years ago. A Matinecock warrior brings a deer he has slain to two women of his tribe and watches as they prepare it for the cooking fire. They are on a bluff overlooking what will later be known as Glen Cove Creek and Hempstead Harbor.

title: DESIGN: BATHING BEAUTIES
description: AS PURVEYORS OF SOCIAL HISTORY HAVE recently observed, it is the bathroom that has grown both in size and prominence in homes across America. According to Kitchen & Bath Business, a New York trade publication, Americans are expected to spend $9.5 billion on bathrooms this year alone. Call it an attempt to create spa life at home or simply a return to sybaritic pleasures, but bathrooms have attained a status once reserved for living rooms, libraries or bedrooms. "We used to decorate a whole house and the bathrooms would be an afterthought," the Manhattan designer Juan Montoya says. "Now they're a priority. Everyone wants a beautiful bathroom."

title: Data Bank/April 21, 1991
From 11 Years Old to 93: County's Top Volunteers
description: SOME of the most honored Westchester volunteers have a special understanding of the needs of those they help. Edward Lash of White Plains, for example, the 1991 Westchester Volunteer of the Year, started a support group for multiple sclerosis patients after he discovered that he had the disease.

title: Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor: Hugo Golin (Letters on Travel, March 17) is correct in his evaluation of the dual billing for foreign visitors to Czechoslovakia. We spent 11 days in Prague last summer, staying at the Forum Hotel with a rate of $175 a night. After Prague we took a two-week tour. Our bus driver paid $40 for a room at the Forum Hotel in Bratislava.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Discount Clubs Proliferate in Connecticut
description: A FEW decades ago, "I can get it for you wholesale" was a refrain that sometimes presaged a rip-off, but often resulted in a terrific deal on anything from a sofa to a fur coat. But to get a deal, you needed a connection.

title: Ignore Beijing's Rules? It Works in a Tiny Village
description: Mayor Bei Lajie wiggled his bare feet and insisted that it was no problem when half the village came by in the evening to watch television in his living room.

title:
DINING OUT;
Offbeat Menu at a Cozy Lakeside Place
description: WITH spring in full bud, a drive into the country for an informal lakeside dinner is hard to resist. But sniffing out a restaurant in the woods that offers better than mediocre fare takes the nose of a truffle-hunting dog. On little Lake Swannanoa in western Morris County, the Water's Edge Cafe, which has the unpretentious, welcoming ambiance of a rustic camp lodge, is one good possibility.

title: Hikers Match Wits on a Woodsy Quest
description: INTO the woods they went, some running, others strolling. One man dashed up a hill; another pushed his daughter's stroller along a path. Friends chatted, Boy and Girl Scouts tramped, and everyone looked for orange-and-white markers placed among the bushes and boulders.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about Armenians waiting to receive food rations in Turkey misstated the date. The picture was made in 1920, not 1929.

title:
FORUM;
Recyclable . . . or Just Fraudulent?
description: Last April 22 was the 20th anniversary of Earth Day, a global epic marked by marches, speeches -- and a new wave of supposedly "environmentally friendly" consumer products like drink boxes, "degradable" plastic bags and "compostable" diapers. This year, as Earth Day approaches again, attention should be focused on the growing phenomenon of "green collar" fraud.

title: Tove Wagner to Wed
description: Harry L. Wagner of New York and Christie B. Wagner of Delhi, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tove Annika Wagner, to Dennis ter Linden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert ter Linden of The Hague, the Netherlands. A June wedding is planned. Miss Wagner, 29 years old, is a graduate of the University of Surrey in Guilford, England. Mr. ter Linden, 27, is a graduate of the Royal Academy of Art in the Hague, where he is a freelance advertising consultant.

title: The Nation; A Crusader Tilts at the Ivory Towers Looking for Old-Fashioned Corruption
description: WIDELY known as the most feared inquisitor in Congress, John D. Dingell has taken on the academic and scientific establishments that have long been sacrosanct on Capitol Hill. The Michigan Democrat's most recent crusades have shaken ivory towers across the country, forcing universities to re-evaluate the way they conduct research.

title: Privacy of Woman in Rape Case Was Invaded; Meaningless Details
description: To the Editor:

title: Life in the 20's
description: THE ART OF CARTOGRAPHY By J. S. Marcus. 129 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.

title: Kenneth Cutshaw Weds Ms. Dracos
description: Diane Elizabeth Dracos, an investment banker, and Kenneth Andrew Cutshaw, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce, were married in Washington yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church at Lafayette Square by the Rev. James C. Holmes.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
A Levitt Community Marks 40 Years
description: ROSLYN COUNTRY CLUB celebrated its 40th birthday this month, but this community of 668 houses in Roslyn Heights is showing few signs of age.

title: Two Cheers for Consensus
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language; Izationization
description: An ugly but necessary new noun is being floated out today: izationization , "the creation of lengthy nouns out of shorter words by adding -ization ."

title: Colombia's Rising Export: Fake U.S. Money
description: At a busy bazaar of electronic goods here, Arturo Abril's smile faded when a customer asked to pay for a video camera with United States dollars instead of Colombian pesos.

title: Headliners; Taking Care
description: Mother Hale, who turned her Harlem home into a nursery for babies born addicted to heroin in the 1960's, will continue to be able to care for babies born addicted to crack in the 1990's. For a while it appeared that might not be the case. Last fall, in a dispute over what care was best for the children, New York City officials decided to stop placing crack-addicted infants in Mother Hale's care, and without city support it appeared that Hale House would lack the resources to continue caring for such infants. But, as she showed the Bush Administration's new drug czar, Bob Martinez, around Hale House last week, Mother Hale told reporters that thanks to a flood of individual contributions and the support of a group of 250 churches, she would continue caring for crack babies. "God has given me the responsibility to care for these children," said Mother Hale, who is 85 years old. "Now we are going to be able to provide for them even better than before." Said Mr. Martinez, "The whole country's proud of you."

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Designing Clean, Delightful Books Charles A. Goodrum reminds us that, while Gutenberg perfected the printing of books, it was Aldus Manutius (born in 1450) who first imagined how a printed book should look. This is from "Treasures of the Library of Congress" (Abrams).

title: City Ballet Embraces a Svelte 'Sleeping Beauty'
description: "The Sleeping Beauty" has long been a standard by which classical ballet has been revealed and judged. At its premiere in 1890 at the Imperial Theater in St. Petersburg, the four-act work, a sumptuous spectacle performed by a company of 250 dancers, epitomized the wealth and aristocratic tastes of czarist Russia. It also contained dance passages of crystalline purity and fluidity that helped to define the genius of Marius Petipa, the director of the Imperial Ballet.

title: Focus: Performing-Arts Centers; Energizing Downtowns in Smaller Cities
description: FOR decades, the nation's larger cities have been building performing arts centers as focuses for their cultural activities.

title: Marsha Norman Finds Her Lost Key to Broadway
description: Frances Hodgson Burnett's classic novel "The Secret Garden," which will open Thursday as a musical at the St. James Theater on Broadway, is a cult children's book, the kind of tender story that women of all generations rapturously invoke as a beloved girlhood treasure.

title: Apartment Service Workers Continue Talks
description: Negotiations between apartment owners and the union representing 25,000 doormen, porters, elevator operators and other building service workers continued last night, as the police prepared to handle any crises that might arise if residential building employees strike in New York City and Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Modern String Quartets
description: The Group for Contemporary Music is to perform string quartets by Wayne Peterson, Jonathan Harvey and Charles Wuorinen in a free concert tonight at 8 o'clock at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street in Manhattan. The performers are Benjamin Hudson and Carol Zeavin, violinists; Lois Martin, violist, and Joshua Gordon, cellist. Information: (212) 874-5210.

title: Baker Initiative Getting Mixed Response
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's Middle East peace mission got a mixed reception today, with Jordan endorsing the American diplomacy, Israeli officials beginning to criticize it harshly, and American officials disclosing that Saudi Arabia is not likely to come to any peace conference with Israel.

title: Miss Lynch Wed To Robert Adrian
description: Carter Tomlin Lynch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Lynch Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., and Bridgehampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Steward Adrian, a son of Irene S. Adrian of Boca Raton, Fla., and Richard A. Adrian of New York. The Rev. Ronald G. Abrams performed the cermony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Bridgehampton.

title: Washed Silk Takes On New Guises
description: Once known as "weekend silk" or "sloppy silk" because of its wrinkled texture, washed silk has become a wardrobe staple year-round. Designers are enamored of the silk's chamois feel and muted hues, which are created by washing the fabric with sand or stones. Now they are freshening its look by experimenting with prints, textures and uses.

title: Arias, Duets and More: Opera Is the Focal Point
description: OPERA takes its turn in the Connecticut spotlight this week. This afternoon at 4, the South Congregational Church in Hartford puts on "A Grand Opera Afternoon." Ten singers are featured, including Richard Donohue, who will double on the podium as needed, presenting arias, duets and several ensemble numbers, like the Sextet from "Lucia di Lammermoor." A donation of $4 is suggested. For information, call 249-8627.

title: Perversions but Not Sexual
description: To the Editor:

title: At 80, a Modern Composer Persists In His 'Marvelous Indulgence'
description: THE April afternoon was bleak, but the composer William Schuman was elated. The night before, in Avery Fisher Hall, a mostly young audience had greeted the New York Philharmonic's "All American Program" with ovations. Two of Mr. Schuman's works had been played, along with music by his late good friends, Leonard Bernstein and Aaron Copland, and others. Mr. Schuman and two other composers, Joan Tower and Morton Gould, were on hand to receive accolades.

title: IN SHORT/SCIENCE
description: QUANTUM PROFILES By Jeremy Bernstein.Princeton University, $17.95.

title: Foreign Affairs; Mission Possible
description: Nothing is impossible when it comes to Iraq. Everything is impossible when it comes to America. That is the misguided message emanating from much of Washington and the think-tank world.

title: Pattern of Change in Eastern Towns Shows How Highways Lead to Growth
description: MAPPING eastern Connecticut by population shows three clear clusters of major growth during the 1980's, all suburban or rural towns along major highways, according to data from the 1990 Census.

title: Sandy Klinzman, Executive, Weds
description: Sandra Jean Klinzman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Klinzman of Redding, Conn., was married there yesterday to William Rawson Baird, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon P. Baird of Lincoln, Mass. The Rev. Dean Ahlberg performed the ceremony at the First Church of Christ Congregational.

title: Now for a Taste of South America's Way With Fish
description: CEVICHE usually refers to seafood that is cured by marinating in lime or lemon juice, then seasoned and served as a first course. It is a dish that originated in South America.

title: A Simple Reminder: Character Counts, Too
description: The National Football League teams that draft the best are the ones that judge character as well as they judge athletic talent.

title: Yes, They Do Windows, Sometimes on Pointe
description: Jessica Weber still sighs in amused disbelief when she recalls the occasion a year or so ago when she was interviewing housecleaners for her 1,850-square-foot loft in Greenwich Village. One of the contenders was just about to get the thumbs-up sign when she announced, "I forgot to tell you: I don't bend."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-14

title: Ruth Remington Wed in Florida
description: Ruth Clark Remington and Henry David Blinder were married last evening at Cheeca Lodge at Islamorada Key, Fla., by Rabbi Brett Goldstein.

title: Mutual Funds; When Bonds Act Like Stocks
description: Junk-bond funds behave very differently from their cousins that invest in higher-grade bonds. Returns on high-quality bond funds, which are very sensitive to shifts in interest rates, tend to rise when the economy is in a recession and as interest rates drop -- exactly when junk-bond funds are most vulnerable to a decline.

title: Miss Boss to Wed Bradley Dorman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell A. Boss of Warwick, R.I., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Robin Lisle Boss and Bradley Page Dorman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Brian A. Dorman of Warwick.

title: The World; No Yen Yet for Soviets
description: IN the first visit of a Soviet leader to Japan, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last week asked Japanese political and business leaders for aid for the distressed Soviet economy. Here are some of Mr. Gorbachev's statements, and some responses from Japanese businessmen whose funds he sought. He Said "If we don't halt the disintegration of the state -- of the economy, the law, and relations between republics -- the country could fall into the chaos that gives birth to dictatorship. Despair and hopelessness are a serious threat to the progress of civilization. Advanced countries help themselves by helping others." -- Mr. Gorbachev, speaking to the Japanese parliament. "These are stormy times, and it is not easy to hold the wheel of the ship steady. Let's not lose time. Don't hold back from taking part in these great projects. Our Far East and Siberia have resources, but they lack the infrastructure to develop them. I appeal to Japanese companies to consider helping develop the region." -- Mr. Gorbachev, speaking to business leaders. They Said "The economic conditions and infrastructure in your country are inadequate. . . . Our countries have to resolve their political problems and your country must lay the groundwork for the transition to an orderly market economy. Long-term investment will require economic and political stability." -- Gaishi Hiraiwa, president of Keidanren, the biggest Japanese business trade group. "I don't think Japanese business people will be attracted by the Soviet Union without having normal and good relations between our two countries. Once that happens, we can start talking about the projects in his speech." -- Yoshihiko Miyauchi, president of the Orix Corporation, a leasing company.

title: DOWNTOWN COUSIN
description: In his attempt to break out of one stereotype by being un-Chinese, Ti-Hua Chang has unwittingly created another -- that of the insecurely assimilated Chinese male, who is vain and always on the defensive about his professional status, his physical appearance, his material accouterments.

title: Assessing the Impact Of Land Use on Water
description: THE effect of land use on the county's water will be the focus of attention at a conference Tuesday sponsored by the Federated Conservationists of Westchester County.

title: Bush Assails Tactics Used by AIDS Lobby
description: President Bush has denounced some of the tactics used by radical advocates of people with AIDS as "an excess of free speech." He particularly singled out their attacks on John Cardinal O'Connor of New York as "offensive."

title: Managing; Americans Aim To Speak in Many Other Tongues
description: Market research told the Ryko Manufacturing Company that selling its car wash equipment in France would be a breeze. But when it tried, potential buyers resisted mightily -- and for a good reason. Ryko's instruction manuals were in English, a language that few car wash operators could read.

title: '20/20' Gives '60 Minutes' a Run for Its Ratings
description: Quick: what is the most popular hourlong show on ABC?

title: Documents Describe Corruption in Painters' Union
description: A detailed look at the day-to-day corruption of leaders of the painters' union that controls much of the painting and wallpapering work in New York City was provided in thousands of pages of taped conversations, affidavits and other documents, released by the Manhattan District Attorney.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Stroudsburg, Pa.;
Adult Village Tripling Size
description: AN adult community on the site of a former rhododendron nursery in the Pocono Mountains, called LaBar Village, is undergoing a $70 million expansion, tripling to 573 units.

title:
PLAINSBORO JOURNAL;
Store and Its Customers Seem Like a Family
description: ASK customers to describe the Lapidus Market, and they use words like homey and higgledy-piggledy. Ask them about the owners, Stanley and Elsa Lapidus, and they wax poetic.

title: Postings: Chinatown Renovation; Beacon on the Bowery
description: For decades, the domed bank building at the corner of Canal Street and the Bowery has dominated Manhattan Bridge Plaza and served as a landmark in its Chinatown neighborhood. Soon the bank, now part of the Manhattan Savings Bank system, will be a standout at night as well as during the day.

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.; Pledges Count The Lengths Over the Charles
description: Last Thursday about 2 A.M., the freshman pledges of Lambda Chi Alpha at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology were at it again, repainting the markers along the Harvard Bridge, one marker for every 10 Smoot lengths.

title: Travel Advisory; Germany Gets New Fast Trains
description: Germany's new high-speed luxury trains are scheduled to begin service on June 2 between Hamburg and Munich. Twenty-five new trains of the German Rail Intercity Express service will go into operation then in the first stage of a $2 billion modernization venture. The trains, which will reach speeds of up to 165 miles per hour, will cut railway travel time by as much as 30 percent immediately and 50 percent within the next five years, officials say.

title: Arts in School as Budgets Shrink
description: THOSE in the county concerned about arts and education spending cuts may find a spokesman in Dr. Howard E. Gardner, a prominent research psychologist and professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. Dr. Gardner will speak locally at two separate events this week.

title:
FOOTBALL;
Seattle or New England Would Please McGwire
description: Dan McGwire likes the idea of living in the Pacific Northwest or New England and playing football next year for either the Seahawks or the Patriots.

title: Students Push for Action on Threats to Gays
description: Hundreds of students demonstrated at the University of Chicago on Friday to dmand a faster investigation into reports of death threats against homosexuals and the beating of at least one homosexual on campus.

title: Plants and Practices Herald a New Era
description: THE first Earth Day was just 21 years ago.Participation grew to thousands of people who decided to "think globally, act locally." But important questions should now be raised: Was the vital message lost in the hoopla? Or has an environmental era really started? Gardeners, who are closest to the land, should know.

title: Miss Smith Weds George Campbell Jr.
description: Sarah Mullen Smith and George Donald Campbell Jr. were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., by the Rev. Bryant W. Dennison Jr. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hal H. Smith 3d of Grosse Pointe Farms. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Duncan C. Gray of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Mr. Campbell.

In the Region: New Jersey;
Banks Turn to an Expo to Sell Properties

title: Stephanie J. Parkinson to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Basil M. Briggs of New York have made known the June wedding plans of Mrs. Briggs's daughter, Stephanie Joy Parkinson, and Dominic John Briguglio 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Briguglio of Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Style Makers; Pati Hillis, Corkscrew Maker
description: Pati Hillis likes to recall the challenge posed to her in 1989 by her husband, Danny, a scientist and maker of supercomputers: "Find me a gift I can give my foreign customers. It must be made in America, functional, unusual and really classy."

title: Kristina Bieker Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Fred W. Bieker of Portland, Ore., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kristina Lee Bieker to David Paul Brady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Brady of West Chester, Pa. A July wedding is planned. Ms. Bieker, 27 years old, is to receive a doctorate in molecular biology from Princeton University next month. A graduate of Swarthmore College, she has a master's degree in biology from Princeton. The future bridegroom, 31, is an assistant professor of electrical engineering at Northeastern University. He graduated from Carnegie-Mellon University and received a master's degree from the California Institute of Technology and a doctorate from Princeton.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; Albany's Budget-Balancing 'One-Shots' Will Reverberate for Years to Come
description: UNLIKE the Federal Government, New York State, as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo likes to point out, does not have the capacity to print money when it needs it. But it does have something almost as good -- and almost as troubling. It has one-shots.

title: Criticizing the Critics
description: THE CRITIC, POWER, AND THE PERFORMING ARTS A Twentieth Century Fund Essay. By John E. Booth. 225 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $27.95.

title: Miss Hochman, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Hochman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Hochman, to Alain Edouard Xavier Kagan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henri Kagan of Paris. A June wedding is planned.

title: 'Yes' to Debt Reduction

title: Once Again, the Retro Realm Of Lenny Kravitz
description: Pop music keeps getting smarter and smarter. There are sub-markets, markets of blond 12-year-olds, markets near the border of the mainstream, the mainstream itself. Pop continually mutates, finding just the right look and sound for the eager consumers who use the music as proof of membership.

Rebman of Fairfax, Va., was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Episcopal Church in Washington to Christopher Neil Jacobs, a son of Gwendolyn M. Jacobs of Frederick, Md., and E. title: Lisa Elliott and Brad Kronauer to Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Elliott Jr. of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Havemeyer Elliott to Brad Jeffrey Kronauer, a son of Maj. Gen. and Mrs. Clifford J. Kronauer of Denver. A July wedding is planned.

title: Ex-University Employee Held in Michigan Shooting Spree
description: A former university employee fired 19 shots from an assault rifle on Friday into an unoccupied University of Michigan building, the police said today.

title: U.S. MARINES LAND IN NORTHERN IRAQ TO SET UP CAMPS
description: A battalion of American marines landed in northern Iraq today to start building the first refugee camp in what is to be an allied-protected zone for Kurds inside Iraq.

title: Byzantium in the Balkans
description: WHEN I first began visiting Sofia during the Communist ice age, the waves of gilded and leaden green domes of the Alexander Nevski Memorial Church, floodlighted in the whispering city at night, called forth a vision of medieval Byzantium; thus putting in historical context such mystifying conspiracies as a murder with a poison-tipped umbrella and an attempt to assassinate a Pope. Moreover, the fantastic icons in the church's crypt, with their strangely austere yet intricate patterns and distorted mirror reflection of the world, provided a psychological clue, however opaque, to what was going on behind the white colonnades of the party headquarters in the 1970's and 1980's. I sometimes felt that if journalists back then spent less time being journalists and more time being tourists -- appreciating the city's treasure of church art -- they would have been less baffled by what they were reporting.

title: Law Students Report On Shortage of Housing
description: IN a report released last week, students at the Pace University Law School in White Plains blamed the state and county governments for the shortage of affordable housing in Westchester. The report suggested that current laws and court decisions could be interpreted in ways that would foster a more activist approach.

title: The World; Old Habits Ensnare the Middle East Again
description: APPEARANCES in the Middle East are almost always deceiving. The Persian Gulf war was initially and widely acclaimed as a decisive victory for the United States-led coalition. So it was, militarily. But it seemed decidedly less glorious last week as 10,000 American soldiers scoured the harsh Iraqi landscape seeking suitable terrain for vast refugee camps to save hundreds of thousands of desperate Kurds, the unanticipated human debris of the conflict.

title: The Nation; Should the Media Name the Accuser When the Crime Being Charged Is Rape?
description: UNLIKE the targets of any other adult crime, rape victims have almost always had their identities shielded by American newspapers.

title: Kimberly Conklin Is Wed
description: Kimberly Burnett Conklin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore B. Conklin of Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married there yesterday to Sean Thaddeus Connett, a son of Albert N. Connett 3d of Quogue, L.I., and Ellen Toland Connett of New Providence, N.J. The Rev. H. Lawrence Whittemore Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church. Mrs. Connett, 24 years old, is a magna cum laude graduate of Long Island University. Mr. Connett, 25, is a quartermaster on the United States Coast Guard cutter Durable.

title: KUWAIT'S RULERS PICK NEW CABINET
description: After nearly two months of speculation and indecision, the Prime Minister named a new Government today. But businessmen, bankers and political opponents dismissed the move as largely a shuffling of posts that preserves power for the ruling Sabah family.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Feeling Young on Ice

title: The Talk of Sayville; For Earth Day, the Island Looks to Sayville
description: IN 1761, when Sayville was a newly settled waterfront community, life in the village revolved around Brown's River and the Great South Bay.

title: THE ROMANIAN BABY BAZAAR
description: There are people who quietly and legally arrange adoptions in Romania for healthy children and infants without encountering the nightmares Kathleen Hunt describes in her article "The Romanian Baby Bazaar" (March 24). It is possible to adopt through adoption agencies and legitimate attorneys in both the United States and Romania, if one follows the rules set up by the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the American Embassy in Bucharest.

title: On the Verge of a Narrative Breakdown
description: WAR FEVER

title:
Hers;
Requiem for a Soldier
description: THE AMERICAN FLAG was draped over the gunmetal-gray coffin at a funeral home in Oradell, N.J. On a table to the left of the coffin was an 8-by-10 photo of a smiling, somewhat shy-looking woman wearing a soft pastel suit and pearls. On the right was quite another photograph, of a leaner-faced woman with a cocky grin, hands on the hips of her desert camouflage uniform, an Army helicopter of the Second Battalion, 159th Aviation immediately behind her.

title: Travel Advisory; Universal Adds 3 Shows in Florida
description: Universal Studios in Orlando, Fla., has opened three new shows and plans to open three more this year, plus one ride. Most of the attractions are pegged to Hollywood themes. The ride, scheduled to open May 2, is inspired by the "Back to the Future" film trilogy, and visitors will sit in a DeLorean car surrounded by a seven-story hemispherical screen. The car will shoot up 10 feet, in an imitation of Michael J. Fox's character blasting off into space.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Cross-Burning Law Stricken
description: Dismissing a felony charge against a high school student accused of burning a cross on school grounds, a Family Court judge has held Virginia's law against cross burning to be unconstitutional.

title: Illegal Aliens And U.S. Border
description: In your article on illegal aliens on Long Island [ "Illegal Aliens Say Census Missed Thousands," March 24 ] you quote a Salvadoran as saying, "I find the North Americans are cold to the suffering of our people." I submit that the question is not a lack of compassion, but rather concern about if the United States is to remain a sovereign nation. Sovereignty implies that a nation controls its own borders and determines who may or may not enter.

title:
ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
The Man Behind Manhattan's Deco Mountains
description: Current architectural criticism has it that the chief sin of today's new office buildings is their inordinate size, which violates the scale of city streets. This is true up to a point. Yet in lower Manhattan there exists a chain of Art Deco "mountains" from the 1920's and 30's, built by the masterly, near-forgotten architect Ralph T. Walker, that are quite large yet never oppress their surroundings.

title: 1990 Census: How Eastern Connecticut Grew
description: During the 1980's rural and suburban towns along major highways showed the largest percentage gains in population in the three counties of Eastern Connecticut, pointing up the link between population trends and transportation networks.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. About five years ago, I painted my garage floor with a latex primer and then a coat of flat exterior latex. The appearance was fine, but the latex lifted off wherever the car's tires rested on it. A year later, I painted the floor again with a good grade of alkyd floor enamel, but the problem remained . One year later, I repeated this paint job, but with no better results. Last year, I cleaned and sanded the bare spots, then repainted with an epoxy. The problem was not quite as bad, although it is still there. Is there some special primer I should apply to the bare concrete spots to keep the paint from lifting?

title: Major League Advice For College Sluggers
description: AT a time when several retired athletes are trying to mount comebacks, here comes George Foster, a onetime star of the Cincinnati Reds and New York Mets, talking about a return to the major leagues. But Mr. Foster's goal has nothing to do with roaming left field again. "I really want to become a hitting consultant," said the 42-year-old Mr. Foster, a Greenwich resident. "I enjoy teaching baseball, and I know all the aspects of the game."

title: Streetscapes: The 168th Street IRT Station; Vaulted Grandeur Deep Underground
description: THE IRT No. 1 line's elegant, barrel-vaulted 168th Street station received a $2.5 million rehabilitation last year that not only cleaned up some of the rougher spots, but also highlighted the clash of architectural esthetics and bureaucratic reality.

title: Travel Advisory; Olympics Tour To Andorra
description: Tour companies are putting together travel packages aimed squarely at the devoted sports fan. One promises a preview of a small part of the 1992 Olympic Games, while the other offers a hefty dose of major league baseball.

title: Shehra Jabeen Tahir-Kheli Is Engaged

Tahir-Kheli of New York and Bala Cynwyd, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shehra Jabeen Tahir-Kheli, to Christopher James Dlutowski, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Dlutowski of Philadelphia. A December wedding is planned.

title: Building for the Performing Arts in Smaller Cities
description: For decades, the nation's larger cities have been building performing arts centers as focuses for their cultural activities.

title: Colby P. Bart and David Alan Harp Are Married
description: Colby Perkins Bart, a daughter of Duffie Bart of Santa Monica, Calif., and Peter Bart of New York, was married yesterday at the home of her father and her stepmother, Leslie Bart, to David Alan Harp, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. H. Richard Harp of Takoma Park, Md. The bridegroom's father, who is the pastor of the National Memorial Church of God in Washington, performed the ceremony.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It is not easy to be a player in the social world, and the frothier the world, the more complex and artful the maneuvers. The game often involves, if not outright deception, at least misdirection. It has its own language, not specific enough to be taught but possible to assimilate over time.

title:
ART;
The Flowery Touch of Spring
description: WITH spring very much in the air, "Primavera," a group exhibition at Gallery North in Setauket, intends to capitalize on the promise of floral abundance and greenery.

title: A Mayoral Rematch in Mount Vernon
description: A DEMOCRATIC primary here is shaping up as a rematch between Mayor Ronald A. Blackwood and one of the city's veteran political figures, Councilwoman Carmella R. Iaboni.

title: Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor: Recent letters about Czechoslovakia reminded me that during a visit to Prague two years ago, I purchased eight 7 1/2-inch plates and a two-piece salad server, which I paid for with a credit card. I received a bill for $420.52. According to my calculation, it should have been about $42; the mistake appeared to be caused by a misplaced decimal point. Unfortunately, I signed the slip, trusting the clerk to make it out properly.

title: A Proud Annapolis Mansion
description: It took Historic Annapolis, a citizen's group, and the Maryland State Legislature 11 years to restore to its original glory the mansion built in 1763 by Gov. William A. Paca, an achievement the more remarkable because the mansion had been engulfed for 69 years by a 200-room hotel and its two-acre formal garden buried beneath a Greyhound terminal. The site, at 186 Prince George Street, is now a National Historic Landmark; the garden was opened to the public in 1972, the house in 1976.

title: At Duke, They're Doing the Right Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Jamieson Weds

Morris of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Sydney A. Woodd-Cahusac performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church. Mrs. Morris, a graduate of the Rochester Institute of Technology, is a freelance graphics designer. Mr. Morris, a graduate of Babson College, is the vice president and an owner of White Contractors in Old Greenwich.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE

title: Centrust Tower: The R.T.C.'s Shimmery Headache
description: It is, without a doubt, the most striking building on the Miami skyline. Designed by world-famous architect I. M. Pei, the shimmering Centrust Tower curves on one side, rises sharply on the other and glows in the nighttime sky. Real estate professionals call it a "trophy property," and millions of Americans know it from the opening credits of the televison show "Miami Vice."

title: Quake in Northern California
description: A moderate earthquake shook Northern California today, but no injuries or damage were reported, officials said. The tremor at 12:41 P.M. measured 4.1 on the Richter scale og ground motion and was centered about 12 miles east of Milpitas, the United States Geological Survey said.

title: IOWA LASER PLAN HITS HARD TIMES
description: In 1987 the State of Iowa approved $25 million to build a laser research center at the University of Iowa. With a faculty of eminent scientists, it was to bring in millions of dollars in research grants, create up to 12,000 jobs in a depressed farm state and make Iowa a world leader in laser research.

title: M.L.A. CONVENTION
description: As I read the letters in response to your article on the M.L.A. convention, I was struck by two things -- first, that the letters seemed to have been written by nonacademics; second, that they ranged from bemused to shocked at what went on there in Chicago. All seemed to be saying, "Those folks must be nuts!"

title: Wall Street; And What's the Yield on Pork Bellies?
description: Gold prices are dull, and oil prices have been demobilized. Grain embargoes are ancient history. In fact, the most exciting story the commodities market has mustered in months is the unexpected volatility in beef cattle prices. Important, yes. Likely to impress your date on Saturday night? Uh, probably not.

title:
The Executive Life;
A Lawyer's Switch to Aid a Hostile Takeover
description: The current dearth of takeover activity has left many of Wall Street's mergers and acquisitions specialists idle, waiting for the economy -- and the merger market -- to heat up again.

title: Steve Marriott, 44, Musician, Is Killed
description: Steve Marriott, who was the leader of Humble Pie and a member of the British rock group Small Faces, died today in a fire at his home, the police said. He was 44 years old.

title: PAC's Attract Funds And New Attention
description: AS members of the New Jersey Restaurant Association walked down aisle 500 at the group's annual trade show in Somerset recently, many were surprised to find a booth for the Good Government Fund tucked in among the pastry, delicatessen and dessert displays.

title:
FILM;
For Peter Greenaway, Movies Are a Dutch Treat
description: Peter Greenaway makes movies that offer viewers little comfort; his plots are not the sort that can be wrapped up with one final, lingering kiss. His films are deeply carnal, but the sexuality he depicts yields little pleasure. And, it seems, he delights in filming bodily functions. Yet when the English director insists that his is a "cinema of esthetics," one has to agree. Mr. Greenaway designs his movies to be beautiful.

title: Travel Advisory; Metro Planning To Drop 1st Class
description: First-class cars on the once-stately Paris Metro face extinction this year because of a decline in ridership. The Paris Regional Transport Authority has recommended that the subway system switch from two to only one class of car by the end of 1991. The board of directors is expected to approve the plan by the summer.

title: Amtrak in Buffalo
description: To the Editor: I made a reservation by calling Amtrak at 800-872-7245 for a trip from Buffalo to Boston. The train was supposed to leave Buffalo on March 7 at 5:23 A.M. When I arrived at the station, it was closed. I later learned that the train does not stop at Buffalo and one should go to another town to take it. Of course, I didn't arrive on time and missed the train.

title: Air Controllers Say Computers Show False Images
description: Air traffic controllers around the country say phantom images of other planes often appear on airliners' cockpit computers.

title: WOODY AND MIA
description: Thank you for that wonderful article on the unorthodox life style of Woody Allen and Mia Farrow. Mia was in a position to have her own children and to adopt, and she did both. What an unselfish person. MARY G. RIVERA Escondido, Calif.

title: World Markets; Switzerland's Door Cracks Open
description: Switzerland's financial world is a rather exclusive place, still renowned for its secrecy. But it is starting to open up, partly in response to changes in stock markets throughout Europe and the world. In the process it is likely that foreign investors will get better treatment.

title: Retailers Start to Praise Business Districts
description: IN the midst of the recession, retailers and property owners in the Village of Great Neck Plaza have voted to increase their taxes.

title: Review/Cabaret; Satirizing Songs and Singers
description: "You're a twit/You're a pack of vermin/You're the wit in a Falwell sermon," sings Rohn Seykell in "You're the Pits," a funny upside-down version of Cole Porter's "You're the Top," with lyrics by Joseph Keenan, that he performs in his cabaret act at Eighty-Eight's.

description: To the Editor:

title: One Man's Desert, Under Glass
description: FLEMINGTON

title: Just a Ragpicker of History
description: As one of the intellectual demigods of the 20th century, Claude Levi-Strauss, the structural anthropologist who formulated intricate methods for analyzing myths and kinship systems, has had his share of believers and disbelievers. While his admirers have enthusiastically welded his theories onto their various fields -- literary criticism, philosophy, history -- his critics, many in anthropology, have claimed that his mathematical and linguistic-based models for cultural behavior are too rigorous to account for all the contingencies of social life. In CONVERSATIONS WITH CLAUDE LEVI-STRAUSS (University of Chicago, $19.95), the French anthropologist discusses his controversial career with the French journalist Didier Eribon and ruminates on other subjects ranging from Picasso to racism. He also reflects on his past, including his early years in New York when he became friends with Andre Breton and Max Ernst, and his election in 1959 to the chair of anthropology at the College de France. Mr. Levi-Strauss, 83 years old, is revealed as something of an iconoclast. Sartre's existentialism, he says, proves that "a superior intellect may talk nonsense if it wishes to predict the course of history." Anthropologists are "the ragpickers of history," and Mr. Levi-Strauss himself has "a neolithic mind. I'm not the kind of person who can . . . make what I've acquired bear fruit." He adds later that he "would have liked to be a playwright." Yet the same idealism that perhaps inspired his attempts to organize the mysteries of the human mind systematically is evident: "I am more and more penetrated by the feeling that the cosmos, and man's place in the universe, surpasses and always will surpass our understanding." Even Mr. Levi-Strauss' disbelievers will find in this book, fluidly translated by Paula Wissing, a remarkable display of unfettered candor and insight.

title: Polly Kaplan to Marry Russell Tigges
description: Mr. and Mrs. Justin Kaplan of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Polly Anne Kaplan to Russell Gerard Tigges, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Tigges of Carroll, Iowa. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Travel Advisory; F.A.A. Lifts Curb On Check-Ins
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is allowing domestic airlines to reinstitute curbside check-ins with appropriate security measures. A spokesman for the Airport Operators Council International said the move would reduce congestion and delays at airports since an estimated 40 percent of passengers check their baggage at the curb.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SOUL MURDER: The Effects of Childhood Abuse and Deprivation, by Leonard Shengold. (Fawcett Columbine, $10.95.) The term in the title was used in the 19th century by an author writing about Kaspar Hauser, a German boy who had spent 15 years chained in a cellar. Dr. Shengold applies his psychoanalytic training to the boy's modern-day counterparts, patients whose individuality has been brutally destroyed. Our reviewer, F. Robert Rodman, said in 1989, "The tension between his devotion to his patients and his adherence to a highly disciplined method gives this book an immense dignity and beauty."

title: Blurred Image; Can Bush Regain Momentum?
description: LIKE a television image during a thunderstorm, the George Bush who finally became so sharp-edged during the war suddenly appears to be slipping in and out of focus.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Charlotte, N.C.;
Fourth Ward Gets a Leg Up
description: AN OFFICE PARK named for Randolph Scott, the late Hollywood star, and an apartment complex with hints of Victoriana are the newest salutes to the past in Fourth Ward, the city's 82-acre historic urban district.

title: Police Sift Many Motives in Gotti Driver's Killing
description: Investigators searching for the gunman who killed reputed mob leader John Gotti's driver last week are looking closely at a man thought to be associated with the Genovese crime family who had a brutal fistfight with the victim more than a year ago, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: The 'Saigon' Picture Is Worth 1,000 Words
description: Put aside for a minute the considerable talent of the British actor Jonathan Pryce and the galvanizing mixture of ferocity and subservience that he brings to "Miss Saigon." Disregard the loud sport shirts and slinky bell-bottom trousers that he wears. Forget, if you can, his bony fingers, always on the move, like those of a cheap magician about to produce a bouquet of paper flowers from an unsuspecting lady's decolletage.

title: A Memorial Concert Celebrates Aaron Copland's Musical Legacy
description: Aaron Copland, who died at the age of 90 on Dec. 2, was a taciturn man in his private life and his public effusions. So it was fitting that the elegantly realized memorial concert yesterday for this most famous and perhaps greatest of American composers was only that: a concert, and nothing else -- no fulsome remembrances, no chatty anecdotes, just Copland's music.

title: Abby A. Spencer, Master's Candidate, To Wed Nathaniel C. Moffat, Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Means Spencer of Wellesley, Mass., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Abby Alden Spencer and Nathaniel Cabot Moffat, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Pierrepont Moffat of Washington.

title: The Therapist Is 87, And She Pumps Iron
description: IDA DAVIDOFF opened the door of her Colonial-style home in New Canaan and welcomed a visitor into a bower of warmth, flowers and animated conversation. At 87 years old, she takes pleasure in dispelling myths about old age.

title: Commercial Property: Underground Spaces; Chemical Branch Moves Main Business to the Cellar
description: CHEMICAL BANK has gone underground, following a well-established New York custom of carving usable space from subterranean expanses.

title: Knicks Go to Playoffs and Hornets Go Home
description: The Knicks' regular-season finale meant nothing in the standing, but at least it was entertaining.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last week about a firefighters' cooking competition misidentified the man shown at the left. He was Leonard Inzerillo.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: STOLLER TO SPEAK

title:
MUSIC;
Conducting That Began by Chance
description: FOR Philippe Entremont, the French conductor and pianist, directing the orchestra from the keyboard is perfectly natural. In the long history of music, "the notion of a conductor is apretty new thing," Mr. Entremont said.

title: On Relocating A Shrub or Tree
description: If you've changed your mind about where small trees and shrubs should be, now is the time to move them.

title: Madeleine Naylor, Paralegal, Is Wed
description: Madeleine Catherine Coffee Naylor and John Frank Pember 3d were married yesterday at St. Thomas More's Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. Robert B. O'Connor. The bride, 27 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Anthony Naylor of New York. The bridegroom, 31, is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Pember 2d of Janesville, Wis.

title: 'Never Say Goodbye'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: IN Frank Gagliardi's favorite books, volcanoes erupt, sails swell, dinosaurs fight, children play, and Victorians misbehave. But such action is not merely described; it pops right up from the pages.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q&A;: ALIDA BRILL;
Safeguarding the Privacy of Life, Death, Sex and Other Data
description: AS a social scientist, feminist and journalist, Alida Brill has often spoken and written about personal freedoms. But it was not until she was confronted with a serious assault on her own privacy, while hospitalized, that she began to see fully the meaning and fragility of privacy.

title: Wendy C. Yarbro Wed in Maryland
description: Wendy Carter Yarbro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan D. Yarbro of Baltimore, was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Ruxton, Md., to Warren Nash Ponvert Jr., a son of Joan L. Ponvert of Locust Valley, L.I., and Mr. Ponvert of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Ben H. Smith Jr. officiated.

title: Making a Difference; Turnaround Time at Ogilvy
description: For several years, Ogilvy & Mather had been in a tizzy over the loss of some major accounts -- and its reputation as a creative hot shop. But since Bill Hamilton took over as creative head at the end of 1989, things have calmed down. Last month, Ogilvy was named agency of the year by Adweek, with Mr. Hamilton getting much of the credit.

title: THE MILITARY VS. THE PRESS
description: After reading Malcolm W. Browne's article "The Military vs. the Press" (March 3), I realize that a Government that limits the press and dictates the news scares me. During World War II, there were many reporters and broadcasters scattered throughout many of the battlefronts over a period of four years. Much of the news they reported was "bad," especially in the early years of the war, but it just made us roll up our sleeves and work harder. Our democratic Government believed we were entitled to hear that news -- both good and bad. RUTH H. COLLINS Decatur, Ga.

title: Corrections
description: A list of heavyweight champions in the SportsSunday section last week misstated the years Gene Tunney fought. He was active from 1915 to 1928.

title: In the Delta, the Blues Play On
description: THERE is a scene in the Wim Wenders film "Wings of Desire," when an angel approaches a man in Berlin. The man is in his last moments and, as the angel nears, he thinks aloud: "But I still have so much to do: the Far East . . . the Wild West . . . the Mississippi Delta."

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article in some editions on March 17 about a proposal to market the drug tacrine to treat Alzheimer's disease misattributed a statement cautioning against allowing emotions to sway the decision. A reader's letter received last Wednesday points out that it was made by Dr. Steven Ferris, not Dr. Leon Thal.

title: Tracing and Repairing a Roof Leak
description: SPRING is the season for roof leaks, which are usually caused by rain penetrating roofing damaged by winter weather. At the first sign of a leak, often a wet spot on the ceiling near the corner of a wall, go to the attic, if possible, and find the spot where the water is dripping.

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.; Students Answer Health Questions About Women
description: Students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology seeking answers to questions about women's health can now call a student-run service.

title: Tales From a Literary Marriage
description: LOUISE ERDRICH AND MICHAEL DORRIS DON'T get out much. They live deep in the New Hampshire countryside, in an old farmhouse in Cornish, where they have children to raise and books to write and not a lot of help from anybody. When I meet them for dinner one mild winter night in nearby Hanover, they have about them an air of intimacy and romance that even the presence of a New York reporter can't fully dispel.

title: Cass Vogt Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. George L. Vogt of Little Silver, N.J., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Carol Currier Vogt and Rollie Erickson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl R. Erickson of Circle Pines, Minn. Miss Vogt, who is known as Cass and is 35 years old, is a poet and an assistant to the president of International Fibre Industries Ltd. in New York. She graduated from George Washington University. Mr. Erickson, 38, is an artist and a museum technician at the Brooklyn Museum. He graduated from the State University at Purchase, N.Y.

title: A Yeshiva Honors Japanese Protector
description: During the dark years of World War II, when Jews were being rounded up and executed in Europe, a diplomat acting on his own saved thousands of lives by issuing visas as fast as he could sign and distribute them.

title: Public Servants: Public Spirited?
description: Where is labor?

title: Postings: Sculptors Guild Show; Loft Building Gets a First
description: In an effort enhance its image as a commercial building at the vortex of the art world, the owners of the Soho Building, a renovated 13-story loft building on Greene Street between Prince and Spring Streets, have persuaded the Sculptors Guild to hold its 54th annual exhibit in a exhibition area on the ground floor.

title: MARSHALS FAULTED ON DRUG PROPERTY
description: The General Accounting Office says the Federal Marshals Service is mismanaging more than $1.4 billion in commercial property seized from drug dealers and other criminals, resulting in a significant income loss for the fight against illegal drugs.

title:
DANCE;
Hoofers Help Liza Get Her Act Together
description: "Stand on this X, where I'll be standing," said Liza Minnelli. "Now -- when the curtain goes up, what do you see?" What one sees as the massive crimson stage curtain is hauled toward the ceiling of Radio City Music Hall is the empty belly of a theater that, according to the management, has 1.8 million cubic feet of space to fill up with charisma.

title: Renee Sall Is Married
description: Renee Sall, a daughter of Frances Sall of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., and the late Dr. Jack Sall, was married in Edgewater, N.J., yesterday to David Eric Miller, a son of Lyn Miller of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Phillip Miller. Rabbi Andre Unger performed the ceremony aboard the Binghamton, a ferryboat. Ms. Sall, 31 years old, will keep her name. She is a graduate of Boston University and the president of the New York public-relations agency bearing her name. Mr. Miller, 35, is a summa cum laude graduate of the University of Florida. He founded and is president of the United Steel Equipment Corporation in Englewood, N.J. His first marriage ended in divorce.

title: Sunday Brunch; Elegance in a Hotel Setting
description: With their nerves frayed after a week of commercial combat in the frenetic city, New Yorkers sometimes seek a calming setting for Sunday brunch. Hotels, with their luxurious space and hushed ambiance, often serve the purpose. Here are three suggestions. 540 Park

title: Gorbachev: A Nickname Turns on Him
description: In the streets and marketplaces, the ordinary masses have always called Mikhail S. Gorbachev the Marked One -- Mecheny in Russian -- a name that originated as a kind of affectionate, magical tribute to the birthmarked Soviet leader as an early whirlwind reformer.

title: Daily News Struggles to Regain Its Readers
description: Nearly a month after a long and bitter strike ended, The Daily News is still struggling to overcome the circulation headaches that slowed its return to some newsstands and doorsteps.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MANIAC MAGEE

title: Mutual Funds; The Rehabilitation of 'Junk Bonds'
description: MutuaL funds that invest in "junk bonds" took investors on a dizzying downhill ride after the junk market collapsed more than a year ago. But in the first quarter of 1991, the funds roared back, recouping last year's losses and then some.

title: Joseph Kell, V. S. Naipaul and Me
description: In the late autumn of 1960 "The Doctor Is Sick" was published. National reviewers were not enthusiastic. "Mr. Burgess," said The Times Literary Supplement, "is apparently so anxious to be up to date that he is out of date already." My mobster admits that he is "kinky," and this was assumed to be a dead usage. In fact, it was just coming back, soon to be applied to erotic leatherwear. Punch found the dialect humor "as heavy as lead" and the whole brief work 50 pages too long. The poet Geoffrey Grigson, in The Spectator, found "fantastic fantasy, which does not work" and ended: "The words this novelist employs just don't produce things, or cohere, or make credible, in a sub-smart funniness (quotations from Webster, Eliot, Auden) I found not at all funny." Maurice Richardson, in The New Statesman, said that "if it were a first novel I should greet it as a promising curiosity. As a fourth it has to be labeled an interesting misfire." It was in fact a fifth.
