title: Talking: Raising Cash; Condos Learn How To Borrow
description: IT never has been easy for a condominium association to borrow for emergency repairs or capital improvements, but now ways are being found for them to negotiate bank loans by pledging their income from monthly carrying charges.

title: Boston Harbor Cleanup Cripples Realty
description: THE latest battle of Boston Harbor is being fought in empty buildings: a new office building here whose tenants cannot move in; a bankrupt condominium in Quincy where a spate of sales cannot be closed; a coin laundry in Somerville whose owner cannot complete renovations and at Harvard, where university officials are scrambling to find homes for students and professors who are blocked from moving into a new dormitory.

title: From Honda, an All-American Wagon
description: Among my friends is a guy named John. Like me, he is sometimes a grouch, but we get along -- arguing about everything -- and he is proud of his curmudgeonry. Less perversely, he is also proud of his lifelong unionism and rightly proud of his patriotism. But he is on his third Honda.

title: M.L.A. CONVENTION
description: A job well done! After running Anne Matthews's conservative, one-sided bashing of the Modern Language Association's annual convention ("Deciphering Victorian Underwear and Other Seminars," Feb. 10), you print five letters to the editor (March 3, March 10) embodying slight variations on the same old theme. Altogether, it was a heartwarming cacophony of agreement: a courageous diatribe against academic women (egad!) and (perhaps even more appalling) people of color, who are not burningly interested in books in which escaping to the high seas and killing a whale are profound symbolic responses to white male adolescent or, excuse me, universal problems. CASEY FINCH New York, N.Y.

title: The World; Europe Discovers The German Colossus Isn't So Big After All
description: RACKED by the growing pains of unification, Germany is beginning to look to its Western European neighbors like something very different from the overbearing colossus they were afraid of when the two parts of the country came together six months ago.

title: Audrey Hepburn's Party
description: No screen goddess ever pleaded more earnestly with her suitors not to admire her, or did it to so little effect. Audrey Hepburn, the subject of the Film Society of Lincoln Center's gala tribute tomorrow night, has always managed to seem even more enchantingly shy, and more unreasonably modest, than she is lovely.

title: Nicklaus Leaves Seniors Lagging 8 Strokes Behind
description: Jack Nicklaus continued to play like a man wrapped in a force field of superiority today as he stretched his lead in the PGA Seniors Championship to eight shots.

title: Hay Bales Cause Bad Wreck
description: Bales of hay fell off a truck into a bus on Friday, causing a collision that injured 28 of the 45 passengers, a dance group headed for a polka convention in the Catskills region of New York. Five of the injured were hospitalized, and the others were treated at hospitals and released. The accident, in Upper Macungie Township, occurred when the truck swerved, causing bales to drop off the back and smash through the windshield of the bus.

title: Lean's Passion Was on the Screen
description: David Lean's was not a name that made moviegoers swoon, film scholars squabble or gossip writers poke through his trash. In an age of celebrity, the English director, who died last week at the age of 83, seemed a blank personality to the general public. And in our age of auteurs, the idea of a David Lean film usually brings to mind only "Lawrence of Arabia" and the word "big."

title: Ms. Davis to Wed James E. Doern
description: The Rev. Thomas R. Davis Jr. and the Rev. Betsy Morgan Davis of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miriam Elizabeth Davis, to James Everett Doern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Doern of North Tarrytown, N.Y. A 1992 wedding is planned.

title: Bush's Plans for Kurds Stir Fears of Indefinite Military Role in Iraq
description: The Bush Administration's intervention in Iraq's refugee crisis has raised concerns that it will lead to an indefinite American military presence in a breakaway Kurdish enclave, or a nascent Kurdish state.

title: Legal Services Lawyers' Strike Puts Cases in Limbo
description: Confused by a locked door, the young woman looked at a small notice taped to the wall. She shook her head over the small print at the bottom, but on the top in block letters the situation at the Legal Services office on 10th Avenue was clearly spelled out: STRIKE.

title: WOODY AND MIA
description: In Eric Lax's article "Woody and Mia: A New York Story" (Feb. 24), we read that Woody Allen spends "only a limited time with kids" but that "not many fathers spend as much time with their children as Allen does." We learn that he prefers not to use the phone, yet gets a kick out of waving his bathroom linen out the windows while he's on the line with his ersatz household across Central Park. His diligent work habits are proved by the declaration that "he takes no vacations apart from the occasional two-week trip to Europe," yet we see pictures, shot within a period of two years, of him and a brood of assorted children in Austria, Venice and Leningrad.

title:
FOOTBALL;
Seattle or New England Would Please McGwire
description: Dan McGwire likes the idea of living in the Pacific Northwest or New England and playing football next year for either the Seahawks or the Patriots.

title: Elisa M. Wholey Wed To Louis Zachary Jr.
description: Elisa Mary Wholey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Wholey of Pittsburgh, was married in New York last night to Louis George Zachary Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Zachary of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Walter E. Modrys performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

title: Housing Markets Evade Human Needs
description: THE housing market in Connecticut will be dominated by major shifts of population in the next 20 years that may reduce the number of first-time home buyers and make it difficult for those who now own homes to move up or out, says a new study by the State Housing Department.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. About five years ago, I painted my garage floor with a latex primer and then a coat of flat exterior latex. The appearance was fine, but the latex lifted off wherever the car's tires rested on it. A year later, I painted the floor again with a good grade of alkyd floor enamel, but the problem remained . One year later, I repeated this paint job, but with no better results. Last year, I cleaned and sanded the bare spots, then repainted with an epoxy. The problem was not quite as bad, although it is still there. Is there some special primer I should apply to the bare concrete spots to keep the paint from lifting?

title: Suits to Fit the Mood of the Evening
description: In certain fashion circles, the ballgown is not just an endangered species. It is very nearly extinct.

title: Rivals in the West Don't Scare Padres
description: The early returns are too early to base a whole campaign on, but given San Diego's early-season schedule, the Padres are in a good position to gauge the initial showing of the three teams considered the ranking contenders in the National League West.

title: Bonn Officer Is Shot Near Soviet Base in Germany
description: A Soviet soldier guarding an arms depot in eastern Germany opened fire on Friday on three uniformed German Army officers apparently in the act of photographing the Soviet base, wounding one of them in the arm, officials said.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Birthdays of the immortals are traditionally celebrated in increments of whole centuries, the Handel and Bach tricentennials in 1985, for example. Consequently the 427th anniversary of Shakespeare's birth on April 26 is expected to pass unobtrusively, except in Stratford-upon-Housatonic. Thanks to the Stratford Library and the Shakespeare Guild, a festive week is planned around his life, times and works.

title: Hitler's Indian Allies
description: BROTHERS AGAINST THE RAJ

title: Making a Difference; Compaq Fires Back at Dell, But the Upstart Keeps Coming
description: For the past nine months, the Dell Computer Corporation of Austin, Tex., has been taking potshots at a giant rival, the Compaq Computer Corporation, with ads suggesting in no uncertain terms that Compaq's comparable products were grossly overpriced. Last week, Compaq fired back with both barrels: it slashed prices by up to 34 percent and filed suit in Federal court to block Dell from running its ads.

title: After Flawed Twin Is Removed, Woman Has Full-Term Baby
description: A woman has carried a baby to full term after its abnormal twin was removed in fetal surgery, a succession of events that doctors believe is a first.

title: Value Added Tax
description: To the Editor: Travelers are generally aware that they are entitled to a refund of value added taxes on merchandise bought abroad.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Romantic French and German Organ Works Marsha Heather Long, organ. Koch International Classics 3-7008; CD and cassette.

title: Paine Lures Historians To New Rochelle
description: "WHEN it shall be said in any country in the world, my poor are happy, neither distress nor ignorance is to be found among them; my jails are empty of prisoners, my streets of beggars; the aged are not in want, the taxes are not oppressive . . . when these things can be said, then may that country boast its constitution and its government."

title: A La Carte: And the Survey Says . . .
description: MIRABELLE, of St. James, is Long Island's top restaurant for food and service, as well as its most popular eating place, the new Zagat Suburban New York City Restaurant Survey says.

title: From Squids to Orchids, All in Glass
description: Working with pincers, tweezers, shears and paintbrushes between 1863 and 1936, Leopold and Rudolf Blaschka devised thousands of exquisitely detailed glass models of flowers, plants and sea creatures.

title: An Honor for Gilbert
description: The Rangers might have wished this season that he were back in uniform and scoring goals, but ROD GILBERT has apparently been making a name for himself in his retirement job as the Rangers' community relations manager and an instructor at youth clinics. For his efforts, Gilbert will receive the 1991 Lester Patrick Trophy for outstanding service to hockey along with MIKE ILITCH, the owner of the Detroit Red Wings, who is one of the nation's leading supporters of youth hockey. They will be honored at the National Hockey League's awards luncheon in Buffalo on June 20. (AP)

title: The View From: Hartford; Entrepreneurs Nibble on Success At Showcase of State's Own Foods
description: JOAN SNYDER runs the graphics department for a company in Glastonbury, but as often as possible, she spends her lunch hour working at a food store in Hartford, trying to persuade customers to try Nip 'N'Tang, a berry-and-horseradish spread she created at home.

title: Miss Pellegrino Plans a June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony M. Pellegrino of Brooklyn have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Theresa Marie Rose Pellegrino, and Christopher John Mathias Moran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Moran of Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: THE ROMANIAN BABY BAZAAR
description: The "nightmare world of hustlers" alluded to in the subtitle of Kathleen Hunt's excellent article seems to include more than just Romanians.

title:
Your Own Account;
Retirement: Too Safe Can Be Sorry
description: New regulations issued by the Labor Department focus attention again on problems inherent in giving employees responsibility for investing their retirement money, particularly in 401(k) plans. Unfortunately, the regulations will do little to improve the situation.

title: Many Good Lawyers Are Women
description: The article "Nassau County Divorce Lawyers Bask in National Attention" [ April 7 ] describes the abundance of prominent and capable matrimonial attorneys in Nassau County. The story is accompanied by two photographs of various Nassau County divorce attorneys, all of whom are males. No women are named in the text of the article.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Pittsburgh;
Town Houses For a Revival
description: A $2 MILLION town-house complex now rising nearby is expected to bring new life to its affluent but shrinking community, which was most recently hurt by the loss of 600 jobs at a Westinghouse Corporation factory.

title: Zinfandel of Yesteryear
description: To the Editor:

title: Kimberly Rossetter Marries
description: Kimberly Rossetter, the daughter of William Aylesworth Rossetter of Corona del Mar, Calif., and Mrs. Laurence Edward Curran of Gulfstream, Fla., was married in Washington last evening to Bradford Robert Higgins, a son of June Ellis Higgins of Saddle River, N.J., and late Richard Thomas Higgins. The Rev. Nancy Early von Oehsen performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's Church. Mrs. Higgins, 35 years old, is a graduate of Bowdoin College. Mr. Higgins, 38, is a graduate of Columbia University and its law school. He is a managing director at the First Boston Corporation in New York.

title: Confronting the Excavation
description: THE excavation on busy Central Park Avenue, opposite the Yonkers Raceway, took on new meaning as it grew larger each day last week. Bob White, representing the developer, saw it as the long-awaited start to construction of prefabricated homes for 24 mostly minority families, "ready for occupancy by the fall."

title: An Opportunity to Look Over Picasso's Shoulder
description: "Picasso's 'Parade' from Paper to Stage," at the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, is a footnote to one of the most brilliant entertainments ever put on the stage. Consisting primarily of previously unpublished preliminary drawings by Picasso, and a photographic reproduction on the far wall of his original drop curtain, it might at first glance seem to lack both bulk and weight. But like many another footnote, it is full of first-hand information of the highest interest that is available nowhere else.

title: Giants' Mediocre Millionaire Silences the Skeptics, for Now
description: Bud Black pitched a five-hitter for his first National League victory as the San Francisco Giants beat the Houston Astros, 4-0, today.

title: Hungary
description: To the Editor: A footnote to Celestine Bohlen's article. The victory over the Turks by John Hunyadi at Belgrade in 1456 is commemorated even today throughout the Catholic world by the order of Pope Calixtus III that the bells of every church should ring at midday. Calixtus III supported Hunyadi's crusade against the Turks. The lack of such support 70 years later was one of the causes of the disaster at Mohacs, the consequence of which was Europe's endangerment of Turkish conquest, which was quelled in 1683 at the gates of Vienna. EMERY BERCZELLER Forest Hills, Queens

title: On the Street; Garb for Easy Living
description: New York City's parks are once again wearing their spring finery of flowering trees and perennial plants, inviting an invasion of visitors.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Old Bridge
description: ALTHOUGH its population has grown by nearly 50 percent in the last decade, the 42-square-mile Old Bridge Townshipin New Jersey's Middlesex County still has a lot of open space and is determined to keep it that way.

title: Misjudged Mothers
description: THREE TIMES TABLE

title: Gorbachev Reaps Accords in Korea
description: In a surprisingly rapid acceleration of their new relationship, President Roh Tae Woo and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev agreed here today to negotiate a mutual cooperation treaty and to multiply trade tenfold over the next five years in an effort to assist the Soviet Union's faltering economy.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Dr. John J. Kirk;
Linking the Clergy and the Environment
description: ALMOST two decades ago, Dr. John J. Kirk first considered an idea that had great potential but seemed improbable to him: enlist the world's clergy in the mission of heightening environmental awareness.

title: France, After a Death, Restricts Abortion Pill
description: The Health Ministry said today that women who are regular smokers or over 35 years of age could no longer receive a pill that induces abortions.

title: A Carnegie Museum
description: "The marvelous, audacious, wonderful bridge to the Canadian side," Tchaikovsky wrote at Niagara Falls on May 12, 1891, "was built, or better to say, thrown across the Niagara, only two years ago. One's head swims when looking down."

title: Economic Progress in China Has a Seedy Side
description: A petite Chinese woman, with a skimpy skirt and a blouse revealing more than it covered, walked daintily across the lobby of the best hotel in this city. A few yards away, several smartly clad women sipping tea in the coffee shop smiled alluringly at the male guests.

title: Lisman Cortner To Marry in June
description: Jack Rice Cortner and Nancy Gailor-Cortner, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisman Cortner, to Gary Vincent Fall, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Fall of Chicago. A June wedding is planned.

title: How a Nice Cup of Tea Comes About
description: THERE'S an old line about an English teataster who took one sip and barked, "Darjeeling, Field No. 4. Consolidated Paper Company bag." His palate, so the story goes, was so finely tuned that he could identify the estate where the tea was grown and even the source of paper for the bag in his cup.

title: Ms. Orkin Is Wed To Marc R. Kotler
description: Patricia Grace Orkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Orkin of New York, and Marc R. Kotler, a son of Judith Kotler of East Hanover, N.J., and Ted Kotler of New York, were married last evening at the Georgian Suite in New York. Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Prokofiev, Hail . . . and Farewell?
description: Now why haven't we heard more about the other big 1991 anniversary, that of Sergei Prokofiev, born 100 years ago this Tuesday in the rural Ukraine? Is it because mere stars of whatever magnitude are inevitably eclipsed by the Mozart sun? No doubt. But the causes may go deeper. For reasons not confined to musical quality as such, Prokofiev's standing, and his future in the repertory, could be in doubt.

title: THE ROMANIAN BABY BAZAAR
description: Since the overthrow of Ceausescu, Romania has experienced an explosion of xenophobic and nationalistic feeling, most frequently targeted at gypsies, the country's largest and most despised ethnic minority. Burning of gypsy homes, beatings, killings and rapes characterize the brutal violence aimed at gypsies by ordinary citizens, often with open encouragement by police. Subjected to such extreme persecution, compounded by abject poverty, unemployment and miserable living conditions, gypsies face such desperate circumstances that they can be further victimized by the kind of "con men" described in the article.

title: The Nation; Republicans Move In on Democrats' Schoolyard
description: IT was as if the Republicans had stolen the Democrats' favorite Nintendo game, or perhaps, considering the emphasis on traditionalism now trendy when talking of education, their little red wagon.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Meganne Ross Is Engaged
description: July wedding plans for Meganne Johanna Ross and John Stephen O'Neil, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. A. O'Neil of Parishville, N.Y., have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David L. Ross of Miller Place, L.I.

title: SAVORING STANLEY ELKIN
description: More than a month after Ken Emerson's superb profile of Stanley Elkin was published, I still savor every word ("The Indecorous, Rabelaisian, Convoluted Righteousness of Stanley Elkin," March 3).

title: THE MILITARY VS. THE PRESS
description: It's time the press stopped complaining about the censorship connected with Operation Desert Storm and understood why it existed. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf has openly revealed that deception played a major role in the liberation of Kuwait. Doesn't it occur to Browne that ruses de guerre are classic stratagems of warfare? Had these tactics been divulged, either on purpose or by mistake, the casualties could have climbed and the hostilities lasted longer.

title: IN SHORT/SCIENCE
description: IN THE COUNTRY OF HEARTS Journeys in the Art of Medicine.By John Stone.Delacorte, $22.95.

title: Kerri S. Evanson To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Evanson of Holmdel, N.J., and Orlando, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kerri Sue Evanson to Darren Carter Hauck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Bruce Hauck of Atlanta. A June wedding is planned.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Futuristic fiction is supposed to be ahead of its time. Elizabeth Ann Scarborough, who served as a nurse in the war in Vietnam, obviously wrote NOTHING SACRED (Foundation/Doubleday, Cloth, $21.95; Paper, $10.95) before Operation Desert Storm was conceived, but readers six months from now will have no way of knowing that: her novel heralds a new subgenre that might be called New World Order science fiction.

title: Campus Life: Syracuse; The Mascot, The Orange, Is Now a She
description: To many, the thought of tumbling around and sweating in a bulky costume in front of huge crowds, trying to make everyone smile without saying a word, is gruesome. To Rana Lee Araneta, it's wonderful.

title: Susan Lee Silk Wed in Vermont
description: Susan Lee Silk, the daughter of John Wesley Silk of Woodstock, Vt., and the late Lois Silk, was married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Woodstock to Robert Ableidinger, a son of William Ableidinger of Durand, Wis. and the late Wilma Ableidinger. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald E. Boyer and the Rev. Edward J. Mahoney, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Human Nature and Nurture
description: To the Editor:

title: Dialysis at Sea
description: To the Editor: As I sat on a comfortable bed, propped up with huge pillows, looking out a picture window at the Pacific, attended by expert nurses, I thought, how lucky I am to have found a way to do the traveling I had thought impossible.

title: A Yank at Wembley
description: JOHN HARKES, a 24-year-old midfielder from Kearny, N.J., who played for the United States in the 1990 World Cup competition, will make a bit of soccer history today when he becomes the first American player to appear in an English soccer final at Wembley Stadium.

title: The Executive Computer; Trying to Assess the Potential Hazards of Video Terminals
description: Several recent studies have provided more information about the health effects of computer use, and one of them included what appears to be reassuring news about the effects of electromagnetic fields on pregnant women.

title: Draft Notes
description: The Washington Redskins select at No. 20 in the first round and will make their first first-round pick since 1983, when they drafted cornerback Darrell Green.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Hanover, N.H.;
More Space For Stores
description: WHEN commercial space became sparse in this college town, retailers converted basement storerooms and second-floor apartments into stores. Now some retailers are becoming commercial developers.

title: Vermont Senate Unit Moves to Weaken a Car Ozone Law
description: A State Senate committee has agreed to weaken Vermont's pioneering law prohibiting the sale of automobiles with air-conditioners that contain ozone-depleting chemicals.

title: Campus Life: Texas A & M; Revising Policies On Discrimination Creates Criticism
description: Despite protests primarily from proponents of gay rights, the president of Texas A & M University is rewriting policies on discrimination and harassment to eliminate references to sexual preference and specific groups.

title: The Creature That Lives in Pittsburgh
description: The last few months have been heady ones for William L. Whittaker, the Carnegie-Mellon University professor considered one the nation's foremost robot designers. First came the demonstration for Government officials of the Ambler, Dr. Whittaker's 19-foot tall, six-legged robot designed to explore Mars someday. In a rock garden on the Carnegie-Mellon campus here, Ambler stepped over high boulders and avoided holes, a formidable achievement for a robot. "It was one of those holy moments," said Dr. Whittaker, 42, a former Marine whose friends call him Red. "It was mystical to see the Ambler get up and go. My heart was in my throat."

title: Allison Wohl Engaged To Christopher George
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Wohl of Roslyn Estates, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Allison Brooke Wohl to Christopher Corey George, a son of Martha Baum of North Hills, L.I., and Charles George of Palm Beach, Fla. An August wedding is planned.

title: Splatterpunk of Tomorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. About five years ago, I painted my garage floor with a latex primer and then a coat of flat exterior latex. The appearance was fine, but the latex lifted off wherever the car's tires rested on it. A year later, I painted the floor again with a good grade of alkyd floor enamel, but the problem remained . One year later, I repeated this paint job, but with no better results. Last year, I cleaned and sanded the bare spots, then repainted with an epoxy. The problem was not quite as bad, although it is still there. Is there some special primer I should apply to the bare concrete spots to keep the paint from lifting?

title: Louisiana Prizes Crawfish: Stewed, Sauced or Plain
description: HOT and spicy cooking smells are one of many signs of Louisiana's seasonal madness -- the pursuit of crawfish, which appear in cafeteria stews, in pies, salads, mousses, on top of pasta and over crab cakes, catfish filets and under silky sauces in better restaurants.

title: Review/Dance; Pieces by and With Susan Osberg
description: Susan Osberg, whose Workwith Dancers Company presented three works at the Dia Center for the Arts on Thursday night, appears to follow no fashion. This independence is embodied in her strong solos. She is an exquisite dancer, and every unfolding elongated line, clear shape and tension-filled detail in her hand gestures can hold a viewer's complete interest.

title: Camera
description: Have you ever had an urge to shoot slides with your point-and-shoot camera?

title: Heard the One About the 'Haffner'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess
description: It is not out of the question to cope with an opponent's surprise -- after all, the Cuban genius Jose Raul Capablanca defeated the Marshall Gambit the first time that Frank Marshall, the United States champion from 1909 to 1936, revealed it to the world, in 1918 at the Manhattan Chess Club. But, by and large, surprises disturb the opponent's equilibrium.

title: Citing Law, Judge Takes Black Child From White Couple
description: A county judge has ruled that a black child can be taken from her white foster parents and given to her grandparents in a case that had challenged a state law giving preference to relatives and adoptive parents of the same race as the child.

title: 'Journey of Hope': From Despair
description: Since the Academy Awards ceremony last month, the French have been grumbling over the fact that "Cyrano de Bergerac" failed to win the prize for best foreign-language film, a verdict they interpret as a sign of American hostility to French movies.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: F. SKIP LATELLA;
Getting in Shape on Exercise Equipment
description: WITH warmer weather here and pools and beaches set to open in about a month, many people are dusting off New Year's resolutions to get in shape. For some, this means buying exercise equipment or joining a health club.

title: Social Events
description: Spartacus' Restored

title:
ART;
Nine Artists From Cuba, At the 'Edge of the World'
description: "THE Nearest Edge of the World," the title of an exhibition of new art from Cuba now at the Bronx Museum for the Arts, refers to Cuba's relationship with the United States. We are neighbors separated by a distance known to schoolchildren -- at least schoolchildren in the 1960's -- of 90 miles. Yet as far as we in the United States have understood Cuban culture since the revolution, Cuba might have fallen over the edge of the known world.

title: Q and A
description: Jersey Tenant Protection Question: We live in a rent-controlled apartment. Three years ago the landlord notified tenants that the building would be converted to a condominium and gave us three years to buy our apartment or vacate. Is there a law in New Jersey that protects tenants in this situation? . . . Mona Vaswani, Jersey City Answer: Yes, but the protection is temporary. On March 4, Gov. Jim Florio signed a bill providing a statewide moratorium on evicting tenants who do not buy their apartments in conversions.

title: Ilse Padegs Wed To John Willems
description: Ilse Padegs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juris Padegs of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Sisk Willems, the son of Jane E. Sisk of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. and Leonard F. Willems of Ottawa. The ceremony, at the Latvian Evangelical Lutheran Church in Yonkers, was performed by the Rev. Albert Ozols, Dean of the church's Eastern District.

title: Bridge
description: It can safely be said that a young woman's laughter changed the history of bridge. The date was 1922, the place was Montreal, and she was laughing at the incompetence of a young McGill University law student trying to play auction bridge. Pride bruised, he went away determined to master the game, which became contract bridge later in the decade.

title: After Customs, A Surprise Tax
description: A New Yorker got a rude shock last winter: The state wrote her to say that she owed $666.60 in sales taxes on $8,080 in purchases she made overseas and brought home through Customs in October 1989, paying the appropriate duty. Worse, the letter said she owed $93.32 more for interest at 1 percent a month.

title: Nets Defeat Heat, 118-103; Fitch Is Planning to Return
description: While the premier teams in the league talked about the playoffs and dreamed of winning a championship, the Nets and the Miami Heat pondered their vacation plans and hoped to avoid last place in the Atlantic Division. And Coach Bill Fitch fended off speculation that he might take a permanent vacation and resign after the Nets finish their season Sunday in Orlando.

title: How Many Microphones?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hungary
description: To the Editor: I thought Celestine Bohlen's article on Pecs ("Glimpsing Hungary's Ottoman Past," Travel, March 10) was just fine, and I was pleased to see that she mentioned the artist Victor Vasarely, a native son.

title: Davis of Orioles Ties Record With 4th Error
description: For a while it appeared that he had come up one short, but after some second thoughts by an official scorer, first baseman GLENN DAVIS of the Baltimore Orioles tied an American league record for first basemen by committing four errors in a single game, including two on one play.

title: Sports of The Times; The Filly Earned Her Chance
description: If they hadn't given her a chance, they would never have known how much the gentle little filly named Meadow Star could do against the big boys.

title: Global Speed Mark Likely to Be Broken
description: Few could have predicted last Sept. 15, at the start of the BOC yacht race around the world in Newport, R.I., how fast the leading single-handed sailboats would circle the globe.

title: Cahill Road Wins Wood But Is Hurt
description: Racing fortunes gyrated wildly yesterday on the road to the Kentucky Derby. Meadow Star lost for the first time as Cahill Road won the Wood Memorial but suffered a leg injury that may end his brief but brilliant career.

title: Unknown Armstrong Songs Come to Light in Jazz Series
description: In the world of jazz, discovering a previously unknown recording by Louis Armstrong is like finding an unknown manuscript by Mozart. Not since 1939 had any surfaced from what are considered Armstrong's most creative years -- the late 1920's and early 30's.

title: Caution Is Not Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Big George's New Niche in History
description: In his other life as a boxer, the other fighter always owned the crowd whenever George Foreman lost. Sometimes even when he won. Before dawn in Zaire in 1974, Africans chanted, "Ali, bomaye," meaning "Ali, kill him."

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: La Jolla, Calif.;
Gothic Temple Stirs a Debate
description: A GOTHIC-STYLE Mormon temple going up near a busy mid-rise office district is this area's most discussed new building. Distinguished by 10 steel-framed spires, it sits on a hill overlooking Interstate 5, just east of this exclusive coastal community.

title: Split Over Police Role In CUNY Turmoil
description: As student protests at the City University of New York approach the end of their second week, administrators, college presidents and the Dinkins administration appear divided over how to handle a series of building takeovers.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: THE bird was as plump as a bumblebee, and it waddled, more than walked, down the branch of the apple tree, poked its head into the cavity and disappeared. A minute later, having completed its housing inspection, the bird renavigated the length of the branch, plumped its feathers, turned a butter-colored bill to the sky and put its acceptance speech into song -- a babble of chips, gurgles, squeaks and whistles.

title: Lilco May Scrap Plan to Buy Quebec Power
description: LILCO is reconsidering a plan to buy 218 megawatts of hydroelectric power from Canada that it had said was crucial to meeting electric demand.

title: Elizabeth Sarnoff to Wed A. S. Cohen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Sarnoff of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ann Sarnoff to Andrew Scott Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester A. Cohen of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Making a Difference; Scouting for Cookies
description: Don't think it's easy getting 165 million boxes of cookies. Ask Mary Rose Main.

title: Met Season: Better Than It Looked
description: Another Metropolitan Opera season has sunk in the west, leaving behind the usual tangle of impressions. A 30-week schedule that began with a Franco Zeffirelli production ("La Boheme") also ended with one ("Tosca"). How fitting. It is likely that recent decades in Met history will be best remembered as a time when celebrated directors and designers like Mr. Zeffirelli and the late Jean-Pierre Ponnelle exercised an unprecedented influence over the company's fortunes. The Met's trustees and its artistic director, James Levine, no doubt believe that history will prove that influence to have been benign. Perhaps so, financially. But the Met, which once could pride itself on being known internationally as a "singer's house," is now at least equally renowned for the empty lavishness of its productions. There seems no reason why the reigning director of the Met's next decade should not be Andrew Lloyd Webber, if the company could afford his fees.

title: Charter Flights
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade compares charter with scheduled airline fares and seating arrangements in "Taking a Trip With a Charter" (Practical Traveler, March 24). I wonder if anything else has changed in charter service since I swore several years ago never to fly charter again. I am talking about the interminable delays at airports, discourtesy and general lack of flight information from ground personnel, plus involved confirmation procedures for return flights. Most charter travelers accepted these indignities in exchange for lower fares.

title: The Tortuous Issue of Diversity
description: Lamar Alexander, the Secretary of Education, has challenged a regional accrediting association to justify its use of cultural diversity as one standard in evaluating colleges and universities. His challenge imposes two burdens. One is on the accrediting body, the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools, to insure that this new standard is an appropriate criterion for accreditation and will not require schools to achieve arbitrary numerical racial, ethnic or sexual balance. Another burden is on Mr. Alexander to insure that his own review of the accreditors is based on a concern for academic quality, not politics.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 21, 1991
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 27 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An F.B.I. man and woman track a serial killer. 2 6 RED DRAGON, by Thomas Harris. (Dell, $5.95.) A retired F.B.I. agent returns to service to track down a serial killer. 3 19 DANCES WITH WOLVES, by Michael Blake. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A Civil War veteran adopts the ways of the Indians and fights for their principles. 4 3 THE EVENING NEWS, by Arthur Hailey. (Dell, $5.95.) Life as lived by two competitive correspondents for a television network. 5 7 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $5.95.) Jason Bourne plans to infiltrate the ruthless Medusa Brigade. 6 4 SKINNY LEGS AND ALL, by Tom Robbins. (Bantam, $5.95.) The horror and humor of the upcoming apocalypse, played out in a restaurant. 7 9 SLEEPING WITH THE ENEMY, by Nancy Price. (Berkley, $4.95.) To escape a cruel marriage, a woman fakes her death. 8 7 BITTER SWEET, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Jove, $5.95.) A widow meets an old flame. 9 * 4 THE FIFTH PROFESSION, by David Morrell. (Warner, $5.95.) Two security agents on a mission to rescue a woman from her billionaire husband. 10 3 WHISPER TO ME OF LOVE, by Shirlee Busbee. (Avon, $4.95.) A street waif and a wealthy American planter in 18th-century London. 11 2 DARK ANGEL, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $5.95.) A waif who becomes a grande dame after being adopted by a wealthy family in Edwardian England learns a shocking truth about her past. 12 1 SPECIAL OPERATIONS, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Jove, $4.95.) The Philadelphia police wage a war against a spree of kidnapping and rape. 13 7 THE SCIONS OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $5.95.) Two brothers practice magic in a fantasy land where its use is forbidden. 14 3 AMERICAN PSYCHO, by Bret Easton Ellis. (Vintage, $11.) A yuppie of the 1980's on a round of sadistic murders and mayhem. 15 8 THE GOLD COAST, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $5.95.) Life changes for an old WASP family when the head of a crime family becomes its neighbor. Weeks This On Week List NonFiction 1 5 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 2 40 NO ONE HERE GETS OUT ALIVE, by Jerry Hopkins and Danny Sugerman. (Warner, $5.95.) The life of Jim Morrison, lead singer of the Doors. 3 36 FROM BEIRUT TO JERUSALEM, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) The Arab-Israeli conflict over the past decade. 4 74 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Ivy, $5.95.) Inspirational essays. 5 14 NOT WITHOUT MY DAUGHTER, by Betty Mahmoody with William Hoffer. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An American woman held captive in Iran. 6 389 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 7 1 THE SPY WENT DANCING, by Aline, Countess of Romanones. (Jove, $5.95.) The experiences of a C.I.A. operative assigned to trap a NATO mole. 8 5 THE SEARCH FOR THE GREEN RIVER KILLER, by Carlton Smith and Tomas Guillen. (Onyx, $4.99.) A serial killer in Washington State. 9 1 STORMIN' NORMAN, by Jack Anderson and Dale Van Atta. (Zebra, $4.50.) The career of Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. 10 29 THE ROAD FROM COORAIN, by Jill Ker Conway. (Vintage, $8.95.) A girl's life in Australia. 11 * 120 LOVE, MEDICINE, AND MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper Perennial, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 12 * 1 THE SLEEPING LADY, by Robert Graysmith. (Onyx, $5.99.) A serial murderer in the California wilderness near San Francisco Bay. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-To and Miscellaneous 1 5 THE REVENGE OF THE BABY-SAT, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $7.95.) Cartoons. 2 38 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) How to reduce fat in one's diet. 3 18 THE SEVEN HABITS OF HIGHLY EFFECTIVE PEOPLE, by Stephen R. Covey. (Fireside/S&S, $9.95.) Principles for success. 4 21 ALL I NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED FROM MY CAT, by Suzy Becker. (Workman, $5.95.) Precepts of a wise cat, in words and pictures. 5 5 THE T-FACTOR DIET, by Martin Katahn. (Bantam, $4.95.) A regimen for weight loss. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Brazil's Chief Revokes Orders That Cut Tribe's Amazon Land
description: President Fernando Collor de Mello has revoked a series of decrees that had sharply reduced the Amazon lands reserved for the Yanomami Indians, one of the world's largest traditional tribal peoples.

title: The World; A Reward, Not a Cure, for South Africa
description: IN the nearly 15 months since he set about to end apartheid, President F. W. de Klerk has tried to convince the world that the political changes he set in motion were irreversible. Last week, the European Community took him at his word, lifting a trading ban, imposed in 1986, on iron, steel and gold coins from South Africa. The community's move, which followed by four months its lifting of a ban on new investments, was welcomed here as presaging the end of an international framework of sanctions enacted in protest against the racist ideology that Mr. de Klerk is dismantling.

title: Technology; New Techniques to Turn an Oil Spill Into a Collectible
description: If there had been any doubt, recent scientific studies of the environmental impact of the Exxon Valdez spill have demonstrated that the toxic effect of oil on animals and plant life persists for years.

title: Miss Fergusson to Wed in September
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Blake Fergusson of King of Prussia, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Munro Fergusson to Benjamin Bacon James, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Renson James of Lincoln, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: Prophet of the Rimrock
description: THE RIVER OF THE MOTHER OF GOD And Other Essays. By Aldo Leopold. Edited by Susan L. Flader and J. Baird Callicott. Illustrated. 384 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $24.95.

title: Privacy of Woman in Rape Case Was Invaded; Identifying the Victim
description: To the Editor:

title: Avery Corman Examines Date Rape
description: WHEN a college tennis star from an affluent family insists on having sex with a coed who tries to fight him off, can she sue him for sexual harassment?

title: Privacy of Woman in Rape Case Was Invaded; Rights of the Accused
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Ancient Ones' Inspire Hopis
description: THE 14 Hopi craftsmen whose work is on exhibition here at the Adobe East gallery trace their inspiration to the symbols and ceremonies of their ancestors. Artifacts and petroglyph stone drawings of the Anasazi, the "ancient ones," who settled in the Southwest before A.D. 700 and whom the Hopi consider their ancestors, provide some of the motifs.

title:
DINING OUT;
Some Surprises at Old Chappaqua Spot
description: DINERS put off in the past by mediocre food, sloppy service and dingy decor at the Kittle House are in for a pleasant surprise. John and Dick Crabtree have wisely stepped aside and left the restaurant's management to Glen Vogt, a thorough professional, whose specialty seems to be spinning straw into gold. While this process is not complete, notable progress must be applauded.

title: Club Where Height Is a Requirement
description: LYNN WASILEWSKI said that one of the most wonderful things happened a few months ago when she joined the New Jersey Moonrakers Tall Club, a group for tall people.

title: Cellist's Transplant Is Colleagues' Cause
description: MUSICIANS in Connecticut are mobilizing to help Michael Jancz, a 30-year-old cellist and bassist from Ridgefield who had a liver transplant in February. Patricia Weiner of Danbury, a concert manager on leave from Yale University and longtime friend of Mr. Jancz, has recruited not only musicians but also businesses, educational institutions, churches and restaurants, primarily in Danbury and Ridgefield, to raise money to help offset his medical expenses.

title: Travel Advisory; War at an End, Cruise Lines Raise Rates
description: As travelers' fears diminish with the conclusion of the Persian Gulf war amid signs of an easing of the recession, several major cruise lines have moved to raise their rates. Many cruise lines had offered discounts or deferred price increases during the war.

title: A July Wedding For Alice Wade
description: The engagement of Alice Evelyn Wade to Joseph Preston Altier, a son of Cornelia Johnston Altier of Lincroft, N.J., and Joseph P. Altier of New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius J. Wade of Glen Cove, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: Review/Music; Banda Loca And Sounds Of Merengue
description: Hits, in whatever market, have a finite amount of capital. Banda Loca, a New York-based merengue group that played at S.O.B.'s last Friday night, is riding a hit, "La Calambrina." The group has been playing regularly around New York on the merengue circuit, and by the time it arrived at S.O.B.'s, the hit was spent. Not many people turned out.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: WEDDINGS MARCH

title: Sterling Forest
description: To the Editor:

title: Trevira Women's Victor Sets Record for 10 Miles
description: A few days after she got lost in Central Park and made one of life's fateful discoveries, Jill Hunter of Newcastle, England, turned her discovery into destiny yesterday. She won the women's leg of the 13th annual Trevira Twosome by running a 10-mile course through the park in 51 minutes 41 seconds, 6 seconds faster than any other woman had run the distance before.

title: Headliners; Telling None
description: The special narcotics prosecutor for New York City seems determined to find out just how far Lynne F. Stewart will go for her client. It may be all the way to jail. Mrs. Stewart, a prominent defense lawyer, has repeatedly refused a demand by the prosecutor, Sterling Johnson Jr., that she disclose the source and amount of fees she got for defending a drug dealer. Last week, in the first such action ever against a New York lawyer, Mrs. Stewart was indicted for criminal contempt for refusing Mr. Johnson's demand, which she said would force her to violate attorney-client privilege. She risks four years in prison and automatic disbarment. Mrs. Stewart said she was being prosecuted because the authorities didn't like her clients. "It is clear that I have been singled out for prosecution," she said, "and the unescapable conclusion is that it must be for a reason, and that can only be that my life's work is an affront to the prosecution."

title: Postings: SoHo Renovation; What's Brewing?
description: The Manhattan Brewing Company, the only working brewery on the island, won't reopen this fall after a major alteration of its building at Thompson and Watts Streets, in SoHo.

title: Amy S. Kaplan To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans for Amy Sue Kaplan and Bjorn Olof Sixten Ahlmen, the son of Birgitta Ahlmen of Stockholm, have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kaplan of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Sunday Menu; Risotto, a Crisp and Creamy Ode to Asparagus
description: A sure sign of spring is the drop in the price of asparagus from astronomical to merely expensive. That time has come, and there is no better way to salute these vivid green stalks than in a primavera dish -- not pasta, but risotto.

title: Leaner Hamburger Undergoes Trial by Taste
description: McLean Left! McLean Left! Make way for the Brave New Burger!

title: Boom in Manufactured Exports Provides Hope for U.S. Economy
description: In a quiet revolution, the United States, long derided as an industrial has-been, has become one of the world's low-cost manufacturers -- lower in many industries than Canada, Europe and Japan.

title: Vicksburg, the Town and the Battle
description: ON our first trip to Vicksburg, my mother-in-law, a Mississippi-reared daughter of a Baptist minister, sang "Amazing Grace" while we stood spellbound in the Illinois Memorial at the Vicksburg battlefield. The monument, one of the most tranquil in America, is renowned for its acoustics. One should go to Vicksburg to learn about the Civil War, to appreciate the profound link between rivers and urban life in 19th-century America, to partake of the hospitality endemic in small towns in the Deep South, but singing, or being sung to, in the Illinois Memorial is a powerful reason in itself.

title: Travel Advisory; Guatemala Alert
description: Violent crime has increased throughout Guatemala, including tourist destinations, in recent months, says a State Department advisory. It warns Americans not to climb the Pacaya Volcano near Guatemala City, adding that several tourist groups have been assaulted there. Two American tourists have died, the advisory, dated April 13, reported; one was murdered. The department adds that travelers to Guatemala City, Antigua, Panajachel and Chichicastenango report an increase in robberies and assaults. And encounnters between security forces and bandits and guerrillas, who sometimes block roads, continue in some areas.

title: Food; The Sweet Season
description: It was during mud season when a woman I know got her car stuck and it froze overnight. When she finally got it out, she found that the wires to the fuel pump were broken, the front wheels frozen, the brakes full of stones, and a joint in the front axle badly damaged. The tow truck ripped the bumper off. The factory undercoating, she recalls, remained in the mud "like a skeleton."

title: No-Nonsense Basketball Player
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: From Depressed To Manic: Is The Street Sick?
description: If psychiatrists were the experts most employed by Wall Street, instead of economists, the term for the 1990-91 stock market would be manic-depressive.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Memphis
description: Along the Mississippi River bluffs, a 32-story-tall stainless-steel-coated pyramid housing a 20,000-seat arena and major exhibit halls has become the symbol of a changing Memphis. The Great American Pyramid is framed by the I-40 entrance ramps to the Hernando DeSoto Bridge to Arkansas and surrounded by an aging commercial and industrial area.

title: Loud Rumors Over Herr's Soft Bat
description: Tom Herr is aware of the whispering the team's pitchers have engaged in, the indiscreet effort to restore Kevin Elster to the starting lineup and thus push him from it. He is, as well, cognizant of the significant focus his lifeless start to the season at the plate has attracted in the media coverage of the Mets.

title:
FORUM;
Why So Many Business Alliances Fail
description: Kubota Ltd., Japan's largest producer of farm equipment, made nothing more complex than a tractor for its first 98 years. Then, in 1988, it shipped a mini-supercomputer that was one of the most advanced in the world. The design, chips and software were all American, coming from strategic alliances with some of the most innovative start-ups in Silicon Valley.

title: F.B.I. Sting Helps Corrupt a Politician
description: STING operation. The words evoke memories of the all-too-frequent exposures of betrayals of public trust perpetrated by elected officials. Grainy film clips broadcast on the television news programs expose politicians in the act of collecting money or drugs, or of accepting payoffs from those for whom the democratic process is a barrier.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: The Senate Banking Committee considers the nomination of Lawrence Lindsey to Federal Reserve Board. * Deadline for HBJ bondholders to tender to General Cinema.

title: The Nation; When Grass Looks Greener On This Side of the Fence
description: ELECTED officials and businessmen have long been used to the Nimby phenomenon. When it comes to locating worrisome facilities -- prisons, homeless shelters, waste dumps -- in their neighborhoods, many residents say, "Not in my backyard." These days, those who conduct public opinion polls are becoming increasingly familiar with another side of Nimby: many of the problems that plague the nation -- pollution, poor schools, police brutality -- occur everywhere, but "not in my backyard." Indeed, when answering questions posed by poll takers the position often adopted by Americans seems to be "I'm O.K., you're not."

title: Robert Capanna Weds Ms. Coate
description: Cathryn Coate, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Coate of Malvern, Pa., was married yesterday to Robert Capanna, the son of Mrs. Armand Capanna of Maple Shade, N.J., and the late Mr. Capanna. The Quaker ceremony took place at the Friends Meetinghouse at Fourth and Arch Streets in Philadelphia.

title: Houston Journal; A House With a History May Not Have a Future
description: The sounds of demolition are now as familiar in the forested suburb of Bunker Hill Village as the sounds of new construction. "Teardowns," old and not-so-old houses bought for their property and then pounded into rubble to make room for new ones, have become the rage here.

title: Blood Drives Halted After Protests By Students
description: A CONTROVERSY over Federal blood-donor restrictions, imposed to protect the blood supply against the virus that causes AIDS, has led to the cancellations of blood drives at the State Universities at Stony Brook and Farmingdale and C. W. Post and Nassau Community Colleges. Last year, a total of 18,000 pints of blood was collected at the four colleges.

title: Stamps
description: To discourage two scams, one organized, one occasional, the United States Postal Service has changed its methods of printing stamps costing 8 cents or less. The public probably will not notice the change; collectors interested in modern United States stamps are puzzling over the likely results.

title: Campus Life: SUNY, Binghamton; Dispute Arises In the Aftermath Of Lecture Protest
description: A coalition of students and faculty members at the State University of New York at Binghamton is challenging the accounts of a professor who contended that a lecture he gave last month was violently disrupted by students concerned about rumors of a Ku Klux Klan presence.

title: Female Athletes Should Be Cheered
description: How sad that once again girls' efforts are considered less worthy of school services than boys! [ "Cheering for Girls," Long Island Journal, March 10 ] The Sayville School District is reluctant to provide cheerleading for its girls' basketball teams as well as its boys'. Yet what an opportunity it has to display its respect for, and encouragement of, its female athletes.

title: Leslie A. White To Marry in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard P. Veler of Springfield, Ohio, have announced July wedding plans for Mrs. Veler's daughter Leslie Allis White and Joseph Thomas Caulfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick L. Caulfield of Short Hills, N.J.

title: 4 Tough Guys in a Morality Fable
description: THE natty Willie, "at the top of his profession," pushes drugs and steals cars.

title: Future in Mind, Choctaws Reject Plan for Landfill
description: Invoking a sense of mystery about the land that has been their home for generations and expressing concern for future generations, the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians has rejected a proposal to develop a hazardous-waste landfill near its reservation.

title: Dumping of Putnam Sewage Is Raising New Questions
description: THE disclosure this month that sewage-waste haulers from Putnam County have been illegally dumping into this county's septic system has raised questions about how well Westchester has supervised its own operations.

title: Her Childhood Was Doomed
description: THICKER THAN WATER

title: Ismail Aims for Rich Deal From Cowboys
description: A bushel of questions and intrigue surrounds today's 56th National Football League draft with the 28 teams hoping that the menu offers more treats than tricks.

title: Marcy Thurman to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Thurman of Alpine, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Marcy Lee Thurman and Christopher Brenner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore E. Brenner of Rumson, N.J. Miss Thurman, 26 years old, is an assistant production manager at Dugan, Valva Associates, an advertising agency in Morristown, N.J. Mr. Brenner, 25, is a sales representative at the R. S. Knapp Company, a graphics concern in Lyndhurst, N.J. Both graduated from the Rochester Institute of Technology.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Motorhead: '1916' WTG/Epic NK46858; all three formats.

title: Be Healthy, Make Money, and Scorn the Sick; Lowest Medicaid Fee
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: Williams and DiMaggio

title: Strike Trouble? Call 267-9800
description: Residents with complaints about emergency conditions in buildings struck by workers can call the Police Department's Office of Emergency Management at (212) 267-9800 between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M.

title: Iceland Conservatives Gain; Parties Discuss a Coalition
description: Iceland's conservative opposition party gained in parliamentary elections, according to final returns announced today, but not in sufficient numbers to guarantee that it can form a government.

title: Healthy Fetal Signs
description: A bill just approved in Albany will require all restaurants, taverns and stores selling liquor in New York State to post conspicuous signs warning of the danger of alcohol consumption for pregnant women. Contrary to the view of some women's rights advocates, the law -- already in effect in nine other states and New York City -- is an inoffensive way to heighten awareness about a significant cause of mental retardation.

title: Review/Theater; Spunky Southern Woman Tells All in a Monodrama
description: Although "Ivy Rowe," the monodrama by Mark Hunter and Barbara Bates Smith that opened yesterday at the Provincetown Playhouse, treads the same narrative path as that of Lee Smith's epistolary novel "Fair and Tender Ladies," it lacks the resonance of the book. It is an episodic selection from a folio of letters rather than a complete dramatic characterization.

title: The Rocket Vanishes
description: IN signing a four-year bonanza with the Toronto Argonauts reportedly worth a potential $26.2 million, the Rocket accepted the money instead of the challenge.

title: Thousands Greet Schwarzkopf's Return
description: America's No. 1 soldier in the Persian Gulf, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, returned home today to a rousing hero's welcome from family, friends and flag-waving admirers.

title: Jo Anne Weisman Weds
description: Jo Anne Weisman, the daughter of Helen Weisman and Henry Weisman Jr., both of Shreveport, La., was married yesterday to Laurence Frank Gordon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Gordon of New York. Rabbi Robert Levine performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York.

title: Cuomo Sends Dinkins Smoky Fiscal Signal
description: New York City officials readily concede that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo plays politics at a level far above theirs, a level that one aide to Mayor David N. Dinkins likened to three-dimensional chess.

title: U.S. Giving Certain Boat Owners Exclusive Rights to Fish Off Coast
description: Without fanfare, Washington has begun to turn over to private interests the exclusive rights to the multibillion-dollar harvest of fish off the United States coast.

title: Kravis Acquires Ranch
description: Henry R. Kravis, a principal of the investment firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, paid $5.5 million in cash on Friday for the 4,500-acre Bricklin Ranch, a week before banks were to foreclose on the property.

title: Sean O'Faolain, an Irish Master Of the Short Story, Is Dead at 91
description: Sean O'Faolain, an Irish writer who was considered a master of the short story, died on Saturday in the Dublin nursing home where he had lived for two years. He was 91 years old.

title: Jerome S. Glazer, 66, New Orleans Importer
description: Jerome Sanford Glazer, a New Orleans businessman and developer long active in political and civic affairs, died early Saturday at his home. He was 66 years old.

title: Gorbachev's Tokyo Miscalculation
description: Only a week ago, as Mikhail S. Gorbachev headed here during the first visit of a Soviet leader to Japan, it seemed as if he might be on the verge of the deal of the Pacific century: an open spigot of Japanese investment and technology in return for a solution to the territorial dispute that has plagued relations between Tokyo and Moscow for four decades.

title: Giants Go First for a Fullback Who Can Block
description: The Giants won Super Bowl XXV in January with a power running attack. Look for the same type of offense this season.

title: Oliver Smith's Vision Of Ballet Theater
description: "We're working within our own company to develop personalities," Oliver Smith said intently, his long lean frame tucked into a chair in an office at American Ballet Theater headquarters, just north of Union Square. "And we're looking for works that will bring out their special gifts." He was pleased, he added, to see Sylvie Guillem, a sleek young guest ballerina from Paris, enthusiastically tackling the starkly unglamorous role of Lizzie Borden in Agnes de Mille's "Fall River Legend," which she is to dance this season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Marie Alonzo Teachers College Performance Space Columbia University 120th Street, near Broadway

title: First Fall in Net At 3M Since '85
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the Scotch tape and abrasives maker known as 3M, has reported its first drop in quarterly profits since 1985. It attributed the decline to the sluggish world economy.

title: A Voyage Through a Harbor's Memories
description: There is no grander spectacle than New York Harbor's imperial skyscraping backdrop, the scene that attracts countless tourists to the sightseeing boats that focus on concrete canyons and the tracery of soaring bridges.

title: Maas Walks Way Through a Slump
description: The rain poured down yesterday as if someone had forgotten to shut off a kitchen faucet, but Kevin Maas turned it into a workday anyway.

title: Review/Theater; 'Black Eagles,' a World War II Fighter Squadron
description: At the curtain call of a press performance of "Black Eagles," the new play about black World War II pilots at the Manhattan Theater Club, the company silenced the applause to introduce some real-life characters in the audience. Two distinguished-looking men, identified as actual members of the squadron known as the Tuskegee Airmen, stood up in the auditorium and received the warmest hand of the night. No wonder. Not only were the men bona-fide war heroes, but they also looked as authentic as the bowing actors dressed in spotless, wrinkle-free khaki looked fake.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Seles Snares Title Top-seeded Monica Seles beat Mary Joe Fernandez for the fifth straight time yesterday, 6-4, 6-3, to win the Virginia Slims of Houston. It was the second championship in Houston for Seles, who won her first career tournament here in 1989. Fernandez, of Miami, played aggressively, but it wasn't enough to overpower the world's No. 1 ranked player. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on Thursday about the Spirit of Achievement Awards of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine referred incorrectly to the soprano June Anderson. She is American, not British.

title: Jill Quentzel Is Married To Dr. Joshua Winston
description: Jill Sondra Quentzel, the daughter of Rochelle P. Quentzel of West End, N.J., and Gerald H. Quentzel of New York, was married yesterday at Congregation Nir Tamid in Las Vegas, Nev., to Dr. Joshua Winston, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis Winston of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Sanford Axelrod officiated.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Discover Credit Corp., a subisidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Co., Chicago, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $1 billion in debt securities.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on Friday about Time Warner Inc.'s first-quarter earnings misstated the increase in Entertainment Weekly's circulation. It is 50,000, not 50 percent, ahead of its rate base, which is 650,000.

title: Sale of California S.& L. Is Cleared
description: The Resolution Trust Corporation has approved the sale of the Imperial Federal Savings Association, based in San Diego, to the Bank of the West and the Household Bank.

title: How to Save Money on Jails
description: Through the 1980's, New York, like other big cities, faced chronic jail crowding. The city sought to keep pace mostly by building more jails. But it can no longer afford that, and Correction Commissioner Allyn Sielaff proposes to limit the jail population by expanding on correctional alternatives well tested in other cities. His program merits Albany's support.

title: Mozart Show at the Morgan
description: An exhibition of autograph scores and letters of Mozart and early printed editions of his music will go on display on May 8 at the Pierpont Morgan Library (29 East 36th Street) in observance of the bicentennial of the composer's death. The show, "Mozart: Prodigy of Nature," will range from four short keyboard pieces Mozart composed at the age of 5 to a draft excerpt of "Die Zauberflote," one of his last works. A half-hour video on Mozart's life, narrated by the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade, will be shown daily as part of the exhibition, which will run through Aug. 4 and then travel to the British Library in London. Information: (212) 685-0008.

title: Kraft Awards Job to Ogilvy
description: Kraft General Foods has awarded its direct marketing account, which is likely to exceed $30 million, to Ogilvy & Mather Direct.

title: ESPN Show Was a Draftnik's Nirvana
description: ESPN's coverage of yesterday's National Football League draft proved one thing: that a record-length near-five-hour first round replete with talking heads need not be a sleepathon. Maybe the folks behind the Academy Awards show will learn from ESPN's run-and-shoot production that vapid song-and-dance numbers are unnecessary. Just put Chris Berman up on the podium to bestow the Oscar on Tom (Let Me Take You On A Sea) Cruise.

title: Study on Children's TV Ads
description: About 20 percent of children's television programming consists of nonprogram material, mostly advertising, a study made public today said.

title: Albania Needs Humanitarian Aid Right Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; In Istanbul, Fighting the Cold War
description: Siro By David Ignatius 467 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title:
TENNIS;
Borg Comes Back to a Court of Curiosity
description: Eight years ago, after Bjorn Borg played what was supposed to be his farewell tennis here at the Monte Carlo Country Club, the 26-year-old retiree said: "I feel good. When I wake up in the morning now, I know I don't have to go out and practice four or five hours."

title: Lisa Nachtigall, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Lisa Beth Nachtigall, a daughter of Dr. Lila E. Nachtigall and Dr. Richard H. Nachtigall of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Charles Flaumenhaft, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Flaumenhaft of Wallingford, Conn. Judd Livingston, a rabbinical student, and Cantor Charles Block performed the ceremony at the weekend home of the bride's family in Kent Cliffs, N.Y.

title: In This Battle of Okinawa, G.I.'s Hold Their Fire
description: American military spokesmen have explained again and again to the people of this town on Okinawa that there is simply no way that marksmen training at a nearby firing range could accidentally send bullets into the resort hotels lining the area's beaches.

title: J. C. Penney's Woes Tied to Lack of Identity
description: The J. C. Penney Company had high hopes that by now it would be enjoying the fruits of its 1987 transformation from a full-line department store to primarily a clothing store.

title: Jill Schlesinger Is Married to Ronald Steven Fuchs
description: Jill Schlesinger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Schlesinger of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday to Ronald Steven Fuchs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fuchs of Wayne, N.J. Rabbis Jack Stern and Israel Dresner performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel.

title: Sununu's Trips On Military Jets Become an Issue
description: John H. Sununu, the combative White House chief of staff, found himself at the center of a new political squall today after news accounts of his extensive travel aboard military aircraft on personal and political trips, as well as on official business.

title: Fans May Be Doubtful But the Knicks Aren't
description: As the Knicks begin preparations for their three-of-five-game playoff series against the Chicago Bulls, most people expect New York to lose.

title: Review/Television; As Networks Go Rural, CBS Goes a Bit Further
description: Television entertainment these days is going out of town, quite literally. Urban America on prime time's plethora of law-enforcement shows is infested with crime and social problems. Suburbia isn't much better. Television does, in its way, reflect reality. Now, more and more, weekly series are fleeing to out-of-the-way towns and villages. The farther away from a big city, it seems, the better.

title: Bridge
description: There are many unsung heroes who work quietly behind the scenes, as amateurs, to make tournaments run successfully. The bridge public has little understanding of the time and effort that is required.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates of major economic indicators this week. Monday None

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Mirage of Discount Air Fares Is Frustrating to Many Fliers
description: The recent spate of airline advertisements offering drastically reduced fares for flights to the umbrellaed tables of the Cote d'Azur or the green felt tables of Las Vegas or other wondrous spots brought a resounding response from would-be travelers.

title: Israel Criticizes Baker's Plea but Denies Crisis
description: In their first public reactions to the latest visit of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Israeli leaders acknowledged today that they had clear problems with the United States' peace initiative, but insisted that no crisis in relations was yet at hand.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week:

title: Richard W. Bolling, Power in Congress; Missourian Was 74
description: Richard Bolling, a Missouri Democrat who served 17 terms in Congress until his retirement in 1982, died today at age 74.

title: Market Place; Municipal Bonds And Extra Yields
description: BORROWING short and lending long can be a sure road to wealth -- unless short-term rates rise too far.

title: Pirates Score 6 Runs in 11th And Shock Cubs, 13-12
description: Don Slaught's two-run double capped a six-run rally in the 11th inning and the Pittsburgh Pirates survived Andre Dawson's second grand slam in three days to stun the Chicago Cubs, 13-12, today.

title: Canadian Cabinet Posts Shuffled
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, threatened by shrinking public support and growing pressure for Quebec's independence, shuffled senior ministers today in a Cabinet overhaul.

title: My Words, My Case
description: A group of respected authors has improperly linked two high-profile cases concerning the press.

title: Doctor Is Killed Trying to Block Purse Snatching
description: A 65-year-old doctor who neighbors described as a dignified and caring man was shot and killed Saturday night in Brooklyn when he tried to prevent a mugger from grabbing his wife's purse as the couple walked home, the police said.

title: Revved Up and Ready to Rise
description: The months of the long, hideous road trips -- the 6 A.M. wakeup calls, the ordeal of four games in five nights -- are over. Eleven teams have been eliminated.

title: Budget Director's Mixed Outlook
description: A big turnaround in the United States economy could come by May or June, the Bush Administration's budget director, Richard G. Darman, said today.

title: Disenchanted With Chamorro, Some Contras Are Taking Up Arms Again
description: A short walk across a newly plowed field in a rural valley of the province of Esteli led to something that most Nicaraguans don't expect to see these days: seven men dressed and armed for guerrilla warfare.

title: Tax Increase Costs Ruling Party Kohl's Home State
description: The ruling coalition of Chancellor Helmut Kohl lost control of the government of his home state today, as voters dealt him a rebuke for reversing pledges not to raise taxes to help pay for German unity.

title: 2 Executives Are Dismissed
description: California regulators have dismissed two top executives of the First Executive Corporation, contending the officers had not cooperated with the state Insurance Department in its financial review of the company's Executive Life Insurance subsidiary.

title: Now Announcing At Breakfast Table
description: Bob Sheppard, the Yankees' public-address announcer, announces in capital letters, with a vaguely Shakespearean resonance. In fact, Reggie Jackson was so enamored of the way Sheppard would intone, "Now bat-ting for the Yankees (pause) number forty-four (pause) Reggie (voice rising) Jack-son," that the slugger would entertain teammates with a wonderfully accurate imitation.

title: Slimmer Magazines for Lean Times
description: This might be called "The Case of the Shrinking Magazines."

title: Businesses Turn to Recycling And Find It's Good Business
description: In the Pacific Northwest, the Pay 'n Save drug store chain recycles more than a million plastic bags a month. In Ohio, the American Honda Motor Company has set up a recycling plant to handle trash from its four factories in the state.

title: U.N. Commander Is 'Confident'
description: The commander of the United Nations peacekeeping force at the Iraqi-Kuwaiti border said today that he was confident that the refugees in the buffer zone were safe and that Baghdad would cooperate in solving the problem.

title: Martin in Campaign For European Travel
description: The European Travel Commission, the European Community and several international travel companies introduced a $2.7 million campaign yesterday that is intended to lure American tourists to Europe.

title: And the 336th Shall Be First
description: Unless they trade up (does George Young have a sleeper, perhaps, in 325th place?), the Giants will today take the 336th, and last, pick in the N.F.L.'s annual draft.

title: Pickens May Sell 26% Stake In Japanese Manufacturer
description: T. Boone Pickens is considering selling his stake in the Koito Manufacturing Company, a Japanese auto parts company that has rejected his efforts to gain a seat on its board, an aide to Mr. Pickens said today.

title: 3 Are Shotgunned to Death In a Long Island Restaurant
description: An off-duty Suffolk County police officer was one of three people shotgunned to death here early today when he apparently stumbled into a domestic dispute in a restaurant where he was moonlighting as a painter.

title: Gloomy Season on Farms as Dip in Profits Is Seen
description: A new mood has settled over the nation's farming regions: a sense of concern at predictions by agricultural economists of a drop in farm profits.

title: 25 Years Later, Honor for Audrey Hepburn
description: In 1966, Audrey Hepburn did what many working mothers would like to do: she gave up her career so she would be there when her children came home from school every day. And since the alternative was "being miserable" on movie sets, she said, it was easily done.

title: Tenants Worry About Trash And Adjust to Inconveniences
description: "Peter, I don't want to live with my garbage," Lauren Bullock said as the security guard behind the front desk at 215 West 84th Street handed her five heavy-duty garbage bags and checked her name off his list. "Oh, God, this is going to be a pain," Miss Bullock said.

title: Harlan Fiske Stone 2d, a Philatelist, Weds Helen Galatan, Legal Assistant
description: Helen Levin Galatan, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert Levin of Philadelphia, and Harlan Fiske Stone 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lauson H. Stone of Brooklyn Heights, were married yesterday at the Brooklyn Club. John R. Bartels, a senior judge of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, officiated.

title: Ms. Vasilopoulos and James Gerkis, Lawyers, Wed
description: Agathy Vasilopoulos, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lambros Vasilopoulos of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to James Gerkis, the son of Catherine Gerkis of Flushing. The Rev. Vasilios Kapsalis officiated at the Greek Orthodox ceremony at Transfiguration of Christ Church in Corona, Queens.

title: That Old Gang Moves to the Hall
description: The old black-and-white photo evokes radio days: the big microphone, the announcers wearing suits, Joe Garagiola sporting hair. In the 1950's photo, Garagiola is shown as part of a St. Louis Cardinal broadcasting team that also includes Jack Buck and Harry Caray.

title: Tokyo Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices in Tokyo finished lower today in light trading. The weak yen and Wall Street's drop by 33.67 points on Friday discouraged investors, traders said. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 304.96 points, or 1.1 percent, to close at 26,237.01. At midday, the Nikkei was down 200.42 points, to 26,341.55, with 140 million shares traded. On Friday, the index fell 256.93 points. "The market is very sleepy today," one trader said after the morning session.

title: Young Kurd Survives and Wonders What For
description: Burhan said he was 13 years old in 1974 when Iraqi warplanes destroyed his hometown of Halabja, Iraq, sending him and thousands of other Kurds fleeing down a looping mountain road to the safety of Iran, 11 miles distant.

title: Several Agencies Plan Ads for Environment
description: Several advertising agencies have announced plans to introduce environmental awareness campaigns.

title: Optimistic Analysts See Further Drops in Rates
description: Although the recent decline in long-term interest rates came to a sudden halt on Friday, optimistic money-market analysts insist that the pause is only temporary, resulting mostly from technical factors. High among the factors they cite is the large volume of Treasury borrowings scheduled for the next three weeks.

title: Cardinal Nsubuga, 76; Uganda Rights Backer
