description: Emmanuel Kiwanuka Cardinal Nsubuga, the former head of the Roman Catholic Church in Uganda and an opponent of human rights abuses under the military dictatorship of President Idi Amin, died on Saturday, a church official said today. He was 76 years old.

title: People
description: * Emily Swartzentruber has been named New York office media director at J. Walter Thompson. * Mike Massaro has been promoted to chief operating officer at Goldberg Moser O'Neill Advertising, San Francisco. * Debra Kaufman has been named vice president-director of account planning at Korey, Kay & Partners, New York.

title: Shame of the States
description: In Deadwood, S.D., where in 1876 Wild Bill Hickok was shot in the back during a poker game while holding a hand of aces and eights, gambling was re-introduced in 1989. Despite a betting limit of $5, the amount wagered by tourists and other suckers in the once-moribund town has already passed a third of a billion dollars.

title: Critic's Notebook; New Co-Host on 'Today' Gets Off to Affable Start
description: When Deborah Norville joined "Today" in January 1990, Bryant Gumbel, her co-host, foresaw "an exciting new chapter in the rich history of this program." That chapter closed this month, when Katherine Couric, who had been substituting for Ms. Norville, took over her job full time. Michael G. Gartner, the president of NBC News, welcomed Ms. Couric (call her Katie) as a "unique talent."

title: Pulling the 'Green' Over Our Eyes
description: On this Earth Day, instead of protesting with signs and sit-ins, most environmentally conscious citizens are protesting the destruction of the environment with their wallets. Environmental consumerism, or "green" marketing, is likely to be one of the most popular movements in the 1990's. There is certainly great potential for the marketplace to help address environmental problems.

title: New York Still Has Time to Undo the Great Fare-Pass Blunder
description: To the Editor:

title: Pressure on Levine, Huntley Grows With Loss of Frito
description: EDWARD VICK, the new president and chief executive of Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver, is not in an enviable position.

title: Jazz Sink to No. 5 From No. 2 in West
description: The Golden State Warriors denied Utah the Midwest Division title today with a 125-106 rout of the Jazz behind Mitch Richmond's 32 points.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The ways of the talk-show circuit are new to JEANNE WHITE, and the other day she said she had yet to become acclimated to them. "I'm on the circuit with Kitty Kelley and Ali McGraw, and it's just not me," said the mother of Ryan White, the teen-ager from Indiana who died of AIDS last year after becoming a national symbol of courage. The book she has been promoting on such venues as ABC's "Good Morning America" and the Phil Donahue and Joan Rivers talk shows is "Ryan White: My Own Story," written mostly by Ryan and finished by ANN MARIE CUNNINGHAM.

title: IRAQI FORCES BEGIN PULLBACK IN NORTH AS THE CAMPS RISE
description: Complying with demands by the United States and its allies, two Iraqi Army battalions began withdrawing today from a 1,500-square-mile swath of northern Iraq near the border with Turkey, American military officers here said.

title: L.I. Man Shot in the Head
description: A 23-year-old man was shot in the head outside his Nassau County home early this morning, the police said. Stephen Taylor, of 36 Stewart Avenue in Hempstead was listed in critical condition at Mercy Hospital, said Officer Howard Grandjean, a county police spokesman.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; For Some, Best Prose Is in Blurbs
description: SIMON & SCHUSTER is apparently still deciding whether to publish "Just Killing Time," a novel by Derek V. Goodwin that was submitted with phony endorsements, or blurbs, from John le Carre and Joseph Wambaugh. Whatever is decided, one thing is sure: The "blurb industry," as some publishing executives call it, is recession-proof and is here to stay.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Lawyers in Palm Beach Will Test Issues on Rape
description: One recent sunny morning, men in suits walked up and down a stretch of sand normally occupied by tanning socialites. They were taking measurements for use in a battle that will test Americans' attitudes toward rape cases, victims' rights and the legal system.

title: With Ismail Out, Defense Is Definitely In
description: With Raghib (Rocket) Ismail off center stage, cornerback Todd Lyght, one of Ismail's teammates at Notre Dame, was expected to steal the show as the first player selected in the National Football League draft yesterday.

title: U.S. Role Temporary, Aides Say
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Vice President Dan Quayle declined today to predict when American soldiers would be withdrawn from northern Iraq, where they are helping to protect Kurdish refugees and provide them with emergency aid. But both repeated Bush Administration assurances that the American military presence there was temporary.

title: Professional Courtesy
description: It would be hard to imagine a more intimidating place than the return ticket window of the Metropolitan Opera House. That's where desperate opera patrons compete for last-minute returns or a chance to bargain with speculators. Not long ago, a New Jersey doctor and his wife arrived at the window hoping for a pair of seats for a performance of "Parsifal." They had left their car in a pricey garage nearby.

title: Dance in Review
description: Demetrius Klein and Dancers Ethnic Folk Arts Center 179 Varick Street

title: Even on Senior Circuit, Nicklaus Is Masterful
description: Jack Nicklaus swept through the P.G.A. Seniors Championship in total command of the present but with a steely blue eye on the immediate future.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Laura Schandelmeier Ohio Theater 66 Wooster Street

title: A Terrible Exodus, in Record Time
description: In terms of numbers, the Iraqi refugee crisis is dwarfed by the Afghans who migrated to Pakistan and Iran in the 1980's. In terms of hunger, the starving millions in Africa certainly have had it worse. In terms of broken bodies, the Cambodians who staggered into Thailand during the 1970's were in more dire physical shape. In terms of death, few groups suffered more than the hundreds of thousands of Armenians who were killed or allowed to die as they were deported from Turkey in 1915.

title: A.T.& T. Revising NCR Bid
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said last night that it was willing to raise its bid for the NCR Corporation to $110 a share, from $90, provided that it could pay for the deal with its own stock and qualify for favorable accounting treatment.

title: Europe Stumbles in Computers
description: Europe's computer makers, outmuscled by their American and Japanese competitors, are desperately fighting for survival. They are laying off thousands as they struggle to slash their losses, but some analysts say most of them will either collapse or sell out to competitors overseas.

title: Afghan Rebels Say Scuds Hit Bazaar, Killing at Least 300
description: An Afghan rebel spokesman said today that the Kabul Government had fired Scud missiles on Saturday into a crowded bazaar in a rebel-controlled city in eastern Afghanistan, killing at least 300 people and wounding up to 500.

title: Wood's Winner and Loser Share a Reversal of Fortune
description: In barn 23 at Belmont Park yesterday, Cahill Road munched oats while his trainer said, "He doesn't even know there's anything wrong with him."

title: Treasury Plan Takes Chains Off Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Will Sell Bills and Notes This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, an offering of two-year notes on Wednesday and an auction on Thursday of five-year notes.

title: Ghost of '75 Dogs A Wary Dinkins In Fiscal Struggle
description: John E. Zuccotti vividly recalls telephoning the White House on the night of Oct. 16, 1975. The incoming First Deputy Mayor was calling to inform President Gerald R. Ford that New York City would run out of money in the morning. Mr. Zuccotti was told that the President was already asleep.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "For many graduating seniors, the door to the employment office has been slammed shut -- and bolted." -- Victor R. Lindquist, director of placement at

title: Civic Pride With Brush and a Bucket
description: Omaha calls it Brush Up Nebraska, Minneapolis-St. Paul calls it Metro Paint-A-Thon, and Tampa settled on Paint Your Heart Out! Regardless of the name, the result is the same: One day a year, thousands of volunteers help the needy by painting homes in poor neighborhoods.

title: Bronx Man Is Smitten By the Bug
description: If Sotero Calo had his way, the streets of the Bronx would be crawling with bugs.

title: A Wheel of Misfortune Hits Playoff Viewers
description: On the East Coast, Vice President Dan Quayle can be seen at Washington Capitals games. On the West Coast, it's Magic Johnson at Los Angeles Kings games.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1951, WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY JR. wrote "God and Man at Yale," a polemic railing against liberalism at his alma mater. So it should come as no surprise that Yale is nowhere to be found in "The National Review College Guide: America's 50 Top Liberal Arts Colleges."

title: Hispanic Paper Defies the Ad Slump
description: As New York City's three big tabloids march off to something resembling newspaper Armageddon, their spoils are looking rather paltry. Advertisers are watching their budgets, readership is on the wane, and profits bear only a ghostly resemblance to their former selves.

title: As Economy Sags, Gorbachev Faces New Demands
description: Amid the bleakest economic readouts in six years of promised reform, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev faced a demand today from rebellious hard-line deputies that he defend his record at an emergency session of the national Congress.

title: Baker Seeks Peace Talks in Two Stages
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he is trying to organize a two-phase peace conference, with Israel and the Arab nations along its borders negotiating their differences in the main talks.

title: Mallory J. Knickerbocker Is Married
description: Mallory Jane Knickerbocker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Candee Knickerbocker Jr. of the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn, was married yesterday at the Whitehall Club in New York to Michael Stanley Anhouse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart M. Anhouse of New Hyde Park, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik performed the ceremony.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In Britain, the talk about television executives is not about who switched or lost their jobs, but who kept a powerful post -- thanks to the prime minister and the royal charter. Prime Minister JOHN MAJOR announced last week that QUEEN ELIZABETH II had approved the reappointment of MARMADUKE HUSSEY, the chairman of the BBC's board of governors, to a second five-year term. Mr. Hussey, 66 years old, was first named to the post by MARGARET THATCHER in 1986. Mr. Hussey, who comes from a newspaper background, is married to LADY SUSAN HUSSEY, a longtime lady-in-waiting to the queen.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about cod misidentified the chef at the Arcadia restaurant in New York. She is Anne Rosenzweig.

title: Secrecy Is Lifted From Military Shuttle Missions
description: For the first time in space shuttle history, the Defense Department is about to embark on a mission unencumbered by military secrecy.

title: American Express's Hard Times
description: The American Express Company, long a dominant force in the financial services industry, faces a series of difficult challenges as new competition and more bad debts land on its corporate doorstep each day.

title: New Network Series Points to Creative Gambles
description: Gunning for a hit television series in Hollywood is a tricky affair, one in which the marriage between art and commerce sneakily spins more intricate webs all the time. But every so often, the fusion of creative and financial interests can create intriguing possibilities.

title: Henderson Placed On Disabled List
description: Rickey Henderson was placed on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to April 12 before Oakland's game against the Seattle Mariners today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 1 about a voting- rights lawsuit in New Rochelle, N.Y., referred incorrectly to George M. Cohan, whose musical "Forty-Five Minutes From Broadway" was set there. He did not live in New Rochelle.

title: Be Healthy, Make Money, and Scorn the Sick; A Managed-Care Plan
description: To the Editor:

title:
FOOTBALL;
Sweet 16 for Seahawks
description: After 6-foot-8-inch Dan McGwire was selected by the Seattle Seahawks this afternoon as the 16th player and first quarterback taken in the National Football League draft, his agent and lawyer, Leigh Steinberg, said he was not surprised.

title: Rocket's Value May Be on the Rise, With a Booster
description: An instant piece of offbeat memorabilia was created yesterday: the Raghib (Rocket) Ismail-Dallas Cowboys trading card.

title: Be Healthy, Make Money, and Scorn the Sick; Model of Inefficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: New Grade of Crude Oil
description: Malaysia says it will introduce a new grade of crude oil on Monday. The Dulang crude oil, from a field off Malaysia's northeastern coast, will be the fifth grade introduced by Malaysia, a big oil producer that is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Refiners said they were unsure about the quality of the new grade. "We have to analyze samples of the new crude in detail first before we can say anything," an official with a Japanese refining company said.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 21, 1991: MONDAY Airborne Fght Lubrizol Corp

title: Corrections
description: A front-page chart in Business Day on April 13 comparing the profitability of cigarette sales by RJR Nabisco and Philip Morris misstated several numbers for Philip Morris. The number of the company's discount cigarettes needed to compensate for a drop in sales of its full-price cigarettes in 1990 was 28.57 billion, not 19.45 billion. After actual sales of 26.02 billion discount cigarettes, there was a shortfall of 2.55 billion, rather than a surplus of 6.57 billion discount cigarettes.

title: Miss Grill Weds Andrew Garber
description: Suzanne Grill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Zelik Grill of Coconut Creek, Fla., and Dr. Andrew Garber, the son of Dr. Michael Garber and Dr. Ella Garber of New York, were married yesterday by Cantor Raymond Smolover in the Pegasus Suite at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Canada Lures N.F.L. Pick as Future Partner
description: The acquisitive combination of Bruce McNall, the entrepreneurial owner of the Los Angeles Kings hockey team, and his star player, Wayne Gretzky, this weekend capped its recent string of unusual big-money deals: McNall induced college football's most acclaimed player, Raghib (Rocket) Ismail of Notre Dame, to spurn the National Football League to play for the Canadian football team McNall owns with Gretzky. More unusual still, McNall and Gretzky brought Ismail in as a future partner.

title: Facing Gotti, A Prosecutor Hard on Mob
description: Andrew J. Maloney, the man who would prosecute John Gotti, has not appeared before a jury in six years. He readily admits he is not a legal scholar of the first rank, or even the second. As they say in his office, he does not "wear his brain on his sleeve."

title: High Hopes and Rejections
description: "I really expected that Yale was going to be the steppingstone to a really sweet job that I would get with no problem. There it would be, on a platter, saying, 'This is your job. Welcome to the real world, Matt.' I had heard about a lot of people going right to Wall Street."

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Pascal Rioult Dance Theater Theater of the Riverside Church Riverside Drive at 120th Street

title: Harvard Stays Unbeaten In Snappy Time at Potomac
description: Gusty winds blowing down the river helped push the Harvard crew to a victory at the Potomac International regatta here today in the remarkable time of 5 minutes 24 seconds over the 2,000-meter course.

title: New Yorkers Hail and Haul As Building Workers Strike
description: Hundreds of thousands of apartment dwellers in New York City and on Long Island awoke yesterday to life without doormen, security guards, porters, elevator operators and concierges, as 30,000 building services workers went on strike.

title: Be Healthy, Make Money, and Scorn the Sick
description: To the Editor:

title: Effort to Move Kurds Takes On Growing Urgency
description: The American-led effort to move hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees back to Iraq went forward with nearly frantic haste today.

title: Lori Ann Yarvis Wed to Ty Burr
description: Lori Ann Yarvis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin R. Yarvis of Long Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Sturtevant Tice Burr, the son of Mrs. Nathaniel B. Rowell of East Kingston, N.H., and the late Sturtevant Burr. The ceremony was performed at the Alger Mansion in New York by Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society in New York.

title: Slow Progress Frustrates All Involved as Oil Wells Burn at $1,000 a Second
description: Nearly two months after the Iraqi Army blew up more than 500 oil wells, firefighters have extinguished and capped about 54, a painstakingly slow start that is straining relations between Kuwait and the firefighters, mostly Americans.

title: An Executive Resigns At J. Walter Thompson
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company said Friday that Stephen G. Bowen had resigned as president of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A.

title: Be Healthy, Make Money, and Scorn the Sick; Paying More for Less
description: To the Editor:

title: Game's the Same; Sounds Different
description: The phrases have a distinctly American tone: first-and-goal, running the football, unsportsmanlike conduct. But what if the football is being played in Barcelona, the Spanish city that has a team in the new World League of American Football?

title: Kellogg Profit Up 69%
description: The Kellogg Company says growing worldwide sales helped first-quarter profits soar 69 percent. Kellogg, the world's largest maker of ready-to-eat cereal, said Friday that net income jumped to $163.1 million, or $1.35 a share, from $96.3 million, or 79 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 17 percent, to $1.42 billion, from $1.21 billion in the quarter a year earlier. A year ago, Kellogg stepped up research, development and marketing of new products to regain market share.

title: INSIDE
description: A Loss for German Leader Voters in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's home state delivered a majority to the opposition, rebuking the ruling coalition for breaking a promise that taxes would not increase. Page A7. Angst Over Cuomo Agenda

title: Accounts
description: * Next Inc., a computer maker in Redwood City, Calif., to Cleary, Kvamme & Suiter, San Francisco, for a portion of its advertising and marketing account with billings of $1.5 million to $2 million. The company is still searching for an agency for its national campaign. Ammirati & Puris resigned the account in March.

title: Five Are Reportedly Defecting to Kidder
description: As many as five executives at UBS Securities' real estate division have resigned or are expected to resign to take senior positions with the Kidder, Peabody Group Inc., Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: Regulators Are Faulted in Problems of Big Insurer
description: As California and New York officials try to assess the possible financial losses facing customers of the Executive Life Insurance Company, many government officials, analysts and consumer groups blame weak regulation for not preventing the insurer's financial problems.

title: When Rocket Skips, Lineman Soars to Top
description: With Raghib (Rocket) Ismail missing from the mix, the National Football League's 56th draft opened with plenty of twists and turns and finally settled into one of the league's most unusual ones yesterday afternoon at the Marriott Marquis in Manhattan.

title: National Tests Aim at Gauging Critical Thought
description: States have long gauged student ability in math, English, science and other subjects with standardized multiple-choice tests. But more and more, many educators as well as state and Federal officials say the patchwork of tests used in 47 states falls short of an adequate test of critical thinking and problem solving.

title: At One Site, a Fire Laughs at the Problems in Fighting It
description: Near the center of Kuwait's biggest oilfield, 16 miles south of here in Ahmadi, the problems piling up for the firefighters of the Red Adair Company were a case study in frustration last Sunday.

title: MISSOURI JUSTICES GET FATHER'S CASE
description: The Missouri Supreme Court has agreed to review the efforts of a man to move his daughter, who is severely brain damaged, to another state for treatment and the possible removal of her feeding tube.

title: Braking the Soviet Slide
description: As the Soviet economy spirals downward and new political fissures erupt everywhere, it's easy to write off the Soviet Union and its bickering leaders as has-beens. But remarkably, allies of both Mikhail Gorbachev and his archrival, Boris Yeltsin, are trying to put together a reform coalition that offers new hope for Soviet politics and policy.

title: Corrections
description: The cigarette article misstated the number of discount packs Philip Morris must sell to compensate for the decline in its premium sales; 530 million packs must be sold, not 74 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about Country Captain Chicken referred incorrectly to the founder of David's Cookies. He is David Liederman.

title: Degrees and Stacks of Resumes Yield Few Jobs for Class of '91
description: America's spring crop of college graduates -- a million young people who matriculated in the booming 1980's with rosy visions of abundant and lucrative career choices -- face the bleakest job market in a decade or more, especially in the New York region and the rest of the Northeast.

title: Mets Break Out Of Slump At Plate
description: There was a home run to left, a triple to right. There were doubles to the corners and singles screaming across all parts of the artificial turf. In all, the totals were 9 runs, 12 hits, one victory and one extended, extravagant night of catharsis.

title: Doorman Faces 2 Strikes
description: Nalin Mishra has two strikes against him. He works as a doorman at night and attends classes at CUNY during the day.

title: Nagle Joins the Jets' Quarterback List
description: It was no secret that the Jets liked Browning Nagle, the Louisville quarterback they used their first draft pick on today.

title: Gangsters in Charge
description: William Casey, President Reagan's Director of Central Intelligence, made a secret trip to Baghdad in March 1982. After his visit the United States removed Saddam Hussein's Iraq from the list of countries supporting terrorism -- a decision that allowed Iraq to acquire sensitive U.S. technology.

title: Newspapers and Magazines Dial 900 for New Revenues
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. used a "900" telephone line last year to sign up 1.6 million subscribers to Episodes, a magazine about its soap operas, charging the subscription price to phone bills and saving millions of dollars in mailing costs. USA Today recently provided ski conditions on a 900 line, drawing fees from callers and advertising from Miller Lite beer.

title: Iraq's Scars of War: Scarce and Precise
description: The first scars of war come into sight only minutes after the caravan of relief workers and journalists moves away from the border crossing at Trebil, on the first leg of a trip across the deserts of western Iraq to Baghdad: a huge vehicle's burned-out carcass blown sideways across half the two-lane highway. But such scars remain scarce during the rest of this 300-mile journey.

title: Armstrong to Appeal Case
description: Armstrong World Industries says it will appeal a decision made Friday by a Federal court jury to award $239 million to a company that charged that Armstrong drove it out of business.

title: White Sox Win Their First at New Comiskey
description: The Chicago White Sox won their first game in three starts at the new Comiskey Park when Lance Johnson's run-scoring single capped a two-run, two-out rally in the ninth inning to beat the Detroit Tigers, 5-4, today.

title: 6 Cape Cod Campers Killed
description: Six people died of what appeared to be carbon monoxide poisoning today after using a portable heater inside a tent at a campground on Cape Cod, the authorities said. Four of the dead were children. Sgt. Antonio Tavares of the State Police said the deaths appeared to be accidental. The victims included members of three families, all camping together in a single tent, said Don Carpenter, First Assistant District Attorney. Weekend temperatures on Cape Cod were in the 40's.

title: 5 Are Killed In House Fire In the Bronx
description: Tran Ba Suu survived a re-education camp in Vietnam, a high-seas escape from his homeland and years of struggle to bring his relatives to his adopted country. Early yesterday a fire whipped through his Bronx home, killing five members of his close-knit extended clan and severely burning Mr. Suu.

title: Olin Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a special charge of $ 80 million to cover losses on disposition and writedown of certain businesses and costs of personnel reductions in continuing operations; this charge comes 91 percent from the chemicals segment, 9 percent from the metals segments.c-Net income and included after-tax gain of about $ 2 million.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stock prices rose today in Tokyo, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues closing nearly 1 percent higher. The index ended the afternoon trading session with a gain of 254.56, at 26,491.57. The Nikkei had fallen at the opening of the trading day, but then gained 69.73 points, or 0.27 percent, by the end of the morning trading session.

title: Heritage Bancorp-Massachusetts reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Republic Capital Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Tisch Investor Role in Saatchi
description: The Tisch family, which controls CBS Inc., is part of a group of investors that holds 9.1 percent of Saatchi & Saatchi under its recapitalization plan, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Cetus Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring charge of $ 10,010,000.Revenue represents total revenues.

title: United Savings Bank (Montana) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
International Game Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 2.4 million related to its 40 percent partnership interest in Connelly Group L.P. The loss related to pre-opening expenses for Riverboat operations in Iowa.

title: Cutting Police Budgets, Safely
description: Gunshots that have struck 43 young New Yorkers in the past six weeks make Mayor Dinkins's "Safe Streets, Safe City" police plan seem more essential than ever. But does that mean the Police Department's $1 billion budget should be exempt from cuts even as plunging tax revenues force the city toward fiscal disaster?

title: American Locker Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,224,822, which included a loss of $ 1,703,777 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Big Tax Bill at Executive Life Is New Threat to Customers
description: The California Insurance Commissioner said today that the Internal Revenue Service had unexpectedly billed the Executive Life Insurance Company $643 million for back taxes and penalties, further imperiling the troubled insurer's ability to pay its policyholders and other customers.

title: Bancorp Hawaii Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bird Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Metropolitan Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gains on the sale of mortgage-backed securities of $ 7,852,000 for the latest first quarter and $ 1,582,000 for year-ago period; the year-ago first quarter also included income of $ 995,000, or 14 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.The latest first quarter results included a non-recurring expense of $ 2 million related to the administration of the company's agreements with the Resolution Trust Corp.

title: Chess
description: The Pan-Pacific Grandmaster Tournament, held in San Francisco from March 2 to 14, was a welcome exception. It was a first-rate, invitational round-robin competition, a rarity now in the United States. Sponsors for this type of event, in which the participants are given playing fees in addition to all expenses and prizes, are hard to come by, but this one was underwritten by the Mechanics Institute, a private club that has from time to time supported chess events.

title: Detroit Edison Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Atlanfed Bancorp reports earnings for Year to March 31
Cotton States Life & Health Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Iomega Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Community Bank System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $ 344,000 in one-time expenses related to restructuring the company's five independent banks into a single bank.

title: Ladd Furniture reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income

title: Yankees, Afloat With 5-0 Lead, Sink to Season Low
description: The words have been spoken before. But this time, when Stump Merrill lamented another loss, his voice seemed to have a sad sense of futility.

title: Mobil Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $ 28 million of prior period tax charges.

title: I.M.F. Doubt On Soviet Bid
description: The Soviet Union's progress in integrating its economy with the West and joining international financial organizations has been stalled by doubts over its political direction and commitment to market-based reforms. Soviet officials say Moscow still hopes to join the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, but Western diplomats are seeking evidence of the economy opening up.

title: Keystone Financial Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Judge in Capital Orders Reporter to Identify Source
description: A city judge hearing a case in which a central issue concerns unauthorized disclosures to the press about an undercover police operation today upheld a subpoena ordering a Washington Post reporter to identify a confidential source.

title: U.S. Acts to Restrict College Research Grants
description: The White House moved today to stop universities from charging the Government for what it called inappropriate expenses -- like yachts, flowers and country club fees -- when the universities receive Federal research grants.

title: Pulses of Light Give Astronauts New Rhythms
description: FOR two weeks before their scheduled launching last May, four crew members of the space shuttle Columbia used brute force to readjust their biological clocks so they could work the night shift. They willed themselves to stay up through the night, watching old movies to stave off slumber. By day, they took to their beds, tossing and turning, determined to sleep. They ate dinner at dawn and breakfast at night.

title: REGULATORS PICK BUYER TO OPERATE NEW ENGLAND BANK
description: The Government today selected Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., a Rhode Island banking company, along with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the big corporate buyout concern, to buy the failed Bank of New England and two affiliated banks that collapsed in January.

title: Healthcare Services Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Amsouth Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Head of Nuclear Panel Named
description: President Bush today announced his selection of Ivan Selin, an Undersecretary of State, to be chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Mr. Selin's appointment a five-year term succeeding Kenneth M. Carr requires confirmation by the Senate. Selin has been Undersecretary of State for management since 1989.

title: Advanced Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bankers Trust New York Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The provision for credit losses for the latest first quarter was $ 51 million, compared with $ 40 million in year-ago period.

title: Edo Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from early retirement of debt of $ 59,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Heritage Bankcorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago 9 months' per share earnings were base upon historical earnings since the issuance of common stock on Aug. 10, 1989.

title: Report Sharply Rebukes School District in the Bronx
description: A vivid and often scathing portrait of the impact that a long history of corruption eventually has on the instruction of schoolchildren is painted in a Board of Education report on a Bronx school district.

title: Nash Finch Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
Crossland Savings FSB reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Crossland said the losses incurred during the latest first quarter included, among other things, an aggregate of $ 27.8 million in provisions for possible loan losses and writedowns on investments in real estate.

title: Maxxam Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from repurchase of debt for $ 6,900,000, or 72 cents a share.

title: Agency Rent-A-Car reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
John H. Payne Jr., 75, Banker and Executive
description: John H. Payne Jr., a banker and former president of the Empire National Bank in New City, N.Y., died on Friday at South Seminole Hospital in Longwood, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Longwood.

title: Amoco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 311,000,000, or 62 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Audrey Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Observer; A Blow for Ignorance
description: The dumbness is spreading, so naturally they are closing the libraries. "A few muddled thinkers," they said, "wanted to close the schools. They said that since the schools were the source of the dumbness while the libraries were keeping learning from going out of style, it was the schools we ought to close."

title: Grossman's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Net Falls 79% at Champion
description: The Champion International Corporation, the large paper and wood products company, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings plunged 79 percent, principally as a result of lower prices for pulp and falling demand for lumber and plywood.

title: South Carolina Federal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income tax benefit from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $ 76,000, or 3 cents a share, and $ 161,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-Included income tax benefit from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $ 44,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 80,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Richard J. Margolis, Writer for Children And Columnist, 61
description: Richard J. Margolis, a freelance writer and columnist on social issues for The New Leader magazine, died yesterday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 61 years old.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of Earth Week Transportation Day, 42d Street will be closed from First Avenue to the West Side Highway tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Free bus service on the street will be offered from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Little Kennesaw, Ga., 30 miles north of Atlanta, had a powerful lesson in spelling on Saturday. Rushing to be first to name something for Gen. H. NORMAN SCHWARZKOPF , the allies' commander in the Persian Gulf war, it spelled his name wrong. A replica of a street sign, unveiled at a public ceremony Saturday heralding the general's return to the United States on Sunday, read "Schwarztkopf Court."

title: Ryder System reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 622,000.Results for the first quarter of 1991 included a charge of $ 5.7 million after tax, related to a reorganization announced in March 1991.

title: Rea Hopper, 85, Dies; Howard Hughes Aide
description: Rea Hopper, a former associate of the industrialist Howard R. Hughes who was the chief designer of the Spruce Goose, a huge plywood flying boat, died on Friday at the Berkeley East nursing home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 85 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: First Indiana Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Equal Rights for Women's Health
description: Despite all the research and therapies, more and more American women are suffering and dying from breast cancer. It now strikes one of nine American women.

title: Indiana Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nagasaki Mayor Re-elected In Spite of Insult to Hirohito
description: In a rebuke to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Liberal Democratic Party, voters in Nagasaki elected Hitoshi Motoshima to a fourth term as Mayor on Sunday, despite a ruling party campaign to oust him.

title: Computer Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 137,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Tirana Journal; The Land of Talkative Men and Toiling Women
description: When Kistrina Budina, a 21-year-old student of linguistics, was asked to describe her view of the situation of women in Albania, she responded instantly with a verse.

title: Thompson Hits for the Cycle But Giants Lose to Padres, 7-5
description: Robby Thompson hit for the cycle, but it wasn't enough as the San Diego Padres beat the San Francisco Giants, 7-5, tonight behind four hits from Tony Gwynn.

title: First Interstate of Iowa reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kimmins Environmental Svcs reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Elmira Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lomas & Nettleton Mortgage Investors reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Vaccine of the Future May Be a Decoy Virus
description: CALIFORNIA researchers are developing a method for making decoy viruses, exact replicas of viruses that look real on the outside but are lifeless inside.

title: Wheeling-Pittsburgh reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Earnings per share for the first quarter of 1990 are not comparable due to the issuance of new shares pursuant to the company's previously reported reorganization plan. The plan was substantially consummated on Jan. 3, 1991.

title: Horizon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Salvadorans Drop Discussion of Truce
description: In a setback to chances for a negotiated settlement, representatives of the Salvadoran Government and its major guerrilla adversaries have failed to reach agreement on the conditions of a cease-fire and have agreed to remove the issue from current negotiations, diplomats close to the talks said today.

title: Bridge
description: Two famous Russians were once arguing about a queen. They were Anatoly Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi, who fought for the world chess championship title in the 70's, but they were not arguing about a wooden queen or even a historical queen, but a pasteboard queen. Karpov, who is known for his logic, argued, rightly in theory, that West ought to have the queen because East had shown length in another suit. Korchnoi, who is known for his intuition, placed the queen with East and proved to be right in practice.

title: Cyprus Minerals Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated for adoption of SFAS No. 96.

title: Conagra to Buy Popcorn Maker
description: Conagra Inc. plans to acquire Golden Valley Microwave Foods Inc. in a stock swap valued at nearly $500 million, the companies have announced. Conagra, based in Omaha, is a giant food processor, which had $15.5 billion in sales last year. Golden Valley, based in Edina, Minn., makes Act II microwave popcorn and other microwave foods and had sales last year of about $172 million.

title: Music in Review: Group for Contemporary Music Ethical Culture Society 2 West 64th Street  The Group for Contemporary Music, now in its 29th season, has given a great many premieres in its time. But on Sunday evening, it performed an equally important service by reviving three string quartets that are neither established oldies nor spanking new. The quartets, composed between 1977 and 1983, proved to be the kind of rigorous, concentrated scores that reward repeated listening. They benefited from powerful, precise readings by the violinists Benjamin Hudson and Carol Zeavin, the violist Lois Martin and the cellist Joshua Gordon.
description: Jonathan Harvey's String Quartet (1977) begins with a sustained pianissimo tone played in raspy harmonics that immediately establish an eerie atmosphere. From there it grows slowly, first through faint, tentative scamperings, then through more assertive chordal passages and more assured melodies.

description: Seafirst is a subsidiary of BankAmerica Corp.

Neutrino Debate Revived
description: COSMIC issues hang on the question of whether or not an elusive subnuclear particle called the neutrino has any mass. The prevailing scientific view is that neutrinos must either have no mass or vanishingly small masses, but a California physicist reported yesterday that he had found evidence for the existence of relatively massive neutrinos.

description: Necessary health services are not provided to many adolescents because they lack health insurance or they face other barriers to health care, a study by a Congressional research group said today.

description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the Federal Voting Rights Act applies to elections for judges. The outcome could ultimately affect the makeup of state courts throughout the South, where blacks win judicial elections in numbers far smaller than their proportion of the electorate.

NCNB said it had not made an offer to acquire Southeast, but said it might do so in the near future. It gave no assurances that an offer would be made. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, shares of NCNB fell $2.375 to close at $37 and shares of Southeast fell 25 cents to close at $5.75.

description: The Union Carbide Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings dropped 11.7 percent, primarily because of costs from an explosion at one of its Texas plants.

Aronson, the company's chairman and chief executive, is currently president of Bon Marche, Seattle, one of the department store divisions owned by the Campeau Corporation.

But it is also reckoning time in Kentucky, and there is also trouble in the air and bankruptcy in the bluegrass.

title: Play That May Be Fateful for the Broadway Alliance
description: The year is 1788, the place Sydney, Australia. Convicts, men and women, transported because of their crimes, sent away from England to colonize the vast continent, are brutalized by their jailers, beaten and hanged for the most minor offenses. One day, the Governor of the colony decides that the prisoners will present a play, to be performed before their masters: George Farquhar's Restoration comedy "The Recruiting Officer." And the rehearsals begin.

description: The Clark Equipment Company said today that it believed a quick recovery in the economy was unlikely. As a result, a spokesman for the company, which makes industrial trucks and construction machinery, said a loss was expected in the second quarter. The securities pay no interest, but if held to maturity yield 7.25 percent. They are priced at $297.99 per $1,000 of bonds, and are convertible into common stock at a price of $18.06 a share. The issue is rated Ba-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B+ by Standard & Poor's. COMMON STOCK * Clinical Technologies Associates Inc., Elmsford, N.Y., has filed for up to 897,000 common shares. * NCNB Corp., Charlotte, N.C., has filed for an offering of 10 million common shares, of which 8.5 million will be offered in the United States market. As many as 550 of the unit's 650 employees will lose their jobs, with the others being transferred to a similar plant in McKinney, Tex., north of the company's Dallas headquarters.

title: Clemens Set for Tonight

Clemens, who pitches every fifth day, would be scheduled to work again Sunday in Kansas City.

Meadow Star Won't Be Entered In Kentucky Derby or the Oaks
description: Meadow Star, the champion filly who won nine races in a row before losing Saturday in her first confrontation with colts, will skip the Kentucky Derby and the Kentucky Oaks and stay in New York this summer to aim instead at winning the Triple Crown for fillies.

description: b-Net income

title: I.B.M. Adds 11 Models To Minicomputer Line
description: I.B.M. "refreshed" its three-year-old midrange computer line yesterday, introducing 11 new models that perform up to 60 percent faster and cost 10 to 40 percent less than the minicomputers they replace. But at the same time, the company acknowledged that sales of its minicomputers lagged behind the rest of its hardware products in the United States in the first quarter of 1991.

title: Rollins Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
National Community Banks reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about the rebels in Afghanistan referred imprecisely to the 1988 Geneva accords that led to the Soviet military withdrawal from the country. The accords did not include a prohibition on Soviet military aid to the Afghan Government; the United States and the Soviet Union had a private understanding that either side could continue to arm the forces it supported in Afghanistan if the other side did.

title: Kurdish-Iraqi Meetings Reported in Baghdad
description: Autonomy talks in Baghdad between Kurdish rebels and the Iraqi Government went into a third day today, Kurdish sources in London said.

title: Robert Kovich, 40, Dancer and Teacher
description: Robert Kovich, a choreographer and teacher who performed with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company in the 1970's and early 1980's, died on Sunday night at a friend's Manhattan home. He was 40.

title: EMC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Why Older Men Keep on Working
description: MEN in their late 50's and early 60's occupy a difficult position in the American labor market. Generous company pension plans have encouraged some to retire, while layoffs and staff cutbacks have pushed out others. For years, these inducements and pressures shrank the number of older men in the labor force, but that is no longer happening.

title: Colorado Springs Bond Issue Priced
description: A $344 million refunding by Colorado Springs was initially priced yesterday for a maximum yield of about 7.06 percent for a bond due in 2021.

title: North Stars Swamp Blues to Take Series Lead
description: Jon Casey made 29 saves and Curt Giles's first playoff goal since 1984 ignited a four-goal outburst in the first 10 minutes 48 seconds tonight as the Minnesota North Stars beat the St. Louis Blues, 5-1, to take a two-games-to-one lead in their National Hockey League playoff series.

title: Justice Department Needs Nothing Short of a Major Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: Lilliputian Rival of Desktops Offered by Hewlett-Packard
description: In a direct challenge to Japanese companies that dominate a fast-growing segment of the computer market, the Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it would start selling a personal computer about the size of a calculator.

title: UST Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
At Least 22 Die in Central American Earthquake
description: A powerful earthquake struck Costa Rica today, with the brunt of its force felt in this coastal city. At least 10 people were killed and scores were missing, while at least a dozen more deaths were reported in neighboring Panama.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We have no democracy in Kuwait. It's very clear. We are asking for democracy, the implementation of the suspended Constitution, forming a real democratic government and to have human rights -- individual rights to speak, to read, to write, to have a small conference, which is forbidden." -- Mohammed al-Khadiri, a Kuwaiti opposition leader. [ A11:2. ]

title: Interest Rates Still Climbing
description: Interest rates continued their climb yesterday in both the long- and short-term Government debt markets.

title: Front-Runner For Opening At Prudential
description: Hardwick Simmons, a former executive at Shearson Lehman Brothers, has become the front-runner for the job of chairman of Prudential Securities Inc. and may be named to the post as soon as today, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: Water-Based Animals Are Becoming Extinct Faster Than Others
description: WHILE the threat of a silent spring may be abating, the danger of lifeless waterways looms ever larger, recent findings suggest.

title: War for Turf In the Bronx Hits Albany
description: Most Bronx street fights unfold on the streets of the Bronx. Every once in a while, though, they wind up in the chambers of the State Legislature.

The company said the earnings improvement demonstrated the major structural and operating changes that have occurred since the merger of Walwyn and Midland last June.Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: In S. Carolina, Small Liquor Bottles Are Volatile Brew for the Electorate
description: Mike Liedberg can usually tell if a patron in his bar is not from South Carolina. "They'll order something we can't make or be real surprised by the price," he said, "and we'll have to explain that it's because we have to use minibottles."

description: The American Express Company is in negotiations with Sumitomo Bank Ltd. to establish a joint company that would issue charge cards in Japan, people who have been briefed on the talks said yesterday.

title: Hawkins Does Little To Improve His Stock
description: Andy Hawkins knows these days he is pitching for his baseball life. When Hawkins needed a nifty curveball or a sharp fastball as a life preserver last night against Detroit, he came up wet. Extremely wet.

title: Short Stories Thrive Out of Mainstream
description: The short story is widely perceived to have awakened, shaken off its doldrums and begun to reclaim its place on the American literary landscape. But you wouldn't know it from browsing through mainstream magazines.

title: Ruth Shatz; Cattle Breeder, 86
description: Ruth Shatz, a cattle breeder and civic leader, died on Sunday at her home in Coral Gables, Fla. She was 86 years old.

title: KURDS RELUCTANT TO RETURN TO IRAQ
description: Five local Kurdish guerrilla leaders spent two hours today touring the still vacant tent city that American marines are building for refugees in a huge wheat field just a mile east of town.

Yumzhagiin Tsedenbal, Ex-Chief Of Mongolia in Hard-Line Years
description: Mongolia's former Stalinist leader, Yumzhagiin Tsedenbal, died Saturday in Moscow, where he lived in exile after more than three decades of iron rule, the Foreign Ministry said today. He was 74 years old.

description: Mark L. Rosen, a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Siff, Rosen & Parker, died on Sunday at his home in Hartsdale, N.Y. He was 48 years old.

title: Detroit Wary of Plan to Sell Old Police Guns
description: Police officials want to buy more powerful guns that would give officers a better chance against well-armed criminals, but the plan to pay for the new weapons by selling off the old ones has raised concerns about where the aging arsenal could end up.

title: Sholom Aleichem Is Merrily Mourned
description: Sholom Aleichem, the writer seemingly beloved by all his readers, died 75 years ago, and more than a hundred of them squeezed into a hall the other night not to mourn him but to enjoy the anniversary of his death. That's what he wanted, and that's what his family and friends have been doing each year on the memorial of his passing.

title: SENATORS ASKING FOR ARMS TREATY
description: Hoping to force the Soviet military to break a stalemate that is delaying the next superpower summit meeting, the three senior members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged President Bush today to send a treaty reducing non-nuclear arms in Europe to the Senate as soon as possible.

title: DISCUSSION OF BIAS SCHEDULED AT F.B.I.
description: William S. Sessions, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has summoned the top agents from the bureau's 56 offices around the country to headquarters to discuss discrimination in the agency, law-enforcement officials said today.

description: Roger Howdyshell, owner of one of the nation's few remaining manufacturers of toy marbles, died Thursday. He was 67 years old.

Rig Count Falls in Week
description: This week's tally of working oil and gas rigs in the United States fell by 39 to continue a seasonal slide, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. As of today, 835 rigs were working nationally, 97 fewer than a year ago at this time. Last week's count was 874. The company has said the rig count traditionally falls in the first quarter of the year and continues to decline through April. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for petroleum and natural gas, not those producing oil and gas.

title: Developer Agrees to Plan to Cut 12 Floors From a Too-Tall Tower
description: A developer has agreed to rip the top 12 floors off an Upper East Side apartment tower that was built too tall for New York City's zoning rules, a dramatic stroke that would bring the unoccupied structure into compliance with the law -- five years after it was built.

title: Loretta U. Boyce, 66, A New York Educator
description: Loretta U. Boyce, an educator who helped create a school for gifted and talented black and Hispanic youngsters in Brooklyn, died on Wednesday at Grady Hospital in Atlanta. She was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Wednesday, April 24. Federal District Judge H. Russel Holland in Anchorage has scheduled a hearing on the criminal-plea agreement negotiated between the Justice Department and the Exxon Corporation.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Leo Burnett Makes the Case For the Comparative Method
description: LAST week, the Leo Burnett agency in Chicago invited employees to a screening of some of television's best comparative advertising -- commercials that pit one product against another. The hourlong video, culled by the agency from television around the world, brimmed with cleverness and was offered as proof that the approach, often considered negative and unseemly, can instead be creative and effective.

title: Chief's Successor Set At Warner-Lambert
description: Melvin R. Goodes, who joined the Warner-Lambert Company as a product development manager in his native Canada 26 years ago, was recommended yesterday to succeed Joseph D. Williams as chairman and chief executive on Aug. 1. Mr. Williams said he would propose Mr. Goodes, who is 56 years old and president of Warner-Lambert, at the July 30 directors meeting. Mr. Williams said that he would recommend that Lodewijk J. R. de Vink, president of United States operations, succeed Mr. Goodes.

title: Tartikoff Is Reported in Paramount Talks
description: Brandon Tartikoff, the chief architect of NBC's supremacy in prime-time television over the last six years, is talking with Paramount Communications Inc. about becoming president and chief executive of Paramount Pictures, a senior television industry executive said yesterday.

title: U.N. Chief Proposes Plan for Referendum In Western Sahara
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar recommended today that a peacekeeping force be sent to Western Sahara to oversee a referendum to decide whether the territory is to become independent of Morocco.

title: Shirley Goodman, Guiding Force At Fashion Institute, Is Dead at 75
description: Shirley Goodman, a driving force behind the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York for more than four decades, died on Sunday at her Manhattan apartment.

6 Cape Cod Campers Killed
description: Six people died of what appeared to be carbon monoxide poisoning on Sunday after using a portable heater in a tent at a campground on Cape Cod, the authorities said. Four of the dead were children. Sgt. Antonio Tavares of the State Police said the deaths appeared to be accidental.

title: Improving Employee Satisfaction
description: ALL work and no play does little for Bruce E. Roselle, a psychologist with Personnel Decisions Inc. of Minneapolis. By stressing the play aspects at work, he thinks, morale can be improved and boredom lessened.

Israel Kills 2 Guerrillas At the Lebanon Border
description: Israeli soldiers killed two Palestinian guerrillas late Sunday night after the Arabs cut through the Lebanon border fence, crept 200 yards into Israel and exchanged fire with an Israeli Army patrol, the army said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: "I think the reason that I'm getting this award is that I'm 65, I'm 40 pounds overweight and have bags under my eyes," TONY HILLERMAN , the author of best-selling mysteries with Navajo themes, said yesterday. He was referring to one of the highest awards for a mystery writer, the Grand Master of Crime Fiction, which he is to receive Thursday from the Mystery Writers of America.

title: Review/Pop; Mildly Manic English Band
description: English pop groups come and go, little puffs of light that make a dim impression.Who exactly were Flock of Seagulls, and were they related to Haircut 100 somehow? Jesus Jones, a young group from London that played at the Marquee on Friday night, is on the ascendant side of its career, trying to avoid the descent. Its newest album, "Doubt" ( SBK Records ), has sold 350,000 copies and the band has broken out of the college-music circuit, attracting supportive crowds around the country.

title: On My Mind; The Way Out
description: The way exists yet for President Bush to escape from the political and moral trap into which he has thrust himself. But he cannot find it in meetings of the National Security Council or in phone calls to foreign leaders.

description: Questions of "do they really deserve it?" always swirl around the highest-paid executives. But it looks as though Rand V. Araskog, the chief executive of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, is in for even more than the usual brouhaha.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about new crime legislation referred incorrectly to the former Presidential press secretary for whom a gun control bill has been named. He is James S. Brady.

Stanford Risks Sanction in Drug Dispute
description: In its latest attempt to compel universities to enforce its anti-drug policies, the Government has warned Stanford University that it risks losing Federal money because an instructor there has advocated drug use and boasted of carrying illegal drugs on campus.

title: California Biotechnology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Listerine Risk Minimized
description: A television report by ABC News has linked Listerine mouthwash with increased cancer risks, but a spokeswoman for the National Cancer Institute said yesterday that any risk was slight.

title: U.S. Wants Saudi Torture Suit Settled
description: The State Department, which has been sharply criticized by some members of Congress for siding with the Saudi Government in a lawsuit involving an American businessman who said he was tortured by Saudi officials, has now urged the two parties settle the case.

title: Say No to Role Models
description: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf's return home reminds us of the recent return of the word "hero" to our vocabulary. Literature had been in the vanguard here, showing the way. As early as the 50's, the "anti-hero" began to pop up in novels with the regularity of losers at singles dances. Behind the anti-hero lay the implicit and larger notion that, in the modern world, heroism was not merely unlikely but an impossibility. The anti-hero was presumably not only like unto you and me but representative of modern man.

title: Q&A
description: Snoring

title: Poor Countries' Arrears
description: Eastern European and developing countries are falling further behind on their interest payments to commercial banks, an international banking official said yesterday. Interest arrears rose to nearly $27 billion at the end of March, from $18 billion at the end of last September, said Horst Schulmann, the managing director of the Institute of International Finance, a trade association in Washington.

title: Bucky Walters, 82, Major League Pitcher
description: Bucky Walters, a pitching star for the Cincinnati Reds in the late 1930's and 40's and a six-time National League All-Star, died Saturday at Abington Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old.

description: It was hard to tell if the dancers were supposed to be allies or enemies in "Eyes Half-Closed," the program of three works that John Jasperse presented Friday night at Performance Space 122. It was an exciting evening, thanks both to the choreography's physical vigor and to its emotional ambiguities.

title: Chavez Turns In a Title
description: JULIO CESAR CHAVEZ said yesterday that he has given up his International Boxing Federation junior-welterweight title rather than accept a mandatory defense against RAPHAEL PINEDA .

title: Concern Weighs Layoffs
description: The chief executive of the United Technologies Corporation, Robert F. Daniell, said today that the company was considering layoffs in all of its divisions in light of the soft economy. Last week, the company reported first-quarter net income of 25 cents a share, or $40.2 million, down 70 percent from $1.05 a share, or $134.5 million, a year earlier. Speaking with reporters after the company's annual meeting, Mr. Daniell provided no specifics on the potential layoffs, but said, "It's going to depend on how rapidly we get a recovery."

description: Prompted by new studies on the damage to Prince William Sound and annoyed that scientific and economic information is being kept secret, lawmakers, environmental groups and many Alaskans are raising increasing objections to the $1.1 billion civil and criminal settlement of the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

Wilkins Goes Back to Work Without a Single Wince
description: Gerald Wilkins spent 20 minutes after the Knicks' practice today shooting jump shots, landing effortlessly on his left ankle. He didn't limp; he didn't wince in pain. He didn't favor his leg at all.

title: Reviews/Dance; What's My Brother's Name?
description: Simone Forti's "To Be Continued" was an hour and 25 minutes of muttering. The dancers were required to speak, and their utterances tended to be low and unintelligible. Metaphorically, the piece also resembled muttering, for the cast usually failed to project across the imposing interior of St. Mark's Church, where the production was presented on Thursday night by the church's Danspace Project.

Whew, It's Just a Bruise!

DEREK SMITH , a veteran guard who played just 10 minutes this season while rehabiliting an injured knee, was activated by the Boston Celtics. The team placed A. J. WYNDER on the injured list. (AP)

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Soviets Crush U.S., 12-2 The Soviet Union, the defending champion, crushed Team USA, 12-2, last night and joined Canada with a perfect 4-0 record at the world championships at Helsinki, Finland. John Vanbiesbrouck, the New York Rangers goaltender, had a nightmare start when the Soviets scored six goals in the first period. He was replaced by Scott Gordon of the Quebec Nordiques after the opening 20 minutes. The United States is 1-2-1, but can still make the four-team medal round. In another game, Steve Thomas and Steve Larmer of the Chicago Blackhawks combined for three goals as Canada beat Finland, 5-3. (AP)

title: Review/Television; Looking Back to Now From Far Ahead
description: Ron Koslow is back in weekly television and romance is not just in the air; it's under the floorboards and coming out of the heating ducts and oozing from the dialogue. When it comes to old-fashioned and unabashed romance, replete with appropriate music and poetry quotations, Mr. Koslow is clearly incurable. He created and wrote a good deal of the cult series "Beauty and the Beast." Now he is offering, on ABC Wednesdays at 9:30 P.M., "My Life and Times." Depending on your internal romance barometer, get ready to swoon or scream.

A lot of students -- poor New Yorkers, many of them single mothers -- would have to leave school, he says.

title: Thousands, Doing Without, Make Do in Apartment Strike
description: On its third day, the strike by 30,000 building service workers in the New York City region settled into a pattern yesterday. Deliverers, repairers, cable television workers and city garbage collectors generally honored picket lines, forcing hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers to devise creative ways to perform ordinarily simple tasks like having a package delivered or taking out the trash.

description: "We've got a week or two of hard fighting to do in the House." -- Sarah Brady, after committee approval of gun-control legislation. [ A16:2. ] "We know that every day we have the opportunity to educate Congressmen."

description: Perhaps John MacLeod's critical comments were designed to motivate the Knicks. Or perhaps he was genuinely baffled by the team's attitude during practice today.

description: After a five-year economic free fall that has wiped out scores of horse farms and sent breeding fees plunging, many people in the thoroughbred industry say its best bet is to launch a national campaign to glorify and advertise the industry's ultimate product: the race horse.

title: Regan Says City Economy Will Still Be Weak in '92
description: New York City's economy will probably continue to falter next year as a deep recession presses all sectors of the local economy, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

description: W. John Devine and Ronald E. Tuchman yesterday were named acting chief executive and chief operating officer, respectively, of Child World Inc., the nation's second-largest toy retailer, after Toys "R" Us Inc. Both are former senior executives of Toys "R" Us.

The company reported a $28.5 million loss for the first quarter, compared with a profit of $5.2 million, or 18 cents a share, for the 1990 period. Sales were $253,2 million, down almost 19 percent from $311.9 million in the quarter a year earlier. Weirton's stock gained 37.5 cents today, closing at $5.375 on the Big Board.

title: Angus Henderson, 84, Water Engineer on L.I.
description: Angus D. Henderson, who started his civil engineering career by taking a correspondence course and rose to become an authority on public water-supply systems through his work on Long Island, died on Wednesday at the R. H. Dedman Memorial Hospital in Dallas. He was 84 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: Armor All Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Slovak Premier and 7 Ministers Are Ousted
description: After weeks of near-paralysis in the Slovak government, the republic's parliamentary leaders dismissed the Slovak Prime Minister and seven of his ministers today.

title: Merritt Parkway on U.S. List
description: The Merritt Parkway, 50 years old, has been placed on the National Register of Historic Places, an honor some state officials oppose. The designation may make it harder to alter the 38-mile road, preservationists said. The State Transportation Department opposed the nomination earlier this year. The tree-lined parkway stretches from the New York State line at Greenwich to the Housatonic River in Stratford. It is dotted by 35 bridges in Art Deco and classical designs.

title: Panel Endorses Waiting Period To Buy Pistols
description: The House Judiciary Committee decisively approved a bill today that would establish a seven-day waiting period for the purchase of handguns, opening the way for the full House to act on the measure in about two weeks.

title: Battle in Northern Nigeria
description: Muslims and Christians clashed in the northern Nigerian city of Bauchi today. Witnesses said at least 80 people were killed and a dozen churches set ablaze. The state's military governor, Lieut. Col. Abu Ali, imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew.

title: Knee Injury Sidelines Brett
description: GEORGE BRETT , the defending American League batting champion, will be out for about a month because of a knee injury he suffered in a game against Cleveland on Monday. Brett suffered a partial tear of the medial collateral ligament in the right knee after he slipped on loose dirt as he came out of the batter's box after hitting a sharp grounder up the middle, said STEVE JOYCE , the Kansas City Royals' team physician, who examined the 37-year-old first baseman.(AP)

title: Leyva Is Replaced By Fregosi
description: The momentum had been building for some time, and yet the speed of it all was startling. Thirteen games into the season, Nick Leyva was dismissed today as the manager of the Philadelphia Phillies and replaced by Jim Fregosi.

title: Economic Scene; The 'No Regrets' Greenhouse Fix
description: THE latest word on the greenhouse effect, from a National Academy of Sciences panel headed by Daniel Evans, a former Governor of Washington, will surely not be the last. But the panel's report, somnolently titled "Policy Implications of Global Warming," is surely a breakthrough -- the first to bridge the canyon between alarmist science and what-me-worry economics.

description: The Monsanto Company reported today that it had a 14.4 percent drop in first-quarter net earnings, in part because of the recession's effect on its chemical business.

description: Fred Levy Jr., one of the owners of the National Football League Rams when they moved from Cleveland to Los Angeles in 1946, died Sunday at his home in Palm Springs. He was 89 years old.

Manuel Signs With Bills
description: LIONEL MANUEL , the former Giants wide receiver, has signed a free-agent contract with the Buffalo Bills. Manuel, 29 years old, was with the Giants for seven seasons before he was released two weeks before the end of the 1990 season after being late for a team meeting. He has caught 232 passes for 3,941 yards and 23 touchdowns, but lost his starting job to MARK INGRAM at the start of last season. (AP)

title: Willi Boskovsky, 81, Waltz Violinist, Dies
description: Willi Boskovsky, a master waltz violinist and conductor, died here on Sunday. He was 81 and lived in Visp, a mountain town 100 miles east of Geneva.

title: Cuban Exile Is Arrested in Florida In 1976 Slaying of Chilean Envoy
description: Nearly 15 years after former Ambassador Orlando Letelier of Chile was slain in Washington, Federal agents today arrested a Cuban exile, the remaining fugitive sought in the assassination.

title: As Crime Drops in Midtown, Even Criminals Credit Police
description: New York's citywide crime statistics have not been especially encouraging lately, but there is good news about the streets and subway stations at the core of Manhattan. Crime in midtown, like so much else there, seems to be in a severe recession.

title: Federal Grand Jury Foreman Jailed for Missing Sessions
description: A man who was chosen foreman of a Federal grand jury in January has been jailed and fined for missing the jury's monthly three-day sessions in February, March and April.

title: Audit Disputes F.D.I.C. Fund's Value
description: The nation's senior auditor has found that the fund that protects bank deposits is in substantially worse shape than has been reported and may be worth only about half of the $8.4 billion that regulators previously calculated, a top banking official said today.

Japan Auto Export Curb
description: Japan has agreed to reduce its auto exports to Britain, where the market is in a slump, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. Japan exported 207,346 cars to Britain last year, down 9.2 percent from 1989, the association said. The Persian Gulf war and new car taxes were expected to hold down sales this year, it added. No specific figures were discussed for 1991 Japanese exports, it said.

title: TVX Gold reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures on a pro-forma basis, assuming the business combination of consolidated TVX Mining Corp. and certain of Inco Ltd.'s gold assets had occurred Jan. 1, 1990 and Jan. 1, 1989, respectively.The company, formerly Consolidated TVX Mining Corp., became known as TVX Gold Inc. following the combination on Jan. 7, 1991 of Consolidated TVX and certain mining assets of INCO Ltd. The company said that, for accounting purposes, the business combination has been treated as a purchase of Consolidated TVX by INCO's Gold business because INCO is the controlling shareholder following the combination.As a result, net earnings, which relate only to the INCO Gold business, were $ 12.8 million in 1990, compared with a loss of $ 4.2 million in 1989.

title: Wrong Solution on Medicaid
description: State budgets are reeling from rising Medicaid costs caused, in part, by extensions of coverage mandated by Washington. Already hit by slumping tax revenues, the nation's governors have now petitioned Congress to suspend some of the new mandates for two years.

title: Kaufel Group Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
description: Results are in Canadian funds.Year-ago results were restated.

title: 30 Scoreless Innings and Counting As Clemens Keeps Jays at Bay
description: Roger Clemens extended his scoreless streak to 30 innings with 7 more shutout innings tonight in a 3-0 victory over Toronto.

But the company added that gross margins, 2.4 percent lower than a year ago, and higher marketing expenses contributed to the decreased operating income.

title: Four Investment Firms Report Big Increases in Income
description: The good financial news continued to flow from Wall Street yesterday, as the Morgan Stanley Group Inc., Salomon Inc., Alex. Brown Inc. and Piper Jaffray Inc. all reported sharply higher earnings.

title: Henry Harrison Dies; Meteorologist Was 87
description: Henry T. Harrison, a meteorologist who accompanied Rear Adm. Richard E. Byrd on his first Antarctic expedition in 1929-30, died Sunday at Deerfield, a retirement home in Asheville, N.C. He was 87 years old.

title: U.S. Sending Carrier to Strengthen Security for Force in Iraq
description: The Pentagon said today that it has dispatched the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt and its battle group into the Eastern Mediterranean to strengthen the "quick reaction" forces providing security to the United States and allied task force inside northern Iraq.

title: Arab Tied to Bombing in Greece Surrenders
description: A Palestinian student suspected in a botched terrorist attack that killed seven people surrendered to the police today.

title: Peter Arnett Wins Special Press Club Award
description: The Overseas Press Club of America honored foreign correspondents, editors and photojournalists for their work in 1990 at its 52d annual awards dinner last night at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Kennedy Unveils Bill To Guarantee the Poor Access to Head Start
description: Complaining that the Bush Administration wanted to pay for its new education program by shortchanging existing Federal aid to schools, Senator Edward M. Kennedy today introduced legislation to guarantee every eligible child a place in the Head Start program.

title: Chief of Waste Panel Is Charged With Theft
description: The head of an interstate commission that is trying to set up a regional storage site for radioactive waste was arrested today and accused of stealing $600,000 from the organization.

title: It Was No Upper-Decker, But Mattingly Will Take It
description: Bucky Dent was the manager of the Yankees the last time Don Mattingly hit a home run. Pete Peterson was the general manager. George Steinbrenner was the managing partner. Slightly more than 11 months, 312 times at bat and perhaps the longest (and loudest) owner's exit in baseball history passed by before Mattingly last night managed to hit another.

title: ANTI-SOVIET RALLY IN A REPUBLIC FAILS
description: The leaders of Byelorussia's anti-Government labor movement began to discover today how difficult it is to sustain popular protest in the Soviet Union.

title: For Bar Codes, an Added Dimension
description: After years of playing an important bit part in the information revolution, the bar code is being groomed for a more demanding role. Several companies that make scanning and printing equipment have designed new codes, the most sophisticated of which can actually work as if they were miniature printouts from computer data files.

title: City-Financed Agency Has Failed To Help AIDS Patients, Stein Says

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about former Representative Richard Bolling of Missouri misidentified a survivor. Jimmy Akin is his stepdaughter, not his stepson.

description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would consider a legislator's proposal that disclosing any rape victim's name without the victim's consent be prohibited by law.

The weekly Ward's Automotive quoted an unidentified Chrysler source as saying the new cars, tentatively named PL, will be introduced in late 1994 as 1995 models. A Chrysler spokesman, Tom Houston, had no comment.

description: After a bitter, nine-month battle, the Rochester school board has approved a new contract for teachers that will raise the average salary to $50,000 next year.

description: Twenty-four people were evacuated from their farms in north central North Dakota after the Air Force detected vapor in an underground Minuteman III nuclear missile silo about 8 P.M. Monday, officials said. Preliminary tests found nothing harmful, but further tests were under way, the Air Force said.

The Saturday evening show will be the 28th regular performance of the play, which is directed by Tony Abatemarco; it had 6 previews.
