title: Panel Faults Rikers Staff In Riot Study
description: A state investigative report issued today concludes that New York City prison guards used "excessive and unnecessary force" on inmates during a bloody riot at Rikers Island last August and recommends a criminal investigation of the violence.

title: Giant Steps: First Zero In on a Target, Then Sweat It Out
description: Had the Giants been unable to get the player they wanted in the first round of the National Football League draft, they probably would have taken no one then.

title: Math Moron Myths
description: The last week in April has been designated Mathematics Awareness Week by the august authorities who declare such things. And prescriptions for the betterment of U.S. math education have been offered by everyone from Secretary of Education Lamar Alexander down to Mr. Logarithm at P.S. 101.

title: Steinbrenner Takes Oath At Attention
description: CHEST out, George Steinbrenner prepared to take the oath in United States District Court yesterday morning, striking a pose so ramrod straight that it would have done George C. Scott, if not George Patton, proud.

title: Britain's New Tax: Rich Will Pay More
description: In the biggest climb-down in British politics in more than a decade, Prime Minister John Major's Government revealed today what would replace the unpopular "poll tax" introduced in England a year ago by his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher: a new "council tax" on property values.

title: Callahan Mining Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Addamax in Suit On Software Prices
description: Addamax, a Champaign, Ill., maker of computer security software, filed an antitrust lawsuit against the Open Software Foundation and two of its sponsors, the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Digital Equipment Corporation. The foundation was established in 1988 to create a version of the Unix operating system as an alternative to the one being developed by Sun Microsystems Inc. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Pro Bono
description: * Angotti, Thomas, Hedge Inc., a New York agency, has created a public service campaign that encourages parents to immunize children against preventable diseases as infants, well before they start school. The campaign, which is sponsored by the Association of Junior Leagues International, will appear on radio, transit displays and billboards in the United States, Canada, England and Mexico.

title: Britain Backs End to South African Sports Barriers
description: President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa got British Government backing today for the lifting of the remaining bans against trade and international sports competition with his country.

title: Faulty Fuel Signal Delays Liftoff of Space Shuttle
description: The planned launching of the space shuttle Discovery today was delayed until Sunday or later after engineers detected a spurious signal in the fuel system of one of the main engines of the winged craft.

title: Centerior Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said major factors in the first quarter earnings drop were a recession-driven 5 percent decline in kilowatt-hour sales and a $ 35 million reduction in deferred operating expenses and carrying charges, compared with the 1990 first quarter.The deferral amounts decline as more of the company's investment is reflected in rate base, in accordance with a January 1989 rate phase-in agreement approved by the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio.Another factor contributing to the earnings decline was a $ 12 million increase in depreciation expense. A $ 6 million reduction in other operation and maintenance expense for the quarter partially offset these effects.

title: Loctite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included restructuring costs of $ 4,434,000.

title: Joseph Lovinger; Jewish Official, 77
description: Joseph Lovinger, a Jewish official in Greece for the last quarter-century and a vice president of the European Jewish Congress since 1985, died on April 9 at a clinic in Athens. He was 77 years old and lived in Athens.

title: North Side Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Yield Put at 9.38% On Sears Notes
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the Chicago-based retailing giant, is offering $500 million in seven-year notes through a group of underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Originally the offering was to have been for $350 million, but strong investor interest prompted the retailer to increase the size by $150 million.

title: James River Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter's results was restated. In 1990, James River changed its fiscal year ending date to the last Sunday in December from the last Sunday in April. The ending date for the 1990 period was March 25.The company said that due to its restructuring program announced in August 1990, the latest figures included only its on-going operations, while figures for last year's period included those of operations slated for divestiture.

description: b-Included gain of $ 46,200,000, or 57 cents a share, from the settlement of litigation relating to natural gas sales contracts.Revenue represented total revenues.

Federal Court Panel Delays Harlem Man's Trial in Florida
description: A man charged last year with killing Miami's first black police officer more than 44 years ago will stay in New York, at least until a Federal appeals court can review his case.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It never occurred to DANIEL C. SHEDRICK when he was a student at Fordham University, class of '64, that someday he would give Fordham the largest gift in its history, $10 million. Today the university is to announce the gift and name a new library on its Rose Hill campus in the Bronx for Mr. Shedrick

title: HIGH COURT EASES RULE ON UNIONIZING HOSPITAL WORKERS
description: In an important victory for organized labor, the Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a National Labor Relations Board regulation that will make it substantially easier for labor unions to organize workers at thousands of community hospitals.

title: Peoples Heritage Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Don Siegel, Whose Movies Herald Tough, Cynical Loners, Dies at 78
description: Don Siegel, a director of tough, cynical and forthright action-adventure films whose taut plots centered on individualistic loners, died on Saturday at his home in Nipomo, Calif. He was 78 years old.

title: Court Puts Off Reporter's Appeal
description: The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has said it will not rule on whether a Washington Post reporter can be compelled by a city judge to name a confidential source until after the reporter has taken the stand and refused to testify.

Northern Telecom Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said geographic revenue growth was led by international (offshore) sales, followed by U.S. sales. Canadian revenues dipped slightly, due to the recession and tax law changes, which resulted in the exclusion of federal sales tax from reported revenues. The change reduced the growth of reported total revenues and orders for the corporation in the first quarter by 3 percent as compared to 1990.

title: Nucor Expanding Its Steel Works
description: The Nucor Corporation said that it planned to spend more than $450 million in the next three years to expand its steel production. It said it would build a new mill near Blytheville, Ark., and expand its naerby Nucor-Yamato mill.

KOHL URGES BERLIN AS UNIFIED CAPITAL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl ended a self-imposed silence today and came out in favor of restoring Berlin as seat of the German Government, but was immediately criticized and accused of playing politics and ignoring the cash-strapped state of the nation's economy.

title: Foreign Affairs; China Ties About To Snap
description: Beijing and Washington soon will mark the 20th anniversary of Henry Kissinger's secret journey of reconciliation to China. Only there is nothing to celebrate. In a drama barely noticed, Chinese actions are tearing apart ties with the U.S.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article in Science Times yesterday about the p53 gene's role in human cancers omitted several words in some editions. The passage should have read, "But damage from the outside is not the only way to disrupt the gene. Dr. Stephen H. Friend of Massachusetts General Hospital and his colleagues have discovered that some people are born with mutant versions of the p53 gene in their germline, meaning that every cell of the body is burdened with the mutation."

title: Offer for Harcourt
description: The General Cinema Corporation extended the deadline for its offer to the bondholders of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. The deadline of 5 P.M. on Monday was extended to 5 P.M. today at the request of a committee of Harcourt bondholders. To complete the $1.4 billion merger, General Cinema said, 90 percent of the publisher's bonds must be tendered; by Monday, 11 percent had been tendered.

title:

People
description: * Sandra L. Greenberg and Terri Meyer have been named senior vice presidents in the New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.* Douglas Behm has been promoted to a creative director in the Chicago office of DDB Needham.* John Sircus has been named senior vice president and director of broadcast production and Lee St. James has been named vice president and associate creative director in the Dallas office of Bozell Inc.

description: The company said the drop in net sales for the year was primarily due to the closing of about 100 stores following its filing for bankruptcy protection and also due to inadequate merchandise levels because of the interruption of shipments from suppliers.The company also said its net loss increase for the year was the result of $ 10 million of restructuring charges, $ 2 million of bankruptcy administrative expenses and a decrease in income tax benefits of $ 3.1 million during the period.The latest quarter includes a credit to the restructuring reserve of about $ 2 million, as well as a charge for bankruptcy administrative expenses of about $ 1.6 million.

title: Tekoah Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for Yosef Tekoah, an Israeli diplomat who was Chancellor of Ben-Gurion University of the Desert in Beersheva, will be held at 4 P.M. tomorrow at 130 East 59th Street in Manhattan. Mr. Tekoah, Israel's Representative to the United Nations for seven years, died in New York on April 14 at the age of 65.

title: Jewish Settlers Time an Opening to Baker's Arrival
description: Eight Israeli families opened a new Jewish settlement on a rocky, barren hilltop here early this morning, repeating what is becoming a well-practiced effort at political obstruction.

Two Families Flee Iraq To a World of Unreality
description: A cloud of dun-colored dust billowed from under the tires of a passing truck and rolled across the sea of blue and orange tents. An unshaved man, summoned by the scuffle and the voices of visitors, crawled from a tent, rubbing his eyes in the dust. He held a blue passport emblazoned with an American eagle.

title: For Expropriated Lands in East, Bonn Must Pay
description: Germany's highest court ruled today that landowners and industrialists whose East German property was seized by the Soviet Union during its occupation from 1945 to 1949 are entitled to compensation but not to the return of the property.

title: Yerba Mate, Ancient Antidote To South America's Heat
description: SULTRY summer afternoons in the American South may be met with long icy glasses of tea laced with lemon or mint. Here in the heart of South America, Paraguay's answer to 100-degree heat is a centuries-old Indian refreshment.

title: Bensonhurst Judge Drops Convictions at Sentencing
description: The most serious convictions against the last defendant in the Bensonhurst murder case, Pasquale Raucci, were dismissed yesterday by the trial judge, who said that prosecutors had failed to prove their case.

title: Earnings Up at Quaker
description: The Quaker Oats Company said today that earnings in its third quarter, ended on March 31, more than doubled from its third quarter of 1990, when the company took a $34.8 million write-off for its attempt to spin off to shareholders its Fisher-Price toy business. Net income for the three months was $63.1 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with $25.6 million, or 32 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter.

title: Freeport-McMoran Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain totaling $ 211,521,000, or $ 3.93 a share, from the sale and restructuring of assets.

description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 22,000.

title: A.T.&T. Deal With NCR May Be Close
description: NCR and A.T.& T. seemed to move closer to a deal yesterday, as NCR said it would accept A.T.& T.'s $110-a-share stock offer if A.T.& T. agreed to provide additional protection to NCR shareholders in the event A.T.& T.'s stock price falls.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Nineteen years ago BURT REYNOLDS posed nude for a centerfold in Cosmopolitan mazagine. But the actor demurred when Cosmetic Executive Women, a professional group, asked permission to reprint the picture in the journal for a luncheon honoring HELEN GURLEY BROWN , the editor of Cosmopolitan.

title: Tultex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First National Bank Corp. (Mich.) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Baby Boom Boom
description: Four million one hundred seventy-nine thousand babies. There haven't been so many born in the United States in one year since 1961, according to a new Federal report on vital statistics. The figure exceeds the 1973 total by a million and comes close to the all-time high of 4.3 million in 1957.

title: International Yogurt reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Jack (Kid) Berg; Boxer, 81
description: Jack (Kid) Berg of England, the world junior-welterweight boxing champion for 14 months in 1930 and 1931 and a whirlwind puncher who was popular in the New York area throughout the 1930's, died on Monday in London. He was 81 years old. British newspapers reported that his death came after a long illness.

title: Market Place; Texscan Trail Leads to Firm
description: THE extraordinary rise in the price of the Texscan Corporation's stock last week, which led the Securities and Exchange Commission to halt trading in the shares on Monday, appears to have been prompted by a strong recommendation of the stock by a Florida public relations firm.

title: From Grains of Wheat, a Bakery Grows
description: EVERY two months, a truck from Montana drops off 400 sacks (12 tons) of hard spring wheat at a small mill here. Michael Coleman grinds the wheat and he and his family use it to bake round, puffy whole-wheat loaves imprinted with flowers and wheat stalks at their bakery, a franchise of the Great Harvest Bread Company.

title: Controller Was Aiding Pilots When Heinz's Plane Crashed
description: An air traffic controller was in nearly constant communication with a small plane carrying Senator John Heinz as well as a helicopter flying nearby before the two aircraft collided in the air near Philadelphia on April 4, according to tape recordings made public today.

title: Consolidated Edison reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed the lower earnings to reduced operating revenues, expenses associated with the scheduled refueling and maintenance outrage at Indian Point 2, and increased operating taxes. These factors were offset somewhat by higher investment income.

title: Ponce Federal Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the St. John's University Law School misstated Dean Patrick J. Rohan's dates of service in the Army. He trained in cryptology in 1957 and 1958, then served in the reserve as a codebreaker for two and a half years.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Role Raises Many Concerns
description: To some people, the acquisition of the Bank of New England by a bidding group that includes the buyout firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company raises the troubling prospect of a powerful industrial conglomerate gaining unprecedented access to what will be one of the 10 largest banks in the country.

title: Freuchen-Gale Memorial
description: A memorial service for Dagmar Freuchen-Gale, an artist and fashion illustrator, will be held at 3 P.M. Friday at the gallery of the Art Students League, 215 West 57th Street. Ms. Freuchen-Gale, a former teacher at the league, died on March 9 in Denmark at the age of 83.

title: Washington Post reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
As Shad Return to Hudson, So Do Fishermen
description: One of the signs of spring in the small towns along the Hudson River is the appearance of hand-lettered signs on lawns offering smoked shad -- a real working-class delicacy. The fish are caught and smoked by local fishermen and sold off back porches or in small stores.

title: Salomon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that Salomon Brothers, the company's securities segment, earned a record $ 503 million before taxes in this year's first quarter, compared with $ 227 million in the year-ago first quarter.The Salomon Brothers unit had first quarter revenues, net of interest expense, of $ 1.1 billion, compared with $ 669 million in the year-earlier quarter.

title: For Many, Singing Is an Untried Art
description: THE candles on the cake were lighted and the 44-year-old man being honored in Calais, Vt., was seated when an off-key warbling bearing a slight resemblance to "Happy Birthday" arose from the gathered guests.

title: Joining Wisconsin, Yale Drops Two Sports
description: In what could signal the beginning of a wave of cutbacks in the nation's lavish collegiate athletic programs, Yale announced yesterday that it was eliminating two varsity sports. The move came as the University of Wisconsin made final its decision to cut baseball and four other varsity programs.

title: Greenspan Is Cautious On Easing
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the economy's slide was drawing to an end and that the central bank needed to be especially cautious before deciding to try to hasten recovery through another round of interest-rate cuts.

title: Toronto Sun Publishing reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and restated due to a change in accounting principles.Figures are in Canadian funds.

When to Protect Children
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta normally advises that children be vaccinated for measles at 15 months of age and again before they enter school.

Treatment for Clarence Kay
description: Rather than penalize CLARENCE KAY , a former tight end with the Denver Broncos, for an April 2 arrest on a charge of driving while his ability was impaired by alcohol, the National Football League will order Kay to attend an alcohol-abuse treatment program, PAT BOWLEN , the owner of the Broncos, told The Rocky Mountain News(AP).

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was a chance encounter on the 2 P.M. Trump Shuttle from Washington to New York Monday. RICHARD M. NIXON was seated to the left of GEORGE S. McGOVERN , his Democratic challenger in the 1972 Presidential election, and the two found plenty to chat about.

title: Nucor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30

description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday priced $100 million in tax- exempt consolidated revenue bonds through competitive bidding and awarded the debt issue to an underwriting group led by Paine Webber Inc.

description: Volvo Cars of North America has selected its American agency, Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer, and a Toronto firm, Media Buying Services Ltd., to handle its Canadian account.

Two Defy Age and Timing To Open Los Angeles Shop
description: THEY are two silver-haired gentlemen of advertising who should be settling comfortably into their statesmanship years. Yet Roger Livingston, at 54, and Paul Keye, at 61, have rejected the comfortable life, choosing instead to form Livingston & Keye in Los Angeles.

description: Maybe this should have been the lineup all along. Maybe Roberto Kelly needed to steal bases and feel more like a leadoff hitter. Maybe Don Mattingly needed to fulfill his craving for runs batted in by returning to the coveted third slot.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE constant companion of Martha Little's grandaughter is a furry gorilla. It is named Pig-Pig and is almost the same size as the youngster, who has her heart set on acquiring Pig-Pig No. 2. Mrs. Little, who lives in Baltimore, has been searching for just such an item with little success.

title: Times Mirror Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Earnings for the latest quarter included a gain of 5 cents a share from the sale of assets.

title: Billy Owens to Leave School To Enter the N.B.A. Draft
description: As expected, BILLY OWENS of Syracuse announced yesterday that he would pass up his final season of eligibility and enter the National Basketball Association draft. The all-America forward is the fourth underclassman to announce for the draft, joining KENNY ANDERSON of Georgia Tech, BRIAN WILLIAMS of Arizona and TERRELL BRANDONof Oregon.

title: Train Bearing Tainted Soil Rolls On
description: Almost three weeks after it left Michigan in a fruitless search for a receptive landfill, a 32-car train carrying 2,400 tons of contaminated soil rolled slowly through the South today toward an undisclosed disposal site and, perhaps, journey's end.

Prices Cut, Models Added In I.B.M.'s New PC Push
description: In an aggressive effort to reclaim its role as the standard setter for personal computers, I.B.M. yesterday slashed prices, introduced models based on the Intel Corporation's latest microprocessor, and said flat out that it would grow faster than its industry rivals for the rest of 1991.

description: The game was not that eventful. The Mets, scoring one run in the fifth inning and one in the sixth, both without benefit of a hit, defeated the Phillies, 2-1, tonight at Veterans Stadium.

description: The NEC Corporation, one of Japan's largest computer makers, said today that it was negotiating with Compagnie des Machines Bull about buying shares in the faltering French computer giant.

title: Oregon Literacy Test Shows Many Lag in Basics
description: In what is being called the nation's first comprehensive statewide survey of adult literacy, Oregon has found that 97 percent of adults can read at some level, but only a small percentage can interpret a poem, use a bus schedule or determine correct change from a lunch bill.

title: Barclays Ends Its Effort In U.S. Equities Business
description: Barclays de Zoete Wedd, the London-based securities firm, has abandoned its move into the American equities business a little more than a year after it began it, the firm announced yesterday.

title: Review/Dance; Ballet Theater Opens Its Season With 'Coppelia'
description: American Ballet Theater opened a nine-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night with a newly designed and effervescent production of "Coppelia," led by Cheryl Yeager and the ever-phenomenal Julio Bocca. For all the fresh window dressing in the sets and costumes, the audience was treated basically to Enrique Martinez's restaging of the version he produced for the company in 1968.

title: Executive Made Dean
description: William A. Hasler, vice chairman and director of KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting and consulting unit of the Pittson Company, will become the new dean of the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. He will replace Raymond E. Miles, who returned to teaching.

title:
Real Estate;
New Offices At a Project In Bergen
description: AFTER a decade of development, a 60-acre tract in the eastern corner of this Bergen County suburb is now midway through its transformation into a two-million-square-foot corporate park. But the work has proceeded more slowly than planned and with adjustments to a softer commercial real estate market.

title: Ismail to Run in Penn Relays
description: The Penn Relays created a special 100-meter dash yesterday to allow RAGHIB (ROCKET) ISMAIL to run Saturday. Ismail, the Notre Dame returner, signed a pro football contract Sunday to play for the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League. He had been scheduled to run in an open 100 at Penn, but international and national rules forbid a track amateur from running against a pro. But the National Collegiate Athletic Association rules allow a pro in one sport to compete against amateurs in another, so Penn added an invitation 100 meters for collegians in which Ismail will run.

title: Barnes Loses Drug Appeal
description: RANDY BARNES , the 1988 Olympic silver medalist in the shot-put and the world record holder, lost his appeal to have a two-year suspension for drug use overturned. A three-member panel from The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for track and field, denied his appeal, leaving the suspension intact through Nov. 1, 1992. Barnes was suspended based on a positive test result for the anabolic steroid methyltestosterone after a meet last August in Malmo, Sweden. Barnes may appeal his case to the United States Olympic Committee.

description: Brian C. Beazer, the 56-year-old Briton who heads Beazer P.L.C., has outlined a plan that in effect would split the company into British and American holdings. On a visit to New York, Mr. Beazer said he wanted to get shareholder approval to form a new company called Beazer Europe, selling about 49 percent of the new shares publicly. The company would consist of Beazer Homes Ltd., a supplier of duplexes and single-family homes; Beazer Property Ltd., a land holding company; Beazer Construction Ltd., which does general building, and Beazer National Construction Ltd., which does civil engineering.

title: Family Leave Bill Advances
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today approved a measure, virtually identical to one vetoed by President Bush last year, that would guarantee workers as many as 12 weeks off in unpaid leave for family emergencies. The White House has already threatened another veto this year. The bill would require large companies to give workers time off in a number of situations, including the birth of a child or a family illness. The committee passed the measure 12 to 5. A similar version of the measure is pending in the House.

Mr. Spier, the chairman of the Sutton Holding Corporation, had threatened to begin a proxy fight last month and to nominate five people to the board.

Kane was the baseball coach at Lansdowne Junior High School just outside of Philadelphia in 1981, when Burrell would have done anything to make the team. description: HEPTATHLON Guthrie Triumphs Diane Guthrie of George Mason took first place in four of the seven events yesterday at the 97th annual Penn Relays in Philadelphia. Her total of 5,648 points set a meet record, surpassing the 5,580 set in 1987 by Heidi Mann of the University of Florida. Guthrie finished 234 points ahead of second-place Shana Williams of Seton Hall. Guthrie won the four field events, and Williams won the three track events. (AP) TENNIS Maleeva, Wiesner Gain Manuela Maleeva-Fragniere of Switzerland, seeded third, and Judith Wiesner of Austria, seeded sixth, advanced to the third round of the Women's Tennis Association tournament in Barcelona, Spain, yesterday. Maleeva eliminated Nicole Jagerman of the Netherlands, 7-5, 6-3, while Wiesner defeated Pascale Etchetmendy of France, 6-4, 0-6, 7-5, on the clay courts of the Royal Tennis Club.(AP) TABLE TENNIS Korean Team Triumphs The first unified North-South Korean sports team opened the world championships yesterday in Chiba, Japan, with a 3-0 victory over France in the women's competition and a 3-1 decision over Taiwan in a men's match. Prince Akishino, second son of Emperor Akihito of Japan, officially opened the 13-day championships, attended by nearly 1,200 athletes and officials from 105 countries.(AP)

title: Social Democrats Explore Anti-Kohl Alliance
description: From the simple arithmetic of the vote in Rhineland-Palatinate on Sunday, the Social Democrats, who emerged victorious, can ally with either the Free Democrats or the environmentalist Greens to form a coalition Government.

title: Earnings Soar 75% At Exxon
description: Exceeding the most optimistic Wall Street projections, the Exxon Corporation said today that net income in the first quarter rose 75 percent, to $2.24 billion, its highest profits for any quarter since John D. Rockefeller organized the company in 1882.

title: World Bank Aids Poles
description: The World Bank approved a $120 million loan today to improve Poland's antiquated telephone network. The loan should enable the national telephone company to connect 70,000 new subscribers in the next two years and help break "a key bottleneck for business," said Ian Hume, head of the bank's Polish office.

title: Andrew Boyle, Author, 71, Dies; Helped Expose a Top British Spy
description: Andrew Boyle, an author and broadcaster whose 1979 book, "The Climate of Treason," led to the exposure of the "fourth man" in a notorious Soviet spy ring in Britain, died of cancer on Monday, his family announced Tuesday. He was 71 years old.

title: Olson to Sue Patriots
description: LISA OLSON, The Boston Herald reporter who said she was sexually harassed by three players on the New England Patriots, will file suit today against the team and the players, the newspaper said. The four-count suit, to be filed in Suffolk Superior Court, will charge civil rights violations, emotional distress and damage to her professional reputation, The Herald reported.

title: Freddie Mac Profit Up

First-quarter 1990 earnings were $111 million, or $1.85 a share. It was the 83d consecutive quarter of profitability for Freddie Mac, a stockholder-owned corporation chartered by Congress in 1970 to create a flow of funds to mortgage lenders to support home ownership and rental housing.

title: Armstrong Suit Raises Questions

On Monday, it was down $2.375, to $27.25. By yesterday's close, it had slipped a bit more, to $26.875, off 25 cents for the day. That put it nearly 30 percent off its 52-week high of $37.875.

title: American, Delta Get British Routes

American will offer passenger and air-cargo service between New York City and Manchester, England. Delta will operate passenger and cargo service to Manchester from Atlanta. Manchester is the third-largest airport in Britain, and the department said the United States-to-Manchester market doubled between 1987 and 1989.

title: Earnings Rise 71.3% At Johnson

title: Review/Film; Stallone the Comedian Is a Sport in 'Oscar'
description: It is no longer inconceivable that someday Sylvester Stallone will be found on network television, rolling his eyes and waving his hands at the weekly antics of a family of cute, unruly kids. In "Oscar," Mr. Stallone displays an unexpected gameness, even a flair, for the kind of broadly durable comedy that is the television sitcom's specialty. It works a lot better than might have been expected. Mr. Stallone may not be a comic genius, but he's definitely a sport.

That could break a costly stalemate that has virtually shut down major-studio film making in New York City since November.

Review/Television; Breathlessly Scratching the Surface on 'Expose'
description: Advance looks are not generally available of "Expose," the NBC news magazine that has been occupying the 8 P.M. Sunday slot since January. So, to give reviewers something to write about, NBC News has put together a tape of five past pieces that do not embarrass the producers. The selections define the strengths and limitations of the half-hour program that has been bringing NBC about as large an audience as it could reasonably hope for against "Murder, She Wrote" on CBS and "America's Funniest Home Videos" on ABC. The segments also expose the differences in content and style between "Expose" on the one hand, and, on the other, "60 Minutes," the CBS Sunday champ, and "20/20," ABC's popular Friday entry.

The program also includes Beethoven's Symphony No. 6, and Brunnhilde's awakening scene, from Act III of Wagner's "Siegfried." The soloists in the Wagner are Linda Kelm, soprano, and Richard Versalle, tenor. The program is to be repeated tomorrow evening at 7:30 and on Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets are $10 to $25. Information: (718) 636-4100.

title: Review/Music; Playing Mozart as Mozart Would Recognize
description: Malcolm Bilson's recital on Wednesday evening testified persuasively for the performance of Mozart's keyboard sonatas on the fortepiano. For many years a leading propagandist for period instruments and historical plausibility, Mr. Bilson is also a talented performer with a flair for putting old wine in appropriately old bottles. His performance of four sonatas, part of the On Original Instruments series at Merkin Concert Hall, was more than a dry argument for the use of an instrument that Mozart might have recognized; it consistently produced music that one recognized as Mozart's.

description: Iraq's new Prime Minister, Saadun Hamadi, struck a broadly conciliatory note today, saying the country is moving toward democracy, wants better relations with the coalition nations and will scrupulously meet the United Nations terms for lifting economic sanctions.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on April 17 portrayed the life and background of the woman who has accused William Kennedy Smith of rape at the Kennedy estate in Palm Beach, Fla., on March 30.

title: MURDOCH SELLING 9 U.S. PUBLICATIONS FOR $600 MILLION
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born publisher whose wide holdings in the United States include New York magazine, 20th Century Fox and several television stations, agreed yesterday to sell most of his magazines in this country for more than $600 million, people involved in the talks said.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Placards and Epigrams

title: Memories of Automats Past: Beef Pie and Depression Cocktails; Visit From Tallulah
description: To the Editor:

title: Allegheny Acquirer Spent $5.8 Million
description: The New York investment firm that acquired Allegheny International Inc. last year spent $5.8 million on legal and other professional fees to buy the company, according to court documents. The firm, Japonica Partners, also reimbursed itself for $940,879 in expenses it incurred during the acquisition, the court documents show.

title: Psychiatrist Hit With 2-by-4 in Mugging Dies
description: A 60-year-old psychiatrist who was bludgeoned by a mugger as he walked home from a concert on the Upper East Side Tuesday night died yesterday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: New Giant Co-Boss Defends Ticket Move
description: Bob Tisch, who bought 50 percent of the Giants on Feb. 20, today defended the team's decision to include exhibition games in season-ticket orders and promised to investigate ways to free up a limited number of regular-season tickets for the general public on a first-come, first-buy basis.

title: Who Knows What Ho Knows?
description: WHEN the Rocket veered north he left a telling trail across the super-starry sky. The National Football League and its media mascots called him greedy, misguided and perhaps not quite man enough to face the challenge of the Big Frat. Most every other non-Canadian with an opinion dubbed Raghib Ismail merely greedy, but found that entirely appropriate in a time of Bo Jackson and Cahill Road. Take the money and run, before the game takes your legs. Only a sportswriter would tell you to do it for love.

title: Iran-Iraq Tension Is Worrying U.S.
description: Bush Administration officials are concerned that tensions are rising between Iran and Iraq after Baghdad's crackdown on Shiite Muslims in southern Iran, stepped-up border incursions by both sides and Teheran's decision to confiscate many of Baghdad's airplanes.

title: Safety Railway Service Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Market Place;
Durakon Attracts Investor Interest
description: UNTIL last week, Durakon Industries was barely known outside an auto industry circle that included pickup truck dealers and the General Motors Corporation -- purchasers of the sturdy plastic liners made by the company that protect the cargo beds of pickup trucks.

title: Pirates Blank Expos for 6th Straight As Bonds and Bonilla Hit Homers
description: Vicente Palacios pitched a four-hitter for his first major league shutout and Bobby Bonilla and Barry Bonds hit consecutive homers as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the slumping Montreal Expos, 8-0, tonight for their sixth victory in a row.

title: Decline in Sales At Rolls-Royce
description: Sales of Rolls-Royce luxury cars are down sharply in Britain and the United States, the parent company's chairman said today.

title: It's Official: July Saw The Recession's Start
description: The committee of seven prominent economists that is the arbiter of when recessions officially begin and end, ruled today that the current one started nine months ago, in July. The panel made no attempt to guess when it might end.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: 4 Directors to Stay

title: Review/Film; Counting to 100 With Peter Greenaway
description: The mind that embraces pure gamesmanship is rarely as fanciful as that of Peter Greenaway, who obviously plays by his own rules. Mr. Greenaway's love of puzzles, riddles, obscure references and obsessive schematization is truly astounding, but it is rarely matched by an equivalent interest in whatever has set these maneuvers in motion. He would be perfectly capable, it often seems, of staging an elaborate whodunit without bothering to determine whether anyone was ultimately to blame.

title: Walt Disney Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Federal-Mogul Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

INSIDE
description: School Doors Closing Strapped for money, a California school district announced it would shut down after classes on Tuesday, 32 days ahead of schedule. Page A10. China Copyright Challenge A Cabinet panel has recommended that the United States cite China, India and Thailand, for violating copyright and patent laws. Page D1. Salvaging Valdez Pact The Exxon Corporation said it hoped to save the $1 billion civil portion of the proposed settlement of the Exxon Valdez oil spill. Page A10. Confidentiality and AIDS A surgeon with AIDS must tell his patients before operating on them, a New Jersey judge ruled. Page B1. Students in Counter Protest About 200 students angry over a protest that had shut Manhattan Community College stormed the building and ended the protest. Page B1. Publisher's Switch on Novel Simon & Schuster said it would not print a book that had false endorsements from two authors. Page C28.

title: Mitsubishi-Volvo
description: The Mitsubishi Motor Corporation of Japan will buy a one-third stake in the Dutch car maker Volvo B.V., a Dutch newspaper reported. Under the terms of the agreement, reported in Het Financieele Dagblad, the Dutch state will reduce its current stake from 70 percent to one-third to lift Swedish Volvo's current 30 percent share to a third and free up a third for purchase by Mitsubishi. In addition, Volvo B.V. will increase its production to 220,000 vehicles a year from the current 150,000. Spokesmen for Volvo A.B. in Sweden, Volvo B.V. of the Netherlands and Mitsubishi declined to comment on the report.

title: Harlem Teen-Agers Checkmate a Stereotype
description: The Raging Rooks are getting a lot of attention this week, and they can understand why. These teen-agers from Harlem have grown accustomed to incredulous stares in airports and hotels when they explain that, no, they are not a rap group, and no, the trophy is not for basketball.

title: Tandy Brands Accessories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included non-recurring spin-off costs of $ 166,000 for third quarter and $ 356,000 for the 9 months.Year-ago share earnings were not available; the company was created in January as a spinoff of Tandy Brands Inc.

title: Guideposts Names Chief
description: Norman Vincent Peale and Ruth Stafford-Peale have turned over control of the company that publishes the monthly inspirational Guideposts magazine. John Temple, 50 years old, of Carmel, was appointed Wednesday to be chief executive and president of Guideposts Associates Inc. The editorial director, Van Varner, was named editor in chief. The Peales, who founded the company 46 years ago, will continue as co-publishers. Mrs. Peale will serve as chairwoman of the executive committee. In making the announcement, Mrs. Peale, 85, said that she and her 92-year-old husband felt that Guideposts was strongly positioned for the future.

title: Pennzoil Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $ 6.9 million in tax refunds and other non-recurring income.Revenue represented total revenue.

title: Fast Track on Trade Speeds Democracy's End
description: To the Editor:

title: Bull and NEC
description: The French state-owned computer group, Compagnie des Machines Bull S.A, is close to completing a stock swap deal with Japan's NEC Corportion, a Bull spokesman said. The swap is expected to involve the exchange of NEC's 15 percent stake in Bull's United States unit, Bull HN Information Systems Inc., for a stake of about 5 percent in the parent company. The move will not involve an infusion of new capital into Bull, the spokesman said. The spokesman said it was not known when the talks would be completed.

title: Southdown Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Calgon Carbon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from prepayment of debt of $ 1,240,000.

title: Times Article Naming Rape Accuser Ignites Debate on Journalistic Values
description: The New York Times's publication of a profile of the woman who has accused William Kennedy Smith of rape, and the use of the woman's name by The Times and other news organizations, have ignited a bitter debate across the country and inside the newspaper.

title: Memories of Automats Past: Beef Pie and Depression Cocktails
description: To the Editor:

title: Overcoming Historic Ban On Jury Duty
description: While many people groan when called for jury duty and look for ways to get out of it, two groups historically excluded from it are trying to fight their way onto juries. The campaign has been slow, but so far, advocates for the blind and the deaf have successfully challenged longstanding practices that bar these people from jury duty.

title: Review/Film; Handsome And Modest, Yes, but Also Murderous
description: "A Kiss Before Dying," written and directed by James Dearden, who wrote "Fatal Attraction," is the entertaining if bent, almost-success story of Jonathan Corliss (Matt Dillon), a poor young man who wants to get ahead.

title: Dofasco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included loss of $ 13.7 million from its investment in Algoma Steel Corp. There is no similar item in 1991 because the entire investment was written off in December.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cremins Considering Job at Notre Dame
description: Georgia Tech Coach BOBBY CREMINS said yesterday that he may look into the Notre Dame job but would not say if he had been contacted by the school.

title: Crown Central Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: William Dozier; TV Producer, 83
description: William Dozier, who produced the campy "Batman" television series, died on Tuesday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center here. He was 83 years old.

title: Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Consolidated reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tremont Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 500,000.

title: Giants Can't Let Parcells Get Away
description: WHEN the Giants selected Jarrod Bunch, a 248-pound fullback from the University of Michigan, in the first round of the National Football League grab bag of college talent last Sunday, their new co-owner, Bob Tisch, turned to one of the coaches in the Giants Stadium offices.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Tuesday about the reinstatement of Geraldine McCann, an official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, referred imprecisely to her new position. She will return from the Newark field office to a post as senior program analyst in Washington, not the New York regional administrator's position she formerly held.

title: Shuttle, After Repair, Set for a Sunday Liftoff
description: NASA said today that two suspect engine components that grounded the space shuttle Discovery had been repaired and that the winged craft was ready for launching Sunday.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
Community Growing Up Around Project in Putnam
description: The 560-acre Mount Ebo project on a former dairy farm here is moving into its fifth year of construction. Development of the farm, which lies on Route 22 three miles north of Interstate 84, began in 1986 with a 396-unit residential section called Fieldstone Pond and the Mount Ebo Corporate Center. The residential complex occupies a 410-acre portion of the land and the million-square-foot office center is on 150 commercially zoned acres.

title: BURNING OIL POOL KILLS 5 IN KUWAIT
description: At least five people were killed a few feet off an oilfield road here Wednesday afternoon, when they blundered with their vehicles into a shallow pool of burning oil, apparently disoriented by shifting clouds of smoke and spreading ground fires.

title: Compaq Computer reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New York's Budget: Unthinkable Thoughts
description: New York City's fiscal problems have become so severe that Mayor David N. Dinkins is forcing his commissioners to contemplate severe cuts that many considered almost unthinkable only a few weeks ago -- from eliminating the city's flagship garbage recycling program to closing scores of branch libraries.

title: Michael Baker Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Abitibi-Price Names Chief
description: Ronald Y. Oberlander has been named chief executive of Abitibi-Price Inc., an integrated Canadian forest-products company based in Toronto. He succeeds Bernd K. Koken who, after 22 years with the company, is retiring from day-to-day operations but will remain chairman.

title: Kentucky Medical Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Satellite Design Pioneer Named TRW President
description: Edsel D. Dunford, an engineer who helped design some of the country's pioneering satellites, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of TRW Inc. The move apparently positions him as the eventual successor to Joseph T. Gorman, the chief executive of the aerospace and automotive components company.

title: A Glance, a Blink and a Wildcat Victory
description: Just before the anchor leg of the women's distance medley relay today in the Penn Relays, Sonia O'Sullivan of Villanova and Jasmin Jones of Tennessee eyed each other.

title: For Children
description: 'Tapori Peace Suitcase' United Nations Visitors' Lobby United Nations Plaza First Avenue and 45th Street (212) 228-1339 Recommended ages: 7 to 12 Through May 5

title: U.S. IS SKEPTICAL ON AUTONOMY PACT FOR KURDS IN IRAQ
description: White House officials expressed skepticism today over President Saddam Hussein's accord with Iraqi Kurds and said the Bush Administration was committed to building camps for the Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.

title: Data General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net lossThe company said that for the current fiscal year, it increased the maximum amoritzation period of capitalized software development costs from two years to three years. The effect of this change in estimate was a decrease in cost of product revenues and an increase in net income of about $ 3 million, or 9 cents a share, for the latest second quarter and $ 5 million, or 16 cents a share, for the latest 6 months.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on April 19 about "The Sunset Gang" carried an incomplete list of actors playing the grown children. It should have included Leslie Ayvazian in the role of Marilyn.

title: 2-Day Gain by U.S. Issues Ends
description: The two-day advance in Treasury bond prices came to a halt yesterday as the market in long-term securities absorbed various economic factors.

title: Bush and Thornburgh Confer On Possible Race for Senate
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has discussed with President Bush the possibility of resigning to run for the vacant Senate seat in Pennsylvania, the White House said today.

title: British Policy Under Study
description: The European Commission, the executive arm of the European Community, is considering whether to question Britain about allegations that it is discriminating against foreign state-owned companies trying to acquire British companies, community officials said on Wednesday.

title: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Trade Representatives Meet
description: Trade representatives met today to try to streamline negotiating procedures in the latest round of world trade talks that faltered in December.

title: TV Weekend; A Simpsonish Family of Dinosaurs
description: The blue-collar worker on television series has ranged from the "real" Archie Bunker to the animated Homer Simpson. Perhaps the next step was inevitable. Tonight at 8:30, ABC introduces Earl Sinclair, a giant puppet employing the latest developments in audio animatronics. Earl, a 43-year-old megalosaur, is the family head of "Dinosaurs," based on an idea by Jim Henson. Both ABC and Jim Henson Productions, working with Michael Jacobs Productions, have a lot of bottom-line hopes riding on this one.

title: Samuel L. Becker, 51; Ran Standards Board
description: Samuel L. Becker, a retired chairman of New York City's Board of Standards and Appeals who worked for city government for 51 years, died on Wednesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Interlake Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 1,444,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Four in New Jersey Treated for Cholera
description: Four people in New Jersey who ate crab meat imported illegally from Ecuador contracted cholera in the largest outbreak of the disease in the United States since an epidemic began in Latin America, health officals said yesterday.

title: Montana Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Chiat/Day/Mojo Gets Ad Age's TV Award
description: The trade magazine Advertising Age presented its annual award last night for the best television commercial to a spot created by the Venice, Calif., office of Chiat/Day/Mojo for the Nissan Sentra SE-R.

title: Jury in Love Triangle Trial Tells Judge It Is Deadlocked
description: After nine full days of deliberations, the jury in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus told the judge in the case today that they were deadlocked, and he in turn told them to continue working.

title: U.S. Backs Route Sale By T.W.A.
description: The Transportation Department gave final approval yesterday to the sale by Trans World Airlines of three London routes to American Airlines. The sale will provide badly needed cash for the struggling carrier, although the amount is still to be negotiated and the talks could be difficult.

title: Lincoln Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Southwest Water Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 160,000 from the sale of property.

title: Gorbachev Offers to Resign as Party's Chief, but Is Given a Vote of Support
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cut short a chorus of invective from hard-line Communist Party chiefs today by abruptly offering to quit as their leader and winning an overwhelming vote of support.

title: International Research & Chemical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Teams Put New Life in 'Cold' Fusion Theory
description: Defying reports of the demise of "cold" fusion, two teams of scientists yesterday announced what they said was new support for its existence.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 544 money market mutual funds fell by $901.3 million, to $469.87 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 190 institutional funds rose by $1.94 billion, to $134.91 billion. The 264 general-purpose funds' assets were down by $631.5 million, to $180.18 billion. Assets of the 90 broker-dealer funds dropped by $2.21 billion, to $154.78 billion, the institute said.

title: Avery Dennison Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Museum; The Artifacts of Tchaikovsky's Visit
description: It is a nostalgic show, a very personal show, a show that takes the onlooker back 100 years to a sweeter age. Most of it is devoted to Tchaikovsky in America. The great Russian composer, then 51 years old, came to New York on April 26, 1891, to take part in the festival that opened Music Hall (as Carnegie Hall was then called) on May 5. And as part of the 100th anniversary of the inaugural, Carnegie Hall has just created a new gallery adjacent to the first-tier boxes. It has been named the Carnegie Hall Museum, and it opened to the public this week.

title: Fuqua Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included charge of $ 5,933,000 for restructuring.c-Net income

title: Accounting Board Member to Be Dropped
description: After meeting in closed session, the trustees who oversee the chief rule-making body for accountants said yesterday that they would not reappoint C. Arthur Northrop to the board when his term expires.

title: Meditrust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
To Refugees, a Saudi Town Offers Hope
description: Ahmed al-Mansawi had not heard of the plan to send him and 15,000 other Iraqi refugees to a new refugee camp being built in Saudi Arabia. Neither had Maj. Tom Grubbs, an Army civil affairs officer helping run one of the refugee encampments here in southern Iraq.

title: Hawkins And 76ers Top Bucks, 99-90
description: Hersey Hawkins scored 25 points and the Philadephia 76ers used an 11-0 third-quarter run tonight to beat the Milwaukee Bucks, 99-90, in the opening game of their first-round playoff series.

title: Matzoh Case Ends in Plea
description: The B. Manischewitz Company, the nation's leading matzoh maker, has persuaded a Federal judge to accept a no-contest plea to settle price-fixing charges, a court order said.

title: KLA Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 13 million from discontinued operations.c-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 496,000 for the quarter and $ 2,366,000 for the 9 months.d-Net income

title: Review/Film; Turks Seek Happiness In Swiss Alps
description: Xavier Koller's "Journey of Hope," the Swiss film opening today at the 57th Street Playhouse, is based on the sad true story of a family of innocents and their efforts to find a new life in the economic abundance of Switzerland.

title: Penguins Eliminate Capitals for Their First Division Title
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins advanced to the Wales Conference final tonight for the first time in franchise history, riding a 33-save effort by goaltender Tom Barrasso to a 4-1 victory over the Washington Capitals.

title: Sterling Chemicals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Wednesday about the Crum & Forster unit of the Xerox Corporation misidentified the Crum & Forster subsidiary that may be taken public. It is the Constitution Reinsurance Corporation.

title: Santa Fe Energy Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Competition vs. Excellence
description: Even before we examine each provision of President Bush's proposal to make our educational system more competitive, we should challenge the premise of his plan. The trouble is our schools are already much too competitive.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas Appoints a New Chief
description: Robert B. Catell, who joined the Brooklyn Union Gas Company as a 21-year-old mechanical engineer in 1958, was named its president and chief executive yesterday. On June 1, he will succeed Elwin S. Larson, who is retiring, as head of the nation's fifth-largest gas distribution company.

title: Infrasonics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ProNet Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hercules Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Graham Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
New Campaigns
description: * In its first creative effort for the Carvel Corporation, TBWA Inc. will introduce a 30-second commercial on Monday for the ice cream shops' new line of "classic cakes." In the spot, a soundtrack of heavenly music accompanies extended, wistful shots of three Carvel confections. At the end of the commercial, a family is seated at a table with halos over their heads; as the father strums a harp, the family dog hovers over the table with angelic wings. The spot is tied to a new marketing campaign in which Carvel stores are identified as "ice cream bakeries."* For the first time, the Schering-Plough Healthcare Products Corporation has developed a television commercial that brings to life the 35-year-old logo for its Coppertone products, in which a dog nuzzles at the bathing suit of a young girl on the beach. The 30-second spot for Water Babies brand sunscreen was created by Cadwell Davis Partners and will be introduced Monday on national television. * Television viewers in the New York metropolitan area can test their knowledge of rock music lyrics in a new series of ads for WNEW-FM. In the ads, lyrics from songs that are not identified, including Bruce Springsteen's "Thunder Road" and David Bowie's "Changes," are printed across the screen, followed by the station's motto, "Where rock lives." The ads were created by Grey Entertainment & Media, a subsidiary of Grey Advertising, and will be introduced this weekend.

title: Giddings & Lewis Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 224,000, or 2 cents a share, in the latest quarter and $ 232,000, or 2 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.

title: Knight-Ridder Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Critic's Choice/Art; An Assemblagist's Debut Is Updating a Genre
description: A fog machine, trails of glitter, a scattered regiment of toy soldiers, a pile of pills, used firing-range targets, an unframed photograph of Napoleon's horse. These are just a few of the things that figure in Karen Kilimnik's edgy, chaotic yet strangely poetic debut at the 303 Gallery in SoHo.

title: Businessland Suits In Settlement
description: Businessland Inc., a personal computer retailer based in San Jose, Calif., said that its board had approved the settlement of five class-action lawsuits brought by shareholders against the company. The settlement, which is still subject to court approval, calls for Businessland to contribute $2 million in cash and shares of its common stock valued at $4 million into a settlement fund being established by the court. The suits were filed on Aug. 6, after Businessland reported a steep loss for its fourth quarter, ended on June 30, and that it would have to restate results for its second and third quarters, resulting in a sizable loss for the year.

title: Atlantic Southeast Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Princeton Impostor Indicted as Swindler
description: A Mercer County grand jury has indicted James Arthur Hogue, who posed as a student at Princeton University, accusing him of swindling thousands of dollars in scholarship funds from the school.

title: Review/Theater; 'Garden': The Secret Of Death And Birth
description: IN "The Secret Garden," the new musical at the St. James, a devoted team of theater artists applies a heap of talent and intelligence to the task of bringing Frances Hodgson Burnett's beloved children's novel of 1911 to the stage. They have accomplished that basic mission, all right, but whether "The Secret Garden" is a compelling dramatic adaptation of its source or merely a beautiful, stately shrine to it is certain to be a subject of intense audience debate. I, for one, often had trouble locating the show's pulse.

title: Herman Somers, 80, Princeton Professor In School of Politics
description: Herman Miles Somers, professor emeritus of politics and public affairs at Princeton University, died Tuesday at his home in Pennswood Village in Newton, Pa. He was 80 years old.

title: Valid Logic Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Ex-Mob Leader, In Trial, Recalls His Life of Crime
description: A former Mafia leader appeared as a prosecution witness yesterday in a racketeering trial in Brooklyn, testifying in a matter-of-fact tone that he had participated in 10 killings.

title: Cheers Greet Sentence for Officer's Slaying
description: More than 200 state troopers and New York City police officers roared thunderously yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan when two drug dealers were sentenced to 40 years to life in prison for killing a state police undercover officer in a drug deal that turned into a shootout on the Lower East Side last year.

title: Japan-Soviet Talks Have Strategic Aspect
description: To the Editor:

title: Memories of Automats Past: Beef Pie and Depression Cocktails; Faithful Clientele
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Holland's Stunning Surprise
description: Since plea bargains are rarely overturned, the chances that a judge would reject a deal crafted by the Federal Government, the state of Alaska and the world's largest oil company seemed almost nil. On Wednesday, however, Judge H. Russel Holland bravely threw out the agreement ordering Exxon to pay $100 million to settle criminal charges arising from the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

title: Review/Film; Preppies Vs. Terrorists At School
description: Novelty counts for a lot in a suspense film, and "Toy Soldiers" has a genuinely novel gimmick. Its setting is a boys' prep school, the kind of place that is more familiarly used as a crucible for shaping young minds and values. In this case, it becomes the serene, leafy setting for a terrorist attack.

title: Broad Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Better Way to Honor Dr. King
description: Among the many victims of New York State's budget crunch is a New York City program to house the homeless. It doesn't need much money to stay on track. But Gov. Mario Cuomo's budget puts a cap on the state's contribution, leaving the city a crucial $1 million short. There is no better place to find that money than the discredited Martin Luther King Institute for Nonviolence.

title: Bronx Teacher Is Held in Rape Of Student, 13
description: A Bronx gym teacher was charged yesterday in the rape of a 13-year-old student in his office during school hours, the police said.

title: Clemens Ruling Today
description: ROGER CLEMENS, winner of his first four pitching decisions this season, might lose a decision from last season today. The Boston Red Sox right-hander will learn whether or not he must serve a five-game suspension and pay a $10,000 fine for his behavior before and after being ejected from the fourth game of last year's American League playoffs in Oakland.

title: Agency Review By Club Med
description: Club Med said yesterday that it had narrowed the review for its $15 million United States advertising account to five agencies.

title: Unisys Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue represented total revenue.

title: General Binding reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
He Turned 40's Music Latin. Now He's Turning 80.
description: The band leader Mario Bauza, who is one of America's most important musicians, celebrates his 80th birthday at Symphony Space tomorrow night with the composer and trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie, the pianist Marco Rizo, the novelist Oscar Hijuelos and others. If past concerts are any indication, he'll be out there directing his orchestra, telling people to solo longer, play louder or softer, and introducing band members. Mr. Bauza likes things to go smoothly.

title: Great Expectations: 4 Chapters Close
description: Leroy Jolley may have said it best: "When you ask a lot, sometimes you ask too much."

title: Hall (Frank B.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There were no share earnings in latest or year-ago periods because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: Burlington Northern Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $ 8,000,000, or 10 cents a share, from extinguisment of debt.The company said first quarter 1991 operating expenses included an accrual of $ 46 million for a possible labor settlement based on presidental emergency board recommendations released in January.This item was $ 40 million, or 33 cents a share, more than the $ 6 million recorded in the first quarter last year as part of a program to accrue for such a settlement over time. A year-over-year increase in fuel cost per gallon added $ 15 million to operating costs as well.

title: Boston Edison Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 15,824,000, or 41 cents a share.

title: Surgery Ruled Out
description: Doctors in Denver have ruled out surgery for BILL SHOEMAKER, the jockey who was partly paralyzed by a spinal column fracture suffered in an auto accident April 8. Shoemaker requires a ventilator to assist in his breathing, officials at Craig Hospital said. He has been weaned from the ventilator for a few minutes each day and he is able to shrug his shoulders, officials said. (AP)

title: Galileo Electro-Optics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Coastal and Pennzoil Report Lower Profits
description: The Coastal Corporation and the Pennzoil Company, two energy companies with operations primarily in the United States, said today that their earnings declined in the first quarter.

title: Israel Pessimistic on Baker Mission As More Settlers Go to West Bank
description: As Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was airborne, on his way to Israel from the Soviet Union, Israelis moved seven more mobile homes to a new West Bank settlement today, and the nation's leaders expressed deep pessimism over the prospects of Mr. Baker's mission.

title: C&S/Sovran
description: The C&S/Sovran Corporation plans to close 50 branches and sell 30 others, the bank's chief financial officer said. The moves are part of a continuing consolidation in the wake of last year's merger of the Citizens and Southern Corporation, and the Sovran Financial Corporation, James D. Dixon, the financial officer, told a conference of stockbrokers in Atlanta. The branches affected by the consolidation are among 998 in the seven states and Washington, D.C., area served by C&S/Sovran.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: Pratt & Whitney said that Korean Air Lines had chosen its PW4000 jet engines to power up to 25 Boeing 747-400 wide-body aircraft. The engine purchase, the largest commercial order so far this year for the division of the United Technologies Corporation, is worth up to $840 million. Delivery of the first aircraft to Korean Air Lines is scheduled for August.

title: UtiliCorp United Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of about $ 10.9 million for the sale of gas and oil reserve assets owned by Aquila Energy.

description: The latest quarter included a gain of $ 5.4 million from the sale of Intermet's 60 percent ownership interest in Intat Precision Inc. The company attributed the decline in sales to units which were in operation during the first quarter of 1990 but have since been sold or closed, and to the recession in the auto industry.

title: Michael Kuhnen, 35, Top German Neo-Nazi
description: Michael Kuhnen, Germany's top neo-Nazi leader, died today at a hospital in the western German city of Kassel. He was 35 years old.

description: b-After pretax provision for restructured operations and divestitures of $ 90 million.c-Net loss

title: Paul Brickhill, 74, Author of War Novels
description: Paul Brickhill, author of "The Great Escape" and other war novels that sold millions of copies and were made into films, died on Tuesday. He was 74 years old.

title: Trenwick Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $ 90,000, or one-cent a share gain, for this year's quarter and a $ 72,000, or 1 cent a share gain, for the year-ago period.

title: Alice Cutts Wainwright; Environmentalist, 83
description: Alice Cutts Wainwright, an environmentalist who wrote the charter for Friends of the Everglades and represented the Audubon Society in South Florida for almost 20 years, died after suffering a heart attack Tuesday at Mercy Hospital here. She was 83 years old.

title: Westar Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and share earnings are nil.Figures are in Canadian funds.

description: b-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,000,000.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Robbery Inquiries End in Case of Beaten Motorist
description: State prosecutors said Wednesday that they would not pursue their investigation of a pizza shop robbery involving Rodney G. King, the black motorist whose videotaped beating by white police officers here has been widely publicized.

title: U.S. Extending Safety Zone for Kurdish Refugees
description: American military units are expanding the safe-haven zone for Kurds in northern Iraq to include a secure route leading from the mountains to a tent city now being built near here, relief officials said today.

title: G.E. Plant to Cut Up to 1,000 Jobs
description: The General Electric Company said it would cut up to 1,000 jobs, or 6 percent of the work force, at its Evendale, Ohio, plant because it lost the competition to build engines for the next generation of Air Force fighter planes. On Tuesday the Pentagon chose Pratt & Whitney, a division of the United Technologies Corporation, over G.E. to build engines for the Advanced Tactical Fighter. A team headed by the Lockheed Corporation won the contract, which could be worth $60 billion, to build nearly 650 of the radar-evading jets.

title: Puhl Signs With Royals
description: TERRY PUHL, a 14-year veteran who was released by the Mets after a spring training tryout, has agreed to a one-year contract with the Kansas City Royals. The Royals said Puhl, 34 years old, would replace first baseman GEORGE BRETT, who will be placed on the 15-day disabled list. Puhl, a .281 career hitter, spent 14 years with the Houston Astros.

title: Stocks Fall And the Dow Drops 28.46
description: Wave after wave of computerized program selling, and widespread investor concern that interest-rate cuts may be out of the question for a while, toppled stock prices yesterday.

title: Key Rates

description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 367,000,000, which included a provision of $ 375 million in connection with investments in VMS Realty Partners.Revenue represented total revenue.First-quarter 1990 results have been restated to exclude revenues and net income of its discontinued real estate and third-party financing business.

title: SOVIETS BACK U.S. ON MIDEAST PARLEY
description: The Soviet Union formally announced today that it was prepared to co-sponsor a Middle East peace conference with the United States, but it appeared to need a little prodding from Washington before it did so.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Placed Felix Fermin, shortstop, on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to April 23. Purchased the contract of Mark Lewis, shortstop, from Colorado of the Pacific Coast League. DETROIT TIGERS -- Placed Lloyd Moseby, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to April 23. Called up Mark Leiter, pitcher, from Toledo of the International League. American Association BUFFALO BISONS -- Promoted Martha K. Hiczewski to vice president of administration. BASKETBALL National Basketball Association ORLANDO MAGIC -- Signed Jerry Reynolds, guard-forward, to a multiyear contract. PHOENIX SUNS -- Signed Dan Majerle, guard-forward, to a three-year contract extension. United States Basketball League LONG ISLAND SURF -- Named Ed Krinsky, general manager, and Bernard Tomlin, head coach and director of player personnel. FOOTBALL National Football League DETROIT LIONS -- Signed Bobby Futrell, defensive back. MIAMI DOLPHINS -- Signed Chris Stablein, quarterback; Richard Buchanon, and Joel Taylor, wide receivers; Darren Handy, and Blaine Rose, offensive linemen; Clifford Champ, and Kevin Pearson, linebackers; Michael Iaquaniello, safety; and Steve Berg, defensive end. NEW ENGLAND PATRIOTS -- Signed Ben Coates, tight end. Announced the retirement of Marc Wilson, quarterback. NEW YORK JETS -- Agreed to terms with Peter Balistrieri and Reggie Moore, wide receivers, and Kip Beach, tackle. PITTSBURGH STEELERS -- Signed Garry Howe, defensive lineman; Kevin Smith, defensive back; and Dan Walsh, running back. SAN FRANCISCO 49ERS -- Signed Doug DuBose, running back, and Ralph Martini, quarterback. SEATTLE SEAHAWKS -- Agreed to terms with Chuck Knox, coach, on a two-year contract extension. WASHINGTON REDSKINS -- Signed Jack Bradford, linebacker; Reggie Howard, tackle; Walter Batson, wide receiver; and James Jenkins, tight end. Canadian Football League BRITISH COLUMBIA LIONS -- Agreed to terms with Matt Clark and Mike Trevathan, wide receivers. HAMILTON TIGER-CATS -- Signed Robert Malcolm, fullback, and Michael Campbell, defensive lineman. World League of American Football LONDON MONARCHS -- Signed John Fruhmorgen, center. Released Damon Baldwin, guard.

description: Shareholders of the Philip Morris Companies today overwhelmingly rejected proposals to study the impact of cigarette and beer advertising on children, to place warnings on cigarettes sold worldwide and to boycott Salvadoran coffee beans.

Review/Art; Indonesia's Sculpture: So Serene, 4-Inch Statues Can Make a Room a Shrine
description: "The Sculpture of Indonesia" brings to the Metropolitan Museum of Art something New York has not seen for some time: a convincing exhibition of classical art. Although Indonesian sculpture has its share of disruptive figures, including the fanged, four-armed, skull-crowned Bhairava mounted on his jackal, most of the figures in this show are serene. This is very much the art of an essentially peaceful nation that was for an extended period at ease with itself.

title: Review/City Ballet; New 'Beauty' Has Point To Make
description: "THE SLEEPING BEAUTY," as produced for the first time by the New York City Ballet, is controversy embodied. Visually spectacular and fiercely polemical, Peter Martins's 21st-century staging of 19th-century ballet's most famous classic is danced at astonishingly breakneck speed and has a shocker of an ending. You will want to see it.

Out of Cash, School District In California to Close Early
description: Eighteen months after it was singled out by the Bush Administration as a model of low-cost improvement of failing schools, the Richmond, Calif., Unified School District has announced it will close its doors after classes on Tuesday.

That title insurance unit had operating income of $ 5.9 million in the year-earlier quarter.The company also said the 1991 quarter includes a gain on investment transactions of $ 2.8 million, compared with a loss of $ 100,000 on investment transactions in the 1990 quarter.

title: Soviet Reform Suddenly Revived
description: In a remarkable turnaround, Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin, setting aside their personal differences, pledged Wednesday to concentrate on saving the Soviet Union from political and economic disintegration. Their agreement is the first hopeful sign in months that radical reform can be revived and hard-line dictatorship avoided. America has an enormous stake in extending support for this promising development.

description: b-Net incomeFigures are in Canadian funds.

title: Critic's Notebook; Carnegie Is Still The Center Of Gravity
description: HOW once again to beat a drum that's already been whacked so long and so hard that ears are ringing from the noise? How to add yet more words to the scrivening torrent that has accompanied Carnegie Hall's centennial celebration -- festivities that reach their peak over the next 10 days with the hall's Centennial Festival in both the main hall and Weill Recital Hall?

title: Waiting for Democrats on the Iowa Hustings
description: Nobody thought it would be like 1988. Even some Iowans acknowledge that their caucuses, the first test of the Presidential nominating season, got out of hand in 1988.

title: From The Highest Court On Down, The Perplexing Problem Of The Proprieties Of Honorifics.
description: Lawyers scheduled to argue before the United States Supreme Court prepare for the experience like Presidential candidates preparing for a debate, trying to anticipate every conceivable question. But John Blume of Columbia, S.C., and Abbey Lowell of Washington were tripped up by something totally unexpected: They both called the Chief Justice "Justice."

title: Manuscript With False Praise Is Rejected
description: Simon & Schuster said yesterday that it would not publish "Just Killing Time" by Derek V. Goodwin, the book it won in an auction two weeks ago with a $920,000 bid. The manuscript was submitted to prospective buyers with false written endorsements from John le Carre and Joseph Wambaugh.

title: Court in a Hurry
description: The Supreme Court has created the strong impression, in recent decisions, that it has an agenda for radical change in one area of the law. A majority seems intent on sharply reducing the availability of constitutional protections for people charged with crime.
