title: Defiant Larry Davis Gets 25 Years to Life in Killing
description: Larry Davis, whose repeated clashes with the law have made him a hero to some and a pariah to others, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life for the 1986 murder of a Bronx drug dealer. But not before he expressed his contempt for the criminal-justice system loudly and at length, creating a tumultuous scene in court until the judge expelled him.

title: Long Memories Make the Kurds Distrust Hussein
description: "Saddam, he says one thing, he does another," said Suleiman Sindi, his lined face a map of past betrayals of the Kurds. "Now we don't go to Zakho because there are men in police uniforms, not police, but army. No."

title: U.S. to Push for Lower Rates At Group of Seven Meeting
description: The United States will emphasize the need to lower world interest rates when it meets in Washington this weekend with its chief economic allies in the Group of Seven, a top Treasury official said yesterday.

title: Panel Asks Bush to Cite 3 Nations
description: A panel of Cabinet officials has recommended to President Bush that the United States officially cite China, India and Thailand on Friday for tolerating violations of American copyrights and patents, Congressional and Administration officials said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: YACHTING Second Finisher in BOC Race Alain Gautier, the French solo sailor who lost first place in the BOC yacht race around the world earlier this week when his sailboat stalled in light air 200 miles from the finish line, finally made it into Newport, R.I., Harbor yesterday afternoon. But it was no day at the beach, either. Gautier sat becalmed for hours aboard his 60-foot boat, Generali Concorde, just five miles from the finish line of the 27,000-mile race that took eight months and was sailed in four legs. Finally, at midmorning, a fresh sea breeze filled in and Gautier was able to complete the event, finishing about 38 hours behind Christophe Auguin of France, whose Groupe Sceta won in an elapsed time of 120 days 22 hours 36 minutes 35 seconds.

description: IS the world economy headed for a split into three warring trade blocs -- Europe, North America and East Asia?

title: Tokyo Stocks Advance
description: Japanese stock prices rose today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 84.82 points, or slightly more than three-tenths of a percent, to end the week at 26,123.68. For the week, the index was down 418.28 points, or about 1.6 percent.

title: Home Resales Are Up 0.6% For 2d Consecutive Increase
description: Sales of existing homes rose in March for the second consecutive month, a real estate trade group said today. The advance of six-tenths of a percent was new evidence, analysts said, that the housing recession has bottomed out.

title: Concessions or No, Boot Hussein
description: To save his skin and re-establish personal control over Iraq, Saddam Hussein has struck a deal with the Kurds, whom he has repeatedly double-crossed and brutally oppressed. But U.S. policy should not be guided by Mr. Hussein's self-interest. For there to be true peace in the region, Saddam Hussein must go.

'Wide World,' at Age 30, Is Still Beating the Odds
description: Of all the singular moments in 30 years of "ABC's Wide World of Sports," none has symbolized the program more than that featuring Vinko Bogotaj. Bogotaj was a mediocre Yugoslav ski jumper with the dubious luck to be competing in the 1970 ski flying championships in Oberstdorf, Germany.

title: New Pact for Majerle
description: DAN MAJERLE, who is finishing the third year of a five-year contract that pays him about $450,000 per season, was given a new three-year contract by the Phoenix Suns yesterday. JERRY COLANGELO, the club president, said Majerle's salary would hit the $1 million mark when the extension begins. (AP)

title: Judge Joseph Lord 3d Dies at 78; Broke Will on All-White School
description: Joseph S. Lord 3d, a senior judge of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia who was known for his decisions on rights issues, died on Tuesday at Presbyterian Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 78 years old and lived in the Germantown section of Philadelphia.

title: U.S. ABORTION RATE SHOWS 6% DECLINE
description: The abortion rate in the United States dropped 6 percent from 1980 to 1987, from 29 abortions for every 1,000 women of child-bearing age to about 27 per 1,000, according to a new study by the Alan Guttmacher Institute.

title: Hybrid Bicycles Give Riders Best of 2 Styles

title: Body Discovery Investigated
description: The authorities have found a body that they believe is that of a woman whom a doctor claimed to have helped commit suicide. The body, which a community college had planned to use as an instructional cadaver, was taken to the Monroe County Medical Examiner's office on Thursday. In the March 7 edition of The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Timothy E. Quill said he prescribed barbiturates for a 45-year-old leukemia patient and made sure that she knew how many pills to take to commit suicide. A spokeswoman for the Medical Examiner said officials believe it is the body of Dr. Quill's patient.

title: Jack Collins, 74, Dies; Public Service Career
description: Jack B. Collins, whose career was spent in public service, died on Thursday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: New Stance on Car Sales
description: The president of the National Automobile Dealers Association urged auto makers today to increase cash rebates and offer lower financing rates to stimulate car sales.

title: Sports of The Times; Ewing Must Turn Into the Cavalry
description: "We've got a lot of work ahead of us," said John MacLeod. That's how Custer viewed it, too.

title: Colorado National Bankshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Continental Bank to Sell Subsidiary
description: The Continental Bank Corporation said it would sell its securities-trading subsidiary to Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a New York-based trading firm, for an undisclosed price. Continental has been trying to sell the unprofitable First Options of Chicago Inc. unit since January 1990. Continental said it expects the transaction to close by May 15, pending approval by regulators and financial exchanges.

title: 30 Die as Tornadoes Sweep Kansas and Oklahoma
description: A cluster of tornadoes crashed down in eastern Kansas and Oklahoma yesterday evening, killing at least 30 people, injuring about 300 and destroying hundreds of buildings and homes.

title: Students Unwanted Elsewhere Seize Their School to Defend It
description: To its 35 troubled students, the sparsely furnished school in Queens is a last chance to avoid life -- or an early death -- on the streets.

title: Time to Branch Out for Gargano
description: Amil Gargano, the highly respected advertising executive largely responsible for campaigns that scored breakthroughs for Federal Express, Volvo and other clients, is leaving as chairman of Ally & Gargano to start his own small spinoff agency.

title: About New York
description: Vera Beaudin Saeedpour remembers the day when the small dark neighbor who could barely speak English came to her door, flowers in one hand, a coffeecake in the other. She had never met a Kurd before.

title: Ameribanc Investors Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Sununu Trips Reportedly Included Recreation
description: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, has sometimes added political chores and recreation to Government-paid airplane trips while on official visits, a magazine is reporting.

title: First United Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE -- Upheld the five-game suspension and $10,000 fine of Roger Clemens, Boston pitcher, for his conduct during last year's AL playoffs. American League

title:
SPORTS LEISURE;
One Man's Journey: Fat Kid To Hulk
description: It all began for me when I was a fat kid growing up on Long Island. I was 13 years old, kind of chunky, with that husky look. I started working out.

title: First State Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Barry (R.G.) Corp.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
5 Cleared of Charges on Toxic Workplace
description: Five current and former corporate executives of a wire-coating plant have been acquitted of criminal charges of knowingly exposing employees to dangerous working conditions. The judge who found the executives not guilty said they were "careless housekeepers," not criminals.

title: Taiwan Belongs in GATT
description: Even as politics divided the world after World War II, trade united it. Now, Communism's collapse and the third world's disenchantment with protectionism makes possible a truly global market -- one world, united in trade.

title: American Precision Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Interfirst Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter's per share earnings is not presented since the bank converted from a mutual to a stock institution on Nov. 9, 1990.

title: Haiti Recalls Greene With Gratitude
description: The lights still go out each day without warning here, and as ever, few tourists brave the poverty-filled streets. But 34 years after its start, the long, dark era of the Duvaliers and their sinister Tontons Macoute finally seems over, and for that, many here say, a belated measure of credit is due to the writing of Graham Greene.

title: Wendall Garnett, CORE Secretary, 58
description: Wendall Garnett, secretary of the board of the Congress of Racial Equality, died on Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Beliefs
description: The title of the lecture was provocative: "The Soul of Man Under Secularism." Christopher Lasch, the distinguished historian from the University of Rochester, had taken it from an earlier provocateur, Oscar Wilde. A century ago, in February 1891, the British playwright and poet published a slim volume called "The Soul of Man Under Socialism."

title: Article 069691 -- No Title
description: Ernst & Young, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, has agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle charges that it portrayed the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association as profitable.

title: Music in Review; Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg and Cecile Licad
description: Alice Tully Hall

title: New York Magazine Hurt by City's Slump
description: New York magazine, perhaps the best-known city magazine, has seen better days.

title: Importing Mayan Artifacts From Guatemala Is Curbed
description: In an effort to help stop the plunder of archeological sites in the history-rich rain forests of the Peten region of northern Guatemala, the United States has banned the import of all unauthorized Mayan artifacts from that part of Guatemala.

title: Franklin First Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Your Money; New Regulations on Stock Options
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted new rules, effective on Wednesday, that will allow many company officers and board members to realize the benefits of their stock options sooner and with less risk, an important matter to many of these officers.

title: School Official Ousted as Prints Reveal 1974 Crime
description: The new superintendent of School District 1 on Manhattan's Lower East Side, who was nominated last year as a Reader's Digest "Hero of American Education," was suspended by the local school board Thursday night after an F.B.I. fingerprint check revealed that he had failed to disclose on his job application a 1974 conviction for selling cocaine.

title: BFS Bankorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Music in Review; Prokofiev Remembered: Chamber Music
description: Town Hall 123 West 43d Street

title: Booton Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Music in Review; "Lo Sposo Deluso," by Mozart, and "Le Donne Rivali," by Cimarosa
description: Juilliard Opera Center Performances today and May 20

title: Jury Quickly Acquits Man Charged in Brush With an Officer
description: A Criminal Court jury in Manhattan took only minutes yesterday to acquit a recent New York University graduate of inciting a riot and assaulting a New York City police officer last summer in Washington Square Park.

title: A No-Confidence Vote for Jails
description: City and state investigations of last summer's disturbance at the Rikers Island jail complex paint a sickening picture of official failure. The findings can only reinforce doubts about Correction Commissioner Allyn Sielaff's fitness for his job.

title: Plan to Ease Mexico Pact
description: The Administration is likely to tell Congress in the next several days that it will pay for some retraining of workers displaced by a proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico and will seek environmental and health safeguards to accompany the agreement, a senator and trade experts said.

title: F.D.A. Approval on Lilly Drug
description: Eli Lilly & Company said that Federal regulators had approved a liquid form of Prozac, an anti-depressant drug that critics say causes suicidal tendencies in some users. Lilly officials said the approval by the Food and Drug Administration strengthened their position that the drug was safe. In addition, pharmaceutical industry analysts said the drug would get a much larger boost if the F.D.A. approved it for treatment of obesity, which is expected possibly before the end of the year.

title: Patents; In the Sun Too Long? Device Sounds an Alarm
description: For people worried about getting too much sun, which can promote skin cancer, an inventor in Southern California has patented a device that measures a person's exposure to ultraviolet rays and sounds an alarm when it is too great.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Stores Corp., Cincinnati, announced the appointment of Robert DiNicola as president and chief operating officer of Bon Marche, its Seattle-based department store unit. * Bank of the West, San Francisco, elected Robert A. Fuhrman chairman to succeed Halsey Burke, who has retired. Michel Larrouilh, chief executive, was named to the additonal post of vice chairman, and Don J. McGrath was made president.

title: Black Hills Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 853,000, which includes a $ 900,000 loss on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Kurds' Chief Ends Chaos but Not Squalor of Camp
description: In the squalor of this Kurdish refugee camp spreading along a narrow mountain river valley, Abdullah Gaudany cuts a commanding figure.

title: So You Want to Be a Tough Gal?
description: Lifting weights is my best bad habit. I say bad habit not because I'm clinically addicted to the sport, the way marathoners can be to running although there have been times in my life when going to the gym has taken priority over finishing a story, doing my taxes, getting enough sleep or even talking civilly to a friend.

title: Review/Theater; Women on Peril's Edge, By Joyce Carol Oates
description: In a quartet of short plays at Long Wharf Theater, Joyce Carol Oates expresses herself in diverse dramatic modes. Each becomes a determined experiment in extending the range of this widely accomplished novelist and short story writer. But as with Ms. Oates's other writing for the theater, the plays are shadowed by the artistry of her prose.

title: Jack Doland, Legislator, 63
description: State Senator Jack Doland, who was head football coach and then president of McNeese State University here before entering politics, died of prostate cancer on Thursday. Mr. Doland, a Democrat, was 63 years old.

title: Throwing Money Down the Jails
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, elected partly because he was expected to improve services for low-income communities of color, has ambitious plans to expand the one program for poor people that his predecessor and political opponent, Edward I. Koch, favored: jails. In doing so, the Mayor has let short-sighted politics cloud his judgment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 20 about Spain's relations with North Africa referred incompletely to Ceuta and Melilla, two Spanish enclaves on the Moroccan coast. Morocco, which claims the two cities, considers them colonies. But a reader's letter dated April 17 has pointed out that Spain treats them as integral parts of its national territory.

title: Napa Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included non-recurring $ 124,000 charges.c-Included $ 288,000 gain from sale of homes in a real estate development project.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Petrofina Inc., Dallas, an oil company, said that it had changed its name to Fina, to establish a firmer relationship with its subsidiary Fina Oil and Chemical Co. * Armco Inc., Parsippany, N.J., a steel and field equipment company, said it had signed a letter of intent to purchase Douglas Dynamics, Inc., Milwaukee, a manufacturer of snowplows, from its stockholders for an undisclosed sum. Armco said it hopes to complete the purchase by June.

title: Review/Music; Favorites of the Golden Toscanini Years
description: The New York Philharmonic program that Giuseppe Sinopoli led on Thursday evening could have been billed as "A Toscanini Tour of Italy." The concert consisted of three pictorially vivid works that were specialties of the great Arturo, whose recordings of them were among the medium-fi glories of the pre-LP age. In recent years, Respighi's "Fountains of Rome" and "Pines of Rome" and even Mendelssohn's "Italian" Symphony have been the victims of condescension and have been slipping over into the pop-classic category. That, however, is the "serious" concertgoer's loss.

title: Celtics Win Opener, but Bird Is Hospitalized After Game
description: Larry Bird, Robert Parish and Kevin McHale, the Boston Celtics' aging front line, have played 451 playoff games in their National Basketball Association careers. Tonight at Boston Garden they combined for 66 points, and were too much for the Indiana Pacers.

title: Ford Plans to Cut Staff in Europe
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would cut its salaried support staff in Europe by 30 percent over the next three years. The cuts mostly involve clerical and accounting workers and will not affect manufacturing and production staff, the company said.

title: Artistic Greetings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
No Glass Slipper Or Invitation for Mirabella
description: Mirabella, not quite two years old and the youngest member of the Murdoch Magazines family, appears to be the rejected child in the agreement by a partnership controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts to acquire all the other magazines put up for sale by Rupert Murdoch.

title: Leonard Eisner, 70, Pianist and Teacher
description: Leonard Eisner, a concert pianist and teacher, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 70 years old.

title: British and Irish Move on Talks
description: Making way for what they called a historic opportunity to address the future of Northern Ireland, the British and Irish Governments suspended their own six-year-long consultations over the troubled province today in favor of new negotiations beginning next week in Belfast.

title: Writing in Fear, Homeless Plead to Save Drop-In Centers
description: New York City's fiscal crisis has taken such a desperate turn this week that Mayor David N. Dinkins may be forced to close down one of his own pet programs -- eight drop-in centers for the homeless that he fought for in past years and praised as a national model for helping the elderly and mentally ill homeless.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 17 about Patricia Bowman, the woman who has accused William Kennedy Smith of rape, misstated her history at the Tallmadge (Ohio) High School. Although she enrolled for the 1976-77 academic year, she withdrew in the fall; her academic record was compiled elsewhere.

title: Atalanta/Sosnoff Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 549,000, or 6 cents a share, from the repurchase of $ 4.9 million of convertible debentures.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Tauziat Upsets Navratilova

title: Music in Review; Tina Chancey
description: On Pardessus de Viole Weill Recital Hall

title: Iran Chief's Ally Wins Vote Test
description: The Iranian Parliament gave a vote of confidence to the Minister of Education, overriding allegations of mismanagement and defeating a new attempt by Islamic radicals to weaken the policy of President Hashemi Rafsanjani's administration.

title: Guidepost; Mixing Investments
description: Individual investors should review their portfolio mix regularly. Joseph V. Battipaglia, director of research at Gruntal & Company, said the first quarter will probably be the worst of the year. His recommended mix for the second quarter favors stocks, with changes only in types of stocks and bonds. Utilities are still a must for steady returns, he said, adding that he also liked environmental and manufacturing stocks. Here are how four brokerage firms recommend allocating assets for the second quarter of the year and what they recommended for the first quarter, by percentage. Firm Stocks Bonds Cash DEAN WITTER 2nd quarter 55 40 5 1st quarter 55 35 10 GRUNTAL 2nd quarter 55 30 15 1st quarter 55 30 15 MERRILL LYNCH 2nd quarter 55 40 5 1st quarter 60 35 5 PAINE WEBBER 2nd quarter 55 40 5 1st quarter 60 35 5

title: U.S. Urges Americans to Quit Ethiopia as Rebels Gain
description: With rebel forces only 65 miles from the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, and dispirited Government troops heading back toward the city, the United States advised all Americans today to leave the country as it appeared to be falling into anarchy.

title: Buckeye Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 300,000.The company said first quarter 1990 results reflect a $ 1.7 million charge for insurance deductibles and other extraordinary costs related to the rupture of one of the partnership's pipelines and subsequent spillage. Expenses were $ 1 million lower in the 1991 first quarter compared with the year-earlier quarter, which included this charge.

title: Review/Theater; A Diverse Cast, All Played By Tina Smith
description: Among the half-dozen intriguing characters portrayed by Tina Smith in "Don't Get Me Started," her one-woman show of monologues at Theater Arielle (432 West 42d Street), are a country-and-western singer whose fictionalized biography is about to be made into a movie, a poet-cum-performance artist from Brooklyn who is grotesquely ill-equipped for a literary career, and a woman who bills herself as "the only holistic new-age exotic dancer in Las Vegas."

title: Lebanese Militias Disbanding
description: Muslim and Christian militias began to disband and disarm today, four days before a Government deadline expires.

title: Bid to Buy Harcourt Withdrawn
description: The General Cinema Corporation said yesterday that it had ended its effort to acquire Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. after failing to come to terms with Harcourt's bondholders.

title: American Educational Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Barringer Technologies reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 325,000.

title: Newspaper Executives Say It's Bad All Over
description: From the Times Mirror Company in Los Angeles to Knight-Ridder Inc. in Miami, executives from 15 newspaper companies who spoke at a two-day conference that ended here today told tales of lower advertising, revenues and earnings in the first quarter of 1991, after a dismal 1990.

title: Penalties Are Upheld by Vincent, and Clemens Starts to Sit
description: Roger Clemens won a partial victory yesterday in a six-month war of words, but ended up the loser anyway.

title: The Court Sets a Death Agenda
description: When new Supreme Court majorities hasten to overrule the Court's own recent precedents, the justices invite the public to believe, as Felix Frankfurter once warned, "that law is an expression of chance -- for instance, of unexpected changes in the Court's composition and the contingencies in the choice of successors." Led by Chief Justice Rehnquist, today's Court is running just such a risk to its reputation and to justice on a death penalty issue that doesn't deserve such abuse.

title: Capitalist Slavery In China
description: After a decade of observing crypto-capitalist "reform" in China, one becomes accustomed to ironies and paradoxes. So I was hardly surprised by a Chinese article on management strategy asserting that good business reputations are "established as a result of a high sense of responsibility and loyalty to consumers in a target market" and that "selling good will means selling quality." After all, for some time China has issued how-to tracts by budding entrepreneurs that sound more like Dale Carnegie than Mao Zedong.

title: U.S. DELAYS ISSUING NUTRITION CHART
description: The Agriculture Department has decided to delay publication of its new Eating Right Pyramid depicting the four food groups, a successor to the department's aging food-wheel chart, which has been distributed to nutrition education programs around the country since the 1950's.

title: Powell Sets British Straight
description: The Times of London was politely corrected in a letter to the editor today by Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, about why his friends call him KOH-lin -- not KAH-lin.

title: KURDS BEGIN MOVE OUT OF MOUNTAINS TO AN ALLIED ZONE
description: Kurdish refugees slowly began moving down from the mountains today as allied troops took effective control of this northern town with the final pullout of several hundred armed Iraqis.

title: America West Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 7.4 million from sale of foreign tax benefits related to the acquisition of aircraft.

title: Review/Dance; Alone in the Wilderness
description: Snow covered the interior of St. Mark's Church on Thursday night. Not real snow -- just a white floorcloth. Yet it transformed the sanctuary into an Arctic waste for the New York premiere of Meredith Monk's "Facing North."

title: Corner of Connecticut Is Foundering as Its Lifeline, the Navy, Scales Back
description: Here in the self-proclaimed Submarine Capital of the World, home of the nation's largest submarine builder and the Navy's largest submarine base, the local economy is declining slowly and may soon reach levels not seen since the demobilization that followed World War II.

title: Washington Presses Japan to Open Construction Jobs
description: After several years of diplomatic fencing, Japan and the United States traded harsher jabs today over American access to the Japanese construction market.

title: Frank Hamilton, 66, Film and Stage Actor
description: Frank Hamilton, a stage, film and television actor, died on Thursday at Brotman Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan and Los Angeles.

title: New Head of Delta Air Aims to See Black Ink
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. this week named a new president, W. Whitley Hawkins, and he assumes his position with the company facing unaccustomed hard times.

title: Advanta Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on the sale of credit card receivables of $ 2,976,000, or 31 cents a share.

title: BayBanks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bank of Boston reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gain of $ 7.8 million from the repurchase of debt.c-Net incomeThe bank said net credit losses totaled $ 100 million in latest first quarter, compared with $ 84 million in year-ago period.

title: Jean-Baptiste Cerrone Dies at 79; A Manager for Dance Companies
description: Jean-Baptiste Cerrone, who managed several major dance companies from the 1930's through the 80's, died on Wednesday at North Broward Hospital in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla., and Nice, France.

title: Federated Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Financial Trust Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
California State Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Looking Up From Bottom, Knicks See a Mountain of Questions
description: In the aftermath of Patrick Ewing's worst-ever playoff game, and the Knicks' worst-ever playoff loss, Ewing and his teammates practiced today while searching for, and desperately needing, the answers to some tough questions.

title: Aztar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 3,496,000, or 8 cents a share.Year-ago income from continuing operations of $ 5,803,000, or 14 cents a share, included a pretax gain of about $ 6,800,000 for sale of Aztar's share in the Tropicana Country Club in Las Vegas, representing compensation for the leasehold interest in the property.The company said its first quarter 1991 net loss was the result of negative effects of the Persian Gulf War and excess capacity in all markets. Aztar said most of its loss occurred in January, with the company returning to profitability in March.

title: Mandela Calls April Deadline For Prisoner Release Flexible
description: Nelson H. Mandela said today that the April 30 deadline set by the African National Congress for the release of political prisoners was flexible, but he demanded again that the Government halt fighting between black factions.

title: Bolt Beranek & Newman reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 5,096,000, or 25 cents a share, from sale of network equipment to Delta Air Lines.c-Net loss

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the height of the awards season, at least one person refuses to accept one or even to allow one to be presented in his name.

title: Baghdad to Disband Militia and End Travel Ban
description: Iraq said today that it would disband its million-man militia and let citizens travel abroad.

title: Bliss & Laughlin Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Aetna Life & Casualty Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said first quarter results reflected strong group health earnings, but financial services earnings were down to $ 1 million from $ 34 million a year earlier.The $ 16.2 million net realized capital loss for the quarter included additions to reserves for mortgage loans and real-estate writedowns of $ 52 million, compared with $ 6 million a year earlier.

title: Plea for College Aid Refused? An Appeal Could Win a Grant
description: Each spring, in a ritual mailing that probably brings more jubilation to American households than even tax refunds, the nation's colleges send millions of acceptances to prospective freshmen. Within a week or two, however, perhaps half of them will get another letter, an "award" letter, with bad news.

title: Beliefs
description: The title of the lecture was provocative: "The Soul of Man Under Secularism." Christopher Lasch, the distinguished historian from the University of Rochester, had taken it from an earlier provocateur, Oscar Wilde. A century ago, in February 1891, the British playwright and poet published a slim volume called "The Soul of Man Under Socialism."

title: Brown & Sharpe reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,180,000.c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 590,000.

title: Commerce Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net incomeAll per share data has been adjusted for the 5 percent common stock dividend declared on Jan. 22, 1991.

title: Crestmont Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and the year included an extraordinary loss of $ 1,504,000 on the penalty on prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: New World for Disabled Preschoolers
description: Joanne Ovalle was born with multiple defects, and medical specialists concluded she was unlikely to talk or walk normally. But with therapy, she has developed into a playful, assertive 3-year-old. Beatriz Alvarez, who has Down syndrome, was a listless, withdrawn toddler until a few months ago, but she now dances and joins games with other children.

title: Cambodia Ruler Shrugs As Plan for Peace Stalls
description: Wide anticipation of an imminent settlement of the Cambodian war now seems to have been premature.

title: Edward H. Gauer, 88; Owned Clothing Chain
description: Edward H. Gauer, a San Francisco clothier who founded the Roos/ Atkins chain, died of complications of emphysema on Tuesday at the Eisenhower Medical Center near Palm Desert. He was 88 years old.

title: Bank of Nashville reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Biospherics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
American Federal Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $ 556,000 gain from sale of loans and securities and a $ 315,000 loss from real estate acquired in the settlement of loans.c-Included $ 240,000 gain from property sale.The company attributed its significant increase in net income to the elimination of interest expense on $ 15 million of subordinated debentures when they were converted into non-interest-bearing preferred stock.

title: Razorbacks Capture Medley by a Whisker
description: The feature race today at the 97th Penn Relays was named the College Men's Distance Medley Relay Championship of America. And that grand name produced a grand race, with Eric Henry of Arkansas outleaning John Trautmann of Georgetown at the finish by a hundredth of a second, or about an inch.

title: Murdoch Gets a Generous Price
description: Publishing executives were abuzz yesterday over K-III Holdings' agreement to pay $650 million for nine of the News Corporation's publications, including New York magazine, Seventeen and The Racing Form. The general consensus is that K-III is paying a hefty, but not exorbitant, price when the future of advertising spending is uncertain.

title: Interchange Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Knight Estate Sells Stock
description: The estate of James L. Knight and the James L. Knight Trust have cut their holdings in Knight-Ridder Inc., the Miami-based media company, it was disclosed today.

title: Continental Savings of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Blues Hold Off North Stars
description: Dan Quinn had a goal and three assists and the St. Louis Blues smothered the Minnesota North Stars with a strong defense to win, 4-2, tonight and stave off elimination from the Norris Division final.

title: Federated Will Offer a Reorganization Plan
description: Fifteen months after entering bankruptcy, Federated Stores Inc. will ask a Federal judge on Monday to approve a reorganization plan that would offer cash and notes worth 100 cents on the dollar to the unsecured creditors of seven of its store groups, including Bloomingdale's, according to creditors and executives close to the company.

title: Dow Off 8.66; Loss for Week at 53.21
description: A depressing report on the state of the economy, although much as expected by Wall Street, brought the bond market down initially yesterday, and stocks followed.

title: A.B. Guthrie Jr. Is Dead at 90; Won Pulitzer for 'The Way West'
description: A. B. Guthrie Jr., a Kentucky journalist who turned to fiction and won a Pulitizer Prize as one of the century's leading Western historical novelists, died yesterday at his home at Choteau, Mont. He was 90 years old.

title: Safe Sex, Safe Contraception
description: Although Americans are increasingly outspoken about sex, they remain curiously uninformed about birth control. Some 10 percent of American women at risk of pregnancy use no method of contraception. They trust to luck alone -- and are responsible for over half this country's 3.5 million unplanned pregnancies.

title: Charter Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflected deduction of preferred stock dividend arrearages of $ 2,312,640 and $ 1,639,000 for latest and year-ago first quarters, respectively.

title: Why Isabella Qualifies for Sainthood
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: Constitution Bancorp of New England Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 270,000, or 8 cents a share, from the utilization of net operting loss carryforward.

title: Apollo Theater Wins Reprieve on Repayments
description: The landmark Apollo Theater, which was scheduled to close on June 1 because of severe financial problems, won some breathing room today when its state and private lenders declared a six-month moratorium on loan repayments.

title: Aetna Profit Declines 24%
description: Aetna Life and Casualty said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 24 percent from last year largely because of declines in commercial real estate.

title: Shell Reports 38.4% Decline in First-Quarter Earnings
description: The Shell Oil Company, citing weak natural gas prices and slumping sales for refined products in the United States, today reported a 38.4 percent drop in first-quarter earnings.

title: Beliefs
description: The title of the lecture was provocative: "The Soul of Man Under Secularism." Christopher Lasch, the distinguished historian from the University of Rochester, had taken it from an earlier provocateur, Oscar Wilde. A century ago, in February 1891, the British playwright and poet published a slim volume called "The Soul of Man Under Socialism."

title: Twin of World's Largest Telescope to Be Built
description: In a grant that will double the light-collecting power of the world's largest telescope, the W. M. Keck Foundation announced yesterday that it would pay $74.6 million to build a twin of the giant Keck telescope, which is nearing completion in Hawaii.

title: War Scars Holy Places of Iraqi Shiites
description: In the year 681 Hussein and Abbas, the sons of the Prophet Mohammed's son-in-law, Ali, met their end here in a battle that split Islam into rival Shiite and Sunni sects.

title: New England Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
L.S.U. Coach Confident O'Neal Will Stay
description: Louisiana State University Coach DALE BROWN said he was certain that SHAQUILLE O'NEAL, his 7-foot-1-inch sophomore center, would not only return to L.S.U. next season but would also be back for his senior year as well.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Friday and Saturday about the Federal job discrimination bill misstated the role of Robert C. Allen, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in negotiations between businesses and civil rights groups. Mr. Allen did not initiate the negotiations; they began in response to an invitation to the Business Roundtable from the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund.

title: Company Agrees to Drop 'Fresh' From Name of Its Orange Juice
description: In a victory for the Food and Drug Administration, the Procter & Gamble Company agreed today to change the name of a popular brand of orange juice. It will drop the word "fresh," which the agency had attacked as misleading.

title: N.B.A. Suspends Teagle
description: The Los Angeles Lakers will have to play Game 2 of their N.B.A. playoff series against Houston without sixth man TERRY TEAGLE.

title: Powell Urges U.S. to Be 'Vicious' In Closing Wasteful Military Bases
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the United States was wasting money on unnecessary military bases and that the Government must be "vicious" in closing installations.

title: Road Officials Say Little Is Done To Reduce Deadly Pileups in Fog
description: After a recent chain of deadly highway crashes involving scores of vehicles that crashed in blinding fog, safety agencies are groping for relief from one of the most terrifying dangers that can face a motorist.

title: Hometown Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
No Hearing on Rape Victim Law
description: A Circuit Court judge today turned down a request by the Palm Beach County prosecutor for a review of a Florida law that forbids public identification of rape victims.

title: Judge Says Trump Tower Builders Cheated Union on Pension Funds
description: They were Polish immigrants who suffered low wages and long hours, lived on junk food and sometimes slept at the work site -- all in the interest of meeting the deadline to build Trump Tower, the gilded centerpiece of Donald Trump's real-estate empire, which has all but disintegrated in recent months.

title: In Building Strike, 2 Sides, One With a Different Face
description: In 1979, the last time that New York City's building service workers went on strike, apartment dwellers and the people who opened their front doors and took out their garbage shared a common enemy: the landlord.

title: Boston College Faulted On Choice for Speaker
description: Bernard Cardinal Law, Archbishop of Boston, has criticized Boston College for allowing a prominent abortion rights advocate to speak at the Jesuit-run college.

title: InBancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Home Federal Savings Bank (Colo.) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: American President Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
description: b-Net loss

title: Mobil Increases Dividend by 7.5
description: The Mobil Corporation, which just reported a 78 percent increase in first-quarter net income, raised its quarterly shareholder payout by 7.5 cents, to 80 cents a share. The board voted for the 10 percent dividend increase. Allen E. Murray, company chairman, said the action reflected the company's strong earnings performance and optimism about future growth.

title: Study Confirms We Aren't Religiously Diverse
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Nation; A Fiery Parallel?
description: The oil-well fires that continue to burn in Kuwait threaten -- if they have not already produced -- an unprecedented environmental catastrophe. The plight of Kurds and Shiites who are fleeing Iraq is more dramatic; but the Kuwaiti fires just keep burning. They may burn for years.

title: Brahms and Nothing But
description: The Orchestra of St. Luke's is to present an all-Brahms program at Avery Fisher Hall at 8 P.M. on May 9. Roger Norrington, the group's music director, will lead the orchestra in the "Tragic" Overture and the Symphony No. 2. The program also offers the rarely heard cantata "Rinaldo," set to a text of Goethe. Jerry Hadley is to be the tenor soloist. Tickets are $14 to $28. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Corrections
description: A graph headed "Comparing Investments," appearing each Saturday on the Market Indicators page in Business Day, has shown an erroneous figure for the gold index weekly since March 30. A reader telephoned this week to point out the error. A corrected chart appears today on page 43.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Friday and Saturday about the Federal job discrimination bill misstated the role of Robert C. Allen, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in negotiations between businesses and civil rights groups. Mr. Allen did not initiate the negotiations; they began in response to an invitation to the Business Roundtable from the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund.

title: Recession Grew Worse in Quarter As Economy Shrank at 2.8% Rate
description: The economy contracted more rapidly in the first three months of the year than it did at the end of 1990, as national output recorded its first consecutive quarters of decline since the recession of 1981-82, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Study Confirms We Aren't Religiously Diverse; Mormon Polygamy
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Confirms We Aren't Religiously Diverse; Native Religions
description: To the Editor:

title: Baldor Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Baker Says Israel Fails to Provide Needed Responses
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that Israel had failed to give all the responses he needed to continue trying to put together an Arab-Israeli peace conference and that as a result he and President Bush would have to reappraise their next steps in Middle East peacemaking.

title: Literacy Day Sought to Publicize Cuts in Library Budgets; Orphan Branches
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Canada Dry Official Gets a Top Seven-Up Job
description: Francis I. Mullin 3d, whose 15-year rise through the beverage industry included the presidency of Canada Dry U.S.A. from 1982 to 1984, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Seven-Up Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the lawyers in the case paraphrased a comment about Mr. Smith imprecisely, and misattributed it. Although issued by David Roth, a lawyer for Ms. Bowman, it should have been attributed to her. The comment was: "Mr. Smith knows exactly what happened and that his lawyer's press release is 100 percent false. I have faith in God and believe in the American criminal justice system. Mr. Smith apparently believes in neither."

title: Manley Talks Dropped
description: DEXTER MANLEY, dropped by the Washington Redskins after failing three drug tests, was barred from making drug-prevention talks at two schools in Virginia because of fear that students might get the wrong message.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As chairman and chief executive of Bear Stearns & Companies, ALAN C. GREENBERG has often been expected to work magic. On Wednesday, at a dinner in his honor to be given by the Raoul Wallenberg Committee of the United States, he is to perform some real magic, tricks he refuses to divulge ahead of time.

title: I.B.M. Model to Be Sold by Mitsubishi
description: I.B.M. has agreed to allow the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation of Japan to sell an I.B.M. mainframe, the first time I.B.M. has allowed another computer company to resell one of its most powerful machines.

title: Seventeen's Success Invites Challenges
description: With its acquisition of Seventeen magazine, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company is gaining access to a huge and growing demographic market as well as one of the most profitable publications in Rupert Murdoch's portfolio.

title: Old National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1990 figures have been restated to reflect all mergers accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: INSIDE
description: Baker Criticizes Israel

title: Bridge
description: Around the world a handful of top-class players are also teachers, passing their wisdom to large groups and distributing detailed notes to the students when class is over. One of these, former world champion Eddie Kantar, sells collections of his notes to the public. The second of them, with in-depth coverage of 15 topics on bidding, play and defense, is available for $35, including postage, sent to him at P.O. Box 427, Venice, Calif. 90291. The price is $50 for both collections.

title: CFS Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Atlantic American Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: "We don't have a rational base structure now. We have Army bases that to some extent are residual of the Indian wars of the last century. We have Air Force bases which are to some extent residual of the early days of the cold war." -- Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. [ 10:1. ]

title: Lawmakers Leave Detroit With Vows to Help Auto Makers
description: Facing record losses, a raft of new regulations from Washington and increased competition from abroad, the American auto industry has spent two days wooing one of the largest delegations of members of Congress ever to descend on Detroit.

title: Gorbachev Warns Secessionists It Won't Be Easy
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev took a hard line on strikes and secession today as 50 million workers in the giant Russian federation staged brief walkouts or protests against poor living conditions and steep price increases.

title: Community Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Dance; Limon Troupe Salutes Its Artists and Its Past
description: The Limon Dance Company is celebrating itself through specific tributes to its dancers in its current two-week season at the Joyce Theater.

title: Archeologists in Arizona Discover 800-Year-Old Indian Catacombs
description: Archeologists said yesterday that they had made the first discovery of catacombs known to have been used by early Indians in the United States. The catacombs, used 800 years ago as tombs for the dead and chambers for sacred rites, could provide insights into the Indians' traditions and philosophy.

title: Fraudulent Third-Party Calls Reported
description: The Federal Communications Commission warns that people claiming to be F.C.C. inspectors or telephone company representatives are calling consumers and trying to get them to accept charges for long-distance calls.

title: Mid Maine Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Metro Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax loss of $ 351,000 for real estate writedown and a $ 110,000 gain for sale of stock.

title: If a College Bars Aid, Consider an Appeal
description: If at first you don't succeed, try, try again. Many families are doing that when the college their child chose rejects an application for aid because "your family's financial position should allow you to cover" the coming year.

title: Electronic Organizers Are Offering More for Less
description: Electronic organizers are no longer executive toys or status symbols. And the current crop is more versatile and less expensive than before.

title: Yankees Find a Way to Win in 11th Inning
description: A week ago, the Yankees would have found a way to lose this kind of game. But tonight, they found a way to survive it.

title: Barringer Laboratories reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 325,000.

title: CUNY Protest Appears Near End As Police Retake Bronx Campus
description: As the protest that has crippled much of the City University of New York appeared on the brink of collapse, 300 police officers streamed onto a Bronx campus before dawn yesterday and, without bloodshed, recaptured it from students who had chained doors shut for the last three weeks.

title: Moscow Journal; A Club for the Oppressed and Insecure: Millionaires
description: The founding of the Russian Club of Young Millionaires has been announced here only a brief limousine ride from Lenin's tomb. Young plutocrats need apply.

title: Frankford Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First National Pennsylvania reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Music in Review; Gustav Rivinius
description: 92d Street Y 1395 Lexington Avenue

title: NFS Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Commonwealth Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dime Savings Bank of New York reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 6,209,000, or 27 cents a share.

title: Bond Prices Lifted by Late Rise in Futures
description: A late rally lifted prices of long-term Treasury bonds yesterday, while the intermediate and shorter maturities remained narrowly mixed. Dealers attributed the late turnabout to an advance in prices of Treasury bond futures in Chicago in the last hour of trading there. The Chicago bond futures market closes at 3 P.M., Eastern time.

title: Bancorp New Jersey Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After non-recurring expenses of $ 94,000 associated with acquisitions.

title: Subpoena Jolts Black Mayors' Meeting
description: A gathering of the nation's black mayors was jolted Thursday night when most of the guests learned that their host, Mayor Michael R. White of Cleveland, had been summoned before a county grand jury investigating a real estate investment he made eight years ago.

title: Bank of Boston in Loss
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation reported that it lost $88.7 million in the first quarter but said it had reduced its troubled assets. The bank projected a loss at its annual meeting last month, but predicted it would fall significantly below the $187 million loss in the last quarter of 1990. In the first quarter of 1990, the bank had a profit of $43.6 million, or 56 cents a share.

title: Fidelity Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Natalie Donay, Advertising Executive, 63
description: Natalie Donay, an advertising and cosmetics executive, died on Sunday at her home in London. She was 63 years old.

title: Publishers Find Profit in Soaps
description: Soap Opera Digest and Soap Opera Weekly look to be two of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company's more valuable acquisitions in the magazine package. The publications expect to have 40 cents of cash flow, essentially profit, for every dollar of revenue this year, according to financial papers prepared for potential buyers. But will the magazines continue to prosper? Stay tuned.

title: Harrelson Off WFAN Show
description: Uncomfortable with the increasingly negative tone of the radio show he inherited when he became manager of the Mets, Bud Harrelson has decided to discontinue his pregame interview program on WFAN.

title: Delay for Hershiser
description: Nearly a year after undergoing reconstructive surgery on his right shoulder, OREL HERSHISER doesn't know when he'll be ready to return to pitching at the big league level.

title: Applied Biosystems reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Included first quarter $ 5 million charge for facilities relocation.c-Net income

title: Regents Clear a Doctor in Libby Zion's Death
description: The state Board of Regents today dropped negligence charges against the family doctor of Libby Zion, the teen-ager whose death in 1984 led to new limits on the hours doctors in training can work in hospitals.

title: Glacier Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Key Centurion Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Navy Wants to Buy and Upgrade To Fill Gap in Carrier-Based Jets
description: Seeking to bridge a gap in its aviation programs through the late 1990's, the Navy submitted to Congress today a plan to upgrade its current fleet of bombers and to buy more fighter jets.

title: Panel Promotes Aqueduct as a '94 World Cup Site
description: Under the pressure of a Wednesday deadline, two groups are intensifying their efforts to bring part of the 1994 World Cup to the New York area. But the practicality of both campaigns is open to question.

title: Study Confirms We Aren't Religiously Diverse; Unitarians and Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: Audio/Video Affiliates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 4,775,000 from an accounting adjustment. The company changed its method of accounting for sales of service contracts in accordance with FASB requirements.c-Included an extraordinary loss on early extinguishment of debt of $ 733,000 and a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 343,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Key Rates
Eastern Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cuomo Guessing Game Under Way on '92 Race
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo says he is much too busy worrying about New York's budget problems even to think about running for President. But sometimes, if he has a spare moment, he likes to talk to reporters and bat around ideas for the future.

title: Study Confirms We Aren't Religiously Diverse; United Church of Christ
description: To the Editor:

title: Philharmonic to Appear In Tillesfest '91
description: The New York Philharmonic is to appear in Tillesfest '91, a six-concert series to take place on three weekends from June 29 to July 14 at the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville.

title: Once Kurds Are Safe, U.S. Will Leave Iraq, Bush Says
description: Expressing doubt that Iraq can find a lasting peace among its ethnic and religious groups, President Bush said today that American troops would stay only "as long as it takes" to care for hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees.

title: It May be a Stretch, But Mets' New Mixture is Tempting
description: The new Met formula appears so simple when it works the way it did last night. With Vince Coleman's speed both saving and creating runs, and with Frank Viola overcoming early trouble to settle into a stifling pattern, eight singles and a double can go a long way. Last night at Shea Stadium the Mets -- did someone say Buddyball? -- stretched them far enough for a 2-0 victory over Pittsburgh.

title: Montana State Worker Strike Spreads as More Guard Troops Are Sent In
description: As a strike by state workers entered its second day today, employees at Montana's home for the mentally retarded and its mental hospital joined state troopers and thousands of others on picket lines.

title: A Plan to Undersell Sandoz on Drug for Schizophrenia
description: A small distributor plans to sell an extremely expensive drug treatment that could help thousands of psychotic patients for a price 30 percent below that set by the drug's maker.

title: Bill to Shield Rape Victims Is Dividing Iowa
description: An Op-Ed page article in The Des Moines Register urging rape victims to step out of the shadows of undeserved shame persuaded Nancy Ziegenmeyer to come forward last year and publicly tell her own harrowing story of sexual assault.

title: From Plandome, Children's Classic on Broadway
description: LIKE flowers that push their way through the earth year after year, Frances Hodgson Burnett's "Secret Garden" resurfaces time and again on Christmas book lists, in full-length feature movies and as television specials.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Lower Second Avenue Street Fair, Second Avenue will be closed today between Second and 14th Streets from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Public & Private; Off the Stroll
description: In New York City there is a street vendor called the Rubber Man. He works nights selling condoms to prostitutes on the West Side, and he is one of the few people who has reason to be unhappy about what Judge Gustin L. Reichbach did when he was working the lobster shift.

title: Jennifer Green to Marry Keith Brown
description: Mrs. Alan C. Green of Pelham, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Jennifer Lyle Green to Keith MacNeil Brown, a son of Anne Brown of Coxsackie, N.Y., and Ralph N. Brown of Slingerlands, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: A Family Turns to Grandpa for Day Care
description: CURTIS MESSINGER, who retired last summer as the executive director of a Manhattan law firm, was pondering his future.

title: School Choice, Without Harm
description: President Bush wholeheartedly supports "parental choice" as a way to improve America's public schools. In announcing his new education plan, he said that giving parents more flexibility to choose schools "will create the competitive climate that stimulates excellence in our private and parochial schools as well."

title: Thaddeus A. Shubsda, Bishop, 66
description: Bishop Thaddeus A. Shubsda of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Monterey, died of cancer on Friday. He was 66 years old.

title: Poet In Prose
description: A HOWARD NEMEROV READER

title: Campus Life: U.C., Irvine; Recruiters Tap Computer Talent On a Reservation
description: To increase American Indian enrollment at the University of California at Irvine, the Information and Computer Science Department last week bused in 16 students from Navajo Community College in Arizona, escorted them around campus and asked them to register for classes.

title: Managing; Gay Rights, Issue of the 90's
description: The Xerox Corporation has a new policy prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Style Makers column last Sunday about Myrna Hollinger, a designer of wearable art, rendered a word incorrectly in quoting her. . She said, "Detritus is what interests me"; she did not say "the tritest."

title: Steinbrenner vs. Ueberroth: You Make the Call
description: Contrary to George Steinbrenner's testimony in the Howard Spira extortion trial, Peter Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, has said that the Yankee owner never told him about Spira or that he was concerned about the possible gambling implications of Spira's association with Dave Winfield.

title: James Joyce's Zurich
description: DEVOTEES of James Joyce have long made pilgrimages to the cemetery on a hill overlooking Zurich and its lake where the writer, his wife Nora and their son Giorgio are buried. Fifty years after the Irish writer's death in 1941, the Swiss metropolis in which he found a refuge during the two World Wars will be visited by Joyceans from all over the globe.

title: Seurat Beckons to Many Worlds Beyond the Dot
description: Almost exactly 100 years ago, on March 29, 1891, a French artist called Georges Seurat died suddenly in his 32d year of an attack of malignant diphtheria. In barely 10 years he had earned for himself a unique position among the new generation of painters in Paris and was recognized by his peers, from Camille Pissarro to Vincent van Gogh, as the most original painter of his time.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
Bali
description: Bali has been luring travelers ever since the Dutch explorer Cornelis de Houtman made anchor here in 1597; the reception was so resplendent that several sailors jumped ship rather than leave the island. Other Westerners, too, have been charmed: Margaret Mead lived here in the 1930's studying the villagers of Batuan, Charlie Chaplin clowned around with mask dancers at about the same time, Mick Jagger jammed with local musicians in the late 70's and, last year, was married here by a Balinese Hindu priest, sparking a theological debate that continued long after the bride and groom had jetted back to New York.

title:
ART;
Abstract Work In Three Materials, Pushed to the Limit
description: LIKE nesting Chinese boxes, Bronxville is a small enclave in Westchester and Concordia College is a small enclave in Bronxville. And the art gallery at Concordia might be seen as another enclave, as it is on the basement floor of the library. An exhibition in this place could easily be ignored, so it is up to everyone concerned to try harder.

title: Small Airports
description: To the Editor: With great interest I read about the advantages of flying in and out of smaller airports (Practical Traveler, March 10). My husband, son and I recently flew to Southern California. We decided to leave from Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., and took a 7 A.M. American flight to Chicago. Since our final destination was Dana Point, we chose to land at John Wayne Airport in Santa Ana.

title: Laura Drabkin, Student, to Wed
description: Laura Drabkin, a medical student at Yale University, and Dr. David Marks, the chief resident in internal medicine at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital, plan to marry in May 1992.

title: Focus: Big Sur, Calif.; An Environmentally Correct Resort Hotel
description: THE start of construction on an upscale resort hotel, even one limited to 30 guest rooms, is a notable event in this coastal community 150 miles south of San Francisco, where no major commercial project has been built in 18 years.

title: Ancient Chinese Alchemy: Turning Bronze Into Art
description: Ancient Chinese bronzes, aglow with brilliant green patinas or polished to mirror brightness, are combined with less pristine vessels encrusted with mud or corrosion in a new exhibition at the China House Gallery, 125 East 65th Street. The unorthodox mix of the glorious and the gross can be seen in "Ancient Chinese Bronze Art: Casting the Precious Sacral Vessel," through June 15. The exhibition documents how bronzes were made between 2205 and 256 B.C. and how they are restored.

title: More Weary Than Tough, Pistons Succumb to Hawks
description: As they grew to power in the late 1980's, the Detroit Pistons were known as the Bad Boys, a nickname they wore like a macro-chip on a burly shoulder.

title: Juror Says the Perry Masons on the Panel Wouldn't Budge
description: As 12 days of deliberation went by for the jury judging Carolyn Warmus, camaraderie gave way to a week of frustration, tears and long, exasperated silences, jurors said today after the trial ended when they were unable to reach a verdict.

title: The New Case for Woman Power
description: Most of the women who work out with weights aren't doing it for their health. They prize the toned look, a quiet affirmation of their vigor and self-confidence. Pumping iron -- whether by wielding barbells or completing the circuit of weight machines at the health club -- accentuates their natural curves, tightens the soft stuff of their thighs, stomach and upper arms and allows them to fit into smaller clothes.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There are several sure-fire ways to learn about your neighbors in a cooperative or condominium building. The first is to attend a meeting on redecorating the lobby. The second is to become president of the board or a member of the house committee. The third is to volunteer for service during a strike.

title: The Nation; In Bush Presidency, The Regulators Ride Again
description: TEN years after President Reagan announced a systematic campaign to cut away the thicket of Federal regulation, the garden of Government is once again teeming with an abundant growth of new regulations.

title: Looking for Players
description: GENE KEADY, Purdue's basketball coach and the coach of the United States Pan American Games basketball team, was completing workouts this weekend in preparation for the selection of 15 to 20 players tomorrow who will advance to the July trials. A 12-member team will then be selected for the games in Havana in August.

title: Too Many Notes? Not When I Play Stuart Goldenberg
description: It is not often that I find myself ahead of modern science, looking encouragingly and perhaps a little patronizingly over a shoulder. That, however, was how I felt when I read that a Swiss geology professor and his son, a musician, had devised a way to condense music to its skeletal essence. Using a system based on fractal geometry, they discovered how to eliminate most of the notes in a Bach Invention while retaining its genetic code, so to speak. In my own modest way, I have been doing that to Bach works for years, but had felt guilty about it. Now I can think of a formerly distressing habit of leaving out notes as intuitive fractalism.

title: Tastes of Thai in Port Jefferson
description: THOSE Long Islanders who love Thai food and drool over the many Thai restaurants in Manhattan have a reason to rejoice. One of them has opened a branch on the Island. There are two Sawadee restaurants in Manhattan and now a third in Port Jefferson.

title: 'Truly, Madly' Favors Ghosts Without Gimmicks
description: Anthony Minghella's first film, "Truly, Madly, Deeply," features among its characters a ghost who returns to be with the grief-stricken woman he loved. But any similarities to "Ghost," insists the British writer-director, are merely coincidental.

title: Campus Life: Sarah Lawrence; From Bronxville To Your Universe It's . . . Mr. World!
description: Ken Markizon and his friends at Sarah Lawrence College sell T-shirts and write children's books about "Mr. World" so they can buy land in Latin America. They also stand watch at the campus dining hall to make sure students use only one napkin.

title: Congressman Assails Safety of 'Walk-In' Medicine
description: While offering hope for new forms of fast and economical medical service, the rapid growth of walk-in clinics and surgical centers is also providing "the last refuge for the medical buccaneer," a Congressman asserts in an opening statement prepared for a hearing on Monday.

title: A Lost Voice
description: THERE WAS SOMETHING OF HISTORY'S self-referential loops in seeing the smart bomb, through the electronic eye of a bomber, hitting the Iraqi-Mesopotamian ground with utter precision and esthetic distance. Imagine, then, Iraq as one of the cradles of writing, and imagine the smart bomb as the ultimate product of the literate human mind. And then imagine that smart bomb destroying the archaeological evidence of its birth some five millennia ago, completing the final, lethal loop: history's snake biting its own tail.

title: The Hogs Came With the Butcher
description: NATURE'S METROPOLIS

title: Strasbourg
description: To the Editor: Mr. Hern explained that the region of Alsace harbored one of the largest Jewish communities in Western Europe in the Middle Ages as a result of French religious toleration. The truth is, however, that most of the region of Alsace did not even come under French sovereignty until after the Treaty of Westphalia in 1648, and the city of Strasbourg itself was incorporated into France only in 1681.

title: The Ghost of Edwin Booth
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo; Jobless Issue Proves Puzzle to Democrats
description: For all the fragmentation of the Democrats over the last three decades, the one issue that has always pulled the party together is the one that created its coalition in the Great Depression: unemployment.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ESCAPES, by Joy Williams. (Vintage Contemporaries, $9.) In one of these stories, a man moves his vintage Thunderbird into his living room to keep it from rusting to death. Last year The Times's Michiko Kakutani said that Joy Williams "demonstrates an intuitive ability to delineate the complexities of an individual character in a few brief pages, a gift for finding those significant moments that reveal the somber verities lurking beneath the flash and clamor of daily life."

title: Miss Smith Weds John Mark Potter
description: Maureen Patricia Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Smith 3d of Washington, was married yesterday in Washington to John Mark Potter, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John F. Potter of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Lawrence J. Madden performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: This Week: Prune and Plant
description: Prune overgrown forsythia and other early-flowering shrubs as soon as they finish blooming.

title: The Executive Computer; Instant Mail, and Other Slick Tricks
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Lotus Development Corporation, two of the biggest companies in the computer business, have just combined to produce one of the smallest and most unusual portable computers.

title: Double Standard on Rose and Hall
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A Posting on April 21 about the Manhattan Brewing Company building incompletely identified the architect for its alteration. It was designed jointly by Harry Simino and Michael Just of Just Architecture in Brooklyn.

title: After 20 Months in Jail, Reputed Mobster Talks
description: Anthony Accetturo, a reputed crime figure who was cleared of Federal racketeering charges in 1988 only to be imprisoned the next year for refusing to talk to a state grand jury, has ended his silence in an attempt to win his freedom.

title: Residential Resales
