title: Chess
description: Luis Rentero has found a way to get fighting chess and keep draws down.

title: Italian Dishes Served in Country Decor
description: THOUGH it may sound like just another neighborhood Italian restaurant, from decor and waiting staff to the culinary feats of the kitchen, Bacci's is a class act.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: RODERICK G. CHRISTIE;
Defending a Yard Against Hungry Deer
description: FOR decades, the classic children's book and Disney movie "Bambi" insured deer a warm spot in the hearts of adults. But that good image has been tarnished in recent years, as hungry deer have moved out of the disappearing forests into backyards, spreading Lyme disease and eating bulbs and shrubs. One deer was reported earlier this month to have slipped into a butcher shop in Tarrytown.

title: HUNGARY RESISTING MOSCOW'S SHADOW
description: With two months to go before the last Soviet soldier leaves Hungary, the Hungarian Government is pressing for a new relationship with its giant neighbor that will be free of any lingering hint of Moscow's once-fast embrace.

title: Jennifer Tilghman Planning to Marry
description: September wedding plans for Jennifer Fox Tilghman and Peter Montague Cholnoky, a son of Mrs. Imre J. Cholnoky of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Cholnoky, have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Chew Tilghman Jr. of Lexington, Ky.

title: New Niantic Drawbridge Should Reduce Gridlock
description: MOST of the drivers who cross the Niantic River Bridge between East Lyme and Waterford have stories to tell about being caught in traffic on the span, the state's busiest drawbridge.

title: Taking a Cruise In the Lazy Land Of Blue Lagoon
description: ON Saturday around lunchtime, the sun came out, and suddenly everything sparkled. The sea glistened. Our white-and-blue ship, the Yasawa Princess, gleamed at anchor off the little island of Nanuya Lailai. For two days, with 46 passengers and a crew of 20, we had been cruising through the Yasawas, a group of 16 main volcanic islands and dozens of smaller, mostly uninhabited ones just northwest of Viti Levu, the main island of Fiji. With a few brief breaks, our weather had been -- well, we'd seen some weather. We'd been drenched, rocked, buffeted and forced to change schedule for one day of our four-day itinerary, forgoing the northernmost leg of our trip -- the part that would have taken us to Yasawa-I-Rara, which we'd heard described as the most spectacular beach in the South Pacific.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a picture on page 13 of the New Jersey Weekly today, showing members of the Carolyn Dorfman Dance Company, is printed upside down. The dancers were photographed lying on the stage.

title: Big Books, Tall Tales
description: MARK HELPRIN'S MOTHER, ELEANOR LYNN -- a Broadway leading lady in the late 30's -- was once sold into slave bondage. Or so her son says. Was she really? Probably not, since Helprin tends to make up stories even when he's talking about his own life. Filling out his first author's questionnaire in 1974, he wrote this about something that was supposed to have happened to him as a boy: "I was almost killed by a Pakistani immigrant to Jamaica, who in 1960 made it possible for me to receive 60 stitches in the head and legs (without any kind of anesthesia) administered over several hours by a Canadian psychiatrist using improvised equipment including a rag for me to bite. I was 13 at the time and consider that my bar mitzvah as I did not have a religious one." Did it happen that way? In a later version of the same story Helprin has changed the doctor's nationality, his specialty and the number of stitches he needed to close the wound.

title: Making a Difference; Modest Fireworks At Amoco
description: With drillers searching the world for crude oil and natural gas, and refiners battling by the hundreds for market share, global oil giants chart varying courses. Some routes paid off handsomely in the first quarter. The Exxon Corporation, for example, reported its best profits ever last week. For others, the results weren't nearly as spectacular. Consider Amoco Inc.

title: Headliners; Like, Why Not?
description: College campuses have long been grounds for experiments. Stuart T. Reges, a 32-year-old Stanford University lecturer, decided that included illegal drug use. Offended by the Federal Government's antidrug campaign, Mr. Reges sent a letter to the Office of National Drug Control Policy on March 28, criticizing provisions requiring universities receiving Federal money to take action against drugs. Mr. Reges, who teaches computer science at the School of Engeineering, wrote, "I am doing everything I can to make fools of you," including carrying drugs on campus and using school funds to buy alcohol for under-age students. Mr. Martinez, the agency's director, responded by writing Stanford's president, Donald Kennedy, warning that if the school did not enforce its anti-drug policies it risked losing Federal money. Mr. Kennedy, in turn, has ordered an investigation into whether Mr. Reges had violated university policy. And Mr. Reges, who has been placed on leave, said he is stunned.

title: For Proms, Short's the Word
description: The days of shopping for a prom dress in bridal or formal-wear shops are gone. Now those dresses are being bought in junior and after-five adult departments, where cocktail dresses are sold.

title: 2 Tar Heels Walking
description: Playing behind the best can be frustrating for the merely promising. That apparently is why CLIFFORD ROZIER and KENNY HARRIS, two young reserves on North Carolina's Final Four basketball team, have decided to leave North Carolina and seek colleges where their talents will be more in demand. In announcing their transfers Friday, neither identifed his new school, but wherever they go it will presumably be a basketball rung or two below North Carolina's level. Rozier, a 6-foot-10-inch freshman who had been hailed as another James Worthy, may have been praised too much too soon, according to COACH DEAN SMITH, who said, "Clifford had undue pressure placed on him." Harris, who played behind star point guard KING RICE, said he thought he could be more succesful "in another setting.". . . CHRIS MILLS, Arizona's highest scorer last season, said he had no intention of entering the National Basketball Association draft this year and wished people would stop speculation to the contrary. "I am going to return to Arizona for my junior year," he said. "I have always intended to return." Rumors that Mills might join the pros were stimulated by the decision of one of his teammates, junior BRIAN WILLIAMS, who announced recently that he would enter the N.B.A. draft. (AP)

title: Lead Hazards at Home
description: CHARITY AND THOMAS Tremblay began renovating their 10-room farmhouse in historic Concord, Mass., in 1985. They lived on the site, tackling the house room by room. When their daughter, Hawley, was born in January 1987, the Tremblays used plastic sheeting and tape to seal off the work area. Every day, they swept and vacuumed the debris from scraping and sanding old paint.

title: Carolyn Gilbert, a Teacher, Is Married
description: The marriage of Carolyn Hope Gilbert and S. Parker Gilbert Jr. took place yesterday at the Manursing Island Club in Rye, N.Y. Judge John Carey of Westchester County Court in White Plains officiated.

title: When the Corporate Lab Goes to Japan
description: Sadaaki Nanai says it took him a while to realize that research and development work in Rochester, N.Y., where Eastman Kodak Company has its headquarters, is very different from research and development in Yokohama, the Japanese industrial center where he opened Kodak's new research laboratory two years ago.

title: Crux of Debate by Group of 7: Interest Rates
description: The Finance Ministers and Central Bank presidents of the seven leading industrial nations, meeting here this weekend, are arguing over whether to reduce interest rates to prevent recession from spreading through the world. But woven into the discussion is another question that will shape their final decision: Does the world have enough savings for all its needs?

title: Laura Weisel Is Married
description: Laura Weisel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Weisel of New Hyde Park, L.I., was married in Williamstown, Mass., last night to David Krawitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Krawitz of New York. Cantor Sheila Cline, a justice of the peace in Needham, Mass., performed the civil ceremony in the Thompson Memorial Chapel at Williams College. Miss Weisel, who is 35 years old and keeping her name, is a consultant to Oxfam America, a Boston-based international relief agency. She graduated from Williams and received a master's in management from Yale University. Mr. Krawitz, 32, is an associate in the Boston architectural firm of Perry Dean Rogers & Partners. He graduated from Princeton University and received a master's in architecture from Harvard University. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Woman to Lead Annapolis Midshipmen
description: For the first time, a woman has been chosen the United States Naval Academy's brigade commander, the student leader of the military college's 4,300 midshipmen.

title: Campus Life: Bryn Mawr; Landmark Status Effort Seeks to Honor Pioneer
description: A legend familiar to every Bryn Mawr student surrounds one of the buildings at the heart of campus. M. Carey Thomas, the first dean and the second president of the college, is said to appear on moonlit nights and stroll in the cloister of the building that bears her name.

title: North's Fate: Concerns and Warnings From the Adversaries
description: John Alderdice

title: Malverne Congregation Gives Hempstead Poor a Helping Hand
description: THE living room is a bedroom for Debra Baldwin and her five, soon to be six, children. Instead of a sofa and chairs, two double beds are the only furniture one sees when entering the family's temporary quarters in Hempstead. Two more beds fill another tiny room.

title: About Men; Doing What Comes Naturally
description: LAST YEAR I BEGAN to play baseball again. It's nothing special, just weekend softball, loosely organized. We gather at a ball field used on weekday nights by serious players: young men who arrive in big-wheeled pickups and Jeeps with fancy roll bars. But on Sunday mornings it's ours. And there's something special about mornings in the summer: the air is so sweet and fresh in Vermont, with a diamond carpet of dew on the outfield grass and the sun low but rising steadily in the eastern sky above the Green Mountains.

title: Lisa Ammirati and John M. Curran Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ammirati of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ammirati, to John Matthew Curran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Curran of Convent Station, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title: Rangers Traded Scoring Talent
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: English Soccer Has Its Defenders
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MUSICAL FAREWELLS

title: A Touch of Lingerie in Outerwear
description: The road between designing lingerie and outer wear is not well traveled. But two designers have made the journey successfully this season. Josie Natori and Fernando Sanchez introduced attractive collections earlier this month, at the same time the fall ready-to-wear styles were presented in New York. Both incorporated lingerie sensibilities into clothes that can be worn outside the home.

title: Karen L. Yashar To Wed in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. James Yashar of Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen Lisa Yashar to Jeffrey Goldenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Goldenberg of Edina, Minn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Use of Libraries Goes Beyond Books
description: Thank you very much for the sympathetic article [ "The View From: New Rochelle Public Library," April 7 ] about the problems of public library service in Westchester County. There is one point that I hope you permit me to clarify concerning the comments attributed to me in the story.

title: Mr. Scully's Architecture Class Is Dismissed
description: Vincent Scully did not want to retire, but Yale University insisted, and so it was time for the last lecture of the class he started teaching in 1947. He was not expecting it to be all that different from the others until he arrived on Friday to see that the audience more or less constituted the course title: Modern Architecture.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DOC-IN-A-BOX By Robert A. Burton.Soho, $18.95.

title: Avoiding Scarring With Dye Lasers
description: You report that use of the dye laser to treat vascular blemishes and birthmarks is currently offered by two dermatologists on Long Island.

title: Headliners; Maximum Wage
description: For the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, 1990 was hardly a memorable year. Earnings increased 4 percent from the year before, but some 21 percent of the net came from selling off assets. At the same time, the compensation paid to the company's chief executive, Rand V. Araskog, was $11.4 million, a 103 percent increase over 1989. "I'll bet 75 percent of the S.& P. companies have performed better than I.T.T. in the last 10 years, yet Araskog's pay seems to be outpacing all of his peers," complained Dale M. Hanson, chief executive of the California Public Employees' Retirement System, which owns more than 1.15 million shares of I.T.T. stock. The association is threatening to vote against re-election of the company's directors at the annual meeting May 7. I.T.T. insists that Mr. Araskog is worth the money. "When Araskog took over this company 11 years ago, it was a mess," said James P. Gallagher, vice president of public relations.

description: COMPANIES Lockheed's Side Gets a Big Boost From the Air Force

description: PACIFIC RISING The Emergence of a New World Culture. By Simon Winchester. Maps. 496 pp. New York: Prentice Hall Press.

title: Katherine Traxler To Wed in August
description: August wedding plans for Katherine Anne Traxler and George William Abele, a son of John J. Abele of Baldwin, L.I., and the late Ruth Ann Abele, have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John J. Traxler of Palos Verdes Peninsula, Calif.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Washington;
Old Post Office Is Renovated
description: A MAJOR renovation and expansion is under way at the white granite Beaux Arts building near Union Station that once served as the city's main post office.

title: Maradona Tested Positive, Report Says
description: An Argentine news agency reported today that police tests on Diego Maradona were positive for cocaine use as the soccer star remained isolated in a jail cell.

title: Emily McLaughlin, Actress, 61
description: Emily McLaughlin, an actress who was a star in the television soap opera "General Hospital" for nearly three decades, died of cancer on Friday at her home here. She was 61 years old.

title: Woman Faces Death in Transient Slayings
description: A 69-year-old woman today was sentenced to death for helping her husband kill five transient farmhands as part of a bad-check scheme.

title: Screening the Tests That Detect Cancer
description: ROSE TAN KAUNG GOT HER first mammogram in 1984 at the age of 40, after doctors in the Philippines had diagnosed her 42-year-old sister with advanced breast cancer, which quickly killed her. That mammogram was normal.

title: Marietta B. Clark To Marry in June
description: David McKenzie Clark Jr. of Greensboro, N.C., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Marietta Brogdon Clark, to Richard Samuel Reynolds 4th, the son of Mr. Reynolds 3d and Sally Owen Reynolds, both of Richmond, Va. A June wedding is planned.

title: Big Haydn Cycle Is Reissued on CD
description: One of the most ambitious recording projects of the 1970's was London Records' complete cycle of Haydn's symphonies, the first release of all the works by a major company. The conductor was Antal Dorati; the orchestra was the Philharmonia Hungarica, a modern-instruments ensemble, which used the first modern edition of the symphonies, edited by H. C. Robbins Landon.

title: Strasbourg
description: To the Editor: A letter and comment in your Feb. 24 issue calls for further explanation.

title: Allison Friedman Is Wed
description: Allison Debra Friedman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Friedman of Latham, N.Y., was married last evening to J. Jeffrey Sullivan, son of Mrs. J. Jeffrey Sullivan of Walpole, Mass., and the late Mr. Sullivan. Rabbi Alvin Roth and the Rev. Eugene P. Sullivan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Union College Chapel in Schenectady, N.Y.

title: PARIS IS BURNING': Love Thrives, Thank You
description: To the Editor:

title:
TRACK AND FIELD;
Jamaican Streak in High School Relays Comes to an End
description: The Jamaica Express was finally derailed today in the high school events at the Penn Relays. After schools from the island of Jamaica had captured nine straight boys' championship relay titles over a three-year period in this meet, Henderson High School of West Chester, Pa., scored a narrow victory over Kingston College, a Jamaica high school, in the 1,600-meter relay.

title: Racial Quotas Are a Fact of Economic Life; An Assault on Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Carmine Coppola, 80; Wrote 'Godfather' II Score
description: Carmine Coppola, a conductor and Oscar-winning composer for his son's film "The Godfather Part II," died Friday morning at Northridge Hospital Medical Center in Northridge, Calif. He was 80 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Talks on Northern Ireland: Optimism Is Avoided
description: In churches throughout the north and south of Ireland on Sunday, Roman Catholics and Protestants will join in a special prayer that political talks about to start here will bring peace to the land, where 2,872 people have been killed in civil strife since 1969.

title: Diane Fusco Engaged to Peter McCann
description: Diane Elizabeth Fusco and Peter Christian McCann plan to marry in December.

title: Paging Dr. Faust
description: THE M.D.

title: Removing Troops and Equipment Isn't Easy Either
description: The effort to extract the more than 200,000 American troops that remain in the Persian Gulf is plotted each day at Gus Pagonis's "Bedouin tent."

title: THE SMURFETTE PRINCIPLE
description: Like Katha Pollitt, I had a 1950's childhood. But I have unfond memories of toys and children's books, movies and television shows that were designed to teach me the "right" values, 1950's style. So I can't share her enthusiasm for monitoring the entertainment of contemporary children for political correctness, 1990's style.

title: Carnegie Hall at 100: The Centennial Hits a Crescendo
description: Carnegie Hall, as everyone must know by now, is celebrating its 100th anniversary. A Centennial Festival will take place all week, culminating in gala afternoon and evening concerts on the actual anniversary, next Sunday.

title:
ART;
Focusing In on Super-Realism
description: LONG before the development of photography, artists were using devices like the camera obscura and the epidiascope to project images of objects and even whole scenes onto the canvas, to make composite pictures out of many details and to facilitate accurate reproduction and enlargement.

title: About Cars; Mercury Applies Conventional Wisdom
description: con-ven-tion-al adj. 1. having to do with a convention or assembly 2. of, sanctioned by, or growing out of custom or usage; customary

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Hartsdale
description: IN many ways, Hartsdale, a hamlet in the Westchester Town of Greenburgh, is a classic suburban community. It has streets of immaculately maintained one-family homes clustered in small, wooded neighborhoods.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Sibelius: Violin Concerto (original and final versions) Leonidas Kavakos, violin; Lahti Symphony conducted by Osmo Vanska. BIS 500; CD.

title: Don't Forget Dumplings
description: How much bird's nest soup can one man put away? If $6 million is enough to lure GEORGE FOREMAN back into the ring, the world may soon find out. According to Foreman's brother Ray, who is his manager, the former heavyweight champion and the ring's reigning trencherman has been guaranteed $6 million to fight any top-10 contender in a bout to be staged in China later this year. If the 42-year-old Foreman, who recently lasted 12 grueling rounds against the champion, EVANDER HOLYFIELD, says yes, it would be the first professional boxing match ever held in China. RAY FOREMAN said his brother was weighing the offer. (AP)

title: Take It Back for the Indians
description: THE CROWN OF COLUMBUS

title: Jack F. Marran Weds Theodora Morris
description: Theodora Winslow Morris, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Cortlandt Morris of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Jack Francis Marran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Marran of Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. Louis Padovano and the Rev. Patrick Frawley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Thomas More Church.

title: Postings: At Lincoln Center; A Fordham Dorm
description: Fordham University plans to proceed with a 20-story, 532-room dormitory on its Lincoln Center campus, despite the failure of a deal that would have helped subsidize the project. Groundbreaking for the dorm, at 155 West 60th Street, is scheduled for fall. The project will be financed by a $51.8 million bond issue by the New York State Dormitory Authority. The architects are Schuman Lichtenstein Claman & Efron of Manhattan.

title:
FORUM;
Behind the Choosing of the F-22
description: Many people were caught by surprise last week when the Air Force announced that the Lockheed-Boeing-General Dynamics team had won the contract to build its advanced technology fighter. After all, two of the three had not built a tactical fighter in decades.

title: ALMA MATERS COURT THEIR DAUGHTERS
description: I read with great interest Anne Matthews's article "Alma Maters Court Their Daughters" (April 7). She points out that alumnae volunteers are dedicated to making sure that an educational experience, which they themselves value, remains available to a diversity of worthy applicants. An example of this dedication is the Bryn Mawr Bookstore, in Cambridge, Mass., which is run by volunteers, some in their 70's and 80's. This enterprise might at first seem an offshoot of what Martha Taylor refers to as the bake-sale mentality. However, the store makes an annual contribution to the New England Regional Scholarship Fund, which is roughly equivalent to the income on an endowment of $1.7 million. ANNE STAINTON DANE Cambridge, Mass.

title: Protesting Students in Office Takeover at Vermont College
description: A student occupation of the president's office at the University of Vermont will enter its second bitter week on Monday with the two sides at an impasse and troublesome questions about ethnic diversity still unresolved.

title: Andrea L. Greene To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. David A. Greene of Smithtown, L.I., have made known June wedding plans for their daughter Andrea Leigh Greene and Dr. Michael Alan Goldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Goldman of Brooklyn.

title: Pamela Jean Berry Is Wed to John W. Pearson
description: Pamela Jean Berry, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Berry of New Vernon, N.J. and Washington, was married yesterday to John Wallace Pearson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bentley Pearson of West Hartford, Conn. Judge Michael B. Mukasey of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, performed the ceremony at the Morris County Golf Club in Convent Station, N.J.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Regaining a Shared Culture

title: Sports of The Times; The Mets' Three Managers
description: For all their glorious goofs, the Mets have never had three base runners on the same base. But suddenly they have three managers in the headlines on the same weekend.

title: Bridge
description: This is the season for world championship contenders, hoping to qualify from their zones and to play in Yokohama in October.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Low-Cost Loans to Improve 2 Communities
description: IN an effort to spruce up their housing stock, two communities have joined with local banks to offer home improvement loans at below market rates to all residents, especially those of low or moderate income.

title: Ozio Gets His First Major Title At Tournament of Champions
description: David Ozio of Vidor, Tex., won his first major Professional Bowlers Association title today, beating Amleto Moncelli in the Firestone Tournament of Champions.

title: Three-Run Homer by Clark Powers Red Sox by Royals, 6-4
description: Kevin Romine hit Dan Schatzeder's first pitch for a two-run, tie-breaking single in the sixth inning and Jack Clark added a three-run homer today as Boston held off Kansas City, 6-4.

title: Farewell to Southfork, Adios J. R.
description: Life without J. R.? Unthinkable.

title:
Northeast Notebook: York, Me.;
Trying to Keep A Lake Pristine
description: A TOWN'S attempt to clear its tax rolls of abandoned property and protect a pristine lake from development may create an unexpected windfall for some residents.

title: A Kase for Lerning How to Spell Rite
description: As an experienced high school English teacher and as a not-so-experienced parent of a second grader, I roll my eyes and grimace at the "invented spelling strategy" defended by Principal Nettie B. Webb [ "Defending Invented Spelling," April 14 ] .

title: Beauty; Weighing Anchors
description: Bobbie Battista, a morning anchor at the Cable News Network, gets a lot of letters -- what she calls "max mail" -- about her hair. "What do you call it?" her fans inquire of her spiky 'do. "How can I get it? Send us a picture of the back; we never get to see that ."

title: Program Notes Explain It All
description: To the Editor:

title: At Home on a Remote Island
description: CHIEF KINI, 73 years old, a gentle smily fellow, father of six, grandfather of 12, gestured for my husband, Mike, and me to remove our shoes, step inside and sit cross-legged on the mats. Of the dozen people in the hut reserved for the drinking of kava, a nonalcoholic but slightly inebriating drink made from the dried root of a pepper plant, he was the only one with his own cup, a half of a coconut shell, which he spun for fun. When the kava root -- a beardlike bunch, fat at one end, thinning to a point -- had been presented and accepted and mashed and strained into the carved wooden bowl, the communal cup was dipped and brought, one by one, to each of us.

title: Campus Life: Cornell; Hotel Students Provide Service To the Homeless
description: The Cornell University School of Hotel Administration has long been proud of educating future leaders of the hospitality industry. From budgeting and marketing to food preparation and restaurant management, students learn the essentials of a field that is often associated with good salaries and pleasant surroundings.

title: Protests Are All but Over at CUNY
description: The protests against tuition increases and budget cuts that have convulsed the 21-campus City University of New York all but unraveled yesterday.

title: Postings: For First-Timers; Home Loans
description: The drop in interest rates and a moderation of housing prices throughout the New York region has opened a window of opportunity for many people who wanted to buy a home during most of the 80's but could not afford one.

title: Visiting Health Officials Fear Outbreak of Cholera in Iraq
description: The United Nations and other relief agencies are reporting a substantial increase in cases of severe diarrhea, vomiting and dehydration among small children in Iraq, symptoms commonly associated with cholera.

title: Deborah Porter Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William P. Porter of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Diane Porter, to John East Apthorp Safford, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas H. Safford of Rockport, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: The World; The Dauntingly Expensive Task of Imposing Arms Control
description: THE incomplete inventory of weapons of mass destruction that Iraq delivered to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar earlier this month has opened a Pandora's box of problems for the United Nations, which must now set out to locate and destroy the weapons and find the money to do it.

title: Social Events
description: For Presbyterian Hospital

title: A Battered Coffey Must Stay Off Ice
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins will be continuing their pursuit of the Stanley Cup without their high-scoring defenseman, PAUL COFFEY. Coffey's doctors have told him his broken jaw will take at least three more weeks and as many as five to mend enough to allow him to return to the ice. "I don't know when I can play," Coffey said. "I don't want to sit out that long, but they put a plate in there and if I get hit and the plate gets drilled into the bone, then I'm really in trouble." Coffey, who was initially injured when he was hit by a puck in the first game of the Patrick Division finals against the Washington Capitals, suffered further damage two nights later when he was hit by an elbow. He had surgery on April 20. Coffey had come back from a serious injury, having missed two games of the Penguins' playoff series with the Devils because of a scratched cornea in his left eye. The Penguins open the Wales Conference finals on Wednesday in either Boston or Montreal. (AP)

title: Amy Stein Is Married
description: Amy Robin Stein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Stein of Lawrence, L.I., was married last night to Michael Lee Moskowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Moskowitz of Lauderhill, Fla. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony at the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Accord on a Cortlandt Development Suit?
description: EARLY next month, the Town of Cortlandt is expected to decide whether to accept a proposed settlement of a suit by a builder whose development rights were sharply reduced by an environmental zoning amendment two years ago.

title: Me Among the Protestants: A Bookish Boyhood
description: There were few books in our house when I was growing up, and reading for pleasure was not approved of. It was thought to be dangerous, like pure laughter. In the Ireland of the 1940's, when an insecure sectarian state was being guided by a philistine church, the stolidity of a long, empty, grave face was thought to be the height of decorum and profundity. "The devil always finds work for idle hands," was one of the warning catch phrases.

title: Coyote Company Revisits Homey Days of Radio
description: IN its ambling, rambling way, "The Voice of the Prairie" evokes an artless time when radio was a new diversion.

title: Corporate Teachers Enroll Schools
description: A PROGRAM in the Port Chester-Rye School District is exploring how corporations can help the public schools by offering administrators, teachers and parents the training in management techniques that companies provide their own employees.

title:
FORUM;
What Shareholders Really Want
description: Many companies push the theory that special-interest groups prod corporations on social, environmental and ethical issues, but that these concerns do not draw widespread support from shareholders in general. That's just not true.

title: Sidelined by Loneliness
description: He's a grown man now, relatively successful as a writer and capable enough in social settings. But if you ask him what he remembers most vividly about childhood, it is the sidelines: sitting on them while watching others at play. His parents moved around a lot, the writer says, "but even when we settled down and I had a bunch of friends, I still felt like a sideline-sitter. The image won't leave me."

title: Kathy Vergara Is Married
description: Mary Kathryn Vergara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Vergara of Westtown Pa., was married yesterday in Philadelphia to Thomas Nelson Cook Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cook of Houston. The Rev. Anthony W. Janton performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Cathedral Basilica of SS. Peter and Paul. Mrs. Cook, who is 34 years old and is known as Kathy, is a vice president at Oxford Shirtings in New York. She graduated from the Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science. Mr. Cook, 35, is a vice president at Kidder, Peabody & Company, the New York investment bank. He graduated from Bucknell University and received an M.B.A. degree from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Minority-Group District Likely in Suffolk
description: THE pencils, protractors and rulers have been dusted off in Albany for the redrawing of Congressional, State Senate and Assembly Districts on Long Island as the electoral map is redrawn to reflect population changes from the 1990 United States Census.

title: Yale Displays Illustrations of a Singular British Brotherhood
description: BEIGE walls lined with black-and-white prints and an atmosphere so quiet that pins hitting the carpet would sound like missiles: this is the third floor of Yale Center for British Art, where hangs the aptly named "Pocket Cathedrals." One of the center's low-light shows, it is billed as the first devoted to Pre-Raphaelite book illustration.

title: SANDINISTAS SEEK NEW ROLE TO PLAY
description: A year after going down to electoral defeat, the Sandinista Front is searching for identity in a world without a powerful Soviet Union to arm and defend it, and in a country without right-wing dictators to fight.

title: A Palestinian Plea
description: During nearly 40 days in in solitary confinement in an Israeli prison, I thought about where we Palestinians are as a people and where we are heading in the post-gulf war Middle East.

title: Seven Thought-Provoking Approaches to Surrealism Today
description: THE "Contemporary Surrealism" show at the New Jersey Center for the Visual Arts involves seven artists, and it comes with a straightforward catalogue setting the prophetic movement in context. This is the work of Joan Good, who, with Hanna Woicke, organized the production.

title: Towns Seek Power To Limit Hunting
description: MARTHA KIMBERLY was getting ready to decorate the Christmas tree in her beachfront house in Westport on a December morning in 1988 when her 30-foot-high living room windows were sprayed with shot. Two men who were duck hunting on the beach nearby had fired in the wrong direction, piercing the windows with 36 holes.

title: Tenant Violation
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Be Overzealous In Child-Abuse Cases
description: Social worker Lisa Katz, who coordinates the Westchester Task Force on Child Abuse and Neglect, says she'd "rather err by being a little too zealous" and removing children needlessly instead of leaving a child home where the child might die [ Looking Out for Other People's Children," March 31 ] . Unfortunately, the child-protective system Katz defends guarantees both.

title: Summertime, and the Prices Are Easy
description: WITH recession gripping the Northeastern states, clouds are hanging over the region's summer resorts.

title: Topics of The Times; Portraying the Artist
description: Controversy about Albert Bierstadt's talent as an artist is alive and well displayed in the Brooklyn Museum's current blockbuster show of his blockbuster landscapes. Bierstadt is famous for giant panoramas of the American West, primarily from the 1860's, when most Americans didn't know what was out there.

title: In Hong Kong, Antique Silks Evoke a Patrician Past
description: ANTIQUE Chinese textiles are enjoying a great new popularity. One reason is that even casual shoppers quickly become intrigued with these highly personal bits of history -- imagining the aristocratic Chinese woman who slipped her bound foot into a tiny pair of four-inch silk shoes, or picturing the pampered Chinese boy who wore embroidered silk earmuffs, each one sliding over an ear like a glove on a hand.

title: Making a Difference; The NCR Deal and an Empty S.E.C. Chair
description: If the American Telephone and Telegraph Company sells the NCR Corporation on its proposed takeover this week, as many expect, the deal will still have to clear the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Mutual Funds; What's in the Convertible Balance
description: Convertible securities funds promise investors the best of two worlds: higher income than stock funds and more potential for appreciation than bond funds. The 31 funds in the class, with assets of roughly $2 billion, invest mainly in bonds that can be exchanged for a set number of shares of common stock at a fixed price.

title: Talking: Insurance; Meeting Mortgage Payments
description: A TERRIFYING prospect for any homeowner with a large monthly mortgage payment is a long period of unemployment. The rise in foreclosures over the last year is a direct reflection of how easily such a calamity can occur during a recession.

title: Jane Brown to Marry Lee Summers
description: The engagement of Jane Wootton Brown, the daughter of Jane Wootton Walker and Archibald McDowell Brown Sr., both of Virginia Beach, Va., to Francis Lee Summers 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Lee Summers Jr. of Staunton, Va., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. An August wedding is planned.

title: Opera House Revival Is Work in Progress
description: IN 1958, a determined group in East Haddam mounted a campaign to rescue a dilapidated opera house that was slated for demolition. They succeeded, and the building became the Goodspeed Opera House, nationally renowned for its efforts to preserve the American musical.

title: Finvola Drury Is Dead; AIDS Scientist Was 41
description: Finvola Drury, who helped create and conduct research that led to a treatment for immune deficency in AIDS patients, was found dead on Thursday evening at the home of a friend in Brooklyn. She was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 'Illiberal Education'
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Tries to Ease the Way to Develop Two County Sites
description: STUNG by claims that major corporations are not moving to Nassau County because of government red tape, county officials want to ease the way for development of two parcels of land that the county owns in Plainview and East Meadow.

title: Atlantic City Mayor Plans to Stop Many Services
description: Mayor James Whelan of Atlantic City plans to shut down all but non-emergency city services starting tomorrow -- indefinitely furloughing about a third of his city's 1,700 civil servants -- because of the City Council's refusal to make a routine budget appropriation.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last week with the Architecture View column misidentified the exterior of a Manhattan building. It was the Western Union building, not the New York Telephone Company offices.

title: Racial Quotas Are a Fact of Economic Life
description: To the Editor:

title: 28 Are Killed by Tornadoes Sweeping Though 7 States
description: Like blows from a scythe, more than 70 tornadoes slashed through seven states on Friday night, killing at least 28 people, including 18 or more in this small town on the Kansas prairie.

title: Students Who Saddle Up Don't Drop Out
description: ANGEL GARCIA, wearing jeans and sneakers, was trotting on a chestnut horse in the white-walled ring at Yale University, looking self-assured. He brought the horse to a stop in mid-ring to consider the question of why he liked riding.

title: Iran's Leader Asks for More Aid to Sustain Kurds
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran arrived here today and appealed for more foreign aid to help his country look after Iraqi refugees.

title: Texas Governor Is Elusive on Taxes
description: One hundred days after becoming Governor of Texas, Ann Richards still seems to be campaigning for the job, except now she looks as if she is having fun.

title: Panel Clears Doctor of Negligence in Sudden Death of a Girl in '84
description: Negligence charges against Libby Zion's doctor, who did not go to the hospital on the night the 18-year-old died in 1984, were dropped Friday by the New York State Board of Regents.

title: U.S. COMPANIES ARE NOT ALLOWED TO OFFER TOURS
description: Ever since a Connecticut travel agency was penalized more than $75,000 in 1989 for promoting trips to Vietnam, a violation of United States Treasury Department law, American tour operators and veterans organizations have been loath to challenge the regulation.

title: Political Talk
description: Miller Defense Fund

title: Data Update
'Kane' at 50 Dazzles Yet with Its High Spirits
description: The ads described it as "The love story that 'dared not be made.' " Louella Parsons thought it trash. John O'Hara wrote that it was the best film he had ever seen. William Randolph Hearst tried to have it destroyed. D. W. Griffith admired it, particularly, he said, for the ideas that had been taken from him.

title: Mayflies Bring Joy to Trout Fisherman
description: If people died the way mayflies do, we'd probably leave this world less protestingly. Until its last day of life, the immature mayfly clings to a rock at the bottom of a trout stream. On that last day, something wonderful happens. The mayfly nymph hatches out of its lobsterlike skin, sprouts beautiful diaphanous wings, takes to the air on a lovely spring afternoon, finds a mate, copulates for the first and only time, lays its eggs and drops dead, tired but satisfied.

title: A Wanderer Among Words
description: THE USES OF ERROR By Frank Kermode. 432 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press.

title: Squeeze Play; Hussein's Ouster Is U.S. Goal, But at What Cost to the Iraqis?
description: THE United States intelligence community this month completed its first full assessment of war damage in Iraq, and the numbers were sobering: $30 billion to rebuild the infrastructure of roads, bridges, power plants and oil installations; five years to repair the electrical grid; months to get water purification plants working; shortages of chlorine and grain, depleted livestock and acute shortages of medicine.

title: Campus Life: Temple; Mentors Teaching Newer Teachers How to Succeed
description: Many newly minted college professors embark on their first teaching assignments with little emotional or intellectual support in the classroom, the department or the institution itself. "Before you become a full-fledged academic, you're forced all of a sudden to deal with a bureaucratic, paternalistic body," said Chris Concolino, an assistant professor of Italian at Temple University.

title: Design; Artful Constructs
description: She learned to say good morning in four languages, to manage a demolition crew of six and to understand the vagaries of plumbing lines. Indeed, Renee Graubart, a Manhattan artist, chose to be her own contractor, a job she knew required plenty of nerve. "All my friends thought I was crazy," Graubart says. "But I had the time and energy to do it."

title: OLD FEUDS TANGLE NEW CITY COUNCIL AS DEADLINE NEARS
description: The commission charged with redistricting the New York City Council is ensnared in a tangle of racial and party politics just three days before it is to present its vision for a legislature that would represent the city's sweeping ethnic diversity.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. IRVIN GLASSMAN;
In Search of a Replacement for Gasoline
description: DR. IRVIN GLASSMAN tinkered with a laminated medal on his desk the other day as he talked about alternative fuels and substitutes for gasoline. The scene was Princeton University's School of Engineering and Applied Science, where Dr. Glassman is the Robert H. Goddard Professor of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ducts from our hot-air furnace pass through the cold basement, and so the longest duct, which goes to the back bedroom, loses a lot of heat on the way and the air is just warm by the time it gets there. I am thinking of wrapping the basement ducts with insulation. What is your opinion?

title:
The World;
It's Hard to be Hopeful About Northern Ireland's Peace Talks
description: THREE things excited particular interest in Belfast in recent weeks. Northern Ireland's political parties, after six years of frigid silence, agreed to round-table talks; violent republican and loyalist groups committed some particularly ferocious murders; and Roscoffs, the city's best restaurant, won a Michelin star.

title: Sunday Dinner; A Global Tour of Tastes
description: In New York City, a turn on a street corner can transport one to another country. This is especially true with restaurants. Here are three dining spots -- one French, one Italian, one Mexican -- in three disparate neighborhoods. Les Halles

title: David Spiewak to Wed Elyse Salman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Salman of Marlboro, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elyse Debra Salman to David Jay Spiewak, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Spiewak of Great Neck, L.I. An October wedding is planned.

title: Seagal Packs More Than a Wallop
description: We may as well face the fact that our reigning action-movie star is a guy with a scowl, a ponytail and an attitude he himself has referred to (while in character, of course) as a "superior state of mind." We should also acknowledge that Steven Seagal, whose first three films have had worldwide box-office and video receipts totaling more than $200 million, and whose new "Out for Justice" was the nation's top-grossing film last week, is someone to be reckoned with.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: New home sales * Spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank * International Business Machines annual shareholders meeting * Office of Thrift Supervision begins hearings in the Charles Keating savings and loan fraud case. TUESDAY: Employment Cost Index * Ford Motor releases its first-quarter earnings * General Motors subsidiaries may report first-quarter earnings.

title: Aquarius Redux
description: Described in retrospect by one of its originators, J. M. Jamil Brownson, as located "somewhere between Marshall McLuhan and MTV," The San Francisco Oracle -- published 12 times between September 1966 and February 1968 -- was a spectacular emblem of the dream decade. But this wild tabloid of poetry, protest, mystical speculation and visionary tracts, decked out in psychedelic graphic art in neon colors, was printed on ordinary newsprint; the few copies of originals that survive are more fragile than butterfly wings and as costly as rubies. Now Allen Cohen, an editor of The Oracle, and a group of ingenious printers have brought out THE SAN FRANCISCO ORACLE FACSIMILE EDITION (Regent Press, 6020-A Adeline, Oakland, Calif. 94608, $175), a large-format reproduction of the entire run of the paper, bound in a sturdy volume. This is an admirable feat. The fantastic graphics of The Oracle, many wrapped around pages or double spreads of text, were mostly printed in black and white, but many glowed in deep reds, fuchsias, blues, oranges and yellows produced in a printing process now extinct. Regent Press has brought them back to life through what must have been maddeningly laborious handwork on the press; here indeed is the old Oracle in all its Oriental opulence. Open any page and you are back on the streets of Haight-Ashbury in a time when that tiny urban spot was the Olympus of the newborn world. The prophets were young then: Gary Snyder, Alan Watts, Timothy Leary, Allen Ginsberg, Lew Welch -- whole ranks of them are here proclaiming their new testaments under hypnotic graphic banners created by Hetti McGee, Rick and Ida Griffin, Bob Branaman and many more, some nameless but still unforgettable. In the politically treacherous and drugged chaos that was Haight-Ashbury, it is no wonder The Oracle dropped dead young; it seems a miracle that it lived even a short time. It's good to have it back.

title: Fiber, Baskets and Paintings: The Whole House Is a Gallery
description: NO signs outside the gray and white farmhouse in Wilton indicate that the contemporary "art in use" inside are the stock in trade of the Brown Grotta Gallery within. Nor is there any sign on the garage to announce that it is a studio housing an advertising agency run by Tom Grotta, a photographer and designer.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 31 about a documentary film, "The Comedian Harmonists," included reversed identifications provided by a publicity agent for two members of the singing group. The man at the far right was Ari Leschnikoff; the second man from the right was Harry Frommermann.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Rocket Misfires at Penn; Lewis's Team Falters, Then Has Comeback
description: The college relays, which are what the Penn Relays are all about, were great.

title: Giants' Rookie Welcomes Old Role
description: As transitions go, this one could be relatively easy for Jarrod Bunch, the Giants' first-round draft pick.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: The Kentucky Headhunters: 'Electric Barnyard' Mercury 848054; cassette and CD.

title: Wall Street; The Dow Looks Even Mightier From Abroad
description: A Dow at 3,000? To Americans who think in dollar terms, that was an extraordinary event. But the strength of the dollar has meant that to foreign investors, American stocks have zoomed much further.

title: Japan Is Not a Closed Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiji's Easygoing Ways
description: THE sign atop the roadside bus shelter, miles from anything else, told me this was the place to turn off Queens Road for the Man Friday Resort. It was a dirt road, more than two miles long, uphill and down, gouged by recent storms. But the views of Fiji's turquoise sea and green hills were glorious, my rented four-wheel drive forged ahead, and at the end was a marvelous reward: a horseshoe of bures -- traditional bamboo-walled, thatch-roofed sleeping houses -- against a hillside, with a sweep of lawn and tropical flora from their doorways to the South Pacific. And one more thing, befitting the name of the place: a small swimming pool shaped like a footprint.

title: Rollin Tyson Gilbreath Marries David Tod 2d
description: Rollin Tyson Gilbreath, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Syndor Gilbreath 3d of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to David Tod 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tod of Youngstown, Ohio. The Rev. Roland Jones performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Mark's Church.

title: Salad Days
description: WHEN IT'S TOO HOT TO cook, it's usually too hot for hot food, anyway. A salad can be an inspired solution for the cook who's running out of steam. Not just any salad, though. Lettuce and lemon juice with a few slivers of carrot for color is fine for dedicated dieters. But most people want a main-course salad for dinner that is low in fat and has a significant amount of protein as well as enough substance to keep them going till breakfast.

title: Celebrations: Ballet, Sports And the Camera
description: A dinner at the Metropolitan Opera House Monday opened the American Ballet Theater's spring season and its new production of "Coppelia." The guest of honor was Oliver Smith, the ballet's longtime co-director.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: IS IT SEXUAL HARASSMENT YET? By Cris Mazza.Fiction Collective Two/Illinois State University, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95.

title: In Patchogue, a Push To Revive Two Lakes
description: IN a tale of two lakes, two citizens' groups have joined forces to revive once popular recreation spots that have fallen prey to the byproducts of years of rapid development and more recent road reconstruction in the Patchogue area.

title: INSIDE GITMO
description: Your article on Gitmo brought back memories. I was stationed there for 18 months during World War II. What do I remember? Iguanas and land crabs running through my tent. Dances at the Officers' Club. Horse and mule patrols around the base. Waiting for mail call. Learning Spanish from Cuban officers. Enjoying a visit from Desi Arnaz.

title: Headliners; Funny Face
description: When Audrey Hepburn came to New York City last week as the honored guest of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, she found herself awash in the accolades and admiration of Hollywood peers and lesser mortals alike. Miss Hepburn, the prototypical sloe-eyed gamine in many romantic comedies of the 1950's and 1960's, had said her career "sort of happened," without ambition or plan. It ended in 1966 when she decided to raise two sons. After her children were grown, she became a special ambassador for Unicef in 1988, visiting and raising funds for children in developing countries. The Film Society tribute included testimonials along with 18 excerpts from such films as "Funny Face," "Breakfast at Tiffany's" and "Charade." BIlly Wilder, who directed her in "Love in the Afternoon," recalled that "Everybody on the set was in love with her within five minutes." Taking the stage at the end of the evening, Miss Hepburn said that she was amazed that she -- a "skinny broad" -- had been turned into a "marketable commodity."

title: Soft Spot for Serial Murder
description: The record jacket, showing a girl who'd just been raped, carried the caption "Guns and Roses were here." Last year, thousands of teen-aged girls paid good money to bring this heavy metal album into their homes.

title: Alisa K. Miller Weds Todd Martin Vallely
description: Alisa Krystyn Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Miller Jr. of Verbank, N.Y., was married last evening in New York to Todd Martin Vallely, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred F. Vallely Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. William Bergen performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title:
FORUM;
Beware the Bankruptcy Judges
description: Pro-debtor bankruptcy judges are violating creditor contracts and the spirit of the bankruptcy code as they award to shareholders, management and labor the resources that rightfully belong to creditors.

title: Travel Advisory; Busy Budapest
description: Budapest expects a busy summer for tourism. Reservations dropped off during the Persian Gulf war, but hotel and tourism officials say that they are optimistic that normalcy -- being completely booked -- will return over the summer season. At Ibusz, the Hungarian national travel bureau, a staff member who deals with finding accommodations for individual travelers said, "The city should be just as full this summer as last." She pointed out that Pope John Paul II is to visit Budapest in August, an event that is expected to produce crowds that will overtax the city's tourism facilities.

title: French
description: To the Editor: David Finkle complains about the habit of the French to reply in English to French spoken to them by Americans ("Plus Ca Change, More She Is The Same," Travel, March 31). To someone who invests a certain measure of vulnerable pride in his ability to speak the vaunted language of Proust and Balzac, this can be extremely irritating.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bohemia 171,500 16 Brooktree Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; dining room, den, basement; taxes $5,400. Kings Park 170,000 25 Saber Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; dining room, partial basement, attached 2-car garage, cul-de-sac; taxes $6,000. Massapequa 216,000 12 Ensign Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $5,400. Seaford 165,000 3722 Somerset Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, solarium, on canal; taxes $1,900. Setauket 185,000 18 Buccaneer Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old Cape Cod; den, family room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace; taxes $5,000. Williston Park 165,000 232 Broad Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; finished attic, 1-car garage, 40- by 100-foot lot; taxes $2,100. OTHER AREAS Peekskill, N.Y. 245,000 15 Gallows Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 4-year-old contemporary; fireplace, deck, eat-in kitchen, loft w/skylights, family room, patio, den, 1 acre; taxes $5,170. Chester, Conn. 147,000 Brooks Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new Cape Cod; w/w carpeting, dining room, close to school, 1.3 acres; taxes not yet available. Ramsey, N.J. 210,000 247 Momar Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial; h/w floors, full basement; taxes $4,319.

title: Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia; Penn Square, After the Fire
description: ALMOST an entire city block remains in limbo two months after a fire raged through a high-rise office building in the city's center. Since the fire, four streets have been blocked off to traffic, disrupting businesses. One, Chestnut Street, reopened last Wednesday.

title: August Wedding For Jenny Dixon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Dixon of Stonington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Hoadley Dixon to John Rowan Boone, a son of Mrs. Rowan Boone of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mr. Boone. An August wedding is planned.

title: Cowboys Prove Swift With a Pen
description: The eyes of the National Football League will be upon Dallas next season.

title: Heidi Broecking, Designer, Is Wed
description: Heidi Charlotte Broecking, the daughter of Mrs. Anderson Broecking of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday at St. Luke's Parish there to Frederick Irving Sklenar, the son of Mrs. Edmund Mullin of Grymes Hill, Staten Island, and Frederick J. Sklenar of Westerly, Staten Island. The Rev. Frederick T. Bender, an Episcopal minister, officiated.

title: Bonnie Jane Ketcham Wed to Andrew J. Doll
description: Bonnie Jane Ketcham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Ketcham of Sanibel Island, Fla., was married in Stratford, Conn., yesterday to Andrew Joseph Doll, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Doll of Bossier City, La. Msgr. John E. Gilmartin performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of Peace Church.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph that appeared on April 7 with an article about biking on the TransAmerica trail was printed in error. The photo showed a sign reading "Maryland Welcomes You"; the trail runs from Astoria, Ore., to Yorktown, Va., and does not go into Maryland. The author took the photograph on a separate trip.

title: Sharon Twersky Is Married
description: Sharon Deborah Twersky, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joshua Twersky of Easton, Conn., was married last evening at Temple Beth-El in Fairfield, Conn., to Keith Paul Savel, a son of Sheila Savel of College Point, Queens, and the late Norman Savel. Rabbi Leon Waldman officiated.

title: Washington
description: To the Editor: I want to alert your readers to the fact that the National Museum of American Art is also in the building containing the National Portrait Gallery ("In Washington, Capital Fun for Children," Travel, March 17). Indeed, the official name of the building is American Art/Portrait Gallery Building. MARGERY BYERS Washington The writer is chief of the office of public affairs of the National Museum of American Art.

title: Love-Triangle Case Ends in Hung Jury
description: The trial of Carolyn Warmus ended today after the jury said it had been deadlocked for more than a week over whether the 27-year-old schoolteacher had murdered her lover's wife.

title: Topics of The Times; Time Will Tell
description: Something is driving over-the-hill athletes over the cliff this spring. Jim Palmer. Mark Spitz. George Foreman. Bjorn Borg. All four were genuine superstars in recent and not-so-recent years -- on the mound, in the pool, in the ring and on the court. All are well past their peak. Indeed, all had retired from active competition. But all four have tried to come back recently, for various reasons. None has succeeded.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "We really don't know what our mission is. The colonel at regiment said we are here to hold a dagger at Saddam Hussein's throat. I think we're holding a volleyball at Saddam Hussein's throat." -- Major Joe Galdis of the Marine Reserves, at Hill 99 in the Kuwaiti desert. [ 1:2. ]

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-17

title: A Changing Neighbor Across the Hudson
description: "IT'S not the city and it's not the country," Craig Firestone said of Rockland County last week. It was 19 years ago that he moved with his parents from Mount Vernon, a Westchester city on the Bronx border, but he still finds Rockland "a good, centrally located spot."

title: Miss von Gal Wed To M.P. Donahue
description: Martha Reed von Gal, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert von Gal of Stamford, Conn. was married yesterday to Michael Phillip Donahue, a son of Phillip John Donahue of New York and Margaret Mary Cooney of Albuquerque, N.M. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn,

title: The Judges Made Good Nazis
description: HITLER'S JUSTICE

title: M. A. Lainoff Weds Kathryn Kincaid
description: Kathryn Burke Kincaid, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Kincaid of Tulsa, Okla., was married last evening at her parents' home to Michael Adam Lainoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Lainoff of Brooklyn. The Rev. Art McGrew, a Methodist minister, and Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A FINALE FOR RICHARDS

title: Shelly Schaenen Weds Craig Vogt
description: Shelly Ann Schaenen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Schaenen Jr. of Madison, N.J., was married in San Francisco yesterday to Craig Nims Vogt, the son of Charlotte E. Divall of Austin, Tex., and the late Lieut. Col. William J. Vogt. The Rev. Charles McLain, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Flood Mansion.

title: Kindergartens Smooth the Way and Soothe the Parents
description: ON an unseasonably warm and sunny April afternoon, the kindergarten wing of the Byram Hills Wampus Elementary School here quietly hummed with the sounds of small children engrossed in school activities.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Henderson, Back in Lineup, Fails to Get to First Base
description: Rickey Henderson got back into action today after missing 13 games with a leg injury, but he remained one stolen base short of Lou Brock's major league record of 938 steals.

title: Grounded: When Your Flight Is Canceled
description: FOR exasperation at the airport, nothing beats the cancellation of your flight. Whether the news pops up on the computer screen, is announced from the check-in desk or merely seeps out like a bad rumor, it induces a combination of fury and despair. How will we get where we are going? When will we get there? Does someone else fly there? Who? How far away is the counter? Can our ticket be endorsed over to another line? Why did the airline do this?

title: 'Illiberal Education'
description: To the Editor:

title: Network Helps With Genetic Syndrome
description: The welcome article on Prader-Willi Syndrome [ "Combating a Rare Genetic Disorder" April 7 ] neglected to mention that, aside from seeking sources of medical help, there are other places to which parents of people with Prader-Willi Syndrome can turn for aid in coping with this rare genetic disorder.

title: Centerport Fights Developer of Mill Pond
description: AT the 38-acre Mill Pond in Centerport, at least 10 species of birds, including herons, canvasbacks, buffleheads, mallards and Canada geese, float and fly about, preparing to migrate. A dabbling duck, tail to the sky, scavenges the bottom of the tidal pond for vegetation, worms and crustaceans.

title: Send Out for More Scarlet Letters
description: THE STRANGE DEATH OF MISTRESS COFFIN

title: Making a Difference; Taking Apart the Empire Donald Built
description: Stephen F. Bollenbach has spent much of his career untangling the financial problems of famous men.

title: Ideas & Trends; Discovered, at Edge of Known Civilization, the Sub-Suburb
description: ABOUT an hour's drive south of downtown Denver, the suburban glass office towers along Interstate 25 finally give way to green pastures, naked hillsides and a distant view of Pike's Peak. The local cattle, stretched out comfortably in fields along the road, mark time by watching the passing automobiles. From these peaceful acres, the noisy metropolis seems a world away.

title: Mutual Funds; Closed-End Munis Lure the Tax-Shy
description: Investors who had high income tax bills this month are prime candidates for closed-end municipal bond funds.

title: Murk of Politics Obscures Baker's Path to Peace in the Middle East
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d briefly interrupted his Middle East diplomacy last week to meet with the Soviet Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh in the Caucasus Mountains. Before their talks, Mr. Baker toured the area, and while standing on a hill, with the giant Mount Elbrus hidden in fog in the distance, he was asked whether from this perch he could see his way to peace in the Middle East.

title: Bird Is Out of Traction But Not Rid of the Pain
description: He may be an ailing 34-year-old, but Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics is still capable of doing what no one else has done on the basketball court.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Washington; Old Post Office Is Renovated
description: A MAJOR renovation and expansion is under way at the white granite Beaux Arts building near Union Station that once served as the city's main post office.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 31 about low-income housing in Philadelphia misidentified the site of the Enterprise Foundation's headquarters. In a letter dated April 11, Mark Sissman, president of the Enterprise Social Investment Corporation, a subsidiary of the foundation, said that both the foundation and the subsidiary were based in Columbia, Md.

title: ALMA MATERS COURT THEIR DAUGHTERS
description: I find our educational institutions to be the last male bastions. At graduation every June, the platforms are filled with tenured male professors and a few token females. The social body -- presidents and chancellors, tenured professors and trustees -- is still unmistakably male. Why should I subsidize this behavior? Until such discrimination is a line item in a history text, I will give my money to more accountable institutions. KAREN STEPHENSON Los Angeles

title: Strong First Half Catapults Knights to Third Victory
description: During recent football seasons at Giants Stadium, it's hardly been news when a home team plays stellar defense. But now it's springtime football and the team turning in the outstanding defensive play is not the Giants, but the New York/New Jersey Knights of the World League of American Football.

title: Kuwaitis, Having Survived Hussein, Now Find Their Environment Toxic
description: With many Kuwaitis remaining out of their country two months after the end of the Iraqi occupation, this country seems in little hurry to measure the long-term health peril resulting from the hundreds of oil-well fires left by the retreating Iraqi forces.

title: After Johnny, Beyond Dave, TV Secrets Lurk
description: People who keep vampires' hours know secrets the rest of the world does not. They know that Ali MacGraw sells makeup in the middle of the night. They know of an 800 number to call where they can order a mathematics teaching aid that turns ordinary mortals into "human calculators." They know that otherwise intelligent adults sometimes sing, "A horse is a horse, of course, of course," softly, so the rest of the house won't wake up.

title: Senator Leaves Hospital
description: Senator David Pryor was released from George Washington University Hospital on Friday, 10 days after suffering what doctors called a moderate heart attack. "The doctors say I have recovered nicely, but the next several weeks are going to require a lot of rest," the Arkansas Democrat said in a statement released by his office. Senator Pryor, 56 years old, suffered the heart attack on April 16.

title: Passions and Provocations
description: GOOD BOYS AND DEAD GIRLS

title: Too-Frequent Fliers
description: John Sununu, the President's chief of staff, isn't the only abuser of taxpayer-subsidized travel in Air Force planes. Junketing members of Congress are the unrivaled champs. The military indulges, too; a Marine Corps general who suspended two colonels at the El Toro Air Station in California for taking unauthorized jaunts is now under investigation himself for possibly doing the same.

title: Data Bank/April 28, 1991
In Africa's War Zones, More of the Red Cross
description: Mohammed Abdi Ismael, a 13-year-old shepherd, lay in the worst-case surgical ward of the war hospital. Both his eyes had been blown out and both hands smashed by two of the thousands of mines planted by both sides in Somalia's civil war.

title: Friction Over Firefighters' Status
description: WHEN a fire alarm rings in this bustling township in Middlesex County, two fire departments respond to the call.

title: Transfer for Bomb Suspect
description: A Federal magistrate on Friday ordered that a suspect in the bombing that killed former Ambassador Orlando Letelier of Chile be transferred to a jail in Washington, to face charges in the case. The 39-year-old suspect, Virgilio Pablo Paz Romero, a Cuban exile, was arrested Tuesday while he was driving to his landscaping business near Palm Beach. Prosecutors say Mr. Paz is the man who detonated a bomb that killed Mr. Letelier and an American, Ronni Moffitt, as they drove a car in Washington 15 years ago.

title: Barrymore Lives, and So Does Light Comedy
description: Here's my theory on why the British actor Nicol Williamson is so vivid in "I Hate Hamlet," the perfectly amiable comedy at the Walter Kerr Theater, in which he plays the ghost of John Barrymore brought back from the hereafter against his will. The black velvet tunic and tights that he's wearing have been wired for electricity. And every now and then someone in the wings is throwing the switch.

title: Plan by New Argentine Economy Chief Raises Cautious Hope for Recovery
description: After years of uncontrolled inflation, gyrating political changes and dozens of failed economic plans, Argentines are not quick to express optimism on prospects for serious improvement in the economy.

title: Victoria A. Perla Married
description: Victoria Alexandra Perla, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George N. Perla of Todt Hill, Staten Island, was married in New York yesterday to Paul Joseph Guagliardo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Guagliardo of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Richard J. Neilson performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Our Savior. Mrs. Guagliardo, 27 years old, graduated from St. John's University and is a copywriter for Lintas New York, an international advertising agency. Mr. Guagliardo, 29, graduated from Northwestern University, from which he also received a master's degree in advertising. He is a marketing executive in the personal products division of the Johnson & Johnson Company in Milltown, N.J.

title: Making a Difference; Tough Time for a Promotion
description: On Jan. 1, Edwin M. Cooperman and G. Richard Thoman became co-chairmen and co-chief executives of the American Express Company's biggest money-maker, the Travel Related Services division. They couldn't have picked a worse time.

title: A Lawyer Well Worth the Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Karin Marie Rose Married To Leighton McIlvaine Jr.
description: Karin Marie Rose, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Holger Arthur Rose of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married yesterday aboard the motor yacht Enticer in Long Island Sound off Greenwich, Conn., to Leighton Howe McIlvaine Jr., the son of the late Mr. McIlvaine and the late Elise Robinson MacIntosh, both of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: INSIDE GITMO
description: The hutia may be a quality- of-life problem for troops stationed at Guantanamo Bay, as Ann Banks indicates in her article. However, it is definitely not an index of Cuban poverty. The hutia is not eaten in Cuba because of food shortages; rather, it is sought as a meat to be enjoyed. The hutia is a rodent of the Capromyidae family, which also includes the nutria, and is no more closely related to the rat than are the chipmunk, the porcupine or the chinchilla, which are also rodents.

title: The Nation; Unresolved: Role of Race In Law Class Admissions
description: AN attack on the standards used by Georgetown University Law School in admitting black students has provoked weeks of debate on campus but has done little to resolve basic differences over affirmative action in education and employment.

title: Carolyn Sweeney To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. James M. Sweeney of New City, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Elizabeth Sweeney to William Paul Murnane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver G. Murnane of Long Valley, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Food; Night of the Long Knives
description: IF MOST DOMESTIC ACCIDENTS OCCUR IN THE bathroom, even money says that today, virtually all arguments start in the kitchen. It's a hazard of dual-income existence. Take a restricted space, fill it with two strong-willed, harried people, add sharp knives and a complicated recipe -- and you've got the ingredients for disaster. We have entered the age of mean cuisine.

title: Young Lobbyists Leave a Footprint on the Law
description: WHAT does a dinosaur footprint have in common with Nathan Hale, the American robin, the praying mantis and "Yankee Doodle"? Thanks to the efforts of Dave Fowler's fourth grade class at Center School in Old Lyme the 180-million-year-old footprint is joining Connecticut's official hero, bird, insect and song, to become the state fossil.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Primer for a Leisurely Brunch of Dim Sum
description: SOME culinary trends reach the county slowly, often years after they have been forgotten as the hot topic of the day in pace-setting places like Manhattan or Los Angeles. Ultimately, however, the ripples do come our way.

title: French
description: To the Editor: Plus ca change, indeed. If David Finkle doesn't think things have changed, he is wrong. We spend several months a year, a few weeks at a time, living in the Marais district in Paris. Mr. Finkle should try to speak to our delightful concierge, our boulanger, our shoemaker, our dry cleaner or the people in any one of the numerous other mom and pop shops that abound in the immediate vicinity. Not a word of English has ever passed the lips of any one of these. ABBIE F. SALNY Wayne, N.J.

title: The Cultivated Gardener; Compost Piles: On Giving Back Earth's Riches
description: The humble compost pile is coming into its own again. The Akkadians of Mesopotomia referred to it in their clay tablets 1,000 years before Moses. The Bible and the Talmud, Shakespeare and Thomas Jefferson have all sung its praises.

title: Sports of The Times; Gina Basile Should Keep the Gold Medal
description: Sometime in the next few weeks, the National Collegiate Athletic Association is going to mail a plaque to the University of Alabama.

title: The Region; Can a City Numbed By False Apocalypses Scare Itself Into Action?
description: IN the annals of public posturing, the three biggest threats by New York City government are: we're closing your neighborhood firehouse; we're cutting subway service; we're not hiring the police officers we promised. And the leading nominee from private industry: we're moving to New Jersey.

title: Goo Galore
description: OUT OF THE CHANNEL The Exxon Valdez Oil Spill in Prince William Sound. By John Keeble. 290 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $22.95.

title: All About/Hiking Shoes; A Resurgence for Hiking -- Make That Strolling -- Boots
description: Hiking boots, those heavy, bomb-proof wedges of leather and rubber that were all the rage on college campuses 20 years ago, have gone through a metamorphosis. They have emerged in a flutter of colorful, high-tech designs that weigh almost nothing and cost anywhere from $50 to $250. In the last few years, the popularity of these boots and their high-tech cousins -- low-cut, hiking shoes -- has spread far beyond the traditional outdoor-enthusiast market.

title: On May Day, Cash for The Bosses
description: May Day is coming, and the talk around Wall Street is that a lot of insiders plan to celebrate by bailing out.

title: Postings: Rating Lenders; Loans in Poor Areas
description: Fresh from receiving high marks for its lending policies in poor neighborhoods, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has announced a new five-year program to originate $250 million in loans, mostly for housing construction and home purchases, in low-income neighborhoods.

title: Over Steep Turkish Passes, the Kurds Start Back to Iraq
description: The movement of Kurdish refugees back to Iraq from their grisly camps in the mountains of southern Turkey appears to be starting in earnest.

title: Why a Dance-World Veteran Decided to Pack It All In
description: THE STUDIO HAD GROWN PROgressively barer over the past few weeks. One day a giddy display case of worn toe shoes and performance photographs hung on the wall. A few days later it was gone. So were a bushy green plant and one packing box. And now the studio is closed and empty.

title: For Family and Special Friends, Risotto
description: IT is not hard to make a good risotto. But you have to stand over it for at least 20 minutes and this makes it difficult for dinner parties. The dish doesn't allow shortcuts and can't be successfully prepared in advance. Basically, it is something to serve when you are cooking for family -- or a couple of close friends.

title: For Many Vietnamese, It's Still Saigon
description: IN Ho Chi Minh City, a lot of the bad old Saigon ways are back -- from the bar girls and beggars to the pickpockets and motorcycle cowboys. But it's a new generation, of course. The kids, who were barely talking when this city fell to the North Vietnamese in April 1975 and the last American was choppered away, seem to be hearing the siren song of the West through Japanese headphones smuggled from Thailand or sent by relatives in the United States.

title: Campus Life: Penn; Campus Survey Finds Believers In Power of Stars
description: While the University of Pennsylvania may aspire to be a stronghold of science and modern skepticism, it still has believers in the powers of stars, planets and the zodiac, a survey by two Penn professors shows.

title: Hoffa's Daughter Sues U.S. for Files on Disappearance
description: Nearly 16 years after James R. Hoffa disappeared from a restaurant parking lot outside Detroit in one of the great unsolved mysteries of the century, his daughter has grown tired of theories and is looking for answers.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Nuptials, Old and New

title: On the Street; Dashingly, the Vest Returns
description: A new generation of men has discovered the vest. But forget about the timid designs that once accompanied three-button suits to the office.

title: 20th-Century Composers at the Fore
description: CREATIVE energy in our century is bountifully on display at several concerts in Connecticut this week.
