Today at 2:30, for instance, Dr. Robert Dix, who retired from a corporate career in 1977 to devote his time to music, is presenting a free "Composer's Choice" program at the Westport Public Library. With four friends -- Eve and Kate Dillingham, Cynthia Petty and Mary Schmidt -- Dr. Dix will introduce what he calls "works in an informal mode" for piano, cello, violin and flute, among them a Flute Trio that still remains "in a rehearsal mode." For information, call 227-8411.

title: Did Agriculture Start in Want or Plenty?
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Italy's Political Circus Maximus Is Becoming A Luxury the Nation Finds Harder to Afford
description: ITALIAN politics has long meant grand theater not as diverting perhaps as a good soccer match and more repetitive certainly than a pornographic movie, but an eye-filling extravaganza just the same, with heroes and villains and sound and fury, all wrapped in tantalizing promises of countless sequels.

title: Mary C. Grandy Wed in Virginia
description: Mary Chambers Grandy, a daughter of Mrs. James Reinhardt McKenry and Charles Rollin Grandy, both of Virginia Beach, Va., was married yesterday to Henry Lee Valentine 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine 2d of Richmond. The Rev. John Jordan, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony in the Selden Chapel at Christ and St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Norfolk, Va.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: JULIUS, THE BABY OF THE WORLD Written and illustrated by Kevin Henkes. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Camera
description: Part of my pursuit of photography is finding the perfect textbook, the one that clearly explains terms and processes that I still do not quite understand after years of trying.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: CATHA ABRAHAMS;
Helping the Victims of Sexual Assault
description: RAPE increased four times faster than any other major crime in the last 10 years, according to the Federal Justice Department. In 1989, Connecticut's 13 sexual assault crisis centers reported 3,016 sex crimes, representing an increase of 21 percent over the previous year.

title: Commercial Property: Manhattan Hotels; Redoing the Sheratons for the Convention and After
description: WHEN the Sheraton Centre asks guests to pardon its appearance during renovation, it means more than indulging a change in wallpaper.

title: JOHN WATERS: KINKMEISTER
description: If indeed Waters has "softened his material . . . to infiltrate a broader cross section of the moviegoing public," has he not, in fact, traded one brand of the inane for another? If it can be said that "on the one hand he accepts everything, and on the other hand he puts up with nothing," does that not also say that he has no discerning taste, no informed parameters that dictate his choices? If the answer is yes, what kind of film maker does that make him? I must disagree with him when he says that his whole career has been irony. Arbitrary ignorance seems a better phrase. KENNETH H. BROWN Brooklyn

title: Q and A
description: Self-Drive Barges in France

title: Sandstrom Holds Up, and Kings Hold On
description: Tomas Sandstrom supplied the inspiration and Luc Robitaille provided the offense Friday night as the Los Angeles Kings staved off elimination from the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Wall Street; Tracking Environmental Risk
description: When the closing bell clanged at the New York Stock Exchange last June 26, the shares of PPG Industries of Pittsburgh weighed in at $49.25 each. By the next day's close, those shares had skidded nearly $3 -- thanks to fresh news reports about the company's potential role in cleaning up chromium-tainted land in Jersey City.

title:
ROWING;
Penn's Varsity Unmasks Harvard's Vulnerable Side
description: Pennsylvania's heavyweight varsity crew knocked Harvard from its undefeated perch today, outracing the Crimson and Navy to retain the Adams Cup.

title: Review/Music; Rostropovich In Concerto By Schnittke
description: Its boxes festooned with bouquets and gauzy cream-colored bunting, Carnegie Hall got its Centennial Festival under way on Friday evening with a concert by the Boston Symphony. (More precisely, the big, main-hall festival got under way, since activities in the smaller Weill Recital Hall had begun the previous night with the Guarneri String Quartet.)

title: An Environmentally Correct Hotel for the Big Sur
description: The start of construction on an upscale resort hotel, even one limited to 30 guest rooms, is a notable event in this coastal community 150 miles south of San Francisco, where no major commercial project has been built in 18 years.

title: Andrew O'Conor Jr. Weds Miss Mackie
description: The marriage of Katherine Anne Marion Mackie to Andrew Joseph O'Conor Jr. took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. Timothy J. Scannell officiated.

title:
DANCE;
Choreography as a Dialogue
description: WHEN the choreographer Carolyn Dorfman speaks, people listen. Whether she talks about dance directly to viewers or lets the language of movement articulate her ideas and feelings, Ms. Dorfman heads her agenda with a profound commitment to communication.

title: Review/Pop; 2 Alternative Rock Bands Suddenly Take a Calmer Path
description: Things change quickly in pop music. Only months ago, quick cutting -- moving rapidly from style to style -- was the thing to do. Agitated and jumpy, the technique mirrored film editing styles at the visual speed with which MTV works. Wednesday night's show at Madison Square Garden, featuring two alternative rock bands, Jane's Addiction and Happy Mondays, wallowed instead in long and undulating pieces that motored along calmly from climax to climax. It was the revenge of the Grateful Dead.

title: 'Illiberal Education'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Comedy of Eccentrics
description: Midway between Death Valley and America's largest nuclear test site sits the town of Beatty (population 500), which is the setting for Steve Swartz's screwball comedy "Never Leave Nevada." Into town one day roll Sean (Mr. Swartz) and his partner, Luis (Rodney Rincon), a team of traveling salesmen with a trunkful of T-shirts bearing slogans like "Nuclear Winter Gives Me the Chills." Sean and Luis, it turns out, make their living going around the country selling these and other items at anti-nuclear demonstrations.

title: THE SMURFETTE PRINCIPLE
description: As the parent of a daughter who is 3 1/2, I empathize with Katha Pollitt. However, as someone who makes television commercials, I can attest to the difficulties of trying to sell any female in a leading role in children's commercials. Our male- dominated society approves of male role models period, and questions the validity and seriousness of any dominant female figures. MATTHEW LESTER New York, N.Y.

title: Mimi Carter, Artist, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Mary Elizabeth Carter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Carter of Somers, Conn., and John Denton Haley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Duane F. Haley of Bloomfield, Conn., took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. Stephen H. Wade officiated. The bride, 33 years old, is known as Mimi. She is a watercolorist and a graduate of St. Lawrence University. The bridegroom, 31, is an architect with the firm of Benjamin Thompson & Associates in Cambridge, Mass. He graduated from the Catholic University of America and received an architectural degree from the University of Illinois.

title: Come to the Winter Games and See France. A Lot of It.
description: ALBERTVILLE, France

title: The Smart Alecks at Sun Are Regrouping
description: On the eve of the introduction of a new line of faster work stations a few weeks ago, a Hewlett-Packard executive pulled a stunt aimed at pumping up his sales team. At a pep rally in Las Vegas, company officials ceremoniously tore up a picture of Scott McNealy, the 36-year-old chairman of Sun Microsystems Inc.

title: On Language; Dancetalk
description: OVER THE OBITUARY of Martha Graham, who died earlier this month at 96, was this New York Times headline: "Choreographer Hailed for Creating a Language."

title: Beth Barton and Bruce Rubin Marry
description: Beth Sanders Barton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gibbs Barton of Barrington, R.I., was married last night to Bruce Lawrence Rubin, the son of Elliott Robert Rubin of Forest Hills, Queens, and Joan Kimmel of New York. The Rev. Daryl W. Stahl and Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the interfaith ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Barrington.

title: Remembering Forgotten Plays
description: To the Editor:

title: Perspectives: The Federal Buildings; A Spur to Slow Construction
description: FOR New York City, the proper word for two major Federal building projects that are going forward in lower Manhattan is opportune.

title: School Nurses Have Broad Responsibilities
description: In the recent "6 Opinions on School Finance Law," Dr. Mark C. Smith, Superintendent of Schools in Westfield, "cited state regulations that require aspirin to be dispensed to a child only by a fully certified school nurse" as an example of excessive intrusiveness by the state into school districts. His solution was to let the principal give medication so that the district would be free to use the allotted money elsewhere.

title: It's All Gravy for the Giants
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: As Ever, Cliburn Does It His Way
description: For millions of Americans who retain the image of a tall, blond and blue-eyed Texas boy who conquered Moscow and returned to New York blowing kisses from an open car, it will seem hard to believe that Van Cliburn is now 56 years old.

title: Keep Trade Out of the Deficit Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Little League Diamonds Filling Up Again
description: THOUSANDS of Long Island youngsters who learned how to walk only a few years ago are learning how to run around the bases this spring, as the baby boom of the 1980's gives rise to the Little League baseball boom of the 90's.

title: Cuba
description: To the Editor: I found it disheartening to read in Howard W. French's article "Cuba's New Hotels Dream of Dollars" (Travel, March 31) that an increasing number of Americans are visiting Cuba every year. Two major reasons for the increased visitors, states Mr. French, are novelty and competitive package rates. Once again the "such a deal" syndrome allows us to visit and enjoy a country with gorgeous natural resources while breaking American law and ignoring the human rights abuses and the impossibility of residents to eat lobster dinners at any price.

title: Family Tends Neighbors' Heads and Hearts
description: ON a Saturday afternoon at Ashe's Barber Shop in New Haven, Chuck Ashe Jr. and his blue-smocked crew were clipping, trimming and shaving one head after another to the sound of popping soda cans and music from the movie "New Jack City." The most-requested styles included fades, slopes, boxes, twists and Gumbies, and Afros appeared to be making a comeback. Waiting time was about one hour.

title: Divac Does It All As Lakers Lead, 2-0
description: Vlade Divac scored 23 points, grabbed 10 rebounds and blocked 3 shots today to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 109-98 victory over the Houston Rockets and a 2-0 lead in their first-round Western Conference playoff series.

title: Jersey Blue Cross Chief Quits
description: The chairman of the financially troubled Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey has resigned, a day after walking out of a meeting of the insurer's board.

title: Q and A
description: Pass-Along for a Doorman Question: Our co-op is about 51 percent owner occupied and 49 percent rental. We have had some security problems recently and the co-op owners have considered hiring a doorman. Could the cost qualify as a building improvement that could be passed along to the rent-stabilized tenants as a rent increase? . . . Jonathan S. Cooper, Manhattan

title: At Large in Bolivia
description: BEFORE THE RAINY SEASON By Gert Hofmann. Translated by Edna McCown. 341 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $19.95.

title: French
description: To the Editor: To frustrated francophiles, such as Mr. Finkle, I recommend the following reply to every Frenchman who responds in broken English to your less-than-perfect French: "Mais, vous parlez anglais tres bien, Monsieur." The results with a waiter in a one-star restaurant were nothing short of miraculous: The sneer was quickly replaced with a smile and the service was warm and friendly instead of cold and condescending. WALTER A. ROSENKRANTZ Amherst, Mass.

title: Anticipating Education Cuts
description: THE auditorium of St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Rocky Point was packed on April 19, when nearly 400 parents, students and teachers turned out for a meeting to protest recent actions by the Board of Education to cut 39 teachers and eliminate some school programs.

title: 95 Leagues on the Island
description: IN an era of time constraints and tightened family budgets, Little Leagues may offer a worthwhile parent-and-child activity for an average of $40, uniforms included.

title: Decaffeinated Dreams
description: To the Editor:

title: Announcements I Wish I'd Missed
description: DURING the heyday of aircraft hijackings to Cuba, The New Yorker ran a cartoon picturing a cabin of startled passengers as they listened to the announcement from the cockpit: "Buenos dias, amigos. This is your new captain, Pedro Gonzales." That cartoon reminds me of a few of the startling in-flight announcements I have heard during 30 years of flying. With today's real threats of terrorism against airlines, it is worth remembering that some alarms are false.

title: The Rain in Barcelona Wakes Up the Organizers
description: As King Juan Carlos officially reopened Montjuic Stadium for the World Cup of track and field on Sept. 8, 1989, he heard whistles, jeers and protests from several thousand Catalan nationists, calling attention to themselves as an "oppressed nation." This was no big deal. The King had been razzed on other occasions, and Catalonians often use public events to express their feelings.

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: Too Much Joy: "Cereal Killers"

title: Style Makers; Nancy Briggs and Juanita Crampton, Caterers and Restaurateurs
description: The Guinness Book of World Records has no category for world's smallest restaurant, but Table for Two here would surely qualify. It offers one luncheon seating Tuesday through Friday, for two.

title: Lisa Taylor, 58, Former Director of Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Dies
description: Lisa Taylor, director of the Cooper-Hewitt Museum of Design from 1969 to 1987, died on Friday in a hospital in Nassau, the Bahamas, said David McFadden, the museum's curator of decorative arts. She was 58 years old and lived in Naples, Fla.

title: Even People in the Hotel Tease the Knicks
description: The Knicks have spent two days in Chicago listening to people tell them how bad they are. They have been lambasted in the newspapers and on television. They have been tormented in the hotel lobby and on the street.

title: The Sweet Sounds of Suburbia: Bang! Whir! Vrrrooooom!!
description: NOW that spring is turning the bend and heading toward summer, it occurs to me that I didn't hear much of last summer, and I probably won't hear much of the coming summer either.

title: For President Bush, 'My Dinner With Ernie'
description: Table No. 11 at the White House dinner April 17 had some true heavies seated around it: President Bush; President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua; Michael Eisner, chairman of Walt Disney Company; actress Teri Garr, and television producer Robert Morton ("Late Night With David Letterman").

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Wall Decoration

title: INSIDE GITMO
description: Many thanks for Ann Banks's article "Inside Gitmo" (March 31). Time may have forgotten Guantanamo Bay, but the thousands of officers and men who served there in the early days of World War II, when the military outpost was a huge convoy port, certainly haven't. I served in Gitmo for a year (1942-43) as the port director's chief boarding officer. It was anything but a sleepy backwater.

title: Travel Advisory; Taking a Break On a Horse
description: For horse lovers and would-be cowboys, Southern Cross Expeditions, an adventure travel company, is offering two 11-day riding trips in Argentina. The first, Gaucho Trails in the Pampas, takes place in Argentina's cooler months, from May to October. Travelers ride along the pampas, or flatlands, to the lush Ibera marshlands noted for their bird life. The cost is $1,460. Gaucho Trails in the Andes is available from October to May during the Argentine summer and takes riders through the mountains, with visits to the wine country and the lake district, for $1,570. Prices include hotels, ranches and campsites, leaders and guides and most meals but not international and domestic air fares. More information: Southern Cross Expeditions, (800) 359-0193.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ducts from our hot-air furnace pass through the cold basement, and so the longest duct, which goes to the back bedroom, loses a lot of heat on the way and the air is just warm by the time it gets there. I am thinking of wrapping the basement ducts with insulation. What is your opinion?

title: Harrelson Generous In Defeat
description: Today's edition of "The Bud Harrelson Report" wishes to emphasize that the Mets, still just one game out of first place, will have an opportunity to win a series from the defending National League East champion Pittsburgh Pirates this afternoon.

title: Years Later, No Clear Culprit in Gassing of Kurds
description: American officials say irrefutable evidence shows that Iraq used chemical weapons against its Kurdish minority at least twice in 1988, but to this day the Iraqi Government's culpability for the most notorious massacre, at the town of Halabja, remains in dispute.

title: Less Lionized Than Lonely
description: To the Editor:

title: A Success in Using Rent Vouchers
description: ELEVEN years after the Justice Department sued this city for maintaining segregated patterns in its housing and schools, four homeless black families have quietly moved into a mainly white section of east Yonkers with the help of Federal housing vouchers.

title: Campus Life: Southern Methodist; Student Senate Gives Gay Group Official Standing
description: The Student Senate at Southern Meth odist University granted charter status last week to the university's Gay and Lesbian Student Organization. The action came in a 20-to-13 vote three weeks after the Senate added a clause to the Student Code of Conduct prohibiting verbal and physical abuse of homosexuals, heterosexuals and bisexuals on campus.

title: Why a Dance-World Veteran Decided to Pack It All In
description: The studio had grown progressively barer over the past few weeks. One day a giddy display case of worn toe shoes and performance photographs hung on the wall. A few days later it was gone. So were a bushy green plant and one packing box. And now the studio is closed and empty.

title: Postings: Along the Platinum Mile; A Campus for Kaiser Permanente
description: Kaiser Permanente, the country's largest group health-care provider, is expanding its Westchester operations into a renovated office campus at 210 Westchester Avenue in White Plains. Alan Ambrose & Associates are the architects for the project, which is to be completed by February.

title: Caro vs. Blumenthal
description: To the Editor:

title: Dear Snorky
description: YOURS, PLUM

title: Medicine: What the Traffic Will Bear
description: THE PROFIT MOTIVE AND PATIENT CARE

title: The World; Gorbachev Agrees, Sort of, To Negotiate the State of Union
description: AMONG the novelties at the "Summit of the Presidents" in a village outside Moscow last week was that Mikhail S. Gorbachev did some listening. That, at least, was what Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian Federation leader and Mr. Gorbachev's premier adversary, reported to his Russian colleagues after the extraordinary meeting between Mr. Gorbachev and leaders of nine Slavic and Moslem republics. (Missing were the three Baltic republics, plus Georgia, Armenia and Moldavia, which have declared their intention to leave the union.)

title:
Your Own Account;
Social Security: Critical Months
description: On Jan. 1, a new law went into effect closing a loophole worth as much as $6,000 in Social Security benefits to many people during their first year of retirement. The change was designed to save the Government $748 million over five years.

title: Float Builders' Craft: Magic in Motion
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON, in full military dress, stands guard at the door, a stern figure ready to rally his country to revolution. Someone has tied a brilliantly colored woolen muffler around the general's neck, creating a merry contrast to the solemn visage of this seven-foot papier-mache statue.

title: 'To Kill or Not to Kill,' That Is the Question
description: Following our recent great success in the gulf, we Americans may be tempted to see war in a more positive light than we did after Vietnam. However. . . . Not too much about the gulf war was "good." True, our technology worked wonderfully, giving "war is hell" a new electronically enhanced, speed-of-light, Nintendo-remote feeling. And we lost amazingly few "good guys" (if you hold the definition strictly to Americans and allies).

title:
BACKTALK;
Yawn. N.F.L. Draft Finishes a Poor Second to Gardening
description: As I sat in front of the television last Sunday, struggling to stay awake during the first round of the National Football League draft, a few things occurred to me. First, the analysts were wrong; the biggest gamble of the first round was not taken by the Cardinals or the Raiders. It was taken by my old team, the Eagles.

title: Foreign Affairs; Look Homeward
description: Our country's leaders are more willing to do whatever is necessary to democratize Iraq and help the Kurds than to fix up America and save the "Kurds of America." I wrote that recently, and if anything, did not carry the argument far enough.

title: Politics, Laced With a Dollop of Strangeness
description: At its best, the art of Rosemarie Trockel, which is on view in a retrospective here at the Institute of Contemporary Art, has about it a wonderful strangeness and understatement that is rare for an art of such strongly political inclinations. Ms. Trockel will, for example, create a set of bronzed ladles whose cups have been replaced by conch shells, so that the combination of the sexually evocative shells and the kitchen utensils produces an exotic form that becomes a subtle meditation on female identity.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RIDERS ON THE STORM My Life With Jim Morrisonand the Doors.By John Densmore.Delacorte, $19.95.

title: Sunday Menu; Grilled Pork With Potatoes
description: With thanks to the Yuca Restaurant in Miami, here is a fresh and sparkling way to serve pork. Some liberties have been taken with the recipe, and the restaurant's side dish of yuca, or cassava, has been changed to potatoes. Anyone familiar with yuca will find the seasonings superb with it, too. Grilled Pork Tenderloin 1/3 cup tightly packed fresh oregano 1/3 cup tightly packed cilantro 1/4 medium-size onion 1/2 teaspoon grated orange rind 1/3 cup orange juice Juice of one lime Freshly ground black pepper to taste 1 teaspoon olive oil 12 to 14 ounces pork tenderloin, trimmed of fat and cut into about 6 pieces 1/2 bunch watercress or arugula, washed and dried 2 small eating oranges, peeled and sectioned.

title: Unsettled, Unseen, Unspoken For
description: We are standing in the shadowy vestibule of a sagging, gray-shingled triple decker on the East Side of Bridgeport, Conn. -- sagging except for the entrance, which is crisscrossed with iron bars.

title: New Group Presents New Play
description: WHEN Jewel, a medical student from South Orange, meets Duke, a medicine man, or psychic healer, at a rain dance one summer, they strike a spiritual connection -- and the sex is pretty good too.

title: another Official May Determine When Sununu Uses Military Craft
description: White House lawyers are likely to recommend that an official other than John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, determine whether his use of military aircraft is for personal, political or official business, a Bush Administration official said today.

title: A Rabbi's Balancing Act: Two Temples Under One Roof
description: AS Rabbi Paul R. Siegel approaches the 40-year mark as leader of what is believed to be the only temple in the country with both a Reform and a Conservative chapel under one roof, he was asked to consider his greatest triumph.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A HISTORY OF CONTEMPORARY ITALY Society and Politics, 1943-1988.By Paul Ginsborg.Penguin, Paper, $9.95.

title: Keeping Siding Tiptop
description: VINYL siding wears long and is virtually maintenance free, but annual cleaning can keep it looking new for years. Should a section of siding become damaged, only a few special tools are needed to repair or replace it.

title:
The Executive Life;
The Whimpering Litany of the Jury Duty Set
description: When Joseph Alaimo, director of investor relations at Continental Bank in Chicago, was picked to serve on a jury for a week earlier this month, he was delighted to have been plucked out of the jury-room bullpen and actually put to use.

title: Karen E. Tanner Weds Kent Allen
description: Karen Elizabeth Tanner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tanner of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y., to William Kent Allen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hayes Allen of Arlington, Va. Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum of the United States District Court in the Southern District of New York performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill.

title: Travel Advisory; London Phones For Theaters And Dining
description: Two new phone services are available in London, one for theaters, the other for dining.

title: How to Foster Self Esteem
description: WHEN OUR TWIN SONS WERE born 21 years ago, my husband and I consulted only two books: Dr. Benjamin Spock's "Baby and Child Care" (Pocket Books), of course, so we'd know what to do when they ran a fever or refused to eat, and Haim G. Ginott's "Between Parent & Child" (Avon Books), so we'd know how to talk to them with respect and authority.

title: Tracy Bohrer Is Married
description: Tracy Lynn Bohrer, the daughter of Virginia Bohrer of Los Angeles and Van Bohrer of Ventura, Calif., was married in Beverly Hills, Calif., last evening to William Alexander Ullman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Anthony Ullman of New York. Rabbi Donald Goor officiated at the ceremony at the Regent Beverly Wilshire Hotel. Mrs. Ullman, 27 years old, is an associate product manager at General Foods USA in White Plains. She graduated from the University of California at Berkeley, and she and her husband received M.B.A. degrees from the University of California at Los Angeles in 1989. Mr. Ullman, also 27, is an associate in the investment banking division of Merrill Lynch in New York. He graduated cum laude from Princeton University

title: Travel Advisory; 31-Day Voyage In the Arctic
description: Seven years after the first passenger ship sailed through the Northwest Passage, the Frontier Spirit, one of the few vessels equipped to operate in arctic waters, will attempt the feat late this summer.

title: JOHN WATERS: KINKMEISTER
description: My first encounter with John Waters was in Provincetown, Mass., in the mid-1970's ("Kinkmeister," by Paul Mandelbaum, April 7). My husband and I had rented a cottage on the ocean with friends and our children. Leaving our friends to baby-sit one evening, we walked into town. The only movie playing was a low-budget feature billed as "Female Trouble." We took our seats amid a packed crowd soon to be engulfed in a mini-riot. The audience howled and cheered. After watching the credits to find out who made this film, we hurried back to the cottage to watch the children while our friends rushed back to town for the midnight showing. For years, I have looked back upon that night and thought, whoever that John Waters guy is, he's nuts, really nuts -- and very, very funny. PATRICIA DOLAN Westfield, Mass.

title: Style Makers; Debbie Gioello, Skivvies Designer
description: United States troops who served in the Persian Gulf war can thank Debbie Gioello for their sweat-free undershirts. She sent the troops a few hundred as a goodwill gesture in November. The response was so great that in January her T-shirts became a part of standard military gear. "They said it was the best thing since sliced bread," she said.

title: A 'Modest Proposal' On the Death Penalty
description: The recent article on the death penalty in New Jersey ("Lawmakers Press Court on Death Penalty") discusses pending legislation that may affect proportionality review, which attempts to insure that the death penalty is applied consistently. The article indicates that narrowing the scope of review may result in unfairness, while widening the scope could place a great burden upon prosecutors who prepare trials.

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth; At Last, a Paper Students Put Out Without Paper
description: Environmen tists and techni cal wizards at Dartmouth College have joined forces to produce a new student publication that is paperless.

title: Technology; Tracking the Path of the Perfect Pitch With 3-D Graphics
description: Does the famous rising fast ball actually exist? Tommy Lasorda, the Los Angeles Dodgers manager, believes that it does. Not all baseball aficionados agree. After all, the idea that a pitcher can hurl a blazingly fast pitch that will defy gravity and not drop as fast as it should is a little hard for some people to swallow.

title: The Latest Quest by the Idea Man of Communications
description: Jack Goeken is bursting out of a suit so old it has begun to shine. The soles of his shoes are flopping about. He drives a rusted-out 1981 Cadillac Eldorado, and he's broken so many briefcases jamming them with papers that he will on occasion carry a plastic garbage bag instead. More to the point, few of Mr. Goeken's many companies -- neither MCI, the long-distance carrier nor Airfone, the air-to-ground telephone company -- were ever profitable while he was at the helm.

title: INSIDE
description: Love-Triangle Killing Trial Ends in a Hung Jury

title: Barbara Nelson Wed To Theodore Janulis
description: Barbara Nelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Nelson of Todt Hill, Staten Island, was married in Pelham Manor, N.Y., last night to Theodore Janulis, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter T. Janulis of Pelham Manor. The Rev. William P. Saum 2d performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Huguenot Memorial Church.

title: How Passe to Be Young
description: To the Editor:

title: The Shops Where Recession and Recycling Meet
description: RECESSION and recycle. Those words are changing the way a lot of people shop. The owners of stores that sell "previously owned" merchandise, for example, say they are seeing a lot of new customers seeking bargains in this form of recycled goods.

title:
ART;
Contrasts in Installations: Randomness vs. Control
description: REVEALING contrasts are suggested in the installation pieces designed by Katarina Isaksson and Brandt Junceau for a new exhibition in the Amelie A. Wallace Gallery at the State University in Old Westbury.

title: How Rockland Fared in 1990 Census
description: During the 1980's, Rockland County's population grew only slightly. The heaviest concentration of residents remain in the central part of the county, which also had the greatest rate of growth over the last decade.

title: Anna Covici Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Pascal Covici of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anna Covici, to Dr. William Henry Propp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Propp of New York. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Covici, 33 years old, is a reference librarian at the University of San Diego. She is a graduate of Stanford University and received a master's degree in library science at the University of Texas. Dr. Propp, also 33, is an assistant professor of biblical and Near Eastern studies at the University of California at San Diego. He is a graduate of Harvard University and also received a Ph.D. in Near Eastern studies from Harvard.

title: Grogan Sent Packing
description: The way the New England Patriots see it, 16 years, 149 games, 26,886 passing yards, 182 touchdowns, and 2,164 rushing yards for an additional 35 touchdowns add up to a complete career for an injury-ridden 37-year-old quarterback.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Merrifield, Va.;
A 'Cathedral' Seeks Tenants
description: A HIGHLY stylized office complex in an emerging office center near Washington is struggling to fill up at a time when leasing has slowed.

title: Claire Wiseman To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Wiseman of Weston, Mass., have made known August wedding plans for their daughter, Claire Victoria Wiseman, and Randall Lee Stump, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milo E. Stump of Churubusco, Ind.

title: Homework
description: REINVENTING HOME

title: Streetscapes: Trinity Baptist Church; Repairs for a Study in Contrasts
description: BE sure to stand near a pew when you take your first look around the 1931 Trinity Baptist Church at 250 East 61st Street; you may want to sit down quickly as you take in the visual surprises of this most unusual house of worship, which is starting a $2 million restoration.

title: Stefanie H. Doak Weds W. S. Frank
description: Stefanie Hamilton Doak, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Doak of Ruxton, Md., was married yesterday in Ruxton to Warren Scott Frank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren J. Frank of West Newbury, Mass. The Rev. Ben H. Smith Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd.

title: Jeffrey A. Gould Weds Bonni Rachel Shaffet
description: Bonni Rachel Shaffet, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Stephen Shaffet of Roslyn, L.I., was married last evening to Jeffrey A. Gould, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric H. Gould of Old Brookville, L.I. Rabbi Abner Bergman performed the ceremony at Water's Edge in Long Island City.

title: J. F. Brose to Wed Marcia Simpson
description: Mr. and Mrs. James W. Simpson of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marcia Vickery Simpson, to James Frederick Brose, the son of E. Jerome Brose of Easton, Pa., and Suzanne Brose-Hemmerick of Brooklyn. An August wedding is planned.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Weill: Symphonies (2), 'Kleine Dreigroschenmusik' Gulbenkian Orchestra conducted by Michel Swier czewski. Nimbus 5283; CD and cassette.

title: Kathryn Nicklas Is Married
description: Kathryn Marie Nicklas, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James N. Nicklas of Glen Cove, L.I., was married there yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church to Anthony G. Gull 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gull Jr. of Glen Cove. The Rev. Nicholas J. Figliola, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Stark G. Jones, a Presbyterian minister.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BENEFIT FOR A THEATER

title: A Sampling of Choices For a Spring Afternoon
description: THE Westchester Musicians Guild presents its spring recital at the College of New Rochelle today at 3 P.M. in a program of piano solos by Bach, Haydn and Schumann, played by Hyla Melnick, and duos for violin and piano by Grieg, Granados and Rachmaninoff, performed by Tatiana and Eugene Feigin (632-9029).

title: Diamond Rings Meant For Hiding and Rattling
description: It's called the Rattle Ring, although it's obviously not for babies unless Baby happens to be chic, stylish, au courant and more concerned with diamonds than diapers. The diamonds, you see (or, more accurately, don't see), are hidden inside this ring. Talk about surprises!

title: More Than One Wallet
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. 335,000 35 Evergreen Row 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split-level; family room, 2 fireplaces, eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,340. Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. 230,000 22 Lounsbury Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 42-year-old contemporary; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage, brook, 1.5 acres; taxes $6,534. Peekskill, N.Y. 245,000 15 Gallows Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 4-year-old contemporary; fireplace, deck, eat-in kitchen, loft w/skylights, 1 acre; taxes $5,170. Chester, Conn. 147,000 Brooks Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new Cape Cod; w/w carpeting, dining room, close to school, 1.3 acres; taxes not yet available. Darien, Conn. 817,000 28 Crooked Mile Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial; 2 basement playrooms, 2 acres; taxes $6,774. Essex, Conn. 314,000 121 Saybrook Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 230-year-old restored Colonial; library, screened porch, 0.33 acre; taxes not available. OTHER AREAS Summit, N.J. 235,000 10 Woodfern Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old split level; greenhouse, updated eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,977. Bohemia, L.I. 171,500 16 Brooktree Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; dining room, den, basement; taxes $5,400. Kings Park, L.I. 170,000 25 Saber Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; dining room, partial basement, attached 2-car garage, cul-de-sac; taxes $6,000.

title: State Police Criticize Town Inquiry
description: STATE POLICE officials have indicated that they are not satisfied with a decision by the Town of Cortlandt to drop an investigation of an incident in which the Cortlandt police chief, Robert L. Pavone, was accused of making a racist remark about black state troopers.

title: Eleni Daskalakis to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elias Daskalakis of Philadelphia have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Eleni Fani Daskalakis and Peter Frederick Henkel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Carl Henkel of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Miss Daskalakis and Mr. Henkel, both 27 years old, are associates at Morgan Stanley in New York, she in corporate finance and he in real estate. She graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received an M.B.A. degree from Harvard University. The prospective bridegroom graduated from Yale University.

title: Wakaya: A Retreat Far, Far Away From It All
description: FOR those who appear to have it all, but for some reason want to get away from it all, the Wakaya Club on Wakaya Island in Fiji, which opened last September, is a beautiful, intimate -- only eight cottages with a maximum of 16 guests -- retreat. It is also very expensive -- perhaps not surprising, given its level of luxury in a remote setting.

title: Diana L. Merrell Wed To Dr. Robert Altman
description: Diana Lynn Merrell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Merrell of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married last evening in Riverside, Conn., to Dr. Robert Alan Altman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Altman of Longmeadow, Mass. Robert Mowbray, Justice of the Peace of Greenwich, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Riverside Yacht Club.

title: A Sense of Renewal for a Rising Celtic Star
description: The problem with being the reigning slam-dunk king is that it can perhaps elevate one's reputation well beyond its relative worth. Dee Brown of the Boston Celtics worries about this, about superficial labels and extremes. True, it has been an intoxicating experience, but he is sometimes left feeling dizzy with an accompanying shortness of breath.

title: Florio's Report Cards Rankle School Officials
description: LEONIA'S School Superintendent, Frank M. Marlow, received his district's "report card" from the state the other day, and he was angry about a chart showing that Leonia had one administrator for every 100 students in the 1989-90 school year. That figure is too high, he said.

title: Why Kansas Is Vulnerable: Inevitability and Pure Chance
description: A conspiracy of nature -- the alignment of the Rocky Mountains, the flatness of the Great Plains and the directions of the winds -- explains why Kansas and its neighbors are struck so often by tornadoes, meteorologists say.

title: Taking Care of the Lawn in a New Age
description: THE seasonal ritual has begun. The lawn mowers are whirring away. The grass is getting thick and green. Homeowners throughout suburbia are busy.

title: A Pianist Succeeds Without Really Trying
description: When Irving S. Gilmore wasn't running his family's department store, the rich man with the soft touch from Kalamazoo, Mich., made a second career of philanthropy, which he practiced with disarming spontaneity.

title: Is That Noise a Nuisance? Towns' Ordinances Vary
description: IT'S 7 o'clock on a Sunday morning, and your neighbor's ear-splitting chain saw has given you an involuntary wake-up call. What can you do about it? In many Connecticut towns, your only recourse is to stick the pillow over your head. The police say there's not much they can do.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FRATERNITY GANG RAPE Sex, Brotherhood, and Privilege on Campus. By Peggy Reeves Sanday. New York University, $19.95.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Campus Life pages last Sunday about the Massachusetts Institute of Technology misidentified the student hot line at Wellesley College. It is called the Wellesley College Hot Line.

title: The Kurds Still Need Protectors
description: It's realistic for Kurdish political leaders to negotiate with Saddam Hussein for autonomy inside Iraq. But it's equally realistic for Kurdish refugees, and Washington, to doubt whether the Iraqi dictator will abide by the provisions of any agreement.

title: The Woman of His Dreams
description: IMMORTALITY

title: Still a Literary Smart Aleck
description: YOU'VE HAD YOUR TIME

title: Air Travel
description: To the Editor: My husband and I recently went to New Orleans on Delta flight 303 out of La Guardia Airport. Although the business section appeared to be filled, the main body of the plane was relatively empty. The flight had snack service and no movie (often a blessing).

title: One, Two, Many Dionysiuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Notes
description: A review on page 23 of The Times Book Review today, about "Out of the Channel: The Exxon Valdez Oil Spill in Prince William Sound" by John Keeble, briefly summarizes the settlement reached by the oil company in March with the United States Government and the State of Alaska by saying Exxon had agreed to pay $1.1 billion. On Wednesday, after The Book Review had gone to press, a Federal judge overturned part of the settlement, saying the criminal portion of the penalty, $100 million, was too small, and leaving the entire settlement in doubt.

title: Japan Has Its Jersey Shore, Too
description: IN his famous story, "The Izu Dancer," the Nobel Prize-winning author Yasunari Kawabata wrote of a shy student whose heartstrings were plucked by a tantalizing young girl in a traveling dance troupe. But as the story follows her from town to town, the reader may become as enchanted by the mountainous landscapes and small country inns of the Izu peninsula as by the dancer. It is still easy to see why.

title: Making a Difference; A Turnaround for Mr. Tellep
description: A year ago, Daniel M. Tellep, the chairman and chief executive of the Lockheed Corporation, was a man under siege. Lockheed's earnings were being battered by losses on weapons development programs and Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor, was waging a bitter proxy fight to unseat the board.

title: Spies & Thrillers
description: Remember those great film comedies in which the heroine (Carole Lombard, say) is so much smarter than the dumb teddy-bear male whom she pushes around and gets into terrible trouble before there is a happy ending? There's something of that in THE SUFI FIDDLE by Richard Bulliet (St. Martin's, $15.95).

title: No 'Death Penalty' Set for U.N.L.V.
description: Nevada-Las Vegas does not qualify for the National Collegaite Athletic Association's so-called death penalty for violations in the latest inquiry of the university's basketball program, according to D. Alan Williams, head of the N.C.A.A. committee on infractions.

title: Shrine to the Fanciful In Northern Thailand
description: JADED templegoers in Thailand who arrive at Wat Khaek expecting yet another serene and uncluttered Buddhist shrine built around the simple form of a stupa are in for an exciting surprise.

title: Congress Gets Sentence Guide on Corporate Crime
description: After three years of debate, the United States Sentencing Commission has unanimously adopted the first guidelines for sentencing corporations and other organizations convicted of Federal criminal offenses like fraud, theft or antitrust violations.

title: Headliners; Under Cover
description: To his neighbors, Virgilio Pablo Paz Romero was known as Frank Baez, the owner of a landscaping business in Boynton Beach, Fla., and an active member of the Cuban exile community. Last week, after an anonymous tipster recognized Mr. Paz on the syndicated television show "America's Most Wanted," he was arrested and charged in the 1976 killing of the former Chilean ambassador Orlando Letelier. Mr. Letelier and his American colleague Ronni K. Moffit were killed when their car exploded in northwest Washington. Prosecutors say Mr. Paz is one of two men who had been hired by Chilean secret police to detonate a remote-control bomb. Federal investigators said Mr. Baez has conceded that he is Mr. Paz but they would not say whether he has admitted taking part in the killing. Clint Johnson, who owns a landscaping business alongside the one owned by Mr. Paz, said he was a generally friendly man who seemed to have access to a steady supply of money and a strange habit of regularly changing his name.

title: Sri Lankans Kill 11 Tamils
description: Government troops shot and killed 11 Tamil separatists in two separate attacks in the Trincomalee district of northeastern Sri Lanka, military officials said today. At least two soldiers were killed in a land-mine explosion. More than 6,000 people have been killed since last June when rebels from the minority Tamil community resumed their campaign for an independent homeland in the north and east.

title: Duo Finds Music Can Pave Way For Cupid
description: THE start of the personal relationship between Alexander and Lu Ann Peskanov almost reads like a Russian novel, but without the angst.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Becker Gains Final

title:
DINING OUT;
Charming Inn Keeps Its Standards High
description: IT'S a great pleasure to return to a restaurant that has given satisfaction over the years and to find not only that the standard of the food remains at the same high level, but also that the prices have risen by a relatively small amount.

title: Fluoridation Fight Arrives in Suffolk
description: THE dispute over the fluoridation of water is approaching a turning point in Suffolk County.

title: Making a Wider Missile Treaty Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Visiting Dissident Urges Gorbachev's Ouster
description: Vladimir Bukovsky, one of the toughest of the exiled Soviet dissenters, has returned home, unrepentant as ever and carrying a prescription for a general nationwide strike and the peaceful downfall of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Marine Reservists in Kuwait Steam at 115degrees and Ask Why
description: On Hill 99 somewhere west of this capital, perspiration glistened on Duane McGary's forehead as he crouched over and squeezed into his "hooch," a hole scooped in the sand covered by a heavy green tarpulin.

title: Correction
description: The "About Cars" column last Sunday, about the 1991 Honda Accord station wagon, misstated the designation for two levels of trim. The LX is the base wagon; the EX is the top of the line.

title:
MUSIC;
Concerto Helps Define A Cellist's Identity
description: It was no accident that the cellist Stephen Kates and the New Jersey Youth Symphony's conductor, George Marriner Maull, chose the Saint-Saens Cello Concerto No. 1 in A minor for Mr. Kates's coming appearance as guest soloist with the Youth Symphony. The concerto is one of the best loved among audiences and is generally among the first few concertos that an advanced cello student learns.

title: Avoiding Scarring With Dye Lasers
description: The article "New Lasers Aim Directly at Port-Wine Stains" [ March 24 ] brought to the public's attention the most recent advances in the treatment of port-wine stains with lasers. Multiple published studies from a local institution, the New York University Medical Center, have added important information that might also be of value to your readership and those considering treatment of their port-wine stains.

title: High Medical Costs Hurt Growing Numbers in U.S.
description: Long a gnawing worry of the poor, medical expenses and health insurance are now a source of mounting anxiety for millions of middle-class Americans -- healthy or sick, insured or not.

title: Miss O'Connell Pans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Cushman of Tokyo and Hartland Four Corners, Vt., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Cushman's daughter Jennifer Gunn O'Connell to A. Mark Connelly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Connelly of Yarmouth Port, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: DR. ANDERSON'S GENE MACHINE
description: Robin Marantz Henig's article "Dr. Anderson's Gene Machine" (March 31) is informative on the subject of developments in gene therapy and the medical, political and ethical considerations involved. What is missing from this article, however, is a picture of the desperation of patients suffering from genetic diseases or cancer. For many of these people, genetic engineering may provide a way to live a somewhat normal life. For those who are dying, political and vague ethical concerns will remain secondary to the more urgent quest for better treatments and effective cures. MIRIAM R. BARRY Brooklyn

title: Emily Unterberg Weds J. E. Satloff
description: Emily Jane Unterberg, a daughter of Susan Unterberg and Thomas I. Unterberg, both of New York, was married last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York to James Eliot Satloff, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Satloff of Rochester. Rabbi Aaron M. Petuchowski performed the ceremony.

title: Campus Life: Syracuse; 25 Bright Ideas To Fight Poverty Win Scholarships
description: Victoria Ther oux, an 18-year-old senior from Newburyport High School in Newburyport, Mass., says one solution to poverty begins by reaching out to her peers.

title: Druse Give Up Ammunition
description: Warriors of the Progressive Socialist Party, one of Lebanon's main militias, gave up their firepower today by handing over 300 tons of ammunition to Syrian troops in the mountains southeast of here. Druse fighters delivered 50 trucks loaded with artillery shells, Soviet-built Katyusha rockets and machine-gun cartridges to Syrian officers at two towns in the Shuf mountains, the party's radio station reported.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Chatham Township 468,000 28 Wickham Way 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-half bath, 20-year-old colonial; library, porch, full basement; taxes $5,971. Essex Fells 317,500 6 Cedar Ridge Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 57-year-old Tudor; slate roof, h/w floors, beamed ceilings; taxes $5,255. Mendham 320,000 1 Talmadge Road 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; gourmet kitchen, h/w floors; taxes $5,468. Ramsey 210,000 247 Momar Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial; h/w floors, full basement; taxes $4,319. Summit 235,000 10 Woodfern Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old split level; greenhouse, eat-in kitchen; taxes $4,977. Verona 172,000 15 Lanning Road 3-bedroom, 1.5-bath, 50-year-old colonial; modern kitchen, new heating system; taxes $4,619. OTHER AREAS Peekskill, N.Y. 245,000 15 Gallows Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 4-year-old contemporary; fireplace, deck, eat-in kitchen, loft w/skylights,family room, patio, 1 acre; taxes $5,170. Chester, Conn. 147,000 Brooks Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new Cape Cod; w/w carpeting, dining room, close to school, 1.3 acres; taxes not yet available. Seaford, L.I. 165,000 3722 Somerset Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, solarium, on canal; taxes $1,900.

title: Blue Cross Struggles To Survive
description: BLUE CROSS and Blue Shield of New Jersey, the state's largest health plan, is struggling to survive in the face of declining enrollments and the biggest deficit of any Blue Cross and Blue Shield company in the country. And unless the New Jersey plan erases its deficit by the end of 1992, it could lose its license to use the Blue Cross and Blue Shield name and insignia.

title: POLES FACE ISSUE OF STATE RELIGION
description: In the face of growing anti-clerical sentiment in Poland, the Roman Catholic Church is calling for an end to this nation's constitutional separation of church and state.

title: Headliners; Echoes From an Explosion of Early Life
description: FOR billions of years evolution was stuck in a rut, with algae, bacteria and other one-celled creatures holding dominion over the seas.

title: Slur Accusation Imperils California School District
description: A rural Northern California school district is fighting for its existence over the accusation that it failed to punish a teacher who parents say used derogatory racial terms with black and American Indian students.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ducts from our hot-air furnace pass through the cold basement, and so the longest duct, which goes to the back bedroom, loses a lot of heat on the way and the air is just warm by the time it gets there. I am thinking of wrapping the basement ducts with insulation. What is your opinion?

title: Peter Levi's Greatest Hits
description: THE ART OF POETRY The Oxford Lectures 1984-1989. By Peter Levi. Illustrated. 331 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Nonstop Gaiety in 'Merry Widow'
description: IF audiences crave excess and frivolity when the economy is in crisis, then the Paper Mill Playhouse production of "The Merry Widow" is just the flaming antidote for a current malaise that has been described as fiscal anemia.

title: In Norwalk, a Revival of George Kelly's "Showoff"
description: ONE of the most useful things a local theater can do is come up with a play that was once popular and is now infrequently seen, allowing us simply to have a look at it, uncluttered. That's just what the Rainbow Theater, a professional group, is doing with the revival of "The Showoff" by George Kelly. Seeing it again after a long time leads one to uncover -- or more accurately, rediscover -- a piece of old news: "The Showoff" is one terrific play.

title: Editors' Notes
description: A front-page article in the New Jersey Weekly section today discusses the financial difficulties facing Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey. On Friday, after the section went to press, the health insurer's director, Donald Daniels, resigned. An article on the resignation appears on page 29 of this section.

title: Who Killed Martin Luther King?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 14 about New York City's housing plans rendered information on rents at the Strycker's Bay project incompletely. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development had said that rents would be limited to $50 a room during renovations. But in two years, when a local nonprofit organization takes over, rents will rise to about $90. Further increases will come under rent-stabilization rules.

title: THE SMURFETTE PRINCIPLE
description: I agree with Katha Pollitt that the Smurfette principle indeed does exist, and the token insipid female certainly is not a character I'd like my daughter to emulate (Hers: "The Smurfette Principle," April 7). But she doesn't; instead, she relates to the characters she finds most inspiring and does not categorize them by sex.

title: Campus Life: Skidmore; Ban on Kegs Opposed by Those Of Drinking Age
description: To reduce the amount of alcohol consumed on campus, the Skidmore College administration has banned kegs of beer from Scribner Village, which houses primarily upperclassmen, many of whom are 21 -- the legal drinking age in New York State. The upperclassmen are not pleased.

title: Space Shuttle Is Set to Start 8-Day Military Mission
description: The space shuttle Discovery and its crew of seven astronauts are set to blast off Sunday morning on an eight-day mission for the Defense Department, space agency officials said today.

title: Hamlet, Prince Of Hallmark
description: Television takes some lumps in "I Hate Hamlet," Paul Rudnick's new Broadway play. In this scene, Andrew, best known for playing a rookie surgeon on the canceled TV series "L.A. Medical," is talking with his agent, Gary, and the ghost of John Barrymore. Andrew has left Hollywood for New York to play Hamlet, but Gary has a hot deal for him to star in a series about a high school teacher with superhuman powers.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE COUNTY GARAGES;
County Cars Provoke Strong Emotions
description: CARS cause controversy.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THERE was a time, not all that long ago, when the old waterfront along New Jersey's Hudson River shoreline attracted stars, presidents and glamorous people from all over the world.

title:
RECORDINGS VIEW;
Brazilians Try to Get Beyond the Rain Forest
description: It must be hard for Brazilians to decide whether the wide appeal of their popular music is a blessing or a curse. Though it has given the nation a global presence otherwise difficult to attain, the music's allure has meant that for years Brazil's international identity has been constructed in and by the West's giddy pop markets.

title: Mandela Calls West Europe Racist on Sanctions
description: Nelson Mandela today accused the European Community of racism over its lifting of sanctions against South Africa this month against the wishes of his organization, the African National Congress.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Las Vegas;
Still Growing, But Not as Fast
description: WHILE the influx of new residents continues to be strong in this casino city, the pace of new home sales and construction has faltered.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ducts from our hot-air furnace pass through the cold basement, and so the longest duct, which goes to the back bedroom, loses a lot of heat on the way and the air is just warm by the time it gets there. I am thinking of wrapping the basement ducts with insulation. What is your opinion?

title: Mississippi
description: To the Editor: We just completed four days at the Natchez Spring Pilgrimage and agree with most of Caroline Seebohm's observations ("Enshrining the Old South," Travel, Feb. 10). However, when it came to food, we found the service and quality disappointing at the Pompous Palate, which, incidentally, moved to 409 Franklin Street on March 7, and we were sorry that there was no mention of the Magnolia Grill at 29 Silver Street. Their gumbo is memorable, thick with chicken, shrimp and okra. The catfish briars with mushrooms, shrimp and parmesan cheese enhancing fresh-caught fish seasoned with delectable spices is worth a return to Natchez, and there was perhaps the best bread pudding we have ever tasted. CLAY BARR, JAY BARR Norfolk, Va.

title: Dana LaRue Ward Wed to Kent Strazza
description: Dana LaRue Ward, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Ward of Austin, Tex., was married yesterday at the Presbyterian Theological Seminary Chapel in Austin to Kent Preston Strazza, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Preston Strazza of Bedminster, N.J. The Rev. William Edwards, a Presbyterian minister, performed the cere mony.

title: Can Keith Carradine Lasso the Essence of Will Rogers?
description: He carries a rope. He chews gum. He scratches his head. He says, "Howdy."

title: Cold Cash and Hard Lessons: My First 'Star' Fee
description: The Moscow Philharmonic had a "club department," which coordinated and "sold" assorted programs to various institutions. At the time, in 1968, this was almost the only chance I had to set foot on stage, even briefly. I could, at least, gain experience and earn something -- a trip abroad was still only a dream. Though I had recently received the coveted title "international competition prize-winner," such performers were hardly in short supply.

title: Sunday Outing; Through a Grand Gateway, a Classic Urban Oasis
description: A leisurely stroll across Long Meadow. A brisk hike through the woods to the top of Lookout Hill. Perhaps a picnic in a paddleboat, mingling with the swans.

title: Coins
description: Commemorative coins are a strange lot. Often they are used as a promotional gimmick to sell bullion at a much higher price than the open-market price. And while advertisements allude to eventual profits, many commemoratives barely return their original investment.

title: Ellen M. Jacobs, Executive, Wed
description: Ellen Meredith Jacobs, a daughter of Jason J. Jacobs of New York and Dolores Jacobs of Great Neck, L.I., was married last night in New York to Jeffrey Lehman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Lehman of New York. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Yanks Hope Success Travels a Long Way
description: The first night of the long and winding road trip could have been a minor disaster. Lose, and who knows what kind of mindset the Yankees would have had over the next 12 days? Win, and it might be a promising start to a difficult stretch. Wouldn't it?

title: 3,000 Lesbians Meet in Atlanta to Set Own Agenda
description: Emerging from relatively anonymous but important roles within larger organizations that are concerned about homosexual rights and women's issues, an estimated 3,000 lesbians gathered here this week for what was billed as their first national conference.

title: A Kase for Lerning How to Spell Rite
description: I am riting yu becuz I liek not havin to spel de same weigh as yu haf too in yore papr. It makes tings so mush eeziyer for me too get tru skul soz I can becum a ritch biznesman or enjinere and hav lots of pippl in my offis or factrie. Dey wil make gud stuff -- maybee even for de spaice kapsul. And den I wil tayk kare of my mudder, hoo kant get a job becuz shee had noo math in skul an kant mayk won an won eekwal too. EMILE BERGER Dobbs Ferry

title: World Markets; Hong Kong Shivers to China's Chill
description: June is creeping closer, which is fine for summer buffs. But in the Hong Kong stock market -- one of the top performers in the world this year -- it is not a fun time. June 3 is the deadline for President Bush's decision on extending China's most-favored-nation trade status, and June 4 is the second anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing.

title: Meredith Miller Is Married
description: Meredith Austin Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Halyburton Miller of Birmingham, Mich., was married in Asheville, N.C., last evening to Carroll Arthur Rutter 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutter Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va. The Rev. Cornelius Zabriskie and the Rev. Alexander Viola performed the ceremony at All Souls Episcopal Church. Mrs. Rutter, 24 years old, graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Mr. Rutter, 27, is an associate vice president and bond trader at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. He graduated from Harvard University.

title: Paula Traktman Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Traktman of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Dr. Paula Traktman, and Stephen Alexander Duncan, a son of Alexander Duncan and Nan Duncan of Glasgow. Dr. Traktman is an associate professor of cell biology and microbiology at the Cornell University Medical College. She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University and received a doctorate in biology from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Mr. Duncan graduated from the University of Glasgow and is studying for a doctorate in molecular biology at Oxford University.

title: Corrections
description: An article last week, about a hotel in Ontario known as Langdon Hall, carried an outdated reference to the general manager in some copies. Geoffrey Bray-Cotton is no longer with the hotel, and his post has not been filled.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Airport in Bayport Is a Rare Survivor
description: IT is off the beaten path, and so well hidden on three sides by one-family houses that even many Bayport residents are unaware there is an airport in their midst.

title: Deer on Your Doorstep
description: ON THE LANE THAT WINDS THROUGH FOREST and brush to the headquarters of Philadelphia's Schuylkill Center, it is easy to forget you are within the boundaries of the nation's fourth-largest city. This precious nugget of nature, surviving within easy reach of so much dense human development, makes an admirable setting for one of the country's outstanding, privately financed environmental education centers. As if to underscore the point, a white-tailed buck deer, trailing several does, ambles from a hedgerow and across the parking lot adjoining the office of Richard L. James, Schuylkill's executive director.

title: Hollywood Keeps Striking Out On Real-Life Baseball
description: Baseball movies are older than the World Series, and as Casey Stengel used to say, you can look it up. The first World Series was played in 1903, and according to Prentice Hall's handy reference book, "Everything Baseball," (the book you can look it up in), the first feature-length baseball movie, "The Ball Game," was cranked out in 1902. There's an old Hollywood adage that baseball movies don't sell tickets, but during the last 89 years more than 150 of them have been made, so somebody must be going to see them.

title: Emily Weissman, Lawyer, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Weissman of New York have made known November wedding plans for their daughter Emily Jame Weissman and Dr. Jeffrey Gunzenhauser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gunzenhauser of Cortland, N.Y.

title: Changing Face of a Neighbor To the North
description: "IT'S not the city and it's not the country," Craig Firestone said of Rockland County last week. It was 19 years ago that he moved with his parents from Mount Vernon, a Westchester city on the Bronx border, but he still finds Rockland "a good, centrally located spot."

title: Female Athletes Get No Respect
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Style Makers; Philippe Ambert, Fashion Designer
description: At the Paris fashion showings in March, Philippe Ambert presented a collection that was both sensual and startling, all the more so because it was his first.

title: Tracy Chutorian Plans July Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Abraham M. Chutorian of New York have made known July wedding plans for their daughter Tracy Anne Chutorian and H. Eric Semler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Semler of Portland, Ore.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on April 7 about price cuts at hotels in Hong Kong misstated the reduced nightly room rate at the Grand Hyatt through the end of August. It is $197, not $147. The report also referred imprecisely to the telephone number for the Hong Kong Hotel Association, 369-9577. It is in Hong Kong, not New York.

title:
POP MUSIC;
In Rap's Hometown, an Icy Reception
description: The Marquee's experiment with rap concerts didn't last long. The small club, in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, usually presents alternative-rock bands. But after the Ritz canceled a show featuring the rap groups Run-D.M.C. and EPMD, the Marquee decided to book the acts for two nights earlier this month.

title: The Nation; A More Potent Heroin Makes a Comeback in a New, Needleless Form
description: JUST as the national problem with cocaine and crack seems to be improving there are disturbing signs that heroin, the monster drug of yesteryear, is making a comeback.

title: THE SMURFETTE PRINCIPLE
description: Pollitt's essay appeared the same week that Roseanne Barr withdrew her Saturday morning TV cartoon show, "Little Rosey," from the air because, she said, ABC "said it didn't appeal to boys as much as girls and kept telling me to put more boys into it. It was the only cartoon on TV with a girl heroine, no violence or sexism." LYNN HECHT SCHAFRAN New York, N.Y.

title: Caro vs. Blumenthal
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Strong,But on Hold
TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Good Health/Magazine Part 2

title: The Nation; Is a Little Gun Control Better Than None?
description: THE bill is named for James S. Brady, the Presidential press secretary who was seriously wounded in the 1981 attempt on the life of President Ronald Reagan.

title: Travel Advisory; Stolen Paintings Back in Paris
description: Nine Impressionist paintings that were stolen from the Marmottan Museum in Paris in 1987 by five gunmen are hanging at the museum once more. The paintings, including Monet's "Impression, Soleil Levant" and other masterpieces by Monet, Renoir, Morisot and Sei-Ichi Naruse (a Japanese who lived in France from 1921 to 1923), were recovered on the French island of Corsica last December and went on display this month. They were found in a quiet villa in Corsica where the paintings had been hidden.

title: Court Orders U.S. to Rethink Ban on Marijuana in Therapy
description: A Federal appeals court has ordered the Drug Enforcement Administration to restudy its opposition to the therapeutic use of marijuana.

title: Where Two Back Porches Provide a Front Seat
description: TWO back porches, each part of a neighboring house, face the audience from the stage of the Theater Three production of "Morning's at Seven" in Port Jefferson. In Paul Osborn's classic comedy, the porches are mezzanines from which four sisters view their unfolding family dramas.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRINCE CHARLES returned to the polo field yesterday for the first time since seriously injuring himself in a fall 10 months ago. The Prince shook off jet lag after a nine-hour flight from Brazil after an official visit there. He went straight to the polo field at Aston Down, a short drive from his country home, Higgrove, about 90 miles west of London in Gloucestershire.

title: Tatiana du Plessix Liberman Dies; Leading Designer of Hats Was 84
description: Tatiana du Plessix Liberman, the leading hat designer for Saks Fifth Avenue for 20 years, died yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan and Warren, Conn.

title: Early Returns for a Police Strategy
description: Crimes reported in New York City last year fell by a modest 0.3 percent. But behind that undramatic figure lie others that may give early, intriguing encouragement to Police Commissioner Lee Brown's ideas about crime control.

title: A CUNY Lesson in Goring the Wrong Ox
description: The collapse of the protest that disrupted the City University of New York for three weeks shows clearly that students were grappling with a different universe of forces than in victorious insurrections of the past.

title: Society of Silurians Announces Awards
description: The Society of Silurians, a club of past and present staff members of newspapers and related organizations in the New York area, last week announced winners of its journalism awards.

title: With Spotlight on Kennedys, Folksy Florida Prosecutor Braces for Heat
description: When the news broke almost a month ago that a woman said she had been raped at the Kennedy compound, David H. Bludworth's reaction was as spirited as it was unprintable.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week. Monday Personal Income...March New-Home Sales...March Tuesday Factory Orders...March Farm Prices...April Wednesday Leading Indicators...March Construction Spending...March Thursday None Friday Employment...April

title: Leslie Praver Is Married
description: Leslie B. Praver, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Praver of New York, was married last evening at the Rainbow Room in Rockefeller Center to Romolo de Vecchi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michele de Vecchi of Salerno, Italy. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, the chaplain at the Church Center for the United Nations, officiated at the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Pistons' Defensive Driving Evens Series
description: The Detroit Pistons, playing defense like the team that won National Basketball Association titles the last two seasons, evened their first-round series with Atlanta as Joe Dumars scored 28 points in a 101-88 victory over the Hawks tonight.

title: Elizabeth Johnson, Lawyer, Is Wed To Neil Bradsher, Securities Analyst
description: Elizabeth Martin Johnson and Neal Clifton Bradsher were married yesterday at the Water's Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens. Samuel Morgenstern, a minister of the Universal Harmony Foundation, an interfaith group, performed the civil ceremony.

title: Boston Economy Stymied by Harbor Effort
description: Gary H. Ruping, a builder in suburban Burlington, Mass., recently sold a new $400,000 house, no mean feat with the recession gripping New England. But his buyer was denied an occupancy permit because a court ban is preventing most new occupants from connecting to the local sewer lines.

title: Dinkins Seeks A Budget Talk With All Sides
description: After a grim weekend reviewing painful proposals to slash city services, Mayor David N. Dinkins last night asked labor leaders and city and state officials, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, to join him this week for what city leaders called a crucial meeting to discuss the city's worsening plight.

title: Corrections
description: A table on the Media Business page on April 15 headed "What Was Watched, and What Wasn't," about changes in ratings for network television programs, misstated the 1989-90 average rating for "Wonder Years." It was 19.2 points, not 29.2.

title: Essay; The Decline of the East
description: In the aftermath of victory in the Persian Gulf war, we made three clearly discernible blunders.

title: Love-Triangle Jury Saw Many Holes
description: For Rosalind Serber, a juror in the murder trial of Carolyn Warmus, it all added up. "I felt very comfortable with their evidence," she said of the prosecution's case against the Westchester teacher charged with killing her lover's wife.

title: 63 Trump Condos: the Art of the Bargain
description: Three machine-gun-mouthed auctioneers went into a verbal rat-a-tat-tat yesterday, trying to talk up the prices for more than 60 condominiums at Trump Plaza of the Palm Beaches in Florida. But some of the bidders kept their hands in their pockets, saying they had megadoubts, not megabucks.

title: U.N. Needs a Supernational Supermanager; A Job for Jimmy Carter
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting for a Mill and a Way of Life
description: The ice on the rivers is breaking up, talk of baseball is cropping up in conversations about hockey and final reports are in on the past winter's tests at the nearby General Motors' Cold Weather Development Center.

title: Giants' Last Pick Seeks Last Laugh
description: After being selected in the 12th round of the N.F.L. draft by the Giants last Monday, the first phone call Larry Wanke received was not from the team.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on April 19 and 20 about the Federal job discrimination bill misstated the role of Robert C. Allen, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in negotiations between businesses and civil rights groups. Mr. Allen did not initiate the negotiations; they began in response to an invitation to the Business Roundtable from the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund.

title: Phils' Ready Opted for 'Easy' Toss And Missed Unassisted Triple Play
description: All Randy Ready had to do for an unassisted triple play was stick out his glove and tag Tony Fernandez. Ready didn't even notice.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The creative mind finds inspiration everywhere. For example, PAUL TAYLOR, the choreographer, found the score for his newest dance on top of a garbage heap in Greenwich Village.

title: Marti Swartz Is Married
description: Marti Anne Swartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Swartz of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Tse-Yung Kung, a son of Chi Kung of Woodside, Queens, and the late David Kung. Cantor Morton Friedman performed the ceremony at the Community Church of New York. The bride, 26 years old, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and is a loan officer at First New York Bank for Business in New York. The bridegroom, 30, attended the New York Institute of Technology and is an assistant vice president at First New York Bank for Business.

title: Family Is About to Lose Land After Tangled Deal With U.S.
description: Caroline Sheedy says she will not be at the Woodson County Courthouse in Yates Center, Kan., on Monday when part of her family's grazing land is scheduled to be sold to the highest bidder.

title: 125 Years as an Institution of Dissent
description: A reporter once asked Calvin Trillin to describe The Nation, the left-leaning journal of opinion. "It's a pinko magazine," Mr. Trillin replied. Surely, the reporter prodded, he must have more to say about it than that. "Yes," Mr. Trillin said. "It's a pinko magazine printed on very cheap paper."

title: Charlotte Nichoson Weds D.A. Ackert
description: Charlotte Chen Nichoson and David Andrew Ackert were married yesterday at the White Hart , an inn in Salisbury, Conn., by Donald Warner, a justice of the peace in Sharon, Conn.

title: European Community Aides Back a U.N. Force for Kurds
description: The European Community today endorsed a British proposal to send a United Nations police force to Iraq to show hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees that it is safe to return home.

title: Metro Matters; Cuomo Strategy: Spare the Rich To Help the Poor
description: Both selectively quote Franklin D. Roosevelt and Kevin Phillips's "The Politics of Rich and Poor." They agree that the Federal Government has abandoned urban America. And they express deep concern about the impact of New York State's budget on the poor. Then they part company.

title: Zhulebino Journal; A Village Turns Tough, Not Wanting to Be Eaten
description: A black-and-white official sign marks the beginning of this small village, a cluster of wooden houses with carved shutters and people working away in gardens of tomatoes and onions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: More than 50 veterinarians will assemble in the Waldorf-Astoria at lunchtime on Wednesday to honor Dr. WILLIAM J. KAY, chief of staff at the Animal Medical Center in New York. He is to receive the Bustad Award, named for LEO BUSTAD, a veterinarian who is considered a leader in efforts to further the understanding of relationships between animals and humans.

title: As They Look Past Their Riches, Athletes Are Turning to Religion
description: When Darryl Strawberry announced over the winter that he had experienced a spiritual awakening, he said he had begun tithing, the biblical tradition of giving part of one's income back to God.

title: Chinese Pupils' Good Fortune Is Multiplied
