description: In June, Dai Manju will celebrate a personal triumph: a quiet, pint-sized 14-year-old who is an ace student, she will become the first person in her family ever to graduate from elementary school.

title: Another Official May Determine When Sununu Uses Military Craft
description: White House lawyers are likely to recommend that an official other than John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, determine whether his use of military aircraft is for personal, political or official business, a Bush Administration official said Saturday.

title: What to Do About Springtime Sneezing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Is for Athlete . . . D Is for Degree
description: If you know an athlete who went to Gonzaga University, better get a graduation present ready. If the student went to Texas Southern, it's likely you don't have to bother.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
New Campaigns
description: * Karl Malden, who has starred in commercials for American Express travelers checks for 18 years, is the subject of a 30-second retrospective spot that the company will introduce on Wednesday. The commercial, which celebrates the 100th anniversary of the company's travelers checks, features clips from Mr. Malden's earlier commercials, including his admonitions that "you're about to witness a crime," and "it's dangerous to carry cash." The commercial was created by Ogilvy & Mather.* The Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson introduces its first commercial for the Sherwin-Williams Company today on national television. The spot seeks to win over both do-it-yourself and professional painters with the theme line: "The pros know. Ask Sherwin- Williams."

title: Pushy Knicks Land on the Edge
description: The Knicks worried the Chicago Bulls today, but they couldn't beat them. Now, unless the Knicks win three consecutive games, their disappointing season will end.

title: Abroad at Home; Gains and Losses in the Gulf
description: Two months after the end of the Persian Gulf war we are beginning to have a more realistic sense of its gains and losses, the objectives that were and were not achieved. It is time for a preliminary reckoning.

title: GULAG STILL OPEN, FREED INMATE SAYS
description: A newly released inmate of the infamous Perm Labor Camp 35 has contradicted the Soviet authorities' insistence that the detention center for political dissidents has been closed.

title: Dance in Review
description: 'New Frontiers' Brooklyn Academy of Music 30 Lafayette Avenue (at Ashland Place)

title: More Supervision Is Being Sought For Government-Backed Lenders
description: Administration officials will recommend a sharp increase this week in the supervision of the Government-sponsored companies that help to finance home purchases, higher education and agriculture.

title: Legislator Fears Redistricting Plan Would Dilute Black Vote in Bronx
description: A state legislator from a predominantly black section of the northeast Bronx yesterday sharply criticized a City Council redistricting proposal that would combine his neighborhood with Co-op City, calling it an attempt to dilute black voting strength.

title: Robbing Armored Car, 5 Men Take $225,000
description: Five gunmen held up an armored car in Queens yesterday, taking "in excess of $225,000 in cash," the police said. No one was injured.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Seoul Ousts Aide for Police Brutality
description: In an unusual show of sensitivity to public opinion in a country where the Government has usually quelled dissent with a heavy hand, President Roh Tae Woo dismissed his Interior Minister over the weekend after the police reportedly beat a student protester to death with steel pipes.

title: Medical Technology 'Arms Race' Adds Billions to the Nation's Bills
description: Dr. George M. Segall held up a set of multicolored images of a patient's heart. On one side, the red was not as sharp, indicating that blood flow to that part of the heart was lacking.

title: Knights (Gasp!) Are No. 1
description: As he scurried around the locker room at Giants Stadium on Saturday night, Mouse Davis, the coach of the New York/New Jersey Knights, made a lot of noise.

title: Ilene Silberman Weds P. Clifford LoBrutto
description: Ilene Silberman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max J. Silberman of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married yesterday at the Water Club in New York to Dr. P. Clifford LoBrutto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter LoBrutto of Astoria, Queens. Acting Justice Herbert J. Adlerberg of State Supreme Court officiated.

title: New Orleans Festival Opens
description: The lightning and the rain that washed out the start of this city's annual celebration of jazz gave way Saturday to sticky heat that seemed just right for a feast of purely American music -- rock, jazz, rhythm-and-blues, Cajun, zydeco, gospel, country and more.

title: Salvadorans in Accord on Army Curbs
description: The Salvadoran Government and its main guerrilla opponents agreed late Saturday night on a package of constitutional amendments that would sharply limit the powers of the armed forces and impose broad changes on the nation's judicial system and electoral process.

title: Review/Jazz; 'Rhythm in Mind' Spans the Generations
description: It's unusual for tension and a clash of styles to be stars of a show, but at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday night, they were. "Rhythm in Mind," produced by the young saxophonist Steve Coleman for Carnegie Hall's Centennial Festival, brought together older and younger musicians with little in common stylistically. The elders -- the eccentric tenor saxophonist Von Freeman, the piano be-bop classicist Tommy Flanagan and the drummer Ed Blackwell -- were matched with members of a group Mr. Coleman leads with the bassist Dave Holland. They included the guitarist Kevin Eubanks, the drummer Marvin (Smitty) Smith, Mr. Holland and Kenny Wheeler as guest trumpeter. It should have been a mess, but it wasn't.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about arguments seeking to overturn two recent Supreme Court precedents that barred prosecutors from presenting "victim impact" evidence to juries in death penalty cases misstated Federal law. There is a Federal death penalty law for certain crimes, like air piracy and murders connected to major drug operations.

title: Potential Buyers At the Green Line
description: The names of 20 "legitimate" purchasers for the Islanders have surfaced since John Pickett announced he wanted to sell the former Stanley Cup champion team, says General Manager Bill Torrey.

title: Nureyev Still Fills a House, But Not Always With Glee
description: Rudolf Nureyev's appearance here at the start of what was billed as a farewell British tour proved that the great dancer can still command a full house 30 years after he fled the Soviet Union to fame in the West. But at 53 years of age, the Tatar dancer is apparently finding it hard to conceal the effects of time. His performance left organizers and much of the audience disappointed.

title: A.T.& T.-NCR Talks
description: In their first joint statement since the American Telephone and Telegraph Company began its pursuit of the NCR Corporation five months ago, the companies announced last night that "discussions are continuing and that progress is being made toward reaching an agreement." The companies added that there was "no assurance that any agreement will be reached." Traders and analysts said NCR's board met over the weekend in New York to review A.T.& T.'s $7.48 billion offer for NCR. The companies declined to comment.

title: Battle Lines Blurred as House Fight Over Gun Control Nears
description: Representatives Craig T. James and Bill McCollum are both Republicans, both from Florida and both members of the House Judiciary Committee. They could not disagree more about gun control.

title: An Eagle With Wings Spanning Over Brooklyn
description: Rich Kotite is the new head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles. But on Saturday night he was going to be just one of the guys again, at the Poly Prep class of '61 reunion in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: Saddam Hussein Skips His 54th Birthday Party
description: Iraq celebrated President Saddam Hussein's 54th birthday today, two months to the day after the Persian Gulf fighting ended, but the Iraqi leader himself never showed up for the party.

title: Official Under Fire: Graft or 'a Dry Hole'?
description: This, a story about three friends from Queens, has its beginning in the dusty southwestern Texas town of Sierra Blanca, near the Mexican border.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL WEEKEND American League

title: Review/Ballet; Hurtling Movement as Fanfare In a Ballet Theater 'Sinfonietta'
description: The sound of trumpets resounds in the air and a green field and blue sky beckon. Exhilaratingly, a flock of figures is released into space. These are, in fact, male dancers leaping on stage and they gallop in circles like wild horses.

title: Celtics Meet Their Match In Person And Pacers
description: Larry Bird, superstar, versus Chuck Person, almost superstar. Matched at small forward in games between the Boston Celtics and the Indiana Pacers, they have developed a rivalry that leaves the impression they don't like each other.

title: Tanks Sent Into Croatia
description: The Yugoslav Army sent tanks and other armored vehicles into several villages in the republic of Croatia today to prevent clashes between Serbs and Croats, the country's largest ethnic groups. The Yugoslav press agency said the army blocked roads around Kijevo and other villages in southern Croatia, where republic authorities set up new police stations last week, angering local Serbs. The agency said the situation was extremely tense, but there were no reports of clashes.

title: After 91 Years, British Planning to Discount Books
description: British publishing houses may allow bookstores to start discounting some best sellers as early as this summer, for the first time this century, leading booksellers and publishers say.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Rouses Itself
description: After almost two years of struggling with its previous investments as the "junk bond" market collapsed, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the giant buyout firm that became a corporate titan in the 1980's, appears to be back on a roll.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Kirshenbaum Awarded Pergament Account
description: Pergament Home Centers, based in Melville, L.I., has awarded its $9 million broadcast advertising account to Kirshenbaum & Bond, a New York agency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about press issues arising from The Times's reporting about the Palm Beach rape complainant misidentified Michael G. Gartner in some editions. He is the president of NBC News, not of the entire network.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: Bridge
description: In all major championships the American Contract Bridge League now provides bidding boxes, which are popular with the experts. Instead of announcing bids orally, the player takes a card out of a box announcing "one heart," or whatever he wishes, and puts it face up on the table in front of him.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 28, 1991: MONDAY Allied-Signal Inc Kennametal Inc Armstrong World Inds Nalco Chem Co CSX Corp Philadelphia Elec Co Golden West Finl Philadelphia Subn Corp Howell Corp TUESDAY American Brands Inc Oryx Energy Co Bausch & Lomb Inc Portland Gen Corp Birmingham Stl Corp Sotheby Hldgs Inc Black & Decker Corp Stride Rite Corp Carpenter Technology USX Corp Cooper Inds Wendys Intl Inc McDonald & Co Invts Inc WEDNESDAY Albany Intl Corp Northwestern Pub Svc Co American Gen Corp Peoples Energy Corp Carlisle Cos Inc Phelps Dodge Corp Fleming Cos Inc Premark Intl Inc General Housewares Thomas & Betts Corp Hanna M A Co Utilicorp Utd Inc Ingersolld Rand Corp Williams Cos Inspiration Res Corp THURSDAY Apache Corp Delta Woodside Inds Avemco Corp Gannett Inc Bemis Inc MDU Res Group Inc Coachmen Inds Inc Universal Corp VA CPI Corp FRIDAY Atlanta Gas Lt Co State Mut Secs Tr Broad Inc Temple-Inland Inc Morrison Knudsen Corp Univar Corp Pittston Co West Inc Ryder Sys Inc

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Valdez Mayor In Exxon Ads
description: The Mayor of Valdez will appear in a series of television commercials for the Exxon Corporation that say Prince William Sound is nearly restored after the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill.

title: Bo Knows Better
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Needs a Supernational Supermanager
description: To the Editor:

title: Madison Square Garden Journal; Attention, Toby Tylers: Joining Circus Isn't Easy
description: Addled by algebra? Depressed because your parents fail to appreciate the bone-rattling nuances of Def Leppard at 120 decibels? You'll show them -- you'll run away and join the circus, right?

title: Emily Wiener Is Married
description: Emily Joan Wiener, a daughter of Janet de Winter of Plandome, L.I., and the late Norman J. Wiener, was married in Chicago yesterday to Peter Dunham Sandquist, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elroy C. Sandquist Jr. of Chicago. Rabbi Howard Berman performed the ceremony at the Cafe Brauer. The bride, 29 years old, graduated from the University of Arizona and owns an interior design company in Chicago. Mr. Sandquist, 33, is a commodities trader at the Chicago Board of Trade. He is a Brown University graduate.

title: Plea by U.S. On Rate Cut Is Rejected
description: The world's largest industrial nations considered and rejected today a Bush Administration request that Europe, and in particular Germany, lower interest rates. But they agreed to consider the request in the future.

title: Shostakovich Leaves New Orleans Symphony
description: Maxim Shostakovich has resigned as the New Orleans Symphony's music director, saying he has not been paid for the past season.

title: INSIDE
description: Salvadoran Accord Reached The Government of El Salvador and its main guerrilla opponents agreed on constitutional amendments, but not on a cease-fire. Page A3.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: COMMON STOCK * Readicare Inc., Irvine, Calif., an operator of workers' compensation outpatient medical and rehabilitation centers, has filed for an offering of 1.75 million common shares. * Suprema Specialties Inc., Paterson, N.J., a processor and marketing of cheese products, is offering one million common shares through J. W. Charles Securities Corp.

title: Korean Ordained in Baptist Church in Queens
description: A largely black congregation in Queens yesterday opened their church doors and their hearts in a welcome for the ordination of a new minister -- a Korean-American -- at a time when tensions between Korean-Americans and blacks in New York City have been on the rise.

title: Article 959691 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Orders for Machine Tools Fell in March
description: New orders for American-made machine tools fell sharply in March, according to a report scheduled to be released on Monday.

title: As Kurds Limp Back In, Ghost Town Relives '88
description: Once a Christian and Kurdish mountain village, Kani Masi today is inhabited by many but home to no one.

title: Kessler of Heat Turns Up Safe
description: Miami Heat forward Alec Kessler turned up safe tonight after his failure to check in with his family during a boating trip in the Bahamas prompted a two-day search by the Coast Guard. Kessler called his fiancee on a cellular phone to say he was in the Abaco Islands and in no danger.

title: Hold That Line? Not for Argonauts
description: To many, the deal still doesn't make sense. Why would Bruce McNall, the acquisitive owner of the Toronto Argonauts, pay Raghib (Rocket) Ismail more than he pays the rest of the team combined?

title: Violence Erupts After Race
description: The police used tear gas today when as many as 2,000 people refused to heed calls to disperse after an annual canoe race. Sixty-five people were arrested. When bars downtown closed, the people poured into the streets and then refused to move on, the police said. Police armed with batons used tear gas to clear the area. The Coon Creek Canoe Races, which take place about 13 miles from here, have been marked by violence for the last two years.

title: Networks in a Quandary With Earlier Reruns
description: Over the next four weeks, television viewers will see mostly original episodes of their favorite series, a kind of springtime treat offered by the three broadcast networks.

title: No. 938 Was Slow in Arriving, but Henderson Ties Brock's Stolen-Base Record
description: Rickey Henderson got his long-awaited 938th stolen base today, tying the career record set by Lou Brock 12 years ago, as Brock watched from the stands among 40,174 spectators in the Oakland Coliseum. After being hit by a pitch on a 2-2 count with one out in the sixth inning, with Jeff Robinson pitching and Lance Parrish catching for the California Angels, Henderson stole second by a wide margin.

title: Turkish Novel as Antidote for East-West Despair
description: The White Castle By Orhan Pamuk Translated by Victoria Holbrook. 161 pages. George Braziller . $17.50.

title: Beazer's Growing U.S. Following
description: IF they love you abroad, but not at home, why not move? That, in essence, is the idea that seems to have occurred to Brian Beazer, the 56-year-old chairman of Beazer P.L.C., a British home-building company.

title: Dance in Review
description: 'Coppelia' American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: BMW-Rolls Venture
description: BMW of Germany and Rolls-Royce of Britain are pumping $600 million into the production of a new generation of civilian aircraft engines by 1996, the chairman of the joint company said Friday. Albert Schneider, BMW/Rolls-Royce G.m.b.H.'s chairman, said he was aiming for annual sales of around $600 million by the year 2000, with the new engines bringing in 60 percent of sales. The venture hopes to capture a share of the growing market for medium-sized passenger aircraft, which are increasingly popular as commuter planes on short routes.

title: Saudi General Sees No Need For Big American Presence
description: A senior Saudi official says he does not think that Saudi Arabia would need or want a larger American military presence than it had before the Persian Gulf war. He also says no decision has been made about whether the United States would be permitted to store heavy military equipment in the kingdom.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "If Jesus were on the field, He'd be pitching inside and breaking up double plays." --Tim Burke of the Montreal Expos. [ C7:2. ]

title: Winnie Mandela Loses Women's League Vote
description: Winnie Mandela, the wife of Nelson Mandela, has suffered a major political setback by failing in a bid for the presidency of the African National Congress Women's League.

title: Job Data Are Not Expected To Affect Fed Rein on Rates
description: Ordinarily, most of the focus of the credit markets this week would be on the Government's report on April employment for a sign of the nation's economic condition. The report is scheduled to be released Friday morning.

title: Equity Issues for the Week
description: The following equity offerings are expected this week: Affiliated Publications Inc., 2.24 million common shares. First Boston Corp.

title: Israelis Retreat on Peace Conference
description: The Israeli Government today retracted the agreement Foreign Minister David Levy made with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d last week on the format for regional peace talks.

title: Review/Television; Columbo Confronts a Literally Criminal Lawyer
description: Certain television oldies can be remarkably dependable goodies. The star is familiar; the formula is unvarying; the production offers the equivalent of a good read, nothing very provocative but consistently diverting. Among detective shows, for instance, there is "Murder, She Wrote" on CBS , anchored securely to Angela Lansbury's performance every Sunday evening. And in the same genre, there is the even more remarkable run of "Columbo" and Peter Falk, now taking the form of periodic two-hour movies on ABC . Tonight at 9: "Columbo and the Murder of a Rock Star."

title: Derby, Minus Stars, a Wide-Open Affair
description: "Everybody," said Angel Cordero Jr., "wants a piece of Kentucky."

title: Following Ted and Joe in the Lineup . . .
description: This is a terrific year for baseball anniversaries. The most celebrated is the 50th of the dual golden year of Joe DiMaggio (56-game hitting streak) and Ted Williams (.406 for the season).

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The tentative schedule of Treasury financings for this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed on Thursday by an auction of one-year bills. The Treasury is also expected to announce this week the terms for the coming quarterly refunding.

title: Trainload of Tainted Soil Is to Be Sent to Utah Site
description: A trainload of 2,400 tons of contaminated soil, rejected by landfills in at least three states, is on its way to Utah for disposal, a Tennessee official said today.

title: North Stars, Oilers Advance
description: Chris Dahlquist's first-ever playoff goal 11 seconds into the third period of a scoreless game tonight helped lift the Minnesota North Stars into the Stanley Cup semifinals for the first time since 1984 with a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Mom-to-Be Tells What Is to Be
description: It's a boy for Chris Evert. Or will be. A sonogram has revealed that the former tennis champion, 36 years old, is carrying a son. He is expected in early October.

title: Calling Speaker Foley
description: "This is not a popular subject with members," says House Speaker Thomas Foley. "They're not pounding the doors down to change the campaign finance laws." Few would dispute that assessment, and, indeed, there's no mystery why members cling to a system that gives incumbents a huge fund-raising advantage, smothers most meaningful competition and lets them stash leftover money for future races. Still, it's hard to excuse Speaker Foley's reluctance to stake out higher ground.

title: Kansas Town Giving Its Best To Aid Victims
description: Much of the debris that used to be Pat Murphy's life was stacked in front of the foundation of what used to be her home.

title: Fears on Cut In U.S. Arms; Shrinking of Industry Is Called Dangerous
description: As Pentagon budgets decline sharply, every big weapons contract takes on added importance for military contractors. But few contracts define the stakes so starkly as the selection the Navy will make soon of a company to build its next attack submarine.

title: This Fighter Will Bust the Budget
description: Peace dividend? The Air Force is acting as if it were about to cash in a war dividend. Last year the Pentagon and Congress ruled out taking advantage of a receding Soviet threat to reap sizable savings from defense. Instead, they agreed to hold the defense budget at current levels for three years.

title: U.S. Is Investigating Baxter
description: The Justice Department is investigating allegations that a hospital supplier, Baxter International Inc., broke a Federal law against complying with an Arab boycott of Israel.

title: 2 Welcomes For Veterans Of Gulf War
description: Amid cheers and tears, the Harlem Hellfighters received a rousing welcome yesterday afternoon upon their return from the Persian Gulf war, while Nassau County held a homecoming for its returning troops complete with brass bands and fluttering flags.

title: Mets Receive Thrashing As Pirates Score 7 Runs In First Two Innings
description: His starting pitcher having put his team in a hole too deep to climb out of for the second straight day, Bud Harrelson yesterday had to grin and bear a 7-3 loss to the Pittburgh Pirates and a pitcher named Smiley.

title: Turkish First Lady in Politics
description: Turkey's First Lady, Semra Ozal, formally entered politics today, winning leadership of the governing Motherland Party's Istanbul branch. The semi-official Anatolian News Agency said Mrs. Ozal, the wife of President Turgut Ozal, won 351 of the 646 votes cast. Her opponent was Talat Yilmaz, the candidate of the party's conservatives. The party postponed the vote until today after a session on March 4 dissolved into chaos, with fistfights and scuffles among delegates.

title: Auctions Change the Way Writers and Agents Think
description: Publishers say there have been very few good proposals for nonfiction books over the last few months. So when an idea from Mikal Gilmore, the brother of the executed murderer Gary Gilmore, arrived on their desks recently, they all sat up, took note and plunged into the auction.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company's purchase of some publications from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation misstated the status of The Racing Times, a newspaper owned by Robert Maxwell. The Racing Times began publication this month.

title: Pat Golden, 48, Artist And Equestrian, Dies
description: Patricia Golden Levine, an artist known professionally as Pat Golden, died on Friday at her home in Chevy Chase, Md. She was 48 years old and also had an estate in Rappahannock County, Va.

title: Dance in Review
description: American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Group Sues Over Montana Bear Hunt, Calling Killings Cruel
description: For a hunter from Vermont it was the thrill of a lifetime. After creeping through the brush in the rugged mountains of west-central Montana, he surprised and shot a 600-pound grizzly bear, one of the largest ever taken.

title: Father of Eurodollars Becoming a TV Star
description: As prime-time subjects go, the creation of the Eurodollar just does not have the sex appeal of "Dallas."

title: 2 Are Slain and 2 Wounded By Gunmen in Store Holdup
description: During what the police termed a "vicious" robbery, two men were shot to death and two seriously wounded in a grocery store in Brooklyn late Saturday night.

title: Senate's Too Smart to O.K. Price Fixing
description: To the Editor:

title: Layoff Is Costly For Cary
description: There was a half-eaten piece of chicken in front of Chuck Cary and a look of frustration on his face. In a sense, he wore it for all of his Yankee teammates today.

title: Shuttle's Crew Members: 5 Are on First Space Trip
description: Michael L. Coats Mission Commander

title: STRIKE PERMEATES LIFE IN MONTANA
description: Motorists can zip along Montana's highways recklessly with little fear of tickets, since state troopers are among the 4,500 state workers who walked off their jobs last week in a pay dispute.

title: U.S. PLAN TO BURN CHEMICAL WEAPONS STIRS PUBLIC FEAR
description: Hampered by flaws in design and operation, the Army's program to incinerate the nation's enormous stockpile of chemical weapons is falling years behind schedule, experiencing huge cost increases and stirring public protests in six states and the South Pacific.

title: From Being a Failure at Ballet To a Success in 'Miss Saigon'
description: In the 1970's, Hinton Battle was taking classes at New York City Ballet. He had studied at the School of American Ballet, had already made his Broadway debut at age 16 as the scarecrow in "The Wiz" and was hoping to dance for the master, George Balanchine.

title: Our Saigon Friends Still Need Help
description: Sixteen years ago tomorrow, North Vietnamese tanks rolled into Saigon, ending a struggling democracy and handing the U.S. its most complete international humiliation. It is painful to recall how many Americans welcomed South Vietnam's fall, believing the Communists' war effort was driven more by a desire for national unification than by totalitarian ideology.

title: QuestionBox
description: This column, which usually responds to questions submitted by readers, is serving today as an Answer Box for the multiple-choice Baseball Trivia Quiz that appeared in The Times on Sunday, April 7.

title: City College Set For Resumption Of Some Classes
description: Student protesters at City College and Hunter College met with university officials yesterday to discuss ending their sit-ins, and officials at City College announced that about a third of classes there would resume tomorrow.

title: Saban's Back; Foster in Touch
description: At the age of 69, Lou Saban is back. He has held more than 25 jobs in athletics, coaching three professional football teams and at seven colleges and at least two high schools. Now he has landed in Peru (State College, Nebraska). He quit his last job two years ago after helping a South Carolina high school end a losing streak at 21 games. . . . Baseball's last 50-home-run hitter before Detroit's Cecil Fielder, George Foster, is no longer part of Cincinnati's Big Red Machine. He has a more modest role with Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn., where he is an assistant baseball coach.

title: U.N. Needs a Supernational Supermanager; A Short List
description: To the Editor:

title: Kara Mazur Wed To M.A. Battinelli
description: Kara Susan Mazur, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Mazur of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Albert Battinelli, a son of Paula Smith of Nahant, Mass., and Cosmo Battinelli of Winchester, Mass. Justice Howard R. Silver of State Supreme Court officiated at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Stormin' Norman In Obscurity
description: Andy Grant, the president of the 67-year-old Hambletonian Society and a leading figure in harness racing, has a sense of American history. So he applied to the United States Trotting Association to name one of his New Jersey-bred yearlings Stormin' Norman, after Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who was commander of the United States and allied forces in the Persian Gulf war.

title: The Long Arm of the Bulls Is in Touch With His Team
description: THE Chicago Bulls are a team of long arms; hardly the shortest pair of them is that attached to their coach, Phil Jackson. Long and angular at 6 feet 9 inches, Jackson, moving at times like an ambulatory Tinker Toy, may be seen in front of the Bulls bench, striding or standing, sometimes crossing his lengthy arms in contemplation, sometimes unfolding them to demonstrate a point to a player, or remonstrate to a referee.

title: Review/Cabaret; Trying English Humor In an American Setting
description: When the English drag comedian Julian Clary describes his humor as working on "smutty innuendo," his tone is haughtily genteel, his look clownishly chic. Dressed in a shiny stars-and-stripes patterned suit whose shoulders jut up like skyscrapers, he recalls David Bowie in his most flamboyantly androgynous phase. With his spiky post-punk haircut and heavily lined eyes, he also bears a striking resemblance to Julia Phillips as photographed on the jacket of her best-selling Hollywood memoir, "You'll Never Eat Lunch in This Town Again."

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER U.S. Women Advance To Finals in China

title: New York Constitution Protects Courts From Governor's Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. READY TO TAKE U.S. REFUGEE ROLE
description: United Nations officials met with top American military officers at the growing Kurdish refugee camp here today in the first step toward taking over responsibility from American troops.

title: Shuttle Is Off at Last, on 8-Day Military Mission Without Secrecy
description: The space shuttle Discovery thundered into a nearly cloudless sky today on the first military mission by a winged spaceship in which there is little secrecy.

title: Maradona Out Of Jail on Bail
description: Diego Maradona was charged today with possession and distribution of drugs and released from jail on $20,000 bond.

title: London Opera Is Losing Its Leaders; Lack of Government Aid Is Blamed
description: The leading opera houses of the British capital are in turmoil, and they place much of the blame on years of insufficient support by the Government.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Network Sales Executive In New Role After 25 Years
description: JERRY DOMINUS, the vice president of sales at CBS for seven years, had an unusual lunch partner recently -- Larry Hoffner, who runs sales at NBC.

title: Big Step in Basketball Toward a Bigger Dream
description: For six days of basketball trials and tryouts at the Gauchos Gym in the South Bronx, Jason Holloway was a 5-foot-10-inch Midget on a nervous, bouncing quest.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 3 P.M. DISARMAMENT COMMISSION -- 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Trade Show in Kuwait
description: At least 60 United States companies will be chosen to exhibit needed products from June 3 to 9 at the first trade show in Kuwait since the end of the Persian Gulf war, the Commerce Department said last week. The department said businesses wishing to participate must apply by May 8 to the exhibition project office in Commerce Room H-4043 or telephone 202-377-2254 for applications and related material.

title: U.S. Weighs New Aid to Iran
description: The White House said it was considering further aid to Iran for 1.5 million Kurdish refugees camped on the Iranian border with Iraq. Page A11.

title: A Decade Into the AIDS Epidemic, The TV Networks Are Still Nervous
description: Julie Andrews, dressed in an elegant white blouse, black slacks and black beaded jacket, is the very image of a high-powered, immaculately tailored executive. Ann-Margret, in a platinum-blond bouffant wig, garish purple slacks and shawl, cuts a vividly contrasting figure. When these two polar opposites meet in a movie, there are sure to be fireworks. "We hate each other on sight," Miss Andrews said.

title: Critic's Notebook; Why Is Doris Humphrey a Lost Choreographer?
description: In the beginning, there was Isadora Duncan, who threw over the ballet barre, kicked off her shoes and wriggled out of her corset to a new, instinctual form of danced self-expression. In 1906, less than a decade after Duncan's earliest efforts, Ruth St. Denis began to cast a shadow with exotic, perfumed solos that established her reputation as a magical artist and strong-willed professional. In St. Denis's wake came Doris Humphrey and Martha Graham, progeny who were as different from each other as they were from her.

title: Money Halted For British Sky
description: Reed International P.L.C. said today that it would not provide more money to British Sky Broadcasting P.L.C., the money-losing satellite television network in which it holds a 10.4 percent stake.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday about Jerry Dominus's move from CBS to J. Walter Thompson misidentified the office in which he was pictured. It was his old office at CBS.

title: Treasuries Lower in Light Day
description: Treasury securities traders marked time yesterday, awaiting the terms of next week's quarterly refunding. Tomorrow afternoon, the Treasury is expected to announce the amount of notes and bonds it plans to auction on May 7-9.

title: Music in Review
description: Evening of Chamber Music Weill Recital Hall

title: Consolidated Selects A New Chief Executive
description: Donald E. Moffitt, who came out of retirement in June to help a turnaround effort at Consolidated Freightways Inc., was named president and chief executive yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: The "On Stage, and Off" column in Weekend last Nov. 10 misstated the circumstances under which William Lindsay Gresham, a writer, committed suicide. His widow, Renee Gresham, informed The Times in February that he killed himself in 1962 because he was dying of cancer, not because of the breakup of his previous marriage, to the poet Joy Davidman, nine years earlier. This correction was delayed by a succession of editing errors.

title: Asbestos Trial Starts
description: Jury selection began today in a trial consolidating 9,032 damage claims against 10 makers of asbestos.

title: It's Not So Difficult to Win On the Road in the Playoffs
description: The National Basketball Association has always been noted as a league where the home club has a major edge. So it's no surprise that the eight teams with the home-court advantage in the opening round of the playoffs won 82 percent of their regular-season games (269-59).

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "When I walk into a store, they don't see my Princeton undergraduate degree, my Harvard law degree, my associate law status. They see a black man." -- Lawrence Otis Graham, a 28-year-old New York lawyer. [ A14:5. ]

title: Who Owns Stolen Artifact? College Confronts a Museum
description: A small college and a big museum are in a tense tug of war over the ownership of a rare piece of Egyptian art stolen more than a decade ago. The case -- which may involve a murder -- raises an important legal question about who owns a stolen article later acquired in good faith.

title: Lantern Festival
description: A seemingly innocuous poem appeared in The People's Daily in Beijing on March 20. The poem has become a cause celebre, for in it was a diagonal acrostic that read, literally, "Li Peng step down; mollify the people's anger."

title: Infant Girl's Body Is Found In Bag on a Brooklyn Street
description: The body of a newborn infant was found stuffed in a yellow plastic bag on a street in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: Murphy Powers Phillies to Third Straight
description: Dale Murphy drove in three runs with a two-run homer and a sacrifice fly as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the San Diego Padres, 7-2, tonight for their third victory in a row.

title: China Still Detains Dissidents Without Trials
description: More than a month after the Chinese Government announced that trials of democracy advocates were "basically completed," dozens of dissidents are still being detained without trial -- people like Han Dongfang, 27 years old, a railway worker who tried to organize an independent labor union during the 1989 Tiananmen protests.

title: Penny Stock Broker Barred
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that it had expelled First Alliance Securities Inc. in Atlanta from the securities business for charging exorbitant prices -- sometimes 3,300 percent above market -- for penny stocks.

title: Surgery for Janssens
description: The Rangers announced yesterday that center Mark Janssens had undergone successful surgery on his left shoulder at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Award Upheld
description: A Federal judge in Los Angeles has upheld a $540,000 jury award to Hall of Famer Joe Morgan, who sued a policeman for roughing him up three years ago at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Samuel Berman, 80, Former Assemblyman
description: Samuel Berman, a Brooklyn Democratic district leader and former New York State Assemblyman, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Beyond Buzzwords in Education
description: With his education plan, President Bush has joined the political left and right in promoting choice -- the right of parents to choose their children's school -- as the solution to building better schools. Choice is a powerful value in a democratic society. It engages the consumer, results in more commitment on the provider's part and creates a competitive tension useful in the public sector.

title: Messages From Managua
description: The first time I saw Nicaragua it was under Sandinista rule and from the moment I arrived I knew exactly where I was. I was back in Eastern Europe during the hard, mean days of Communism -- Poland with palm trees.

title: Do Mets Hurt as Carreon Gets More Splinters Than Cuts?
description: Mark Carreon, according to a reliable Mets source who is not named Mark Carreon, right now takes a back seat to no one on the team as a hitter. The question is: how long must he take a seat on the bench?

title: U.S. Airlines Get Warning
description: The Transportation Secretary said today that if United States airlines fail to control their costs they could find Congress writing a labor agreement for them as it did recently for the railroads.

title: In India, the Star of the Video Is the Candidate
description: The truck lurches down a narrow dirt road, flanked by scampering packs of excited children. The van's doors open, revealing a 100-inch screen. As curious people gather in the dark silence of a village night, the entertainment rolls. Songs, dances and a dizzying array of special effects on the giant screen deliver a basic message: Vote for me. A politician has come to town -- on video.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League

title: When Blacks Shop, Bias Often Accompanies Sale
description: Last month, Cedric Holloway, a 20-year-old chef's helper, decided to invest $1,000 of his savings in a certificate of deposit or money-market account.

title: Anger at Florio Is Less, But Forgiveness Is Slow
description: Assemblyman James E. McGreevey often walks down Main Street in this town of middle-income residents, where tax increases and the state's Democratic Governor sent voters into a fury last year.

title: Odds Are Getting Longer as Derby Day Nears
description: Meadow Star won't be there, trying to become the fourth filly in 117 years to win the Kentucky Derby. Dinard won't be there, trying to extend the recent success of horses from California. Cahill Road won't be there, trying to make history by winning the big race the year after it was won by his full brother, Unbridled.

title: Stocks Flat in Tokyo
description: Stock prices were virtually unchanged here today after rising slightly in the morning. By the end of the afternoon trading session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues had lost 12.43 points, or just five-hundredths of a percent, to close at 26,111.25. Trading was described as extremely thin.

title: 36 Women Pregnant Aboard a Navy Ship That Served in Gulf
description: Thirty-six crew members of the supply ship Acadia were pregnant and had to be transferred during the ship's deployment to the Persian Gulf, naval officials say.

title: Bridge
description: Benito Garozzo, the Italian world champion who lives in Palm Beach, Fla., has always favored attacking leads from a king against small slam contracts when dummy is likely to have a long suit. The theory is that it can be vital to build up a trick in the suit quickly if partner has the queen. If he does not, it may not matter, for the declarer's losers may disappear on dummy's long suit whatever the lead.

title: De Klerk Sees Danger of Civil War
description: President F. W. de Klerk warned today that political violence was polarizing South Africa and could end up plunging the nation into civil war.

title: A Child's-Eye View Of Microscopic Realms
description: FOR children whose contacts with microbes have been limited to sore throats and stomachaches, the New York Hall of Science is offering a treat: a new kind of microscope that puts on spectacular live shows starring microscopic denizens of pond water, cheese mold and breweries.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Quake Kills 30 A powerful earthquake jolted the mountainous heart of Soviet Georgia, killing at least 30 people, demolishing buildings and cutting several villages off from communications. Page A3. The First Pressing Archeologists say they have evidence that the first wine dates from 3500 B.C., and a robust vintage it must have been. Science Times, page C1. Campeau Chains Offer Deal The bankrupt chains once controlled by Robert Campeau filed a reorganization plan that calls for suppliers to get stock in a new company. Page D1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Jail Officials Haggle Over Transfer Delays
description: New York State and City prison officials skirmished yesterday over who is responsible for delays in transferring about 1,000 sentenced inmates from city jails to state prisons.

title: Jackson Healing
description: A physician who examined BO JACKSON in Birmingham, Ala., yesterday said the athlete was making significant recovery from a hip injury but shouldn't get rid of his crutches yet.

title: Chip Maker's New President
description: Micron Technology Inc., a maker of computer memory chips based in Boise, Idaho, appointed a new president and chief operating officer today in a reorganization aimed at strengthening the company's research and development and manufacturing efforts.

title: Syria and Iran Agree Militias Can Remain in Parts of Lebanon
description: After three days of talks here, the leaders of Syria and Iran agreed today that armed, Iranian-backed forces could remain in southern Lebanon near an Israeli-controlled border enclave and in the eastern Bekaa region, Iranian officials said.

title: Music in Review
description: Duo Volodarsky Alice Tully Hall

title: CHRONICLE
description: BILLY DEE WILLIAMS is usually associated with stage and film roles, but he is a painter, too, and yesterday he unveiled his latest work: a portrait of the first Avon lady.

title: Standard & Poor's Cuts Rating of Issue For New York City
description: As New York City prepared to sell $1.2 billion in short-term notes to help pay its bills, Standard & Poor's, a major rating agency, yesterday downgraded the notes to its lowest investment grading -- and the lowest level of any municipal notes.

title: Topics of The Times; Still the Big Apple
description: Over a cup of coffee the other day with an out-of-town guest, a New York City woman was just getting started on the usual litany of local negatives. "The filth and the violence are making it unlivable," she was saying. "And with the budget crisis, it can only get worse. Everyone I know is thinking about moving out."

title: Howard Lanin Dies; Band Leader Was 93
description: Howard Lanin, a band leader whose orchestra played for many well-known families, died on Friday at Jefferson Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 93 years old.

title: For Court Cameras, the Trial's Over
description: Cameras, once forbidden in courtrooms across the land, have become a fixture in all but a few states. New York State, a hub of celebrated trials, is nearing the end of more than three years of experimenting with court photography. The cameras have already passed the test. Now the Legislature needs to make them a permanent part of state justice.

title: Lee Wulff, 86, an Outdoorsman Who Transformed Sport Fishing
description: Lee Wulff, one of the world's best known and most respected sports fishermen, as well as an author, lecturer, artist and film maker, died Sunday when the light plane he was flying crashed into a wooded hillside near Hancock, N.Y. He was 86 years old.

title: Shuttle Studies Aurora; Recorders Still Inactive
description: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery observed eerie waves of light above the horizon in a "Star Wars" experiment today, and ground controllers struggled to fix data recorders needed for other tests.

title: Costly Special Classes Serving Many With Minimal Needs
description: Tens of thousands of children with no identifiable physical or neurological defects are being shunted into expensive programs for the handicapped, programs established with the best of intentions for children with specific disabilities but now often used for children who simply need counseling and smaller classes.

title: Ashland Oil Plans to Buy Permian
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said today that it would purchase the Permian Corporation, one of the nation's largest marketers of crude oil, in a deal valued at almost $250 million.

title: Review/Television; The Financial Burden of Old Age
description: For more and more people, the golden years do not glitter. They bring sickness, separation and, as tonight's somber edition of "Frontline" reports, impoverishment. "Who Pays for Mom and Dad?," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, brings out the emotional and economic pain of providing long-term care for old people.

title: Daring Rescue Attempt Ends Tragically for Boy
description: James Diodato reacted within seconds yesterday, stripped and jumped into the swirling, cold waters under the Verrazano Narrows Bridge. For more than half an hour, the 23-year-old former Marine tried to reach a 14-year-old boy flailing against the current and screaming, "Help me, I'm going to die."

title: Costs of Drug Research Seen as Overestimated
description: Government economists said in a draft report circulating in Washington that the estimates of research costs frequently cited by spokesmen for drug companies were too high and based on information that could not be independently substantiated. The report questions the pharmaceutical industry's main justification for the high prices of many new drugs.

title: Steinbrenner Contradicts Aide on Payment
description: The reasoning behind George Steinbrenner's $40,000 payment to Howard Spira occupied much of Steinbrenner's third and last day of testimony in Spira's extortion trial yesterday as the Yankee owner contradicted statements by his chief aide.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Accounts
description: * Delonghi America, an Italian maker of home appliances, to Stogel Cos., a New York agency, for consumer and trade advertising in the United States. Billings are estimated at $2 million.* PPG Industries to Wyse Advertising, Cleveland, for trade advertising for its Olympic professional stain and paint products. Billings were not disclosed.* Physicians Health Services, a health maintenance organization, to KZS/Ely Group, Southport, Conn., an affiliate of Kopf Zimmermann Schultheis. Billings are in excess of $1 million.

title: Freeing Kuwait Didn't Justify Destroying Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: The Key Role of Smell In an Infant's Bonding
description: FOR a newborn infant, whose fuzzy vision registers only the most obtuse rendering of its mother, it is not love at first sight, but love at first scent.

title: Our Towns
description: The idea didn't come to Martha Fox in a dream or a blinding flash or anything like that. In fact, when some future newspaper reporters go to write the political profile of Ms. Fox, the new Governor of New York who won a resounding victory on a platform of populist environmentalism, they will probably trace the plan to the back seat of the Fox family's '89 Oldsmobile. That's where Martha always sat and looked out the window on the way home from Little League practice way back when.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Saturday about Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent's decision to uphold the suspension of Roger Clemens misattributed comments about an earlier appeals hearing in the case. The comments, which suggested that a suspension of Clemens would be justified by the need to keep control on the field, were made by Eugene Orza, associate general counsel for the Major League Baseball Players Association. Mr. Vincent cited the comments in defense of his decision; he did not make them.

title: For Creditors, Class Divisions
description: For makers of shoes, dresses and other items sold by department stores, it was a better idea to sell goods to Bloomingdale's than to Abraham & Straus before the chains controlled by Robert Campeau went bankrupt last year.

title: Orchids' Deceptions Are Part of a Grand Strategy
description: THEY are the P. T. Barnums of the flower kingdom, dedicated to the premise that there is a sucker born every minute: a sucker, that is, with wings, a thorax and an unquenchable thirst for nectar and love.

title: SCHOOLS ARE TOLD NOT TO END TERM
description: A judge's order today salvaged six weeks of instruction for a bankrupt school district that was scheduled to shut down after classes on Tuesday.

title: Music in Review
description: 'Iphigenie en Aulide' Gould Hall 55 East 59th Street

title: Dinkins Aims At the Critics Of His Tennis
description: Faced with criticism that he spends too much time on tennis courts and not enough on city business, Mayor David N. Dinkins spent time on a tennis court yesterday and made sure everyone knew it.

title: Fashion's Heavy Hitter: The Ever-Versatile Jacket
description: Fashion flirted with hemlines, toyed with dresses and re-established pants as major players of the season. But the strongest message from the fall shows in Paris, London, New York and Milan, Italy, was an affirmation of the jacket as the heavy hitter in the current fashion scene.

title: Why Reading-Test Scores Don't Measure School Effectiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. MAY SEND MORE TO KURDS IN IRAN
description: The White House said today that it was considering further direct shipments of aid to Kurdish refugees in Iran after the flight to Teheran on Saturday of an Air Force cargo plane loaded with blankets for people in Iranian refugee camps.

title: Supreme Court to Rule on Key Issue in Child Sex-Abuse Cases
description: Closely divided on how far states can go to shield young victims of sexual abuse from having to appear in court, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide an important constitutional issue in the prosecution of such cases.

title: Spending Up 0.6%; Income Gains a Bit
description: Consumers increased their spending by sixth-tenths of a percent in March, the Government reported today. It was the second monthly advance, and analysts said it could mean the end of the recession is near.

title: Banking Chief Is Hired By American Express
description: After working for almost six years as New York State Superintendent of Banks, Jill M. Considine has decided to expand her banking reach a little farther around the globe.

title: Mexico-Europe Accord
description: Mexico has signed a cooperation accord with the European Community that it hopes will increase its trade with the 12-nation bloc. The accord was signed last week and is similar to ones the community has with Argentina and Chile.

title: Chess
description: The Dutch island of Aruba in the Caribbean was the site of an exhibition match in early March between Judit Polgar, the Hungarian whiz who is not yet 15 years old, and the renowned Soviet grandmaster Lev Polugayevsky. The experienced player, who is 56, won by 5-3, but the rapidly advancing teen-ager put the experience down as "very useful." Polugayevsky predicted a bright future for Judit, who has the highest International Chess Federation rating of any woman.

title: Jersey City Policeman Shot in Face As Robbers Hold Up Jewelry Store
description: A police officer was shot in the face this morning after an armed robbery in the heart of Journal Square, Jersey City's main commercial district, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Best Buy Co., Minneapolis, named Brad Anderson president and chief operating officer and Allen Lenzmeier executive vice president and chief financial officer. * Contel Cellular Inc., Atlanta, an indirect majority-owned subsidiary of GTE Corp., named Paul G. Kozlowski chairman. He succeeds Charles Wohlstetter, who will remain on the board.

title: A Big Step Toward Salvador Peace
description: Can a political settlement of El Salvador's endless civil war really be near? Hopes have been raised before, only to fall victim to new rebel offensives or death squad outrages. But the agreement on constitutional reform announced in Mexico City on Saturday could prove more durable.

title: Dead Brains Society
description: It's obvious the United States is ready for what used to be called socialized medicine. The Democrats ought to be leading the agitation for it and the fact that they aren't is further evidence suggesting their party is brain dead.

title: A Man, A Horn, And a Band With Jazz To Play
description: When the tenor saxophonist David Murray arrived in New York in the late 1970's, it was as if the cavalry had ridden into town. Jazz, many critics and fans were saying, had run its course. But Mr. Murray, a powerful instrumentalist and a writer with an ear for American vernacular styles, formed a big band that merged the experimentation of the 60's avant-garde with hard-swinging arrangements and improvisation, charged with a gospel fervor. Jazz seemed to have possibilities again.

title: Non-Automotive G.M. Units Post Mixed Income Results
description: The non-automotive subsidiaries of the General Motors Corporation posted mixed first-quarter results today. The Electronic Data Systems Corporation reported a 10.9 percent profit increase, the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation reported a 37.7 percent drop and the General Motors Acceptance Corporation posted a 9 percent decrease.

title: Yale Drops Challenge To Paper's Ownership
description: Yale University has announced that it has dropped its fight for ownership of the St. Petersburg Times.

title: American War Tactics Now Used to Save Lives
description: Using the tactics of war toward a goal of mercy, the American military's huge and incongruous relief operation here is transforming this empty, hardscrabble landscape in remarkable ways.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Waring & LaRosa Names Two Insiders to Top Posts
description: WARING & LaROSA, which has endured several tumultuous years re-establishing its independence from the Omnicom Group, promoted two insiders yesterday to become president and creative director.

title: Steps of Light
description: Dutch scientists have discovered a new property of the behavior of light waves that is identical to the behavior of electronic waves.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY -- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: A Judge Likens Legal Abortions To Executions
description: A municipal court judge today convicted 15 abortion opponents of criminal trespass for forcing their way into a doctor's office where an abortion was to be performed, but in his ruling said that human life begins at conception and described legal abortions as "legal executions."

title: Magnesium May Play Role in Chronic Fatigue
description: TWO small studies suggest a possible organic explanation for chronic fatigue syndrome. British scientists report that low levels of magnesium may play a part in this illness of unknown cause.

title: Complaint on Dibble
description: A woman claiming she was injured by a ball Cincinnati pitcher ROB DIBBLE threw into the stands after a game said yesterday she had filed a complaint with the Reds. Dibble hurled the ball into the center-field stands at Riverfront Stadium in an outburst Sunday after giving up two runs to the Chicago Cubs. The Reds ended up beating Chicago, 4-3.

title: Districting Panel to Offer Options
description: Still mired in political dogfights over how new City Council districts should be drawn in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Staten Island, the New York City Districting Commission said yesterday that it would present more than one possibility for those boroughs in its preliminary citywide plan tomorrow.

title: I.B.M. Forecast
description: Business prospects for the International Business Machines Corporation will remain weak for the remainder of the year, the computer maker's chairman told shareholders at the company's annual meeting today. "While we'd like to believe economic recovery is just around the corner, we'll have to wait and see," John F. Akers said. "We have seen no evidence yet to indicate any improvement in the near term, and consequently the year remains uncertain."

title: Albania Is Rife With Disease, Short on Essentials
description: Albania is facing chronic health and medical deficiencies, including serious malnourishment and shortages of such hospital essentials as disposable syringes, members of a United States Government emergency relief team have concluded.

title: Datascope Device In Successful Test
description: The Datascope Corporation said it had developed a device called Vasoseal that can seal puncture wounds in arteries caused by coronary angioplasty, angiography and other procedures requiring the insertion of catheters in arteries. The company said it had successfully tested the device in 70 clinical trials in Europe. The company said Europe would be the product's first market.

title: Missile Mania in the Middle East
description: The poor performance of Iraq's Scud missiles in the gulf war has done little to dampen the Middle East's enthusiasm for ballistic missiles.

title: Nippon Steel Reportedly Settles Patent Suit
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation has agreed to pay $5 million to $10 million to settle a patent infringement lawsuit filed by the Allegheny Ludlum Corporation, Allegheny Ludlum said today.

title: No Quick Fix on Banks
description: Comptroller General Charles Bowsher scared Congress on Friday when he described the fund that backs up Federal deposit insurance as "nearly insolvent." He proposed to replenish the fund with a $15 billion special assessment, more than doubling the price banks pay for insured deposits.

title: Gladys Marcus, 79, Fashion Institute Dean
description: Gladys Marcus, dean of liberal arts at the Fashion Institute of Technology, died on Sunday at New York University Medical Center. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.N. SEEKS ACCORD ON A POLICE FORCE IN NORTHERN IRAQ
description: The five permanent members of the Security Council are seeking agreement on establishing a United Nations police force in the Kurdish region of northern Iraq. The force would take over from American and allied military units, which have set up a refugee zone in the area.

title: U.N. to Conduct Western Sahara Plebiscite
description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to conduct an independence referendum in Western Sahara.

title: India Seeks U.S. Talks
description: India is willing to discuss trade problems with the United States, a top trade official said after Washington accused India of pirating American copyrights and patents.

title: Musburger's Vistas: Barcelona and Beyond
description: On April Fool's Day 1990, Brent Musburger was fired from CBS Sports. The ensuing Sturm and Drang over the ubiquitous one's dismissal was such that you'd think Kitty Kelley had discovered that Musburger had done the play-by-play of Nancy Reagan's White House "lunches" with Frank Sinatra.

title: Floyd McKissick, Civil Rights Maverick, Dies at 69
description: Floyd B. McKissick, an early leader of the civil rights movement who was named a state district judge in North Carolina last June, died Sunday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 69 years old.

title: Brown Abolishes 4 Varsity Teams
description: Cutbacks in intercollegiate sports continued yesterday when Brown University announced it would drop four varsity teams: men's golf and water polo, and women's gymnastics and volleyball.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Fabricland Inc., Portland, Ore., a fabrics company, said it would incur additional charges against earnings related to House of Fabrics Inc.'s unsolicited tender offer and its March 30 merger agreement. * Harsco Corp., Camp Hill, Pa., an industrial products company, said its BMY-Combat System division had been awarded a $20.7 million Army contract to design and build an Advanced Technology Transition Demonstrator to support the Combat Mobility Vehicle.

title: Diamond Layer
description: A new process that uses powerful bursts of laser light can transform ordinary carbon into a flawless thin film of diamond, researchers report.

title: Pickens, Admitting Defeat, Plans Sale of Japanese Stake
description: After two years of wrangling for a seat on the board of the Koito Manufacturing Company, T. Boone Pickens said today that he planned to give in and sell his 26.4 percent stake in the Japanese automobile parts maker.

title: Refugee Kurds Occupy Tent City After Guerrillas Lift Barricades
description: Allied officers ordered Kurdish guerrilla leaders today to let Kurdish refugees through rebel checkpoints and into a safe-haven zone in northern Iraq. A Kurdish commander complied, and the first refugee families arrived tonight at the tent city near this occupied town.

title: U.S. Won't Give Soviets Credits
description: President Bush said today that the United States was not ready to extend additional agricultural credits to the Soviet Union, because Moscow had "regrettably" not made sufficient market reforms.

title: Topics of The Times; Cooperating on Garbage
description: New York City's Health Department sniffed the growing mounds of uncollected garbage and wisely declared that the city and its people are being subjected to an unacceptable health nuisance. The department then ordered city sanitation workers to remove the mess from the apartment houses, where it has been accumulating.

title: Music in Review
description: Sequentia Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: Judge Questions Exxon Pact's Fairness to Natives
description: A Federal district judge said today that he was not satisfied that the rights of 5,000 native Alaskan villagers had been protected in the $1 billion civil settlement the Government reached last month with the Exxon Corporation and the State of Alaska.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: YACHT RACING Frenchwoman First to Solo

title: Patterns
description: Marilyn and More

title: Renew China's Trade Status
description: China presents the American Government and people with one of their more difficult and important international relationships. It is extremely valuable to have continuing trade and cooperation with this nation of more than a billion people, for its strategic influence is crucial to stability, peace and progress in Asia.

title: Corrections
description: Charts on Sunday and Monday about the price of health care omitted the illustrator's name in some editions and rendered it incorrectly in others. He is Philippe Lardy.

title: Mitsubishi's Big Campaign in U.S.
description: At a time when brutal competition and a recession are forcing American car makers to lay off workers and delay new models, Mitsubishi of Japan is pushing to expand its foothold in the American market.

title: Canada's National Health Plan Gives Care to All, With Limits
description: Since a heart attack in 1989, Len Quesnelle has had a dozen tests to study the blocked arteries of his heart, spent weeks in intensive care because of chest pain and finally, in March, had a triple bypass.

title: Profit Up 2.9% At Control Data
description: The Control Data Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 2.9 percent despite a 3.7 percent decline in revenue.

title: Arts Advocates Sound Alarm as Cuts Near
description: A range of horrors from a cultural Dark Age to the specter of loose rattlesnakes was conjured yesterday by representatives from a dozen New York arts institutions as they defended their budgets at City Hall.

title: Iraq Asserts Its Weakening Will Mean a Stronger Iran
description: With United Nations sanctions still in place two months after the end of the Persian Gulf war, senior Iraqi officials say the West should be concerned that Baghdad's weakening economic and military position will shift the regional balance in favor of Iran.

title: Texas Instruments To Sell Division
description: Texas Instruments Inc. agreed to sell its industrial controls business in Johnson City, Tenn., to Siemens A.G., the German electronics giant. Terms were not disclosed. The sale is subject to approval by regulators and the directors of both companies. The 900 employees in Johnson City and 300 others around the world associated with the division will become employees of Siemens. The sale also includes facilities and equipment.

title: New-Home Sales Rose 1% in March
description: Sales of new homes picked up by 1 percent in March, the second consecutive monthly advance, the Government said today in a report that reinforced the belief that the housing recession has reached bottom.

title: Padres, Starting From Scratch, Are Whipping Up a Real Winner
description: With nothing but harmonious sounds emanating from their clubhouse, the San Diego Padres are hard put to say what came first to them this season: their winning ways or the new, improved team attitude.

title: Knicks Still Trying To Maintain Some Hope
description: The Chicago Bulls believe the Knicks are in trouble. History says the Knicks are in trouble.

title: Libya Wants U.S. Punished
description: Libya stepped up its criticism of the United States today when a newspaper accused Washington of violating international law and said it should be brought to account, boycotted and punished. The call followed weekend remarks by the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, monitored in Nicosia, that the United States-led war against Iraq had been aimed at strengthening Israel and that Libya would be the next American target.

title: Atlantic City's Council Ends Service Shutdown
description: By a nearly unanimous vote, the City Council here ended a one-day shutdown of city services tonight, but left unresolved a battle with the Mayor over layoffs of city workers.

title: Books of The Times; 2 Women, One Poet and the Ghost of Another
description: The Year of the Death of Ricardo Reis By Jose Saramago Translated by Giovanni Pontiero. 358 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $21.95.

title: Q&A
description: Noisy Waves

title: Amazon Advocate's Unsettling Vision
description: ALONE in a cottage, deep in a forest here, lives a man with unruly white hair and an unsettling vision of the world.

title: Big Chains Plan to End Bankruptcy
description: The bankrupt department store chains once controlled by Robert Campeau, the Canadian financier, filed a preliminary reorganization plan yesterday that calls for many suppliers who are owed money to get no cash. Instead, they would get stock in a new company that would control some of the nation's largest department-store chains.

title: ARCO and Unocal Net Off As Gas and Oil Prices Fall
description: ARCO Inc. and the Unocal Corporation reported lower profits for the first quarter today, continuing a trend for large oil companies with operations primarily in the United States.

title: Peru Struggles to Digest Free-Market Reforms
description: A year ago, Alberto K. Fujimori, a little-known agronomist, rode a tidal wave of left-wing votes to capture the presidency of Peru, swamping the candidacy of Mario Vargas Llosa, an outspoken admirer of Margaret Thatcher's economic policies.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Buckley DeCerchio Sees Greener Grass in Movies
description: Bryan Buckley and Tom DeCerchio, two of Madison Avenue's hottest young talents, have decided to shut their three-year-old New York agency, Buckley DeCerchio Cavalier Inc., and move to Hollywood to pursue screenwriting.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
People
description: * Jerry Grossman has been promoted to vice president-management supervisor at Ammirati & Puris.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about prizes given by the Overseas Press Club in New York misidentified the winner of the Cornelius Ryan Award for best book on foreign affairs. He is Tad Szulc.

title: Pepsico Net Up 12.9% on Foreign Strength
description: Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday that its first-quarter profits increased 12.9 percent, aided by especially strong foreign sales in soft drinks, snacks and fast food.

title: Investigators in Florida Say They Know Students' Killer
description: Eight months after five college students were found slain here in a span of 40 hours, law-enforcement officials say they are sure they have found the killer.

title: Charting the Flow
description: ANYONE who has ever had to chart the steps in a procedure or detail the organization of a company knows what a messy job it can be. A program called AllClear automates the process.

title: Iraqis Give More Data To U.N. on A-Material
description: Iraq has given a detailed response to a request for more information about the location of its nuclear material, the International Atomic Energy Agency said today.

title: The Earliest Wine: Vintage 3500 B.C. and Robust
description: LONG before Noah supposedly planted his vineyard after the Flood or the first toast was drunk to Dionysus on the shores of Homer's wine-dark sea, the taste of the grape was one of life's pleasures. Indeed, archeologists have now found chemical evidence that people were making and drinking wine at least as long ago as the fourth millennium B.C., the earliest established occurrence of wine anywhere in the world.

title: Careers; More Math, Well Taught, Is Her Goal
description: PATRICIA CLARK KENSCHAFT, a mathematics professor at Montclair State College, would like to see two things happen in the nation's schools. She would like to see more students, especially women, major in mathematics and she would like to see better-trained math teachers in the elementary grades to give pupils a grounding at an early age.

title: Experts Clash Over Project To Detect Gravity Wave
description: A PROPOSAL to stake $211 million in public money on the chance that gravity waves could be exploited to fathom black holes and other cosmic enigmas has deeply divided scientists and will force Congress to make a difficult decision in the next few weeks.

title: Hispanic Drug Agents in Accord on Bias Suit
description: Hispanic agents have reached a tentative agreement with the Drug Enforcement Administration to settle a six-year employment discrimination lawsuit, the agents' lawyer said today.

title: Argentine Angst Grows as Maradona Tragedy Sinks In
description: A stunned Argentine public today poured out sympathy for its fallen soccer hero, Diego Maradona, as the country struggled to make sense out of his arrest Friday on drug possession charges.

title: Market Place; Bond Funds Bulge as Rates Fall
description: Investors worried about falling short-term interest rates are buying bond mutual funds at the fastest pace in years, mutual fund managers said yesterday.

title: Stocks Tumble, With Dow Falling by 35.40
description: Propelled by exceptionally heavy program selling, stocks dropped sharply yesterday in the slowest trading in three weeks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Customer Killed in a Holdup
description: A customer in a Brooklyn grocery store was shot in the head and killed last night during a holdup by three gunmen, the police said. The gunmen entered the store at 306 Franklin Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section at 7:40 P.M., asked for cigarettes, then pulled out guns, said Officer Fred Weiner, a police spokesman. They told two store employees and a customer to lie on the floor and not look up. The customer, Santos Cosme, 57 years old, of 318 Franklin Avenue, apparently lifted his head and was shot, Officer Weiner said. The gunmen, 25 to 35 years old, rifled the cash register and fled. It was not immediately known how much money they took, the police said.

title: Moog Leads Bruins Into Conference Final
description: The goaltending was inspiring, the penalty killers were perfect and the shooters came through for the Bruins tonight in the seventh game of the Adams Division finals in rocking Boston Garden.

title: Freeing Kuwait Didn't Justify Destroying Iraq; The Hitler Comparison
description: To the Editor:

title: Texaco Names a President For Its U.S. Operations Unit
description: Don H. Schmude was named president of Texaco Refining and Marketing Inc. and was also named a vice president of its parent, Texaco Inc. He had previously been president and chief executive of Star Enterprises, a refining and marketing company that is co-owned by Texaco and Saudi Refining Inc.

title: Coming Soon (to Trial): Marcos and the Golden Buddha
description: Out of the typhoon of paperwork and verbiage that swirled through the Marcos racketeering trial has come an intriguing tale of how the late Philippine President and his wife might have come by their wealth: from a cache of gold, gems and artwork buried by a Japanese general during World War II and unearthed 20 years ago by a man who says the Marcoses stole it from him.

title: Sports of The Times; Are Your Autographs Forged?
description: FOR decades, it's been a daily ritual in every big league clubhouse. On a table are two or three boxes of baseballs, a dozen to a box. One by one, players stop to autograph those balls for the club's promotional purposes. Usually the space between the seams is reserved for the manager's signature, as it was when Charlie Dressen was the manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers four decades ago.

title: LEGISLATURE VOTES TO EASE BALLOTING IN NEW YORK STATE
description: The New York State Legislature tonight approved its first significant step in more than a decade toward making it easier to vote. But it was far less than the major changes that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and government watchdog groups had sought.

title: At Least 30 Die in Soviet Georgia Quake
description: A powerful earthquake jolted the mountainous heart of Soviet Georgia today, killing at least 30 people, severing communications with several small villages and demolishing buildings, homes and factories, Soviet officials reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a Canadian newsprint company owned by the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company rendered its name incorrectly. It is the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company. The article also misidentified the Mayor of Kapuskasing, Ontario. He is Theodore K. Jewell.

title: Business and Health; Effect of Decision By Supreme Court
description: LABOR experts say nonprofit hospitals in Northern and West Coast states will be the first to feel the effects of a unanimous decision last week by the Supreme Court, upholding National Labor Relations Board regulations that make it easier for unions to organize hospital workers. The ruling is less likely to affect investor-owned chains and Southern hospitals at first, experts on both sides of the table say.

title: Blocs Battle to Draw Chinatown's New Council Map
description: In a Chinatown garment factory, where scraps of cloth clutter the floor like vegetation, Margaret Chin is working the room. For most of the women at the sewing machines Ms. Chin represents their vision of the future: She hopes to become the first Asian-American member of the New York City Council.

title: Article 259891 -- No Title
description: The USX Corporation, which operates a vast energy business and is the nation's largest steel producer, yesterday reported a first-quarter net loss of $237 million. The company said the loss was primarily a result of lower steel demand and the cost of closing some of its steel plants.

title: Review/Theater; Broadway Season's Last Drama Offers a Defense of Theater
description: This is the final week of a parched Broadway season, so the timing could not be better for "Our Country's Good," a play that says, yes, the theater is important, inspiring, a boon to civilization.
