Actually, when you consider "La Bete" and "I Hate Hamlet," it could be argued that roughly half the new plays on Broadway this season delivered the very same gung-ho message about the theater, as if New York's producers were in a desperate conspiracy to reassure audiences (and themselves) that it is not a sign of certifiable insanity either to attend or to present drama in a commercial playhouse.

title: Freeing Kuwait Didn't Justify Destroying Iraq; Bush's Restraint
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: With no strings attached, Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS will give away 24 silver dollars on June 3. It will come from neither the city coffers nor his own resources but rather from the Museum of the City of New York, which is presenting its 20th annual $24 award to LOUIS S. AUCHINCLOSS. Mr. Auchincloss, the lawyer and author, stepped down from the museum's presidency last year after 23 years in the post.

title: Bangkok Journal; Thailand Coup Casts Up a Most Reluctant Premier
description: Anand Panyarachun must be one of the world's most ambivalent leaders. His appointment as Thailand's interim Prime Minister is "the biggest accident in Thai history," he says, and he is eager to finish his work, promote new elections and be gone from a post he never wanted in the first place.

title: Fondness and Grief Run Deep for Laz Barrera
description: The memory and the spirit of Laz Barrera hover over the 117th Kenucky Derby this week. Not just because he won it twice, with Bold Forbes in 1976 and Affirmed in 1978, but because he won it twice with the traits that set him apart: brilliance with horses, warmth with people.

title: Boeing Reports 2% Increase In First-Quarter Earnings
description: The Boeing Company today reported a slight increase in earnings for the first quarter, but it said sales were down, primarily because fewer 747 jumbo jets were delivered than in the period last year.

title: I.M.F. Is Now Cool on Soviet Membership
description: Only one Russian, Grigory Yavlinsky, an economist and politician, came to Washington for the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund -- and he went home before it started today, disgruntled.

title: Goodwill Games Topic of Talks
description: Representatives of Ted Turner, the cable television executive, will meet with officials of the International Olympic Committee in June to discuss Turner's Olympic-style Goodwill Games, an event the I.O.C. has unofficially opposed.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
President for 13 Offices At Earle Palmer Brown
description: Mark Goldstein, the president of the Bethesda, Md., office of Earle Palmer Brown, has been named to oversee the advertising operations of the firm in its 13 offices.

title: New Model Of a Classic Printer
description: THE Hewlett-Packard Company introduced yet another low-cost laser printer yesterday, the HP Laserjet IIIP. The Laserjet IIIP turns out the same four pages a minute that the popular Laserjet IIP does, but it adds some advanced features that improve its overall speed and print quality.

title: 2 Economists Question Benefit of Cleaning Up A Major Air Pollutant
description: THE health benefits of cleaning up a widespread urban air pollutant, ground-level ozone, may not be worth the price, two economists argue in a new study.

title: Boston School-Bias Suit On Hiring Is Reopened
description: Eleven months after issuing orders that were to have ended a Federal District Court's role in Boston's school desegregation case, the judge who closed the case has reopened it, ruling that Boston's schools have failed to meet goals for hiring minority teachers.

title: A.T.&T. Deal May Hinge on S.E.C. Ruling
description: Resolution of an accounting issue seems to be one of the final barriers left to resolve in A.T.& T.'s five-month pursuit of NCR.

title: Swaggering A's Love to See Yanks Come to Town
description: The Yankees rested today, but they have considered the days to come, days to be filled with the kinds of memories they would just as soon dismiss.

title: TV News of the Poor Often Has a Black Face
description: To the Editor:

title: LTV Corp. Reports a Loss Of $46.3 Million for Quarter
description: The LTV Corporation, the giant aerospace and steel company, reported a first-quarter loss of $46.3 million yesterday, citing depressed conditions in the steel industry. The company said the recession and lower demand from auto makers had contributed to the loss.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It will hardly be a step out of character when WYNTON MARSALIS, the trumpeter, takes the stage at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center to make his acting debut this week. He will play a trumpeter in "The Reincarnation of Mozart," a musical fantasy for children that is to be presented (one performance only) on Friday at noon.

title: Baseball Players Need More Rewards
description: To the Editor:

title: Kansas Is Eligible for U.S. Aid
description: President Bush signed a disaster declaration today, making Federal grants and low-cost loans available to help Kansas recover from tornadoes that killed 19 people in that state on Friday. The latest count of the dead from the tornadoes that swept through eastern Kansas and six other states is 22, including three in Oklahoma.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Allergan Inc., Irvine, Calif., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $100 million in notes due 1998 through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: Insurers Forced to Report More Investments as 'Junk'
description: Under a new, broader definition of "junk bonds" imposed by state insurance commissioners nationwide, life insurers are reporting increasing percentages of their policyholders' money invested in these high-yield, high-risk securities.

title: LACROSSE: Notebook; Brown Plays With Anyone, No Matter What Style Is
description: The success of Brown's ambidextrous lacrosse team continues.

title: Key Rates
Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States slipped by 11, to 824 last week, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The Houston-based oilfield tool maker said the count was down by 103 rigs from the period a year earlier. The count represents the number of rigs exploring for petroleum and natural gas. Baker Hughes officials noted that the rig count traditionally falls during the first four months of the year.

title: Airlift Moves 640 Refugees
description: About 640 more Iraqis were airlifted today from a United States Army refugee camp to Saudi Arabia, moving American troops a step closer to final withdrawal from southern Iraq.

title: Mitchell Decides Not to Appeal
description: KEVIN MITCHELL of the San Francisco Giants, the National League's leading home-run hitter with seven, has withdrawn his appeal of his two-game suspension, imposed by the National League president, BILL WHITE .

title: Cremins Stays Put
description: Bobby Cremins took himself out of the running for Notre Dame's vacant coaching job yesterday, deciding instead to remain at Georgia Tech.

title: Music in Review
description: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center Alice Tully Hall

title: New Method Allows Organ Transplants in Rats Without Usual Drugs
description: THE beginnings of a remarkable new path in transplant surgery may have been opened up by new experiments conducted in Philadelphia and in Bergamo, Italy. Tissues and organs have been successfully transplanted in rats using an immunological method that enabled the rats to survive without the immunosuppressive drugs usually needed to prevent rejection of the transplanted organ.

title: G.O.P. Waiting for Thornburgh's Decision
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is keeping Republicans in Pennsylvania off balance as they await his decision on whether he will run for the Senate seat left vacant by the death of John Heinz.

title: By Design; The Chameleon Maillot
description: A lot of women think maillots are one of fashion's better inventions. They're right. These simple one-piece coverings serve all sorts of purposes, especially in summer. A tank-top maillot is the ideal bathing suit or workout costume. It's comfortable, durable and functional. Because it's woven with stretch fibers it not only fits over a variety of shapes, it also gives a nice, slightly firm molding to the body.

title: Marks & Spencer To Cut 850 Jobs
description: Marks & Spencer P.L.C., the British retailer whose holdings include the Brooks Brothers clothing stores in the United States, plans to reduce its British work force by 1.4 percent. The company said it would cut 550 jobs at its London headquarters and 300 trainee and junior manager jobs at its stores. Six hundred of the cuts will be achieved through layoffs, and the remainder through attrition, the company said.

title: Elinor Remick Warren; Composer, 91
description: Elinor Remick Warren, who composed more than 200 works for orchestra and voice, died at her home on Saturday. She was 91 years old.

title: Fairfield's Choice
description: Paul Cormier, who has spent the last seven years as head coach at Dartmouth, yesterday was named by Fairfield University to succeed Mitch Buonaguro, who resigned on March 12. The 39-year-old Cormier finished his seven years at Dartmouth with a record of 87-95. (AP)

title: Salvadoran Legislature Passes Reforms in Time
description: The outgoing legislature unanimously approved constitutional reforms tonight that are expected to widen the path toward an end to the 11-year-old civil war.

title: Freeing Kuwait Didn't Justify Destroying Iraq; Arab Jews of Israel
description: To the Editor:
